title: Seoul's Trade With Soviets
description: South Korea's trade with the Soviet Union is likely to soar to $2 billion in 1991, more than double the $889 million in 1990, said a report issued today by the Korea Institute for Economics and Technology.

title: MANY KURDS LEAVE BORDER FOR TOWNS THEY FLED IN IRAQ
description: Thousands of Kurdish refugees came pouring out of the mountains today, the vast majority of them rolling right past the new tent city built for them by the United States in a wheat field here and heading for their old homes in this city and surrounding villages.

title: Lin Names New President
description: Tom A. Alberg yesterday was named president and chief operating officer as well as a director of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, which is 50 percent owned by McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.

title: Theater in Review
description: Love Lemmings The Village Gate, Upstairs 160 Bleecker Street By Joe DiPietro; directed by Melia Bensussen; music by Eric Thoroman; lyrics by Mr. DiPietro and Mr. Thoroman. Presented by Fireball Entertainment, in association with Mark May. WITH: Steve Ahern, Becky Borczon, John Daggett and Helen Greenberg.

title: Ken Curtis, Actor, 74, Festus on 'Gunsmoke'
description: Ken Curtis, a singer and actor who played the scruffy deputy Festus on the television series "Gunsmoke," died in his sleep on Sunday at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Medical Test Stolen in Texas
description: Copies of the national Medical College Admission Tests were stolen from the University of Texas over the weekend, shortly after a new edition of the test was given, testing officials said Monday.

title: Familiar Face Wins in Albania
description: Ramiz Alia, the Albanian Communist leader, was re-elected President today by the country's first freely elected Parliament in four decades, despite losing his seat in the recent general election. In the absence of a candidate from the country's fledgling opposition, and facing only a token challenger from his own party, Mr. Alia won 68 percent of the vote. The opposition abstained.

title: Robert K. Pfister, 72, Drug Executive, Dies
description: Robert K. Pfister, former vice chairman of Sterling Drug Inc., died last Wednesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and also lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Eating Well
description: "ENOUGH of this third world diet," was the anonymous message left on the answering machine after last week's Eating Well column appeared. No one said it would be easy to convince a nation of meat eaters to cut back on animal protein, no matter how convincing the data that such diets may be a contributing cause to the chronic diseases of the industrialized world.

title: Layoffs at G.E.
description: The General Electric Company said its jet-engine division would lay off 1,800 people, including 1,000 who worked on its losing bid to supply engines to the Air Force's newest jet fighter. The layoffs had been expected since last week, when the Pentagon chose Pratt & Whitney Inc. to supply engines for the Advanced Tactical Fighter. The layoffs represent about 5 percent of the work force of 37,000 at G.E.'s plant in Evendale, Ohio.

title: Mitsuo Mutai, Newspaper Executive, 94
description: Mitsuo Mutai, honorary chairman of the Yomiuri Shimbun, the world's largest daily newspaper, died today of heart failure at a Tokyo hospital, officials of the paper said. He was 94 years old.

title: Bush Plan On Lenders Is Disclosed
description: The Bush Administration today disclosed the details of its plan for a significant increase in the supervision of the Government-sponsored companies that help finance home purchases, higher education and agriculture.

title: More City Business, for Less Money
description: Mayor David Dinkins of New York has taken a small but firm step in the right direction by consolidating six city agencies concerned with economic development into two agencies: a new Department of Business Services and the New York City Development Corporation. This will eliminate 71 jobs, saving $5 million over 18 months.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 9 about the killing of a law professor in Cambridge, Mass., referred incorrectly to an earlier murder victim in the Brattle Street neighborhood, in 1973. That victim was a woman.

title: Mellon to Sell More Shares
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of five million common shares through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Dolphin-Safe Tuna In Safeway Effort
description: Safeway Inc., in the first action of its kind by a large supermarket chain, will require that all tuna products it sells be certified as dolphin safe. The decision comes about a year after the three largest tuna suppliers, Star-Kist, Bumble Bee and Chicken of the Sea, said they would sell tuna only if it was caught without endangering dolphins. But 30 percent of the market is still controlled by smaller brands that are not dolphin-safe. Brian Dowling, a Safeway spokesman, said the chain would not now sell those brands, as well as frozen foods and pet foods that are not certified as dolphin safe.

title: The Crowd's Farewell Is a Not-So-Fond One
description: The mood of the crowd at Madison Square Garden began getting nasty last night after Will Perdue, the Bulls' backup center, scored on a layup to expand Chicago's lead to 90-78.

title: S.& P. Lowers Its Rating On Procter's Senior Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered Procter & Gamble's senior debt rating yesterday, saying it anticipated the company would have problems assuming the additional debt brought on by its $1.14 billion acquisition of the Max Factor and Betrix beauty lines from Revlon Inc.

title: Washington Talk; Of Rehnquist's Mission, And Patience to Match
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist is a man with a mission; that much has been evident throughout his 19 years on the Supreme Court.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pro Bono
description: The San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam has undertaken a campaign designed to help the city's homeless find jobs. The campaign, for a San Francisco organization called the Central City Hospitality House, will use bus shelters and commercials to inform business leaders about the organization's employee referral service.

title: U.S. Drug Maker's Yugoslavia Move
description: SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc., a California drug maker, said it had taken over Galenika, Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceuticals company. SPI, a unit of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., said it would invest $50 million in cash, plus drugs and technology worth millions more, and would distribute $12 million in stock to Galenika's 5,500 employees in Belgrade.

title: Public Stock Offering Is Set by Maxwell
description: Robert Maxwell announced today that 49 percent of his privately held Mirror Group Newspapers would be sold to investors in Britain and abroad next week at $:1.25 ($2.14) a share, to raise $:228 million and reduce the company's debt by $:210 million. The balance will repay a loan from his private company, RM Holdings.

title: A Look at the City; On Speaking Terms
description: In college, people meet at parties. In New York it takes a strike -- of doormen, hall porters and handymen.

title: ULSTER TALKS OPEN ON A DIVISIVE NOTE
description: The first significant political talks in strife-torn Northern Ireland in 15 years got under way here today with a wide gulf separating Roman Catholic nationalists and Protestant unionists and with unionists deeply divided themselves.

title: Weicker, to Block Indian Casino, Seeks Repeal of Charity Gambling
description: In senior centers, church basements and high school gymnasiums across the state, nonprofit groups are allowed to go crazy once or twice a year and pretend that old Connecticut is really wild Las Vegas. With play money and small prizes, "Las Vegas nights" are a way to raise money.

title: Daniels Tries Again
description: LLOYD DANIELS was given another chance yesterday to prove why he was once called the greatest high school basketball player in New York City history. The 23-year-old, 6-foot-9-inch guard signed a one-season contract with the new Miami Tropics of the United States Basketball League.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Bar Association Focus Is on the Bill of Rights
description: The American Bar Association and Arian, Lowe & Travis, a Chicago agency, are to introduce a provocative public service campaign today that uses stark scenes of burning crosses, torture and famine to emphasize the importance of the Bill of Rights.

title: 2 Health Plans With Payments Tied to Income
description: In Germany and Japan, employers and employees contribute to health care, but in a radically different system that holds down society's total costs and treats workers more equally, guaranteeing insurance coverage for all with payment levels linked to incomes.

title: Yeltsin Has an Offer for Striking Miners
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, leader of the Russian republic, held a daylong round of meetings today with striking miners in the Siberian coalfields, raising expectations that the costly two-month-long strikes may soon end.

title: Video Game Uncovered in Europe Uses Nazi Death Camps as Theme
description: A home video game circulating in Austria and Germany puts the player in the role of a commandant of a Nazi death camp earning points for gassing prisoners and selling gold fillings, a Holocaust study center says.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * CBS Television and Nabisco announced a sweepstakes in which the grand prize is a walk-on role in the soap opera "The Young and the Restless." The promotion ties the daytime drama to five Nabisco products: Ritz Bits, Triscuit Bits, Cheddar Wedges, Honey Maid Graham Bites and Premium Bits.* Two Houston agencies, Fogarty & Klein Inc. and Winius-Brandon Advertising Inc., will merge on July 1 into the firm Fogarty & Klein/ Winius-Brandon, with total billings estimated in excess of $97 million.

title: State Makes Winning Bid In New York On City Notes
description: In an odd twist to the city and state's intertwined fiscal mess, the State of New York submitted a winning bid on $50 million in short-term city notes auctioned yesterday, effectively lending the city money that it needed because the state has failed to give the city aid that it owes.

title: Holiday Inns Sets Cuts in Revamping
description: Holiday Inns Inc., the world's largest lodging chain, announced a corporate restructuring that includes moving its headquarters to Atlanta from Memphis. Bryan D. Langton, the chairman and chief executive, said the move would create 900 new jobs in Atlanta, including about 160 to be taken by current employees in Memphis. But he said the job losses in Memphis would affect about 1,000 of the company's 1,500 workers.

title: Girl, 11, Gives Birth to Girl; Man Accused of Raping Her
description: A 23-year-old Westchester County man was held in lieu of $15,000 bail today, accused of raping an 11-year-old girl who gave birth to a healthy girl on Monday.

title: Virginia Symphony Names Music Director
description: JoAnn Falletta has been appointed music director and conductor of the Virginia Symphony, the orchestra has announced. The appointment is effective on July 1 and runs through June 30, 1994.

title: Children's TV, Where Boys Are King
description: When ABC announced next fall's schedule for Saturday morning children's programming, Jennie Trias, the network's vice president for children's programs, had some bad news for girls: their favorite Saturday morning show, "The New Kids on the Block," the cartoon adventures of the rock band with an enormous preteen-age following, would be canceled.

title: Vietnam Vets Built Memorial Themselves; The Hostile Reaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert P. Cawley, Priest, 57
description: The Rev. Robert P. Cawley, a Roman Catholic Vincentian priest and a former director of libraries at St. John's University, died on Thursday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 57 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Blind Trust for a Blind Regulator
description: Robert Clarke is Comptroller of the Currency, the nation's chief banking regulator. Mr. Clarke also serves on the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which manages the Government's holdings of junk bonds and other assets taken over from failed savings and loan institutions.

title: About New York
description: The giggling couple cut their cake and made a wish, one seemingly already granted. "She means the world to me," the groom said. "This is just the beginning," the bride promised.

title: Freda Resika Caspersen, Executive, 82
description: Freda Resika Caspersen, an executive, philanthropist and former director of the Beneficial Corporation, died on Friday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. She was 82 years old and lived in Venice, Fla.

title: Nathan I. Nagler, Executive, 68
description: Nathan I. Nagler, a retired food industry executive, died on Monday at Albert Einstein Hospital in the Bronx. He was 68 years old and lived in Oceanside, L.I.

title: Reject U.S. Aid to Refugees, Hard-Liners in Teheran Urge
description: Islamic radicals in the Iranian Parliament urged the Government today to return all aid sent by the United States for displaced Iraqis and to expel allied soldiers assigned to set up camps and field hospitals in western Iran.

title: Henderson Breakdown on Bases Produced
description: One way to relate Rickey Henderson's base-stealing skill to his team's production is to create a new baseball statistic: bases produced.

title: Agriculture, Cowed
description: Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan can't seem to decide which duty comes first: promoting meat and dairy products or sound nutrition.

title: New Orders At Factories Drop by 2.8%
description: Orders for factory goods fell 2.8 percent in March, the fifth straight decline, the Government said today in a report showing widespread weakness persisting in the industrial sector.

title: Japanese Bank Assets
description: The combined assets of Japan's offshore banking companies rose 1.7 percent, to $578.5 billion, at the end of March, from $568.9 billion at the end of February, the Finance Ministry said today. Of the total, assets denominated in foreign currencies rose 1.7 percent from a month earlier, to $303.4 billion, while those denominated in yen rose 1.6 percent, to $275.1 billion, it said.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Mall of America, a shopping and entertainment complex under construction in Bloomington, Minn., to Martin/ Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis. Billings are estimated at $2 million.

title: Unocal to Cut Back Stations in West
description: The Unocal Corporation plans to cut costs by closing up to 300 of its service stations on the West Coast over three years. The company said it would begin notifying its dealers in Washington, Oregon and California within 60 days. Unocal has about 2,900 stations on the West Coast, 1,900 alone in California. The closings include about 100 announced last year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A voice from the past, that of JUNE VALLI , will be heard again on May 15 in Brooklyn. The concert is scheduled for 2 P.M. at Walt Whitman Hall on the campus of Brooklyn College.

title: Students in South Korea Continue Protests
description: The country was hit today with another day of widespread though generally nonviolent student demonstrations after a student set herself on fire to protest the beating to death by riot police officers of another student on Friday.

title: 'Sleeping Beauty' Hits the Jackpot
description: The New York City Ballet's biggest gamble in years -- Peter Martins's grand and now totally successful staging of "The Sleeping Beauty" -- has paid off. With a series of debuts in the leading roles over the weekend, everything locked sharply into place.

title: Baltusrol Shifts a Bias Policy
description: Baltusrol Golf Club, host of the 1993 United States Open, has reversed its policy and is accepting women and minority members, the club's vice president said today.

title: Bush Offers Trade-Pact Concessions
description: The Bush Administration, facing a critical vote in Congress next month over its authority to negotiate with other countries on trade, will make significant environmental and job-security commitments to accompany a trade pact with Mexico, Administration and Congressional aides said today.

title: Don't Make Greece Europe's Black Sheep
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Champion Parts Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., a maker of automotive parts and systems, will close its Fort Worth plant this year. * Compucom Systems Inc., Dallas, a microcomputer dealer, has completed the acquisition of Computer Factory Inc., Elmsford, N.Y., for $38 million.

title:
Real Estate;
Cambridge Office Space Doing Well
description: AS an office market, Cambridge had long been considered a minor suburb of Boston on the wrong side of the Charles River -- when it was considered at all. In 1980 it had only two million square feet of office space, in contrast to 33 million square feet in Boston.

title: U.S. ASSERTS K.G.B. ENTERED EMBASSY
description: Soviet intelligence agents dressed as firefighters entered secure areas of the United States Embassy in Moscow during a major fire last month, and an inquiry is under way into whether any secret material was lost as a result, the Bush Administration said today.

title: PACT WOULD BAN ANTARCTIC MINING
description: In an action praised by environmentalists, delegates at a meeting on Antarctica have drafted an agreement to ban mining there for at least 50 years.

title: Brooklyn Tells Tourists, Yo! Don't Overlook Us
description: The bedroom's lace curtains rustle in a cool spring breeze, filtering dots of sunlight onto a four-poster bed. Like hundreds of other bed-and-breakfasts throughout America, the appeal of Donald Kurz-Fiedeke's small hostelry is its 19th-century charm, its whiff of romance.

title: Labor Secretary Proposes Revamping Pension Laws
description: Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin proposed changing the nation's pension laws today to encourage employers to create retirement programs for about 42 million workers who are currently not covered.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Laughter and Lust'

title: Richard McDonough, Tire Retailer, 71, Dies
description: Richard A. McDonough, a former tire retailer, died on Sunday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in Sea Girt, N.J., and South Orange, N.J.

title: California Has Agreed On Bailing Out Schools
description: California officials agreed last night to bail out the bankrupt Richmond Unified School District, but Gov. Pete Wilson maintained that he still planned to appeal the county court order that forced the state to rescue the system.

title: Accord With Chief Is Rejected
description: The Los Angeles Police Commission today rejected a proposal by the City Council to let Chief Daryl F. Gates keep his job while a group of Los Angeles police officers are investigated for the beating of a motorist.

title: At This Circus, The Sideshow Is in the Kitchen
description: "I NEVER had sushi before I joined the circus," David Lebel, an acrobat, was saying the other day between numbers at the Cirque du Soleil, the French Canadian circus that is appearing at Battery Park City in New York through May 19.

title: Ex-Executive at Sears Named Hills President
description: In a surprise appointment yesterday, Michael Bozic, the former president and chief operating officer of Sears, Roebuck & Company's Merchandising Group, was named president and chief executive of Hills Department Stores Inc. Hills, a 150-store discount chain, has been in voluntary bankruptcy since February.

title: McAnally May Double His Chances
description: Two days before the deadline for entries for the 117th Kentucky Derby, it looked today as though a field of 16 was likely, with another one possible if Ron McAnally hops off the fence and decides to enter Olympio.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: U.S. Says Iraqis' Uranium Is Still Enough for One Bomb
description: Despite the intensive allied bombing of Iraq's strategic military sites, Iraq still has enough undamaged weapons-grade uranium to make one nuclear bomb, according to Administration officials and scientists who reviewed an Iraqi letter delivered to the United Nations that details its nuclear holdings.

title: Nettie S. Horch, An Arts Patron, Is Dead at 94
description: Nettie S. Horch, an arts patron and co-founder of the Master Institute of United Arts in New York City, died at the Humana-Biscayne Hospital in North Miami on Monday. She was 94 years old and lived in Hallandale, Fla.

title: Ollie Spencer, Football Player, 60
description: Ollie Spencer, a National Football League lineman for 9 years and the offensive line coach of the Oakland Raiders for 17 years, died Sunday, apparently after a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Chip That Sends Light
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had developed a computer chip that used light instead of electrons and wire to transmit information. The advance could sharply increase computer speed. James Yuan, who led the research, said conventional wires created bottlenecks that could limit the performance of complex chips.

title: Most Montana Employees Return to Jobs
description: A five-day strike by more than 5,000 Montana state employees all but ended today after Gov. Stan Stephens signed legislation giving across-the-board raises of $1.15 an hour over two years.

title: Cigar Smokers vs. Doctors
description: To The Living Section:

title: Jacob Rootenberg, 55, A Computer Professor
description: Jacob Rootenberg, a professor and former chairman of the department of computer sciences at Queens College, died on Friday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 55 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Bush Denies Satellite Parts to China
description: President Bush has barred the sale of American components for a Chinese domestic communications satellite because of concerns about Chinese exports of possible weapons of mass destruction to third-world countries, the White House announced today.

title: Interim Archbishop of Atlanta Named to Post Permanently
description: The priest who had been acting as Roman Catholic Archbishop of Atlanta since his predecessor resigned almost a year ago over an affair with a woman was named to the post permanently today.

title: Tsongas Is First Entrant In '92 Presidential Race
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts began a long-shot campaign for the Presidency today with a scornful indictment of "Washington mediocrity" and a plea for "a different path" toward economic and political renewal.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Thomas F. Burchill has been named chairman of the board of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau.

title: Review/Television; For Young and Adult, It's AIDS Day on Channel 13
description: Television's sorry record in dealing with the AIDS epidemic is by now numbingly familiar. Homosexuals and drug addicts, the people hardest hit so far, are not Madison Avenue's favorite demographic groups. But every once in a while television makes a special effort that, in relative isolation, is commendable. This usually happens outside the jittery precincts of the commercial networks.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: CARNEGIE HALL, 1960 At 17 I came to New York. The dormitory Was higher than most buildings I'd ever Been in. I ate in a coffee shop Where people never looked at you, Went on a tour of Bellevue Because it was a place, like Lindy's Or the Metropolitan Museum of Art, So legendary that being there was magic. Some New York kids I met said, "Let's go to Carnegie Hall." From Standing Room We looked down at the Philharmonic And their TV-star conductor, jumping Up and down on his podium, all creating Wonderful noise that filled the place And vibrated to the roots of my hair. The things you could take for granted in New York! -- LEWIS GARDNER

title: Lesotho's Military Leader Ousted by Army Officers
description: The head of Lesotho's military junta was forced to resign today after a bloodless coup by rebel army officers.

title: Now Bruins Are Looking to Stop Lemieux
description: Now that the demons of the Montreal Canadiens have been exorcised from Boston Garden, the next challenge for the Boston Bruins is Mario Lemieux and the Pittsburgh Penguins, who are playing like a team possessed.

title: Americans Teaching English in Czechoslovakia Learn About Themselves
description: Missy Darwin teaches English at a parachuting club in Prague. She never trained to be a teacher and has no textbooks. For St. Patrick's Day, she asked students to wear green and bring whatever green food they could find in the drab wintertime stalls of Czechoslovakia's markets.

title: Bridge
description: A slight deviation from normal bidding practice often has a major impact on the play. On the diagramed deal from a duplicate game at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, Marcel Friedman as North chose to open one diamond rather than a routine one club. When six hearts was reached, West did not consider an attacking diamond lead, which he might have done if the suit had not been bid.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in April
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products were unchanged from March to April, but the overall commodity index slipped 1.3 percent below its level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Purse Is Increased
description: The total purse for the Wimbledon championships this year will be a record $6.8 million, but it will not be equally distributed among the men and women, Wimbledon officials said yesterday.

title: Vegetable-Rights Bill Vetoed
description: A bill that would have barred unwarranted negative remarks about vegetables has been vetoed by Gov. Roy Romer.

title: Hannibal the Cannibal Coming To Friday Night Stay-at-Homes
description: The promos on NBC this week are promising a chilling prospect: "Hannibal the Cannibal Lechter is coming to your house Friday night."

title: Auburn Receives N.C.A.A. Inquiry
description: Auburn University received an official letter of inquiry from the National Collegiate Athletic Association regarding possible major rule violations in its basketball and tennis programs, James Martin, prsident of the university, said today.

title: Noriega's Lawyers Say He Aided Anti-Drug Effort
description: Lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that documents seized by the United States armed forces in the invasion of Panama would show that the former dictator helped law-enforcement authorities in combating drug trafficking.

title: Tale in Tail(s): A Study Worthy of Alice's Friends
description: Lewis Carroll's passion for word games has kept many a scholar busy, and amused, prowling editions of his work looking for verbal intricacies to decipher.

title: Theater in Review
description: Modigliani Jewish Repertory Theater 344 East 14th Street By Dennis McIntyre; directed by Bryna Wortman; sets, Scott Bradley; costumes, Barbara A. Bell; lights, Brian Nason; sound, Aural Fixation; production stage manager, D. C. Rosenberg. Presented by Jewish Repertory Theater, Ran Avni, artistic director; Edward M. Cohen, associate director. WITH: David Beach, Ronald Guttman, Daniel James, Dane Knell, Martin Rudy, Will Scheffer and Karen Sillas.

title: Economic Scene; Credit Card Conundrum
description: EVER wonder why your bank charges 19 percent interest on credit card balances when it is paying only 6 percent on money market accounts? Join the throng. Interest on bank cards seems to be defying the laws of competition, having risen almost a percentage point in the last two years even as the rates banks pay to attract deposits have fallen.

title: Big Losses For Ford And G.M.
description: The nation's two biggest auto makers announced huge first-quarter losses today.

title: Rudolf F. Haffenreffer 3d, Industrialist, 88
description: Rudolf F. Haffenreffer 3d, an industrialist whose family controlled the Narragansett Brewing Company, died Sunday at his home in Bristol. He was 88 years old.

title: Workers Widen Scope of Strike At Apartments
description: Representatives of apartment building owners and striking service workers resumed contract negotiations yesterday for the first time since the start of the strike, which was expanded yesterday beyond Manhattan.

title: Lewis Bruce Carr, 76, A Real-Estate Lawyer
description: Lewis Bruce Carr, a real-estate lawyer for more than 40 years, died on Saturday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 76 years old and lived in Westhampton Beach.

title: As Green Fiddles, Harrelson Burns
description: WHEN Dallas Green was manager of the Yankees, one thing he grew to detest was the collection of Yankee ex-managers -- Lou Piniella, Billy Martin, Gene Michael -- broadcasting Yankee games, sitting in the owner's box, hovering so close that Green often felt like carrion.

title: Books of The Times; A Pair of Artists in an Unconventional Romance
description: O'Keeffe and Stieglitz An American Romance By Benita Eisler Illustrated. 546 pages. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $29.50.

title: Some in Prison as Deadline for Pretoria Passes
description: The date set for the release of South Africa's political prisoners passed tonight with the Government and the African National Congress differing sharply over how many prisoners remained in jail and when they would be freed.

title: Enron Income Up 7.9%; Tenneco Plunges 99.3%
description: The Enron Corporation, a diversified energy company whose operations include the nation's largest natural-gas pipeline system, said today that net income rose 7.9 percent in the first quarter.

title: Mitchell Reconsiders
description: KEVIN MITCHELL of the San Francisco Giants changed his mind yesterday and decided to continue his appeal of a two-game suspension for charging San Diego pitcher BRUCE HURST during a game three weeks ago.

title: For Fearful Kurdish Refugees, a Long Trek Home
description: High above Bezenik, a littered junkyard of a highland meadow that looks across a deep valley to the Turkish border, Iraqi refugees trekking homeward resemble a stream of overburdened ants.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about John E. Leslie, former chief executive of Bache & Company, omitted aspects of his career. A native of Vienna, he was an honorary consul general of Austria in New York, a former president of the United States Austrian Chamber of Commerce and the founder of the American Austrian Foundation.

title: With Militia Rule in Last Hours, Lebanese Army Moves Into Place
description: The Lebanese Army went into full mobilization today as it prepared to take control of most of the country and re-establish the authority of the central Government, ending a decade and a half of militia rule.

title: Food Notes
description: Not Just a Chicken

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M.

title: New Jersey to Add Trains to Midtown
description: Thanks to almost $100 million in new money from the Port Authority, New Jersey plans to start work next year on a long-delayed railroad connection that will give four counties a direct train link with Penn Station in Manhattan.

title: Igal Roodenko, 74; Led Anti-War Group
description: Igal Roodenko, a printer arrested many times in anti-war and civil-rights protests, died on Sunday at Downtown Beekman Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhatttan.

title: Doctors in Survey Support Marijuana Use by Cancer Patients
description: Nearly half of the cancer specialists responding to a questionnaire on the controversial subject of marijuana used as medicine said they would prescribe the drug if it were legal, researchers at Harvard University said yesterday.

title: Theater in Review
description: Carousel Village Light Opera Group Fashion Institute of Technology 227 West 27th Street Through May 5 Music by Richard Rodgers; book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d; direction and musical staging, Margaret Rose; music director and conductor, Ronald W. Noll; choreography, Bill Waldinger; scenic design, Kevin Sullivan; costumes, Jamie Weeden; lighting, Jeff Zeidman; production stage manager, Dan Rubenstein; technical director, Rick Stanley; producer, Fredda Kaufman. WITH: Rodne Brown, Teresa Lane Hoover, James Lightstone, Kim Stengel and Mira Stunkel.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Sonat Inc. is offering $100 million in 9 percent noncallable notes due in 2001 at 99.5 to yield 9.077 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * Texas Utilities Electric Co. is offering $300 million in 9.75 percent bonds due in 2021 at 100, through Bear, Stearns & Co. The issue is not callable for 10 years and is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

title: Padres' Hopes at Shea Disappear Prematurely on Foggy Night
description: The flag pole was lost to the fog early on last night. Soon, the upper deck had vanished, the ring of lights atop Shea Stadium nothing more than a dull detached halo. Through it all, the scoreboard burned more or less brightly: Mets 6, Padres 3.

title: Brooklyn Store Worker Is Killed in a Robbery
description: Two gunmen walked into a small grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn last night, shot an employee to death and rifled the cash register before leaving, the police said.

title: Judge Frees Widow of Soldier Slain on Return From Gulf
description: The widow of a soldier who was shot to death last month, one day after he had returned from service in the Persian Gulf, was freed Monday when a judge ruled that there was not enough evidence to try her for the slaying.

title: HIGHER COST SEEN FOR NEW SPACE LAB
description: The more modest version of the space station proposed recently by NASA will cost about $40 billion when completed and occupied in 1999, or about $10 billion more than the agency projects, according to a new estimate from the General Accounting Office.

title: Catholic Colleges Chart Paths Still Catholic and Yet Diverse
description: After two decades in which the backgrounds of students and the viewpoints of faculty at the nation's 230 Roman Catholic campuses have steadily grown more diverse, many Catholic educators are asking whether their institutions are in danger of losing their religious identity.

title: Port Is Replaced
description: MIKE PORT, who was unable to assemble a pennant winner in six seasons as general manager of the California Angels, was dismissed yesterday. Port, who had worked for the Angels since 1977, was replaced by his assistant, DAN O'BRIEN .

title: Officials Press for Strong Banking Changes
description: Setting the stage for the first showdown over banking legislation between the Administration and Congressional Democrats, four senior regulators urged lawmakers today to adopt a Treasury Department proposal for overhauling the banking system.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Creative Firebrand Settles In At Ketchum's Staid Office
description: STEVE PENCHINA thought the New York office of Ketchum Advertising was hardly the place for him. The 45-year-old creative firebrand cut his teeth on "Try It, You'll Like It" for Alka-Seltzer at Wells, Rich, Green and later joined Needham Harper Steers, where he helped create the Xerox campaign in which a monk uses an office copier to duplicate manuscripts. "It's a miracle!" the other monks marvel.

title: Book Notes
description: 'M' Is for Money

title: Don't Make Greece Europe's Black Sheep; North vs. South
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: In one of the more amicable celebrity splits of the year, JOHN W. KLUGE , 76, called the richest man in the nation by Forbes magazine last year, and his wife, PATRICIA KLUGE , 42, were granted a divorce recently in a Virginia court, according to Mrs. Kluge's lawyers.

title: Rival Cambodian Forces Accept Cease-Fire
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk's guerrilla army said its field commanders had been ordered to respect a temporary cease-fire in Cambodia starting on Wednesday.

title: United Technologies' Bumpy Ride
description: These should be heady days for the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Eleanor King Memorial
description: A memorial service for Eleanor King, a leading modern dance choreographer who performed with Doris Humphrey, is to be held Thursday at 12:15 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The memorial will include reminiscences by friends and colleagues and performances of Miss King's work by Lori Belilove, Andrea Seidel and Sarah Stackhouse. Miss King died on Feb. 27 at the age of 85.

title: Recycling to Expand to Businesses in New York
description: New York City's mandatory recycling program, limited so far to residences, will soon be expanded to include the five boroughs' 200,000 businesses.

title: For Children's Day, Sweets, Of Course
description: IN Japan and in Japanese communities in the United States, May 5 is Children's Day, or Kodomo no Hi. In Japan, it is a national holiday. Schools are dismissed, offices close, paper carp fly on bamboo poles and special pastries are eaten.

title: Bordeaux's Adolescent Reds Make U.S. Debut
description: BORDEAUX'S 1988 aristocratic reds, cast into the unlikely role of Cinderellas by the acclaimed 1989's, formally made their debut in New York on Sunday. The guests at their coming-out party pronounced many of them elegant beauties.

title: Telemarketing Fraud Case Is Tentatively Settled
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it had tentatively settled its largest telemarketing fraud case ever, one that is expected to return $47 million to 8,230 consumers who bought phony oil and gas leases in the early 1980's.

title: Man Shot at Botanic Dance
description: A sound engineer taking a break from a dance at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden was shot in the arm Monday night, apparently by a burst of submachine-gun fire from a nearby rooftop, the police said.

title: Dow Edges Upward 10.89, to 2,887.87
description: After stock traders waited a month for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, the Fed finally came through with a surprise cut, but stock prices did not respond much.

title: Paramount Pictures Job
description: Brandon Tartikoff is expected to be named chairman of Paramount Pictures within the next several days, a person close to the company said yesterday. A Paramount executive declined to comment on the likelihood of the appointment of Mr. Tartikoff, who is head of NBC Entertainment. The executive also declined to comment on rumors that some kind of merger between Paramount and NBC was being considered. He did confirm that the Paramount Communications board met yesterday.

title: Review/Ballet; A Vision of Hell From Ohio In Kudelko's 'There, below'
description: Ballet Met, an enterprising young company from Columbus, Ohio, made its New York City debut over the weekend with a varied program that says a great deal about its repertory and ambitions.

title: William Paton, 101, Pioneer Accountant, Theorist and Scholar
description: William A. Paton, a certified public accountant who was a pioneer in modern accounting theory, died Friday at the Whitehall Convalescent Home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 101 years old and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: Historians Rebut Plagiarism Charge
description: Twenty-two Civil War and Lincoln scholars and historians released a statement yesterday saying the charges of plagiarism against Prof. Stephen B. Oates "are totally unfounded."

title: DeShields's Leadoff Homer In 9th Inning Beats Dodgers
description: Delino DeShields led off the ninth inning with a home run for Montreal's second hit of the game tonight, leading Dennis Martinez and the Expos past the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0.

title: Schrempf Gets Award
description: DETLEF SCHREMPF, a versatile 6-foot 10-inch forward for the Indiana Pacers, yesterday was named the winner of the National Basketball Association Sixth Man Award, edging out DAN MAJERLE of the Phoenix Suns, 38 to 37.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Fired Mike Port, general manager. Named Dan O'Brien general manager. BASKETBALL Continental Basketball Association LACROSSE CATBIRDS -- Acquired Kenny Drummond, guard, from Grand Rapids to complete an earlier trade. United States Basketball League MIAMI TROPICS -- Signed Lloyd Daniels, guard. Named Kevin Koffman director of operations; Jonathan Grossman assistant director of operations; and Mark Macelli director of marketing. World Basketball League FLORIDA JADES -- Signed Darryl Kennedy and Winston Morgan, forwards. FOOTBALL National Football League CLEVELAND BROWNS -- Signed George Hemingway, Archie Herring, Terry Strong and Fred Word, running backs; Nathaniel Bolton, wide receiver; Terrill Chatman, offensive tackle; Ben Mitchell, offensive guard; Terrence Sanders, defensive end; Theron Ellis, Dwayne Fontenette and Douglas Moore, linebackers; and Charlie Oliver, defensive back. Waived Ralph Stephens, punter.

title: Unlikely Union Arises To Press Family Issues
description: An unusual alliance of conservative Republicans and liberal and moderate Democrats is pressing the Federal Government to adopt policies that members say will reverse the decline and breakup of American families.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: TO my taste, pork has more flavor in certain dishes than veal or beef. With summer barbecue season here, I often prepare highly seasoned pork burgers with caraway seeds. The recipe works equally well indoors with a skillet.

title: A Colombian Who Led Fight Against Drugs Rings Is Slain
description: Gunmen riding a motorcycle tonight killed a former Colombian Justice Minister who led the campaign to extradite drug traffickers to the United States, the Bogota radio said.

title: Test All Hospital Patients for AIDS, New Jersey Doctors Urge
description: The Medical Society of New Jersey today called for testing all hospital patients for the AIDS virus. Homosexual rights groups were angered by the move and said it was the first such proposal by a medical society in the nation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY J. STERN , president of the Citizens Union, a New York City civic group, thought the traditional categories of donors for benefit parties -- sponsors, patrons and benefactors -- a bit stuffy. So he named the groupings for guests at a dinner next week "Minnows" (they pay $56), "Trout" ($156) and "Sturgeon" ($256).

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Abbey Home Healthcare, Huntington Beach, Calif., named Timothy M. Aitken president. * Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., Decatur, Ill., named Martin L. Andreas corporate vice president-marketing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Wages Show a More Moderate Advance
description: Wages, salaries and benefits paid to American workers rose 4.6 percent over the last 12 months, a much slower advance than the year before, the Government said today in a report viewed as evidence that wage inflation was abating.

title: U.S. to Study Big Rise in Medicaid Costs
description: The White House today appointed what officials called a "budgetary swat team" to find out why Medicaid costs were expected to rise more than $15 billion over the next fiscal year and why the Government had failed to foresee the huge increase.

title: Loss on Mail at $1.4 Billion
description: The United States Postal Service said today that it had a $1.4 billion loss in the first half of the fiscal year 1991, largely because of increased payments to the Federal Treasury.

title: Despite Soviet Turmoil, Credits Are Held Likely
description: It is growing harder for the Administration to guarantee bank loans to the Soviet Union for the purchase of American grain, Congressional and Administration trade experts said yesterday.

title: Key Treasury Adviser To Join J. P. Morgan
description: Charles H. Dalarra, one of the Treasury's top international experts, will join J. P. Morgan & Company in June, the Treasury said today. Mr. Dalarra, 42, is well known in international financial circles for his work on the third-world debt problem and in helping to coordinate economic policies among the industrial nations that make up the Group of Seven.

title: Burdens of Keeping New York City Going Must Be Shared
description: To the Editor:

title: For A Lot of Mainers, Lobstering Life Is Losing Allure
description: IT was more than 100 years ago that Maynard Post first put down lobster traps in the icy waters off this isolated fishing village on the craggy Maine coastline.

title: Tommy Paul, Boxer, 82
description: Tommy Paul, a former world featherweight boxing champion, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: In Trash, a Brief Life and a Note of Love
description: In New York City it is not unusual for newborn babies, some still alive, to be discarded like mistakes into trash cans and garbage bags, down chutes and into Dumpsters. Usually they die anonymously. Only occasionally do they command the public's attention.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed " 'Junk Bonds': The New Accounting," about the junk bond holdings of insurance companies, referred incompletely to the Sun Life company involved. It was the Sun Life Insurance Company of America, chartered in Maryland.

title: Vietnam Vets Built Memorial Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Found Guilty In Bias Murder
description: A Prince George's County jury today convicted two men of charges they killed James Stanley (Jay) Bias 3d, the younger brother of the late University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias.

title: Treasury Issues Sharply Higher
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday as prices of Treasury and other fixed-income securities soared in response to two moves by the Federal Reserve to reduce borrowing costs. The first was to cut the discount rate, which the Fed charges member commercial banks, to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Believed to Retain Material for Nuclear Bomb Despite intensive allied bombing, Iraq still has enough undamaged uranium to make one nuclear bomb, officials and scientists conclude from an Iraqi letter to the United Nations on its nuclear holdings. Page A14.

title: Dibble Offers Apology For His Heated Mistake
description: ROB DIBBLE, the Cincinnati pitcher whose temper is nearly as quick as his fastball, has apologized to the MEG PORTER, the first-grade teacher he injured on Sunday after throwing a baseball into the stands at Riverfront Stadium and hitting her in the elbow at game's end.

title: Around Barn 42, Lots of Buzzing
description: Heywood Broun once said it about Casey Stengel: "He can talk all day and all night on any kind of track, wet or dry."

title: The Great Game Of 'Gai-atsu'
description: The word for it in Japanese is "gai-atsu," literally "foreign pressure," but in effect "Japan-bashing." It covers all those things like extracting billions of dollars to help pay for the gulf crisis, pushing on the sacrosanct ban against rice imports, trying to set market quotas on semiconductor chips.

title: Irwin Baron Executive, 89
description: Irwin Baron, former president of James Felt & Company, a Manhattan realty concern, died on Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 89 years old and had lived in Brookfield, Conn., and in Manhattan.

title: Henderson and Yanks Go Nowhere
description: Rickey Henderson's pursuit of baseball's career stolen-base record was stalled tonight, but the evening was not a total loss for Oakland. Henderson, stuck at 938 steals, scored a run and helped send the Yankees to their 15th straight loss against the Athletics.

title: Rauschenberg Work Brings Sale Record
description: Robert Rauschenberg's "Rebus" from 1955 -- auctioned 18 months ago for a record $6.3 million -- was sold last night at Sothebys's in Manhattan for $7.3 million. The price was the highest paid at auction for a work by the artist and at Sotheby's current sale of postwar art.

title: Water-Sewage Fees to Rise 18.5% In New York, and Ocean Benefits
description: New York City property owners, experiencing first-hand the costs of environmental protection, face an 18.5 percent increase in water and sewer charges beginning July 1. The increase is intended largely to pay for ending ocean dumping of treated sewage.

title: Key Rates
Gulf War II
description: U.S. Army Capt. Bill Moss, a reservist from Memphis, describes the work of the riggers who work furiously tying together chin-high pallets of food to parachute to Kurdish refugees. "We've been working without a break except to eat," he says. "But let me tell you, the guys feel better about this than Desert Storm."

title: So Call It a 'Victory Dividend'
description: What's in a name? Sometimes, hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: No-Good-Knicks: Bulls Complete a Playoff Sweep
description: The Knicks' season came to an abrupt and disappointing end last night. And there is little doubt that the franchise will undergo major changes within the next several weeks.

title: Ballyhoo Behind, Abner Still Seeks Niche
description: The warm feeling that Shawn Abner used to experience when he thought about playing baseball at Shea Stadium has worn off. It was never very warm anyway. When Abner went hitless in three times at bat during a 6-3 loss to the Mets last night, it was just another game and just another ballpark.

title: Most Teachers Vote to Stop Strike in Washington State
description: Most of Washington State's 20,000 striking teachers returned to work today after voting Monday night to end a walkout that kept 300,000 students out of class for more than a week.

title: Disney and Henson In Muppet Settlement
description: The Walt Disney Company can proceed with plans for two attractions featuring the Muppets as part of a settlement with Henson Associates, which owns the rights to the Muppets.

title: Avianca Pilots Blamed by U.S. In '90 L.I. Crash
description: The pilots of a Colombian jetliner that ran out of fuel and crashed last year on Long Island were mainly to blame for the accident because they never declared an emergency when talking to air traffic controllers, the National Transportation Safety Board determined today.

title: Arab Slays a French Woman In a Bethlehem Restaurant
description: A Palestinian described by the Israeli Army as a Muslim fanatic stabbed a 64-year-old French woman to death today in a restaurant on Manger Square.

title: Pivotal Redistricting Figure Criticizes Commission Plan
description: A pivotal member of the panel drawing new districts for the New York City Council said yesterday that the process had been poisoned by the desire to protect incumbents and create minority seats where they logically should not exist. He made his remarks on the eve of the presentation of the preliminary districting plan.

title: In the Nation; What's Improper?
description: The issue of propriety in public life and especially in public office gets headline and television coverage and has assumed political importance often out of all proportion to alleged or real behavior. But not always.

title: United Airlines Employees Testify On Threat Allegedly Made by Spira
description: A United Airlines employee testified yesterday that Howard Spira threatened another employee over a lost-luggage claim, saying he would have "his blood or his life."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a news conference by a secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party misidentified him. He is Aleksandr Dzasokhov.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN COSTS TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Trying to end the recession, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates today, noting as it acted that the latest data showed the economy to be still quite weak.

title: Proof That Cholesterol Can't Kill: An Egg Shop That Thrives
description: IT was one thing when cholesterol became the national bogyman, when the very word tugged the collective fear of mortality and dread of fragility and began to represent the failure of self-control. It was one thing when the test for cholesterol levels became part of the Complete Physical Exam and the tally became standard dinner-party chat. It was one thing when things like cholesterol-free egg substitutes appeared in groceries.

title: Bad Frankenhausen Journal; A Hero and a Picture From History's Attic
description: Here amid the low hills where 5,000 of his followers were killed one afternoon in 1525, Thomas Muntzer still casts a bizarre shadow.

title: Israelis Say an Arab University Can Reopen
description: The Defense Ministry announced today that Palestinian students could return to Hebron University, more than three years after the school was shut to prevent political activity on its campus.

title: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the ninth straight week ended yesterday, with the size of the declines diminishing in recent weeks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They are the children of a legendary songwriting team, and on May 15 MARY RODGERS and WILLIAM HAMMERSTEIN will get together at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan to share "Happy Talk: Reflections on Rodgers and Hammerstein."

title: VERDICT APPEALED IN BARRY DRUG CASE
description: Former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. urged a Federal appeals court today to overturn his conviction and six-month prison sentence for cocaine possession, arguing through his lawyers that the evidence did not merit a guilty finding and that the judge had been racially biased and had incorrectly applied sentencing rules.

title: House Members to Explore Suspicions in '80 Campaign
description: Several senior members of the House of Representatives, encouraged by Speaker Thomas S. Foley, are beginning to explore informally charges that the 1980 Reagan-Bush campaign staff dealt with Iran to make sure 52 American hostages were not released until after the election.

title: Air-Conditioning a 32-Mile Tunnel
description: Rail tunnels have always been able to maintain a comfortable temperature because air circulates freely from one end of the passage to the other. But with the construction of the world's longest underwater tunnel, beneath the English Channel between Britain and France, come several unforeseen challenges in keeping things cool underground.

title: Burdens of Keeping New York City Going Must Be Shared; What Teachers Got
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Studies New Role For Thruway Authority
description: A New York State advisory council is studying whether the state's Thruway Authority has the resources to take control of New York's entire interstate highway system, officials said today.

title: Howard R. Staub, 87, Real-Estate Consultant
description: Howard Randall Staub, a retired Connecticut real-estate consultant who was director of enemy property for the United States headquarters in Japan after World War II, died on Monday at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in New Preston, Conn.

title: Market Place; Fed Move Raises Odds for a Rally
description: THE stock market had a mixed reaction yesterday to the Federal Reserve's third discount rate cut of recent months. Prices rallied at the opening, then traded much lower most of the day, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the day up 10.89 points, to 2,887.87.

title: 'Misguided' Food Groups
description: To The Living Section:

title: SOVIET QUAKE TOLL RISES TO OVER 100
description: The death toll from the powerful earthquake in Soviet Georgia rose today to more than 100 as rescue teams combed through the rubble of buildings and homes to uncover the dead and the injured.

title: Barkley and 76ers Complete a Knockout
description: Charles Barkley, leaping off a left knee encased in a brace, had 30 points and 12 rebounds as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 121-100, tonight to sweep their first-round playoff series.

title: Fire Damages a Nuclear Plant in Maine
description: A nuclear power plant in Maine was crippled by explosions and a fire Monday night, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today, but it said no radiation was released into the air.

title: Stonebridge To Mobil Unit
description: The land development unit of the Mobil Corporation said today that it had signed an option to acquire the vast Stonebridge Ranch property north of Dallas from the Government. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Kimberly-Clark Notes Are Priced
description: A $200 million offering of 10-year notes issued by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation was priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Unresolved Questions
description: Although the draft agreement reached in Madrid appeared to satisfy environmental groups as well as the nations that had sought to keep open the option of mining in Antarctica, many questions remain unresolved.

title: South Carolina Prices Bond Issue
description: South Carolina, one of just a few states whose credit rating is still rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, priced $85 million in capital-improvement general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding.

title: Grumman Earnings Climb
description: The Grumman Corporation today reported first-quarter profits of $22.5 million, but the gain was due entirely to accounting procedures taken to offset a large charge.

title: Violent People Go To Violent Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Creditors React to Offer By Retailers
description: Merchandise creditors of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores reacted with general approval yesterday to the companies' reorganization plan because they would get the biggest share -- about $513 million -- of the $850 million in cash to be offered.

title: George Speri Sperti Is Dead at 91; Invented Several Patent Medicines
description: George Speri Sperti, a research scientist who invented a wide range of products, including a sunlamp and the patent medicines Preparation H and Aspercreme, died Monday at St. Elizabeth Medical Center North in Cincinnati. He was 91 years old.

title: Taiwan Ends Emergency Decree, Opening Way to Closer China Ties
description: President Lee Teng-hui declared an end to 43 years of emergency rule today, paving the way for greater democracy on the island and closer relations with China.

title: Movie Explores 'Slaves' of Food
description: WHEN Henry Jaglom was young, he used to hang around his mother and her friends, listening to them talk and talk and talk. He grew up relishing the words of women, preferring their open emotionality to the ways of men, who were more likely to slap one another on the back than to share confidences.

title: Recycled Trash Is Put To Use in Construction
description: The country's first building that uses blocks made from recycled incinerator ash is being built in Stony Brook, L.I., on the campus of the State University of New York there.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I knew I wanted to become a lobsterman when I was 2. But these days it's gotten almost to the point where it no longer pays. The price of bait keeps going up but the price of lobster keeps going down. Everyone's got ideas but no one really knows what to do." -- Richard Post of Spruce Head, Me. [ C6:2. ]

title: Conference on Boat People Sidesteps Repatriation Issue
description: An international conference meant to decide the fate of Vietnamese boat people today sidestepped the issue of whether to force them to go home if they do not face persecution.

title: Comptroller's Investments
description: The official in charge of supervising federally chartered banks trades in stocks and "junk bonds" and has borrowed money to invest, according to a newspaper report on his 1991 financial disclosure form and filings for earlier years.

title: Wine Talk
description: LONG ago, there was a time each year when cynical newspaper people, sitting around their offices, would ask each other, "Hey, isn't it time for the annual 'Frost Destroys Florida Orange Crop' story?"

title: Sports of The Times; Grunfeld Must Lift Knick Fog
description: A FEW white rally flags, a few sporadic chants of "Dee-fense," just for old time's sake, and a chance to see Michael Jordan one more time in April.

title: Al Oliver to Coach Shawnwee State
description: Al Oliver, who made 2,743 hits during his 18-year major league career, has been selected as the first baseball coach at Shawnee State University.

title: Insurance as a Job Benefit Shows Signs of Overwork
description: World War II was only a few months old. The nation was mobilizing. With millions of young men in uniform, civilian workers were in short supply and the War Labor Board, to avoid inflation, put a ceiling on wages.

title: European Plan On Japan Cars
description: Japan will be allowed to raise car exports to the European Community gradually over six years, starting in 1993, European officials said today, but they announced no quotas.

title: At a Book Fair in Germany, There's Freedom With a Twist
description: In the halls and aisles of this year's Leipzig Book Fair, publishers and booksellers discuss soaring prices and collapsing markets and readers flocking to once-forbidden foreign authors and new media, like video. Under Communism, it was said that the newspapers printed fiction, so people sought the truth in books. Now that is reversing, so while newspapers flourish, book publishing is caught in crisis.

title: Continental Air Has a Loss
description: Continental Airlines, citing a drop in passengers because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war, announced today that it lost $195 million in the first three months of 1991.

title: Courts' Role as Land Manager Grows
description: A zoologist who tracks nocturnal birds in the forest was in court here today, trying to explain the breeding habits of an owl to a Federal judge. One floor below, another Federal judge was going over maps prepared by the Government to determine how much land the owl needed to avoid extinction.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Soviet Union Tops U.S. Vyacheslav Fetisov scored two early goals as the Soviet Union beat Team USA, 6-4, at Turku, Finland, yesterday in the opening game of the medal round at the world championships. The Soviets, defending champions and favored to win a record 23d title, took a 4-0 lead with just 12:20 gone in the first period. But the Americans, losers to the Soviets by 12-2 in the preliminary round a week ago, got back in the game as defensemen Craig Wolanin and Joe Sacco scored just 25 seconds apart late in the first period. After another Soviet goal, Brian Mullen and Tom Fitzgerald scored within 1:42 early in the second period to make it 5-4. In the other medal-round opener, Canada and Sweden played to a 3-3 tie. (AP) TENNIS Pernfors Upsets Pate Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, plagued by injuries and without a victory on the Association of Tennis Professionals tour since the 1990 Australian Open, upset fifth-seeded David Pate, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the first round of the United States Tennis Association's men's clay courts event in Tampa, Fla. (AP) Gustafsson Tops Stich: Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden upset Michael Stich of Germany, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the rain-troubled first round of the BMW German Open in Munich. (AP) Graf Romps: Second-seeded Steffi Graf breezed, 6-1, 6-3, over Marketa Kochta, also of Germany, in just 58 minutes yesterday in the first round of the Hamburg Open. (AP) Connors Loses: Jimmy Connors was beaten in his first clay-court tournament in two years, losing at the Villa de Madrid tournament. Cassio Motta of Brazil outlasted the 38-year-old Connors, 7-6, 1-6, 6-1, in just under two hours. Top-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain was another first-round victim, losing to the 65th-ranked Renzo Furlan of Italy, 4-6, 7-6, 6-3. (AP) TABLE TENNIS Sweden Retains Title Sweden edged Yugoslavia, 3-2, at Chiba, Japan, and retained its world men's team championship. The United States team finished 15th after beating Poland, 3-0. (AP)

title: Review/Ballet Theater; A New but Familiar 'Don Quixote'
description: Restaging is the name of the game at American Ballet Theater this season, and the audience will be counting the ways. The company's new version of "Don Quixote," 19th-century Russian ballet's most famous pretext for bravura dancing, received its uneven but energized premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night.

title: HOSPITALS CITED IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Eight New York City hospitals were among 161 in the nation with higher-than-expected death rates for Medicare patients, according to a Federal report released yesterday.

title: Man Kills Wife, 2 Children
description: An auto mechanic shot and killed his wife and two small children Tuesday night, and then apparently committed suicide, while the family was at a fishing spot along the Hudson River here, the state police said today. The bodies were found by Conrail workers this morning. The police said the man, William Allen Walberg, 29 years old, who lived in Rhinecliff, had shot his wife, Dawn, 26, who lived in Hyde Park, and the children, John, 7, and Kayla, 3, who lived with their mother.

title: U.S. Team Seeking Exodus of Ethiopian Jews
description: After talks with the Ethiopian President, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, American officials expressed hope today that the embattled leader would allow the exodus to Israel in the next few weeks of up to 18,000 Ethiopian Jews, before feared chaos descends on the capital, Addis Ababa.

title: Planting by the Full Moon: Bright Idea, or Lunacy?
description: LAST Sunday the moon was full. It flooded the fields and spilled light into the windows of high-rise apartments. And all over the country, moon gardeners were planting by it -- corn, pole beans, sweet peas -- because they know that a full moon will make corn grow tall and pull a vining bean right up the pole.

title: Japan Vehicle Sales Up
description: Japanese vehicle sales, excluding mini-vehicles, were estimated at 470,549 in April, up 1.1 percent from a year earlier, an official of the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. The rise was the first in six months, the official said. The sales were a record for April, surpassing the previous record for the month set a year ago. But sales were down 36.6 percent from 742,507 vehicles in March. April sales of imported vehicles fell 12.8 percent from a year earlier, to 17,569. It was the fourth monthly consecutive decline.

title: Bush Trade Concessions Pick Up Some Support
description: The Bush Administration got a favorable reception in Congress today to its commitments to insulate American workers and the environment from the effects of a free trade agreement with Mexico.

title: Bloomingdale's Is Closing Store in Queens, Its First Branch
description: Bloomingdale's announced yesterday that it would close its Fresh Meadows, Queens, store on July 13 after 42 years of operation. It is the only other New York City department store that the retail chain operates besides its Manhattan flagship store at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Top Andy Honors Go To Saatchi New Zealand
description: The New Zealand office of Saatchi & Saatchi took top honors last evening at the 27th International Andy Awards sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.

title: Fast When Breaking Records, Too
description: In setting his record for stolen bases at the age of 32, Rickey Henderson has achieved in mid-career the type of cumulative statistic ordinarily unreachable until the late stages of a man's playing life.

title: Rock-a-Bye Baby? That May Not Help
description: Rocking a baby to sleep with a tender lullaby may not be the best routine if the child wakes frequently during the night, new research suggests.

title: Barnett in Discussions With Ailing Southeast
description: Barnett Banks Inc., operator of Florida's largest bank, said today that it was in discussions with the ailing Southeast Banking Corporation, which is looking for a merger partner or buyout.

title: Reader's Digest Group Gives Duke Media Unit $3 Million
description: Duke University announced yesterday that its Institute of Policy Sciences and Public Affairs has received an unrestricted endowment grant of $3 million from the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Special Projects Fund. The money will be used to support the Center for the Study of Communications and Journalism, one of the several centers that the institute comprises.

title: Seattle Showpiece of Health Care by Democracy
description: For a single monthly fee, most members of Group Health Cooperative have access to nearly unlimited medical care. If they live well, without smoking, drinking heavily or becoming overweight, they can pay even less. If they do not like the way their local clinic is being run, they can change it by voting out the management.

title: U.S. Chief Is Named For Conran's Habitat
description: After a flashy entry into the United States home furnishings business in 1977, Conran's in the last five years failed to sustain the momentum that it achieved early on for unusual, modern furniture design.

title: Public & Private; The Human Condition
description: To learn about The Human Condition, you must watch the daytime television talk shows. The Human Condition is not your condition. Your condition is mortgage payments, lost dry cleaning, fleas on the cat and 10 pounds overweight.

title: Dow Rises 42.33; Closes At 2,930.20
description: Wall Street got back on track yesterday, lifting stocks sharply in heavy trading. Most of the buying, though, came from small investors, not big institutions, which were selling while the others were buying.

title: IN THE IRISH SOUTH, SOME COMPROMISE
description: The opening of new talks on peace and stability in Northern Ireland has stirred a growing willingness on this side of the border to compromise on one of the most cherished and long-held ambitions of Irish nationalists: a united Ireland.

title: Another Record Brewing? A's Beat Yankees Again
description: The significance of the game may have been obscured by Rickey Henderson's record-breaking day, but it was not lost entirely. The Yankees still cannot find a solution to their long-term problem: how to beat the Oakland Athletics.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Y.&R.; Loses Lipton Ads To Ogilvy
description: The Thomas J. Lipton Company shifted about $7 million worth of food advertising assignments yesterday from Young & Rubicam to Ogilvy & Mather in a consolidation move.

title: Lebanon on Verge of Cementing Reunion
description: The Lebanese Army deployed thousands of troops in areas south, east and north of the capital today, taking another big step toward reuniting Muslim and Christian parts of a country that was partitioned for years by civil war.

title: Legal Code: Goodbye Jeans
description: The prosecutors at the United States District Court House in Brooklyn are being dressed down for not dressing up.

title: Wave Hill Puts Itself On Display
description: "WAVE HILL PICTURED," an exhibit of photographs, opens on Tuesday at Wave Hill Garden, the 28-acre public estate in the Bronx over the Hudson.

title: Market Place; Two Indictments In Texscan Case
description: A FLORIDA public relations man and an Arizona broker were charged yesterday with stock manipulation that caused a sharp and surprising rise in the price of shares in the Texscan Corporation last month.

title: Roberts Proves He Can Take the Call
description: Bip Roberts remembered receiving the telephone call about a year ago and hearing a familiar voice crying out for help. He can't remember the date of the conversation, but he said he can't forget the voice. It was a voice he knew well as a boy. It was a voice he lost touch with.

title: 15 Top Journalists Object to Gulf War Curbs
description: Editors from 15 major American news organizations complained to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney today that the Pentagon had exercised "virtual total control" over the American press during the Persian Gulf war and said they would press for more open coverage of future military operations.

title: Hollow Rhetoric From the Unions
description: There are a lot of unhappy people in New York City and throughout the state. The rally on Tuesday in downtown Manhattan arranged by public employees' unions was one of the latest expressions of dissatisfaction with the cold reality of the recession, a recession felt not only by New Yorkers but by nearly every American.

title: Fly So Free: a Song of Love, Life and (of Course) Winning
description: It was only a morning workout, but it was staged three days before the Kentucky Derby and it starred the favorite, Fly So Free.

title: Times Mirror in Plan For Environmental Aid
description: Beginning in July, Times Mirror Magazines will contribute to environmental education causes a portion of its revenues from ads that include an environmental message.

title: Apple Warns of an Earnings Dip
description: Although its sales are growing rapidly after it cut prices on its popular Macintosh machines, Apple Computer Inc. said today that its earnings for the third quarter of its fiscal year might be lower than for the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: A Cease-Fire in Cambodia Disappears in a Few Hours
description: A temporary cease-fire in the long Cambodian conflict, agreed upon by all sides and supposed to begin today, lasted only a few hours before being broken by tank and artillery battles, Cambodian guerrilla leaders said tonight.

title: G.M. Outlet In Manhattan Closes Doors
description: The last remaining General Motors Corporation dealership in Manhattan, a Cadillac-Buick-Chevrolet franchise belonging to Roger S. Penske and G.M., quietly closed its doors today.

title: Hybrid Lantanas: Beauties and Beasts
description: BEFORE saying a single good word about hybrid lantanas, I need to point out that in some parts of the world they represent an ecological disaster of high magnitude, an unintentional outcome of a seemingly harmless human desire to add new and lovely plants to gardens.

title: MacLeod Will Resign Today to Take Notre Dame Coaching Post
description: John MacLeod, whose future with the Knicks was in doubt, will resign as coach today and expects to be named head coach at Notre Dame by tomorrow.

title: Review/Music; Mozart's Diversions and Naughty Rounds
description: Lincoln Center turned another page Tuesday evening in its encyclopedic observance of the Mozart Bicentennial. The project, which involves presenting virtually all of the composer's more than 600 works within a 12-month period, naturally allots most of the popular repertory to professional performers. Were it not, however, for the participation of music schools and their students, that would leave large areas of his output all but untouched.

title: Pop in Review
description: Al Grey Trio Fortune Garden Pavilion 209 East 49th Street Manhattan Through May 12

title: LTV Files Payment Plan For Pensions
description: In its first formal proposal to end one of the longest and most rancorous bankruptcies in corporate history, the LTV Corporation offered today to pay $3 billion into steelworker retirement plans over 28 years, but at a huge cost to creditors and its own future.

title: Rape Inquiry Nearly Over, Police Chief Says
description: More than a month after a rape was reported at the Kennedy estate here, Palm Beach police officials said today that they expected to turn the case over to the county prosecutor next week.

title: Anti-Boycott Legislation
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, accused the Commerce Department yesterday of inadequate efforts to enforce a law that bars American companies from complying with an Arab trade boycott of Israel. The Congressman introduced legislation to transfer jurisdiction over anti-boycott violations to the Justice Department. The Commerce Department had no immediate comment.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: In-line skating, better known as blading or roller blading, is the hottest new sport in town. It arrived just in time for exercisers who were looking for a low-impact activity that they could enjoy while strengthening their muscles and improving the function of their hearts and lungs.

title: Indicators Are Up 0.5% In 2d Consecutive Rise
description: Sending an ambiguous message about the economy, the Government's principal forecasting index rose for the second straight month in March although most of its components fell.

title: Hasbro-Tonka
description: Hasbro Inc. said it expected to complete its $486 million takeover deal for the Tonka Corporation, a rival toy maker, by next Tuesday. It said that as of Monday, Tonka stockholders had pledged to sell 8.7 million shares to Hasbro. Tonka's bondholders have already agreed to the deal. Hasbro is expected to finance the acquisition entirely on its own, probably through borrowing in the public and private markets, including a certain amount of bank debt. An equity element is "under review," the company said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Lou Brock is the symbol of great base stealing, but today I'm the greatest of all time." -- Rickey Henderson. [ B17:2. ]

title: 161 Hospitals Found With High Death Rates
description: Federal health officials today listed 161 hospitals with higher-than-expected death rates for Medicare patients, including 15 that have had high rates for four years in a row. Six of the 15 were in Puerto Rico.

title: Kodak Net Dips to Low End of Forecasts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings declined 10.6 percent, to $178 million, or 55 cents a share, from $199 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: For Iraqis, Slow Return To Normality
description: The Baghdad Observer, the only English-language paper in a country where foreign publications are not available, reappeared today for the first time since the start of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Paul B. Hoeber, Publisher, 76
description: Paul B. Hoeber, former head of the medical book division of Harper & Brothers, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: N. F. Washburne, 64, Professor of Sociology
description: Norman F. Washburne, a professor of sociology at the Newark campus of Rutgers University, died on Saturday at Reed Memorial Hospital in Richmond, Ind. He was 64 years old and lived in West Windsor, N.J.

title: Good Friday Holiday Is Upheld for Hawaii
description: Hawaii's observance of Good Friday as a legal holiday has been upheld by a Federal appeals court here, which says the state is not favoring religion but simply giving government workers a day off.

title: Stricken Nuclear Plant Was at Capacity
