description: The fire that has indefinitely shut the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant occurred while the plant's operators were running the reactor here at record power levels, plant officials said today.

title: Precious Time
description: National Football League officials agreed several months ago to limit the time draftees and rookie free agents could spend with their new pro teams during the school year, hoping to keep the students in classes.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Atlantic Richfield Co. is offering $100 million in noncallable 9 percent debentures due 2031 at 100 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

title: U.S. Wants Iraq to Finance Kurdish Relief Operations
description: The United States wants Iraq to pay for the American-led effort to help Kurdish refugees in the northern part of the country, senior Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Cowering Before Medical Costs
description: Medical costs are skyrocketing. Millions of underinsured citizens live in fear of financial ruin from medical catastrophe. Clearly the nation's system of medical insurance cries out for reform. But the Bush Administration barely listens, content to bury the issue in an internal working group with no compelling mandate and no specific timetable.

title: Celtics Stop Pacers' Person to take 2-1 Lead in Series
description: After losing five straight times at Market Square Arena, the Boston Celtics beat the Indiana Pacers, 112-105, tonight to take a 2-1 lead in their first-round playoff series.

title: Angry Taxpayers Reject 44% of New Jersey School Budgets
description: After a year of angry debate over tax increases and the way New Jersey finances public education, voters on Tuesday rejected 44 percent of the local school budgets submitted to them in one of the most politicized school elections in years.

title: Tax-Exempt Issue Is Priced by Utility
description: A $177 million bond offering by the Modesto-Santa Clara-Redding Public Power Agency was priced yesterday for a maximum yield of 6.87 percent, for a bond due 2017.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Omnicom Net Down
description: The Omnicom Group Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter net income fell 2.7 percent, to $10.5 million, or 40 cents a share, from $10.8 million, or 42 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1990. Revenues climbed 3 percent, to $282.8 million from $274.3 million. Omnicom is made up of several agencies, including BBDO Worldwide, DDB Needham Worldwide and Tracy-Locke.

title: Ames Brown, Consultant, 58
description: Ames Brown, a financial consultant, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Manchester, Vt.

title: Review/Dance; Counting On the Past To Inspire
description: Modern dance of another era can live freshly in a different time, and influence the creation of strong works. That was the message of two revivals and a premiere presented by the Jose Limon Dance Company on Sunday afternoon and evening at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, where the troupe is to perform through Sunday.

title: Purchasers Find Economy Is Still Sluggish
description: The nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday that their monthly survey showed that the economy remained in a recession in April, although with a slight improvement in new orders, production and deliveries.

title: Chrysler's 'Abysmal' Loss of $598 Million
description: The Chrysler Corporation, hurt by slumping automotive demand, posted a first-quarter loss of $598 million today. However, the ailing auto maker said it would build more vehicles in the current quarter than it did in the first quarter, and said it did not plan to draw on backup credit lines for the remainder of the year.

title: British Sky Financing
description: The two major shareholders of British Sky Broadcasting P.L.C. said today that they had reached an agreement on providing additional financing for the money-losing satellite television network. The network was formed through last year's merger of Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting. The amount of financing and the breakdown of how much each shareholder is providing was not released.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of Nova Scotia, Toronto, named John F. Crean and Richard E. Waugh executive vice presidents. * Chemical Bank, New York, named Thomas S. Keating managing director in charge of its debtor-in-possession financing unit.

title: Earthquake Buries Soviet Village, Killing All
description: Standing in the lush green hills of Georgia, Andrei Gagiyev gazed across a creek today at the fresh mound of rock and earth where his hometown, Khakhieti, stood two days earlier.

title: NASA Says It Is Time to Build Space Station
description: Responding to suggestions from members of Congress that NASA should have independent auditors review cost estimates and that experts should study whether necessary research could be done elsewhere, Admiral Truly defended the current plan.

title: Building Museum: Learning by Doing
description: Visitors who come to the National Building Museum on Sunday will be put to work. In brief apprenticeships and by watching demonstrations they will learn how to stencil a floor, thatch a roof or build an aquatic garden at the museum's sixth Festival of the Building Arts.

title: Review/Dance; Pas de Deux For Women And for Men
description: "His and Hers," the program offered Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, should have been called "His and His" and "Hers and Hers." It featured two duets: one for men, the other for women.

title: Murdoch Plan in Britain
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said today that it would close one of its British magazines and was considering selling most of its other magazines in Britain. The company said it was closing the British version of Mirabella, a fashion magazine, just months after its October 1990 start. The United States version of Mirabella will continue publishing.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Wednesday, about the trainer of the Kentucky Derby entry Strike the Gold, misidentified him in some copies. He is Nick Zito.

title: Johnson & Johnson Ordered to Pay 3M
description: A Federal arbiter awarded $107 million in damages to the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company after ruling that Johnson & Johnson infringed 3M's patents for a fiberglass medical casting tape. Janice Symchych, a former Federal magistrate, found that Johnson & Johnson had copied 3M's Scotchcast Plus in 1987 to produce a nearly identical fiberglass tape. Ms. Symchych's order also forces Johnson & Johnson to stop selling the tape or pay royalties.

title: Rothstein Resigns as Coach of Heat
description: Citing the emotional toll of coaching an expansion team, RON ROTHSTEIN resigned yesterday as coach of the Miami Heat. Rothstein's announcement came at a news conference after he met with Heat managing partner LEWIS SCHAFFEL and limited partner BILLY CUNNINGHAM.

title: Blackstone Group Gets Expert in Reorganizing
description: The Blackstone Group yesterday named Arthur B. Newman, head of the Restructuring and Reorganization Group at Chemical Bank, to be a general partner. He will head the restructuring group at Blackstone, a private investment bank in New York.

title: House Panel in Compromise on Bank Bill
description: House Democrats reached a compromise today that increased the chances of banking legislation being passed in the next few months.

title: 10-Year Note Sale By ICI Americas
description: ICI Americas Inc., a subsidiary of London-based Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., priced a $250 million issue of notes yesterday in the United States market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1951, a well-to-do American woman helping in the post-war reconstruction of Germany met a starving young voice student in Berlin and took him under her wing, even to the point of buying him his first overcoat and his first dinner jacket.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $250 million of notes due May 1, 1998. The financing was increased by $50 million because of strong investor demand.

title: Ragu Agrees to Take 'Fresh' Off Sauce Labels
description: Continuing a campaign to restrict claims made on food labels, the Food and Drug Administration today turned Ragu pasta sauces from "fresh" to "fine."

title: Is Age of Ewing Ending for Knicks?
description: Several years ago, after a Christmas Day game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden, Michael Jordan agreed to play a game of make believe. What if he were the general manager of an expansion team and had to choose between two stars, himself and Patrick Ewing, as a foundation?

title: 'Star Wars' Test Sends Shuttle Flipping in Space
description: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery guided the craft through a series of flips and twists high above Earth today in a critical "Star Wars" experiment delayed by an errant satellite.

title: S.E.C., in Budget Request, Expects 20% Rise in Cases
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission expects a 20 percent increase in litigation, including cases involving overseas investors, according to a commission budget request scheduled to be released on Thursday.

title: Hatcher to Coach
description: MICKEY HATCHER, released by the Los Angeles Dodgers on March 24, was hired by the team yesterday to be a non-playing coach for their Albuquerque farm club of the Pacific Coast League. Hatcher, 36, played 12 years in the major leagues and had a career batting average of .280. (AP)

title: London Reacts to Sharpton
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton is visiting England, provoking responses that reveal more about the British than the Brooklyn preacher. Page A4.

title: Felker Gets M Inc. Post
description: Clay Felker yesterday succeeded Jane F. Lane as editor in chief of M Inc. magazine. Ms. Lane had been editor in chief of M, the Fairchild publication that last Septeber merged with Manhattan,inc. to become M Inc. Mr. Felker had been editor of Manhattan,inc. before assuming the position of editor at large at the merged magazine. He has been editor, publisher and president of Esquire; director and president of the New York Magazine Company; editor and founder of New West; editor in chief and publisher of The Village Voice, and founder, editor and publisher of New York magazine.

title: National Gallery Given $7.5 million Grant
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has given the National Gallery of Art a $7.5 million grant for its 50th anniversary to endow three new senior positions.

title: Russell A. Ziegler, 83, Advertising Executive
description: Russell A. Ziegler, a retired advertising executive, died on Tuesday at the Abbey Delray Health Center in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Delray Beach and Point O'Woods, Fire Island.

title: Cambodia's Voiceless - A special report.; No Haven From Agony for Cambodians
description: There is a Cambodian proverb that neatly sums up the life of Say Nom and her husband, Chel Chim, and the circumstances of their country, after more than 20 years of superpower intervention, immeasurable brutality, invasion and civil war.

title: INSIDE
description: Santucci Plans to Leave After 14 years in which he went from relative obscurity to almost constant controversy, John J. Santucci plans to step down as Queens District Attorney on June 1. Page B2.

title: Frank N. Ikard, Ex-Congressman and Oil Lobbyist, Is Dead at 78
description: Frank N. Ikard, a former Congressman from Texas who headed the American Petroleum Institute in the 1960's and 70's, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: U.S. Cellular to Buy Part of 12 Markets
description: The U.S. Cellular Corporation said it had entered agreements to acquire controlling interests in 12 rural cellular telephone markets for $104 million. The company said the markets are in California, Iowa, Maryland, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Texas, Virginia and West Virginia.

title: Clinton Hill Journal; Towering Broken Angel Is a Dream Made Whole
description: Folks in the neighborhood call him Noah, thinking perhaps that if a Biblical rain ever washed over Brooklyn, Arthur Wood would gather up his wife and assorted pets, climb aboard his house and float away.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * William A. Overlock has been named to the new position of executive vice president-chief financial officer of Lintas the Americas, a Lintas Worldwide division that encompasses agencies in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico and Central and South America.* Martin Grant has been promoted to senior vice president of Chiat/Day/ Mojo.

title: Jays Sign Hernandez
description: Left-handed reliever GUILLERMO HERNANDEZ, the 1984 American League Cy Young Award winner and most valuable player while with the Detroit Tigers, signed a Class AAA contract with the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday. Hernandez, 36, who last pitched in the majors in 1989 with Detroit, will report to the Syracuse of the International League. (AP)

title: Comptroller Seeks Review
description: One of the nation's top banking regulators, Robert L. Clarke, said today that he had asked Government ethics officials to review questions raised about his personal finances.

title: Michael Hagerty, Actor, 39
description: Michael Hagerty, an actor and publicity consultant, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: T.W.A. Reported Nearing An Accord With Creditors
description: Trans World Airlines and its biggest creditors are close to an agreement in which note holders would be paid the interest they are owed in return for extending payments on the principal.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The best-laid social plans can go awry when there is a building workers' strike, so yesterday NAN A. TALESE suddenly found herself planning a party on 24-hour notice.

title: Critic's Notebook; Networks May Revert o Cliches, After All
description: The 1990-91 television season is officially over, and the final half, the so-called second season, just couldn't whip up the breakaway hits desperately needed by the industry.

title: Britain Moving to Allow Trials of Suspected Nazis
description: Invoking a rarely used constitutional procedure, the Government leader in the House of Commons moved today to overrule rejection by the House of Lords of a bill to permit prosecution of suspected Nazi war criminals living in Britain.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Carmichael Lynch Inc., a Minneapolis agency, said it had agreed to buy Harris & West Advertising Inc., another Minneapolis agency, whose annual billings were estimated at $11 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Americans Keep Buying, and Using, Pens
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Bid Is Withdrawn
description: New Orleans will withdraw its bid to host the 1995 Super Bowl because of scheduling conflicts, according to Mayor Sidney Barthelemy.

title: Beman Wants to Play
description: DEANE BEMAN, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, will attempt to qualify for the United States Open this year. Beman, a former two-time United States Amateur champion and winner of four events on the PGA Tour, has paid his $75 entry fee to become one of more than 6,000 players vying for 91 non-exempt spots in the 156-man field. Beman, 53, no longer plays in PGA co-sponsored events because of his position as commissioner. However, he has played in the Irish Open and the Volvo Seniors British Open since becoming commissioner. (AP)

title: Pretoria Shifting Attention to Local Apartheid
description: With its national dialogue with the African National Congress stalled over township violence and recriminations on the release of political prisoners, the South African Government is pressing ahead with plans to start dismantling apartheid at the local level.

title: Japanese in U.S. Aiding Charities As Volunteers
description: If Toshio Matsunami's countrymen in Tokyo could have seen him and several of his co-workers, they would not have believed it. There he was, the executive vice president of the Fuji Bank and Trust Company, carrying rubbish out of a building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that is being turned into a residence for the homeless. Nearby, two bank managers were painting a ceiling in the building.

title: Chinese Ties: Frosty to Icy
description: While China is normalizing its ties with many Western countries, its relations with the United States are severely strained and may deteriorate further in the coming months. Behind the strains are both specific disagreements and a fundamental gulf in the way the two countries see each other.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Ernest & Julio Gallo Winery, Modesto, Calif., to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, for several brands of wine, brandy and champagne. Billings were not disclosed.* Foulds Inc., Libertyville, Ill., to Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, for its No Yolks Noodles, a cholesterol-free egg noodle substitute. No billings were disclosed.

title: Stars Daze Opponents With the Glare of Success
description: A year ago, Norman Green was a minority owner of the Calgary Flames, Bob Clarke had just been dismissed as general manager of the Philadelphia Flyers, Bob Gainey was a minor league hockey coach in France and the Minnesota North Stars almost moved to San Jose because few fans in the Twin Cities would pay to watch them play.

title: Kemp Sees Israel's Housing Chief At Embassy After Baker Objection
description: A State Department official said today that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d tried to keep Jack Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, from receiving Ariel Sharon, the Israeli Housing Minister and an opponent of the President's Middle East policy, in his H.U.D. office.

title: U.S. Holds Up Visa for Iranian Ex-President
description: The State Department has held up a decision on whether to grant a visa to Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who was President of Iran during part of the hostage crisis, forcing him to delay or cancel a United States tour to promote a new book.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: UNATTRACTIVE or damaged walls and ceilings can present a problem for remodelers. Applying new paint or paper may not be possible without first repairing the walls. But such a repair may be more time-consuming or expensive than it is worthwhile.

title: Door Opens a Crack for Colombia's Indians
description: With his brown bowler hat, striped poncho and blue wraparound dress, Lorenzo Muelas Hurtado causes more than a sartorial clash as he moves among the delegates in business suits at Colombia's constitutional convention.

title: Making a Studio Feel Like a Loft
description: TORTURE is cramming legs fit for a Lincoln Town Car into a Volkswagen Beetle. That's how Jack Travis felt after he broke up with his girlfriend and gave up a loft with a fireplace for a studio apartment with a sleeping alcove.

title: Fanfare For a Purple Pretender
description: A TYPE of coralbells called Heuchera Palace Purple has been voted the 1991 plant of the year by the Perennial Plant Association. Although named for the spot where it was found -- the Queen's Garden at the Kew Palace in London -- the plant is thought to be a descendant of an American native introduced to England by John Tradescant the Younger, who visited Virginia in the 17th century.

title: Moscow May Day: Unrest on Display
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presided over a joyless, sparse and tightly controlled May Day rally on Red Square today, listening stoically to litanies of woe and accusations of misrule at what used to be the premier Communist rite of spring.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical failure, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about preventing organ rejection in rats omitted several words in some editions. The passage should have read: "While recognizing the enormous hurdles that have yet to be overcome, Dr. Starzl said he was enthusiastic about the Philadelphia and Italian research 'because it is a crack in the door about the biologic manipulation of the immune system.' He added, 'Whenever that happens, if the door opens a little bit, then there is a crush of effort to try to jam it open.' "

title: How to Fill Dents in Wooden Furniture
description: The deliberate mistreatment of furniture surfaces with the intent to forge the signs of long wear is usually overdone. A list of instruments used for this practice, known as distressing, includes the shotgun and the barbed-wire cudgel.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Top B.S.B. Shuffle Continues As New U.S. Head Is Named
description: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES WORLDWIDE INC. replaced the president of its American operations yesterday, the second big personnel move made by the agency since it lost the $110 million Miller Lite account in March.

title: Mets Come Unglued During a Sideshow of Errors
description: No doubt the Mets spent most of last night looking forlornly, even desperately for the fog to return. Had it, there would have at least been a place to hide. It never came, and so neither did any relief from a relentlessly embarrassing 8-7 loss to the San Diego Padres.

title: New York City's Loss Is Albany's Gain
description: What happened in the State of New York this week sounded like a political satirist's idea of a joke, but it was far from funny.

title: Pop in Review
description: Lush Marquee 547 West 21st Street Manhattan

title: Strike Woes: Leaks, Bugs And Waiting
description: The plumber can't come, so the pipe keeps leaking. The baby's diapers are doing the same, but the diaper man can't deliver.

title: Santucci Is Retiring as the Queens District Attorney
description: After 14 years in which he went from relative obscurity to almost constant controversy, John J. Santucci plans to step down as Queens District Attorney on June 1, according to retirement papers he has filed with New York State.

title: If a Tree's Too Big to Hug, Just Salute It
description: THE search for the nation's biggest trees continues. Nominations are being accepted until May 17 for the 1992 list of behemoths in the National Register of Big Trees, published by the American Forestry Association and co-sponsored by the Davey Tree Expert Company in Kent, Ohio.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Essay; Going After Them
description: When Thomas Jefferson's political hatchet man, James Monroe, was told to derail the career of Alexander Hamilton, he leaked to a sycophantic editor some embarrassing letters. They seemed to show Hamilton abusing the public trust by secretly making payoffs.

title: Rescuing Health Care
description: Chaotic, costly and even cruel, the nation's health care system may pose the supreme political test of the 1990's.

title: Chinese Occupation Denies Tibet's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Business and the Law; Moves to Speed Asbestos Cases
description: CONFRONTED by a torrent of asbestos personal injury lawsuits, Federal and state judges are becoming innovative in moving their caseloads.

title: Juozas Urbsys Is Dead; Lithuania Aide Was 95
description: Juozas Urbsys, the last Foreign Minister of independent Lithuania, died early today in Kaunas, Lithuania, after a long illness, officials reported. He was 95 years old.

title: New York City Transit Unit Prices $125 Million in Notes
description: The New York City Transit Authority priced $125 million in revenue anticipation notes yesterday. In competitive bidding a group led by Bear, Stearns & Company won the largest portion, $50 million in notes.

title: Suit by Intel Moves Forward
description: A Federal judge today denied a motion by Advanced Micro Devices Inc. to dismiss a copyright lawsuit brought by the Intel Corporation.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Lord, Dentsu President Quits in Los Angeles
description: Charles W. Reynolds Jr. has resigned as president of the Los Angeles office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners and been replaced by an executive committee of three of the agency's top managers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Clorox Co., Oakland, Calif., a maker of cleaning and household products, has formed a subsidiary in Seoul called Clorox Korea Ltd. * Data General Corp., Westboro, Mass., a designer of computer systems, has sold its Clayton, N.C., manufacturing plant and accompanying property to Caterpillar Inc., Peoria, Ill., a maker of tractors and trucks, for $5.2 million.

title: Key Rates
Calendar: Crafts, Plants And Staten Island Tour
description: Craft Preview Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; (212) 935-1033.

title: Soviet Catholics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about United States Marine reservists in Kuwait who consider themselves forgotten by the high command rendered a quotation from Lance Cpl. Dana Deree incorrectly, misidentifying a Democratic Representative, Ray Thornton. The corporal correctly identified Mr. Thornton as representing the Second District of Arkansas, not Louisiana.

title: World Cup Not Hurting for Host Cities
description: By the deadline at noon yesterday, the largest number of cities ever, more than 30, had applied to stage games and other events of the 1994 World Cup. The group included New York, which bid for the maximum number of games possible despite the lack of a stadium in which to play them.

title: Unhittable, Unbelievable: Ryan Fires No. 7
description: Nolan Ryan pitched his seventh no-hitter tonight in what he called the most dominating performance of his amazing 25-year career.

title: Still a Wonderful Town
description: Why do tourists come to New York? Simple. They're here because this is the quintessential Wonderful Town. Yes, New York has trouble, lots of trouble, but it also has treasure: the most extraordinary array of museums, galleries, concert halls and theaters in the United States. Maybe the world.

title: Angola's 30-Year Story: Turmoil and Finally Peace
description: 1961 The Portuguese colonial government is challenged by popular uprisings.

title: Freddie Mac Debt Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which is known as Freddie Mac, is offering $500 million in five-year debentures through various securities dealers.

title: Editorial Notebook; Why the Kurds Fled
description: "Who are the Kurds and what are they afraid of?" I asked my flight companion in Turkey, a relief worker fresh from two weeks among 75,000 Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq. He answered with a frustrated grimace.

title: Celebrating 100 Seasons
description: The Oratorio Society of New York will celebrate its 100th season with a concert at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. The group's music director, Lyndon Woodside, is to conduct the chorus and orchestra in a program featuring the premiere of Tcherepnin's Cantata, Poulenc's Gloria and Berlioz's Te Deum. The soloists are to be the soprano Benita Valente and the tenor David Britton. Tickets are $12 to $320. Information: (212) 228-5307.

title: Metro Matters; Prosecutor Whose Reach Rarely Left Queens
description: During his 14 years as the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci was never invited to address a periodic forum sponsored by a citywide anticrime group that had heard from most of his fellow prosecutors. The reason: none of the organizers thought Mr. Santucci had anything significant to say.

title: Colonies in 1776 Had Democratic Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers' Compensation Needs Overhauling; Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop in Review
description: Marlon Jordan Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South (at Perry Street) Greenwich Village Through Saturday

title: Building Spending Down 1.5%
description: Construction spending dropped 1.5 percent in March, erasing a small February gain that had been the first advance in 11 months, the Government said today.

title: Book Says Powell Had Doubts on Bush's War Plan
description: A new book on the Bush Administration's decisionmaking in the Persian Gulf war says that Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had serious reservations about the President's push for an offensive military strategy against Iraq's army in Kuwait.

title: Warren V. Bush, 65, a Television Producer
description: Warren V. Bush, an independent television producer and writer, died on April 16 at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Treasury Issues End Unchanged
description: Prices of Treasury securities were largely unchanged yesterday, while the shorter maturities were narrowly mixed in light trading.

title: Tassels, Big and Small
description: IN 18th-century Europe, well-dressed curtains, sofas and armoires were often garnished with decorative bundles of cotton, wool or silk yarn. These tassels could be large or small, elaborate or plain. Their main purpose was to add a whimsical dash of color.

title: David Twain, Professor of Criminal Justice, 62
description: David Twain, a professor of criminal justice at Rutgers University, died on Tuesday at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Workers' Compensation Needs Overhauling
description: To the Editor:

title: First Effort to Treat Muscular Dystrophy
description: The first attempt to treat the underlying cause of muscular dystrophy is to occur today, amid a swirl of controversy over ethics and efficacy.

title: N.C.A.A. Retains 3-Point Distance
description: The 3-point arc will remain the same for National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball for both men and women, the heads of the rules committees announced today.

title: Bridge
description: The first tournament with substantial international participation ever played in Czechoslovakia was held in Prague from April 19 through 21. The principal event was the Prague Cup, contested by invited teams from Austria, Estonia, Germany, Hungary, Poland and the United States as well as Czechoslovakia.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday identified a player traded by the Knicks in return for Dave DeBusschere incorrectly in some editions. He was Howie Komives, not Bad News Barnes.

title: Explosions at Louisiana Plant Kill 2 and Hurt 120
description: Explosions devastated a large fertilizer plant here today, killing two people and injuring more than 120, including people who lived near the plant, officials said.

title: Virtue Isn't Always Its Only Reward
description: APPLICATIONS are being accepted for the Molly Parnis Dress Up Your Neighborhood contest. For nearly 20 years, cash awards -- up to $500 -- have been made to groups that improve New York City with community gardens, block clean-ups, park projects, murals and the like.

title: BIG BANKS REDUCE PRIME LOAN RATE TO 8 1/2% FROM 9%
description: Most of the nation's largest banks reduced their prime lending rate yesterday to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent, a move that will cut borrowing costs for small businesses and some consumers, and could eventually help stimulate the lagging economy.

title: Pop in Review
description: Tim Buckley Tribute Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Brooklyn Heights

title: Claude Gallimard, 77; Led Publishing House
description: Claude Gallimard, who headed his family's publishing company, Editions Gallimard, until 1988, died on Monday in Paris, the company announced. He was 77 years old.

title: Merck Debt Priced For Yield of 7.92%
description: Merck & Company, the world's largest pharmaceutical company and among the few corporations whose debt is still rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, yesterday took advantage of lower interest rates in the market and priced $250 million in noncallable notes with a maturity date of May 1, 1996.

title: Howard Ashman Memorial
description: A memorial service for Howard Ashman, the lyricist and librettist, will be held at 7:30 P.M. Monday at the Orpheum Theater, 126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street. Mr. Ashman, the author and director of "Little Shop of Horrors," won an Academy Award for the song "Under the Sea" in the Disney film "The Little Mermaid." He died on March 14 at the age of 40.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on the Company News page of Business Day on Tuesday referred incorrectly to the outlook for the International Business Machines Corporation. The company's chairman, John F. Akers, said at the shareholders meeting that prospects for the rest of the year were uncertain; he did not say "weak."

title: Ameritech Part Of Bid in Poland
description: The Ameritech Corporation said it was a member of a consortium with France Telecom that is one of three finalists in the competition to build and operate a cellular communications system in Poland. Poland's Ministry of Communications will make the final selection by the end of June, Chicago-based Ameritech said in a statement.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ONE of the most difficult tasks of childhood is to learn how to resist social pressure. The challenges come from many directions: a dare to shoplift a pack of baseball cards, an invitation to use an illegal drug, a demand for sexual intimacy, an offer to join a gang.

title: Angola Agrees On a Cease-Fire With Guerrillas
description: After 16 years of civil war, Angola's leftist Government and United States-backed rebels agreed today to call a cease-fire before the end of this month and to hold the nation's first free elections in the second half of 1992.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks Must Pursue Pat Riley
description: More than 1,000 Knick loyalists were smart enough not to waste $17 on a ticket Tuesday night. But now it's time for the Knicks' new management team to be smart enough to pursue Pat Riley as their next coach.

title: Washington Talk; Gun Measure Is Lesson in Geography
description: The Brady bill is the first tough domestic issue the House will face this year, and the whole issue of gun control has stirred intense ideological passions. But next week's vote will not be an occasion for rounding up the usual stereotypes of the 101st Congress.

title: Brady Gun-Control Bill Imperiled by Rules Dispute
description: A bill that would impose a national seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases is being threatened by a procedural dispute with the House leadership, the measure's sponsor said today.

title: The Interest-Rate Battle; U.S. Wants to Grow Out of the Recession, But Its Partners Fear Rekindled Inflation
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's efforts this week to bring down worldwide interest rates are being portrayed in the Bush Administration as the opening round in a battle between a rather pessimistic American view of the world's economy and a more buoyant German approach.

title: A Favorite Strolls, but No Sweat
description: There may be as many as 50 horses on the track at the same time at Churchill Downs on these mornings before the Kentucky Derby. Some jog, some gallop, some walk alongside stable ponies. But 16 or so are the Derby horses, the superstars, and they are followed, clocked and analyzed.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Krickstein Prevails

title: Rebellion Spreads for Walkable Cities
description: FOR a new generation of urban design advocates, walking has become a first step. Brandishing "Touch-the-earth . . . walk" buttons, this new generation of urban pioneers is advocating walker-friendly design to improve the lot of the hapless pedestrian.

title: Fed Sees Signs That Slump May Be Close to Low Point
description: Despite the ending of the Persian Gulf war, economic activity remained weak in much of the nation during the early spring, the Federal Reserve said today. But the central bank said its latest survey of the economy found scattered signs that the recession may be nearing its low point.

title: Thornburgh Still Weighing Race for Senate
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he is in no hurry to decide whether to enter the race for the Senate seat left vacant by the death of John Heinz of Pennsylvania.

title: Auction Fever Cools For Art
description: The fevered speculation that drove art auction prices up over the last five years was virtually absent this week as collectors, dealers and museum curators crowded into Sotheby's on Tuesday night and Christie's last night for contemporary art sales. Most came to see if the works presented would sell, and at realistic prices. Others came in search of bargains, and many were successful.

title: MILITARY JET USED FOR A QUAYLE TRIP
description: Vice President Dan Quayle's office said tonight that he and Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner had taken a military plane on a golf trip to Augusta, Ga., last Friday, as the White House was struggling to answer questions about John H. Sununu's trips.

title: Review/Theater; The 2 Personalities of 'Will Rogers Follies'
description: Will Rogers never met a man he didn't like. Tommy Tune never met a costume he didn't like. Just how these two great but antithetical American archetypes -- the humble cowboy philosopher, the top-hatted impresario of glitz -- came to be roped together in a multi-million-dollar Broadway extravaganza is the real drama of "The Will Rogers Follies," the most disjointed musical of this or any other season.

title: Pollution Shrouds Shenandoah Park
description: In the 1930's, when Shenandoah National Park was established here in the Blue Ridge Mountains and engineers boldly stretched the Skyline Drive from one lofty end of the mountain range to the other, visitors could clamber up Mary's Rock and, on a clear day, make out the tip of the Washington Monument 65 miles to the east.

title: London Journal; Roil Britannia! It's a Reverend From Over the Sea
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton has given everybody something to talk about this week.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Seoul Aches From 3d Day of Protests and Tear Gas
description: Demonstrators, tear gas and violence filled several neighborhoods of the capital today for the third day in a row as protests over the beating death of a student by the police last week turned the ralies that usually begin at this time into the largest in several years.

title: Tartikoff to Run Paramount Pictures
description: Brandon Tartikoff, the chairman of NBC's entertainment division, will become the chairman of Paramount Pictures on July 1, the studio announced yesterday.

title: Liberal Party Is Expected to Back Abrams for Senate
description: Leaders of the Liberal Party are expected to announce on Thursday that it will support Attorney General Robert Abrams in the 1992 campaign for the United States Senate, several state political leaders said today.

title: Penguins Blunder and Bruins Reap the Benefits
description: Pittsburgh was supposed to provide the firepower and Boston the defense, but with help from several Pittsburgh mistakes in its zone, the opening game of the Stanley Cup semifinal series between the teams worked out exactly the opposite.

title: MINORITY DISTRICTS FOR COUNCIL ADDED IN NEW YORK PLAN
description: The commission charged with drawing a new political map to better reflect the increasing diversity of New York City proposed a plan yesterday that could increase black and Hispanic representation on an expanded City Council.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed, But Analysts Expect Decline
description: The yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report remained mixed for the second straight seven-day period, which ended yesterday.

title: Pfizer Pays Fine
description: Pfizer Inc. paid a $3.1 million Federal fine for dumping pollutants into the Delaware River from 1981 to 1987. Federal officials said it was the largest penalty of its kind, but Pfizer disputed that it was the largest under the Clean Water Act of 1972. The civil settlement covers violations at an iron oxide plant formerly owned by the chemical company in Easton, about 50 miles north of Philadelphia.

title: Like What an Idea! Baby-Sitters' Clubs!
description: THE first call actually came from Danielle Brussel-Smith's mother. She needed someone the next Saturday at 7:30 P.M. to watch Danielle's brother, David, who is 4 years old and prone to drive baby sitters into alternate occupations.

title: Books of The Times; Sex and the Single Werewolf: A Cautionary Tale
description: Wilderness By Dennis Danvers 255 pages. Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: Woman and Son, 7, Die in Leap
description: A Bronx woman leaped to her death with her 7-year-old son from the roof of their apartment building yesterday, and the police said they were investigating reports that the mother had killed herself and her son because she believed she might have been infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Textron Unit to Pay E.P.A. Penalty
description: Textron Lycoming, a unit of Textron Inc., agreed to pay a $147,500 fine for shipping hazardous waste to Canada without notifying United States regulators or getting Canadian Government approval. The Environmental Protection Agency said that the aircraft engine company shipped at least 834 loads of metal hydroxide sludge, a byproduct of its manufacturing process, to Stablex, a Montreal hazardous waste company, from 1987 to 1989.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the threat of budget cuts to various New York cultural institutions misstated Gregory Long's titles in some copies. He is president of the New York Botanical Garden and chairman of the Cultural Institutions Group, an organization of arts institutions that occupy city-owned buildings.

title: Quilts That Honor Columbus, Indians and Even New Yorkers
description: A LARGE spectrum of fabric-minded people are expected to participate this week in the third Great American Quilt Festival, on Pier 92 at West 52d Street in Manhattan. Organized by the Museum of American Folk Art, the five-day extravaganza, which runs through Sunday, features 100 vendors of antique quilts and quilting supplies, exhibits of nearly 200 quilts and drawings on fabric and lectures, tours and workshops.

title: All of United Artists Sought By Tele-Communications
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, said yesterday that it was offering to buy the 46 percent of United Artists Entertainment that it does not already own.

title: Cuomo Sees Budget Battle Through June
description: With New York State's budget a full month overdue today, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo raised the possibility that the political stalemate might drag on through June. And that, he said, could force New York City and some other local governments to default on payments for their borrowing.

title: Pressing Iraq to Pay for Kurds
description: Washington wants Iraq to pay for the Kurdish relief effort. It is seeking to link approval of resumed Iraqi oil exports to such payments. Page A16.

title: Please Don't Feed The Shrubbery
description: EUROPEAN gardeners first clipped plants into fanciful topiary forms in ancient Rome. This week Deborah Reich put finishing touches on a topiary condor of ivy and mondo grass at the San Diego Zoo. The bird is one of several dozen creatures and other forms by 16 topiarists for an exhibition called "Animals in the Garden," part of the zoo's 75th anniversary celebration.

title: Chernobyl: It Can't Happen Here
description: The horrors of Chernobyl should not be used as an argument against nuclear power, as was the case last week when the fifth anniversary of the disaster at the Soviet nuclear reactor was widely noted. A Chernobyl accident cannot happen here. The design of a Chernobyl-type reactor is completely different from any reactor in the West; it would never have been licensed in any Western country.

title: Edward F. D'Arms, 87, Executive and Teacher
description: Edward F. D'Arms, a former classics professor and an executive with the Rockefeller and Ford Foundations, died on Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 87 years old.

title: Brooklyn Academy Preparing Festival Despite Money Fears
description: With its customary buoyancy, the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday announced details of its next Next Wave Festival, which has become New York City's foremost showcase for the vanguard performing arts.

title: A.T.& T. and NCR
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had extended the expiration date of its $90-a-share cash tender offer for the NCR Corporation to midnight May 20, from midnight this past Tuesday. A.T.& T. said it had received tenders for about 18.4 million shares, or about 27 percent of NCR stock. Analysts said the low number of shares tendered for the $90 offer was not surprising because A.T.& T. had said it was willing to pay $110 a share for NCR if the two companies could negotiate terms. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, NCR shares closed at $103.50, up 12.5 cents, and A.T.& T. shares gained 37.5 cents, closing at $37.50.

title: Therapists Say a Single Session May Be Enough
description: In keeping with the mood of the times to economize in all things, some therapists are saying that a single session of psychotherapy is enough for most people.

title: Dynamics Set to Trim 27,000 Jobs
description: In another stark illustration of the painful shrinkage facing the military contracting industry, the General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it expected to cut at least 27,000 jobs from its 90,000-member work force over four years.

title: Turn for Worse
description: CHUCKY MULLINS, whose fight to overcome a paralyzing football injury also made him a symbol of school spirit at the University of Mississippi, was hospitalized in critical condition yesterday after suffering apparent respiratory problems, school officials said. The Ole Miss sports information director, LANGSTON ROGERS, said Mullins, who is almost completely paralyzed from the shoulders down and confined to a wheelchair, became ill at his home near the campus and was rushed to Baptist Memorial Hospital in Oxford. (AP)

title: ALLIES TO EXTEND SAFE ZONE IN IRAQ 70 MILES EASTWARD
description: British and American marines prepared tonight to push their security zone in northern Iraq roughly 70 miles eastward at dawn to enable Kurdish refugees in remote mountain camps to join the return home.

title: Strategy for a Boston Comeback
description: As the nation's banks try to recover from the billions of dollars in bad real estate loans they made during the 1980's, the road back will inevitably lead past places like 89 Broad Street, a 14-story Art Deco office building in this city's financial district.

title: Home Video
description: Give-and-Take Marketing

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIAN ANDERSON, the great contralto, has rarely been seen in public in recent years, but tonight she will make an exception when she goes to the Kennedy Center for a showing of a new film about her life. The program, which simply bears her name, is to be shown Wednesday on public broadcasting stations across the country. Earlier in the day, accompanied by her nephew JAMES DuPRIEST, a conductor, and SHARON PERCY ROCKEFELLER, she is to go to the White House for tea with BARBARA BUSH and a photo with PRESIDENT BUSH. Now 89 and a resident of Danbury, Conn., Miss Anderson gave her farewell concert at Carnegie Hall in 1965.

title: Strong Quake Jolts Alaska
description: A strong earthquake jolted Alaska on Tuesday night, causing rock slides, knocking people out of bed and toppling bottles from shelves. There were no reports of injuries or serious damage, however. The quake, which hit at 11:19 P.M. and lasted about 40 seconds, measured 6.0 on the Richter scale of ground motion. It was centered in south-central Alaska about 110 miles northwest of Anchorage.

title: Lower East Side and Chinatown Need Distinct Council Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball National Baskeball Association

title: Brewers Beat White Sox in 19
description: Willie Randolph singled home the winning run with two outs in the 19th inning today as the Milwaukee Brewers outlasted the Chicago White Sox, 10-9, in the longest American League game since the same two teams played 25 innings in 1984.

title: Safe! Henderson Steals No. 939, and Brock Is Out
description: The afternoon had begun to evolve into another long and unrewarding day for Rickey Henderson. In the first inning, he reached first base and was thrown out trying to steal. In the second, he took a called third strike. The wait continued.

title: When It Comes to Winning, Moog Has Bruins Covered
description: The loudest noise at Boston Garden during the National Hockey League playoffs sounds like a jeer for the home team. Actually, it is a cheer for the home goalie, Andy Moog.

title: Underwriters Set G.E. Notes at 7.89%
description: The General Electric Company took advantage of favorable rate conditions yesterday, entering the debt market to sell $500 million in five-year notes through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Law School Admissions Policies Are Unequal; Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Riley Believed to Be Choice To Take Over for MacLeod
description: As John MacLeod said goodbye yesterday, the Knicks began another search for a head coach.

title: Amoco Unit in Deal To Sell U.S. Reserves
description: The Amoco Corporation said today that a subsidiary would sell some oil and gas properties to the Apache Corporation in a deal worth more than $546 million.

title: Cuts at McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it would lay off 290 union employees in the first phase of dismissals attributed to the loss of the Navy advanced tactical fighter contract and declining orders for the F-15 fighter. The company said about 100 white-collar workers would also be laid off soon. The company dismissed about 5,600 workers in January after the Pentagon canceled the A-12 Avenger attack plane, but a spokesman said the current cuts would not approach the size of the January layoffs.

title: Albany's Fair-Weather Foolishness Makes a Rainy Day Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Fernandez Is Planning an Overhaul for Special Education
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez will propose an overhaul of New York City's expensive and much criticized system of special education to reduce the number of children wrongly assigned to classes for the handicapped and to channel more money to children in regular classes.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Singing From the Soul

title: Review/Film; Living Or Dead, Too Good To Be True
description: At the beginning of "Truly, Madly, Deeply," Anthony Minghella's new English romantic comedy," Nina (Juliet Stevenson) is trying to put her life together after the death of her lover, Jamie. She isn't having much success.

title: Fiat Takeover of Ford Unit
description: The European Commission today approved the takeover of the Ford Motor Company's European farm machinery subsidiary by Fiat S.p.A. after the Italian company made a key concession.

title: Fly So Free Gets Post 1; It's Not the Favorite Spot
description: Sixteen colts were formally entered today in the 117th Kentucky Derby, and the free-for-all nature of the race was steepened when the No. 1 post position went to the favorite, Fly So Free.

title: U.S. Force Asked to Leave Iraq-Kuwait Line
description: American troops have been asked to withdraw from their remaining positions along the Iraq-Kuwait border by Wednesday, the commander of the United Nations observer mission said today. At the same time, Iraq is to withdraw its remaining forces in the coastal town of Um Qasr.

title: Abroad at Home; Powell Was Right
description: Time and human disaster had already cast increasing doubt on President Bush's decision to go to war against Iraq. Now the doubts have further weight. For it appears that Gen. Colin Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, opposed the President's course.

title: For Dinkins, Fiscal Countdown Time
description: By calling a cast meeting of most of the big players in New York City's fiscal drama for tomorrow, Mayor David N. Dinkins hopes that if he tells them all at once how much the city will suffer without their help, they will all agree to help him at once.

title: 'Star Wars' Satellite Is Retrieved After Space 'Ballet' With Shuttle
description: The astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery aimed a "Star Wars" research satellite at rocket fuel spewed in space today, then retrieved the craft and put it back in the shuttle's cargo bay.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a consumer financial services company, named Roy W. Haley president. Daniel Leitch 3d succeeds him as president and chief executive of American General Finance, a subsidiary. * Ferro Corp., Cleveland, a producer of industrial materials, named Albert C. Bersticker president and chief executive, succeeding Adolph Posnick, who has retired.

title: Texscan's Shares Plunge by $2.375
description: The shares of the Texscan Corporation, a El Paso-based supplier to the cable television industry, fell sharply on the American Stock Exchange when trading was resumed after an eight-day suspension. The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the stock on April 22 after two men were indicted on charges of stock manipulation in connection with a rapid rise of the shares last month.

title: Officer Is Shot Lining Up 3; Suspect Slain
description: A plainclothes officer investigating a 911 call about a teen-age gunman was shot and seriously wounded in Queens yesterday afternoon when he ordered three young people to line up against a wall and one whirled around, firing three shots from a .38-caliber revolver, the police said.

title: TV Weekend; Victim or Murderer? The Plot Still Dangles
description: It's shelf-clearing time at the networks, and the schedules over the next few weeks are cluttered once again with made-for-television movies. For the most part, they are not the prestige productions aimed at winning Emmys: "Separate But Equal," and the like. These are the standard items, the chase plots, the supernatural tinglers, the crime thrillers. Among the last, on CBS at 9 P.M. this Sunday, is "Victim of Love," quite typical of the pulp-fiction mentality in so many prime-time movies. The concept: A dangerous love triangle.

title: Czechoslovakia Clings to Arms Sales
description: Soon after becoming President of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel expressed his revulsion at the country's large arms exports. But a year and a half after the Communists were forced from power, his Government is having a hard time weaning its feeble economy from such trde.

title: Theodore Jones, 80; Minister Was Head Of a Radio Station
description: The Rev. Theodore Jones, a Unitarian Universalist minister who was a founder and co-chairman of WCRB, a classical-music radio station in the Boston area, died yesterday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 80 years old.

title: Peninsula of Tranquillity In the Fifth Avenue Sea
description: AMBITION abounds at the Peninsula Hotel, and I do not mean the crass extravagance that usually passes for it in the form of revolving restaurants, vertiginous atriums of the Hanging-Gardens-of-Babylon variety. This hotel, open barely one year, aspires to something more genuine and risky, the emulation of two esteemed ancestors.

title: Lottery Ticket Worth $12.5 Million Buys Trouble in S. Dakota
description: One day after a $12.5 million lottery drawing last month, Ionia Klein, a clerk at a convenience store, found a discarded ticket behind the counter with all the right numbers.

title: Lawyer Layoffs: Boon to Temporary Job Agencies
description: In waves of cost-cutting, law firm associates have been laid off, suffering misery if not calamity. The firms suffer fear of hiring. And this is an opportunity for people like Lesley Friedman, who notes that "some incredible talent" has been set adrift since she started a temporary placement agency for lawyers in 1987.

title: Indian Women's Group Takes On Abuse Cases That Government Neglects
description: When the middle-class women of Chittaranjan Park decided to form a neighborhood association in 1973, they thought their effort would focus on educational projects and a clinic. Less than two decades later, they are deeply involved in a mission they never anticipated: curbing domestic violence against women.

title: Educators Examine Standards for Athletes
description: College administrators, who have been challenged to bring athletes into the mainstream of campus life, are also being faced with this thorny question: Should athletes recruited by big-time sports programs receive special treatment in admissions?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., is offering $200 million of 8 7/8 percent debentures due 2021, at 99.81, to yield 8.92 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

title: Britain's Tories Suffer in Local Council Votes
description: Returns from local elections indicated early today that the opposition inflicted a heavy defeat on Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party, virtually ending the prospect of an early general election this summer.

title: Jury Told Failure to Buckle Up Girl Was Homicide
description: In a case that has fueled national debate over parental responsibility, prosecutors today blamed a Nicaraguan immigrant for his daughter's death in a traffic accident, saying his failure to buckle her into a child-restraint seat was part of a pattern of reckless conduct.

title: Judge Voids Rules on Scientific-Fraud Inquiries
description: A Federal judge in Wisconsin has struck down the procedures used by the National Institutes of Health to investigate allegations of scientific misconduct, ruling that those procedures violate the Federal Administrative Procedures Act.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
No Hidden Meaning Here: Seagram Goes 'Subliminal'
description: FOR decades, radical theorists have preached about the existence of subliminal advertising -- ads implanted with messages and images too small to be noticed consciously but intended to arouse desires and sell products.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY

title: A Generic Version Of Lilly Antibiotic
description: Biocraft Laboratories said it was seeking Food and Drug Administration approval to produce a generic version of Eli Lilly & Company's antibiotic Ceclor, the top-selling brand antibiotic, with annual sales of more than $800 million. The drug is often used to treat respiratory and ear infections in children.

title: Robbery Suspect Escapes Jail
description: Michael Mails, a 31-year-old robbery suspect awaiting trial, escaped from the Manhattan House of Detention last night while on a clean-up detail in a visitors area, correction officials said. He ran from the area as an officer superivising the detail opened a door at 8:35 P.M. to permit visitors to leave. Officials said Mr. Mails was the first inmate to escape this year.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about investigations by the National Collegiate Athletic Association into athletic infractions referred incorrectly in some copies to legislation aimed at insuring due process in Illinois and Nebraska. In Illinois a bill has been passed by a House judiciary committee and will be voted on within two weeks. In Nebraska it has been signed into law.

title: 10 Yugoslav Officers Said to Die in Strife
description: Serbian militants and police officers battled in two Croatian villages on Thursday, leaving at least 10 Croatian police officers dead, the authorities said early today. There were unconfirmed reports that as many as 20 civilians were also killed.

title: New Zealand Pay-TV Deal
description: The two largest American cable television companies and two regional Bell telephone companies announced today that they had bought 51 percent of Sky Entertainment Television, a fledgling pay-television service in New Zealand.

title: False Crash Alarms Spur F.A.A. To Cut Off Units on 200 Planes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the shutdown yesterday of collision-warning devices on 200 commercial airliners because of a computer fault that gives pilots false warnings.

title: Queens, Doorstep to the Whole Wide World
description: THE crossroads of the world has moved eastward about a half-dozen miles from its traditional intersection at Times Square, to central Queens. Like continental plates overlapping on the unsettled global surface, the most unlikely mix of newcomers, from Colombians to Koreans, from Indians to Uruguayans, has established communities virtually beneath the flight paths of the airplanes that brought these settlers to their new world.

title: House Panel Backs Easing of RICO Law
description: The latest effort to roll back the long reach of the civil racketeering law known as RICO began today when a House panel approved legislation that would sharply limit its use in a wide array of cases against accountants, manufacturers, Wall Street firms and other businesses.

title: For Children
description: Walking Tour: 'The Great Brooklyn Bridge'

title: Ben Hur Meets Red Guards
description: "China Cry" has many of the features of a Hollywood biblical epic except that it is set in the 20th century. Instead of Romans persecuting early Christians, the villains are Communist zealots inflicting Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution on a helpless China. The movie portrays a privileged bourgeois family under attack by Mao's Red Guards, and the brilliant, beautiful daughter, Sung Neng Yee (Julia Nickson-Soul), who eventually escapes to Hong Kong with her Prince Charming husband (Russell Wong).

title: A Man of Hate Meets His Violent Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem Chess Kings Tell Dinkins: Study It
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins took time from his budget troubles yesterday to honor the Raging Rooks, a championship chess team from a junior high school in Harlem, and a member of the team had a little advice for him on the budget.

title: Hartford Tax Panel Avoids Voting on Tax
description: The General Assembly's tax-writing committee closed up shop today, as required by law, and adjourned without taking a vote on the burning question of state finance: whether Connecticut should have an income tax.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Branded by 'Will Rogers'

title: Market Place; Goldman Phasing Out Big 'Junk Bond' Fund
description: A Goldman, Sachs fund that had become the largest fund speculating in the bonds of financially troubled companies said yesterday that it would begin phasing out operations immediately despite what it said were excellent financial results.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEAN KENNEDY SMITH has stayed out of the limelight ever since her son William was accused by a woman of raping her in Palm Beach, Fla., more than a month ago. But that did not stop Mrs. Smith from attending a ceremony in Manhattan yesterday honoring Very Special Arts, an organization she founded in 1974.

title: PEN/Faulkner Award For a Wideman Novel
description: "Philadelphia Fire" (Henry Holt), a novel by John Edgar Wideman about the 1985 bombing of a Philadelphia row house occupied by the Move cult, has won the 11th annual PEN/ Faulkner Award. This is the second time that Mr. Wideman has won the award, which is given to the best work of fiction published the previous year. In 1984, Mr. Wideman won the award for "Sent for You Yesterday" (Holt), the third novel in a trilogy set in Homewood, the Pittsburgh neighborhood where he was reared.

title: Review/Art; Nicholas Africano Explores the Melding of Innocence and Experience
description: Bit by bit, Nicholas Africano has been expanding the formal and narrative base that built his reputation in the 1970's. In the 80's, his highly theatrical pictorial psychodramas, with little people caught in various crises in nondescript spaces, became more general and less overtly personal. And his people began to grow and step out of the paintings into actual space as sculptures. In his current show at the Holly Solomon Gallery, one sculpture is life-size and three paintings reach from the ceiling to the floor. The privacy and wistfulness remain.

title: Alfred Bornemann, 82, Economist and Author
description: Alfred H. Bornemann, an economist who taught at several colleges and who wrote extensively on economics, died on Friday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S., Japan Reach Pact On Exports
description: Export financing agencies of the United States and Japan announced the first cooperative arrangements today between the two Governments, a plan in which Japanese money will be used to help finance American exports to Japan and to third world countries.

title: 'Playing It by Ear'
description: While talk continues about turning the refugee effort over to the United Nations, and the Kurds and Saddam Hussein work on their peace accord, the United States is steadily expanding its military role in northern Iraq.

title: Coke's Splash in Eastern Germany
description: Wolfgang Schulze was running a ramshackle soft-drink plant in a former Weimar brewery when East Germany's Communist system crumbled last year. Now, he is overseeing construction of a fully modern bottling plant for one of capitalism's flagships: the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Utah's Malone Terminates Suns' Season
description: Karl Malone scored 11 of his 38 points in the fourth quarter as the Utah Jazz pulled away for a National Basketball Association playoff-clinching 101-93 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Maurice Zolotow Memorial
description: A memorial service for Maurice Zolotow, a writer on show business and its personalities, will be held Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. at the Century Club, 7 West 43d Street. Speakers will include Betty Friedan and Milton Hindus. Mr. Zolotow died in Los Angeles on March 14 at the age of 77.

title: Navy Drops Charges Against Two Muslims
description: The Navy said tonight it had dropped charges against two Muslim sailors accused of plotting to sabotage their ship to help Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Music; Super Sunday at Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall has been celebrating its centennial all season, but the real party takes place Sunday, the anniversary of the hall's opening concert. Carnegie's program planners have wisely resisted the temptation to re-create the original 1891 program; indeed, several of the works to be performed during the daylong celebration were composed in the century since the hall opened. Among them are pieces by Mahler, Richard Strauss and Copland, not to mention the world premiere of a work composed for the occasion by Joan Tower.

title: PAPAL ENCYCLICAL URGES CAPITALISM TO SHED INJUSTICES
description: In a major encyclical addressing the economic questions raised by the upheaval in Eastern Europe in 1989, Pope John Paul II warned capitalist nations yesterday against letting the collapse of Communism blind them to the need to repair injustices in their own economic system.

title: The Importance of Being Cranky
description: As a university teacher and editor, I keep beside my desk a shelf of books for my professional needs. An unabridged dictionary, a style manual, a thesaurus, a one-volume encyclopedia -- these are reference works I consult regularly. On the same shelf is something more unusual, a copy of the August 1928 issue of The Forum: The Magazine of Controversy.

title: Nuclear Panel Says Reactor Can Restart, Giving Industry Lift
description: Deciding that one of the most ambitious nuclear power programs in the nation has solved longstanding design and management problems, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved the restart of a nuclear reactor at the Browns Ferry plant in Alabama.

title: Education Chief Assailed on Ratings
description: The board of a leading accrediting association for colleges and universities assailed Education Secretary Lamar Alexander yesterday, saying he had exceeded his authority in questioning the organization's new emphasis on cultural diversity as a means of evaluating institutions.

title: Dresden Journal; As the East Hunts for Its Bootstraps, He's Helping
description: Few Germans argue the case more forcefully than Kurt Biedenkopf: he says eastern Germans cannot be humiliated or their accomplishments besmirched by western Germans if the reunification of the country is to succeed.

title: The Start Treaty: Finish It or Lose It Richard Burt was chief negotiator in the strategic arms talks from June 1989 through last March.
description: After nearly a decade of negotiations, the United States and Soviet Union don't seem able to finish a treaty that would reduce their arsenals of long-range nuclear missiles, submarines and bombers. Only a few technical issues still remain. But if Washington and Moscow don't complete a treaty soon, the opportunity for nuclear arms control may be lost for years to come.

title: Still Waiting for Democracy
description: As countless candidates can testify, it takes a good lawyer and strong resolve to surmount the pointless obstacles in New York State's arcane election law. Yet despite perennial outrages, the Legislature remains unwilling to pass more than an insultingly modest set of reforms.

title: Review/Rock; The Loud and the Rude
description: "Mute Over Amerika," a show produced by Mute Records that is meant to capture some of London's dance-party feel, lumbered to slow death during Renegade Soundwave's short set at the Limelight on Tuesday night. The band, made up of a lead singer and rapper, Gary Asquith, two drummers and a disk jockey, moved slowly through some of their tunes: "Cocaine Sex," "Biting My Nails" and "Thunder."

title: Regulator Praises Kohlberg
description: T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, yesterday praised the investment by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in the acquisition of the failed Bank of New England by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group.

title: A Roar, Then Blackness: 'I Have Lost Everything'
description: Mufizur Rahman said that before he blacked out, he saw waves "as high as mountains" sweep toward his village with a powerful roar.

title: Law School Admissions Policies Are Unequal
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Fed Posts Loss For Period
description: The HomeFed Corporation, the parent company of one of California's largest savings institutions, said today that it lost $173.9 million in the first quarter, leaving it short of the Government's standards for financial strength.

title: New Florio Fiscal Move: Selling a Stretch of I-95
description: The Florio administration hopes to help balance its next budget by selling one of the state's busiest stretches of highway, the 4.4 miles of Interstate 95 between the George Washington Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike, for $400 million.

title:
Retirement Communities;
Ailing Development in Millbrook, N.Y., Gets Reprieve
description: For residents of a 136-unit retirement community in Millbrook, N.Y., the memory of almost losing their homes and their investments is still vivid.

title: CUNY Protest Is Over as Students End Siege
description: Protests at the City University of New York ended yesterday after demonstrators surrendered five buildings at City College in Harlem.

title: Merrill Is Sitting Pretty Amid Yanks' Ugly Play
description: In another time, and under a different boss, Stump Merrill might already be back home in Topsham, Me., mowing the lawn and reading box scores with his morning coffee.

title: Hope of Human Malaria Vaccine Is Offered as Mice Are Inoculated
description: In what may be a major step toward developing a vaccine for malaria, Navy medical researchers have succeeded in inoculating mice against infection.

title: The Old, The Dream And Nolan
description: OLD athletes chasing the dying sun are seen as sad by some. Not by these eyes.

title: Pictures At an Execution
description: Today, public television station KQED in San Francisco will return to Federal court to argue for the right to videotape and later broadcast the gas chamber execution of Robert Alton Harris, who murdered two teen-agers in 1978. Because the death sentence constitutes the most severe criminal penalty a state can mete out, KQED claims the public has a profound right to watch.

title: Bladder Cancer Detected With Standard Test on Urine
description: Scientists have taken the first step toward developing a method for detecting certain kinds of cancer simply by analyzing the cells that are shed daily in bodily fluids. They have shown that with a standard test they can pick out a few aberrant genes indicative of cancer from among a large number of mostly normal cells.

title: Lesbian Loses a Ruling on Parent's Rights
description: In the first ruling of its kind by any state's highest court, the New York Court of Appeals decided today that a lesbian cannot seek visiting rights to the child of her former partner.

title: New Claims by Jobless Again Hit Half a Million
description: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits hit the half-million mark again in April as the ranks of those seeking help rose for the second straight week, the Government said today.

title: Hostile Reception For Top Prospect
description: When Eric Lindros took the ice for warmups at the Memorial Gardens tonight, a fan threw a pacifier at him that landed harmlessly by his skates.

title: Giants Stay Cool as Mitchell and Bat Go Silent
description: "I don't know nothing about nothing," Kevin Mitchell said as he sat with his back to reporters earlier this week at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia, trying to figure which end was up with his warmup jacket.

title: Nolan Ryan, the Wonder Who Never Ceases
description: He is John Wayne with a baseball cap. He is Betty Grable with a magnificent arm. Because he throws the ball so hard and has done it for 25 years, Nolan Ryan makes people stop what they are doing and watch him. And baseball fans, it seems, can never get enough of this wondrous 44-year old pitcher.

title: Surgery for Harkey
description: The Chicago Cubs said right-handed pitcher MIKE HARKEY won't be able to throw again until at least August.

title: Lebanon Traffic Flows Freely as Army Consolidates Hold
description: The Lebanese Army consolidated its hold in mountain districts today, removing barricades, opening roads and generally spreading a sense of security missed during the long years of civil war.

title: Our Towns
description: This city is home to the most colossal, stupendous museum in human history. It is a towering monument (actually, a three-story building in the shadow of a big bank) to P. T. Barnum, the marvelous merchandiser of awe-inspiring circus acts, human oddities, wild-animal deformations, misleading word plays and fictitious phenomena (but what do you want for a nickel -- the truth or a good time?).

title: Rachel Blinken and Rony Herz Marry
description: Rachel Blinken, a daughter of Jeanne Atkinson of Westport, Conn., and Robert J. Blinken of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married last evening in New York to Rony Herz, the son of Zehava and Yehuda Herz of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at Bridgewaters.

title: Brown (2-0) Flirts With No-Hitter As Brewers Continue Torrid Play
description: Kevin Brown held Minnesota hitless for five and one-third innings, and Dante Bichette and Willie Randolph had two runs batted in apiece as Milwaukee beat the Twins, 5-1, tonight.

title: Plastic Pancreas in Diabetic Dogs Brings Human Tests Closer
description: A plastic pancreas kept diabetic laboratory animals healthy for months with automatic doses of insulin, offering hope that the method could eventually help people with the disease, researchers say.

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE, Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street, Manhattan. "House of Heritage," a lecture-and-slide presentation on the history of the museum and the surrounding area, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $2. Information: (212) 431-0233.

title: German Rates Stable
description: The Bundesbank left credit policies unchanged after today's regular meeting of its council, a spokeswoman said, despite cuts in key interest rates in the United States earlier this week. The German discount rate remains at 6.50 percent and the Lombard emergency financing rate at 9 percent.

title: SportsChannel, Mets End Their Wrangling
description: The New York Mets and SportsChannel yesterday ended more than three years of legal hostilities with an agreement that holds SportsChannel to its schedule of 75 Mets games a year through 1994. Under the agreement, SportsChannel will temporarily eliminate an option in its 1982 contract that allowed the cable service to air up to 100 games.

title: Restaurants
description: Harry Cipriani

title: Topics of The Times; Name for a Beauty
description: The small, grassy-leafed plant that is coming up now along shaded roadsides and open patches of woods has a flower as fetching as its name. Its five white petals are traced with pink, its center is flecked with gold and it is called Spring Beauty.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Xerox Imaging Systems, a subsidiary of Xerox Corp., to the Martin Agency, Richmond. Billings were not disclosed.* VF Corp., an apparel manufacturer, to the Martin Agency for its corporate advertising account. Martin currently handles advertising for Wrangler, a VF brand. Billings were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. FRANCES DEGEN HOROWITZ, 59 years old, a vice chancellor at the University of Kansas in Lawrence, has been named president of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York. She will take over on Sept. 1.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Qantas Airways Gives Account to D.M.B.&B.;
description: Qantas Airways has awarded its worldwide advertising account to D.M.B.&B.;/Weekes Morris Osborn, the Sydney, Australia, office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League SAN DIEGO PADRES -- Placed Pat Clements, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Steve Rosenberg, pitcher, from Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Confirming Retirement, Santucci Assails Press
description: With a bitterly passionate attack on the press, John J. Santucci of Queens confirmed to his staff yesterday that he was stepping down as Queens District Attorney after 14 years.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Yum! British Food

title: A Korean Demonstrator Dies After Setting Himself Ablaze
description: Demonstrators battled riot policemen in Seoul, Pusan, Kwangju and other South Korean cities today to protest the fatal police beating of a student last week.

title: Ms. Smith Wed To Daniel Senise
description: Courtney Hollinrake Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Damon B.
