Smith of New York, was married last evening at her parents' home to Daniel Senise, a son of Angelina Senise Portela and Daniel Ariosto Portela, both of Rio de Janeiro. The Rev. Richard W. Bauer, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 538 money market mutual funds decreased by $4.78 billion, to $464.93 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 189 institutional funds fell by $2.39 billion, to $132.52 billion. The 259 general-purpose funds' assets were down by $565.8 million, to $179.46 billion. Assets of the 90 broker-dealer funds dropped by $1.83 billion, to $152.95 billion, the institute said.

title: Stake in Equitable
description: The American International Group, a New York insurance company, said it was part of a group considering an investment in the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Equitable has been seeking a cash infusion to convert from mutual ownership by policyholders to a stock-owned company. Richard Jenrette, Equitable's chairman, said on Wednesday that there were five bidders for the stake. An unidentified Wall Street executive was quoted in The Wall Street Journal as saying the stake could be as much as 40 percent.

title: Marketing Executive Is New Head of Godiva
description: When David L. Albright took over as president of Godiva Chocolatier earlier this week, he brought with him more than 20 years of experience marketing greeting cards, paper towels, chocolate mousse, and most recently Pepperidge Farm cookies.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Festival

title: Review/Ballet Theater; New Leads in 'Don Quixote' Face the Hustle and Bustle
description: One of the 19th century's most episodic extravaganzas, "Don Quixote" is a silly ballet in any staging. Nevertheless, bright dancing can make its foolishness tolerable, even amiable.

title: Big LTV Order From Boeing
description: The LTV Corporation, the steel and aerospace company that is struggling to emerge from bankruptcy, received a $1.5 billion order from the Boeing Company.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Joseph Markovitch and John Luciani have been named vice presidents and management supervisors in the Vancouver and Toronto offices of Campbell-Mithun Esty Advertising Ltd.* Jeff Ginsberg has been named president and Jane Stark has been named vice president at Milton Samuels Advertising, a New York agency.

title: Corrections
description: A map in the sports pages on April 23 showing Kentucky horse farms in financial distress misidentified the farm sold by Nelson Bunker Hunt. It was Bluegrass Farm, not Bluegrass Heights Farm.

title: South Africa Is Planning to Scrap Provisions Used to Crush Protest
description: President F. W. de Klerk announced plans today to end preventive detention and scrap other repressive provisions of the Internal Security Act of 1982, which the Government used for years to punish anti-apartheid organizations and restrict political activity.

title: How to Disarm Iraq
description: Allied bombs destroyed Iraqi nuclear reactors and chemical weapons plants but not all of Iraq's nuclear facilities. And the bombing did not destroy most of Iraq's chemical weapons or the uranium in its reactors that could be used to make bombs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Brooklyn Academy of Music misstated the circumstances under which the New York International Festival of the Arts canceled its contract to support the import of "The Black Rider," a Hamburg theater production. The contract was canceled at the request of the academy, after its negotiations with the producers of the show had broken down.

title: Wider White House Inquiry Focuses on Sununu's Flights
description: The White House said today that it was widening its review of travel by senior Administration officials to investigate the accuracy of records submitted by President Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu.

title: Paul E. Klopsteg Is Dead at 101; A Leading Figure in U.S. Science
description: Paul E. Klopsteg, a scientist, administrator and inventor who helped organize the National Science Foundation and was president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, died Sunday at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 101 years old.

title: Court Overturns Texas Benefits Tax
description: A Federal appeals court in New Orleans ruled that Texas could not place a 2.5 percent tax on the health benefits that self-insured companies provide for their employees. The court ordered the state to return the taxes paid by the health plans of E-Systems, Shell Oil, Pillsbury, Kimberly-Clark and several smaller companies.

title: Miss Goodman, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Wendy Goodman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Goodman of North Miami Beach, Fla., was married last evening in Kew Gardens, Queens, to Mark Ratafia, a son of Lois Ratafia Diamond of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Julian Ratafia. Rabbi Zelig Epstein performed the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Tova.

title: Liberal Party Backs Abrams
description: The Liberal Party yesterday endorsed New York Attorney General Robert Abrams in the 1992 campaign for the United States Senate. Fran Reiter, the state party chairwoman, made the announcement in Manhattan. Party officials said they had also been approached for an endorsement by Representative Robert J. Mrazek, a Long Island Democrat; the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, Liberal-Republican candidate for Mayor of New York in 1989. The seat is now held by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican.

title: Rates on Treasury Issues Ease
description: Rates on long-term Treasury securities continued to ease yesterday, prompting a flood of corporate debt offerings. Most corporate bond and other debt issues are priced relative to comparable Treasury maturities.

title: At the Bar; A commencement invitation to Sununu touches off a brouhaha at the New York Law School.
description: The season of commencement speakers is upon us. So, too, is the season for protesting commencement speakers. Among this year's prime targets is John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff who is the featured attraction at next month's ceremonies at New York Law School.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is a vast devastation, and the loss of human lives could exceed 100,000. The information is incomplete. We fear it could go up much more. I pray to Allah it's not true." -- Prime Minister Khaleda Zia of Bangladesh. [ A1:6. ]

title: D'Amato Holds Forum For No-Show Accusers
description: At almost exactly 2 P.M. yesterday, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato strode up to a stage in a midtown hotel and with an expression of exaggerated disappointment on his face, looked and then looked again, at a row of empty chairs.

title: Splashing Debut for New Class of Boats
description: A new class of America's Cup boats -- longer, lighter and more powerful under sail than their 12-Meter predecessors -- has spawned a new era in cup competition this week.

title: Suspect in '76 Killing of Envoy Denies Guilt
description: The final suspect in the 1976 assassination of former Ambassador Orlando Letelier of Chile pleaded not guilty today to five counts of murder and unlawful use of explosives.

title: Topics of The Times; Hanging Governors
description: It's traditional in traditional Boston for the governor of Massachusetts to hang a portrait of one of his predecessors behind his desk in the State House on Beacon Hill. Gov. Michael Dukakis hung Samuel Adams. Adams did not particularly shine in his one term as Governor in the 1790's, but did distinguish himself as a pre-Revolutionary polemicist and the instigator of the Boston Tea Party. For Democrats, a good aura.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Seles and Graf Advance Monica Seles and Steffi Graf scored straight sets victories and led eight seeded players into the quarterfinals of the Hamburg Open in Germany. Seles, the top-seeded player, beat Regina Rajchratova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-0, and Graf, a four-time winner in Hamburg, defeated Julie Halard of France, 6-2, 6-3. In the quarterfinals, Seles will play sixth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who beat Elena Brioukhovets of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-2. Graf's quarterfinal opponent will be fifth-seeded Katarina Maleeva of Bulgaria, the winner over Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-0. (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Lilco Prices $830 Million Of 5- and 30-Year Bonds
description: The Long Island Lighting Company priced $830 million in general and refunding bonds yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: German Confesses Role in '79 Attack on Haig
description: An accused member of the Red Army Faction confessed in court today that she helped plot the 1979 assassination attempt on Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Baseball Stars' Success Aids Young & Rubicam
description: Virtually no one in the advertising industry had more reasons to celebrate the record-setting accomplishments of Nolan Ryan and Rickey Henderson than Young & Rubicam.

title: Books of The Times The Evolution of Power Over Nine Presidencies
description: Keepers of the Keys

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the quarterly reports of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company misstated Ford's first-quarter revenue in some editions. It was $21.3 billion, down 9.7 percent from $23.6 billion in the comparable quarter last year. The article also misstated the first-quarter performance of two of G.M.'s non-automotive units in some editions. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation had lower, not higher, profits; the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation had lower profits, not a loss.

title: Panel Backs DNA Tests on Lincoln's Tissue
description: There are no compelling legal or ethical reasons to bar an attempt to clone Abraham Lincoln's genes from tissue samples obtained at the time of the President's assassination, a panel of experts concluded today.

title: At a Shelter, Lacking Blankets and a Crib
description: In Room 311 of the Catherine Street shelter for the homeless on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Hector, 13 months old, slept for five nights with no crib. His mother, Lydia Jackson, said she had held him in her arms so he would not roll off the bed. She said she had been given no towels to dry her three children with, no pillows, no blankets and only two beds for the four of them.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday about a quilt by Robin Schwalb misstated the location of the Great American Quilt Festival. The festival runs through Sunday on Pier 92 at West 52d Street, not Pier 52.

title: Duracell Has A Big Day On the Street
description: A frenzy of buying activity greeted the new offering of stock in Duracell International Inc. yesterday, pushing the price up $5.75 from its Wednesday offering price of $15, to $20.75, in what portfolio managers said was one of the heaviest first days of trading in years.

title: Ana Cristina Bozzo; Organizer of Show On Hunger Was 47
description: Ana Cristina Bozzo, an art teacher at Hunter College High School who spent the last decade organizing the International Art Show for the End of World Hunger, died Monday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. She was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kurds and Baghdad to Open New Round of Talks
description: Kurdish opposition leaders and the Government of President Saddam Hussein will open a second round of peace talks in the next few days, taking up crucial issues like international guarantees for greater Kurdish autonomy and how to divide oil revenues from the region between Baghdad and the local Kurdish majority.

title: U.S. and Private Agencies Assess Aid Needs
description: Already burdened by efforts to help Kurdish refugees and famine-stricken Africans, the United States and private relief agencies are beginning to assess ways to provide aid to Bangladesh, where tens of thousands died in a cyclone, officials said today.

title: Alaska House Rejects Settlement for Exxon Spill
description: The Alaska House of Representative tonight rejected the $1 billion civil settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill, a move that puts the agreement closer to collapse.

title: Kurd Caring for 31 of Kin Doesn't Expect Miracles
description: Kurds have stories like few others to explain why they have no faith in miracles and do not think that any are about to befall them now. Take Faek Abdi, whose life seems framed by one uprooting after another.

title: Japan Site Sought For Universal Park
description: A planning group has been formed to select a site for a Japanese version of Universal Studios' $600 million Florida attraction. "Japan is on the front burner for us," said Sid Sheinberg, the president of MCA Inc., which was recently acquired by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan.

title: Review/Film; Panning for Gold in 1950's Harlem, via Himes Novel
description: Bill Duke's "Rage in Harlem," adapted from a novel by Chester Himes, is a lightweight caper comedy set in 1956. Its effect, though, is to recall the early 1970's, the time of Ossie Davis's seminal "Cotton Comes to Harlem" (also based on a Himes novel) and Sidney Poitier's "Uptown Saturday Night," when black films were discovering their own comic identity.

title: Michigan Judges' Views of Abortion Are Berated
description: A month after Michigan enacted a new abortion law that lets probate judges decide on cases involving minors, several judges have provoked a firestorm by publicly criticizing the law and suggesting that they would not abide by it.

title: Massachusetts Governor Seeks Sharp Cutbacks in the Budget
description: Gov. William F. Weld announced a Draconian package of budget cuts today that would sharply curtail the General Relief program for the hard-core unemployed, force state employees to accept salary cuts and reduce scholarships for students at state colleges.

title: Angola Accord May Help Heal Old Wounds
description: Perhaps out of exhaustion, perhaps because of caution, Portugal's mediator offered no overt signs of satisfaction on Wednesday night as he watched representatives of Angola's warring factions finally initial a peace accord to end 16 years of civil war.

title: Israelis Protest to U. S. Over Snubbing of Sharon
description: Israel delivered an uncommon protest to the United States today, complaining about the "inappropriate way" in which the Bush Administration this week snubbed Ariel Sharon, Israel's Housing Minister and a strong opponent of American policies in the Middle East.

title: Auctions
description: Act II of the two-week marathon of spring art auctions at Manhattan's two major houses begins at 7 P.M. on Tuesday at Sotheby's with Impressionist and modern art that the house estimates will bring $31 million to $43 million. The sales continue on Wednesday at 7 P.M. at Christie's, where the estimated total ranges from $34 million to $47 million. The totals expected by these houses are the lowest in five years -- one-half or one-third of the presale estimates of the sales held in November.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For those who miss the sound, and sometimes fury, of EDWARD I. KOCH on television, there is good news. The former mayor will return to the screen on WNYW, Channel 5, Fox Television's flagship station, as a commentator.

title: Court Rejects Mandatory AIDS Tests
description: Upholding the state's strict privacy protections for AIDS patients, New York's highest court today rejected the arguments of doctors seeking mandatory testing and reporting of the disease.

title: SAYS IT MAY EXCEED 100,000
description: Prime Minister Khaleda Zia said today that at least 100,000 people may have died in the devastating cyclone that pounded this low-lying country's densely populated coastal areas on Tuesday, leaving hunger, disease and homelessness in its wake.

title: On My Mind; Support A Toe Shoe
description: Who was that standing and cheering, so full of pleasure and happiness?

title: By the Truckload -- Theft at a City Warehouse; Stealing From New York, With Little Done About It
description: City workers for years have systematically looted a huge Brooklyn warehouse containing cribs, clothing and other supplies meant for New York's poorest families, according to city investigative reports and interviews with former and current city officials at the warehouse and at the agencies involved.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Horses, Taxes And You
description: THE barns used to buzz with dentists at play, jolly men with gold chains and open hands. They loved to get their Guccis dirty and play Owner. If the trainer said that Doc's horse -- call it Perio Dough or LuvWendy -- needed special X-rays or a Calvin Klein blanket or a Florida trip so she could run with her own class, Doc would say, No problem, I'll make it up in gold crowns.

title: The Domineering Center Could Be Losing His Grip
description: Patrick Ewing, Hakeem Olajuwon and David Robinson are the premier centers in the National Basketball Association. Yet, with the playoffs a little more than a week old, Ewing is back home tending to his newborn daughter, Olajuwon is looking after his business interests in Houston and Robinson and the San Antonio Spurs are one defeat from an early summer vacation.

title: Review/Theater; Sailing to Atlantis on a Ship of Fools
description: In Arthurian legend, Morgan le Fay practiced the art of mirage, placing her enemies in situations that resembled reality but were actually fantasies of her invention. In his new play, "Fata Morgana" (the Italian name for Morgan le Fay), Paul Zimet keeps the witch at bay, but her spirit haunts all that happens in this mystical voyage at sea.

title: At Yale Rally, Many Protest Cuts in Budget
description: Hundreds of Yale employees and graduate students rallied today on Beinecke Plaza to protest the university's budget cuts.

title: Dow Gains 8.412 Points, To 2,938.61
description: The popular Wall Street averages inched ahead yesterday in strong trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing only 8.41 points, to 2,938.61, for its third gain in three days. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was also up, but just barely.

title: Compliments Evaporate As Rematch Nears
description: On March 18, when their fight ended, MIKE TYSON, the former heavyweight champion, and DONOVAN (RAZOR) RUDDOCK appeared to suffer a rapprochement.

title: Mary Kay Settles
description: The Mary Kay Corporation, the parent of Mary Kay Cosmetics, said it would pay about $3 million to settle a tax dispute. The Internal Revenue Service said the company owed $13 million for the years 1983 through 1985 and $15.8 million for 1987 and 1988. Those amounts do not include interest. Most of the tax deficiencies and penalties were attributed to the disallowance of certain deductions from management's leveraged buyout of the company in 1985.

title: On S.I., Whites Like Plan A, but Blacks Like B
description: Two maps for new City Council districts on Staten Island got two reactions last night: black residents liked one, white residents liked the other.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about news organizations' complaints about Defense Department press restrictions in the Persian Gulf referred incorrectly in some editions to 15 journalists' contact with the Pentagon. They sent a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, but did not meet with him.

title: Washington at Work; Stormy Days and Sleepless Nights For 'Lightning Rod' at Arts Agency
description: The cliche around town on the performance of John E. Frohnmayer as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts is that he arrived in the capital without a grasp of the art of politics or the politics of art, and not much has changed in the 18 months he has been here.

title: Thief and Shopkeeper Die In Gunfight With the Police
description: Upstairs, a Manhattan man and two nephews hid with guns in the darkness of their family's store to protect it from being robbed. On the street below, plainclothes officers saw a burglar climbing in, and followed.

title: New System for Trading in Treasury Securities
description: Seeking to reduce the cost of trading Treasury securities, EJV Partners, a newcomer with blue-chip backing, plans to introduce a new computerized system where trading firms will arrange their purchases and sales electroncially.

title: Edward F. D'Arms, 87, Executive and Teacher
description: Edward F. D'Arms, a former classics professor and an executive with the Rockefeller and Ford Foundations, died on Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 87 years old.

title: Retrospective of Films By William Greaves
description: "William Greaves: Chronicler of the African-American Experience," a retrospective of works by the documentary film maker, continues at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. The series, which began on April 13, continues through May 26 and features a variety of guest speakers. The screenings are the first in the Cantor Auditorium at the museum, which opened three weeks ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Maradona in Therapy
description: DIEGO MARADONA has begun psychological treatment to rid himself of a drug problem that threatens to end his soccer career, his manager said.

title: Rooker Faces Jail
description: JIM ROOKER, a pitcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1972 to 1980 and currently a Pirate broadcaster, faces 90 days in jail and the loss of his drivers license for one year for violations related to drunken driving.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler's Efforts on Mixed Fuel
description: Joining other auto makers working on flexible-fuel vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it had developed a sensor that would allow cars and trucks to run on gasoline, methanol or a combination of the two.

title: Graffiti Vandal Is Suspected Just After Release From Jail
description: A teen-ager whom prosecutors described as the nation's most prolific graffiti vandal was suspected today of scrawling his nickname in a courthouse elevator after he was released from jail.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The poet laureate of the United States, MARK STRAND, will not seek another term and plans to return to the faculty of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. He intends to spend most of his time writing poetry instead of reading it, his main occupation for the last year.

title: 100 Years of Encyclicals: Church and Capitalism
description: 1891: "Rerum Novarum" ("Of New Things," often given the English title, "On the Condition of Workers"). Increasing class conflict, the emergence of a revolutionary socialist movement and appeals from groups of Catholic workers and thinkers moved Pope Leo XIII to write this document. The encyclical defended private property, attacked socialism and reflected a medieval ideal of a static society where rich and poor carried out mutual duties. But Pope Leo also condemned the "inhumanity of employers and unbridled greed of competitors" and "the yoke almost of slavery" laid on "unnumbered masses" of propertyless workers. He called for government regulation of working hours and conditions, and his endorsement of the right of workers to form their own associations was a charter for Catholics to support the labor movement.

title: Excerpts From the Pope's Encyclical: On Giving Capitalism a Human Face
description: Following are excerpts from the official English version of an encyclical issued yesterday by Pope John Paul II:

title: Review/Film; Not Quite Dirty Harry, But No Joe Friday Either
description: The word "good" would not ordinarily apply to a police detective who robs, cheats and kills in the line of duty, as Artie Lewis (Michael Keaton) is seen doing in "One Good Cop." But Heywood Gould, who wrote and directed the first known Disney film (actually a release of Hollywood Pictures, a Disney subsidiary) to include a close-up of somebody who has been run through by a sword, envisions his story's hero as a latter-day ultrapractical Robin Hood.

title: Spira Defense Calls No Witnesses And Motion for Dismissal Is Denied
description: Testimony in the Howard Spira extortion trial ended yesterday with the final witness, a Texas lawyer, saying he maintained ties to Spira after the relationship deteriorated because he was afraid of being blackmailed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Health Services Corp., Newport Beach, Calif., an operator of medical laboratories, said Harpener A.G. would sell its stake in the company to Koven Enterprises, which owns about 17.5 percent of American Health's common stock. * B & H Bulk Carriers Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda, an operator of cargo vessels, said it was considering a management proposal to merge the company with B & H Ocean Carriers Ltd. and BH Maritime Carriers Ltd.

title: Just Another Day for the Texan With the Strong Arm
description: In his tweed sports coat, maroon tie and white button-down shirt, Nolan Ryan looked crisp and buoyant speaking to reporters today, 14 hours after pitching his seventh no-hitter Wednesday night against the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Western Union Service Acquires a President
description: The New Valley Corporation, the debt-laden company that changed its name from the Western Union Corporation last month, named Brian S. Gaylord president of Western Union Priority Services, a unit that until recently had been up for sale.

title: INSIDE
description: Wider Inquiry on Sununu

title: 2 Wilson Premieres
description: Leon Botstein is to conduct the Hudson Valley Philharmonic Chamber Orchestra in the world premiere of Richard Wilson's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 8:30 P.M. The program also includes the New York City premiere of Mr. Wilson's Symphony No. 2, Mozart's Concerto in E flat for Two Pianos and Orchestra (K. 365) and Schumann's Overture, Scherzo and Finale (Op. 52). Blanca Uribe is to be the piano soloist in the Wilson. Mr. Wilson and Miss Uribe are to be the soloists in the Mozart. Tickets are $10 to $15. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Johnson's Turn to Faith Smoothes Rough Spots
description: For Howard Johson, there was no public humiliation that had to be atoned for, no disgrace from which to seek recovery. Nor was there any personal tragedy that sent him to the Bible to salve the wounds of loss or despair.

title: Mostly Clowns and Daring Make a Circus
description: To the Editor:

title: Skiles Most Improved
description: SCOTT SKILES, who improved his scoring average by 9.5 points and his assist average by 3.6 over the 1989-90 season, yesterday was named the National Basketball Association's most improved player this season.

title: Man, in Error, Kills His Son In Their Home
description: A Bronx father who bought an unlicensed handgun to protect his family after their house had been burglarized several times shot and killed his teen-age son yesterday morning when he mistook the youth for a burglar, the police said.

title: School Stops Students' Article
description: In one week, say students at the Horace Mann School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, school officials censored their newspaper twice: first, by holding an article describing drugs on campus, and then by hiding all 1,000 copies of the newspaper after an article on censorship was substituted in its place.

title: Retailers' Accord With Developer
description: Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation said they had reached an agreement with the JMB Realty Corporation to resolve more than $588 million in claims involving a 1983 real estate development accord.

title: Harris Opts Out
description: MAJOR HARRIS, the former West Virginia quarterback who was unhappy as a backup to DOUG FLUTIE with the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League last season, will sit out the remaining year of his $90,000 contract, according to his agent, ED ABRAM. (AP)

title: Topics of The Times; Where Confusion Reigns Supreme
description: How odd that New York State's Supreme Court chose May 1, Law Day, for a celebration of its founding 300 years ago on May 6, 1691. Law Day is the legal profession's annual event to promote popular understanding of the legal process. But in New York State, "Supreme Court" is a misnomer that baffles the public and defeats understanding.

title: Allies Double Protected Area for Kurds in Iraq
description: American and allied forces doubled the size of their safe zone for Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq today, securing a region that included the hilltop summer palace of Saddam Hussein.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Crisis for a Hoboken Institution
description: On any Friday or Saturday night on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River, only a few hundred yards from the Maxwell House coffee sign that drips neon drops into the water, a simpler black-and-white sign that reads Maxwell's overlooks the corner of Washington and 11th Streets in Hoboken. People casually mill about on the sidewalk while faces at the restaurant's tables line the shaded windows. Inside, a jukebox blares nonhits by college-radio favorites like the Pixies, the Chills and Throwing Muses; work by local artists hangs on the brick walls high above patrons' heads.

title: Review/Art; Anti-Hitler Images, Relentless and Harrowing
description: Sometimes, though not very often, an art exhibition is as educational as it is esthetic and as harrowing as it is beautiful. This is the case with the meticulously documented show of John Heartfield's anti-Fascist photomontages from the 1930's, now on view at Kent Fine Art. This exhibition provides an unforgettable glimpse of the rise of the Nazi party as seen by one of its most stalwart opponents, a German artist whose unusual talent fused political awareness and visual imagination.

title: The Case of the 'L.A. Law' Marathon
description: LA-LA. La. La-laaa . . .

title: Papal Encyclical Urges Capitalism to Shed Injustices
description: In a major encyclical addressing the economic questions raised by the upheaval in Eastern Europe in 1989, Pope John Paul II warned capitalist nations yesterday against letting the collapse of Communism blind them to the need to repair injustices in their own economic system.

title: Key Rates
Law School Admissions Policies Are Unequal; Value of Grades
description: To the Editor:

title: Law School Admissions Policies Are Unequal; Deserves an Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Of Gorging and Gossiping Where God Is Food
description: Of the 38 women who gather for a birthday party in Henry Jaglom's "Eating," almost none of them will touch the cake. And the few willing to do so hide out in solitary places, like the bathroom, so as to commune with dessert in perfect privacy. Food assumes near-religious importance in Mr. Jaglom's portrait of needy, anxious women who spend an entire day playing upon one another's insecurities, and waxing rhapsodic about well-remembered culinary thrills. That perfect bodies are irreconcilable with cream puffs becomes a source of genuine and amusingly well-expressed regret.

title: Economic Scene; Pressure Mounts On Fed to Do More
description: THE good news is that the Federal Reserve Board has cut the discount rate and the Federal funds rate, and leading commercial banks have followed with cuts in their prime lending rates. The bad news is that the Fed made the rate cuts because the economy is softer than most economists had expected.

title: 4-Year-Note Offer By Texaco Capital
description: Texaco Capital Inc. is offering $150 million in four-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Broadway Mall Street Fair: The east side of Broadway between 110th and 116th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Dinkins and State Settle Battle on Care of Retarded
description: Settling a five-year-old lawsuit, New York State has promised to provide long-term care for 600 mentally retarded children and adults who would otherwise stay in city hospitals and foster-care residences, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday.

title: Wage Accord Ends 12-Day Strike by New York Apartment Workers
description: The 12-day strike by building service workers that had disrupted life for several hundred thousand New Yorkers ended last night after union leaders and representatives of apartment building owners announced a tentative settlement.

title: Grieg and Bartok
description: Joseph Smith, a pianist, is to play Grieg's Ballade in G minor (Op. 24), Bartok's "Mikrokosmos" (Vol. 6), and Schubert's Impromptus (Op. 90) at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $8 to $14. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Anti-AIDS Marathon
description: The New York chapter of the American Guild of Organists is to present its third annual Organists Against AIDS marathon at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, Manhattan, tomorrow morning at 10. Performers in the 12-hour marathon concert include William Trafka, Kyler Brown, Gwendolyn Toth, David Graf, Harold Stover, Nancy McDill, David Schofield, Eugene Hancock, Donald Joyce, Michael Kleinschmidt, Claudia Dumschat, Terrence Flannagan, Timothy Smith, Chris Creaghan, Mark Bani, Walter Hilse, Kirsten Seadale, Thomas Schmidt and the Arden Trio, David Hurd, Leonard Raver, Mollie Nichols, Dennis Keene and Jacques Taddei. The program is to end with a sing-in performance of the Faure Requiem, to be conducted by Robert Page, with Carolann Page, soprano, William Sharp, baritone, and Harry Huff, organist, at 9 P.M. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 666-0675.

title: Bush Says He Has No Quarrel With Powell on the Gulf War
description: President Bush said today that he had no quarrel with his top military adviser, Gen. Colin L. Powell, for having expressed any reservations to Mr. Bush last fall about the push for an offensive military strategy against Iraq.

title: Greenspan Urges Changes by Bankers
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that the banking system of the 1990's was likely to be smaller but stronger.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the first-quarter loss at the Chrysler Corporation misstated the Ford Motor Company's loss for the quarter. It was $884 million.

title: At the Movies
description: Insecure Bryan Brown

title: Epilogue to Gulf War: 25 Marines Face Prison
description: The scent of victory still hangs in the air on this sprawling military base, which is awash in flags, yellow ribbons and bumper stickers reading: "America's No. 1. And Don't You Forget It."

title: Lawyer Wins One; So Do the People
description: A private lawyer in Miami played a central role in helping the Federal Trade Commission bring its largest case of telemarketing fraud to a conclusion this week. Underlying the case is a curious detective story, featuring the lawyer as a hero and a Better Business Bureau official as a major villain.

title: Ford Aids Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company borrowed $150 million from a $473 million reserve left over from the 1987-90 labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union to help pay benefits for laid-off workers. The transfer was announced earlier this week to local union officials by Ernest Lofton, U.A.W. vice president and head of the union's Ford Department, and confirmed by Ford.The auto maker and the union signed a contract last fall requiring Ford to pay up to $1.6 billion in supplemental unemployment benefits. The money will be paid out as needed.

title: No News Is Safe News
description: Television station KXAS, the Fort Worth NBC affiliate, agreed yesterday to pay a penalty to the commissioner's office for showing live coverage of the last two outs of NOLAN RYAN'S no-hitter Wednesday night on its regular 10 P.M. news program.

title: Ruzicka Gets 5 Points and Bruins Lead 2-0
description: When a player assists on all of his team's four goals in regulation, it is perhaps fitting that he is rewarded with the winner in sudden-death overtime.

title: Review/Music; A Schnittke Premiere by the Cleveland
description: New music frequently gets off to a weak start in the world by being played tentatively, or worse. No such problem arose for Alfred Schnittke's Concerto Grosso No. 5 in its world premiere at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. The Soviet-born composer's score, one of 13 works commissioned by Carnegie for its centennial celebrations, received a scorchingly intense performance by its violin soloist, Gidon Kremer, whose virtuosity was matched on every page by the Cleveland Orchestra under Christoph von Dohnanyi.

title: Wall St. Is Suddenly Farsighted
description: Not long ago, the Wall Street definition of long-term planning was "deciding what to do after lunch." But lately, the Street's fascination with a fast buck seems to be cooling.

title: Wright-Designed House Appears Saved
description: A retired architect has made an apparently successful bid to buy and save a house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright that was to have been demolished.

title: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 6.6% IN APRIL, REVERSING A TREND
description: The Labor Department reported today that payroll jobs fell in April but at a much reduced pace and that the unemployment rate edged down two-tenths of a point, to 6.6 percent. The figures point over all to an economy that while probably not yet starting to recover from recession seems to be approaching its low point, analysts said.

title: Dinkins Prepares Deep Cuts If Unions Don't Reach Deal
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to lay off thousands of workers and make scores of deep cuts in New York City services -- from shutting off some streetlights to closing clinics at city hospitals -- if municipal unions do not agree to concessions, senior city officials said last night.

title: Arraignment Set
description: Former Boston Celtics guard CHARLES SMITH will be arraigned May 16 on two charges each of manslaughter and motor vehicle homicide in connection with the deaths of two Boston University students March 23. A Suffolk County grand jury indicted Smith, 23, on Thursday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They are the unsung heroes of literature: the translators who take a writer's words and make them accessible to readers in other lands and cultures. On Tuesday, four translators will receive PEN literary awards: the authors WILLIAM WEAVER and LYNN SHARON SCHWARTZ and the team of RICHARD PEVEAR and LARISSA VOLOKHONSKY .

title: Your Money; Teaching Youth Virtue of Saving
description: When Steven L. Sanders was a kid, his parents were about to buy him a pair of cheap sneakers instead of the terrific pair he wanted. He bargained with them. "Give me the money you were going to spend," he said, "and I'll earn the difference."

title: College's Shifting of Prayer Service Creates Furor in New Hampshire
description: A little-noticed decision that a college in this southwestern New Hamphsire town made months ago has created a statewide furor this week.

title: Stretcher Accident Kills Man
description: A 76-year-old man died Wednesday after the ambulance stretcher he was strapped to rolled down a grade and overturned. The man, Edward Juchniewicz of Canonsburg, was being transported Monday from a nursing home to a doctor's office for an appointment.

title: Review/Film; From Privilege to Sleaziness
description: Bored with privilege, Courtney Wells (Jill Schoelen) runs away from her little red sports car and her fancy wardrobe and her father's California mansion with the swimming pool. Determined to lead a more meaningful life, she finds waitressing work at a rock-and-roll club, where she can meet new people, wear a scanty outfit complete with little black ankle boots, and listen to all the loud, screamy, mediocre music her heart desires.

title: Music in Review; New York Philharmonic
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Observer; Uttered at Third
description: This is not about baseball, so bear with it while we touch down briefly at third base and listen to some praise for Rickey Henderson. Playing for the Oakland Athletics, Mr. Henderson has just set a baseball record for stolen bases, and the game is stopped for ceremonial doings.

title: A. & S. to Close Store and Open Another on L.I.
description: Abraham & Straus will close its store in Hempstead, L.I., once the nation's largest suburban department store, and open a new one in Garden City, A. & S. officials said yesterday.

title: Official Toll Reaches 92,000 in Bangladesh Cyclone
description: Four days after a cyclone of unimaginable fury swung across the flat coastal plains of southeastern Bangladesh, swallowing up villages and sweeping away food crops, almost no emergency supplies have reached the newly destitute, relief officials and villagers said today.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration in The Home Section on Thursday about planting by the phases of the moon reversed the progress of light and shadow across the moon's face from new moon (entirely dark) to full moon and back to new moon. The first crescent of light appears on the right side of the moon, and grows larger each night from right to left till full moon; then a crescent of shadow appears on the right and grows night by night across the face. At the first quarter, the right half of the moon is bright and the left is dark; at the last quarter, the left half is light and the right is dark.

title: Scientist Accused of Spiking Spray In Attempt to Kill Texas Colleague
description: A prominent scientist at the University of Texas has been accused of trying to kill a colleague by spiking his nasal spray with a chemical that is suspected of causing cancer.

title: School Chief's Handling of Drug Record Splits Board
description: The school district that encompasses the tumbledown and drug-infested streets of the Lower East Side is being torn apart by a charge that its superintendent concealed a 1974 drug conviction.

title: How Big a Man in Ankara?
description: Before President Bush finally decided to support safe havens for Iraqi Kurds, he telephoned the Turkish President, Turgut Ozal. It was his 43d such call to Ankara. This only begins to suggest why Turkey's solid, foursquare President is now seen as an essential partner in the quest for a more stable new order in the Middle East.

title: Shopping in Europe From Home
description: The latest evidence that shopping at home is here to stay: the Next Directory, a glossy hard-cover mail-order catalogue of spring and summer women's fashions.

title: Go-Video 'Fib' to Japanese
description: The founder of Go-Video Inc. says he told a "fib" when he wrote to Japanese executives in 1988 that his tiny company had received hundreds of thousands of orders for its unique dual-deck videocassette recorder.

title: Meagher Is Retiring
description: RICK MEAGHER of the St. Louis Blues, one of the oldest players in the National Hockey League, is retiring.

title: H. G. Germ Weds Kimberly Cramer
description: Kimberly Bodell Cramer, a daughter of Barbara Browne Cramer and Gerald B. Cramer, both of New York, was married last evening at her mother's home to Dr. Hermann Gunther Germ, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Germ of Bleiberg, Austria. Judge Jeffry H. Gallet of State Family Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Capezio Dance Awards To Be Given on Monday
description: The 40th annual Capezio Dance Awards will go to John Curry, the ice dancer; Katherine Dunham, the modern-dance choreographer; Darci Kistler, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, and Igor Youskevitch, a leading dancer with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo. The awards will be presented on Monday afternoon in a private ceremony at the Hudson Theater.

title: The Peril to Wetlands and Why We Must Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 30 about the reopening of Boston's school desegregation case referred incorrectly in some editions to the reported increase in black teachers in the current school year. The petition filed by black parents contended that the proportion of black teachers in the public school system rose by eight-hundredths of one percentage point, not eight- tenths.

title: About New York
description: The strike is over. People who can afford to live in buildings with built-in servants can go back to their accustomed life style, and the servants themselves can again be paid for standing out front.

title: Vehicle Sales Dropped 21.4% in Late April
description: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April from a year earlier, deflating the industry's hopes that a rebound was imminent.

title: Ned Rifkin Appointed Head of High Museum
description: Ned Rifkin, the chief curator at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, has been appointed director of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. He replaces Gudmund Vigtel, who is retiring after directing the High museum for 28 years.

title: Miss Kirkland Has Wedding
description: Heidi Kirkland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Kirkland of Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York to William Ward Carey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carey of Palm Beach. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title: Routine Replaces Disorder at Turkey's Camps
description: In an improvised incubator slapped together from a cardboard box, some plastic sheeting and a blanket, Sahat Mahudi, 2 days old and purple in the cold, fights for life.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's been 365 years since a Dutchman, Peter Minuit, landed in Lower Manhattan, at what later became Bowling Green. And today that event will be celebrated in Central Park because of what he brought with him: the sport of lawn bowling.

title: Bridge
description: Whether or not it is right to lead an ace against a slam contract is a simple question that has no simple answer. It is likely to be right if the leader has another probable trick, or if he sees a prospect of giving his partner a ruff in the suit led, or if dummy is marked with a long suit that will provide discards. In a match-pointed event it may be sensible to cash a winner to prevent an overtrick. But in other situations it tends to help the declarer by establishing a trick for him or solving a potential guess.

title: Sabres Retain Top Staff
description: Despite a disappointing season and playoff showing, the Buffalo Sabres will retain General Manager GERRY MEEHAN and COACH RICK DUDLEY but will hire a high-level administrator from outside the organization, the team's owner, SEYMOUR H. KNOX 3D, said yesterday.(AP)

title: Stars Get Jump on Oilers
description: The odds already suggest that the Minnesota North Stars will advance to the Stanley Cup finals for the first time since 1981 and that the Edmonton Oilers will lose in the semifinals for the first time ever.

title: Submarine Job Won by Dynamics
description: In a political and economic duel between New England and Virginia, the Navy today named Electric Boat of Connecticut to build its next $2 billion attack submarine.

title: Bust the Insurance Cartel
description: The collapse of the multi-billion-dollar Executive Life Insurance Company has riveted public attention on the precarious financial condition of many insurance carriers. But there is another industry problem, just as invidious if less spectacular: price fixing, restricted coverage and other anti-consumer conspiracies.

title: Walter Reder, 75, Dies; A Nazi War Criminal
description: Walter Reder, a Nazi war criminal who ordered the deaths of hundreds of Italian villagers, has died in a Vienna hospital, a news agency reported on Thursday. He was 75 years old.

title: Nobelist Apologizes for Defending Research Paper With Faulty Data
description: Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel laureate biologist, has offered an apology to a young researcher and others in science for his prolonged defense of a scientific paper found to have included faked data.

title: Michelin Son Named Eventual Successor
description: Groupe Michelin, the world's largest tire producer, said yesterday that Edouard Michelin would be the eventual successor to his father, Francois Michelin, the chairman.

title: Meridian Bancorp in Mellon Accord
description: Meridian Bancorp Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the $197.7 million credit card portfolio of its Meridian Bank and Delaware Trust Company subsidiary to the Mellon Bank Corporation for undisclosed terms. It said the transaction would result in a pretax gain of about $35.2 million.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing nuclear power plants that have had long shutdowns misstated the location of the Sequoyah plant. It is 18 miles northeast of Chattanooga, Tenn., not 95 miles.

title: In Novels and Life, a Maverick and an Eccentric
description: Jerzy Kosinski was a maverick, an eccentric, a celebrity who was an intimate of many other celebrities, a Polish-born novelist who immigrated to the United States at age 24 and achieved perhaps his greatest success with his first novel.

title: Food Program for Poor Mothers and Children Hasn't Worked
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: General Dynamics Division To Build Navy Submarine

title: Injured Officer Stable; 2 Teen-Agers Are Held
description: A 28-year-old police officer was listed in stable condition yesterday at Booth Memorial Hospital after being shot in the chest by a gunman as the officer tried to arrest him and two teen-agers in Queens on Thursday afternoon.

title: Labor Official to Leave
description: Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the last 12 years, said today that she would not accept reappointment when her four-year term expires this summer. Dr. Norwood, who is 67 years old, said she planned to join a university or research organization and to write, teach and perhaps serve as a corporate director.

title: A New Suspension for Reds' Dibble
description: Cincinnati Reds reliever Rob Dibble was suspended for four games and fined an undisclosed amount by National League President Bill White today for throwing a baseball into the stands and hurting a spectator. But Dibble delayed the penalties by appealing.

title: Teaching Dogs to Stay Where They're Wanted
description: There often comes a time in the relationship between an owner and a dog when the one who is supposed to be in charge realizes that thousands of years of domestication have gone only so far.

title: Prison for Ex-Detroit Aide
description: A former deputy police chief and business partner of Mayor Coleman A. Young was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison for his role in a precious-metals pyramid investment scheme. The 45-year-old defendant, Kenneth Weiner, was indicted in February 1990 on fraud and other charges.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cyprus Minerals Co., Denver, named Chester B. Stone Jr. chief executive, and Calvin A. Campbell Jr. chairman.

title: Key Rates
Franklin Mohney, 64, A Business Consultant
description: Franklin Walter Mohney, a management consultant and former president of the General Battery Corporation, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: I Hate Hamlet' Co-Star Walks Out
description: Evan Handler, a co-star of "I Hate Hamlet," left the stage near the end of the first act Thursday night, gave his notice, and walked out of the Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Handler's unplanned departure came after a dueling scene with Nicol Williamson, the play's star, who apparently ignored the choreography and struck Mr. Handler on the back with the flat part of his sword. Andrew Mutnick, Mr. Handler's understudy, finished the performance.

title: The Peril to Wetlands and Why We Must Care; Misreading the Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Woof. Pant Pant. Dogs Are Runners, Too.
description: Woody Gloth, a 45-year-old runner from Freehold, N.J., has an ideal training partner. His companion runs the same pace as Gloth, enjoys the same park trails, is highly motivated, never late for a workout and has helped Gloth achieve a three-hour marathon.

title: Patents; Weed's Sap Is Used to Relieve Poison Ivy
description: T. Paul Misenko, a retired preacher and nursing home administrator in Bristolville, Ohio, this week patented a new way to relieve the itch and rash of poison ivy.

title: Mitsubishi in Accord For Dutch Volvo Stake
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan said today that it would pay $120 million to the Dutch Government for a one-third interest in the Netherlands operations of Volvo A.B., the Swedish car maker.

title: 2 Yugoslav Factions Blaming Each Other For Deaths in Clash
description: A day after the worst communal violence between Serbs and Croats since World War II, representatives of both nationalities blamed each other today and gave contrasting accounts of the village firefight in which more than a dozen people were killed.

title: Review/Pop; So Shirtless and, Oh, So Powerful
description: L. L. Cool J (James Smith) brought a hyper-realistic world view to his how at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night. Power was on his mind, and in his raps and in the skits he performed with a troupe of women, all human interaction revolved around the exercise of power, making all interchange seem contaminated.

title: Whose Culture Is It, Anyway?
description: I recently asked the dean of a prestigious liberal arts college if his school would ever have, as Berkeley has, a 70 percent nonwhite enrollment. "Never," he replied. "That would completely alter our identity as a center of the liberal arts."

title: 11-Month-Old and His Mother Hit in Crossfire
description: In one arm, Parshia Cook carried her 11-month-old son and in the other, the gifts she had just bought for his first birthday. Just then, in one of those unthinkable moments that are no longer unexpected on upper St. Nicholas Avenue, two men came racing down the street firing guns at each another, not pausing to take clear aim.

title: Backer of Abortion Rights Barred as Speaker at School
description: An invitation to the Lieutenant Governor of Massachsetts, a Roman Catholic, to speak at his old high school here has been rescinded because he supports a right to abortion.

title: Sports of The Times; Tail Tale: Sea Cadet May Get One
description: Just as the French swashbucklers could not take their eyes off Cyrano de Bergerac's nose, so one's vision is drawn to Sea Cadet's hindquarters.

title: Businesses in Maryland Gain Priority on Kuwait Contracts
description: The State of Maryland and the Government of Kuwait signed an agreement today to give Maryland companies an advantage in the competition to win contracts to rebuild the sheikdom.

title: Hasbro Advances in Bid for Tonka
description: Hasbro Inc. said a final hurdle had been cleared in its takeover of the Tonka Corporation when the Governor of Minnesota, Arne H. Carlson, signed legislation that exempts friendly takeovers from provisions of the Minnesota Control Share Acquisition Statute, which makes unwanted takeovers difficult. Hasbro had said that passage of that legislation was an obstacle it needed to pass before completing the takeover of Tonka, which is based in Minnetonka, Minn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Cone Gets a Grip on Real Stuff, Mesmerizes Giants
description: After inspiring the premature thought that last night might be the night of the first no-hitter in Met history, David Cone was merely extremely efficient.

title: Suspension and Streak Over as Clemens Defeats White Sox
description: Roger Clemens returned from his five-game suspension tonight and ran into little trouble with either umpire Terry Cooney or the Chicago White Sox, pitching the Boston Red Sox to a 7-2 victory.

title: Commercial Loans Drop
description: Commercial and industrial loans on the books of United States commercial banks, excluding acceptances, fell by $1.92 billion, to $315.53 billion, in the week ended April 24, the Federal Reserve Board said today. Including acceptances, loans fell by $2.06 billion, to $317.11 billion.

title: I.B.M. of Britain Plans to Cut Jobs
description: The British unit of the International Business Machines Corporation plans to cut its work force by about 5 percent over the next two years as part of a strategic shift in its operations. The cuts would shrink the number of employees at I.B.M. of Britain to 17,000 from 18,000.

title: Roemer's Rocky Path to Re-election 2 Months After Switching to G.O.P.
description: It took a long political career for Gov. Buddy Roemer and the Democratic Party to become so alienated from each other that he preferred to become a Republican.

title: Music in Review; Gamelan Son of Lion
description: Washington Square Church 135 West Fourth Street

title: String of Crisis Overwhelms Relief Agencies and Donors
description: Officials of private relief agencies said today that the string of refugee crises and natural calamities across the globe had depleted outside donations as well as their own energies.

title: Switzerland Plans to Abolish Anonymous Bank Accounts
description: Switzerland, where discretion has long been the watchword among bankers, is abolishing most of its anonymous bank accounts to crack down on criminal transactions, the Federal Banking Commission said today.

title: Con Edison Seeking Albany's Approval for a 9% Rate Rise
description: Citing inflation and higher costs, Consolidated Edison is seeking approval from the New York State Public Service Commission for a 9 percent rate increase.

title: Neighbors Movement Is Going National
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay-to-View Test Is Set For Denver
description: Three of the country's biggest telecommunications companies announced today that they would test whether cable television subscribers were interested in expanded pay-per-view services.

title: Lite Light Wins Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- Meadow Star was back in the barn in New York, and it was probably just as well. In the absence of the champion filly, Lite Light gave a record-breaking performance before a record-breaking crowd at Churchill Downs today and won the 117th Kentucky Oaks by 10 lengths.

title: Picking Out a Home Video Game System
description: Any parent not yet acquainted with the seductive world of video games might find the current array of hardware and software choices daunting enough to thwart even the Super Mario Brothers. The ongoing adventures of the brothers have sold 29 million cassettes since they were introduced as game characters in 1985.

title: Illinois Central Ends Midsouth Bid
description: The Illinois Central Corporation, a railroad freight company, said it was withdrawing its offer to acquire the Midsouth Corporation. It said the original stock-for-stock exchange no longer was attractive given the 58 percent increase in Illinois Central stock, to $19.125 a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, from $12 a share in December.

title: Rev. George W. Moore, 64, Pastor Who Invigorated 'Actors' Chapel'
description: The Rev. George W. Moore, pastor of St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church at 239 West 49th Street, commonly known as "the actors' chapel," died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 64 years old and lived at the rectory in Manhattan.

title: Music Teacher Held in 5 Rapes of His Students
description: A 24-year-old musician who worked two days a week as a volunteer teacher in a Brooklyn intermediate school was arrested yesterday on statutory rape charges. He was accused of having sex with five female students over a three-year period, officials of the City Department of Investigation said.

title: Strains Appear Between Turks And Aid Troops
description: The American and allied relief program for the more than 500,000 Kurdish refugees stranded here is beginning to cause strains with Turkey, which has traditionally regarded the Kurds as a restive, potentially subversive minority.

title: Allied-Lyons Chiefs to Quit
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the beverage and foods company, said today that its top two executives would step down. The move comes after the company reported huge foreign-exchange losses in March.

title: Music in Review; James Tenney
description: Greenwich House Auditorium 27 Barrow Street

title: Father Cleared In Child's Death In Car Seat Case
description: In a sharp reversal for prosecutors trying to use Florida car-seat laws to win a verdict of homicide, a judge threw out the state's case today against a Nicaraguan immigrant accused of killing his daughter in a traffic accident.

title: No Rush to Replace MacLeod
description: The Knicks' decision on a new coach will probably take several weeks, at least.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Exxon's backing out and the governor is backing out and we're getting ready for trial. I think it is unlikely further negotiations are feasible. It's too complicated a problem to solve. Sometimes there are things that need to be resolved in court." -- Thomas A. Campbell, a Government lawyer. [ 1:1. ]

title: Earl Pardon, 64, Artist Known for His Jewelry
description: Earl B. Pardon, an artist and craftsman who was best known for his colorful enamel mosaic jewelry, died on Wednesday at the New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: In Fly Fishing, Carter's Record Can't Be Assailed
description: In the tight little world of fly fishing, everybody gets graded for skill, and that includes Presidents.

title: An Old Club Breaks Bread, and a Tradition Crumbles
description: When the Ivy Club, the oldest eating club at Princeton University, formally inducted its first female members tonight, the celebration was replete with wine, women and song. Only the song, with its reference to the 112-year-old social organization's "sons," was a problem.

title: Marlboro Plans 'Mediums' to Stem the Brand's Decline
description: Philip Morris, trying to stem the slow decline of its best-selling cigarette, plans to introduce a version of Marlboro called Marlboro Medium that has tar and nicotine levels between those of the regular and light versions.

title: Mafia Trial in Hartford Opens With Guilty Plea
description: The murder and racketeering trial of nine reputed members of New England's largest organized crime family began in Federal District Court here this week with one defendant pleading guilty and an expert witness detailing Mafia initiation rites.

title: Manhattan's Own Loons Fish in Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Frances Schachter, A Child Psychologist And Researcher, 61
description: Dr. Frances Fuchs Schachter, a child psychologist, died on Thursday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 61 years old.

title: Apache-Maxus
description: The The Apache Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the majority of its natural gas properties in the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles to the Maxus Energy Corporation for $51 million. Apache said its share of the proceeds would be about $28 million and the rest would go to interests it represents. Apache said recent net production from the 300 wells involved has been averaging 25 milliion cubic feet of natural gas and 550 barrels of condensate a day. On Thursday, Apache said it would pay $546 million for domestic oil and gas properties of the Amoco Corporation situated mainly along the Gulf coast and in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Continental Can and VIAG in Deal
description: The German industrial group VIAG A.G. said it had agreed to purchase Continental Can Europe from Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., a mining and construction group based in Omaha. The Bonn-based aluminum and utilities group did not disclose financial terms. The Ball Corporation of Muncie, Ind., had reportedly offered $1 billion for Continental Can Europe, but backed out because of a lack of financing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Vassar College, in Poughkeepsie, opened its doors in 1861 with the first art museum on a college campus, a museum older than the Metropolitan in New York and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about Maxwell's, the music club in Hoboken, N.J., referred incompletely to the owners. There is a fifth partner, Kathryn Jackson Fallon.

title: Owners, Renters and Strikers Count Costs After Settlement
description: Early last week, as service workers wearing red-and-white strike placards began patrolling the sidewalks in front of Manhattan apartment buildings, an official of another New York union took stock of the situation. "It's kind of refreshing," she said. "This is a conventional, old-fashioned strike. Management isn't hiring replacements; it's not trying to break the union. The issues are simply economic."

title: Traffic Alert
description: Broadway Mall Street Fair: The east side of Broadway between 110th and 116th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Music in Review; David Van Tieghem
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: U.S. Envoy Criticizes Israelis on Settlements
description: The United States Ambassador to Israel leveled unusually blunt criticism at the Israeli Government today for its settlement and immigration policies.

title: Religion Notes
description: New Bible for Family

title: A Wary Leader in Superconducting
description: Business is better than ever at the Intermagnetics General Corporation, with the latest profits easily setting a company record. But those who follow the company wonder how long it can remain the world's leading independent supplier of products based on superconductivity.

title: Music in Review; Dmitri Berlinsky
description: 92d Street Y 1395 Lexington Avenue

title: China Trade Lobbying
description: The American Chamber of Commerce in China urged the United States today to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status, arguing that human rights complaints are best dealt with separately.

title: Charles F. Jones, 79, Oil Executive, Is Dead
description: Charles F. Jones, a former president and vice chairman of Humble Oil and Refining Company, the forerunner of the Exxon Company USA, died at his home in Houston on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Day to Stay in School
description: TODD DAY, Arkansas' leading scorer and a second-team all-American last season, said yesterday that he would return for his senior season with the Razorbacks. Day, a 6-8 forward, had been projected as a first-round draft choice if he turned pro. (AP)

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Slick Deals on Nice Cars Powered by Corruption
description: When the summer traffic was in full swing in February, and Argentines were flocking to the Uruguayan beaches, it seemed odd to customs officials at a river crossing that so many imported luxury cars, bearing the licence plates of invalids, had wind-surfing gear and surfboards strapped to their roofs.

title: 9 Held in Raids That Yield Pirated Videos
description: More than 50,000 pirated copies of film videocassettes have been seized and nine people have been arrested in raids on what Attorney General Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan described as possibly the largest manufacturer of illegal videocassettes in the country.

title: Patents; Tobacco Plant Is Source of Chemical
description: Using modern techniques of plant breeding, a researcher at DNA Plant Technologies Inc. has developed a tobacco plant that produces relatively large volumes of a scarce chemical used in both food and fragrances. The chemical, called sclareol, is a principal source of the musk fragrance in men's deodorant and after-shave lotions. It is also used as a flavor enhancer and as a way to reduce bitterness in some foods.

title: 4 Guards and 4 Games Do It For Warriors
description: Tim Hardaway scored 32 points and the seventh-seeded Golden State Warriors eliminated the San Antonio Spurs, 3 games to 1, with a 110-97 victory tonight in their Western Conference first-round playoff series.

title: 'I Hate Hamlet' Co-Star Walks Out    BYL>By ALEX WITCHEL
description: Evan Handler, a co-star of "I Hate Hamlet," left the stage near the end of the first act Thursday night, gave his notice, and walked out of the Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Handler's unplanned departure came after a dueling scene with Nicol Williamson, the play's star, who apparently ignored the choreography and struck Mr. Handler on the back with the flat part of his sword. Andrew Mutnick, Mr. Handler's understudy, finished the performance.

title: Vehicle Sales Dropped 21.4% in Late April
description: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April from a year earlier, deflating the industry's hopes that a rebound was imminent.

title: Police-Buyers Recover Stolen Painting
description: After several days of clandestine telephone negotiations and a crash course in 16th-century art, two New York City detectives yesterday recovered an Italian painting stolen in 1989 from a Long Island home, and arrested the dealer who had offered to sell it to them for $150,000, the police said.

title: Marine Is Found Guilty Of Attempted Spying
description: A marine who had passed maps, manuals and other sensitive documents to a Federal agent posing as a Soviet spy was convicted today of attempted espionage.

title: Coleman Honor Near
description: The Nets announced yesterday that they would hold a news conference on Monday, at which time DERRICK COLEMAN is expected to be named the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year. Coleman averaged 18.4 points this season and led the team in rebounding with 10.3 a game.

title: St. Bart's to Open Its Doors to an Adversary
description: Peace may never come to the roily realm of New York City real-estate development, but a remarkable cease-fire has been declared that is to be played out next month under the Byzantine dome of St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue.

title: ALASKA AND EXXON DROP SETTLEMENT IN VALDEZ OIL SPILL
description: The $1 billion agreement to settle civil complaints against Exxon in the Alaska oil spill collapsed today, and state and Federal officials plan to go to court. The process is likely to take years.

title: Honda Raises Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company raised prices today for Honda and Acura cars sold in the United States. The average price of a Honda car rose by $92, or six-tenths of 1 percent, and the average price of an Acura went up $197, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, the company said. The company attributed the higher prices to increased manufacturing costs.

title: Jacqueline Bonesi Weds David Beazer
description: Jacqueline Joan Bonesi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bonesi of Trumbull, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Lawrence Beazer, a son of Marilyn Smith Beazer of New York and the late William D. Beazer. The Rev. Paul E. Dinter performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church.

title: TENNIS
description: Double Duty for Lendl Top-seeded Ivan Lendl had a long day on the court yesterday, beating two opponents to move into the semifinals of the BMW Open in Munich, Germany. Lendl started by completing a third-round match suspended by rain on Thursday. He beat Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2. Lendl came back in the afternoon to defeat Todd Witsken, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5, in chilly, drizzly weather, and moved into the semifinals where he takes on Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden today. Gustafsson defeated the only German left in the tournament, Udo Riglewski, 6-2, 7-5. In other matches, Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina upset second-seeded Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, 7-6, 6-1, and moved into the semifinals against Christian Bergstrom of Sweden who defeated Lars Jonsson, also of Sweden, 4-6, 6-2, 6-0. (AP)

title: Righetti Has No Problem Cheering for the Yankees
description: Dave Righetti's morning began in Manhattan, as most of them had begun during his 10 seasons with the Yankees. But once his day began moving, everything was just a little different.

title: Bush Visits a Project to Push Tax Cuts
description: President Bush came to a housing project here today and told its tenants that they would benefit from a cut in the capital gains tax that Democrats have rejected.

title: Review/Music; A Festival Celebrating Variety
description: The second Corner Store Syndicate Festival at the Knitting Factory got off to a good start on Sunday night with a set by Phil Haynes's Four Horns and What?, a belligerent brass band supported by Mr. Haynes's crashing drums. The three-day festival, run by musicians, brought together players who don't really fit any genre and are rarely heard. It's a good idea, and it brought out polished music, though its democratic impulse was slightly undercut by a paucity of either blacks or women among the musicians.

title: Foreign Aid Workers -- and Some Old Ways -- Intrude on the New Iran
description: A jeweler packed away his wares the other night in a main street store, placing the gold, the diamonds and the pearls in their red velvet boxes and then entrusting his riches to a safe. Was business good? he was asked. "Praise God," he replied, it was.

title: Guidepost; Travels With Charley
description: It's easier than ever for pets to take a trip. The percentage of lodgings belonging to the American Hotel and Motel Association that will let pets stay rose from 53 percent in 1988 to nearly 60 percent in 1990, and more than two million animals are transported by air every year in the United States. Here are some sources of up-to-date information on travel regulations and lodging. REGULATIONS

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Warren V. Bush, a television producer, rendered the names of his brother and sister incorrectly. They are Ross Vollman and Cynthia Vollman.

title: Jerzy Kosinski, The Writer, 57, Is Found Dead
description: The writer Jerzy Kosinski was found dead in his apartment in Manhattan yesterday morning, an apparent suicide, the police said. He was 57 years old.

title: Vehicle Sales Dropped 21.4% in Late April
description: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 21.4 percent in late April from a year earlier, deflating the industry's hopes that a rebound was imminent.

title: A Co-Founder of Next Is Quitting the Company
description: Susan Kelly Barnes, co-founder and chief financial officer of Next Computer Inc. and a longtime aide to Steven P. Jobs, the company's president, is leaving the company.

title: Carol DiScala Is Married to Thomas A. Calicchio
description: Carol Ann DiScala, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. DiScala of Norwalk, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Thomas A. Calicchio, a son of Lee Calicchio and John Calicchio, both of New York. Judge Anthony M. Andreacchi of New York City Civil Court on Staten Island performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: Shuttle Arm Dangles 'Star Wars' Satellite for Tests
description: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery dangled a "Star Wars" research satellite on the end of the shuttle's outstretched mechanical arm today for 24 hours of tests.

title: In the Nation; Upbeat or Down?
description: At home, the Bush Administration is singing one tune about the economic outlook; but abroad, it's following another melody. To Americans out of jobs or looking for customers, Washington is predicting a quick upturn; but to the the Group of Seven nations, it's pleading a need for action to stimulate economic growth.

title: RJR Nabisco Buying Back Costly Debt
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation is taking another big step to reduce the cost of history's most expensive leveraged buyout. The company announced yesterday that it was buying back more than $1.8 billion in high-interest debt for 100 cents on the dollar, plus some unpaid interest.

title: Richard Thorpe Film Director, 95
description: Richard Thorpe, who directed hundreds of movies, including Elvis Presley's "Jailhouse Rock," died on Wednesday. He was 95 years old.

title: Bond Prices Plunge in Confused Day
description: Long-term interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury bonds plunged in what dealers called a most confused session. The confusion stemmed from outwardly conflicting Government employment data for April.

title: Joan Marcus Is a Bride
description: Joan Marcus, a daughter of Mildred Apter of Pittsburgh and the late Raymond Sidney Marcus, was married in Washington yesterday to Adrian Bryan-Brown, a son of Dr. Christopher Bryan-Brown of New York and Deirdre Bryan-Brown of Oxford, England. Judge Robert M. Scott of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the bride's home. The bride, 37 years old, is the resident photographer at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. She is a graduate of George Washington University. The bridegroom, 34, heads his own theatrical public relations firm in New York. He is a graduate of London University.

title: Patents; Keeping Toppings Soft in Ice Cream Treats
description: Researchers at Kraft General Foods Inc. won patent approval this week for ice cream toppings like fudge and caramel that they say will not harden into solid chunks at freezer temperatures. The new toppings make it possible to prepare ready-to-eat frozen sundaes or ice-cream sticks with a core of soft fudge.

title: Different Names For the Storms
description: Cyclones, typhoons and hurricanes are the same kind of violent tropical storm, a spiral of high winds and heavy rain, but the names differ depending on where the storms occur.

title: New Inquiry on Pilfering of Warehouse
description: An investigation into widespread theft at a warehouse owned by New York City has led to the arrest of a storeowner accused of illegally possessing three dozen of the city's cribs.

title: Underdogs, and Rabbits' Feet, in Derby Stew
description: On the eve of the Kentucky Derby, with jitters surrounding some of the barns at Churchill Downs and bravado surrounding some others, the historic hope of all race horses and their entourages was voiced by David Cross, who trains the 30-1 long shot Quintana.

title: Mastodon Yields Living Organisms
description: In the remains of a mastodon's last meal 11,000 years ago, preserved with a skeleton dug up in Ohio, scientists have made two surprising discoveries. They found living bacteria that they believe had dwelled inside the mastodon. And what they learned about its diet could upset some theories of what drove the mastodons to extinction.

title: Spending and Learning; Money's Role Questioned in Schools Debate
description: Five years ago Samuel Billups, principal of Walbrook High School in Baltimore, took a hard look at his school and winced. Test scores were low and students, in his words, "came out not really prepared for anything."

title: Chrysler Closings
description: The Chrysler Corporation will idle two of its seven United States car and truck assembly plants next week to adjust inventories. Chrysler said it would not operate its Newark, Del., and Toledo, Ohio, plants next week.
