About 2,950 hourly employees will be on temporary layoff at Newark, which is scheduled to resume production the week of May 13. About 4,600 hourly workers will be on temporary layoff at Toledo, which is also scheduled to resume production the week of may 13, Chrysler said.

title: Officer Sold Drugs, Police Say
description: A police officer who was suspended on Tuesday when he failed a drug test was arrested last night after selling six vials of crack in the Norwood section of the Bronx, the police said. The officer, 30-year-old Edward Coughlin, who worked in the 34th Precinct in Manhattan, was charged with criminal possession of narcotics, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. She said he was seen selling drugs outside 665 Burke Avenue at 6:25 P.M. during routine surveillance by undercover narcotics officers.

title: Gay Groups Protest a Film Script
description: A film script that raised industry concerns about runaway prices after it sold for a record $3 million last year is at the center of another controversy. "Basic Instinct," a thriller written by Joe Eszterhas and starring Michael Douglas, has set off a furor among gay activists and women's groups here. It has also put Mr. Eszterhas at odds with the director for a second time.

title: Stocks Seesaw; Dow Rises by 0.25
description: After three good days, Wall Street had a tough time yesterday deciding what to do; conflicting road signs kept investors guessing.

title: Trustees Seek Hunt Assets
description: Trustees liquidating the estates of Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt have asked a judge for permission to file a suit seeking $100 million that they say the former billionaires gave to family and friends just before filing bankruptcy.

title: Western Values Are Central
description: Americans do not share a common ancestry and a common blood. What they have in common is a system of laws and beliefs that shaped the establishment of the country, a system developed within the context of Western civilization.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Guns Are Poor Protection
description: Fear of crime leads many New Yorkers to a facile conclusion: For real protection, get a gun. Two stories on the same page of Friday's New York Times make clear how deadly a conclusion that may be.

title: Auto Production Report
description: Auto makers were scheduled to produce 240,164 cars and light trucks in the United States and Canada this week, up from last week's 230,278, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade newspaper. This week's production is lower than in the comparable week a year ago, in which 271,691 cars and light trucks were produced, the paper said Thursday.

title: Young Gets $4.5 Million as Montana's Backup
description: Quarterback STEVE YOUNG, the backup to JOE MONTANA, has agreed to a new two-year contract with the San Francisco 49ers that will make him the highest-paid reserve in the National Football League.

title: British Tories Lose Many Local Posts
description: Results of local government elections across England and Wales on Thursday showed today that Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party had taken a drubbing, despite his recent decision to abandon an unpopular per-capita community charge.

title: Bonn Seeks Help for East
description: Germany appealed today to foreign companies to invest in eastern Germany, promising them large subsidies.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AW Computer Systems Inc., Mount Laurel, N.J., has received an order for more than $800,000 of Aware/4680 equipment and service from Safeway Stores Inc. * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a newsprint, wood and paper products company, will sell its Pine Falls newsprint operation in Winnipeg, Manitoba, to the local group that manages and operates it. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Yanks Solve One Riddle But Still Face Dilemma
description: Just two weeks and eight games after he became the Yankees' everyday third baseman, Mike Blowers was back on the bench tonight. So who's turn is it now?

title: Shaping, Slowly, a New City Council
description: Redistricting is one of those eye-glazing words that only a political junkie can love. But it's a vital issue right now in New York City.

title: Vitas Gerulaitis Sr., Tennis Teacher, 76
description: Vitas Gerulaitis Sr., who nutured his son, Vitas Jr., into becoming one of the world's top professionals and later became the first head pro at the National Tennis Center in Queens, died on Thursday in Woodhaven, L.I.

title: 1920 Treaty Granted A State to Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: End Hostage Deal 'Rumors,' Bush Asks
description: President Bush today called for an end to "rumor-mongering" about reports of an effort by the Reagan-Bush campaign to keep Iran from freeing 52 American hostages just before the 1980 election.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about complaints of censorship on the school newspaper of the Horace Mann School in the Bronx misidentified the faculty adviser in some copies. He is Adam Kenner.

title: Neighbors Movement Is Going National; Try Volunteer Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Rentals By Cox to End
description: Cox Cable Communications said it intends to sell its 82 Blockbuster Video stores and withdraw from the videocassette rental business. Just a month ago, Cox was aggressively opening Blockbuster stores and said it intended to operate 122 stores by the end of the year.

title: Patents; Plastic Wrap Allows Vegetables to 'Breathe'
description: Researchers at Hercules Inc., a diversified manufacturing company in Wilmington, Del., obtained a patent this week on a "breathable" plastic wrap that they said could extend the shelf life of fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: U.N. CHIEF ANGERED BY DELAY CHARGES
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar was "dismayed" and "angered" today over British assertions that he had been slow in setting up a United Nations police force to protect Kurdish refugees inside Iraq, his spokesman said.

title:
Beauty;
Body Language: Hip
description: The hip joint, a knobbly ball and a socket, defines the tiny summit, a knoll from which swales and meadows fall away. Start in any direction and you pass through landscapes designated by the hybrid terms (Latin with much seasoning from English) of anatomy. Go far enough back up the side and you'll reach the lower edge of the chest, the "costal margin," formed by the cartilaginous parts of the seventh to tenth ribs. Or travel diagonally up the abdominal wall in the general direction of the navel. You'll cross the linea semilunaris, or "half-moon line," formed by muscles, and later the linea alba, or "white line," the slim column of down that runs from the navel to the pubic tuft.

title: War and Memory
description: A SOLDIER OF THE GREAT WAR By Mark Helprin. 792 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Miami Airport
description: To the Editor: I had to laugh at a recent letter complaining of discrimination toward foreign tourists in India. If you want to see discrimination toward foreigners, come to Miami International Airport any busy afternoon. While the handful of returning American passengers on international flights gets whisked through immigration in 5 or 10 minutes, hundreds of exhausted, confused foreigners are herded into a 45-minute wait for one of the few available immigration officers.

title: Riley Gives Knicks Hope
description: The Knicks have contacted Pat Riley about becoming their next head coach. And Riley, former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers and a commentator for NBC Sports, is interested in holding further discussions.

title: Carolyn Kee Is Married
description: Carolyn Ann Kee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kee of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married yesterday in Greenville, Del., to James Carr Gamble 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gamble Jr. of St. Louis. The Rev. William B. Lane, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church.

title: A Show in Berlin That's All Over the Map
description: The most interesting fact about "Metropolis," the international exhibition of contemporary art recently inaugurated in Berlin, is that anyone in this once-divided city who wants to see it can. It is exciting to think of the show as symbolic of unregulated artistic exchange between East and West, or of a rejuvenated, culturally prominent Berlin implied by the exhibition's title.

title: James A. Walsh, Federal Judge, 84
description: James A. Walsh, a Federal district judge who issued the antitrust ruling that allows competing newspapers to pool resources in non-news operations, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospice. He was 84 years old.

title: The Wonderworld of a Stage Designer Who Defies Reality
description: Actors and singers normally play their roles before sets of greater or lesser grandeur, as spotlights illuminate them with greater or lesser imagination and brilliance. But in the designer Jerome Sirlin's world, they live their theatrical lives deep within the sets, which glow with an inner life and flicker instantaneously into new incarnations.

title: Sasser and Carreon Seek Their Day in Sun
description: Mark Carreon and Mackey Sasser began the day sitting quietly in the dugout at Shea Stadium, as they have done for most of the year. Both think they should be playing more, but their manager thinks otherwise.

title: East End Planners Cautious As Indian Artifacts Surface
description: IN 1988, when a house on Sugarloaf Hill in the Town of Southampton was going up, some residents of the Shinnecock Reservation protested, saying that town planners had carelessly allowed the desecration of a site with Indian remains and artifacts.

title: Kurdish Leaders Put Off 2d Meeting With Hussein
description: Kurdish rebel leaders have postponed a crucial second round of peace talks with President Saddam Hussein, which was scheduled to start today.

title: CHERNOBYL FIVE YEARS LATER
description: Chernobyl should not be forgotten. It was a tragedy of enormous proportions, but its lesson is not in abandoning nuclear energy at the very time that it can make such a large contribution to the world's energy needs with minimal environmental effect. Rather, it is to proceed rationally through international cooperation to prevent Chernobyl's reoccurrence. DANIEL BERG Institute Professor of Science and Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Troy, N.Y.

title:
ART;
Provocative Sculptures
description: VISUALLY strong and loaded with potential for symbolic interpretation, Carolee Thea's robustly animated papier-mache figurative sculpture at the Hofstra Museum makes a provocative installation.

title: Home Sales Continue to Rise in New York Area, Brokers Say
description: An upswing in home sales that began in January has been sustained in three months of active buying across New York City and its suburbs, real-estate executives and lenders say.

title: Gambling With the Big Boys
description: A group of men, mostly middle-aged, sporting identical safari hats and lightweight binoculars, is sitting in the bleachers one summer evening around sunset at the San Diego Wild Animal Park. A perky, blond-haired trainer is demonstrating the finer qualities of a porcupine and asks for a volunteer to join her in petting the large, prickly animal.

title: Coming Out of Hiding: Childhoods as Non-Jews
description: In World War II, when Abraham Foxman's parents fled to escape the Nazis, they left him, a child of 2, in Vilnius, Lithuania, with his Christian nanny. She had him baptized as a Catholic.

title: Columbia Social-Work Students Protest
description: A GROUP of students training to become advocates for the disenfranchised have been fighting their own battle recently at the Purchase campus of the Columbia University School of Social Work.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: DISTURBING THE PEACE: A Conversation With Karel Hvizdala, by Vaclav Havel. Translated by Paul Wilson. (Vintage, $11.) In interviews with a fellow playwright, Vaclav Havel talks about the absurd theater of life, in which a former dissident like himself can end up President of Czechoslovakia. Last year our reviewer, Robert Brustein, said this book is "the finest work this Czechoslovak artist has yet produced. . . . 'Disturbing the Peace' leaves no room for controversy about his place in the moral pantheon of our century."

title: Couple's Clowning Cheers Sick Children
description: SENDING in the clowns could not have come at a better time for 3 1/2-year-old Lasheera McBride. As the child, recovering from a brain tumor operation at Beth Israel Hospital's Valerie Fund Children's Cancer Center, giggled and made funny faces at two goofy clowns one recent afternoon here, her pain seemed very far away.

title: Miss Randolph Weds KeGang Wang
description: Katherine Anne Randolph, the daughter of Dagmar Wintzer Randolph of Ridgewood, N.J., was married in Brooklyn yesterday to KeGang Wang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wang Zuo-bin of Beijing. The Rev. Michael Otte, a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church, officiated at the Old First Reformed Church.

title: Focus: Northern Vermont; A Big Drive to Bring Back Better Times
description: HARD times are no stranger to this city of 4,400 residents at the confluence of two major rail lines just south of the Canadian border.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in the Residential Resales column on March 31 on an apartment in the Imperial House at 150 East 69th Street contained several inaccuracies. The closing price was $995,000, not $1 million, and the maintenance was $1,869, not $869. There were 2 1/2 baths, not 3 1/2, and there was no maid's room. The errors occurred in information supplied by the brokerage, Charles H. Greenthal, which submitted corrections on April 26.

title: Brandeis University Selects Samuel Thier As Its New President
description: Samuel O. Thier, president of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, has been selected as the sixth president of Brandeis University, ending a long and difficult search for new leadership for the financially troubled institution.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about the TransAmerica bicycle trail misidentified the water at the edge of its eastern terminus in Yorktown, Va. It is the York River, not the ocean.

title: In Groton, Family-Style Lebanese Fare
description: THE restaurant Diana, which was named for a member of the owners' family, has the look of a simple storefront in a shopping mall in Groton. Red leatherette booths line one long wall, and other tables are well spaced. But there are clues that Diana is something more. Oriental rugs are on the terrazzo floor and hung on the walls, along with framed pictures of Lebanon. A glass case near the front is full of Middle Eastern pastries, and the tables are covered with white cloths trimmed in green and red, the colors of the Lebanese flag.

title: Identity Becomes Central to Debate as Democrats Prepare for 1992 Race
description: The quest has begun yet again to define what a Democrat is and what a Democrat stands for, in a way that can attract a majority of the voters.

title: Marjorie Kehm Engaged
description: Priscilla Kehm of Harrison, N.Y., has announced December wedding plans for her daughter Marjorie Nossen Kehm and Stephen Francis Xavier Roney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Walter Roney of White Plains. Miss Kehm, 24 years old, is also the daughter of the late Walter C. Kehm. She is a travel consultant at U Name It Travel in Harrison and a graduate of Skidmore College. Mr. Roney, 25, is a sales trader for Salomon Brothers in New York. He graduated summa cum laude from Fordham University.

title: Posy Sheppard, Ex-Red Cross Official, Is Wed to Jeremiah Milbank, Investor
description: Rose Jackson Sheppard of Greenwich, Conn., a former vice chairwoman of the American Red Cross, was married in Greenwich yesterday to Jeremiah Milbank, the New York investor, also of Greenwich, in the Round Hill Community Church. The interdenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph Ahlberg, a Congregational minister, assisted by the Rev. Sidney Woold-Cahusac, an Episcopal priest.

title:
Beauty;
Body Language: FEET
description: Feet occupy a peculiar in-between zone in the topography of the body. Sometimes you see them, but mostly you don't, given that they are not meant exclusively for either public or private viewing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The notion of 'political correctness' has ignited controversy across the land. And although the movement arises from the laudable desire to sweep away the debris of racism, sexism and hatred, it replaces old prejudices with new ones." -- President Bush. [ 1:3. ]

title: Excerpts From President's Speech to University of Michigan Graduates
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address at the University of Michigan's commencement exercise today.

title: Few New Charges Seen In Beating of Motorist
description: A county grand jury that is investigating police conduct in three officers' widely publicized beating of a black motorist is not expected to indict any of the 17 officers who stood by and did nothing to stop it, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: New Mexico Cave Yields Clues to Early Man
description: Archeologists have discovered bones, charcoal and possible stone artifacts in a New Mexico cave that they say is strong evidence that humans arrived in North America more than 35,000 years ago, much earlier than generally estimated.

title: Carol Spiro Wed To Mark Feldman
description: Carol Ann Spiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., was married in Lake Success, L.I., last evening to Mark Koeppel Feldman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Feldman of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor Stephen Duboff, performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.

title: Lunging for War?
description: For three months last year, President Bush defied the hasty hawks who wanted to turn Iraq into a parking lot after its brutal invasion of Kuwait. At least until Nov. 8, two days after the election, the President's assignment to the American forces in the Persian Gulf was to defend Saudi Arabia. He seemed to be filling the role of a brave statesman, using force in carefully measured amounts -- and to achieve carefully deliberated goals.

title: He's Not a Miracle Man
description: More than a month after he took over as coach of the United States national soccer team, BORA MILUTINOVIC, will finally coach the squad in a game today when it takes on Uruguay in a stop in Denver on the World Series of Soccer tour.

title: Graphic Revolutions
description: One byproduct of glasnost is the extraordinary business in Soviet revolutionary art and artifacts from the 1920's. Current revivals of the Russian avant-garde apparent in fine art and graphic design are due in part to the scores of books on Russian masters, as well as histories, analyses, monographs and collections. Included are volumes and catalogues on a wide variety of Soviet avant-garde movements, from architecture to ceramics, advertising to clothing. (Indeed, there is now so much arcana being uncovered that perhaps the next wave might include a title like "Sports Heroes of the Russian Avant-Garde.") The most recent is an interesting document for what it says about contemporary Soviet art. First issued in the Soviet Union for export to the West, and now published here, is THE SOVIET ARTS POSTER: Theatre, Cinema, Ballet, Circus, 1917-1987 (Penguin, Paper, $24.95), edited by Nina Baburina and translated by Boris Meerovich and Era Mozolkova. Included are innovative film posters of the early 20's, which, when compared with the best of the later posters, illustrate how bad Soviet applied arts were forced to become under Stalin. Yet much of the book showcases the Western- and Polish-inspired poster images done in the spirit of glasnost. Sadly, however, even when comparing these relatively more imaginative works to those of the avant-garde one realizes that Soviet poster art never fully recovered from Stalin's purges.

title: World Markets; Drug Stocks as a Global Play
description: Bolstering its reputation as recession-proof, the pharmaceutical business is prospering on both sides of the Atlantic. Demand for prescription drugs continues to be strong, although French Government agencies have cut the prices of several products this year and Germany has also started to squeeze prices.

title:
MUSIC;
A New Work reflects Family Values
description: IN honor of the Colonial Symphony's 40th anniversary, the composer David Sampson, a Morristown resident, has written a commemorative work about the passage of time and changing perspectives that draws upon the influence of his grandmother and her two sisters on his life.

title: Officers' Lifetime Heart Benefits Are Costly for Connecticut Towns
description: A dozen Connecticut towns do not hire police officers or firefighters who smoke. Some pay bonuses to officers who keep their weight and cholesterol levels down. Others pay for exercise programs. At least one restricts smokers to special patrol cars.

title: Players Who Put Down a Stethoscope to Pick Up a Horn
description: IF it is Wednesday night there is music in the air at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University here. Live music, coming from a live symphony orchestra, rehearsing on the stage of an auditorium designed to be a lecture hall.

title: All About/Trucking; A Whole Lot of Shaking Going On
description: When the trucking industry was deregulated in 1980, thousands of new companies sprang up seeking to take advantage of the new ease of entry and greater freedom to set their own prices. Hundreds of existing companies expanded quickly, adding non-union divisions and entering new markets ranging from pickup and delivery to storage.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE COOKCAMP

title:
THEATER;
Professional Company Settles In at Waterbury
description: SEMINA DE LAURENTIS was working as an actress in Los Angeles in 1988, when a writers' strike halted production there, prompting her to come home to Waterbury for the summer. She found people there eager for someone to bring professional theater back to their community.

title: Ms. Jeremko and Steven Tucker to Wed in Fall
description: November wedding plans for Margaret Alice Jeremko and Steven Danforth Tucker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Tucker of Kinnelon, N.J., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Jeremko of West Goshen, Conn.

title: Little House in Albania
description: DOROTHY THOMPSON AND ROSE WILDER LANE

title: Just Like A Fortepiano?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Peter and the Wolf' Ends a Concert Season
description: MANY ensembles and presenting organizations are preparing to call it a season. Heading the list of today's finales are two programs especially suitable for young listeners, although both involve a short drive out of the county.

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: The leading lady in "The Little Mermaid" has adventures that are "limited to romance and over with the wedding bells," and yet the movie meets with the mild approval of feminist Pollitt because Ariel is "active, brave and determined, the heroine of her own life."

title: Travel Advisory; Costa Rica Assesses Quake
description: The major tourist areas of Costa Rica were left largely undamaged by an earthquake on April 22 that took the lives of up to 70 people, according to the country's Tourism Minister.

title: Travel Advisory; Hawaii's Plans For July Eclipse
description: When a solar eclipse takes place July 11, the path of totality will pass over the Big Island of Hawaii's Kohala Coast for about four minutes. Lectures by astronomers about the eclipse, which will begin there at 7:28 A.M., and outings timed to coincide with the event are among special activities scheduled on the island.

title: Tallying Poland's Jewish Population
description: To the Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Odenton, Md.;
Sewer Dispute Slows Project
description: THE recession and a dispute over sewers have slowed work on Seven Oaks, a development just north of here, even as the nearby Piney Orchard project enters a depressed housing market.

title: Style Makers; Atil Kutoglu, Fashion Designer
description: Atil Kutoglu, 24 years old, is a man with a mission. His aim: To produce exciting new fashion in Vienna, and to sell throughout Europe and the United States. An impossible dream? Not really. He already has a toehold in several countries.

title: Chess
description: A perverse choice of opening strategy plays right into the champion's hands.

title: Ideas & Trends; Getting the Royal Treatment, Tabloid Style
description: "SEPARATE HOMES," screamed the front-page headline in The Sun two weeks ago. The story -- "an extraordinary series of disclosures," in the tabloid's understated prose -- was presented as an inside account of prickly and distant relations between Prince Charles and Diana, the Princess of Wales, provided by a former security policeman, whose post was outside the gates of Charles's country house in Gloucestershire. The story included the kind of intrusive details, real or invented, about separate households, the bedroom decor, waking hours, eating habits, likes and dislikes of Charles and Diana, that feed the public obsession with the British Royal Soap Opera. The Sun ran the security guard's tale for a few days ("Tomorrow: More Amazing Revelations"), while the other Fleet Street tabloids scrambled to follow.

title: A La Carte: East End Gets San Remo Touch
description: BOTH Sapore di Mare, the stylish Italian restaurant in Wainscott, and its owner, Pino Luongo, are making culinary news on the East End and beyond.

title: Emily Loesser, Actress, Marries
description: Emily Loesser, a daughter of Jo Sullivan Loesser of New York and the late Frank Loesser, was married at the James Burden Mansion in New York last evening to Donald Ragan Stephenson 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Don R. Stephenson Jr. of Chattanooga, Tenn. Judge Alvin Schlesinger of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: Eason, a Pricey Reserve, Won't Return to the Jets
description: Tony Eason was not among the 86 draft picks, veterans and free agents at the opening day of the Jets minicamp drills at Hofstra University today, a clear indication that last season's backup quarterback to Kenny O'Brien was through as Jet.

title: Tracy M. Stolls Is Wed To Mark J. Berlinsky
description: Tracy Marlene Stolls, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Stolls of Bethpage, L.I., was married last night to Mark Jonathan Berlinsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Berlinsky of East Windsor, N.J. Rabbi Robert Jacobs performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I.

title: You Want Repertory? Here It Is
description: Recently in this space I asked a simple question: why has so little music composed since 1950 entered the repertory? Because the problem has puzzled me, I assumed others might also be baffled. Yes and no. A few readers refused to agree that there was a problem and expressed annoyance that a critic would waste time on it. "How much more responsible it would be," protested one, "if you devoted your space to educating audiences about why new music is still being written." (I fear there could be the germ of another irresponsible column in that sentence.)

title: Police Raid Hostels in Effort to Halt South African Chaos
description: The police raided workers' hostels and squatter camps today in an effort to halt chronic violence that has killed more than 100 people in a week.

title: Dollar Is Quiet Despite Fed Move
Dog Owner Guilty of Homicide
description: The owner of two pit bulls that killed a 57-year-old woman last summer was convicted Friday of criminally negligent homicide. The 44-year-old defendant, Edwin Hill, a former policeman, faces up to two years in prison when he is sentenced next month. The victim, Betty Lou Stidham, was one of 24 people killed by dogs in the United States last year, said Ann Joly of the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Battle Aftermath
description: To the Editor: In his article on Verdun ("The Longest Battle," Travel, Feb. 17), which recently came to my attention, Alistair Horne pointed out that no birds are found at Fort Douaumont or a sector called Mort Homme where the fighting was particularly savage.

title: Look Out, New Jack, the Love Man's Back
description: Hip-Hop and New Jack Swing have given innocent love a bruising. Over the last five years, people have been singing or rapping an unsanitized version of love. Domination, objectification, violence -- it's a war out there. Under the assault of the new admissions, gospel-influenced pop-soul singers -- crooning their love ballads, repressing their animal instincts -- have sounded absolutely archaic.

title: Project Tries New Ways To Intervene in Families
description: RICHARD PURCELL was doing his best as a single parent, but his conversations with 14-year-old Melissa often turned into fights. That was before the father and daughter were referred to the Yonkers Youth Connection. Now they communicate better, Mr. Purcell and Melissa agree, thanks to the social worker who has met with them regularly.

title: Let's Give Aaron His Just Due
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ninnies, Pedants, Tyrants and Other Academics
description: The children of the 60's have returned. Twenty years have passed, and many of us, through folly, hubris or mischance, have died or been left sleeping in the land of the lotus-eaters. The palace has been taken over by shallow upstarts, raiding and wasting the treasury laid up by so many noble generations. It's time to clean house.

title: Blazers Finally Win Series From Stubborn SuperSonics
description: The Portland Trail Blazers returned to their basic strengths -- defense and rebounding -- to beat Seattle, 119-107, today and finally eliminate the SuperSonics from the playoffs.

title: Relief Officials Say Bad Planning Proves Calamitous in Bangladesh
description: Bangladeshis and international disaster experts are criticizing the Government's slow response in assessing needs and moving supplies to survivors of the cyclone that struck this country with devastating force on Monday.

title: Charmed by Death and Chaos
description: ANATHEMAS AND ADMIRATIONS By E. M. Cioran. Translated by Richard Howard. 256 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing/Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.

title: An Irregular Heartbeat, Usually Not Serious
description: For someone like President Bush, who has never before suffered from atrial fibrillation, the experience typically comes on suddenly, often when the patient is in the midst of exercise, and it can be alarming.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The roof on the south side of our house is shaded most of the day and keeps collecting moss. How do I remove the moss without damaging the shingles, and what can I do to keep it from coming back? A. Garden-supply stores sell numerous products for removing moss, and one I am familiar with is called De-Moss. You can also wash moss off with a copper sulfate solution (one-half ounce to 10 gallons of water). This solution has some residual effect to keep moss from coming back for a while. Because the solution can damage shrubbery and cause harm to metal, flush it off thoroughly. Copper pieces along the roof ridge will help prevent moss growth for about 10 feet down from the ridge. Also, string copper wires horizontally along the roof to protect sections further down. Each wire will prevent moss growth for about four feet below it. Q. Our bathroom has tile around the tub, with pink tiles scattered among the white ones. The effect is atrocious, and we would like to paint all the tile white. Can you suggest how to paint ceramic tile? A. Ceramic tile can be painted with any good grade of alkyd enamel. Clean the surface first with a strong detergent or scouring powder. Rinse off with plain water, then allow the surface to dry for a day or two. Apply a bonding primer coat of white, pigmented shellac like BIN or Enamelac and then apply two coats of the enamel, sanding lightly between coats. Once the tile has been painted, it should be repainted periodically.

title: Dentists Are Divided On the Risk of AIDS
description: SINCE July, when it became widely known that a young woman in Florida had acquired AIDS after being treated by an infected dentist, anxiety has been growing about such risks.

title: DOWNTOWN COUSIN
description: It was refreshing to see an article about Asian-Americans, written by an Asian-American, that deals with something besides how to be a model minority (About Men: "Downtown Cousin" by Ti-Hua Chang, March 17). The story of an uptown yuppie traveling to Chinatown for the ultimate bargain was funny and humanizing.

title: Carolyn Wemple To Wed in August
description: Mrs. Gordon Kinder of Naples, Fla., and Point O'Woods, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Carolyn Christina Wemple to Scott Warren Steffey, a son of Warren Steffey of Mesa, Ariz., and Frances Culviner of Washington. An August wedding is planned.

title: A TV Set That Shapes Up Movies
description: The mutilation of movies for video presentation may finally come to an end. A new type of television set allows feature films to be shown on a wide screen with the same shape as a movie screen. As a result, it will no longer be necessary to cut off part of the picture to make it fit within the dimensions of the video screen.

title: State Tries to Thwart Collegians By Banning Alcohol From a Park
description: FOR years, Mansfield Hollow State Park has been the prime party spot for college students and other young people. But now, the State Department of Environmental Protection has banned possession of alcohol in the park, and rangers say that should reduce the number of gatherings.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Glen Ridge 146,000 47 Willow Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 76-year-old colonial; parquet floors, family room, in-ground pool; taxes $5,648. Hopatcong 145,000 7 Cove Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old lakefront ranch; new septic system, deck, dock; taxes $4,317. Jackson 132,750 93 Buckingham Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; c/a, 1-car garage, family room, fireplace; taxes $3,527. Manalapan 189,900 5 Clinton Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old split level; family room, 2-car garage, c/a, w/w carpeting; taxes $3,576. Montclair 168,000 97 Haddon Place 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; eat-in-kitchen, close to transportation; taxes $5,795. Nutley 162,500 407 Prospect Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; family room, dinette, cedar closets; taxes $3,952. OTHER AREAS Nesconset, L.I. 175,000 1 Sunhill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; new kitchen, den, basement, fireplace, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,800. Westport, Conn. 200,000 6 Lakeview Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; h/w floors, on cul-de-sac, 0.50 acre; taxes $3,021. New Rochelle, N.Y. 263,000 1 Glenfruin Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 53-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,799.

title:
Forum;
A Vote for Peer Pressure
description: The moaning and groaning coming from American corporations seems excessive. It has been going on since well before the United States Sentencing Commission presented its recommendations on penalties for corporate crime to Congress last week, and it may even accelerate while Congress studies the report.

title: DINKINS PRESENTS A DIRE NEW PLAN TO MEET BUDGET
description: In a daylong series of meetings yesterday with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, legislative leaders, local officials and union representatives, Mayor David N. Dinkins sketched out a dire plan to end New York City's fiscal slide through cuts in city services and work force that go far deeper than any the Mayor had said might be needed.

title: Saudi General Has Kinship for 'Norm'
description: The first thing Prince Khaled bin Sultan did after being appointed joint commander of the anti-Iraqi coalition forces was to transfer the gym equipment at his farm to his office at the Defense Ministry. He vowed to exercise four times a week, war or peace.

title: Camera
description: Rampant zoom technology has reduced focal length to a mere compositional convenience. Why move back and forth, camera makers seem to ask, when you can just stand there and zoom to make your subject fit the frame?

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Hicksville 135,000 5 Winter Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Lake Grove 179,000 8 Cristi Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,000. Levittown 105,000 143 North Wantagh Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,000. Mineola 160,000 160 Roosevelt Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,200. Nesconset 175,000 1 Sunhill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; new kitchen, den, basement, fireplace, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,800. Port Jefferson 110,000 8 Shenandoah Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,000. OTHER AREAS Glen Ridge, N.J. 146,000 47 Willow Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 76-year-old colonial; parquet floors, family room, in-ground pool; taxes $5,648. Westport, Conn. 200,000 6 Lakeview Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; h/w floors, on cul-de-sac, 0.50 acre; taxes $3,021. New Rochelle, N.Y. 263,000 1 Glenfruin Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 53-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,799.

title: By Bicycle
description: To the Editor: Michael Finkel's "Pedaling Their Way Across America" (Travel, April 7) reflected many of the joys and heartaches of my touring experience. It's a pity that the Bikecentennial route does not take cyclists to the continent's edge, only to the York River in Yorktown, Va. In many other respects the Colonial Parkway route into Yorktown provides a fitting way to end a Trans America trek: scenic, historic and no trucks. DAVID HOWELL Nashville

title: After a Life of Writing, A First Novel at Age 70
description: WHEN listeners gather on Wednesday for the last of the season's lunchtime programs at the Westport Library, they will be greeting an old friend in a new role. Ethel Gorham, who organized this popular series of talks by local authors in 1977, will retire as chairwoman and address the audience in her new role as novelist.

title: Polo Field Proposal Questioned
description: A PROPOSAL to build a polo complex in the Town of Southampton on land that was set aside for farming has rivals fighting over the town's Farmland Preservation Program of 1980.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AGASSIZ A Novel in Stories.By Sandra Birdsell.Milkweed Editions, $18.95.

title: New Jersey High Court Sets Rules On Mental Handicap in Sex Cases
description: In a unanimous opinion, the New Jersey Supreme Court has established guidelines for cases that involve a charge of sexual assault on a mentally defective person.

title: Human Values, Inhuman Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Island-Hopping the Caribbean, Against Drugs
description: For the crew of the Farallon, a sleek white Coast Guard cutter, dusk signals the start of "stealth" operations, when surprise becomes the crucial weapon in a cat-and-mouse struggle to police the Caribbean against drug smugglers.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Indianapolis;
Navy Anchors Research Park
description: A HIGH-TECH Navy research center that moved here from Ridgecrest, Calif., is helping the city attract housing and businesses to a narrow canal skirting the western edge of downtown.

title:
FOOTBALL;
Knights Seek 4th Straight Against the 0-6 Skyhawks
description: This city is hardly the most alluring venue in the World League of American Football, which boasts a team in Montreal and three in Europe. But given the Raleigh-Durham Skyhawks' record, a visit to the North Carolina capital surely will have considerable appeal to the New York/New Jersey Knights on Sunday afternoon.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Historical Pains BECAUSE it took 200 years for the problem to develop, perhaps it is not surprising that it took 10 months for it to be resolved.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: Concerning your article on women and college fund raising, I take exception to Willard F. Enteman's assertion: "With male alums, you often go out drinking till all hours to extract some whopping donation."

title: Commencement; Baker, at Rice, Hails Exploit of a Forebear
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d spoke at Rice University in Houston yesterday, 60 years after his grandfather delivered the commencement address there.

title: Elissa D. Fischbach to Marry in June
description: Drs. Gerald and Ruth Fischbach of Cambridge, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Elissa Diane Fischbach, and Jonathan Neil Grayer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Grayer of Westport, Conn.

title: August Bridal Planned By Jan D'Alessandro
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. D'Alessandro of Green Village, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jan D'Alessandro to John Vredenburgh Wadsworth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wadsworth of Buffalo. An August wedding is planned.

title: The World; Some Lessons From A Failed Assault On a Japan Inc. Fortress
description: FOR the last two years, T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who hates to be called a corporate raider, has been devoted to a colorful if quixotic effort to breach one of the strongest fortresses in Japanese business, the corporate empire built around the Toyota Motor Company.

title: Growth In Putnam Is Straining Rural County
description: PUTNAM COUNTY, like most other counties in the Hudson Valley, experienced population increases in the last decade. Along with that has come some growing pains.

title: The Don Juan From Spokane
description: SWEAT TRICKLES DOWN Thomas Hampson's face as he wriggles out of his striped leather doublet and collapses into a folding chair. The tall, robustly handsome baritone has just left the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where he has sung the buoyant Champagne Aria in the first act of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" with breathtaking agility and cynical charm.

title: Free Hostages, Iranian Says
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said today that Western hostages held in Lebanon should be freed "as soon as possible," along with Israeli prisoners. Speaking at a news conference with Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, Mr. Velayati gave no indication if there was renewed movement on efforts to free the Westerners held by pro-Iranian Shiites in Lebanon.

title: Good Sense on Mexican Trade
description: President Bush has responded constructively to critics of his proposed free-trade pact with Mexico by pledging to protect U.S. workers and the environment. In a 70-page statement, the White House promises to retrain dislocated workers, preserve existing U.S. environmental standards and incorporate environmental reviews into the negotiating process.

title: Sarina Prizzi Married To Peter A. O'Loghlin
description: Sarina Prizzi, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Prizzi of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Prizzi, was married yesterday to Peter Anthony O'Loghlin, the son of Cornelia Collins of Adelaide, Australia, and the late John O'Loghlin. The Rev. Raymond Chappetto officiated at Our Lady of Miracles Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Bridge
description: Modern players owe much to a few great theorists like Norman Squire.

title: Mutual Funds; Try a Dry Run Before Cashing Out
description: Last month, a couple in New York nearly bounced checks to the Internal Revenue Service for their 1990 taxes. The problem: A transfer from their money-market account at an out-of-town mutual fund to their local bank went awry.

title: Let's Do Lunch
description: When the Greater New York March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation holds its 8th annual sports luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow, the guests of honor will be a couple of guys who'd rather run than march.

title: No Feminist Is an Island
description: FEMINISM WITHOUT ILLUSIONS

title: THOUSANDS BATTLE SEOUL RIOT FORCES
description: Nearly 10,000 protesters battled riot policemen through clouds of tear gas in central Seoul today in disturbances prompted by the police killing of a student.

title: Data Bank/May 5, 1991
Corrections
description: An article on page 38 of the Arts and Leisure section today about designer furniture misidentifies the woman who hand-tooled the leather for two armchairs. She is Wendy Wahl, not Jennifer Wahl.

title: Teachers Can Help Rescue St. Paul's School
description: The death of St. Paul's, Garden City's renowned private school, appears imminent [ "Cathedral Plan Shakes Up Schools," April 14 ] . Besides being a travesty in itself, its death will help further the deterioration of public schools, because there will be one less standard to gauge its worth, one less model to emulate, one less competitor to compete with.

title: Sunday Outing; 19th Century Lives On In a 'Museum Village'
description: Drive 50 miles northwest of New York City and step back in history to a village that shows how many Americans lived and worked about 150 years ago.

title: Topics of The Times; Pro Bono
description: Several Japanese executives spent their free time last week sprucing up a tenement on Manhattan's Lower East Side. They were picking up trash and painting cracked walls voluntarily, and talking about giving something back to the community. Their friends back in Japan, as reporter Kathleen Teltsch noted in The Times, will never believe it.

title: The Executive Computer; Intel's Latest Microprocessor Addresses a Niche
description: The Intel Corporation, which makes the microprocessors that are the heart of most I.B.M. PC-compatible computers, recently introduced a chip called the i486SX, a scaled-down version of its i486 chip. To create the i486SX, Intel engineers disabled the powerful, built-in math processing component of the i486, which is used for intensive computational chores like extremely complex financial analysis and three-dimensional graphics. They also made the i486SX operate more slowly than its i486 sibling. In return, computer makers can buy the i486SX chip for half the cost of the i486.

title: Why Not Child-Care Loans on Same Terms as Student Loans?; Stereotypes and Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy Poretzky Wed to David Zweig in New Jersey
description: Joy Poretzky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Poretzky of West Long Branch, N.J., was married in West Deal, N.J., last night to Dr. David Zweig, the son of Belma Zweig of Toronto and the late Robert I. Zweig. Rabbi Jacob Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Festive Setting for Mexican Dishes
description: A MARIACHI band and special dishes are on tap at El Bandito this week to celebrate Cinco de Mayo, the anniversary of the day the Mexicans defeated French troops in 1862.

title: Hers; Count Your Losses
description: SEVERAL WEEKS AGO I briefly considered risking my life -- or, at least, a limb or two -- in order to retrieve a scarf I had left in the taxi that was just pulling away. I was with a friend, and the two of us had become engaged in a conversation about the gulf war with our opinionated and well-informed driver. The scarf in question was newish, one of those vast challis paisleys that are meant to be draped, shawl-like, over (rather than under) a coat. I might add that it was the first such scarf I owned; prior to it, I had a drawer full of haphazardly gathered, skimpy silk squares, most of which I never wore.

title:
THEATER;
A Day in Hollywood, A Night in Waterbury
description: SEMINA DE LAURENTIS was working as an actress in Los Angeles in 1988, when a writers' strike halted production there, prompting her to come home to Waterbury for the summer. She found people there eager for someone to bring professional theater back to their community.

title: In New Hampshire, a Move to Test Abortion Pill
description: The Legislature in New Hampshire, a state widely known for conservatism as well as a fierce belief in individual freedom, is moving toward approval of a resolution offering the state as a test site for the French abortion pill RU-486.

title: Daphne Gardiner, Student, to Wed
description: Daniel W. Gardiner of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Eleanor C. Dwight of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Daphne Willard Gardiner to Andrew Frank Trotter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin I. Trotter of Midlothian, Va. An August wedding is planned.

title: Ideas & Trends; Sunset At Southfork
description: WHEN Joel Grey, playing a helpful angel, took J. R. Ewing through his wicked, wicked ways in the "It's a Wonderful Life" knockoff on the 356th and final episode of "Dallas" on Friday night, he probably should have included some reference to what television would have been like without J. R. and friends.

title: A Humane Move to Stop Fight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bush Selects Texas A&M for Site of Library
description: President Bush has chosen Texas A&M University in College Station as the site of his Presidential library.

title: Noel M. P. Reilly, 88, British Economic Aide
description: Noel M. P. Reilly, an economic official for the British Government who retired in 1965 and then became active in politics in New Hampshire, died April 22 at the Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia, N.H. He was 88 years old and lived in North Sandwich, N.H.

title: Bush Suffers Shortness of Breath During a Jog and Is Hospitalized
description: President Bush was taken to a hospital in a helicopter this afternoon after suffering shortness of breath and an irregular heartbeat while jogging at Camp David, Md.

title: Penny Warter to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. J. Pennington Warter of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Gail Pennington Warter, and Matthew William Longo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Longo of Clarendon Hills, Ill. Miss Warter, who is 33 years old and is known as Penny, is an advisory systems engineer in Chicago with the International Business Machines Corporation. She graduated from Vassar College and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. Mr. Longo, 34, is a senior chemist with the Daubert Chemical Company in Chicago. He graduated from Northern Illinois University.

title: This Is L.A.
description: BIODEGRADABLE SOAP

title: The Million-Dollar Tattoo
description: LAURA'S SKIN

title: Amid Layoffs, the Froth Is Gaining
description: FIGHTING recessions used to be a two-front war. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, and the politicians raised spending and cut taxes.

title: Mutual Funds; Stretching Maturities as Rates Fall
description: As interest rates fall, money-market fund managers tend to lengthen the maturities of their portfolios so as to lock in higher yields for a longer time.

title: Chernobyl Makes Ukraine Want Independence; In U.S., No Stockpiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Menu; A Little Lamb Filling for Pita
description: This menu should be subtitled "Making a little lamb go a long way and enjoying it."

title: Review/Dance; Going Solo But Never Truly Alone
description: Phoebe Neville offered an eloquent solo program on Thursday night at the Warren Street Performance Loft. Although she called it "Phoebe Neville Dances Alone," she was not really by herself, for she conjured up hosts of invisible presences.

title: Classroom Visitors: Schools Seek New Friends
description: SCHOOL systems, facing diminishing state aid and stiff resistance to local tax increases, are having to work harder to get their annual budgets approved. Growing numbers of taxpayers who no longer have school-age children are forcing educators to look for new ways to bolster community support. Besides pledging to keep budget increases low, school officials are intensifying their community-relations efforts, often by inviting elderly residents back to school as students and volunteers.

title: Costly Incident
description: To the Editor: While visiting Tulum on Feb. 28, we entered a shop selling inexpensive souvenirs. My husband picked up a small statue, and while he was examining it, the statue fell to the floor and broke. The storekeeper demanded $500 or my husband would "go to jail." He yelled for the police, who appeared immediately. My husband said he was willing to pay but questioned the $500 price.

title: Nicole M. Russell To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Russell of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nicole Marie Russell to Peter Raymond Reilly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reilly of La Jolla, Calif. An August wedding is planned.

title: Headliners; Two for the Records
description: One takes bases, the other denies them, and both do what they do more than anyone has done it before. On the same day last week, Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers pitched his seventh no-hitter, breaking his own record, and Rickey Henderson of the Oakland Athletics stole his 939th base, edging past Lou Brock as baseball's career stolen base leader. Ryan's game was all the more thrilling for the fact that at 44 years old -- he is also the oldest pitcher to throw a no-hitter -- he gave one of his strongest performances ever. Summing up a game in which two-thirds of his 122 pitches were strikes, Ryan said, "This is my most overpowering night." Henderson, too, had something more than just another record. At 32, he had stolen more bases in 12 years than Brock did in 19, and did it in 1,000 or so fewer games. Brock, who was on hand to help celebrate, said the new record holder was "the greatest competitor that ever ran the bases." Henderson, never one to let praise go unimproved-upon, said, "Brock is the symbol of great base stealing, but I'm the greatest of all time."

title: After 15 Long Games, Meulens Ends Drought
description: The first home run must have felt like a relief.

title: Chez Vous in French Farm Country
description: WE were only two miles from the highway, less than 15 from the city of Limoges, but we sensed that we had entered "La France profonde," deepest France. From the roadside, brown cattle of the ancient Limousin breed looked up, then returned to their grazing. Across a stone bridge, we spotted a yellow and green sign that said "Chambres d'Hotes."

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Nashua. N.H.;
An Old Factory Now Rentals
description: CONSTRUCTION was completed last month on the second and final phase of Clocktower Place, a 19th-century factory complex that has been turned into rental apartments.

title: Remembering a Classicist
description: To the Editor:

title: Eight Years of Living Languorously
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN The Role of a Lifetime. By Lou Cannon. Illustrated. 948 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Only the Wind Should Sigh in This 'Garden'
description: All during "The Secret Garden," the new musical at the St. James Theater, I kept trying to account for my mounting sense of claustrophobia. But it wasn't until midway through the second act that an explanation occurred to me. No one was paying the slightest attention to the weather.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Is it possible that in Paris the shellfish are too fresh? Patricia Wells's article "In Paris, Shellfish Platters" (Travel, March 31), brought back wonderful memories but failed to mention a culinary phenomenon we have encountered nowhere else.

title: Elizabeth Gilman, Banker, Marries
description: Elizabeth Barnard Gilman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Vincent Gilman Jr. of Rumson, N.J., was married there last night to William Thomas Hobbs Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Branson Hobbs of Rocky Mount, N.C. Jay Cleveland Harbeck, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Church.

title: Headliners; Chinas Syndrome
description: Though President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan didn't go so far as to end his country's 42-year state of war with China, he all but admitted last week that his side lost. In a step that opened the way toward greater democracy in Taiwan and closer ties with China, Mr. Lee declared an end to the "Period of Communist Revolution," a decree under which hundreds of parliamentary deputies who were elected in China in 1947 remained in office supposedly representing constituencies that were in fact governed by Beijing. When a new National Assembly is elected later this year it the first to have as a majority members who represent districts on Taiwan. Though the assembly will continue to have a few "mainland" seats to back Taiwan's claim to sovereignty there, Mr. Lee made it clear that Taiwan would not regard leaders of the Beijing Government as "authorities" instead of rebels. "From now on," he said, "we must accept the reality that the Communists control the mainland."

title: Beauty; Body Language: Brow
description: The brow is seriously underestimated as an erogenous zone. Of all the parts of the body that can be caressed or kissed, the brow is the most accessible and the most mysterious, just as sensual as more celebrated body parts but less frightening. It hides only the mind.

title: In Stamford, Whitney Offers Diversity of Faces and Figures
description: THE show at the Whitney Museum's Fairfield County branch in Stamford comes from the museum's gallery at Federal Reserve Plaza in lower Manhattan, where it was organized by Kathleen Monaghan, director of the Whitney at the Equitable Center, in midtown. Its title is "Image and Likeness," and its contents are 22 figural paintings and sculptures drawn from the permanent collection at the Whitney's home in uptown Manhattan.

title: He Led Eight Wives
description: LIFE IS TOO SHORT By Mickey Rooney. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Villard Books. $22.50.

title: The Executive Life; Grit Those Teeth, It's Annual Meeting Time
description: In spring, as flowers bloom and days lengthen, many a chief executive's thoughts turn to annual meetings.

title: Style Makers; Gloria Prival, Metal Necktie Designer
description: Gloria Prival does not use silk or a sewing machine to make her neckties. She hammers them out of silver, bronze, copper and other metals.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Connecticut Revaluations Raise Hackles
description: FALLOUT from the excesses of the 80's continues drifting into some unexpected places. One example is the revaluation of real estate in Connecticut, which takes place at staggered 10-year intervals in each of the state's 169 communities.

title: James Scher Wed To Ann Sullivan
description: Ann Elizabeth Sullivan and James Douglas Scher were married yesterday at St. Brigid's Church in Peapack, N.J., by Msgr. George M. Brembos. The bride is a daughter of the late Shirley M. Littell of Point Pleasant, N.J., and the late William R. Sullivan of Florham Park, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Scher of Bedminster, N.J.

title: Making a Difference; Getting The Job, but Not the Shoes
description: When Warren Littlefield was named president of NBC Entertainment last July he said he had been given complete authority over the network's programming decisions.

title: Sounds of Suburbia: Whir! Vrrroooom!!
description: NOW that spring is turning the bend and heading toward summer, it occurs to me that I didn't hear much of last summer, and I probably won't hear much of the coming summer.

title: Michael Haskins, 44, Interior Designer, Dies
description: Michael A. Haskins, an interior and product designer, died April 19 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Iraq Says Priceless Art Was Looted by Rebels
description: Priceless artworks and artifacts, some of them Islamic but many dating back thousands of years to the ancient civilizations of Babylon, Nineveh and Ur, have been looted from Iraqi museums by rebels and may soon appear on the international art market, Iraq's Director General of Antiquities said in an interview today.

title: Sunday Menu; Oriental Shrimp With Pasta
description: Although this is probably not a recipe anyone from China ever saw, it has a Chinese sensibility and flavor.

title: Madonna's Love Affair With the Lens
description: Of all the descriptions of "Madonna Truth or Dare" offered in advance of the film's opening, none has caught the flavor more pungently than the star's own capsule summary.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Norwalk, Conn. 131,000 22 Todd Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; new roof, gutters and siding, needs work, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,607. Ridgefield, Conn. 290,000 120 Mimosa Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; new kitchen, enclosed porch w/woodstove, oversized deck, 1.2 acres; taxes $3,378. Westport, Conn. 200,000 6 Lakeview Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; h/w floors, on cul-de-sac, 0.50 acre; taxes $3,021. New Rochelle, N.Y. 263,000 1 Glenfruin Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 53-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,799. Rye, N.Y. 325,000 49 Meadow Place 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 74-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, computer room, playroom; taxes $4,981. Waccabuc, N.Y. 371,500 Chapel Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, den, sunroom, patios, stream, stone walls, 3.9 acres; taxes $4,487. OTHER AREAS Montclair, N.J. 168,000 97 Haddon Place 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; eat-in-kitchen, close to transportation; taxes $5,795. Nutley, N.J. 162,500 407 Prospect Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; family room, dinette, cedar closets; taxes $3,952. Levittown, L.I. 105,000 143 North Wantagh Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,000.

title: Postings: Postscript to the Steam-Pipe Blast; The Damages Go for a Better Building
description: The Consolidated Edison steam pipe that exploded on Third Avenue two years ago shattered windows, ripped awnings, sprayed asbestos insulation and damaged building facades in the Gramercy Park area. Now that the utility has performed its clean-up and repairs, the condominium owners in 151 East 20th Street, at Third Avenue, have decided to use a $125,000 settlement for damages to give themselves a better building.

title: Nancy Judson Weds
description: Nancy Laura Judson, the daughter of Mrs. Morris Judson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Judson, was married last evening to Steven David Tanzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Tanzer of Scarsdale. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky officiated at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. The bride, 29 years old, founded and heads Tripbuilder Inc., which publishes travel guidebooks in New York. She graduated cum laude from Union College and received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Tanzer, 30, is an associate in the New York office of the Los Angeles law firm of O'Melveny & Meyers. He graduated cum laude from the University of Michigan and magna cum laude from the National Law Center of George Washington University.

title: James M. McDonough, Surgeon, 57
description: Dr. James M. McDonough, an orthopedic surgeon in Morris Plains, N.J., for 25 years, died on Thursday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Morris Plains.

title: Beauty; BODY LANGUAGE
description: Bit by tidy bit, cosmetics companies are deregulating the human body. It's a grand scheme, this, one that jettisons the catchall phrase "body lotion" in favor of more anatomically precise titles. Here's just a tiny sampling of their efforts: Progres Throat Creme (Lancome), Neck Firming Cream (Jeanne Gatineau), Firming Gelee for Neck and Decollete (Orlane), Firming Concentrate for Bust (Gatineau again), Bio-Buste (Biotherm), Bust Firming Gel (Clarins, the grande dame of subspecies, has no less than seven different "buste beauty boosters"), Stomach Firming Treatment (Biotherm), Energizing Emulsion for Tired Legs (Clarins). . . . Stop me before I need a good dose of Princess Marcella Borghese Terme di Montecatini Splendide Mani (a.k.a. hand cream) to revive my digits.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BRITISH FAIR

title: Strawberry Takes Returns in Stride
description: When Reggie Jackson returned to the city that made him king of the hill and top of the heap, Rod Carew laid a white carpet made of towels from clubhouse door to dugout in honor of the occasion.

title: James E. Lawler to Marry Jessica Phillips in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael E. Phillips of Greenwich, Conn., have made known October wedding plans for their daughter, Jessica L. Phillips, and James Edmonds Lawler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Lawler of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Tiny Victory for Figure in $10 Million Theft
description: It was hardly a victory for Albert M. Ranieri, but after having his house searched twice by the police, and his car hit from behind by the F.B.I., the dismissal this week of reckless driving charges was welcome news.

title: Artist Frosts, Etches and Sandblasts
description: THOMAS EMERSON'S commissions in etched glass have taken him from the kitchen to the altar. He has even decorated the facade of a Manhattan skyscraper. The versatile artist, who calls himself the Sandman, lives and works in Durham. He prefers his technique to that of stained glass, he said, adding, "My designs can flow freely, because they don't have to be leaded together."

title: Campus Life: North Carolina; Disco Mania: Bee Gees And Leisure Suits Live
description: When Dayna Baird, a senior English major at the University of North Carolina, packed her polyester bell-bottoms and sent them home, she had not yet received her invitation to the 1970's disco night at the local dance club here. But when the invitation arrived, she immediately called her parents in Dublin, Ohio, to send back the pants.

title: Postings: Renovation; A Rededication For L.I. Church
description: A member of the congregation, Wendy Daigneault, wrote and directed a musical play that packed the house and raised more than $3,500. Another member, Donald Pollitt, took charge of the landscaping. Sunday school children tucked some of their own savings into little church-shaped boxes and donated them. And members of Alcoholics Anonymous who meet in the church helped with pruning and planting.

title: Abortion Rights Backer Barred as Speaker
description: An invitation to the Lieutenant Governor of Massachsetts to speak at his old high school here has been rescinded because he differs with his Roman Catholic Church on the right to abortion.

title: Justice Dept. Reviewing Gifts to Oregon Senator
description: The Justice Department is reviewing Senator Mark O. Hatfield's acceptance of $9,265 worth of gifts that he received over a four-year period but that he failed to list on annual Senate financial disclosure forms as required by law.

title: EVERY DAY A TEST
description: Mayor David Dinkins is going to need more than sartorial splendor, a junket to Israel and a walk with the gay community to solve the problems of New York City ("Mayor Dinkins: Every Day a Test" by Sam Roberts, April 7).

title: Video Store Stakeout Leads to Arrests of 5 In 23 Armed Thefts
description: A stakeout of a Queens video store by plainclothes police officers has led to the arrest of five men on charges of robbing 23 stores and restaurants at gunpoint recently in Nassau County and Queens, the police said.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'WOMEN AT RISK'

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review last Sunday about Sawadee, in Port Jefferson, misstated its hours. It is open Sunday through Thursday from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. and Friday and Saturday from 11 A.M. to midnight.

title: Sports Briefings; Bo Jackson Cards Tossed in Furnace
description: The Kansas City Royals started the season by unloading Bo Jackson, so sponsors of a Royals baseball card series decided to unload their Bo cards as well. About 350,000 of the cards were destroyed Friday in an Armco Steel plant furnace.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GENTLEMEN, I ADDRESS YOU PRIVATELY By Kay Boyle.Capra Press, $18.95.

title: It's Not Just a Man's World for Blake Edwards
description: Blake Edwards has once again answered Henry Higgins's question -- "Why can't a woman be more like a man?" -- in ways that make the head spin. In Mr. Edwards's "Victor/Victoria" in 1982, a female singer posed as a female impersonator and thus had the effect of throwing his/her admirers into utter confusion. Now, in "Switch," Mr. Edwards presents a ladies' man whose death becomes the occasion for a celestial prank. As punishment for his transgressions, Steve (Perry King) is sent back to earth in the form of Amanda (Ellen Barkin), a long-haired, leggy blonde.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ARE WE WINNING YET? How Women Are Changing Sports and Sports Are Changing Women.By Mariah Burton Nelson.Random House, $20.

title: Tech Notes; Corning's Slenderized Hard Disk
description: Ceramic engineers are developing new substrate materials for hard disks that they expect to be used in new generations of portable computers. The disks, they say, can be made thinner than the aluminum ones used now because of their greater rigidity. And the smooth surface of the disk helps preserve the life of the heads that read the magnetically encoded information.

title: London
description: To the Editor: Regarding Adam Dadeby's complaints about the London Underground (Letters on Travel, March 24), I can only wonder what his standard for quality underground transportation is. I have just returned from London where I used the Underground several times each day for a week and found the trains fast, efficient, reliable, clean and full only during rush hours. Further, employees were always helpful and courteous. L. PATTON DAVIS Cincinnati

title: Nicole Blom Wed To Thomas Pura
description: Nicole Jan Blom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Charles Blom of Seattle, was married there yesterday to Thomas Ray Pura, a son of Nancy Pura of Salinas, Calif. Leslie I. Larsen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the Unitarian ceremony at the University Unitarian Church.

title: G. T. Delacorte, Philanthropist, 97, Dies
description: George T. Delacorte, the founder of Dell Publishing and a philanthropist who gave millions to embellish New York City with fountains, statues, theaters and schools that bear his name, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97 years old and also lived in North Palm Beach, Fla., and Sharon, Conn.

title: Boats Shiny and New With Fragile Warnings
description: SAN DIEGO, May 4 --

title: 'Battery,' Tale Of an Outcast Reborn
description: LEAVE it to the Renegade Theater Company to unearth an unacknowledged, offbeat play. Never settling for the safe or familiar, the plucky group usually spawns new works, and "Battery" could as well be just that, unless one remembers its two-week Off Off Broadway run almost 10 years ago, or a Los Angeles production five years later.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: For several years I have had a Christmas week timeshare in Cancun, and every year, no matter when I try to reserve seats on whatever airline, I am too late. I used to be able to reserve seats in October, then it was necessary to call by July, and last year April was too late. This year I started calling in January, and Mexicana, which has the best schedule and fare for my needs, told me in several phone calls that I was too early, and each Mexicana reservations taker I spoke to gave me a different start date. When I called back on the earliest start date that I was given, I was told I was too late and could only be wait listed.

title: CELEBRATING PAINT
description: When Murray says "abstract art left out too much," she's making an outrageous statement. For the great revolutionary painters -- Turner, Cezanne and Mondrian -- the longer they painted, the more they liberated space, color and line. They weren't leaving anything out, but creating a majestic simplicity out of their visual experiences.

title: Talks in Manila on U.S. Bases Stall Over Length of New Lease
description: Negotiations on the future of the American military bases in the Philippines are stalled because of disagreement over the expiration date of a new treaty governing the lease, Foreign Affairs Secretary Raul Manglapus said today.

title: Mountain Man in the Death House
description: THE CHOIRING OF THE TREES By Donald Harington. 388 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Hotel Packages In Europe
description: Inter-Continental Hotels has announced "European Spectacular" packages, with rates guaranteed in dollars, at 30 Inter-Continental and Forum hotels in 24 cities. Available from June 14 to Sept. 2, the package includes a double room, American breakfast for two, tax, service charges and a number of extras. Sample prices, per room, are $114 at the Europa in Brussels and the Penta in Munich; $139 at the Inter-Continental in Cologne and the Forum in London; $189 at the Inter-Continental in Vienna, and $249 at the Inter-Continental in Paris. Reservations are required; a spokesman for the hotel company said "at least half" the rooms at participating hotels would be made available at the package rate. More information: (800) 327-0200.

title: The Fuhrer's Disciple
description: THE ARCHITECT OF GENOCIDE Himmler and the Final Solution. By Richard Breitman. 335 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23. HIMMLER Reichsfuhrer-SS. By Peter Padfield. Illustrated. 656 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $29.95.

title: Making a Difference; Making Money by Printing It
description: Perhaps it was an odd move for Martin Ferenczi to leave the button-down world of corporate banking to run a rough-and-tumble start-up in a business he barely knew. But as he begins his second year at the Banknote Corporation of America, a printer of currency and other high-security documents, he doesn't seem to be suffering from anything other than creative chaos.

title: Twins End Brewers' Streak at 4 As Starter's Sour Streak Ends, Too
description: Chris James drove in nine runs with two homers and two singles today, breaking Cleveland's club record for runs batted in and leading the Indians to a 20-6 rout of the Oakland Athletics.

title: A Clever Lad From Tikrit
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN

title: Elizabeth Hilles Martin Weds Eric Maxwell Olson
description: Elizabeth Hilles Martin, the daughter of Hilles Elizabeth Martin of Haddonfield, N.J., and the late Terrence Michael Martin, was married in New York yesterday to Eric Maxwell Olson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Olson of New York. The Rev. Christopher Brown performed the ceremony at the Grace Episcopal Church.

title: Rising Foreclosures Portend Wide Problems
description: ON the steps of the old Nassau County Courthouse in Mineola and outside the 10 Town Halls in Suffolk County, court-appointed referees call out the bad economic news with increasing frequency.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'UNCLE TOM'S CABIN'

title: Slowing the Spiral in Company Medical Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Show House Transformed, In and Out
description: AS plants have begun to bloom this spring, so have the neglected rooms and gardens of Marywood in Greenwich, the Georgian Revival house on an estate that was later used as a convent and school. The town's Junior League has invited 32 interior-design companies and 14 landscapers to transform the house and grounds for its Designer Show House, with public tours of the building and gardens through May 19. Funds raised from the tours, which began on April 28, will go to the league's community projects.

title: Abolish the White House Lawn
description: Three years after candidate George Bush told us he wanted to be remembered as the "environmental President," he has done little to earn that distinction -- unless one regards his catch-and-release policy on bonefishing as a major environmental initiative.

title: A Sayville Writer Finds Reality in Fantasy
description: WHEN John Lee wrote his first novel in three months, he said, he thought that his new career as an author would be an easy one.

title: 'The Truth About Chernobyl'
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Second-quarter productivity figures * Federal Reserve reports on selected interest rates. TUESDAY: March wholesale trade figures * First-quarter home sales released by the National Association of Realtors * Federal Reserve reports on consumer installment credit.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: We have recently re-evaluated our institutional fund-raising program, based on Anne Matthews's observations in her article "Alma Maters Court Their Daughters" (April 7). As director of development at the Cambridge School of Weston, Mass., and as an alumnae class president of a former all-women's college, I offer these thoughts on how development officers and volunteers might increase effectiveness in fund raising.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Doylestown, Pa.;
At the Woods, Close to Stores
description: IN a departure from typical new housing developments in Bucks County, a project called Doylestown Hunt Estates is being built within walking distance of the historic downtown district of Doylestown Borough, the county seat.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: I AM THE BLUES The Willie Dixon Story. By Willie Dixon with Don Snowden. Da Capo, Paper, $12.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Purchase
description: "PURCHASE does not exist," said Vincent Pasquale, a Westchester County Planning Department associate planner. "It is a neighborhood term for a section of Harrison."

title: Easier Money; Who Benefits As the U.S. Cuts Interest Rates to Fight Recession
description: THE American recession, now nine months old, reached a turning point of sorts last week. Weeks of optimism that it will end soon gave way to doubts, not only among the naturally melancholy but even at the Federal Reserve, which is often the last to admit that a recession might be more severe than was initially predicted.

title: Q and A
description: Selling Garage Spaces Question: For the last 15 years, garage spaces in our condominium, which is completely owner-occupied, have been a common element under the control of the board of directors. Spaces have been assigned without any rental charge or cost to the owners. We are considering the sale of the spaces to the owners who occupy them as a way to increase our reserve fund. The prospectus's only reference to parking says "the board will assign spaces" and the by-laws merely outline the method of doing so. Can the board sell the spaces without the agreement of a majority of the owners? . . . Bernard Durham, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Fax and the Quality of Legal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Stahl to Wed Charles K. Bacon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Stahl of Huntington Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Beatrice Stahl, to Dr. Charles Kingsley Bacon, a son of Francis Lyman Bacon of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Mrs. R. Bruce McGill of Westwood, Mass. A September wedding is planned.
