title: Postings: Phoenix House; New Center On West 80th
description: Since 1983, when the Community Child Day Care Center sold its red, blue and yellow building at 223 West 80th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, the structure has stood empty, its stucco facade collecting dirt and its metal doors serving as a canvas for graffiti artists.

title: Visitors to North Korea Denounce Rights Abuses
description: Delegates to an international conference here have accused North Korea of human rights abuses, almost certainly the first public attack over human rights made against the Communist Government of North Korea on its own soil.

title: Laura Green to Marry Bradford Singer in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. David V. Green of Madison, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Laura Anne Green and Bradford Schenk Singer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis P. Singer of Edison, N.J.

title: Elisabeth Fox to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Fox of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Rose Fox, to Matthew David Hickey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Hickey of Scarsdale, N.Y. A June 1992 wedding is planned. Miss Fox, 25 years old, is an elementary-grade teacher at the H. C. Crittenden Middle School in Armonk, N.Y. She and her fiance graduated from Vassar College in 1988. She received a master's degree in education from Fordham University. The prospective bridegroom, 24, is an editorial assistant in the children's book department of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group in New York.

title: Rochester in Bloom
description: WHEN Rochester was all the world I knew, it was rich and strange, in a reassuring way. The magisterial sweep of East Avenue, lined with mansions in all styles, punctuated with curbside granite blocks so that ladies and gentlemen could step into carriages, was made to order for a child's fantasies. So was much in the city's three main cultural storehouses. In the Memorial Art Gallery, the worryingly small Roman sarcophagus and the nervous-looking dogs that stared down from the medieval tapestry were pleasurably unsettling. (On the other hand, Matisse's "Girl With a Tricorne" and Degas' bronze "Dancer Holding Her Right Foot in Her Right Hand" were purely pleasurable.)

title: Sunday Dining; To Treat Mother Elegantly On Her Day, Three Choices
description: Mother's Day, next Sunday, is among the busiest days of the year in restaurants, and this year more places than ever are vying for the daylong dining bonanza. It is always advisable to reserve early and reconfirm to assure there are no snags. Here are three elegant restaurants that are likely to please the most discriminating of mothers. The Hudson River Club

title: Acclaim Inspires Young Independent Film Makers
description: A LOW-BUDGET film that started as a senior-year thesis at Harvard University, has firmed the resolve of Gordon Eriksen, formerly of Uniondale, and his wife, Heather Johnston, to pursue careers as independent film makers.

title: Beth Raskin Is Married
description: Beth Amy Raskin and Steven Keith Robinson were married last evening at Congregation Beth Shalom in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Gilbert Klapperman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Raskin of Dix Hills, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Sandra Friedman of East Brunswick, N.J., and a stepson of Dr. Marvin Friedman. Mrs. Robinson and her husband are 25 years old and graduates of Rider College. She is the office manager for Mariaschin & Company, an executive search company in New York. He is a certified public accountant with Curchin & Company, accountants in Red Bank, N.J.

title: 100 Years of Small-Town Banking
description: EVEN as a wave of failures sweeps through the savings and loan industry, the Sound Federal Savings and Loan Association in Mamaroneck is celebrating its 100th year of small-town banking.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Madison Avenue from 37th to 56th Streets will be closed from noon to 4 P.M. today for the Cuban Independence Day Parade.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: HANAN MATARI;
A Health Educator for Passaic's Arabs
description: OF the 80,000 Arabs living in the metropolitan area, said Hanan Matari, an Arab community educator at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center, 29,000 reside in Passaic County, where the hospital is situated. Hospital officials say Mrs. Matari is the state's first educator to concentrate on the Arab community.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. SUSAN M. BAUM;
Keeping the Gifted Student in Mind, Too
description: BECAUSE of drastic reductions in state aid, many Westchester school districts are trying to cut their budgets. Often the first programs to go are those not mandated by the state.

title: League of Laughs Says It's No Joke
description: Just when bans on the Icky Shuffle and fraternization among players has led some to call the National Football League the "No Fun League," along comes its springtime offspring: the World League of American Football, which has become known as the "Laugh League.

title: Astronaut-Electricians Fix Faulty Data Recorders
description: Astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery succeeded in getting data from three scientific instruments to Earth today after splicing wires and rearranging cables in a 97-step salvage operation.

title: Travel Advisory; Mohawk Flies To the Hamptons
description: Mohawk Airlines introduced daily service between La Guardia Airport in New York and East Hampton, L.I., last Thursday. One round-trip flight each weekday is scheduled, with additional flights on weekends. The round-trip fare for the 23-minute flight is $196, tax included.

title: K Mart and Gauguin
description: THE EDGE OF PARADISE America in Micronesia. By P. F. Kluge. 244 pp. New York: Random House.

title:
Beauty;
Body Language: Knee
description: If God indeed made the world in six days and rested on the seventh, I'd lay odds the knee was crafted late Saturday night, say around 11:59 and 59 seconds, when the Deity, no doubt, was looking forward more to future relaxation than to the work at hand. For of all body parts, the knee is the most ill-conceived and badly made: subject to all the indignities of age, its task an unending succession of demands encompassing the banal (kneeling to pick up Kitty Litter) to the demented (super-marathons) to the sublime (squatting to deliver babies in the bush).

title: For Gypsies, Free Market Can Be Bad News
description: For the two dozen gypsy families living here in the ruined shell of an old army barracks, the dawning of a market economy has brought nothing but bad news -- layoffs, high prices and still no relief from the discrimination that has always kept Hungary's half million gypsies at society's edge.

title: The Nation; For Civil Rights Bill, the Name's the Game
description: LIKE it or not, the 1992 Presidential campaign is beginning. And not just with last week's first declaration of candidacy by a Democrat, former Senator Paul Tsongas, but even more significantly with the overtures to the Congressional debate on this year's civil rights bill.

title: BUSH SEES THREAT TO FLOW OF IDEAS ON U.S. CAMPUSES
description: In a commencement address at the University of Michigan today, President Bush attacked what he called the "notion of 'political correctness,' " saying it had led to "inquisition," "censorship" and "bullying" on some college campuses.

title: More Riders Heading South
description: The number of Metro-North passengers heading south during morning rush hour from Putnam County nearly doubled in the last eight years, said Daniel Brucker, a spokesman for the railroad.

title: Graduates Urged by Sununu to Become Public Servants
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, encouraged graduates of Miami-Dade Community College today to make an impact on their world by choosing public service.

title: War and Memory
description: WARTIME LIES

title: Bangor Journal; Maine Refines the Welcome Home
description: Since long before dawn, about 50 men, women and children had waited in the Bangor International Airport terminal for the next plane load of troops to arrive from the Persian Gulf.

title: Making a Difference; Sumitomo Does the Unusual: It Brings In an American
description: When Sumitomo Bank Ltd. decided to get into equipment leasing in the United States -- a business that has thrived here, but not in Japan -- it took a practical, but for the company novel, approach: It hired an American.

title: Campus Life: Trinity U.; Program Pushes Inner-City Pupils To Stay in School
description: "When I say beer, what do you say?" shouted a pair of Trinity University education students.

title: Kathryn Lewallen to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Emory Lewallen of Wilmington, N.C., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Kathryn Louise Lewallen and Jeffrey Brett Aibel, the son of Benjamin G. Aibel of New York and Ellen A. Bierman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Lewallen, 24 years old, graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. She is a pharmacist-manager at Kerr Drugs in Charlotte, N.C. Mr. Aibel, 31, graduated from Lehigh University and received an M.B.A. from U.N.C. at Chapel Hill. He is a management consultant in the Atlanta office of Ernst & Young.

title: DR. ANDERSON'S GENE MACHINE
description: I learned the following things from Robin Marantz Henig's article "Dr. Anderson's Gene Machine" (March 31): that two cancer patients and two young girls (4 and 9 years old), who suffer from an enzyme deficiency that leaves them vulnerable to infection, have been given gene therapy. The 4-year-old has been receiving the therapy for six months; she was the first in her family to recover from the flu; she smiles more and Dr. Anderson believes it is because of the therapy. I learned also that Anderson is as successful a politician and businessman as he is a scientist.

title: Campus Life: Brown; White House Sees Smuggled Tape Of Vilnius Strife
description: Brown University students who made a documentary with scenes of the Soviet Union's crackdown on the Lithuanian sovereignty movement were given a chance to talk about it at the White House on Friday.

title: The World; By Default, Iraq's Kurds Are Wards Of Military
description: WHEN President Bush announced a plan to save the Kurds of Iraq, he made it sound rather straightforward: American and allied troops would urgently build camps that would serve as huge protected bubbles where the refugees would be given food, shelter, medical care and protection from the wrath of their bully-President, Saddam Hussein. The troops would not stay very long, Mr. Bush stressed, because the allies would quickly hand over the camps to the United Nations. The plan assumed that the Kurds would soon feel secure enough to return home, and that the camps, only temporary resting places, would then be dissolved.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: Unlike many of the colleges Matthews describes in her article, Hunter College of the City University of New York has enjoyed the "fiscal allegiance" of its daughters for 121 years. Generations of graduates, primarily children of the working class, remember their alma mater for giving them the chance to realize their potential.

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: Katha Pollitt has pointed out very effectively what should be obvious to any parent raising daughters -- there just aren't enough female characters in children's stories, cartoons and movies (Hers: "The Smurfette Principle," April 7).

title: MacLeod In Control at Notre Dame
description: With a five-year contract in the offing, JOHN MacLEOD has little reason to be in a hurry, but the new Notre Dame basketball coach said yesterday that speed would be his primary objective. "I will recruit players who can play a faster, up-tempo style of basketball," he said in South Bend, Ind., after holding his first team meeting.

title: Sports Briefings; College Series to Cover Signs
description: The billboards at Rosenblatt Stadium will be covered at this year's College World Series to prevent the kind of mistake that happened last year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WAR IN 2020 By Ralph Peters.Pocket Books, $19.95.

title: Reagan Campaign Couldn't Outfox Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Kermit K. Schooler, 67, Psychologist and Dean
description: Kermit K. Schooler, a psychologist and former dean of the school of social work at Syracuse University, died on Tuesday at his home in Manlius, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: Widening Gulf in School Spending Seen
description: LAST June, when the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the state to devise a new school financing formula to create statewide parity in per-pupil spending by 1995, the court cited a gulf between wealthy and poor school districts.

title: Ship Travel
description: To the Editor: "Getting there" has become increasingly unbearable and it's almost not worth going, what with long tedious waits at airports and subsequently being herded onto cramped space in jumbos. Trains in the United States go nowhere one wants to go unless it's between Washington and Boston. And bus travel is anything but last-resort transportation.

title: Viral Apocalypse
description: BEYOND LOVE By Dominique Lapierre. Translated by Kathryn Spink. 400 pp. New York: Warner Books. $22.95.

title: Buyers Hunt Bargains On Banks' Real Estate
description: COUPLES pushing babies in strollers mingled last weekend with suit-and-tie clad investors carrying leather briefcases in the ballroom of the Park Plaza Hotel in New Haven. They ambledfrom booth to booth, looking for bargains at the Connecticut Foreclosed Real Estate Sell-Off. But those who attended said the bargains were hard to come by.

title: U.S. Helps Black South Africans Get M.D.'s
description: Vanessa Pakkiri's mother died when she was little more than three years old, and ever since, Miss Pakkiri recalled, she wanted to become a doctor.

title: A Chef's Ideas for Accenting Spring Ingredients
description: SPRING represents a beginning. In cookbooks that are organized by the seasons, the chapter of springtime recipes always comes first.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Sweden Takes the Gold

title: Rethink Railroads Before It's Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Searches for Birth Mother
description: "PHANTASIE," the title of a Sybille Pearson play at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, is a German word for imagination. In the play, the main character, a young woman named D, imagines what her birth mother was like and what the circumstances were that led her give up D for adoption.

title: The Penguins' Flight Out of Mediocrity
description: The transformation of the Pittsburgh Penguins from an average team into one that could reach the semifinals of the National Hockey League playoffs started 17 months ago in a living room in Youngstown, Ohio, and was completed in a lounge at Buffalo Airport last June.

title: Grace Pastiak's 'Web of Inclusion'
description: Last fall, Tellabs Inc., a maker of sophisticated telephone equipment, received an important order that would have to be completed by the end of the year. Instead of simply posting overtime notices, as would happen in many factories, Grace Pastiak called a meeting of the plant's workers.

title: Sherlock Holmes and the Case of the Alpine Publicity Stunt
description: Sherlock Holmes and his arch-foe, Professor Moriarty, fought to the death today above the Reichenbach Falls.

title: Building Self-Esteem For Survival
description: REGINA DYTON'S career has had one underlying force, she said: to start with people where they are and take them someplace better. Still, she was surprised, she said, when she was hired to develop esteem-enhancing programs for youngsters in Hartford, and she learned what the girls at one elementary school wanted most. They did not ask for computer classes or basketball games; they wanted to go to charm school.

title: Struggling in a 40-Year-Old Straightjacket
description: To the Editor:

title: W.L.A.F. Seasoning in the Sun
description: There is plenty to like, said New York/New Jersey Knights receiver Cornell Burbage, about the World League of American Football.

title: N.B.A. Underdogs Turning Vise in First-Round Finals
description: When the National Basketball Association playoffs got under way 10 days ago, the talk centered on the Detroit Pistons' prospects for winning a third consecutive championship, the Portland Trail Blazers' regular-season dominance and Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls.

title: CELEBRATING PAINT
description: Elizabeth Murray, with her rigor and passion for her work, is the consummate artist. She is an artist who believed that she had to choose between art and parenting; she chose both and won. Working parents (and artists) who have arranged their lives for the benefit of their children as well as for their work are the heroes of our time. MC CRADY AXON Madison, Conn.

title: Stamps
description: "The Fundamentals of Philately" is a ponderous title, and indeed it is a very heavy book. But those interested in graphic design and printing will find this an indispensable reference.

title: Pamela Knecht Weds Marc Milkin in California
description: Pamela Knecht, a freelance television producer, and Marc Anthony Milkin, a freelance cameraman and producer, both in New York, were married yesterday in Monarch Beach, Calif. The Rev. Ginny Wheeler, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Monarch Bay Club.

title: Roni Rothenberg Wed in New York
description: Roni Rothenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark D. Rothenberg of New City, N.Y., was married last evening in New York to Kenneth R. Goldberg, a son of Terrie Levy of Closter, N.J., and Ivan Goldberg of Ramsey, N.J. Rabbi Andrew Strauss officiated at the Union League Club.

title: The World; Again, the Sea Betrays Bangladesh
description: IN a season of so many dispossessed, the photographs from Bangladesh in the aftermath of last week's's devastating cyclone convey the particular frights and sorrows of people victimized not by man but by wind and seas. Along with the shock they reveal, their faces often register the resigned fatalism of those whose lives are spent at sea level, lapped by tides that both feed and betray.

title: The Images That Haunt Washington
description: Much has been made in recent weeks of television's success in concentrating the Bush Administration's attention on the Iraqi refugees. Those nightly pictures of so many weary and desperate people, of sick children and dying babies, shook the nation and, commentators agree, compelled the White House to act despite initial reluctance. So much, so good. Yet television's accomplishment also raises the possibility that a policy driven by the hour's emotions might prove ill-advised or dangerous in the long run.

title: Jaguar's XJ-S: Sunshine and Power
description: In 1961, married and with a new baby, I came close to buying a Jaguar roadster.

title: Fresh Air for the Children
description: The more hostile the inner cities become, the more important it becomes for children to escape the city streets in summer. The Fresh Air Fund, which has been in operation for more than a century, has provided more than 1.5 million children with life-affirming trips into nature.

title: White House Memo; Sununu: A Case Study On Flouting the Rules
description: When John H. Sununu arrived in Washington, he announced his credo: "I don't care if people hate me, as long as they hate me for the right reasons." The most polite of Presidents had taken a chief of staff who seemed to enjoy being rude just for the fun of it.

title: Campus Life: Barnard; Different Cultures Unite 8 Students In Shared Housing
description: The special-interest suites at Barnard College's 10 dormitories have typically revolved around common interests. But in the fall semester, eight undergraduates will establish a living arrangement based on their differences.

title: Priscilla Clark Weds
description: Priscilla Mills Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Clark of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday in Melville, L.I., to Ryad Abed Kahale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abed Kahale of Hoffman Estates, Ill. The Rev. John Wallace officiated at the Presbyterian Church of Sweet Hollow. The bride, 33 years old, teaches at the East Memorial Elementary School in Farmingdale, L.I. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Kahale, 29, is the Southeast regional sales manager for the Chyron Corporation, an electronics company in Melville.

title: Karen Miller and Edward M. Philip Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Miller of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lynn Miller, to Edward Michael Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Philip of Miami. An October wedding is planned.

title: Will vs. Williams
description: To the Editor:

title: Jews in Moscow Expect Flow of Emigrants to Israel to Pick Up Again
description: Jews in the Soviet Union say that although many are postponing emigration, most expect that once conditions are more favorable, they will reach Israel.

title: The Succulent Walleye of the Midwest
description: ONLY someone who had once voluntarily moved from Arizona to Nebraska in the middle of winter would get as excited about a trip to Michigan as I did last summer. Not only did the state seem exotically Midwestern, but its food had fascinated me for all the years I had been stuffing files full of stories about the cherries and asparagus, the wild mushrooms and baby vegetables, even the dried beans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 20 about searching out family roots in Scotland misidentified the architect of the New Register House in Edinburgh. In a letter dated March 19, the deputy registrar general has pointed out that the architect was Robert Matheson, not Robert Adam; this correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Cologne
description: Testimonials to Cologne, Germany's fourth largest city after Berlin, Hamburg and Munich, certainly abound. Petrarch, the Italian poet and humanist, who visited in the 14th century, lauded its civilized ways and expressed surprise that "an urban center of such beauty" existed in a land that he otherwise considered barbarian. Half a millenium later Victor Hugo outdid Petrarch by calling himself the barbarian in light of "this admirable city, a city of dreams." And Heinrich Boll, the 1972 Nobel literature laureate, a rather caustic critic of the town of his birth, in which he lived until his death in 1985, once said, "It is the city in which Hitler felt least comfortable and which he visited the most rarely. That speaks a lot for the spirit and people of Cologne."

title: Trying to Murder a Statue
description: MENDELSSOHN IS ON THE ROOF By Jiri Weil. Translated by Marie Winn. 228 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Strike the Gold Hits Pay Dirt and Wins Derby
description: Supposedly suffering from slow workouts, fast competition and even the wrong pedigree, Strike the Gold won the 117th Kentucky Derby today with a rousing end run through the homestretch that defeated Best Pal by nearly two lengths and buried the other favorites by much more.

title: Just One More Kiss Before Dying
description: How does a director make a 90's version of a 50's film? For James Dearden, the challenge of writing and directing a remake of the 1956 movie "A Kiss Before Dying" was to intensify its suspense and update its treatment of greed, obsession and murder. The result is an "entertaining if bent almost-success story," to quote from Vincent Canby's review of the film in The New York Times when it opened last month.

title: Laura Bruggman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Harry Bruggman of Ruxton, Md., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Laura Medill Bruggman and David Alan Wingate, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Wingate Jr. of Baltimore. Ms. Bruggman, 26 years old, is a sales and marketing executive at WMAR-TV in Baltimore. She graduated from the University of Delaware. Mr. Wingate, 30, is the field sales supervisor for the Williams & Wilkens Company, a scientific and medical publisher in Baltimore. He graduated from the University of North Carolina.

title:
Forum;
Is Curbing Crime Worth the Cost?
description: A relatively obscure Federal agency -- the United States Sentencing Commission -- has proposed huge increases in criminal penalties that will affect both innocent and guilty corporations. In effect, these guidelines have already claimed their first victim -- the Exxon Valdez settlement, where the judge determined that Exxon's plea bargain was not tough enough. Unfortunately, these proposals were not the result of a careful study.

title: Clare Cushman, Editor, Marries
description: Clare Hepburn Cushman, the director of publications for the Supreme Court Historical Society in Washington, and Amedee Stephane Prouvost, a senior financial officer at the World Bank in Washington and the bank's financial representative in Europe, were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson officiated.

title: Lucinda Ziesing, an Actress, Weds Desmond FitzGerald, a Fish Farmer
description: Lucinda McLean Ziesing, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hibben Ziesing, was married yesterday to Desmond FitzGerald, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Desmond FitzGerald. The Rev. Carl Reimers, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Ziesing home in Princeton, N.J.

title: Food; Chicken Feed
description: BUFFALO IS A WING TOWN. HOUSTON IS A LEG TOWN. Boston favors breasts. There is an odd congruence between the nature of a given city and its preference in chicken. It comes as no surprise that New York City wants the whole bird.

title: When Michael Met Mickey
description: THE DISNEY TOUCH How a Daring Management Team Revived an Entertainment Empire. By Ron Grover. Illustrated. 315 pp. Homewood, Ill.: Business One Irwin. $22.95.

title: Michelle Giraldi, Executive, Is Wed
description: Michelle Elizabeth Giraldi, an office administrator, and Eli Hassine, a financial-services executive in New York, were married last night at Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Marshall Meyer officiated.

title:
Tavistock Journal;
Census Says 35, Borough Says 13, and Small Dispute Goes On
description: IT was big news: the state's smallest town had experienced the state's highest growth rate during the decade, a population increase of 288 percent. There used to be 9 residents. Now there were 35. Or so the Census Bureau said when it released the 1990 figures.

title: Historic Cape in the Pacific Northwest
description: TUCKED into the southwest corner of Washington State, the Long Beach Peninsula is one of the Northwest's most handsome pieces of coastline. Here, at the end of the Lewis and Clark Trail, the Columbia River reaches out of its jacket of evergreen timber, sunders Washington from Oregon, then empties into the Pacific, spitting up sand and silt that 10,000 years ago created this thin, fertile wand of shore and rock, forest and lake.

title: Making a Difference; Big Computer Discounts, Courtesy of Arnold Cohen
description: ARNOLD COHEN, the Digital Equipment Corporation's sales manager for the Boston area, likes his job. And he's good at it. Although the computer maker as a whole has been posting sluggish results, its sales in Boston are holding up nicely.

title: A Thinking Person's 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: Thanks to Peter Martins's persuasive staging and to Lincoln Kirstein's magnificent obsession with an 1890 Tchaikovsky-Petipa masterpiece, the New York City Ballet finally has its own version of "The Sleeping Beauty."

title: September Wedding For Susan Campbell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Campbell of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Burgess Campbell to Charles Garrison Meyer 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Fern Foliage

title: Rock Star Leads Girls In Softball
description: FOURTEEN high school girls were huddled on a grassy softball field in Redding, trying to understand why sliding into first base looks so much easier than it is.

title: WELCOME TO TWIN PEAKS AND VALLEYS
description: Special Agent Dale Cooper will enjoy his last cup of coffee and a farewell doughnut on June 10, when "Twin Peaks" ends its second and almost certainly final season on ABC. It will be a damn fine cup of Joe, but if the show's recent ratings hold steady, about 95 percent of America won't bother to watch him drink it. And it's a safe bet that many of the viewers who do tune in will be content to see the series call it a day after 30 episodes. The doughnuts turned stale awhile back.

title: Wall Street; A Lawsuit Sears Doesn't Mention
description: For more than two years, the board of directors of Sears, Roebuck & Company has been quietly battling a civil lawsuit that charges that Sears executives and officers hastily initiated a costly restructuring plan in 1988 chiefly to foil any hostile bid for the company and to entrench themselves in office. The case, filed in Chicago, is expected to come to trial in the fall.

title:
DINING OUT;
A View and More in North Tarrytown
description: GOOD news travels fast. Open scarcely two months, Goldie's has not advertised yet on some evenings prospective diners will find every one of this miniature restaurant's 44 seats occupied. It's not the decor that draws the crowd: the interior seems nothing more than an unplanned, homey hodgepodge of several dark woods and a bit of brick and stained glass. But one hardly notices because of the splendid, eye-catching view of the Tappan Zee Bridge beyond the restaurant's picture windows.

title: Women in Business Expand a Network
description: HAVING "a business of one's own" has become a reality for increasing numbers of women, as was clear from the record turnout at this year's Showcasing Expo sponsored by the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners.

title: Ways to Approach Hospital Fund Problem
description: Re: "Hospitals Face Cash Shortfall," March 17:

title: The World; As the Going Gets Tougher, So Does Mandela
description: SINCE his release from prison in February 1990, Nelson Mandela has become familiar as a symbol of the African National Congress, champion of those oppressed by apartheid and negotiator with President F. W. de Klerk. Yet in recent weeks, the courteous firmness that characterized Mr. Mandela's early months of freedom has been yielding to perceptible militancy, leading to the deadline of next Thursday that his congress has set for the Government to end the violence racking black townships. Failing some compromise before Thursday, the African National Congress appears determined to carry out its threat to break off talks with the Government on the nation's future.

title: Miss Brufsky Wed To Peter Waltman
description: Naomi Brufsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Brufsky of Weston, Conn., was married in Tarrytown, N.Y., last evening to Peter Barnett Waltman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Waltman of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi James Prosnit officiated at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill.

title: SALVADORANS FACE A 'CRISIS OF PEACE'
description: At the conclusion of the recent round of talks to end the Salvadoran civil war, photographers captured a seemingly historic moment when the deputy army commander and the top guerrilla leader, both smiling broadly, shook hands.

title: Postings: 66 New Houses; 2-Families In a Mews
description: Moderate-income New Yorkers in search of homes they can purchase have a new option in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, where the New York City Partnership, one of the city's largest developers of affordable housing, has begun selling the Stuyvesant Mews Houses.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE road that describes the eastern boundary of the Institute Woods in Princeton was lined with cars -- just about what you would expect for a Saturday morning in mid-May. On this particular morning, a few years ago, we nudged our sedan into a recently vacated spot and stepped into a world wrapped in song.

title: THE KURDS: IN FLIGHT, ONCE AGAIN
description: AMONG THE REFUGEES huddled on the mountains between Iraq and Turkey, an old saying could be heard again and again: The Kurds have no friends. It was uttered so often among the wretched thousands fleeing Iraq that it became a frayed cliche. But cliches develop because they are at least in part true: over the decades, few peoples have wound up on the short end so consistently as these champions of failed rebellions against central authority. Perhaps no ethnic group so large has gone so long without a homeland.

title:
POP MUSIC;
A Musician With Lightning in His Hands
description: Sonny Sharrock knows what it's like to hold lightning in his bare hands. During the late 60's, in an attempt to emulate the atonal squeals and spluttering trills of saxophonists like Ornette Coleman and Albert Ayler, Mr. Sharrock turned up his amplifier and invented free jazz guitar. It was a music of raw power and high voltage.

title: Euphoria Over Methadone Fades
description: THE euphoria that greeted the introduction of methadone as a heroin treatment 26 years ago has faded. With treatment stretching more than 10 years for some patients and the median age of new admissions rising, critics say the system has created a group of addicts dependent on the new opiate of methadone.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Foreign Twists on an American Style
description: Minimalism, when it leapt into public consciousness in the late 1960's, seemed nothing less than a gauntlet thrown down before the Serial avant-garde. In works like Terry Riley's "In C" (1964), Philip Glass's "Music in Fifths" (1969) and Steve Reich's "Drumming" (1970), a new esthetic was born, one that rejected the inaudible structure of Serialism and insisted on a rigorous clarity of process. And Minimalism drew inspiration from sources Serialism had shunned, especially non-Western music, jazz and rock. Ceaselessly kinetic, delighting in steady pulse and tonal center, this bare-bones Minimalism was a quintessentially American invention.

title: Campus Life: Lafayette; Students Win Cut In New Meal Fees But All Must Pay
description: Protests over a proposed mandatory meal charge at Lafayette College, which would have added as much as $1,100 to the college's annual fees, have resulted in what many students consider to be a Pyrrhic victory. All students -- even those who do not use campus dining rooms -- must still buy the new meal ticket, called Flex Dollars, but none will pay more than $250 a semester for it.

title:
Beauty;
Body Language: Neck
description: Protecting the spot on the neck, drawing attention to it -- tender, pulsing. For the Japanese, the neck is the most sexually arousing spot in a woman. The neck of the kimono, shaped like an irregular vase, curving out in back to reveal the erotic place.

title: Do-It-Yourself Art Appreciation in Moscow
description: Moscow's Tretyakov Gallery, with its vast collection of Russian painting, has been closed for five years, awaiting marble from the Ukraine and wood from Byelorussia for its restoration. Three years from now it should reopen, if the supply lines hold.

title: Extra! Read All About It -- Carnegie's $1.25 Million Hall
description: A hundred years ago, on Tuesday, May 5, 1891, all the newspapers in New York City -- some 15 dailies and another 15 or so weeklies and foreign-language journals -- had one major local story on their minds: the opening of Music Hall, on the corner of Seventh Avenue and West 57th Street in Manhattan.

title: Armenians Mourn Dozens Slain in Azerbaijan
description: Tens of thousands of Armenians packed the central square of the Armenian capital, Yerevan, today to mourn victims of the latest eruption in the Armenian-Azerbaijani blood feud.

title: Iraqi War Prisoners Now Find Themselves Men Without a Country
description: When Iraqi rebels launched their insurgency after the Persian Gulf war, Salah Abdali Lefta left the Iraqi naval base at Umm Qasr to join the revolt.

title: Even in Pinch-Penny Times, Silver Is Holding Its Own
description: Is antique silver recession-proof?

title: Political Memo; Tax Plans Keep Falling Into Growing Budget Gap
description: AT a news conference last week, State Representative Alan R. Schlesinger, a Republican from Derby, urged that the state sales tax, already the highest in the nation at 8 percent, be hiked to 10 percent. Mr. Schlesinger, whose opposition to an income tax is among the hardest of the hardcore in the General Assembly, said the beefed-up sales tax should also be extended onto previously untaxed items like bus and train tickets.

title: Leib Lensky, 82, Dies; Acted in Films and TV
description: Leib Lensky, an actor who appeared in plays, films and television programs and performed in English, Yiddish and Hebrew, died on Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 82.

title: Pamela B. Schargel Is Wed
description: Pamela Beth Schargel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schargel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married there last night to John Beaton Montgomery 2d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Montgomery of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer officiated at the Hampshire Country Club. The couple, both 28 years old, graduated from the University of Rhode Island. Mrs. Montgomery is a freelance visual display artist in New York. Her husband is a financial consultant at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

title: Causes of Crisis: 7 Fat Years, Then Recession
description: For months a faltering economy and plummeting tax receipts have set the rhythm for the Dinkins administration as it scrambled to stay ahead of the bad news.

title: Touches of Affordable Luxury
description: AT lunchtime, there is a long procession of court workers, often led by Italian-American judges, making a beeline for Ristorante Venere on Carman Avenue in Westbury. Those people from the nearby Nassau County Family Court come down on the side of truth, justice and good Italian food at bargain tariffs.

title: Cameras Focus on Human Rights
description: Chronicling human-rights problems around the world has been largely the domain of print journalists and activist organizations.

title: The Elusive Elizabeth
description: THE VIRGIN QUEEN

title: Abigail Moore to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Robert Moore of Chatham, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Abigail Moore and Marc Philip Reiter, a son of June Shannon Reiter of Albany and the late Sanford David Reiter. Miss Moore, 25 years old, is an art director at the McCann-Erickson Worldwide advertising agency in New York. She received bachelor's and master's degrees from the Parsons School of Design. Her fiance, 27, is the director of marketing at Epic Records, a New York division of Sony Entertainment. He graduated from the College of St. Rose in Albany.

title: Chernobyl Makes Ukraine Want Independence
description: To the Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Nashua. N.H.;
An Old Factory Now Rentals
description: CONSTRUCTION was completed last month on the second and final phase of Clocktower Place, a 19th-century factory complex that has been turned into rental apartments.

title: The Region; The City Strains to Hit A Financial Target That May Be Too Small
description: IMAGINE a huge 747 jetliner trying to land on a dirt strip that ends abruptly after 200 feet and you will have some idea of the financial exercise the Dinkins administration is currently engaged in.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WILLIAM AND MILDRED LASDON PARK;
Six Young Birch Trees Are the Seedlings of an Arboretum
description: THE birch trees are the beginning. Six young trees, 10 to 12 years old and 14 feet high, but destined to grow much taller, were planted at the William and Mildred Lasdon Park here eight days ago.

title: Word From Nikita: Hold the Subtitles
description: When is a French film not really French? When its style is nouveau "Miami Vice," its hero is Bruce Willis with a sex change and its dialogue -- in French with English subtitles -- is not entirely needed in either language. Nothing is lost in translation in "La Femme Nikita," the slick, stylish, tremendously entertaining story of a bedraggled punk murderer transformed into an elegant government assassin. There is nothing to translate, for "Nikita" already speaks the international language of American action films, with an added soupcon of familiar French sexiness.

title: Headliners; Stuck Wicket
description: Last Wednesday proved a milestone of sorts for the British, who like nearly everyone else are growing accustomed to seeing barriers fall and new standards raised. It seems Rachael Heyhoe Flint decided the time was right for her to become the first female cricketeer admitted to London's 204-year-old Marylebone Cricket Club, one of the world's most famous cricket enclaves. Ms. Flint, who was captain of England's women's cricket team from 1966 to 1977, submitted her application last October after the club's secretary, Lieut. Col. John Stephenson, had gone on record saying that nothing in the club's constitution prohibited a woman from being a member. The matter was put to a vote, and some of the Marylebone's 17,500 members responded: 2,371 for Ms. Flint, 4,727 against. There was an additional vote on whether women should be allowed honorary membership. As a result, Lord's, the club's headquarters and cricket pavilion, remains perhaps the only field in the world closed to women.

title: Jil Robbins and John H. Pollock Marry
description: Jil Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Robbins of New York, was married yesterday to John Henry Pollock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Pollock of Menlo Park, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Timothy Stevens, a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Jeanne Vail Chapel at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill.

title: Labyrinthine Syntax
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: New Soviet Ethnic Unrest

title: Protecting a Rare Plant In Camp Smith's Marsh
description: THE spongy arrowhead -- also known as sagittaria calycina -- is being watched over at Camp Smith in Peekskill. So is its habitat, a brackish tidal marsh at the mouth of Annsville Creek, a tributary of the Hudson River.

title: Headliners; Pollution, a New Worry for Smokey the Bear
description: BY definition, parks are meant to be restful places. But rest and retreat are increasingly difficult to come by in many national parks. There are too many cars, too many hikers, too many campers, too many climbers, fishermen and bird lovers, and too many developers crowding subdivisions and ranchettes up against park boundaries.

title: Travel Advisory; Attacks Prompt U.S. Warning About Kenya
description: Renewed attacks on visitors to Kenya have prompted the United States Embassy here and the State Department to issue a new advisory to Americans traveling to Kenya. Despite efforts by the Nairobi Government to improve security in the game parks, the State Department says the security situation remains unchanged and visitors taking safari trips should exercise caution.

title: Review/Music; Met Opera Orchestra at Carnegie Hall
description: Like groundhogs squinting with unsure optimism into unfamiliar sunlight, the members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra emerged from their customary dark pit and clambered up onto the festively lighted stage of Carnegie Hall on Friday night. The occasion was one of the more glamorous events in the hall's Centennial Festival, certifying the graduation of James Levine's prized operatic ensemble into a full-fledged symphony orchestra, on display in the country's most famous concert hall.

title: Rottweilers, the Dogs of the Moment
description: Harold Ramos tugged his 4-month-old Rottweiler along Central Park West near 103d Street, wondering when the dog would turn mean.

title: People Should Live Closer to Mass Transit
description: Automobiles are "central to our culture" and a "rite of passage" not because cars are inherently amazing, but because people love mobility. Most people will admit driving to work in traffic is about as much fun as having a tooth pulled. We can thank Federal taxation and transportation-investment policies for this agony.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Prospect Park referred incorrectly to the man who designed the park with Calvert Vaux. He was Frederick Law Olmsted. The article also misidentified a structure awaiting restoration. It is the Concert Grove Music Pagoda, not the Oriental Pavilion. The article also included incorrect dates provided by the Prospect Park Alliance for free admission to the carousel sponsored by the Helena Rubinstein Foundation. The correct dates are May 16, May 23, May 30 and June 6. There will be no free admission on May 9.

title:
WINE;
New Italian Offerings Are Available Locally
description: RECENT additions to the wine lists at a number of local Italian restaurants expand the opportunity to sample some of the newest creations from Tuscany, Trentino and Sicily, as well as products made in Italy for decades but only now reaching the United States.

title: Classroom Variety: Parents Foster Enrichment
description: EVEN in the best of economic times, subjects like puppet making, carpentry or weaving -- not to mention double-Dutch rope jumping, mask making or knitting -- would probably seem like luxurious extras in most public elementary schools. Given the budget cuts most school systems are now facing, many taxpayers would probably consider such courses downright frivolous.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 5, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 MESSAGE FROM NAM, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.99.) A woman journalist's coming of age in the 1960's and 70's. 2 29 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 3 8 RED DRAGON, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $5.95.) A retired F.B.I. agent returns to service to track down a serial killer. 4 2 AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $5.99.) Manners, morals and murder in Los Angeles's high society. 5 21 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 6 2 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Signet, $6.99.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 7 2 VENDETTA, by Peter David. (Pocket, $4.95.) "Calvin and Hobbes" cartoons. 2 40 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 23 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The roof on the south side of our house is shaded most of the day and keeps collecting moss. How do I remove the moss without damaging the shingles, and what can I do to keep it from coming back? A. Garden-supply stores sell numerous products for removing moss, and one I am familiar with is called De-Moss. You can also wash moss off with a copper sulfate solution (one-half ounce to 10 gallons of water). This solution has some residual effect to keep moss from coming back for a while. Because the solution can damage shrubbery and cause harm to metal, flush it off thoroughly. Copper pieces along the roof ridge will help prevent moss growth for about 10 feet down from the ridge. Also, string copper wires horizontally along the roof to protect sections further down. Each wire will prevent moss growth for about four feet below it. Q. Our bathroom has tile around the tub, with pink tiles scattered among the white ones. The effect is atrocious, and we would like to paint all the tile white. Can you suggest how to paint ceramic tile? A. Ceramic tile can be painted with any good grade of alkyd enamel. Clean the surface first with a strong detergent or scouring powder. Rinse off with plain water, then allow the surface to dry for a day or two. Apply a bonding primer coat of white, pigmented shellac like BIN or Enamelac and then apply two coats of the enamel, sanding lightly between coats. Once the tile has been painted, it should be repainted periodically.

title: Public & Private; Citizen As Consumer
description: Here in our town, municipal elections are greeted by many with a feeling of resignation and despair. Across the river in Manhattan, up in Albany, down in Trenton the chief executives are like alligator wrestlers as they tussle with their budgets, trying to get a hold on something mean, slippery, and obviously more powerful than they are.

title: From Year of Adversity to Season of Success
description: When James Ruocchio stepped into the batter's box recently in the eighth inning of C.W. Post's game against Temple University, he did not think of the moment as the one to define what could be an unprecedented triple-crown season.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The roof on the south side of our house is shaded most of the day and keeps collecting moss. How do I remove the moss without damaging the shingles, and what can I do to keep it from coming back? A. Garden-supply stores sell numerous products for removing moss, and one I am familiar with is called De-Moss. You can also wash moss off with a copper sulfate solution (one-half ounce to 10 gallons of water). This solution has some residual effect to keep moss from coming back for a while. Because the solution can damage shrubbery and cause harm to metal, flush it off thoroughly. Copper pieces along the roof ridge will help prevent moss growth for about 10 feet down from the ridge. Also, string copper wires horizontally along the roof to protect sections further down. Each wire will prevent moss growth for about four feet below it. Q. Our bathroom has tile around the tub, with pink tiles scattered among the white ones. The effect is atrocious, and we would like to paint all the tile white. Can you suggest how to paint ceramic tile? A. Ceramic tile can be painted with any good grade of alkyd enamel. Clean the surface first with a strong detergent or scouring powder. Rinse off with plain water, then allow the surface to dry for a day or two. Apply a bonding primer coat of white, pigmented shellac like BIN or Enamelac and then apply two coats of the enamel, sanding lightly between coats. Once the tile has been painted, it should be repainted periodically.

title: The Region; Learning Economics
description: THE protest that crippled the City University of New York campuses for more than three weeks unraveled last week, with protesters apparently failing to block plans for a yearly $500 tuition increase and a $92 million reduction in the university's budget.

title: Theresa Tierney To Marry in July
description: Rear Adm. and Mrs. John M. Tierney of Merion, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Theresa Paige Tierney to Jonathan Crawford Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Clark of Aiken, S.C. A July wedding is planned.

title: Style Makers; Bruno Pittini, Hair Stylist
description: For 20 years, Bruno Pittini was the creative force behind 360 Jacques Dessange beauty salons around the world as well as the Bruno Dessange salon in New York. He has styled the hair of Brigitte Bardot, Catherine Deneuve and Jodie Foster, cuts the hair of Dustin Hoffman and Donald Sutherland and is responsible for Raquel Welch's gamine haircut and Rachel Ward's new short crop.

title: Tracey McGan, Executive, Wed
description: Tracey Elizabeth McGan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Belser McGan of Shrewsbury, Mass., was married in Providence, R.I., yesterday to Robert Brewster Hamill, the son of Mrs. Philip Axel Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and the late James Lyon Hamill 3d. The Rev. Steele Martin performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: Talking: Cable TV; Disruptive Upgrading Of Systems
description: SOME 440,000 Manhattan residents are having their homes rewired to bring cable television service up to contemporary standards, and the work is causing some controversy.

title: Campus Life: Haverford; A New Elective Proves Satisfying: Community Work
description: For about 140 Haverford College undergraduates -- 12 percent of the student body -- one weekend last month was not play as usual. Instead the students joined the volunteer efforts that are sweeping many American campuses and devoted their free time to Haverford's first annual Community Service Day.

title: Northeastern Upsets Harvard on the Charles
description: Northeastern upset Harvard and Brown defeated Princeton and Yale yesterday in major crew races among the men's heavyweight eights.

title: Will vs. Williams
description: To the Editor:

title: Austrians Wait to See if Waldheim Will Run
description: Although the presidential election is more than a year off, Austria's decision-makers and the press are already preoccupied with the uneasy question of whether President Kurt Waldheim is preparing to run for a second term.

title: The Region; Nassau and Suffolk Ponder a Little Change
description: AS their elected leaders struggle with budget crises, Long Island's two counties are facing serious internal challenges to their systems of government. Although the proposed changes may seem cosmetic, they signal a real dissatisfaction with county government on Long Island, especially in Suffolk. If they take effect, they could mean a major shift in both the way government works and the way political power is meted out across the Island.

title:
FILM;
Ugly Truths of Date Rape Elude the Screen
description: Ever since Rhett Butler forcibly abducted an angry, fighting Scarlett O'Hara up that grand staircase -- only to have her appear the next morning with a sly, happy grin on her face -- Hollywood has misunderstood rape between people who know each other.

title: Travel Advisory; London Town House to Open
description: One of London's few remaining great 18th-century town houses, Spencer House, at St. James's Place, Piccadilly, has been restored and will open to the public May 12.

title: Past and Present Collide at a Cemetery
description: AS cars rush by on busy Ashford Avenue and residents go about their daily business here, time is quietly but persistently taking its toll on a one-square-mile piece of property that holds much of this village's history.

title: Separate Senior Proms Reveal an Unspanned Racial Divide
description: The rented limousines carrying young men in tuxedoes and young women in taffeta began arriving at a Gold Coast hotel shortly after dusk on Friday. It was the official Brother Rice High School prom, and it was virtually all white.

title: Big Increase in Addicts Strains Drug Centers
description: THE problems of intravenous-drug users on Long Island are increasing so rapidly that treatment agencies are straining under the new load.

title: Gavels Falling In Manhattan
description: AFTER circling the island for a year like pesky salesmen, housing auctioneers finally are breaking into the Manhattan apartment market this spring, carrying a bag of bargains on one shoulder and a bit of a chip on the other.

title: The Fresh Air Fund, at 115, Seeks Families and Donations
description: For thousands of children living in the city's poorest neighborhoods, summer vacation means sitting on stoops or watching street life from fire escapes and tenement windows.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a controversy over the role of race in school admissions referred incorrectly in some copies to a participant in the landmark 1978 Supreme Court reverse-discrimination case. He was Allan Bakke.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about frontier forts in Texas misstated the founding date of the 24th Infantry. A reader has written to point out that the year was 1869, not 1860; the correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title: Shortwave Radios
description: To the Editor: In answer to Francis Tedeschi (Letters on Travel, March 17), who stated that not all shortwave, AM and FM radios have oscillators in their circuitry, which might interfere with navigation and communications equipment on airplanes:

title: Nancy Ambrose Weds Eric Wentz
description: Nancy Lee Ambrose, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Ambrose of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married there yesterday to Eric Howard Wentz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney F. Wentz of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson officiated at the Presbyterian Church.

title: The World
description: IN March, the venerable satiric journal Krokodil published its first cartoon of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a drawing by Aleksandr Umiarov showing the President trying to stitch the Soviet Union together.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; Potatoes' Homage To the Good Earth
description: Eating a fresh-dug potato is about as close to eating the earth as you can get. It's as if this humble tuber, swelling beneath the ground, gathers together the essences of good, rich soil -- minerals and trace elements and air and moisture in a kind of hologram of taste that says earth .

title: Ms. Kissick to Marry Bradley Richards
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Lee Kissick of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Davenport Kissick, to Bradley Keegan Richards, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy W. Richards of Westerly, R.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: Doing More With Less, Environmentally
description: PROTECTING the environment in an era of dwindling state and Federal funds is among the many challenges faced by Timothy R. E. Keeney, the new Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection. Mr. Keeney, a lawyer whose specialty has been the environment, said that among his priorities is reducing the backlog of applications for permits, to enable his staff to devote more time to enforcement and finding alternative sources of money for personnel, efforts to clean Long Island Sound and local recycling programs.

title: CELEBRATING PAINT
description: I was amused at Elizabeth Murray's assertion that Frank Stella's work says, "Look at me, I'm a big, powerful man!" -- she of the nine-foot canvases and the repudiation of "domestic dramas" in her work ("Celebrating Paint" by Deborah Solomon, March 31). Just imagine the reaction had a painter, who happens to be a man, described the work of a painter, who happens to be a woman, as "tiny and so female."

title: Life as One Grand Taste Test
description: SCENTS AND SENSUALITY The Essence of Excitement. By Max Lake. Illustrated. 242 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: John Murray/Trafalgar Square.

title: Sports of The Times; For Ryan, Another Shot at Vander Meer
description: Mark Belanger didn't notice Nolan Ryan staring at him in the eighth inning of that 1973 game, but his Baltimore Oriole teammates did.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
The Effort To Save Young Landmarks
description: ONLY a few hours after the North Hempstead Historic Landmarks Commission turned down a landmarking application on April 3 for the 50-year-old Village Bath Club in Manhasset, a developer's bulldozers were at work obliterating all traces of the 2.5-acre recreational complex.

title: Man Who Deserted 41 Years Ago Gets Discharge Instead of a Trial
description: A man who deserted from the Coast Guard 41 years ago and was not taken into custody until last month, after decades of homelessness, has been spared a court-martial and been discharged.

title: Q and A
description: Skiing in New Zealand

title: Israeli Economy Is Keeping Many Jews in U.S.S.R.
description: The Israeli Government is openly acknowledging for the first time that tens of thousands of Soviet Jews are postponing or canceling their moves to Israel because of the country's inability to provide jobs for those already here.

title: Not Necessarily Numbing
description: AS if my ultimate objectives weren't going to be stimulating enough, I had an appealing surprise on the bus ride up Interstate 5 from Seattle to the Alaska Marine Highway Terminal. A passenger three or four seats back started making calls on his mobile phone.

title: K. L. Brett to Wed Laura E. Ulrich
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gardner Ulrich of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Elizabeth Ulrich to Kirk Llewellyn Brett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Samuel Brett of Great Neck, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Co-Producer: No Newcomer
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Parking Rules For the Disabled
description: In an attempt to eliminate confusion over different regulations for using handicapped parking spaces from state to state, the United States Department of Transportation has established a uniform set of rules.

title: CHERNOBYL FIVE YEARS LATER
description: Congratulations to Felicity Barringer for her article "Chernobyl Five Years Later" (April 14). I returned recently from a four-month trip to Lithuania. While there, I witnessed the anger Lithuanians feel over the lies and deceptions of the Soviet Union, particularly in regard to the handling of the Chernobyl accident. Many people told me that they had been outdoors on the day of the explosion. It had been a particularly warm and beautiful weekend. Many were spending it in the countryside, near lakes and rivers. Parents had urged their children to take off their clothing and sun themselves.

title: When Each Planting Recalls a Friend
description: MY friendship garden is in bloom. Every gardener has one or should have one. It features those plants that friends have shared, and each plant is a reminder of that friendship.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 5, 1991

LP indicates that a book is available in large print. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: VIRGINIA LAW FOCUS OF U.S. GUN DEBATE
description: Virginia's system of instantaneously checking the backgrounds of prospective handgun buyers is generally praised for preventing felons from buying pistols, but it also underscores the limits of any effort to determine who is fit to own a firearm.

title: Managing; Fitting the Bonus to the Performance
description: Like most companies, the International Business Machines Corporation used to pay bonuses only when its business units hit some predesignated growth goal. How competitors were doing didn't matter at all.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Putting Names to Actions Actions create the need for words, the historian Christopher Hill reminds us, and words in turn give shape and permanence to what we have done. This is from "A Nation of Change and Novelty: Radical Politics, Religion and Literature in Seventeenth-Century England" (Routledge).

title: A Vermont City Acts to Bring Back Happier Times
description: Hard times are no stranger to this city of 4,400 residents at the confluence of two major rail lines just south of the Canadian border.

title: CRIME
description: Xenia Smith and Leslie Wetzon, the high-powered Wall Street headhunters who were such a caution in Annette Meyers's "Big Killing" and "Tender Death," return in THE DEADLIEST OPTION (Bantam, $18) with more blood on their manicures. Business is still bullish at their cloak-and-dagger firm, but in the wake of Black Monday the brokers they serve have grown more devious and ruthless. ("Eat with brokers," says Smith of the "lying scuzzballs" she deals with, "get up with fleas.") Wetzon, the good-natured, principled partner in this cutthroat business, quite properly gets the wind up, then, when she learns that a client firm is secretly planning a structural overhaul that will "change the face of the retail brokerage industry" -- and throw them out of work. Not to worry, though. A rash of murders at the maverick brokerage house soon scotches that bit of industry reform.

title: Rebecca Stone Is Wed to Stephen Walt
description: Rebecca Elisabeth Stone, the daughter of Harold Stone Jr. of New York and Antonia Stone of Somerville, Mass., was married in Chicago yesterday to Stephen Martin Walt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Walt 4th of Los Altos Hills, Calif. Judge Theodore M. Swain, a retired justice of the Cook County Circuit Court, officiated at Le Meridien Hotel.

title: Data Update
Young Artists, Solo and in Ensemble
description: SOME of the finest young instrumentalists in Connecticut are in the spotlight this week. The first-prize winners of the annual piano competition sponsored by the Schubert Club of Fairfield County will appear at 3 P.M. today at a free recital in the First Presbyterian Church in Stamford. The six pianists, from 9 to 18 years old, are Heather Anne Brown and Jeb Dennis of Stamford, Jennifer Basill and Peter Yao of Norwalk, and Yoko Taminaga and Jacqueline Blair of Darien. For information, call 637-2990.

title: A Bernstein Mahler Eighth
description: When Leonard Bernstein died last October, the most important project he left unfinished was his second recording of the complete symphonies of Gustav Mahler. The project was for Deutsche Grammophon (in the 60's he had recorded all the symphonies for Columbia).

title: Going Forward By Looking Back
description: THE latest trend in crafts is to look backward not over the shoulder at the competition, but at masterworks of the past.

title: Social Events
description: At Rusty Staub's

title: You'd Never Suspect Kathleen
description: THE RISE OF LIFE ON EARTH By Joyce Carol Oates. 135 pp. New York: New Directions. $16.95.

title: Karen Schnurr to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. T. Schnurr of Sheffield, Mass., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Karen Schnurr and Peter Jonathan Secrist, the son of Maryellen Secrist of Aspen, Colo., and the late Dr. Donald M. Secrist. The couple, both 26 years old, are graduates of St. Lawrence University. Ms. Schnurr is a sales assistant in the Boston office of Brown Brothers Harriman, the private commercial bank. Mr. Secrist is to begin an M.B.A. program at the University of Colorado in the fall.

title: Hudson Valley
description: To the Editor: I appreciate Harold Faber's mentioning our Historic Hudson House Tour this May 25 in "What's Doing in the Hudson Valley" (Travel, April 14). However, describing our city as rundown was uncalled for. Hudson is no more rundown than the overwhelming majority of American cities and is far safer than most. It also probably has the finest collection of 19th-century buildings in New York State and one of the finest in the country.

title: Of Tributes And Honors
description: A silent art auction and cocktails benefited the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo on Monday. The party then moved to the Manhattan Center Studios on 34th Street for dinner, dancing and a live auction.

title: World of Ideas Meets World of Mime
description: YASS HAKOSHIMA matches the rush of ideas that spill from him with eloquent gestures and quicksilver expressions. To meet him in an intimate setting, like a living room, is to experience close up the compelling quality that makes his singular brand of mime so powerful.

title: Lydia Ann Kelley Weds Thomas Matthew Nelson
description: Lydia Ann Kelley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Telfair Kelley Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., was married in Summit, N.J., yesterday to Thomas Matthew Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Nelson of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. William Strain officiated at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: Once a Nun, Now a Leader in Alternative Church for Blacks
description: ROSE VERNELL, a former nun, compares her decision to leave the Roman Catholic Church and join the Washington-based Imani Temple of the African-American Catholic Congregation to the historic decision made in 1955 by Rosa Parks to keep her seat on an Alabama bus.

title: Co-op Workouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Diary/April 28-May 3
description: COMPANIES So Many Auto Makers . . . and So Few Sales

title: For Winner Antley, There's No Feeling Quite Like It
description: For a race that seemed filled with question marks going in, there were no mysteries afterward among the jockeys who navigated their horses in the 117th Kentucky Derby.

title: Maryse Bousso Is a Bride
description: Maryse April Bousso and Howard Bruce Bloom were married last evening at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club. Rabbi Gordon L. Gladstone and Cantor Lee Fowler officiated. The bride, 32 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bousso of Bayonne, N.J. The bridegroom, 34, is the son of Arlene Bloom of Union, N.J., and the late Marvin R. Bloom. Mrs. Bloom, a graduate of Syracuse University, is the treasury manager at Farr Man & Company, a commodities and futures trader in New York. The bridegroom is a lawyer in Union. He graduated from Seton Hall University, where he also received a law degree.

title:
Beauty;
Body Language: Back
description: I have always loved backs. I wonder what it says about me, that I worship a part of the body that signals a turning away. Does it mean I'm a glutton for abandonment, or a timid voyeur who prefers a surreptitious gaze that will not be met and challenged? I only know I have often felt the deepest love at just that moment when the beloved turns her back toward me to get some sleep.

title: When Artists and Art Have Common Roots
description: AN Irish tin-whistle player, a Cambodian court dancer and a Polish-American paper cutter are all on Dr. Rebecca Joseph's list. She plans to document their work.

title: Shooting Fish Has Become an Endangered Sport
description: John Roy peered out the kitchen window of his 200-year-old farmhouse atop this island in Lake Champlain, pointed with his pipestem to the neighboring marsh and ticked off the reasons why nostalgia isn't what it used to be, at least not for him.

title: Pamela Gore Weds C. L. Bringsjord
description: Pamela Ann Gore of Montgomery, Tex., and Conrad Lehne Bringsjord, a senior associate in mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley in New York, were married yesterday in Montgomery. The Rev. Dowan Johnson, a minister of the Assembly of God Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony at April Sound Church.

title: Streetscapes: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum; Recalling the Urban Pioneers
description: FIRST they found a tenement at 97 Orchard Street that no one had lived in for half a century. Then they got an option to buy it for close to $1 million. Now they have to raise that, plus $2 million to fix it up.

title: Campus Life: Rutgers; President Listens At a Protest Rally For 2 Professors
description: The organizers of a rally last week at Rutgers University expected many students and faculty members to turn out in support of two professors whose jobs are in jeopardy. But they did not expect the university's new president, Francis L. Lawrence, to show up, too.

title: Leslie Barton Wed to James Wheaton
description: Leslie Anne Barton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Barton of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Russell Wheaton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warde Wheaton of Deephaven, Minn. A nondenominational ceremony was performed by David E. Nesmith and Catherine E. Fox, an archbishop of the Universal Life Church, at Falkirk, a historic site in San Rafael, Calif.

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: Last August I rented a car from Europcar of Italy at Reggio di Calabria Airport in Reggio Calabria. All went well for the first five days. However, the morning that I was to return the car to the airport, the vehicle failed to start. I called Europcar at the Reggio airport. No one answered so I called the number listed on my contract, Europcar's central office in Milan. They assured me that a car would be sent to me immediately so I could get to the airport. One-half hour later a service truck appeared with two men to take the car to a nearby town for repairs, but they had no knowledge of a replacement car. At this point there was no way to make it to the airport in time for my flight, since I was in a town that was two hours from Reggio.

title: If a Chair Is a Work of Art, Can You Still Sit on It?
description: When is a chair not a chair? When it is a work of art. That, at least, is the assumption of a growing number of collectors, critics, museum curators, gallery owners and furniture makers, who form the vanguard of the growing studio furniture movement.

title: Residential Resales

Forum;

title: The Nation; Testing for AIDS: The Questions Go Beyond the Clinical

While medical groups are increasingly on record as urging physicians to notify their patients if the doctors have become infected with the HIV virus, proposals for mandatory testing raise difficult issues of efficacy, privacy, necessity and fairness.

title: Will vs. Williams
description: To the Editor: George F. Will gets much too exercised about Ted Williams's refusing to swing at dubious pitches in clutch situations. To do so, say, with a man on second and one out would have reduced his efficiency considerably; hacking at a ball low and away, Williams would have been just another .250 hitter. Taking a walk forced the pitcher to give Vern Stephens or Jackie Jensen a golden opportunity to clean up; why does Mr. Will think those hitters knocked in so many runs? ROBERT H. BELL Williamstown, Mass.

description: FIFTY years ago, the entire population of Ocean County's 33 communities was 38,000. Today, there are more students than that in the county's public elementary schools.

description: A prominent Kenyan editor and lawyer, whose imprisonment in solitary confinement by the Government here has raised international protests, is in deteriorating health and may be suffering from a brain tumor, medical tests indicate.

title: On the Street; Onward and Upward
description: There are no longer any rules on the length of women's skirts, but the spring suits blossoming on Manhattan's streets show that the above-the-knee hemline is very popular. Just how far above the knee depends on the wearer. Many of the shorter skirts are worn by younger women, on whom hems rise to midthigh and the occasional suit jacket becomes longer than the skirt. The stockings are both light and dark, with an occasional back seam to accentuate the leggy look, set on high-heeled shoes.

title: Topics of The Times; Senator Hatch Rewrites History
description: If proof were needed that the proposed civil rights bill is not a "quota bill," Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah provided it last year. Although he has opposed rights bills in the past, Senator Hatch joined in marathon compromise efforts with Senate Republicans and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights to produce a bill he recommended to the White House. President Bush vetoed the bill anyway, insisting that it would induce employers to hire by racial quotas rather than defend their practices in court.

title: Commercial Property: Unusual Spaces; A Striking Medley For the Right Renter
description: TO describe it as 18,150 square feet on East 42d Street would be accurate -- but scarcely fair to the subject.

title: Junkyards? No More. They're Auto Recyclers
description: AT Webster's Used Auto Parts in Terryville, the telephones ring all day with customer inquiries. On a recent Wednesday, the office manager, John Goscinski Jr., sat behind a cluttered counter consulting a computerized inventory and rattling off prices into one telephone receiver while he listened intently to an question on another. Across the counter, the yard manager, Joseph Harnois, was busy answering another call and assuring walk-in customers that he would help them in a minute. Everyone was hoping to locate just the right part among the 1,200 wrecked cars on Webster's 14-acre lot.

description: Lee Wulff was possessed by a furious desire to refine the art of angling and was extraordinarily successful in that quest, right to the end of his 86 years.

title: Ideas & Trends; Rome's 100-Year Hunt For a Middle Ground
description: AN aura of secrecy has long surrounded the Vatican. But one of its best-kept secrets has been entirely unintentional. For a century popes have been elaborating a systematic body of social thought that attempts to steer a path between capitalism and socialism. Whatever the importance of this teaching to Catholic leaders dealing with social problems, most of the laity has been scarcely aware of it. Now the word is spreading, helped last week by Pope John Paul II's important encyclical on the economic and moral lessons of the collapse of Communism.

Murray has a large sense of humor and a score of memorable abstract paintings behind her, so we will forgive her this trespass. EDWIN RUDA New York, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The roof on the south side of our house is shaded most of the day and keeps collecting moss. How do I remove the moss without damaging the shingles, and what can I do to keep it from coming back? A. Garden-supply stores sell numerous products for removing moss, and one I am familiar with is called De-Moss. You can also wash moss off with a copper sulfate solution (one-half ounce to 10 gallons of water). This solution has some residual effect to keep moss from coming back for a while. Because the solution can damage shrubbery and cause harm to metal, flush it off thoroughly. Copper pieces along the roof ridge will help prevent moss growth for about 10 feet down from the ridge. Also, string copper wires horizontally along the roof to protect sections further down. Each wire will prevent moss growth for about four feet below it. Q. Our bathroom has tile around the tub, with pink tiles scattered among the white ones. The effect is atrocious, and we would like to paint all the tile white. Can you suggest how to paint ceramic tile? A. Ceramic tile can be painted with any good grade of alkyd enamel. Clean the surface first with a strong detergent or scouring powder. Rinse off with plain water, then allow the surface to dry for a day or two. Apply a bonding primer coat of white, pigmented shellac like BIN or Enamelac and then apply two coats of the enamel, sanding lightly between coats. Once the tile has been painted, it should be repainted periodically.

title: Correction

title: Cuba
description: To the Editor: I found it disheartening to read in Howard W. French's article "Cuba's New Hotels Dream of Dollars" (Travel, March 31) that an increasing number of Americans are visiting Cuba every year. Two major reasons for the increased visitors, states Mr. French, are novelty and competitive package rates. Once again the "such a deal" syndrome allows us to visit and enjoy a country with gorgeous natural resources while breaking American law and ignoring the human rights abuses and the impossibility of residents to eat lobster dinners at any price.

description: UNTAMED The Autobiography of the Circus's Greatest Animal Trainer. By Gunther Gebel-Williams with Toni Reinhold. Morrow, $19.95.

title: Escape From Tiananmen Square: A Chinese Odyssey
description: WERE YOU FOLLOWED?" LIU XIANG ASKED anxiously, by way of greeting. It was a bright September day last year when we met for dinner at a restaurant in the center of Beijing. He hardly touched his food, spending much of his time looking over his shoulder. A fugitive from the law, Liu was very different from the easygoing physics student who, the year before, was at the center of the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square.
