title: People Should Live Closer to Mass Transit
description: The article "Out of Love and Necessity, Cars Boom on L.I." [ March 31 ] points up what is going to become an unprecedented problem in the not-too-distant future. This problem, pointed out by a British land-planning expert who visited Long Island last year, is the eventual need to tear down a great deal of Long Island's housing and build new, more densely compacted housing units.

title: Sey Hey Kid's 60th
description: One, two, three, four. . . . Let's see, that's 22 years in the majors, 25 league-leading efforts in 9 statistical categories, 660 career home runs, one spectacular over-the-shoulder World Series catch that became the enduring symbol for innumerable routine regular-season miracles, and, say hey, what's this, 60 years on earth?

title: Review/Dance; Movements From Spain
description: One would think that nothing could quell the fire of Spanish dancing. But a program by the Carlota Santana Spanish Dance Arts Company on Thursday night at Gould Hall lost much of its vitality because the microphones were too loud. The unatmospheric auditorium is not a good place for the intimate art of Spanish dancing, and the bright hard sound deadened the music and hung over the dancing like a heavy, suffocating canopy.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Breathes there a soul anywhere who has never been brushed off, put down or pointedly ignored? Is there anyone who has suffered from any of these slights or insults who hasn't, at least for a short time, felt depressed, insecure or furious and even, depending on the degree of hurt, all three combined? Probably not.

title: Islanders Skeptical About Their Fate
description: This season, the ice was slipperier than anybody could remember, so slippery that the Islanders could have sworn they felt it being pulled out from under them by their owner the way a magician displays his sleight of hand with a tablecloth.

title: Hatcher Begins Battle to Regain Spotlight in Gary
description: On the streets of this faded steel city, many people still refer to Richard G. Hatcher as Mayor, almost four years after he was voted out of office, and they pronounce the title and name as one word: "MayorHatcher."

title: Bhutto and Her Party Languish After Defeat
description: Five years after she triumphantly returned from exile to reclaim the political mantle of her father and lead the Socialist Party he founded back to power, former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is trapped in a political limbo and her party is mired in defeat.

title: The Legend Grows For Bird and Celtics
description: The Indiana Pacers had to battle Celtic tradition and the Larry Bird mystique today, and the intimidating combination proved to be unbeatable.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Currents column of The Home Section on Thursday about the exhibition "Wave Hill Pictured" at Wave Hill Garden in the Bronx omitted the name of the author of the exhibition book, published by Harry N. Abrams. She is Jean E. Feinberg.

title: Dance in Review
description: Sarah Skaggs Bessie Schonberg Theater 219 West 19th Street

title: In the Cards: Tennis Players
description: You can't call them bubble-gum cards because hardly anyone bothers with the gum these days. The term is trading cards, and now tennis players will be appearing on them. ANNE SMITH , who has a string of United States and foreign doubles titles, was at a baseball card auction last September and thought, "Why can't tennis do this?" She is now signing up many of her friends as the marketing director for ProTennis Player Cards. The first batch is out this summer. . . . ROZIER COHEN JOHNSTON , a fixture of New York horse racing, died last week. Johnston's father began the binocular concession at New York tracks in 1891, and for 100 years, the stand has been a meeting place for the rich and informed and the poor and uninformed. His clients included ALFRED G. VANDERBILT, BERNARD GIMBEL, WALTER P. CHRYSLER and assorted touts and punters.

title: As Cultures Meet, Gang War Paralyzes a City in California
description: The back streets of this port city are the scene of a violent gang war between Hispanic and Cambodian residents, two immigrant cultures with almost nothing in common except their attempts to build a new life in the same neighborhood.

title: Met Infield Unsettled Again By Groin Injury to Elster
description: Kevin Elster broke from first base, took his first stride and felt the top of his left leg pop. What went with it was the Mets' latest infield alignment and all the longed-for stability it had promised.

title: Decline in Taxi Ridership Has to Do With Decline in Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Jefferies Talks Back on 'Pet' Image
description: Gregg Jefferies had left the clubhouse that afternoon in 1989 with the reasonable request that his bat a teammate was swinging be placed back in Jefferies's locker. Famous already for his possessiveness concerning his bats, Jefferies was standing on the field at Busch Stadium a quarter of an hour later when word came that he should return to the clubhouse.

title: Where Political Elite Go for Medical Care
description: The Bethesda Naval Medical Center has played a leading role in the treatment of the nation's political elite.

title: Noel M. P. Reilly, 88, British Economic Aide
description: Noel M. P. Reilly, an economic official for the British Government who retired in 1965 and then became active in politics in New Hampshire, died April 22 at the Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia, N.H. He was 88 years old and lived in North Sandwich, N.H.

title: Pistons in Overdrive Against Hawks
description: Dennis Rodman's barber can keep the hair-cutting tools handy, either to spiff up the current message or to carve out a new one.

title: The Attack of the 'Killer Micros'
description: The Convex Computer Corporation plans to introduce its first supercomputer on Tuesday. But Cray Research Inc., the king of supercomputing, says it is more worried by "killer micros" -- compact, extremely fast work stations that sell for less than $100,000.

title: There's No Place Like Chittenango
description: When corporate sponsors suddenly pulled out of a plan to bring Munchkins back to the Land of Oz, people here were distraught. Unless help came from somewhere over the rainbow, they joked morosely to one another, the plan was dead.

title: Inge Jonckheer Is Wed To Eric Maki on a Yacht
description: Inge Jonckheer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy F. Jonckheer of Wassenaar, the Netherlands, was married in New York yesterday to Eric Maki, the son of Verne Maki of Clarence, N.Y. and the late John W. Maki. Dr. Don Robert Johnson of the New York Society for Ethical Culture performed the ceremony on the yacht Princess in the Hudson River.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions yesterday about spending reductions proposed for New York City agencies by Mayor David N. Dinkins omitted an explanation of the amounts of spending that had been planned for 1992. The figures were in thousands of dollars.

title:
FOOTBALL;
Knights (4-3) Take a Romp Down Tobacco Road
description: The most improved team in the World League of American Football met the weakest one this afternoon at Carter-Finley Stadium. The result was an overwhelming 42-6 victory by the New York/New Jersey Knights over the Raleigh-Durham Skyhawks.

title: Disapproval Of Building Stirs Asians
description: As tens of thousands of Chinese, Korean and other Asian immigrants settled quietly into Flushing, Queens, in recent years, many residents saw the community as a welcome example of tolerance in a world of racial and ethnic conflict.

title: 'A Lot of Hoopla About Nothing'? No Way
description: According to Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, President Bush thinks the reaction to his irregular heart beat "is a lot of hoopla about nothing." But that's not what the rest of Washington thinks.

title: National Academy of Sciences Elects 60 Members and 15 Foreign Associates
description: The National Academy of Sciences, an independent organization that is an official adviser to the Government on science and technology has elected new members.

title: Gasoline Prices Rise
description: A seasonal increase in demand for gasoline pushed prices up by nearly 3 cents a gallon in the last two weeks, according to an industry survey released today. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service pumps increased 2.77 cents a gallon, to 122.61 cents, by Friday, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,000 stations nationwide. The price increase reflected a surge in motorist demand as the weather has grown warmer, said Trilby Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. Ms. Lundberg noted that prices were at the highest levels for this time of year since 1985. The national average in May 1985 was 122.68 cents a gallon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Shock Treatment Common if Drugs Fail
description: The electrical shock treatment that President Bush's doctors are considering is commonly used to correct irregular heart rhythm when drugs fail.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week: American Health Properties Inc., 1.5 million common shares. Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Review/Television; Confronting the Supernatural at Home and in the Past
description: Ghosts and various forms of exorcism are, it seems, forever with us. Consider just the last couple of decades. William Peter Blatty's best-selling novel "The Exorcist" was turned into an enormously successful movie in 1973. Since then, the mass-market machine has been humming lucratively with everything from the Amityville stories to the fictions of Stephen King.

title: Law on Auditing Is Urged
description: The Comptroller General of the United States, Charles A. Bowsher, says in a report that new legislation is "urgently needed" to prevent American companies from engaging in financial irregularities like those that have caused huge losses to the Government and investors.

title: Black Rewards Giants By Outpitching Gooden
description: The Mets called a news conference before they left Florida this spring and announced to the world that Dwight Gooden would get his money. Gooden smiled, all those shutters clicked, the pitcher signed the three-year, $15.45 million contract extension and the telephone callers ceased screaming, "Pay the man!" on the radio.

title: Zulu Leader Threatens to Shun Peace Talks
description: The leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, threatened today to boycott a proposed peace conference because of what he called police collusion with the rival African National Congress.

title: Iraq Ends Censorship
description: Iraq said today that it had lifted reporting restrictions imposed on visiting journalists during the Persian Gulf war. An Information Ministry official said Western reporters in Baghdad would no longer have to submit their reports to ministry censors before transmitting them. Visiting journalists will still need to be accompanied by ministry guides on trips outside Baghdad "for their own protection," the official said, but are free to move independently in the capital.

title: Julie A. Goldstick, Lawyer, Marries
description: Julie Ann Goldstick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Goldstick of New York, was married there yesterday to Robert Michael Haroun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haroun of Norwich, Conn. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Kermit K. Schooler, 67, Psychologist and Dean
description: Kermit K. Schooler, a psychologist and former dean of the school of social work at Syracuse University, died on Tuesday at his home in Manlius, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: Judith M. Yourish Wed To Edward E. Maurer
description: Judith M. Yourish, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Yourish of Lido Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Edward E. Maurer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Maurer of Freeport, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Reuben M. Katz at Fox Hollow, a restaurant in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Guilty Plea in '88 Theft Of a Rodin Sculpture
description: An unemployed truck driver has pleaded guilty to an armed robbery in which a 12-inch bronze sculpture was taken from the Rodin Museum here on Nov. 23, 1988.

title: Ms. Hunter Wed To George Agnew
description: Alexa Hunter, a daughter of Edys Merrill Hunter of New York and Sam Hunter of Skillman, N.J., was married yesterday at the Princeton Club in New York yesterday to George McDowell Agnew, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm J. Agnew of McLean, Va. The Rev. Darrell Berger, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Alice Greenway Weds T. D. Cornwell
description: Alice Lauder Greenway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. S. Greenway of Needham, Mass., was married yesterday in Dover, Mass., to Timothy David Cornwell, a son of Mrs. Roger Martin of Coxley, Somerset, England, and David Cornwell of London. The Rev. Lyle G. Hall Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Dunstan's Episcopal Church.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Gold Bond Shifts Account
description: Gold Bond Ice Cream, whose brands include Popsicle and Good Humor, has moved its $6 million advertising account from the Grant Jacoby agency, Chicago, to McCann-Erickson.

title: Mayor of San Antonio Loses
description: Two City Council members defeated the Mayor, Lila Cockrell, and eight other candidates in Saturday's mayoral race. The two will face each other in a runoff later this month. The candidate who won the most votes was Councilwoman Maria Berriozabal, 50 years old, who received 31 percent of the votes. Councilman Nelson Wolff, 50, a former state legislator, was in second place with 26 percent. If Ms. Berriozabal is elected in the runoff, on May 25, she will become the first Hispanic woman to be Mayor of a major American city.

title: Decline in Taxi Ridership Has to Do With Decline in Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Europe's Hardships Grow As Trade With Soviets Dries Up,
description: For years, the nations of the Eastern bloc grumbled that Moscow's arcane system for trade with its allies was little more than a swindle. Just give us a chance to sell our goods for cold hard dollars, they insisted, and we will show you who comes out ahead. On Jan. 1 they got their wish, and they have rued the day ever since.

title: Excerpts From the White House's Briefing on Bush's Medical Condition
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing tonight by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, on the medical condition of President Bush. OPENING STATEMENT

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Productivity . . . 1st Qtr.

title: Brazil's Plans For Economy Drawing Fire
description: Without fanfare, the central bank here has quietly placed into circulation Brazil's latest and highest-denomination bank note, the 10,000 cruzeiro bill.

title: As Champion Relaxes, Trainers Get Busy
description: On the day after Strike the Gold won the Kentucky Derby, deposing Fly So Free in the process, Nick Zito stood in the shed row of the winner's barn at rainy Churchill Downs early this morning and said, "Even Muhammad Ali got beat."

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Changing Times magazine, the money management publication founded by the Kiplinger organization in 1947, will change its name to Kiplinger's Personal Finance Magazine, beginning with the July issue. Kiplinger said in a statement that the name "Changing Times" did not "clearly describe the contents of the magazine."

title: Bush's Heartbeat Still Erratic, but Condition Is Stable
description: President Bush continued to suffer an irregular heartbeat tonight, despite the use of a second drug, and the White House said his doctors would decide Monday morning whether to use an electrical shock to restore the normal rhythms of the President's heart.

title: Hair Compound Tested
description: The Procyte Corporation, a developer of pharmaceutical products, said tests of its hair growth compound, PC1031, had caused "significant" hair growth in fuzzy rats. It said a single injection had caused a significant increase in the numbr of hairs grown, and enlarged hair follicles in both the resting and active phases of hair growth. Procyte said it had started two clinical human hair growth studies in France. The only current hair growth drug approved for United States marketing is the Upjohn Company's Minoxidil, which is approved only for treatment of male pattern baldness. Procyte shares gained 75 cents in over-the-counter trading on Friday, closing at $7 each.

title: Political Worries, Quiet and Outspoken, on Quayle
description: There were two dramas played out this weekend after President Bush's heart began beating irregularly while he was jogging at Camp David and he had to be taken to a hospital.

title: La Guardia High School Plans a Benefit Concert
description: A benefit concert for the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts will be held at 8 tonight at the auditorium of the school, 108 Amsterdam Avenue, near 65th Street. Alumni who have gone on to professional music careers are to perform a program that includes Bach, Brahms and Mozart along with works by composers who have graduated from the school.

title: Arabs Adding Maxwell To Company Blacklist
description: The Arab League said today that it had lifted an official boycott of the Coca-Cola Company but imposed one on businesses owned by the publisher Robert Maxwell because of his dealings in Israel.

title: Cleveland, Scoring 15 More Runs, Makes A's Look Like the Indians
description: With 35 runs and 40 hits over two games, the Cleveland Indians ended a season-long hitting slump.

title: Young Chess Players Show It Can Be Done
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Z. Schepps, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Sara Zoe Schepps, an associate at the New York law firm of Richards & O'Neil, and William Thomas Matschke, the controller at the law firm of Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Specthrie & Lerach in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Herbert N. Schwartz and Rabbi Mark D. Finkel performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Springfield, Mass.

title: A Blunt-Speaking Doctor (Bush's Own) Leads Team Treating President
description: The medical team caring for President Bush is led by a handful of doctors supervised by the President's personal physician, a man known for candor and blunt speaking.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Backer Spielvogel Hires Executive for Wendy's
description: Gary W. Steele, a 16-year veteran of the J. Walter Thompson Company, has been appointed an executive vice president in the New York office of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., where he will be responsible for the Wendy's International account.

title: Eugene Spellman Dies; Federal Judge Was 60
description: Judge Eugene P. Spellman, an 11-year veteran of Federal District Court who was known for innovative sentences and supporting social causes, died of cancer on Saturday at Mercy Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Spinglish
description: "It's easy to tell which kids are the Americans and which are not," reports a young woman who has spent her post-college year teaching and traveling in Europe. "Look at the signs on their clothes. The Americans don't advertise."

title: Repairs Over, Astronauts Rush Their Experiments
description: The seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery squeezed in as many experiments as possible for the Pentagon today on the last full day of a mission that has been plagued by problems with recording equipment.

title: Ms. Ceisler Weds Mark L. Blitzer
description: Emily Joanne Ceisler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Ceisler of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Blitzer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Blitzer of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title:
TENNIS;
A Walking Billboard for Sport and Profit
description: Pete Sampras is back, and the four corporations with whom he has endorsement contracts are glad that he is. The 19-year-old United States Open champion is (in some cases, literally) wearing their commercial hearts on his sleeve.

title: Former Engines of Kuwait Line Up Bleakly for Alien Status
description: They squatted on curbs amid garbage and broken glass, the men on one curb, the women along another, waiting to register with the Government of Kuwait as Palestinians.

title: Dispute About Violence Continues in Yugoslavia
description: Shortly after noon last Thursday, a contingent of police officers from the Yugoslav republic of Croatia walked into this predominantly Serbian town. Gunfire erupted. More than a dozen people, most of them police, were fatally wounded. Three hours later, the Yugoslav national army's tanks rolled down the main street and ended the carnage.

title: The Cold War and the Hyphen War
description: Thousands of shouting Slovaks today are likely to crowd the center of Bratislava, the old red-roofed city on the Danube. Their scheduled general strike is intended to show their Czech partners how much Slovakia resents being taken for granted. It will also demonstrate something to the West: the nasty legacy of Communist influence the cold war has left in Eastern Europe.

title: San Francisco Journal; Doing His Duty, Juror Finds a Cause
description: In the drug-infested cor ners of this city, where AIDS advocates have for years exchanged clean syringes for dirty ones, an airline mechanic new to civil disobedience recently joined the ranks of those breaking the law in the name of public health.

title: The Taming of a TV Series Teaser, Or Less Talk About the Bedroom
description: A television series' teaser -- otherwise known as an opening vignette or setup -- is a device that has practically come to border on self-parody. The bigger the tease, or the more intimate, the better. Usually.

title: In Manhattan, Black Doormen Are Rare Breed
description: Until last month, many New Yorkers may have shared Billiam Coronel's bewilderment about why the city has a doormen's union.

title: Ahoy, Mates, the Institute's Back at the Seaport
description: Nearly 150 years ago, the Seamen's Church Institute came to South Street to protect seamen from the perils of shore, from crimps and pimps, from the bars and brothels that marked the inland limits penetrated by jack-tars crossing from the tall ships that carried the wealth that made New York a financial and cultural capital of the world. It has been 25 years since the institute left South Street, and even then the waterfront street was a boulevard of obsolescence.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND Baseball American League

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; Agencies Hope Books Help Their Images
description: FROM the time he began drawing cartoons as a teen-ager, John Emmerling wondered how the mind and body conspired to make ideas a reality. Later, running his own advertising agency, he thought he could help other business executives harness their own creativity. So he wrote a book, "It Only Takes One: How to Create the Right Idea and Then Make It Happen," which Simon & Schuster will publish later this month.

title: Instant-Replay Rule Costs Kite As Price Wins Nelson Classic
description: Nick Price's first victory in eight years on the American pro golf tour was upstaged today by the initial application of golf's instant-replay rule.

title: New Rule Reduces Swiss Banking Secrecy
description: With little home-grown enthusiasm Switzerland has bent to pressure from the United States and the European Community and opened a new hole in the wall of secrecy that for generations has been its principal attraction as a banking center.

title: Sound-Bite Job Search For Riley and Knicks
description: The more Pat Riley talks, the more he sounds seriously interested in coaching the Knicks.

title: The Pains Are Sharp In Hungary
description: Like other Hungarian companies doing business with the Soviet Union, BEAG, a small concern that produces audio systems and recording equipment, was braced for bad news this year. But it was not prepared for the disaster that struck in January when the Soviet Union's state television and radio system suddenly canceled its contract, saying it had no money.

title: Johnson's Triple-Double Puts Warriors Down, 1-0
description: Magic Johnson had 21 points, 17 assists and 10 rebounds tonight, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 126-116 victory over the Golden State Warriors in the opener of their second-round Western Conference playoff series.

title: Suzanne Vine Marries
description: Suzanne Ellen Vine, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwood Vine of Trenton, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Peter Adam Drucker, the son of Lenore Paddock of Montville, N.J., and Daniel Drucker of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Morton Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Mountain Lakes House. The bride, 31 years old, is keeping her name. She is a Legal Aid Society lawyer in Brooklyn. She graduated from Harvard University and received a law degree from Rutgers University. The bridegroom, 28, is a Deputy Attorney General in Newark. He is a graduate of Columbia University and received a law degree from Rutgers.

title: Decline in Taxi Ridership Has to Do With Decline in Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Perils on the Mountaintop
description: President Bush's irregular heartbeat may not be tied to the pressures of his job and those he visits on himself. But the news that he suffered atrial fibrillation while jogging near Camp David surely serves as a reminder of the uncertainties of life, not least life at the top of the mountain.

title: A New Magazine for U.S. School Leaders
description: Members of Congress, business executives and Government officials will soon be reading a magazine from a publisher that many may not have seen since their grade-school days.

title: Entry-Level Jobs Remain Out There
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Home Offers Refuge From Danger of Lead Paint
description: Felisa Whitfield and her daughters moved into the three-story brick building on Steuben Avenue in the Bronx on Friday, finding a haven from the insidious ravages of invisible lead-paint particles that have contaminated their house.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * David Marans and Alice Sylvester have been named senior vice presidents at J. Walter Thompson Co.* Sally Spooner, Janet Kraus, Dannielle Colliver and Robert Chimbel have been named senior vice presidents at Ayer Inc.

title: More Reports Of Sununu Trips
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and his family have taken several skiing trips and one trip home to New Hampshire that were financed in large part by corporate interests, Time magazine has reported.

title: Susan Brune Weds Carl Loewenson Jr.
description: Susan Elizabeth Brune, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Brune Jr. of Louisville, Ky., was married in New York yesterday to Carl Hanline Loewenson Jr., the son Diane F. Rossheim of Philadelphia and Mr. Loewenson of Elkins Park, Pa. Judge Whitman Knapp of Federal District Court in New York performed the ceremony at Marymount School.

title: Texas Dome: Haven or Hazard? - A Special Report; Site for Toxic-Waste Cave Stirs Texas Political Fight
description: Here on the verdant coastal lowlands of Texas, a little-known company is pursuing one of the most risky, politically sensitive and potentially lucrative goals in American business today -- a permit from Federal and state authorities to build a huge hazardous-waste disposal site.

title: A Tide of Anxiety Over Rabies Sweeps the New York Region
description: For the first time in decades, a strain of rabies that is a danger to people is moving across a broad swath of New York City suburbs, and health officials say the disease is headed toward the parks, streets and sewers of the city itself.

title: Poorer New York School Districts Challenging State Aid as Unequal
description: Just a few miles from this Suffolk County community, there are public-school districts that spent more than $17,000 for each student last year, with schools that boast of computers in every classroom and a vast array of extracurricular programs.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Pet Inc., a grocery manufacturer whose brands include Progresso Italian foods, to the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles for all media planning and buying. D.M.B. & B. already handled Pet's creative assignment, with billings estimated at $45 million. Media planning and buying had been handled since 1973 by the Haworth Group, Minnetonka, Minn.* Doubletree, a chain of hotels in the southwestern United States, to Ayer Inc. with a budget estimated at $10 million. Canadian Pacific Hotels and Resorts, which acquired Doubletree last year, has had its account at McKim Advertising, Ayer's Canadian agency, since 1916.

title: Schwarzkopf Conquers 28,000 at Homecoming
description: As Air Force jets roared overhead and daytime fireworks by Walt Disney World showered the afternoon sky, 28,380 fans smiled down on Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf in Tampa Stadium today and almost had to wonder: What could he do for an encore?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS France Beats Australia Fabrice Santoro, an 18-year-old newcomer to the French Davis Cup team, surprised Wally Masur in the deciding match yesterday in Nimes, France, as the French team moved into the semifinals with a 3-2 victory over Australia. (AP) Rain Halts Seles-Graf Final: Monica Seles saved two match points and forced Steffi Graf into a third set before rain halted the final of the German Open in Hamburg. The match between the two top female players in the world will resume today. (AP) Arrese Defeats Filippini in Madrid: Jordi Arrese of Spain served his way to a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay in the final of the Villa de Madrid tournament in Spain. (AP) Agassi Connects: Top-seeded Andre Agassi defeated David Wheaton, 7-6, 6-1, to win his third consecutive A.T.& T. Challenge. Agassi earned $100,000, while Wheaton, seeded sixth, took home $50,000 after the three-day round-robin event at Horseshoe Bend Country Club in Roswell, Ga. (AP) Reneberg Gets First Title: Top-seeded Richey Reneberg won his first pro title with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory over fourth-seeded Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia in the United States Tennis Association Clay Courts of Tampa, Fla.(AP) SOCCER U.S. Beats Uruguay Peter Vermes took a cross from Chris Henderson and cracked a volley past goalkeeper Fernando Alvez in the 26th minute to lead the United States to a 1-0 victory over the national team of Uruguay in Denver yesterday. The victory was the first for Bora Milutinovic, the new coach of the United States team. Milutinovic coached Costa Rica during the 1990 World Cup and led Mexico in the 1986 World Cup. A crowd of 35,772 attended the match in Mile High Stadium. Uruguay was missing most of its starters, who are playing with clubs in the Italian League, which has two weeks remaining. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Fastest Time in 400 Ivan Jeanmarie, a senior at Prospect Heights High School, ran in the open division 400 meters in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress meet at Randalls Island and won the event in a swift 46.58 seconds, the fastest time in the metropolitan area this season for school boys. Then Jeanmarie came back later and won the high school 200 meters in 21.34 seconds. Frank Mensah of Boys and Girls in Brooklyn won the 110 hurdles in 14.71 seconds and the 400 hurdles in 54.45 seconds. Nathalie Jones of John Jay won the girls 200 meters (25.24 seconds) and 400 meters (57.14 seconds). In open competition, Mike Pascuzzo of the New York Athletic Club leaped 7 feet 5 inches in the high jump and Pamela Simmons of Bronx Express took the women's 400 dash in 56.40 seconds and the 400 hurdles in 62.8 seconds. Navy Captures Men's Title: Navy took the men's team title in the Heptagonal championships in Princeton, N.J., but Cornell and Brown battled for the women's title down to the final event. The Navy men were led by Anthony Terrell, who won the long jump and triple jump, and Brian Proctor, who won both sprints. Meet records were broken by Terrence Ferguson of Brown, with 7-4 1/4 in the high jump, Kevin McGuire of Princeton, with 16-9 1/2 in the pole vault, and Nick Sweeney of Harvard, with 189-8. The women's competition featured Brown's sprinter-hurdler corps, led by Teri Smith and Susan Smith, versus Cornell's middle-distance stars, Stephanie Best, Jennifer Cobb and Pam Hunt. Between them they finished first in every running event today. In the final event, Brown needed to win the 4 by 400-meter relay and beat Cornell by at least three places. Brown won, but Cornell, with Best running an unaccustomed 400-meter relay leg, finished second and captured the team title.

title: 2 Shot to Death in L.I. Fast-Food Restaurant
description: The manager and the cook of a fast-food restaurant were shot and killed during a robbery Saturday night in Rockville Centre, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: Mother Nature Calls the Game
description: News item: Fog at Shea Stadium halts game for 1 hour 38 minutes, and ultimately forces the chief umpire to call it.

title: Dance in Review
description: Lori Belilove, Deborah Carr and Nancy Zendora Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church 152 West 66th Street

title: So 'Dallas' Is Finally Over. Or Is It?
description: After 13 years and 356 episodes of infidelity, scheming and double-dealing, CBS 's longtime hit series "Dallas" turned its much-awaited finale into yet another finagle.

title: INSIDE
description: Delays in Aid Endangering Bangladesh Survivors For many of the 10 million people displaced by the cyclone that devastated Bangladesh, help continues to be slow. Relief officials and doctors warned that many could die soon on remote islands awaiting aid. Page A7. Fireworks for Schwarzkopf From war hero to full-fledged media phenomenon in two weeks: A celebration in Tampa, Fla., was just the latest round of fanfare for Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. Page A10.

title: Producing N.F.L. Rivalries With an Eye to the Fan
description: How sweet it would be for New York fans, say, to see the Giants and the Jets in the same National Football League division, playing twice a year. Or the two Florida teams, Tampa Bay and Miami, mixing it up in the Sunshine State. COMMISSIONER PAUL TAGLIABUE reports that an expansion committee is considering realigning divisions along logical geographical lines.

title: Mariners Overcome the Yankees, 5-4, in 16 Innings
description: The Yankees, after wasting leads in the seventh inning, the 12th and the 16th, finally were beaten by Seattle tonight when Greg Briley hit a two-run homer off Rich Monteleone in the bottom of the 16th to give the Mariners a 5-4 victory.

title: U.S. GENERALS SEEK BIGGER IRAQ HAVEN
description: Senior American military commanders here said today that they wanted to extend the allied safe-haven area in northern Iraq to include the city of Dohuk in an effort to draw hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees down from their perilous mountain camps.

title: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week includes bills, notes and bonds, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills totaling $17.2 billion.

title: Barbershop Singing Thrives in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracy Berliner Weds Robert L. Silverschotz
description: Tracy L. Berliner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Berliner of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Louis Silverschotz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford B. Silverschotz of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Avram Arian officiated at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Iraq Christian Minority Begins to Look for Door
description: In the northern Iraqi town of Dohuk the other day, three middle-aged women, enveloped from head to toe in long black veils, did something that is very unusual in this part of the world.

title: Bridge
description: Two of the best raconteurs the game has ever known are retired national tournament directors who are also old friends. One is Jerry Machlin of Silver Spring, Md., who is not totally retired; three weeks ago he was in Prague, Czechoslovakia, where he directed the Prague Cup. The other is Harry Goldwater, who celebrates his 90th birthday today at his home in Manhattan.

title: Auctions Expected to Draw Buyers
description: The credit markets face a record volume of Treasury debt issues at the quarterly refunding auctions this week, but analysts expect the sales to attract buyers because of the recent rise in yields.

title: A Rich Old Age?
description: As a septuagenarian, I have been following the national debate about Social Security benefits with considerable interest. Is there any truth to the charge that we senior citizens are grabbing more than our share of the national treasure at the expense of our children and grandchildren?

title: Carnegie Celebrates 100 Years and Itself
description: With bouquets and bunting, great performers and a starry audience and the glare of television lighting, Carnegie Hall gave itself a big-time 100th birthday party yesterday.

title: Sears Is Urged to Study a Revamping
description: Robert Monks, a dissident shareholder who is battling to become a director of Sears, Roebuck & Company, says the company should hire an independent Wall Street firm to determine whether shareholders would benefit if Sears was carved into four companies: the Sears retail stores, the Dean Witter Reynolds brokerage, the Coldwell Banker real estate operation, and the Allstate insurance company.

title: Japan Shouldn't Cut Off North Korean Trade; Accept the Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Eldridge, a Producer, Is Wed
description: Emily Eldridge, a daughter of New York City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge and the late Dr. Lawrence Eldridge, was married last evening to Michael Silberman, the son of Leona Nevler and James Silberman, both of New York. Rabbi Rachel Cowan performed the ceremony at Tavern on the Green.

title: Dinkins Seeks Ways to Save Some Services
description: Having proposed budget cuts that would darken New York City's streets and dry up its swimming pools, Mayor David N. Dinkins will embark this week on negotiations with municipal unions and state officials intended to avoid such severe service cuts and to preserve the city's traditional broad-shouldered mission.

title: On Amazon Frontier, Brazil Keeps Cholera at Bay
description: In this garrison town on the upper reaches of the Amazon River, Brazil appears to be winning the first round in a battle against a deadly invader: cholera.

title: Anna Rosen Weds Dr. Jonathan Rosen
description: Anna Beth Rosen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Rosen of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Dr. Jonathan Minder Rosen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert P. Rosen of Fair Lawn, N.J. The families are not related. Rabbi Marc Margolius, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actress MARIEL HEMINGWAY and her husband, STEVE CRISMAN, are involved in many businesses across the nation. Now they are facing a peril of entrepreneurship. The couple and Mr. Crisman's brother, Eric, are all being sued in Federal Court in Manhattan for securities fraud. The two men are also being charged with embezzlement in a civil action.

title: James M. McDonough, Surgeon, 57
description: Dr. James M. McDonough, an orthopedic surgeon in Morris Plains, N.J., for 25 years, died on Thursday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Morris Plains.

title: Amy J. Cogan Marries Gamiel Avram Ramson
description: Amy Jocelyn Cogan, a daughter of Florence Cogan of Plainview, L.I., and Bernard Cogan of Tallahassee, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Gamiel Avram Ramson, a son of Elaine S. Dinerman of New York and Murray Ramson of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El.

title: Rona M. Wittels and Jack Wenik Are Married
description: Rona Marla Wittels and Jack Wenik, assistant United States attorneys in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Stanley Steinhart.

title: Lorraine E. Levitt and Eric S. Katz Are Married
description: Dr. Lorraine Elizabeth Levitt, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Levitt of Fairfield, Conn., was married in Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday to Eric Samuel Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Katz of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Israel C. Stein performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom.

title: Ms. Young Wed To J. B. Talman
description: Nancy Young, a daughter of Dr. Everett M. Young of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Renee Young, was married yesterday at her father's home to Jeffrey B. Talman, the son of Nancy Henry of Pulaski, Tenn., and Wesley F. Talman of Asheville, N.C. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Atlantic County, N.J., is offering $41.47 million in utility-authority solid waste bond anticipation notes, due on May 1, 1992, at 100, through Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: Dalton and Bronx Students Win National Chess Contest
description: For the seventh consecutive year, a team from the Dalton School in Manhattan has won the primary division of the national elementary chess championship. And a student from the Bronx has won in the elementary division.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. RICHARD K. LIEBERMAN, a historian and the director of the archives at LaGuardia Community College, is ecstatic about his latest acquisition, the memorabilia of three generations of Wagners: Senator Robert F. Wagner, the New Dealer; his son, New York's 102d mayor, Robert F. Wagner, and his grandson, ROBERT F. WAGNER, a former deputy mayor and president of the Board of Education.

title: Japan Shouldn't Cut Off North Korean Trade; Threat Remains Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Babbin Weds
description: Jennifer Ann Babbin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm J. Babbin of Riverdale, the Bronx, and William M. Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Clark of Clarklake, Mich., were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel. Mrs. Clark, 29 years old, is an associate at the Boston law firm of Sullivan & Worcester. She is a magna cum laude graduate of Brandeis University. She and her husband, 30, received law degrees in 1986 from Boston University. The bridegroom is an associate at the Law Offices of Thomas S. Francis in Boston. He is a cum laude graduate of the University of Michigan.

title: Question Box
description: No Scoreless Innings

title: Ferguson Looking To Barcelona
description: It's similar to diving off a three-story building. After taking off from the 10-meter platform, KENT FERGUSON was traveling 30 miles an hour when he hit the water and dislocated his left shoulder in 1988. His chance for Olympic glory that year, in Seoul, South Korea, where GREG LOUGANIS swept the 3-meter and 10-meter events for the United States, drifted away.

title: VIOLENCE FOLLOWS POLICE SHOOTING
description: At least two dozen people, ten of them police officers, were injured tonight and six vehicles were burned in a street melee that broke out in Washington's Hispanic section after officers shot a man they said was resisting arrest.

title: Summer's Game and the Ties That Bind
description: Henry Payano, age 10, took a seat in the bleachers at George Washington High School among a cluster of teen-age girls who all knew him and couldn't stop hugging and kissing him.

title: Japan Shouldn't Cut Off North Korean Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss King Weds B. A. Estupinan
description: Barbara King, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent F. King of Southampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to Bernardo Augusto Estupinan Gaisbauer, a son of Dr. Leonardo Estupinan of Quito, Ecuador, and Munich, Germany, and the late Lydia Gaisbauer de Estupinan. Msgr. Edmond J. Trench and the Rev. Manuel Quesada performed the ceremony at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Wilder Cancels at Bridgeport Day Before He Was to Speak
description: The University of Bridgeport in Connecticut, besieged by a yearlong faculty strike and financial problems, held its graduation exercises yesterday -- but its featured speaker and honorary degree recipient stayed home in Virginia.

title: Backward With Baker
description: The ancient Hebrew word sachel means "understanding"; in Yiddish, the same word (rhymes with playful , with a throat-clearing sound in the middle) has a more practical, less profound meaning: "common sense," a feel for the way human beings react.

title: Honoring a Lifelong Love Affair With Dance
description: Louise Roberts was 18 when she fulfilled a childhood dream and returned to dance classes. Short and compactly built, she was ignored by the ballet teacher until one day, in the midst of a deep back-bend to the floor, she heard the woman announce, "Look, it can move."

title: New Zealand Is First In Second Fleet Race
description: New Zealand took early control to win the second fleet race of the World Championship Regatta today, finishing ahead of the Italian boats, which finished 1-2 in the opening race.

title: Review/Theater; A.R. Gurney's Expanded View Of Old Boys and Their Milieu
description: The title of A. R. Gurney's entertaining new play at the Playwrights Horizons Studio Theater, "The Old Boy," could also serve as the title of such past Gurney comedies as "The Dining Room," "The Cocktail Hour" and "Love Letters." In this prolific writer's accounts of the upper-middle-class precincts of Northeastern WASP-dom, the men are almost always boys who have not grown up and do not really have to. Fortified by privilege and gin, they sail through life via the old-boy network that assures them entry to the right schools, the right clubs, the right firms.

title: The Possibility of Quayle
description: The concern about President Bush's health has touched off talk about whether he should pick a new running mate for 1992. Page B8.

title: Dance in Review
description: Twyla Tharp American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Shengli Journal; China Is Learning English and Finds It a Mouthful
description: It was time for a pronunciation drill in Chen Xinyu's first-year English class, so the 45 junior-high students sat back on their wooden benches and gazed toward Ms. Chen and the blackboard.

title: Critic's Notebook; Documentaries That Lean Left
description: The Committee on Media Integrity is the newest member of the cottage industry that specializes in attacks on what it deems the left-wing propensities of television, in this case public television. It is run by David Horowitz and Peter Collier, who were partners in radicalism in the 1960's and have since found the light. Although their current ideological preferences (close to those of Ronald Reagan) peek through their avowals of desiring nothing more than "balanced and responsibly reported programming," their description of the leftward bent of public broadcasting documentaries has enough truth to invite discussion.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDY WILLIAMS, the 60-year-old singer known for his rendition of "Moon River," married Debbie Hass, 36, on Friday night, The Associated Press reported.

title: 'To See Oursels . . .'
description: The American press takes pride in courageous scrutiny of those who hold power in our society. Today the press should be summoning up the courage to look at itself.

title: Tartikoff's TV Valedictory: It's Tougher Now Than Ever
description: NBC was still the No. 1 network last week when the chief architect of its six years of prime-time leadership, Brandon Tartikoff, announced that he was leaving network television to run a movie studio.

title: White House in Shift on Job Relief
description: The White House, in offering enticements to win approval for trade legislation it sorely wants, has abandoned a position that has been held dear by the Bush Administration -- and earlier by the Reagan Administration. It has also revived a debate over whether the Government should give special help to workers who lose their jobs because of competition from imports.

title: Market Place; Investing in Farm Biotechnology
description: THE argument for investing in the small group of agricultural biotechnology companies working on pesticides is unusually compelling. Farmers have to do something to control insect pests, weeds and fungi, but environmental regulators are making it harder and harder to use chemicals. What better tactic than using genetic engineering and other biotech weapons to arm plants with more biopesticides, the very micro-organisms they have used for self-defense for millions of years?

title: Summers Game and the Ties That Bind
description: Henry Payano, age 10, took a seat in the bleachers at George Washington High School among a cluster of teen-age girls who all knew him and couldn't stop hugging and kissing him.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Can Products Be Marketed On TV Networks Alone?
description: JERRY SOLOMON runs the Busch Media Group in New York, which buys national television and radio commercial time for Anheuser-Busch, and he doesn't like to complain, but his job keeps getting tougher.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on April 24 about cooking classes referred incorrectly to the Mary Beth Clark Cooking School. It has not closed; it continues to offer classes.

title: British Publisher Enters the U.S., Forgoing Its Past Noms de Plume
description: After more than 15 years of conceiving, editing and producing books for Alfred A. Knopf, Random House, Little, Brown and other publishers, Dorling Kindersley Ltd. of London has decided to publish books under its own name in the United States.

title: Norway Again Debates European Membership, Rekindling Old Hostilities
description: When voters in Norway narrowly decided in 1972 to stay out of the European Community, siding with Sweden, Finland and their other neutral neighbors, the debate inflamed the nation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Economic Memo; Consumers Are Willing but Weak
description: With surveys showing a sharp rebound in consumer confidence after the Persian Gulf war, one might assume that it would not be long before the economy itself started to pull out of recession. The nation's households, after all, account for two-thirds of economic activity -- half of this at retail counters and half in paying for things like sailing lessons, subway tokens, boarding-school tuition and the monthly mortgage.

title: Books of The Times; Early Assessment of How the Gulf War Was Won
description: The Commanders By Bob Woodward Illustrated. 398 pages. Simon & Schuster.

title: Regulator Raises Lights, Finding Critics All Over
description: Like the industry that he oversees, Robert L. Clarke has been having a troubled time. In recent months, the nation's senior regulator of nationally chartered banks has been squirming from one crisis to another.

title: Time Is Running Out for Survivors As Bangladesh Airdrops Go Awry
description: Steady rain and inadequate transportation upset distribution of relief supplies today to an estimated 10 million people displaced by the cyclone that devastated the coast of Bangladesh. Relief officials and doctors warned that many could die soon on remote islands awaiting aid.

title: Gun Control's Red Herring
description: The National Rifle Association hopes to head off passage of a sensible new gun law by persuading Congress to adopt an unrealistic substitute. Lawmakers who value their credibility on crime control won't be fooled.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on April 10 about the rise of warehouse shopping clubs misstated the corporate affiliation of Costco Wholesale Corporation. Costco is an independent corporation wholly owned by its shareholders.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 5: 1991: MONDAY Cooper Tire & Rubber Gen Mtrs Corp Jefferson Pilot Corp Lockheed Louisiana Pac Corp Rohm & Haas Co Source Cap Inc

title: Decline in Taxi Ridership Has to Do With Decline in Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Don't worry about me." -- President Bush. [ B8:1. ]

title: Should Have Been In Baseball
description: GORDIE HOWE started playing in the National Hockey League in 1946 and stopped playing after the Beatles did. Now he is suing the league over what he claims is an unfair distribution of pension funds.

title: A Draft Bargain for Jets Now Competes for Time
description: Blaise Bryant remembers the first time he made a big impression on somebody because of his name. It was back at Cyprus High School in his hometown, Huntington Beach, Calif., and it wasn't related to football.

title: No False Modesty For Henderson
description: RICKEY HENDERSON became the Tarzan in all of us, standing triumphantly at third base and beating his gums instead of his chest.

title: Penguins, Led by Lemieux, Cut Bruin Edge to 2-1
description: Mario Lemieux scored on a breakaway and set up another goal as the Pittsburgh Penguins scored a 4-1 victory over Boston tonight that cut the Bruins' lead to 2-1 in the Wales Conference finals.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Creative Group Chief Leaves BBDO for Chiat
description: Richard Sabean, whose work at BBDO most recently included the "You got the right one baby, uh-huh" campaign for Diet Pepsi, has left the agency to become vice president and associate creative director at Chiat/ Day/Mojo, New York.

title: Shearson Plan for Insurer
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers is negotiating with California insurance regulators, trying to head off a potential failure of the First Capital Life Insurance Company, which has more investments in "junk bonds" than any other insurer still operating, people who have been briefed on the talks said yesterday.

title: Keeping the News in Step: Are the Pentagon's Gulf War Rules Here to Stay?
description: Midway through the air war against Iraq, two words began to reappear in the press, spooking White House aides with ghosts from conflicts past: "credibility gap."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Last Wednesday GERTRUDE HIMMELFARB, the historian, gave the Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities at the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington. Tomorrow she will deliver it again at the New York Public Library. Being chosen to give the lecture, which has a $10,000 honorarium, is the Government's highest honor for achievement in the humanities.

title: Democrats Seek Higher Tax for Richer Americans
description: Reviving the debate over which party stands for fairer tax policy, four senior Democrats today proposed raising taxes for the wealthiest Americans and cutting them for everyone else.

title: INSIDE
description: Complaints Preceded Crash On a Los Angeles Runway

title: Stay In or Get Out of Iraq?
description: How does one make sense of the conflicting news from Iraq? Down south, in the demilitarized zone on Kuwait's frontier, withdrawing allied forces yesterday formally handed over command to United Nations peacekeepers. Meanwhile, up north, also yesterday, U.S. commanders urged that safe-haven areas for Kurdish refugees be extended, all the way to Dohuk, a big provincial city 50 miles within Iraq. Americans may justifiably wonder whether President Bush's victorious coalition is heading into, or out of, a quagmire.

title: Mentor Picks Executive To Develop Circuit Unit
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation yesterday named John B. Wise, a former technical executive of the Unisys Corporation, to be president of its integrated circuit business. Mr. Wise joined Mentor, which is based in Wilsonville, Ore., in February as vice president for corporate engineering.

title: Cuts by Michigan Papers
description: The Daily Tribune of Royal Oak and The Macomb Daily in Mount Clemens, two daily newspapers in the Detroit suburbs, said today they would drop the Saturday issuess and expand their joint Sunday issue. The Adams Publishing Corporation, which owns both newspapers, said the change would take place next weekend. Officials said that Saturday papers were not as well read, and the move would allow them to include more local news in the combined Sunday paper, which is called Suburban Sunday, and deliver it earlier in the day.

title: Patterns
description: Going Public

title: Fashion's New Star: The Properly Dressed Leg
description: Karl Lagerfeld showed almost his entire fall collection in Paris over tights and jump suits made of what looked like molten gold. He found a winning formula. With it he attracted the best reaction ever for the collection he designs under his own name.

title: More Tarpley Problems
description: ROY TARPLEY, a 7-foot forward for the Dallas Mavericks, was arrested in Houston Sunday and charged with misdemeanor assault in the beating of a woman who claims to be his girlfriend. He was released from the City Jail on $500 bond. The police said there was no indication of alcohol or drug use by Tarpley, who is a two-time offender of the National Basketball Association's anti-drug program. If convicted on the assault charge, he could face up to one year in jail and a $2,000 fine.(AP)

title: Review/Television; Sex Abuse Charges Disrupt a Small Town
description: Goodbye Twin Peaks. Hello, Edenton. "Innocence Lost," tonight's absorbing and troubling report from the wishfully named North Carolina coast town of 6,000, digs into the fears and weaknesses behind the golf and horseback riding, the cocktail parties and churchgoing that make small-town life seem so quietly inviting. The title of the two-hour edition of "Frontline," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, refers less to the scores of children between the ages of 2 and 5 who their parents and the District Attorney say were sexually abused than to the town itself.

title: Cost Is Put in the Millions For Computer Gun Check
description: The Congressional Budget Office says it would cost Federal and state governments hundreds of millions of dollars to establish automated criminal-background checks for prospective gun purchasers.

title: A Writer and Political Aide Guiding WNYC in 'Tough Times'
description: It was just a year ago that Thomas B. Morgan shot to the top, an ascension that gave him two overviews. One was of City Hall, which is catty-corner to the Municipal Building, where he sits in the ornate tower that is the nesting place of the WNYC Communications Group. The other was of the broadcasting operation from the chair of the president, a position given him by Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Foyt Gets Clearance For Another Indy 500
description: A. J. FOYT, who sustained severe leg and foot injuries in a crash at Elkart Lake, Wis., last fall, yesterday passed a physical examination and was cleared to begin practice for the Indianapolis 500 race on May 26. He must, however, undergo periodic re-examinations before race day. In the event he is not able to drive in the race, he has said he would offer his car to AL UNSER SR., the only other driver to win four times at Indianapolis. Foyt, 56 years old, who limps and still feels pain, has said this race at Indianapolis, his 34th, will be his last. (AP)

title: Off-Duty Officer Held in Assault That Left Man Dead in the Village
description: An off-duty police officer who is a Golden Gloves boxing champion was charged with assault after a street scuffle over a traffic dispute left a pedestrian dead in Greenwich Village Saturday night, the police said.

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime; The Survivor's Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Easy Road to a Map
description: MANY businesses and government agencies need to create maps. A map might show sales figures in Western Europe, country by country, or the number of registered voters in southern California, county by county. But not everyone wants to learn a complicated computer program for mapmaking.

title: Safer Firefighter
description: A new fire-extinguishing chemical has been shown to be less destructive to the earth's protective ozone layer than two compounds now in use, researchers say.

title: Cheers and Jeers Await Strawberry's First Return to Shea
description: The Mets, focused on the long season that stretches out in front of them, have nonetheless each kept an eye on the calendar countdown to May 7. And though they are chiefly concerned with their own statistics and the final results of their own games, the Mets have quietly but steadfastly kept abreast of Darryl Strawberry's fortunes with the Dodgers.

title: Kremlin Transfers Coal Mines To Control of Russian Republic
description: The Soviet Government transferred control of the Siberian coal industry to the Russian republic today, marking a milestone in Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign to wrest economic and political authority from the Kremlin.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan misstated the charge on which her father, former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was hanged in 1979. The charge was conspiracy to murder a political opponent, not treason.

title: A.I.D. Is Criticized on Population Control
description: The Agency for International Development, a primary force in shaping the world's favorable attitude toward population control, is now in disarray on population matters, a private organization says in a new report.

title: Q&A
description: Jumping Chinese

title: Topics of The Times; Unusual Taxis (2)
description: Two Manhattan women were among the thousands of grumbling fans who poured out of Madison Square Garden last week after the Knicks lost their final playoff game to the Chicago Bulls. When they spotted a cab on 31st Street from which two passengers were disembarking, they rushed to grab it.

title: In the Turkish Mountains, U.S. Hears an Echo: 'Lead Us to Dohuk'
description: Dohuk is important to Lazden Doski and about 90 percent of the 40,000 other refugees camped in the slopes and valleys of southeastern Turkey. It is their former home, lying just south of the security zone carved out of northern Iraq by American, British, French and other Western troops.

title: 'Will Rogers' and 'Saigon' Top Tony Race
description: "The Will Rogers Follies," the last show to open on Broadway this season, and "Miss Saigon," the most publicized extravaganza of this or perhaps any season, came in first in the Tony Award nominations derby yesterday with 11 each, including nods for best musical.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Jewish children who survived World War II because they were hidden by friends misidentified a woman who is organizing a conference of such survivors in New York City. She is Rochel Berman.

title: With Rookie Award Won, Marketing of Coleman Begins
description: Despite all the losses and the empty seats this season at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, people still noticed: The Nets' Derrick Coleman could play basketball better than any other rookie in the National Basketball Association.

title: Music in Review
description: Isaac Stern, Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax Carnegie Hall

title: CHRONICLE
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN was perhaps one of the few musicians in the world who was not playing at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. Instead, he was in Jerusalem, getting and giving. He got the 1991 Wolf Foundation Prize for Arts, worth $100,000, The Associated Press reported. And he gave some advice to Parliament, urging Israel to make peace with Palestinians seeking their own homeland.

title: Woman at Window Is Shot
description: A 19-year-old woman washing the dinner dishes Sunday night was struck by a bullet that whizzed through an open window in her fifth-floor Brooklyn apartment.

title: Cultural Olympics in Greece Urged by Greek King for '96
description: Herodotus, the fifth-century B.C. historian of the Persian Wars, once recited a chapter of his famous chronicle at an Olympics festival, and a movement is under way to restore that kind of class, if not Classicism, to the modern Olympics in Greece.

title: Stralsund Journal; Winds Feel Fair Again for Unsinkable Baltic City
description: A brisk wind blew through the streets of this stately Baltic port as Peter Schneider, a raconteur and former theater director, shared a local secret.

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Picassos Stolen In Czechoslovakia
description: Thieves broke into the Czechoslovak National Gallery through a glass door early Monday and stole four paintings by Picasso.

title: Dinkins Asks Stations To Air Budget Speech
description: To explain his approach to the city's fiscal problems, Mayor David N. Dinkins will deliver a half-hour speech from City Hall tomorrow night, which he has asked local television stations to carry live at 7:30.

title: Man Is Killed by Falling Tree
description: A man was killed when the tree he was cutting fell on his head, the police reported today. Troopers discovered the body of the man, Elmer Taylor, 41 years old, of Canandaigua, when they went to his summer cottage to investigate a missing person's report filed by the victim's family. Mr. Taylor was using two chain saws to cut down the tree at his cottage along Lake Ontario, 20 miles east of Rochester. His body was discovered beneath the tree he was cutting. He had been struck in the head by a branch.

title: 5 Books Banned in Indonesia
description: Indonesia banned a calendar illustrated with political cartoons today, along with five books on politics and religion, and said it would maintain its ban on foreign travel for 17,000 dissidents. The calendar and books were banned because the Government feared they could cause public unrest, the Attorney General's office said. Two of the banned books criticized Government actions in 1989 clashes between soldiers and Muslim militants, which left 38 people dead by official count.

title: New View of Fantasy: Much Is Found Perverse
description: THERAPISTS who once viewed perverse sexual fantasies as the furtive compulsions of a lonely minority are seeing them in a new light, as more and more "normal" people report them in therapy and new studies suggest that even violent fantasies are surprisingly common.

title: Finally, Mariners' Martinez Making a Name for Himself
description: If October, as it is said, belongs to hitters like Reggie Jackson, than who gets to lay claim to the other months that dot baseball's calendar?

title: In the War on Cancer, A New Kind of Weapon
description: SCIENTISTS have begun to develop a new generation of drugs that they hope will in time do for cancer what penicillin did for infections. The first few of these drugs have glided through laboratory and animal tests and are now being tested in patients.

title: California Said to Bar Insurer Aid
description: Negotiations between executives of Shearson Lehman Brothers and California insurance regulators broke down yesterday, as an effort to avert a potential failure of the First Capital Life Insurance Company grew more intense, people who have been briefed on the talks said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE A.T.& T.-NCR DEAL

title: Occidental Selling Half Of Gas Unit
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a half interest in its natural gas liquids business to a Texas investment company in a two-step deal for $600 million.

title: Prognosis for President Concerns Some Doctors
description: Doctors found cause for elation and concern today as President Bush's heartbeat finally settled into a normal pattern after two long episodes of atrial fibrillation.

title: Hurdler Suspended
description: LAVONNA MARTIN, the top-ranked American woman's 100-meter hurdler last year, was suspended for two years yesterday by T.A.C. But the organization labeled her an "innoncent victim" of her coach and recommended she apply for early reinstatement.

title: Cheney, in Riyadh, Appeals For the Right to Store Arms
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived here today and proposed that the United States store military equipment in Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations and conduct regular exercises in the region.

title: Sony Picks Burnett for Consumer Products
description: THE Sony Corporation of America has seen the future of its advertising communications for the 1990's, and it's a lot like the past. Yesterday, the electronics giant decided once again to consolidate ad work for its consumer products group at a single agency with a global reach.

title: Lawmaker Is Target on Gun Issue
description: Wallace Coon came to Representative Les AuCoin's town hall meeting carrying copies of National Rifle Association magazines in which he had highlighted articles about gun control legislation with a neon orange marker.

title: Bridge
description: It is, in theory, impossible to be in two places at the same time, but 20-year-old Brad Moss of Manhattan made a valiant effort over the weekend. He is a member of the United States team scheduled to compete in the World Junior Championships in Ann Arbor, Mich., in August, and was required to take part in a three-day team practice in Dallas beginning on Friday. But he also needed to be in Manhattan Saturday and Sunday for Grand National knockout team play: He was part of a foursome that had eliminated a top-seeded group of national champions in an earlier round.

title: Pistons-Celtics Series Is Becoming a Tradition
description: Once again, the Detroit Pistons are colliding with Celtic tradition.

title: TEHERAN COURTING WESTERN EUROPE
description: The slogan at Teheran's main airport that was coined by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini proclaims "No East, No West," meaning that revolutionary Iran does not need either. A parade of Western European ministers trooping by it on their way to town these days seems to offer a different message.

title: Judge Drops Charges In Death of Dog
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday dropped all charges against the Transit Authority in the death of a stray dog hit by a subway train on the Upper West Side on March 13.

title: 2 Koreas Field Joint Sports Team, First in Decades
description: By the time the world table tennis championships ended here this afternoon, all the Korean competitors had been eliminated. But there was an unmistakable flush of satisfaction among the team's officials: They had succeeded in establishing a beachhead of good will between the cold war's harshest remaining foes by fielding, for the first time, a joint South Korean-North Korean team.

title: Bethlehem Steel Unit Is Being Sold
description: TMB Industries, an investment company, said it and the Onex Corporation iin Toronto had agreed to buy the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's freight-car unit for an undisclosed price. The operation, based in Johnstown, Pa., makes all types of freight cars except tank cars. Its sales totaled about $200 million last year.

title: Cornell Names Coach
description: JAN VAN BREDA KOLFF, who played professionally for nine years with the New Jersey Nets, the Denver Nuggets and the Kentucky Colonels, yesterday was named head coach at Cornell University. He succeeds MIKE DEMENT, who resigned on April 1 to become coach at North Carolina-Greensboro. Van Breda Kolff's father, Butch, is coach at Hofstra.(AP)

title: Reynolds Goes to Court
description: Olympic medalist BUTCH REYNOLDS, banned from competition for two years because of a positive drug test, yesterday asked a Federal appeals court to allow him to resume his track career.

title: A New York Constitutional Convention Could Cut Huge Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Sallie Mae Prices Short-Term Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes due Nov. 14, 1991, at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: U.S. Denies That It Donated Shoddy Blankets to Teheran
description: The United States today denied Iranian accusations that it had sent used blankets to help Iraqi refugees in Iran.

title: Seminary President Installed
description: The Rev. Dr. Barbara Brown Zikmund has been installed as president of Hartford Seminary, making her the first woman to preside over an interdenominational seminary in North America. Dr. Brown Zikmund, 51 years old, an ordained minister, had been president of the seminary for 10 months. Her installation was postponed until Sunday because spring is the traditional time for the ceremony, the seminary said. The Christian seminary has made special efforts over the years to develop communications with other faiths, the new president said.

title: Cartel Inquiry by Europeans
description: The European Commission's new cartel office started investigations today into ties between leading companies in Europe's car and packaging industries.

title: Pepsi Plans Campaign On 'Chill Out' Theme
description: This summer, as Coca-Cola pitches hot pop music, Pepsi-Cola will chill out.

title: Shevardnadze Appeal
description: On a visit to Washington, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed for new food credits to the Soviet Union, saying the fate of democratic change could be at stake. Another visitor, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, offered the opposite advice.

title: An Oceanic Indication That Earth's Climate Might Regulate Itself
description: DOES the earth's climate regulate itself, enabling global temperatures to stay within certain broad limits?

title: BAKER TO RESUME MISSION IN MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that he would return to the Middle East this week because, with another diplomatic push, it might be possible to get the Arabs and Israelis to agree to attend a peace conference.

title: GAF Subsidiary To Offer Shares
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that its newly formed subsidiary, International Specialty Products Inc., had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 17.4 million common shares, or 17.8 percent of its common stock, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Small-Business Ownership Poll
description: Despite an increase recently in the number of women who own businesses, most small businesses formed in the 1980's were owned by middle-aged men, a survey released today said.

title: Bacteria Tied to Stomach CancerWASHINGTON, May 6
description: Bacteria that infect about 30 percent of Americans may play a major role in the development of stomach cancer, a report by Stanford University researchers suggests.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM, GOVERNING COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Judge Tells Con Man To Avoid Playwright
description: A convicted con artist who inspired the play "Six Degrees of Separation," was ordered yesterday to stay away from the playwright John Guare after complaints that he had threatened Mr. Guare's life.

title: 443 Nonpaying Parents Held In Sweep for Child Support
description: A statewide sweep to collect millions of dollars in overdue child support payments today netted more than 400 delinquent fathers and mothers owing nearly $2 million.

title: Jail Agency's Contract Criticized
description: New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman yesterday criticized city jail officials for awarding a $250,000 management consultant contract to a company that she said had limited expertise and charged more than twice as much as a rival.

title: M.B.A.'s Told To Look Into 'Green' Jobs
description: WITH jobs harder to find for new M.B.A.'s, placement directors work harder to find spots for them, and some are looking at environmental organizations.

title: U.P.I. Closing Base in Chicago
description: United Press International said today that it was closing the Chicago base of its national broadcast news wire, dismissing the eight employees who ran it and moving the operation to its Washington headquarters.

title: Chucky Mullins, 21; Paralyzed in Game
description: Chucky Mullins, the University of Mississippi football player who was paralyzed after making a tackle in a game two years ago, died today. He was 21 years old.

title: AID TO BANGLADESH IS STILL HAMPERED
description: Survivors of last week's cyclone in Bangladesh are suffering from a lack of food and clean water, and many could die of disease, the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies said today.

title: To Cantonese, A Little Graft Is Forgivable
description: Lei Yu charges into the room, his extraordinary energy a fitting reflection of one of China's fastest-changing cities.

title: Our Towns
description: When Robert Fishwick left his home here for work Jan. 10, he was a regular county Parks Ranger. Today, he still is. And that's why he's become the focus of an unusual legal dispute pitting New York and the Federal Government against Suffolk County.

title: She Won't Give Up on a Place Called Home
description: New Yorkers will put up with a lot to hold onto a rent-controlled apartment, but Dalma De La Rosa turned that ordinary struggle into a crusade.

title: Dow Gains 2.78 on a Day of Light Trading
description: Wall Street showed little reaction yesterday to President Bush's heart problem. In the first day of trading since the President suffered an irregular heartbeat while jogging on Saturday, the Dow Jones industrial average bounced back from a fairly small decline and ended the day at 2,941.64, up 2.78.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Pathe Owner Is Pressed To Sell Stake in Studio
description: Giancarlo Parretti, who acquired MGM/ UA last year, is being forced by a lender to sell a large stake in the troubled studio or lose ownership control, Mr. Parretti's company, the Pathe Communications Corporation, said in Government documents released today. He was ousted as chairman last month.

title: Heart Controlled, Bush Returns to Work
description: President Bush returned to work at the White House today after almost 40 hours in Bethesda Naval Hospital, his erratic heartbeat apparently brought under control by two drugs.

title: Redistricting Oddities Reflect Racial and Ethnic Politics
description: If City Councilman Samuel Horwitz wanted to travel the length of his new Brooklyn district without leaving it, according to one proposed version of the district, he would have to make his way for nearly two miles along the Coney Island Boardwalk.

title: U.S. REPORT FINDS COSTS WERE HIDDEN AT AN ARMS PLANT
description: The companies that operate the Savannah River nuclear weapon plant in South Carolina hid huge cost overruns by unlawfully transferring tens of millions of dollars in and out of a $400 million account meant for new construction, the Energy Department's inspector general has reported.

title: Standing Squarely for Dissent at The Nation
