description: To the Editor:

title: Music in Review
description: The Madrigals of Love and War Measured Breaths Theater Company Gene Frankel Theater 29 Bond Street Manhattan

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL Continental Basketball Association OKLAHOMA CITY CAVALRY -- Named Henry Bibby coach. COLLEGE AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL -- Named Denise Taylor women's basketball coach.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, part of the Chronicle column was omitted from some copies yesterday. Readers wishing copies of the complete column may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arby's Inc., Atlanta, named a new executive management team. It includes: Leo Johnson senior vice president for finance; Joe Langteau senior vice president for operations; Barry Russo senior vice president for marketing, and Gaylon Smith senior vice president for franchising. * Marsh & McLennan Companies, New York, named Joel Hirsch chairman and Claude Y. Mercier president of Seabury & Smith Inc., a subsidiary.

title: Schwarzkopf Chooses An Agent
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander during the Persian Gulf war, has selected Marvin Josephson to represent him in negotiations for book and television projects. Mr. Josephson is the chairman of Josephson International Inc., which owns International Creative Management, the literary agency, and International Creative Management Artists, Ltd., a leading classical music talent agency.

title: Landlords Plan To File Lawsuit On Rent Control
description: New York City's largest landlords' association said it will file a suit today to lift rent controls on the city's most expensive rent-controlled apartments.

title: Yanks Save Some Time, but the Result Is the Same
description: For an encore, the Yankees played only nine innings tonight. Same result, though.

title: Bill Rates Are Lowest Since '87
description: Prices of Treasury securities were unchanged to slightly higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers bided their time in advance of the start of record quarterly refunding auctions, which begin today.

title: Big Deal That Poses Little Threat
description: The acquisition of NCR finally seems to give A.T.& T. the chance for success in the computer business that it has long craved. With its huge size, vast telephone network and the technological resources of its Bell Laboratories, A.T.& T. would seem to have the potential to become one of the successful information technology companies of the next century.

title: Bang on a Can Festival Shifts 2 Performances
description: The performances in the Bang on a Can Festival that were to take place at the RAPP Arts Center have been moved to two other theaters.

title: Margaret Tallichet Wyler, Actress, 77
description: Margaret Tallichet Wyler, who appeared in films including "It Started With Eve," "Every Man for Himself" and "Stranger on the Third Floor," died on Friday. She was 77 years old.

title: Schwarzkopf to Capitol Hill
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf war, will address a joint meeting of the House and Senate to honor him on Wednesday, Congressional leaders said today. General Schwarzkopf, who returned from Saudi Arabia last month, was honored at a ceremony on Sunday in Tampa, Fla., where his Central Command headquarters stands.

title: A.T.&T. Buying Computer Maker In Stock Deal Worth $7.4 Billion
description: After more than five months of stubborn resistance, NCR agreed yesterday to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock.

title: Jesse Siff, Economist, 67
description: Jesse Siff, chief economist for Lehman Brothers from 1954 to 1972, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Douglas Damrosch, 76, Medical Administrator
description: Dr. Douglas Stanton Damrosch, a physician and medical administrator, died on Sunday at a health center in Ellsworth, Me. He was 76 years old and lived in Blue Hill, Me.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a seizure of pirated videocassettes misstated Robert M. Morgenthau's title. He is the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: Dykstra and Daulton Injured in Car Accident
description: Lenny Dykstra slammed his new red sports car into two trees while driving home from a bachelor party early this morning, causing multiple injuries to himself and Philadelphia Phillies teammate Darren Daulton, the authorities said today.

title: Space Shuttle Diverts To a Landing in Florida
description: After a last-minute diversion from its normal landing site, the space shuttle Discovery touched down here this afternoon, ending an eight-day mission devoted to "Star Wars" research.

title: Coffee Shop Dispute Ends in Fatal Gunfire
description: A dispute that began in a Brooklyn coffee shop and spilled into the street erupted in gunfire that killed one man and wounded three others yesterday, the police said.

title: Knicks Can Scratch Moe (He's Having Too Much Fun!)
description: Doug Moe said yesterday that he was not interested in coaching the Knicks.

title: Pirates Top Reds, 3-1, Behind Palacios
description: Vicente Palacios gave up one run in seven-plus innings -- Eric Davis's homer -- and Bobby Bonilla drove in two runs as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 3-1, tonight.

title: NCR Acquisition Is Giving Wall Street Millions in Fees
description: The multibillion-dollar acquisition of NCR by A.T.& T. is bringing a welcome stream of tens of millions of dollars in fees to Wall Street, which has been struggling with a dearth of deals since the collapse of the "junk bond" market.

title: Excerpts From Medical Assessment on Bush
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Dr. Burton J. Lee 3d, physician to the President, Dr. Bruce K. Lloyd 3d and Dr. Allan M. Ross at a news conference yesterday morning in Bethesda Naval Hospital: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Relations Require 2 Parties, China Tells Visiting U.S. Aide
description: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen told the highest-ranking American official to visit China in more than a year today that improving relations could not be done by one side alone, the official New China News Agency said.

title: DEMOCRATIC GROUP ARGUES OVER GOALS
description: Striving to present their philosophy as the best way for Democrats to recapture the White House in 1992, members of a conservative wing of the Democratic Party struggled today to redefine the party amid signs of growing tension with more traditional party members.

title: New Battle Opens Today On Smog In the East
description: When smog descends on the Eastern Seaboard, it respects neither state lines nor the boundaries of nature preserves and parks, fouling the air above cities, villages and even the coast of Maine.

title: The Best Of Enemies
description: Gorbachev's nemesis, Gorbachev's archenemy, Gorbachev's archrival -- these are the epithets plastered over the politically and otherwise broad face of Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Republic. Tactically, these epithets are correct; strategically, they are superficial. The Gorbachev-Yeltsin phenomenon is multidimensional, and if we go to its heart we will find that Mr. Yeltsin is Mikhail Gorbachev's secret weapon, the indispensable condition of his survival.

title: Stolen-Property Charge for New York Officer
description: A suspended New York City police sergeant, who already faces a charge of attempted murder in Suffolk County, was arrested in Jersey City yesterday and charged with driving a car with stolen license plates and having five stolen credit cards and a fake police badge, the police said.

title: Genetics Institute In New Offering
description: INVESTING in a young and still unprofitable technology company is always betting on the future. But in the case of a new stock offering by Genetics Institute Inc., a Cambridge, Mass., biotechnology company, investors are also being encouraged to forget troubles in the recent past.

title: A Comic-Strip Ad Tries To Lobby the President
description: Some corporations seek influence in the capital by hiring smooth-talking retired Administration officials and former members of Congress to lobby their former colleagues. Many companies join trade associations, which produce long studies to advance their interests.

title: New Dance Myths Cut From the Everyday
description: Outside the studio windows, the sunny street echoes to the blare of traffic, which sounds almost cheerful as it roars down Broadway through SoHo. Inside, seven dancers move through a dark and gritty vision of Hades. Body crashes into body. Bodies balance cantilevered against each other. There is an odd look of suspension, as if the dancers are riding the wind or hanging and turning loosely in it. Yet there is something very everyday and ordinary about it all. When the studio telephone rings, it might be part of the dance.

title: Surprising North Stars Thrash Oilers, Lead Series by 2-1
description: Minnesota's minor miracle grew a little larger and a lot louder tonight when the North Stars defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 7-3, in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Share prices fell moderately today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei average of 225 selected issues lost 135.72 points, or 0.51 percent, and closed the afternoon trading session at 26,342.14. Japan's financial markets were closed on Friday and Monday for national holidays. On Thursday, the average fell 11.14 points, or 0.04 percent.

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Stops Seles Now that she is ranked No. 2, Steffi Graf is rediscovering the shots that once made her No. 1 -- at least against Monica Seles. Yesterday, Graf completed a rain-delayed 7-5, 6-7, 6-3 victory over the top-ranked Seles in the final of the women's German Open in Hamburg. "This win was very important for my confidence, especially before the French Open," Graf said after winning her second title of the year. Seles upset Graf last year in the final here, ending Graf's 66-match winning streak. (AP)

title: The Recreation Director
description: IN the litter alongside the Harlem River Drive, the armory on West 143d Street resembles a red-brick fortress from another era. But inside, it's now a city shelter for homeless men. Behind green-metal lockers, rows of beds fill the old wooden floor. Some of the 500 men are asleep, a few with blankets pulled up over their heads. Most of the others, while waiting for their dinner to be trucked in, cluster in their worn clothes, watching television.

title: Chaim Gross, 87, Wood Sculptor Of Exuberant Human Forms, Dies
description: Chaim Gross, a master wood sculptor and teacher of his centuries-old art form, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chrysler Officer Is Injured
description: Robert Lutz, president of the Chrysler Corporation, was treated for minor injuries after his helicopter crashed between airport runways Sunday as he tried to land it.

title: Recovery Awaits Housing Revival
description: AS the recession enters its 10th month, all eyes are on home construction. When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, talks of a recovery, he is counting on new-home construction, particularly the building of single-family houses, to give the economy its first lift. Other economists share his view that without the stimulus of home building, the recession could drag on.

title: Shevardnadze Asks U.S. Food Credits
description: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, appealed to the Bush Administration today to extend new food credits to the Soviet Union, asserting that the fate of democratic change in Moscow may be at stake.

title: Global Treasure Hunt
description: SCHOOL is nearing adjournment for the summer, and some parents have asked about computer programs that might compete with Nintendo or Ninja Turtles for the attention of America's future leaders.

title: Limits Expected on Lead in Water
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to announce strict limits on lead in drinking water that could require several thousand suppliers to replace old pipes.

title: Liverpool Loses; Arsenal Gets Title
description: Arsenal captured its second English League title in three years today when Nottingham Forest beat Liverpool, 2-1.

title: Dennis M. Crosby, 56, Nightclub Performer
description: Dennis M. Crosby, one of Bing Crosby's twin sons by his first marriage, was found dead in his home on Saturday. He was 56 years old.

title: Key Rates
The Blue Grass Factor In Winning the Derby
description: "The key," said trainer Nick Zito, "was running in the Blue Grass. That's the key: coming here."

title: Another Yankee Manager Is in Peril. Sound Familiar?
description: He is not the first manager to go through this, but Stump Merrill has already begun to look like most of his Yankee predecessors: beleaguered and beaten with each mounting loss, growing older by the day and wary that somehow George Steinbrenner is about to pounce again.

title: A Top Post for a Quota-Beating Salesman
description: Gilbert P. Williamson, a career NCR employee whose record as a top salesman propelled his ascent to the presidency of the company, will become its chief executive once A.T.& T. completes its acquisition.

title: When Derby Sportscasters Also Own Horses
description: A few minutes into the pre-race programming for the Kentucky Derby on Saturday came a reminder that ABC apparently doesn't mind a helping of conflict of interest when it involves star announcers Jim McKay and Al Michaels.

title: Observer; Making President Quayle
description: Suppose Vice President Quayle never really wanted to be President. There are plenty of people who don't, including some politicians.

title: On My Mind; A Chance for Quayle
description: Beginning pretty soon, Vice President Quayle will have to start fighting for his job, which will be a good thing for the country and for him.

title: Gorbachev Warns Against Chill in Ties
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has warned Washington that a new cold war could emerge if the Bush Administration continues to pursue political and economic steps that appear to undermine the Soviet Government, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: U.S. and France Finally Agree In Long Feud on AIDS Virus
description: The question of who first isolated the AIDS virus, a subject of heated debate between researchers in France and America for more than six years, may have been at least partly resolved today.

title: Cuomo Turns From Fencing To Courting Fiscal Aid to City
description: After weeks of fencing publicly with Mayor David N. Dinkins and city labor leaders, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo began a quiet but intense campaign late last week to rally support among labor leaders and state legislators to avert a fiscal crisis in New York City.

title: Syria Advises Lebanese Guerrillas To Hold Out Till Israel Quits Zone
description: Syria, the main foreign power broker here, says guerrillas fighting Israel should not lay down their weapons under a Lebanese Government plan for disarming all militias until Israel evacuates what it calls its security zone in southern Lebanon.

title: Japanese Criticized by Chip Makers
description: As Administration negotiators near a trade agreement with Japan on computer chips, Sematech officials said today that American chip makers faced long delays, or higher prices, in trying to buy advanced equipment from five Japanese companies.

title: Critic's Notebook; Feminine Beauty as a Masculine Plot
description: One of the most astute and troubling feminist observations I can recall leaped out of the least likely place: a movie about an aircraft carrier caught in a time warp. When the ship went spiraling from the 1980's back to 1941, there was the film's token woman, Katharine Ross as a senator's beautiful, brilliant speech writer. "I've spent a lot of time trying to hide the way I look, hoping to be recognized for my abilities," she confessed to a man from the future, who asked, "How's it going so far?"

title: Smithsonian Board Backs National Black Museum
description: The Smithsonian board of regents unanimously approved the establishment of a National African-American Museum today. The museum would be on the Mall and administered by the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Clothing Gifts to Charities May Not Reach Needy
description: Faded jeans and outmoded shirts tossed into collection bins bearing the names of churches and charities will probably never wind up directly clothing the needy.

title: A.T.&T. Buying Computer Maker In Stock Deal Worth $7.4 Billion
description: After more than five months of stubborn resistance, NCR agreed yesterday to be acquired by A.T.& T. for $7.4 billion worth of A.T.& T. stock.

title: Apple Ready to Introduce Delayed Macintosh System
description: System 7, the long-awaited upgrading of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, is scheduled to be introduced next Monday.

title: Cadillac's Bid to Recapture Youth
description: After a decade of sluggish sales and new-product disappointments like the Cimarron and the Allante, Cadillac is putting the final touches on a redesigned Seville, the latest attempt to get the prestige division of General Motors back into the luxury car ball game where the Japanese are the new stars.

title: Saab Cash Infusion
description: The Swedish auto maker Saab Automobile, which is owned by Saab-Scania A.B. and the General Motors Corporation, needs six billion krona, or about $9.7 million, in capital, Saab-Scania's new president, Lars Kylberg, said. The figure was based on a report by J. P. Morgan & Company, the American investment firm, he said. Mr. Kylberg said most of the infusion would be in cash, to strengthen the Saab unit's balance sheet and to finance investments over six years.

title: What if We Outgrow Our Environment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Platinum Rise Tied to Fears On South Africa and Soviets
description: Fears that unrest in the Soviet Union and South Africa could interrupt the supply of platinum sent the futures price for the metal sharply higher yesterday.

title: How to End Our Fiscal Follies
description: New York City comes to its annual budget checkup bleeding from a $4 billion deficit and a national recession. While we rush to stop the hemorrhaging, we must not neglect less visible threats to our long-term survival. Neither the end of the recession nor the resolution of our present crisis will restore New York City to full fiscal health.

title: Fiery Debate at Redistricting Forum
description: The panel drawing the maps for 51 new City Council districts in New York was told last night that it was "racist," "silly," "immoral" and "malicious" -- and that was just for the 10 Manhattan districts -- during a spirited hearing at City Hall.

title: Shareholders at Sears Sue to Delay Meeting
description: A group of shareholders sought today to postpone Thursday's annual meeting of Sears, Roebuck & Company, accusing the retailer of failing to disclose critical financial and legal information.

title: Music in Review
description: Joseph Smith Pianist Alice Tully Hall

title: Iraqis Withdrawing From Kurdish City, U.S. Says
description: The State Department said today that Iraqi forces were withdrawing from Dohuk, a major Kurdish city in northern Iraq, but that no decision had been made on whether to push the allied safe-haven zone into the city.

title: Pam Martin Sarnoff, Author, 61
description: Pam Martin Sarnoff, an author and a volunteer in charitable causes, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old.

title: Officers in Beating Case File 30 Pretrial Motions
description: A superior court judge today began to work his way through a four-foot stack of 30 legal motions that try to dismiss, delay, transfer or modify the case against four white police officers charged with assault in the videotaped beating of a black motorist.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Vitas Gerulaitis Sr. referred incorrectly to a tennis championship he won. It was the Baltic States championship.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Connecticut Health and Educational Facility Authority is offering $23.3 million in hospital revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum 6.65 percent for a bond due in 2006 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. Yields on shorter maturities range from 4.50 percent in 1992 to 6.30 percent in 2002. The bond issue is for a Stamford Hospital project and is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp., giving the securities a triple-A rating by both Moody's and S.&P. * Lee County, Fla., is offering $35.6 million in tax-exempt capital and transportation facilities revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum 6.90 percent for a bond due 2011 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Yields on shorter maturities range from 5.70 percent in 1996 to 6.20 percent in 2001 and 6.60 percent in 2005. The financing is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.&P. * Whirlpool Corp., Benton Harbor, Mich., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities and warrants through Goldman, Sachs & Co. COMMON STOCK * Pier 1 Imports Inc., Fort Worth, has filed for a public offering of nine million common shares through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.

title: Books of The Times; On a Scale From the Fantastical to the Mundane
description: The Voice of America Stories By Rick DeMarinis 215 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Experts Race to Save Dwindling Rhinos
description: FOR tens of millions of years, the rhinoceros has rumbled across the world's landscapes. Squat, muscular, thick-legged and broad-chested, it is the very embodiment of raw animal power.

title: Loss at TV Broadcaster
description: Pinelands Inc., the parent company of the television station WWOR, said today that it lost $2.1 million in the first quarter despite a 5.8 percent increase in revenues. WWOR is an independent station broadcasting in the New York City area. Pinelands said its revenues in the three months that ended on March 31 were $34.3 million. In the first quarter of 1990 the company had a loss of $685,000 on revenues of $32.4 million. Provisions for income taxes and increased operating expenses were blamed for the higher loss.

title: Soviet Talks On Helicopters
description: Aerospatiale of France and M.B.B., a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, said today that they had held talks with manufacturers in the Soviet Union about the possibility of cooperating in building nonmilitary helicopters.

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime; 'I Live With the Guilt'
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal Access? Not at This Court
description: The Supreme Court, the one in Washington with "Equal Justice Under Law" carved in marble at its entrance, is finding new ways to slam its doors on poor people. It declared the other day that henceforth petitioners who submit "frivolous or malicious" petitions would be denied the privilege of filing them free even if they were too poor to pay court costs. The announced purpose is to relieve the Court of burdens caused by "those who would abuse the integrity of our process."

title: Iraq, Citing Need to Rebuild, Asks U.N. for Reprieve on Reparations
description: In a letter to the Secretary General, Iraq has asked for a five-year delay on paying war reparations so that it can focus on rebuilding its shattered economy. Paying the reparations out of current oil revenues was one of the conditions Iraq agreed to in exchange for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Drackett Shifts Windex From Grey to Laurence
description: The Drackett Company, a division of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, said yesterday that it had moved its Windex glass cleaner account from Grey Advertising to Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What has 99 sides and is located in the Bronx? The new 17th Council District." -- Borough President Fernando Ferrer. [ B1:4. ]

title: Street Unrest Flares Again in Capital
description: Disturbances broke out Monday on the streets of a troubled Hispanic neighborhood for the second night, but they subsided this morning after Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon declared a state of emergency and imposed a curfew.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, two pictures yesterday carried misplaced captions in some copies.

title: By Design; Perky Pique
description: Have you thought about pique lately? It's enjoying a revival, especially in such 60's-inspired styles as sun dresses with bouffant skirts and A-line shifts.

title: Reagan Guest Stars Before the California Assembly
description: In his first appearance at the Capitol since his terms as California Governor, a nostalgic Ronald Reagan today stepped lightly over the state's budget deficit and instead celebrated the California that "encourages the dreamer in us all."

title: Newly Confident Hussein Takes Show on the Road
description: After waving silently for several minutes to an enthusiastic but organized crowd in the northern city of Mosul over the weekend, President Saddam Hussein performed his new trick.

title: Bani-Sadr, in U.S., Renews Charges of 1980 Deal
description: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the former President of Iran, is renewing his three-year-old charges that the Reagan campaign struck a deal with Teheran to delay the release of the hostages in 1980. The allegations have recently been given a fresh life by news articles in the United States.

title: Energy Service Hints at Plan To Sweeten Deal for Penrod
description: The Energy Service Company said yesterday that "it is willing to make one last attempt" to resolve differences with its partners in the Penrod Drilling Corporation and hinted at sweeteners it might offer for a friendly deal.

title: German Production Up
description: Industrial production in the former West Germany rose a provisional 1.2 percent in March from the previous month after a revised fall of 2 percent in February, the Economics Ministry said today. But the ministry said it expected a significant upward revision in the March data when final figures are released next month.

title: G.I.'s Leaving Iraq DMZ and Its Refugees Today
description: An empty cargo plane, its rear gate yawning in the heat, stood on the runway waiting for any last-minute refugees from Iraq. By 2 P.M., none had come down the road, so the black-and-green aircraft pirouetted slowly, rushed down the runway and was gone.

title: Split Stock Approved For USX
description: Shareholders of the USX Corporation approved a plan yesterday to separate the company's vast energy business from its steel operations by issuing new common stock linked to its steel business.

title: CHRONICLE
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II wanted to do more than just send a note. So she is coming in person to say thank you to PRESIDENT BUSH on her first official visit to the United States since 1983. She is to arrive in Washington next Tuesday.

title: Desoto Gets Offer From First Allied
description: Desoto Inc. said it had received a $6.25-a-share merger proposal from the First Allied Corporation, a holding company based in Boynton Beach, Fla. Desoto, a maker of consumer and industrial products that has been resisting a bid from the Sutton Holding Corporation, said the offer appeared to be all cash.

title: South African Pact Imperiled by New Violence
description: The peace accord achieved to great acclaim between the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party nearly 100 days ago has been pushed to the brink of collapse by continuing political violence that has already claimed more than 600 lives this year.

title: Productivity Down, Then Up, as U.S. Errs
description: In one of the most embarrassing statistical mistakes in recent memory, the Labor Department announced late today that American business productivity was up, not down, as it had said in the morning.

title: Music in Review
description: Manhattan Philharmonia Manhattan School of Music 120 Claremont Avenue

title: Regulators Are Faulted
description: Federal regulators missed warning signs in the late 1980's that the Bank of New England was on a reckless and ultimately fatal lending binge, according to testimony at a Senate hearing today.

title: Keep the Peace in Lebanon
description: Contrary to almost everyone's expectations, peace is taking root through much of Lebanon. That's worth celebrating. But big problems remain, and the United States has a role to play in resolving them.

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape, However, Is Not Like Any Other Crime; Let's Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: SRI LANKA BATTERS LAST REBEL GROUP
description: Using ground troops and planes, the Sri Lankan Army appears to be battering a thinly stretched Tamil guerrilla army all across the northern tier of this island nation.

title: Nycor to Keep Pressing Zenith
description: Nycor Inc., the largest shareholder of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, said it would press its effort to restructure the company despite failing to have its nominees elected to Zenith's board.

title: Federal Jury Begins Deliberations in Spira Case
description: George Steinbrenner set up Howard Spira and orchestrated the Federal extortion indictment against him in an attempt to avoid trouble in baseball, Spira's lawyer charged in his summation yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; Unusual Taxis (1)
description: Now plying the streets of New York City is a cab whose driver has a sign above his dashboard, just to the right of the rear-view mirror. This sign does not list the driver's allergies, nor does it list any demands upon his passengers. Instead it reads:

title: Turner Broadcasting Profit Fell 11.6% in First Quarter
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter of 1991 fell 11.6 percent because of slightly higher interest expenses.

title: Change at Top of Publishers Group
description: The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced today that Cathleen Black would leave her position as publisher of USA Today to become the association's president and chief executive.

title: Shoemaker Absolved
description: BILL SHOEMAKER, who retired as the winningest jockey in history, will not be prosecuted for driving under the influence of alcohol in a car accident that left him paralyzed, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office said yesterday.

title: Early Sibling Rivalry Among Spotted Hyenas
description: CARRYING sibling rivalry to an extreme, hour-old spotted hyenas routinely attack their younger siblings just moments after birth, University of California scientists say.

title: Eveready Says Coors Poached
description: The Eveready Battery Company and the Coors Brewing Company found themselves in a rabbit stew yesterday.

title: Dispute Delays Ireland Talks
description: A new round of Northern Ireland peace talks was postponed at the last minute because of a dispute over the site of future negotiations, British officials said today. Peter Brooke, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, was to have brought together political leaders for talks in Belfast on Tuesday, but officials here say the talks are being put off because of a dispute over the site of a June round of talks, which the Irish Republic is to join.

title: Bulls Fend Off 76ers, 112-100, to Take 2-0 Series Lead
description: Michael Jordan scored 29 points and Scottie Pippen added 21, but the Chicago Bulls had to put down a late surge by the Philadelphia 76ers tonight for a 112-100 victory.

title: Study of British Stockholders
description: The Conservative Government of Britain has had limited success in promoting a nation of stockholders. Although the number of Britons owning stock has nearly quadrupled since 1979, to 11.1 million people, or 25 percent of the adult population, the portion of shares owned by individuals has fallen steadily in recent years.

title: Textbooks Fall Behind Advances in Medicine
description: WHEN doctors seek guidance on new therapies and preventions, they reach for their professional bibles, the medical textbooks. But increasingly the texts are being criticized as out of date through failing to keep pace with the explosion of medical knowledge.

title: Old Friends Break Up: Trenton Democrats and Angry Unions
description: With his popularity already low, Gov. Jim Florio is being attacked by two important former allies: the statewide teachers association and the unions representing state workers.

title: LACROSSE: Notebook; 5 Teams Fret Over 3 Tournament Spots
description: There are 12 places to be filled in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's lacrosse tournament. The selection committee will have no trouble choosing the first nine teams.

title: Chess
description: The player who is off form is going to be picked on by his rivals. That is a fact of life in top echelon tournaments. And it does not matter who it happens to be: if it is a world champion, this is the time to score against him.

title: Wilfrid Hyde-White, 87, Actor Known for His Urbane Drollery
description: Wilfrid Hyde-White, the English actor who appeared in films including "My Fair Lady," "Ten Little Indians," "The Third Man" and "The Browning Version," died yesterday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Yugoslav Army Warns It Will Quell Unrest
description: The Yugoslav national army has warned that it will step in to restore order if civil authorities fail to stem a widening crisis that led to the killing today of a young military policeman during angry anti-army protests in the coastal city of Split.

title: Chlorine Fumes Rout Thousands in Nevada
description: A cloud of chlorine gas leaked from a chemical plant for seven hours today, forcing thousands of people to flee their houses and sending dozens to hospitals.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices Of Work Stations
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was reducing prices on its top work stations and increasing the performance of some software. I.B.M. said its primary work station competitors, Sun Microsystems Inc., the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, had made pricing and performance changes in recent months.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Systems Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a software maker, signed an agreement giving Lexmark International Inc., the former information products division of International Business Machines Corp., rights to Adobe's postscript language interpreter. * Alta Energy Corp., Midland, Tex., an oil and gas company, said a special board committee had decided to negotiate with Hartford Energy Corp., Alta's controlling stockholder, a business combination involving Hartford, its affiliates and Alta.

title: Complaints Preceded Airport Accident
description: Four days before two planes collided on a runway here in February, local Federal Aviation Administration officials sought the agency's "highest priority" for replacing faulty radar equipment meant to avoid such accidents.

title: New Ladenburg Team To Focus on Banking
description: While legislators and lobbyists in Washington are working on broad-based legislation that would change the banking industry, financiers on Wall Street are rubbing their hands in anticipation of the transactions they expect will soon follow.

title: Footnote in Dinkins's Plan: $1 Billion Property Tax Rise
description: Even as he proposes huge service cuts and tax increases to balance New York City's budget next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins is planning on the financial help of annual property tax increases in the years after that.

title: Elster to Be Examined
description: KEVIN ELSTER will still be examined today even though he reported less soreness from a strained left groin muscle suffered in the Mets' loss at Shea Stadium on Sunday, the Mets said. JAY HORWITZ, a Mets spokesman, said Elster's status is day-to-day, pending the examination.

title: Iacocca Is Offered, but Rejects, Heinz's Seat
description: Under pressure to appoint a strong Democrat to replace the late Senator John Heinz, the Governor of Pennsylvania offered the post to Lee A. Iacocca, a political independent. But Mr. Iacocca, who has never held political office and lives in a Detroit suburb, turned it down.

title: New York Bangladeshis Cry for a Battered Land
description: Mubashir Choudhury takes a break from his job at a Manhattan restaurant at least once a day to pray at the Madina Masjid, a small mosque on the corner of First Avenue and 11th Street. Usually, his thoughts focus on his love of God and his devotion to Islam.

title: Food Notes
description: Award for Greenmarket

title: 2d Arrest in Artist's Death Is Also Misdemeanor Charge
description: Friends of a young artist who died in a fistfight with an off-duty police officer and his companions in Greenwich Village Saturday night expressed outrage over the handling of the case yesterday and called for an independent investigation.

title: Tenneco Unit Fights Loss of Submarine Job
description: The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company said today that it had filed a lawsuit challenging its loss of a contract to build the Seawolf submarine.

title: Last G.I.'s Leave a Major Iraq-Kuwait Border Post
description: Two lime-green firetrucks from Ohio led the way out of southern Iraq for United States forces today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages on Monday detailing Pete Sampras's income from commercial endorsements misstated the amount he is paid by Ray- Ban. It is $200,000 over three years.

title: Sadie Daniels; Volunteer, 90
description: Sadie Daniels, for many years a leader in the Ladies Auxiliary of the Jewish War Veterans and a former president of the organization's New York State chapter, died on Monday at Long Beach Memorial Hospital on Long Island. She was 90 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: Key Rates
Fannie Mae Prices $900 Million Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association priced a $900 million debenture issue yesterday through its various securities dealers.

title: Chagall Murals Banned by Stalin Go on Exhibition in Switzerland
description: Banned by Stalin, hidden to protect them from destruction and neglected in the country where they were created 70 years ago, seven works from Marc Chagall's Russian period have finally been returned to public view.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Monday about families of baseball players at George Washington High School in Manhattan misidentified the team's center fielder, and the caption also misidentified his father, The player is Elvis Gomez; his father is Ramon Rodriguez.

title: Laissez-Faire Legacy on Jersey Shore: How Not to Do It
description: So intense and so haphazard is development along the Jersey Shore that it has become an example to other coastal states of what not to do.

title: Gruber on Disabled List
description: KELLY GRUBER , the third baseman for the Toronto Blue Jays, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to May 2. He had been bothered by a sprained ligament and a chip fracture in his right thumb, suffered during a rundown in a game against Texas last Thursday. . . . EDWIN NUNEZ , a right-handed relief pitcher with a 1-1 record, 3 saves and a 4.09 earned run average, will be lost to the Milwaukee Brewers for three or four months while he recuperates from surgery to repair a ruptured disk in his back. Nunez, who has been placed on the 60-day disabled list, will undergo the operation today at Sinai Samaritan Medical Center in Milwaukee. (AP)

title: Theater in Review
description: Pageant Blue Angel 323 West 44th

title: Comcast's $1.1 Billion Phone Deal
description: The Comcast Corporation, a cable television company that is expanding into the cellular telephone business, agreed yesterday to buy the Metromedia Company's cellular operations in Philadelphia for $1.1 billion.

title: In New York City, Officials Say Rules Mean Few Changes
description: For several years, officials in New York City have been aware of the potential for toxic lead to enter the water supply through pipes and plumbing fixtures.

title: Parcells Auditions for Future in TV
description: Bill Parcells, who has appeared uncertain about his future as coach of the Giants in the months following his second Super Bowl victory, took a step toward a new career recently by auditioning for an analyst's job at NBC Sports, said a person who has seen the audition tape.

title: Frederick G. Atkinson, Ex-Macy Executive, 86
description: Frederick Griswold Atkinson, a former vice president for personnel at R. H. Macy & Company, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: 2 Are Killed and 3 Injured As Van Swerves Into Traffic
description: Two people were killed and three injured when a van swerved into oncoming traffic yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: A Redistricting Puzzle: Just Where Is Harlem?
description: For most of this century, exactitude was of little concern when defining Harlem, a name that suggests a romantic past of speakeasies and literary salons but a more dreary present of poverty and crime. That was until the New York City Districting Commission began dividing the city into 51 Council districts.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Tony Gill, an associate creative director at Young & Rubicam Inc., has created a pro bono ad for A Partnership of Faith in New York City, a group of about 70 members of the clergy who are trying to encourage optimism about the city's future. The ad, which appears today on page B5 of The New York Times and is also to appear in The Daily News, New York Newsday and The New York Post, shows an apple core changing back into a whole apple.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Stocks Slump, With the Dow Sliding 24.15
description: Stocks slumped yesterday in the face of weakness in the bond market, which feared the sheer size of the Treasury's $37 billion bond refinancing. Program selling, particularly late in the day, contributed heavily to the decline.

title: A Singapore Nightclub Is Opening Off Broadway
description: Can a musical featuring Frank Sumatra (that's right, Frank Sumatra) make it big Off Broadway? Its producers are betting $950,000 it can.

title: Human Threat Ruled Out in Drug for Cows
description: A new Congressional report concludes that genetically engineered bovine growth hormone, which is being used to increase milk production in cows, poses no safety hazards to humans or to the animals in which it is injected.

title: Albert E. French, 81; Led Technical College
description: Albert E. French, a retired technical educator, died April 25 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 81 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: More Educated Officers Won't Mean Less Police Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Injury Sidelines Bird As Celtics Lose Opener
description: The first game of the Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series between the Boston Celtics and the Detroit Pistons got under way tonight with Larry Bird, Boston's star forward, missing from the lineup because of severe back spasms.

title: Paul J. Stapleton; F.B.I. Agent, 60
description: Paul J. Stapleton, a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 26 years and later vice president and director of security for Paine Webber, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: More Woe for Dinkins: Income-Tax Revenue Is Off
description: The Dinkins administration said yesterday that income-tax collections from April were running significantly below the city's already shrunken expectations in the crucial final weeks of the fiscal year.

title: FRANCE CONCEDES ITS FAULTS IN WAR
description: In the first public recognition by France that it was ill-prepared to fight the Persian Gulf war, Defense Minister Pierre Joxe conceded today that French forces were overwhelmingly dependent on military intelligence provided by the United States.

title: Italy Gives $17.5 Million for Academy at Columbia
description: In a rare partnership between a university and a foreign government, Columbia University and the Government of Italy yesterday announced the creation of a $17.5 million Italian Academy for Advanced Studies in America.

title: In Adversity, El Al Turns a Profit
description: Last August, when the Persian Gulf crisis erupted, Rafi Harlev, president of El Al Israel Airlines, decided to act quickly, knowing that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait meant hard times for his business.

title: Storm Over, Saudis Revert to Routine
description: The Persian Gulf war, which brought almost 700,000 troops from 37 countries to this desert kingdom along with thousands of planes and armored vehicles, has swept through Saudi Arabia like a giant winter sandstorm, with little discernible disruption or obvious effect.

title: From Florida, Tropical Food Worldly Enough For Your Home
description: EVERYONE has heard all the phrases: young American chefs, new American cooking, fresh local ingredients, regional style. Hardly a food story of the 80's went by without some such reference.

title: A Healthy Toon Sets Sights on '91 Season
description: Al Toon has returned. The small fracture in his back that he suffered early last season has healed. And he has recovered from the groin injury that kept him out of the Jets' last two games of the 1990 season.

title: The Double-Bogey Man
description: With polls indicating that of post-World War II vice presidents, he is the least credible to become President, Dan Quayle has long been a political disaster waiting to happen. Now George Bush's medical problems have focused the spotlight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dame MAGGIE SMITH was awarded the 1991 Shakespeare Prize for outstanding work in the arts from the FVS Foundation, based in Hamburg, Germany. The prize, about $17,500, was established in 1937 by a German philanthropist, Dr. ALFRED TOPFER , now 97 years old.

title: Lodestar in French Deal
description: The Lodestar Group, a New York investment bank, is forming an alliance with Societe Generale, France's largest private bank, in a move that points to the shift of the mergers business toward international deals. The agreement was announced earlier this week and requires Federal Reserve approval. The partnership would specialize in corporate finance advisory work, emphasizing on cross-border mergers, acquisitions and other deals.

title: Goodwin W. Gilson; Teacher, 72
description: Goodwin W. Gilson, a teacher in New York City for more than 40 years, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Eli Rabineau, 76, Dies; Westchester Architect
description: Eli Rabineau, an architect who designed buildings in Westchester County, died on April 27 at the North Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Maxwell Abramson, Disease Researcher, 55
description: Dr. Maxwell Abramson, chairman of the department of otolaryngology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died on Friday at Kona Hospital in Hawaii. He was 55 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Frenzy, and Plenty of Blood, In a One-Day Halibut Season
description: There are as many ways to catch fish as there are lies to tell about them, but none are stranger, more frenetic or less safe than the annual Alaska halibut derby, the Oklahoma land rush of commercial fishing.

title: Prague Errs on Law For Restitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Layoffs Expanded By Caterpillar
description: Caterpillar Inc. plans to shut down its factory in Aurora, Ill., for the week of July 8 because of slumping demand for heavy machinery. Similar cutbacks were recently announced at other Caterpillar factories in the Peoria area. A spokesman said the 2,500 workers at the Aurora plant would be temporarily laid off during the shutdown.

title: Strawberry's Favorite Path: All 4 Bases at Shea
description: There was a huge home run and a major disappointment. People will argue deep into the night about whether that isn't the story of Darryl Strawberry's entire career. There is no disputing that it was the story of his dramatic comeback to Shea Stadium.

title: Frank Tamagna, 81, Professor of Economics
description: Frank M. Tamagna, a former official of the Federal Reserve System and a professor emeritus of economics at American University in Washington, died on Sunday at the Washington Home. He was 81 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Yugoslav Army Puts Troops on Combat Alert as Ethnic Hostilities Mount
description: The Yugoslav Army put its troops on combat alert today and regrouped forces in several tense regions after a week of conflicts between Serbs and Croats, the two largest national groups, inflamed ethnic hostilities.

title: Hatcher Unsuccessful in Bid To Regain Mayoralty of Gary
description: Richard G. Hatcher, who was the Mayor of this economically troubled city along Lake Michigan for 20 years, was defeated today in his effort to regain the job. The city's incumbent Mayor, Thomas V. Barnes, easily won the Democratic nomination for a second term.

title: Fed Nominee Discusses Rate Cuts
description: Lawrence Lindsey, nominated to be a Federal Reserve Board governor, suggested to the Senate Banking Committee today that he would have cut interest rates more than the Fed did last fall. But he also endorsed the Fed's most recent rate cuts as adequate for the moment, and he hesitated to say the economy was now in recession.

title: Officer Dismissed and 3 Others Face Hearings in Motorist's Beating
description: Police Chief Daryl F. Gates today dismissed an officer involved in a videotaped beating of a black motorist two months ago and ordered three others to face a police trial board.

title: Abbott Mead Confirms A McCabe Investment
description: Speculation about start-up financing for Ed McCabe's new advertising agency has proved true: Abbott Mead Vickers P.L.C. is making an investment in McCabe & Company, New York.

title: A U.S. Clinic, Harassed, Withdraws From Iran
description: The only American charity operating inside Iran has withdrawn its seven-member medical team from a Kurdish refugee camp after harassment by Iranian officials, including one who threatened to shoot a nurse, the doctor who headed the team said today.

title: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall In Yield for the 10th Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts plunged in the week ended yesterday for the 10th consecutive decline.

title: 'Mistakes,' Says Hussein Aide
description: The Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, Tariq Aziz, said in an interview that the Government of President Saddam Hussein had made "mistakes" because it had been in power so long, The Washington Post reported today.

title: Rating 1,000 German Wines
description: IN Germany's cool and fickle northerly climate, splendid back-to-back vintages are rare. But the 1988 and 1989 harvests were excellent, and when Stuart Pigott saw that the 1990's were also outstanding, he checked historical records.

title: Ethiopia Peace Talks Planned
description: The Ethiopian Government and the three rebel groups fighting to unseat it have agreed to sit down together with the United States later this month for their first peace talks, officials said today. The peace conference, to be led by Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen, will be held in London in about two weeks, the officials said. It will focus on ending the civil war in Ethiopia, one of the world's poorest countries. The war has been raging in some areas of the country for 30 years.

title: Network Systems Buying Vitalink
description: The Network Systems Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Vitalink Communications Corporation for $10.50 a share, or about $146 million. Vitalink, based in Fremont, Calif., supplies systems that are used to build large computer networks. Network Systems makes high-performance data communications systems.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg Romps Top-ranked Stefan Edberg swept into the third round of the German Open yesterday in Hamburg, beating Alexander Mronz of Germany, 6-3, 6-1. Edberg, who had a bye in the first round, looked comfortable on the red clay court and Mronz could not cope with the Swede's aggressive net game. Juan Aguilera of Spain, a two-time winner of the German Open, was eliminated by Jordi Arrese, also of Spain, 6-2, 7-5. Yannick Noah beat Richard Fromberg of Australia, 7-6, 6-0, which is more than any of his French Davis Cup players did last weekend in France's victory over Australia. Noah was France's non-playing captain and Fromberg won both his singles before France won the series, 3-2. Franco Davin of Argentina moved into the second round with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over 11th-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador. (AP)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., named Gino J. Giocondi vice president-special projects. * Coltec Industries, New York, an automotive and aerospace manufacturing concern, named John W. Guffey Jr. president and chief operating officer.

title: BUSH'S PHYSICIANS SAY THYROID GLAND DISRUPTED HEART
description: An overactive thyroid that is easily treatable caused the irregular heartbeat that struck President Bush on Saturday and put him in a hospital for two nights, the President's physicians said today.

title: Air Traffic Controller Describes Actions That Led to Fatal Crash
description: An air traffic controller whose actions led to a fatal collision here on Feb. 1 described today how she confused two planes as they were preparing to take off and never realized that one had entered the runway where a third plane was about to land.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday headed "U.S. Vehicle Sales" misstated the sales of Subaru of America Inc. Subaru sold 9,898 domestic and imported cars in April 1991, an increase of 5.2 percent from the same month last year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Market Place; Blue-Chip Phase For Hostile Deals
description: THE merger deal finally reached on Monday between A.T.& T. and NCR illustrates the sea change that has occurred in takeovers in the last year, and may signal the beginning of a new stage in the business.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: LEAN, light chicken breasts are a summer favorite. They can be baked, sauteed, poached or grilled. Because of their neutral flavor, chicken breasts need substantial seasoning. This recipe calls for a Dijon mustard sauce, which can be made in minutes.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: THE Greeks stuff grape leaves, cook them and serve them cold as part of meze, their free-form before-the-meal meal. In Chile, grape leaves are stuffed with a beef, rice and cumin mixture and generally made large enough to be a main course. In many other countries, stuffed cabbage is a culinary staple.

title: Review/Salsa; Music to Be Enjoyed Live and Dancing
description: Given that mainstream pop, in its live forms, has pretty much given up its function as dance music, it's almost shocking to hear dance orchestras blasting through a performance. At the Village Gate on Monday, two world-class salsa orchestras from New York, Conjunto Clasico and Jose (El Canario) Alberto, produced exciting, barely controlled performances that kept a consistent intensity for a series of long pieces. Salsa, which relies on musicianship rather than spectacle for its excitement, is still a genre that is best appreciated in concert.

title: Review/Ballet; New Auroras and Princes In 'The Sleeping Beauty'
description: Was it harder to get into "Miss Saigon" or Peter Martins's controversial but fabulous staging of "The Sleeping Beauty" over the weekend? A ballet production that becomes a hot ticket is well within the New York City Ballet's tradition; one has only to utter the word "Nutcracker" to make the point.

title: Philharmonic Is Seeking $75 Million
description: The New York Philharmonic has begun what it described as the most ambitious fund-raising campaign in its history.

title: A Free-Emigration Bill Is Debated in Moscow
description: The Soviet national legislature moved today to enact an emigration bill that would lift decades of legal restrictions denying Soviet citizens the freedom to leave the country.

title: Miscellany
description: * Publicis-FCB, the European network partners of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, said it would acquire the Dutch communications group Overad B.V., which includes the Prad advertising agency, Amsterdam. Publicis-FCB, which intends to purchase all of Overad's shares, said 51.25 percent of Overad was previously controlled by British Lopex P.L.C., while the remainder was held by directors of various Overad organizations.

title: Latin Immigrants in Capital Find Unrest a Sad Tie to Past
description: With the smell of tear gas lingering in the air, Central American immigrants said today that the unrest in their neighborhoods was rooted in what they saw as brutality and discrimination by the Washington police and was an unwelcome reminder of the strife they thought they had left in their native lands.

title: Man Acquitted in Triple Murder
description: A Queens man who the police say heads a large, violent crack-trafficking ring was acquitted of charges yesterday that he had ordered the murders of three drug dealers in a plot to rob them of $200,000 worth of cocaine.

title: Democrat Session Previews '92 Race
description: A group of centrist and conservative Democrats approved a policy agenda here today intended to broaden their party's appeal to the middle class and distinguish themselves from traditional liberals.

title: James H. Nichols, 76, Minister and Historian
description: The Rev. Dr. James H. Nichols, a Presbyterian minister who was a church historian and religious educator, died on Friday at his home in Bedford, Mass. He was 76 years old.

title: Theater in Review
description: Moe Green Gets It in the Eye RAPP Arts Center 220 East Fourth Street. Through May 26

title: New York City Names A New Chief of Bridges
description: After vitriolic public debate over the safety of the city's long-neglected bridges, Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio yesterday announced the appointment of an experienced transportation official to head the bureau that oversees them.

title: Keep Meat and Dairy Products in Diet
description: To the Editor:

title:
Real Estate;
A Drab Hotel Is Rejuvenated in Manhattan
description: AFTER decades of decline, the Hotel Wales on Madison Avenue at 92d Street is near the end of a major restoration that is turning this 90-year-old institution into one of Manhattan's newest boutique hotels. It is being given a distinctly European flavor and a moderate price structure to compete in today's soft lodging market.

title: Black-Held Businesses In Sales Gain
description: The nation's largest black-owned companies, despite weakness in the economy, said they had a 5.2 increase in sales last year from the previous year, according to an annual survey being released today by Black Enterprise magazine. By contrast, the top 500 American companies listed by Fortune magazine showed a 1990 sales increase of 6.4 percent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THELMA GOLDEN is the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, a mid-Manhattan branch of the Upper East Side museum. Ms. Golden, who took over last Wednesday, replaces JOSEPHINE GEAR , who left the museum last February to work as a writer.

title: Wine Talk
description: PHYLLOXERA, a devastating plant louse, was first found in California, in a vineyard in northern Sonoma County, in 1873. This was six years after the organism, which ravaged the great vineyards of Europe and indeed of the rest of the world, was discovered in France.

title: Abrams, in Hindsight, Backs War
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams, a Senate candidate who had refused to say whether he would have voted to authorize the Persian Gulf war, said today that with "hindsight" the war was correct.

title: Polaroid Shows New Products
description: The Polaroid Corporation introduced three new products today.

title: Top U.S. Marketing Post Is Filled at Zenith Data
description: Zenith Data Systems yesterday named Michael J. Poehner as its executive vice president for North American sales and marketing, its top United States marketing job. Mr. Poehner, 44, now heads national sales and marketing for Businessland Inc., a national computer chain.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Browning-Ferris Inc. is offering $100 million in 9 1/4 percent noncabllable debentures, due in 2021, at 100 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Reclusive Building Union Chief Earned $412,000 in 1989
description: As negotiations were beginning last week between New York City apartment building owners and their striking employees, a union delegation left the meeting room on the 37th floor of a midtown hotel. A reporter and photographer approached a heavyset man wearing an open-collar shirt and dark sunglasses and asked if Gus Bevona, the union's president, was there.

title: Katya Alpert Gilden, Novelist, Is Dead at 72
description: Katya Alpert Gilden, who with her husband, Bert, wrote novels under the name of K. B. Gilden, died on Sunday at Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston. She was 72 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Benjamin Glass Dies; A Retired Justice, 79
description: Benjamin Glass, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and had moved to White Plains from Queens last year.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTING IN SOVIET CAUCASUS
description: Intense raids were reportedto be erupting along the Armenian-Azerbaijani border in a fierce flareup of the three-year-old feud between the neighboring republics.

title: Carlos Marquez Sterling; Cuban Statesman, 92
description: Carlos Marquez Sterling, a Cuban historian and statesman who led the drafting of the country's 1940 Constitution, died of heart failure on Friday. He was 92 years old.

title: Public Interest, Public Naming
description: The decision by Palm Beach police to recommend that criminal charges be filed in the alleged rape at the Kennedy estate will inevitably heighten the controversy over naming rape victims in the news. But the controversy goes too far when legislators in five states want to regulate news accounts to keep names out, as Florida already tries to. Even beyond constitutional questions, the law shouldn't impose a sweeping generality where room for judgment is needed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about stock market activity on Monday referred incorrectly to a comment by Charlotte Walker of Labe, Simpson & Company about a copyright suit involving Borland International and Lotus Development. She said she had downgraded her rating on Borland stock from a "buy" to a "hold" because of concern over the suit; she did not say she expected Borland to lose.

title: New Jersey Bank Losing Depositors
description: The Statewide Bancorporation of Toms River, N.J., which admitted that its capital was wiped out when it announced on Friday that it lost $168.5 million in 1990, is now struggling to keep the confidence of depositors.

title: Ailing Senator Wants to Leave Ethics Unit
description: Senator David H. Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who is recuperating from a heart attack, has asked to be replaced on the Senate Ethics Committee, a spokesman said today.

title: G.A.O. Job Study Expected To Fuel Trade-Pact Debate
description: A study by the General Accounting Office has found that employment in the Los Angeles furniture industry has dropped by as much as one-tenth in the last three years as companies have moved to Mexico in pursuit of lower wages and less stringent environmental laws.

title: A Union Agrees To a Times Plan To Reduce Staff
description: The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild reached an agreement yesterday in which the company will offer cash incentives to employees who are over age 55 with 15 years' experience and who agree to retire.

title: Kentucky Catches Itself
description: The University of Kentucky, which has just completed two years of National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions for recruiting violations and academic fraud, yesterday reported it had caught itself in another infraction and was turning itself in to the N.C.A.A.

title: Senior U.S. Official Visiting China to Mend Ties
description: A senior United States official said today that he had held candid discussions with Chinese officials about human rights, trade and weapons sales, in what appeared to be a stepped-up effort to mend Chinese-American relations.

title: U.S. Mandates Tests for Lead In Tap Water
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today directed 79,000 utilities, virtually all of the water suppliers in the United States, to test tap water in hundreds of thousands of homes as the first step in a new program to reduce concentrations of hazardous lead in drinking water.

title: Borg Comeback Stalled
description: BJORN BORG is taking his comeback bid back to the drawing board.

title: Magazine Publishers Toast A TBWA Ad for Absolut
description: WHEN the nation's magazine publishers gathered last night in New York to salute the best print advertising of 1990, the winner wore a familiar, though welcome, face.

title: Palm Beach Police Say They'll Seek a Rape Charge
description: The Palm Beach police said today that they would recommend to prosecutors that William Kennedy Smith be charged with the rape of a 29-year-old woman at his family's ocean-front estate here on March 30.

title: Arena Stage Receives 9 Helen Hayes Awards
description: Arena Stage was the big winner at the seventh annual Helen Hayes Awards presented on Monday evening at the National Theater here. The winners, honored for outstanding artistic achievement, were selected from 149 productions at 30 professional theaters in Washington in 1990. Arena Stage received nine awards, including three for its production of "Stand-Up Tragedy," a play by Bill Cain about a teacher's failure with a gifted student. In total, 19 awards in different categories were given out.

title: A Close Call For Herschel Walker
description: The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today that Minnesota Viking running back Herschel Walker was taken by ambulance to Irving (Tex.) Community Hospital early Sunday morning after his wife, Cindy, found him unconscious in the garage of their home. Walker told the newspaper yesterday that he was suffering no after-effects from carbon-monoxide poisoning he sustained while sitting in his car in the closed garage.

title: A Different Rodman Goes Back to Boston
description: The door to locker room No. 7 opened with a gentle elbow shove from Dennis Rodman, the kind he might stick in the back of the man with the ball. He took two steps into the short, narrow corridor, turned left and stopped in his tracks.

title: DE KLERK SEES GAIN ON HALTING UNREST
description: President F. W. de Klerk held talks tonight with Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, and appeared to have made progress toward persuading Chief Buthelezi to have his Zulu supporters lay down their so-called traditional weapons in the interests of restoring peace.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 3-Year Notes Sell Well, but Rates Go Up
description: The first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions was fairly well received yesterday, but Wall Street traders, fearing that coming sales of more speculative securities might not go well, sold outstanding issues of Treasury securities, pushing down prices and raising interest rates.

title: Accounts
description: * Endicott Johnson Retail Corp., a footwear retailer, to the New York office of Earle Palmer Brown. Billings were not disclosed. * Tultex Corp., Martinsville, Va., a fleece and jersey clothing manufacturer, to McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C. Billings are estimated between $4 million and $6 million.

title: A European Crusader For an Open Market
description: Sir Leon Brittan has been called a lot of things. As the European Community's commissioner for competition and financial services, he has been called the second-most-influential man in Brussels, after the European Commission president, Jacques Delors.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a speech by Ronald Reagan referred incorrectly to his audience. It was a joint session of the California Legislature, not just the Assembly.

title: Hawkins's Tailspin Puts Job On Line
description: Two seasons ago, Andy Hawkins was called the anchor of the Yankees' staff. Tonight, his career with the team may have sunk ingloriously on a pitcher's mound at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Belgian Chocolates, Made in Venezuela
description: THIS is a busy week for Ludo and Lisette Gillis, two chocolate makers from Belgium who have opened a shop, La Praline, here in the capital of Venezuela. Sunday will be Mother's Day, an occasion when Venezuelans, like Americans, buy candy to give as gifts.

title: Fly So Free to Forgo Next 2 Triple Crown Races
description: Fly So Free, the champion colt who ran fifth in the Kentucky Derby, was withdrawn from the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes yesterday and was aimed instead toward a new career in shorter races.

title: Review/Film; Exotic Mating Rite Imperiled
description: Werner Herzog's fascination with the natural world at its most enduringly strange has led him to the southern Sahara for "Herdsmen of the Sun," a startling anthropological documentary about the nomadic members of the Wodaabe tribe.

title: The Quayle Questions
description: Two days before President Bush's coronary episode, Vice President Quayle was asked on CNN whether he was troubled that only 19 percent of people polled said they would vote for him for President. Well, Mr. Quayle replied cheerfully, when "you think of my 19 percent and the President's 81 percent, we've got it all."

title: Legumes? Instead of What?
description: How have we eaten? Let us count the ways.

title: Hasbro's Takeover Of Tonka Advances
description: Hasbro Inc. said it had virtually completed its acquisition of the Tonka Corporation, which owns the Monopoly board game and Play-Doh modeling compound. Hasbro said it had acquired 13 million Tonka shares, or approximately 87 percent of Tonka's stock, at $5 a share. It also said that 90 percent of Tonka's outstanding bonds had been tendered.

title: Phil Zwickler, 36, A Director of Films On Gay Issues, Dies
description: Phil Zwickler, who directed documentaries and wrote articles about gay and lesbian issues, including the AIDS crisis, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 36 years old.

title: Filipino Immigrant Brought Yo-Yo to U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Representative Les AuCoin of Oregon and his support for the Brady gun-control bill misstated the extent of support among the state's House delegation as a whole. The bill is backed not merely by Mr. AuCoin but also by Representative Ron Wyden.

title: House Panel Votes to Help Banks and Insurance Fund
description: A Congressional panel began drafting legislation today to strengthen the banking industry and the rapidly deteriorating program that insures deposits.

title: Drunken Driving, a Transcendent Horror
description: At four in the morning, a telephone call often sounds more like a blood-curdling jangle than a ring, and Bill Giles's first thought was that something had happened to either his wife or one of his boys.

title: Graft Takes the Gloss Off Mexican Drug Haul
description: Stressing its commitment to combat drug trafficking, the Mexican Government announced this week that it had intercepted a Colombian aircraft carrying more than five tons of cocaine, worth up to $100 million on wholesale markets. But praise for that achievement was quickly muted by the news that no suspects were apprehended and that the flight was protected at its destination by corrupt officials of the Government's own Federal Highway Police.

title: Jacuzzi Bid for Eljer
description: Eljer Industries, a maker of plumbing and building supplies, said it had received an unsolicited $20-a-share takeover offer from Jacuzzi Inc., a unit of Hanson P.L.C. of Britain. Eljer said its board would discuss the offer on June 18. The announcement was made after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where Eljer shares lost 50 cents, closing at $13.

title: 'Marketing' the War
description: "No news was manufactured" by the Pentagon or the armed services during the Persian Gulf war. "None, period."

title: Mayor Breaks Budget Bargaining Logjam But Scare Tactics May Imperil Some Goals
description: By proposing budget cuts so horrible that he hopes never to make them, Mayor David N. Dinkins has broken a bargaining logjam with municipal unions and state officials whose help he needs, but at the expense of confusing and angering constituents with doomsday tactics that may haunt him.

title: INSIDE
description: Yugoslav Army Put on Alert As Ethnic Clashes Persist

title: Protester in Korea Kills Himself, Third Such Suicide in Two Weeks
description: A young man yelling anti-Government slogans set himself on fire and jumped off a university building today in a protest against the fatal beating of a student by the police.

title: Borrowing by Consumers Down for 4th Month in a Row
description: Consumers cut back on borrowing for the fourth straight month in March, a degree of spending restraint not seen since 1980, when credit controls were in place, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Airline Cuts Coach Fare Almost 40%
description: America West Airlines said yesterday that it would cut most of its full coach fares by an average of almost 40 percent. The cuts, effective tomorrow, will bring down the cost of business travel on many major routes.

title: Riney's Saturn Manager Returns to Foote, Cone
description: Pat Sherwood, who supervised the introduction of the Saturn car for Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, has left the agency and moved to the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, where he will be responsible for the Nintendo of America account.

title: Joseph H. Krug, 75, An Ophthalmologist
description: Dr. Joseph H. Krug, an ophthalmologist who specialized in treating glaucoma, died on Saturday at the Dunroven Nursing Home in Cresskill, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: More Educated Officers Won't Mean Less Police Brutality; Flaws in Corps Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: In Fetal-Tissue Research, Caution Is Best; Data Mostly From Rats
description: To the Editor: In "Fetal Research Is Pro-Life" (editorial, April 17), you recommend discontinuance of the Government's ban on the use of fetal tissues. In support, you provide the emotional appeal of the Walden case, dealing with fetal-to-fetal, in-utero tissue transfer to correct a fatal genetic illness and repeat the advice of several specially appointed (but strongly biased) committees opposing such limitations on fetal experimentation.

title: Damages Are Reversed In the Korean Air Suit
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $50 million award for punitive damages against Korean Air in the 1983 deaths of 269 people aboard a jumbo jet shot down by a Soviet fighter.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Stage of Her Own
description: She walks down the left-hand aisle, a tall, thin woman in a raincoat and droopy hat, and mounts the steps to the speaker's platform. Once there she hangs the hat and coat on a rack, fiddles with her notes, sits for a minute. Finally she rises to face her audience.

title: Housing Plan In New York Taps Banks From Abroad
description: Several large foreign banks, concerned that their lack of local lending in New York City could hurt their standing with banking regulators, are joining a lending program to finance construction of new low- and moderate-income housing.

title: Are Cattlemen Now Guarding The Henhouse?
description: ON April 24, after three years of study, research, consultations and discussions with consumers, the Agriculture Department sent its Eating Right Pyramid to the printer. This new chart was to have replaced the food wheel used since the 1950's to provide information about a healthy diet.

title: Spira Jury Progresses
description: The jury in the Howard Spira extortion trial signaled yesterday that it had made progress in its first full day of deliberations.

title: Gilbert Chin, 56, Dies; Bell Labs Researcher
description: Gilbert Y. Chin, who headed a research team that improved the performance of telephones, died on Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 56 years old and lived in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: Ameritech Credit Line at $2 Billion
description: Ameritech, the parent company of the Bell companies serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, announced yesterday that it had established revolving lines of credit totaling $2 billion with the First National Bank of Chicago and the Northern Trust Company serving as agents.

title: 'Son of Sam' Law Is Upheld in Jean Harris Case
description: New York's landmark "Son of Sam" law, intended to deter criminals from reaping profits when they sell their stories to publishers or movie producers, was upheld by the state's highest court today in a ruling that denied Jean Harris, who was convicted of murder, the proceeds of an autobiography she wrote in prison.

title: Baltic Leaders Find Support In Congress for Independence
description: Leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania politely asked members of Congress today to continue supporting their efforts to restore full independence to their lands.

title: Trump Sells His Plane
description: Donald J. Trump has sold his personal 727 jet for $6.5 million as part of his effort to sell off assets to survive his financial woes, according to documents released today. The sale of the jet was disclosed in a letter the Trump Organization filed with the state Casino Control Commission, which has ordered that it be given a weekly report updating Mr. Trump's finances. The letter dated Monday from Stephen Bollenbach, the Trump Organization's chief financial officer, said Mr. Trump would get $3.25 million from the sale to meet cash requirements and the other $3.25 million would go toward reducing his debt. Mr. Bollenbach did not disclose who bought the plane.

title: People
