description: * Mark Stewart has been promoted to senior vice president of J. Walter Thompson, New York. * Terrence P. Powers has been promoted to vice president of McCann-Erickson, New York.

title: Book Notes
description: Discussions on Atlantic

title: The Quayle Factor
description: "A sphinx without a riddle" is how Bismarck described Napoleon III. As much could be said about Dan Quayle, ever awkwardly posed with a plastered, slight smile.

title: The Pleasures of a Cigar
description: To The Living Section: Perry Garfinkel's piece on cigar smoking, "Cigar Smokers Try to Prove Freud Wrong" [ April 10 ] , dwelled almost exclusively on peripheral aspects of the habit: famous men who indulged, the Freudian angle, cigars as status and so on.

title: No Hazard Is Found In Drug Used in Cows
description: A hormone created through genetic engineering that increases milk production in cows injected with it is not a health threat to the cows or to people who drink the milk, a Congressional agency reported.

title: Educator's Legacy: Success, and Shaky Finances, in Several Districts
description: Long before Walter L. Marks was blamed for the bankruptcy last month of the Richmond, Calif., school district, his reputation had been cast: An innovative administrator and educator whose concept of budgets was elastic at best.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Leagues Faulted on Alcohol Policies
description: Major league sports will not admit that alcohol is a problem among their athletes because of the cozy relationship with the beer industry, an official of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence said yesterday in the wake of recent car crashes involving athletes allegedly driving under the influence of alcohol.

title: Reynolds Grant to School: A Pilot Program or a Peril?
description: A proposed North Carolina public school that was hailed recently as a winner in the RJR Nabisco Foundation's Next Century Schools competition for innovative school proposals is now being criticized for its plan to set aside up to 60 percent of its seats for children of employees of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

title: Chief Stepping Down At Troubled HomeFed
description: The HomeFed Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest savings and loan company, said yesterday that Robert F. Adelizzi had agreed to resign as its president and chief executive under pressure from Federal regulators concerned about its mounting financial problems.

title: WORLDWIDE EFFORT TO AID BANGLADESH CALLED TOO LITTLE
description: The world has failed to mount an adequate relief effort to help survivors of last week's deadly cyclone in Bangladesh, international relief agency and United Nations officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's a little unsettling to turn on the news and see Peter Jennings pointing to a diagram of a heart with your name on it. It isn't even Valentine's Day." -- President Bush. [ A21:3. ]

title: Tigers Overcome 4-0 Deficit To Beat Slumping Royals, 5-4
description: Bill Gullickson won his fourth consecutive decision as the Detroit Tigers rallied from a four-run deficit tonight and beat Kansas City, 5-4, the Royals' ninth loss in 10 games.

title: Samuel Payne, a Former President Of Morgan Stanley, Is Dead at 84
description: Samuel B. Payne, a former president of the investment banking firm Morgan Stanley, died on Sunday at the Franklin Medical Center in Greenfield, Mass. He was 84 years old and lived in Shelburne, Mass.

title: 7-Day Wait for Gun Purchases Hits Crucial Obstacle in House
description: Supporters of a bill that would impose a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases were dealt a setback today when the House Rules Committee said a competing measure could be taken up by the House of Representatives on Wednesday.

title: Theater in Review
description: When the Bough Breaks La Mama E.T.C. 74A East Fourth Street

title: Mr. Gephardt's Design for Monopolies
description: Representative Richard Gephardt is sponsoring a pernicious bill that threatens to raise consumer costs each year by hundreds of millions, perhaps more. The proposed Design Protection Act of 1991 promises to safeguard product designs from unfair imitation, especially foreign. What it would really do is hand over monopoly rights to manufacturers of ordinary household items.

title: Joel C. Kleinman, 44, A Health Statistician
description: Dr. Joel C. Kleinman, an authority on the causes of infant mortality who was director for analysis at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md., died on Thursday at Morgan County War Memorial Hospital in Berkeley Springs, W. Va. He was 44 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Want to Keep the Dog Off the Couch?
description: People who like to have their dogs in the house sometimes turn their rooms into prison cells and act like wardens to keep their pets off valuable furniture or out of certain areas. A company that has sold underground outdoor electrical fences for the last dozen years is now selling an indoor device that sends dogs a mild electrical shock when they go where they should not.

title: Regulator Urges Shearson To Add to Insurer's Funds
description: A dispute between Shearson Lehman Brothers and California insurance regulators intensified yesterday, with the state's Insurance Commissioner contending that the Wall Street firm had a responsibility to infuse a struggling insurance company with more capital.

title: Panel Urges New Inspections For Half-Million U.S. Bridges
description: The nation's half-million bridges, many of them aging, need additional inspections and maintenance "if we are to keep them from collapsing," the nation's top transportation safety official said today.

title: Rightist Party In India Gets Wide Backing
description: Baikunth Lal Sharma is off and running at dawn, plunging into the back streets of India's second-largest constituency to campaign under the green and orange flags emblazoned with a lotus that identify him as a candidate of the right-wing, pro-Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party.

title: U.S. Asks Prague Not to Sell Weapons to Syria and Iran
description: The United States has appealed to Czechoslovakia three times in the last two months not to sell arms to Iran and Syria, the State Department said today. A spokesman, Richard Boucher, said the American Ambassador, Shirley Temple Black, personally delivered the latest message on Monday to the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry.

title: New England Hydro Notes
description: New England Hydro Finance has privately placed a $214.97 million three-part issue of guaranteed notes through Goldman, Sachs & Company and the First Boston Corporation.

title: Joseph M. Katz Dies; Manufacturer Was 77
description: Joseph M. Katz, an entrepreneur who donated more than $10 million to the University of Pittsburgh, which named its business school for him, died of cancer on Sturday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 77 years old.

title: Pacific Music Festival To Take Place in Japan
description: The second annual Pacific Music Festival is to take place from July 13 to Aug. 7 at Art Park in Sapporo, Japan. The festival, which is co-directed by the conductors Michael Tilson Thomas and Christoph Eschenbach, was founded last year by Leonard Bernstein. A total of 66 concerts will be performed by the Festival Orchestra, the Houston Symphony, the Vienna Philharmonic String Quartet and Wind Quintet, the soprano Arleen Auger, the mezzo-soprano Christa Ludwig and others.

title: Economic Scene; More Green For Less Gold
description: AS many a candidate for public office has discovered, green is beautiful: Voters much prefer their air pristine, their water potable and their garbage somewhere else. What elected officials are also discovering is that green can be expensive: According to the Environmental Protection Agency, Americans spend $100 billion annually to comply with Federal environmental rules.

title: About New York
description: Herman Jarvis refers to Kafka in summarizing all that has happened to him. "It's a dream scene," he says. "It's this bureaucratic madness."

title: Donnels, Intense in Tense Debut, Grabs Final Out
description: In a game of hidden signals and messages, there was nothing secretive about the sign transmitted from Met Manager Bud Harrelson to Chris Donnels, the 88th and newest Met third baseman, in the ninth inning last night.

title: Dinkins Speech On TV Tonight
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will give an address on New York City's budget crisis tonight at 7:30 from City Hall. The speech will be broadcast live on radio and television in the metropolitan area.

title: Another Strawberry Moment, and Fans Comply
description: The "Darryl, Darryl" chants started before the first pitch was thrown. When Darryl Strawberry emerged from the other dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon as the sun was drooping in the sky, the fans studied his every move and readied their lungs.

title: Sports of The Times; The Straw Wants It Both Ways
description: DARRYL-DARRYL-DARRYL was always a streak talker as well as a streak hitter. Line drives for a week, strikeouts the next. Sweetness and light one day, talking trash the next.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Automotive, Southfield, Mich., said its friction-materials group had agreed to a joint venture with Pacific BBA Ltd. of Australia to manufacture and market friction-materials products in the Asia-Pacific region. * BASF Corp., Parsippany, N.J., said its Winterhall Energy unit, an oil and gas exploration, production and transportation concern, was for sale.

title: Lemieux Leads the Way As Penguins Even Series
description: Mario Lemieux had a goal and an assist as the Pittsburgh Penguins overcame superb goaltending by Boston's Andy Moog to beat the Bruins, 4-1, tonight and even the Wales Conference finals at two victories apiece.

title: Blazers Win Opener, 117-97
description: Clyde Drexler ignited a 24-5 second-half surge and Portland held Utah without a field goal for nearly seven minutes tonight in a 117-97 victory over the Jazz in their second-round playoff opener.

title: The Pop Life
description: Back in New York

title: After a Split, 2 Sets Of Cookbook Prizes
description: THIS year, for the first time, two sets of awards have been given for cookbooks. A dispute about procedures for the original awards program caused its co-sponsors, the International Association of Cooking Professionals and Joseph E. Seagram and Sons, to sever their relationship last fall.

title: In Shift, Cuomo Backing Is Expected for Drug for Mental Illness
description: In a policy shift that could cost the state more than $20 million a year, the Cuomo administration is expected to make Medicaid coverage available for an expensive new drug that has had remarkable success in combating schizophrenia.

title: In Fetal-Tissue Research, Caution Is Best
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP SOVIET SOLDIER DUE FOR U.S. TALKS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the United States today that he was sending the Soviet Union's top general to Washington next week to try to resolve the dispute that is keeping the conventional arms treaty from being put into effect, Administration officials said.

title: Adversity to Elation for Coach of Surprising North Stars
description: When winning comes so suddenly and so unexpectedly, the celebrations can get giddy. Such is the case at the Met Center, where the surprise party for the Minnesota North Stars is into its second month.

title: Richmond Aid Challenged
description: Gov. Pete Wilson has asked the California Supreme Court to overturn a what he termed a "truly dangerous decision" that requires state funds to keep the bankrupt Richmond schools open.

title: Feminist Detectives, One Familiar, One New
description: "H" Is for Homicide By Sue Grafton 256 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $17.95. Everything You Have Is Mine By Sandra Scoppettone 261 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: New Materials to Keep the Refrigerator Cool
description: Researchers are experimenting with a new class of ultralight materials called aerogels that could one day replace polyurethane foams. These foams provide insulation and help hold up refrigerators and freezers, but are considered harmful to the environment.

title: Discussing What Just Isn't True (Is It?)
description: Not long ago, the story goes, baggage handlers at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago discovered a dead poodle in a crate being sent to Rome. Fearing they would be held liable for the dog's death, they bought an identical, live poodle and shipped it off to Italy.

title: Drummer and Choreographer Honored
description: The fifth annual Martin E. Segal Awards were presented to Kenny Washington, a drummer who plays in Lincoln Center's Classical Jazz Orchestra, and Miriam Mahdaviani, a dancer and choreographer with the New York City Ballet, at Alice Tully Hall yesterday.

title: Cedric Tallis, 76, Baseball Executive
description: Cedric Tallis, who ran the Kansas City Royals and the New York Yankees during a 43-year career in professional baseball, died here today. He was 76 years old.

title: Bridge
description: The leadership of the World Bridge Federation changed hands three weeks ago, when its executive committee met in Florida. The new president is Ernesto D'Orsi of Brazil, who has every qualification for his new role. As secretary he has performed many duties involving world championships with quiet efficiency, and he has successfully organized two in his own country.

title: Neglected Refugees Languish in Iran
description: At this slack and dejected camp for Shiite Muslim refugees from Iraq, the homes are ragged tents and food and medical care are in short supply. Some say the foreign organizations that have gone elsewhere in Iran and to Turkey to help Iraq's fugitives seem to have forgotten them on this bald plain in southern Iran, where heat builds without hope.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER W. STANLEY , a program director at the Ford Foundation, is to be the next president of Pomona College. Mr. Stanley, 51 years old, will succeed DAVID ALEXANDER , who will retire after 21 years as head of the liberal arts college in Claremont, Calif.

title: Review/Television; Marian Anderson's Life Of Unfailing Dignity
description: Marian Anderson redeems "Marian Anderson." The contralto is described in tonight's documentary, at 9:30 on Channel 13, as a queen, a national treasure, an inspiration, a great lady and an icon. These tributes and more are no doubt well deserved, but icons do not make for enthralling television, and "Marian Anderson" is more reverential than revealing.

title: A Homeland? White Volk Fence Themselves In
description: The discredited and dying doctrine of apartheid has found sanctuary in a prairie ghost town where white supremacists dream of carving out an idyllic homeland for Afrikaners fleeing the inevitability of black majority rule.

title: New Convex Lines
description: The Convex Computer Corporation introduced three new families of supercomputers. The C3 series includes the high-end C3800 family, the departmental C3400 family and the low-cost C3200 family. The units are priced from $350,000 to $8 million. Convex now offers a range of air-cooled supercomputers and the largest library of Unix-based, third-party applications software in the industry.

title: New Storms Add to Misery in Bangladesh; Disease Threatens Many
description: A tornado and thunderstorms today brought new misery and death to Bangladesh.

title: Dennis M. Crosby, 56, Nightclub Performer
description: Dennis M. Crosby, one of Bing Crosby's twin sons by his first marriage, was found dead in his home on Saturday. He was 56 years old.

title: Troops to Leave South Iraq Within 2 Days, Cheney Says
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States had stopped air patrols over southern Iraq and would remove all its troops from the demilitarized zone along the Iraq-Kuwait border within two days.

title: Yields 4.75%-6.8% On Virginia Bonds
description: The Prince William County Service Authority of Virginia yesterday tentatively priced $113.4 million in tax-exempt water and sewer system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 6.8 percent for an issue due in 2021 through underwriters led by Graigie Inc.

title: Dr. H. I. Biegeleisen, An Expert on Veins, 86
description: Hyman I. Biegeleisen, founder of the Phlebology Society of America, the country's first society for doctors and surgeons devoted to the treatment of varicose veins and other vascular diseases, died on Friday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THIS is how Tom Leonard describes what happened to him during the recent apartment workers' strike: "I became a Born-Again Menu Lover."

title: How an Overactive Thyroid Affects Health
description: The thyroid, a gland under the Adam's apple, secretes a hormone whose main function is to help regulate the body's metabolism or use of energy.

title: Sharing a Life Of Chefs' Hours And Pancakes
description: BOBBY FLAY and Debra Ponzek, two well-known chefs in the New York food world, are getting married on Saturday. They seem very calm. Andrew Wilkinson, the chef of the Rainbow Room, is cooking the wedding dinner. He does not.

title: Plan for Redistricting Is Faulted in Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn residents had their say last night on the creation of 51 new City Council districts, and they told the districting commission that their communities are being split up and that black and Hispanic voters are being disenfranchised to help incumbents.

title: LeMond on Brink of Summer Form
description: The 11-day Tour Du Pont, America's premier bicycle race, will begin here Thursday night with a 3.1-mile time-trial prologue.

title: Review/Music; Glass and Ginsberg Cycle: 'Hydrogen Jukebox'
description: "Hydrogen Jukebox," which arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening for a six-performance run, will quite rightly be perceived as yet another Philip Glass music-theater piece.

title: Soviet Aide Tells Syria of Support for Arabs
description: Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union met with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today and emphasized Kremlin support for Arab positions as he began a Middle East tour that will include a stop of a few hours in Israel.

title: People
description: * Dorothy Marcus has been named senior vice president and director of corporate communications at J. Walter Thompson Co., New York, from vice president and director of worldwide corporate affairs for Grey Advertising Inc., New York. * Tom Kenney has been appointed vice president-director of advertising at Tiger Electronics, Vernon Hill, Ill., a toy manufacturer.

title: 'Revenge!' Upsets Hearing on Kahane Killing
description: A court hearing for the man accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane erupted in pandemonium yesterday when the rabbi's son jumped to his feet screaming "Revenge!" in Hebrew at the Arab-born defendant.

title: 3 Youths Held In the Slaying Of a Merchant
description: Three Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with killing a grocery store owner during an attempted holdup last week.

title: How House Members Voted On Bill for a Waiting Period
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 239 to 186 by which the House today approved a bill requiring a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun. A "yes" vote is a vote to require the waiting period. Voting "yes" were 179 Democrats and 60 Republicans. Voting "no" were 83 Democrats, 102 Republicans and one Independent. Y is a "yes" vote. N is a "no" vote. X denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were "present" at the time of the vote but did not vote "yes" or "no" on the issue. There are four vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Accounting Board to Alter Tax Rule
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board tentatively agreed yesterday to change a highly unpopular rule on accounting for corporate income taxes. If adopted, the new version would enable some companies to lower the tax expenses they report to shareholders, which would indirectly raise income.

title: Skinner Wants to Stay Put
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner does not want to become Attorney General if that post opens up, Bush Administration officials said today. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that soon after the possibility arose that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh would resign to run for a Senate seat in Pennsylvania, Mr. Skinner told the White House that he wanted to remain in his job.

title: Stocks in Tokyo Gain
description: Japanese stock prices closed higher today for the first time this week. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 128.71 points, or 0.49 percent, to 26,438.50.

title: Qualex Chief's Strategy To Beat Photo 'Minilabs'
description: Although customers of photofinishing labs operated by Qualex Inc. usually wait 24 to 48 hours to get their photos, the company's new president is relatively unconcerned about the proliferation of laboratories that can process film in under an hour.

title: Books of The Times; When History Is Just One Puzzle After Another
description: Dead Certainties (Unwarranted Speculations) By Simon Schama Illustrated. 333 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: GOVERNOR NAMES HEINZ SUCCESSOR
description: After searching from Washington to Michigan for a powerful Democratic candidate to succeed the late Senator John Heinz, Gov. Robert P. Casey today announced that a little-known member of his Cabinet would fill the vacancy.

title: Man Who Set Son Afire Is Paroled a Second Time
description: A man who doused his son with kerosene and set him ablaze was freed today from state prison after serving seven years of a 13-year sentence.

title: 3 CBS Men Released by Iraq
description: One British and two American technicians from CBS News were released today after being detained in Iraq for four days. The three -- Richard Parrott, 26 years old, of Woodford Green, Essex, England; Olcott Mills, 56, of Palm Harbor, Fla., and Barry Severson, 26, of Phoenix -- said they were well treated after being detained Saturday at an Iraqi checkpoint near the southern border town of Safwan. They said they had been questioned but not harassed.

title: Resignation in Brazil
description: Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello resigned today, ending a 14-month struggle to rein in her nation's astronomical inflation rate. The decision was announced late today by Justice Minister Jarbas Passarino, who said Brazil's Ambassador to Washington, Marcilio Marques Moreira, would replace Ms. Cardoso de Mello.

title: Asian Venture Joined by MTV
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. said today that it had joined with MTV Networks to produce a 24- hour music and entertainment service that it plans to broadcast on its pan-Asian satellite television network.

title: Iranian Says West Has Failed To Deliver Some Kurdish Aid
description: An Iranian official in charge of relief for Kurds and other Iraqi refugees criticized Western aid again today as "very small" and said hundreds of millions of dollars in promised assistance had not been deposited in banks here.

title: Rent Board Proposes Increases of 3% a Year
description: In a move that left tenants' groups unhappy but not as unhappy as landlords' representatives, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board proposed last night that apartment rents rise 3 percent for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year leases in rent-stabilized buildings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Commonwealth Energy System, Cambridge, Mass., named William G. Poist president and chief executive. * Consolidated Freightways Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., named John M. Kelly senior vice president, general counsel and corporate secretary.

title: Francisco Soldati, 51, Argentine Economist
description: Francisco Soldati, an Argentine businessman and former director of the Central Bank of Argentina, died Monday at the Diagnostic Institute in Buenos Aires. He was 51 years old.

title: Pop in Review
description: Brand-New Heavies S.O.B.'s 204 Varick Street

title: Wild Over Painted Wood
description: "I'LL paint anything if it's wood and not nailed down," said Pia Ledy, a Manhattan artist who can't bear to see a blank surface.

title: Pop in Review
description: Marni Nixon Ballroom 253 West 28th Street Through May 26

title: Mullins Eulogized On Ole Miss Campus
description: Chucky Mullins, the University of Mississippi football player who died Monday 19 months after suffering a paralyzing injury, was eulogized as an inspiration at a campus memorial service today.

title: A Modernist Paints Again in the New Albania
description: Eighteen years ago, Ali Oseku was this country's most celebrated set designer, a painter who had won a national competition and had been awarded a Communist order, Up With Revolutionary Spirit. He was 28 years old.

title: Lift Iraq Sanctions For Sake of Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop in Review
description: Mike LeDonne Trio Zinno 126 West 13th Street Through Sunday

title: Counseling on Stress From Gulf War
description: Recognizing that the stress of war does not always end with the cease-fire, the American Psychological Association will continue offering a nationwide toll-free telephone service that links callers with counselors.

title: A Moving Call to Arms, Or Too Little, Too Late?
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's appeal to New Yorkers last night to make sacrifices in a time of fiscal trouble was praised by many city leaders invited to hear it as an eloquent call to arms. But City Council leaders derided the Mayor's plea as too little, too late, and two key labor leaders, while praising the speech, said they were not ready to give Mr. Dinkins what they would call concessions.

title: Napkin Rings In Pretty Paper
description: PERI WOLFMAN always wanted to produce the paper napkin rings she remembered seeing years ago in a restaurant in Paris. Now Ms. Wolfman, one of the owners of Wolfman-Gold and Good Company in the SoHo section of Manhattan, is doing it.

title: Low Price May Not Be Best
description: To The Home Section: Those of us in the construction business are acutely aware of present market conditions and the intense competition brought to light in the article, "For Remodelers, the Time Is Now" [ April 25 ] .

title: Pianist Postpones Concert
description: The pianist Alexis Weissenberg, who was to perform Bach's "Goldberg" Variations on Saturday at the 92d Street Y, has postponed his concert because of illness. He is to perform at 8 P.M. on June 24. Tickets for the Saturday concert will be honored on June 24; those wishing a refund must return their tickets no later than June 1 by mail to the Y Box Office, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10128. Information: (212) 415-5450.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about friction between the United Nations Secretary General and Western nations over plans to protect Kurdish refugees in Iraq misidentified the High Commissioner for Refugees. She is Sadako Ogata; Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan is the Secretary General's chief representative for relief aid in the Persian Gulf.

title: Republic New York Sets Stock Sale
description: The Republic New York Corporation is offering to the public $150 million in convertible preferred stock through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The issue of 3 million shares of the convertible preferred being sold by the bank holding company is priced at $50 a share with a dividend of $3.375, to yield 6.75 percent.

title: That Bottle of Water Had to Pass Many Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: In the Bronx, Plants to Buy and View
description: Of Scents and Sketches New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (212) 220-8777.

title: Tiger Wins Seats At Cleveland-Cliffs
description: The Tiger Management Corporation, a New York investment concern, said it had won five seats on the 12-member board of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. Cleveland-Cliffs's mangement acknowledged that Tiger had elected a "significant" number of directors and said it expected to have the full results next week.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CERAMIC tile countertops in kitchens or bathrooms are elegant and, generally speaking, not too hard to install over an existing countertop with a plastic laminate surface like Formica, after the sink and faucets have been removed.

title: Leading Carolina Lawmaker Admits Guilt
description: The man who was the second-ranking member of the South Carolina House until his indictment four months ago pleaded guilty today to a racketeering charge resulting from the Federal investigation of bribery at the Statehouse.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Review/Dance; Narrative Works by Ralph Lemon
description: There are many good, as opposed to interesting, choreographers around. But Ralph Lemon is extremely interesting, as his new program of three premieres proved on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: SOVIETS ASK WEST FOR HELP ON RUBLE
description: The Soviet Prime Minister said today that if the West was genuinely interested in the success of economic reforms in the Soviet Union it could not take a "wait and see" attitude.

title: Bellcore Scientists Report Superconducting Advance
description: Scientists at Bellcore, a research consortium of the regional phone companies, reported yesterday that they had developed a technique for making high-temperature superconducting devices.

title: Money Fund Yields Lower As Analyst Cites Confusion
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Navy Plane Fired On by Iraq, U.S. Says
description: An American Navy plane was fired at by Iraqi antiaircraft guns during a patrol over northern Iraq, American officials said today.

title: Furniture as Art: Shape and Symbol
description: VISITORS to the American Craft Museum in Manhattan are encouraged to sit on the furniture on display in the lobby, a rare gesture in the world of museum shows. "Sitting is part of the experience," said the museum's senior curator, John Perreault, who organized "Explorations II: The New Furniture," an exhibition of 60 pieces that go on display today.

title: Chairs That Can Soothe Even the Professionals
description: THEY came in droves to a rather stark, all-white space on Milan's Via Maffei, dragging heavy shoulder bags filled with catalogues and price lists.

title: Cutback in Britain
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British airplane-engine maker, said it was doubling the number of job cuts planned by the end of the year to 6,000. Blaming the recession and cuts in military spending, the company said the work force would be reduced from 34,000 to 28,000. Rolls-Royce said the cuts would be made at all levels and affect all areas of the group.

title: Dinkins Urges New Yorkers to Ride Out Fiscal Cuts
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins painted a grim picture of a fiscally flattened New York in a somber speech last night that served as his strongest appeal yet for sacrifices from every corner and constituency of the city.

title: Ruddock Promoter Out
description: Promoter MURAD MUHAMMAD was fined $25,000 yesterday and barred from promoting fights in Nevada for a year for his role in a brawl following the controversial ending to the Mike Tyson-Razor Ruddock fight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The new ring on the third finger of the left hand of MARLA MAPLES isn't being called an engagement ring, but that doesn't mean it isn't. A gold band with a cluster of small, independently set diamonds in a rectangular bar across the top, it replace the friendship ring Miss Maples had been wearing for some time. The replacement is from Tiffany and DONALD TRUMP gave it to her in Atlantic City last weekend. The engagement - or whatever it is - was first reported yesterday in Newsday.

title: Deadline for a Proud Reform
description: A day of reckoning for New York City's new and widely lauded campaign financing system is at hand. The program, successfully tested in the 1989 mayoral contest, dispenses public matching funds to candidates who agree to abide by limits on private donations and campaign spending. By tomorrow night, candidates in this fall's special City Council election must notify the Campaign Finance Board if they intend to participate.

title: Historians Honor the Pursuit of a Shared Passion: the Bronx
description: They went to a 233-year-old stone house in the Bronx last week to revel in a subject that, in varying degrees, has been their obsession: the Bronx.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Review/Concert; Botstein And Hudson Valleyans At Tully Hall
description: In an age of specialization, the versatility on display in the Hudson Valley Philharmonic Chamber Orchestra's Sunday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was truly refreshing. Leon Botstein, the ensemble's director since 1981, is also the president of Bard College, a history professor and an eloquent writer on music. But his conducting, clear, detailed and purposeful, was by no means that of a part-time musician.

title: Capital Repeals Liability Law For Assault-Weapons Makers
description: The District of Columbia Council has repealed a law that made manufactures of assault weapons legally liable for the deaths and injuries the weapons cause.

title: Army Dentist Tests Positive for AIDS Virus
description: A military dentist has tested positive for the AIDS virus, and officials are notifying his patients, base officials said today.

title: Judge Webster's High Standard
description: William Webster resigned yesterday, an unofficial casualty of the Persian Gulf war.

title: North Stars Strike Again, Forcing Oilers to the Edge
description: The Minnesota North Stars added a 5-1 thumping of the Edmonton Oilers to their spring string of major upsets and took a commanding three games to one lead tonight in the Campbell Conference final.

title: Magazine Name Change
description: World Tennis magazine will change its name to Tennis Illustrated starting with the September issue. The magazine, owned by the Family Media publishing company, has used its current name for 38 years. The revamped monthly will have later deadlines, allowing for more timely coverage. It will also use bolder graphics, more photographs and higher-grade paper.

title: Johnson Outguns Mullin (44-41), but Warriors Rally, 125-124
description: Mario Elie made two free throws with 3.1 seconds remaining tonight, giving the upstart Golden State Warriors a 125-124 upset of the Los Angeles Lakers and tying their Western Conference semifinal playoff at one victory apiece.

title: EX-DEPUTY IN LINE
description: President Bush today announced the retirement of William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, who polished the image of the espionage community in his four years in the job but remained on the fringes of the Bush Administration's national security operation.

title: Productivity Error Fixed
description: Correcting an embarrassing mix-up, the Labor Department issued a new report today on the productivity of American workers to officially fix inaccurate figures issued earlier this week.

title: Thomas A. Carlin, 62, Stage and Film Actor
description: Thomas A. Carlin, a stage, film and television actor, died Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Public & Private; Experience and Truth
description: This week there were two memorial services for Gad Gross, one in New York, the other in Boston. There has not yet been a funeral. Neither his family, his friends nor those they have interested in his case have been able to persuade the Iraqis to produce his body.

title: STRATEGY DIVIDES TOP REPUBLICANS
description: A dispute has broken out among top Republicans over the party chairman's plan to work with black and Hispanic groups in the struggle over redrawing Congressional, state and local legislative districts.

title: New England Bank Woes
description: A study of the nation's commercial banks shows that 11 banks in New England are among those posing the greatest threat to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's fund.

title: State Inmate Logjam Cost $15 Million, New York City Says
description: A backlog of inmates who were supposed to be transferred from New York City jails to state prisons earlier this year cost the city more than $15 million, a city official acknowledged yesterday.

title: Old Soldiers, Old Ovations
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the last general to address both chambers of Congress before Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf did so today, won a standing ovation with this declaration, "Backed at home by resolve, confidence, patience, determination and continued support, we will prevail in Vietnam over the Communist aggressor."

title: Bridge
description: The American Bridge Association, a much smaller organization than the American Contract Bridge League, concluded its Spring National Championships in Reno a month ago. Bob Friend of Irvine, Calif., one of the association's most respected veteran stars, was a winner in the Knockout Teams along with Willis Troy of Henderson, N.C., Ed West of Seattle, and Henry Bell of Des Moines, Wash.

title: When a Young Doctor Errs, Open Discussion Is Advised
description: Doctors in training should be encouraged to discuss their mistakes with senior physicians, patients and patients' families, a new study suggests.

title: Maybe He Is Only Human: Jays Beat Ryan in Rematch
description: "It's not going to be the same."

title: New Haven Feels Strain Of Increasing Fiscal Blows
description: For more than three decades, Arnie Brown waited for a redevelopment plan that would revive the last old section of this city's downtown district, an area known as the Ninth Square, just blocks from the town green and the towers of Yale University.

title: Knicks To Knock On Texas Coach's Door
description: The Knicks plan to speak with Tom Penders about their vacant head coaching position. But Jimmy Rodgers, the former Boston Celtics coach, has not been contacted by the Knicks, nor does he expect to be.

title: HBO Planning to Add New Movie Channels
description: Concerned about the high turnover rate of its subscribers, Home Box Office, the longtime leading premium cable channel, said yesterday that it planned to add two more channels each for HBO and Cinemax, its sister movie service.

title: Donations to Homeless To Make a House a Home
description: THE Metropolitan Life Insurance Company gave furniture from corporate apartments it no longer uses; Conran's/Habitat , 100 mattresses, and the textile company Sina Pearson , bolts of fabric.

title: For the Disabled, Products That Help, but Have Style, Too
description: Tom Mullen, a wheelchair designer, fears that neon is losing favor with the California beach crowd.

title: U.S. Sees End of Slide In Housing
description: The housing slump appears to have bottomed out in much of the nation, the Government reported today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Iraqi reparations referred incorrectly to a United Nations police force to guard Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq. Such a force has been proposed, but not deployed.

title: Japan Defense on Chip Issue
description: Japanese companies today rejected an American Senator's allegation that they had withheld semiconductor technology from American companies.

title: A LEGAL ADVISER IS FREED IN CHINA
description: The Government has released a prominent legal scholar who had advised an underground labor union during the Tiananmen democracy movement in 1989, a human rights group said today.

title: Review/Theater; Brecht's Cauliflower King In Another Resistible Rise
description: Carey Perloff's production of "The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui" is an opportunity to encounter Bertolt Brecht in his most virulent, polemical mood and to see the actor John Turturro venture away from the contemporary tales of urban violence with which he has won his reputation. In several respects, "Arturo Ui" is a challenge. The fact that it is less than a success is attributable to the play as well as to the revival at the CSC Repertory Theater.

title: Driver Killed at Rail Crossing
description: A driver was killed near this south-central Iowa town today when he backed his car into the path of an Amtrak passenger train while trying to avoid a freight train on another set of tracks. The driver, identified as William Gary Bain Jr., 21 years old, of Ottumwa, was hit by the train at a crosssing on a private gravel road. The train remained on the tracks, and none of its 398 passengers or crew members were hurt.

title: Insurer Pays Price for Risk Strategy
description: Like its crosstown rival, the First Executive Corporation, the First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles built itself into a major life insurance company by investing heavily in high-risk "junk bonds," and like First Executive, whose Executive Life insurance subsidiaries were seized by regulators last month, First Capital is now paying the price for that strategy.

title: Tomato Pickers' Hope for Better Life Becomes Victim as Industry Steps In
description: Every day, October through May, scores of vans and pickup trucks displaying boxes of semiripe tomatoes park on the dusty sand of an open-air market here. The tomato merchants of Immokalee, home to one of the nation's largest concentration of migrant workers, are first- and second-generation Mexicans.

title: Guazapa Journal; Under the Volcano, Peaceful Scenes Now Erupt
description: In the sugar cane fields around Guazapa Volcano, a guerrilla stronghold for 11 years, and under siege by the army for just as long, Candelario Landaverde is ready for peace.

title: Heroes, Old and New, Revisit Randalls Island
description: When he vaulted, he cradled a bamboo pole, and when he landed it was in sawdust. And that is the frozen image of CORNELIUS WARMERDAM, the world's first 15-foot pole-vaulter and the only man to have achieved that height with a bamboo pole.

title: Early Farmers and the Sowing of Languages
description: A new study of genetic patterns among modern Europeans lends support to a novel theory that starting 9,000 years ago early farmers spread from the Middle East all across Europe, transmitting a common language along with the new agricultural techniques.

title: How About Some Cuts of Political Appointees?
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk; In Clashes, a Hispanic Agenda Enters
description: The riots of the 1960's in Watts and Washington helped to push the questions of civil rights, political representation and economic opportunities for blacks to the top of the national political agenda, and this week's disturbances in the capital could focus national attention on the wide array of problems facing Hispanic Americans.

title: Chintz Galore: Just What She Wanted
description: WITH Mother's Day just days away, many sons and daughters are racking their brains to figure out what they can possibly do to make mother happy.

title: Kurds See Their 'Best Chance' With Baghdad Now
description: "We are closer than ever to autonomy," said Jalal Talabani, leader of one of the two largest political groups for Iraqi Kurds. "This is the best chance we've had this century."

title: Toys 'R' Us Sales Results
description: Toys "R" Us Inc., the nation's largest specialty toy retailer, said yesterday that sales at its domestic stores open at least a year fell 4.7 percent in the first quarter.

title: Jonathan R. Goldberg, Civil Rights Lawyer, 61
description: Jonathan R. Goldberg, a Manhattan lawyer who specialized in civil rights cases, died on Monday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 61 years old.

title: Education's Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Federated's Bank Creditors Balk at Reorganization Plan
description: Bank creditors of Federated Department Stores have raised strong objections to the reorganization plan that the company recently submitted to the Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Excerpts From the Bush News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday as supplied by Reuters: OPENING STATEMENT

title: F.T.C. Obtains Concessions On Children's '900' TV Ads
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had filed complaints against three companies that entice children to run up large phone bills calling "900" numbers. "Hey kids! I'm the Easter Bunny," said an animated rabbit in commercials broadcast by one company.

title: Soviet Miners Vote an End to 9-Week Strike
description: Soviet coal miners have voted to end a devastating nine-week old strike, averting a clash with President Mikhail Gorbachev and opening the way for radical reforms in the industry.

title: Accounts
description: * Maxell Corporation of America, Fair Lawn, N.J, to McCabe & Co., New York, with a budget between $5 million and $6 million. The account, which was handled by Scali, McCabe, Sloves, New York, was in a review that involved 20 agencies. The two other finalists were Partners & Shevack Inc., New York, and Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor Inc., New York. * Avianca Airlines to Font & Vaamonde Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Lawyer Is Held on Sex Charge
description: A Manhattan lawyer was arrested last night and charged with sexually abusing and attempting to rape a female client, the police said. The lawyer, Joseph L. Colp, 44 years old, surrendered about 7 P.M. to members of the Manhattan sex crimes unit, said Sgt. Grace Ridley, a police spokeswoman. Mr. Colp was charged with assaulting the client, who was not identified, on Feb. 3 at his office and residence.

title: Disney Plan For Expansion
description: The Walt Disney Company today made public a proposal to greatly expand its Disneyland theme park in Anaheim, Calif., by adding new resort hotels and attractions, including one patterned after the EPCOT center at Walt Disney World in Florida.

title: Firefighting Pace Quickens in Kuwait Oilfields
description: Slowly, the recovery of Kuwait's oil industry, its only basic industry, is taking shape.

title: Fred Russell Eggan Is Dead at 84; A Retired Anthropology Professor
description: Fred Russell Eggan, a leading anthropologist who was a professor at the University of Chicago specializing in the Hopi Indians and the indigenous people of the Philippines, died Tuesday at his home in Sante Fe, N.M. He was 84 years old.

title: Curfew Still On In Capital Area
description: Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon said today that a predominantly Hispanic neighborhood where street disturbances broke out Sunday and Monday would remain under an overnight curfew for at least one more night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEPHEN KING wasn't home, but his wife, TABITHA KING, was when, she said, a man broke into their house April 20 in Bangor, Me., and threatened her with a bomb. ERIK KEENE, who says that the plot of Mr. King's novel "Misery" was stolen from him, was indicted Monday by a grand jury on charges of burglary and terrorizing. He has been in jail in Bangor since the break-in.

title: Bill McPeak, Football Scout, 64
description: Bill McPeak, head coach of the Washington Redskins from 1961 to 1965 and for the last dozen years the director of professional scouting for the New England Patriots, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Foxboro, Mass., Patriots officials said. He was 64 years old and had recently retired.

title: Newspaper Ads, for Newspapers
description: The newspaper industry ended its annual convention here today by announcing a national multimedia advertising campaign to promote a product that has rarely been effectively advertised: newspapers themselves.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO SET 7-DAY WAIT TO BUY HANDGUNS
description: The House of Representatives decisively approved a bill today that would establish a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases, beating back a vigorous challenge by opponents of gun control who said the measure would punish law-abiding gunowners.

title: Spira's Jury Didn't Clear Steinbrenner
description: NOW that Howard Spira has been convicted of extortion, including five counts involving threats to George Steinbrenner, the next voice you hear, if you haven't heard it already, will be that of the Yankees' principal-owner-in-exile shouting that he deserves to be restored to pin-striped power at Yankee Stadium.

title: Untimely Rivalry Weakens Spain's Socialists
description: After nine years in office without a serious challenge from the opposition, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has been unexpectedly tested by a bitter power struggle between members of his Government and leaders of his Socialist Workers' Party.

title: Intermec Takeover
description: The Intermec Corporation, a maker of bar code reading devices, said its $24 a share takeover by a unit of Litton Industries could close as scheduled because the Federal Trade Commission had not requested additional information on the $200 million deal. Intermec said the waiting period required under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antiturst Improvements Act of 1976 had passed without any such request being made. The tender offer is due to close on May 16. Intermec stock closed at $23.875 today, unchanged in over-the-counter trading.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary last Thursday about Michael Hagerty, an actor and publicity consultant, misstated a film credit. He did not appear in "Overboard"; the actor who did is Michael G. Hagerty.

title: Offer to Acquire Henley Withdrawn
description: An investor group has withdrawn its $22-ashare offer to acquire Henley Group Inc., a maker of industrial and scientific products based in Hampton, N.H. The group, which disclosed its decision in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, includes Libra Invest and Trade Ltd., a Zurich-based holding company controlled by Toufic Aboukhater, a Lebanese investor.

title: Mail-Order Sales Tax Upheld in North Dakota
description: In a decision that could substantially aid small merchants and state treasuries, the North Dakota Supreme Court decided late Tuesday that out-of-state telemarketers and mail-order houses must start collecting a 5 percent sales tax on purchases by North Dakota citizens and sending it to the state.

title: David Sohappy, 66; Won Fishing Ruling
description: David Sohappy, a Yakima Indian who helped win a ruling that affirmed Indian fishing rights and later served 18 months in prison for poaching on the Columbia River, died Monday at a nursing home in Hood River, Ore. He was 66 years old.

title: Sasser Stands Pat and Strawberry Steals Second Base
description: Mackey Sasser sensed some progress last night in the bizarre struggle that begins when a baseball lands in his glove.

title: C.I.A. in Search of a Role
description: With his retirement as the Government's chief spymaster, William H. Webster leaves the Central Intelligence Agency with its image and internal controls on misdeeds visibly stronger, but with its own destiny muddled and its performance in the Persian Gulf crisis under a cloud.

title: Big Gain in Chip Index
description: The semiconductor industry's closely watched index rose sharply in April, suggesting that sales of computer chips will be strong in the coming months. The preliminary book-to-bill ratio for the industry rose to 1.15 in April, compared with a preliminary figure of 1.09 for March, the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group, reported today. The April ratio means that for each $100 of products shipped, or billed, the industry received $115 in new orders, or bookings, from American customers. Average monthly orders for the three months ended in April were $1.45 billion, a record, and 6.2 percent higher than the figure for the three months ended in March. Average shipments for the three months ended in April were $1.26 billion, 1.5 percent more than the March figure.

title: WAR PREPARATIONS BY YUGOSLAV ARMY
description: With the nation's political leaders deadlocked over whether to impose martial law, the Yugoslav Army inched closer today to strategic locations in Croatia and Slovenia, the republics where separatist feeling has been strongest.

title: Violent Impasse in Seoul
description: One of the more revealing moments in the flare-up of violence between student demonstrators and the South Korean Government over the last two weeks was the hasty retraction of comments by a senior member of the ruling party that the much-feared plainclothes riot police should be disbanded.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BioGenex Laboratories, San Ramon, Calif., a biotechnology company, has acquired the assets of American Bionetics Inc., Hayward, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. * Biscayne Holdings Inc., Miami, an apparel manufacturer, said its Biscayne Apparel Inc. unit would acquire the manufacturing assets and product lines of New England Mackintosh Inc., a wool coat manufacturer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Panel Votes 'Star Wars' Cuts
description: The House Armed Services Committee today voted large cuts in President Bush's plans in the 1992 military budget for the anti-missile defense system and the B-2 stealth bomber.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN Sharon Kimmich got married seven years ago, she looked forward to becoming close to her husband's two children. "I thought they would be my children, the children that I'd never had," said Ms. Kimmich, who lives in Oakton, Va. Her stepchildren, now 16 and 18 years old, live with their mother and stepfather in Minnesota.

title: Prices Rise After Auction of Notes
description: The second phase of the Government's quarterly refinancing -- an auction of $11.75 billion worth of new 10-year Treasury notes -- went slightly better than expected yesterday. And prices of other Government securities rose modestly after the results of the sale were announced.

title: Personal Health
description: My son complained recently that his eye was bothering him. The white of the eye was red and felt gritty and the eye kept tearing and releasing a pale yellow discharge. Two days later I awoke to the same symptoms. Within 12 hours my eye had swollen nearly shut and was constantly filling with the opaque discharge. The doctor's diagnosis was bacterial conjunctivitis, one of the many forms of what most people call "pink eye." Conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva, the transparent tissue that covers the white of the eye and lines the inside of the eyelids.

title: Friedelind Wagner, 73, Opponent Of Nazism Despite Family's Ties
description: Friedelind Wagner, a granddaughter of the composer Richard Wagner who won fame for her courageous opposition to Nazism, died early yesterday evening at the Community Hospital in Herdecke, Germany, in the Ruhr. She was 73 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Trusteeship Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM - GOVERNING COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS -- 3 P.M.

title: Southland Reports Profit
description: The Southland Corporation, parent of 7-Eleven stores, today reported profits of $91.2 million, or 68 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with a $96.9 million loss during the period last year. Southland said earnings were helped by a gain of $144 million from the bankruptcy restructuring it completed during the quarter. Without the gain, Southland would have reported a loss of $52.6 million. Revenue in the three months ended on March 31 came to $1.88 billion, down 3 percent from $1.94 billion a year earlier.

title: Burst Pipe Spills Raw Sewage Into Jamaica Bay
description: Sixty-eight million gallons of raw sewage flowed into Jamaica Bay, threatening a wildlife refuge, after a 39-year-old pipe burst on Monday afternoon in a sewage-treatment plant on the Rockaway peninsula, city officials said yesterday.

title: Wood That's Too Good to Throw Away
description: Each year, close to half the hardwood timber cut in the United States winds up as shipping pallets: the "skids," or platforms, used for stacking merchandise to be moved.

title: Ex-Iraq Envoy to U.S. Is Admitted to Canada
description: The former Iraqi Ambassador to the United States has been granted permanent resident status in Canada, officials said today.

title: Dinkins Takes a Poke At Koch on Lobbying
description: Inserting off-the-cuff remarks into his prepared text, Mayor David N. Dinkins took a poke at his predecessor, Edward I. Koch, last night by wishing that the former Mayor had lobbied in Washington for gun-control legislation rather than against a civil rights bill.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about El Al Israel Airlines misstated the extent of service to Tel Aviv during the Persian Gulf war. Along with El Al, Tower Airlines, a New York-based carrier, maintained its flights there.

title: Singles Are Jilting City for the Suburbs
description: WHEN Lauren Taber was commuting from Park Ridge, N.J., to Manhattan, which she did for seven years, she would occasionally think of moving to the city. Still, despite the daily bus trip, which involved two to three hours of travel, the thought would be fleeting.

title: Jobless Rates For Germany
description: Unemployment in the former East Germany climbed to 9.5 percent in April from the month before, but dropped in what had been West Germany to 5.5 percent, from 5.8 percent, the Federal Labor Office said.

title: In Hard Times, A Realty Coup
description: THE surprising success of a recent real estate deal seems to suggest that even in bad times strong properties with good cash flow can be used to raise a barrel of cash.

title: Excerpts From Dinkins Speech: 'Our Difficult Journey Ahead'
description: Following are excerpts from an address last night by Mayor David N. Dinkins, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Clemens Goes to 6-0 If Not to Perfection
description: Roger Clemens gave up a run tonight, and his earned run average soared from 0.66 to 0.73.

title: Bush Begins Tests to Treat Thyroid That Disrupted Heart Rhythm
description: President Bush began a series of tests today to determine how to treat an overactive thyroid that his doctors say led to the erratic heart rhythm that put him in the hospital last weekend.

title: Ambac Inc. Files For Refinancing
description: Ambac Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $150 million debt offering consisting of notes due in 2001 and debentures due in 2011.

title: James B. Lile, Knifesmith, 57
description: James B. Lile, a knifesmith whose customers included Presidents and movie stars, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home here. He was 57 years old.

title: 28 Penguin Authors Protest to Publisher in an Ad
description: Twenty-eight Penguin USAauthors have protested to the publishing company, saying that Penguin offers better contracts to its writers in Britain than in the United States.

title: Licenses for 2 Trump Casinos Are Renewed
description: State regulators conditionally renewed gaming licenses for two of Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos today amid concern about his tottering finances, propped up just last December at one of the casinos by a $3.5 million cash infusion disguised as a chip purchase by his father.

title: Whirlpool Begins Note Offering
description: The Whirlpool Corporation is offering $600 million in zero- coupon convertible subordinated notes due 2011 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Miscellany
description: * Arnold Fortuna Lane, Boston, will be starting a design division, Cipriani Kremer Design, with a 10-member staff. Bob Cipriani is the division's president and creative director, and Murray Kremer is executive vice president.

title: New Group Is Formed For AIDS Campaigns
description: A nationwide organization billed as the advertising industry's first concerted cooperative effort to fight AIDS was announced at a press conference in New York yesterday.

title: Jury Finds Airline Solely Liable in '87 Crash
description: After a civil trial that lasted a year and a half, a jury in Federal District Court decided today that Northwest Airlines was solely at fault for the crash of a jetliner that killed 156 people at Detroit Metropolitan Airport in 1987.

title: Article 308091 -- No Title
description: The recession in the art market continues, judging by this week's auctions of Impressionist and modern works at Christie's and Sotheby's . A majority of paintings at both auctions sold either well below or right at low estimates, and private buyers dominated the market.

title: Glyndebourne to Build A New Opera House
description: One of the world's most famous opera houses, at Glyndebourne, will be replaced by a new structure for $56.6 million, its chairman has said. The new opera house is to be built on the same site and will be slightly larger than the original.

title: Ringside in Iowa
description: MICHAEL NUNN has a homecoming tomorrow night.

title: Alumnus of Stanford To Manage Its Assets
description: After 11 years as a partner in a St. Louis investment management firm, Laurance R. Hoagland is returning to his family's roots. Mr. Hoagland, 54 years old, was named yesterday as the chief executive of the Stanford Management Company, which manages the holdings of Stanford University, the school that he and most members of his family attended.

title: Washington Sq. Arch Fenced Off as Peril
description: The Washington Arch, the marble gateway that dominates Washington Square Park at the foot of Fifth Avenue, is being fenced off because city officials fear that crumbling pieces of the 100-year-old structure might strike people passing under it.

title: Corrections
description: A movie review in Weekend on Friday about "Eating" included an erroneous rating note supplied by the distributor. The film has no rating, not an R rating.

title: Lintas Creates a Job For Unilever Accounts
description: In a move that is true to its name, Lintas Worldwide has created a new position, worldwide client director for its Unilever accounts. Terry Rosenquist, formerly a group executive vice president for Lintas New York, has been promoted to the job. Lintas Worldwide said it was probably the first agency to establish such a post.

title: Reader's Digest Offering Stock
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc., which sold stock to the public for the first time last year, said today that its principal stockholders would sell an additional 15 million nonvoting shares.

title: Peters Quits Columbia, but Will Produce
description: After months of speculation in Hollywood about his ability to adapt to the demands and discipline of running a major corporation, Jon Peters announced today that he had resigned as co-chairman of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. but would continue to be affiliated with the studio through his own production company.

title: For Floyd Bennett Field Past Should Be Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Kurds Overflow U.S. Mountain Camp
description: The stepped-up flow of tens of thousands of Kurdish refugees from the western Turkish mountains has all but filled the new tent city here, and about 3,500 people were camped today around the registration tents just outside.

title: Campaign for Luxury Car Polishes Up Diamond Image
description: MITSUBISHI, the auto maker whose name means "three diamonds" in Japanese, is leaving no gemstone unturned in image-laden advertising for an important new model.

title: Key Rates
Stormin' Jonathan's Mission Is To Rescue America West
description: America West Airlines may not have a general in command as it flies into battle against the nation's leading carriers, but the advertising campaign it is introducing today features all the trappings of a military briefing, not to mention a well-known impostor who bears a striking resemblance to Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

title: Review/Television; Real Mystery Still Lacking Real Solution
description: Having just finished the London-Hamburg thriller mini-series called "Die Kinder" and now gearing up for next week's return of Inspector Morse in new adventures, public television's "Mystery" takes a bit of an offbeat breather tonight with a 90-minute film called "The Man From the Pru." On Channel 13 at 8 and Channels 21 and 49 at 9, the production offers a painstaking re-creation of a murder that took place in Liverpool, England, 60 years ago. It was never solved. Diana Rigg, the series host, asks viewers only to "consider the evidence and judge for yourself."

title: CONGRESS MEMBERS HAIL SCHWARZKOPF
description: In a triumphant homecoming address to the House and the Senate, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf today thanked God, the President, Congress, the troops and the American people for their willingness to "get the job done" and "kick the Iraqis out of Kuwait.

title: U.P.S. to Move To Atlanta Area
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said it would move its corporate headquarters to the greater Atlanta area from Greenwich, Conn., beginning this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 27 about Karbala, Iraq, misstated the effect of the battle fought there in A.D. 681 between Muslim factions. The battle perpetuated a split between the Shiites and the Sunnis, but it did not cause it.

title: All the Lonely People
description: In truth, most of them may not be lonely, those 23 million Americans -- a quarter of the nation's households -- who the Census Bureau reports live alone. They're more than double the number who lived alone in 1970, and they range from the elderly who've outlived their marital partners to the young who are more eager than ever for their own apartments, and privacy.

title: Here, I'm an Arab; There, an American
description: "Have you been in London before? Why are you here? How long will you stay on?" The customs man at Heathrow rattled his questions as he scanned the "A" page of a large book kept on the left side of his desk.

title: Wally Toscanini, Charity Worker, 91
description: Wally Toscanini, a daughter of Arturo Toscanini who was known in Italy for her charitable works, died yesterday at the home of her daughter in Rome. She was 91 years old and had lived in Rome in recent years.

title: Essay; Landsbergis for Nobel Laureate
description: Through an area under curfew where 66 were arrested the night before; past boarded-up shops, recently looted, with shards of glass cluttering the sidewalk; into the very eye of defiance of authority I made my perilous way to breakfast with Vytautas Landsbergis, President of the Republic of Lithuania.

title: Income Slides At Woolworth
description: Citing lower than expected revenues in all but its German operations, the Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter net income dropped 65.8 percent, to $13 million, or 10 cents a share, from $38 million, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year.

title: Poland Ends Subsidies for Birth Control Pills
description: The Polish Government, which finances at least 70 percent of all medicines, has eliminated subsidies for birth control pills, more than tripling their price.

title: INSIDE
description: Housing Slump May Be Over A new Government survey shows that residential real estate sales improved throughout the country over the last six months. Page D1.

title: In Warmup for '92, Bush Defends Quayle and the 1980 Campaign
description: President Bush moved today to beat back speculation on a pair of nettlesome political problems that threaten to make his re-election campaign less than the coronation his advisers have anticipated.

title: BANGLADESH ASKS MORE AID COPTERS
description: The Government appealed to foreign countries again today for more helicopters to augment its efforts to get food, medicine and clothing to survivors of last week's cyclone.

title: Gains Seen in de Klerk-Mandela Talks
description: On the eve of a deadline set by the African National Congress for the curtailing of township violence, President F. W. de Klerk and the congress leader, Nelson Mandela, appeared to have made progress today in their search for a solution to the crisis.

title: Europeans Are Jittery With Quayle an Irregular Heartbeat Away
description: The irregular heartbeat that President Bush experienced over the weekend has also set off some nervous flutters in Europe, where commentators and newspaper editorials have been raising questions about Vice President Dan Quayle's competence to take over at the White House.

title: Fiat Deliveries Fall
description: Deliveries of new cars by Fiat S.p.A. to the Italian market fell 15.5 percent in April, to 100,577 units from 119,018 in April 1990, according to data compiled by Anfia, the Italian automotive industry group. Total deliveries by all producers to the Italian market fell 3.55 percent from a year earlier, to 212,424 last month. In the first four months of 1991, Fiat Group sales were down 16.31 percent from the similar period a year earlier.

title: Surgery for Swann
description: ERIC SWANN, the defensive lineman who was the first draft choice of the Phoenix Cardinals, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his left knee on Tuesday. Swann, the overall No. 6 choice in the draft despite never having played college football, injured his knee last Friday, the first day of the Cardinals' minicamp.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Occidental Selling Sites In North Sea
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its North Sea oil and gas holdings for $1.35 billion in cash, its second big divestiture announcement in three days.

title: Nowadays, Robin Hood Gets the Rich to Give to the Poor
description: In the financial world, big payoffs often come to those who can spot the unknown, untested investment opportunity -- and are willing to take the risk.

title: In New York's Crisis: Opportunity
description: New York City will cobble together a solution to its immediate fiscal crisis; it has little choice. By law, it must balance its budget and will do so with a hotly debated assortment of tax increases and harsh service cuts. But unless the city's leaders use this emergency to pursue fundamental reforms, nothing will change.

title: U.S. Opens Inquiry on Nuclear Weapon Plant
description: The Energy Department's inspector general has opened a criminal investigation into the unlawful use of tens of millions of dollars at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina, department officials said today.

title: Shooting Diplomacy in the Foot
description: As Secretary of State James A. Baker embarks on his fourth trip to the Mideast aimed at opening the door for diplomacy, his efforts could be undercut by the Administration's plans to sell $20 billion in arms to friendly Arab countries. Diplomacy will fail if parallel steps are not taken to ease the underlying insecurity of Arabs and Israelis alike. Pouring more arms into the region would do the opposite. The new arms package, justified on the basis of an Iraqi threat that no longer exists, would raise Arab-Israeli tensions, undermining the fragile moves under way toward peace and stability.

title: Government to Suspend U S Sprint's Navy Contract
description: The General Services Administration dealt a setback to the U S Sprint Communications Company today, agreeing to put on hold a contract for it to provide a new, high-technology telephone system to the Navy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILSON PICKETT, whose hit songs include "In the Midnight Hour," took a drive across his neighbor's lawn Tuesday at 4 A.M. in Englewood, N.J. His neighbor is the Mayor, DONALD ARONSON.

title: Knapp Fills A Top Post
description: Thomas P. Losee Jr., vice president and publisher of Architectural Digest magazine, has been named senior vice president and publishing director of the Knapp Communications Corporation, the parent company. His successor is R. Jeffrey Petersen, Architectural Digest's advertising director and associate publisher.

title: Bank Free-for-All Will Need Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: New Japanese Lesson: Running a 7-11
description: With its orange, green and red signs spread across America, the 7-Eleven chain elevated the business of serving consumers-on-the-run into a multibillion-dollar enterprise. It seemed a uniquely American success story -- until 7-Eleven's parent, the Southland Corporation, joined the next corporate wave with an ill-conceived leveraged buyout that swamped the company in debt.

title: Spira Guilty of Attempting Steinbrenner Extortion
description: Howard Spira, the 32-year-old Bronx man who George Steinbrenner says "ruined my life," had his own life jolted yesterday. A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted Spira of attempting to extort money from Steinbrenner.

title: California Rejects Big Utility Deal
description: California regulators unanimously rejected today the proposed $2.9 billion merger of Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric. The ruling scuttles the deal unless the utilities can successfully appeal the ruling, which appears unlikely.

title: An Auction of Masks To Aid Assault Victims
description: GARY STEPHAN used plastic and fabric (above left); Ernst Caramelle used Foamcore (below) and a lighted candle. Of course.

title: Judge Won't Delay Sears Annual Meeting
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia today denied a shareholder request to postpone Sears, Roebuck & Company's annual meeting so that new proxy materials could be distributed.

title: With Strawberry on Deck, Harrelson's Decision Backfires
description: There could have been more high drama at Shea Stadium last night. Darryl Strawberry could have come to bat with the bases loaded and the score tied in the eighth inning. He could have had a chance to redeem himself for making the final out the evening before.

title: It Didn't Hurt Foreman
description: The veteran Jets broke minicamp yesterday, two days after the draft choices and free agents left for home. They won't be fully assembled again until training camp reopens July 16.

title: Lean Back, Open Wide And Say, 'Holy Cow!'
description: If the first shot of Novocain doesn't ease the fears, Dr. Martin Handlers tells patients to just look out the window.

title: Urban Yard Sale, Without the Yard
description: THIS being the month for yard sales, 2,000 families in two huge red-brick apartment complexes in the heart of Manhattan set up shop last weekend, planting card tables and blankets and bedspreads under the trees.

title: Events: Shows of Art, Tours on Foot or by Bus
description: Across the Channel Place des Antiquaires, 125 East 57th Street, (212) 758-2900.

title: Indian Forces in Kashmir Fire on Rebel Mourners
description: Indian paramilitary forces fired on hundreds of mourners today as they carried four victims of police bullets for burial. At least 14 people were killed, raising the day's death toll to 47 in violence stemming from a Muslim insurgency for an independent Kashmir.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co., a wholly owned subsidiary of Centerior Energy, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million in medium-term notes to be sold periodically through Morgan Stanley & Co. and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. * Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, is offering $250 million in 7.71 percent medium-term notes due 1995 at 100 through the First Boston Corp.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday about the resignation of Robert F. Adelizzi as chief executive of the HomeFed Corporation misstated the reason for the resignation of his predecessor, Kim Fletcher. Mr. Fletcher retired voluntarily, not under pressure from regulators.

title: Sills Joining Board Of Her Old Rival, The Met Opera
description: Beverly Sills, whose career as a soprano and administrator has linked her name intimately with the New York City Opera for more than a generation, will join the board of that company's Lincoln Center competition, the Metropolitan Opera, as a managing director. She will be elected to the post at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Association next Thursday afternoon.

title: Bush Is Leaning To Food Credits For the Soviets
description: With the United States and the Soviet Union seeming to move toward another summit meeting, President Bush hailed the accomplishments of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and indicated that he was inclined to find a way to satisfy the Soviet leader's request for emergency aid to buy American food.

title: Madonna Wanna-Sees Get an Eyeful at Film
description: Madonna was on her way, and the people standing on the sidewalk on West 54th Street were expectant, hopeful, but contained. For the moment, they talked quite coolly, with an element of dry sophistication, about what Madonna signified.

title: Rookie Police Officer Is Shot While Investigating Burglary
description: A rookie police officer was shot and wounded last night while responding to a report of a burglary in Queens, the police said.

title: Studios Are Relying on Big Movies To Make Big Summertime Money
description: Despite their continuing talk of the need to contain costs and their promises to stress story over spectacle, Hollywood studios are once again pinning their hopes for a hot summer at the box office on expensive, action-adventure movies. Nevertheless, this summer promises to offer more diversity of choice to moviegoers than any in recent years.

title: Doubts On Thomas And Hopes For Bird
description: "What's with Larry Bird?"

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: A Revival of Ornaments
description: American Wood Column Corporation 913 Grand Street (near Bushwick Avenue), Brooklyn, N.Y. 11211; (718) 782-3163.

title: Pop in Review
description: Eddie Floyd, Booker T. and the M.G.'s and Carla Thomas Lone Star Roadhouse 240 West 52d Street

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We simply do not have the resources to pay for what we need and our city, like every urban center in our country, has been abandoned in the past decade by the Federal Government." -- Mayor David N. Dinkins. [ B2:3. ]

title: Dirks Is Back, With A Hot Stock
description: Ray Dirks has twice become famous on Wall Street. First he uncovered an insurance company fraud. Then he ran a brokerage firm that went bankrupt after underwriting a series of offerings that in his words "went down the tubes."

title: Paul Mittler, Lawyer, 77
description: Paul Mittler, a former lawyer for the United Restititution Organization, which seeks restitution for victims of Nazi atrocities, died on May 2 at the Robert Woods Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Highland Park. N.J.

title: Dow Up 13.41; Impact of Bond Sales Cited
description: Stocks took a cue from bonds yesterday and moved into higher ground.

title: Shaky Consensus in Albany
description: Legislative leaders have decided to restore hundreds of millions of dollars in spending cuts but not how to pay for it. Page B1.

title: Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Higher
