description: The dollar rose yesterday in quiet trading as investors were heartened by the results of the Treasury's bond auction.

title: That Bottle of Water Had to Pass Many Tests; Why Chlorination
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislators Know What to Spare in Budget, but Not How to Pay
description: Five weeks after the budget deadline, lawmakers here have reached a consensus on restoring hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed spending cuts, only to run into an even more politically divisive problem: how to pay for them.

title: 7-and-0 Monarchs Stir a Loyal Uprising
description: When he acquired the London Monarchs of the World League of American Football, Jon Smith thought he might have some problems getting British fans to recognize and accept the new sports franchise.

title: Withers Stakes Won By Subordinated Debt
description: Belmont Park rang up the curtain on 66 days of racing yesterday with the 116th running of the Withers Stakes and a rousing victory for Subordinated Debt, a 7-to-1 outsider who outran Scan, Kyle's Our Man and half a dozen other colts with varying designs on the Preakness and other 3-year-old classics.

title: Window Case Figure Shot and Wounded By Pair of Gunmen
description: A reputed mobster who was the only defendant to plead guilty in an organized-crime case now on trial was shot and wounded yesterday in what the police called an unsuccessful mob hit on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Home Video
description: Sports Star

title: CHRONICLE
description: KUKI GALLMAN was honored at the United Nations Tuesday night, at a reception hosted by Dr. NOEL BROWN, head of the United Nations Environment Program, for her work in trying to save the black rhinoceros. She has 44 of the last 250 rhinos in Kenya on her private land.

title: George B. Lucas, Broker, 90
description: George B. Lucas, a retired investment broker, died yesterday at Moorings Park, a retirement community in Naples, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: McGwire and A's Club Orioles
description: Mark McGwire hit two three-run homers today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Baltimore Orioles, 9-3, despite losing starter Dave Stewart to a second-inning injury.

title: Mattingly Misses the Boss; Yanks Remember to Win
description: It was another afternoon, the last one before the last game of the Yankees' troubled trip. In a corner of the clubhouse, Don Mattingly dressed slowly, but he stopped when someone asked about the current condition of the team.

title: Plan on Iraqi Arms Is Faulted
description: The United Nations program to destroy Iraq's chemical and biological weapons is unworkable, a member of the commission set up to do the job has said.

title: Slobodan S. Zarkovich, Ex-U.N. Official, 78
description: Slobodan S. Zarkovich, a statistician and a retired official of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome, died on Tuesday in Bala Cynwyd, Penn. He was 78 years old and lived in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

title: Most Airlines Are Cautious On Fare Cut
description: Worried about profits after a period of record losses, airlines reacted cautiously today to sweeping fare cuts by America West Airlines.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SALMAN RUSHDIE met with two Muslim leaders in London in December and embraced Islam. But before prayers at the London Central Mosque last Friday, one of the leaders announced that Mr. Rushdie could not be accepted into the faith until he had completely withdrawn his novel "The Satanic Verses" from publication.

title: And Now, a Circuit For Top Senior Horses
description: When Strike the Gold arrived at Pimlico Race Course near Baltimore the other day, he was checked into the barn customarily reserved for winners of the Kentucky Derby. But the 3-year-old son of Alydar, the only horse in America with a chance to win the Triple Crown, found himself surrounded by senior celebrities already there for a race tomorrow that for now upstages next week's Preakness.

title: Outdoor Date For Rangers?
description: The Los Angeles Kings may play an exhibition game against the Rangers in September at an outdoor arena outside Caesars Palace, Bruce McNall, the Kings' owner, said today.

title: CNBC Wins Bidding War For FNN
description: After an increasingly tense bidding war, a Federal bankruptcy judge decided yesterday that the Financial News Network should go to NBC's Consumer News and Business Channel for $154.3 million and a share of future revenues.

title: Let Athletes Remain Childhood's Idols
description: To the Editor:

title: BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has established a foothold in Texas by buying a failed bank there from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. It will acquire $27 million in deposits and about $6 million in loans of the Village Green National Bank, which operates one branch in Houston. BankAmerica paid the F.D.I.C. $1.8 million and will rename the bank Bank of America Texas.

title: Philip Spiewak; Clothier, 95
description: Philip Spiewak, a manufacturer of clothing for men and boys, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95 years old.

title: Bell Units' Rivals Gain At F.C.C.
description: In a move that could greatly increase competition for many local telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission proposed a rule today that would force them to let rivals plug directly into local telephone systems.

title: Alaska Claiming Royalties and Taxes
description: Three of the companies producing oil from the Kuparuk River field in Alaska must pay about $28 million to the state in back royalties and taxes owed from 1984 to 1988, according to Gov. Walter J. Hickel. The companies are the Atlantic Richfield Company's ARCO Alaska, Inc. unit, with a 55.1 percent stake in the field; the British Petroleum Company P.L.C.'s BP Exploration Alaska Inc. unit, with 19.2 percent, and the Unocal Corporation, with 4.95 percent, the Governor's office said.

title: Review/Film; Chopper Chicks vs. Zombies
description: From its amusing title, "Chopper Chicks in Zombietown," the newest film from Troma Inc. promises to be one of the company's typical free-for-all B-movie romps. Alas, it is not. Written and directed by Dan Hoskins, the relatively straight-faced generic hybrid of horror and biker films doesn't go nearly far enough in showing how a female motorcycle gang, aided by a local school for blind orphans, rids a tiny desert town of its exploding zombie population.

title: China Stock Sale Abroad
description: Foreigners will soon be allowed to buy Chinese stocks for the first time in four decades of Communist rule. Gong Haocheng, chairman of the Shanghai branch of the People's Bank of China, said that Shanghai companies would be allowed to sell their stock abroad, issued in foreign currencies. His comments, made at an economic seminar, were reported late Wednesday by the state-run New China News Agency. Shanghai opened the nation's first computerized stock market last year, but only seven stocks are listed for sale. Few Chinese companies issue stocks, and those that do generally sell them only to employees.

title: As Things Ease in China, an Envoy Departs
description: Two months ago a man named Zhang boarded a train with nearly $2,000 in life savings, disembarked more than 400 miles later at the nearest United States Consulate and plunked his money down as a contribution to helping American soldiers wounded in the Persian Gulf.

title: Key Rates
Edward G. Breen; Ex-Congressman, 82
description: Edward Grimes Breen, a former Mayor of Dayton who served four years in the House of Representatives, died Wednesday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Dayton, where he had been a patient since 1986. He was 82 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS -- 11 A.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM, GOVERNING COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS -- 10 A.M.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Festival of the Americas, Madison Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 42d to 57th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Springtime For Frau Hess
description: The tale of Frau Hess's gardener caught my eye when I was searching among the microfilms of Heinrich Himmler's Gestapo files in Washington archives. The story is nothing special. Rather matter of fact. But the ordinariness doesn't quite muffle the whisper of the ax.

title: Dissident Sears Holder Fails to Win Board Seat
description: Robert A. G. Monks, the eloquent institutional investor whose pointed criticism of Sears, Roebuck & Company made him a symbol of the activist shareholder, today lost his campaign to become a Sears director.

title: Pop/Jazz; Cecil Taylor, Long a Rebel, Is Finding Steady Work
description: The pianist and composer Cecil Taylor made his first record in 1955; for the next 25 years, he had a tough time. Mixing 20th-century European music and jazz, Mr. Taylor was viewed as an outsider, a role that brought him press attention, but not much work.

title: Our Towns
description: For a while the other afternoon, Jean Shellhammer was concerned about the behavior of her daughter Candice. The third grader ran up to the family's Oldsmobile outside Harrison School. She jumped in. And she began to talk the way 9-year-olds talk after a birthday candy overdose.

title: Steaming to Serenity At the Turkish Baths
description: FLASHBACK: A stark-naked John Belushi, his whalelike physique crimson from being beaten with oak branches, bursts from the hades that is the Russian radiant heat room. He emits a piercing cry and leaps into the pool of ice-cold water. Good morning, America!

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a sewage leak in Jamaica Bay in Queens referred incorrectly in some copies to the day the leak began. It was Monday, not Tuesday.

title: Refinancing Step By Illinois Central
description: The Illinois Central Corporation plans to refinance $150 million of its high-interest series K mortgage bonds, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Waiting Period for Gun Purchases Faces Tough Going in the Senate
description: After winning passage by a big margin in the House of Representatives on Wednesday, the bill to establish a national seven-day waiting period for a handgun purchase could face a much tougher test in the Senate, supporters and opponents of gun control said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Caterpillar Financial Services Corp., Peoria, Ill., the financing and leasing subsidiary of Caterpillar Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $700 million in debt securities. On Tuesday, the parent filed to sell $500 million in debt securities.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Robin Hood Foundation, a philanthropy founded by three Wall Street traders, omitted attribution for a quotation explaining the foundation's strategy. It was Glenn R. Dubin, a founder, who said: "We also saw the possibilities of leveraging money from other sources. This strategy worked for us in the business world and should succeed in philanthropy as well."

title: Maryland Acts On 2 Insurers
description: Two life insurance companies linked to Michael R. Milken, the "junk bond" innovator, have been ordered to stop selling or renewing policies in Maryland.

title: A Time Warner Venture in Japan
description: In an effort to change the habits of a country that seems more interested in buying movie studios than movie tickets, Time Warner Inc. said today that it was joining with a Japanese shopping-mall developer to build hundreds of movie theaters here.

title: Soviet Emigres Arrive And All Is Remembered
description: People who remember the days of Dimona's founders are dusting off long-forgotten dreams now that the population has been expanded by 1,000 Soviet families over the last year and more are expected.

title: 49ers Sign Barnes
description: RANDY BARNES, the world-record-holding shot-putter suspended for steroid use, has signed a contract with the San Francisco 49ers, the team said yesterday. The 6-foot-4-inch 300-pound Barnes will try to make the team as a defensive lineman. The club said the National Football League office did not object to the signing.

title: Long Bond Yield Averages 8.21%
description: The Treasury struggled to complete the final leg of a record $37 billion set of auctions yesterday, as an $11.75 billion auction of new 30-year bonds attracted the smallest amount of bids since early 1977, when the United States began to sell such securities on a regular basis.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Suffolk's Pioneering Plastics Ban
description: A ruling today by the state's highest court will allow Suffolk County to enforce its pioneering but long-delayed ban on plastic grocery bags and many plastic food containers.

title: White House Memo; Leashing Sununu, Bush Sets a Tone
description: President Bush has been struggling with a miasma of health and political problems this week. But today, in handing down a tough ruling banning the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, from using military aircraft for most political and personal trips, Mr. Bush tried to cut through the static and send a clear message about the nature of his Presidency.

title: Sinn Fein Spokesman Jailed For 8 Years in Informer Case
description: The former chief spokesman for the Irish Republican Army's political wing was sentenced to eight years in prison today after being convicted in the imprisonment of an I.R.A. member who was a police informer.

title: Council Speaker Vows to Avert Steep Cuts by Dinkins
description: A day after Mayor David N. Dinkins warned New Yorkers to show courage in the face of devastating cuts in city services, the Speaker of the City Council vowed yesterday to head off the worst of the reductions.

title: No Tax Dollars to Support Parochial Schools; What Competition Does
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Even though its name is Dutch, Van Cortlandt Park in the northwest Bronx offers more than a whiff of activities and features associated with the British Isles. From the Van Cortlandt Mansion, a handsome Georgian edifice, to the Gaelic football played by Irish-Americans, this park's 1,146 acres accommodates longtime New York families and those newly arrived. The west side of the park is accessible by the No. 1 train to 242d Street, which drops visitors off at the southwestern entrance. The eastern half (several highways weave through the park) is more easily approached by car, although the No. 4 train, stopping at Woodlawn, is near one of the park's golf courses and a playground. A handy guide is available at the administrative office on Broadway at 242d Street, (212) 549-6494, or at the Urban Park Rangers' office inside the western side of the park at the Clubhouse, (212) 548-7070. Both offices are usually open daily from 7 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Amid Old Questions, Backing For Chief Candidate for C.I.A.
description: Influential Democrats and Republicans in Congress today expressed support for Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, if President Bush nominates him for the job.

title: Wal-Mart Net Up 21%
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest-volume retailer, said yesterday that its net income jumped 21 percent in the first quarter, to $306.9 million, or 27 cents a share, from $253.4 million, or 22 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Wonders of Wilder, The Movies' Master Wit
description: IN Billy Wilder's unregenerately satiric "Ace in the Hole" (1951), Kirk Douglas gives the performance of his life as Charlie Tatum, a scrappy, none-too-ethical reporter with no fixed address. Charlie's boast is that he's been fired by newspapers with a total circulation of 11 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Iraq Acts to Halt the Spread Of Allied Zone for the Kurds
description: A top-ranking Iraqi general met with American commanders today, apparently in an effort to block expansion of the allied-controlled zone for Kurdish refugees.

title: Yugoslavia Forges Ethnic Peace Plan
description: This nation's political leadership agreed early today on a plan to disarm paramilitary units, averting for the moment the imposition of martial law sought by the Yugoslav Army.

title: Wages Rise In Japan
description: The number of hours worked annually by the average Japanese worker declined for the third consecutive year while wages rose by the highest rate in nine years in 1990, the Labor Ministry said.

title: Darryl and George, in Perfect Harmony
description: NOW we can think about Darryl Strawberry and George Steinbrenner without guilt or tears. Darryl has come and gone without tilting the universe. He's still not as good as we want him to be. And George has once again claimed he was mugged by a sleazeball. This time, it was a Federal case, and a jury believed him.

title: Retailers Post Low Sales For April
description: Retail business picked up slightly around the country last month, but the gains hardly signaled a new surge of consumer buying, according to reports issued yesterday by leading retailers.

title: Courage, Finally, on Gun Control
description: The customer shows up at the Ohio shop every couple of weeks looking for 9-millimeter semiautomatic handguns. He doesn't look like a local man, but he produces what looks like a valid local ID. So the dealer sells him the guns. He's not sure what the man does with all those 9-millimeters. But that's not his concern.

title: Conflict on Unpublished Work Is Resolved
description: A long-running conflict between writers and the computer industry that blocked authors' efforts to quote liberally from letters, diaries and other unpublished material has been resolved, opening the way for legislation that will give historians and biographers greater freedom.

title: Ford Layoff Hint
description: The possibility of further layoffs in the Ford Motor Company's salaried work force cannot be ruled out, the auto maker's chairman said. "I would like to think that we will experience the additional reductions in employment as a result of normal retirements or attrition," Harold A. Poling said at a news conference after the company's annual meeting here. "I cannot say without reservation that there will not be."

title: Israelis Held in Jerusalem Shooting Incident
description: The Israeli police detained a militant anti-Arab rabbi and 10 other Israelis today after shots were fired at Palestinians who threw stones at them in Jerusalem's Old City, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Editorial Notebook; The First Capitalist in Prague
description: Petr Meissner is nervous. His blue eyes flash restlessly above his half-glasses. His busy hands tap out one cigarette after another from the pack of imported Rothman's. Already lean, he has recently lost 30 pounds. Small wonder, for he is out on a limb.

title: New Bantam Publisher
description: Matthew Shear, the director of sales and marketing for Bantam and Dell since 1989, was named publisher of Bantam adult hardcovers and trade paperbacks on Wednesday, replacing Jeff Stone, who resigned for personal reasons. Mark Faller, who has been controller of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group Inc. since 1987, was appointed to the newly created position of head of Bantam publishing operations, responsible for the company's day-to-day administrative, financial and business matters.

title: Suspension for Corson
description: SHAYNE CORSON of the Montreal Canadiens has been suspended for the first four games of the next National Hockey League season for injuring RAY BOURQUE of Boston with a cross-check to the head in the seventh and deciding game of the Adams Division final of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Corson was also fined $500 for boarding GARRY GALLEY of the Bruins after the buzzer ended the game and the season for Montreal. . . . The St. Louis Blues gave Coach BRIAN SUTTER and General Manager RON CARON new two-year contracts. (AP)

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE, Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street, Manhattan. "House of Heritage," a lecture-and-slide presentation on the history of the museum and the surrounding area, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $2. Information: (212) 431-0233. GALLERY TALKS AND LECTURES, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. "The 1991 Biennial," by Leslie Heiner, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 3:30 P.M. Free with museum admission: $5 ($3 for the elderly; free for students). Information: (212) 570-3611. GALLERY TALKS AND LECTURES, Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Sculpture of Indonesia," by Marie-Helene Weill, today at 11 A.M.; "Beauty and the Feminine Ideal in American Art," by Hazel Rodriguez, today at 11:30 A.M.; "Claude Monet," by Rebecca Rabinow, today at 3 P.M.; "Pots and People in the Ancient Near East," by Karen Rubinson, today at 3:30 P.M.; "The Robert Lehman Collection," by Jillian Ehninger, today at 6 P.M.; "Roman Baroque Architecture as Urban Scenography," by John Pinto, professor, department of art and archeology, and director of graduate studies, Princeton University, today at 6 P.M.; "Understanding Northern Art: Landscape," by Katie Luber, today at 7 P.M.; "The Exotic and the Precious in 19th-Century Furniture," by Christopher Miele, tomorrow at 11 A.M.; "The Artist at Work: The Development of an American Style," by Carrie Rebora, tomorrow at 7 P.M.; "The American Wilderness," by Pat Sands, Sunday at 11 A.M.; "Chardin the Magician," by Edgar Munhall, curator, the Frick Collection, Sunday at 3 P.M. Free with museum admission, $6 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 570-3764. GALLERY TALK, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, Manhattan. The artist Sokari Douglas Camp will discuss the communal functions and social meanings of African art, tomorrow at 2 P.M. Free with suggested contribution. Information: (212) 219-1222. LECTURE, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Samuel Segev, visiting professor at Hofstra University and author of "The Iranian Triangle: The Untold Story of the Israeli Role in the Iran-Contra Affair," will discuss the current situation in the Middle East, Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $14. Information: (212) 996-1100. LECTURE AND SCREENING, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. With Sarah Ozacky-Lazar, associate director of the Institute for Arabic Studies at Givat Haviva, Israel, who will speak about the image of Arabs in Israeli films, after a screening of "Dreamers (Unsettled Land)," Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $8. Information: (212) 996-1100. LECTURE, the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons, Bridgehampton Community House, Bridgehampton, L.I. "Beyond Flowers: Color and Contrast With Foliage," by Ruth Clausen, teacher at the New York Botanical Garden and co-author of "Perennials for American Gardens," today at 7:30 P.M. Free for members, $5 for nonmembers. Information: (516) 537-2223.

title: Review/Film; No One Ever Called Her Shy
description: MADONNA had a dream that Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to see her show. "My first reaction," she says wickedly in her new concert documentary, "Truth or Dare," "was that Warren Beatty would be so jealous that I got to meet him first!" Probably, but no doubt Mr. Beatty would understand why Madonna's star power has brought her serious attention and international renown. As the apotheosis of brilliant artifice, flagrant exhibitionism and self-conscious celebrity, Madonna has succeeded in taking on real importance. She perfectly mirrors the troubling pop-cultural climate over which she holds sway.

title: Albanian Names an All-Communist Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Fatos Nano of Albania announced an all-Communist Cabinet today that includes a new Defense Minister but many holdovers, including the chief of security forces.

title: The Worst Is Yet to Come
description: New York City, like most people and organizations, tends to respond to difficulties only when they become emergencies. This leads to grasping for solutions that have an immediate impact -- whatever the cost the day after tomorrow. This is happening in the municipal financial crisis.

title: Senate Panel Says Lawn Chemicals Harm Many
description: A Senate subcommittee today criticized the manufacturers and commercial applicators of pesticides used on lawns and golf courses, saying thousands of Americans exposed to the chemicals were being injured.

title: Pretoria to Limit Zulus' Arms
description: In a last-minute effort to avert a rupture with the African National Congress over township violence, President F. W. de Klerk said today that he was banning the carrying of so-called traditional weapons, except for spears, in areas troubled by unrest. And he said the Government would review laws on carrying dangerous weapons in public.

title: Review/Dance; What Is City Ballet's Encore After 'Sleeping Beauty'?
description: As the lights dimmed at the start of the New York City Ballet's first repertory program of the season, on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, one audience member wondered aloud if the dancers could possibly have any energy left after two weeks of "The Sleeping Beauty." As if in answer, George Balanchine's "Raymonda Variations" received one of its most exuberant performances ever.

title: Black Revolution's 'Legal Arm' Weakens in 90's
description: Opposition to the war in Vietnam was mounting. Race riots were erupting in the nation's cities. Militant young people were challenging the older civil rights leaders. The Federal Bureau of Investigation was infiltrating movements for social change. And the first wave of blacks was attending the nation's top law schools.

title: Worry on Quayle Continues With News of Bush's Health, Poll Says
description: Thrust into the spotlight because of President Bush's health problems, Vice President Dan Quayle continues to stir deep anxiety among Americans, with 62 percent saying they worry about the prospect of a Quayle Presidency, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Docucon Inc., San Antonio, a computer services company, has received a three-year, $12.4 million contract to provide document conversion and imaging services to the Navy and other government agencies. *Gazelle Microcircuits, Santa Clara, Calif., will join the previously announced merger between two other companies that sell computer chips made from gallium arsenide, Gigabit Logic of Newbury Park, Calif., and Triquint Semiconductor, a subsidiary of Tektronix based in Beaverton, Ore. The new company will be called Triquint.

title: Review/Film; Elderly Women, Waiting to Be Rescued
description: The gentle Canadian film "Strangers in Good Company" feels less like a drama than a vacation, and an outstandingly tranquil vacation at that. Conceived as a kind of Outward Bound expedition for elderly women, it tells of how a group of them on a sightseeing trip becomes marooned when the tour bus breaks down. These travelers, the oldest of whom (Constance Garneau) is 92 years old, must make their way to a deserted vacation house and spend a few days together waiting until a rescue can be arranged.

title: Linda Byron Marries
description: Linda Byron, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert G. August Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y., and Stuart D. Byron of New York, was married yesterday in New York to James Glucksman, the son of Ruth Bellsey of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Jerome B. Glucksman. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Hotel Parker Meridien. Mrs. Glucksman, 30 years old, is the operations manager at Forbes magazine in New York. She graduated from Tulane University and received a master's degree in speech pathology from New York University. Mr. Glucksman, 34, is a lawyer in practice with Rattet & Company in New York. He graduated from Cornell University and received a law degree from Boston University.

title: Treasury's Sale Result Lifts Stocks
description: The stock market came out of a slump late yesterday and moved sharply higher. Traders attributed the upturn to Wall Street relief that in spite of all the concern over the huge three-day Treasury refinancing, the sales came off well.

title: Arthur W. Glick, 85, Retired Dermatologist
description: Arthur W. Glick, a former head of dermatology at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, died at the hospital on Wednesday. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lendl to Miss Event
description: IVAN LENDL has been forced to withdraw from next week's Italian Open because of a hand problem that will require surgery. Lendl, ranked third in the world, had been seeded second at Rome. VITTORIO SELMI, an official of the Association of Tennis Professionals, said that an operation would be needed to repair an accumulation of tissue in Lendl's hand. . . . STEFFI GRAF, ranked No. 2 in women's singles, was forced to quit an exhibition match against JANA NOVOTNA in Frankfurt, Germany, yesterday because of a wrist injury. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about a concert by Van Cliburn with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall misstated the concert date. It was May 1, not May 2.

title: In Strange Twist, Bush Is Suffering From Same Gland Disease as Wife
description: In what President Bush's doctors said was a bizarre twist to his medical story, his overactive thyroid was found today to be caused by the same, noncontagious thyroid condition for which his wife, Barbara, is being treated. The condition is Graves' disease, an affliction in which the immune system inexplicably attacks the gland in the neck.

title: Poland to Pay Interest
description: Poland has told its bank creditors it will pay $100 million worth of interest arrears on a total $11 billion of debt owed to banks, Warsaw's chief debt negotiator, Janusz Sawicki, said today. Mr. Sawicki also said Poland would deposit 20 percent of its interest payments with the Bank for International Settlements as part of a deal to help cut the debt. Poland, which has not paid any interest since late 1989, said the $100 million payment would be made in July.

title: An Angry McReynolds Returns the Fans' Jeers
description: Kevin McReynolds's last trip to the plate in the ninth inning Wednesday night had ended in familiar futility. Having performed quietly, the left fielder for the Mets, under an avalanche of Shea Stadium boos, disappeared into the dugout without a peep.

title: Put Down the Remote; Yachting's on ESPN
description: So it's action you want and tomorrow at 4 P.M. you're torn between NBC's Portland-Utah game and yachting on ESPN. You know what you'll get with the Blazers and the Jazz. Clyde Drexler will be swooping and hooping (whoa, stop me before I Walt Frazierize again) and Karl Malone will be delivering roundball mail.

title: Romanian Creates a Cabinet To Press Economic Policies
description: Prime Minister Petre Roman has reshaped the Government by creating an eight-member inner Cabinet to insure that his new economic policies are properly implemented, the Government press agency Rompres said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 539 money market mutual funds increased by $3.57 billion, to $468.63 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 190 institutional funds increased by $3.51 billion, to $136.16 billion. The assets of the 259 general-purpose funds were up by $307 million, to $179.76 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $241.8 million, to $152.71 billion, the institute said.

title: N.A.S.D. Sets Rules for Brokers on Limited Partnerships
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, after months of criticism, imposed rules yesterday to eliminate potential conflicts of interest for brokers participating in a type of restructuring of limited partnerships, an investment vehicle that became widely popular in the 1980's, particularly for tax shelters.

title: Kuwait Will Begin Trying Collaboration Suspects
description: The first trials of people accused of collaborating with Iraqi forces during the seven-month occupation of Kuwait are to begin on Saturday.

title: Where Do We Look For Our New Heroes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nunn Fight Looks Like an Economic Prize for His Resurgent Hometown
description: In an era when prime-time fights routinely land in Las Vegas and Reno and Atlantic City, where casinos use them to draw high rollers to their gaming tables, a hometown hero has returned here to the banks of the Mississippi to defend his world title.

title: INSIDE
description: Kennedy's Nephew Charged William K. Smith was formally charged with the rape of a woman at the Kennedy family's seaside estate in Florida. He must surrender by early next week. Page A18. Anxiety Over Quayle A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that most Americans were worried about the prospect of a Dan Quayle Presidency. Page A14.

title: BAGHDAD REJECTS U.N. POLICE FORCE TO PROTECT KURDS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations told President Bush today that Baghdad had turned down an American-supported proposal for a United Nations police force in northern Iraq, raising the possibility that American troops might have to stay there far longer than the Administration had hoped.

title: Avery Fisher Mit Schlag
description: Opulent pastries and high-octane coffee are featured at a new Austrian-style coffeehouse that opens today in the lobby of Avery Fisher Hall. The theatrical 90-seat cafe, with hand-painted murals depicting scenes from Mozart's operas as well as displays of costumes from famous Austrian operas, is a gift to Lincoln Center from the Federal Economic Chamber of Austria. The donation honors the center's current Mozart Bicentennial celebration, which continues through August 1992.

title: In the Center of the Storm at Stanford
description: Most mornings, Donald Kennedy, the gangly president of Stanford University, is out at dawn running the smooth foothills that edge this 8,000-acre, palm-lined campus nicknamed The Farm.

title: TV Weekend; 'Summer's Lease': Gielgud in Chiantishire
description: Filmed in the Tuscany region of Italy, with its enchanting hill towns and sumptuous vistas, "Summer's Lease" is more successful as travelogue than drama. But the four-part series, having its "Masterpiece Theater" premiere on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. on Sunday, does have its dotty moments, most of them provided by John Gielgud as an irrepressible old satyr who insists, with unflagging elegance, that "most of what's interesting in life goes on below the belt."

title: TV Audience Hears It Loud: New York Is in Big Trouble
description: As Maria Tisch heard Mayor David N. Dinkins tell New Yorkers on television on Wednesday that their libraries could close and that thousands could be laid off in the coming hard times, she was struck, she said, by a single thought: New York is no longer a place where dreams come true.

title: Stewart Streak on Line
description: DAVE STEWART, the Oakland Athletics right-hander who has won at least 20 games in each of the last four seasons, is in danger of ending his streak of 166 consecutive starts. Stewart, 34 years old, has never been on the disabled list in his 10-year major league career, but he now admits to concern about his current condition. He was forced to leave a game against the Baltimore Orioles in the second inning on Wednesday after feeling a sharp pain in his left side as he was striking out SAM HORN .

title: Leslie John Adkins, 92, Pastor and Psychologist
description: Leslie John Adkins, a Congregational minister and a psychologist, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Market Place; Santa Anita Sees Odds in Its Favor
description: CLIFFORD C. GOODRICH says his business drew fewer customers this year than last, and he thinks the number will fall off dramatically next year. And those facts are positive, he says.

title: Baker Carrying Compromise Proposals to Mideast
description: When he leaves for the Middle East on Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will be looking for answers to some compromise proposals that American officials say might finally bridge the differences between Israel and the Arabs over how to convene a peace conference.

title: American Air Adds Flights to Britain
description: American Airlines announced an expanded schedule between the United States and London after acquiring routes into Heathrow Airport last week from Trans World Airlines. American, the biggest United States carrier, will fly 12 times a day from seven American cities to London with the inclusion of T.W.A. routes from New York-Newark, Boston and Los Angeles. The Boston service and most of the routes from the New York-Newark area begin on July 1. The rest begin on July 20.

title: Hey, Dude, That's One Serious Pitch
description: Madison Avenue is being overrun by dudes with attitudes. This time, though, the dudes are working not in the advertising agencies, but in the ads.

title: Head of Quaker State Steps Down at Meeting
description: Quentin E. Wood, who rose during a 43-year career at the Quaker State Corporation from field engineer to chairman, resigned at the motor oil company's annual meeting yesterday. He will be succeeded by Jack W. Corn, who will also retain the title of chief executive.

title: Bullets Name Woman As Team President
description: ABE POLLIN, owner of the Washington Bullets, named SUSAN O'MALLEY team president yesterday, making her the first woman in National Basketball Association history to hold that title.

title: Fielder Ends Home Run Drought in Tigers Victory
description: Cecil Fielder homered and Dan Petry combined with Paul Gibson on the shutout as the Detroit Tigers beat the Minnesota Twins, 3-0, tonight for their eighth victory in nine games.

title: At the Bar; Don't be surprised if the next landmark ruling is 'Day v. Knight' or 'Dog v. Katz.'
description: William Marbury, Homer Plessy, and Clarence Earl Gideon, all of whom are enshrined in Supreme Court lore, were real people with real names. Not so Jane Roe, as in Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 decision upholding legalized abortions.

title: Abroad at Home; Abusing The Law
description: American law offers numerous examples of vexatious litigation -- abusive, inflated, meritless lawsuits. But my candidate for the prize in outrageousness is a libel suit still making its way through the courts. It is called Immuno A.G. v. Moor-Jankowski.

title: Soak the Rich? No. Help the Poor
description: Four senior Democrats, led by Senator Albert Gore and Representative Thomas Downey, proposed a bill to lower taxes on poor families with children and raise taxes on the very rich. That's a seductive combination: a way to play Robin Hood without costing the Treasury a dime.

title: Saddam Hussein's Pistol
description: Once again Saddam Hussein is sending an important message, clear and in the open.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "I think we are really changing this shack," ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG said Wednesday night at the opening reception for the National Gallery of Art exhibition, "Rauschenberg Overseas Culture Interchange." The exhibition, which opens to the public Sunday, includes 150 works created in a nomadic six-year project that took the artist to 10 countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's commissioner for competition and financial services, misidentified the Italian company ordered by the European Commission to repay certain state subsidies. It was Finmeccanica, the state-owned company that sold Alfa Romeo to Fiat; it was not Fiat. Finmeccanica was ordered to reimburse the Italian Government for subsidies Finmeccanica had given to Alfa Romeo.

title: Gephardt Backs Effort On Trade With Mexico
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader, who ran for President in 1988 on a platform of restricting trade with unfair competitors, today cautiously endorsed the negotiation of a free-trade pact with Mexico.

title: Man vs. Nature in L.I. Beach Restoration
description: One end of Dune Road washed away here five years ago, when a raging northeaster sent the ocean crashing in. Now there is only sand, marked by the deep ruts of four-wheel-drive vehicles and the top of an occasional buried fire hydrant.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Japan Brokerages On Credit Watch
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday put the debt ratings of the four largest Japanese brokerages on credit watch with negative implications. S.& P. said the potential amount of debt that might be affected was about $2.39 billion.

title: Bons Mots of a Master
description: Though Billy Wilder always collaborates on his screenplays, there is a cutting edge to the dialogue that is consistent throughout his work with each succeeding partner.

title: Sage-Allen Merger With Addis Seen
description: Sage-Allen & Company, an 11-unit department store chain based in Hartford, reached a tentative agreement to merge with Addis & Dey's of Syracuse, which operates seven stores. The two companies said a final agreement was expected within the next few weeks. No financial information about the merger was available.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Post-Mortems, Round 1

title: Auctions
description: A Frida Kahlo

title: Earle Palmer Brown Gets Lottery Account
description: There will be no fantasies of picking the right number and becoming a millionaire in the new advertising for the Florida State Lottery.

title: Jerome P. Pickard, 74, Is Dead; Early Forecaster of Urban Spread
description: Jerome P. Pickard, a geographer and a specialist in economic development who was senior adviser on demographics to the Appalachian Regional Commission for two decades, died on Monday at his summer home in Amagansett, L. I. He was 74 years old and also lived in Somerset, Md.

title: Van With $305 Million in Cocaine Is Seized
description: The van rolling up Riverside Drive was riding low -- weighted down, drug agents found, by more than 1,000 pounds of cocaine.

title: Man Admits Bomb Scheme
description: A man accused of planning to bomb a chemical storage center in a case that raised fears of terrorism during the Persian Gulf war pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court. The 57-year-old defendant, Charles Edward Gresham Jr., admitted conspiracy, manufacture of an illegal bomb and attempted bombing in an unsuccessful plot to collect from an insurance policy covering chemicals he owned. The chemicals were stored at the Allied Terminals center, 10 miles from the Norfolk Naval Base. He faces up to 25 years in prison and a $750,000 fine when he is sentenced on Sept. 4.

title: Soviet Army Is Reported to Attack And Occupy 2 Armenian Villages
description: The Soviet Army was reported to be occupying two Armenian-populated villages in the republic of Azerbaijan late today after opening fire, officials of the Armenian republic said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Today I have received a very clear rejection from the Iraqi government. They do not want a United Nations police force." -- Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations. [ A10:1. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the political situation in Yugoslavia referred incorrectly to the Information Minister of Slovenia, Jelko Kacin. He is the former Deputy Defense Minister of Slovenia, not of Croatia. A map with the article located Listica incorrectly. It is in Bosnia and Herzegovina, not in Croatia.

title: Alarmed Australia Bans Political Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Death, Sex Change and Resurrection
description: In the Opening sequence of "Switch," the new Blake Edwards comedy, Steve Brooks (Perry King), a serenely unaware male chauvinist pig, finds himself sharing a hot tub with three beautiful women who hate him. Just as he's warming to the situation, they drown him. Steve, who is as resilient as Rasputin, rises from the water seriously irritated. They shoot him.

title: Critic's Choice/Festival; Stories, Songs and Dance
description: Some festivals are named for the charming Old World cities or balmy resorts where they occur. Others have names that allude to a lofty art form or a pricey commercial sponsor. Not Performance Space 122, whose spring performing-arts festival is sponsored by the Veselka Coffee Shop, a popular neighborhood hangout just a block away. The programs are just as down-to-earth in the Sixth Annual Veselka Festival this weekend. The evenings start at 8 in the second-floor theater with Rocky Bornstein's "For Crying Out Loud," which includes a dance duet for a large man and a small woman seeking equilibrium in an out-of-kilter world, set to rollicking music by Blue Gene Tyranny.

title: No Tax Dollars to Support Parochial Schools; Value of Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: Aureole

title: Economic Scene; Why Some See A Longer Slump
description: IS the recession bottoming out?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS No. 1 Edberg Advances Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the world's top-ranked player, defeated Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the German Open in Hamburg. Edberg will play a hometown hero, Michael Stich, who advanced by defeating Francisco Clavet of Spain, 6-1, 6-4. Pete Sampras of the United States was eliminated by Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-2. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: A campaign to aid Kurdish refugees, conceived by the author JEFFREY ARCHER, will reach its peak Sunday at a four-hour benefit concert in London with an international cast of performers. The final lineup, announced yesterday, includes CHRIS de BURGH, M. C. HAMMER, GLORIA ESTEFAN, WHITNEY HOUSTON, NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, PAUL SIMON, STING, ROD STEWART and SINEAD O'CONNOR.

title: Golf on TV? Certainly. Television in Golf? No.
description: Golf has always been proud of its fierce adherence to its rules, but last Sunday in the final round of the GTE Byron Nelson Classic, it adhered so fiercely it impugned the integrity of one of its most respected players.

title: Joe Isuzu Loses a Big Client And So Does Della Femina
description: The advertising agency that created the popular "lying" Joe Isuzu car campaign was dismissed yesterday. No lie.

title: New Claims by Unemployed Fell Sharply in Late April
description: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits declined significantly at the end of April, the Government reported today. Analysts saw the drop as a possible sign that the worst of the recession was over.

title: Diluted New Jersey Gun Bill Advances
description: A bill that would allow 200,000 owners of assault firearms to keep the high-powered weapons seemed assured of passage after a committee vote today, but it is unlikely to take effect in time to shield the gun owners from possible prosecution under a ban on the guns that Gov. Jim Florio won last year.

title: Alice Fetzer Carse, 59, Humanities Professor
description: Alice Fetzer Carse, a professor of comparative humanities at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, L.I., died on Wednesday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 59 years old.

title: Brady Hopeful on Bank Bill After Talk With Democrats
description: Encouraged by discussions with some Democrats on Capitol Hill today, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady predicted that Congress would adopt "significant banking legislation" by its August recess.

title: Review/Art; What an Old Scroll Tells About Buddhism in Korea
description: "The Story of a Painting: A Korean Buddhist Treasure From the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation" is the first exhibition at the Asia Society that was conceived under its new director, Dr. Vishakha N. Desai, and it points one of New York's revered institutions of Asian art in a new direction.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: Books of The Times; Her Friends Included Nietzsche, Rilke and Freud
description: Looking Back The Memoirs of Lou Andreas-Salome Illustrated. Edited by Ernst Pfeiffer. Translated by Breon Mitchell. 226 pages. Paragon House . $18.95.

title: Review/Theater; Lindsay Crouse as the Wife of a Klansman
description: Although it surely was not her intention, Darrah Cloud has brought off the bizarre feat of writing a politically correct play about the 1963 bombing of a black church in Birmingham, Ala., that all but ignores the bombing's victims. The play is titled "The Stick Wife," and rather than concern itself with the casualties of racism, it pleads what the author seems to feel is the now more timely cause of the Ku Klux Klan's oppressed wives. They, too, have a cross to bear.

title: Weekly Newspaper Charged With Violating Law on Rape
description: The Palm Beach County prosecutor today charged The Globe, a weekly newspaper printed in nearby Boca Raton and circulated in supermarkets nationwide, with two misdemeanor counts of violating a Florida law that prohibits disclosure of a rape victim's name.

title: New Jersey Bonds
description: An $84.8 million bond offering by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency was initially priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for securities due in 2011 and 2012 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The tax-exempt mortgage revenue bonds were priced to yield from 5.40 percent for an issue due in 1993 to 6 percent in 1996, 6.4 percent in 2001, 6.9 percent in 2007 and 7.05 percent in 2010. Underwriters said the bonds had been rated AA+ by S.& P.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., named Fred P. Corson vice president-research and development. * Orion Pictures Corp., New York, named Robert M. Mott vice president-finance and administration.

title: American Express Unit Names New President
description: The data processing unit of the American Express Company yesterday named Jeremiah M. Callaghan as president of its newly formed Securities Information Group division.

title: '900'-Line Curb Voted in House
description: A House subcommmittee today approved restrictions on "900"-number telephone lines and on telephone and facsimile advertisements.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Noises Off'

title: Citytrust Bancorp Says Help Is Near
description: Citytrust Bancorp Inc., the money-losing banking company that has asked the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for financial assistance, said it was nearing an agreement with private investors to infuse capital and help it avert a Government takeover. Elizabeth T. Doetzel, Citytrust's executive vice president for marketing, would not identify the potential investors, whom she described as individuals. She said that a merger with another financial institution was not part of the plan, and added that a recapitalization plan could be filed with regulators within the next few weeks.

title: SUNUNU IS ORDERED TO CLEAR FLIGHTS WITH BUSH LAWYER
description: Responding to embarrassing reports about the heavy use of military aircraft by his chief of staff, President Bush today ordered John H. Sununu to clear all future flights with the White House counsel in advance and banned the use of military aircraft for most of Mr. Sununu's political and personal travel.

title: A First for USAir: Corporate-Image Ads
description: Making USAir Group Inc. seem small town but not small time is the goal of the airline's first corporate-image campaign. The campaign, which will start on Monday, will be supported by $50 million in spending in the next 12 months.

title: Accounts
description: * Sterling Optical Inc. to Rothenberg, Winter & Davis Inc., New York, from Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York. Billings are $5 million to $7 million. * Faultless Starch-Bon Ami Co., Kansas City, Mo. to GSD&M Advertising, Austin, Tex., for consumer starch products. The budget has not been determined. The agency already handles advertising for the company's Bon Ami cleanser. * Harmon Glass, an installation and distribution division of Apogee Enterprises Inc., to the Edison Group, Minneapolis, a subsidiary of Martin-Williams Advertising Inc. * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a computer software company, to Bronner Slosberg Humphrey Inc., Boston. The agency said the account exceeded $5 million.

title: Transit Chiefs' Surprise Package: No Fare Increase in New York City
description: Months of dire threats about sharply higher fares for subway and bus riders came to an unexpected end yesterday when transit officials said they had found another way to close the Transit Authority's $232 million budget deficit.

title: Cheney Reports Gulf Accepting A U.S. Presence
description: The United States has reached general understandings with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf governments about the storing of American military equipment and other steps to maintain a long-term military presence in the region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today.

title: Review/Film; The Old Gift for Gadgetry And a New Robotic Sidekick
description: The real star of "FX2: The Deadly Art of Illusion" isn't Bryan Brown or Brian Dennehy, who have reunited for the sequel to the 1986 sleeper hit "F/X," but a clown robot named Bluey. Bluey is an ingenious contraption created by Rollie Tyler (Mr. Brown), a retired wizard of movie special effects turned toy designer whom the police persuade to apply his skills to a case that turns out to be at least as complicated as any of his inventions.

title: Progress In U.S.-Japan Building Pact
description: The United States and Japan have agreed on most issues in their dispute over public works contracts, but remain undecided on how many major Japanese projects to target for extra American participation, a senior Commerce Department official said today.

title: Supercollider Outlook: Higher Cost, Less Income
description: The cost of building a giant particle accelerator in Texas continues to rise while the prospects of attracting foreign partners to share the expense, as required by Congress, are declining, Congressional critics said today.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: No Boundaries

title: People
description: * Richard Hedger has been named chairman and chief executive of Ayer Europe, London. * Rosemary Serviss and Joe Venturini, both senior vice presidents and creative directors of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, have been appointed to the agency's operating committee.

title: Blazers Stave Off Jazz Rally, Lead 2-0
description: Terry Porter scored inside with 3.6 seconds to play as the Portland Trail Blazers survived an incredible Utah rally to beat the Jazz, 118-116, tonight and take a two-games-to-none lead in their Western Conference semifinal series.

title: Former Executive at Drexel Indicated in Conspiracy Case
description: A former senior executive with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was indicted yesterday on charges that he engaged in an illegal conspiracy with Michael R. Milken and a former Drexel client to commit securities fraud, embezzlement and other crimes.

title: Duncan Stalker; Editor, 36
description: Duncan Stalker, senior editor of Vanity Fair magazine, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 36 years old.

title: Brawley Case Ruling Favors Ex-Prosecutor
description: A state judge has ruled that Tawana Brawley intentionally inflicted emotional distress upon a former Dutchess County assistant district attorney by falsely claiming that he was involved in a sexual attack on the teen-ager in November 1987.

title: India Sends Army to Srinagar After Killings
description: India sent the army into Srinagar, the Kashmiri capital, today and imposed a curfew to prevent disturbances after the killing of 14 people on Wednesday by security forces.

title: Review/Art; 'Pontormo to Seurat,' Drawings From Art Institute of Chicago to the Frick
description: For most people, a great museum means great paintings, and drawings are an afterthought. But as "From Pontormo to Seurat," at the Frick Collection, makes clear, great museums view things differently.

title: No Tax Dollars to Support Parochial Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Bird and Celtics Bounce Back to Tie Series
description: Chuck Daly, the Detroit Pistons' coach, maintains that "losing teams make changes." But the Celtics needed only one change this afternoon at the Boston Garden. They needed Larry Bird back in the lineup.

title: Boston's Answer? 2 Inspiring Birds
description: Forget the shaky symbolism of the bird's being a pigeon. Its heritage notwithstanding, this was one stubborn, feisty little critter, much like the other resident Bird of Boston Garden.

title: What Law Can Do in Interstate Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title:
Housing in Brooklyn;
70 Condos in a Former Furniture Plant
description: Tiffany Mews, a 70-unit condominium development refashioned from a 19th-century brick factory in South Brooklyn, opened for sales last week at a time the area's housing revival has been forced into slow motion by the recession.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League NEW YORK YANKEES -- Placed Andy Hawkins, pitcher, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Purchased the contract of Steve Howe, pitcher, from Columbus of the International League. National League CHICAGO CUBS -- Optioned Erik Pappas, catcher, to Iowa of the American Association. Recalled Steve Wilson, pitcher, from Iowa.

title: New York: It's Not For Everyone
description: HERE is the beautiful thing about Fun City: It costs $4 to enter via the George Washington Bridge, but absolutely nothing to leave.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Flavored Oils Return

title: Violence Program Gives High Value for Money
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warns 250 Campuses of Audit on Overhead Costs Linked to Grants
description: The Government put 250 of the nation's universities on notice today that overhead charges connected with research grants may be audited. It acted after naming 14 more universities that had tried to charge the Government for things like jewelry, trips to Caribbean resorts and the operation of a "haunted" burial ground for radioactive cadavers.

title: Broadest Protests Since '87 Rock Korea
description: Tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters rallied in major cities across South Korea today, demanding the resignation of President Roh Tae Woo.

title: Officer Injured By Bomb Tossed In Robbery Bid
description: A rookie police officer was listed in stable condition yesterday after being wounded by a bomb as three men bungled a house robbery in Queens late Wednesday and then terrorized other people as they fled, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about WNYC's television and radio stations misidentified a program on WNYC- TV. It is "New York Hotline," not "Prime Time."

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Duo Reunited

title: Kelly Trying to Recover Ground Lost to Injuries
description: Sean Kelly was the first to admit he did not learn from his mistakes.

title: Review/Art; A Weaving of Stainless-Steel Thread
description: Kyoko Kumai is identified as one of "Japan's leading fiber artists" in the brochure accompanying her "Projects" exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. The artist, who is 48 years old, is virtually unknown in the United States, but the claim is easily confirmed by "Air," a large environmental weaving that fills the Modern's "Projects" gallery with a cascade of stainless-steel thread.

title: Brazil's Economy Chief Out; Envoy to U.S. Gets the Post
description: Pressed by a deep recession, stubborn inflation and restive foreign creditors, President Fernando Collor de Mello today replaced Zelia Cardoso de Mello as Economy Minister, traditionally Brazil's second most powerful Government post, with Brazil's Ambassador to the United States.

title: Penguins Push Bruins To Brink
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins' firepower finally came to the surface tonight in a 7-2 triumph over the Bruins that silenced Boston Garden.

title: Educator Back After Removal Over '74 Crime
description: After hearing from hundreds of angry parents, Community School Board 1 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan has reversed itself and reinstated a Superintendent it removed for failing to reveal a 1974 conviction on drug charges.

title: Kennedy Nephew Is Charged With Rape
description: William K. Smith was formally charged by a county prosecutor today with the rape and battery of a woman who said she drove him home from a nightclub, walked with him on the beach and then was assaulted by him on the grounds of his family's seaside estate.

title: Voyage Across a Storm-Shattered Bangladesh
description: Three-year-old Badshar survived when a cyclone sent a 20-foot storm tide into this village last week, but it is too early to say whether that makes him lucky. Lacking shelter, food and clean water, he is already ill, and it may be that he withstood the destruction only to face a slow death from hunger and diarrhea.

title: Florio Lays Off 1,000 Workers In Fiscal Trims
description: The Florio administration today announced the layoffs of 1,000 state workers and sent notices to 20,000 workers that their jobs may be affected by cuts meant to balance New Jersey's 1992 budget.

title: Rudolf Serkin, 88, Concert Pianist, Dies
description: Rudolf Serkin, one of the most revered pianists of his time and a founder of the Marlboro Festival, the summer music series in Vermont, died on Wednesday night at his Vermont home after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Yankees Drop Hawkins and Recall Howe
description: The Yankees spent another day in last place, but they have apparently decided to finally do something about it. Yesterday, they took the first step in a belated shakeup, releasing pitcher Andy Hawkins and purchasing the contract of Steve Howe from their Columbus farm team.

title: Rebel Attacks in El Salvador Cut Power Supplies in Half
description: In what they say is a tactic to put pressure on the Government to negotiate a cease-fire, leftist guerrillas have sabotaged the power system in recent days on a scale that has left El Salvador with about half its normal electricity supply.

title: How House Members Voted
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 239 to 186 by which the House approved a bill on Wednesday requiring a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun. A "yes" vote is a vote to require the waiting period. Voting "yes" were 179 Democrats and 60 Republicans. Voting "no" were 83 Democrats, 102 Republicans and one Independent. Y is a "yes" vote. N is a "no" vote. X denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were "present" at the time of the vote but did not vote "yes" or "no" on the issue. There are four vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats -- Bevill, N; Browder, N; Cramer, N; Erdreich, N; Harris, N. Republicans -- Callahan, N; Dickinson, N.

title: New York's Government: Is It Too Big?
description: As New York City officials struggle to cope with a tide of red ink by turning off street lights and shutting down drug-treatment programs, many are asking a more fundamental question: has the local government simply grown too big for its own good?

title: Miscellany
description: * Bozell Inc., New York, has formally entered the Irish advertising market. The agency's European division yesterday signed an exclusive contract with Quinn McDonnell Patterson, Dublin. * Howard-Sloan-Koller Group, New York, an executive recruiting firm, has acquired Jerry Fields Assocites, an executive search firm specializing in advertising, graphic design and marketing. Jerry Fields will remain chairman of his namesake company.

title: NEC Unit to Pay $34 Million to U.S. in Bid-Rigging Case
description: The Justice Department said today that a subsidiary of the NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest electronics manufacturers, had agreed to pay the United States Government $34 million to settle bid-rigging charges arising from telecommunications contracts with the United States military in Japan.

title: Israel's Man, Scorched Once, Adjusts To Life in the Diplomatic Minefield
description: "Outrageous and outside the bounds of acceptable behavior."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a House vote on the Brady gun control bill characterized the votes of two members incorrectly. Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa, voted against both an amendment offered by Representative Harley O. Staggers Jr. and the Brady bill. Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, favored the Brady bill both this year and in 1988. Neither reversed his position on the Brady bill after the 1988 vote.

title: Holiday for Civil Rights, Not Just Dr. King
description: The House of Representatives in New Hampshire, one of only two states that do not have a paid holiday for state workers in honor of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., has voted to create a paid holiday honoring civil rights but has left King's name off the measure.

title: OLDER WOMEN FACE BIAS IN WORKPLACE
description: Although middle-aged and older women make up an increasing portion of the work force, they are paid substantially less than men their age, reach their peak earnings a decade earlier than men and are still largely segregated in traditional "women's jobs," a report by the Older Women's League says.

title: Your Money; School Vacation Tax Advantages
description: With school holidays approaching, single parents and working couples with young children are scrambling to arrange for their care, while many older students are looking for summer jobs. Both situations can offer opportunities for tax savings.

title: Executive Pay in 3 Countries
description: The top salaries in large American companies go to financial officers, while in Germany the top pay goes to those in charge of research, according to a survey by a United States management consulting firm.

title: New Saturn Setback; G.M. to Replace Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation's bid to make and market a small car that directly challenges Japanese models suffered a serious blow today when its Saturn Corporation announced a second recall and made an unprecedented offer to replace 1,836 cars with faulty engine-cooling systems.

title: The Promise of Peace in Belfast
description: The telltale figures in Northern Ireland are these: 900,000, 600,000 and 2,875. The first figure represents the Protestant population in the British-ruled province; next is the total of Roman Catholics; third is the number of people slaughtered there in political violence since 1969. The ambitious purpose of talks just begun in Belfast is to quell the violence by establishing a regional government acceptable to majority and minority, thereby ending direct rule from London.

title: South Korea Softens a Tough Security Law
description: In an effort to quell the protests that have disrupted the country all week, Parliament relaxed the country's strict national security law today. But tonight a fifth protester set himself on fire in a protest against the Government of President Roh Tae Woo.

title: Governing Governor Sununu
description: John Sununu has greatly enjoyed the vast power that goes with being White House chief of staff, including virtually unlimited discretion over his own travel budget. Yet he somehow managed to exceed even those generous boundaries and embarrass his boss, George Bush, who aspires to lead an ethical Administration. For this Governor Sununu has been spanked, his perquisites pulled. Oddly, he professes not to understand what happened.

title: Loss Ahead for Shearson
description: The action taken yesterday against the First Capital Life Insurance Company will have a large impact on Shearson Lehman Brothers, which announced that it would take a charge to earnings of about $144 million related to its 28 percent stake in the company.

title: U.P.S. Is Latest to See Prices Diminish the Lure of Suburbs
description: When the United Parcel Service moved its corporate headquarters here in 1975, it was part of an exodus of companies fleeing the high costs of living and working in New York City.

title: Tarpley Enters a Plea
description: ROY TARPLEY, the beleagured Dallas Maverick who was charged on Sunday with beating his girlfriend, entered a plea of not guilty yesterday and given 14 days to secure an attorney. Tarpley, who was suspended from the National Basketball Association last month after his latest run-in with the police in Dallas, was arrested in Houston early Sunday after ARDIA PRESTON called the police from his apartment there and told them Tarpley had beaten her after she told him she was returning to Dallas. Tarpley, who lives in Dallas, has been staying in Houston while undergoing his latest round of treatment for alcohol abuse. . . . DAN MAJERLE, the star Phoenix Suns who has been bothered by numbness and weakness in his right thigh since early April, will undergo surgery, probably next week, to remove a spinal cyst doctors say has been causing the problem by irritating a nerve. (AP)

title: Mass Transit Must Be Considered a Necessity
description: To the Editor:

title: Redcoats Are Coming, Again
description: In a bit of overstatement, which doesn't seem out of place in the World League of American Football, Jon Smith, the chief executive officer of the London Monarchs, equated tonight's game at Giants Stadium between his team and the New York/New Jersey Knights to the American Revolution.

title: Rates Climb in an Unsettled Market
description: Long-term interest rates soared yesterday as the Treasury securities market was unsettled by fact and rumor. After shrugging off a modest rise in the April Producer Price Index, dealers began shaving prices of Treasury notes and bonds they had bought at this week's quarterly refunding auction.

title: Fishing Rights for the Few Is Un-American; No to Inefficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget to Raise a Host of Fees
description: Besides about $1 billion in new taxes, the budget plan of Mayor David N. Dinkins relies on many increased fees and charges, including 1,000 new meters in the Theater District to charge 75 cents an hour for evening parking that is now free.

title: NWA Has Loss of $62 Million
description: NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, said today that it lost $62 million in the first quarter of 1991. It attributed the results to higher fuel prices and lower traffic caused by the recession and the Persian Gulf war.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Movie Clock in Weekend yesterday omitted listings intended for readers in New York City, Long Island and Connecticut. A corrected version appears today on page 14.

title: Phinney Takes Stage With Help of Friends
description: The 11-day Tour Du Pont bicycle race hit the road today, and the outcome was almost a case of deja vu. With a mad sprint finish over the last 300 meters, Davis Phinney broke away from his old 7-Eleven teammates and won the day's 106-mile stage by the length of a bicycle, about 6 feet.

title: North Stars Rise to Final Berth, Ending Era of the Oilers
description: The Minnesota North Stars' incredible playoff journey is now three-fourths complete. The Edmonton Oilers' glorious ride as one of sports' great dynasties is apparently over.

title: Loyal Fans Around the Diamond: 'You Can Do It, Baby!'
description: Early in the season, 19-year-old Yesenia Herarte, the George Washington High School baseball team's most radiant fan -- she finds it necessary to wear a fake wedding ring to discourage men -- had some fielding advice for the star third baseman, Manny (the Hitman) Ramirez.

title: Patents; New Memory Chip Said to Aid Data Processing
description: Steven G. Morton, an entrepreneur in Oxford, Conn., obtained a patent this week on what he called an "intelligent memory chip" that features both a memory and dozens of small processors.

title: Propeller Inspections Ordered on Commuter Planes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered commuter airlines to inspect immediately a type of engine used on scores of the world's most popular small passenger planes, looking for worn propeller parts that could cause pilots to lose control of the propellers suddenly.

title:
OUTDOORS;
A New Canoe and a New Outlook
description: The canoe, a gift from a friend, arrived by truck from Massachusetts on a somber November day, one of those winter days when the cold goes deep, settles against the bones.

title: Surgery for Kocur
description: You think repeatedly beating rival hockey players about the head and face without so much as a glove to protect your knuckles doesn't take its toll on a man's fist? Just ask JOE KOCUR, the notorious enforcer the Rangers acquired from the Detroit Red Wings late last season. Yesterday the Rangers said Kocur had undergone surgery to repair damage to the knuckle below the middle finger of his right hand, the very one Kocur has used to knock out rivals throughout his career. (AP)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cartier Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Cartier International Inc., named Robert Filotei vice president of its wholesale division. * Food Lion Inc., Salisbury, N.C., named John P. Watkins senior vice president of operations.

title: A Reckoning For Dinkins
description: In proposing the darkest budget New York City has seen since its brush with bankruptcy 16 years ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday, "No one is to blame for this crushing burden." But it is weighted by bundles this Mayor chose to carry.

title: Mourning and Keefe Planning to Stay Put
description: On the eve of the deadline for declaring early eligibility for the National Basketball Association college draft, two star juniors, Georgetown center ALONZO MOURNING and Stanford center-forward ADAM KEEFE, said yesterday that they had decided to stay in college rather than turn pro this year.

title: Patents; Obtaining A Videotape Day or Night
description: Call it video to go. The Thru-the-Wall Corporation, a start- up company in Madison, Conn., has invented an automated teller machine that lets customers check out videocassette tapes from their video stores 24 hours a day.

title: Music in Review
description: Marc-Andre Hamelin and Sophie Rolland Pianist and Cellist Weill Recital Hall

title: Bela A. Balassa, 63, Economics Professor Who Fled Hungary
description: Bela A. Balassa, an economist and a retired professor of political economy at Johns Hopkins University who specialized in trade and development, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 63 years old.

title: Inquiry at Howard
description: Howard University said the National Collegiate Athletic Association was investigating irregularities the school had uncovered in its Division I-AA football program under former coach, WILLIE JEFFRIES, who left after the 1988 season to take over the program at South Carolina State.

title: About New York
description: Dear Anolta,

title: Soviet Minister Ends Visit to Israel With No Accord but Little Discord
description: The highest-level visit to Israel by a Soviet official ended this evening with no significant agreement to renew formal diplomatic relations or resolution of outstanding differences between Moscow and Jerusalem.

title: Officers Who Watched Beating Are Cleared
description: A grand jury has decided not to indict any of the police officers who stood by and watched as fellow officers beat a black motorist two months ago, the Los Angeles County District Attorney said today.

title: Wheat and Lumber Surge as Supplies Appear Lower
description: Wheat prices bounded higher today after the Agriculture Department released a lower-than-expected estimate for the winter wheat crop. Lumber prices also rose sharply on tight supplies.

title: Joseph A. Numero, Shipper, 94
description: Joseph A. Numero, an executive credited with revolutionizing the transportion of perishable foods, died Wednesday at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 94 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Central Bancshares of the South Inc., Birmingham, Ala., completed the acquisitions of two Dallas area banks from Metroplex Bancshares Inc. for undisclosed terms. * Chili's Inc., Dallas, a restaurant operator, changed its name to Brinker International Inc.

title: Beliefs
description: Two years ago doctors found that Michael, a 53-year-old Minnesotan, was suffering from lung cancer and that the disease had spread to his brain. He underwent surgery and radiation treatment. Some months later a tube was inserted into the membrane surrounding his spinal cord so painkillers could be regularly injected. But eventually the injections no longer checked the pain.

title: Loyal Fans Around the Diamond: You Can Do It, Baby!
description: Early in the season, 19-year-old Yesenia Herarte, the George Washington High School baseball team's most radiant fan -- she finds it necessary to wear a fake wedding ring to discourage men -- had some fielding advice for the star third baseman, Manny (the Hitman) Ramirez.

title: SAUDIS EASE STAND ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: Saudi Arabia plans to announce that it will join with its five Arab gulf allies in sending an observer to attend any peace conference between Israel and the Arabs, a senior Saudi official said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Top-Seeded Chang Eliminated

title: Medeva P.L.C.
description: Medeva P.L.C., a British medical and science group, agreed to buy M D Pharmaceutical Inc., a privately owned pharmaceutical company in California, for about $77 million. It said it planned to finance the deal by offering new shares. The purchase would be Medeva's first move into the United States pharmaceutical market. M D's 1990 operating profits were $8.3 million on sales of $15.5 million.

title: Dr. Lewis Shenker, 64, An Obstetrician, Dies
description: Dr. Lewis Shenker, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died on Thursday at the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson. He was 64 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Dinkins Budget Recalls His Promise to Be the Toughest Mayor on Crime
description: The stark differences in financing between the Police Department and the Department of Parks and Recreation exemplify the harsh choices that Mayor David N. Dinkins has had to make. In a sense, it is a battle for diminishing resources between those who count themselves among the keepers of the city's soul and those who are the keepers of its safety.

title: Stocks Wilt in Fallout From Treasury Sale
description: Stocks fell sharply late yesterday, more than erasing Thursday's strong gains. Traders attributed the slide to plunging bond prices.

title: Ticket-Writing Quotas Abuse the Motorist
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Bugging Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Lee Adding Australian Units
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed to buy 10 subsidiaries of the Linter Textiles Corporation, an Australian apparel company, for an undisclosed sum. Sara Lee, which makes food, clothing and other consumer products, said it would run the subsidiaries as separate entities. The Hilton Hosiery Company Ltd., a Linter subsidiary purchased by Sara Lee, controls about 70 percent of the domestic market in Australia.
