title: Modest Steps In Yugoslavia
description: The latest round of violence in Yugoslavia has jolted the nation's quarreling leaders into taking the first modest steps toward a negotiated settlement of their differences.

title: Ford Shifts Top Posts in Sales and Marketing
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a shuffling of some top sales and marketing executives yesterday as part of its effort to improve domestic car sales.

title: Fishing Rights for the Few Is Un-American; Conflicts of Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: The Accused in the Palm Beach Case: Quiet, Different and Somewhat Aloof
description: They bear little resemblance to each other, the William K. Smith charged as a rapist in Palm Beach and the William K. Smith described by friends, fellow medical students, relatives and teachers who knew him before.

title: Bush Scolds Congress at Princeton
description: Making his first trip out of Washington since he was released from the hospital, President Bush traveled to Princeton University today to receive an honorary degree and deliver a speech criticizing Congress as usurping the powers of the Presidency.

title: Lifeline for Children: New Laws for Pools
description: Tougher safety regulations for home swimming pools, intended primarily to protect children, are being imposed in many states. At the same time, safety experts are continuing to warn against the use of a popular device, the floating alarm, as the sole source of protection.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Miami was not so sunny for LESLEY STAHL, a correspondent for the CBS program "60 Minutes." On Wednesday afternoon, she and an associate producer, BARBARA DURY, were driving to an interview when a mugger leaped into the back seat of their car.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about an agreement in the dispute over the discovery of the AIDS virus misstated the date of an article to be published in Science magazine. It will appear on May 17, not this week.

title: In Bangladesh's Storms, Poverty More Than Weather Is the Killer
description: Behind the immediate horror of the cyclone that killed more than 100,000 people last week lies a painful truth: It is not so much weather that is killing people as it is poverty.

title: Comptroller to Put Holdings in Trust
description: Robert L. Clarke, one of the nation's senior banking regulators, said today that he would place his investments in a blind trust in an effort to "lay to rest" questions about his financial affairs.

title: With G.I.'s Gone, Fear Creeps Like Sand Into an Iraqi Town
description: Little more than a scorching sand-laden wind filled the streets of this war-weary town today. There was, though, the unmistakable scent of fear.

title: Music in Review
description: Musicians From Marlboro Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Stanford Dismisses Instructor Who Boasted About Drug Use
description: Stanford University today dismissed a computer science instructor who had advocated drug use and boasted of carrying drugs in his backpack while on campus.

title: Guidepost; New Coats for the House
description: Late spring is an ideal time to paint the exterior of a house. There are four major gloss categories: flat, satin, semigloss and gloss. Either latex or oil-based (alkyd) paints can be used. Never paint unless the temperature is between 50 and 90 degrees and the surface is dry and clean. First scrape peeling areas, fill cracks and holes and replace damaged or rotten wood. Choose a paint that can be applied over the existing paint. (Latex paints do not do well over oil paints.) Use a primer if the wood is porous. Latex vs. Oil-Based Paint

title: The Recession Hits Home
description: Last Friday, my husband was laid off from his day job. Since I lost my full-time job nine months ago, he has taken every piece of work he can get. Next month, he will be laid off from his night job for just a few weeks, we hope.

title: Hawkins Is Sent Packing With Very Little Adieu
description: Andy Hawkins spent his first day home in Waco, Tex., watching his 4-year-old daughter run in a track meet. The pitcher said yesterday that he was adjusting to things, and was glad to have the burden of his release by the Yankees finally off his shoulders. But there was still one regret.

title: Beliefs
description: Two years ago doctors found that Michael, a 53-year-old Minnesotan, was suffering from lung cancer and that the disease had spread to his brain. He underwent surgery and radiation treatment. Some months later a tube was inserted into the membrane surrounding his spinal cord so painkillers could be regularly injected. But eventually the injections no longer checked the pain.

title: Lakers Beat Warriors and Grab 2-1 Lead
description: James Worthy scored 36 points as the Los Angeles Lakers cooled off the Golden State Warriors, 115-112, tonight, taking a 2-1 lead in their Western Conference semifinal series.

title: Isabel Cary Lundberg, Sociologist, 87
description: Isabel Cary Lundberg, an educator and sociologist, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: C. McKim Norton, 84, Ex-Leader Of Regional Plan Group, Is Dead
description: C. McKim Norton, former president of the Regional Plan Association, a private nonprofit group working for the development and conservation of the New York metropolitan region, died early yesterday at the Brookhaven Nursing Center in Lexington, Mass. He was 84 years old.

title: China Has Used Prison Labor in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridal Veil Journal; Town's 9 People Told: Make Way for Nature
description: Most company towns in the Pacific Northwest, where a timber baron or mining boss controlled the store, the housing and the people who labored there, are long gone.

title: Texas Governor Tells Graduates at A&M Of 'Star Trek' Path
description: In a commencement speech today at Texas A&M University, Gov. Ann Richards of Texas praised science and technology while also urging graduates to remember that "people are more important than things."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Protecting the Batter's Face
description: The sounds of baseball are familiar: the roar of the crowd, the smack of the ball hitting the glove, the crack of the bat. But too often what is getting cracked and smacked are teeth, jawbones, eyes and noses.

title: Black Frats Step Back
description: While verbal and physical attacks against African American students are at an all-time high nationwide, and while battlelines are being drawn over admissions quotas and culturally diverse curriculas, many black students are their own worst enemies.

title:
BASEBALL;
In Winning, Phils Count Their Losses
description: Under other circumstances it would have been cause for great celebration. The Philadelphia Phillies had beaten the San Diego Padres, 9-6, behind a superb performance by first baseman Ricky Jordan, and in doing so achieved a two-out-of-three victory in the series.

title: Joseph Brodsky Goes From Gulag to U.S. Poet Laureate
description: Joseph Brodsky, a former inmate of a Soviet farm labor camp who went on to master the idiom of American poetry and who won a Nobel Prize, was named the fifth poet laureate of the United States today by James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress.

title: Observer; Progress Crunches On
description: Prolix Illustration: There has been a fresh onset of technology at the office. As a result it is almost impossible to find out how long this column must be to fit the space. Literary people often make light of journalists because they have to write to fit the space, but while there are many things about newspaper prose to make light of, fitting the message to the space is not one of them. Sonnets are also written to fit the space, and a great deal of literature that isn't would be improved if it were. It is rare these days to find a biographer or historian who can tell his tale in fewer than 800 pages averaging 500 words per page. This results from the decline of editing in the book trade and the spread of the word processor, which makes it so easy to write that people keep doing it long after their minds have bedded down for the night. This paragraph, written on a word processor and prohibitively long by newspaper standards, illustrates how easy the new technology makes it to keep writing long after the author has forgotten what he started to say, as I have at this point.

title: Las Vegas, Connecticut
description: Gov. Lowell Weicker's last-ditch effort to forestall a casino on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation in Connecticut is legally uncertain, but his fear of spreading high-stakes gambling is well founded. The state already has a lottery, offtrack betting, dog racing, jai alai and charitable "Las Vegas nights." One casino would invite more, and the state would sink deeper into gambling.

title: An MCA Suit in Australia
description: MCA International sued Australia's Ten television network for $40 million today over the rights to screen movies and television shows.

title: California Curbs First Capital Life
description: California regulators placed sharp operating restrictions on the First Capital Life Insurance Company today. It was the second time in a month they have moved against a large insurer burdened with a deteriorating portfolio of high-risk "junk bonds."

title: Educator Returns to Roots at a Seminary
description: In the late 1960's, when Holland Lee Hendrix was an undergraduate at Columbia University, students there were wrestling with questions of war, racism and rights. He found answers to those questions at an institution just to the north -- Union Theological Seminary.

title: Let Patients Decide On Alzheimer's Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Pours In 46 Points But 76ers Find Way to Win
description: Even the magic of Michael Jordan could not stop the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: NCR to Speed A.T.& T. Link
description: The chairman of the NCR Corporation said today that his company would move swiftly to combine its operations with those of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Fishing Rights for the Few Is Un-American
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Makers Face Pressure To Restrain Price Increases
description: A new Federal law requiring drug makers to cut their prices to Medicaid programs has touched off efforts by virtually every other major purchaser to control the costs of prescription drugs.

title: Jobless Rise in Australia
description: Australia's unemployment rate has soared to 9.9 percent, the highest level in nearly eight years.

title: Boston Curator Moving to Whitney
description: Elizabeth Sussman, interim director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, has been named a curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art. The appointment, which is to take effect in the fall, was announced by the Whitney's director, David A. Ross, who was formerly the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art.

title: Beliefs
description: Two years ago doctors found that Michael, a 53-year-old Minnesotan, was suffering from lung cancer and that the disease had spread to his brain. He underwent surgery and radiation treatment. Some months later a tube was inserted into the membrane surrounding his spinal cord so painkillers could be regularly injected. But eventually the injections no longer checked the pain.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Festival of the Americas, Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 42d to 57th Street from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Merced Leads Pirates to 4th Straight
description: Rookie Orlando Merced continued his hot hitting with a tie-breaking home run and John Smiley became the National League's second five-game winner, leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight. It was Pittsburgh's fourth straight victory.

title: Ansonia Copper Buyout Approved
description: Employees of the Ansonia Copper and Brass Company have approved a buyout plan that will give them control of the company, the city's largest employer and taxpayer. The buyout plan, which gives the employees control over two-thirds of the company's stock for an undisclosed price, was approved by a vote of 299 to 99. The transaction should be completed by June 30, said the chairman of the buyout committee, Robert Pagano.

title: Airlines Pressed to Stop Transporting Wild Birds
description: Environmental groups are putting pressure on commercial air carriers to stop transporting wild tropical birds for the pet trade.

title: Mild Rise in Producer Price Index
description: Prices of finished goods as they left the factory rose a mild two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today. The report was fresh evidence that the recession is taking the steam out of inflation.

title: Charles Maurice Gourdon, Silk Manufacturer, 88
description: Charles Maurice Gourdon, a retired silk manufacturer died on Tuesday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 88 years old.

title: Key Rates
U.S. Presses Baghdad To Accept U.N. Force
description: The Bush Administration pressed Iraq to reconsider its rejection of a United Nations police force to secure the repatriation of the country's Kurdish population. United States military leaders said they would try to avoid further expansion of their security zone in northern Iraq.

title: 4 Officers Held in Illegal Search
description: Two sergeants and two officers from a narcotics team in Brooklyn were indicted yesterday in connection with an arrest last year in which prosecutors say a drug dealer's apartment was illegally searched.

title: Carner to Get Award
description: JOANNE CARNER will receive the Gold Tee Award at the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association annual awards dinner, which will be June 5 at the Sheraton Hotel in Stamford, Conn. Carner has won 42 L.P.G.A. titles, two United States Women's Opens and is a member of the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: A conference on architectural preservation ended in Prague on Thursday night with an plea from PRINCE CHARLES for international cooperation in preserving monuments. The conference, organized by the World Monuments Fund and the Prince's Business Leaders Forum, included 80 civic, cultural and business leaders from Europe and the United States.

title: Luxury Tax Under Attack
description: Repeal of the luxury tax on expensive cars is a top priority of the American International Automobile Dealers Association, the group's president, Walter Huizenga, said today.

title: Israelis Drop Order to Raze Home of a Slain Palestinian
description: The Israeli Army today canceled an order to demolish the three-room house of a Palestinian who was dead at the time that the military decided to punish him by tearing it down.

title: Woodbridge Schools Pay for Voter Support
description: As scores of communities in northern New Jersey rejected school budgets last week, residents of this sprawling suburb of 93,000 people voted their approval of a budget for the first time in 27 years.

title: A First Lady Bows Out
description: Martha Wilkinson, Kentucky's First Lady, today ended her campaign for the Democratic nomination to succeed her husband as governor. Mrs. Wilkinson said it had become clear that she could not win the race and that her continued presence was distracting the public from issues she considered important. Gov. Wallace Wilkinson, who is barred by state law from seeking another term, stood at his wife's side during her comments, which she made in front of the Governor's Mansion.

title: U.S. Will Cite Manhattan for Soot Level
description: After three years of monitoring bus and truck fumes on Madison Avenue, the Federal Government is preparing to cite New York City for violating health standards for the city's most visible form of pollution: soot.

title: Nancy Reagan: Mending a Frayed Image
description: Last week, as 25,000 children chanted her name at a Rose Bowl rally, Nancy Reagan heard herself described as "a terrific mother, a devoted wife and our guiding light." This week, Mrs. Reagan joined her husband to luxuriate in the applause of the California State Legislature and then took her "Just Say No" drug crusade to an Orange County elementary school.

title: Gertrude Z. Kemper, Philanthropist, 101
description: Gertrude Ziesing Kemper, chairman of the Kemper Educational and Charitable Foundation of Chicago, died Wednesday at her home in Chicago. She was 101 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in some editions on Wednesday about a fatal traffic accident on Flatbush Avenue in downtown Brooklyn misidentified one victim. She was Imogene Thompson.

title: Making Sense of Telephone Services
description: As long-distance and local telephone companies blanket the country with offers of new and elaborate services, more and more of their customers are becoming confused and irritated. Everywhere they turn, consumers are being confronted with yet another batch of choices through direct mail, telephone solicitations and advertisements.

title: Choral Works
description: Charles Dodsley Walker is to conduct the Canterbury Choral Society in Verdi's "Four Sacred Pieces" and Faure's Requiem at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, Manhattan, at 4 P.M. tomorrow. Suggested contribution is $10. Information: (212) 289-3402.

title: Chemical Ties by Venezuela
description: The Venezuelan oil industry plans to invest $500 million in the construction of 12 petrochemical plants in the eastern state of Anzoategui in a joint venture with foreign companies, officials said today.

title: Aetna Car Insurer Quits 8 More States
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said that it was withdrawing from the private passenger auto insurance markets in eight more states in its plan to pull out of unprofitable regions. The move brings to 22 the number of states in which Aetna has stopped writing personal auto insurance in the last 18 months. "These withdrawals are part of the company's nationwide strategy not to commit capital to areas where it cannot earn an adequate rate of return," said Sal Foti, Aetna spokesman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Sears, Roebuck annual meeting referred incorrectly to the affiliation of Robert A. G. Monks with the Boston Company, an American Express subsidiary. Mr. Monks, who was trying to win a seat on the Sears board, is a former top executive of the Boston Company, not a current one.

title: Patents; Composition May Help in Treating Glaucoma
description: David F. Woodward, a researcher at Allergan Inc., a manufacturer of eye care and skin care products, has patented a composition that could prove useful in treating glaucoma.

title: No Headline
description: Hong Kong Tower Sale by Citibank

title: Man Cleared of Murder In Aiding Wife's Suicide
description: A 73-year-old California man who traveled with his cancer-stricken wife to Michigan last year so that he could help her take her own life was found not guilty today of second-degree murder.

title: A Summer Summit to Cut Arms
description: Once-dreaded Soviet SS-20 missiles no longer threaten Europe or the Far East. They've been destroyed to comply with the 1987 treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles. But the U.S. and the Soviet Union have yet to reduce the missiles aimed at each other.

title: Music in Review
description: The American Boychoir, Albemarle Consort of Voices and Levin Baroque Ensemble St. Bartholomew's Church Park Avenue at 51st Street

title: Piano Recital
description: Frederick Moyer, a pianist, is to play Haydn's Sonata No. 9 in F (Hob. XVI:9), Beethoven's "Moonlight" Sonata (Op. 27, No. 2), Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition" and selections from the Chopin Etudes at 2:30 P.M. today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 570-3949.

title: London Journal; Commuters Underwhelmed by the Underground
description: When the engine pulling Queen Elizabeth's train unregally broke down last weekend, leaving Her Majesty 10 miles short and 20 minutes late for a royal ceremony in Glasgow, millions of weary British commuters knew just how she felt.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Ex-Education Chief's Travel Is Under a Criminal Inquiry
description: Lauro F. Cavazos, the former Education Secretary, is under a criminal investigation by the Justice and Education Departments in connection with his travel as head of the agency, Administration officials said today.

title: Kennedy Defends Avoiding Police Questions
description: Reacting to a police affidavit that said he had initially failed to talk with the authorities about a sexual-assault accusation against William K. Smith, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he had not known that Mr. Smith, his nephew, was actually being accused of rape.

title: Focusing on Welfare
description: President Bush has struck a partisan blow against critics who accuse him of having no domestic policy: He has denounced Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society. By doing so he also invigorated a national debate about what type of social welfare programs the nation needs, and how effective other Presidents have been in combating poverty and racial bias.

title: Washington Bank Seized
description: Federal bank regulators today seized the Madison National Bank, one of the largest in the Washington area, after declaring it insolvent.

title: For Mother, a Little Something for the Garden
description: Unless you're a perfect child, you probably forgot that tomorrow is Mother's Day. You have no present, no book that will change her life and make you her favorite and you have no dinner reservation at the unforgettable, undiscovered restaurant. So you'll probably dash out to the corner for a bouquet of flowers -- a lovely gift, but temporary. It will fade within the week.

title: Chiller Theater As Mets Star in a Horror Show
description: Dwight Gooden left the ball park. A moment later, Will Clark, with one sweet, terrible swing of his bat, had forced the baseball to leave it, too. All of a sudden, the seventh inning had become a series of disturbing exits for the Mets, and it all amounted to an ugly start to their trip through California.

title: Memorial to Astronauts
description: A monument to the 15 American astronauts killed in the line of duty was dedicated here Thursday by Vice President Dan Quayle. The black-granite surface of the 42-foot-high monument is polished to a mirror finish and mounted on a motorized base that tilts, so that the 15 names, cut through the surface, appear to be shining in the heavens. In the crowd on Thursday were relatives of the seven astronauts who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986.

title: 2 Europe Tire Makers Set New Merger Talks
description: Continental A.G. and Pirelli S.p.A, two of Europe's largest tire makers, said today that they would resume merger talks. The move followed the resignation on Thursday of Continental's chairman, Horst Urban, who had opposed the merger.

title: INSIDE
description: F.A.A. Orders Inspections

title: Adventures Into the Danger Zones
description: They jump off mountain cliffs attached to powerless, rudderless gliders hoping to fly on fickle winds. They drop, skis in tow, from helicopters onto slopes so steep and snowy, there's no telling where the runs might end.

title: Soviet Troops Fire on Town In Armenia After Ambush
description: Soviet helicopters fired machine guns into an Armenian village today, apparently in reprisal for an overnight ambush against a column of troops that left one soldier dead, Armenian officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on April 10 headed "The Highly Indebted," listing countries with large amounts of outstanding debt, referred incorrectly to the scope of the list. Only developing countries were covered.

title: DINKINS PRESENTS '92 BUDGET, VOWING TO BAR TAKEOVER
description: A somber and sometimes angry Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a worst-case New York City budget yesterday filled with sharp tax increases, searing service cuts and more than 20,000 layoffs and declared that he was committed to carrying it all out if necessary to stave off a takeover of city finances by a state oversight agency.

title: Kenneth L. Isaacs, 86, An Investment Banker
description: Kenneth Lothaire Isaacs, an investment banker and former chairman of Massachusetts Investors Trust, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 86 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Body of Baby Found at River
description: The body of an unidentified girl about 18 months old was found by a fisherman last night on the Bronx bank of the Harlem River at the foot of Depot Place in the High Bridge section, the police reported. The child was black, wore a gold earring in her left ear, and was clad in a blue jumper, a yellow sweater, a jacket, white tights and white shoes. An autopsy was ordered to determine the cause of death.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Two Are Killed in an Ambush in Forest Hills
description: The gunmen surrounded the Mercedes-Benz as it pulled onto Austin Street in the heart of Forest Hills's shopping district just before 4 A.M. yesterday. The men, more than seven of them, opened fire, riddling the car with 29 bullets, killing the driver and his companion and critically wounding a couple in the back seat.

title: Bridge
description: The 17th Cavendish Invitational Pairs will be played today and tomorrow with a star-studded field of 40 pairs, including six from Europe and one from South America. Play will be at the Summit Hotel, at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Toney Stops Nunn in 11th to Take Title
description: James Toney spoiled Michael Nunn's homecoming tonight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In honor of LLOYD RICHARDS, who is retiring as the dean of the Yale School of Drama and as the artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, a permanently endowed chair for a black professor is being established at the school. On Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria, a benefit to raise money for the chair has been organized by his friends and former students.

title: James L. Reinsch, 82, Consultant To 4 Presidents on Broadcasting
description: James L. Reinsch, former chairman of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation, who advised four Presidents on radio and broadcasting, died Thursday at Johns Hopkins Medical Center in Baltimore. He was 82 years old and lived in Marietta, Ga.

title: Critic's Notebook; At Cannes, A Not-So-Festive Festival
description: More than 30 years ago, at an earlier Cannes Film Festival, Robert Mitchum received some unexpected publicity when a starlet with whom he was posing on the beach suddenly ripped off her bra to please the photographers.

title: Music in Review
description: Oratorio Society of New York Carnegie Hall

title: Bass to Acquire Granada's Bingo
description: Bass P.L.C., the British brewing, hotel and leisure group, will pay $:56 million, or about $92 million, and assume $:91 million, or abourt $123 million, of debt to acquire the Granada Group P.L.C. bingo business. Granada, a British television program producer and broadcaster, operates 73 clubs in Britain where bingo is played. Granada said it would use the proceeds of the Bass deal to pay down debt and invest in its core businesses, which include a stake in British Sky Broadcasting, a satellite television venture.

title: Franklin Lee Mewshaw, Television Executive, 77
description: Franklin Lee Mewshaw, a former Foreign Service officer and retired CBS executive, died on Tuesday at Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: In the Nation; Death of a Freeway
description: What may be the most gratifying urban scene in any American city today is actually an area of rubble and destruction -- the demolition of the Embarcadero Freeway, a double-decked eyesore of roaring traffic that has blighted this city's waterfront since the mid-1950's.

title: Addicts' Parents Live the Pain on Stage
description: Indomitably, the eight parents standing on the small stage began speaking about their children. Their stories were not the comfortable anecdotes that parents are so fond of recalling. One mother told how her teen-ager set fire to the family automobile and pushed it into a nearby lake so he could collect the car insurance. Another child successfully managed to play hooky for months by lying to his high school attendance officer that his family was moving to Colorado. And yet another child deviously spent down a $30,000 bank account to $300 in three months.

title: From Futile to Facile, Yanks Thwart A's (At Last)
description: After 20 months of futility against the same arrogant bunch, too many games filled with Rickey Henderson running wild and Jose Canseco pounding pitchers, the Yankees finally vanquished the mighty Oakland Athletics last night.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Teheran Bazaar, Discreet Grumbling Over Official Interference
description: Down alleyways crammed with people and roofed with tin, where men burn incense to banish evil, Teheran's bazaar unfolds like a catalogue of plenty. Here there are shoes, and there, there is gold, and food mixes and rugs of silk and wool, all ranged in blocks of small stores selling the same wares.

title: A Senior Vice President for Simon & Schuster
description: When she joined Prentice Hall as a copywriter in 1968, Janet Wikler wrote "flap copy" for book jackets, including that on Vince Lombardi's autobiography and on the large-print edition of "The Power of Positive Thinking." Last week, she was appointed to the newly created position of senior vice president and director of strategic planning of Simon & Schuster.

title: Dutch Export Violator Barred on Sales to U.S.
description: The Defense Department has for the first time banned a company from doing business with any Federal agency because it reportedly exported high-technology products in violation of American export controls.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Where would I go here, and it's all I have. I have no choice but to stay." -- Aminsharif, who lost his family to the Bangladesh cyclone. [ A1:4 ] .

title: Music in Review
description: 'La Finta Giardiniera' Indiana University School of Music Juilliard Theater 155 West 65th Street

title: Canada's Jobless Rate
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 10.2 percent in April from 10.5 percent in March, although the number of people with full-time jobs declined, the Government said today. The number of jobless fell for the first time since last June, dropping by 44,000 to 1,398,000, Statistics Canada said. The number of employed swelled by 39,000, to 12,330,000, reversing a steady slide that started in September, but the increases came only in part-time jobs. Part-time employment rose by 48,000, while the number of Canadians with full-time jobs dropped by 6,000.

title: U.S. Presses Iraq to Accept U.N. Force to Protect Kurds
description: The Bush Administration pressed Iraq today to reconsider its rejection of a United Nations police force to secure the repatriation of the country's Kurdish population as United States military leaders said they would try to avoid further expansion of their security zone.

title: African Renaissance
description: After decades of unspeakable repression at the hands of authoritarian regimes, Africans stand at the threshold of a new epoch. Across the continent, millions are demanding freely elected legislatures, an independent judiciary and an accountable executive. This democratic renaissance cuts across linguistic lines and national borders, from Nigeria to Kenya, from Mali to Zaire.

title: Japan Air Lines Lease
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it would sign a two-year contract to lease four Boeing 747 cargo planes, each with crew, from Evergreen International Airlines Inc., an Oregon-based cargo concern.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater, From Classicism to Copland
description: By giving fine performances of three admirable works on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater reaffirmed its policy of eclecticism and reminded audiences that the one-act creation is this century's major balletic form.

title: Spill of Beer Kills 3,000 Fish
description: Some 3,000 fish died after many thousands of gallons of Coors beer spilled into a creek by accident last weekend. John Schallenkamp, director of environmental control for the Adolph Coors Company, said an operator apparently opened a valve and diverted the beer to a wastewater treatment plant that empties into the Clear Creek. The spill, estimated at 155,000 to 310,000 gallons, killed white suckers, bass fry and trout along a three-mile stretch of the creek.

title: Detroit's Assault on Mileage Bill
description: The American auto industry, a perennial straggler in Washington regulatory battles, has been waging an uncharacteristically effective fight against proposed legislation to make cars and trucks much more fuel efficient.

title: Sports of The Times; More Than One Bird to Worry About
description: For years the Celtics have had so many tricks up their sleeve that other teams actually stopped making deals with them. When, for example, executives from other clubs saw Red Auerbach, first the coach and then the general manager and currently the semi-retired vice president, enter a room, his renowned cigar smoking like an engine to herald his entrance, they fled, matching poof for puff. "It got frustrating," Auerbach once lamented.

title: Drexel's Bankruptcy Plan Offers Creditors $2.1 Billion
description: Almost 15 months after the powerful investment house of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. collapsed, it proposed a reorganization yesterday under which it would emerge from bankruptcy as a much smaller company.

title: U.S. Effort for Alliance in Gulf Suffers Setbacks, Officials Say
description: Despite Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's buoyant assessment, the Bush Administration's effort to help build a stable postwar alliance in the Persian Gulf has suffered setbacks in recent weeks in a dispute between Saudi Arabia and the other gulf states, Bush Administration officials and Arab diplomats say.

title: Inhumanity Is the Theme Of Festival
description: At a certain moment in Nestor Almendros's documentary "Nobody Listened," Huber Matos, the former revolutionary comandante and 20-year inmate of a Cuban jail, declares, "No tyrant will admit guilt for his own crimes."

title: 'Superstars and Screwballs'
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandra Hutchinson Wed
description: Alexandra Victoria Hutchinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ashton Hutchinson of Wilton, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Richard Gruyer Kline Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kline of Arnold, Md. The Rev. William Weisenbach officiated at the Central Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Kline, 25 years old, graduated from Hood College and is a sales associate with Ann Taylor shops in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Kline, 34, graduated from the University of South Carolina. He is a regional vice president in Jupiter, Fla., for the Investment Trust of Boston. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Abandoned Toddler Sent to a Shelter
description: A toddler found wandering alone on a bustling corner in midtown Manhattan Friday evening was placed in a shelter for abandoned children yesterday while puzzled authorities tried to locate the parents of the healthy, well-dressed boy.

title: When the Spirit of Neoclassicism Swept America
description: Neoclassicism -- the aristocratic style of art and design that evolved abroad and in this country during the early 19th century -- spawned a broad spectrum of artifacts in the United States, including some as American as spread-winged eagles. Just how stateside examples echoed or differed from their European counterparts is explored in the exhibition "Neoclassicism in America: Inspiration and Innovation, 1810-1840," at Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street in Manhattan, through June 7.

title: Is De La Soul Dead, Or Just Too Famous?
description: It used to take four or five aLbums before rock musicians started writing about how tough it is being famous. Rap moves faster. "De La Soul Is Dead" (Tommy Boy 1029; all three formats) is only De La Soul's second album, but the group already gripes about the annoyances of being recognized and the onslaught of people proffering their demo tapes. Where De La Soul's debut, "Three Feet High and Rising," offered an amiable, good-humored but socially aware alternative to every rap orthodoxy of 1989, most of "De La Soul Is Dead" is defensive and parochial. Now, the band is protecting its turf.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Dollars Can Still Get You Scotch and Waterford Crystal in Baghdad
description: So far, Iraq's dollar-owning bourgeoisie with a taste for foreign living has been hit only selectively by the United Nations trade embargo.

title:
Your Own Account;
When Singles Share Real Estate
description: Five years ago, Mary Beth Mullen and her sister, a mother of two who had recently been divorced, decided to join forces to buy a house because neither could afford to do it on her own.

title: Jazz, Now Down by One, Hope to Get Even With Trail Blazers
description: Karl Malone never bought all that stuff about the Portland Trail Blazers sweeping the Utah Jazz in the playoffs.

title: KUWAIT IS BRINGING ITS REFUGEES HOME
description: Gareed al-Shatta emerged from the door of the blue and white jet, knelt on the rubber-mat terminal floor and kissed the ground. Tears streamed from his eyes, and his hands were shaking slightly as he rose to his feet.

title: FOOTBALL: Notebook; Vikings and Walker Discuss Close Calls
description: Jeff Diamond, the Minnesota Vikings' vice president, said he was not reading anything into Herschel Walker's brush with death last week, and added it would have no impact on the running back's contract negotiations with the team.

title: House Sellers Looking for House Buyers
description: DIANA ROSS and Bob Guerra of Hampton Bays shared an afternoon recently. They both took part in a Long Island real-estate auction.

title: Fire Guts Executive's Office
description: A fire at the Corning Inc. headquarters building destroyed the office of Chief Executive Officer James R. Houghton, officials said. The fire was contained to the ninth floor of the building and there were no injuries, but most of Mr. Houghton's office equipment and possessions were destroyed, fire officials said Friday. Investigators are trying to determine the cause of the blaze, Fire Chief William R. Flohr said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14

title: Topics of The Times; Slorc Quiz
description: Myanmar's oddly named junta, the Slorc, for State Law and Order Restoration Council, seized power nearly three years ago (when the country was known as Burma) by mowing down thousands of unarmed students. Its repressive methods are no more subtle now.

title: The World; For Saudis and Kuwaitis, Differing Views of U.S.
description: THREE months after the allied victory in the Persian Gulf, the perceptions of the United States in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are as different as high noon and darkest night.

title: New Trial Is Ordered in U.S. Drug Agent's Death
description: Because Government prosecutors provided incorrect information about the crime, a judge has thrown out the conviction of the most prominent of 22 people charged in the abduction and slaying of Enrique Camarena Salazar, a Federal drug agent.

title: Awe-Inspiring Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion: European Report; Milan: Echoes of the Silver Screen
description: IN THE PARADE OF IMAGES THAT WAS FASHION week in Milan in March, surely the most sensational was that of Linda Evangelista clad in nothing but a towel. When the sullen-mouthed, sometime-blonde model emerged wrapped in terry at Dolce & Gabbana's show of fall clothes, there were more than a few gasps.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My kitchen linoleum is 42 years old, cracked and lifting up in many areas. The base under the linoleum is made of plywood. What is the best way to remove this old linoleum?

title: The Nation; Worry for an Industry Selling Peace of Mind
description: WHEN California and New York state regulators seized the troubled insurance operations of First Executive Corporation last month, they registered a major failure in an industry that most consumers had considered rock solid. How it happened was junk bonds, the biggest portfolio of the risky investments in the industry. Why it happened has cast doubts on the way insurers are monitored.

title: Penguins Sashay Into Stanley Cup Finals
description: Mark Recchi scored the biggest goal in Pittsburgh hockey history with 4 minutes 20 seconds left as the Penguins rallied from a two-goal deficit to beat the Boston Bruins, 5-3, tonight and earn their first trip to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about a desegregation case involving the public schools in Englewood, Englewood Cliffs and Tenafly misstated the percentage of white students in the Tenafly schools. It is 74 percent, not 98.

title: Brutus Returns to the Scene of His Crimes Against Racism
description: When Dennis Brutus left South Africa in July 1966, he left with the knowledge that if he ever returned he would be arrested upon arrival.

title: Fresh Air Fund Builds Lasting Links
description: IN July, Lisa Carena of North Stamford will welcome a visitor from the Bronx. For two weeks, 10-year-old Nina Washington will make her third summertime visit to Ms. Carena's home as part of the Fresh Air Fund's program to bring poor city children to the country.

title: Mozart, the Great Chameleon
description: The other evening, at a concert that included several of Mozart's notoriously vulgar canons, the thought occurred to me that if science could ever untangle the mystery of his creativity, it might as easily go on to crack the code to the cosmos. Despite the ever expanding presence of the composer, especially in this bicentennial period, the man himself seems to recede from us. When we try to pin him down for observation, the uncertainty principle takes effect, and he is no longer there. The universe, if you will indulge a fancy, may be only Mozart writ large.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are any number of mothers who think that the day named for them is just another excuse for commercial hype, and still more who believe that they should be considered and honored, if such is the word, all year and not merely on one day. Both points of view are, in fact, essentially correct. Still, there is a Mother's Day and even most mothers who claim that it's a lot of nonsense are pleased to be recognized in some way.

title: Valerie Cella Is Married
description: Valerie Cella, an office manager, and Neil Kuska, an insurance executive, were married yesterday at St. Hughes of Lincoln Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Kevin Smith performed the ceremony. Mrs. Kuska, 28 years old, manages the Jericho, L.I., office of Robert Half AccountTemps.She is a daughter of Peter and Therese Cella of Huntington. The bridegroom, 35, an associate manager with the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company in Uniondale, L.I., is the son of Edward and Mary Kuska of Port Richie, Fla.

title: Headliners; Exiting, Stage Up
description: Some intricate choreography is going on behind the scenes of New York's opera world. Beverly Sills, long identified with the New York City Opera, is to take her place this week on the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera. At the same time, the former board president and general manager of the Metropolitan, Bruce Crawford, will be put back in the president's chair as the chief executive officer. Over at the New York City Opera, Christopher Keene is expected to sit a little easier as general director, a post in which he succeeded Miss Sills. Because Miss Sills stayed on as president, a post she resigned in October, Mr. Keene, she said, operated in her shadow. "I had to withdraw totally from the City Opera in order to allow Christopher to put his imprimatur on the company," said Miss Sills. "As long as I was president, this young man would come in with all these bright ideas and the board would look to me for approval." For his part, Mr. Keene wished his predecessor "happiness and satisfaction."

title: Ms. Boonjamalik to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vichai Boonjamalik of Yonkers have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jirakal Boonjamalik, and David Chul Kwon Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haeng Ung Lee of Little Rock, Ark. Ms. Boonjamalik, 23 years old, is a financial analyst at Chemical Bank in New York. She graduated from Barnard College. Mr. Lee, 25, is a senior associate in New York at Lazard Freres. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Valentino Even Sang, Sort Of
description: It is possible to tire occasionally of Beethoven and Mozart and lesser classical composers. There also comes a moment when one has had enough of Madonna or Miles Davis or Engelbert Humperdinck. Which raises the question: is there life beyond classical and pop and rock and jazz and all the other styles that crowd the record shops and airwaves?

title: Miss Beck Weds Robert E. Chmiel
description: Kristin Mary Beck, a daughter of George J. Beck Jr. of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Rosemary Beck, was married yesterday in New York to Robert Emmett Chmiel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix J. Chmiel of Tequesta, Fla. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: When a Painter Becomes a Printmaker
description: GEORGE McNEIL'S print retrospective at the Montclair Art Museum draws attention to his 1987 painting "Disco Deliverance," which was recently acquired by the museum. It also proves that in a world crammed with young emerging artists, Mr. McNeil is an older emerging artist. Though hardly a newcomer, he achieved fame later than most, possibly because he spent from 1948 to 1981 teaching, at the Pratt Institute.

title: Postings: 'Artspace'; Town House In New Role
description: The interior of the old American Automobile Association headquarters at 28 East 78th Street has undergone a $1 million renovation and emerged as a combination consignment art gallery and museum.

title: Laura B. Schacht To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Schacht of Columbus, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Becker Schacht to George William Bilicic Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bilicic of Charleston, W.Va. An August wedding is planned.

title: Serial Murder by Gaslight
description: THE WOMEN OF WHITECHAPEL AND JACK THE RIPPER By Paul West. 420 pp. New York: Random House. $22.

title: Making an Art of Angst
description: WOODY ALLEN

title: Headliners; Touching That Dial
description: What with "The Simpsons," "Twin Peaks" and that new hit show with the rubber dinosaurs, some might have thought there was a chance that Newton N. Minow was ready to upgrade his opinion of television. Not a chance. Mr. Minow, who 30 years ago became one of the few people ever to be catapulted to fame from the Federal Communications Commission when he told a convention of television broadcasters that their medium was a "vast wasteland," said in a speech last week that there has been little improvement. In the speech, which was prepared for a meeting at the Gannett Foundation Media Center commemorating his 1961 speech, Mr. Minow, now a professor at Northwestern University, said that television had become an impediment to political discourse, and that it had been greatly underused in education. "In 1961, I worried that my children would not benefit much from television," he said. "But in 1991, I worry that my grandchildren will actually be harmed by it."

title: Conservatives' Progress
description: THE RHETORIC OF REACTION

title: Foreign Peanut Toxins Could Harm Liver; Not Protein but Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen A. Kiernan Weds J. J. Ayers
description: Ellen Ann Kiernan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kiernan of New Scotland, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Jeffrey John Ayers, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William B. Ayers of Old Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Review/Music; Americans Abroad
description: Although Cole Porter used his beloved Paris as the setting for five of his 23 Broadway musicals, in none of those shows was his affection for the city more palpable than in "Fifty Million Frenchmen," from 1929. A frivolous romp, subtitled "A Musical Comedy Tour of Paris," the show follows a bunch of well-to-do Americans abroad in search of excitement, and it pokes fun at the sight of puritanical Americans pining after a discreet taste of Continental depravity.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Southport, Me.;
A Lighthouse For Summers
description: WHAT is believed to be the only privately owned active lighthouse in northern New England has been bought for $850,000 by Benjamin Russell, an Alabama timberlands owner.

title: How a Work Force Responds When Equal Rights Is a Goal
description: Few companies push civil rights in the workplace harder than the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. In the past decade, the giant utility has put hundreds of female, black, Hispanic and Asian workers into jobs that were once the exclusive domain of white men.

title: Robert Greene Got There First
description: To the Editor:

title: African Dilemma: Food Aid May Prolong War and Famine
description: ONCE again, the reports of starvation are trickling in from parts of Africa. And it is clearly no coincidence that the countries most menaced by famine this season are those that have been mired in long civil wars. Impoverished, warring nations have the worst food problems: peasants cannot plant or harvest during war, armies and rebels confiscate food for themselves, including in some cases well-intentioned Western supplies.

title: Women and the Motor Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds; Time to Abandon the Indexes?
description: Funds that duplicate market indexes have jumped in popularity in recent years, partly because stock fund managers have failed to match the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for eight years. But stock fund managers beat the index for the seven years before that.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Industrial production for April * Federal Reserve reports on selected interest rates. TUESDAY: Consumer price index for April * Early May automobile sales * Federal Open Market Committee meets to decide monetary policy for next seven weeks * Retail sales figures * Industrial production and plant capacity figures * Real earnings figures.

title: The Psychiatrist Who Pleaded Insanity
description: THE PSYCHIATRIST HAD CALLED UP HIS golfing buddy, the police chief, to ask for a meeting and his help. When the two got together, the chief listened carefully to the psychiatrist's highly unusual request, tried to talk him out of it, then finally agreed to send one of his men who was good, he said, at taking care of "special favors."

title: MONUMENT MAKER
description: Since moving to Baltimore from Chicago and Hawaii, we have received many visitors ("Monument Maker," by Peter Tauber, Feb. 24). We take them to see Washington and, invariably, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. No matter what holiday mood may prevail, I've noticed all those in its vicinity turn quiet, contemplative and respectful.

title: Women and the Motor Age
description: To the Editor:

title: . . . Mozart Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Farma Way Becomes Speedy Winner at Pimlico
description: Farma Way unleashed a devastating display of speed today, beating the nation's best older horses in the $750,000 Pimlico Special.

title: Safety and Power Tools
description: POWER tools are a part of nearly every home-improvement tool kit. But being commonplace does not mean they are inherently safe to use. In fact, because accidents with such tools can happen quickly and be severe, safe operating procedures are imperative.

title: Campus Life: Tulsa; Foreign Students Learn the Quirks of U.S. English
description: Trying to interpret idiomatic expressions like "fly off the handle" and "raining cats and dogs" can get foreign students "down in the dumps," said Janice Fonkalsrud, a speech pathology professor at the University of Tulsa.

title:
ART;
No Muffling of Women's Voice
description: THE National Association of Women Artists celebrated its 1989 centennial with an exhibition that had its premiere at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Rye Brook
description: THE Village of Rye Brook is Westchester County's newest municipality, formed in 1982 from what had been the unincorporated section of the Town of Rye. Since its creation, it has worked hard to establish its own identity.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: RYAN WHITE

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: Despite what the Alaska Tourism Marketing Council said in supplying information for the item on the Northern Lights (Travel Advisory, March 10), we found that no single scientist predicted that 1990-91 "will provide the best displays of Northern Lights seen in decades, and perhaps centuries" (my emphasis). Perhaps the council was carried away by their enthusiasm. No auroral scientist could make such a statement.

title: Indy Rookie Injured
description: MARK DISMORE, a 34-year-old driver practicing for his first attempt at the Indianapolis 500, was severely injured Friday when his 1988 Penske race car spun out of control at 216 miles per hour and slammed into three walls in a fiery crash that scattered parts of the disintegrating car over a quarter-mile stretch of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Skippers of Newer Boats Face a Seaworthy Test of Sorts
description: Has technology taken America's Cup racing to the edge of a dangerous abyss or are the innovations part of the allure that makes cup competition a challenge for the best sailors in the world?

title: Kuhn's Descent From Commissioner to Legal Outcast
description: As the lawyer for the National League in 1969, Bowie Kuhn was in the right place at the right time when major league club owners were searching for a new baseball commissioner. As the outgoing commissioner in 1984, Kuhn picked the wrong place at the wrong time in resuming his career as a lawyer. The decision, which Kuhn acknowledges was not a wise one, took him on a trail that has plunged him to the nadir of his career and severely damaged his reputation.

title: 100-Year-Old Fire Marshal Still Answers the Call to Serve
description: JIM GROTE never stops. In Chester, where he is the town's fire marshal, he spent most of a recent day investigating the cause of a house fire. Then he was a featured speaker at a fire service banquet and finally got to bed at 2 A.M.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEBANON: Death of a Nation, by Sandra Mackey. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.) Carved out of Syria by the French as a haven for Maronite Christians, Lebanon has always teetered on the brink of self-destruction, Sandra Mackey writes. She makes "the story of Lebanon's morass readable for the uninitiated," Robin Wright said here in 1989. THE FLOATING WORLD, by Cynthia Kadohata. (Ballantine, $4.95.) In the 1950's, Olivia, a 12-year-old Japanese girl, and her family live their life on the road, as they travel through the Pacific Northwest looking for work. "Writing in beautiful, clean yet lyrical prose, Ms. Kadohata creates an emotionally precise picture of each member of Olivia's family," Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1989. "Ms. Kadohata does not shirk from examining all the sad, painful details of her family's thwarted lives, but she does so with tenderness, compassion and wit. . . . 'The Floating World' marks the debut of a luminous new voice in fiction."

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Buffalo; Arts and Sciences Put New Stress on the Sciences
description: After a semester-long debate, the State University of New York at Buffalo has reshaped and expanded the core curriculum for students in the arts and sciences, with an emphasis on classes in science and mathematics. New courses in American Pluralism and World Civilizations will also be required.

title: Making a Difference; Weighing the Facts for Congress
description: In issuing its report last week on the use of genetically engineered growth hormone to boost milk production in cows, the Office of Technology Assessment didn't shrink from controversy.

title: MONUMENT MAKER
description: Tauber is entitled to prefer Lin's design for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial to Frederick F. Hart's. However, he is unfair in suggesting that Hart was overpaid for his work ("Hart's commission . . . was . . . ten times Maya Lin's"). Included in Hart's fee was compensation for the time and effort involved in modeling his figures.

title: Nepal Holding First Open Election Since '59
description: The Kingdom of Nepal, its powerful monarchy trimmed by a new Constitution, will hold its first fully democratic election in more than 30 years on Sunday.

title: Gwynne Bruce Weds William J. Barrett Jr.
description: Gwynne Anne Bruce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Bruce of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to William Joel Barrett Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett of Rumson, N.J. The Revs. Gary P. Fertig and George Willis Jr., both Episcopal priests, and the Rev. Bernard Campbell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: U.S., Deeming Policy Outmoded, May Cut Off Aid to Afghan Rebels
description: In a growing recognition that an 11-year policy aimed at overthrowing the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan is outdated, the Bush Administration has not requested funds for the Afghan rebels in its proposed 1992 budget, senior Administration officials say.

title: Beached Seals Pose Mystery For Scientists
description: SCORES of dead seals have washed ashore off Shinnecock Bay at Hampton Bays, and Federal, state and local authorities are jointly investigatng the reasons.

title: Beth Grossman, Law Clerk, Wed
description: Beth Stacey Grossman and Richard Lawrence Reinhold were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York by Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Travel Advisory; Bill of Rights Celebration
description: One of the original copies of the Bill of Rights is in an exhibition in Philadelphia marking the bill's 200th anniversary. The exhibition, through December at Old City Hall in Independence National Historical Park, is open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; admission is free. More information: Independence National Historical Park, (215) 597-8974.

title: Smith Posts Bond in Florida Rape Case
description: With his mother and a lawyer by his side, William K. Smith surrendered to the Palm Beach police today on charges of rape and battery.

title: Article 838091 -- No Title
description: A gunman made off with $500,000 in cash from four automatic teller machines at a midtown Manhattan bank yesterday after waylaying a repairman who had been sent to the bank to check on a complaint about a malfunctioning machine, the police said.

title: Headliners; Writing Doesn't Pay
description: Jean Harris, who has spent a decade behind bars for murder, was doubtlessly aware that under New York State's "Son of Sam" law she could not keep the profits from a book about her crime. Now a court has ruled that she can't give them away either. Mrs. Harris, who was convicted in 1981 of killing her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower, the "Scarsdale Diet" doctor, planned to donate about $100,000 in proceeds from her autobiographical account, "Stranger in Two Worlds," to a foundation that represents the children of prisoners. Her lawyers argued that the "Son of Sam" law, named for the serial killer David Berkowitz, abridged the right of free speech. The New York State Court of Appeals didn't buy it. "Criminals covered by the statute had no marketable asset before the crime," the presiding judge wrote. They are perfectly free to write about their crimes, the court ruled, they just aren't allowed to profit from those writings. Royalties from Mrs. Harris's book are to be set aside for Dr. Tarnower's survivors.

title: The Perils Of Roe v. Wade
description: Feminist author Alida Brill maintains that under the Roe v. Wade decision the Supreme Court "says that the choice to have an abortion should be made before the end of the first trimester by a woman and her doctor" [ Long Island Q&A, April 21 ] .

title: Food; The Phony Farm
description: OURS IS THE LITTLE FARM THAT couldn't. The idea was to "live off the land" not that the land would live off us. But that is what happened: My husband and I stagger, lugging 50-pound sacks of chow, dragging water buckets with our chapped hands out to a crowd of 45 fat animals who do little but chew grass. I cannot even call these animals decorative as they waddle from one meal to the next. How did I, a city person, get stuck running a salad bar for useless animals?

title: Paula Abdul's State-of-the-Art Dance Pop
description: Just as there are those who worry about additive-riddled junk food, so too there's an unofficial "campaign for real music." Adherents fret about the unauthenticity of mainstream pop performers who, in the tradition of Milli Vanilli, mime to backing tapes when supposedly performing live. For these people, Paula Abdul has become the focus of the latest crisis of confidence.

title:
FORUM;
Unlock American Energy Policy
description: With the gulf crisis simmering down and the Administration's new energy policy on the table, critics are howling for more Federal energy regulations and initiatives.

title:
FORUM;
The Risk of Ignoring Latin America
description: Winning a new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is now a top priority in Washington, but the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative shouldn't get lost in the shuffle. The Administration proposal could provide major opportunities for the United States economy -- in trade and investment -- and encourage progress on issues like immigration and drugs.

title: WHAT DIVIDES BERLIN NOW?
description: I am German, with ancestors on both sides of the wall, and I recently spent several months working in Germany and traveling in various parts of the country. I saw the injustices that Germans from the eastern region are experiencing. This seems ironic; after all, the East Germans initiated the revolution that led to reunification (although the West Germans are apt to take credit -- erroneously -- for these events). Now those same West Germans are reducing East Germans to second-class status. KAREN HAASEN Chicago

title: Concert Is Celebrating A Hartt School Founder
description: MOSHE PARANOV is on a pilgrimage, to lead the children of Connecticut to music. "You can graduate after four years in many schools here and not have had one note of music,"he said. "And you find people in administration who don't know the difference between Beethoven and a ham sandwich."

title: Melissa Simon Plans To Wed Shawn Singer
description: The engagement of Melissa Cheryl Simon to Shawn Singer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Singer of Howell, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Simon of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Throwing Boomerangs Across America
description: SOME people see no more in a flying boomerang than a stick that comes back when it's thrown. But Paul Sprague sees "the curling, arcing, never-ending cycle of birth and death, loss and redemption, turbulence and peace."

title: Tami Bitter Is Married to Kevin Cook
description: Tami Bitter, an architect, and Kevin Cook, a bond broker, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gertrude's in Bayville, L.I. The Rev. James P. Swiader performed the ceremony.

title: Fresh Domestic Rabbit Invites Diverse Seasonings
description: FOR sentimental reasons, rabbit has never been a great favorite on the American dinner table. But now that people are looking for low-fat alternatives to beef and pork, it is becoming more popular. Organically raised domestic rabbits are available fresh in many butcher and specialty shops. The meat is light and delicate, similar in taste to chicken -- but with a more pronounced flavor and with more bones to negotiate.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Rossini: Overtures (7) London Classical Players conducted by Roger Norrington. Angel CDC 54091; CD and cassette.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Pop Goes the Gas Tank

title: Fresh Air Fund Tells Youths to Study
description: Pecuniary interests may have been uppermost in the minds of about 100 poor New York City teen-agers who recently attended the Fresh Air Fund's second-annual Career Day, but all seemed to acknowledge the importance of their counselors' exhortations to stay in school, study hard, stay away from drugs and believe in themselves.

title: More Single Women Adopting Children
description: GAIL S. BRUNO'S daily routine is much the same as that of any other working mother. She drops off her 22-month-old daughter, Kara, at the baby sitter's at 7 A.M. and heads for her job as a guidance counselor at West Windsor-Plainsboro High School.

title: The Disasters Multiply And Compassion Falters
description: RELIEF agency officials say there has never been a time in recent history when so many disasters with such different natures have struck so many people.

title: Irresponsible Bliss
description: NOW YOU SEE IT By Cornelia Nixon. 186 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: Town Meets Gown at Fields and Gyms
description: THIS spring, for the first time in nearly 40 years, Yale University's 18-hole championship golf course is being made available to the public. Yale's golf director, David Paterson, said a limited number of memberships are available.

title: Fashion: European Report; Paris: A Show of Force
description: NOBODY EXPECTED IT. IF DESIGNERS preparing their next collections had been thrown off course by uncertainties over the Persian Gulf situation -- if the style changes they came up with had been slight, the tempo uneven or the presentations just a continuation of the status quo -- it would have been perfectly understandable. But when the international fashion crowd assembled in Paris in mid-March to see what the ready-to-wear talents had planned for next fall, what a surprise! It turned out to be one sensational season.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SKINNER TO SPEAK

title: Miss Griffiths Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Catherine Clark Griffiths and Philip Dashiell Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Harrison Jr. of Philadelphia, has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Dana R. Robes of Etna, N.H., and James W. Griffiths of East Plainfield, N.H. An August wedding is planned.

title: Portia Fane Bock Weds Craig Shipler
description: Portia Fane Bock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Bock of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Craig William Shipler, a son of Betty Boone and Bill Shipler of Salt Lake City. Judge Franklin Weissberg of the New York State Court of Claims performed the ceremony.

title: Managing; Computing the Assignment Abroad
description: Not long ago, a "company man" accepted assignments overseas, no questions asked. Pulling the kids out of school, disrupting the wife's career, those were small prices to pay for proving loyal to your company and committed to your vocation.

title: Erosion Leads to Talks On Beach-House Limits
description: SINCE a major hurricane slammed into Charleston, S.C., in September 1989, the destruction of oceanfront houses has strengthened arguments to move housing from coastal areas.

title: Celtics Pound Pistons
description: In Game 1, Boston's Larry Bird didn't play and his absence was cited as a reason for Detroit's victory. In Game 2, the Pistons' Isiah Thomas didn't play and his absence was cited as a reason for the Celtics' victory.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Stockbridge, Mass.;
New Museum For Rockwell
description: CONSTRUCTION has started here on a building that will allow the Norman Rockwell Museum to move from the Old Corner House, a small house in the center of town, to the 34-acre Linwood estate two miles northwest of here.

title: The Region; Dreams Deferred and Payments Due
description: AS he urged New Yorkers to pitch in with sacrifice and courage to endure the city's worst fiscal pains in years, Mayor David N. Dinkins promised last week, "Together, we can ensure that our dreams, though deferred, will never, ever be denied."

title: Political Talk
description: New Way to Run

title: Travel Advisory; Rembrandts to Tour Europe
description: Recent curatorial scrutiny has whittled away the number of Rembrandt paintings, as a number of works formerly attributed to the artist are now believed to have been executed by his students. However, 50 paintings unmistakably by Rembrandt, along with his drawings and etchings, will make up an exhibition that will tour Berlin, Amsterdam and London starting in the fall. A section of the show will feature an additional 20 works once thought to be by Rembrandt alongside an equal number of paintings by the students to whom the works are now attributed.

title: Nantucket Bridal For Ms. Patterson
description: Catherine Eve Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Daniel Patterson 3d of New York, was married in Nantucket, Mass., yesterday to Michael Josiah Jensen, a son of Phoebe Jensen of New York and the late David Jensen. The Rev. Joyce Tompkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Making a Difference; No Waiting in Line for These Bank Customers
description: Bankers have always had a special fondness for rich people, and like Mr. Drysdale in "The Beverly Hillbillies" TV show, they are more than willing to provide extra-special service for the 1.5 million households with $1 million of investments or incomes above $250,000.

title:
DANCE;
Mixing the Historic and the Brand-New
description: "WHEN I first joined the company in 1983, we were the local town softball team," said the dancer and choreographer Janet Rowthorn, invoking her favorite analogy to describe the progress of the New Jersey Center Dance Collective.

title: Susan Davis Marries Michael Moran
description: Susan Mabon Davis, a furniture buyer for Bloomingdale's, and Michael Gerard Moran, a commodities broker, were married yesterday at Christ Church Cathedral in Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Vernon Decoteau, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Canon William Coyne, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: WHAT'S DOING ALONG THE: Brandywine
description: Visitors to the Brandywine Valley seeking the pastoral landscapes of Andrew Wyeth's paintings have to make an effort to find them. In this part of northern Delaware and southeastern Pennsylvania, farms and woodlands can still be seen along the back roads, but shopping centers and housing developments have made a lot of headway in recent years.

title: Perspectives: Westchester Co-ops; Getting Renters Into Unsold Apartments
description: VACANT apartments are a housing resource. The proposition is self-evident, but it has a special significance in Westchester County, where there is a chronic shortage of affordable, or lower-cost, housing.

title: The Glory of Old Castile
description: THE man's face, four centuries old, emotes unbearable grief. His sagging cheeks and sensitive lips almost quiver with sadness. Nearby, a young woman, sensual despite her sorrow, tips her head toward her right shoulder, her eyes brimming with elongated tears that have rested on her cheeks since 1548.

title: Vietnamese Streaming Into Hong Kong
description: Ignoring constant warnings carried by Vietnamese radio and television about the bleak reception awaiting them here, Vietnamese boat people are once again sailing to Hong Kong in large numbers.

title: Judith Reitman and David M. Belkin Are Married
description: Judith Sue Reitman, the daughter of Anita Yanuck of Huntington, L.I., and Richard Reitman of Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I., to David Michael Belkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rupert Belkin of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated.

title: On Language; Let Forthcoming Come Forth
description: "THE EMIR AND THE crown prince were very forthcoming ," said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, using one of the most frequent words in the vocabulary of diplomacy. It means "open to new ideas, cooperative, willing to bring helpful suggestions to the negotiations."

title:
SOUTH ORANGE JOURNAL;
In Village Election, It's Town vs. Gown
description: EXCEPT during basketball season, when the Pirates of Seton Hall University put the Village of South Orange on the same map as Las Vegas, Nev., and Chapel Hill, N.C., many residents here do not talk much about their academic neighbor. But this spring has been different.

title: The Region; Now the Work That's Never Done Is Grandmother's
description: THIS Mother's Day, when thousands and thousands of children in New York City hug and kiss the most important person in their lives, it will be their grandmother.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Singer With a Gift to Be Simple Lends Others the Gift to Be Free
description: If the already terse "Elements of Style" could be reduced to one imperative, it might be "Be simple" (or the closedly related "Be clear"). And Joseph Conrad's often cited aim in writing, to "render justice to the visible world." expresses an unclouded humility - you can't render justice to anything if you're busy calling attention to yourself.

title: Making a Difference; Pictures of Progress
description: Although the troubled Eastman Kodak Company's major concern has to be getting the average consumer to take more photographs, the company continues to court the attention of prestigious professional photographers, designers and artists.

title: Focus: Restrictive Covenants; From Grass to Garages, a Litany of 'Don'ts'
description: IN the DeKalb County community of Mainstreet 10 miles east of downtown Atlanta, homeowners are prohibited from putting television antennas on their roofs or birdbaths in their front yards.

title: Overly Hasty Farewell
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Big Bang Theory: Complex Program For Computers
description: Scientists at Princeton University have devised what they say is the most sophisticated computer program to date for testing theories of the formation of structure in the universe.

title: Miss Beardmore Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Lauren Helen Beardmore and Brian Jay Ivanhoe were married yesterday at the East Hampton, L.I., home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Dr. and Mrs. David Paton of New York. Justice of the Peace Shep Frood performed the ceremony.

title:
FORUM;
The Risk of Ignoring Latin America
description: Winning a new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is now a top priority in Washington, but the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative shouldn't get lost in the shuffle. The Administration proposal could provide major opportunities for the United States economy -- in trade and investment -- and encourage progress on issues like immigration and drugs.

title: The Executive Computer; For the Boss's Office, Two Helpful Books
description: Just as it is rare to enter a modern company that has no personal computers, it is rare to enter the office of a chief executive and find a well-worn PC. Many senior executives simply do not compute.

title: The Ultimate Mother
description: Some of the people gathered on the Adirondack hillside called the woman a priestess, others a witch. She filled a bowl with water and pondered it for a few moments. Then she passed it to the person on her right, asking the group to concentrate on the water, putting into it prayers for their families, friends, community.

title: Contender Criticizes Bid Process for Sludge
description: THE third choice among bidders for a $380 million, 25-year contract to dispose of Westchester's sludge has charged that political considerations have tainted the selection process, and is demanding that the bids be made public so taxpayers can judge for themselves.

title: F.D.A. TO EXAMINE FOOD LABEL CLAIMS OVER CHOLESTEROL
description: Having forced leading food companies to stop using "fresh" to describe orange juice from a factory and pasta sauce from a jar, the Food and Drug Administration next plans to focus on products whose labels claim low or no cholesterol.

title: Ellen H. A. Smith Wed To Stuart Paul Scott
description: Ellen Hawley Anne Smith and Stuart Paul Scott, television account executives in New York, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tuxedo, N.Y. The Rev. John Breen performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge
description: Three separate competitions will begin Wednesday in Memphis, Tenn., to determine the United States entry in the World Championship to be played in October in Yokohama, Japan.

title: St. Croix
description: To the Editor: As a visitor to St. Croix for over 20 years and a present villa owner, I enjoyed "What's Doing in St. Croix" very much. However, having dined at most of the restaurants mentioned, I thought that your readers might be interested in knowing that by not having a bottle of wine and passing up desserts, we have been able to dine for 30 to 35 percent less than the prices quoted. MARGARET ALBERT Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Unnerved by Braves and Penguins, Drabek Equals Loss Total for '90
description: National League Cy Young Award winner Doug Drabek equaled his loss total for last season when Ron Gant hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning to give the Atlanta Braves a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: Correction
description: A box last Sunday with a front-page article about the television series "Twin Peaks" referred incorrectly to the broadcast date of the final episode. It will be shown on ABC on Monday, June 10.

title: Ms. Preston Wed To Derek Buzasi
description: Heather Lee Preston and Dr. Derek Laszlo Buzasi, astronomers in Baltimore, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Edwin A. Ankeny officiated at the Mount Vernon Place United Methodist Church.

title: Lori J. Pearlman Wed To Martin Lee Wachs
description: Lori Jill Pearlman and Martin Lee Wachs were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Gerald Wolpe. The bride, 22 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth P. Pearlman of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. The bridegroom, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Wachs of Penn Valley, Pa.

title: Romancing the Street Sweeper
description: LOVE AND GARBAGE By Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. 224 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: Chief Executives See Recession Lingering to 1992
description: Differing markedly from the view of most economists, the people who run the nation's biggest companies say the recession is likely to linger for many more months, with a recovery not likely until next year.

title: Lee Garvey Wed To C. F. Carmel
description: Lee Norris Garvey, a daughter of John P. Garvey of New York and Catrina N.
