Herrick of West Hartford, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Christopher Ford Carmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Carmel of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson officiated at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Fresh Air Family Ready for 9th Reunion
description: THERE were two reasons Tom and Mary Stauber first decided to be hosts of a New York City child through the Fresh Air Fund. They wanted a playmate for their young son and, having both grown up in the Bronx, they remembered how hot and uncomfortable summers of asphalt and concrete could be.

title:
FORUM;
The Risk of Ignoring Latin America
description: Winning a new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is now a top priority in Washington, but the Enterprise for the Americas Initiative shouldn't get lost in the shuffle. The Administration proposal could provide major opportunities for the United States economy -- in trade and investment -- and encourage progress on issues like immigration and drugs.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; Growing Cutting Flowers: Choices Can Be Surprising
description: To some literal-minded types, a cutting garden is a patch of earth that's cordoned off from the rest of the yard for cut flowers. But I like to think of my whole garden as the sacrificial lamb, offering up blooms from February to frost.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Living Near the Tracks Is Gaining Cachet
description: LIVING near the railroad tracks once was thought to be socially unacceptable. But judging by the number of trackside developments contemplated in Westchester on municipal, private and Metropolitan Transportation Authority land, that is far from the case now.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My kitchen linoleum is 42 years old, cracked and lifting up in many areas. The base under the linoleum is made of plywood. What is the best way to remove this old linoleum?

title: Wine; The Long and Short of Wine Lists
description: THERE ARE STRONG MEN WHO would rather face a firing squad than a wine list. Men keen of eye and firm of grip, masters of the world they survey, find their vision blurred and their hands atremble as they struggle with the foreign names and, quite often, appalling prices.

title: Making the Grade
description: SHUT UP AND LET THE LADY TEACH

title: Laura Williams to Wed Patrick Jodice
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Williams of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Lamson Williams, to Patrick Gerard Ralph Jodice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick R. Jodice of Shallotte, N.C. A September wedding is planned.

title: Karen F. Jacoby Weds R. P. Furst
description: Karen F. Jacoby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. James Jacoby of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Philip Furst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Furst of Huntington Station, L.I. Rabbi Barry Friedman and Cantor Bruce Benson officiated at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: D. I. Gans to Wed Anne T. Hupper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joel H. Hupper of New Canaan, Conn., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Anne Thayer Hupper, and David Ian Gans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Gans of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Public & Private; The Days Of Gilded Rigatoni
description: Breakfast will be perfect. I know this from experience. Poached eggs expertly done, the toast in triangles, the juice fresh squeezed. A pot of coffee, a rose in a bud vase. A silver tray. I will eat every bit.

title: Tennis Yes, Vacation No
description: MANY body parts can sabotage a personal physical fitness program. But the first to go is usually the mind. If it gets bored or discouraged, you're back on the sofa -- just as surely as if a tendon had snapped.

title: Verbal High Jinks In 'Alphabetical Order'
description: In the library of a small English newspaper, a tennis racquet and a shoe are jutting out of a couple of overflowing file drawers, none of which are shut. The door of one locker is about to fall off. A broken chair and a jar are perched atop a cabinet. Have been for years.

title: In Maine, Tell Them Pauline Sent You
description: EMBARKING passengers quickly got a feel for the relaxed atmosphere aboard the motor yacht Pauline one Sunday afternoon last summer as they stepped from wharf to ship and Capt. Jonathan Bacon Smith, dressed in baggy khaki pants and a Pauline T-shirt, cautioned, "Watch the varnish." He was toting his 15-month-old daughter aboard for a brief visit with Dad.

title: Little Wave Rocks Spain's Euroboat
description: Spaniards are not about to end their five-year-old love affair with the European Community because of a row over a squiggle, yet things may never be quite the same now that Spain believes that it has seen the insensitive and interfering side of its new partner.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; 20 Loft-Studios For Artists
description: WHAT its developer describes as the first new artists' lofts in Venice, a waterfront section of Los Angeles, is nearing completion.

title: St. Croix
description: To the Editor: My wife, Mary, and I recently returned from an 11-day visit to St. Croix, our 22d visit. Our findings were similar to those of Cynthia Hacinli ("What's Doing in St. Croix," Travel, March 10) with a few additions.

title: International Calamities Tax America's Compassion
description: Caroline Trinidad, a New York City housewife and mother of four, cringes when she sees the painful images of a Kurdish woman cradling her hollow-eyed child or a Bangladeshi father touching his dead son's head. Then, as quickly as she can, she turns away.

title: Wall Street; Pity These Minority Shareholders
description: The head of Hercules gazes out of a catalogue from the Daedalus Gallery, a tiny exhibit space in the Fuller Building, at the hub of New York's uptown gallery scene. The owner of this heroic head is Asher B. Edelman, the former corporate raider.

title: Sunday Menu; Pairing Turkey and Tomato but Keeping Fat at a Minimum
description: Using wine as a sauteing agent is one way to cut down on fat. It is most successful in recipes that do not cry out for the taste of onions sauteed in fat.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. 555,000 6 Frog Rock Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old contemporary; fireplace, w/b stove, new kitchen, family room, workroom, 2.5 acres; taxes $8,826. Bedford, N.Y. 425,000 Quarry Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, wet bar, 1 acre; taxes $8,543. Chappaqua, N.Y. 184,000 81 Orchard Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 61-year-old colonial; w/b stove, eat-in kitchen, new den, slate patio; taxes $3,998. Simsbury, Conn. 186,000 45 Farms Village Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, family room w/fireplace, rustic setting, 2.9 acres; taxes $2,831. Weston, Conn. 526,316 15 Slumber Corners 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 39-year-old riverfront ranch; private swimming area, on cul-de-sac, 1 acre; taxes $5,204. Wilton, Conn. 640,000 83 Belden Hill Road 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 200-year-old converted barn; 2-story great room w/beams, on reservoir, 1.3 acres; taxes $6,457. OTHER AREAS Mount Sinai, L.I. 131,000 19 Echo Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $3,300. Patchogue, L.I. 95,000 43 Jennings Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 42- year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. West Orange, N.J. 260,000 15 Cullen Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; c/a, patio, eat-in-kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $6,611.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Donizetti: 'L'Elisir d'Amore' Kathleen Battle, soprano; Luciano Pavarotti, tenor; Leo Nucci, baritone; Enzo Dara, bass-baritone; Metropolitan Opera Chorus and Orchestra conducted by James Levine. Deutsche Grammophon 429 744; two CD's and cassettes.

title: The Stan Musial of Essay Writing
description: BULLY FOR BRONTOSAURUS Reflections in Natural History. By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 540 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: The Nation; Hot Debate Magnifies A Modest Gun Law
description: THE dust was settling after the gun control fight in Congress last week when Representative Edward Feighan, a Democrat from Ohio who has pushed versions of the Brady bill in three successive sessions, conceded that his measure had been somewhat oversold.

title: Janet Frost Costikyan Wed to John W. Waite
description: Janet Frost Costikyan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Costikyan of Beaufort, S.C., was married in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday to John Wardwell Waite, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Parker R. Waite of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. George Chorba officiated at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Sports of The Times; For Sports, the When to Say When Is Now
description: If ostriches put their heads in the sand, sports commissioners put their heads in the foamy heads of all those beers that bankroll their games.

title: Belgium
description: To the Editor: Arriving recently at the central railroad station in Brussels late at night without a hotel reservation, I was armed only with your article highlighting our destination ("What's Doing in Brussels, Travel, Feb. 17).

title: Campus Life: S.M.U.; Facing a Deficit, A University Gets Aid From Students
description: Facing budget problems, Southern Methodist University has found help in an unexpected place: Several student organizations have joined together to donate $88,000.

title:
ART VIEW;
An Undeserved Pulitzer for a Pop Biography?
description: The award of the Pulitzer Prize for Biography to "Jackson Pollock: An American Saga" by Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith makes it official: pop psychologizing and amateur art criticism are now acceptable methods of cultural discourse.

title: Mutual Funds; Mixed Reviews on Redemption Fees
description: The Baltimore-based T. Rowe Price fund group recently mailed proxies asking investors for permission to add a fee to several funds that invest abroad or in small-company issues. Under the proposal, investors in these funds who sold their shares within a set time of purchase, either 6 or 12 months, would pay a 1 percent fee to compensate the funds for the extra costs created by short-term trading.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday with a theater article about the actor John Turturro characterized a comment by the director Ethan Coen incorrectly. The remark -- "socially maladroit, a bit of a noodge" -- referred not to the actor but to two film roles he played.

title: Riders Beware as Anderson Prepares a Line of Attack
description: He is properly addressed as Philip Grant Anderson, OAM. The OAM stands for Order of Australia Medal, an honor conferred by Queen Elizabeth in 1986.

title: Too Many Lawyers, Too Many Suits
description: THE LITIGATION EXPLOSION

title: Airline Creates Affirmative Action Program to Settle Job Bias Suit
description: Northwest Airlines has agreed to create a multimillion-dollar affirmative action program to settle a job-discrimination suit brought on behalf of thousands of its black employees, former employees and job applicants.

title: Headliners; The Case of the Contaminated Culture
description: ON paper, the dispute over who discovered the AIDS virus was resolved in 1987 when France and the United States agreed to share the credit. Not only honor was at stake. The two countries also agreed to split the royalties from a blood test designed to detect the infection.

title: Data Bank/May 12, 1991
Postings: Feng Shui Programs; Harmonious Placement
description: Feng Shui, an ancient Chinese art of placement, will be the focus of two unusual programs planned by the New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architects and open to the public. Both will be led by Thomas Yun Lin, described by the institute as a "living Buddhisattva," or master of the highest order, who has lectured on Feng Shui, Taoism, I-Ching, Confucianism and other philosophical and esthetic systems at the United Nations, the Library of Congress and several universities.

title: Gentlemen, Restrict Your Engines
description: A multicar accident in the Winston 500 at Talladega (Ala.) Superspeedway last Monday rekindled the debate over the carburetor restrictor plates that Nascar uses to hold down speeds at its two fastest tracks, Talladega and Daytona.

title: Town Devises A New Plan For Disposal Of Garbage
description: THE Town of North Hempstead, at the center of Long Island garbage-disposal problems for several years, is expected to choose this week from among 13 haulers to take care of the town's annual 219,000 tons of garbage.

title: Business Diary/May 5-10
description: COMPANIES An Overloaded Occidental Is Shedding Debt When the late Armand Hammer was chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, he dismissed at least one would-be successor who dared say the company should pare down its debt. But now that Dr. Hammer is gone, Ray R. Irani, Oxy's new chairman, has a free hand. And last week he started moving toward his stated mission of trimming the company's $8.8 billion of debt by $3 billion this year. He made a deal to sell 50 percent of Trident Energy Inc., a producer of liquefied natural gas, for $600 million to a subsidiary of Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas-based investment firm. After taxes and other costs, the deal will yield $432 million for Occidental. Then he sold Oxy's North Sea oil and gas holdings for $1.35 billion to France's Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and Enterprise Oil P.L.C. of Britain. Mr. Irani is now more than halfway to his goal. And the market likes it. Occidental shares closed the week at $21.125, up $2.125. NCR -- Who Is the Real Winner? Who benefits most from A.T.& T's $7.4 billion purchase of the NCR Corporation? The American Telephone & Telegraph Company says it does; the deal puts it back in the computer business. But the real winners may be the Wall Street firms that advised the companies during their five-month fight. The advisers get millions in fees at a time when dealmaking is all but dead. Dillon Read & Company and Goldman Sachs & Company, which advised NCR, will each receive about $18.5 million. Morgan Stanley & Company, which advised A.T.& T., will get $13.28 million. Proxy solicitation firms also did well. Morrow & Company will receive $1.7 million and Georgeson & Company will receive $2 million for trying to sway NCR's stockholders. And then there were the lawyers. Two firms will split $20 million for the paperwork. Metromedia's Mighty Returns John W. Kluge, the billionaire chairman of the Metromedia Company, has been making money even in the money-losing cellular-telephone business. His formula has been simple: unload as much of your holdings as you can. Last week, he sold Metromedia's cellular telephone company in Philadelphia for $1.1 billion. The buyer was the Comcast Corporation, an operator of cable television systems there. Metromedia, based in Secaucus, N.J., is one of the nation's largest private partnerships. Since 1986, when it began selling its cellular systems in New York, Washington, Baltimore, Boston and Chicago, the partnership has received $3 billion. The company invested just $20 million in Philadelphia a decade ago. Not a bad return for Mr. Kluge. Troubles for G.M.'s Saturn The General Motors Corporation spent $3.5 billion just to get the Saturn Corporation off the ground. It was supposed to be "a laboratory for all of G.M.," said Ronald Glantz, an automobile analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. But last week it announced it would be replacing 1,836 of its 1991 model cars that were filled with the wrong coolant. And another laboratory -- one at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration -- said Saturn was not as safe as any of the other cars in its class in a front-end collision. Should G.M. and the nation's Saturn owners be worried? "The data bear little relationship to reality," Mr. Glantz said. "Saturn is under a magnifying glass right now. It was a smooth startup and it's a good product." USX Bidding Farewell to Steel Carl C. Icahn wants the USX Corporation to sell its steel business, the nation's largest. Mr. Icahn, the company's biggest shareholder, is finally getting his way. Last week, shareholders approved a plan to separate the company's stock into two groups. One would comprise the steel business; the other, the Marathon Oil Company. With two groups of stock, the steel business would be easier to sell. Charles A. Corry, the company's chairman, is talking to potential buyers. Of Batteries, Beer and Bunnies First there was "Harvey," the six-foot rabbit in the 1954 movie starring Jimmy Stewart. This time around, there are two: one mechanical and one played by Leslie Nielsen, the star of "Naked Gun." And the bunny masters are suing each other. Eveready, the battery-making subsidiary of the Ralston Purina Company, alleged last week in a lawsuit that the Adolph Coors Company was unfairly parodying its mechanical rabbit in a new series of commercials starring Mr. Nielsen. Coors, in a countersuit, is trying to stop Eveready from interfering with its new campaign. The problem, said Eveready, is that it doesn't want people to associate its bunny with beer. In Brief The Justice Department said a subsidiary of Japan's NEC Corporation agreed to pay $34 million in fines to settle charges that it rigged bids on contracts worth $103 million at an American military base in Japan. THE ECONOMY

title: KURDISH LEADERS INSPECT IRAQI CITY
description: American and Iraqi officers took two Kurdish guerrilla leaders to inspect the city of Dohuk today in a sign of a possible deal that could coax hundreds of thousands of reluctant refugees down from the Turkish mountains.

title: Foreign Peanut Toxins Could Harm Liver
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Alabama; Icarus Falls Yet Again, But Vandals Are at Fault
description: Not even three guardian angels were enough to protect Icarus at the University of Alabama.

title: Jane N. Barrett, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Jane Nicholls Barrett, a lawyer in New York, and Christopher Ridley, a Boston television executive, were married in Concord, Mass., yesterday. She is a daughter of Harry L. Barrett of Wayland, Mass., and the late Barbara Barrett. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Edmund C. Ridley of New York and the late Mr. Ridley. The Rev. Kenneth Sawyer, a Unitarian minister, officiated in the chapel at Concord Academy.

title: Ms. Scott Weds David S. Fortney
description: Jacqueline Rose Scott, a Washington tax lawyer, and David Scott Fortney, the Deputy Solicitor for National Operations of the Department of Labor, were married yesterday in Mystic, Conn. Michael Hurley, Administrative Judge for the Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of New London, officiated at the Mystic Hilton.

title: Heavenly Table Crumbs
description: COMETS A Chronological History of Observation, Science, Myth, and Folklore. By Donald K. Yeomans. Illustrated. 485 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $35.

title: Hate 'Hamlet'? Who Are You Kidding?
description: Talk about art imitating life. A young actor spends 15 years in Los Angeles in television and the movies. Moves to New York. Lands his first role on Broadway, in the Paul Rudnick comedy "I Hate Hamlet" at the Walter Kerr Theater. Plays Gary Peter Lefkowitz, the quintessential Hollywood agent, padding around in a wrinkly unconstructed jacket and delivering perhaps the best line of the entire show: "Death, man. Think about it -- the third coast." His on-stage client? A young actor who has just moved from Los Angeles to New York.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Brian: Symphony No. 1 Soloists and choruses; CSR Symphony and Slovak Philharmonic conducted by Ondrej Lenard. Marco Polo 8.223280; two CD's.

title: The Morals of Insider Stock Trading
description: "THE ARRANGEMENT," a new play by Eric Eisenberg at the Arena Players Repertory Theater, explores insider trading, how it happens and who is involved.

title: New York Is Buying Albany's Trash
description: As New York State struggles to slash billions of dollars in spending on education and health care, it is planning to increase its budget for something else this year: Albany's garbage.

title: A la Carte: Delivery for the Stay-at-Home Diner
description: A TUXEDOED waiter knocks on the door of a house in Manhasset. He ceremoniously enters and serves mammoth helpings of Haagen-Dazs ice cream to a gathering of friends attending a 40th-birthday party.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL

title: Travel Advisory; Jewish Roots In Poland
description: Tours of Poland that will focus on genealogical research, especially among Polish archival material, are being sponsored by the American Jewish Congress. The tours, called "Routes to Roots," will take participants into branches of the Polish State Archives throughout Poland, including the archives at Auschwitz and Birkenau. Photocopying, photographing and videotaping will be allowed. The tours will also feature lectures, cultural events and guided tours of historically important Jewish sites in Warsaw, Cracow and Lublin. They will be led by a genealogist, Miriam Weiner, of Secaucus, N.J., who will also conduct preliminary genealogical research for participants before departure.

title: Shill for Stalin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Declines On Rate Worries
Shore Tries New Tack In Luring Tourists
description: IN years past, the tourism industry in New Jersey largely relied on the 127-mile stretch of sandy beaches from Sandy Hook to Cape May to sell itself. Now, with many vacationers discouraged by the recession and by the pollution of summers past, and with the state cutting back on promotion money, tourism and local government officials have teamed up with business owners to package and sell the Jersey Shore.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Home's a Castle Besieged by Restrictive Covenants
description: In the DeKalb County community of Mainstreet 10 miles east of downtown Atlanta, homeowners are prohibited from putting television antennas on their roofs or birdbaths in their front yards.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Festival of the Americas, Madison Avenue will be closed today from 42d to 57th Street from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Yugoslav Spurns Bulls
description: The Bulls wanted him badly and made a big-money offer to lure him to Chicago, but after a year's flirtation, TONI KUKOO, a top European star, has accepted an even bigger-money offer to play for Benetton of the Italian League.

title: For New Yorkers,Something Is Gone With Budget
description: To the people who live in New York City, there is nothing abstract about the fiscal crisis anymore. Experts prescribe and politicians spar, but New Yorkers look past them at the city. What they see is loss.

title: After the War: A Photographer's Portfolio; Children of Grief: Kurds in Refuge
description: When the Kurds fled President Saddam Hussein's army, the children ran with their parents over the Turkish frontier, crossing tortuous mountain roads and rocky passes with the same courage as their elders.

title: First a Pizza Machine, Then a Safer Bet
description: Eight years ago, Joe Forlivio invented a pizza machine. Pop in a loaf of bread. Put in fixings. Wait a bit. And, voila -- here comes a whole herd of pizza slices, individually wrapped.

title: On the Street; Spring: Old Checks, New Combinations
description: Black and white houndstooth checks, square checks and diamond checks make some of this spring's clothes graphic. The patterns are traditional, but the mix is new and so are the stretch leggings that pull things into Op-Art designs. One woman mixed large and small houndstooths. Another topped her stretch houndstooth leggings with a denim jacket, the back painted with giant salt and pepper shakers. And a woman wearing a black and white checked suit and scarf passed a very tall man suited in a black and white tablecloth check.

title: To Help Understanding Of Port-Wine Stains
description: I am the parent of one of the children featured in "New Lasers Aim Directly at Port-Wine Stains" [ March 24 ] , which dealt with laser surgery being used in the treatment of various types of birthmarks and other conditions.

title: WHAT DIVIDES BERLIN NOW?
description: John Tagliabue's article "What Divides Berlin Now?" (April 7) was insightful in explaining the social dichotomy of the new Berlin. I was there last July to cover for WNEW-FM Roger Waters's benefit performance of "The Wall" at Pottsdamerplatz. While I was there, a cabdriver (a West Berliner) said to me: "Philosophically, reunification is wonderful. In reality, it stinks. We are not ready to destroy a thriving economy so that millions of Ossies can suck the system dry. They offer nothing."

title: An American Wrestles With a Troubled Future
description: For the McDonald's Corporation whose name, golden arches and Big Mac are American icons -- a reckoning is at hand.

title: The Flutters; Adding Up Concern For Bush and Doubts About Quayle, the Democrats Get Zero
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S irregular heartbeat sent a tremor through American politics last week. Suddenly, there was new talk of the "Quayle factor" and a flurry of polls that showed a majority of Americans still queasy at the thought of a Quayle Presidency.

title: Birthday Greeting
description: To the Editor:

title: Amanda Bassett Corroon Is Married To Richard Francis Dolan in Delaware
description: Amanda Bassett Corroon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Larkin Corroon of Greenville, Del., was married there yesterday to Richard Francis Dolan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Dolan of Lakeville, Conn. Msgr. Paul J. Schierse performed the ceremony at the church of St. Joseph's on the Brandywine.

title: Windsor Knot
description: In a 1957 essay, the English novelist and playwright J. B. Priestley lamented Britain's decline into an offshore province of the new American empire. Perhaps surprisingly for such a man-of-the people author, he wrote: "That is why we are so happy and excited when we can send abroad a good-looking young woman in a pretty new dress to represent us, playing the only card we feel can take a trick -- the Queen."

title: Lorraine L. Chow, Student, to Marry Mark D. Hansen, Software Developer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Li Hang Chow of Cedar Knolls, N.J., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Lorraine Lee Chow, and Mark David Hansen, a son of Ann Hansen of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late Dr. David Hansen.

title: New England Spring: How's That Again?
description: I'M just Puritan enough to enjoy a north country spring, though goodness knows it isn't easy. Sure, the mud on Goose Pond Road is so deep it would take a hydrofoil to cross it, we've had more snow squalls since the equinox than we had all winter, the crocuses in our garden took one look at things and immediately died, but what of it? That's the Puritan part, seasonal character building, a spring to scrub away winter's staleness, steel wool for the soul.

title: Data Update
Wall Street; The Seed Money Flow Slows in Computers
description: The high-technology darlings of tomorrow's stock market are incubating in the venture-capital nurseries today. That's the good news. The bad news is that the nanny may be about to give notice.

title: Nature Photographer Teaches His Students New Ways to See
description: THERE were few trees in the Brooklyn of Allen Rokach's childhood and flowers were rarely seen. Yet Mr. Rokach, who is 50, is now well known for his photographs of flowers and gardens. His photographs of flowers, reviewers have said, seem even more beautiful than the flowers themselves.

title: Czechoslovak Sculptor Enjoys His U.S. Debut
description: TIBOR BARTFAY used to hide the collages with anti-oppression themes that he created in his studio in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, between government commissions for monumental public sculptures. Now the 68-year-old artist, whose once-private works have been freely shown in his homeland for two years, is being given his first United States exhibit, through May 25, in the Carriage Barn at Waveny Park in New Canaan.

title: Style Makers; Stephen Piscuskas, Home Furnishings Designer
description: What does a furniture designer do with scrap wood? For several years, Stephen Piscuskas has used leftovers from his York Street Studio in Brooklyn Heights to build boxes as gifts for friends.

title: The Nation; As Funds for Welfare Shrink, Ideas Flourish
description: NOBODY likes welfare, and this year it shows. Across the country, officials are unveiling proposals to pay the poor less, work them more and coerce or cajole them into families with fewer children and a father at home. Black and white, liberal and conservative -- everyone seems to have a thirst for change and a six-point plan to boot.

title: Last-Minute Gifts That Don't Look It
description: So you've let Mother's Day slip up on you without a thought as to what to get her. Shame on you! But last-minute shopping need not seem done at the last minute. Many stores in Manhattan and its suburbs are open today, for that thoughtful memento that just happened to be picked up on the wayto her home.

title: Ms. Marmor Wed To F. B. Eisman
description: Jennifer Laura Marmor, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Marmor of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married in Westport, Conn., last evening to Frederic Bruce Eisman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Eisman of New Rochelle. Rabbi Jonathan Singer and Cantor Helene Reps officiated at the Inn at Longshore.

title: Review/Ballet; A Tribute in Pure Dance, From 2 Different Approaches
description: The 1940's, a decade that has invited increasing re-examination in many fields, was well represented in American Ballet Theater's most recent triple bill.

title: China Party Chief Due in Moscow as Ties Gain
description: When the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, visited Beijing two years ago, the Chinese welcomed him with embarrassed smiles, but when China's Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, travels to the Soviet Union on Wednesday, the roles will be somewhat reversed.

title: Pity the Stepmother
description: In many fairy tales, from the best-loved like "Cinderella" to lesser known stories like "Donkeyskin," a corpse lies hidden: the body of the heroine's mother. Beauty in "Beauty and the Beast," Rapunzel, Snow White and Cinderella are all motherless children. The disappearance of their mothers seems taken for granted in the stories: the reasons for their death are seldom given and the women rarely glimpsed alive.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday showing two members of the Albert Einstein Symphony Orchestra was inadvertently reproduced in mirror image, and the caption was incorrect accordingly. In the picture as published, Dr. Marc Wager appeared on the left and Dr. Martin I. Surks on the right.

title: Q and A
description: Automatic Tellers Abroad

title: At F.D.R. Library, Students Enter a Hands-On History Lab
description: FOR most high school students, field trips are an inalienable right of spring. Few prospects are as appealing as a temporary escape from the school grounds in balmy weather. But when the destination is the archives of a historical library, the classroom might not look so dull after all.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The West may have been this country's Manifest Destiny, but in the mid-19th century it had yet to make itself manifest -- few knew what the frontier looked like. In 1863 Albert Bierstadt charged a 25-cent admission to view his 6- by 10-foot panoramic painting "The Rocky Mountains, Lander's Peak." Crowds came, captivated by such minutely observed details as a prairie dog sniffing the air near an Indian encampment. Nobody was better at self-promotion than Bierstadt (1830-1902), who made his initial trip along the Overland Trail in 1859 and found the subject that would make him famous until styles changed; he died forgotten. In ALBERT BIERSTADT: Art & Enterprise (Hudson Hills, $75), Nancy K. Anderson, an assistant curator of American art at the National Gallery of Art, and Linda S. Ferber, chief curator at the Brooklyn Museum, reintroduce and insightfully reassess a painter who gave America a vision of itself. Bierstadt's exalted landscapes, often more grand and pure than reality, offered hope and "the promise of a second chance at Eden" for a nation torn by the Civil War. The title's allusion to commerce is a pointed reference to Bierstadt's entrepreneurial instincts, which some felt exceeded his talent. Bierstadt was canny enough to capitalize on the myth of the wilderness, so crucial to the American psyche. But the opportunist who rechristened a painting "Mount Corcoran" in a blatant (and successful) effort to shoehorn his work into the newly established Corcoran Gallery also produced remarkable oil sketches of Yosemite National Park. Despite reservations, one contemporary critic acknowledged, "In the quality of American light, clear, transparent, and sharp in outlines, he is unsurpassed."

title: Q and A
description: Refinancing a Co-op Question: I am the secretary of a residential resort co-op in Hampton Bays, L.I. Our current balloon mortgage comes due in August. We are having a hard time refinancing. Banks tell us they would be unable to sell the mortgage to Fannie Mae because it refuses to buy mortgages on properties without sewer systems.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Greenberg Is Married
description: Dr. Elizabeth Emily Greenberg, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Newton Greenberg of New York, was married in New York last night to Dr. Cory Peter Frank, a son of Rita F. Paleschuck of East Hills, L.I., and the late Elliott S. Frank. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the Governors Island Officers Club.

title: Reformer or Apparatchik?
description: WHY GORBACHEV HAPPENED

title: Yonkers Neighborhood Sets Up a Land Trust
description: AN unusual land conservancy has been established in Yonkers. Using some of the techniques usually employed for protection of large open spaces, the Park Hill Land Conservancy plans to preserve 100 or so lots, each about one-eighth of an acre in size.

title: Gabrielle Buckley Weds Daniel Dolan
description: Gabrielle Marguerite Buckley, a lawyer in Chicago, and Daniel Dolan, a New York architect, were married in Chicago yesterday. She is the daughter of Justice and Mrs. Robert Chapman Buckley of Arlington Heights, Ill. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dolan of Deerfield, Ill. The Rev. Terrance Keehan performed the nondenominational ceremony in the Rockefeller Memorial Chapel at the University of Chicago.

title: Marking Years At Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall celebrated its centennial last Sunday and the music, the flower-decked boxes and the decorous audience recaptured for a few hours the splendor of a 19th-century concert gala. The music was followed by an intermission dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom, where the designer Philip Baloun put a pagoda bandstand into the center of a gold chiffon tent illuminated with tiny white lights and surrounded by yellow roses.

title: Charter Flights
description: To the Editor: Regarding Daniel G. Smith's comment that he had not flown on charter flights for years (Letters on Travel, April 21), I would like to inform him that although charter flights can be a problem, two companies, Balair and Martinair, which were covered by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, March 24), are exceptions.

title: Elizabeth Coyner to Wed Adam B. Sauer in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Coyner of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Robyn Coyner and Adam Bruce Sauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Sauer of Rockville Centre.

title: A Crashing Left Hook and a Title for Toney
description: There are punches that shock and amaze -- and make victories out of apparent defeat.

title: A Crisis at Prenatal Clinic in Yonkers
description: DELIVERY DAY was near for Tawanya Tuck and Ronda Terry, two Yonkers women expecting their first babies this month. The women, who are friends, had come to the prenatal clinic at St. John's Riverside Hospital here for their weekly checkups. After being examined by a doctor, the mothers-to-be met with a registered nurse, Margie Linton, to learn more about what to expect during labor.

title: U.S. Sees New Mideast Peace Momentum
description: American officials said today that the decision by Saudi Arabia and five other Arab gulf states to participate in a peace conference with Israel should intensify pressure on both Syria and Israel to drop objections to such a gathering.

title: Informer Tells of Corruption in Window-Installation Trade
description: An informer who admits participating in six murders began testifying in a major racketeering trial last week, telling of corruption, rigged bids and labor payoffs in the window-installation industry.

title: Chess
description: Frank Marshall gave his philosophy of a sound gambit for Black in Chess Review, No. 3, 1943. The United States champion from 1909 to 1936 said, "By this I do not mean that Black necessarily wins; I merely claim that the attack gives Black many winning chances and should be good for at least a draw."

title: Home Is Where the Checkbook Is
description: WARM HEARTS AND COLD CASH

title: Aiding Fresh Air Fund: The Things That Count
description: NEW JERSEY has not been pulling its weight for the Fresh Air Fund, said Linda Leyhane, the fund's coordinator for central New Jersey.

title: Miss Briggs Weds Geoffrey Braswell
description: Jennifer Backman Briggs and Geoffrey Emory Braswell, anthropologists working for their doctorates at Tulane University, were married yesterday in the chapel at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kittredge, a sister of the bride, officiated.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Yankee Classics: Grunts, Fools, Slumps and Duffs
description: ANY innocents visiting our rolling lands and sea-swept shores for the first time might be alarmed, indeed, if, without warning, they found the likes of grunts and slumps, crisps and fools, buckles and cobblers -- to say nothing of flummeries, duffs and pandowdies -- listed on restaurant menus. But in spite of the words' primary meanings, these ludicrous-sounding concoctions are some of New England's favorite and most traditional desserts. Made of fruit or berries, sweetened and spiced, baked or steamed, sometimes even pureed, all of them with the exception of fools are enhanced with some form of pastry, bread or dough, and generally they are served hot with a bath of heavy cream, whipped cream or gradually melting ice cream.

title: House Leaders Push Weakened Rights Bill
description: Seeking to shore up support among Southern members of Congress, House Democratic leaders are asking supporters of a civil rights bill to accept limits on Federal jury awards to female victims of employment discrimination.

title: Regina Casey Weds Mark Chiaviello in New Jersey
description: Regina Casey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Casey of Oradell, N.J., was married in Emerson, N.J., yesterday to Mark Edmund Chiaviello, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Chiaviello of Rutherford, N.J. The Rev. Charles McCusker officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption. Ms. Casey, 34 years old, is known as Gina and is keeping her name. A graduate of the College of the Holy Cross, she is the vice president of sales for Franklin Electronic Publishers, a computer company in Mount Holly, N.J. Mr. Chiaviello, 33, graduated from Manhattan College and is a salesman for the SEI Corporation, a financial services company in Wayne, Pa.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PRIZE STORIES 1991 The O. Henry Awards. Edited by William Abrahams. Doubleday, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Falling for the Work Ethic Barbara Ehrenreich offers a wry revision of the origins of the work ethic in "The Worst Years of Our Lives: Irreverent Notes From a Decade of Greed" (Harper Perennial, paper).

title: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER
description: That Francke would take her daughter to the armed- services recruiting station strikes me as a mockery of both women's liberation and a mother's concern about the loss of women's lives in combat. It makes me wonder to what ironic ends the quest for equal opportunity will ultimately take us. Why have we not seen mothers, and feminist mothers especially, decrying the absurdity of women's (and men's) involvement in war?

title: Tune's 'Grand Hotel' Checks Into New Haven
description: IN his resplendent career as mover of musicals, Tommy Tune has taken on some mighty sources, from a classic Fellini film ("8 1/2," from which he made "Nine") to the life of a legendary showman (Will Rogers). Invariably, Mr. Tune triumphed over the resulting material, transcending murky librettos or lackluster scores. For all his avowals about the collaborative forces of musicals, Mr. Tune has been the undisputed star, the prime mover, of the shows that bear his directorial and choreographic imprint, with designers and dancers turning out to be his most felicitous partners.

title: Memo to Mattingly: You-Know-Who Wrecked Yanks
description: On a day last week when he and his team were mired in a state of depression, given an absence of victories, Don Mattingly said he longed for the presence of George Steinbrenner. "I miss him; I really do," the Yankees' elder statesman said. "I feel like we'd be doing something if he were around."

title: A Word or Two (Or Three) on Love, Death and Insects
description: DeClan Patrick Aloysius MacManus, a k a Elvis Costello, is such a skillful manipulator of words, it's easy to overlook the fact that he has almost nothing to say. His songs are virtual piles of words: he stacks them one upon another, shoves them together to create unusual images, then shoves the images together to create abstruse sentences. Mr. Costello's lyrics have complete authority over his music: he writes melodies that rise and tumble oddly to keep pace with his verbal spate, and he sometimes extends a melodic phrase when he wants to tag an extra line onto a verse.

title: Juxtapositions Infused With Humor
description: DONALD LIPSKI entered the art scene in the 1970's and has been at it ever since, "it" being assemblages of found and bought objects. There is no rhyme or reason for the items he collects, sometimes in job lots, for it seems that nothing is unimportant to this artist. (He could do a mean commercial for Meinecke Discount Mufflers.)

title: Sunday Dinner; Places Where Comfort Comes at a Fair Price
description: Along with lower prices in Manhattan restaurants, there is a trend toward less opulent dining rooms. Silk curtains and brass chandeliers are being supplanted by cotton and pewter. But this does not necessarily mean discomfort, as the three comfortable and moderately priced restaurants here illustrate. Chelsea Central

title: In Search of That Great Good Place
description: HUNTING MISTER HEARTBREAK

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Copland: Orchestral and Ballet Works

title: Streetscapes: The Columbia President's House; An Elegant 1912 Home With a Vacancy Sign Out
description: SINCE 1980, the 1912 structure at the northwest corner of 116th Street and Morningside Drive has been the Columbia University president's house in name only.

title:
FORUM;
Unlock American Energy Policy
description: With the gulf crisis simmering down and the Administration's new energy policy on the table, critics are howling for more Federal energy regulations and initiatives.

title:
DINING OUT;
California Flair in Croton-on-Hudson
description: TUCKED away in a complex of shops and offices, Sonoma could be missed by all but the determined seeker. Those who find this oasis will be charmed by its California conception edged with a bit of the Southwest. The peak and beams of its ceilings and the clean white and oak look are inviting, as are its genuinely caring service, its laid-back ambience, its menu, its wine list of Sonoma Valley bottles, its moderate prices and much of its food.

title: Deborah Weinberger, an Executive, Weds Charles Everett Hoyt, a Lawyer
description: Deborah Weinberger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Weinberger of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md., to Charles Everett Hoyt, a son of Elizabeth S. Hoyt of Ponte Vedra, Fla., and the late Everett W. Hoyt. The Rev. Stewart Pierson, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Club.

title: Art vs. Propaganda
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mother's Day Gift From Mr. Chips
description: The day her youngest child left home, when the suitcases were piled by the apartment door, and all the goodbyes and tears had been shared, the mother found herself wanting to say something more, something profound. But what?

title: Mary Beth Geier Is Married
description: Mary Elizabeth Geier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Geier of Williamsville, N.Y., was married in Eggertsville, N.Y., yesterday to Joseph Thomas Donohue Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donohue of West Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Michael P. Juran officiated at St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Donohue, who is known as Mary Beth, is an administrative trainee at Sotheby's in New York. She graduated cum laude from Middlebury College and received a master's degree in management from the American Graduate School of International Management in Glendale, Ariz. Mr. Donohue is a vice president at J. P. Morgan in New York. He graduated from Hofstra University and received a master's degree in management from Yale University.

title: California
description: To the Editor: "What's Doing in San Jose" (Travel, April 7) included many of the outstanding cultural resources in San Jose. As director of the San Jose Museum of Art, northern California's only museum dedicated to contemporary art on an international scale, I wanted to add to that impressive list.

title: Citing Abuse, Women Ask For Clemency In Killings
description: IN a small loft room inside the visitors center at the Connecticut Correctional Institution in Niantic, Diane Bartholomew's hands trembled and her large brown eyes filled with tears as she struggled to recount her marriage of 24 years to Harry Bartholomew. The relationship, she said, began at a roadside restaurant in rural Pennsylvania where she worked as a waitress and he "would always come in wearing his cute little baseball cap." It ended on Feb. 19, 1989, in the couple's Middlebury home, when Ms. Bartholomew fired the single shotgun blast that killed her husband while he slept.

title: Girl Held in Death of Abandoned Baby
description: When Tawana Scott conceived her second child last year at the age of 15, she hid the pregnancy from her closest friends, her mother and even the baby's father. When she gave birth last August, she ran away from the hospital, abandoning the baby in the nursery, and told her family and friends that the baby had been stillborn.

title: Susan Hostetter Weds
description: Susan Marie Hostetter, a daughter of Juanita H. Watson of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Douglas Lee Forman, a son of Leonard M. Forman of Los Angeles and Rhoda B. Forman of New York. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated at the Church Center of the United Nations. Mrs. Forman, 24 years old, is a pharmacist at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. She graduated from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science. Dr. Forman, 29, is a surgical resident at Mount Sinai Hospital. He graduated from San Diego State University and received his M.D. from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Ann Tuttle Weds Kenneth Koster
description: Dr. Ann Abeel Tuttle, the daughter of Gordon M. Tuttle of Darien, Conn., and the late Alice W. Tuttle, was married in Darien yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Henry Koster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Koster of Cincinnati. The Rev. Edward Danks officiated at the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: Ian Highet Wed To Lea W. Paine
description: Lea Warren Paine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Paine of New York, was married yesterday to Ian Highet, the son of Mrs. Eliot Stewart of New York and Keith Highet of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. John Fisher, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Michael Crimmins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Tech Notes; A Cheap Cell for Electricity
description: Texas Instruments and Southern California Edison are working on developing a new type of photovoltaic device that uses thousands of tiny silicon spheres embedded in a sheet of aluminum foil to convert sunlight into electricity. The first cells for field tests are expected to be ready before the end of the year.

title: 7th-Grade Tennis Ace Is Varsity's No. 1 Man
description: RYE NECK

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Nicholas J. Montano;
Screening Job Applicants by Handwriting
description: EMPLOYERS looking for an edge in matching an applicant with the right job have turned to handwriting analysis, said Nicholas J. Montano, a handwriting consultant.

title:
Technology;
And Now, the Modular Auto Engine
description: Since Henry Ford started mass-producing internal-combustion engines in 1913, the United States automotive industry has been constrained by a seemingly immutable rule: Each engine line can produce only one type of engine.

title: Unbeaten Monarchs Cool Red-Hot Knight Streak, 22-7
description: The matchup was billed as the best team in the World League of American Football, the undefeated London Monarchs, versus the hottest team in the league, the New York/New Jersey Knights.

title: Travel Advisory; Carnival Buys Disney Cruise Competitor
description: The names of the ships won't change and the companies will continue operating separately, but if the acquisition of Premier Cruise Lines by Carnival Cruise Lines takes place as planned by June 21, Carnival, the world's largest cruise line, will be the sole operator out of Cape Canaveral, Fla., the port for cruises that offer a Walt Disney World package.

title: New York Raises the Price That Dairies Pay Farmers for Milk
description: An emergency price increase of seven cents a gallon for milk produced by New York dairy farmers was announced today by the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

title: Kuwait to Try Collaborators
description: Kuwait's Justice Minister said in an interview published today that dates would soon be fixed for the trials of hundreds of people held on charges of collaborating with Iraqi occupation forces. The official, Ghazi al-Sammar, told a Kuwaiti newspaper, New Dawn, that prosecutors were preparing paperwork for the trials. "God willing, the dates for the trials will be set in the next few days," Mr. Sammar said.

title: Stephanie Zoes Wed to R. D. Warner
description: Stephanie Pella Zoes and Raymond Darrow Warner, investment bankers in New York, were married yesterday at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Vance Polley performed the ceremony.

title: Mines and Old Bombs Are Still a Threat in Kuwait
description: In most of this country, a U-turn on a dirt road is a life-threatening maneuver, unless performed entirely in an area covered by fresh tire tracks. Covering new ground here, whether by car or on foot, risks detonating one of the myriad mines, bombs and other explosives left from the Persian Gulf war.

title: JERSEYANA
description: SO we live our little suburban lives in New Jersey today. We have our little triumphs: a promotion, a wedding, a new house. And we have our little tragedies: the car breaks down, the property tax goes up.

title: The Stanley Cup? The North Stars? Why Not?
description: Before the game, the players growled and glowered at one another, threatening to brawl during the warmups and forcing officials in street clothes to come on the ice to keep them apart.

title: A Miss America Says She Was Incest Victim
description: A former Miss America says her father sexually abused her when she was a child.

title: Giving Philanderers a Bad Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Huntington Ponders Hindu Church
description: HUNTINGTOWN TOWN officials are expected to decide shortly whether to delay issuing a permit for the construction of a $1.4 million Hindu church in Dix Hills because of neighbors' assertions that it is not a church but a boarding house.

title: Susan D. Gross, Architect, Weds
description: Susan Deborah Gross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Gross of Sands Point, L.I., was married last evening to Adam Moss Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Cohen of New York. Rabbi Martin Rosenberg officiated at the Century Club.

title: About Men; Making His Own Mark
description: IN A GESTURE ODDLY ancient, a young man's chest was offered for tribal marking. He stood on his knees, bare from the waist up. His irregular breathing spoke fear in an arrhythmic cadence of grunts and sucking air.

title:
DINING OUT;
Dishes of Morocco and the Middle East
description: THE exterior of Alkhimah, an 18-month-old restaurant in a shopping mall in the Gloucester County community of Cherry Hill, gives no indication of the Middle Eastern and Moroccan delights inside. After passing through the front door and parting the long, heavy draperies covering the inner doorway, diners may take a moment to become accustomed to the dimly lighted interior.

title: Camera
description: When the first single-use cameras were introduced four years ago, they were unabashedly called disposable. Their fate, once the photo processor removed the film from their plastic bodies, was usually the garbage dump.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: COLONIAL MOTHERHOOD

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about the new film version of "A Kiss Before Dying" misstated the number of sisters in the Ira Levin novel on which it is based and misstated the fate of one sister in the 1956 film version. There were three sisters in the novel. The sister named Ellen did not die in the 1956 film.

title: Ms. Craighead Wed in Seattle
description: Catherine Ruth Craighead, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Craighead of New York, was married yesterday in Seattle to William Maitland Wappler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wappler of Seattle. The Rev. Robert H. Cochrane, bishop emeritus of Olympia, Wash., performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: Call the Next Witness
description: DEAD CERTAINTIES

title: Things Back To Normal At Stadium
description: Oakland has the sort of lineup that can bury an opposing pitcher before he gets the chance to break a decent sweat. A single here, a double there and the inevitable homer tossed into the mix can end a pitcher's day prematurely.

title: Travel Advisory; Dulles, Toronto Airports Grow
description: To accommodate increasing numbers of overseas passengers, Dulles International Airport near Washington has opened a new international arrivals building and Toronto's Pearson Airport has opened Trillium Terminal Three, Canada's first privately owned and operated international airport facility.

title: The Tall Truths of a Yarn Spinner
description: After all the bad blood stirred up on Broadway by "Miss Saigon," along comes "The Will Rogers Follies" to make things better again.

title: Environmental Myths and Nonproblems
description: To the Editor:

title: Emotional Wallops in 'Sunshine'
description: NOT only is William Mastrosimone a gifted and prolific playwright, but also he's a a lucky one. Ever since he made a name for himself with "The Woolgatherer" and "Extremities," in the early 1980's, small theaters countrywide have been vying for his new works. But Mr. Mastrosimone's new works are often reworkings of older ones.

title: Why Salvadorans Flock to the Island
description: I must take issue with some of the economic and political implications of the article "Illegal Aliens Say Census Missed Thousands" [ March 24, 1991 ] . The tone of the article suggests that most Salvadorans are here in this country because of political repression back in El Salvador and that they held the U.S. responsible.

title: New Limits Sought on Campaign Finances
description: IN the months before the general election in November 1990, two candidates spent more than $1 million between them in competing for a State Senate seat that would be up for grabs again just one year later. The loser spent nearly three-quarters of a million dollars, which works out to about $30 for every losing vote.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Retail Complex to Give Patchogue a Lift
description: CONSTRUCTION of the Shoppes at Village Square, a 27,000-square-foot retail center on Main Street in the Village of Patchogue, will bring a new kind of retailer to the central business district -- national and regional stores.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. ARNOLD KRUPAT;
Making the Curriculum Less Exclusive
description: IT used to be that taking an American literature course, whether it was in high school or college, meant reading Hawthorne, Poe, Melville, Twain, Hemingway, Fitzgerald and others, most of whom were white men.

title: Emma H. Rymer Wed in Rhode I.
description: Emma Harrison Rymer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Rymer of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to T. Williams Roberts 3d, the son of Mr. Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and the late Frances Kellett Roberts. The Rev. Daniel Burke officiated at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence.

title:
FILM;
Demi Moore, Overnight Star, At Long Last
description: It's easy to take Demi Moore not quite seriously. She has starred, for the most part, in a series of films -- "Blame It on Rio," "No Small Affair," "The Seventh Sign," "We're No Angels" -- for which the word "forgettable" would be kind. Until last year, her most famous role was in "St. Elmo's Fire," a 1985 film often dismissed as the quintessential Brat Pack film.

title: Rangers Need New Chemistry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Credit Check
description: The hereafter has become a favored movie theme recently, what with the popularity of "Ghost" and now "Defending Your Life," in which one's future existence is determined by the record of one's past.

title: Review/Music; A Minimalist Route at Bang on a Can
description: One school of polemical pop criticism argues that symphonic music in the United States is entirely a European imposition. Six generations of American symphonists belie that notion. Now Minimalism has proven that the trade routes work in both directions. The Bang on a Can Festival noted that point in its opening concert on Thursday evening, when it presented a program of European Minimalists at Town Hall. American Minimalism had its turn Friday evening at La Mama.

title: Anna K. P. Law Weds
description: Anna Katharine Pickering Law, a daughter of Alfred John Law 3d and Katharine S. J. Law, both of New York, was married in Los Angeles yesterday to Alan Douglas Rast, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald James Rast of Costa Mesa, Calif. Bishop Daniel Setjo officiated at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Mrs. Rast, 24 years old, and Mr. Rast, 27, are production coordinators at the Fox Television Center in Los Angeles. She graduated from Northwestern University.

title: Janine Wollis Marries Robert Tabas
description: Dr. Janine Gayle Wollis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Wollis of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Robert Royal Tabas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Tabas of Haverford, Pa. Rabbi Frederick Kazan officiated at the Twelve Caesars in Philadelphia.

title: Patricia M. Doykos to Marry in August
description: August wedding plans for Patricia Mae Doykos and David Joseph Duquette Jr., a son of Dr. Duquette of Loudonville, N.Y., and the late Joan Culverhouse Duquette, have been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. John D. Doykos 3d of Methuen, Mass.

title: On Screen, Robin Givens Looks for New Beginnings
description: During her student days at Sarah Lawrence, Robin Givens hung up lifesize posters of Marilyn Monroe and Rita Hayworth, symbols of her fantasies about a film career. In the new film "A Rage in Harlem," Ms. Givens plays a woman similar in some ways to the sultry and sizzling yet vulnerable roles Monroe and Hayworth were known for.

title: The World; Effects of War Begin to Fade In Iraq
description: THE Persian Gulf war, early reports indicated, meant the end of modern Iraq. Allied bombing knocked out most of Iraq's industrial capability, according to these reports, not to mention nearly all telephone, electricity and water-supply systems. But a recent three-week visit to Baghdad and the surrounding area shows a different picture.

title: Suits That Cover a Multitude of Sins
description: This season, swimsuits are ruffled or sleek, skimpy or high-necked, strapless or with sleeves. Some suits can even double as disco dresses. But what is most alluring is that for women who do not have reed-thin bodies, but who do have full breasts, rippling tummies or large hips, there are what the designer Norma Kamali calls "hideout suits."

title: Pamela Ruddick Plans to Marry in '92
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Perry Ruddick of Cedar Grove, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Mull Ruddick to William Burton Holding Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Holding of Darien, Conn. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: THE UNFINISHED POLITICIAN
description: Senator Bob Kerrey sounds like someone important ("The Unfinished Politician," by Robin Toner, April 14). Republicans are already unsheathing the "L" word to describe him.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article in the Real Estate Section today about a proposal to designate 25 Harlem structures as landmarks includes conflicting dates for the first hearing by the Landmarks Preservation Commission on the matter. It will be sometime in July, not on June 11.

title:
TELEVISION;
'Schwarzkopf,' the Sitcom?
description: Somewhere in Hollywood the king of programming charged out of his office shouting "Air war, ground war,

title: No Sovereignty For Suffering
description: When U.S. forces vio lated Iraqi sovereignty crossing a border without permission -- to care for the suffering Kurds, Washington committed a constructive act with tremendous and unforeseeable consequences.

title: Now, CD's Emit Sights as Well as Sound
description: The consumer electronics industry is preparing fresh battle for another spot in America's living rooms. With sales of video cassette recorders slowing, several consumer electronics companies are about to unveil what they hope will be their next big blockbuster, a new type of compact disc player that displays sophisticated audio and video programs on a television set. The players come equipped with hand-held controllers that enable viewers to manipulate and navigate by sight and sound through such programs as encyclopedias, the complete works of Shakespeare, and a library of children's songs.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. DARYL B. LUND;
Food Science Means Engineering, Too
description: STEEPED in agriculture on both sides of his family, Daryl B. Lund was nevertheless planning to teach ninth-grade mathematics when he accepted a graduate assistantship in food science during his senior year of college. Once he did, the die was cast.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ANARCHY AND ELEGANCE Confessions of a Journalist at Yale Law School. By Chris Goodrich. Little, Brown, $19.95.

title: Ground Sununu? Nah, Put Them All in the Air
description: Instead of jumping all over White House chief of staff John Sununu for wasting our money by flying military planes for skiing trips to Vail, Colo., perhaps we should look a little differently at this tempest in a tailwind.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: If Anne Matthews had extended her research to a few women's colleges, she could have discovered how to raise significant funds from alumnae at coed colleges and universities ("Alma Maters Court Their Daughters," April 7).

title: MONUMENT MAKER
description: Lin's Civil Rights Memorial in Montgomery, Ala., is clearly one of her triumphs as a sculptor and architect. However, Martin Luther King Jr. would be astonished to be credited with the inscription: ". . . until justice rolls down like water, and righteousness like a mighty stream."

title: Carolyn Holmes, Executive, Weds
description: Carolyn Gay Holmes, the daughter of Joseph Horne Holmes 3d of Norwalk, Conn., and Mrs. David Hugh Kelsey of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Walter Coffey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Daniel Coffey of Midlothian, Va. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Parish in Darien, Conn.

title: Curtailing Oil Spills
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Help the Soviet Union?
description: Sending the Soviet people $1.5 billion in new credits to buy food would be a decent thing to do. It would also serve hard-headed American interests. So it is good to hear that President Bush is looking for a way to provide the aid, despite considerable advice to the contrary.

title: Real Life Takes Its Cue From the Movies
description: No one presented evidence of boiled bunnies, but there was a blond woman obsessed with her former lover and there was a dead, dark-haired wife, shot nine times. So when Carolyn Warmus was accused of the 1989 murder of Betty Jeanne Solomon, the tabloids and television news called it "the 'Fatal Attraction' trial." In time, it became "the so-called 'Fatal Attraction' trial."

title: Amy Weiss Plans to Wed
description: Dr. B. Allen Weiss of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Willie Weiss of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Amy Weiss and John Tobe, the son of James Tobe and Mabel Tobe, both of Los Angeles. Ms. Weiss, 26 years old, is the communications director of the Center for National Policy, a nonprofit research group in Washington. She graduated from American University. Mr. Tobe, 30, is a political analyst at the Japanese Embassy in Washington. He graduated from the University of Southern California.

title: Social Events
description: Yachting Around Manhattan

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MOVING PICTURES By Ali MacGraw.Bantam, $20.

title: DESIGNER SECONDS
description: As a red Bordeaux enthusiast for the past four decades, I'd like to answer Frank J. Prial's question: Which is the better deal, a first growth's second label or a lesser chateau? (Wine: "Designer Seconds," April 7).

title: World Markets; Good Times for Japan's Banks?
description: A great deal of abuse has been heaped on Japan's battered banks in the past year as their profits have plummeted and their stock prices have tumbled. But in recent months, the shares of these financial giants have staged a dramatic rebound. Is it reckless speculation, or is there a message in the price rise?

title: Belle Hits Fan With a Ball
description: Indians outfielder Albert Belle threw a baseball at a heckler in the left-field stands at Cleveland Stadium today, hitting the man in the chest.

title: Resisting Conservatives, Moderates Among Southern Baptists Set Up a Rival Group
description: Teetering on the brink of forming a new denomination, 6,000 disaffected Southern Baptists set up an organization today that will allow them to operate independently of the conservative leadership of the Southern Baptist Convention.

title: U.S. SENDS TROOPS TO AID BANGLADESH IN CYCLONE RELIEF
description: In a major military response to the devastation in Bangladesh from last week's cyclone, the United States has dispatched thousands of marines and dozens of helicopters as part of an amphibious task force to bolster relief operations there, White House and Pentagon officials said today.

title: Winners All, By a Knockout
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Executive Life; Another Vote on Girls in an Old-Boy World
description: Last month, a furor erupted at Yale University when the 15 seniors in the all-male Skull and Bones broke with a century and a half of tradition by "tapping," or selecting, seven women for the secret society's next "delegation." Stunned, the alumni board of directors padlocked the club's windowless crypt and declared the election void. No matter, the students countered; their hallowed rites would continue in exile until a compromise could be reached.

title: Beyond Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lens on a Photographer's Submerged Conflicts
description: WHEN Minor White died in 1976, he was known as one of the most influential American photographers of three decades. Artistically, his prints were highly valued for their clarity and grace. But to Peter C. Bunnell, the Princeton University art historian who sorted, catalogued and interpreted the artist's estate, White's photographs mirror a life of submerged conflicts.

title: Dr. Mary Kline Marries
description: Dr. Mary Chapman Kline, a doctor of podiatric medicine practicing in Buffalo, and Wayne Douglas Bacon, who heads two upstate New York welding-supply companies, were married yesterday at St. Francis Episcopal Church in North Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Richard Mayberry officiated. Dr. Kline, 30 years old, graduated from State University of New York at Oneonta and the New York College of Podiatric Medicine. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Chapman Kline of Stamford, Conn. Mr. Bacon, 42, is president of Mills Welding Supply in Buffalo and Falls Welding Supply in Niagara Falls. He received a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A. from the University of Delaware. His previous marriage ended in divorce. He is a son of Mary N. Bacon of Riverton, N.J., and the late W. Garwood Bacon Jr.

title: Margaret Schellbach Wed
description: Margaret Jane Schellbach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Schellbach of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to Ronald James Fraser, a son of Karen Jensen of Mount Vernon, Wash., and the late Douglas H. Fraser of Alsgarde, Denmark. The Rev. Leslie Hughes officiated at Christ Episcopal Church. Mrs. Fraser, 28 years old, is an accountant in the Plainsboro, N.J., office of the Caxton Corporation, a financial trading company. She graduated from Marymount Manhattan College. Mr. Fraser, 36, is an assistant vice president at the United Jersey Bank in Hackensack, N.J. He graduated from the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University.

title: Coins
description: For several years, Korean War veterans have urged the construction of a memorial marking their military service, contending that they are the only veterans who have not been so honored. Last week the first Korean War Memorial silver dollars were struck at a ceremony in the United States Mint in Washington. The dollars will be sold to help finance a memorial in Washington.

title: No Light at End of the Dandelion Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampling of Two Nations in Smithtown
description: ASIDE from language, Spanish and Mexican cuisines have very little in common. Yet, many diners confuse the two. Casa Luis will add to their confusion. The new Spanish-Mexican restaurant in Smithtown offers the food of both nations under one roof.

title: Corrections
description: A Posting on May 5 about a moderate-income housing development in Bedford-Stuyvesant misidentified its architect. It is Stephen B. Jacobs & Associates of Manhattan. The misinformation was provided by the developer, the New York City Partnership.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: My daughter was in London earlier this year, scheduled to return on Jan. 16 on a nonrefundable, nonchangeable British Airways ticket. Because of the then-impending situation in the Persian Gulf, we elected to purchase a full-fare, one-way ticket on British Airways for her return on Jan. 14. Subsequently, we wrote British Airways, requesting compensation for this unexpected expenditure. They have most graciously refunded the full cost of the one-way ticket, and, thereby, earned our gratitude. ROBERT A. WOOLFITT Norfolk, Va.

title: Sylvie Guillem Has A Mind of Her Own
description: Sylvie Guillem, who begins a month of guest appearances with American Ballet Theater on Saturday night, was a virtual unknown when she made her United States debut with the Paris Opera Ballet in 1986. She returns now as one of the few genuine ballet superstars on the international circuit. With her bird-of-paradise style, she's a singular dancer whose reputation is also fueled by a determination to do things her way.

title: Campus Life: Yale; Graduate Students Try to Establish Their Own Union
description: Yale University's graduate students have collected more than 1,200 signatures supporting unionization of the school's 2,500 graduate students.

title: Fighting Words
description: CORNER MEN Great Boxing Trainers. By Ronald K. Fried. Illustrated. 414 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. $21.95. IN THE CORNER Great Boxing Trainers Talk About Their Art. By Dave Anderson. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $20.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Stockbridge, Mass.;
New Museum For Rockwell
description: CONSTRUCTION has started here on a building that will allow the Norman Rockwell Museum to move from the Old Corner House, a small house in the center of town, to the 34-acre Linwood estate two miles northwest of here.

title: Rabies Scare Elicits Clinics and Hot Lines
description: THREE weeks after the Westchester Board of Legislators declared a rabies health emergency, confirmed reports of the disease among animals are increasing. With concern growing about the threat in the suburbs, pet owners are lining up outside clinics to have their animals vaccinated.

title: Magic Gets a Horse And Potential Conflict
description: With his team leading the Golden State Warriors two games to one in the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, MAGIC JOHNSON of the Los Angeles Lakers hopes to have the four-of-seven-game series wrapped up before Game 7, provisionally scheduled for Los Angeles on Saturday.

title: Scandals Casting Shadows Over Public Life in South Carolina
description: From its aristocratic beginnings in the great Low Country plantations to the development of what many consider the nation's most powerful state legislature, South Carolina has always been a state accustomed to rule by a few.

title: The Mambo Is Back, 40 Years Later
description: Every Thursday evening, at a time most people are heading home from work, the dance floor at Club El Morocco on East 54th Street in Manhattan is elbow to elbow in men and women trying to mambo.

title: Miss Oestreich to Wed Thomas George Loeb
description: Mrs. George H. Oestreich Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., has announced September wedding plans for her daughter Jean Ferguson Oestreich and Thomas George Loeb, the son of Mrs. Frank S. Knox of Longboat Key, Fla., and the late George Loeb.

FORUM;

description: With the gulf crisis simmering down and the Administration's new energy policy on the table, critics are howling for more Federal energy regulations and initiatives.

title: WHERE DAY IS NIGHT
description: SULEIMAN AL-MUTAWA, THE MINISTER OF Planning, is one of the more unorthodox members of the Kuwaiti Government. While his colleagues insist on the traditional headdress and dishdasha (the floor-length robe), Mutawa, who is Berkeley-educated, prefers impeccably tailored Western suits. Because of his attire, he says, he understands the plight of the Palestinians in Kuwait better than most of his colleagues. Kuwaiti soldiers think he is Palestinian and regularly hassle him at military checkpoints. Even after he shows them his ministry identity card, they have a hard time believing he is not only a Kuwaiti but also a high-ranking official.

title: New York Educator Praises Bush's Plan to Improve Schools
description: Addressing 1,600 graduates of the Catholic University of America yesterday, P. Michael Timpane, the president of Teachers College of Columbia University, said President Bush's crusade to improve education in the United States was badly needed,

description: WHEN the "white tablecloth" restaurants in Manhattan that flourished during the 1980's started to wither and die in the 90's, the future of the Westchester Restaurant Supply Company in Elmsford was threatened.

title: Springtime Steps Insure Autumnal Color
description: AZALEAS, dogwoods and other spectaculars of May are bursting with beautiful flowers. It hardly seems the time to think about fall. But this is exactly what gardeners must do if they expect to have some flower color in September and October.

ART;
In Waterbury, Constructions Speak With Geometric Vocabulary

Many of the works will be familiar to those who have closely followed Mr. Ajay's work, but the eight pieces that have never been shown before are a tonic turn on his trademark structures.

title: WINNIE MANDELA AWAITS A VERDICT
description: The trial of Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, has drawn to a close with a small fraction of the public attention that accompanied its opening more than three months ago.

title: Headliners; Wrong for the Part
description: That muffled rumble from California last week came not from some tectonic jostling but from several thousand triumphant exclamations, in unison, of "I told you so." As much of Hollywood had been expecting, Jon Peters, the free-wheeling producer of "Batman" and a few other big moneymakers, announced his resignation as co-chairman of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. Mr. Peters, for all his success as a producer, was not generally viewed as studio executive timber, and Columbia's parent, the Sony Corporation, appeared to be acknowledging as much. Sony acquired Columbia from the Coca-Cola Company in 1989 and spent several hundred million dollars more to acquire the services of Mr. Peters and his partner, Peter Guber, from Warner Brothers. Mr. Guber will be Columbia's sole chief executive, but Mr. Peters will continue to be associated with the studio through his own production company. This, a Sony spokesman said, would provide Mr. Peters with "a true showcase for his talents."

A September wedding is planned. Ms. Sonenshine, 26 years old and a cum laude graduate of the State University at Albany, is an advertising account manager at McCall's magazine in New York. title: CELEBRATING PAINT
description: I very much enjoyed Deborah Solomon's article "Celebrating Paint" (March 31). Elizabeth Murray may well be the finest painter working today, and it is wonderful to see her work gaining a wider audience. Murray's paintings reveal the universal through her concentration on the personal and the domestic. Concentration, like meditation, can be heightened by focusing attention on a simple or familiar object like a dish or a flower. This is a way of clearing one's mind of distractions, permitting the entry of more complex thought. The point of focus becomes an anchor. In this way, Murray's domestic images take on the character of her thought -- her coffee cups burst with the shock of sudden insight. Familiar objects, in her studio or close by, become fused with the fire of her observations. DEBORAH EVERETT Brooklyn
