Ms. Mastrey built her reputation as "the leather nun" at KNAC, the Los Angeles heavy-metal radio station that features a traffic reporter named Headbangin' Barb, car insurance ads for "dudes" with questionable driving records and a turbo-charged playlist that "will make your ears bleed."

description: JONAH AND THE PINK WHALE By Jose Wolfango Montes Vannuci. Translated by Kay Pritchett. University of Arkansas, Cloth, $22.95; Paper, $12.95.

title: Sunday Outing; On the Lower East Side, A Spectrum of Tastes
description: The Lower East Side, once virtually a Jewish enclave, is now a neighborhood of Jews, Puerto Ricans and Asians, a place where eclecticism reigns. The streets just east of the Bowery from East Houston to Grand Street are littered with garbage and resistant to gentrification, but good food and high style lurk in shops founded at the turn of the century -- or as recently as last summer.

title: Darling Gives the Mets Just What They Needed
description: Ron Darling walked to the mound after his final warmups, his right elbow free of pain, his right shoulder comfortable and loose. Still, it was hard not to feel the strain of the circumstances.

title: Philadelphia Journal; First They Dine, Then Talk Turns To Murder
description: There have been enough bizarre killings in this city to keep a full house at the morgue and make homicide detectives and medical examiners wish they could get away from it all. And when some of them do take a break, they like to sit back and listen to the one about the Cleveland torso murders.

title: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER
description: Linda Bird Francke's column "Requiem for a Soldier" (Hers, April 21) reflects the same sort of schizophrenia I felt during the war in the Persian Gulf. I've been a pacifist most of my life, and I was in tears at the thought of bombs raining down on Iraqi women and children. Yet, whenever I saw a young American woman step out of a helicopter or perform military maneuvers, my heart soared. GABRIELLE BERNARD Winsted, Conn.

title: Bridge
description: Three separate competitions will begin Wednesday in Memphis, Tenn., to determine the United States entry in the World Championship to be played in October in Yokohama, Japan.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Unfancied Shad Make Move Upriver
description: The trout is the glamour fish of the Catskills, so it is hardly surprising that many of those fishermen who like to call themselves anglers look down their noses at the American shad. After all, the shad has often been described as "the poor man's salmon," and a lot of anglers don't want to be associated with the poor man's anything.

title: A Village Focuses Peril to Yugoslavia
description: Three days after the country's political leaders agreed to disarm all civilians and paramilitary groups, this village in the republic of Croatia today remained the focal point of an armed standoff.

title:
FILM;
Maverick Movie Makers Inspire Their Successors
description: It might have been "Shadows" or "Faces" or "A Woman Under the Influence." A kid in his teens or early 20's sits in a little art house or college auditorium watching the screen, and it dawns suddenly -- "This is an American movie, but I

title: Style Makers; Michelle Marcuse, Silk Painter
description: Five years ago, Michelle Marcuse put aside her oil paints and canvases to paint on silk. Using translucent dyes in vibrant colors, she creates designs inspired by African art, her sensitivity to nature, and her desire to make "art that doesn't just sit on the wall but will become a part of somebody's life."

title: Bridge
description: Three separate competitions will begin Wednesday in Memphis, Tenn., to determine the United States entry in the World Championship to be played in October in Yokohama, Japan.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My kitchen linoleum is 42 years old, cracked and lifting up in many areas. The base under the linoleum is made of plywood. What is the best way to remove this old linoleum?

title: A World Ripe With Magic
description: THE ALCHYMIST'S JOURNAL By Evan S. Connell. 214 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $19.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Minnesota Having Glory Days
description: The Twin Cities are quiet this weekend, a huge chunk of the populace gone north for the opening of fishing season. Most of the cabins don't have cable television, but the new-found friends of the Minnesota North Stars crowded into bars Friday night, to watch the latest bizarre little miracle of sports.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sullivan's Island, S.C.; Island House Looses a Storm
description: TO replace a small cottage swept away by Hurricane Hugo in October 1989, John Massey wanted a house that could withstand nature's fury. But the 3,700-square-foot structure he is building has unleashed a different fury -- his neighbors'.

title: Rehabilitation Hospital Forges Link With Yale
description: THREE years ago, when Henry Chauncey Jr. became president of Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford, one of his initial goals was "to see if a great hospital like this could be part of great science," he said. To him, he said, that meant establishing a formal relationship between the hospital, which provides rehabilitation for disabled adults, and a major medical school.

title: 'Wolfe Must Not Die Like a Common Soldier'
description: It was the light that did the trick; a clean, shrewdly directed radiance illuminating the face of the martyr and bathing the grieving expressions of his brother officers in a reflection of impossible holiness.

title: How Best to Teach the Blind: A Growing Battle Over Braille
description: Kenneth Silberman was in graduate school when he realized he had to learn to read and write.

title: Inn to Inn in the Finger Lakes
description: THE Finger Lakes region of New York is clearly defined by the 11 skinny lakes on the map, but if history is mixed with geography, it stretches from Syracuse to the Genesee River Valley, and from Lake Ontario to the Pennsylvania border.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Schumann: Symphonies Nos. 1, 4 London Philharmonic conducted by Kurt Masur. Teldec 2292-46445; CD.

title: What Went Wrong in Yugoslavia
description: THE CONTESTED COUNTRY

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Fears Voiced on Great Swamp Projects
description: COVERING 6,800 acres of rugged woodlands, ponds and meadows in Morris and Somerset Counties, the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge is a prized suburban wilderness where development does not intrude.

title: A New Disney Building Mixes Art With Whimsy
description: For all the hoopla that has surrounded the recent outpouring of buildings commissioned by the Walt Disney Company -- unquestionably the most conspicuous patron of high-design architecture of any corporation in the world in the last few years -- none of these structures has been strong enough to transcend its origins and stand on its own as a great work of architecture. Entertaining, controversial, intriguing, lively, compelling -- the Disney buildings have been all these things and more. But they have not been buildings that have stopped you in your tracks and made you realize, as only a few great works can, the profound powers of architecture.

title: Queens Woman Is Shot to Death in Encounter With Transit Police
description: A Queens woman -- one of three people stopped for fare beating at a Bronx subway stop early yesterday -- was shot to death when at least one of two men she was with exchanged gunfire with police officers, a Transit Authority Police spokesman said.

title: Refinancing
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SCHOOL NO. 25 IN YONKERS;
A Natural Partnership When a Museum Is Down the Block
description: NINE-YEAR-OLD Noel Hernandez painted gold and silver stars against a space-black background like those at the Andrus Planetarium at the Hudson River Museum. Arnita Terry, 13, built a carboard gazebo illustrating the use of columns and classical structures. Ricky Rodriguez, 7, learned about pueblo tribes, then spent a day in art class making a crayon drawing of a mesa.

title: Guttenberg Seeking Strength on Broadway
description: STEVE GUTTENBERG strode backstage glowing from his performance in "Prelude to a Kiss" at the Helen Hayes Theater on Broadway.

title: Counting Dead Sea Mammals Started in 80's
description: FIGURES for sea-mammal deaths along the Long Island coasts are kept by the National Marine Fisheries Service.

title:
TV VIEW;
In Minor Dramas Lurk Major Sagas
description: Everything changes in television, and nothing changes. New docudramas emerge every season, and every season they are attacked as sacrificing accuracy for the sake of entertainment. It is a complex problem, and one that has been pondered at great length -- but there may yet be a solution.

title: John G. Trezevant, 67, a Publishing Executive
description: John Gray Trezevant, a retired news executive, died Thursday at Marin County General Hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 67 years old and lived in Tiburon, Calif.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Hauppauge 158,000 10 Calico Tree Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; fireplace, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Massapequa 205,000 125 Hunter Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, family room, pool; taxes $5,300. Mount Sinai 131,000 19 Echo Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $3,300. Patchogue 95,000 43 Jennings Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 42- year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Nesconset 183,000 18 Lloyd Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; new kitchen, new bathrooms, c/a, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,000. Roslyn Heights 295,000 158 Stratford Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,500. OTHER AREAS Bedford, N.Y. 425,000 Quarry Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, wet bar, 1 acre; taxes $8,543. Weston, Conn. 526,316 15 Slumber Corners 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 39-year-old riverfront ranch; private swimming area, on cul-de-sac, 1 acre; taxes $5,204. West Orange, N.J. 260,000 15 Cullen Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; c/a, patio, eat-in-kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $6,611.

title: Mapping a Bike Route on Cape Cod
description: EACH summer, when traffic begins to stall around the Orleans rotary, supermarkets and Main Streets, when parking lots fill up early at the best beaches, more and more Cape Codders are jumping on their bicycles to shop and swim. At the same time, many visitors are discovering traces of a long-lost Cape that can easily be reached on two wheels through a network of off-road trails and meandering back roads.

title: Officials Say Popcorn Did Not Cause Illnesses
description: New York State health officials have retracted their recommendation that people not eat Jolly Time Butter Flavored Microwave Pop Corn. They said researchers had found no link between the popcorn and flu-like symptoms that 67 people statewide reported after eating it.

title: Checking Up on the Doctors
description: STRANGERS AT THE BEDSIDE

title: District in TriBeCa Wins Historic Designation and Elbow Room to Flaunt and Flex
description: Gritty and lovely by turns, still evoking the power and pretense of 19th-century commercialism, a portion of lower Manhattan has been designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission as the TriBeCa West Historic District.

title:
FILM;
Maverick Movie Makers Inspire Their Successors
description: "You're letting yourself be taken up by illusions," a well-meaning nurse tells the frazzled heroine of "My Name Is Julia Ross," the 1945 Gothic melodrama with which the director Joseph H. Lewis first made his mark. "It's all in the mind. People can think themselves into anything."

title: Kohl's Standing Trailing
description: An opinion poll released today said Chancellor Helmut Kohl, his standing battered by tax increases and high unemployment in eastern Germany, trailed the opposition Social Democratic Party for the first time since the unification of Germany last fall. General elections do not have to be called until 1994, but if they were held now, the Social Democrats would defeat Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats by 40 percent to 38 percent, said the poll in Der Spiegel.

title: Foreign Affairs; The C.I.A. in Limbo
description: The next Director of Central Intelligence will inherit various spying activities totaling $30 billion yearly and a Central Intelligence Agency, the jewel in his crown, on the verge of irrelevance. The successor will step into a universe of a dozen grossly overlapping agencies, of cutthroat bureaucratic competition, of dizzyingly potent and expensive equipment like a spy satellite costing $1.5 billion and of organizations clumsily trying to make the transition from the cold war to a bewilderingly diverse "peace."

title: Children's TV Programmers Have Sat Too Long in the Dark; Wrong Message
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Praises Gorbachev

title: YELTSIN NOW SAYS GORBACHEV IS ALLY
description: After months of criticizing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a virtual dictator, the Russian republic's leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, said in an interview published today that Mr. Gorbachev was in fact "an ally" of the democratic movement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 28 about a plan to build near Mill Pond in Centerport misstated the circumstances under which Donald A. Pius, the developer, bought real estate 20 years ago. Mr. Pius said he had purchased properties with his own funds and rented to tenants eligible for Section 8 subsidies.

title: Summer Respite From the Inner City
description: WHEN Tonya Flowers, 11 years old, of Brooklyn, boards the bus for Commack in the summer, she will do it like a trooper, unlike her first visit to the Schehr family four years ago. That was when she was so frightened that she arrived sick to her stomach.

title: Mexico City's Toxic Residue Worsens Already Filthy Air
description: Whether the weather is cold or hot, one thing is usually certain in this northern Mexico City suburb: it snows.

title: Chinese Reformer Quitting as Governor in Canton Area
description: Ye Xuanping, the popular Governor of Guangdong province in southern China, is stepping down after six years of overseeing the economic transformation of what is now the most prosperous region in this country, the official People's Daily said today.

title: U.S. Sending Team to Advise Soviets on Food Distribution
description: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev spoke for 45 minutes by telephone today, and during the conversation Mr. Gorbachev accepted an American offer to send experts to discuss Soviet food distribution problems, the White House said.

title: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER
description: Francke calls herself a feminist and yet she insinuates that women, but not men, should be exempt from fighting and dying in war. She writes of her "uneasiness at women in their modern military roles" and of "values gone entirely awry." "I feel," she says, "that women and men should share equally in the burdens and the opportunities of citizenship. But the new military seems to have stretched equality to the breaking point."

title: Virginia's Foothills, The Tranquil Piedmont
description: THE foothills of Virginia are gentle and unassuming and have usually served as a corridor to somewhere else. Somehow the region's quiet hamlets, rolling cornfields, dense woods and clear trout streams have been largely overlooked in the tourists' push from one urban mass to the next.

title: Energy Dept. to Pay Fine for A-Plant Cleanup
description: Bringing an end to a highly unusual interagency fight, the Energy Department has agreed to pay a fine to the Environmental Protection Agency for failing to meet cleanup schedules at a nuclear weapons plant in Ohio, a Government official says.

title: A 300-Year-Old House: Is It a Landmark?
description: COVERED in places by aluminum siding, the 300-year-old Schumacher House stands among the storage buildings, tennis courts and trees of Clinton G. Martin Park in the Town of North Hempstead.

title: Man Killed as Azerbaijanis Shoot Up Town
description: Troops from the southern Soviet republic of Azerbaijan landed today by helicopter in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh and shot up an Armenian village, killing one man, Armenia's Interior Ministry said.

title: Airline Removes Agent for Not Using Makeup
description: A ticket-counter agent at Logan International Airport here has been dismissed by Continental Airlines because she refused to wear makeup on the job.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DRUMMIN' MEN The Heartbeat of Jazz:The Swing Years.By Burt Korall.Schirmer, $24.95.

title: Ancient Mexicans Used Sculpture to Connect Another World
description: IN "Life, Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Mexico," an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Nov. 3, funerary ceramics illustrate an ancient people's approach to death and its relationship to fertility and regeneration.

title: In the Beginning Was Belief
description: MYTHOLOGIES Compiled by Yves Bonnefoy. Translated under the direction of Wendy Doniger. Illustrated. Two volumes. 1,267 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press.

title: Escape From Milk Farm Road
description: A CURE FOR DREAMS

title: Talking: Conflicts; Resolving Internal Disputes
description: AN ophthalmologist in a New York City co-op becomes furious when the board refuses to let him sell his apartment for professional use.

title: The U.S. Tries to Decide Just How Important China Is
description: AS Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State, left Beijing last week, he made it clear that he had delivered a stern message from the Bush Administration to China's leaders.

title: Postings: City Auction; Choice Parcels on the Block
description: As part of its ongoing effort to put tax-foreclosed properties back on the rolls and add to New York City's revenues, the Department of General Services' Division of Real Property will auction off 174 properties tomorrow.

title:
MUSIC;
Festival Goes Forth To Meet Its Audience
description: MICHAEL NEWMAN and Laura Oltman organized the Raritan River Music Festival to bring concerts to the communities in Hunterdon and Somerset Counties. The couple, who are married and live in Carpentersville, are guitarists who play as a duo, as soloists and as ensemble performers.

title: Style Makers; Seth Godin, Flashcard Maker
description: Seth Godin promotes communication. He does so with flashcards in foreign languages, in a series of pocket-size ringbound language books, with 100 common questions and phrases shown in large type in flashcard formats.

title: Karen Weintraub and Steven E. Cooper Married
description: Karen Weintraub, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weintraub of New York, was married last evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Steven Edward Cooper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bentley Cooper of Rumson, N.J. Rabbi Miriam Shapero officiated.

title: A GARDEN REGAINED
description: Roger Cohen's column "A Garden Regained" (About Men, March 31) is a painful and moving account of his relationship with his father. What may not be so obvious, however, is that the real culprit in the story is postpartum depression. Cohen says that his mother suffered a relapse of "a scourge that had afflicted her for two years" following the birth of his younger sister. She became suicidally depressed; his father became morose and increasingly distant.

title: BATHING BEAUTIES
description: Are toilets just vulgar? Not one can be seen in the bathrooms pictured in Carol Vogel's article "Bathing Beauties" (Design, April 21). Many an American has written off whole continents for want of a properly functioning, flushable toilet. I have seen friends, lifelong liberals brimming with cultural tolerance, turn into free-market capitalists for want of their favorite brand of toilet paper.

title: All About/Computer Retailers; Superstores Force PC Chains to Reinvent Themselves
description: For personal computer sellers looking ahead, the future suddenly offers very few alternatives: get big, get specialized or get out.

title: Postings: Shingle Style; Pound Ridge Houses
description: The Glazer brothers of New Canaan, Conn., believe they are going against the trend in residential development -- that is, they are actually selling a few lots and building a few houses. Indeed, they have even raised prices in their subdivision in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;
Stores Worry Chestnut Hill
description: A 7,500-SQUARE-FOOT drugstore is to open in June in the quaint Chestnut Hill neighborhood. Part of the CVS chain, based in Woonsocket, R.I., it is one of several big national retailers whose arrival is raising concern for the section's character.

title: The World; The Search For a New Security Umbrella
description: AFTER watching the Soviet Union's slide into civil strife and the quick American military victory in the Persian Gulf, the countries of Southeast Asia are a bit puzzled about who their enemy is supposed to be, but they are clear about what: anything that gets in the way of trade and the easy shipment of goods, the basis of the Asia-Pacific region's extraordinary prosperity.

title: A Reprise for a Favorite Tune
description: WHEN a singer is presented with a new song, the singer, according to a cliche in the music business, knows it will be a hit.

title:
BACKTALK;
South Africa Has Not Earned Olympic Berth
description: The debate about South Africa re-entering the Olympics is reaching a crucial stage. While comments and decisions are still being formulated, the facts seem to indicate that South Africa should not be allowed to re-enter now, should not be allowed to become a full member of the Olympic movement or participate in the Olympic Games.

title: Learning to Laugh
description: MOVE ON

title: Mr. Bush and the Freedom to Hurt
description: Just before falling ill last weekend, President Bush endorsed a wide, hysterical attitude toward "political correctness." In a speech at the University of Michigan, he exaggerated one danger and underestimated another.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Connecticut Guide last Sunday about the Children's Services Horse Show in Farmington misstated the schedule. The event concludes today, not next Saturday.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Cellular Research Aids Knowledge Of Memory Use
description: For scientists at the University of California at Berkeley, the journey to understanding short- and long-term memory began with a single brain cell.

title: Ted and Joe, Live and in Person
description: Fifty years after achieving milestones that have not been surpassed, Ted Williams and Joe DiMaggio embraced at home plate at Fenway Park today.

title: THE UNFINISHED POLITICIAN
description: Kerrey's showing up at the Capitol during the budget crisis with Debra Winger in tow strikes me as inappropriate behavior -- the sort of gesture that says, "Hey guys, look what I've got." It seems to me some maturing is necessary if statesmanship is his goal. ELLIOTT SACKS New York, N.Y.

title: Making Mom's Day
description: Babies don't come with an instruction manual, Kim Alexis, the host of the Family Channel's "Healthy Kids" show, likes to say. But they did once come with more of a support system, in the way of extended families and neighborhood moms ready to offer advice and help. Now "American Baby" helps fill that advisory role, along with another show on the Family Channel, "Healthy Kids."

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY MOTHER'S DAY

title: Dance in Review
description: Rocky Bornstein and Company Performance Space 122

title: Accounts
description: * Hilton Nevada Corp., Las Vegas, to Kobs & Draft Advertising Inc., Chicago, for a direct-marketing campaign. The billings were not disclosed. * F. I. Service Inc., Milwaukee, a financial-data services company, to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee. The agency said billings exceed $1 million.

title: Q&A
description: Mets' Dugout Alumni

title: Play on Racism Opens New Dialogue
description: In the state's whitest county, where miners once panned for gold and urban refugees now seek respite from crime and congestion, the opening of a play about racism has prompted residents to search their souls about what it means to live in a place where there are virtually no blacks.

title: Lord, Dentsu Confronts Its Samurai Heritage
description: On "Saturday Night Live," John Belushi played a samurai who doubled in jobs like hotel desk clerk and delicatessen counterman. But it looks as if Richard Lord is going to be the world's first samurai advertising executive.

title: A Late Call on a Bad Hop
description: Every time NOLAN RYAN pitches a no-hitter, baseball scholars pore over arcana. By now, everyone knows that JOHNNY VANDER MEER remains the only pitcher to pitch consecutive no-hitters, in 1938. And that the closest anyone else has come was EWELL BLACKWELL, the sidearmer known as the Whip. In 1947, Blackwell got one out in the ninth inning against the Dodgers before EDDIE STANKY, a .252 hitter, spoiled the bid for a second no-no in a row.

title: Brazil Hits Oil Offshore
description: Brazil's state oil monopoly, Petrobras, said it had made a large oil discovery off the country's southeast Atlantic coast. A spokesman said the discovery in the Campos Basin, 57 miles from Rio de Janeiro, added some 830 million barrels of crude to the country's proven oil reserves of 2.8 billion barrels. It is too early to say how much the discovery will increase Brazil's daily oil production, currently 670,000 barrels, Petrobras said. Sixty percent of this oil already comes from the Campos Basin.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sabatini Defeats Seles Gabriela Sabatini beat top-ranked Monica Seles, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in Rome to win her third Italian Open championship. Sabatini dominated the rain-delayed match, keeping Seles off balance with sharply angled groundstrokes and rushes to the net. Sabatini, ranked third in the world, was leading by 5-3 when rain interrupted play at the Foro Italico. When the players returned to the court after a 1-hour-25-minute delay, Sabatini broke Seles to take the first set, then won the first three games of the second set. (AP)

title: Pro Bono
description: * Bradford & Maloney Inc., a Greenwich, Conn., ad agency, is creating a campaign for the Center for Graphic Communications Management and Technology at New York University. The print campaign, intended to raise awareness of career opportunities in the graphic arts, features graduates who have become executives. * City-as-School, a New York City high school program that offers students academic credit for their business internships, has enlisted Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, for a campaign to increase its enrollment. The campaign will include bus, subway and print ads.

title: Bush Enters Malpractice Debate With Plan to Limit Court Awards
description: In his first response to calls for changes in the nation's health care system, President Bush will send to Congress this week a proposal to help control the fastest-rising part of medical costs -- malpractice litigation and the insurance to cover it. The plan would press the states to enact limits on court awards.

title: Miss Evans Wed To Peter Joseph
description: Wendy Evans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Evans of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Peter Thomas Joseph, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Joseph of Cincinnati. The Rev. Joan E. Fleming, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons.

title: Desert Suite
description: First Movement(Time frame: November 1990)I'm the kinda guy who digs the sun and lotsa sand,I like to drive my 4-wheel,And I like to get a tan,But when the day is done and 1900 comes around,I tune in Baghdad Betty on my box and party down.

title: SYRIA TURNS DOWN BAKER'S PROPOSAL FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria categorically rejected Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's compromise proposals for convening a peace conference today, raising serious doubts that Washington will be able to organize Arab-Israeli talks in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Upstart Rivals Are Gaining On Local Phone Companies
description: They are still tiny companies, each a few years old, but they may be in the forefront of a revolution in the telecommunications industry. Armed with high-speed fiber-optic lines and an important regulatory victory on Thursday at the Federal Communications Commission, the companies aim to compete directly against the nation's local telephone companies by luring away the biggest and best customers.

title: Economic Pulse; The Southwest - a special report.; Far From an Arid Economy, Desert States Thrive
description: The Phoenician Hotel, where there is not much of a waiting list for its $4,000-a-night suites, stands in suburban Scottsdale in all its ostentatious splendor, a glittering monument to the savings and loan debacle, a hangover from the reckless building spree of the 1980's.

title: Fund-Raising on Target for Whopping Victory Parade
description: With a month to go, New York's salute to the veterans of the Persian Gulf war -- a huge, triumphant ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway's Canyon of Heroes -- is on schedule, planners say, and very likely to meet its twin goals of total private financing and a spectacle rivaling those for Lindbergh or V-J Day.

title: Seville, Long a Plot Backdrop, Now Gets Its Own Opera House
description: Barely 100 yards from where Carmen met her death, near the streets where Don Giovanni had his trysts, in the city where Figaro made his name, Seville's first opera house opened on Friday with a dazzling exhibition of what Spain still contributes to the world of opera today.

title: Israel Reacts Negatively to Latest Moves in Baker's Mission
description: While Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d won few if any concessions today from the Syrians in Damascus, the latest Israeli reactions to the progress of his peace initiative suggest that he will fare little better when he comes here on Tuesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Miscellany
description: * Greenstone Roberts Inc., Melville, L.I., has acquired the MacKenzie Group, an Orlando, Fla., ad agency. Greenstone Roberts said the purchase would add billings of about $8 million. Clients brought in by the acquisition include Sundor Brands Inc., a subsidiary of Procter & Gamble Co., and the Daytona Beach Hilton Hotel.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters in Business Day on Thursday about the Reader's Digest Association misstated the intention of the two foundations that own virtually all voting stock in the company with regard to reducing their holdings. Because of Federal tax laws, they plan to reduce their holdings to 50 percent of the voting stock, not of the company, by the year 2000.

title: New Thinking About Old Byways
description: Five Democratic and Republican Senators are plotting a revolution in Federal aid for transportation. Their bill focuses on the maintenance and efficiency of existing roads, bridges, rails and waterways, rather than dishing out billions for building more. They would also eliminate the bias of aid formulas that favor highways over mass transit. Their plan would cost the same as President Bush's and accomplish more.

title: Mitchell Stays Flexible In Gun-Control Debate
description: Six weeks ago the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said he opposed a bill that would impose a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases. In doing so, he immediately earned a reputation as the Democratic leader most likely to kill the measure.

title: Cards Miss Their Mothers
description: A mail handler at the Postal Service's General Mail Facility was accused Saturday of stealing about 100 Mother's Day cards. The suspect, whose name was not made public, was suspended pending an indictment by a Federal grand jury, said Charles Lanks, postal inspector. Greeting cards that had been opened were recently found discarded around the city. "A lot of people send money, or tickets, to their mothers so they can come visit them," Mr. Lanks said.

title: A New Lite and New Ads, As Miller Seeks the Young
description: A FASCINATING experiment in advertising's ability to shape consumer perceptions gets under way this week when the Miller Brewing Company begins the test of a beer that could have been called Miller Lite Junior.

title: Memoirs of a (Maybe the) Washington Insider
description: Counsel to the President A Memoir By Clark Clifford, with Richard Holbrooke Illustrated. 709 pages. Random House. $25.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DEBORAH NORVILLE returns to the airwaves in September, but on a different network and in a different medium.

title: Gant and Justice Hit Homers As Surprising Braves Win, 6-1
description: Ron Gant and Dave Justice hit two-run homers as the Atlanta Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-1, today in a matchup of National League division leaders.

title: Jane Bland Dies at 91; Art Expert and Teacher
description: Jane Cooper Bland, a teacher of art and art appreciation to young children, died on Friday at Hahnemann University Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 91 years old and had an apartment in Greenwich Village.

title: Dr. Lynn Farkas, Internist, Marries
description: Dr. Lynn Sharon Farkas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Farkas of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in Harrison, N.Y. yesterday to Dr. Gary Neil Schwartz, a son of Ethel Schwartz of Minneapolis and the late Irving Schwartz. Rabbi James Perman and Cantor Lee Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Industrial Production...April Capacity Utilization...April Tuesday Consumer Prices...April Retail Sales..April Wednesday Inventories...March Thursday Housing Starts...April Friday Balance of Trade...March

title: Dance in Review
description: Joyce Theater 175 Eighth Avenue (at 19th Street) Through Sunday

title: Continuous Sun for 83 Days
description: Residents of the country's northernmost city began their summer season on Saturday, as the sun rose overhead to stay for the next 83 days. The sun will remain above the horizon in Barrow until 2:20 A.M. on Aug. 2, said Jim Fraser of the National Weather Service. And even on that day, the sun will only fall from sight for 27 minutes.

title: Strange-but-True Final: Penguins vs. North Stars
description: There is a sense of giddiness and disbelief in Pittsburgh and Minnesota this week as the Penguins and the North Stars prepare to meet in the championship round of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Vermont Protesters Removed
description: Acting on the orders of the president of the University of Vermont, campus police officers today removed eight protesting students and a faculty member who had been occupying his office.

title: Bush Greeted With Silent Protest at Black College
description: Two-thirds of 1,023 graduating seniors at Hampton University, a historically black institution, remained seated and silent to protest the Bush Administration's civil rights policies today as the President received an honorary degree.

title: NEPALESE FLOCK TO FREE ELECTION
description: As its people thronged the polls to vote in national elections, Nepal today joined the ranks of countries that have restored democracy in recent years.

title: At Vassar, Expanded Role for Blacks at Commencement
description: Classes have ended at Vassar College. Students in baggy jeans and white T-shirts cram for finals under the shade of towering sycamores and pink dogwoods, while seniors await the customary rites of commencement week -- from the infamous "booze cruise" down the Hudson River to the traditional graduation ceremony held in an outdoor amphitheater.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 10 about the Karamajong tribe of Uganda referred incorrectly to two Ugandans shown at the center, wearing Western-style clothing. A recent letter from the photographer points out that although the men stood with a group of warriors, they were not tribe members.

title: Review/Opera; 5 Ways With Music and Drama That Share the Bond of Brevity
description: Opera is never more torn between its duty to music and its duty to drama than in one-act form. If one buys old theories about the medium -- that opera gravitates toward grand themes and outsize passions, that it simplifies human motives and discourages the ambiguities of the day-to-day -- then brevity would seem a natural enemy. Weight accumulates with time, and time is in short supply.

title: Legalized Gambling and the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Jazz; Phrases for Charlie Parker
description: The alto saxophonist Charles McPherson started his first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night with a litany of Charlie Parker phrases. All alto saxophonists working within the be-bop form have favorite Parker ideas, depending on which records they learned from, and Mr. McPherson played with the chattering good-natured side of Parker.

title: CHRONICLE
description: By coincidence, SIR RICHARD ATTENBOROUGH and his brother, SIR DAVID ATTENBOROUGH, are scheduled to appear at lunch together on Wednesday in the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress.

title: NCR to Introduce a Mainframe Computer Today
description: Fresh from its merger with A.T.& T., the NCR Corporation will introduce its first mainframe machine today.

title: Medical Honors For Eric Heiden
description: ERIC HEIDEN has a new title: Doctor. The 32-year-old has just graduated from Stanford Medical School, an accomplishment he seems to take more pride in than the five gold medals he swept in speed-skating at the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Wary of Expense, Soviets Debate Bill to Ease Travel and Emigration
description: Soviet legislators today discussed the financial and human-rights considerations raised by a long-debated bill that would allow citizens the freedom to travel and emigrate. But they were unable to resolve their conflicting concerns and postponed a vote on the measure.

title: Doris Scharfenberger Weds
description: Doris Joan Scharfenberger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Scharfenberger of Lakehurst, N.J., was married in New Hope, Pa., yesterday to John Edward Shea, the son of Lester A. Shea of Seal Beach, Calif., and the late Corinne M. Shea. The Rev. Kyle St. Claire Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Philip's Chapel.

title: Brazil Vow On Inflation
description: Brazil's new Economy Minister, Marcilio Marques Moreira, says fighting inflation remains a top priority of his Government regardless of the resignation of two powerful ministers last week.

title: Dinkins and Koch Trade Barbs on Fiscal Performance
description: In a whirlwind round of live and taped television appearances yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins defended his handling of New York City's fiscal problems and took some sharp swipes at the stewardship of his predecessor, Edward I. Koch. The former Mayor replied with a few barbed counterpunches reminiscent of the blows he delivered in his own days at City Hall.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions yesterday about Jane Bland, an art teacher in New York, misidentified the surgery Mrs. Bland underwent recently. It was hip surgery. The corrected obituary appears today on page B12.

title: Mary McKinney, Student, Is Wed
description: Mary Kathryn McKinney, the daughter of Kathryn McKinney of New Canaan, Conn., and David E. McKinney of Paris, was married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan to Dr. Steven Richard Meshnick, the son of Martha Meshnick of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Frank Meshnick. The Rev. B. Harrison Taylor, a Presbyterian minister who is an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated.

title: Maryland Switches to Bank Cards For Distributing Welfare Benefits
description: Maryland will soon become the first state to distribute welfare and food stamp benefits electronically through automatic teller machines, abandoning the traditional system of monthly checks and coupon books.

title: Brave New TV World: 300 Channels
description: Advances in video technology are likely to transform the television landscape over the next several years, expanding the number of channels available on cable systems to as many as 300 from an average of 33 today.

title: Amy Miller Is Married
description: Amy Rose Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stan Miller of Stamford, Conn., was married in Stamford yesterday to Michael Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Diamond of London. Rabbi Alex Goldman and Cantor Sidney Rabinowitz performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.

title: After 10 Innings of Misfires, Mets Win in 11th
description: Dave Magadan turned on Dave Righetti's two-out, 11th-inning fastball and already in his mind was turning back to the dugout. The first baseman for the Mets had hit safely in only 3 of his previous 32 times at bat, and he had not made great contact on the 1-0 pitch from Righetti. Worst of all, Magadan looked up as he broke from the box to see the baseball bounce high and Will Clark, arguably the finest fielding first baseman in baseball, pounce to his right.

title: Tokyo Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 181.09 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,093.20. But at midday, the Nikkei was up 10.85 points, to 26,285.14, with 120 million shares changing hands. Brokers said investors shrugged off Wall Street's 50.98-point dive on Friday, to 2,920.17, but were remaining cautious. Last week, the Nikkei fell 203.57 points.

title: In Central Park, Competitive Spirit Thrives
description: Frederick Law Olmsted had something in mind when he laid out Central Park: 843 civilized acres, an oasis where he could boast of "each individual adding by his mere presence to the pleasure of all others, all helping to the greater happiness of each, poor and rich, young and old."

title: Retired Detective Slain In Flower Shop on S.I.
description: On one of his store's busiest days of the year, a retired New York City detective was shot and killed yesterday during an attempted robbery at the flower shop he owned in the Mariner's Harbor section of Staten Island, the police said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Placed Alex Cole, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Activated Felix Fermin, infielder. Sent Jose Escobar, infielder, to Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. OAKLAND ATHLETICS -- Activated Vance Law, infielder. Sent Fred Manrique, infielder, to Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. National League SAN DIEGO PADRES -- Placed Marty Barrett, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to May 8. Recalled Scott Coolbaugh, infielder, from Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL Italian League BENETTON -- Signed Toni Kukoc, forward, to a five-year contract. WRESTLING USA WRESTLING -- Named Dan Chandler assistant coach of the Olympic greco-roman team. COLLEGE ST. PETER'S -- Announced the resignation of Bob Thomas, football coach.

title: Kurds Spurn Rebel Advice; Reject Plan to Return to City
description: Kurdish tribal leaders rejected an American-brokered plan to return to the crucial city of Dohuk today, dashing, at least for the moment, hopes for an Iraqi-Kurdish deal that would bring all of the refugees down from the mountains and allow American troops to go home soon.

title: It's No Mirage: Yankees Beat A's
description: The Yankees and Athletics played a game yesterday that did not appear as if it would ever end. The second inning felt like it was the seventh and the ninth inning felt like the 19th.

title: Graham's Spirit Willing, But His Line Was Weak
description: It was hard to tell whether the tears streaming down the face of Knights quarterback Jeff Graham's were from the pain of a disappointing 22-7 loss to the London Monarchs or from the pain of a physical pounding he took for three hours in a World League of American Football game Saturday night at Giants Stadium.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 12, 1991: MONDAY FPL Group Hannaford Bros Gabelli Equity Tr Motorola TUESDAY Greyhound Dial Stone Container International Paper United Ind. 3M WEDNESDAY American Intl. Meredith First Amer. Bk. Northrop First Bk. Sys. Omnicare Fleet/Norstar Pacificorp Florida East Coast Inds. Precision Castparts Foote Cone & Belding Realty Refund Tr Geico Storage Equities IBP Tribune Leggett & Platt Wynns Intl. THURSDAY AmSouth Bancorp Green Mountain Pwr. Ashland Oil Perkin-Elmer Centex Sterling Bancorp Champion Intl. Tiffany Dresser Inds. Vulcan Matls. Florida Progress Xerox FRIDAY Allegheny Ludlam Reynolds Metals Baltimore Gas & Elec. Superior Inds. Intl. Barnes Group SATURDAY Dillard Dept. Stores

title: In India, Hinduism's Crisis Holds Election Key; Abduction in Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Fraternities' Drug Plans Approved
description: The University of Virginia has agreed to allow three fraternities to continue to participate in campus activities after they pledged to keep themselves free from drugs.

title: Penn Eight Is Winner In Eastern Sprint Race
description: "We wanted to become legends," said Evan Roth, the Penn coxswain. In the final strokes of the race this afternoon, he yelled at his stroke and roommate, Janusz Hooker, "Don't you want to be a legend?"

title: Essay; Ghost of a Spook
description: Through a generation of cold war, James Jesus Angleton was America's bulwark against the infiltration of its intelligence service by the K.G.B.

title: New Campaigns
description: * With hay fever season starting, the makers of Chlor-Trimeton allergy medicine are introducing aggressive commercials that attack a main competitor, Benadryl. The spots urge people who are shown dozing off in awkward situations to "Wake up, Benadryl users." Warwick, Baker & Fiore, New York, created the $5 million campaign for Schering-Plough Healthcare Products Inc. * Susan Lucci, who portrays the vixen Erica Kane on the ABC-TV soap opera "All My Children," performs in a 30-second soap-opera-style commercial for Wendy's International Inc. The spot shows Ms. Lucci writing a letter to "Dave," as in R. David Thomas, the founder of Wendy's. "I've strayed," she says, wiping a tear from her cheek. She then complains that the lower-priced fare at other fast-food restaurants did not measure up to Wendy's Value Menu. The spot was created by Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., New York.

title: Magazines' Changing Faces: Those of Real People
description: After decades of being disheartened by magazine pictures of young, beautiful and very thin models, some women are beginning to object. For magazines, at least, the Age of Intimidation seems to be drawing to a close.

title: Dr. Michael L. Lewin, A Plastic Surgeon, 81
description: Dr. Michael L. Lewin, a pioneer, innovator and educator in reconstructive surgery, died on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 81 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Leonard S. Kandell; Developer, 85
description: Leonard S. Kandell, a developer and investor in Manhattan real estate for more than half a century, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Lowell Broomall, 78, Western Union Official
description: Lowell Broomall, a retired senior vice president of Western Union International who won accords with many countries to bridge the continents by undersea telecommunication cables, died on Friday at his home in Fairfield, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: Subway Journal; Mass-Transit Etiquette: Making the Right Moves
description: Courtesy is apparently a word seldom associated with public transportation. Miss Manners gives only scant attention to the niceties of riding on subways and buses or in taxicabs, disposing of the subject in two tart entries concerning the proper way to offer seats to the elderly and physically disabled. Letitia Baldridge devotes a mere half-page to mass transit's do's and don't's, and then assumes that buses are the only means (besides limousines, of course) of gadding about town. As for Emily Post, well, she declines to discuss the matter.

title: Dance in Review
description: Zapateado Pace Downtown Theater

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for the week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Defendant Seeking to Quash Admission of Killing Gay Man
description: In the early-morning darkness of July 2, a 29-year-old homosexual, Julio Rivera, was stabbed to death after being beaten on the head with a hammer in a Queens schoolyard.

title: Too-Tall Building Could Provide an Annuity
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Call the Maras The Unspeakables
description: Even at the end of their joint ownership of the New York Giants, the warring Maras refused to talk to each other.

title: People
description: * Walter R. Petersen, director of public relations at Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, has been named a vice president at the agency. * Cathy A. Beres, an account supervisor in the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt, has been named a vice president at the agency. * Gerry O'Hara has joined Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, Conn., as vice president and associate creative director for art. Mr. O'Hara was previously senior vice president and executive art director for Fearon/ Gleckler, New York.

title: Marta Siberio Weds Martin Saggese
description: Marta Siberio, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Siberio of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Martin Saggese, a son of Theresa Saggese of Brooklyn and the late Vincent Saggese. The Rev. Charles G. Gonzalez performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Keep Moving, Mr. President
description: THE President of the United States believes that athletes make good role models. His own sports hero was Lou Gehrig, the stoic Iron Horse who kept playing first base until he practically stumbled on the bag. The President has recently been praising ageless Nolan Ryan, who keeps hurling no-hitters.

title: Long-Term Interest Rates Resist Downward Pressure
description: After 10 months of recession, long-term interest rates remain stubbornly high, and a number of credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether bond yields may have reached a trough in February, when they briefly dipped below 8 percent.

title: 27 Die in Attack By Zulu Raiders In South Africa
description: As many as 1,000 Zulu raiders identified with the Inkatha Freedom Party swept through a squatter settlement at dawn here today, leaving in their wake at least 27 residents dead, up to 30 wounded and 82 shacks burned down.

title: In India, Hinduism's Crisis Holds Election Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Apartheid, By Other Means
description: Everyone laments the violence among blacks in South Africa. The white regime depicts it as an uncontrollable, spontaneous conflict between "tribes," or between the African National Congress and the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party. The implication is that blacks are not fit to rule their country.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DICK EBERSOL, the president of NBC Sports, his wife, the actress SUSAN SAINT JAMES, and ROBERT W. PITTMAN, the creator of MTV, have been granted a Federal permit to build an FM radio station in Litchfield County, Conn., where they live.

title: Caroline Apovian Wed To Jon F. Scheiber Jr.
description: Dr. Caroline Apovian, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Apovian of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday in Ipswich, Mass., to Dr. Jon Frederick Scheiber Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Scheiber of Quaker Hill, Conn. The Rev. Michael J. Feketie performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Carnig Hallajian, an Armenian Apostolic priest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's hard not to sound like Luddites, but technology does not always drive you in one direction. Have you ever tried to watch all the channels available on a satellite dish? You can drive yourself mad." -- Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group. [ D10:2. ]

title: Bush Cool to Having Gorbachev at Economic Meeting, Officials Say
description: President Bush is reluctant to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request to observe an economic conference of the seven leading industrial countries in London this summer, but is moving toward agreeing to a visit to Moscow late in June, officials said today.

title: Ways to Conjure Demons of Defeat
description: The next time jockey ANGEL CORDERO Jr. fails on a favorite and hears the New York bettors cursing, let him remember that the Roman charioteers had it worse.

title: Ticker-Tape Challenge: Planning the Big Parade
description: Everybody loves a parade -- but not everybody has to plan one.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about a Government report critical of the United States Marshals Service's management of commercial property seized from drug dealers and other criminals misstated the value of that property. It is about $19.5 million; $1.4 billion is the total value of seized cash and property of all types currently under the service's management.

title: Review/Theater; Demons Living Within
description: In a variation on the opening lines of "Anna Karenina," a character in Keith Curran's "Walking the Dead" announces that "all cultural stereotypes are equally infuriating." The play, a dark cul-de-sac of a comedy, bears witness to that mock Tolstoyan statement, but not without falling victim to fallacies of Mr. Curran's own creation, including a melodramatic ending. "Walking the Dead," which opened last night at the Circle Repertory Company, is a flawed work that manages to shed humor -- if not a clear light -- on some of the more bizarre recesses of the human psyche.

title: Paifang Journal; Pilgrims Find the Hometown That Deng Ignores
description: More than seven decades ago, a teen-age boy left this tiny, remote farming village in Sichuan Province, forsaking his well-to-do family for a long painful journey through war and revolution that in the end put him in the highest seat of power in China.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week: American Health Properties, 1.5 million common shares. Dean Witter Reynolds. Carlisle Plastics Inc., 9.6 million common shares. First Boston Corp. Celgene Corp., 1.75 million common shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Cincinnati Gas and Electric Co., 3.1 million common shares. Morgan Stanley & Co. Cytogen Corp., two million common shares. Lehman Brothers. Danek Group, 1.8 million common shares. Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Daniel Industries, 1.3 million common shares. Lehman Brothers. Elbit Computers, two million common shares in a global offering, with 1.5 million to be sold in the United States. Lehman Brothers. Envoy Corp., two million common shares. Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. Fruit of the Loom Inc., 14 million common shares in a global offering, with 11.2 million to be sold in the United States. First Boston Corp. Immulogic Pharmaceutical Corp., three million common shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc., three million common shares. Morgan Stanley & Co. Ivax Corp., 3.5 million common shares in a global offering, with 2.5 million to be sold in the United States. Paine Webber Inc. Jones Apparel Group, 5.6 million common shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. Lynx Energy Services Inc., three million common shares. Salomon Brothers. Mellon Bank Corp., five million common shares. Goldman. Sachs & Co. Michael Foods Inc., 2.5 million common shares. Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood. National Medical Enterprises, 1.735 million common shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. OW Office Warehouse Inc., 1.8 million common shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. Telefonos de Mexico S.A., 1.5 billion series L stock in a global offering, with 100 million shares to be sold in Mexico and 40 million American depository shares, each representing 20 series L shares, to be sold in the United States through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Tucker Group, 1.275 million common shares. First Albany Corp. Vigoro Corp., 6.625 million common shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. Wisconsin Central Transportation Corp., two million common shares. Goldman, Sachs & Co. Source: MCM Corporate

title: Bridge
description: Two Midwestern experts surged ahead at the start of the second day of play yesterday in the prestigious Cavendish Invitational Pairs, played at Loew's Summit Hotel, 51st Street and Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, a three-time world champion, and Perry Johnson, Southfield, Mich., gained 741 imps in 15 deals and moved far ahead of their nearest rivals.

title: How the Beer Ads And Sports Mix
description: The two largest beer companies in the United States, Anheuser-Busch and Miller, spend a total of more than $225 million a year in sports television advertising and in sponsoring events.

title: Latest Rock-Star Relief Effort Benefits the Kurds
description: Twenty years after the Concert for Bangladesh fused the idea of disaster relief with rock and roll, more than 20 performers on three continents joined today in an internationally televised five-hour broadcast to raise money for Kurdish refugees.

title: Iraqis Display Bodies of 100 That They Say Shiites Killed
description: Iraqi officials displayed the corpses of about 100 men today, blindfolded and with their hands tied behind their backs, and said the men had been killed by Iranians and Shiite Muslim rebels in southern Iraq.

title: He's Back: Perez Set For Angels
description: Pascual Perez strolled into the Yankee clubhouse two hours before the game yesterday, sporting eight gold chains around his neck, a new haircut and a broad smile he has waited a year to unveil.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Celebrating Bob Marley, Voice of the Dispossessed
description: For years, Bob Marley's biting reggae was so shunned by Jamaica's elite that it could scarcely by heard on the radio here, even as the singer's popularity abroad began the steep rise that eventually would make him the third world's first global pop star.

title: Drexler's Late Heroics Give Blazers 3-1 Lead in Series
description: Clyde Drexler refused to lose heart when the Portland Trail Blazers' 17-point lead over the Utah Jazz evaporated tonight night.

title: Justice Means Struggle, Wilder Says
description: Addressing graduates of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, the nation's first elected black Governor, spoke yesterday of "the long and bloody struggle for justice" in the United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Delta Air Lines, Atlanta, is offering $350 million in 9 3/4 percent debentures, due in 2021, at 99.42 to yield 9.81 percent, 160 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Noncallable, the debentures are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corp. * Manitoba Province is offering $300 million in 8.75 percent notes, due in 2001, at 99.55 to yield 8.818 percent, or about 75 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

title: 2 Die in Storms and Flooding
description: A man from a trailer park was killed, campers were forced out of a state park and hundreds of cattle died when flash floods swept through parts of the town here in the northwestern corner of the state over the weekend.

title: Girl Charged in Baby's Death
description: The teen-age mother of a baby whose body was found on rocks near the Harlem River on Friday night was charged late Saturday with the murder of the child and remanded without bail to jail on Rikers Island. The teen-ager, Tawana Scott, 16 years old, was arraigned in Criminal Court in the Bronx in the death of her 8-month-old daughter, Shaquay.

title: Royalty Statements Remain A Mystery Story for Authors
description: IMAGINE a bank statement gone haywire, awash in mysterious figures and abbreviations, full of debits and credits listed in no particular order, and you will begin to have some notion of an author's royalty statement.

title: At Columbia Rite, a Sum of Diverse Cultures
description: They prayed in Arabic, pondered in Chinese and sang Hebrew, Latin and Southern Baptist strains. The multi-lingual congregation was dressed in the uniform blue gowns of Columbia University graduates, with a cultural diversity of Nikes, Birkenstocks and combat boots poking out beneath.

title: Owners Gain an Inside Track
description: It has been 13 years since a horse won the Triple Crown, with Affirmed prevailing in three stirring duels against Alydar, who lost the Kentucky Derby by a neck, the Preakness by a nose and the Belmont Stakes by an eyebrow.

title: Businessland Expected to Post Loss
description: Businessland Inc. is expected to report another huge loss this week that could deepen the computer retailer's financial woes, industry analysts and company executives say.

title: Chastise China; Don't Isolate It
description: By June 3, President Bush must tell Congress whether he wants China's "most favored nation" trading privileges extended for another year. Congress has three months to weigh any such request. At stake are billions in commerce, a million jobs in China and thousands in the U.S.

title: U.N.C. Earns No. 1 Seeding
description: North Carolina's undefeated lacrosse team was seeded first yesterday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I tournament. Two Ivy League teams, Brown and Princeton, were seeded second and third, respectively, with Johns Hopkins fourth.

title: In India, Hinduism's Crisis Holds Election Key; Mass Rape Allegations
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Heart Surgeon Imprisoned in 1986 Is Practicing Again
description: Dr. Donal M. Billig, the Navy surgeon court-martialed in 1986 on charges he bungled operations that led to three deaths, but whose conviction was later reversed, is practicing medicine once again, U.S. News & World Report said this weekend.

title: A Hard Line From China On Trade
description: China faces a difficult battle in Congress this summer to retain its preferential access to the United States market, but you would hardly know it from the unconciliatory remarks being made by Chinese officials.

title: Review/Television; Behind the Hate, With Bill Moyers
description: Bill Moyers, television's Captain Ahab, sails forth again tonight on his chase after the big idea. "Moyers: Beyond Hate," the 90-minute program at 9 on Channel 13, is his effort to harpoon the common elements in all manner of violence-prone groups and individuals: Los Angeles gangs; Ku Kluxers, skinheads and other white supremacists; religious fanatics; wife batterers; homosexual bashers and soccer rowdies; the rulers of South Africa and China; soldiers in Vietnam and the Persian Gulf; Palestinians and Israelis; feuding neighbors around the United States. Also monkeys and people who don't like Donald Trump and Leona Helmsley. It's reductivism rampant.

title: Some Baseball Numerobabble Has Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Belle Stays in Lineup Pending League Review
description: Albert Belle will stay in the Cleveland Indians' lineup while the American League decides how to punish him for hitting a fan with a baseball. Belle was in the lineup as a designated hitter today as Cleveland beat California.

title: Driven Despite Delicate Odds
description: The glimpse into the future was brief and terrifying: four minutes left in an Eastern Conference semifinal playoff game, and fans were marching out of Boston Garden.

title: Dance in Review
description: American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: INSIDE
description: Clark Clifford Deal Studied Investigators are trying to learn if stock profits were a reward to the former Secretary of Defense for any help to money-launderers. Page D2.

title: U.S. Lawyers Flock to Brussels
description: As Brussels strengthens its hold as the administrative capital of the new Europe, American law firms have rushed to open offices to do everything from lobbying on waste-disposal rules to defending clients charged with antitrust violations.

title: Review/Concert; The Early-Music Esthetic Applied to Brahms
description: Nothing has attracted greater attention -- and controversy -- to the early-music movement than its forays into standard orchestral repertory. Creeping closer and closer to the present and thereby crowding the turf of conventional orchestras, Roger Norrington brought an all-Brahms program to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The New Prague Spring
description: The raw new politics of free Czechoslovakia are contained by the magisterial stature of a president who transcends politics. Chalked on a wall on Zatecka Street is a heart, containing the words "Vaclav Havel." Is there another country in the world where a political leader enjoys such popularity? The raw new economic freedoms, meanwhile, seem to be popping out everywhere.

title: Desalting Unit Wins Approval
description: By a vote of 11 to 0, the California Coastal Commission on Thursday approved a proposal by drought-stricken Santa Barbara to build the state's first large-scale desalination plant. The vote by the commission, which regulates development along California's oceanfront, will allow Santa Barbara to build a plant able to take enough sea water to produce 10,000 acre feet of drinking water.

title: Jails to Add 1,000 Beds In New York
description: New York City plans to add 1,000 beds to its jail system by late summer, but officials say the $375 million expansion will probably fall short of resolving the chronic overcrowding and violence in a prison population that is projected to climb to 24,000 by September.

title: Sharing Ideas With Women Of the World
description: Helen Cruickshank, 89 years old, was in Wyoming studying trumpeter swans and mountain bluebirds, so she had to miss today's meeting of the Society of Woman Geographers. But she sent a letter.

title: Dairy Industry Price Supports
description: The Government has announced a temporary program to bolster flagging dairy prices.

title: Surgeons Should Know If Patients Have AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: First U.S. Troops Arrive in Bangladesh to Begin Large-Scale Relief Effort
description: A team of about 64 marines and Army Special Forces troops flew from Okinawa to Bangladesh today to begin preparing for a large-scale American relief effort in the cyclone-battered country.

title: Gaping Loophole For Petrie Stores
description: IT is a rare company that can scoff at found money. So some investors and tax experts are puzzling over why the Petrie Stores Corporation has not taken advantage of a proven technique to solve a tax problem it has had for years.

title: Lebanon Army Deploys Troops in the South
description: Lebanese troops took up positions today at the entrances to Palestinian refugee districts in southern Lebanon as well as posts close to an enclave bordering Israel, military officials said.

title: Metro Matters; More Thinking About Proposing The Unthinkable
description: In his broadcast call to alms last week, Mayor David N. Dinkins took pains (a word whose variants he invoked seven times) to distinguish the fiscal crisis New York City faced 16 years ago from the great (a word whose derivatives he employed nine times) challenges posed by the current budget crisis.

title: Top Military Court Hears Appeal of a Marine Convicted of Spying
description: Clayton J. Lonetree, the Marine sergeant convicted of espionage for his role in disclosing secrets about the United States Embassy in Moscow, is asking that his conviction be overturned because he never learned the identity of one accuser. He also says that his lawyer, William J. Kunstler of New York, misled him about the possibility of a plea agreement.

title: Political Memo; For New York City Finances, Critical Deadline Is in Albany
description: In the syncopated rhythm of state budget negotiations, deadlines have been approached like a great crescendo only to be skipped like a forgotten beat.

title: Two Admit Bombing Plot
description: Two Arizona men pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Friday to charges of scheming to blow up chemical tanks here in February so that a third man in the plot could collect insurance benefits. The defendants, Joseph Wayne Openshaw, an engineer, and Cecil Howard Ross, a power plant contractor, entered the pleas in a deal with prosecutors.

title: Tree Yields a Cancer Treatment, But Ecological Cost May Be High
description: A new cancer drug that can melt away tumors that resist all other treatments has been found to help many more patients than researchers had realized. But very few people will get the drug because its only source is the bark of a sparsely distributed tree in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Review/Television; A Robin Hood for Today Sees the Humor in His Job
description: Beating Kevin Costner to the finish line, Patrick Bergin can be seen as "Robin Hood" tonight at 8 on the Fox network. Mr. Costner's "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves" will be released this summer amid expectations of big box-office business. The Bergin version, meanwhile, will be distributed in theaters in Europe. The mechanics of movie marketing grind endlessly.

title: Abroad at Home; Why Judges Act
description: A striking development in our political system over recent decades has been the increasing involvement of Federal judges in state and local problems. Judges, for example, have issued orders affecting the way officials may operate state hospitals, prisons, schools and other facilities.

title: Easing of Law in Seoul Leaves Many Unimpressed
description: When President Roh Tae Woo became this country's first democratically elected leader in several decades, South Koreans said the litmus test of his commitment to reform would be how he changed the much-dreaded National Security Law, used by a succession of military governments to suppress dissent and keep political opponents and labor leaders in jail.

title: 'Will Rogers' and 'Yonkers' Win Drama Desk Awards
description: "The Will Rogers Follies" was named best musical and Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers" was chosen as best play in the 1991 Drama Desk awards, which were announced yesterday.

title: Lakers Near Another Conference Final
description: Sam Perkins scored 27 points and the Los Angeles Lakers moved within one victory of reaching the Western Conference finals for the ninth time in 10 years with a 123-107 victory over the Golden State Warriors this afternoon.

title: Clifford Stock Deals Scrutinized
description: Federal and New York investigators are exploring whether a series of lucrative stock transactions were part of an elaborate scheme to reward Clark M. Clifford and his partner for any help they may have given international money-launderers to illegally acquire a secret share in a Washington banking company they head.

title: Square D Agrees to Takeover
description: Capping a 10-week fight, Groupe Schneider S.A., a French electrical equipment company, said last night that it had at last won its bid for the Square D Company with a sweetened offer of $2.23 billion and a favorable ruling from the Justice Department.

title: Armstrong May Not Win, But Watch This Space
description: Lance Armstrong is a boy doing a man's job, a 19-year-old American amateur racing against some of the world's best professional bicycle riders.

title: 76ers Lose; Barkley Considers Trade
description: After dominating their playoff game today, the Chicago Bulls may not have the Philadelphia 76ers to kick around much longer.

title: Bruce Friedricks Wed To Amy Carol Ravitch
description: Amy Carol Ravitch, the daughter of Gloria M. Ravitch and Donald N. Ravitch, both of San Francisco, was married in San Francisco yesterday to Bruce Andrew Friedricks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Friedricks of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert Kirschner performed the ceremony at the Hamlin Mansion.

title: Got $100 Million? See the Islanders
description: The Islanders will not comment, but hockey sources say that owner JOHN PICKETT's asking price of about $100 million is slowing sale of the team. The Islanders' cable-TV revenue of about $10 million a year, one of the highest in sports, is part of the negotiating strategy.

title: Dance in Review
description: Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith St. Mark's Church

title: Knight to Join Mentors And the Game's Greats
description: The sounds coming from the sidelines at West Point, N.Y., and Bloomington, Ind., have lasted long enough to be measured in decades as well as decibels, two and counting. The letters Bob Knight has received from former players, describing the value of their basketball experience, have come from a jungle in Vietnam and a storm in the desert in the Middle East.

title: Claude Marks, a Painter, Writer And Art Lecturer, Is Dead at 75
description: Claude Marks, a painter, writer and longtime lecturer on art at the Metropolitan Museum, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Publisher Looks to Hispanic Children for Growth
description: Generations of American children have been thrilled by Charles Perrault's 300-year-old tale about the rascally cat who became a lord. Soon, even more children in the United States -- those who primarily speak Spanish -- will be able to read "Puss in Boots."

title: Argentina's President Battles His Own Air Force on Missile
description: President Carlos Saul Menem is locked in a battle with the Argentine Air Force for control of a secretive program to develop a surface-to-surface missile.

title: A Blood Feud Feeds Unrest In Soviet Area
description: The scourge of inter-ethnic vendetta has a bucolic routine to it here in the Caucasus as the Azerbaijani people talk mundanely of "blood for blood" and little mourn the latest death-stained flight of their Armenian neighbors.

title: OPEC Output Fell in April
description: OPEC production fell by 804,000 barrels a day in April, to around 22.35 million barrels, roughly in line with a cutback proposed by the group's oil ministers in March, an oil industry newsletter reported today.

title: South Africa Needs Loans for Democratization; Enriched by Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: Canseco Flamed By Fans
description: Jose's Excellent Adventure in New York came to a semi-productive end last night. Jose Canseco's extended weekend included one visit to a material girl on the Upper West Side, 2 hits in 13 times at bat, several thousand epithets, many loud boos from the stands at Yankee Stadium, one confrontation and one designated ejectee.

title: Help Lines: The Benefits Are Mutual
description: Every 30 seconds or so, a consumer calls one of the toll-free numbers at the Kraft General Foods office here, adding another voice to a chorus of complaints, praises and questions on products like Kool-Aid and Stove Top stuffing.

title: Dr. Edward Rockey, A Surgeon, Dies at 79
description: Dr. Edward M. Rockey, a surgeon and a specialist in thoracic medicine who developed techniques for tracheobronchial drainage, died on Thursday at His home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: Semiconductor Accord With Japan Still Elusive
description: United States and Japanese trade negotiators met through the weekend in Washington but failed to arrive at a new semiconductor trade agreement between the two nations. Negotiations will resume on Friday in Tokyo.

title: A Remorseful Dykstra Admits Error
description: Phillies outfielder Len Dykstra says he "screwed up big-time" when he lost control of his car last week and smashed into two trees.

title: Jailer's Allegation Heard In Sex Abuse at Nursery
description: An Essex County corrections officer testified today that within hours of Margaret Kelly Michaels's conviction on charges of sexually abusing 19 nursery-school children, Miss Michaels and her father kissed passionately during a jail visit and the father fondled his daughter.

title: Massachusetts Housing Issue
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is offering $106.4 million in tax-exempt single-family housing revenue bonds that were initially priced yesterday to yield a maximum of 7.35 percent for an issue due in 2016.

title: Miscellany
description: * Micar Advertising & Marketing Inc., New York, has opened an alternative media division to handle in-theater advertising and catalogue distribution. Michael DeStefano is president, David M. Shapiro, media development director, and Ric Sicillano, marketing director. * Public Relations Organization International Ltd., London, has established partnerships with four United States companies: Bohle Co., Los Angeles; Aaron D. Cushman & Associates, Chicago; David M. Grant & Partners, New York, and Daniel S. Roher, New York.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Increase
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in moderately active trading yesterday, with dealers reporting that some retail accounts were buying notes and bonds following Friday's big selloff.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a front-page article on Saturday about Bangladesh misstated its population. It is 118 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Moron Of the Month
description: LENNY DYKSTRA was not the first major league ballplayer to wrap his car around a tree at an odd hour for someone who is supposed to be keeping his body fit for play. Thirty-five years ago in spring training, for example, Don Larsen did the same, at 5 A.M.

title: Refugees, and Raucous Life, Return to Kurd City
description: There was a wondrous sight near the bus depot over the weekend, something that people had thought they might never see here again: a traffic jam.

title: English Intellectuals Between the Cataclysms
description: Our Age English Intellectuals Between the World Wars: A Group Portrait By Noel Annan 479 pages. Random House. $30.

title: Energy Department to Pay Fine for Waste Cleanup
description: The Department of Energy announced yesterday that it would pay a fine to another Federal agency for failing to clean up a nuclear weapons plant outside Cincinnati as promised. It would be the first time the Energy Department has paid a fine to another Federal agency.

title: Shrimp Hatch in Space
description: Forty-four brine shrimp were hatched on the space shuttle Atlantis in April, making them among the first animals ever born in space.

title: Health Insurance Gaps Laid to Racial Bias
description: The editor of a medical journal said today that longstanding racial discrimination was one reason black and Hispanic people were slipping through ever-widening cracks of the nation's health care system.

title: Boston Schools Panel Elects Chief After 15-Month Search
