description: Lois Harrison-Jones, an associate superintendent for education in Dallas, was chosen tonight as superintendent of the Boston Public Schools, ending a 15-month search for new leadership for the nation's oldest school district.

title: Johnson's Home Run Too Little For Mets
description: Howard Johnson's home run into the bleachers in the seventh inning created the appearance of a contest. But the Mets, who had manufactured nothing previously, could create nothing else, and they lost to the San Diego Padres, 5-2.

title: Communists Take Early Lead in Nepal Vote
description: As early returns began to arrive from the first openly contested election in Nepal in 30 years, Communist candidates took strong leads in many areas today, threatening to upset the country's oldest party, the Nepali Congress.

title: Workbench Campaign In John Weitz Tradition
description: It would be difficult to have lived in New York for the last 10 years and not know who John Weitz is.

title: Ease Fear, Build Staff in Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental's New Face Is Red
description: Some women like to wear the kind of makeup that shouts. Some women like to wear the kind of makeup that whispers. And some women like to wear no makeup at all. For very few of them does not using cosmetics mean the difference between a job and the unemployment line. Teresa Fischette is one of those few.

title: Accounts
description: * Britain's Liberal Democratic Party to TBWA-Holmes Knight Ritchie's London office for advertising for the general election campaign. Billings are estimated at $4.25 million, the agency said. * Carriage House Imports Ltd., Springfield, N.J., which imports liquor brands like Appleton and Wray & Nephew rums, to Omon, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Judge Convicts Winnie Mandela As Accessory in Assault on Youths
description: After a trial lasting 14 weeks, Winnie Mandela, wife of the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, was found guilty in a Johannesburg court today of kidnapping four youths who were taken to her home late in 1988 and severely beaten.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: The Price of Cleaner Government
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, last month introduced an amendment to eliminate public funding of Presidential campaigns through a $1 tax checkoff and reallocate the money to child nutrition programs. The proposal, later withdrawn, was a mischievous effort to embarrass supporters of Federal campaign funding by suggesting that the money could be better used elsewhere. It was also a clear signal of how demagogic the upcoming debate over campaign financing is likely to be.

title: U.N. Takes Over From U.S. At Camp for Kurds in Iraq
description: The United Nations took administrative control of the main Kurdish refugee camp in this border town today, marking an important shift for the United States-backed relief operation in northern Iraq.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. to Sell Special Stock, Raising Cash
description: Betting on a bright future, the General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to raise as much as $600 million by selling an unusual type of stock that will save money for the company if the price of its common shares rises, but will cost it money if the common stock declines.

title: Back in Saddle Again
description: Jockey PATRICK VALENZUELA had a rocky return to riding Sunday following a six-month suspension for refusing to submit to a drug test.

title: Clemens Goes to 7 . . . Oh No!
description: Pinch-hitter Matt Merullo hit a home run with two outs in the ninth inning off Jeff Reardon, costing Roger Clemens his seventh consecutive victory, and the Chicago White Sox beat the Boston Red Sox, 4-3, in the 10th on Ron Karkovice's single.

title: Penguin Goalie Proves Nay-Sayers Wrong
description: After his Pittsburgh Penguins defeated Boston to earn a berth in the Stanley Cup finals, goalie Tom Barrasso wasn't one to get mushy or silly in the post-game celebration.

title: Charles L. Whipple; Journalist, 77
description: Charles Lewis Whipple, a former editor of the editorial page of The Boston Globe and the newspaper's first ombudsman, died of complications after surgery on Sunday at Cooley-Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 77 years old.

title: 'Six Degrees' and 'Rogers' Honored by Critics Circle
description: John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation" was named best new play of the 1990-1991 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at the critics annual awards meeting yesterday at the Coffee House. "The Will Rogers Follies" was selected as best new musical and Timberlake Wertenbaker's "Our Country's Good" as best new foreign play. The critics also voted a special citation to Eileen Atkins for her portrayal of Virginia Woolf in "A Room of One's Own."

title: New Russian Channel Ends Soviet Television Monopoly
description: The Soviet Government television monopoly ended today with the start of a rival channel by the Russian republic.

title: Census Finds Households Are Growing In New York
description: After declining steadily for most of this century, the average number of people living in a household in New York City began to rise again in the last decade, according to an analysis of 1990 census data by New York City planners.

title: New Species of Whale Is Discovered in Pacific
description: AN elusive gray creature that looks more like a dolphin than Moby Dick has been identified as the first new species of whale to be discovered in 28 years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Gov. PETE WILSON of California is deciding whether to sign a bill requiring that all motorcyclists wear helmets. And, true to their popular maverick image, the bikers are not in harmony on the issue.

title: New St. Regis: '04 Pomp, '91 Prices
description: In the glisten of snowy marble walls, the gleam of sinuously twisted bronze and the glint of gold-leafed moldings, the freshly rebuilt St. Regis Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street is meant to recall its turn-of-the-century origins.

title: Drexel Agrees to Join U.S. In Suing Its Ex-Employees
description: After years of defending its former employees, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. appears to be ready to cross to the opposite corner of the ring. As part of its bankruptcy reorganization plan, the once-mighty investment house has agreed to join the Government in lawsuits against some of the people who once worked for it.

title: Go to the Bottom Line
description: NUMBERS are the heart and soul of business, and Finance10 calculates many of them simply and quickly. The program equips a computer with 10 different financial calculators:

title: More Health Care for Less Money
description: The $750 billion Americans will spend on health care this year -- and the trillion dollars in 1994 -- should be an opportunity to release the poor from rationing and give all Americans all the health and long-term care they need. Instead, to stem rocketing costs, Richard Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, some legislators and the General Accounting Office suggest rationing health care for all of us.

title: Dozens of Agencies Pursue Three Japanese Car Makers
description: ALTHOUGH car and truck sales in the United States remain mired in a slump severe enough to sadden any glad-handing dealer, the appeal of creating vehicle advertising remains strong enough to entice more than two dozen agencies into eagerly pursuing three Japanese auto makers.

title: Intel Executive Is Chosen To Be President of Maxtor
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a disk drive maker based in San Jose, Calif., yesterday named Laurence R. Hootnick president and chief executive, effective immediately. Mr. Hootnick was most recently president of the Intel Corporation's embedded controller and memory group.

title: 2 Rival Designers Led the Way To Stealthy Warplanes
description: THE Air Force's award last month of a huge contract to build "advanced technology fighters" marks a new era, experts say, in which virtually all new warplanes will incorporate the stealth technologies that make a plane hard to detect by its radar reflections or heat emissions.

title: Southern Baptists: Facing a Deep Rift
description: Southern Baptists are not only the nation's largest Protestant denomination, but they also have long been an unusually cohesive body whose internal theological quarrels were offset by a deep sense of regional and religious identity. But over the weekend, when 6,000 disaffected members of the Southern Baptist Convention met in Atlanta to form a new Cooperative Baptist Fellowship, it showed that Southern Baptists were torn by the same cultural rift that now runs through most major American religious groups.

title: By Design; The Button Brigade
description: Buttons are big business, both literally and figuratively. They have become the season's most important accessory.

title: Business and Health; The Drug Makers' Defense on Costs
description: PHARMACEUTICAL executives jousted with Government economists last week over a draft report to Congress that questions the drug industry's main justification for charging thousands of dollars per patient annually for some drugs.

title: Flawed U.S. Weather Satellite May Be Lofted to Avert Crisis
description: As the nation's main weather satellite nears the end of its life span, the Government is rushing to avert a potential crisis in forecasting by lofting a replacement, even though it has a serious defect that will limit its powers of observation.

title: Heads That Roll if Computers Fail
description: The last decade has brought chief information officers, the executives who manage corporate computer systems, into the upper ranks of their companies. But their prominence has come with a price: When something with the computers goes wrong, they often get the blame and the dismissal notices.

title: Dr. Michael L. Lewin, A Plastic Surgeon, 81
description: Dr. Michael L. Lewin, an innovator and educator in reconstructive surgery, died on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 81 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Music in Review
description: Frederick Moyer Pianist Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Woman Held in Beating of 3-Year-Old Son
description: A pregnant woman accused of beating her 3-year-old son unconscious in their upper Manhattan apartment, has been arrested, the police said yesterday.

title: Alexander's Jumps On Trump Rumor
description: The common stock of Alexander's Inc., the New York retailer, rose $2.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $29.25, on speculation that the stake held by Donald J. Trump might be sold to another investor. The Trump holdings of 27.4 percent in Alexander's were to be turned over to Citicorp this week as part of Mr. Trump's settlement with creditors. Wall Street officials said that the bank holding company was already seeking to sell the stake.

title: Service for Anthropologist
description: A memorial service for Stanley Diamond, a poet and anthropologist, will be held on Thursday at 2 P.M. at the Albert List Academic Center of the New School for Social Research at 65 Fifth Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets. Dr. Diamond, who founded the anthropology department at the New School, died on March 31 at the age of 69.

title: Smokers' Bill Gains in Trenton
description: A weakened smokers' rights bill was unanimously approved by a Senate committee today, setting the stage for its likely adoption this month.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States slipped by three last week, to 802, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The oilfield tool maker said the decline followed a drop of 19 in the previous week. A year ago, 941 rigs were operating. At the height of the oil boom, in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. It was at a low of 663 after oil prices plunged in the summer of 1986.

title: For Many Jurors, Trials Begin After the Verdict
description: THE ladies and gentlemen of the jury could use some help themselves, psychiatrists say. The stresses of being on a jury, new studies show, can cause emotional problems, like insomnia and nervous tension, that can continue for months after a trial ends.

title: Mulroney Outlines New Unity Strategy
description: Amid indications that Quebec may resolve differences with the rest of Canada without breaking away, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney outlined a strategy of broad public consultation today as the key to national unity.

title: Q&A
description: Death Rattle

title: Court Backs Reinstatement of Los Angeles Chief
description: A judge ruled today that the City Council had acted properly in reinstating Daryl F. Gates as Chief of Police.

title: Harry Slochower, 90, Professor; Lost Job in Communism Inquiry
description: Harry Slochower, a Brooklyn College professor who refused to tell a Congressional commmittee in the 1950's whether he had been a Communist Party member, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 90 years old.

title: POPE VISITS FATIMA TO OFFER THANKS
description: Ten years after he was shot and seriously wounded by a Turkish gunman in St. Peter's Square, Pope John Paul II visited the shrine of the Virgin of Fatima today to thank her for saving his life and for interceding to free Eastern Europe from Communism.

title: Rabies Shots Become a Public Health Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep the Heat on Gorbachev
description: To sort out Soviet politics, Americans need a seasonally adjusted method for interpreting the zigzags of Mikhail Gorbachev. In fall and winter, he typically aligns himself with reactionary forces. But in spring and summer, he turns toward reform and compromise with progressive forces.

title: Peripatetic Roman Bronzes Trailed by Lawsuit
description: If a small second-century Roman leopard could change its spots, there might be no problem.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about NCR's introduction of a new mainframe computer misstated the product's history. NCR has previously made a number of mainframes; the new 3600 computer is not its first.

title: Smith's Lawyer Wants File Shut On Rape Case
description: A lawyer for William K. Smith has accused the police and prosecutors here of generating prejudicial pretrial publicity in the rape case against him by improperly releasing information to the public.

title: Some Say the Rockets' Red Glare Is Eating Away at the Ozone Layer
description: HUNDREDS of rockets roar to life every year, some trailing clouds of toxic exhaust that chew up the life-protecting ozone shield high in the atmosphere. How much ozone is destroyed in this fashion is unknown, and may be small compared with indstrial pollution. But it is large enough to have worried some scientific and public-interest groups.

title: Cash-Strapped Cities Turn to Companies to Do What Government Once Did
description: Seventy years after Philadelphia helped launch a new era in American politics by having public workers provide most public services, many politicians here are saying the city's survival may depend on bringing that era to a quick close.

title: Robber Kills Bronx Man in an I.R.T. Station
description: A young man on his way to work was shot and killed early yesterday in an elevated subway station in the Bronx when he and his cousin refused to hand over their cash to a gunman, the transit police said.

title: Ethiopia and 3 Rebel Groups Look Toward U.S.-Led Peace Talks
description: A common desire to forestall another deadly wave of famine and a similar, shared eagerness to avert a costly battle for this capital have led the Ethiopian Government and three rebel groups fighting it to inch toward participation in American-sponsored peace talks that the Bush Administration has proposed be held in London next Monday.

title: Stock Prices Edge Upward on a Quiet Day
description: Stocks edged higher yesterday in quiet trading as investors tried to figure out where the economy was heading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Strang Cancer Prevention Center has received a contribution from a volunteer: $3 million. It comes from WANDA JABLONSKI, who works full time without pay as the coordinator of the National High Risk Registry, a data bank for statistics and research on the prevention of genetically linked cancer. Hers is the largest gift in the 58-year history of Strang, which is affiliated with New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Council to Add Minority Seats In Latest Maps
description: Under intense public criticism that it had shortchanged minorities and protected incumbents, the panel drawing 51 new City Council districts in New York City said yesterday that racial and ethnic minorities would gain seats and more incumbents would be pitted against one another in its latest plan, to be released on Thursday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The publishers of books, magazines and newspapers joined forces last night to help Literacy Volunteers of New York City, which teaches reading to adults. Drawn by the promise of appearances by BARBARA BUSH, LIZ SMITH and WALTER CRONKITE, the event lured more than 700 people to hear readings by and dine with the authors JOHN GUARE, JOYCE CAROL OATES, MARK STRAND, CALVIN TRILLIN and ALICE WALKER.

title: Japanese Broker Curbed
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company said today that it had been told by the finance ministry to no longer give selected investors preference in buying shares. Yamaichi earlier received a warning from the Japan Securities Dealers Association for having sold more than one million new shares of Amway Japan Ltd. to about 1,000 direct distributors of Amway products before that company's shares were listed over-the-counter in April. Yamaichi said it would review the way it underwrites new issues.

title: Tylenol Maker Settles in Tampering Deaths
description: Almost nine years after seven Chicago-area residents died from swallowing Tylenol capsules laced with cyanide, the manufacturer has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to the families of the victims.

title: 3 St. John's Students on Trial in Sex-Assault Case
description: A year after St. John's University was rocked by a graphic account of sexual assault, three former members of the school's lacrosse team have gone on trial on charges of brutalizing a female student at a house near the school's campus in Queens.

title: The High and the Mighty
description: I just finished reading the proceedings of the Heritage Foundation's seminar for members of Congress and their staffs on "How To Ensure a Drug-Free Congressional Office." I, for one, don't believe we'll ever make Congress dope-free -- there are too many of them.

title: And Now, The Uphill Showdown
description: For its first five days, the 11-day Tour Du Pont bicycle race has been kind to American riders. But it seems that this is about to change, because the race is actually just beginning.

title: New Chairman Elected At Coopers & Lybrand
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, said yesterday that its partners had elected Eugene M. Freedman to take over as chairman when Peter R. Scanlon steps down on Oct. 1.

title: MGM-Pathe Suit Dropped
description: Creditors who had threatened to push the MGM-Pathe Communications Company into involuntary bankruptcy said today that they had settled their differences and were dropping their complaint against the film studio.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ABB Henschel Waggon Union G.m.b.H., a unit of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, has received an $80 million order for railway cars from Deutsche Bundesbahn, Frankfurt. * Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company, will acquire Butler Cox P.L.C., London, an information technology consulting firm, for about $22 million.

title: Israel Tabak, 86, Dies; Led Rabbinical Group
description: Israel Tabak, a retired Baltimore rabbi who was a former president of the Rabbinical Council of America, died April 17 at Shaarei Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. He was 86 years old.

title: Music in Review
description: Olga Szwajgier Soprano Washington Square Church

title: Bernard Ozer, Fashion's Oldest Junior, Dies at 60
description: Bernard Ozer, a merchandising executive and one of the most colorful figures on Seventh Avenue, died Sunday night at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bill Curbs Bids By Foreigners
description: Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, and Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, introduced a bill today that would tighten controls on foreign investment in the United States.

title: A Little Bones Trouble
description: The Eastern Establishment press, also known as the press for people who think they're better than everybody else, has been filled lately with news about Skull and Bones. This is a secret society at Yale. It is composed of men who are expected to do very well in life and sometimes do. A typical member is George Bush, of whom it is often said, "He is Skull and Bones to the marrow."

title: Baker, Rebuffed in Syria, Sees Soviets on U.N. Force for Iraq
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d interrupted his Middle East peace efforts today to press the Soviet Union to accept a United Nations force to replace allied troops in northern Iraq.

title: Yank Flair and A's Flare-Up Turn Game to Glory
description: If you like seeing a superstar get upset, a reserve get respect and a pitcher get revenge against a team that did not want him, then last night was your kind of night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Pistons And Celtics Tied at 2-2
description: Despite a fairly long and relatively successful career as a professional basketball player, Mark Aguirre never has earned the admiration and recognition that go to those at the elite level of the National Basketball Association.

title: Ho Dam; North Korean Official, 62
description: Ho Dam, Foreign Minister of North Korea from 1971 to 1983, has died after a long illness, the official press agency reported on Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Where Crime Went On Leaving Midtown
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS An Upset for Gilbert

title: Music in Review
description: Barbara Shirvis Soprano Weill Recital Hall

title: A Disease Of Dogwoods Is Unmasked
description: A SCIENTIST has identified the pernicious fungus that is ravaging one of the most sensuous symbols of spring, the native American dogwood.

title: Bulls Are Outbid
description: TONI KUKOC, a 6-foot-8-inch Yugoslav forward whom many observers call the best basketball player in Europe, yesterday signed a six-year contract with Benetton Treviso, a major league team in Italy.

title: Rodman Is Named Defensive Player of Year
description: For the second consecutive season, DENNIS RODMAN of the Detroit Pistons has been named the National Basketball Association's Defensive Player of the Year in voting by a nationwide panel of sportswriters and broadcasters.

title: A Setback on Fernandez; Elster on the Disabled List
description: The Mets, mildly concerned about the healing of Sid Fernandez's fractured bone in his left arm and more considerably upset by his poor physical condition, said the target date for the left-handed pitcher's return had been pushed back to June 15 at the earliest.

title: Courtlandt Otis Dies; Insurance Broker, 91
description: Courtlandt Otis, retired executive vice president of Johnson & Higgins, Manhattan insurance brokers, died on Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: J. William Rosenbluth; Lawyer, 82
description: J. William Rosenbluth, a lawyer in Manhattan for more than 60 years, died on Sunday at Boca Raton Hospital in Florida. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Boca Raton.

title: Daily News Is Rebuilding Circulation But Is Still Below Level Before Strike
description: Eight weeks after the British publisher Robert Maxwell took over The Daily News and ended a bitter five-month strike, the New York newspaper has overcome initial difficulties in production and distribution and has begun to rebuild its circulation.

title: Quayle's Hometown Gets a Jump on History
description: People in this picture-postcard town of Victorian houses and clean streets don't care what Jay Leno or the polls or the Democrats or disgruntled Republicans have been saying about Dan Quayle in the days since President's Bush's health problems made the Vice President a national preoccupation.

title: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Gets New-Product Jobs
description: After losing or resigning three big accounts in the last six months, Scali, McCabe, Sloves announced yesterday that it had been awarded what it called two significant new-business assignments.

title: Peru Is Selling Stake in Mines
description: Peru has announced plans to sell stakes in its largest state- owned mines to private interests as part of a program to open the economy to foreign investment.

title: Retiree Status At Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines, which stopped flying in January after 65 years, has refused to bend on its threat to cut off medical insurance for retirees, a lawyer for a group of them said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council SOCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: INSIDE
description: Ethiopia's Peace Prospects

title: Fatal Clashes in El Salvador
description: Weekend clashes between rebels and Government troops killed more than 10 people and wounded 24, army and rebel spokesmen said today.

title: Review/Jazz; The Necessity of Growling
description: The Harlem Blues and Jazz band, which headlined the final Highlights in Jazz concert for the year at Pace Downtown Theater, is a good idea. Put together by Dr. Albert Vollmer, an orthodontist from Westchester County, the band features veterans of the swing era, musicians who can still conjure up the drama that jazz demands. That the jazz system doesn't really make any place for them hasn't diminished their abilities, and on Thursday night, the trumpeter Bill Dillard, who is 79 years old, came out and ripped through "Basin Street Blues," growling and shouting, using a glass mute to flatten and smear notes.

title: Justices to Rule on Tax Deductions in Takeovers
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether corporations can take Federal income tax deductions for expenses incurred in arranging to be acquired in a friendly takeover.

title: South Africa's Exile May Be NEaring End, Signs Suggest
description: South Africa moved closer to returning from athletic exile yesterday when the president of the world governing body for track and field said that South Africa could be readmitted in time for the world championships, beginning Aug. 23 in Tokyo.

title: Careers; Dreaming Up New Courses For M.B.A.'s
description: AS many graduate business schools update their programs, some deans have developed "dream" curriculums they would like to offer, if only often-skeptical faculty members would approve them.

title: South Africa Needs Loans for Democratization
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chase Manhattan Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $725 million in debt securities and warrants.

title: Belle Is Suspended For Hitting a Fan
description: Indians outfielder Albert Belle was given a one-week suspension today by Bobby Brown, the American League president, for intentionally hitting a spectator with a baseball.

title: Virginia Seizes Insurer, A Unit of First Capital
description: Virginia regulators today seized control of the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company of Richmond, the smaller of the two insurance subsidiaries of the troubled First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles.

title: African Oriented: Reviving a Magazine Of Change and Ideas
description: Thirty years ago almost exactly, Rajat Neogy, a Ugandan intellectual of Indian ancestry, started a magazine called Transition that, in the editor's words, was committed to change, "perpetual change which is the nature of live bodies." The magazine, which was eventually declared "subversive" by the Ugandan Government and forced to move to Ghana, quickly became the leading journal of freely expressed opinion among the newly independent countries of Africa.

title: First to Rise May Be First to Finish
description: You know they're getting down to the desperate hours behind the scenes of the Triple Crown: It is 5:20 in the morning and still dark on the backstretch at Pimlico Race Course when Chris Antley arrives to ride his horse in the workout.

title: Genetic Marker Found For a Heart Disorder That Kills the Young
description: SCIENTISTS have linked a gene to an inherited heart disorder that kills young and otherwise robust people without warning.

title: Tippett Accused
description: The police in Weymouth, Mass., said yesterday that they would pursue assault and battery charges against ANDRE TIPPETT, a linebacker with the New England Patriots, who is accused of scuffling with a customer in a sports bar in Weymouth on Sunday. The police said patrons apparently made insulting remarks about the Patriots, who were 1-15 last season.

title: Liquidation In Australia
description: The company that operates Australia's cash-short Ten television network was ordered into liquidation today.

title: Market Place; Hunt Transport At a Crossroads
description: FOR most of the last 10 years, J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. has thrived under the freedoms brought by the deregulation of the trucking industry in 1980.

title: Arizona Catacombs Yield Clues to a Vanished People
description: FROM the rim of the broad mesa, as a dust devil whistled its way across dry grassland like a whirling apparition, John W. Hohmann looked down the slope on the stone ruins of a prehistoric pueblo. Some 700 years ago this was a village of the Mogollon, a hunting and farming people. Now it was his archeological domain.

title: U.S. WEIGHS A PLAN FOR ARMS CONTROL IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: The Bush Administration has prepared an arms control plan that would bar Israel from producing material for nuclear weapons and require Arab nations in the Middle East to give up their chemical weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: Nursing Homes Drain Connecticut Budget
description: Grete Struch, blind but barely slowed down, marches the hallways at the Jewish Home for the Elderly with a Braille copy of a Danielle Steel novel under her arm and a fistful of raffle tickets to sell. She also has the Sweetheart's Ball coming up, plus an afternoon sing-along, a cocktail party, and the next crafts sale.

title: Staring Into the Abyss: Books on the Holocaust
description: Half a century after the Third Reich created a death industry tobeat, starve and gas millions of men, women and children in concentration camps, an unusually large number of books are being published on the Holocaust.

title: Knicks Pick 4 Finalists Then Seal the Envelope
description: Pat Riley, Paul Silas and Tom Penders have emerged as finalists to become the next coach of the Knicks as the team narrowed its list of candidates from 10 to 4.

title: Bizmart to Be Bought In a $192 Million Deal
description: Intelligent Electronics Inc., which sells computers and computer services, said today that it would buy Bizmart Inc., an office-products supplier, in a deal valued at $192 million.

title: Historic Hotel Is S.& L. Victim
description: The hotel where the postwar international monetary system was born in the 1940's has fallen victim to the savings and loan debacle of the 1980's.

title: U.S. Output Up by 0.1% Last Month
description: Snapping a six-month decline, the nation's factories, mines and utilities raised production slightly in April as assemblies of trucks and automobiles rebounded, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: People
description: * Elizabeth A. Mason has been promoted to senior vice president-director of business development from vice president-associate director of new business at Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, New York. * Lawrence M. Kimmel has joined the New York office of Kobs & Draft Advertising, Chicago, as vice president-management supervisor. He was formerly president of Unimark, his own marketing service. * Rick Ender has been promoted to senior vice president-creative director of the Atlanta office of Fahlgren Martin from vice president-associate creative director. * Kurt Tausche has been named executive vice president-creative services for the newly renamed advertising agency, Tausche Martin Lonsdorf, Atlanta. The 11-year-old agency had been called Umphenour Martin Lonsdorf.

title: Saudis Seen Getting Loan
description: Saudi Arabia will again have to borrow billions of dollars on international markets if it is to repay its Persian Gulf war contribution to the United States soon, Western diplomatic sources say.

title: A Cuomo Postage Stomp: No Budget, No Tax Check
description: In perhaps an overly successful bid to dramatize the turmoil caused by the state's budget stalemate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that his Tax Department was about to run out of money for the postage it needed to mail tax refunds to 1.3 million New Yorkers.

title: Newmark Tie To Ayer Is Brief
description: Less than a month after Newmark & Lewis, the consumer-electronics retail chain, awarded its $18 million advertising account to Ayer, the relationship has been terminated.

title: Bonn Bank Chief Expected to Quit
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the longtime president of the Bundesbank and Western Europe's most powerful central banker, will resign later this year, two leading West German newspapers reported today. The reports were given credence when Mr. Pohl pointedly refused to deny them.

title: 7 Die as a Sightseeing Plane Crashes Near Grand Canyon
description: A sightseeing plane crashed and burned today on a plateau near the Grand Canyon, killing all seven people aboard, the authorities said.

title: Pratt & Whitney's Connecticut Layoff
description: Pratt & Whitney Inc., the aircraft engine maker, laid off 837 hourly employees from its Connecticut operations. The layoff will reduce by about 3.5 percent Pratt & Whitney's work force in the state, which stood at 24,500 the end of April, the company said. Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, had said last August that it would eliminate 4,000 positions by the end of 1993 because of the decline in military spending.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet Finds the Center Of Balanchine's Erotic Fantasy
description: "Bugaku" is one of George Balanchine's strangest works. It is an Oriental fantasy, inspired by Japan's refined court music and dancers, and yet it is also one of the most erotic ballets on the boards.

title: New York's Pain: Deeper, Longer
description: The more one studies Mayor David Dinkins's new budget proposal the worse New York's fiscal crisis looks. The budget confirms that, even assuming some exaggeration for bargaining purposes, the crisis is real and it is deep. What's worse is how long it is projected to last.

title: Correction
description: An editorial Friday misidentified the House sponsor of the gun legislation known as the Brady bill. He is Edward Feighan, Democrat of Ohio.

title: Review/Fashion; New Furs For the Fearless
description: The short, swingy, bright plaid fur coats that looked like velvet brought the first applause when Oscar de la Renta showed his ready-to-wear in Paris two months ago. They were joined by other dazzling concoctions in the same sheared mink, which looks and feels like velour, in the fall collection by Mr. de la Renta at the Parsons Fashion Center on Seventh Avenue yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Saturday referred incorrectly to a chair that Yale University is establishing at its Drama School. The school said the chair, in honor of Lloyd Richards, who is retiring as dean, was "the first permanently endowed chair recognizing the achievements of an African-American." It is not specifically for a black professor.

title: New Jersey Bank Awaits U.S. Reply
description: A plan to bail out the First National Bank of Toms River should be reviewed within a week by Federal regulators, an official said. The troubled bank met a deadline on Friday to submit the plan to the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, said Kenneth Motz, the senior vice president. "We would expect to hear from them within a week," he said. He would not disclose details of the plan. Last week, bank officials said it could involve a merger with another bank.

title: Sharp Gains At Nordstrom And Dillard
description: Nordstrom Inc. and Dillard Department Stores, two of the nation's most widely followed retailers, reported sharp increases in quarterly income yesterday.

title: Mobil Gas Find
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it had found natural gas in the North Sea about five miles north of an area where the company discovered gas five years ago. Mobil North Sea Ltd., a unit of the Fairfax-based oil company, said the well opened up a new area for development. Mobil North Sea Ltd. supplies natural gas to Britain through an affiliate company, Mobil Gas Marketing Ltd.

title: Pennsylvania Turnpike Bonds
description: A $258.56 million tax-exempt issue of Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission revenue refunding bonds was intially priced yesterday to yield a maximum of 6.85 percent for a 6 1/4 percent bond, due in 2011, and a 6 percent bond, due in 2015, through an underwriting group led by RRZ Public Markets Inc.

title: 3 Drugs Found to Resemble Toxin That Causes Parkinsonism
description: THREE drugs commonly used to treat schizophrenia bear an uncanny resemblance to a toxic chemical that can cause Parkinson's disease, researchers have found.

title: Stocks Retreat in Tokyo
description: Stock prices fell back in the afternoon after posting a modest rise in the morning. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the day down 63.12 points, or 0.24 percent, at 26,030.08.

title: Barrymore's Sword Made a Laertes Bolt
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sees Trade as Spur
description: International trade will continue to stimulate global economic growth, but at a slower rate this year before picking up momentum in 1992, the Bush Administration said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Anchor Savings Bank, Hewlett, L.I., a unit of Anchor Bancorp Inc., has named Richard G. Federman senior vice president-consumer lending. * Coltec Industries, New York, an automotive and aerospace manufacturing unit of Coltec Holdings Inc., has named Klemens B. Schoenfelder president of its Garlock Mechanical Packing division.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Farmers Idle More Land
description: Farmers are taking about 8.5 percent more land from production in 1991 than they did last year under Government acreage programs, according to preliminary figures released by the Agriculture Department today.

title: Europe Paper Is a Year Old
description: The European, the English-language weekly newspaper printed in Britain, France and West Germany, has completed its first year of publiation.

title: Ford Unit Offers 10-Year Notes
description: Ford Capital B.V., a Dutch unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $250 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.

title: Citicorp Selling $1.405 Billion Issue
description: Citicorp is selling $1.405 billion in credit-card-backed certificates, due in 1996, through Standard Credit Card Master Trust 1 Series 1991-1, officials at Salomon Brothers International in London said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday headed "Subway Journal," about manners in the New York City subways, rendered the name of an etiquette-book author incorrectly. She is Letitia Baldrige.

title: Justices Say Suspects Can Be Held Up to 48 Hours Without Warrant
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that people who are arrested without a warrant may be imprisoned for as long as 48 hours while awaiting a judicial determination of whether the arrest was proper.

title: Music in Review
description: Elisabeth Soderstrom Alice Tully Hall

title: Stars and Penguins: Cable Compatible
description: It's probably best that the Stanley Cup finals are on cable because the Minnesota North Stars-Pittsburgh Penguins series would be a match-up headed for network hell.

title: Helping Actors Make Each Time the First Time
description: It was, says Mike Nichols, the only time he was ever cruel to an actor. The year was 1976, the play was David Rabe's "Streamers" at Lincoln Center, and the actor had been playing his role for three months when Mr. Nichols came by to take another look.

title: Hawaii Insurer
description: The Meiji Mutual Life Insurance Company, a Japanese insurer, said it was negotiating to buy the Hawaiian Life Insurance Company, an affiliate of the American General Corporation. A spokesman declined to divulge details, but said the aim was for talks to be completed by next month. Hawaiian Life Insurance, based in Honolulu, is ranked fifth in the state by size of insurance revenues, with total assets at around $117 million, the Meiji spokesman said.

title: MCI Chairman Is Back at Work
description: William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, was back on the job today, just three days after his release from a hospital where he underwent chest surgery.

title: Polish Cardinal Withdraws Demand on Link to the State
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, has withdrawn a demand by the church to abolish its constitutional separation from the state and make Roman Catholicism, in effect, an official religion.

title: Welfare Bank Card Is Tested
description: Maryland has begun to distribute welfare and food stamp benefits electronically through automatic teller machines, abandoning the traditional system of monthly checks and coupon books. The program already includes 6,000 Baltimore residents and is expected to be in use statewide by fall. Under the program, welfare benefits, child support, food stamps and any state assistance is put into one account that is replenished by the government every month.

title: Our Towns
description: When Gail Albert was pregnant with Garland, she had incredible daily cravings for Italian food. Garland ended up with a passion for pizza.

title: Matsushita Drives
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said it had developed a 3.5-inch hard disk drive that can store 210 megabytes of computer data, which it says is the highest storage capacity developed. Formerly, the highest-capacity 3.5-inch hard disk drives were made by the NEC Corporation and could store 176.5 megabytes, a company spokesman said. The new Matusushita disk drives, called the RD-210AA's, are likely to be used in work stations and high-end personal computers, the spokesman said. The company will start sample shipments by the end of this year and will start mass production in mid-1992, he said.

title: A Former Professor Joins Kidder, Peabody
description: Richard L. Sandor, a former professor who is widely credited with inventing the market for interest-rate futures, has joined Kidder, Peabody & Company as one of six executive managing directors reporting to Michael A. Carpenter, the firm's chairman.

title: Chess
description: What looks like bravado in the play of a top chess computer is really something else. When you see the computer seize a pawn and undergo an arduous defense -- doing what from a human point of view would be taking an extreme risk -- it sees its action merely as an effective way to gain the advantage.

title: Key Rates
Double Jeopardy: Life With AIDS and No Place to Live
description: For the last year, a 30-year-old man known as Papo has sold used clothes and paperbacks on the sidewalk near Tompkins Square Park to scrape together enough money to support his drug habit and to live on the street.

title: Ex-Darling of India Press Finds Himself Ignored
description: A crowd of about 5,000 had been waiting six hours when V. P. Singh rolled into this agricultural town in the early hours of the day on his nonstop election campaign.

title: Dell Computer Joins in Price Cuts
description: Responding to price cuts by larger competitors, the Dell Computer Corporation said today that it would lower prices by a range of $100 to $900 on nine of its desktop and laptop personal computers.

title: All in the Family
description: It was the HARRY, SKIP, and CHIP CARAY Show at the Braves-Cubs' game last night.

title: For China: Action Now
description: Jimmy Carter went to Communist China. He made a speech to Beijing's diplomatic trainees. He spoke privately to China's leaders.

title: SOVIETS STALLING A BILL TO PERMIT FREE EMIGRATION
description: Despite two years of preparation and hours of debate, the Soviet legislature failed today to adopt a long-awaited law on freedom to travel and emigrate. It voted instead to send the bill back to committee for discussions that could delay its passage for several months.

title: Music in Review
description: Emilian Sichkin Composer Carnegie Hall

title: Bridge
description: When play ended Sunday night in the Cavendish Invitational Pairs at the Loew's Summit Hotel, 51st Street and Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, the victory went to a European partnership for the third time in four years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "He has taken such a bad rap. If people knew him, they'd see he's a regular person. If they had a chance to sit down with Dan as a neighbor, they would see the extremely good values in the man." -- David Schenkel, coordinator of the Dan Quayle exhibition in Huntington, Ind. [ A12:4. ]

title: Gain in Square D Deal Seen After Slump Ends
description: The agreement by Groupe Schneider S.A. of France to buy the Square D Company for $2.23 billion is one of the largest consolidations in the electrical equipment industry. But that industry is facing some serious challenges because of lower demand in the construction market, which accounts for more than 60 percent of Square D's sales.

title: South Africa Needs Loans for Democratization; On Keeping Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-Year-Old and Pregnant Woman Among 5 Slain in Brooklyn
description: Five people -- two women, two men and a 3-year-old boy -- were found shot to death in an apartment in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn last night, the victims of an execution, the police said.

title: Deputy Security Aide Is Still Seen As C.I.A. Choice Despite Delay
description: Administration officials said today that Robert M. Gates remained the top candidate for Director of Central Intelligence and could be named in the next two days if the White House did not uncover signs that there would be a major Senate battle over his confirmation.

title: SALMON 'PIRATES' IN PACIFIC ASSAILED
description: More than a year after several Asian countries agreed to stop using vast "drift nets" to fish for salmon in international waters, a "pirate fleet" from Taiwan continues to drag the high seas, American officials said today.

title: Does the Royal Treatment Pay Off? Sure, Sometimes
description: Norman Green, chief executive officer of those fashionable Minnesota North Stars, began this season boasting the highest player payroll in the National Hockey League. Eight months later, his financially fit athletes are in the Stanley Cup finals.

title: New York Can Afford Clozapine
description: The Cuomo administration faces a decision on whether to appeal or comply with a court ruling requiring Medicaid to pay for an expensive new drug to treat schizophrenia. There is a strong case for compliance.

title: Syrian Leader's New Gamble: Pursuing Power as Arab Champion
description: Through a long and crisis-prone rule that has often resembled a poker marathon, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has rarely blinked, always believing that the chips at game's end would vindicate the way he played the hands.

title: Panel Urges Wider State-City Fiscal Ties
description: New York City and State suffer deep and inseparable fiscal problems that will not be solved by an economic recovery, and should agree on a multiyear plan to shift tax burdens from the city to the state, shrink their work forces and improve management, a major civic group said yesterday.

title: Tonka Headquarters to Close
description: Hasbro Inc. said today that it would integrate Tonka toys into Hasbro's other units, effectively shutting down the newly acquired division.

title: Ford Recalls Million Vehicles With a Variety of Problems
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling more than one million cars and trucks for safety and pollution problems.

title: Concord-Keystone
description: The Concord Camera Corporation said that the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey had approved its plan to buy the assets of Keystone Camera, the Clifton, N.J., company that calls itself the last domestic maker of 35-millimeter and 110 cartridge cameras. Concord struck the deal last month with Joseph DiPasquale, the trustee a Federal bankruptcy judge appointed to oversee Keystone's liquidation. Concord, based in Avenel, N.J., sells inexpensive 35-millimeter and 110 cartridge cameras manufactured and assembled in China. Concord said it intends to complete the buyout by the end of the month. Keystone said it was forced to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in January, even though more customers had shown a desire to "buy American."

title: GEPHARDT ATTACKS BUSH ON RACE ISSUE
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, attacked President Bush's opposition to Congressional civil rights legislation today as an effort to pander to "the politics of racial resentment."

title: A Circus On Its Way To Stores
description: "I WANT my MPC!"

title: Patterns
description: No one seemed to get it right away, but something hairy was happening at the Oscar de la Renta fur show yesterday. The first four people down the runway at the Parsons School of Design wore stretch bodysuits and flesh-toned panty-bra sets -- and the only animal fur they had on was their own.

title: Nepal King Names a Caretaker Leader
description: The Prime Minister of Nepal, who was instrumental in restoring democracy here a year ago only to go down to defeat on Sunday in a Communist sweep of voting in the capital, resigned today.

title: 42 KILLED IN JAPAN IN TRAIN COLLISION
description: A crowded tourist train slammed head-on into a local train on Tuesday in western Japan, killing 42 people and injuring 415 others in the nation's deadliest railway accident in 28 years.

title: Plan May Open Some Wetlands For Developers
description: Under pressure from home builders, farmers and lawmakers, three Federal agencies today proposed allowing more development on millions of acres of low-lying forests, bottom lands, flood plains and other ecologically sensitive areas now classified as wetlands.

title: As Kurds Quit the Mountains, the G.I.'s Go Too
description: In these forbidding mountains where Iraqi Kurds sought refuge and found despair, American soldiers who were suddenly turned into relief workers folded their tents today and unceremoniously stole away.

title: Aaron Confers With Vincent on Remarks About Hiring
description: Henry Aaron, baseball's career home run king, met yesterday with Commissioner Fay Vincent over remarks Aaron made to a Houston newspaper in which he characterized Vincent as a "big disappointment," particularly in the area of minority hiring, where Aaron said Vincent had done "absolutely nothing."

title: 3-Year-Old Boy Dies in Fall From Window
description: A 3-year-old boy fell to his death yesterday afternoon after he scaled a window guard in his grandmother's sixth-floor apartment in the Highbridge section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Wall Street Acts to Calm the Policyholders of Insurer
description: The deteriorating financial condition of First Capital Holdings has set off a scramble among a number of Wall Street firms to calm clients who purchased insurance policies from the company's subsidiaries through the brokerages.

title: Lakers Prevail Over Warriors
description: They trailed for most of the night, but the Lakers emerged from their playoff series with the Golden State Warriors tonight with a 124-119 overtime victory to advance to the Western Conference finals.

title: Winnie Mandela Given Sentence Of 6 Years in Kidnapping Case
description: Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, was sentenced today to six years in prison in the kidnapping and beating of four young men in Soweto in late 1988.

title: Gordon Ericksen, Educator, 73
description: Gordon Ericksen, director emeritus of the American Language Institute at New York University, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and also had a residence in Pedona di Camaiore, Italy.

title: Brooks Slams Door Early On Padres
description: The job description was presented to Hubie Brooks the first morning of spring training. The requirement was simple: hit in the clutch. Brooks smiled and accepted the role.

title: Giving Aliens A Nicer Image
description: The foibles of the advertising business have been recounted by countless scriptwriters for movies and television programs, from "The Hucksters" to "Thirtysomething." Now it's a playwright's turn.

title: An 'Orderly Transition' Begins at Korn/Ferry
description: One of the nation's best-known executive recruiters, Lester B. Korn, co-founder and chairman of Korn/Ferry International, said yesterday that he was retiring after 22 years and would become the concern's chairman emeritus. Richard M. Ferry, 53, the other co-founder, will assume the chairman's duties while remaining president and chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an American arms-control plan for the Middle East referred incorrectly to President Bush's announcement about chemical weapons. He said the United States would forswear the use of chemical weapons "for any reason," including retaliation, but only after an international convention on chemical arms took effect. He also said Washington would destroy all of its stocks of chemical weapons "within 10 years" of such an agreement's effective date.

title: Bozell Challenges Loss Of the Florida Lottery
description: Less than a week after losing the $25 million Florida State Lottery account, Bozell Inc., New York, has filed a petition with the state government challenging the selection process as unfair and biased.

title: Books of The Times; Steel Stories: A U.S. Success and a Soviet Failure
description: American Steel Hot Metal Men and the Resurrection of the Rust Belt By Richard Preston 278 pages. Prentice Hall Press. $19.95. Steeltown, U.S.S.R. Soviet Society in the Gorbachev Era By Stephen Kotkin Illustrated. 269 pages. University of California Press. $24.95.

title: Ammirati Hires 2 Men With Auto Experience
description: Ammirati & Puris said its New York office had hired two new senior vice presidents-associate creative directors who are well known in the creative community for their work on automotive campaigns.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Kansas Power and Light is offering $327.5 million in tax-exempt pollution-control revenue refunding bonds due in 2031 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Co. The 7 percent bonds are priced to yield 7.09 percent. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S. &P.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Tumble
description: A favorable report on inflation yesterday was not enough for the credit markets to overcome news that consumers may be leading the economy out of recession, and Treasury bond prices tumbled.

title: Eating Well
description: SEEKERS of magic bullets will be happy to know that a successor to oat bran, the cure-all of the late 80's, is faintly visible on the horizon. Hardly anyone ate oat bran until 1988; its successor, garlic, has not only been a dietary staple for thousands of years, but magical qualities have also been imputed to it for at least as long.

title: Prime Computer To Cut 800 Jobs
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it would cut 800 jobs and require workers to take vacations, some without pay. A company spokesman said most of the 800 jobs would be eliminated through attrition. The company employed about 8,700 people as of Dec. 31.

title: Wiggled, Over Jell-O
description: To The Living Section:

title: California Agency Prices Water Issue
description: The California Department of Water Resources priced $180 million in tax-exempt water-system revenue bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Fall Kills Woman Trying to Help a Friend's Child
description: A 29-year-old woman died Monday night after she fell six stories from the roof of an Upper West Side hotel while trying to reach a friend's child who had locked himself in his room, the police said.

title: Sports and Alcohol: Break the Deadly Bond
description: To the Editor:

title: For-Profit Grade Schools Planned
description: Chris Whittle, the media entrepreneur who last year introduced Channel One, a newscast containing advertising for high schools, says he plans to build a nationwide network of futuristic elementary and secondary schools.

title: U.S. PANEL WARNS OF RAIL CAR PERIL
description: Dangerous chemicals are routinely moved by railroads in tank cars that are too fragile to survive accidents, even though sturdier cars are readily available, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today.

title: 3 Companies Cited on Cholesterol Claims
description: Attacking what it regards as mislabeling of low-cholesterol foods, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday assailed three large food concerns, including the Procter & Gamble Company.

title: Broadcaster Loses Post
description: Pittsburgh Pirates broadcaster JIM ROOKER was removed from a special probation program by a judge yesterday for failing to disclose a previous drunken driving conviction in Florida. Rooker, 48 years old, a former major league pitcher, had no comment following the brief hearing before Judge ROBERT DAUER of the Allegheny County Common Pleas Court. The revocation means Rooker will be scheduled for trial for a drunken driving arrest last Oct. 13 outside Three Rivers Stadium. The arrest was his third in a little more than seven years. Under Pennsylvania law, a third drunken driving conviction carries mandatory penalties of 90 days in jail, a $300 fine and a one-year suspension of driving privileges. (AP)

title: Walter Hirshon, Stockbroker, 84
description: Walter Hirshon, a retired stockbroker, died on Sunday at his home in Sands Point, L.I. He was 84 years old.

title: Net Up 5% at Daimler-Benz
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the maker of Mercedes-Benz vehicles, said today that its first-quarter profit edged up nearly 5 percent from a year earlier as sales rose 3.5 percent.

title: Sticks and Stones and Words That Really Can Hurt Sports
description: In hammering out the judicial guidelines for the "fighting words" doctrine in a landmark First Amendment case about 50 years ago, the United States Supreme Court, quoting a lower court with approval, stated:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cali Earns a New Reputation: World's No. 1 Cocaine Seller
description: This modern city, stretched across Colombia's fertile southwestern plains, has long been known as a center of salsa music and sugar cane. In recent months, Cali has also earned the reputation of being the world's leading exporter of cocaine.

title: New York City Asks For Themes for 1992
description: New York City's economy is faltering, but Mayor David N. Dinkins's office is beginning to think ahead to better days and a time when advertising agencies might be able to help the city's image.

title: Accounts
description: * J. P. Morgan & Co., New York, to its in-house advertising unit from Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York. The agency will continue to handle Morgan's advertising outside the United States. Worldwide billings for Morgan are estimated at $9 million, the bulk of which is for U.S. advertising.

title: Concert Artists Guild Announces a Winner
description: Lauren Wagner, a soprano, was named the winner of the Concert Artists Guild's 40th annual New York competition at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday. She is to receive free management from the guild, recitals in New York and other cities, a commissioned work by a composer of her choice and $2,500 cash.

title: Skywriting From the High Court
description: In declaring that people arrested without a warrant can be locked up for 48 hours without seeing a judge, the Supreme Court has done two rare and remarkable things. First, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor managed to deliver a majority opinion without those little shows of learned authority known as footnotes. Regrettably, however, she also managed to deliver a constitutional ruling that has no roots in the Constitution.

title: PRESIDENT CHOOSES NO. 2 SECURITY AIDE FOR C.I.A. DIRECTOR
description: President Bush today gave Robert M. Gates an unusual second chance to become Director of Central Intelligence. The President chose the career intelligence analyst for a job he was denied four years ago in the face of intensive questioning about the Iran-contra affair.

title: A Royal Couple Receives a Presidential Welcome
description: Queen Elizabeth II arrived here today, hatted and suited in royal purple piped in white, to begin a 13-day visit to the United States with her husband, Prince Philip.

title: Gain Seen in Iraqi-U.N. Talks
description: Iraqi and United Nations officials appear to be making progress in talks on setting up a United Nations police presence to protect Kurds in northern Iraq, the State Department said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Already at the Top, Two Tenor Stars Dare To Reach for More
description: Like some eternally revolving celestial constellation, beaming down benignly upon adoring mortals, that mythic duo of Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti remains after more than two decades the lodestar for contemporary tenorism. A Domingo-Pavarotti-Carreras album may have topped the classical charts recently, but who's kidding whom? One can admire Jose Carreras's voice and style and courage, but the uppermost altitude of the tenorial mountain is still a twin peak.

title: DROP IN CASUAL SEX TIED TO AIDS PERIL
description: One-third of the unmarried women who are sexually active say they have changed their sexual behavior in response to their fear of AIDS, a new Federal study has found.

title: Clara Leiser, Helper Of Young Refugees In War, Dies at 93
description: Clara Leiser, founder of Youth of All Nations, a nonprofit peace organization that grew out of her experience with refugee children in World War II, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

title: Four Questions for Robert Gates
description: In weighing President Bush's nomination of Robert Gates as Director of Central Intelligence, the Senate will need to look two ways. At this juncture in international relations, it has an unusual opportunity to raise fundamental questions about the future course of U.S. intelligence. In so doing, it also has the duty to examine Mr. Gates's extensive record in Government service.

title: House Panel Bars Proposal To Limit Deposit Insurance
description: The Bush Administration's attempt to rewrite the banking laws suffered a political setback today when a House panel rejected its proposals to limit coverage of deposit insurance.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Capital Cities/ABC Inc., New York, has named David Kantor president of Satellite Music Network, a subsidiary. * Halls Merchandising Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a subsidiary of Hallmark Cards Inc., has named Robert Leitstein president.

title: Theater in Review
description: Colette Collage Two Musicals About Colette Theater at St. Peter's Church Citicorp Center 54th Street at Lexington Avenue Through Sunday

title: A Marketer of Civil Rights Who Has Made a Difference
description: NEXT week, several thousand direct marketers will honor a man who has used their commonplace, often-derided medium for uncommon persuasive purposes.

title: Living and Breathing, Yes, but Not Healthier; The Doctors' Slice
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAOS SLOWS AID TO BANGLADESHIS
description: When nearly 8,000 American troops arrive in Bangladesh on Wednesday to assist victims of last month's cyclone, they will step into a relief effort hobbled by a lack of coordination and information that is as fundamental as the lack of food and medicine.

title: Agriculture Food Chart's Ups and Downs
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Falls Amid Pressure From a Bundesbank Rumor
description: The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday, under pressure in part from persistent speculation that the president of Germany's Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, would resign.

title: New Era for Design by Computer
description: Computer-aided product design is no longer the exclusive province of engineers and technicians. Many industrial designers are abandoning their sketch pads and clay models for work stations and innovative software. These powerful new systems accept commands simple enough for novices to master. Some auto makers say they can use the new methods to trim their product cycles by months, even more than a year.

title: Port Newark: Busy Corner Of Commerce And Worries
description: Everything seems outsized in the Port of New York and New Jersey, the docks around New York Harbor that have dominated the Atlantic maritime trade since the 1600's.

title: A 24-Hour New York City News Channel
description: Time Warner will create a new cable television channel devoted exclusively to news about New York City, the company announced yesterday.

title: The 'October Surprise' Made Unsurprising
description: When Gary Sick was on President Jimmy Carter's National Security Council staff, I worked closely with him on the negotiations for the return of our hostages in Teheran from late 1980 to January 1981. I admire him and agree that Congress should fully investigate the alleged efforts of the Reagan-Bush campaign team to delay the hostages' release until after the 1980 Presidential election.

title: First Death Sentence Under New Drug Law
description: A man described as the leader of a marijuana operation today became the first person sentenced to death under a Federal capital punishment law aimed at drug trafficking violence.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARCHIBALD COX, the Watergate special prosecutor, is to retire next year as chairman of Common Cause, a post he has held for a dozen years, the public-affairs lobby said on Tuesday.

title: Judge Declines to Separate Trials Of Officers in Los Angeles Beating
description: A judge refused today to grant separate trials to four white officers charged in a black motorist's beating but said he may choose a second jury to decide the case against the sergeant who was in charge.

title: Boston Ends Long Search for Schools Chief
description: The selection of Lois Harrison-Jones, an associate superintendent for education in Dallas, as superintendent of the Boston Public Schools on Monday night ended a long and difficult search for new leadership for the nation's oldest school district.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acclaim Entertainment Inc., Oyster Bay, L.I., a distributor of home entertainment software, acquired the right from Nintendo Co. to release five additional Nintendo Entertainment System titles a year in Europe. Terms were not disclosed. * Boeing Co., Seattle, said its Defense and Space Group would close its office in Brussels on July 1 and that it would consolidate northern European, NATO and British operations at its London office.

title: Yanks Win 3d in Row As Perez Comes Back
description: Watching Pascual Perez pitch is a real experience. He hops around the mound as if he has a pesky mosquito in his uniform pants. He pumps a fist in an exaggerated manner after outs and he forces you to watch and wonder what he is going to do next.

title: Jefferson to 'Preside' at Queen's Luncheon
description: For weeks scholars at the Library of Congress have been perusing rare manuscripts, and the chefs at the catering firm of Maynard & David have been testing and tasting. The plan is to produce a Jeffersonian luncheon fit for a queen.

title: Garden to Charge More To Be Near the Action
description: The prices of the best seats for Rangers and Knicks games at Madison Square Garden are going up from $45 each to $65 a game, the Garden announced yesterday. The hike could increase ticket revenue for the arena's two major league sports teams by more than $3.7 million next season.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Mistrial in Officers' Beating of Motorist in '89
description: A judge dismissed charges of police brutality against two former police officers on Monday after a jury announced it was deadlocked over a case in which a black man was beaten during a traffic stop.

title: Icahn Sale Of USX Stock Seen
description: Carl C. Icahn apparently sold his entire stake in the USX Corporation yesterday for more than $1 billion and a profit of about $200 million.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE people, people who make a living from it, that is, can make somber companions these days. They sigh, they shrug their shoulders and the roll their eyes. Can't blame them. The recession and the strong wave of anti-alcohol sentiment in the United States have combined to deliver the trade a one-two punch. Not fatal, but not pleasant, either.

title: Seoul Protest Sets Off Street Clashes
description: An all-day funeral procession for a student beaten to death by the police turned into some of the fiercest anti-Government street battles since President Roh Tae Woo took office three years ago, setting streets aflame and covering much of the city in tear gas.

title: Galloping Ghosts! Pieces of Old Coney Island Turn Up
description: A generation after their last metallic gallop around a track at the fabled, long-defunct Steeplechase amusement park on Coney Island, and 20 years after apparently vanishing, 9 of 16 historic Steeplechase horses have resurfaced.

title: Merle W. Kremer, 75; Headed GTE Sylvania
description: Merle W. Kremer, former president of GTE Sylvania, died on Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 75 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: Bridge
description: One partnership in the team playoffs beginning here on Wednesday will be following the results in another division with great interest. Tom Sanders of Nashville and Bill Pollack of Englewood, N.J., will play together for the Vanderbilt team while their wives, Carol and Rozanne, will be rivals in the women's division. There is a good chance that there will be at least one Sanders or Pollack going to Yokohama, Japan, in October as a result of play here this week.

title: Retailer Said To Focus on 2 Candidates
description: The search for a successor to Marvin S. Traub, Bloomingdale's chairman and chief executive, has been narrowed to two finalists, industry executives said yesterday.

title: Time Warner Fills Chief Operating Post
description: Gerald A. Levin yesterday was named chief operating officer of Time Warner Inc., the media and entertainment company that owns Warner Brothers, Warner Records, Time magazines, Home Box Office and cable systems.

title: Citicorp 2-Part Issue Priced; Demand Raises Offer's Size
description: Citicorp priced a two-part, $1.686 billion global offering of asset-backed securities yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The certificates are being sold simultaneously in the United States and international capital markets.

title: Wells Fargo And Buffett
description: Wells Fargo & Company said today that the investor Warren E. Buffett had filed for permission to increase his company's stake in the San Francisco bank, now at 9.7 percent, to as much as 22 percent.

title: Pohl Plans A Statement
description: Germany's central bank said today that Karl Otto Pohl, its president, would issue a statement later this week to address news reports that he planned to resign.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Blazers Take 5 To Chase Jazz
description: Clyde Drexler and Terry Porter led a 16-0 outburst to start the third quarter and the Portland Trail Blazers held on to beat the Utah Jazz, 103-96, tonight to advance to the Western Conference finals.

title: A Thunderclap . . .
description: Secretary of State Baker has gotten no Mideast conference and no coonskin, no peace process and no one to blame. He and President Bush have squandered American prestige and power in vain attempts to squeeze micro-mini procedural concessions from the warring parties.

title: Myron Brinig, 94, Novelist Noted For Works on Montana's Infancy
description: Myron Brinig, a novelist most noted for early works recalling the settlement and development of Montana, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: AMR Wary On Quarter
description: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said today that its second-quarter net income would come in below most Wall Street estimates, suggesting that the airline industry's problems continue.

title: Loss Could Force Businessland Into Bankruptcy
description: Businessland Inc., once considered the nation's premier retailer of personal computers, said today that it had been cut off by one of its key lenders and might have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Continental Seeks New Investors
description: Continental Airlines Holdings said it was negotiating with three large companies and two investor groups to raise $600 million in new capital. The cash would be used to help Continental emerge from bankruptcy proceedings within a year, said Hollis L. Harris, Continental's chairman.

title: Wolfensohn Leaving As Carnegie Chief; Weill Takes Over
description: James D. Wolfensohn, who guided Carnegie Hall through its recent renovation and oversaw this year's centennial celebrations, announced yesterday that he would step down as chairman.

title: Man in the News: Robert Michael Gates; Analyst With Strong Views
description: Though President Bush said today that he did not want the Central Intelligence Agency involved in policy making, by nominating Robert M. Gates as the agency's new director Mr. Bush has picked a man with strong opinions about the Soviet Union and a strong belief in aggressively packaging intelligence to serve the Administration's foreign policy agenda.

title: Bombardier Group Rail Plan Favored
description: Bombardier Inc. said a Texas official had recommended that the state's High Speed Rail Authority use the Canadian company's technology for a planned high-speed rail service to connect the Dallas-Fort Worth area, San Antonio and Houston.

title: Kennedy Actions in Florida Just After Incident Are in Spotlight
description: The day after a rape was reported at the Kennedy estate here, Senator Edward M. Kennedy initiated a legal defense for his family, even as he avoided police detectives who were beginning to investigate the case, according to documents made public today by the Palm Beach Police Department.

title: Agriculture Food Chart's Ups and Downs
description: To the Editor:

title: Prose, Not Recipes, Now Sells Food Books
description: IN his 1976 introduction to a collection of five of M. F. K. Fisher's books published by Viking, Clifton Fadiman said, "We Americans do not as a rule take gladly to the literature of gastronomy."

title: 8 Bids Spurned By Potomac
description: The Potomac Edison Company yesterday rejected all bids from investment banks on the sale of $50 million in first mortgage bonds, an official at the parent company, Allegheny Power Systems Inc., said.

title: Theater in Review
description: The True Story of a Woman Born in Iran and Raised to Heaven in Manhattan One Dream Theater 232 West Broadway, at North Moore Street Through May 25 Written and directed by Assurbanipal Babilla; assistant director, Donal Egan; set design, Sonia Balassanian; light design, Kristabelle Munson. Presented by Purgatorio Ink and One Dream. WITH: Mr. Babilla; Leyla Ebtehadj, Donna Linderman, Jessie Marquez and Tom Pearl.

title: Living and Breathing, Yes, but Not Healthier; Religious Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Swap Of Offices In Houston
description: NEARLY every weekend for the last year, a fleet of moving vans has shuttled furniture and equipment between two Houston office complexes five miles apart. Dresser Industries and its M. W. Kellogg subsidiary are swapping office buildings in one of the largest and most complex corporate relocations in this city's history.

title: Dow Falls 37.57 Following a Drop in Bonds
description: Stocks plunged yesterday in sympathy with a sharply depressed bond market.

title: A Menu Celebrating Spring With Lots of Lamb and Eggs
description: SPRING always brings to mind visions of pale, tender baby lamb, as well as eggs, both in main course dishes and desserts. This diversified, elegant menu makes a great Sunday family meal.

title: Include Sinn Fein in Ulster Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fairer Shake for Poorer Schools
description: About 40 of New York's 720 school districts have challenged the state's school financing system as unconstitutional. Their lawsuit is the latest in a series of challenges in many states to equalize spending among rich and poor school districts. Despite successful actions in other states, the New York challengers face an uphill struggle. All the more reason, then, for Gov. Mario Cuomo and the State Legislature to move aggressively to remedy inequities in the system.

title: Guests at the State Dinner
description: Queen Elizabeth II was the guest of honor tonight at a state dinner at the White House.

title: New York Is Pressed to Pare Welfare as Home-Relief Rolls Grow
description: As the recession robs hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers of work, the state's welfare program for the employable poor is growing at an astounding rate.

title: The Pop Life
description: Costello's Skepticism

title: Consumer Prices Up A Modest 0.2% in April
description: The prices that consumers pay for goods and services rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in April despite a sharp jump in food costs and the first increase in gasoline prices since November, the Government reported today.

title: Gantlet Awaits Gates: Iran-Contra
description: Concerns about Robert M. Gates's connection to the Iran-contra affair boil down to three questions.

title: INSIDE
description: Plan on Iraqi Reparations

title: Owen D. Nee, Lawyer, 78
