description: Owen D. Nee, assistant general counsel for R. H. Macy & Company from 1961 to 1980, died on Monday at the Plantation Estates retirement community in Charlotte, N.C., where he lived. He was 78 years old and had lived in Bristol, Conn., and Rye, N.Y., for many years before moving to Seabrook Island, S.C., in 1980.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on April 24 about yerba mate, a Paraguayan beverage, referred imprecisely to a group of herbs used medicinally in Paraguay. Some of them, including palo santo and naranjo, have Spanish names.

title: DiMaggio's '41 World Was Simpler
description: UP the hill beyond the Yankee Stadium bleachers, at the new Thomas Gardens apartments at 840 Grand Concourse, six rooms with two baths were renting for $75 a month. In the classisfied want ads, $16 a week awaited a "thoroughly experienced" female stenographer, while a male traveling salesman with a "late sedan" carrying samples could earn $30 to $35 a week.

title: Imperial Chemical Shares Up Sharply
description: Shares in Imperial Chemical Industries surged here after the investment firm Smith New Court P.L.C. confirmed that it was offering $353 million to buy 2.4 percent of Imperial for an unidentified investor. Smith New Court said it was offering to buy 17.5 million shares at $20.19 a share for "investment purposes only."

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q&A column of Science Times yesterday about boiling water misstated the location of the New York Hall of Science in some editions. It is in Queens, not the Bronx.

title: Despite Rights Issue, Chinese Hope U.S. Trade Status Stays
description: As a battle looms in Washington over whether to end normal trade relations with China, many Chinese are finding themselves reluctantly siding with their hard-line rulers in hoping that the status is maintained.

title: Key Rates
Mark Cantwell Dollard, Investment Manager, 58
description: Mark Cantwell Dollard, an investment manager who was a senior vice president of the Amivest Corporation, died on Thursday at his home in Queens. He was 58 years old and also lived in Charlottesville, Va.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was, perhaps, the surprise of a lifetime for MICHAEL CAINE to learn that he has a brother he didn't know existed. A reporter for The Daily Mirror of London showed Mr. Caine copies of the birth certificate of his 65-year-old half-brother, DAVID BURCHELL, who has lived most of his life in hospitals for the mentally ill. On Monday the newspaper ran a long account of Mr. Caine's meeting with a reporter who showed him the documents.

title: Living and Breathing, Yes, but Not Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: Winnie Mandela's Sad Fall
description: Nelson Mandela loyally asserts that the last word has yet to be said on his wife's conviction by a South African court on charges of kidnapping and being an accessory to assault. And perhaps Winnie Mandela can successfully appeal the six-year sentence imposed yesterday by Justice Michael Stegmann. But credible evidence produced during a three-month trial has stained her name and clouds the struggle for racial justice led by her husband and the African National Congress.

title: Carl Weinrich, 86, Bach Organist, Dies
description: Carl Weinrich, an organist and professor emeritus of music at Princeton University, died on Monday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: More Recruiting Woes Emerging for Rozier
description: CLIFFORD ROZIER, a forward who is planning to transfer from North Carolina, is off to a shaky start in his search for a new school. Early this month he was involved in a recruiting violation by the University of Kentucky, which Kentucky reported to the National Collegiate Athletic Association and then promptly stopped recruiting Rozier. Now, Rozier may have unwittingly caused problems for another Kentucky school, the University of Louisville.

title: Correction Officer Shoots Son in Car, Police Say
description: A New York City correction officer shot and critically wounded his 18-year-old son as they were driving through Brooklyn yesterday, and then drove off after his son tumbled out of the car bleeding, the police said.

title: U.N. Plan Could Have Iraq Yield 25% of Oil Revenue
description: The United States and the four other permanent members of the Security Council have drawn up a plan under which Iraq could be compelled to pay 25 to 30 percent of its $20 billion annual oil revenue as reparations for the invasion and looting of Kuwait and as repayment of its debts to foreign governments.

title: Ethics Panel Reviews Gifts to Hatfield
description: In the latest sign that Senator Mark O. Hatfield's ties to the University of South Carolina will continue to dog him, the Senate Ethics Committee is examining the propriety of the Oregon Republican's accepting gifts from the university.

title: Police Link Site of Killings to Drug Sales
description: The apartment where four adults and a 3-year-old boy were shot to death in Brooklyn on Monday was used to sell drugs, the police said, and investigators theorized yesterday that the massacre was either a botched robbery or a vicious act of revenge intended to send a message to other dealers.

title: E. L. McNeely Is Dead; A Retail Executive, 72
description: E. L. McNeely, the former president and chairman of Wickes Companies, a diversified retail concern, died Sunday at the Green Hospital Cancer Clinic-Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif. He was 72 years old and lived in La Jolla.

title: 60-Minute Groumet
description: MANY home cooks miss the point when it comes to cooking pasta. They spend most of their time fussing over ingredients for the sauce, buying the best herbs and cheese and so on. That is fine, but in the process they forget the most critical element of preparing excellent pasta: timing.

title: Deadline Today on Picking Site for Ulster Talks
description: A British official said today that rival parties in the Northern Ireland talks have until Wednesday to break a deadlock over how and where to convene future negotiations, or risk the collapse of the peace process, barely two weeks after it began.

title: There Will Always Be an England
description: Dear Sir:

title: Rohatyn Ties Aid to New York City To Greater Role for a State Board
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, says his agency will give New York City $1 billion over four years to avoid layoffs and service cuts if a state board's role in overseeing the city's finances is expanded.

title: Worldwide Illiteracy Shows a Slight Drop, U.N. Agency Finds
description: For the first time ever, the number of illiterate people in the world declined slightly in recent years, a report released here said today.

title: At Last, the Showdown
description: BEN JOHNSON and CARL LEWIS, two of the fiercest rivals in track and field, will race against each other for the first time since the 100-meter final of the 1988 Olympics in a Grand Prix meet July 1 in France. The two had previously planned to meet May 30 in Seville, but negotiations broke down. For all the expectations of the race in France, to be held in a small town outside of Lille called Villeneuve d'Ascq, it will not include the world's fastest sprinter over the last two years, LEROY BURRELL.

title: Canada Admits Errors in Giving Speedy Entry to Ex-Hussein Aide
description: The Canadian Government has acknowledged a series of mistakes that gave fast-track immigration privileges to one of the chief apologists of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein.

title: Madonna and Film Enliven Cannes Festival
description: Unlike most successful actresses, Madonna makes no attempt to convince the public that beneath the artifice of the star she's just an ordinary woman. There is no room in her image for the commonplace. Though, by her own admission, she is neither a great singer or dancer.

title: Book Notes
description: Poems of the Month

title: Tomb of Warlike Maya King Found in Guatemala
description: Archeologists digging in the jungle of Guatemala have found the tomb and remains of an eighth-century ruler who they believe began the policies of militarism and territorial expansion that eventually led to the collapse of the classical Maya civilization.

title: F.D.I.C. Is Selling Last Shares in Bank
description: Shares in the Continental Bank Corporation of Chicago will be sold by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Government agency has been the largest shareholder of the banking company since 1984, when it acquired a controlling interest as part of the $4.5 billion bailout of the old Continental Illinois Corporation. The shares to be sold are the Government's last holdings in Continental. The F.D.I.C. had previously sold stock in 1986 and 1988.

title: Rival's Building In Apple's Ad
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would continue to run newspaper advertisements for its Macintosh software, even though a photograph of a competitor's office building is inadvertently featured in the ad.

title: Hansel, Disappointing in Derby, Will Try Again in Preakness
description: The field for Saturday's Preakness Stakes grew to eight yesterday with the late addition of Hansel, the record-breaking colt who began the Kentucky Derby as the public's betting favorite but finished a dull 10th.

title: Retail Sales Data Viewed as Sign That Economic Decline Is Halting
description: Evidence mounted today that the economy has halted its slide and that the improvement already under way in housing may have begun to spread.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Nortek in Default
description: The building products manufacturer Nortek Inc. said it would default on $31 million in bonds. The 8.92 percent notes mature on Wednesday, but Nortek said it could not repay the debt while meeting its other obligations.

title: Washington Talk; Return of a Lawmaker, Dusting Off an Old Idea
description: At a time when most Democrats have modest legislative agendas, it would be normal to dismiss as an idealistic neophyte any newly elected Congressman who wants to spend $110 billion or so on education and roads and the environment and that sort of thing.

title: Shintaro Abe, Japanese Politician And Ex-Cabinet Aide, Dies at 67
description: Shintaro Abe, one of Japan's top politicians for nearly two decades and leader of an influential faction of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, died today after a two-year illness. He was 67 years old.

title: Strike Halts French Trains
description: Thousands of rail workers went on strike today over retirement benefits, disrupting train traffic across France. Service was halted almost completely on some lines in the Paris suburbs, while traffic on most long-distance routes was reduced by 50 to 75 percent, the national railroad said. One of the worst-hit lines links central Paris with Charles de Gaulle international airport. Railroad officials said they expected operations to return to near normal on Wednesday.

title: Digital Plans New Effort In PC Market
description: Kenneth H. Olsen, president of the Digital Equipment Corporation, announced yesterday that the company would market a new line of powerful personal computers made by the Intel Corporation and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company.

title: Sasser Still Won't Let Go, A Habit Perplexing to Mets
description: From the first pitch Monday night, the problem was obvious and there was every indication it would be unconquerable. Soon, Mackey Sasser's difficulty returning the baseball to the pitcher was out of control, and the crowd's taunting was constant and fierce.

title: Dee Brown and You
description: Once again the Rehnquist Court has shown its appetite for nibbling away at the constitutional protections we once thought we had, without discarding those protections entirely.

title: Houston Grand Opera To Present 'Parsifal'
description: A new Robert Wilson production of Wagner's "Parsifal," the premiere of Robert Moran's "Desert of Roses" and a new production of Dvorak's "Rusalka" are among the highlights of the Houston Grand Opera's 1991-92 season. The season will be David Gockley's 20th year as the general director of the company.

title: Felton Is Let Go
description: GEORGE FELTON's South Carolina team finished 20-13 this past season, its first 20-victory season in eight years, and it made it to the second round of the National Invitation Tournament. Yesterday, Felton was dismissed, ending his five-year tenure at his alma mater with one year left on his contract. Athletic director KING DIXON said an "extensive and consuming" examination of the basketball program that began in late January led to his decision to make the change. Felton, whose teams were 67-62, could not be reached immediately for comment. (AP)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Ailing Becker Pulls Out in Italy Boris Becker, ranked second in the world, withdrew from the Italian Open yesterday without playing a match, complaining that his back was simply too sore. "The muscles are very tight," said Becker, 23 years old, who explained that he decided to opt out of the event in Rome when he realized in a practice set that there was something seriously wrong. "Every time I try to serve it gets worse and worse, and after a half-hour I can't use the muscles anymore." He said he was returning to Munich to consult with his personal doctor. In matches yesterday, United States Open champion Pete Sampras struggled through three sets before beating Soviet qualifier Vladimir Gabrichidze, 7-6, 4-6, 6-2, and Andre Agassi, seeded second, was upset by unseeded Eric Jelen of Germany, 6-3, 7-6, in their first-round match. Jelen converted on the third match point in the tie breaker, which he won, 9-7. Agassi had great difficulty holding his serve. Jelen broke him twice in the second set. "It was cold and the court was wet," Agassi said. "It never seemed to roll my way."

title: About New York
description: Vincent V. Vendetti has devoted much of his 49 years to working with people whose minds can't navigate challenging passages. He is what is known as a personal adjustment trainer in a workshop for handicapped people in Coney Island.

title: Social Work Goes to School - A special report.; Schools' New Role: Steering People to Services
description: At 7:45 each weekday morning, 20 Plainfield High School girls descend from school buses, holding the hands of their children. Inside the high school, in a nursery filled with children's artwork and toys, the toddlers will sing, play and sleep while their mothers go to school.

title: Chrysler Move On Research
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had entered a joint manufacturing research program with Mercury Marine that is expected to speed the development of a smaller, lighter and more fuel-efficient two-stroke engine.

title: See the City From Here, Hudson Tells Tourists
description: Hudson County, long known as a staging area for getting into New York City, now wants people to stay a while. Tired of their county's being known to outsiders chiefly as the entrance to the Holland and Lincoln tunnels, its leaders have begun a campaign to attract some of the tourists heading toward New York.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Down 11th Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, the 11th consecutive decline.

title: Correction
description: A recipe in the Eating Well column on May 1 for orzo with vegetables and chicken included an incorrect nutrition analysis. This is the correct information for each serving: 493 calories, 9 grams fat, 33 grams cholesterol, 163 milligrams sodium, 28 grams protein, 78 grams carbohydrate.

title: Second Thoughts On Mexico Trade
description: THE campaign for "fast track" authority to negotiate a trade agreement with Mexico is nearly over, and the Administration seems headed for a lopsided victory. The President's strategy, a mix of high-minded talk about global competitiveness and coolly calculated concessions to interests ranging from anti-pesticide lobbyists to brewers, has apparently succeeded in isolating hard-core protectionists from the what's-in-it-for-my-district pragmatists.

title: Man's Failing Heart Gets Aid From Fully Portable Implant
description: For the first time, surgeons have implanted a fully portable mechanical device to help a patient's failing heart pump until a heart donor can be found.

title: Tourist's Wild Taxicab Ride Battling Biting Bat for a Seat
description: To the legend and lore of New York City taxis, let now be added the tale of the bat in the back seat.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY A. KISSINGER is taking on a different sort of advisory role next Tuesday when he appears as the weatherman on "CBS This Morning." He will be on for the first hour of the two-hour program, doing two weather segments.

title: Newsday Subway Columnist Receives a Reporting Award
description: Ellis Henican, who writes the column "In the Subways" for New York Newsday, has won the 1991 Meyer Berger Award for reporting on New York City, Joan Conner, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, announced yesterday.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices closed lower today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 207.61 points, or 0.80 percent, to 25,822.47.

title: Reserving a Table: Less Waiting, Except at Lutece or Bouley
description: 1. THE feeding frenzy is over -- no great loss to people who don't want to make reservations three weeks in advance to dine at their favorite restaurant at a civilized hour.

title: Myers and Blue Jays Give Gubicza A Not-So-Welcome-Back Present
description: Greg Myers's two-run homer helped David Wells to his fourth consecutive victory, and the Toronto Blue Jays' sixth victory in seven games, 4-1 over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: For Parcells, It's More Than Money Matter
description: If Bill Parcells resigns today as the Giants' coach, as expected, his reasons will involve several factors but not the one that some people might assume: money.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gastineau Turns Self In
description: MARK GASTINEAU, a former Jets' defensive end, walked into the Fourth Precinct in Hewlett, L.I., yesterday morning and surrendered to the Nassau County police on a complaint he punched a bar patron at J. Sprat's Saloon in North Long Beach in the face at 3 A.M. Sunday. Gastineau listed his occupation as football player, "unemployed." After being fingerprinted and charged with third-degree assault, he was released and scheduled for arraignment May 29 at First District Court in Hempstead. (AP)

title: The New Hitler Youth Are Troubling Germany
description: The scarred tenement is being restored by a gang of skinheads, but nearby squatters have smeared it with the words Nazi Club.

title: Kuwait Jails 5 Opponents for Homecoming Posters
description: Five Kuwaiti students from a leading opposition group have been jailed since Friday for putting up posters welcoming Kuwaitis home from abroad.

title: Collins to Talk With Knicks
description: Doug Collins confirmed today that he would be interviewed by the Knicks for their coaching position by the end of the week.

title: Proxy Challenge At Moore Medical
description: IN fights for corporate control, the dissident is at a severe disadvantage. While management's pleas for votes are paid for by the company, the dissident must finance his own campaign. Thus, unless there is a large and angry holder, or a bidder trying to buy the company, proxy fights are highly unlikely.

title: When It's Time to Eat, Chilies Replace the Baton
description: A CAREFULLY orchestrated scene unfolds time and again in restaurants around the world when Zubin Mehta, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, enters to dine.

title: Gulf War Security Measures To Be Eased at U.S. Airports
description: Security measures at American airports will soon be reduced from the high levels imposed during the Persian Gulf war because the threat of terrorism has eased, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today.

title: Spanish Banks Plan Merger
description: Two of Spain's biggest private banks, Banco Central and Banco Hispano Americano, plan to merge to create the nation's largest commercial bank, Economy Minister Carlos Solchaga said today.

title: Firefighters Rescue Two Men Trapped In Burning Building
description: Two workers trapped on the 12th floor of a midtown office building were plucked from smoke-wreathed windows yesterday by firefighters lowered on ropes from the roof.

title: Baker's Hope: Jordan River As Peace Sign
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has not been able to get Arab and Israeli leaders to sit around a conference table yet, but for one fleeting moment today he got Israeli and Jordanian soldiers together on a tiny wooden bridge over the Jordan River.

title: Article 185391 -- No Title
description: As part of President Bush's education plan, 10 states have been awarded $75 million by the National Science Foundation to develop comprehensive mathematics and science programs for students from kindergarten through college.

title: Sales of American Vehicles Off 18.3%
description: Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States and Canada fell 18.3 percent in early May, and remained stuck at recessionary levels.

title: Playing Numbers Game In Albany Budget Battle
description: In their enormous and so far fruitless struggle to come up with a state budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have disagreed on almost everything except the size of their problem: they generally concur, amid much wringing of hands, that the state is facing a budget gap of almost $6.5 billion.

title: Gaylord Perry Quits
description: GAYLORD PERRY, who will be inducted into the Hall of Fame this summer, resigned yesterday as baseball coach at Limestone College in Gaffney, S.C., after five seasons. He cited "personal reasons" for his resignation, but the former pitcher threatened to quit earlier this month over a dispute concerning how much money was being spent on the program. (AP)

title: Theater in Review
description: Julius Caesar Bouwerie Lane Theater 330 Bowery

title: CONGRESS PANELS VOTE TO ADVANCE FREE-TRADE PLAN
description: House and Senate committees voted overwhelmingly today to endorse negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers, opening the way for passage by both houses before the end of next week.

title: Exxon Project Finds Deep-Water Reserves
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that it had made a potentially large oil and gas discovery in the Gulf of Mexico. Conoco Inc., a Du Pont subsidiary, holds a 50 percent interest in the project.

title: Moving Fast to Protect Ozone Layer
description: The nation's leading electronics companies are moving more rapidly than they expected to phase out the use of industrial cleansers that damage the earth's protective ozone layer.

title: Sugar Maples Sicken Under Acid Rain's Pall
description: All over the Northeast, the sugar maples are dying.

title: LeMond Produces for Team
description: There are 104 bicycle riders in the Tour Du Pont. Never mind the sophisticated European professionals or the hotshot American amateurs in this 11-day stage race, though. For the public, there is only 29-year-old Greg LeMond of Wayzata, Minn., charming and winning, an authentic American folk hero.

title: Great American
description: The Great American Bank said it was still not in compliance with its federally approved capital plan because of a first-quarter loss of $46.8 million. Great American said its noncompliance was a violation of an Office of Thrift Supervision order and could result in the appointment of a conservator or receiver, though Federal regulators had not yet taken any action. Great American said that although it expected to complete two transactions with Wells Fargo & Company that would result in a pretax gain of about $86.8 million, it would still fall short of compliance.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Volunteers Just Maybe Are Making a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: NCR and A.T.&T. Ratings Affirmed
description: The senior debt ratings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the NCR Corporation were affirmed yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which had placed them on credit watch in December.

title: Parcells Is Expected to Step Down Today
description: Bill Parcells is expected to resign today as head coach of the New York Giants, according to a person who knows Parcells well and is familiar with the team's coaching situation.

title: First Capital Unit Seized In California
description: State regulators today seized the California insurance subsidiary of the First Capital Holdings Corporation after an attempt by Citibank, the troubled company's main lender, to force it into involuntary bankruptcy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "For 25 years, how good you were in conducting operations against the Soviets was the fastest ticket to the top. Now it's trying to understand this changing world." -- Bobby R. Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. [ A22:4. ]

title: Jean Langlais Is Dead; French Composer, 84
description: Jean Langlais, a composer and organist who had an international career despite being blind from birth, has died, his family said Monday. He was 84 years old.

title: A New Form of Brass, to Cut Lead in Drinking Water
description: Researchers at A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories said yesterday that they had invented a new form of brass that could be used in faucets to help reduce dangerous concentrations of lead in drinking water.

title: Vindication for North Stars' Clarke
description: Each year, the National Hockey League offers a variety of awards that rival Hollywood's Oscars in number and in detail.

title: Jordan's Punch Knocks Out the 76ers
description: With his team staggering in the fourth quarter tonight, Michael Jordan did what he does best: everything.

title: Two Anti-Abortion Bills Pass by Big Margins In Louisiana House
description: The State House of Representatives here has approved two measures that would mandate long prison terms for people who perform abortions.

title: Resident Arrested in Condo Officer's Death
description: The complaint from the condominium board had been delivered to Mehmet Ljikovic in the last week, the police said. In it, the board took issue with noise it said Mr. Ljikovic's 11-year-old son and 12-year-old daughter had been making, disturbing the quiet in the Village Park Garden Condominium at 64-17 72d Street in Middle Village, Queens.

title: Korea to Act On Inflation
description: The South Korean Government reiterated today that its economic priority this year was to curb inflation and the balance of payments deficit.

title: Food Notes
description: For Amber Waves of Beer

title: MCA Is Sued By Motown
description: Motown, the record label that included stars like Stevie Wonder and Diana Ross, filed a lawsuit today against MCA Inc., its distributor.

title: A Historian Enters Fiction's Shadowy Domain
description: The last time Simon Schama burst on the literary scene, it was with "Citizens," a panoramic narrative that did for the French Revolution what last fall's public television series did for the Civil War: established a standard for serious but popular history against which future works will be measured.

title: Manaus Journal; For the Rubber Soldiers of Brazil, Rubber Checks
description: Graying now and less firm of step with the passing years, the veterans marched recently through this Amazon city. The front ranks held banners reading, "Rubber Soldiers Demand Pensions."

title: New York Restaurateur Plots A Resurrection in Budapest
description: George Lang, the Hungarian-born New York restaurateur, thinks of life in graphic terms. Some people, he says, have a life that goes up and down. With the purchase of Gundel's, a revered relic of Budapest's culinary belle epoque, his will have come full circle.

title: John I. Coddington, Genealogist, 88
description: John I. Coddington, a former history instructor and the last surviving founder of the American Society of Genealogists, died on Friday at his home in Bordentown, N.J. He was 88 years old.

title: Foe of Apartheid Is Put on Defensive
description: First thrust upon the world stage as a conduit for her jailed husband's pronouncements, Winnie Mandela over a quarter century became in her own right a vigorous symbol of resistance to South Africa's system of racial separation.

title: Miscellany
description: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, has sold a significant minority interest of its Singapore branch to Tokyu Agency International, Tokyo. The new Singapore agency will be called DMB & B Tokyu. Last year, the two agencies also became partners in a Bangkok-based agency.

title: Egyptians vs. The 'Pure' Arabs
description: It did not take very long for the Arab coalition to unravel. Egypt's decision earlier this month to withdraw its troops from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, at the time they were to relieve American soldiers, indicates a serious rift that jeopardizes stability in the gulf. Among other things, the pullout could create a vacuum that might put the gulf states at the mercy of a Syrian-Iranian axis, no less a threat than Saddam Hussein.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aecom Technology Corp., Los Angeles, an architectural, engineering and construction concern, named Richard G. Newman chief executive. * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., has named Raymond A. Peterson president of its Paper Corp. of America unit.

title: Stars Change Coaches
description: BORIS BECKER and MARY JOE FERNANDEZ, both managed by ION TIRIAC, have each hired new coaches. Becker, who withdrew from the Italian Open in Rome this week due to back pain attributable to his service motion, has reportedly split with NIKKI PILIC after a four-month association and will work with TOMAS SMID.

title: Hunt Decides to Skip Senior Year at U.N.L.V.
description: ANDERSON HUNT announced yesterday that he had decided to skip his senior year and had submitted his name for next month's National Basketball Association draft. His departure means the University of Nevada-Las Vegas has lost all of its starters from the team that went 34-1 this past season before losing to Duke in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Portugal Press Is Now Private
description: The Government completed the return of Portugal's press to private hands today with the sale of the prestigious Lisbon newspaper Diario de Noticias.

title: New Video Releases
description: Desert Triumph CBS News. Three cassettes. $49.95. 3 hours 37 minutes. Desert Storm: The Victory Turner. $14.98. 1 hour 41 minutes. Gulf War: The Complete Story Strand VCI. $19.95. 2 hours.

title: Astounding North Stars Do It Again
description: Clearly, there is a pattern here, consistent for both the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Minnesota North Stars.

title: New Sundials Let Buildings Tell Time
description: DAVIDSON NORRIS, a Manhattan architect, admits that watches tell time better than sundials. Nevertheless, he is enamored of the ancient instrument.

title: Noriega Brief Shows Lawyers' Trial Strategy
description: In the first substantive outline of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's defense on narcotics charges, lawyers for the former Panamanian ruler say he not only helped in anti-drug efforts but also aided the United States with covert operations around the world.

title: U.S. to Examine Spending at Nuclear Weapon Plants
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins has begun an inquiry into how the companies that operate the nation's nuclear weapons plants and the Federal officials who oversee them spend more than $1 billion a year in construction money.

title: Pistons Survive a Scare From Ghosts of Celtics Past
description: Larry Bird did not steal the ball.

title: Israel Rejects Baker's Plan for Mideast Peace Talks
description: Israel today rejected Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's proposals for bridging the differences between Israel and Syria on how a Middle East peace conference should be organized and on what role the United Nations should play in it, American and Israeli officials said.

title: Fidelity Bancshares Has Merger Pact
description: Fidelity Bancshares Inc. said it had a definitive agreement to merge into the Union Planters Corporation for $23.50 a share, or a total of about $79 million. Fidelity, a Federally chartered savings bank with assets of $1 billion, said it would convert to a national bank after the acquisition and merge into the Union Planters National Bank. Fidelity Bancshares said the transaction was subject to approval by regulatory agencies and Fidelity shareholders and other conditions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sampras Loses in Italian Open Pete Sampras, the only one of the top four seeded players to make it past the first round at the Italian Open, was knocked out in the second round yesterday in Rome. Sampras, of Bradenton, Fla., who said he lacked patience and an effective serve on the clay surface, was beaten by Fabrice Santoro of France, 6-2, 4-6, 7-5. That left only four of the top 16 seeded players still alive in the third day of the tournament, including Jim Courier of Dade City, Fla., seeded sixth, who defeated Nicklas Kulti of Sweden, 6-0, 6-3, and ninth-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain, who won his second-round match against Horst Skoff of Austria, 6-4, 6-3.

title: The Feature-Length Cartoon Returns
description: Inspired by the success of movies like "The Little Mermaid" and by a continuing baby boomlet, Hollywood studios are energetically plunging into the production of feature-length animated films, a realm both they and movie audiences have long regarded as a monopoly of the Walt Disney Company .

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 25 people and organizations who received Chevron Conservation Awards yesterday in Washington included MARTINE COLLETTE, founder of the Wildlife Waystation in the Angeles National Forest in California. In 1969, while working as a clothing designer for department stores and boutiques in Los Angeles, Ms. Collette founded the 160-acre way station, which cares for injured and helpless wild animals.

title: OPEC Raises Bank Deposits
description: With higher profits from the war-related surge in crude prices, Middle East oil- exporting countries increased their bank deposits in the West by a record $21.5 billion in the last quarter of 1990, according to a survey released today.

title: Preakness Issue: Will Race Go to the Freshest?
description: Can a horse win Act II of the Triple Crown if he skipped Act I?

title: Revamping at Intel
description: The Intel Corporation said it had reorganized its business groups in response to changes in the microcomputer market. The computer chips maker said it would now have five product groups and three staff operations on the group level, compared with three product groups and two staff groups previously. The changes were motivated more by a need for greater organizational efficiencies than by cost-cutting concerns, a spokesman said. No layoffs are expected as a result.

title: Milt Bruhn; Football Coach, 781
description: Milt Bruhn, whose 11-year career as head football coach at the University of Wisconsin featured a stunning comeback by his team in a 1963 Rose Bowl defeat, died on Tuesday in Madison, Wis. He was 78 years old.

title: New Crisis Grips Yugoslavia Over Rotation of Leadership
description: The leadership of Serbia plunged this volatile country into a constitutional crisis today by blocking the installation of a Croat as federal President, a position that in the decade since the death of Tito has automotically rotated each year among the six republics.

title: A Machine That Outsews Grandfather
description: MY grandfather would be proud. I am carefully sewing bias tape to a neckline, guiding the fabric under the pulsing needle, cursing when my foot presses too hard on the pedal and the needle rushes ahead of my skills. I am making a dress for my daughter.

title: Special Music Stands
description: Creative Carving 1040 Metropolitan Avenue (near Morgan Avenue), Brooklyn, N.Y. 11211; (718) 387-1327.

title: Pop in Review
description: Billy Stritch Eighty-Eight's 228 West 10th Street Through May 25

title: Street Riots Shake Belgium; Immigrant Programs Urged
description: A fourth night of sometimes-violent protests by young Moroccans in immigrant neighborhoods has led to calls for new government programs and an integrated police force.

title: Towson State Rallies And Upsets Virginia
description: Towson State upset Virginia on its home ground yesterday, while Syracuse trounced Michigan State, Maryland beat Rutgers and Loyola of Baltimore defeated Massachusetts in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's lacrosse tournament.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about the discovery of a Mayan ruler's tomb included a misplaced passage. The seven lines at the bottom of column 3 should have appeared at the bottom of column 2. The affected paragraph would have read: "Excavations at Dos Pilas, Dr. Webster said, focused attention on a major shift in scholarly attitudes toward the Maya culture. Until recent years, scholars tended to idealize the Maya as a peaceful and industrious people. The only warfare was supposed to be the limited, ritualized battles fought between rulers as part of dynastic struggles, but rarely involving the common people. That interpretation reflected the apparent absence of fortifications at Mayan cities, but overlooked evidence on icons depicting warfare and human sacrifice."

title: Sit-In by 1,000 on Taiwan
description: About 1,000 students and teachers conducted a sit-in today at a train station here to protest the arrests of four campaigners for independence. Advocating independence is a crime in Taiwan.

title: Sonesta Hotels Expects Sale Profit
description: The Sonesta International Hotels Corporation said it expects to report an after-tax gain of about $19 million, or $6.52 a share, from the sale of the Amsterdam Sonesta Hotel to a group of German investors. The transaction, which is expected to be completed on May 31, calls for Sonesta to receive, after sales expenses, about $47 million in cash and a $5.8 million second-mortgage note, based on current mark-dollar exchange rates.

title: Events: Island Hopping To Revisit 19th Century
description: An Early Suburb The Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place (off Richmond Terrace), St. George section, Staten Island; (718) 727-1135.

title: Martin J. Feldman, 58, Dentist and Legislator
description: Dr. Martin J. Feldman, a dentist and a former Democratic legislator in predominantly Republican Suffolk County, L.I., died on Tuesday at his home in Dix Hills, L.I. He was 58 years old.

title: Illusions in Glass, at Two Shows in SoHo
description: Glasswork full of surprises and illusions can be seen this month in two new shows in the SoHo section of Manhattan. The main surprise, although it has been coming for a while, is the fact that glass blowing is no longer the sine qua non of contemporary art glass.

title: Brazil Fills Economy Posts
description: The Brazilian Government filled most of the major posts in the economic team that is to advise Marcilio Marques Moreira, the new Economy Minister.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers continued to whittle down large inventories of 30-year bonds bought at last week's quarterly refunding auctions.

title: FOOTBALL: Decision; A Giant Among Giants, Parcells Says Goodbye
description: In an enigmatic farewell that only partly explained his decision to quit as coach of the Super Bowl champions, Bill Parcells said goodbye to the New York Giants today and was immediately succeeded by his long-time offensive assistant, Ray Handley.

title: Agencies Are Urged to Revitalize Industry
description: SOME people in advertising think their industry needs another David Ogilvy. Others think their industry needs another William Bernbach. But Keith Reinhard thinks the industry needs another Ted Turner.

title: New Children's Show to Promote Reading
description: Children's Television Workshop, the educational production company responsible for bringing "Sesame Street" to public television, announced yesterday that it would begin work on an ambitious new series intended to improve children's reading and writing skills.

title: OFFICIALS CHANGE PLANS ON COLLIDER
description: In a decision likely to have a major effect on the giant particle accelerator planned in Texas, the project's management announced yesterday that it had ruled out the participation of an international consortium planning to build detectors that are essential to obtaining information in the device's operation.

title: Academy Honors A Composer And a Writer
description: The composer David Diamond and the poet Richard Wilbur were honored by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday as the 93-year-old organization inducted new members and bestowed more than $500,000 in awards on 43 artists, architects, writers and composers.

title: ROHATYN DROPPING BID TO AID DINKINS
description: In a setback for the Dinkins administration, Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, yesterday abruptly dropped his plan to give the city $1 billion after a bond rating agency said the plan could lead to an immediate downgrading of city bonds.

title: Police Arrest Joan Kennedy On Drunken-Driving Charge
description: Joan Kennedy pleaded not guilty yesterday in a Massachusetts court to a charge of driving under the influence of alcohol after being arrested Tuesday night. Mrs. Kennedy, 55 years old, has said she is a recovering alcoholic.

title: Small-Business Agency Gives Award to Woman
description: Joann R. Schulz has been named the National Small Business Person of the Year by the Small Business Administration. She is the first woman so honored in the 27 years that the Federal agency has presented the award.

title: Southwestern Bell
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said today it would take a one-time charge of $80 million against second-quarter net income from the early retirement of $732 million in debt. The company said it was calling for redemption of three different issues of debentures on June 21. It said the charge would reduce quarterly earnings by about 27 cents a share. The company said it expects to replace its high-coupon debt with lower-cost instruments. Southwestern Bell shares lost 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $49.50.

title: Cleveland Jury Decides Not to Indict the Mayor
description: A grand jury has indicted four people in connection with real estate partnerships that involved Mayor Michael R. White, but declined to indict the Mayor, county officials say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I look at the big picture. I look at the support we got from China back in Desert Storm, the importance of China as a country. And I don't want to see us isolate them." -- President Bush. [ A1:2. ]

title: '86 Memo Suggests C.I.A. Choice Knew Of Help for Contras
description: A 1986 internal White House computer message suggests that Robert M. Gates, President Bush's nominee to head the Central Intelligence Agency, may have been given an earlier and fuller account of covert efforts to arm the Nicaraguan rebels than he has acknowledged.

title: Gooden Enjoys New-Found Support
description: There was fury in Dwight Gooden's fastball. There was menace in the bats of the Mets. And so the sense existed in the clubhouse after today's 7-1 thrashing of the San Diego Padres that the Mets might be moving toward becoming a force with some genuine momentum.

title: Donation Will Keep 32 Public Pools Open
description: The sound of splashing will linger over New York City's 32 outdoor swimming pools this summer after all, thanks to a $2 million donation from the Sol Goldman Charitable Trust presented to the Mayor on Tuesday.

title: Stephan Berko Dies; Physics Professor, 66
description: Stephan Berko, a professor of physics at Brandeis University for three decades, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 66 years old.

title: British Ford Posts a Loss
description: The British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company today reported its first pretax loss in 20 years.

title: Endless Season: 16 Games and More, Camps, Training, Drafts, Deals
description: Bill Parcells's sudden retirement yesterday, after leading the Giants to six winning seasons and two Super Bowl victories, reflects the enormous and sometimes destructive pressures head coaches in the National Football League face, no matter how successful their teams become.

title: The Serbs and Croats: So Much in Common, Including Hate
description: The bitter and often violent contest in Yugoslavia between Serbs and Croats, who share a common language and much common history, is of recent origin.

title: Special Committee Set
description: In a move that will virtually assure the induction of at least one woman each year, the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., has set up a special nominating committee for the women's game.

title: Ruddock Quits Tyson Bout
description: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock has agreed to pull out of his scheduled fight with Mike Tyson next month in order to let Tyson pursue a fight with heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield, Joe Safety, a spokesman for promoter Don King said last night. As a result, the Tyson-Ruddock fight scheduled for June 28 has been canceled. The bout had been scheduled as a rematch of Tyson's controversial victory on March 18, and was to have been held at the Mirage hotel-casino in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: British Chief and Ulster Unionists Agree to Keep Peace Talks Going
description: Prime Minister John Major and leaders of Northern Ireland's two mostly Protestant unionist parties agreed today to keep peace talks for Ulster going next week while they work out the remaining differences that have imperiled the two-week-old negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a cleaning process for electronic components at I.B.M.'s disk-drive factory in San Jose, Calif., referred incorrectly to the machine in the background. It was part of the old cleaning process, which used chlorofluorocarbons; it was not part of a new process that uses water.

title: Palestinians Urged By Israel to Prepare Colleges for Opening
description: The Israeli military government in the West Bank told Palestinian university officials today that they should prepare their schools for reopening soon, Palestinian educators said.

title: Hong Kong, Citing Inflation, Cuts Cigarette-Tax Increase
description: The Hong Kong Government, which raised the cigarette tax here by 200 percent two months ago, citing "health not fiscal reasons," cut that increase in half today, citing fiscal, not health reasons.

title: U.S. WILL ENHANCE DEALS FOR BUYERS OF S.& L. HOLDINGS
description: Conceding that it has been unable to sell its growing inventory of assets taken over from failed savings and loans, the Government said today that it was giving up marketing them piecemeal and would bundle them in a new program intended to attract big investors.

title: Kvalsvoll of Norway Maintains Overall Lead in Tour Du Pont
description: Four riders shared the glory today in the 11-day Tour Du Pont bicycle race. Fernando Quevedo of Spain and Andy Bishop of Tucson, Ariz., led for most of the race; Steve Bauer of Fenwick, Ontario, finished first and Atle Kvalsvoll of Norway retained the overall lead.

title: The Names Are Miller and Marino
description: New York State was supposed to have a new budget by April 1. Six weeks later it still doesn't have one, and the delay is costing local governments a fortune because they have to borrow to make up for the missing state aid. Worse, if the impasse continues much longer, New York City may find itself broke. What's Albany's problem?

title: Bank Merger In Austria
description: The third- and fourth-largest banks in Austria announced plans yesterday for a merger that would create the largest bank in the country.

title: Egyptian Official Named to Head the Arab League
description: At a meeting marked by recrimination between officials from Iraq and Kuwait, the 21-member Arab League elected the Foreign Minister of Egypt as its new secretary general today, formally restoring Cairo's role as a center of Arab diplomacy.

title: New Honda Mini-Car
description: The Honda Motor Company will begin selling a new two-seater convertible mini-car, the Beat, in Japan on Thursday, a Honda spokesman said today. The car is powered by a three-cylinder, single-cam, 12-valve, electronic fuel-injection engine. The car is the first available in Japan with an air bag as optional equipment.

title: Coach to Go On Trial
description: PHILIP PARKER, the wrestling coach at Michigan State University, has been ordered to stand trial on a charge of raping a 20-year-old woman. District Court Judge JULES HANSLOVSKY set the hearing for next Wednesday in East Lansing, Mich. Parker, 41 years old, faces a charge of third-degree criminal conduct, which carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison. (AP)

title: After 9-Year Hunt, 3 Face Charges in Widow's Murder
description: In his 20-year police career, Denis O'Sullivan had handled many murder cases on the Upper West Side. But no case obsessed him like the murder of Alice Serghiescu, an elegant, imperious 85-year-old widow of a Columbia professor who loved to play bridge.

title: Upholstery Perfect For a Bride
description: WHEN Tami Bitter married Kevin Cook last Saturday on Long Island, the wedding party was upholstered in more than 70 fabrics from Scalamandre , the bride's family business.

title: PANEL VOTES DOWN RULES ON MILEAGE
description: In a victory for the Bush Administration, the Senate Energy Committee voted today against imposing higher fuel economy standards for automobiles.

title: Senate Asks Bush to Back Loan Guarantees for Soviets
description: The Senate passed a resolution today asking President Bush to approve an additional $1.5 billion in loan guarantees for grain shipments to the Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about protests in South Korea referred incorrectly to the Kwangju uprising. It was in 1980, not 1982.

title: Another Frantic Finish Looms for High Court
description: According to the calendar, the time has arrived for the Supreme Court's annual sprint to finish its term.

title: At Vassar, an Art Gallery Designed to Enlighten
description: IN 1994, Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., will have a new museum: the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, designed by Cesar Pelli, a New Haven architect. "This is not a normal art gallery," he said. "It is primarily a teaching experience."

title: Pop in Review
description: Maureen McGovern Rainbow and Stars 30 Rockefeller Plaza Through June 11

title: U.N. Begins Inspection of Iraqi Atom Plants
description: United Nations experts began inspecting Iraq's nuclear installations today under Persian Gulf war cease-fire terms requiring destruction of Baghdad's most lethal weapons.

title: 'Peace Is More Important Than Real Estate'
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Ends Reatta
description: Production of the Reatta, a sporty two-seat Buick, has ended to make way for a new electric car by the General Motors Corporation. The last Reatta came off the assembly line on Tuesday. Although G.M. has not said officially, the company is expected to build a version of its Impact electric car at the plant by 1993. Through May 10, G.M. had sold 1,008 Reattas, down 60.2 percent from the same time a year ago. During its four years in production at the Craft Centre plant, about 21,000 Reattas were built. About 500 workers will be laid off at the plant, as maintenance and cleanup work is done.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: OUTDOOR decks should be cleaned and inspected at least once a year and repaired whenever damage is found. Scrubbing with a stiff-bristle brush dipped into a solution of warm water and ordinary household detergent will remove ordinary grime. Use about half a cup of detergent to a gallon of water or as the label recommends for heavy-duty cleaning. Afterward, rinse the deck with a hose.

title: Forfeitures By Traders
description: Eight soybean traders convicted earlier this year under a tough racketeering law may have to forfeit thousands of dollars to the Government based on the value of their seats at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Northrop Plans To Trim Jobs
description: The Northrop Corporation, which builds the B-2 stealth bomber, said today that it would trim 1,000 jobs and establish a research unit to refocus efforts on developing military planes.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League

title: CHRONICLE
description: Custom-made furniture being shipped to DON JOHNSON fell off a truck. Really.

title: White Knight Falls Off His Charger
description: Just when Mayor David N. Dinkins thought he had persuaded the diverse players who might ease New York City's fiscal pains to stop arguing over who would help first and agree to help together, it became clearer than ever yesterday how hard it is to assure that anyone will help at all.

title: Desert Inn Auction Set
description: The Desert Inn and Casino was put up for auction today after eight and a half months of futile efforts by its owner, Kirk Kerkorian, to sell the Las Vegas, Nev., resort for $200 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The chairman of Loews Theaters, which operates 866 theaters in 16 states, A. ALAN FRIEDBERG, said yesterday that the company would not distribute the latest film by ANDREW DICE CLAY, "Dice Rules." "It's so offensive to women as to make its exhibition by Loews Theaters inappropriate and unacceptable," Mr. Friedberg said.

title: Commencement; At Columbia, Plea for Action in World Affairs
description: From the sun-drenched steps of Low Memorial Library, the president of Columbia University, Michael I. Sovern, yesterday urged the graduates of the university and its affiliated schools to show the same resolve fighting the world's problems that the United States and its allies displayed fighting Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf war.

title: A Revitalized Norman Resumes a Major Quest
description: For the last decade, no golfer has chased wealth and glory more fervently than Greg Norman. But while the millions have mounted, the major championships have not and Norman has increasingly seemed a Faustian figure destined to achieve everything but the titles he covets most.

title: Chinese Party Chief Mending Relations in Moscow
description: The Chinese Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, began a visit with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and quickly demonstrated improving relations by confirming that part of the two nations' once-volatile border dispute had been settled through compromise.

title: Jones Foundation Aids New Stage Works
description: Seven grants totaling $925,000 have been awarded by the W. Alton Jones Foundation of Charlottesville, Va., to theaters in the United States for developing and producing new works for the musical or dramatic stage. The grants are part of the foundation's New American Plays program.

title: For Summering:: Beach, Backyard Or City Rooftop
description: WITH the Memorial Day weekend just nine days away, thoughts turn to beach picnics, lawn parties and cookouts. Some people are also thinking about accessories for warm-weather fun, whether on terraces high above the city or on faraway verdant mountaintops. The gear can include foam-rubber hats, reusable wraparound sunglasses, an inflatable sink to wash dinnerware at a picnic and extra patio chairs that are colorful, comfortable and lightweight. Six-foot-wide parasols made of oiled paper and bamboo can provide shade for a table for six at a summer garden party. Stuck in the city with no garden and no terrace? For indoor cookouts without the bugs, wind or heat, there is a virtually smoke-free stovetop grill that fits any type of gas or electric range. Add a set of shiny skewers with stay-cool handles.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * AMR Corp. is offering $200 million in 9 1/2 percent noncallable notes due 2001 at 99.464, to yield 9.584 percent, through Salomon Brothers. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: Dow Off 21.47 As Compaq Leads Way
description: A forecast of tumbling profits at Compaq Computer sent the stock market into a tailspin yesterday, particularly the over-the-counter market.

title: Tenant Held in Killing: Pressure and Tragedy
description: Mehmet Lijkovic was under a lot of pressure.

title: Review/Dance; Californians and a Teen-Age Whiz Tap Into Town
description: The current tap dance renaissance has many faces, and one of the most original is represented by the Jazz Tap Ensemble from Los Angeles, which returned on Tuesday night with Savion Glover as guest artist.

title: A Modern Tradeoff: Longevity for Health
description: The good news is that Americans are living longer. The bad news is that, as a result, they are sick longer. And recent studies show that women lose more time to illness than do men.

title: Sports of The Times; Parcells To Tampa In 1992
description: THE best football coach in Giants' history kept saying, "I feel like it's time" to resign. And for Bill Parcells, it was as if he were finally enjoying his stature in assembling two Super Bowl championship teams. At age 49, his face suddenly was younger, his smile quicker and wider. But every so often his words would betray what he eventually knows will happen: He will return to coach a National Football League team.

title: Oakland Signs Hawkins
description: ANDY HAWKINS, a free agent, joined the Oakland Athletics yesterday and will make his first start on Saturday against the Cleveland Indians.

title: New York's County Governments: Paying Their Unfair Share
description: To the Editor:

title: House Subcommittee Votes to Stop Financing Space Station
description: The Bush Administration's plan to build a vast outpost in space for American astronauts suffered a very serious blow yesterday when a powerful House subcommittee voted to end the beleaguered project, which has been mired in disputes almost from the day it was proposed seven years ago.

title: Grand Met's Net Falls 84%
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate that owns the Burger King chain and Pillsbury foods in the United States, said today that profits fell 84 percent in the six months ended March 31.

title: The Novel Re-examined In a Novel by Kundera
description: Immortality By Milan Kundera Translated by Peter Kussi. 345 pages. Grove Weidenfeld. $21.95.

title: U.S. Agency and Its Critics Disagree On Cancer Risk From Breast Implant
description: In an effort to calm women alarmed over reports that a chemical on some breast implants can cause cancer, the Food and Drug Administration has sent a letter to plastic surgeons saying that the lifetime cancer risk from the implants is probably from 1 in 10,000 to 1 in a million. But critics, including some of the agency's own scientists, say the estimates are much too low.

title: Ilse Koehn, 61, Dies; A Writer and Artist
description: Ilse Koehn, a writer and graphic artist, died on May 8 at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 61 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Parcells Courted By TV
description: Despite Bill Parcells's protestations yesterday that he has no plans for his post-Giants future, he has laid the groundwork for at least two possible career moves -- to NBC and the Madison Square Garden Network.

title: Driver Absent for Sentencing
description: A truck driver whose vehicle slammed into a Greyhound bus during a December storm, killing seven passengers, failed to appear for sentencing today. An arrest warrant was issued for the driver, Robert W. Williams, 47 years old, of West Jordan, Utah. He had pleaded no contest to a charge of driving too fast for the weather conditions. The misdemeanor charge carries a penalty of up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

title: A Town That's Addicted To Illegal Drug Money
description: Contrasts between wealth and poverty in this dilapidated outpost on the Mexican border stand out as sharply as the extravagant yellow blooms on a lowly prickly pear cactus.

title: Personal Health
description: Few children grow up without at least one race to the emergency room, usually after an injury while playing. Most escape without much more than a scare or a scar. But each year 50,000 are permanently maimed and 8,000 do not survive their injuries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, a bank holding company, said it had received proposals to enter into merger talks. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., said its G.E. Information Services unit would take a significant minority interest in Data Management International Ltd., a distributor of G.E.'s teleprocessing services and related software in Korea. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Illinois Housing Authority Offering
description: The Illinois Housing Development Authority is offering $143.3 million tax-exempt multifamily mortgage refunding revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum 7.40 percent for a bond due in 2023.

title: Crack Dealer Feeds a Family And Habits of Fewer Addicts
description: In the soft light of morning on most week days, a young Harlem father takes his 2-year-old son to the baby sitter, then walks home to watch a few hours of television before going out to work as a crack dealer.

title: Relics of the Ancient World (Chipped Nose on Request)
description: LAST December, Duncan Darrow, a Manhattan lawyer, asked his wife, Wendy Moonan, what she wanted for Christmas. Ms. Moonan, a magazine editor, didn't hesitate: "I was dying for an antiquity."

title: Airline Retracts Rule Requiring Makeup Use
description: Continental Airlines retracted a new rule today that required female employees to wear makeup and offered to rehire a woman who was dismissed this month for refusing to put on lipstick.

title: Nomination To Fed Seat Is Expected
description: President Bush is expected to name Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, to a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Nissan Offers a Look at Its New Mini-Van
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation today showed a final prototype of the new luxury mini-van that will be manufactured by Ford, and said it would be called the Quest.

title: INSIDE
description: Parcells's Final Play Is a Handoff Bill Parcells, left, with Ray Handley, his successor, yesterday at Giants Stadium, where Parcells announced his resignation as head coach less than four months after leading the Giants to the Super Bowl championship. Page B11. * Dave Anderson says Parcells will coach again, and soon. Page B11.

title: ABORTION-BAN BILL IS DIVIDING POLAND
description: Poland's legislators face a wrenching choice this week as they take up a bill that would ban abortion, this country's leading form of birth control.

title: Agency Named By Newmark
description: Newmark & Lewis Inc., the consumer-electronics retail chain based in Hicksville, L.I., said yesterday that it had awarded its $16 million account to the agency that placed second in its latest advertising review, Partners & Shevack.

title: Profit Increases at Campbell
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that strong gains in soup sales raised profit by 40 percent, to a record $76.4 million, in its third fiscal quarter.

title: Stocks Decline in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices fell today, dragged down by Wednesday's decline on Wall Street. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks lost 302.20 points, or 1.2 percent, to close at 25,520.27. Volume was relatively light, with 260 million shares traded. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 207.61 points.

title: 'The Fighter' of France: Edith Cresson
description: When Edith Cresson was named Minister of Trade and Industry in 1984, she took to riding French motor scooters to work to show that they were just as good as Japanese ones. She even chartered planes and flew dozens of French executives to New York and Tokyo so they could publicize their wares.

title: Key Rates
Democrats Weaken Bill on Campaign Financing
description: As the Senate opened debate on a new drive to overhaul the financing of Congressional campaigns, Democratic leaders today weakened a proposal opposed by Republicans that calls for the Government to help pay candidates' television advertising costs.

title: India Wary of U.S. Relief Force in Bangladesh
description: As American forces move into Bangladesh to assist in cyclone relief and rehabilitation work, hackles began to rise today in India, where there is a tradition of criticizing any United States military presence in the region as a direct threat to New Delhi.

title: White House Calls for Limit on Research Expenses
description: The White House proposed today that a limit be placed on the amount of money universities may charge the Government for administrative costs on research grants.

title: Mapping Meals, With a Bit of History
description: USING place mats printed with the streets of New York, Paris and Moscow, it's possible to learn some geography, nurture a little wanderlust and eat, all at the same time.

title: Sotheby's Posts a Loss
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the auction house, said yesterday that it lost $5.2 million in the quarter ended March 31 on revenues of $32.4 million. In the period last year, the company had a profit of $6 million, or 10 cents a share, on revenues of $61.4 million. "The downturn in the art market that began in the second half of 1990 has carried over into the first quarter of this year," said Michael L. Ainslie, Sotheby's president and chief executive. The company expects second-quarter results will also be lower than last year's.

title: FOOTBALL: Players; Retirement's Timing Is Biggest Surprise
description: Several of the Giants' players seemed surprised at the timing of Bill Parcells's decision to resign as coach yesterday, but they said they could understand his reasons for stepping down.

title: Laimbeer's Hot Shooting Rescues Pistons
description: Bill Laimbeer is the Detroit Pistons' career rebounding leader. But the hallmark for the 6-foot-11-inch center is his outside jump shot.

title: Where Car Makers Fear to Cut
description: Auto executives traditionally do not discuss future car and truck models for fear buyers might put off a purchase until the new ones arrive. But the Chrysler Corporation took that risk by recently allowing dealers, journalists and others onto its test track to give them a glimpse of the 1993 mid-size models on which Chrysler is pinning its hopes for a recovery.

title: Let's Borrow More Money
description: One cannot but marvel on encountering an issue of major popular concern on which, as now, there is a broad unity as to response. That issue is the recession and what to do about it. The truly complete agreement by all levels of government is on measures designed to make it worse.

title: Hundreds of Bees Close Upper East Side Street
description: It's not the usual thing that closes off an Upper East Side street, but the police said the hundreds of bees that had attached themselves yesterday to the back side of a four-door Honda Accord were too dangerous to leave alone.

title: Prof. A. Bharati, 68, A Monk Who Served On Syracuse Faculty
description: Agehananda Bharati, a Hindu monk and the Ford-Maxwell Professor of South Asian Studies at Syracuse University, died on Tuesday at the home of a friend in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 68 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: Ban Asked on Non-Alcoholic Beer to Minors
description: A State Senator who wants to ban the sale of non-alcoholic beer to minors said today that it was a "training beverage for the real thing."

title: Satirist Gets Pedestal (What Would Stalin Say?)
description: The Kremlin has done something to delight the ordinary, literate Muscovite who prefers the day's lot of desperation laced with satire: The Government recognized Mikhail Bulgakov, the great comic novelist of underground anti-Communist literature, as deserving of official birthday honors.

title: Bush Backs China Trade Status, Reopening Conflict Over Rights
description: In a move that immediately reopened a conflict with Congress over relations with China, and surprised even his staff, President Bush said today that he wanted to extend China's favorable trading status for another year despite misgivings about its human rights record.

title: Omar Burleson; Ex-Congressman, 85
description: Former Representative Omar Burleson, who served in Congress for 32 years, died Tuesday night at Hendrick Hospital Medical Center in Abilene. He was 85 years old.

title: Fire Guts House on Coney I.; Was in '77 Woody Allen Film
description: A tumbledown frame house nestled beneath an abandoned Coney Island roller coaster, which became briefly famous when it appeared in the 1977 Woody Allen film "Annie Hall," was gutted by fire yesterday morning.

title: How Power Is Shared
description: The eight-person federal presidency of Yugoslavia is in effect the country's collective head of state. It is made up of members from each of the country's six republics and the republic of Serbia's two provinces.

title: A.I.G. Picks President As Part of Revamping
description: Thomas R. Tizzio yesterday was named president of American International Group Inc., a New York City-based international insurance company and an underwriter of commercial and industrial insurance in the United States.

title: Business and the Law; Congress Moves On Price-Fixing
description: CONGRESS is moving quickly to adopt significant antitrust legislation that its supporters assert will encourage price competition by making it more difficult for manufacturers and retailers to fix prices.

title: Papers Sue Agency Over Payment for Ads
description: Six newspapers have filed suits in Federal and state courts against Wells, Rich, Green Inc., New York, accusing the agency of failing to pay for ads for its client, Continental Airlines.

title: Coors TV Spot Is Approved
description: A Federal judge cleared the way today for the Adolph Coors Company to use a beer commercial with the actor Leslie Nielsen appearing as a rabbit in a spoof of the Energizer bunny.

title: Mostly Mozart Celebrates 25 Summers
description: The 25th annual Mostly Mozart Festival is to begin July 9 with an all-Mozart program of the Overture to "The Marriage of Figaro," the Flute Concerto No. 1, with James Galway as soloist, and the Piano Concerto No. 9, with Andre Watts as soloist. Gerard Schwarz, the festival's music director, will conduct the Festival Orchestra.

title: Hanson Buys Stake In Imperial Chemical
description: Hanson P.L.C., Britain's largest industrial conglomerate, said today that it had bought a 2.82 percent stake in Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., one of the world's largest chemical companies.

title: Wheeling Steel To Pay Fine
description: The Government said today that the Wheeling- Pittsburgh Steel Corporation had agreed to pay a record $6 million civil penalty to settle charges it violated clean water laws at three plants in Ohio.

title: Kennedy Insists That He Did Not Avoid Palm Beach Police
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy sought today to dispel the impression left in sworn statements that he had avoided police officers who were investigating allegations that his nephew, William K. Smith, had raped a young woman on the grounds of the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Yugoslavia Loses Its Head
description: Yugoslavia's fracturing federal system received another sledgehammer blow yesterday when allies of the Serbian Communist strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, denied Croatia its rightful turn in the federal presidency. Non-Communist Croatia, already pressing for a looser union, has a fresh grievance over an issue that strikes at the very heart of Yugoslavia's federal constitutional bargain. And, for now, the country is without a president.

title: March Inventories Fell 0.8% While Sales Declined by 1%
description: Businesses cut their inventories by eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly decline, and analysts said it could be a sign of increased production and jobs when sales improved.

title: 'Peace Is More Important Than Real Estate'; Old P.L.O. Demands
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Time-Life Books has awarded a marketing assignment to the Alexandria, Va., office of Bozell Inc. The agency will handle Time-Life's military history products. Billings were not disclosed. * Janssen Pharmaceutica, Piscataway, N.J., to Botto, Roessner, Horne & Messinger, New York, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc. for Hismanal-D, an antihistamine and decongestant. Billings are to be determined.

title: Pop in Review
description: Pat Benatar Beacon Theater

title: Well, Maybe Fiscal Woe Isn't All Bad
description: To loll in bed or, perhaps, to take a leisurely lunch, even if the street outside is a little more littered -- it is a trade-off that would gladden the hearts of thousands of New Yorkers who deal almost daily with the maddening ritual of driving their cars all the way to the other curb.

title: Media Influences Are Powerful and Real
description: To the Editor:

title: French Prime Minister Quits; Woman Named to Post
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard resigned today after three years in office, and Edith Cresson, a Socialist and former Cabinet minister, was named to replace him, making her the first woman to serve as Prime Minister of France.

title: Knicks Interview Uncertain Collins
description: Doug Collins was interviewed by the Knicks for about two hours yesterday, but he was not offered their head coaching position. And even if the Knicks do eventually make an offer to Collins, he is not sure he would accept.

title: Selloff Hits Compaq on Profit News
description: Shares of the Compaq Computer Corporation lost more than a quarter of their value today after the company said it expected earnings to plummet at least 79 percent this quarter, mainly because of a sharp downturn in orders from some big retailers.

title: Allied Irish Banks
description: Allied Irish Banks P.L.C., Ireland's largest commercial banking group, is bidding for the Midlantic Corporation's York Bank and Trust Company, an Allied executive said. Patrick Dowling, Allied's deputy chief executive, said his company was among four or five bidders for the southern Pennsylvania bank, which Midlantic is seeking to sell to raise cash. Allied said it had not submitted a final bid for the 26-branch bank, which has $1.4 billion in assets, but had given Midlantic "a range we are willing to pay." Midlantic, based in New Jersey, disclosed in March that it was entertaining bids for the York operation.

title: Death Watch
description: Before he was executed by the state of California in 1960, Caryl Chessman arranged with a reporter to communicate from behind the glass wall of the gas chamber. As the cyanide pellets mingled with the sulfuric acid, the convicted murderer brought his head up and down violently in a last nod. Yes, he was saying, it hurts. The reporter wrote: "Whatever medicine says, the eyes said Chessman did not die quickly, not even gracefully, after his twitching reflexes took over from a dead brain. It is probably for the best that only 60 shaken witnesses have to know exactly how it happened."

title: T.W.A. Acts To Buy Debt Below Value
description: Trans World Airlines yesterday offered to buy back debt securities from creditors far below face value, arguing that the creditors faced even larger losses if the airline was forced to file for bankruptcy protection.

title: U.S. Cyclone Relief Forces Reach Bangladesh Port
description: Eight American ships carrying 7,500 troops arrived off the port of Chittagong today and prepared to use their helicopters and Hovercraft to bolster relief efforts for hundreds of thousands of victims of last month's devastating cyclone.

title: Pop in Review
description: Noreen and Earl Sauls J's

title: Malpractice Victims: Ignored
description: Medical liability insurance premiums are rising by more than 20 percent a year, forcing some physicians to practice defensive, and therefore costly, medicine and to withdraw from risky service altogether. What can government, which pays some of the bills, do about it? Yesterday the Bush Administration issued its answer.

title: Review/Theater; Letters Across a Cultural Divide
description: While visiting Beijing as a tourist, a young Chinese-American accidently encounters a Chinese woman of her own age. Their fleeting conversation leads to an epistolary friendship that extends over a period of 10 years, until the student uprising in Tiananmen Square.

title: Court Ruling on Greyhound
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. said today that a bankruptcy judge had reduced by 75 percent the Government's claim against the company for back wages for 6,300 striking bus drivers.

title: Casino Losses In Atlantic City
description: Dragged down by losses at Donald Trump's three casinos, the Atlantic City gaming industry suffered its worst first quarter since gambling came to the Boardwalk in 1978, according to results released today.

title: Wanted: Boarders for Older Homeowners
description: The never-ending chores of maintaining a home can be even more daunting to those slowed by age. As a result, programs that match elderly homeowners who have extra room with younger people looking for inexpensive housing are becoming increasingly popular.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Derwent Award Winners
description: Jane Adams of "I Hate Hamlet," Danny Gerard of "Lost in Yonkers" and "Falsettoland" and James McDaniel of the original cast of "Six Degrees of Separation" were chosen on Monday as winners of this year's Clarence Derwent Awards. A $1,000 prize and an engraved crystal trophy go to "the most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene." The awards were established in 1944 by Clarence Derwent, a former president of Actors' Equity Association, and are overseen by the Actors' Equity Foundation.

title: Weicker Income-Tax Plan Dying As Bipartisan Opposition Grows
description: Three months after Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. proposed that Connecticut resolve its fiscal crisis by adopting an income tax, his budget plan appears to be heading for defeat.

title: Some Bullying, Much Beauty
description: The accident that spilled raw sewage into Jamaica Bay a few days ago, though troubling, still is a reminder of an extraordinary piece of urban renewal.
