Bit by bit it has been cleaning up the bay's almost fatally polluted waters, reclaiming its shores and, out in the middle of the bay, building an urban nature preserve that is now a springtime showplace.

title: Hamilton Standard
description: The Hamilton Standard Company, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said about 150 employees would be furloughed over the next three months. Hamilton said the furloughs would be at its aircraft repair plant in East Windsor, Conn. The company said reduced commercial air travel had resulted in a shortage of work at the plant.

title: A Record Night at Fenway For Red Sox and White Sox
description: A passed ball by Carlton Fisk on what should have ended the sixth inning -- allowed the game to be tied, and the Boston Red Sox rallied for a 9-6 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight in the longest nine-inning night game ever.

title: Let There Be Light, Without Wires
description: TO David Maccarone, a design engineer, radio technology has unlimited applications. In 1987 he invented the Wireless Wall Switch, which eliminates the need for new wiring. It was recently introduced by his company Vantage Technologies in Fall River, Mass.

title: 'Peace Is More Important Than Real Estate'; Injury to Insult
description: To the Editor:

title: Era of Utility Deals Fails to Arrive
description: In 1987, Edward Tirello, then at Shearson Lehman Hutton, was the most outspoken of the many analysts who expected electric utilities to consolidate rapidly. "One hundred and fifty to fifty in five years: That's our motto," he said.

title: News Corp. Loss Widens
description: The News Corporation, the international media and entertainment company led by Rupert Murdoch, said today that it lost $162.7 million (United States) in its third fiscal quarter.

title: Bush Tired, but Doctors Say His Health Is Fine
description: President Bush said today that his doctors had given him a very good report about his thyroid, but earlier a spokesman said the President had been uncharacteristically tired.

title: People
description: * William J. McGowan has been named senior vice president-advertising sales for the Discovery Channel, Bethesda, Md. He had been vice president-operations and sales for Fox Television Stations Inc. * Valerie Di Maria has been named executive vice president of the GCI Group, the New York-based public relations subsidiary of Grey Advertising. She will also serve as co-director of GCI's marketing group in New York. * David Floren, chairman and chief executive of Martin/Williams Advertising, Minneapolis, has been elected international chairman of Affiliated Advertising Agencies International.

title: Market Place; The Bullish, and Bearish, Moves by Buffett
description: Warren E. Buffett is bullish on Wells Fargo shares, but he may be bearish on some other securities, including "junk bonds," whose prices have zoomed this year. It appears that his company has sold large quantities of RJR Nabisco bonds, and may have sold other low-quality bonds as well.

title: Major Airlines Are Cautious On Matching America West
description: America West's cuts in full coach fares last week have been matched in some markets by other leading carriers, but the Phoenix-based airline has been left with a price advantage in hundreds of routes where it does not have frequent flights.

title: Pacific Gas Bonds
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company priced $200 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, the bonds due in 2024 have an 8 7/8 percent coupon and are priced at 95.50, to yield 9.314 percent. Proceeds from the sale will be used for general corporate purposes, including the redemption on June 1 of about $119 million in series 86A bonds.

title: U.S. Accuses 7 Gold Traders
description: Federal regulators today accused seven gold futures traders and brokers of defrauding customers at the Commodity Exchange in New York.

title: Shintaro Abe, Japanese Politician And Ex-Cabinet Aide, Dies at 67
description: Shintaro Abe, one of Japan's top politicians for nearly two decades and leader of an influential faction of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, died today after a two-year illness. He was 67 years old.

title: Review/Television; 2 Mysteries, Heavy on the Red Herrings
description: Regarding a certain English police inspector, it can hardly be a coincidence that the addition of a single letter can change the name Morse into the adjective morose. As played by John Thaw, Chief Inspector Morse of Oxford is certainly the most dour detective regularly featured on public television's "Mystery" series. Tonight, at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channels 21 and 49, he is returning for a fourth season in three two-part stories and, happily, remains steadfastly glum.

title: Ad Executives Cheer As Ethics Wins the Day On 'Thirtysomething'
description: In a fit of ethical fury, Michael Steadman finally quit his advertising agency on Tuesday. And the real advertising industry cheered him on.

title: Bridge
description: Three separate contests beginning here today will decide the American representation in the world team championships scheduled in Yokohama, Japan, in October.

title: Kuwaiti Collaboration Trials Now Scheduled for Saturday
description: Public trials will begin Saturday for people accused of collaborating with Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait, officials here said today.

title: John Grady Memorial
description: A memorial concert for the organist John Grady is to be held at 6 P.M. on Sunday at the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 86th Street, Manhattan. Mr. Grady, who was director of music for St. Patrick's Cathedral and an organist there and at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Sept. 27 at the age of 56. The program will include choral and instrumental works led by Richard Woitach, a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting next week, the Health page will appear on Wednesdays, in The Living Section.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Money Market Funds Post Declining Yields in Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week ended yesterday.

title: Pretoria Moves Hunger Strikers Off Robben Island
description: The last political prisoners on Robben Island left today but their departure elicited concern and outrage rather than gratitude from opponents of apartheid.

title: Kurdish Tent Cities Rise At Allies' Way Stations
description: As Iraqi Kurds climb down from their mountain refuges in Turkey, new complications have arisen in the military-led campaign to get them back to their homes.

title: District of Columbia Prices General Obligation Bonds
description: The District of Columbia priced $196 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Water and Some Stamps Don't Mix
description: The parade of problems embarrassing the Postal Service has lengthened.

title: Guard Unit Is Criticized for Using Fund for Parties
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today accused the New York State National Guard of misusing almost $1 million on parties, liquor, convention trips, greeting cards and magazine subscriptions.

title: Gardening Events: Twilight Walks
description: Gardens at Dusk Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: Cheats Outfox New Turnstile For Subways
description: Despite transit officials' promises that a new turnstile would virtually eliminate fare evasion in the city's subways, City Council investigators have observed riders using all the old tricks to slip through the bars of the prototype to avoid paying.

title: FOOTBALL: Successor; As Handley Steps Up, Old Issues Strike Fast
description: Minutes after he was announced as Bill Parcells's replacement, Ray Handley, who had been promoted to offensive coordinator in February, was asked what plans he had in store for the Giants' offense. Would there be any shake-ups on his staff? Who would be his starting quarterback when the season started?

title: Sony Plans a Portable Disk System
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it planned to introduce a Walkman-like audio disk system late next year that will be able to record music as well as play pre-recorded disks.

title: Citicorp Plans Global Move
description: Citicorp plans a $2 billion credit-card-backed global commercial paper program this summer.

title: To Hell With Yew?
description: I like trees, and respect other people who like trees. Tree people are stalwart.

title: Legal Program For Homeless Is in Jeopardy
description: A plan by New York City budget officials to eliminate a legal-services program from next year's budget could jeopardize the city's efforts to stop using welfare hotels to house homeless families, city social-service officials say.

title: Panel Gives Chip Outlook
description: A panel of experts has concluded that advanced semiconductor factories are likely to cost about $2 billion each by 2000 and that the world would be able to afford only about 25 of them, with 10 in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a proposal to reduce New York City's budget deficit with the help of the Municipal Assistance Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the bonds that would be refinanced to provide the money. They were the corporation's bonds, not the city's.

title: Karl Reuling; Editor, 60
description: Karl Reuling, a writer on music and dance and a founding editor of Ballet News, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: Parent & Child
description: SHARON HULBACK has gotten used to hearing her children's tattling. The words come cloaked as regular battlefield reports issued by her 9-year-old daughter and 5-year-old son as they vie for her attention. They tell her about each other's behavior, usually applying their own spin to the vivid descriptions of injustice.

title: Visiting Royalty Views 'Cricket,' Colonial Style
description: As thousands of baseball fans roared their approval, Queen Elizabeth II strode onto the field at Memorial Stadium this evening, accompanied by President and Mrs. Bush, for a few minutes of queenly greeting before a Baltimore Orioles game.

title: 1991 Delivery Set For Cray Computer
description: The Cray Computer Corporation said its first 16-processor Cray 3 supercomputer, which can perform a calculation in one two-billionths of a second, is scheduled to be shipped this year. Officials at the company's annual meeting said the $30 million computer had been purchased by the Department of Energy's Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in Northern California.

title: Bush May Seek U.N. Ruling For Force in Kurdish Zone
description: President Bush said today that he was willing to seek Security Council authority to create a United Nations security force in northern Iraq that would pave the way for the withdrawal of American and allied military forces from the Kurdish region.

title: Breast Cancer Cases Fewer Than 1 in 9
description: To the Editor:

title: Cary Is Rocked and Yanks Are Routed
description: Chuck Cary stared at the left-field seats, stared at his feet and kicked the dirt on the mound. He did not stare into the Yankee dugout to see if Manager Stump Merrill was about to remove him from the game. He did not have to.

title: Baby Beckons. Why Is Daddy at Work?
description: "THIS is Gordon Rothman at 'CBS This Morning,' but you can call me Mr. Mom."

title: Loving Paws, Helping Hands
description: THE tall man with elaborate tattoos was not the person Ed Jenkins expected when he arrived at the West 50th Street apartment. "Patrick just went into the hospital," the man said.

title: Home Video
description: Video Piracy

title: Let the Healing Begin for War Resisters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bensonhurst Journal; Poet Is People's Voice, Even in a Foreign Tongue
description: To his adoring Sicilian paesani in Bensonhurst, the poet Vincenzo Ancona is an author they can't refuse.

title: Six Finalists Selected For Subaru Account
description: After approaching almost 40 agencies for a review of its $60 million advertising account, Subaru of America, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., announced yesterday that it had narrowed the field to six finalists.

title: The Action of a Lawyer in Occupied France Raises the Question: Is Nit-Picking Collaboration?
description: From the little we know about him, Joseph Haennig was a respected lawyer in his day. Besides his practice, he wrote for one of France's most prestigious legal publications. Contemporary American legal periodicals are filled with the words of lawyers like him.

title: 350 Libyans Trained to Oust Qaddafi Are to Come to U.S.
description: For two years, United States officials have been shopping around for a home for about 350 Libyan soldiers who cannot return to their country because American intelligence officials had mobilized them into a commando force to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: Scientist Accused of Faking Data Calls the Scandal a 'Witch Hunt'
description: The researcher at the center of a bitter scientific scandal said Wednesday that it was a "witch hunt" caused by decreasing Federal research funds.

title: More Therapy for Davis
description: GLENN DAVIS must undergo at least three more weeks of therapy before he can take batting practice, and it will be much longer before he returns to the Baltimore Orioles' lineup. Davis, obtained in an off-season trade with the Houston Astros, stretched the spinal accessory nerve in his neck on March 12. . . . Boston Red Sox pitcher ROGER CLEMENS and his brother entered pleas of innocent yesterday to misdemeanor charges stemming from a January bar brawl in Houston with an off-duty police officer. A motions hearing was set for July 22, and the trial date is expected to be set then. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about grants to improve mathematics and science programs misidentified the National Science Foundation. It is a Government agency, not a private organization.

title: Jordan Rests His Aching Left Knee
description: Michael Jordan, still bothered by tendinitis in his left knee, did not show up for practice today, but the Chicago Bulls weren't worried.

title: Hundreds File for Grants to Run for City Council
description: Lured by 16 new City Council seats, hundreds of New Yorkers -- many of them political neophytes -- have signaled their intention to run for the Council this year by filing applications for matching public funds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE, Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street, Manhattan. "House of Heritage," a lecture with slides on the history of the museum and the surrounding area. Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission: $2. Information: (212) 431-0233.

title: Queen's Address to Congress Celebrates Mutual Respect
description: Queen Elizabeth II celebrated the cooperation and commonality between the United States and Britain in an address to Congress today.

title: People
description: * Patricia Haegele has been named senior vice president of Gannettwork, New York, a cross media packaging program of Gannett Co. Inc., Arlington, Va. The company also announced three new vice presidents in USA Today's advertising department: Jim Gath, Jack Dickman and Janet Smith. * James D. Patterson has been named managing director of Leo Burnett Company Inc.'s Singapore office. He is currently vice president-account director in the agency's Chicao headquarters. * Kay Lucas has been promoted to vice president-media director at Mingo Group Inc., New York. She began at the agency one year ago as media director. * J. Walter Thompson, New York, has promoted Isabelle Albanese, W. Scott Frank, and Patrick Howley to vice presidents. * Medicus Intercon International Inc., New York, a partner company of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, announced several new appointments. They include: John La Mare, senior vice president-account group director; Lindsey Fox, vice president-media director, and Judy Block, vice president-account supervisor.

title: Corrections
description: Because of computer programming errors, a table last Nov. 8 portraying the electorate for the House of Representatives included incorrect figures for many categories of voters. Recently revised data from Voter Research and Surveys, the four-network agency that conducted the Election Day poll, yield figures that differ from the originals by up to six percentage points. Corrected copies of the table are available from the News Surveys Department (Sixth Floor), The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Quayle to Press to Save Space Station
description: The Bush Administration vowed yesterday to keep alive its plan to build an orbiting space station as the centerpiece of the manned space program, after a powerful House subcommittee voted to end the beleaguered project.

title: Baines's Lethal Bat Buries Orioles
description: Harold Baines continued his assault on Baltimore pitching with a three-run homer, two singles and a walk tonight as the Oakland Athletics beat the Orioles, 11-5.

title: Review/Dance; Symmetries, Tygerish (Blake's) and Tame (Bach's)
description: Perhaps the members of the New York City Ballet should imagine that "Concerto Barocco" had been renamed "Fearful Symmetries" or, at least, "Awesome Symmetries." Their interpretation of "Concerto Barocco" might improve as a result.

title: Illogical Lawns
description: Dutiful grass cutters, trudging behind their mowers and trying to find some logic in what they are doing, are wasting their thoughts. There is no logic in a lawn or in lawn keeping.

title: Prejudice Is Still a Fact of Life for Blacks; Separate, and Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Turtles Put New Friction In U.S.-Japan Trade Quarrels
description: With its hooked beak, scaly neck and stubby legs, the yard-long hawksbill sea turtle will win no beauty contests. But this homely creature, an endangered vestige of the dinosaur age, is suddenly at the center of a squall in United States-Japanese relations.

title: TV in the Death Chamber: a News Story Like Any Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Backs Expanded I.R.A.'s
description: Legislation that would make tax-deductible individual retirement accounts available again to all Americans won a lukewarm endorsement today from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MOLLY YARD, the president of the National Organization for Women, suffered a stroke Wednesday night and was listed in serious condition yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. SHARON FISCHMAN, a spokeswoman for NOW, said Ms. Yard was apparently stricken while working in her Washington office.

title: Review/Theater; 'Hunchback' of Preening and Peeping Tomfoolery
description: In Everett Quinton's highhanded adaptation, "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" becomes a free-for-all in a camp Quasimodo mode. Though not a bell ringer like Charles Ludlam's vintage travesties, the show is far more lighthearted (and less miserable) than that uptown Victor Hugo frolic. In its own chaotic, Ridiculous Theatrical fashion, Mr. Quinton's "Hunchback" is even quasi-faithful to the plot of the original novel.

title: Study Says U.S. Rejected Safer Nuclear Test Site
description: When the United States chose Nevada as the site for atmospheric tests of nuclear weapons four decades ago, Government officials knew the choice would mean that more people would be exposed to radiation than at an alternative site in North Carolina, a new study asserts.

title: Calamity's Lessons
description: The world's human tragedies suddenly seem too much for the heart to bear or the mind to comprehend. A million Iraqi Kurds flee to the mountains, prompting a desperate multinational aid effort. A cyclone lashes the Bay of Bengal, killing as many as 200,000 and leaving millions homeless. All the while war and famine stalk the Horn of Africa, imperiling 20 million in Ethiopia, Somalia and the Sudan.

title: TOXIC POLLUTION SHOWS DROP IN '89
description: For the second consecutive year, manufacturers in Texas and Louisiana released more toxic chemicals into the environment than any other states in 1989. But the overall amount of about 330 hazardous substances poured into the air, water and the ground by manufacturers has sharply decreased since 1987.

title: Tribune Co.'s Bleak News
description: The Tribune Company's 1991 earnings will fall far short of last year's earnings, even excluding losses at The Daily News in New York, according to Charles T. Brumback, the president.

title: Hubert C. Taylor, Architect, 53
description: Hubert C. Taylor, an architect and president of an organization for black artists, died on Friday at his home in Center City here. He was 53 years old.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Ninth Avenue Food Festival: Ninth Avenue between 37th and 57th Streets will be closed tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Economic Scene; Bonn's Contrasts With Washington
description: A COALITION of top Administration officials and business executives has been pushing the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates, and thus far Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, and a majority of the Fed's policy makers have been cautiously going along. The Economist last week read the riot act to both the Administration and the Fed: "Not only has the Bush Administration shown itself incapable of exercising wise economic leadership but, much more disturbing, it seems that the Federal Reserve stands ready to do its bidding."

title: AIDS Walk on Sunday
description: Some 25,000 participants are expected for the 10-kilometer AIDS Walk on Sunday at 10 A.M., rain or shine, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The sixth annual walk will begin and end at Lincoln Center, where registered participants may check in at 9 A.M. Special guests include the actress Tyne Daly and Mayor David N. Dinkins. The walk is sponsored by the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's oldest AIDS organization. Registration and information: (212) 807-9255.

title: Larry McGill, Advocate for Homeless, 36
description: Larry McGill, an advocate for the homeless, died on May 4 at North General Hospital in Manhattan. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gay Jews Thwarted in Search for a Rabbi
description: It happens almost every other week at Congregation Beth Simchat Torah in the West Village of Manhattan. The president gets up after Friday night services and announces that there has been another death in the synagogue family.

title: Cinema Shootout: Now a Murder
description: A Nassau County grand jury has indicted on murder charges four Queens men accused of taking part in a fatal shootout inside a packed movie theater in Valley Stream on Dec. 25.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Industry Tries to Laugh in the Face of Hard Times
description: THE leaders of the country's advertising industry might not be smiling through the apocalypse, but as their annual meeting continues here they are trying at least to chuckle their way through their two recessions.

title: Stronger Right-to-Die Law Gains Approval in Missouri
description: The State House of Representatives has overwhelmingly approved a right-to-die bill inspired by the case of Nancy Cruzan, allowing food and water to be withdrawn from patients who put their wishes in writing before becoming incapacitated. Current law allows the removal of life support equipment but not food and water.

title: Blacks' Syphilis Rate Up Sharply
description: Fueled by a sharp rise among blacks, the nation's syphilis rate has reached its highest point in more than four decades, Federal officials said today.

title: Oiler Banned 3 Games
description: GLENN ANDERSON of the Edmonton Oilers was suspended for the first three games of next season by the National Hockey League for a kicking incident in Game 4 of the Campbell Conference finals against Minnesota. Anderson kicked North Stars forward GAETAN DUCHESNE with his skate, prompting a review of the incident by N.H.L. executive vice president BRIAN O'NEILL, who issued the suspension. (AP)

title: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
description: Stock prices rose today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the week at 25,701.94, up 181.67 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent. For the week, it fell 572.35, or about 2.2 percent.

title: Thomas F. Hennessy, Architect, 80
description: Thomas F. Hennessy, an architect in Manhattan for four decades, died on Tuesday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 80 years old and had lived for many years in East Williston, L.I.

title: Msgr. Henry Lenahan, Principal in Bronx, 85
description: Msgr. Henry J. Lenahan, a former principal of Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx, died on Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived in Point Lookout, L.I.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Market Place; DeSoto Is Facing Proxy Showdown
description: THROUGHOUT the 1980's, any number of novel takeover defenses were created by corporations to ward off unwanted suitors. But DeSoto Inc., once one of the largest suppliers of paint to Sears, Roebuck & Company, found what may well be one of the most unusual: liquidate about 80 percent of itself while paying top management millions of dollars in "golden parachutes" -- even as they retain control of the company.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance; Savion Glover, Tapping His Way to Stardom
description: One of the happiest moments in recent tap history occurred at a Duke Ellington celebration several years ago at City Center when a young tapper named Savion Glover danced onto the stage and imperturbably claimed it as his own. The competition included some of the biggest names in tap. But Mr. Glover's sleek and sparkling professionalism and rapid-fire tapping had the crowd cheering.

title: Busch Theme Park Unit Names 3 to Top Posts
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, whose theme park business has been hurt by the recession, yesterday named the No. 2 executive at its theme park unit as president and made two other executives officers of the subsidiary.

title: Disney Center In Singapore
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it would set up a regional headquarters in Singapore to sell more than 16,000 different Disney products in Southeast Asia.

title: New Chairman At Fleet Banks
description: The Fleet-Norstar Financial Group today named Robert J. Higgins chairman and chief executive of Fleet's Connecticut banks, including the Fleet Bank of Connecticut and the New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company.

title: Wrecks of Planes Found at Sea
description: Explorers have found what appear to be the wrecks of five Navy planes that vanished off Florida in 1945, a salvor said today. The TBM Avengers were spotted in 750 feet of water, about 10 miles off Fort Lauderdale, said Robert Cervoni, managing director of Scientific Search Project. The planes disappeared Dec. 5, 1945, in a training flight from the Naval Air Base in Fort Lauderdale, an event that helped create the myth of the Bermuda Triangle.

title: TV Weekend; A Willa Cather Classic About Settlers in Nebraska
description: With a gracious bow to Thornton Wilder's "Our Town," Darrah Cloud's adaptation of "O Pioneers!," Willa Cather's 1913 autobiographical novel, uses a bare stage and a few props to conjure up the life of a family and community over several decades. The place in this instance is rural Nebraska, and the story begins with the arrival of Swedish settlers in the 1870's. In their midst is a remarkable woman named Alexandra. She holds the story and this play together, giving "American Playhouse" -- at 9 on Channel 13 this evening -- claim to still another fine presentation this season.

title: Handley Promises to Run Patterns of His Own
description: Bill Parcells loved to talk about "my lunch-pail guys." Even though he came from a fairly comfortable upper-middle-class background, where the lunch pails belonged to the workers at the country club, he identified with that working-class attitude.

title: Compaq Acts Quickly to Stem Slide
description: Moving quickly to rebuild investor confidence after its shares plunged 27 percent Wednesday, the Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it planned to repurchase up to 10 million, or 11 percent, of its common shares.

title: In Retail, It's Perilous at the Top
description: Frank Doroff, the chairman of Bonwit Teller stores, yesterday became one more merchant without a store. After spending more than half his life in retailing, he will be on the outside looking in, probably wondering which fork in the road proved the wrong one.

title: Acquisition By Gannett
description: The Gannett Company said today that it had agreed in principle to buy several divisions of the the Times Journal Company, including five daily and 10 weekly community newspapers in the Washington area.

title: Turks Angry as Kurd Aid Backfires
description: To many Turks, whose country was chief benefactor for a long while to half a million fleeing Iraqis, the Kurdish refugee crisis has reinforced widely held resentments that they are not liked abroad and may well never be.

title: As Coffey Remains Idle and Irritable, So Goes the Penguin Power Play
description: Despite being blessed with some of Bobby Orr's Hall of Fame talents, Paul Coffey can't even be an active hockey player at the moment. That is something that irks him greatly.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10:30 A.M. STATES PARTIES TO INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION AGAINST APARTHEID IN SPORTS -- 10:30 A.M. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M.

title: Connecticut Clears Way for Indian Casino
description: The last barrier to an Indian tribe opening Connecticut's first gambling casino fell tonight when the state House of Representatives rejected Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s emergency request to repeal the legal basis for the casino, a law allowing nonprofit groups to run "Las Vegas night" fund-raisers.

title: All-Terrain Vehicles Won't Be Regulated
description: On a 2-to-1 vote, the Consumer Product Safety Commission decided Wednesday that it would not impose mandatory Federal standards for all-terrain vehicles.

title: Floods Kill 30 in Turkey
description: Flash floods killed at least 30 people in eastern Turkey and left scores of others homeless, the Anatolia news agency and state radio said today. Torrential rain and winds up to 75 miles an hour lashed the region, inundating houses, roads and farmland and knocking out electricity, the reports said.

title: Manville's Fund to Get More Cash
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn yesterday approved a bitterly disputed plan to revise the trust fund set up by the Manville Corporation two years ago to compensate asbestos victims. In doing so, Judge Weinstein, who has tried aggressively to streamline the handling of the nation's asbestos litigation, issued an opinion that proposed radical changes to this end.

title: Poor Planning Blamed for 'Star Wars' Waste
description: Much of the $24 billion spent to develop the Pentagon's space-based antimissile defense program may have been wasted because of overly optimistic budget requests, poor planning and pressure to field unproven technology, a House panel was told today.

title: Treasuries Down in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved lower at the end of a slow session yesterday, as dealers continued what has become a lengthy process of distributing notes and bonds purchased at last week's refunding auctions and digested reports that provided little new economic insight.

title: Accounts
description: * Citibank, New York, a subsidiary of Citicorp, to Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago. The $10 million account will be handled by the agency's New York office, FCB/Leber Katz Partners. The incumbent agency was Ayer. Citibank said the reason for the change was to consolidate its advertising in one agency and that Foote, Cone & Belding already handles Citicorp banks in other locales. Ayer retains other Citicorp accounts.

title: SOVIET REPUBLICS ARE SAID TO AGREE ON CRISIS PROGRAM
description: The Soviet Government announced today that 13 of the nation's 15 republics had agreed on the details of an emergency plan to steer the nation out of economic crisis. The plan includes a new effort to ban strikes, budget cuts and fresh assurances for skeptical foreign investors.

title: Woman Aboard Bus Is Slain by Deputies After Killing a Man
description: An agitated woman, speaking incoherently of "Nazis" and waving a large handgun, shot and killed a fellow passenger aboard a public bus as it entered Beverly Hills on Wednesday night, the police said. They said the woman then barricaded herself alone inside for several hours until a sheriffs' assault team stormed the bus and killed her.

title: Robert Humphrey, 88, Chemist and Engineer
description: Robert Humphrey, a chemist, metallurgical engineer and founding chairman of Bayside Controls, an aerospace manufacturer, died Monday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 88 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Robert A. Lowe, Lawyer, 43
description: Robert A. Lowe, a lawyer who specialized in adoption cases, died on Thursday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Murdoch Keeps Ties to Eight Magazines
description: A grim advertising climate can make for strange bedfellows. As such, Mirabella magazine will continue to be part of the same advertising sales program as eight other Murdoch magazines, even though those publications are to be sold next month to another company.

title: Cuomo Expects City to Still Get Some State Help
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he expected the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to give New York City at least $200 million next year to avert some of the deep service cuts proposed by Mayor David. N. Dinkins, even if a more ambitious aid plan remains stalled.

title: Prejudice Is Still a Fact of Life for Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Friend Is at Center of Inquiry Into Obstruction of Justice
description: Sworn testimony given in a rape investigation at the Kennedy estate appears to support complaints by police officials that they were misled when they first sought information from the Kennedy household.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Much Ado About 'Nunsense'

title: Robert S. Heaney, British Diplomat, 88
description: Robert S. Heaney, a former British diplomat in China and a retired businessman in Manhattan, died on Monday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 88 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Geraldine N. Moon, Democratic Leader, 57
description: Geraldine N. Moon, vice chairwoman of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee, died at her home in Camden County on Wednesday. She was 57 years old.

title: MGM-Pathe Gets Settlement
description: A Federal judge today approved a settlement between the MGM-Pathe Communications Company and creditors who tried to force the movie studio into bankruptcy.

title: L.I. Mall Fire Leaves 1 Dead And 29 Hurt
description: One person was killed, one was missing and at least 29 were injured when a fire swept through the Walt Whitman Mall in South Huntington, L.I., last night, sending hundreds of shoppers fleeing, officials said.

title: It's Only a Movie? Not When It Comes to The Boz
description: The Boz roars into the neighborhood today, all noise and attitude. As usual. A punk hunk in a 'roid rage. He is not a good actor, but then he wasn't such a good football player, either. As a linebacker for the University of Oklahoma and the Seattle Seahawks, Brian Bosworth parlayed an excess of personality, earrings, dyed blond hair and a better body through chemistry into national celebrity that led to a best-selling book and positioned him to be packaged as a "modern anti-hero" for the kids who overdose on movies.

title: Citicorp Bad-Loan Rate
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest lender in mortgages and credit cards, said yesterday that delinquencies on home loans and all other kinds of consumer credit continued to increase in the first three months of the year. In a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Citicorp said 4.8 percent of its home mortgage loans were delinquent in the first quarter, up from 4.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990 and 2.8 percent in the first quarter of 1990. The increase in delinquencies on other consumer loans, including credit cards, rose to 3.9 percent in the first quarter from 3.6 percent in the fourth quarter and 3.5 percent a year earlier. Citicorp warned that delinquencies and credit losses could continue to increase because of the weak economy.

title: Gay Head, Mass., Keeps Name
description: Voters in this town on Martha's Vineyard rejected a proposal on Wednesday to change the name of the community to Aquinnah, a name that evokes the island's rich Indian history. Voters rejected the change 89 to 36, officials said. Aquinnah is the original Wampanoag name for the area.

title: S.E.C. Case Says Scheme May Have Defrauded 40,000
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had uncovered an investment scheme that may have defrauded 40,000 people, mostly from lower-income families and minorities, of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Chicago Clinic Closes After New AIDS Scare
description: A clinic where a woman was given a gynecological examination last month with swabs that had been used on an AIDS patient was temporarily closed Wednesday after two girls were found playing with a used syringe.

title: Auctions
description: A Tlingit Thunderbird

title: Review/Film; A Sly Satire About a Mean Old Lady and Her Willing Victims
description: The milk of human kindness curdles in the veins of Tatie Danielle (Tsilla Chelton), a malicious old lady who delights in bringing tears to the eyes of those who treat her kindly. A magnificent monster, she has long since passed the point of respecting middle-class pieties. Irritable and unloved at the age of 82 (and a widow for 50 years), she has attained the freedom to say exactly what she likes, and the crueler the better. Another old woman's deferential remark, "I'll die before you," prompts Tatie Danielle to snap, "I certainly hope so."

title: Give British Due on 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike the Gold in Position as Preakness Favorite
description: Strike the Gold drew the No. 3 post position today for the 116th Preakness Stakes on Saturday, and his trainer, Nick Zito, greeted the draw with cheers and said, "He's on the right trail: the Triple Crown trail."

title: Sound Heard in the Bronx Was Yanks Going Ker-Plunk
description: Eric Plunk was just not with it last night. The Yankee right-hander's pitches were not there, his mind seemed to be on vacation and the Angels were happy to exploit his foibles.

title: Review/Art; Poetic 'Experiences' Of Fernando Melani
description: Fernando Melani's small monochrome paintings, metal reliefs and wire sculptures are alternately rigorous and whimsical, modest and grandiose. Either way, they are almost completely unknown in America. This is a fate entirely undeserved by these often beautiful, always exuberant little objects, which continually transform the simplest of materials into an intimate form of visual poetry.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Would James Dean have sold insurance? Liberty Mutual Insurance may find out, as it begins a corporate campaign on Saturday that includes one commercial with shots of the film actor who died in a car accident in 1955. The campaign portrays the company as a longtime advocate for air bags, safety belts and other safety measures. "We understand the cost involved," is the tagline for the five commercials. Wells, Rich, Greene Inc., New York, created the campaign, which has a budget exceeding $10 million. * Bill and Ted, the two teen-age movie characters who popularized the phrase "most excellent," will be pitching their own cereal. The animated commercials begin Monday for Ralston-Purina Co.'s new Bill & Ted's Excellent Cereal, inspired by the movie "Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure." The spot was created by the New York-based agency Avrett, Free & Ginsberg. * American Express Travelers Cheques will begin using a new theme on Sunday. Along with their now famous slogan, "Don't leave home without them," two new commercials will include the tagline: "It's your vacation. Do something about it." The first commercial shows a thief spending someone's vacation money, while actor Karl Malden, who has appeared in American Express Travelers Cheques commercials for 18 years, provides the voice-over. Ogilvy & Mather, New York, created the campaign. * The Bronx Zoo started advertising Wednesday to dispel what it fears is a widespread image: that the zoo is a depressing place, where animals are locked in cages. The television commercials and 60-second spots for movie theaters show a black panther, baboons and other animals running about in their natural-habitat homes, called Jungle World and Baboon Reserve. Geer, DuBois Inc., New York, created the $1 million campaign.

title: Terms Sought on China Trade
description: Senator George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, introduced legislation today that is meant to force President Bush to declare that China has halted a long list of human rights violations if he wants to continue China's favorable trading status.

title: For Children
description: Children's Tap Concert and Tap Jam Woodpeckers Tap Dance Center 170 Mercer Street Manhattan (212) 979-6005 Recommended ages: 5 and up Sunday

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEWIS L. GLUCKSMAN and LORETTA BRENNAN GLUCKSMAN will pay to renovate a town house near the New York University campus in Greenwich Village as a center for Irish culture. It will be called Ireland House. Mr. Glucksman, the vice chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company and an alumnus of the N.Y.U. business school, is a fan of Celtic literature.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 539 money market mutual funds decreased by $3.71 billion, to $464.92 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 190 institutional funds decreased by $2.32 billion, to $133.83 billion, while those of the 259 general-purpose funds dropped by $637.6 million, to $179.12 billion.

title: Key Rates
Allure of California May Keep Riley From Knicks Job
description: Dick Ebersol, president of NBC Sports, said yesterday that Pat Riley was still trying to decide if he wants to coach the Knicks.

title: Ex-Patriot Owner Sues Tagliabue, Rozelle and 21 Teams
description: William H. Sullivan Jr., the former owner of the New England Patriots, filed a $348 million lawsuit yesterday against the National Football League, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, former commissioner Pete Rozelle and 21 N.F.L. teams. The suit charges that Sullivan was illegally barred from selling 49 percent of his team to an investment banking company in 1987.

title: Suicides by Korean Protesters Stir Unease and Fear of a Plot
description: Even before Yun Yong Ha methodically poured paint thinner over his body the other day, set himself on fire and ran through a college campus denouncing President Roh Tae Woo, a haunting question hung over South Korea: Is some evil force commanding the country's young radicals to commit suicide?

title: Questions on Gates Are Tied To C.I.A. Role in Iran-Contra
description: The issue of how much Robert M. Gates knew about the Iran-contra affair is tied to the larger issues of the Central Intelligence Agency's role in the matter and who authorized it, subjects that have proved difficult for investigators to piece together.

title: Hartford Backs Casino
description: A Connecticut Indian tribe will be able to open the state's first gambling casino. The State House of Representatives last night rejected Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s emergency request to repeal the legal basis for the casino, a law allowing nonprofit groups to run "Las Vegas Night" fund-raisers.

title: Brokers and Lenders Join To Push Cape Cod Sales
description: Anyone interested in buying property on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard this summer can get a quick one-stop look at what's available on Sunday when 22 real estate brokers, two mortgage loan companies and a Cape Cod bank will display their wares in a Hyannis hotel showroom.

title: Prejudice Is Still a Fact of Life for Blacks; Marketers Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: Pavin Scorches Memorial Opener
description: Corey Pavin, the leading money and tournament winner on the PGA Tour this year, continued his superlative play today with a six-under-par 66 to take the first-round lead of the Memorial Tournament.

title:
COLLEGES;
New Idea For Bowls Discussed
description: Representatives of three major New Year's Day bowls, the athletic director of Notre Dame and the commissioners of the Big East and Atlantic Coast conferences are close to an agreement that would significantly alter post-season play in college football. The plan, which avoids a playoff system, would enhance the chances of producing a national-championship bowl game.

title: Florida Shop Acquires Needham & Grohmann
description: It is not uncommon for New Yorkers to sell their homes and head down to Florida when they reach retirement age. But it is a little more unusual when it happens to an advertising agency.

title: A Low-Rent 'High Noon' Set in Texas Prairie Town
description: "I stay with him because as low as I am, I can turn around and see him and remember there's somebody lower," declares Molly (Carol Kelly), the tarnished girlfriend of a hired killer in "Terror in a Texas Town."

title: In This Lotto, All They Need Is a Dollar and a Dupe
description: When New York State introduced Lotto, a game that entices people with get-rich fantasies while skimming 60 cents of each dollar bet, con artists on the street complained that the government was stealing their techniques. But some were inspired by the competition. They responded by using state lottery tickets for an improved game that skims 100 cents of each dollar.

title: Florio's Auto Insurance Law Upheld
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the Florio administration's new auto-insurance law, but it also ruled that the increased costs it imposes on insurance companies can be passed on to motorists.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Iowa Electric Light and Power Co., Cedar Rapids, is offering $60 million in 8 5/8 percent noncallable first-mortgage bonds due 2001 at 99.437 to yield 8.710 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P. * Golden West Financial Corp., Oakland, Calif., is offering $100 million in 9.15 percent noncallable notes due 1998 at 99.847 to yield 9.18 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. * Kane County, Ill., is offering $20 million in tax-exempt Public Building Authority revenue bonds through underwriters led by First Chicago Capital Markets. Yields range from 4.8 percent in 1992 to 6.5 percent in 2003. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's. * MDU Resources Group, Bismarck, N.D., is offering $50 million in 9 1/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due 2006 at 99.785 to yield 9.152 percent through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The bonds are nonrefundable for five years and are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. * Mead Corp., Dayton, Ohio, is offering $100 million in 8 1/2 percent noncallable notes due 1996 at 99.834 to yield 8.55 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P. * State of Washington, the Department of Ecology, through the Department of General Administration, is offering $78.8 million in certificates of participation with a maximum yield of 7 percent for an issue due 2012 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Yields on short maturities range from 6.1 percent in 1998 to 6.95 percent in 2006. The yield on certificates due in 2016 is about 6.97 percent. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P. Preferred * PNC Financial Corp., a Pittsburgh-based bank holding company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to six million shares of preferred stock. Common Stock * Fruit of the Loom Inc., Chicago, is offering 12.75 million common shares at $14.25 a share through First Boston Corp. Of the shares involved, 7.5 million are being offered by the company and the rest by certain shareholders. Proceeds from the company's sale of shares will be used to reduce bank debt.

title: Angels' Polonia Draws Strength From Taunts
description: Luis Polonia is a fan favorite at Yankee Stadium, but not the kind who receives adulation. Whenever Polonia bats for the California Angels, he is a player opposing fans enjoy berating. That kind of favorite.

title: South African Drama
description: The photographer caught Winnie Mandela as she left the court after her conviction for kidnapping. She was smiling exuberantly, as if she had just won a great victory. Behind her was Nelson Mandela, eyes downcast, looking stricken and exhausted.

title: U.S. Begins Relief Flights to Bangladesh
description: They came from the southeast, just as the cyclone had come: suddenly, noisily and with a tremendous wind that knocked children over and sent clothing flying in every direction.

title: The Unmaking of a Multimillion Rematch, From Ruddock's Side
description: The way Murad Muhammad tells it, his fighter, Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, precipitated the cancellation on Wednesday night of the June 28 Mike Tyson-Ruddock rematch at the Mirage in Las Vegas, Nev. The change clears the way for a world heavyweight title fight between Tyson and the champion Evander Holyfield, perhaps this fall.

title: At the Movies
description: Filming Madonna

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., an operator of movie theaters, will sell eight theaters, with 45 total screens, to Carmike Cinemas Inc., Columbus, Ga. Terms were not disclosed. * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, said its clinical products division would build a multipurpose facility in Strasbourg, France. * Fifth Third Bancorp Inc., Cincinnati, will acquire Pinnacle Bancorp Inc., Middletown, Ohio, in a merger valuing each Pinnacle share at $12.50 to $15. * Fingerhut Cos., Minnetonka, Minn., a catalogue merchandiser, and Avon Products Inc. said they planned a joint venture under which Avon's sales representatives would have access to merchandise from two Fingerhut units. Fingerhut is a an affiliate of Primerica.

title: The Story As Lived by Cindy Howe
description: SHE had pretended she was sleeping. Her husband stirred in bed beside her, then he rose and went down the stairs to the living room. Quietly, she followed him. She saw him pull from behind a cabinet a small packet of cocaine. As he was about to pinch some of the contents, he looked up.

title: Pohl, as Expected, Says He Will Quit Bank Post
description: Karl Otto Pohl, Europe's most powerful financial leader and the architect of a strong German mark, announced today that he would resign as president of the Bundesbank in October.

title: Professor, Ousted on Sex Charge, Disputes Policy
description: A former drama professor at Bennington College who was accused of sexual harassment by a student is suing the college, accusing its administration of trampling on his rights when he was dismissed last year.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Parker's Legacy

title: First Fidelity Sale
description: Shareholders of First Fidelity Bancorp approved an agreement to sell 13.3 percent of the company to Banco Santander of Spain for more than $220 million. Under the agreement, which is subject to approval by the Federal Reserve Board, Banco Santander would be able to increase its ownership in New Jersey's largest bank to 23.5 percent over the next four years. The plan calls for Banco Santander to buy 9.5 million shares of newly issued common stock for more than $220 million, and to be issued warrants to buy another 9.5 million shares over the next four years at an exercise price of $25.50 a share. First Fidelity shares gained 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $26.

title: Early Operas
description: The Mannes Camerata is to perform Marco da Gagliano's opera "La Dafne" (1608) and Claudio Monteverdi's pastoral ballet "Tirsi e Clori" (1615) at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan, tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock. The performance features singers and musicians who are students at the Mannes College, including a period-instrument orchestra that is to be conducted from the harpsichord by Bradley Brookshire. Dorothy Olsson is the choreographer of the Monteverdi. The works are to be repeated on Sunday at 4 and 7 P.M. Tickets are $12 to $15. Information: (212) 496-8524.

title: Japanese Parent to Aid Bridgestone/Firestone
description: The Japanese parent of Bridgestone/ Firestone Inc. said today that it would inject $1.4 billion into the debt-ridden United States tire maker.

title: Horizon Air's Dornier Deal
description: Horizon Air, a regional carrier in the Northwest, said it would buy up to 60 new aircraft from Dornier Luftfahrt G.m.b.H. of Germany. The deal includes firm orders for 35 Dornier 328 turboprop aircraft valued at about $260 million, and options for another 25 planes. Delivery is to begin in mid-1993 and continue through 1997.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary column of The Living Section on Wednesday referred incorrectly to a sign in the window of the Lorango Restaurant. It read: "Come Celebrate Cinco de Mayo With Us on May 3d." The column also misstated the restaurant's address. It is 323 Third Avenue (at 24th Street).

title: Japan Trade Surplus Up
description: Japan's trade surplus grew in April for the fourth consecutive month, swelling by 79.3 percent, to $6.31 billion, from the period a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The surplus with the United States in April shrank 7.2 percent from a year earlier, to $2.26 billion, but the surplus with Europe and Asia widened sharply. Over all, exports totaled $24.07 billion, up 9.8 percent from April 1990.

title: Critic's Notebook; 'Jungle Fever' Sweeps Cannes
description: FOR the first time since it began just a week ago, the 44th Cannes International Film Festival has one clearly popular favorite for the Palme d'Or, the festival's top prize. It is Spike Lee's "Jungle Fever," which was shown here on Thursday night in the presence of Mr. Lee; two of his stars, Wesley Snipes and Anthony Quinn, and Stevie Wonder, who composed the film's original music and title song.

title: Review/Film; Cassavetes, Rowlands And the Play Within
description: "Opening Night" could be described as John Cassavetes's version of "All About Eve" if Mr. Cassavetes were the sort to be strongly influenced by the work of other film makers, which he most certainly is not. Like the characters who ramble amiably through this sprawling, funny, emotionally raw 1978 film -- which has a style that's of a piece with the director's other long films of the 70's, among them "Minnie and Moskowitz" (1971), "A Woman Under the Influence" (1974) and "The Killing of a Chinese Bookie" (1976) -- Mr. Cassavetes displays a remarkably free-spirited point of view.

title: N.Y.U. President Compares Goals and Progress in His Tenure
description: Dr. John Brademas said farewell to 6,500 graduates, and to the university he has led for 10 years, in his commencement address yesterday in Washington Square Park.

title: Daniel A. Bailey, Accounting Executive, 49
description: Daniel A. Bailey, a senior audit partner at Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, died on Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 49 years old and lived in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Saturn Wrinkle On New-Car Sales
description: The Saturn Corporation said that cars it would use to replace 1,100 recalled vehicles would be counted as new-car sales. Saturn will not report how many of the replacement vehicles will be among the new-car sales reported by its parent company, the General Motors Corporation, during the next month or so, according to a Saturn spokesman, Mark Tanner. "We're not going to know that breakout," Mr. Tanner said. If supplied over a month's time, 1,100 vehicles would raise Saturn sales for that month by about one-fifth.

title: Daughter of India's Mean Streets Battles City Hall
description: Mamata Bannerjee is riding around south Calcutta in a small car stuffed with campaign workers looking for her election rally. Ignoring her loyal but inexperienced staff, she flags down wilted bystanders to ask directions. The mercury is nosing toward 100, and it's just as well that nobody around here has heard of the temperature-humidity index.

title: Baseball Broadcasts And the Bottom Line
description: Saturday afternoon network baseball -- you remember that, don't you? -- returns to CBS tomorrow at 3 P.M. when the Mets play the Dodgers in Los Angeles. The last CBS Occasional Game of the Week was on Sunday, May 5. The last Saturday game on CBS popped up on April 27.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Kurds Outline Their Demands for More Autonomy
description: With thousands of Kurds still seeking American protection in Iraq, Kurdish leaders are pressing Baghdad for enough autonomy to encourage the refugees to return home, say exiled members of opposition groups.

title: Review/Theater; Sam Shepard Returns, On War and Machismo
description: SAM SHEPARD has been away from the New York theater for only six years -- since the epic "Lie of the Mind" -- but "States of Shock," his new play at the American Place, could lead you to believe he has been hibernating since his East Village emergence in the Vietnam era. "States of Shock" is in its own elliptical way an antiwar play, written with the earnest -- one might even say quaint -- conviction that the stage is still an effective platform for political dissent and mobilizing public opinion. Whether or not one agrees with Mr. Shepard's contrary views about recent history, his ingenuous faith in the theater is uplifting. "States of Shock" is less so.

title: Japan's Top Securities Firms Report a Big Drop in Profits
description: Japan's major securities houses today reported their worst earnings in years, reflecting last year's stock market crash and a near-cessation in new issues of securities.

title: Twila L. Cavert, 96; Advocate for Women
description: Twila Lytton Cavert, an educator who was an early advocate of higher status for women in church affairs, died on Tuesday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 96 years old.

title: July Retirement Set At Fairchild Industries
description: Emanuel Fthenakis, a pioneer in missile and space technology, announced his retirement yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the Fairchild Corporation and as the chairman and chief executive of its Fairchild Industries subsidiary. His retirement takes effect July 1.

title: Chrysler Plans New Small Car
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to build a new model small car here and expects to make a profit on it. The company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said in a speech at the company's annual shareholders meeting on the loading dock of Chrysler's Belvidere assembly plant that the "PL" car would replace the big, dated cars made here now. He said production of the "PL" would start in late 1993 for the 1994 model year.

title: Our Towns
description: Final exams were but 46 hours away and for many of these college students entry into the real world loomed just beyond. But there they were, three dozen young men and women, wearing their grungies, hair pinned up, work gloves on, favorite baseball caps firmly seated, hard at work in the dirt of downtown White Plains.

title: District Map For Council Changes Little
description: The panel drawing 51 new City Council districts for New York City released a final proposal yesterday that is little changed from previous versions. A few incumbents opposed the changes, while many members of minorities said the plan was not changed enough.

title: Mideast Geography Lessons
description: "We've learned in the modern age, geography cannot guarantee security and security does not come from military power alone."

title: Who's Left and Who's Right in Soviet Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Things a Queen Can't Do
description: There is much that separates the Queen of England from the rest of humanity. Her money, for instance. Her houses. Her crowns. And her refusal to eat in public. A Queen of England can so refuse. A President of the United States wouldn't dare.

title: INSIDE
description: 1 Dead, 29 Hurt in Mall Fire A cigarette tossed into fake flowers sparked a blaze that raged through a Long Island shopping mall. Page B1.

title: A Mix-and-Match Lineup Suits Mets for the Time Being
description: Some players, eager to get on to Los Angeles for the weekend series, slid into suits and splashed on cologne in front of their lockers. Others, lingering over the details of the game, sat on stools draining last cups of coffee.

title: BUSH AIDES PUSH STATE GUN CASES INTO U.S. COURTS
description: The Bush Administration is establishing a system to have as many criminal cases as possible prosecuted in Federal courts rather than state courts when the cases involve guns, because prison sentences are generally much tougher in the Federal system.

title: A Service Is Dropped By Prodigy
description: Prodigy, which provides computerized services to nearly a million subscribers, dropped its grocery shopping service on Wednesday in a cost-cutting move that is part of its continuing attempt to become profitable after three years of operation.

title: J.W.T. Obtains Supercuts Job
description: The San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson announced yesterday that it had been awarded the $6 million account for Supercuts Inc., San Rafael, Calif.

title: AIDS Virus Found in 2 Orthopedic Surgeons
description: A survey of 3,420 orthopedic surgeons, conducted to help learn the risk of AIDS infection between doctors and patients, has found that two were infected with the virus, Federal health officials reported today.

title: AIDS Fighter's Spirit Is Recalled
description: A woman's scared voice told of Iris De La Cruz, of the way she commanded attention, always bursting into rooms, turning an outsider into a friend with a blunt remark, confronting people who looked at her and her struggle -- with drugs and prostitution and finally with AIDS -- as shameful, and telling them she was not ashamed.

title: 2 Views of Henry Miller, One Harsh and One Not
description: Henry Miller A Life By Robert Ferguson Illustrated. 397 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95. The Happiest Man Alive A Biography of Henry Miller By Mary V. Dearborn Illustrated. 368 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Ex-Celtic Enters Plea
description: CHARLES SMITH, a former guard with the Boston Celtics, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Suffolk Superior Court in Boston to charges in connection with the hit-and-run deaths of two Boston University students on March 22. Smith has been charged with two counts of vehicular manslaughter (driving to endanger and leaving the scene of an accident). He was arrested a mile away from the scene of the accident. . . . A county criminal court judge in Dallas yesterday set July 8 as the trial date for ROY TARPLEY of the Dallas Mavericks on his felony charge of driving while intoxicated on March 30. . . . DERRICK COLEMAN of the Nets, who was voted the National Basketball Association rookie of the year last week, yesterday was a unanimous choice on the all-rookie team, as selected without regard to players' positions by the league's 27 coaches. The other selections are LIONEL SIMMONS of Sacramento; DEE BROWN of Boston, KENDALL GILL of Charlotte and DENNIS SCOTT of Orlando.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Information Services Corp., New York, a subsidiary of American Express Co., named Raymond L. Mobley president of its integrated systems technologies unit. * Federal Paper Board Co., Montvale, N.J., named William R. Snelling vice president of bleached paperboard and recycled paperboards sales and packaging grades. * NCNB Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a bank holding company, named Brian F. Meltsner vice president and national advertising manager in marketing services. * Northeastern Bank of Pennsylvania, Scranton, Pa., an affiliate of PNC Financial Corp., named Joseph C. Guyaux president. * Northern Telecom Ltd., Mississauga, Ontario, named Larry M. Speakes, a former spokesman for President Reagan, as vice president for communications. * Sizzler International Inc., Los Angeles, named Christopher R. Thomas executive vice president-finance. * Tenneco Inc., Houston, named Kenneth D. Allen senior vice president of public and governmental affairs. * Unum Corp., Portland, Me., a specialty insurance holding company, named Kevin J. Tierney senior vice president and general counsel. W. Francis Brennan was named executive vice president of the related businesses group.

title: More Economic Pain Seen for Soviets
description: The economy of the Soviet Union faces a decline in output of 10 percent, an inflation rate exceeding 100 percent and the likelihood of a "radically worse" year, American intelligence agencies said today.

title: Monteverdi Staged
description: Opera Quotannis is to present a staged version of Claudio Monteverdi's "Combattimento di Tancredi e Clorinda" at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue at 60th Street, Manhattan, tonight at 8 o'clock. The cast includes Tracey Mitchell, soprano; Thom Baker, tenor, and Ridley Chauvin, baritone, with a period-instrument orchestra to be conducted by Bart Folse. The program also includes selections from Monteverdi's "Madrigali Guerrieri et Amorosi," the collection in which "Combattimento" was first published. Tickets are $10 to $15. Information: (212) 307-7171.

title: The (Dirty) Sidewalks of New York
description: Residents, commuters and visitors moan about filth in New York City. True, the streets don't sparkle; they never did. But there's a lot less mess now than 10 years ago. Alas, there will be more again when the sanitation budget is cut. Instead of cursing the inevitable, everyone can help.

title: Edward Craven, 83, Stage and Film Actor
description: Edward Craven, a stage and film actor, died on Tuesday at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: With a Troubled Perspective, Prospering on the Edge
description: On the periphery of the rock mainstream, where bands can make a living performing at small clubs, being played on college radio stations and never appearing on the "Today" show, the members of Dinosaur Jr. are gods. Their gritty guitar-based music, played at brutally high volume onstage and given low-fi grainy production on records, has become the archetype of the independent-rock sound, influencing an entire school of peripheral periphery bands like Superchunk, Teen-Age Fan Club and Buffalo Tom.

title: Cashier Is Slain During Robbery At Gas Station
description: Joginder Singh Sehmbi came to New York City two months ago, moved in with his brother in Queens and began searching for a job. A 40-year-old civil engineer from Punjab State in India, Mr. Sehmbi finally found work as all-night cashier at a gas station a month ago, partly because New Yorkers appeared reluctant to hire a man who wore a turban, his family said.

title: Greetings From Coney Island
description: A LOT has changed at Coney Island over the years, but in one respect, at least, the windblown stretch of sand at the foot of Brooklyn remains what it has always been: one of the most gloriously seedy and wistful places on earth, washed by the sea, by the memory of something lost, and by an irresistible optimism about the future.

title: Ninth Avenue Festival
description: The 18th annual Ninth Avenue International Food Festival will take place tomorrow and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., rain or shine, in Manhattan. Some 300 kinds of food representing more than 30 countries will be sold outdoors on Ninth Avenue from 37th to 57th Street. Ruth Messinger, Manhattan Borough President, will speak at the opening ceremony at 11 A.M. tomorrow at 50th Street. On Sunday, Mayor David N. Dinkins, with members of the Ninth Avenue Association and community and civic leaders, will lead the Mayor's walk starting at 12:30 P.M. Foods to be sold includes seafood, hot dogs, six-foot heroes, Greek pastry, sausages, homemade pastas and raviolis, souvlaki, shish kebab, cotton candy, candy apples, funnel cakes, calzones, Polish pirogies and Brooklyn Lager. Information: (212) 794-2231 or (212) 581-7217.

title: A Role for Nystrom
description: The Islanders have named BOB NYSTROM, their long-time right wing, the director of amateur hockey development and community relations. Nystrom will take on an active role working directly in all facets of amateur hockey in the surrounding community, coordinating hockey clinics for players, coaches and officials involved in area youth leagues, high school leagues and colleges.

title: How Jewish Artists Found Their Place in New York
description: To a considerable degree, "Painting a Place in America" is a recapitulation of the history of early 20th-century art in New York City. In this sense, it tells a remarkable story.

title: Africans Explore Their Own Evolving Cultures
description: "Africa Explores: 20th-Century African Art" may not seem like a radical exhibition, but it is. A lot in it seems familiar. There are realistic sculptures, objects following tribal traditions, large paintings with touches of Velazquez and Jasper Johns and small paintings that combine words and images in ways suggesting Conceptual art.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Carolina Reborn

title: After 19 Years, Fletcher Resigns as Flames G.M.
description: CLIFF FLETCHER, the only general manager the Flames' franchise has ever had, stepped down from that post and as team president yesterday in Calgary and said he might move on to another National Hockey League team. DOUG RISEBROUGH will add the general manager's duties to his role as coach, while Hockey Canada president BILL HAY will take over as team president.

title: New Unemployment Claims Up Slightly in Early May
description: The number of people filing their first claims for unemployment benefits rose a slight 4,000 in the week ended May 4, to 459,000, the Labor Department said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: K. D. LANG, the country singer, is making her acting debut in "Salmonberries," a film directed by PERCY ADLON that will have its premiere in August at the Montreal World Film Festival. And the music, written by BOB TELSON with lyrics by Ms. Lang, will have its premiere on Monday at Lincoln Center.

title: Assistant Moves On
description: TIM WELSH, a Syracuse assistant the last three years, has resigned to join his father's coaching staff at Iona. His father, Jerry, became Iona's head coach in March after 22 years at Division III power Potsdam State in upstate New York. Also joining the Iona staff is JEFF RULAND, a former all-America center at the school in New Rochelle. (AP)

title: Whose Pace in Mideast?; U.S. Seeks a Quick Regional Peace Accord But Arabs and Israelis Want Slow Changes
description: In the midst of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's long negotiations on Wednesday with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, a Shamir aide began complaining about a statement made by the Saudis nine months ago.

title: Martin B. Dickson, Professor, 67
description: Martin B. Dickson, a professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton University, died on May 14 at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was 67 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Camacho, Haugen Keep It Sweet
description: Hector Camacho and Greg Haugen each resisted disparaging remarks aimed at the other today at the final news conference before their World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title rematch here Saturday night. But Haugen (28-3-1, 13 knockouts) and Camacho (39-1, 17 knockouts) each vowed to win on Saturday.

title: Dinkins and the 'Invader'; His Fear of State Control Prompts Debate: Would Fiscal Intervention Be Good or Bad?
description: For months, Mayor David N. Dinkins has said New York City must keep its budget balanced at all costs -- including cuts in city services that he calls unthinkable -- to avoid sharing control of its spending with a little- understood state board that he describes as if it were an alien invader.

title: Adjusting of Test Scores Inflames Rights Debate
description: While legislators are still struggling to defuse the issue of quotas in hiring and promotions, a new problem is complicating the debate over the civil rights bill as the House prepares to bring it to the floor for a vote.

title: Yugoslav Rivals Charge Plots to Break Up Country
description: Yugoslavia's leadership crisis took another turn today as each side in a stalemate on the governing federal council accused the other of trying to break up the country, at a time when ethnic tensions are in danger of running out of control.

title: Vacation on the Horizon As Celtics Face Elimination
description: It looks bad for the Boston Celtics.

title: Brazilian Pianist
description: Jose Carlos Cocarelli, the Brazilian pianist who won the silver medal at the Van Cliburn Competition in 1989, is to play the Berg Sonata, Chopin's 24 Preludes (Op. 28), Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Schumann (Op. 9), and Liszt's paraphrase on the Waltz from Gounod's "Faust" at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $8 to $30. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Ralph Bisdale, Lighting Artist, 46
description: Ralph Bisdale, a lighting artist and design consultant, died on Sunday at the Greenery Rehabilitation Center in Seattle. He was 46 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Housing Starts Rose by 6.2 Percent in April
description: The Government said today that builders increased construction of new homes and apartments by 6.2 percent in April, a report seen by analysts as evidence that the housing industry is making an erratic, rather than brisk, recovery from the recession.

title: Breast Implant Maker Calls Cancer Risk Small
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb company said yesterday that its breast implants covered with polyurethane foam were absolutely safe and that the risk of getting cancer from them was negligible.

title: Bridge
description: Three major title events in the United States bridge championships continued here today, with world championship honors beckoning on the horizon for all contestants. The survivors when play ends on Sunday will compete in Yokohama, Japan, in October as representatives of the United States.

title: Getting Through August When the Shrink's Away
description: On July 31, a date guaranteed to strike terror into analysands everywhere, Dr. Leo Marvin (Richard Dreyfuss) inherits a model patient. He is Bob Wiley (Bill Murray), who is polite and appreciative and likes to pay his bills ahead of time. Bob talks to himself, as well as to his goldfish. He has a set of symptoms -- fear of germs, fear of elevators, fear of sleeping unless pointed in the proper direction according to a compass -- that many a psychiatrist would kill to treat.

title: With the Royal Visit, Britain Signals a New Reality
description: The appearance of Queen Elizabeth II on Capitol Hill this morning, like her participation in the Bicentennial celebrations in 1976, had the unmistakable whiff of history about it. But it also had a practical, modern purpose: to symbolize and shore up the enduring 20th-century alliance between the two countries, by emphasizing the values, traditions and experiences they share, the latter most recently in the Persian Gulf.

title: Voicing Hope, Baker Ends Mideast Trip
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ended his fourth Middle East mission in two months today projecting optimism, even as he acknowledged that in two days of talks here he had not resolved the principal disagreements between Israel and Syria over how a Middle East peace conference could be convened.

title: Stolen Bikes Join War on Pollution
description: Nelson Galligan used to drive a smog-spewing pickup to work. Now he pedals a bicycle to his job. The environment is healthier for it. So is Mr. Galligan.

title: Dow Climbs 28.63 Points, To 2,894.01
description: Buyers moved back into the stock market yesterday to pick up a few bargains, with Wall Street apparently concluding that it had overreacted the day before to the bad news from Compaq Computer.

title: Debt Issue By Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday priced $400 million in floating-rate certificates backed by loans of its auto dealers, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Congressional Inquiry Criticizes Navy's Proposal on Base Closings
description: Congressional investigators said today that the Navy had underestimated the number of sites that could be closed to save money and had not fully explained why they chose the bases they did.

title: Miscellany
description: * C&S/Sovran Corp., Atlanta, a bank holding concern that says it has $50 billion in assets, has narrowed its advertising account review to three agencies: DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, GSD&M, Austin, Tex., and Young & Rubicam, New York. The company said it has not included the two incumbent agencies, the Atlanta office of Ogilvy & Mather and Earle Palmer Brown/Lawler Ballard, Norfolk, Va. The two incumbents created campaigns for C&S and Sovran respectively before they merged in September.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sanchez Rolls to Quarterfinal Ninth-seeded Emilio Sanchez, yet to lose a set at this year's Italian Open, rolled into the quarterfinals yesterday in Rome with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Wayne Ferreira of South Africa. Sanchez will play Richard Fromberg of Australia, who reached the quarterfinals by beating Cristiano Caratti of Italy, 7-5, 6-0. Fromberg, after trailing by 5-1 in the first set, reeled off 12 straight games. (AP) Graf Romps in Berlin: In a match that lasted only 44 minutes, top-seeded Steffi Graf routed Elena Brioukhovets of the Soviet Union, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the Lufthansa Open in Berlin. An American, Ginger Helgeson, upset eighth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-3, and moved into the quarterfinals, along with Jana Novotna and Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia. (AP) CYCLING Aldag Takes Mountain Stage Rolf Aldag of Germany and the Swiss team Helvetia won by 6 feet from Greg Oravetz of Huntington Beach, Calif., and the American Coors Light team in yesterday's 175-mile mountain stage of the Tour Du Pont raced from Hot Springs, Va., to Winchester, Va.
