Sean Kelly of Ireland and the Dutch team PDM finished third. Aldag also won Sunday's circuit race in Arlington, Va. Three stages remain in the race. GOLF 2 in Lead in Tallahassee Lenore Rittenhouse birdied the final two holes yesterday to finish with a six-under-par 66 and a share of the first-round lead with Lisa Walters in the $1.1 million Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla. Walters, who has never won a tournament in eight years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour, matched her career-best round while Rittenhouse was just one stroke off her best round in quest of her second career victory. (AP) Senior Amateur Winner: Don Edwards of Winged Foot, N.Y., shot a 73 yesterday at the Hackensack Golf Club in Oradell, N.J., for a 36-hole total of three-over-par 147 to win the Metropolitan Golf Association Senior Championship by one stroke over Joe D'Auria of Rotella, N.Y. COLLEGE BASEBALL Fordham Gains in Tournament Pete DeLuca, Fordham's junior first baseman, got four hits, including a home run, and knocked in four runs to lift the Rams over Northeastern, 14-6, yesterday in Orono, Me.

title: Breathing Room For Businessland
description: Businessland Inc., the struggling computer retailer, said that the ITT Corporation had agreed to continue to finance Businessland's inventory through the end of June. The San Jose, Calif., retailer said the brief reprieve would allow it to continue shipping products of Apple Computer Inc. and the Compaq Computer Corporation without interruption. But it must still find a source of financing beginning in July.

title: Labor Party Wins Welsh Seat In Conservatives' Stronghold
description: The Labor Party defeated the governing party in a by-election Thursday in the Welsh district of Monmouth, which had been controlled by the Conservatives for 25 years.

title: Bank Loans Still Tight But Less So
description: The ability of business borrowers to get loans from banks worsened in the latest three months but the credit-tightening was "considerably less" than in the preceding quarters, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Searing at 60

title: Roger N. Metz, Physics Professor, 52
description: Roger N. Metz, a professor of physics at Colby College in Waterville, Me., died Tuesday at a hospital in Cleveland. He was 52 years old and lived in Fairfield, Me.

title: But Another Mideast Door Opens
description: Secretary of State James Baker certainly seems to have failed to achieve the goals with which he began his shuttle diplomacy two months ago. The prospects of a Mideast peace conference, despite his fourth try, remain tangled in differences between Israel and Syria.

title: Coke in Indonesia
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it plans to open a bottling company in Indonesia to take advantage of increasing demand for soft drinks there. Coke will own 49 percent of the new venture, the Coca-Cola Tirtalina Bottling Company, a joint venture with the Tirtalina Group of Indonesia. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Coke has been available in Indonesia since 1932. The company said that the annual per capita consumption of Coke products by Indonesia's 182 million people was four servings, compared with 292 servings in the United States. Coke also announced preliminary plans to form a second joint venture company with the Indonesian Pan Java Group.

title: Archdiocese Will Close a Bronx High School
description: After struggling for years with a mounting deficit and a shrinking enrollment, St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School in the Bronx will be closed at the end of June, Roman Catholic officials said yesterday.

title: Restaurants
description: Somebody once postulated that there are only two anchovies in the world and that they simply get passed uneaten from plate to plate. If that is true, there is now only one. The freebie nibbles at Provence, like the smoked salmon garnished with miniature nicoise olives and anchovy, are too delicious to pass up. I ate one of the fuzzy little fellows.

title: San Diego Gas Merger Canceled
description: The Southern California Edison Company and the San Diego Gas and Electric Company said that they had canceled their merger agreement, eight days after California regulators rejected the deal on the ground that it was anti-competitive. Southern California Edison, a unit of the SCEcorp, said that it had reviewed the California Public Utilities Commission's rejection of the merger and decided not to appeal.

title: What Can Save New York City? Let Them Count the Ways
description: The Op-Ed page this week asked New Yorkers to suggest several ways to help the city out of its crisis. Jill M. Considine State Superintendent of Banks

title: New York Workers Accept a Film Pact, Ending a Shutdown
description: Reversing an earlier vote, members of a film-crafts union local accepted an accord yesterday with leading Hollywood producers to end a bitter stalemate that had virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City since November.

title: Bolar Agrees to Compensate Stockholders
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $20 million to thousands of stockholders to make up for losses they incurred when the company's share price fell after Bolar was accused of engaging in fraudulent practices to obtain approval of its products.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Wednesday with a picture from The Associated Press about the rescue of a man from a burning building in Manhattan misidentified the firefighter shown. He was Kevin Shea, not Patrick Barr. The rescued man was later identified as Peter Lewis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Once you see the ticket and you hear the number matches, you just completely lose track of yourself, Your mind just is not there. The way I was acting, I wonder if there was some chemical on that ticket they handed me." -- Jesus Molina of the Bronx, victim of a lottery scam. [ B4:2. ]

title: DONORS TO PARTIES SIDESTEPPED RULES
description: Wealthy individuals, corporations and labor unions that are prohibited from giving large sums to political campaigns instead donated more than $25 million to the Republican and Democratic parties in 1990, a new study says.

title: 13 Reported Killed In Rioting and Fire At Mexican Prison
description: At least 13 people were killed and as many as 11 injured tonight in a riot and fire at a federal jail in the border city across from Brownsville, Tex., officials in the United States and a news agency reported.

title: Lumber Output Down
description: Lumber production and shipments fell in 12 Western states last week, but orders increased, a trade association reported. The Western Wood Products Association said that lumber production was 403 million board feet in the week, 8 million less than in the previous week. But orders were 463 million board feet, 45 million more than in the previous week. Shipments were reported at 392 million feet, a decline of 50 million feet.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about some state employment agencies that have adjusted aptitude-test scores to help black and Hispanic job applicants misstated a position of the United States Labor Department. The department is considering asking states to stop using the test, but has not done so.

title: Abortion Ban, Sought by Church, Is Rejected by Polish Parliament
description: The Polish Parliament today rejected legislation that would have banned abortions, dealing the Roman Catholic Church here its first political setback since the fall of Communism in 1989.

title: Dentist Who Avoided Prison Pleads Guilty to New Charge
description: Dr. Marsha Cohen is a 36-year-old dentist and former heroin addict who avoided most of her prison term for burglary last year by convincing prison authorities that she was through with drugs and would devote her life to treating AIDS victims' teeth.

title: Record Profit for Fay's
description: Fay's Inc., a regional drugstore chain, said today that its earnings rose by 24.3 percent, to a record $1.84 million, or 12 cents a share, in the first quarter, from $1.48 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. But the company took a charge of $574,000 in the first quarter of 1990 to retire some of its long-term debt, dropping its earnings in that period to $902,000, or 6 cents a share, officials said. Sales for the first quarter this year were $177.2 million, up 15.6 percent from $153.2 million a year ago. Fay's operates nearly 250 drugstores in New York, Pennsylvania, New Hampshire and Vermont, plus 27 Wheels Discount Auto Supply stores and 26 Paper Cutter stationery stores.

title: Doesn't Take Much for Mariners to Humble Yanks
description: Randy Johnson got into trouble three times against the Yankees last night, but slithered away from danger in each inning by tossing nasty breaking balls and 97-mile-an-hour fastballs.

title: Guidepost; Winter Garb Cools It
description: Now is the time to store furs, shearlings and woolens. Before storage, repair rips, tears and loose linings, and replace missing buttons. Here are some tips on how to keep garments at their best.

title: Often-Ravenous Hanson Takes a Taste of I.C.I.
description: As politicians, union leaders and management prepared to fight a possible takeover of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., investors waited today to see if I.C.I., Britain's third-largest company, would become the next and largest course for Hanson P.L.C., a conglomerate that has swallowed a slew of American and British corporations.

title: Music in Review
description: New Music Consort Merkin Concert Hall 129 West 67th Street

title: Washington Times Editor Resigns, But Will Stay On to Write Articles
description: Arnaud de Borchgrave, editor in chief of The Washington Times for the past six years, is relinquishing editorial control of the newspaper and will be suceeded by Wesley Pruden, the managing editor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Sport Camps Offer Winning Skills
description: Adult golf and tennis players across the country are increasingly improving their strokes and serves by combining vacations with a concentrated period of instruction at camps devoted exclusively to their favorite sport.

title: New Haven Youth Charged in Slaying of Student at Yale
description: A 16-year-old boy was arrested Thursday night and ordered held on $1 million bond today in the shooting death of a Yale University student on campus in February, apparently during a robbery.

title: Music in Review
description: Concerto Gala Carnegie Hall

title: REPORTER ORDERED TO REVEAL SOURCE
description: The District of Columbia Court of Appeals today ordered a Washington Post reporter to disclose her source of information about an unsuccessful drug raid or be jailed for contempt.

title: Trail Blazers Must Contend With the Older Lakers' Mystique
description: By almost any standards that measure age in professional basketball, the Los Angeles Lakers are growing older.

title: Review/Film; Andrew Dice Clay Essence: Misogyny, Insult and Sex
description: Batting slightly higher than his previous zero on the big screen, Andrew Dice Clay can at least be seen in his natural element in "Dice Rules," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters (after having been dropped by the Loews chain.) This concert film finds him at Madison Square Garden, presiding over fist-waving, slogan-chanting fans who explode with enthusiasm every time Mr. Clay says something insulting, imbecilic or obscene (and nothing he says is otherwise). This audience even enjoys being personally insulted by Mr. Clay, for whom "Shut up, stupid" is a favorite witticism.

title: Taylor Faults Young on Giant Loss
description: Lawrence Taylor, who tends to speak as well as play with reckless abandon, yesterday painted a bleak picture of life on the Giants without Bill Parcells as head coach.

title: Ex-Justice Brennan Acknowledges Cash Gifts
description: Former Justice William J. Brennan Jr. has disclosed that he and his wife received $20,000 in cash gifts last year from a wealthy real estate developer who also forgave $120,000 of a $170,400 mortgage on the Brennans' condominium apartment.

title: Apple Is Quiet On Job Cuts
description: Apple Computer Inc. today refused to confirm or deny a published report that it was considering laying off up to 12 percent of its work force of 15,600. A spokesman, Christopher Escher, said the computer maker was exploring ways to offset its lower profit margins by reducing operating expenses, but that he could not speculate as to what form the reductions might take.

title: Coffey Helps Penguins Show Their Worth
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins, who may be for sale, might be worth a little more tonight than they were this morning.

title: The Day the Chickens Stood Still
description: For horse-racing enthusiasts, the first Saturday of May ushers in spring with the Kentucky Derby.

title: St. Luke's Gives Care to the Medically Needy
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Ends Dispute on Memorial to Pupils
description: Parents and school officials have tentatively agreed on a memorial to nine schoolchildren killed when tornado-like winds blew down a school cafeteria wall a year and a half ago.

title: F.H.A. Posted Big Loss in '89
description: The Federal Housing Administration suffered another multibillion-dollar loss in 1989 and its books are in such poor shape that the loss may be greater than indicated, Government auditors said today.

title: Patents; A Container to Store Radioactive Waste
description: Alternative Technologies for Waste Inc., a family-owned research concern in Goleta, Calif., has patented a new container and method for storing low-level radioactive waste.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article by The Associated Press on Tuesday in which Len Dykstra of the Philadelphia Phillies discussed his recent car accident misstated his blood-alcohol level that night. According to the police in Radnor Township, Pa., it was 0.179 percent; the legal limit is 0.10 percent.

title: Pan Am Posts Wider Loss In Quarter
description: The Pan Am Corporation, battered by high fuel costs and a drop in traffic during the Persian Gulf war, said yesterday that it lost $249.2 million in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $190.7 million a year earlier.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Review/Film; A Football Star's Debut With Drug-Dealing Bikers
description: Except for his blond hair, Brian Bosworth, the football star turned movie actor who makes his film debut in "Stone Cold," is almost a dead ringer for the young Burt Reynolds. Mr. Bosworth has the same carved-in-granite facial bones, the same deep-set squint that seems directed toward a private, prehistoric memory, the same aura of suppressed intelligence struggling below the pumped-up macho facade.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT DROPPED IN MARCH TO AN 8-YEAR LOW
description: A jump in exports and sinking demand for imports narrowed the nation's trade deficit in March to $4.05 billion, the smallest monthly imbalance in almost eight years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Auto Racer's Latest Tools: Diet and Exercise
description: When Emerson Fittipaldi won the 1989 Indianapolis 500 in a wheel-banging duel with Al Unser Jr., he displayed a competitive hunger not often seen in a driver in his 40's. Even now, as he approaches his eighth Indy 500 with two world championships and an Indy-car title to his credit, Fittipaldi still drives as if he is in his 20's. Maybe that is because, with his diet and exercise regimen, he feels as young as his opposition.

title: Mets for Sale? It's an Error
description: Fred Wilpon, who shares ownership of the Mets with Nelson Doubleday, said early this morning that a report that the team was up for sale was "totally erroneous."

title: Sports of The Times; It's Fun Playing The Numbers
description: When Mitch Williams was traded to the Phillies this spring, the first thing he did was to start coveting John Kruk's number. Anybody could see that Williams was not a 29, and besides, his wife had all that gold jewelry with 28 on it.

title: Harvey E. Brazer, 68, Professor of Economics
description: Harvey E. Brazer, professor emeritus of economics at the University of Michigan and a United States Treasury official in the Kennedy Administration, died Wednesday of cancer. He was 68 years old.

title: Beating Victim Stopped Again
description: Sheriff's officers stopped the motorist whose beating by police officers two months ago was videotaped The motorist, Rodney G. King, was stopped Saturday by a sheriff's deputy while driving in Santa Fe Springs for an expired registration on his car. He was not cited, a sheriff's spokesman said.

title: Just a Day on the Course: Ace, Record and the Lead
description: With a flurry of spectacular shots accented by a hole-in-one, Kenny Perry shot a course record eight-under-par 63 today to take a three-shot lead after two rounds of the Memorial Tournament.

title: Okla. St. Suspension
description: Oklahoma State's acclaimed wrestling coach, JOE SEA, who has admitted what he considers a couple of trivial N.C.A.A. violations, was suspended by athletic director JIM GARNER yesterday. Sea immediately complained that Garner had made him a sacrificial lamb to avoid a possible ban on the wrestling program.

title: Quest for Third Title Alive as Pistons Eliminate Celtics
description: The Detroit Pistons have championship character and they needed all of it to win tonight.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sabatini Upset in Berlin

title: Los Angeles Loosening Its Grip on Water Rights
description: Water is the ultimate source of growth and political power in the arid West, and probably no place has sought it with more ruthlessness than Los Angeles.

title: Deadline Extended on Spruce Falls
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation extended until June 30 the deadline for an agreement that would turn its 50.5 percent owned Canadian newsprint operation over to employees.

title: Separate Ethnic Worlds Grow on Campus
description: Sergio Perez lives in an off-campus apartment with other Chicano students at the University of California at Berkeley. A senior, he is majoring in Chicano studies, and participating in bilingual commencement exercises reserved for Chicano and Latino students.

title: Dollar's Rise Lifts Notes and Bonds
description: A big jump in the value of the dollar had a salutary impact in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose on the news.

title: Patents; A Machine to Monitor Cholesterol in Bakeries
description: Using principles underlying advanced medical imaging systems, a Massachusetts company has patented a machine to measure the fats, oils and moisture in baked goods as they come off the assembly line.

title: Auburn's New Coach Has Big Shoes to Fill
description: HARVEY GLANCE, who won a gold medal in the 400-meter relay at the 1976 Olympics, has been named to replace MEL ROSEN as head track coach at Auburn when Rosen steps aside later this year to coach the United States Olympic team. Glance, who has been helping Rosen since September, knows he has a tough act to follow. One of Rosen's former athletes won 4 National Collegiate Athletic Association and 14 Southeastern Conference championships. His name was Harvey Glance. (AP)

title: Put On a Prettier Face
description: You buy a vivid red lipstick and later decide the color is too dark for you. Now, using one of a new group of cosmetics, you can make the lipstick more to your liking.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 29 about the Army's program to incinerate chemical weapons placed Johnston Atoll incorrectly, and an article on Jan. 26, 1990, about Kilauea Volcano placed Hawaii incorrectly in some copies. A recent letter from a geographer points out that both are in the North Pacific, not the South Pacific.

title: Samuel R. Green, Microbiologist, 71
description: Dr. Samuel R. Green, a microbiologist and enzymologist, died on Thursday at the Community Medical Center in Toms River, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Toms River.

title: In the Nation;
description: Three cheers for the House Appropriations Subcommittee, which got its back up this week and voted to scuttle NASA's grandiose space-station program. That will save $2 billion immediately and $118 billion or more over the next three decades.

title: France, Where the Center Holds
description: During the 1981 elections, which brought the Socialists to power, one of their stars, Lionel Jospin, said, "The political center in France is like the Bermuda Triangle. Whoever approaches it disappears."

title: Egypt to Get an I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $372 million loan for Egypt to help that country carry out tough economic reforms. The credit agreement, reached after three years of negotiations, is expected to lead to a steep reduction in Egypt's $35 billion in foreign debt.

title: New York Ethics Law Leads Local Officials to Quit Posts
description: Scores of municipal officials across New York State are resigning their positions on public boards and authorities rather than filing extensive financial disclosure reports required by a new state ethics law.

title: Once Risk Arbitrager, Now S.E.C. Regulator
description: William H. Heyman, who until recently headed the risk arbitrage department at Smith Barney Inc., was named yesterday as the new director of the market regulation division at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Arthur L. Green, 62, Leader of Rights Panel
description: Arthur L. Green, former director of the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities, died on Thursday in Atlanta on a business trip. He was 62 years old and lived in Manchester, Conn.

title: In Bad Company: Censorship in the Gulf War; An Unwelcome Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brooklyn High School Starts on a Long Climb Back
description: Eastern District High School in Brooklyn is saddled with a reputation for academic futility and sporadic mayhem. Long known for turning out more dropouts than graduates, the school saw its notoriety crowned a year ago with a destructive rampage by 200 students.

title: Generic Drug Guilty Plea
description: A former employee of Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. pleaded guilty today to submitting falsified test results to the Food and Drug Administration to win approval for the company's generic drugs.

title: Queen in Florida for Cruise and a Knighting
description: Queen Elizabeth II flew from Washington to Miami aboard a chartered Concorde jet today and visited an inner-city school and met with a 101-year-old environmentalist.

title: A New Chief Executive Is Named at Courtaulds
description: Courtaulds P.L.C., the international specialty industrial materials group, has appointed Sipko Huismans chief executive, effective Aug. 1.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY TO SEEK $1 BILLION IN A NEW TAX PLAN
description: Legislative leaders agreed today on $1 billion in new taxes as they struggled to fashion a budget now certain to be the latest in the state's history. Among the new taxes would be $150 million in corporate taxes, as well as taxes on petroleum products that could add as much as 4 cents a gallon to the price of gasoline.

title: Bush May Send Baker Back to Mideast
description: Despite four inconclusive trips to the Middle East by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, President Bush said today that there was "real cause for optimism" about the regional peace process and left the door open for a fifth round of shuttle diplomacy.

title: Lightning Kills 1 and Hurts 9 At a Washington Prep School
description: One person was killed and at least nine injured this afternoon at St. Albans preparatory school when lightning struck a tree that they had been using as shelter during a thunderstorm.

title: John F. Chapman, 88, Business Review Editor
description: John Forrest Chapman, a business magazine editor and a former executive editor of The Harvard Business Review, died Thursday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Key Rates
Education Reform vs. Civil Rights Agendas
description: The Achilles' heel of education renewal is the lack of real-world incentives for young Americans to excel in school. Creating such incentives without triggering charges of discrimination is harder still.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "My objection is that I'm a volunteer. I'm not elected and I'm not paid. I wasn't going to sacrifice my privacy for the so-called privilege of giving up my family time and my free time." -- Christopher H. Brown, who quit the Niagara Falls library board over a financial-disclosure law. [ 1:2. ]

title: OPPOSITION OFFICE IN MOSCOW BOMBED
description: A powerful blast wrecked the headquarters of the Soviet Union's leading anti-Communist opposition movement on Thursday night, and leaders of the group today described the explosion as an act of political terrorism.

title: 3 Die of AIDS After Getting Organs From a Man Infected With the Virus
description: Three people have died of AIDS after receiving organ transplants from a Virginia man infected with the AIDS virus, setting off a search for nearly 50 others who may have received his tissues and organs, Federal health officials said here today.

title: A $1 Million Fine for Manischewitz
description: The B. Manischewitz Company was given a $1 million fine by United States District Judge Harold Ackerman for conspiring to fix the price of Passover matzohs. Manischewitz had pleaded no contest to a criminal indictment last month, saying it could not defend charges it conspired to fix prices from 1981 to at least April 1986.

title: Mets Reveling in California Hospitality
description: The fans, notorious for their early exits, didn't have to feel guilty about the exodus that got under way at Dodger Stadium tonight in the top of the eighth inning.

title: Submarine Award Is Held Up Again
description: A Federal judge extended for 10 more days an order blocking construction of the nation's second Seawolf nuclear submarine. United States District Judge Robert G. Doumar made the announcement while hearing arguments regarding the Seawolf contract awarded May 3 by the Navy.

title: Igal Roodenko Memorial
description: A memorial service for Igal Roodenko, a former chairman of the War Resisters League and a longtime antiwar protester, is at 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Washington Square United Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street in Manhattan. Mr. Roodenko died on April 28 at the age of 74.

title: Thon's Single Puts Phillies On Top
description: Dickie Thon's run-scoring single with two outs in the 16th inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Ninth Avenue Food Festival: Ninth Avenue between 37th and 57th Streets will be closed today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Dow Drops by 7.38; Loss for Week at 33.54
description: A late flurry of selling pushed the stock market into the minus column yesterday in a relatively active session.

title: R. Taylor Cole, Educator, 85
description: R. Taylor Cole, a retired political scientist and administrator at Duke University, died in Durham on Wednesday. He was 85 years old,

title: Clorox, in Revamping, to Drop Detergent
description: The Clorox Company said today that it would restructure parts of its operations and get out of the detergent business to focus on core products and future profitability.

title: Patents; A Treatment For Severe Fractures
description: Three researchers at the University of Pennsylvania this week patented a way to speed the healing of bone fractures using electromagnetic fields.

title: The Impact on Scorsese Of a British Film Team
description: Like many American children of the 1950's, Martin Scorsese fell in love with movies sitting before a television set in the afternoon, watching grainy, badly cut films on the "Million Dollar Movie." He saw more than the average child because he had asthma, and spent much of his time indoors in his family's four-room tenement apartment in New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Democrats See Hope for Gains On Rights Bill
description: House Democratic leaders hope to agree Monday on a package of amendments to the civil rights bill aimed at bringing enough Southern Democrats and Republicans on board to match or exceed last year's total of 273 votes.

title: Breaking of Blacklist Predated 'Spartacus'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bad Company: Censorship in the Gulf War
description: To the Editor:

title: FMC Is Awarded Army Contract
description: The Army awarded the FMC Corporation a $1.12 billion contract to build 1,600 Bradley Fighting Vehicles and 251 multiple-launching rocket systems.

title: Drop in British Inflation
description: Britain's inflation rate dropped by nearly two percentage points last month, to 6.4 percent, the sharpest fall in more than a decade, the Government said today. The price increase in April compared with a rise of 8.2 percent in March, and was the lowest annual inflation rate since November 1988, the Central Statistical Office said.

title: Preakness Trainers Pout a Little, Tout a Lot
description: With one-third of racing's Triple Crown won, Nick Zito waved the flag today for Strike the Gold, predicted that he would win another third in the Preakness and said, "He's a professional horse, a wonderful horse, and he's on top of his game."

title: Wise Target: Mideast Weapons
description: A New World Order: what is it? President Bush's new initiatives to control arms in the Middle East could finally give some substance to all the vague and virtuous talk.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blistex Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., named Ronald H. Kovich vice president, sales. * Collection Clothing Co., New York, a newly formed subsidiary of Aeneas Group, an affiliate of Harvard Management Co., named G. Raymond Empson president.

title: U.S. Insists on Progress Report on Child-Resistant Lighters
description: Four years after it decided to require that disposable lighters be safer in the hands of children, the Federal Government is finally demanding that companies divulge what they are doing to make lighters safer.

title: 13 Are Charged in Violence Tied To Queens Gang
description: Federal authorities charged 13 people yesterday with operating a murderous gang headed by a man in China who wielded power on New York streets through a violent group of enforcers.

title: Anchor Away, Pete
description: Don't expect to see him in the broadcast booth at Riverfront Stadium, but PETE ROSE tiptoed back toward major league baseball yesterday. Rose, the former Reds star and manager who was banned from baseball in 1989 after Commissioner Bart Giamatti concluded that he had bet on Reds games, began working as a substitute sports anchor at WLWT-TV, the flagship station of the Cincinnati Reds television network.

title: F.T.C. Investigating Pricing of Appliances
description: Government regulators are investigating possible price collusion among the nation's biggest makers of home appliances, officials from the companies and the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Review/Music; Tribute to Serkin Replaces 'Joke' in an All-Mozart Concert
description: Zubin Mehta was to have opened the New York Philharmonic's all-Mozart concert on Thursday evening with "A Musical Joke," Mozart's parody of mediocre serenade composition and inept ensemble playing. But after Rudolf Serkin's death on May 8, Mr. Mehta reconsidered the program.

title: Bridge
description: The Grand National and Vanderbilt teams, named for the events that qualified them for playoff competition, began the final here tonight that will qualify the winners to represent the United States in the world championships in Yokohama, Japan, in October.

title: Fatal Fire Is 4th in 6 Months at Store in Long Island Mall
description: A fire that killed two people and destroyed a McCrory's store in a rush of black smoke and 10-foot flames at the Walt Whitman Mall here on Thursday night was the fourth suspicious fire at the store in six months, officials said today.

title: Iraq Accepts U.N. System for Weapons Inspections
description: After an initial show of resistance, Iraq agreed today to a rigorous system of inspections of its military and scientific installations by an international commission charged with locating and destroying its most dangerous weapons.

title: Observer; Makes You Think
description: Maybe the most exciting play on Broadway just now is about a nation obsessed with locking people up and throwing away the key. It opens with a lashing: 50 strokes across a bare back. At first we seem to be in one of the deeper pits of hell, and metaphorically speaking, that is indeed the setting for the entire play, "Our Country's Good."

title: DEATH TOLL RISING FOR YOUNG KURDS
description: She was only 10 months old, and the French physician at her bedside today said that she probably did not have another day of life in her.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alcoa shareholders turned down a proposal to reincorporate outside Pennsylvania to avoid the state's anti-takeover law. * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., a maker of home repair products, sold the Brazilian division of its Mallory Controls business to Cent Investments, Dublin, for about $11 million.

title: Knicks Close to Picking From Their Final Four
description: The Knicks hope to offer their vacant coaching position to someone by late next week.

title: YUGOSLAVIA FAILS TO FILL PRESIDENCY
description: The office of the President of Yugoslavia was dealt a crippling blow today when representatives from the country's feuding republics failed again to fill the post, leaving a vacuum at the top of the country's crumbling federal structure.

title: Music in Review
description: Swiss Composers Amor Artis Chamber Choir and Orchestra St. Jean Baptiste Church 184 East 76th Street

title: Tardily, Democracy Reaches Nepal
description: The democratic tide has now reached the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal. For the first time in 30 years, the restless Nepalese have been able to vote in an open election. But in Nepal, unlike Eastern Europe, it is the Communists who are challenging the status quo. Their strong showing on Sunday may leave the moderate Nepali Congress Party with only a bare majority -- a result that suggests the punishing costs of delaying reforms.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday about the mambo misidentified a new book about the dance. It is "Mango Mambo," by Adal Maldonado.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN TALKS ON '92 RACE
description: Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has organized a quiet meeting of potential Presidential candidates, party leaders and major financial contributors to plot strategy for the 1992 general election.

title: Virginia Reviews Loans
description: The University of Virginia said yesterday that it was investigating whether three dozen loans given mainly to student-athletes by the Virginia Student Aid Foundation had violated N.C.A.A. rules.

title: Pamela Kelly Wed to A. W. Robertson
description: Pamela Deidre Kelly, a daughter of Mrs. James M. Kelly of Beverly, Mass., and the late Mr. Kelly, was married yesterday to Andrew Whitmore Robertson, the son of Olivia G. Robertson of Foxboro, Mass., and Eugene C. Robertson of Washington. The Rev. Steven E. Crowson performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Salem, Mass.

title: Tilting at Taxes in Connecticut
description: Gov. Lowell Weicker's proposal that Connecticut tax personal income has produced a menacing coalition of Democratic and Republican legislators who (1) don't like the tax and (2) don't like Mr. Weicker. Their shortsighted scrambling for a no-income-tax alternative puts politics ahead of Connecticut's long-term interest.

title: Chrysler to Export Special Cherokees
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would build right-hand-drive Jeep Cherokees next year for export to foreign markets. The Cherokees will be produced at the Beijing Jeep Corporation, Chrysler's joint venture in China, and at the company's Toledo, Ohio, assembly plant. Karen Stewart, a Chrysler spokeswoman in Detroit, said the company would not disclose how many modified Cherokees would be produced at the two plants.

title: Connecticut Casino: Eagerness and Anxiety
description: When the Connecticut House of Representatives on Thursday rejected a last effort to block the Mashantucket Pequot from building a casino on their land here, one legislator joked that the reservation, with just 150 tribe members and an estimated $18 million in casino profits, would become "the Kuwait of Connecticut."

title: Review/Rock; Guns 'n' Roses Back, in a Not-So-Sneak Preview
description: The semi-secret club date, which was once a way for the Rolling Stones, Prince or Bob Dylan to relax and play for dedicated fans, now has its own routines. When Guns 'n' Roses played at the Ritz on Thursday night, in a show announced that afternoon, the anointed rock rebels of the late 1980's brought all the show-business trappings.

title: Survey Finds Shift in View By Ad Clients
description: Clients are already sold on the value of a fundamental shift in advertising philosophy to integrate the marketing messages that consumers receive, according to the results of an eagerly awaited survey that was released here today.

title: Seville Journal; Picture a U.S. Pavilion (Better Late Than Never)
description: One year before the opening of Seville's universal exhibition, Expo '92, the large plot of land assigned to the United States is already a tourist attraction. While new pavilions are going up all around it, the American site is silent and deep in weeds.

title: Roger N. Metz, Physics Professor, 52
description: Roger N. Metz, a professor of physics at Colby College in Waterville, Me., died Tuesday at a hospital in Cleveland. He was 52 years old and lived in Fairfield, Me.

title: Kim Sparber Is Married
description: Kim Andrea Sparber, the deputy general counsel at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, was married yesterday to Dr. Gary Mark Glickman, an ophthalmologist and an attending surgeon at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. Rabbi Brad Boxman officiated at the Caneel Bay resort at St. John, V.I. The bride, 34 years old, is keeping her name. She graduated from William Smith College and received a law degree from Emory University. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Sparber of Glen Cove, L.I. The bridegroom, 34, graduated from Northwestern University and received his M.D. from New York University. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Glickman of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Times Mirror-Cahners Deal For Broadcasting Magazine
description: Broadcasting, the 60-year-old weekly trade magazine, will be acquired by Cahners Publishing Company for $32 million from the Times Mirror Company, the two concerns announced yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; Mixing Debuts and Experience
description: American Ballet Theater's season continues with a stream of debuts, the latest being Julie Kent's brave if tentative stab at the fiendishly difficult ballerina role in George Balanchine's "Ballet Imperial" on Thursday night.

title: Japan Agrees to Gradual Ban on Imports of Turtle Shells
description: Under heavy American pressure, Japan said today that it had agreed to gradually end imports of the shells of the hawksbill turtle, an endangered species. President Bush responded in Washington by postponing possible trade sanctions.

title: F.C.C.'s 'Indecency' Ban Is Upset by Appeals Court
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today declared unconstitutional a recent Federal law that banned "indecent" radio and television programming.

title: Driver Slain and Passenger Is Hurt in Brooklyn Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with firing into a car in which his former wife was riding yesterday afternoon, killing the driver and critically wounding the ex-wife, the police said.

title: New I.B.M. Price Cuts Expected
description: I.B.M. will reduce prices by 6 to 24 percent on Monday on some of its most popular desktop systems, according to industry executives familiar with the action. The cuts are in response to continued deep price cuts by other makers of personal computers.

title: Midlantic Accord on Improvements
description: The Midlantic Corporation, the holding company for New Jersey's second-largest bank, said it had agreed with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to take certain steps to improve operations. Midlantic said that as part of the deal, it would not pay dividends on its common or preferred stock without prior approval from the Federal Reserve Bank. It will also review and strengthen its credit-risk management, loan-loss reserve methodology, management succession and capital and liquidity planning.

title: 'Stumbling Drunk' Denied by Dykstra
description: Len Dykstra denied today that he or any of his teammates on the Philadelphia Phillies were "stumbling drunk" at a get-together before the auto accident in which he and catcher Darren Daulton were injured.

title: New York Can Afford Its 'Consumer Cop'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson Will Never Become Loon Lake
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl Rogers, 70, Dies; a Magazine Publisher
description: Carl Edward Rogers, an advertising executive and publisher of the old Madison Avenue Magazine, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dutton Buys Novel Rival Dropped
description: "Just Killing Time," the novel by Derek V. Goodwin that was canceled by Simon & Schuster because it was submitted with false written endorsements from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh, has been bought by E.P. Dutton for more than $500,000. The thriller, about a serial killer, has also been bought in England for about $145,000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What does a woman who has everything want? The PRINCESS OF WALES asked for a piano concerto for her 30th birthday, on July 1. On Sunday she and PRINCE CHARLES are to attend the world premiere of a concerto by HOWARD BLAKE, to be performed in London at Royal Festival Hall by the Philharmonia Orchestra, conducted by CARL DAVIS, with the composer on the piano.

title: J.C. Hartney Jr., 44; Founded a Charity to Help Fight AIDS
description: Joseph C. Hartney Jr., a photographers' representative and former director of development for the San Francisco and Joffrey Ballets, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 44 years old.

title: Rensselaer
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the entrepreneur and former commissioner of baseball, was the keynote speaker yesterday at the 185th commencement at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y.

title: Women Who Need to Escape Men
description: Mary C.'s ex-boyfriend thought she was dead when he stuffed her into the trunk of his car until a relative found her and rushed her to a hospital. Thanks to inner strength and her determination to protect her 4-year-old child, Mary survived multiple stab wounds, a broken neck and a fractured skull. Mary is in mortal terror of testifying against this man in court, but she knows she must.

title: Soviet Strike Ban Rejected
description: A Russian trade union leader today rejected President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new ban on strikes, saying it was intended to cure the symptoms but not the causes of Soviet economic problems.

title: Barclays-G.E. Unit
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said that its Mercantile Credit Company Ltd. subsidiary had agreed to sell its vehicles-loans business to the GE Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company. Terms of the sale, which involves six Mercantile Credit branch offices in Britain and 130 staff members, were not disclosed. Barclays estimated the assets were worth $450 million.

title: About New York
description: To hear his friends tell it, John Krieter was a man of gifts. A hair stylist, decorator and carpenter, he gave Irene Burns a sense of style. He helped free Mitchell Motsinger from agoraphobia, a fear of public places. To Gretta Wren went encouragement in her music career, and he guided Robin Macdonald to self-confidence in her femininity.

title: Successor to Traub Reported
description: Michael Gould, the president of the Giorgio Inc. fragrance empire, will succeed Marvin S. Traub as head of Bloomingdale's, executives at the chain's parent company said yesterday. On Monday, they said, Mr. Gould will be named to one of the industry's most prestigious jobs, chairman and chief executive of the trendy New York-based department store chain that caters to the affluent. .

title: Dr. Hector Perrone, 77, Is Dead; Physician Charged $5 for Visits
description: Dr. Hector Perrone, an internist whose patients said he charged as little as $5 a visit, died on Tuesday in his house in Greenwich Village. He was 77 years old.

title: Irene Samuel, 76, Dies; Wrote Books on Milton
description: Irene Samuel, an authority on the poet John Milton and a professor emeritus of English at Hunter College, died on Thursday at her home in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 76 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Japan Yields on Turtles

title: A Professor's Class Video Runs Into an MTV Protest
description: A professor at the University of Massachusetts wants his MTV, but the music television network may not let him have it. So what does a communications professor do when he has a cause? Take it to the news media, naturally.

title: 2 BOMBS WOUND 12 IN JOHANNESBURG
description: Fears of a revived campaign of terror gripped Johannesburg today after an abrupt and mysterious wave of bombings that wounded at least 12 people.

title: CHRONICLE
description: REGGIE JACKSON is appearing in a public-service television spot urging students to stay in school. The spot, to be broadcast this weekend, is tied to the IBM Student Pennant Race, a program involving the International Business Machines Corporation and major-league baseball teams. Students are selected by their teachers to meet with baseball players and managers, current and retired, and attend a major-league game. About 26,000 seventh- and eighth-grade students participate each year.

title: Religion Notes
description: Shabuoth in Gulf

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about commencement at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan misidentified Dr. Donald W. Shriver Jr., the commencement speaker, in some copies. He is the departing president of the Union Theological Seminary.

title: Corrections
description: A report on May 5 about the marriage of Tamara E. Gould to Joshua A. Leuchtenburg in New York misidentified the church. It was the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Your Money; Raising Returns With Less Risk
description: A low-risk, high-return portfolio sounds like an investor's impossible dream, but proponents of "asset allocation" theory contend that a properly diversified portfolio can indeed bring solid returns while minimizing risk.

title: Alternatives to the Portable Phone
description: There are times when everyone wants to be reachable without sitting by the telephone or hovering within in earshot of the doorbell. For most people, wearing a beeper and paying for a paging service month after month would be overkill.

title: New Zealand TV Deal
description: The Government's Antitrust Commerce Commission approved the purchase by an American consortium of a 51 percent interest in Sky Entertainment Television Ltd., a spokeswoman said today. "It has been cleared today," she said. "It raised no competition concerns." Local newspapers said the purchase of the stake in Sky, a subscription television program service, cost about $100 million. The consortium consists of Time Warner Inc., Telecommunications Inc., the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Ameritech Corporation.

title: In Bad Company: Censorship in the Gulf War; 'Prisoners of War'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: RYOEI SAITO, the head of the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Company, shocked the art world a couple of weeks ago when he expressed the wish to have two valuable paintings, a Renoir and a van Gogh, placed in his coffin when he dies. And the prospect that he might be cremated and the paintings burned intensified the uproar.

title: Boys Town Journal; There's No Such Thing As an Unfulfilled Dream
description: Like the Mickey Rooney character in the old movie about this storied home for wayward youths, the newly elected Mayor exulted in victory with clenched fists raised high in the air: a dream come true for a teen-ager who has not always known such approval.

title: Keep Medical Technology Healthy
description: The word from Washington is that Medicare, which serves 34 million older Americans, will now start to pay for new medical techniques only if they are proved to be cost-effective. That appears to mean that the new techniques must cost no more than alternative techniques already on the market, or must provide medical benefits commensurate with the cost.

title: GASES MAY REVEAL PLANET FORMATION
description: New and more detailed observations of gas clouds circling a star have revealed for the first time the broad structure and dynamics of what could be a planetary system in the making, or one that failed, astronomers of the Hubble Space Telescope reported yesterday.

title: A Security Adviser, and Friend, to the Kennedys
description: William G. Barry, the former F.B.I. agent who deflected Palm Beach, Fla., police officers from the Kennedy estate at the start of a rape inquiry six weeks ago, is a respected security expert who served as Robert F. Kennedy's personal bodyguard in the 1968 Presidential campaign and has since kept close ties with the Kennedy family.

title: Music in Review
description: 'Acis and Galatea' By Handel St. John's Chorale Merkin Concert Hall 129 West 67th Street

title: Moscow to Ask Help From West On Reform Plan
description: The Kremlin has begun an initiative to get major Western countries to join directly in drafting and financing a far-reaching plan for economic and political reform, including creation of a market economy, political decentralization and privatization.

title: Albert Barnes: Man of Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Bucknell; Protest on Dorm Plan Splits Fraternity Groups
description: Bucknell University is sending letters to more than 5,000 alumni to counter what university administrators say are attempts by 10 fraternities and sororities to hamper fund raising.

title: Travel Advisory; Dining Cars On the Auto Train
description: First-class passengers on Amtrak's Auto Train between the Washington area and Florida now have their own dining cars. The two-level dome cars began offering full-service dining with linen napery, crockery and glassware this month, and the two meals served on the trip, dinner and breakfast, are included in the fare. Previously, passengers in first, or sleeper class, shared cafeteria-style buffet cars with coach passengers. The coach passengers continue to get their complimentary meals in the buffet car.

title: Corrections
description: A map legend last Sunday about landmarks proposed for Harlem omitted the identity of the property designated No. 8. It is a residence at 12 West 129th Street.

title: Nassau Limits Water Despite Abundance
description: EVEN though Nassau County says its has water reserves for 80 years, it continues to restrict lawn watering.

title: Stamina-Building Drug Linked to Athletes' Deaths
description: A genetically engineered drug that was created for people suffering from kidney failure has become the latest substance to be abused by athletes seeking enhanced stamina and performance. The consequences, in some cases, may be deadly.

title: Ice-T: Movie Stars Talk Tough, Too
description: Now that gangster rap is an established genre, Ice-T wants it known that he led the way for West Coast rappers to rhyme brutal tales of gang warfare, crime and punishment. "Didn't fantasize -- kicked the pure facts," he declares in the title rap of "O.G. Original Gangster" (Sire 26492; cassette and CD). "No imagination needed 'cause I lived it."

title: Redefining 'Productive'
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Learning to Read Our Lives Reading closely and well, Robert Scholes argues, always returns us to a consideration of our own lives. This is from "Protocols of Reading" (Yale University, paper).

title: Dinkins Staff Gets Budget Briefing in Capitol
description: As legislative leaders continued work today on a state budget plan, top Dinkins administration officials came to the Capitol to hear descriptions but no final assurances of a $250 million package of state help intended to ease New York City's fiscal plight.

title:
FILM;
Jane Campion's 'Angel' Is Another Quirky Soul
description: "Just show me an ordinary person," says the director Jane Campion, "and I'll show you a troubled soul." And she should know; troubled souls are her stock in trade. Her first feature, "Sweetie" (1990), revolved around two warring sisters: the dour Kay, who has nightmares about trees with human powers, and Sweetie, who is exuberant, impulsive and destructively out of control. The heroine of Miss Campion's new film, "An Angel at My Table" -- adapted from the autobiography of the renowned New Zealand poet and novelist Janet Frame -- is a prickly introvert who spent eight years in a mental institution and much of the rest of her life repairing her fragile sense of self. But where Miss Campion was casually hard on Kay in "Sweetie," she is gentle to the awkward, high-strung Miss Frame, kinder even than the author is to herself.

title: Architectural Visions, From the Drawing to the Photograph
description: A WRITER with an interest in architecture, Susan Kelz Sperling, has assembled a show on the subject for the Rye Arts Center. The curator's purpose is to draw attention to the "artistic relationship between the two-dimensional medium of the drawing and three-dimensional reality." The reality, however, is not too real, because it comes strained through professional photographs.

title: Fixing Porch Railings That Are Weak or Ugly
description: METAL porch railings need regular maintenance. A weak railing is a safety hazard, and a railing needing paint can spoil the appearance of an entire porch or entrance.

title: Joanna Putney Weds David Pavlik in Philadelphia
description: Joanna Elizabeth Putney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Putney of New York, was married yesterday to David Phillip Pavlik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Pavlik of Struthers, Ohio. The Rev. William H. Pindar officiated at the Old Pine Street Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia.

title: Somers Absorbing Its Surge of Growth
description: PEOPLE were shaking Frances Lee's hand and patting her on the back. A bearded young man sang out, "Congratulations," and an elderly woman declared that it was the best news she had heard all year.

title: A New Craft for a Sunken Market
description: A slump in the boating market has prompted an elite group of yacht designers and builders to develop a futuristic design that they hope will rejuvenate a stagnant marine industry.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Those Moist Amphibian Lips
description: THE FROG PRINCE, CONTINUED

title: Hello, Young Lover
description: GLAD RAGS By MacDonald Harris. 327 pp. Brownsvillle, Ore.: Story Line Press. $21.95.

title: Anne Marie de Curieres de Castelnau Is Engaged
description: The Marquis and Marquise de Curieres de Castelnau of Marc-en-Baroeul, France, have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Anne Marie de Curieres de Castelnau and Joseph Robert Paolino 3d, the son of of Mr. and Mrs. Paolino Jr. of Haverhill, Mass.

title: The Boy With the Problem Proboscis: A Quiz
description: Is a floribunda a rose? Would you take a book off the shelf if it had another name? A pompous pedant has wandered into a children's bookstore and absent-mindedly inflated the titles of the books there. Can you deflate them into more familiar form? Hint: All books are in the public domain.

title: The Fresh Air Fund Returns Children to Summer Families
description: The setting was urban, a community room in a public housing project in Queens, but the talk recently was of back yards "the size of Central Park," of swimming holes, parades and softball games.

title: Where the Understated Is Celebrated
description: IN an era of hyperbole and hoopla, it is welcome to find a restaurant that lets its food speak for itself. Such is the case at Brookfield Bistro, a small storefront restaurant in Brookfield. Everything about the place is understated. Upon arrival, you are greeted by lace cafe curtains on the front windows, knotty pine wainscoting around the dining area walls and a glass display case near the entrance (full of desserts and quiches that may be ordered to take out).

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Paul Bley, Jimmy Giuffre, Steve Swallow: 'The Life of a Trio:Saturday and Sunday'

title: How to Be the World's Policeman
description: ON AUG. 2, 1990, the very day that Iraqi forces swept into Kuwait, Congressional negotiators and the Pentagon agreed to a "peace dividend" budget that would, among other things, slash troop levels by 25 percent over the next five years, do away with six active Army divisions, cut back the Navy to 451 warships from 545, and transfer nine active-duty Air Force tactical fighter wings to reserve status.

title:
DINING OUT;
11 Varieties of Pizza in White Plains
description: UNO, self-proclaimed originator of deep dish or Chicago pizza, has added another eatery to its thriving nationwide dozens, this time a block away from the Court House in White Plains. This modestly priced restaurant is a versatile addition to the area's eateries. Children can have early supper in the dining room while the separate, roomy, convivial bar plays to a dressy, well-heeled, after-work crowd (standing five-deep on a recent Friday afternoon). Later, couples and friends fill the banquettes, and politicos wind down with even later-night snacks in the calm of the greenhouse -- Uno's prettiest spot. A sidewalk cafe will soon be in full swing as well.

title: Upbeat Apocalypse
description: MISTER TOUCH

title: Alison Kroll Wed To C. L. Hessert
description: Alison Cordelia Kroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Kroll of New York, was married in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Christopher Lee Hessert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Hessert of New York. The Rev. James N. Lodwick performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Bradley Chapel at the Daycroft School.

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Cairo
description: CAIRO'S HEAT BEGINS TO build in the springtime, and by midsummer it is daunting. The first option for escape is air-conditioning -- chilled cars, glacial apartments, arctic hotel rooms, refrigerated offices. Then there's the Nile: not to swim in, but to sail on.

title:
THEATER;
Comedy, Manners and Brickbats
description: Currently at the public Theater and opening Tuesday is an elitist play that has been attacked roundly by conservative moralists, led by a demagogic clergyman. But it will not be shut down by incensed watchdog groups, since the play is nearly 300 years old: William Congreve's classic "The Way of the World," in a revival directed by David Greenspan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the prenatal clinic at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers reversed the names of the two pregnant women shown. Tawanya Tuck was at the left and Ronda Terry at right.

title:
TELEVISION;
Cafe Society
description: "There is a cloud of weirdness that hangs over Saratoga Springs," says the singer-songwriter Bruce (Utah) Phillips. He should know, having spent most of the mid-60's period he calls "the great folk-music scare" in the small upstate New York city, along with Arlo Guthrie, Don McLean, Rosalie Sorrels, Bob Dylan, Spalding Gray and others.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a deck built last fall with pressure-treated lumber. We were told to let it weather for six months. Now we are ready to apply a clear water-repellent sealer. But we don't know how to remove the manufacturer's ink stamps. Our dealer says the only way is to try sanding out the marks out. What do you suggest?

title: Ode to Billie Poe
description: THE FIREMAN'S FAIR By Josephine Humphreys. 263 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Woolf, Proust and Joseph Kell
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BALLOONS OVER BRISTOL

title: Travel Advisory; Americans Are Happy Campers, Surveys Show
description: In an apparent reflection of a growing interest in the environment, more Americans are spending their vacations camping, either in recreational vehicles or in tents, according to industry surveys.

title: Postings: 1923 Harlem Synagogue; Stolen Community Assets
description: There are many ways to lose a distinguished building. Perhaps the most painful is a bit-by-bit dismantling by vandals. And that, say two preservationists, is happening to the abandoned Temple B'nai Israel on 149th Street, west of Broadway.

title: Legislators 2, Weicker 0 On Taxes and Gambling
description: THE novelty of having a third-party independent Governor in Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has obsessed and intrigued much of Connecticut's Capitol since his inauguration in January. The wonderment only increased when Mr. Weicker broke the mold again in February and said the state must impose a long-avoided income tax as the only way out of a deep fiscal crisis.

title: Israel Expels 4 More From the Gaza Strip
description: Israel expelled four Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Lebanon early this morning. All four were accused of fomenting and carrying out violent acts on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization .

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Just when we can begin to be hopeful that gun control measures like the Brady Bill will be adopted, it is unthinkable to promote the issuance of more firearms so that people can prevent their shrubbery from being eaten. More patience is needed to pursue alternative methods of population control. We ought not to solve the problem with the speed of a bullet. MICHELE CHAMOT Roxbury, N.Y.

title: Interns Seek Edge in a Tough Job Market
description: JOSEPH ENANG, a 24-year-old senior from Mount Vernon majoring in business administration at the College of Mount Saint Vincent, did not get paid for the hours he spent at Shearson Lehman Brothers in White Plains this semester, researching stocks and bonds and helping with the mailings and seminars that attract customers.

title: Brazil's Forests in the Balance
description: WITH "green tourism" expected to triple in the Amazon basin in the 1990's, environmentalists in the region's largest city are weighing its impact on the fate of the forest.

title: Mutual Funds; Management Is Asking for a Raise
description: For many mutual fund investors, 1990 was a losing year. But the fund industry over all pulled through in fine shape, reaching $1 trillion in assets. Now funds want bigger profits for themselves.

title: Lakers Defuse Charging Blazers in Opener
description: The Trail Blazers' lead may have looked like an imposing mountain range when the fourth quarter began this afternoon, but by the end of the day the Los Angeles Lakers had conquered it almost routinely. Like Magic Johnson said when the afternoon was over, no lead is safe.

title: Men's Style; Thinker, Tailor
description: HOUSED AT THE rear of Martin Greenfield's Brooklyn clothing plant is an informal archive, a sturdy steel rack that holds the tailor's interpretations of men's wear's past glories. There, sleeve by sleeve with a fancy top-stitched Western sport coat and a denim leisure suit hangs an old Eisenhower jacket. Greenfield, who produced the general's original model, and who went on to make Eisenhower's suits after he moved to the White House, pounced on the chance to tailor executive policy. "I didn't like the way the President handled Suez," he recalls, "so I sewed notes inside all the pockets of one of his jackets to tell him so."

title: This Week: Tomatoes
description: Now that the danger of frost is past, plant tomato, eggplant and pepper plants. Encircle the plants with cardboard or some other barrier to guard against cutworms. Add a generous dose of compost to each hole and water deeply.

title: Charles H. Wilson, Executive, 71
description: Charles H. Wilson, a retired vice president of Philip Morris, U.S.A., died on May 9 at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 71 years old and also lived in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Arizona's True Nature
description: ON vacations I'm usually a decent fellow. But when I go car camping with my wife at state and national parks I find myself tempted to pummel the I.Q.-less campers who think all Mother Nature lacks is a good cow-sized stereo boom box. So, this spring, to avert an ugly scene of vigilantism -- "Camper Strangled With Own Cassette Tape!" -- we sought refuge at two Arizona preserves managed by the Nature Conservancy.

title: Foreign Affairs; Oil Facts and Follies
description: Certain facts pack a thermonuclear bang. Consider this one: Before the end of the decade, the Soviet Union -- the world's largest oil producer -- will become a net importer of oil.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
City, Rutgers and Hospital Join Forces
description: THE tide of renewal that has swept many sections of downtown New Brunswick in the last 16 years has skirted lower Easton Avenue. But an arrangement involving the city, Rutgers University and a local hospital is soon to change that.

title: The Executive Computer; For Macintosh Users, a Very Long Wait Is Over
description: Apple Computer Inc. last week formally introduced a substantially upgraded version of the Macintosh operating system, called System 7.0. It had been eagerly awaited and long delayed.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DAYS OF MY LIFE By Macdonald Carey. St. Martin's, $19.95.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Affordable Co-ops for Nassau's Elderly
description: A PROPOSAL being discussed by Lazarus Burman Associates of Syosset and officials of the Town of Hempstead and Nassau County could create up to 600 affordable one- and two-bedroom apartments for the elderly on a Mitchel Field tract in East Meadow.

title: 'Gurrelieder' in Concert: Hotter Makes a Brief Role Memorable
description: Among living vocalists, Hans Hotter may truly be termed legendary. At Wieland Wagner's Bayreuth, just after World War II, his capacious bass-baritone, Lear-like dramatic gift and towering physical presence ruled the stage; no other Wotan mat tered. He was a disciple of Richard Strauss (three of whose operatic roles he created, and whose grandson married Mr. Hotter's daughter), a close colleague of Clemens Krauss, Hans Knap pertsbusch, Otto Klemperer. And yet this afternoon he arrives in Manhattan, age 82, to take part in Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder" with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday, Friday and May 28.

title: Q and A
description: A Heathrow Layover

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Capriati in Semifinals

title: Leslie Veith Wed To J. S. Reed Jr.
description: Leslie Elizabeth Veith, a daughter of Karen McDonald Veith and Dr. Charles J. Veith 3d, both of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday in Centerville, Del., to John Shedd Reed Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reed of Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Roy A. Martin Jr. performed the ceremony at the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church.

title: U.S., Citing Human Rights, Halts Economic Aid to Yugoslavia
description: The Bush Administration has quietly suspended all economic assistance to Yugoslavia, including support in international financial institutions for loans and credits.

title: Americas' Game
description: SUGARBALL The American Game, the Dominican Dream. By Alan M. Klein. Illustrated. 179 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95. BEISBOL Latin Americans and the Grand Old Game. By Michael M. Oleksak and Mary Adams Oleksak. 303 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: Masters Press. $22.95.

title: Headliners; A French First
description: In politics, at least, the French apparently do not hold by long honeymoons. No sooner had Edith Cresson become the country's first female Prime Minister last week when the carping started. President Francois Mitterrand named Mrs. Cresson, a Socialist and former cabinet minister, partly in hopes that she could pull in enough Communist and centrist votes to move Mr. Mitterrand's stalled legislative proposals through the National Assembly. Mrs. Cresson, a former Trade Minister, said she planned to turn France into an industrial power rivaling Germany. Known for her combative style, the new Prime Minister said her government would be decisive and energetic. But when she announced her cabinet, which included many holdovers from that of her much-criticized predecessor, Michel Rocard, opposition party leaders expressed doubt that she could put together a winning coalition. And the influential newspaper Le Monde headlined a story about the new Prime Minister with a question: "For How Long?"

title: How the 'Homeboys' Got That Way
description: It's early spring, six months after principal photography has been completed on "Hangin' With the Homeboys," and the director/screenwriter, Joe Vasquez, is back in the South Bronx neighborhood where he grew up and where most of his film was shot.

title: The Shy Radish Tries Its Wings in Other Dishes
description: "IT insults radishes, the most ancient of appetizers, to chop them up and bury them in a salad," said Jane Grigson, the English food writer, in "Jane Grigson's Vegetable Book" (Penguin Books). Despite their forceful flavor, radishes, of all vegetables, seem to inspire the least invention.

title: A Rare Breed of Speculators Who Builds Mansions
description: BOCA RATON, FLA.

title: Hotel Programs For Children
description: "KIDS STAY FREE" is a reigning theme in the hotel and motel business these days: Close to 81 percent of hotels now offer such a program, according to the industry association, and the percentage was up almost a point between 1988 and 1990.

title: Pistons-Bulls Rivalry: a History of Domination and Denial
description: The last time he saw the Detroit Pistons, Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls had the playoffs on his mind.

title: The Mekons Try a Little Wizardry
description: In a career that's persisted for more than 13 years, the Mekons of Leeds, England, have shifted musical styles (and record labels) in an erratic pattern that suggests both a playful Miro squiggle and the reeling stumble of a drunkard. Over time, the band has presented itself as everything from university bohemians and wastrels to Communists and cowboys. On the new "Curse of the Mekons" (Blast First bffp80cd; CD and casette), they are ironic incarnations of wizards and demons. Looking past all the guises, it's evident that this pop outfit will be claimed as a model by young bands years from now, probably long after the Mekons have given up the commercial struggle.

title: Hundreds in Preschool Special Education
description: WILLIAM ELSBECK, a happy alert 1-year-old, goes willingly from his mother's arms to Sue Hockett, a special-education teacher in Infant Toddler Outreach Program in South Huntington. The program cares for handicapped children from birth to 3.

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Paris
description: IT MAY BE A TOUCH DISRESPECTFUL to visit a museum for reasons other than cultural. But on a sticky summer's day in Paris, when even the Louvre is a museum too far, the shaded gardens of the Musee Rodin invite escape from the heat and traffic. Most of Auguste Rodin's fine sculptures are in the Hotel Biron, an 18th-century mansion that houses the museum. Parisians in the know, however, head for the gardens -- to stroll, read, court, snooze or simply to recover their strength.

title: Ban Pesticides, Rally Organic Gardeners for Turf Lawndering; Green Air Conditioner
description: To the Editor:

title: On Seeing The Forests For The Trees
description: A BOLE OF OAKS, A brush of pines, a rigging of larches, a hearth of maples . . . There should be specific collective nouns for trees as they are seen at their best: growing in pure woods undiluted and uncluttered by rival vegetation.

title: 'Invented Spelling' Is the Way to Learn
description: It is easy for someone not knowledgeable about the development of literacy in young children to mock "invented spelling," as Emile Berger does in his letter, or to criticize this approach as "sloppy" teaching, as Amy Benjamin does [ "Letters to the Westchester Editor," April 28 ] .

title: As Team Owners Consider Designating Two Cities, What Price Expansion?
description: Is baseball ready for the Miami Vise or perhaps the Denver Sprawl? For the first time since 1977, major league owners are preparing to make room in their elite circle. And in spite of the $95 million initiation fee, they do not want for applicants.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kaolin, Pa.; A 2,000-Acre Master Plan
description: IN an unusual attempt at regional land planning, four major landowners in this mushroom-growing area have joined in an informal master plan for 2,000 acres.

title: Political Talk
description: Feud Gathers Momentum

title: The Plight of Malaysia's Leatherback
description: THE pearl-gray light of predawn is just seeping into the sky above the Rantau Abang beach in Malaysia when the early-morning silence is shattered by the arrival of a convoy of cars and minibuses. More than 200 eager tourists pour out, stumbling at a half trot down from the road, through the deep sand toward the sea. The guide, a small man wearing jeans, running shoes and a jacket advertising Marlboro, is standing over the huge dark shape of a leatherback turtle. He waves the new arrivals over with his flashlight, a lighted cigarette dangling from his mouth.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Imagine if You Will
description: THE GHOST HORSE OF THE MOUNTIES

title: La Jolla Stages a 'Hamlet' II
description: When the curtain falls on a stage strewn with corpses, audiences hardly expect a sequel. But there will be one this summer at the La Jolla Playhouse in Southern California: the premiere of a new Lee Blessing comedy, "Fortinbras," which takes off where "Hamlet" ceases to be. The June production is Mr. Blessing's fourth collaboration with the theater's artistic director, Des McAnuff, who directed the playwright's 1988 drama, "A Walk in the Woods," at La Jolla and on Broadway.

title: Fordham Graduates Urged to Defend the Poor
description: Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund, told graduates at Fordham University yesterday that the nation must turn from its recent battle abroad to "confront the deadly war against children and the poor" at home.

title: Chess
description: While the blockaded side marks time, the blockader builds the attack force.

title: Miss Mashburn Wed in Cincinnati
description: Meredith Olin Mashburn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Olin Mashburn 3d of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to Andrew Scott Keating, a son of Shirley Keating of Toronto and Ross Keating of Haliburton, Ont. The Rev. Paul R. Long performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Indian Hill Church in Cincinnati.

title: 'Moon for Misbegotten' At Yale Repertory
description: THROUGHOUT its volatile history of failure, neglect, acknowledgment and eventual triumph, "A Moon for the Misbegotten," Eugene O'Neill's last play, has carried a weighty burden. In spite of numerous revivals, it is still perceived as intimidating.

title: Perspectives: Bronx Town Houses; Nice Design, but Oh Those Parking Pads!
description: ATTACHED two-family houses are old hat in New York City. Usually they are to be found in the low-density zones of Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Eduardo Lopez Is Wed To Roma T. Friedman
description: Roma Torre Friedman, a television newswoman on Long Island, was married in East Islip, L.I., yesterday to Eduardo Ivan Lopez, a New York playwright. Msgr. Thomas Hartman performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church.

title: Lucretia Osborne, Teacher, Is to Marry Jonathan H. Wells, a Geologist, in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederik R-L. Osborne of Auburn, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucretia Mott Osborne, to Jonathan Hatfield Wells, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Wells of Shrewsbury, Vt. A July wedding is planned.

title: The Scaffold Awaits
description: LIES OF THE NIGHT

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "In any country, those who work can survive. But those who get $180 for working seven days, what can they do? They return defeated to Mexico."

title: Dr. Carey Marries Dr. M. G. Ewend
description: Dr. Lisa Anne Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Matthew Glaize Ewend, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Ewend of Saginaw, Mich. The Rev. Joseph W. Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: Aid Cuts Could Hurt More Than Just Schools
description: IN a new approach to securing support in hard economic times, school officials are asking people to think of education not just as a learning process, but also as a threatened industry.

title: Topics of the Times; Ties That Shine
description: Two bright academic tiles are being set in what Mayor Dinkins calls the splendid mosaic of New York City. Uptown at Columbia University, an Italian Academy for Advanced Studies in America has just been established in partnership with the Government of Italy. And downtown at New York University, Ireland House is about to be established as a center for studying contemporary Irish culture and politics.

title: Ecotourism: Can It Protect the Planet?
description: EAGER to see unspoiled natural habitats, threatened animal species and rare birds, travelers have forsaken loafers for hiking boots and surged into the world's game preserves, remote rivers and jungles. Statistics are not readily available, but by some estimates as many as five million Americans took a trip last year with an environmental theme.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
For Lacquerware, The Place Is Japan
description: A SMALL tea caddy, egg shaped except for the flattened lid, gleams darkly, its only ornamentation a series of undulating curves of gold, dull pewter and rainbow-hued mother-of-pearl; a widely flaring sake cup of ocher red, polished to a dull lustre; a gleaming black tray, round and shining like the full moon, further brightened by golden grasses and a lonely autumnal deer -- these are jewels of lacquerware from Wajima, on the outer coast of the Noto Peninsula, which juts out into the wild Sea of Japan.

title: Woolf, Proust and Joseph Kell
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, N.Y., It's a Recording Town
description: New York City, in many respects the classical music capital of the world, has nevertheless seemed in recent years to be a stepchild in the recording studio. This is partly because of the high cost of recording in New York and partly because of a feeling on the part of some record-label executives that record buyers prefer European ensembles.
