While many New York-based performers have long been prominent on records, the two most visible entities -- the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera -- had been missing from the recording scene.

title: Truck Hits a School Bus, Killing 3 Students
description: Three children were killed and 12 injured Friday when a dump truck smashed into their school bus at an intersection in this town 15 miles north of Charlotte.

title: Invasion of the Burbs
description: THE INCUBATOR BALLROOM

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: An additional title of interest:

title: New Movements in China
description: Four years ago, modern-dance instructors from the American Dance Festival left Durham, N.C., bound for China and the provincial capital of Guangzhou, the home of the Guangdong Dance Academy. Their mission: to teach modern techniques to Chinese students recruited from some of the country's professional dance troupes, students trained in traditional techniques but virtually unschooled in modern dance.

title: 'Lollapalooza': A Summer Alternative
description: Jane's Addiction's latest album, "Ritual de lo Habitual," zoomed into the Top 20, and the band sold out Madison Square Garden last month. Yet they still live up to their alternative-rock origins. With like-minded musicians -- Living Colour, Siouxsie and the Banshees, the Butthole Surfers, Ice-T and Nine-Inch Nails -- the band headlines a 20-city tour, beginning July 19, that salutes divergent rock and addresses social issues. Called the "Lollapalooza" festival, the tour will feature a dozen tents, each festooned with displays about a particular issue like abortion rights or pollution control.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Farmington, Conn. 499,000 8 Fernhurst 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; crown moldings, screened porch, brick patio, 1 acre; taxes $5,222. Hartford, Conn. 100,000 185 Campfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old, brick Cape Cod; new roof, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,974. Norwalk, Conn. 290,000 122 West Norwalk Road. 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old garrison colonial; 375-ft pond frontage, sunroom, 2.5 acres; taxes $4,284. Harrison, N.Y. 915,000 Rye Ridge Road 6-bedroom, 4 full- and 2 half-bath, 51-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, den, enclosed porch, 2 dressing rooms, 3-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $18,502. Ossining, N.Y. 300,000 5 Pheasant Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, country kitchen, family room, Jacuzzi, c/a; taxes $6,111. Scarsdale, N.Y. 395,000 2 Rodney Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 61-year-old colonial; new eat-in kitchen, patio, 2 covered porches, new playroom; taxes $7,263. OTHER AREAS Hackettstown, N.J. 108,000 17 Shelly Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,938. Hopatcong, N.J. 105,000 148 Lakeside Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,348. Levittown, L.I. 138,000 27 Old Oak Lane 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 41- year-old ranch; new kitchen, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500.

title: New York Philharmonic to Play at Tilles
description: CAN Long Island provide a home for a major international music festival?

title: Camacho Takes Back W.B.O. Title
description: Hector Camacho won the vacated World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title tonight, gaining a split decision over Greg Haugen at Reno-Sparks Convention Center tonight.

title: The Delicate Bankruptcy Balancing Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Gina Reid Weds Christopher Maxmin
description: Gina Rogers Reid, a producer of television commercials in New York, and First Lieut. Christopher Wardenburg Maxmin were married yesterday at the home of her parents in Westchester County. Chief Judge Charles L. Brieant of Federal District Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the documentary "Caffe Lena," misstates the telecast date. It is Saturday, at 12:10 A.M. on WNET.

title: A Mall Builder Bets On Recession's End
description: THE developer of a proposed one-million-square-foot luxury hotel, retail and office complex -- the third large development proposal for the eastern edge of downtown White Plains -- is betting that the recession will be short-lived, opening new opportunities to lure well-to-do shoppers.

title: Nia Judson Wed To Collin McNeil
description: Virginia Wallis Judson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Judson 2d of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Collin Farquhar McNeil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa. The Rev. James Armstrong Trimble performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title: The N.B.A. Lottery for 1991: It's No 'St. Patrick Ewing Day'
description: The National Basketball Association's seventh draft lottery, which will be held this afternoon at halftime of the Pistons-Bulls playoff game, lacks the hoopla of the years when players like Patrick Ewing, David Robinson and Danny Manning were the top prizes.

title: Dr. Robinson Wed to Dr. S. C. Saddler
description: Dr. Antoinette Elaine Robinson and Dr. Stephen Charles Saddler, physicians in postgraduate studies in New York, were married in New York yesterday at Christ United Methodist Church by the Rev. Stephen P. Bauman.

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Miami
description: IN A CITY WHERE VIRTUALLY everything seems to be of recent vintage, Coconut Grove, one of Miami's oldest communities, provides the surest respite from Florida's long hot spells. Settled in the latter half of the 19th century, the Grove is a distinctive, heavily wooded area hugging Biscayne Bay, just a few miles south of downtown Miami. With its hulking, spider-legged banyan trees and high-walled pastel mansions, the neighborhood exudes a cool, tropical charm.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: MARGARET M. MCMAHON;
Using Early Pension to Cut State Payroll
description: MANY New Jerseyans jog before going to work, but Margaret M. McMahon does not. She swims. Ms. McMahon, the director of the State Division of Pensions, arrives in Trenton about 6:45 A.M. and heads for a Y.W.C.A. swimming pool, where she swims for half an hour before getting to her office at 7:50.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about stores in the Chestnut Hill neighborhood of Philadelphia misidentified the Maloumian family's former business there. It operated a rug store.

title: Headliners; Royal Treatment
description: Hailing from Buckingham Palace, Queen Elizabeth II is familiar with the idea of subsidized housing. Thursday, during her visit to the former colonies, she stopped by the Marshall Heights Community Development Organization in Washington to admire a public and private partnership that helps lower-income families buy their own modest homes. Accompanied by Barbara Bush, Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon and Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, she was greeted at the door of one of the houses by Alice Frazier. "How are you doing?" Mrs. Frazier asked, dispensing with the customary curtsy and giving the Queen a bear hug instead. Then she invited her to stay for lunch. "I told the Queen this was my palace," Mrs. Frazier, a 67-year-old great grandmother, said. But Her Majesty, apparently not offended by the breach in protocol, had already made plans for lunch at the Library of Congress, with actors Sir John Mills, Jessica Tandy and Ben Kingsley and director Martin Scorsese.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: SHEILA D. BLUME;
The Need to Identify Problem Gamblers
description: IN 1866, Fyodor Dostoyevsky, a problem gambler, described the high experienced by the central character of his novella "The Gambler" on winning a large sum of money: "It could hardly be called thinking. I only felt a sort of terrible delight in success, victory, power."

title: Nostalgic for Dr. King
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Difference; Hard Times Hit the Streets in Out-of-Step Businessland
description: Earlier in his career, David A. Norman founded Dataquest, a Silicon Valley market research firm. But it was a failure to react to changes in the personal computer market that has brought him to what may be the end of the line at Busi-nessland Inc.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Witch Hazel Search

title: On Language; An Unstaid Heads-Up
description: WHEN CALLED TO account by a Washington Post reporter, Susan Schmidt, for his personal stock and bond trades, which were said to average twice a month over the past four years, the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, expostulated: "There is no requirement for putting these investments in a blind trust." He added, in words that were blown up in a "bank" on the front page (apt journalese, as Mr. Clarke is the nation's top banking regulator): "I don't find anything the slightest bit unsobering in those dealings."

title: Postings: 42 Condominium Units; Filling a Gap in Port Chester
description: Westchester Avenue in the Village of Port Chester has followed the same course of development as many other streets in suburban New York communities: It has gone from a rural road to a main street lined with big Victorian houses to a thoroughfare of multifamily dwellings.

title: Big Comebacks on Small Screens
description: Jill Clayburgh poses in the doorway of a grim 10-foot-square set whose walls have been painted to resemble tan padding. Neill Barry, playing her teen-age son, is crouched at her feet; his character has just been arrested for drunken driving, and hers has just reached the jail cell in a fury.

title: Food; The Emperor's New Clothes
description: NAPOLEON MAY HAVE LOST TO WELLINGTON AT Waterloo in 1815, but in 1991 the conquering hero is not Wellington, as in beef, but Napoleon, as in everything under the sun.

title: Cyclone in Bangladesh Tests the Fragile New Democracy
description: The destitute victims of last month's cyclone may lack food, water and shelter, but they have one asset that is often wanting in developing countries: the vote.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-13

title: A New Program Tries To Catch Welfare Fraud
description: THE County Social Services Department is receiving statewide attention for a program to prevent welfare fraud

title: Louisa Giannelli Weds G. A. Ritter
description: Louisa Kiil Giannelli, a daughter of Karen K. Giannelli and Dr. Stanley Giannelli, both of New York, was married yesterday at the Epsicopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Gregory Alan Ritter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Ritter of Nashville. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

title: The Twilight of the Russian Bourgeoisie
description: One of the oddest and most hotly debated results of the thaw in cultural relations between the Soviet Union and the West is an enormous exhibition called "The Twilight of the Czars," which runs through today at the Hayward Gallery in London.

title: Camera
description: Photography runs along paths laid down by available equipment. Ninety years ago, large-format dry plate cameras and richly toned printing-out paper made it easy for any reasonably adept photographer to produce beautiful portraits and landscapes.

title: Casting For Trout In Western Waters
description: I STARTED MY SONS, NOW 18 and 20, on fly fishing as soon as they were old enough to master the four-beat rhythm of the cast. When my wife, Susan, signed up for fly fishing lessons last year, we lost our last holdout against folie a famille. So we headed west on one of the most daunting ventures in the field of domestic travel: the family fly fishing vacation.

title: Sarah Brakman,Student, Is Wed
description: Sarah Vaughan Brakman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Brakman of Brookville, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. James Maurice Youakim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice I. Youakim of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Kevin W. Wildes performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: No one who talks of "nailing" deer (because he "doesn't consider them to be wildlife anymore"), as the Schuylkill Center's executive director, Richard L. James, does, should be regarded as an environmentalist. Deer have at least as much right to the land as do the people who spend $12,000 on their shrubbery and obsess over their rhododendron.

title: Moving Beyond the Exchange of Business Cards
description: ALMOST every day, somewhere in Westchester, business people are approaching strangers, introducing themselves and saying, "Hi, what do you do?" After exchanging business cards and small talk, they move on, circling the room. And so goes the typical networking get-together.

title: 5 Massachusetts Towns Continue a Tradition of Tax Rebellions
description: The hill towns of western Massachusetts have a long history of independent mindedness, going back to 1786, when a band of impoverished farmers took pitchforks and guns and headed down from the hills to protest high taxes. The insurrection, known as Shays' Rebellion for its leader, Daniel Shays, was ultimately put down.

title: Tie Goes to . . .
description: Nobody turned in a faster qualifying run than STERLING MARLIN, who whipped around the Charlotte Motor Speedway in 31.499 seconds for a lap speed of 171.434 miles an hour. So why will Marlin be sitting in the No. 2 position rather than at the pole when the Winston Open gets under way today?

title: The Justices Vs. the Majors
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; The Philosophy of the 'New F.D.A.' Is Mostly a Matter of Packaging
description: RELATIVES of people with Alzheimer's disease were stunned in March when an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration refused to recommend that an experimental treatment, tacrine, be licensed. Weren't people with fatal diseases like Alzheimer's or AIDS supposed to get special consideration, they wondered -- even if, as with tacrine, a drug was, at best, only slightly effective? Whatever happened to the new F.D.A.?

title: Hansel Captures Preakness By 7
description: "Horse racing," Nick Zito likes to say, "is a sport that humbles kings."

title: Review/Pop; Chris Isaak In a Display Of Inspired Silliness
description: "If we know it, we'll do it, and if we didn't write it, we'll rip it off," Chris Isaak boasted early in Thursday's opening-night show of a two-night stand at the Beacon Theater. It was the first appearance in New York City by the charismatic neo-rockabilly singer and songwriter from Stockton, Calif., since he scored a top-10 hit with a brooding country-rock ballad, "Wicked Game." An instrumental version of that hit was first heard in the soundtrack of David Lynch's "Wild at Heart," a film whose surreal, off-kilter humor is very close in spirit to Mr. Isaak's playful stage personality.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on April 28 about the actor Keith Carradine misstated the length of his absence from Broadway. After appearing in "Hair," he was in "Foxfire" before his current role in "The Will Rogers Follies."

title: Mixing Old and New at the Harbor
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR is a charming 19th-century whaling village bursting with boutiques, but short on places to eat. What is there caters to the quiche-and-salad set.

title: William Ashby, Longtime Worker For Civil Rights, Is Dead at 101
description: William M. Ashby, a fighter for civil rights for more than nine decades and New Jersey's first black social worker, died on Friday at the Brookhaven Nursing Home in East Orange, N.J. He was 101 years old.

title: Girl, 5, and 4 Other Bystanders Hurt in Shootings
description: Five bystanders, including a 5-year-old Brooklyn girl, were wounded on Friday night in three separate shootings in New York City, the police said. None were seriously injured.

title: Australia's Remote Pearl Coast
description: ON A LITTORAL OF the Indian Ocean in the northwest of Australia is a town of corrugated iron bungalows called Broome. Its population is close to 8,000, food comes in by road from 1,400 miles away, and there are two newspapers, produced monthly.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a deck built last fall with pressure-treated lumber. We were told to let it weather for six months. Now we are ready to apply a clear water-repellent sealer. But we don't know how to remove the manufacturer's ink stamps. Our dealer says the only way is to try sanding out the marks out. What do you suggest?

title: The World; Glimpsing the Future, The Red Army Frets
description: THE American military successes in the gulf war seem to hold a clear message for the Soviet high command: a professional army with exotic electronic weaponry can make mince-meat of a massive land force of conscripts and tanks. Indeed, Soviet marshals have been quick to seize on the demonstration of the West's high-tech muscle to call for a tune-up in their air defenses and, not surprisingly, to argue for more money.

title: St. Croix
description: To the Editor: Returning recently from St. Croix, a year after volunteering to clear debris from the plant nursery of St. George Village Botanical Garden, I was as delighted as Cynthia Hacinli ("What's Doing in St. Croix, Travel, March 10) to find the island well on its way to recovery.

title: Brush Up Your Shakespeare
description: "There is a sort of rampant Bardophobia in this country," says Attilio Favorini, who founded Three Rivers Shakespeare Festival in Pittsburgh in 1980.

title: Laura Davis Wed To David Soper
description: Laura Jensen Davis, the daughter of Mrs. Richard M. Davis of New York and the late Mr. Davis, was married yesterday to David Bradley Soper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Soper of Cincinnati. The ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was performed by the Rt. Rev. John M. Krumm.

title: Suzi R. Schiffer Wed in Vermont
description: Suzi Rachel Schiffer and Franklin Parrasch were married yesterday at the Hermitage in Wilmington, Vt., by Connie Montemagni, a justice of the peace in Stratton, Vt. The bride, 30 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Schiffer of New York and Wilmington. Mr. Parrasch, 32, is the son of Walter Parrasch of River Edge, N.J., and the late LaRae Parrasch.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Plan for Storing Radioactive Waste Is Under Review
description: Princeton University officials are thinking about using a room beneath the geology library to temporarily store low-level radioactive waste -- a proposal that concerns librarians there.

title: African Beadwork That Is Rich With Status Symbols
description: In West Africa a century ago, beadwork was a status symbol reserved for kings and priests. Skilled artisans, using gloriously colored glass beads and cowrie shells, devised the ritual artifacts of great fantasy assembled in "African Beadwork: Traditional Symbols," an exhibition at the Tambaran Gallery, 20 East 76th Street in Manhattan, through June 28.

title: Style Makers; Anita Samuels, Fashion Designer
description: When she was 10, Anita Samuels designed and sold shoes made of Kleenex boxes and clothing to children in her neighborhood in Miami. Now, she designs women's clothing with a romantic style and sells them from a Manhattan showroom.

title: Recycling? Try Reverse Shopping
description: The article about recycled commingled materials demonstrates that the only moneymaker for the intermediate processing plants to which the mixed items are delivered is the aluminum beverage can portion.

title: Miss Brooks Weds Robert Stafford 3d
description: Victoria Sara Jane Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Brooks of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Henry Stafford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stafford Jr. of Somerset, Mass. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title: Belts Tightened, Parks Brace for Crowds
description: FROM Muscoot Farm Park in Somers to Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers, a collective sigh of relief could be heard last month when the County Board of Legislators restored $2.6 million in financing for parks programs, which are predicting a big demand this season from county residents feeling the effect of the recession.

title: Bush's Illness Shows Folly of 'Cost Containment' in Health Care; Prescription: Broccoli
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Indonesia's Courtly Arts
description: More than 150 works of art that reflect artistic traditions of the royal courts of Indonesia go on display today at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: The statement that "deer in unprecedented numbers are making man's turf their own" set the tone for the article.

title: Pillow Talk
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, America's oldest dance festival, remains faithful to its tradition of being ever new. This summer's festival, which runs from June 14 to Aug. 31, is the first under the direction of Sam Miller, who obviously realizes that the only predictable thing at the Pillow is variety.

title: BUDGET THREATENS PHYSICS PROJECT
description: The search for the top quark, an elusive subnuclear particle regarded by high-energy physicists as a kind of Holy Grail, will probably be delayed for years because of financing problems, leading physicists say.

title: In Fiscal Crunch, Frills of Office Can Loom Large
description: When City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman appears in public, two police detectives accompany her. When Mayor David N. Dinkins arrives each morning at City Hall from Gracie Mansion, one of his police bodyguards carries a cooler containing the Mayor's specially prepared diet lunch. When Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown travels the two blocks from Police Headquarters to City Hall, he drives, with a back-up car.

title: John F. Gruen Weds Miss Kiebert-Boss
description: Cathleen Kiebert-Boss, a representative for a film production company, and John Fredrick Gruen, a creative director in advertising, both in New York, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Christopher Brown performed the ceremony.

title: Data Bank/May 19, 1991
Mistake Shuts Down Reactor
description: A technician accidentally removed the wrong fuses and shut down the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on Friday, leading to the release of steam into the air, an official said. No one was injured and no radioactive material was released, said a Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman, Greg Cook.

title: Drawing the Civil Rights Line
description: The preliminary jockeying is over. On Monday, supporters of a new civil rights bill will add the final touches and soon send the bill to be voted on by the House of Representatives. That vote will, at last, draw a clear line between promoting racial politics and promoting racial justice.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: It is no coincidence that the state with the greatest number of hunters, Pennsylvania, also has one of the largest deer herds. Hunting actually creates ideal conditions for accelerated reproduction. The abrupt drop in population caused by a fall hunt results in decreased competition among survivors for food, space and mates. This results in an increase in the birth rate among survivors. Some studies show that, after a fall hunt, two to three times as many fawns are born than in a reasonably competitive, nonhunted population. In the long run, when left to their own devices, wildlife populations regulate themselves. We need only look at the millions of acres of national parklands in which hunting and trapping are prohibited to see demonstrated the ability of wildlife to regulate their numbers. JESSICA T. SANDLER Silver Spring, Md.

title: Nothing to Vote For
description: WHY AMERICANS HATE POLITICS

title: Recitals Along The Moscow River
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Rallies On Trade Figure
Help in Buying A Phone Call Away
description: GENERAL information on property sales by the Resolution Trust Corporation may be obtained in "How to Buy Real Estate," a free, newly revised booklet published by the agency. It may be ordered by calling (800) 431-0600.

title: The Skill of the Watercolorist
description: THOUGH titled "Watercolor Across the Ages," the show at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Gallery covers only the 20th century and the work of Americans.

title: The Nation; The Task: Slip Spies Into the New World Order
description: IF confirmed by the Senate as the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates may well take the United States intelligence "community" through its most important transition since President Harry Truman set the structure for America's bureaucracy of spies in 1947.

title: Look Again At That Resume
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Tanner to Wed Grant I. Greely in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mitchell M. Tanner of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Laura Tanner, to Grant Ives Greely, the son of Mrs. John A. Greely of Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Greely. A July wedding is planned.

title: Janet Mahnke Married To Jeffrey Allen Zorek
description: Janet Elizabeth Mahnke, a daughter of Carol Mahnke of Sausalito, Calif., and Dr. James M. Mahnke of Kalispell, Mont., was married last evening in New York to Jeffrey Allen Zorek, the son of Elizabeth Zorek of New York and the late John Zorek. The bride's godfather, the Rev. Samuel W. Hale, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Mark Hotel.

title: Postings: For the Aged Homeless; An Eyesore No More
description: A dirty and dilapidated hotel, long an eyesore on one of Chelsea's loveliest blocks, has been turned into a clean and comfortable home for some of the city's elderly homeless.

title: David Mellgard Weds Georgiana Slade
description: Georgiana James Slade and David Morse Mellgard, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. officiated.

title: A LOST VOICE
description: If the logic of Anton Shammas's premise -- that dialects automatically embody justice and morality and thereby deserve territorialization -- were to hold universally (and that, after all, is the test of logic), then he is arguing that it would have been right for the secessionist American South to achieve sovereignty, notwithstanding its practice of human chattel ("A Lost Voice," April 28).

title: Perry, Working for First Tour Victory, Leads by 2 Shots
description: With a hot putter and all the poise a non-winner can muster, journeyman pro Kenny Perry gamely fought off the best efforts of several estimable veterans today to keep the lead in the Memorial Tournament after three rounds.

title: CLOTHES THAT WORK
description: Nobody's afraid of style - as long as it functions. Designer labels are a plus - if what they're sewn into has a useful edge as well as a cutting one. Fashion now fits into almost all walks of work, which has not always been the case. Nancy Hall, one of the three career women shown on these pages, says: "My frame of reference is Wall Street, and there has been a real evolution there in the last three years. Women look more feminine, and at the same time more competent." Bright hues are key to the new expression. It is quite acceptable for a financial whiz or a serious doctor to go about her business wearing a strong dose of color. Costume jewelry goes to work, too. The only rule that applies is, Don't overdo it. As always, good taste is a matter of simple lines accented with well-designed details.

title: UMass to Cut 4 Varsity Sports
description: Hit by budget cuts, the University of Massachusetts will drop four varsity sports and reduce funding in five other areas, officials said Friday.

title: Postings: $1 Million Project; Greenwich Park Plans Spruce-Up
description: When the owners of the nine-building, 420,000-square-foot Greenwich Office Park decided earlier this year to invest $1 million in a three-year capital improvement program, they said the complex was over 90 percent occupied, with no large vacancies in sight. But that changed on May 9, when United Parcel Service, which leases 200,000 square feet in the park for its world headquarters, announced that it will move from Greenwich to Atlanta. The company said the move -- involving 1,000 headquarters employees -- would begin in the fall and be completed by next May.

title: On Bumpy Road to Love, Author Charts a Course
description: MEETING someone special requires careful planning and creativity and should not be left to chance, says Sharyn Wolf, a social worker, consultant and workshop leader.

title: Bay Bass Are Back, Anglers Take Bait
description: It was a madcap opening of the Chesapeake Bay's special season for trophy striped bass, which drew thousands of maniacal anglers to a raucous day of fishing.

title: Music in Review
description: New York New Music Ensemble Miller Theater Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street.

title: Barbara Gooding Wed in Rhode I.
description: Barbara Gooding, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vaughn G. Gooding of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday at the chapel of St. George's School in Newport, R.I., to James Bartlett Littlefield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Littlefield of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. John S. Rogers, an Episcopal priest and the chaplain of St. George's, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Byrolly, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bride.

title: Bottom Line On Fan Reaction
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: With a Dip, a Dart and a Dash, Lemieux Delights as Well as Delivers
description: There may be sights in other team sports just as intimidating to the opposition as that of Mario Lemieux -- puck on his stick, picking up speed and bearing down on a goaltender.

title: Darman Tackles Domestic Issues in Talk at College
description: Solving America's toughest domestic problems cannot be done with just money and a sense of mission, the Bush Administration's budget director said today, but requires basic changes in technology and values, from the development of a better car battery to the determination that children spend more time in school.

title: Review/Ballet; 'La Bayadere' Returns In Its Full-Length Glory
description: "La Bayadere," a white elephant of a 19th-century ballet that has shown unexpected staying power for one good reason, returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title:
Style Makers;
Yoke Abolafia, Needlepoint Specialist
description: When Yoke Abolafia was a child in the Netherlands, needlework was a required subject in school. These days she is running a fruitful cottage industry that operates out of her apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Social Events
description: Jazz at the Copacabana

title: Guiana's Green Mansions
description: THERE is still a place where tour buses do not deposit shoppers. Deep in the largest remaining expanse of uninterrupted tropical rain forest, another world exists where enormous vines crawl into the canopy of trees, iridescent butterflies and keel-billed toucans flash psychedelic colors and howler monkeys send their eerie roar through the still night air.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;
Old Buildings, New Froth
description: HISTORIC buildings here, reclaimed by small brewers, are finding a second life as pubs and breweries. Among them are a 1920's movie theater and a former county poor farm.

title:
FORUM;
Bush Takes On Third-World Piracies
description: On Sukimvit Street in Bangkok, Thailand, you can buy an imitation Ralph Lauren shirt for a fraction of its cost in New York City. Knowing the right person in Shanghai can help you get a diskette with Lotus 1-2-3 on it for the equivalent of $1.50. If this makes you ill, you can buy locally manufactured prescription drugs in Calcutta for less than one cent a capsule.

title: Lorna Duncan Mack to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Mack of Ringoes, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lorna Duncan Mack and Barry Edward Sheridan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Finbar Sheridan of Richmond, Mass. Miss Mack, 25 years old, is an associate at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. She graduated from Princeton University. Mr. Sheridan, 26, is an account executive at the Earle Palmer Brown advertising agency in New York. He graduated from Tufts University.

title: CROATIA REJECTS A YUGOSLAV PANEL
description: Leaders of the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today rejected a federal panel formed on Friday by the country's Prime Minister to keep this six-republic federation functioning after the collapse of the federal presidency.

title: Soviet Pilot Insists Downed Korean Jet Was Spy Plane
description: The Soviet figher pilot said to have shot down a Korean Air Lines jumbo jet in 1983 insists that he had no idea it was a civilian airliner and that he still thinks "it was a spy plane."

title: Kevin Walsh Wed To Ms. McEneny
description: Molly Ann McEneny, the daughter of Gerald J. McEneney of Middletown, N.J., and the late Catherine G. McEneny, was married yesterday in New York to Kevin John Walsh, the son of Beatrice M. Walsh of Whiting, N.J., and the late Denis Walsh. The Rev. Henry J. Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the American Irish Historical Society.

title: Mozart's Fiddle
description: ANTONIETTA By John Hersey. 304 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Review/Music; The Vision of an Eccentric: A Partch Double Bill
description: American experimental music has long been the province of outsiders, strange, eccentric and unstoppably original creators who simply cannot conform to received notions of what art must be. Of those outsiders, all different yet linked by their uniqueness, the strangest and most eccentric was surely Harry Partch.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on April 21 about ruble exchange for visitors to the Soviet Union misstated the rate at which hotel accommodations and transportation are calculated. It is 1.8 rubles to the dollar, not 5.87.

title: Business Diary: May 12-17
description: COMPANIES A Giant Killer Stumbles and Takes a Big Fall

title: A 1992 Wedding For Anne S. Toker
description: The engagement of Anne Stone Toker to Dr. Dana Leifer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Leifer of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Beatrice Toker of New York. A June 1992 wedding is planned.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Augusta, Me.;
Gifts of Land For Approvals
description: A CHANGE in the state's subdivision review law is generating land donations and conservation easements in several Maine towns.

title: Social Security Benefits Shouldn't Be Taxed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A summer theater listing today in the special Arts Almanac section (2A) misstates the schedule for the Alabama Shakespeare Festival in Montgomery. It should read: "All's Well That Ends Well" and "The Two Gentlemen of Verona," through July 28; "I'm Not Rappaport" and "Inherit the Wind," through July 27; "The Cherry Orchard" and "The Rivals," through July 28; "Romance, Romance," Aug. 1-31, and "The Rover," Aug. 8-11.

title: New Ethics Law Is Called Obstacle For Local Officials
description: A NEW state statute that sets strict standards of ethical conduct for several thousand county and municipal officials has aroused concern that the new regulations may inhibit citizens, particularly professionals, from participating in local government.

title: Mutual Funds; The Right Investor for Municipals
description: Several years ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission told money funds with more than 20 percent of "private purpose" paper in their portfolios that they could no longer call themselves tax-free funds. Private-purpose paper is issued by governments to finance housing projects and student loans, among other things.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Ninth Avenue Food Festival: Ninth Avenue between 37th and 57th Streets will be closed today from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: A's Hawkins (Remember Him?) Gets Victory in Oakland Debut
description: Former Yankee Andy Hawkins pitched five and one-third shutout innings in his Oakland debut and Dave Henderson hit his major league-leading 11th home run as the Athletics beat the Cleveland Indians, 3-0, today.

title: Talking: Decks; No Longer Just a Box On Stilts
description: THE deck -- that quintessential suburban amenity -- is growing in popularity as advances in technology produce materials that provide longer life and greater flexibility of styling and usage.

title: Pirates, Pashas and the Imperial Astrologer
description: THE WHITE CASTLE By Orhan Pamuk. Translated by Victoria Holbrook. 161 pp. New York: George Braziller. $17.50.

title: Q and A
description: A Sponsor in Default Question: I own an apartment in a co-op with 32 apartments. Last year the sponsor defaulted on the mortgage he had on the building. Soon we were informed that he had borrowed money from an investment company, using 20 unsold apartments as collateral, and had defaulted on that loan, too. The lender took over the unsold shares and has written to the shareholders explaining that it will continue to pay maintenance, But I am still worried. Could we lose our equity and our apartments because of the sponsor's defaults? . . . Awaris Tchlemarian, Jamaica, Queens Answer: Yes, but it is not likely, according to Arthur Weinstein, a lawyer who specializes in real estate matters and who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.

title: A LOST VOICE
description: I wonder what Shammas was doing while the rest of us were glued to our television sets during the gulf war. Those of us who were watching (in our case, it was a CBS affiliate station in Boca Raton, Fla.) had no trouble seeing Palestinians jubilantly celebrating the first Scud missile that landed on Tel Aviv. There they were, on the evening news, jumping up and down, on the rooftops and in the streets of the West Bank village where the CBS reporter had gone to get in-the-street reaction to the Scud attack. BRANA GUREWITSCH Brooklyn

title: Alexander Kendrick, CBS Correspondent, 80
description: Alexander Kendrick, who in nearly four decades as a newspaperman and television correspondent covered world events, including World War II from the Russian front, and as an author wrote a biography of of his colleague Edward R. Murrow, died Friday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 80 years old.

title:
DIALOGUE -- American Intelligence: Do We Still Need the C.I.A.?;
The State Dept. Can Do the Job
description: The nomination of Rob ert M. Gates a career officer and sometime head of the Directorate of Intelligence of the C.I.A. -- to be head of the agency comes at a moment when it is possible, for the first time since the onset of the cold war, to ask whether we need the agency as it now is.

title: Making a Difference; A Casual Saturday Date With Drexel and Destiny
description: At a Friday lunch last year, Ira M. Millstein, a senior partner with Weil, Gotshal & Manges, asked Alan Miller, another partner at the prominent New York law firm, if he would be willing to spend a couple of hours on Saturday visiting Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel had a cash flow problem, and it wanted a lawyer there to discuss options.

title:
Northeast Notebook;
Philadelphia Chefs' School In New Home
description: A COOKING school with a commercial restaurant that outgrew its space in Center City has relocated in a restored 19th-century Italianate villa in the Spruce Hill section, an ethnically and architecturally diverse neighborhood where the real-estate market has staged a comeback in recent years.

title: IN DEFENSE OF HACKERS
description: With violent crime at an all-time high, with crack dealers killing each other and innocent bystanders in unprecedented numbers and with the savings-and-loan crooks having looted billions from the Federal treasury, it is reassuring to know that both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Secret Service are out chasing teen-age computer hackers who have "stolen" memos from phone company computers ("In Defense of Hackers" by Craig Bromberg, April 21).

title: Custom Shirts
description: To the Editor: The late Cary Grant, Sean Connery, Tony Curtis, Warren Beatty, Jackie Stewart, Michael Caine, Vidal Sassoon and untold numbers of equally noted style- and quality-conscious customers of Frank Foster, Shirtmaker and Hosier of 10 Clifford Street, London W1, might disagree, as I do, that "the conventional wisdom is that there is really only one place to have shirts made and that is Turnbull & Asser" (Shopper's World, April 21).

title: Playing Name That Tune With 'Miss Saigon'
description: Can a melody be genuinely original and still stick in the mind? Or are catchy songs memorable only because they subliminally recall other tunes in our musical memory banks? That is one of the questions raised by the original London cast album of "Miss Saigon" (Geffen 24721-2; all three formats). (The American cast album will be released Sept. 3.)

title: Indian Election Campaigning Ends Amid Political Violence
description: With opinion polls warily predicting a rightward shift in Indian politics, campaigning ended today with a sense of relief in this capital city and several Indian states that are scheduled to vote on Monday for a new Indian Parliament.

title: On Airline Screens,Bombs Away
description: I'VE been brooding over the way nobody complains about the movies on planes. Everybody complains about the food, but the movies are just as bad, and they're in your face a lot longer.

title: One Bet Lost, General Motors Places Another
description: Financial engineers at General Motors have a tradition of being more creative than their automotive counterparts. But it is arguable as to which group is more responsible for the company's current need for cash.

title: Life Without Father
description: CECIL'S STORY By George Ella Lyon. Illustrated by Peter Catalanotto. Unpaged. New York: Orchard Books. ALL THOSE SECRETS OF THE WORLD By Jane Yolen. Illustrated by Leslie Baker. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. AT THE CROSSROADS Written and illustrated by Rachel Isadora. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Henrietta in Beijing
description: THE CHINA YEAR

title: A Few Bright Passages
description: THESE are the quiet concert days in Westchester, as the music makers rest up from their winter and spring travails and plan ahead for summer. Worthy events remain on the calendar, though, starting this afternoon at 3 o'clock, when the two winners of the Westchester Conservatory's Concerto Competition in March claim their prizes by performing with the Conservatory Orchestra in a free concert at the Stepinac School in White Plains.

title: Westport Wizard: The World Beats a Path to His Door
description: CARL WHITEFORD'S friends say he reminds them of Thomas Edison, and even a casual observer can see his resemblance to Benjamin Franklin. But the 74-year-old Mr. Whiteford says he just wants to be known as a man who has lived his life as an independent inventor.

title: Illusions and Allusions Fill a Show of Fiber Art
description: IN "New Ends," a fiber art exhibition filled with illusions and allusions, nothing is entirely what it seems. This major exhibition by 14 nationally known artists, all of whom are women, is not a show to skate through, glancing at themes, colors and textures with your peripheral vision.

title: In the Language of Lockjaw, Subtext Is All
description: Early on in his career, the playwright A. R. Gurney once observed, he found his subject -- the upper-class WASP's who inhabit the Northeastern corner of the United States and who, for the first half of the 20th century at least, not only ran the country, but also most of the country clubs. For better or worse, he joked, it was a little like writing about the 1957 Chevy. Great car for its time, even if the times had moved on.

title: A LOST VOICE
description: Shammas's article is a much needed antidote in these days when strong opinions are easily come by and current events seem to need no background, no history.

title: For Accuracy, Go to a Ballpark
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Andrew Hill: 'But Not Farewell'

title: Woolf, Proust and Joseph Kell
description: To the Editor:

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Beijing
description: IN YOUR SEARCH FOR A Chinese summer breeze, the best path to choose is the one taken for centuries by China's Emperors and Empresses. When the heat of Beijing became unbearable, all the more stifling for the layers of silk royalty wore, the imperial court would sometimes travel about seven miles northwest of the city to a tranquil lakeside enclave called the Garden of Peace and Harmony.

title: Leslie Bitman Married To John Carroll Weiler
description: Leslie Michelle Bitman, a daughter of Dr. Doris Sumerson Calman of Philadelphia and Dr. Kenneth Bitman of Paoli, Pa., was married yesterday in Philadelphia to John Carroll Weiler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Weiler of New York. District Justice John T. Sachaczenski of the Montgomery County (Pa.) District Court officiated at the Eleanor Widener Dixon House.

title: What Is Chris Whittle Teaching Our Children?
description: It was warm in the living room of Chris Whittle's relentlessly neat living quarters. Outside, rain began to spit from the troubled Tennessee skies, spoiling the arboreal view. Sitting on the couch, straight as a furled umbrella, Whittle placed a phone call to Phil Guarascio, the head of advertising at General Motors. Earlier, he had booked a call with him at this time. But Guarascio was not there. Whittle gave a withering look. "Some day, someone is going to invent a phone system that will automatically find people," he said. "They could be in another city, but the phone will get them. It has to happen. One of the biggest wastes of time is not being able to reach people, even if, like now, you've made an appointment to call them."

title: Ban Pesticides, Rally Organic Gardeners for Turf Lawndering
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan's Friend in Court
description: ORDER AND LAW

title: Charles B. Colmore Jr., Retired Executive, 78
description: Charles Blayney Colmore Jr., a retired executive of the Procter & Gamble Company and a former chair umpire for the United States Lawn Tennis Association, died on May 12 at his home in Baltimore. He was 78.

title: France
description: To the Editor: While trying to pay for merchandise with my Mastercard in Strasbourg recently, I was asked to enter my personal identification number (PIN) on a numeric keypad. Given that I had just received my card, I told the cashier that I did not know my PIN but that I had my passport to prove my identity. I was told that the only way that I could use my Mastercard to make a purchase was by entering my PIN on the keypad. I ended up paying cash. I understand that it is increasingly common for stores in France to ask credit card customers to enter their PIN's when making purchases.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Ramsey
description: ALTHOUGH the six-square-mile borough of Ramsey grew up around its railroad station, there is no wrong side of the tracks. On one end is a private golf club and on the other houses priced from $500,000 to $1 million.

title: Making a Difference; The Man From Spam
description: Call him Mr. Spam. He likes it.

title: Sports of The Times; Preakness: Dreams Die Fast
description: This town is not always kind to hopeful young horses fresh from winning the Kentucky Derby. Too many crabcakes the night before, not enough furlongs in the stretch, too many miles in the van, mud on the track. Whatever. Besides, horses are only human.

title: Ban Pesticides, Rally Organic Gardeners for Turf Lawndering; Truth-Prompting Tree
description: To the Editor:
