description: Chester 380,000 7 Forest View Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, screened porch, deck; taxes $5,970. Freehold 169,000 50 Partridge Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, family room, central air-conditioning, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $3,600. Hackettstown 108,000 17 Shelly Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,938. Hopatcong 105,000 148 Lakeside Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in-kitchen, private location; taxes $2,348. Howell 150,875 9 Stowe Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, central air-conditioning, family room, patio; taxes $3,219. Summit 235,000 10 Woodfern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old split level; updated kitchen, greenhouse, full basement; taxes $4,977. OTHER SALES Hartford, Conn. 100,000 185 Campfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old, brick Cape Cod; new roof, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,974. Ossining, N.Y. 300,000 5 Pheasant Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, country kitchen, family room, Jacuzzi, central air-conditioning; taxes $6,111. Searingtown, L.I. 315,000 122 Serpentine Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $4,400.

title: Kvalsvoll Takes Small Step Toward Today's Big Finish
description: A professional bicycle-racing team is headed by one or two stars. Everyone else is usually a support worker, or, in the inelegant term of the sport, a domestique.

title: Northeast Notebook: Kaolin, Pa.; A 2,000-Acre Master Plan
description: IN an unusual attempt at regional land planning, four major landowners in this mushroom-growing area have joined in an informal master plan for 2,000 acres.

title: INDIA'S DESCENT
description: UNDER THE WHITE-HOT sky of a Delhi summer, a few thousand thin men in faded clothes and tattered turbans have been waiting several hours in the sun for a political rally. There is no spontaneity or joy here, however. The men and a few dozen listless women are mercenaries of a sort, trucked in from the neighboring state of Haryana on the promise of a few rupees or a free trip to town to provide a sea of faces and applause. The portable crowd belongs to Devi Lal, Haryana's political godfather and the Deputy Prime Minister of India. He's sitting in a shaded pavilion, surrounded by a dozen fawning politicians who are preparing to kick off their campaigns for national elections this week. They are served mango juice.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Providence
description: When I moved to Providence over a dozen years ago, a friend who grew up in New York said, "Oh, that's the place where my father always got lost when we drove to Cape Cod." Now that the final Interstate connections are in place, motorists can zip right through Providence. What they are missing is a city with one of the largest and finest collections of 18th- and 19th-century buildings in the country.

title: Corrections
description: A credit today on page 4 of The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentifies the illustrator of the cover. He is Gary Overacre.

title: Oldsmobile Rolls Out a Sporty Truck
description: Last year, for the first time in almost seven decades, Oldsmobile returned to the business of building trucks -- sort of.

title: Tech Notes; Using Sound Waves on Dirty Dishes
description: A small company in California has invented a water-saving dishwasher that removes particles of food from dishes using ultrasonic waves in the same way that jewelry is cleaned. The concern, Ultrasonics Products Inc. of Channel Islands Harbor, Calif., is a subsidiary of a British company that makes jewelry-cleaning equipment.

title: Daniela von Estorff, Marketing Specialist, Marries
description: Daniela Donata von Estorff, a marketing specialist in New York, and Thomas William Rowe, a producer and writer at Visnews, the international television news agency, were married yesterday. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn officiated at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church.

title: The Everyday Disaster of Life in Bangladesh
description: A CYCLONE in the south, flooding in the north, and tornadoes in the center. Those are the latest natural disasters in a country that is often regarded, by Bangladeshis and foreign aid workers alike, as bountiful primarily in misfortune.

title: Recycling? Try Reverse Shopping
description: The recent article "Recycling: No Longer If, but How" prompts these thoughts:

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 14 about artists establishing a cooperative gallery in Hastings-on-Hudson characterized the gallery incorrectly. It is not the first artists' cooperative in the county. A reader's letter received on May 9 points out that in 1963 eight artists opened a cooperative gallery in White Plains; it closed in 1973.

title: Nepalese Party Edges Out the Leftists
description: The centrist Nepali Congress Party, buttressed by support in remote areas after setbacks in Katmandu, was today officially declared the winner of national elections on May 12.

title: Gari Lister Wed To Gerald Farano
description: Penelope Margaret Lister, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lister of Arlington, Va., and London, was married in Washington yesterday to Gerald Patrick Farano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Farano of Smithtown, L.I. The Rev. Kwasi Thornell performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington Cathedral.

title: 'Thicker Than Water'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RED WOLF, RED WOLF By W. P. Kinsella.Southern Methodist University,Cloth, $17.50; Paper, $8.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MEMOIR OF ITALO SVEVO By Livia Veneziani Svevo. Marlboro, $28.95.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Working Girl
description: LYDDIE

title: A la Carte: Beyond Pasta and Pizza
description: THE little storefront Italian cafes and trattorias of Long Island are omnipresent. One can drive past dozens daily. Some serve great gobs of the ordinary and are no more than dispensers of steam-table style cafeteria fare, just a step up from fast food.

title: Bibliophilic Pleasures
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Moscow Hotel Back in Business
description: The landmark Metropol Hotel in Moscow has reopened, with a joint Soviet-American management team at the helm.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the pop page of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about the singer Paula Abdul referred incorrectly to Janet Jackson's album "Rhythm Nation 1814." It was her fourth album, not her second.

title: 'The White Castle'
description: A new star has risen in the east -- Orhan Pamuk, a Turkish writer. And if "The White Castle" is representative of his fiction, he has earned the right to comparisons with Jorge Luis Borges and Italo Calvino, both of whom preside over this novel like beneficent angels.

title: Math Regents Anxiety? Stay Tuned
description: STUDENTS throughout the state who are preparing for the Sequential Math I Regents examination may see a telecast of a teacher discussing the exam and answering their call-in questions from a cable television studio in Ossining on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a deck built last fall with pressure-treated lumber. We were told to let it weather for six months. Now we are ready to apply a clear water-repellent sealer. But we don't know how to remove the manufacturer's ink stamps. Our dealer says the only way is to try sanding out the marks out. What do you suggest?

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: It sounds as if Tom Horton has been camping in our backyard ("Deer on Your Doorstep," April 28). We live in a suburb 25 miles from Manhattan, in the most densely populated state in the country. Our neighbors and frequent visitors include deer, raccoons, groundhogs, skunks, opossums and chipmunks.

title: Grace Rhee Wed To James S. Biggs
description: Grace Jin Rhee, an office manager in San Diego, and Lieut. James Sheridan Biggs of the United States Naval Reserve were married yesterday in St. Christopher's Galilee Chapel at the North Island Naval Air Station in Coronado, Calif. Comdr. Floyd C. Ellison, a Protestant chaplain and an American Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Headliners; Settlement Ends Legal Action Over Tainted Tylenol
description: IN September 1982, seven people died in the Chicago area after swallowing Tylenol capsules that had been tainted with cyanide, replaced in their packaging and put on store shelves for sale. The killings marked the first such product tampering and instilled a new kind of fear in consumers who had taken for granted the safety of the over-the-counter products in their medicine chests. For their part, manufacturers were forced to rethink packaging to incorporate the stamp "tamper-resistant."

title: Style Makers; Nancy Whitney, Jewelry Designer
description: It's not necessary to have jewelers' skills to design and make jewelry but in the case of Nancy Whitney, who started her business two years ago, such skills would most certainly be superfluous.

title: All About/Snack Foods; Keeping the Gobblers, Chasing the Nibblers
description: As aging baby boomers thicken around the middle, they nibble instead of gobble. Blithe college students shovel corn chips straight from the bag into their mouths, but paunchy young professionals count their Ritz crackers as they reach for the bean dip.

title: Bottom-Fishing in the Gas Patch
description: If natural gas ever had a chance to move closer to center stage in supplying the nation's energy needs, the time is now. The war in the Persian Gulf exposed anew America's vulnerability to imported oil. Five years after Chernobyl, nuclear power is still shunned. And global warming has further darkened the cloud over coal.

title: Topics of the Times
description: There's a Catch

title:
Your Own Account;
Are 'Wrap Arounds' Overpriced?
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into potential abuses in wrap accounts, one of the most rapidly growing financial services products.

title: Visiting Volunteers Help Parents Cope
description: HER name isn't Mimi. But when Dorothy Leyendecker walks into the Malan household in Manchester, three blond-haired toddlers dash up to her shouting, "Hi, Mimi L." She gathers them up into her arms for a communal hug.

title:
ART;
Liberation Through Collage
description: MANY people would agree that a major significance of collage as an art technique lies in its ability to liberate forms, images and objects from pre-existing connotations. Sometimes the approach produces layers of material and texture. In other instances it leads to layers of suggestive ideas that become pithy and provocative in their new artist-invented juxtapositions.

title:
Creative Landscapes;
The Giants of the Black Hills
description: YOU REMEMBER MOUNT RUSHMORE FROM YOUR ninth-grade civics class. It's the four President heads carved into the mountain. The sculpture is huge and is called "America's shrine of democracy" because it commemorates the vision of this country that the men on the mountain maintained through trying times in our history. I know all this because I am too often impressed into service as an amateur Mount Rushmore tour guide. This is tough duty because, for all of its seriousness, there is something about Mount Rushmore that is hard to love.

title: Sayonara, San Francisco
description: STRAWBERRY ROAD

title: When Mouse and Tony Got Married
description: THE DIAMOND LANE

title: Jennifer Kimball Wed to Daniel Beard
description: Jennifer Dodge Kimball and Daniel Parker Beard, graphics designers in Massachusetts, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Phillip J. Zaeder officiated, assisted by Charles F. Harper, a seminarian.

title: The World; Democracy or Not, This Is Riot Season in Seoul
description: WHEN the tear gas cleared in early 1988 and Roh Tae Woo transformed himself from a general into South Korea's first directly elected president in decades, politicians of all stripes said they knew the solution for all of the country's ills: more democracy.

title: Personal Landscape
description: Is this Persia? No, it's Hudson, N.Y., where Olana, the fantasy mansion perched above the Hudson River, embodies the Romantic vision of the 19th-century artist Frederic Edwin Church. At Olana, the painter not only built the house, but also customized the surrounding scenery. And just as people act upon landscapes, so do landscapes act upon people. For our authors, a stand of tricentenary oaks, a wild and ragged Australian coast or a quirky Georgia sculpture garden are personal Elysiums. The choice is yours: let your fancy take you to a feast in a remote Mexican village, or head for the Black Hills of South Dakota, where Mount Rushmore, celebrating its 50th birthday this year, is perhaps the biggest man-made landscape of them all.

title: Sunday Outing; An Old-Fashioned Day at the Races
description: When Belmont Park Race Track opens each May, a day at the races turns into an event for the whole family, even people who have little interest in thoroughbreds.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Outsmarting Smarty-Pants
description: BEST ENEMIES AGAIN

title: Suffolk Bar Group Offers Wide Training
description: I was pleased to read "Nassau County Divorce Lawyers Bask in National Attention" recognizing the quality of competency of the Nassau County matrimonial bar.

title: Nature Can Live With Free Trade
description: President Bush's commitment linking the environment and free trade has made it possible for environmentalists to support putting the negotiations on the U.S.-Mexico pact on the "fast track." The National Wildlife Federation can thus confidently call for Capitol Hill's endorsement of this process, which would prohibit amendments to the trade agreement and force Congress to accept or reject the accord in its entirety.

title: Poor and Illegal, Mexicans Lose Hope in New York
description: Beaten down by a dismal economy, Lucas V. left his construction job, a wife and two children in Mexico and ventured to New York in search of the nest egg that would enable him to open a small business back home. After two years of laboring on construction sites for $260 a week, he is no closer to his goal than when he first arrived.

title: Designated Deity
description: ALMIGHTY ME By Robert Bausch. 263 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: NEWARK ANNIVERSARY

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Kings Park 147,000 10 Norma Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,400. Levittown 138,000 27 Old Oak Lane 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 41- year-old ranch; new kitchen, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. Muttontown 630,000 85 Coach Lane West 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage, 0.50 acre; taxes $10,000. Ronkonkoma 71,000 21 Creighton Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $866. Searingtown 315,000 122 Serpentine Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $4,400. Syosset 202,000 74 Meadowbrook Road, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 62-year-old colonial; sunroom, front porch, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. OTHER AREAS Hartford, Conn. 100,000 185 Campfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old, brick Cape Cod; new roof, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,974. Ossining, N.Y. 300,000 5 Pheasant Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, country kitchen, family room, Jacuzzi, central air-conditioning; taxes $6,111. Hopatcong, N.J. 105,000 148 Lakeside Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in-kitchen, private location; taxes $2,348.

title: Seattle Downs Punchless Yanks
description: For eight innings yesterday, the power was out, the lineup was still and there again were no Yankees at home. Then came a home run by Jesse Barfield, the first Yankee bat to return from an unwanted 32-inning vacation from scoring.

title: Promoting the Arts And Good Health
description: Literacy Volunteers of New York City was the beneficiary of an evening of readings by authors at the Vivian Beaumont Theater Monday night. Barbara Bush was the guest of honor.

title: The World; Wanderers In the Desert Of Diplomacy
description: MORE than two months after the gulf war ended, its real impact on the Persian Gulf, on the Arab-Israeli conflict and on the Middle East as a whole was finally coming into sharp focus last week, as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d paid yet another visit to the region. It is an odd picture, full of large victories and unintended consequences, hornets' nests where people least expected them and business as usual where people most wanted change.

title:
POP MUSIC;
Out of the 60's, Into His 50's
description: Bob Dylan has long led his generation, and not only by influencing the way we sing and write, speak and look. His 1963 anthem, "Blowin' in the Wind," revolutionized pop music by showing that topicality that was radical and sincere could sell millions of records. His 1985 "Biograph" -- three compact disks mixing greatest hits with outtakes -- kicked off a boom in boxed sets and reissues. Both set trends from which the music business still profits.

title: Young Performers Share Spotlight
description: IN 1961, 55 students from nine towns played the first concert of the Connecticut Youth Symphony, a program that featured, among other compositions, the March from Mendelssohn's "Athalie." The original objective, "to provide an outlet for young musicians interested in acquiring ensemble experience" has remained in place through the years, but almost every other aspect of the symphony has expanded.

title: Take Your Places, Please, Ladies And Gentlemen
description: The following list is selective. Performances rarely occur every day of the week, and programs are subject to change. Alabama

title: A Legacy of Idealism from Serkin
description: Memory has its own priorities, its own bent logic. When I first heard of Rudolf Serkin's death 11 days ago at the age of 88, the image that came to mind immediately was not that of Serkin the magisterial performer of Beethoven, Schubert and Mozart. Instead, what I instantly remembered was another pianist's Beethoven recital, an event made indelible for me because Serkin was in the audience, seated a few rows away.

title: Kurdish Leader Reports Accord With Baghdad
description: In a potentially significant move toward ending the refugee crisis, Kurdish rebel leaders in Baghdad announced today that they had reached a 20-point agreement in principle with the Iraqi authorities for democracy throughout the country and autonomy in the Kurdish-speaking north.

title: Creative Landscapes; Persia High on the Hudson
description: "A FEUDAL CASTLE WHICH I AM BUILDING UNDER THE modest name of dwelling house," wrote the painter Frederic Edwin Church to a friend in 1871, "absorbs all my time and attention. I am obliged to watch it so closely, for having undertaken to get my architecture from Persia where I have never been, nor any of my friends either, I am obliged to imagine Persian architecture, then embody it on paper and explain it to a lot of mechanics whose ideal of architecture is wrapped up in felicitous recollections of a successful brick schoolhouse or meeting house or jail."

title: DIALOGUE -- American Intelligence: Do We Still Need the C.I.A.?; Independence Means Integrity
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's effort to abolish the Central Intelligence Agency and transfer its functions to the State Department is a recipe for disaster. Giving the Secretary of State chief responsibility for intelligence raises the specter of "cooking" intelligence to support a preconceived policy. The separation of intelligence-gathering and foreign policy is a fundamental principle.

title: Angela Janklow, A Writer, Weds
description: Angela LeRoy Janklow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Janklow of New York, was married yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden to Gerald Christopher Harrington Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrington of Bronxville, N.Y. Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: A Women's Collective Makes Its Debut
description: MAMAYA, the world's first mother, says she has been cleaning up the planet for centuries. When the house of a successful journalist burns down mysteriously, Mamaya, who has been "around the world in the past 24 hours," materializes to help the renovators, who are stuck in their own emotional wreckage, get rid of personal "residue": heartache, self-hatred and hurt feelings.

title: Children Find a Message in Trash
description: AMONG piles of discarded tires, crumpled soft drink cans and coiled garden hoses poised as if to strike, 7-year-old Nicole Maiello of Wayne stood wide-eyed and transfixed. A battered steam radiator, lurking behind a mound of construction refuse, cast an ominous shadow.

title: Death by Red Tape
description: "If we providers were to design a maternal health care system," a nurse at New York's St. Vincent's Hospital says, "this is the one we'd provide." Her praise is for the "one-stop shopping" system urged by the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality for the three million American women who receive little or no prenatal care. All these women are poor. Most are minority. And the chaotic fragmentation of their medical care helps explain why the United States trails 22 other nations in preventing infant deaths.

title: New Strains of Lyme Bacteria Found
description: AS the warming weather brings more outdoor activities, many people are aware of the danger posed by ticks that carry Lyme disease. But even after 16 years of study, the tiny deer tick has not yielded all its secrets.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: A leak in the ceiling is a disaster and a dripping tap is not. But despite the undoubted inconvenience and the expense of repairing the ceiling, there's absolutely no question that the drip, drip, drip, or plop, plop, plop, or call it what you will is the thing that, unchecked, will drive most people crazy.

title: Honor for Laettner
description: When CHRISTIAN LAETTNER, the high-scoring center who led Duke to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, learned that he had been chosen as the Harvard Lampoon's 1991 Man of the Year, he thought it was a joke.

title: 'Does Your Flesh Wobble and Seem Dimpled?'
description: THE BEAUTY MYTH How Images of Beauty Are Used Against Women. By Naomi Wolf. 348 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

title: U.S. Planning to Send a Brigade to Kuwait
description: The United States agreed this week to a request from Kuwait to send a brigade of 3,700 armored troops there from Europe to help maintain order while Kuwaiti forces regroup in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today.

title: Propane Tanks Nettle Garden City
description: HOMEOWNERS in Garden City are trying to have two propane tanks and a gas-distribution plant moved out of their area. The two 30,000-gallon containers and a group of smaller ones are at a propane-filling station at 39 Denton Avenue South on a congested industrial strip in the unincorporated section of New Hyde Park.

title: Campus Life: Missouri-Columbia; New Curriculum Is Emphasizing Required Courses
description: Abandoning a "smorgasbord" approach to education that left students relatively free to study whatever they wanted, the University of Missouri-Columbia is increasing the number of courses students must take and narrowing their choices among courses they can elect to take.

title:
Hers;
Common Decency
description: SHE WAS DEEPLY IN love with a man who was treating her badly. To assuage her wounded ego (and to prove to herself that she could get along nicely without him), she invited another man, an old boyfriend, to a dinner

title: 'When Mother Became History'
description: A WOMAN'S STORY By Annie Ernaux. Translated by Tanya Leslie. 92 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. $15.95.

title: Coping Without the Cold War
description: SECURING EUROPE

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Sophisticated Traveler/Mag. Part 2

title: Despite a Sharp Darling, Mets Crumble
description: Bad baseball left a heap of debris on the field -- terrible errors, unearned runs, wasted performances, a 4-3 loss to the Dodgers. Bad feelings afterward left some almost equally unpleasant litter throughout the Mets' clubhouse -- anger, confusion, paranoia, doubt.

title: Iraqis Pull Back in North; U.N. to Send Some Guards
description: Iraqi troops withdrew today from some positions around the provincial center of Dohuk, and the United Nations said that it would send a small contingent of armed security guards to the city on Sunday under an agreement being worked out with the Baghdad Government.

title: Say Ouch; Demands to Fix U.S. Health Care Reach a Crescendo
description: THE American health care system is the most expensive in the world, but for those not in its mainstream, the care it offers is among the most unsatisfactory. Americans pay $700 billion a year for health care but 34 million of them remain uninsured. Life expectancy in the United States is shorter than in 15 other nations, and infant mortality is worse than in 22 other countries.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: I was dismayed to learn that "Winter's Tale" "suffered from an excess of surrealism." The book was one of the reasons I moved to New York City. Because of it, I am now, eight years later, unable to go into Grand Central Terminal without looking up at the constellations on its high ceiling. I cross the Brooklyn Bridge with reverence.

title: First Briton in Space Goes Aloft With 2 Astronauts on Soviet Craft
description: A 27-year-old chemist today became the first Briton in space when she and two Soviet astronauts blasted off here aboard a spacecraft on an eight-day mission.

title: 'Best Lawyers' Include Women
description: I was very disturbed by the gender-biased and prejudicial nature of "Nassau County Divorce Lawyers Bask in National Attention" [ April 7 ] .

title: Managing; Back from the Great Outdoors
description: When Thomas E. McGee, the training director at the Naval Weapon Support Center, a naval base in Crane, Ind., sent civilian employees to climb high ropes and bridge wide chasms, he was sure he was helping them build self-esteem and become better team players. After all, that's what proponents of so-called outdoor challenge training had always claimed.

title: Streetscapes: 128 East 93d Street; Status for an 1866 Frame Home
description: HIDDEN within almost any historic-disrict proposal is the opportunity to preserve buildings that once managed to escape individual landmark designation but that now face regulation as part of a protected neighborhood.

title: Miss Fairchild Weds R. P. Griswold Jr.
description: Stephanie Boyd Fairchild was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York to Roger Parkman Griswold Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Griswold of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Luke L. Travers, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Twilight Racing At Finger Lakes
description: Finger Lakes Race Track will introduce a twilight racing program on June 5, track officials announced Friday.

title: Liz Buckingham, Lawyer, Marries
description: Elizabeth Cooley Buckingham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Buckingham of Baltimore, was married yesterday at the Old Otterbein Methodist Church in Baltimore to Denny Howard Silverman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Silverman of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Douglas Fox officiated

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We had a deck built last fall with pressure-treated lumber. We were told to let it weather for six months. Now we are ready to apply a clear water-repellent sealer. But we don't know how to remove the manufacturer's ink stamps. Our dealer says the only way is to try sanding out the marks out. What do you suggest?

title: In Search of a Good Borrower
description: Get rid of the money. That is usually what bankers do. Theodore H. Silbert, at 86 perhaps the country's oldest active banker, knows that. Bankers are supposed to loan money. But Ted Silbert is rattled easily. Which is why for quite a few years the bank he runs has clung furiously to so many of its dollars.

title: Design; Kitchen Debates
description: Kitchens date easily. Appliances, materials, color schemes and layouts reflect the tastes and social habits of an age. An untouched kitchen in a classic prewar apartment speaks volumes. Relegated to the back of the apartment, the kitchen is generally a simple, dingy space entered through a long butler's pantry with a rabbit warren of maid's rooms extending off it.

title: Technology; Metals That Memorize a Shape
description: When most eyeglasses are accidentally bent out of shape, it is hard to repair them perfectly. But if the frame of a pair of glasses is made with a metal with "shape memory," the frame can be restored to its original shape by dipping it in warm water. And in the latest refinement, some glasses are now available with frames that regain their shape without the liquid.

title: New York Transit Is Called Better but Still Bad
description: Dangerous and plagued by fires and crime, yet better than just a couple of years ago. That is the mixed report card given to trains, buses and subways in the New York metropolitan region in a study that is to be released on Sunday by the Department of Transportation.

title: A Drape of One's Own
description: NURSE LUGTON'S CURTAIN By Virginia Woolf. Illustrated by Julie Vivas. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title:
BACK TALK;
Born and Bred to Be a Coach
description: Driving home after my first informal practice as the varsity basketball coach at River Dell High School in Oradell, N.J., in 1958, I realized that one player had continually attracted my attention because of his athletic skills, work ethic and instincts. But the more I thought about it, I realized that this player had been watching me even more than I had been watching him.

title: Headliners; Out of the Game
description: Before the football season started last year, Bill Parcells, the head coach of the New York Giants, said, "If we win the Superbowl again, I'm gone." They did. He is. Parcells announced last week that he was quitting after 10 years with the Giants, eight of them as head coach. Parcells, who has taken the team to five playoffs and two Superbowl victories, was vague about why he was leaving and where he was going. There was speculation that he was worried about his health -- he has had weight problems for years and has recently experienced chest pains -- and that he was considering a move to broadcasting -- he auditioned for NBC -- though he might make less as a commentator than the $750,000 a year he earned as coach. Of his plans, he would only say, "My interests are going in a new direction." But the coach also conveyed a sense of wanting to leave football at the top of his game. "I've given everything I could for 10 years," he said. "The job for me now was going to be just to maintain."

title: Louis Severin Tregre, Interior Designer, 66
description: Louis Severin Tregre, an interior designer who specialized in health-care centers and furnishings for the elderly, died on Friday at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dangerous Don DeLillo
description: Until 1985, when "White Noise," his eighth novel, won the National Book Award, Don DeLillo was something of a cipher. He had for years been the kind of writer whose books commanded front-page reviews but still managed not to sell. He was well known in literary circles, and to a small, devoted following, but the chiselled sentences and prescient terrors of his fiction made him difficult to promote. His work seemed privy to a flow of recent history that had been obscured from the rest of us -- DeLillo had important information about the tenor of our national life, information that we had been feeling in our bones but that he had hardened into words.

title:
ART;
The Circus Returns, On Canvas, at Least
description: ANNE COHEN DEPIETRO, former curator of the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, has returned by invitation to put into effect an idea that arose several years ago, while she was on the museum staff.

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; Rome
description: WHEN SUMMER GETS fierce in Rome, even the occasional breeze has trouble denting the heat shimmying off the cobblestones. The best thing to do then is to head for the hills, which is what Romans have wisely been doing for centuries. One of my favorites is the Janiculum, not one of the famous Seven Hills but a pleasant oasis looming behind and above the narrow streets of Trastevere. It is a short cab ride from the city center, or, if you prefer, a trip on the No. 41 bus.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Hunters may scorn a mounted doe's head as a fitting trophy for their macho sport, but it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that killing bucks and leaving does free to reproduce adds to the total number of deer rather than decreases it. If wildlife "managers" were genuinely interested in reducing the deer population, they would permit only does to be hunted. Better still, they would ban hunting and let nature achieve a natural population balance. GENELL SUBAK-SHARPE New York, N.Y.

title: Design Bill Protects Against Trade Theft
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 14 with the Streetscapes column, about Public School 16 on West 13th Street in Manhattan, misidentified the year. A recent letter from a reader questioned the date; the picture was made in 1933.

title: Theft Abroad
description: To the Editor: During an Easter trip through Switzerland and France, my pocketbook was stolen at a ski resort. The beauty of the snow-capped mountains was so awesome that I let down my vigilance. In that unguarded moment, I became an American stripped of all identity and completely penniless.

title: Six Promising Designers Get a Stage
description: Designers who can't afford to put on fashion shows can get lost in the shuffle. So Saks Fifth Avenue turned the spotlight on six small but promising design companies at a show on Wednesday evening. The lucky designers were Bradley Bayou, Eva Chun, Badgley Mischka, Tom and Linda Platt, Arabella Pollen and Rodney Telford. Each showed 12 outfits.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Gary Thomas: 'While the Gate Is Open' JMT 834439-2/4; CD and cassette.

title: Once Headed For Trouble, Students Are Bound For College
description: NOT too long ago, Cle Johnson had few illusions about what life held for him after high school. "I'd be dead or in jail," said Mr. Johnson, an 18-year-old from Norwalk. "It didn't look too good out there."

title: In Chicago Courtroom, Nation's First Super Gang Fights for Life
description: In two heavily guarded courtrooms high above the streets of the city, Federal prosecutors deliver what they hope will be the decisive blows in a 25-year battle with Chicago's most notorious street gang, the El Rukns.

title: Wall Street; A Good Bargain in Blue Chips?
description: Back in the Roaring Twenties, when the national cocktail was bathtub gin and the stock market was everybody's dream machine, the Adams Express Company was at a crossroads. Its basic business, shipping small parcels around the country, had been invaded by the Post Office Department, and the nation's booming railroads were offering handsome prices for its rolling stock. It was time for a change.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE beach was alive -- buried beneath birds and hard-shelled animals. The din was incredible.

title: A Sampling of Expeditions
description: ECOTOURISM is the travel buzzword of the 90's. Dozens of nonprofit environmental groups are vigorously working to preserve natural areas and selling field excursions to their members. And a new crop of environmental entrepeneurs -- scientists, professors, former Peace Corps workers and tour operators -- has begun capitalizing on the interests of a generation raised on Rachel Carson and Jacques-Yves Cousteau.

title: Meredith Maurer Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Meredith Ann Maurer, an interior designer, and Jeffrey Morris Hutchison, an architect, both in New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert C. Maurer of Westport, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: AUDIT FINDS LOSSES IN MORTGAGE FUNDS
description: An independent audit of several Federal funds that insure mortgages shows that they lost $3.9 billion in 1989 and are likely to lose more in the future.

title: Patches
description: EIGHT HANDS ROUND A Patchwork Alphabet. By Ann Whitford Paul. Illustrated by Jeanette Winter. Unpaged. New York: HarperCollins Publishers.

title: No Architect Is an Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Pill Politics
description: RU 486 The Pill That Could End the Abortion Wars and Why American Women Don't Have It. By Lawrence Lader. 172 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A WALK IN PARK HILL

title: Topics of the Times; The War According to Riyadh
description: Saudi Arabia is understandably sensitive to reminders that it invited infidels to the Persian Gulf to help settle an Arab dispute. And officials in Riyadh are now said to be upset that the world has not fully appreciated their financial and military contributions to the allied victory.

title: COURTING THE VIRGIN QUEEN
description: ONCE UPON A time, my driver tells me, he drove Bing Crosby and Bob Hope all over England and Scotland looking for interesting golf courses to play. Hope and Crosby were wonderfully funny, he says. The driver, a cheerful Scotsman, allows that he knows a lot about Americans and their odd interests and habits but has never yet met one like me. He has never before driven anyone who wanted to go very slowly along very old routes and roads, looking at the landscape, with books and notebooks, maps and guides scattered all over the car, trying to keep count of streams and old stone bridges, searching for ruins and monuments, farmhouses and guildhalls, a parish church here, an inn or market cross there, and sometimes a sudden view of what the Elizabethans called a great house, one of those palatial mansions we now call stately homes.

title: Italy Reopens Investigation Into 1981 Shooting of Pope
description: Ten years after Pope John Paul II was shot and nearly killed in St. Peter's Square, the Italian Government is reopening its investigation into who and what was behind the Turkish gunman now serving a life sentence for the attack.

title: Suffolk Bar Group Offers Wide Training
description: I was pleased to read "Nassau County Divorce Lawyers Bask in National Attention" recognizing the quality of competency of the Nassau County matrimonial bar.

title: More Self-Immolations in Seoul Protests
description: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into streets in cities across South Korea again today, clashing with the police in the fourth week of anti-Government protests.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
'Gurrelieder' on Records: Two of the Best Ever
description: The period of music we call Romantic reached several sorts of culminations in the works of composers like Gustav Mahler and Richard Strauss. But no summation could be more final and magnificent than Arnold Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder," composed with symbolic fitness mostly in 1900 (though not performed until 1911).

title: Why Mixing Defense and Commercial Ventures Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Madonna and the Master at Cannes
description: Madonna and Akira Kurosawa: flesh and the spirit. Also, for that matter, spirit and the flesh. To be a show-business legend in your own time, you can't have one without the other. This was what film aficionados might call the subtext of the first week of the 44th Cannes Film Festival, which ends tomorrow night after 12 days of screenings.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Large-Size Gowns

title: The World; A Verdict Against His Wife Brings New Grief for Mandela
description: NELSON MANDELA'S face froze in bereavement last week as he heard a Johannesburg court convict his wife, Winnie, as a kidnapper and accessory to assault. When the judge was done, he slumped into a chair vacated by a policeman and suddenly seemed very frail.

title: Clothes That Reflect a Culture
description: In recent years young black professionals who wanted their wardrobes for work to reflect their culture started wearing scarfs, bow ties and cummerbunds made of kente, a colorful cloth with intricate designs, tightly woven on narrow looms in Ghana. But now some are finding that these modest additions are no longer enough.

title: Woolf, Proust and Joseph Kell
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Opposes a Budget Without Stealth
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that he would recommend that President Bush veto the proposed defense budget unless it contained money for additional stealth bombers and for the "Star Wars" antimissile system.

title: Stamford Snags Baseball Memories That Could Bring Joy to Mudville
description: SOUNDS of a roaring crowd introduce "Play Ball," an exhibition of baseball lore that will be on view through July 7 at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: Travel Advisory; Taking the River Bus to the Plane
description: The London river bus has increased its service to City Airport, in East London, from one every hour to three an hour and has added four departure points to the airport along the River Thames. The first bus leaves at 7 A.M. Monday to Friday from Charing Cross Pier and then every 20 minutes until 7:40 P.M., when the last bus leaves.

title: Data Update
Nancy Wu Wed To Edwynn Houk
description: Nancy Hsueh-Min Wu, and Edwynn Houk were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Bruce W. Forbes. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Ching-Te Wu of Syracuse. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guilford E. Houk of Detroit.

title: The Nation; 'Race Norming' Tests Becomes a Fiery Issue
description: IN the Reagan Administration 10 years ago, the Department of Labor started encouraging state employment agencies to give black and Hispanic applicants a break on employment aptitude tests. It asked the agencies to rig the scores of minority group members to enhance their chances of getting jobs. Without the rigging, the minority applicants typically scored lower than whites.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the British royal family misstated the reason the sovereign is called Defender of the Faith. In 1521, Pope Leo X gave the title to King Henry VIII, who had written a defense of the Roman Catholic Church in response to Martin Luther; the title did not derive from Henry's later break with the church. The article also referred incorrectly to the sovereign's role as head of the Church of England. It derives from an act of Parliament, not from the designation as Defender of the Faith.

title: Forwarding Address for Billy Owens: Easy Street
description: Sometime between now and November, the fortunes of the Owens family will take a dramatic turn for the better. Eugene William (Billy) Owens, the youngest of Marsha and William's five children, is expected to be the first player selected in the National Basketball Association draft on June 26.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: In 1958, I was the producer of "Eye on New York," a WCBS-TV news and documentary program. One of our segments in the fall of that year dealt with the growing deer population, similar to that described in your article. One of the ways suggested to cull the herds of deer was to extend the hunting season for bow-and-arrow hunters. To illustrate, we asked an expert archer to shoot several arrows the length of the studio, using a drawing of a deer's head as a target. This was in the pre-videotape days and was telecast live. As those steel-tipped arrows hit the target, the control room phones lit up with viewers deploring the killing of Bambi.

title: Bush's Illness Shows Folly of 'Cost Containment' in Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Difference; Green Machine
description: Baby boomers who spent much of the 1980's tending their bank accounts now seem to be turning to more organic pursuits: growing flowers, trees and vegetables.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BRONX RIVER PARKWAY;
From Bikes, a New Landmark Is Glimpsed at a Proper Speed
description: DAVID M. BROWN was all geared up for bike riding.

title:
Creative Landscapes;
A Vision of Paradise In Georgia
description: HOWARD FINSTER saw his first vision at the age of 3, and in the 71 years that have followed, that image has multiplied and splintered and grown and been made manifest in a garden of art that beats anything this side of Eden.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Days of Borscht and Herring
description: The sparkling IT HAPPENED IN THE CATSKILLS: An Oral History in the Words of Busboys, Bellhops, Guests, Proprietors, Comedians, Agents, and Others Who Lived It (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $24.95), illustrated with evocative period photographs, captures the flavor of the Borscht Belt -- that 250-square-mile area of Yiddish culture and Yankee ambition north of New York City. Beginning in the 1920's, as many as 500 hotels and bungalow colonies catered to the "organized pursuit of pleasure" of thousands of vacationers. Ironically, write Myrna Katz Frommer and Harvey Frommer, while the avowed purpose of hotels like the Concord and Grossinger's was to give city people a chance to enjoy the fresh mountain air and the beautiful countryside, memories cling to the inside -- the dining room, the nightclub, the dance studio. (The comedian Mal Z. Lawrence quipped, "They have an outside here, too?") Entertainers such as Eddie Fisher, Tony Martin, Neil Sedaka, Jackie Mason and Sid Caesar faced the most critical audience they would ever meet; the Catskills resorts served as a springboard for the pursuit of the American dream. The area was also the true home of improvisation -- the architecture itself was a product of fantasy and necessity -- from the proprietors, who sometimes rented the same room twice, to the musicians who doubled as waiters and bellhops, to the entertainers who nightly played the same show at three hotels, to the medical and law students who earned tuition as busboys. Between the seven kinds of herring in the dining room and Simon Says at the pool, the Frommers, who write frequently on sports and on Jewish subjects, take the reader on a sunny cruise down memory lane.

title: Bridge
description: For the first 13 years of its history, the prestigious Cavendish Invitational Pairs was won by American players. But their period of dominance has come to an end. When the 1991 event ended a week ago in Manhattan, the victory went to a European partnership for the third time in four years.

title: Waves of Sewage and Auto Traffic Sweep Down on U.S. From Canada
description: The complaints from American officials sound familiar: pollution from an outdated sewage system fouling international waters, and a surge of people crossing the border, some of them illegally, in search of economic oppportunity.

title: Review/Ballet; Ballerina Takes Charge in a Robbins Duet
description: It seemed as if it would be a relatively ordinary night of repertory on Thursday evening when the New York City Ballet performed at the New York State Theater. Then Kyra Nichols danced onto the stage with Robert La Fosse in Jerome Robbins's "Other Dances," and the night became historic.

title: Mets Deny Report of Sale
description: Fred Wilpon, who shares ownership of the Mets with Nelson Doubleday, said early yesterday morning that a report that the team was up for sale was "totally erroneous."

title: Boxing's Biggest Showcase: Atlantic City or Las Vegas?
description: THE recent heavyweight championship fight between Evander Holyfield and George Foreman has focused new attention on the competition between Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., to become the nation's boxing capital, experts on the boxing industry say.

title: On the Street; Let's Take The Mules For a Walk
description: The Marquise de Pompadour and Marie Antoinette popularized the mule in the 18th century because it put their feet on dainty pedestals and made them look very small. Marilyn Monroe and Joan Crawford revived the style in the 1950's because Hollywood thought it was sexy. The backless shoes they wore were set on stiletto heels. Back then, an elastic band set into the arch kept the shoe on and give it some spring; hence its name,Spring-o-Lators. Today, women are wearing mules set mostly on Louis XV heels because they are comfortable and look chic with the popular leggings that end above the ankle. Pumps and strappy sandals don't quite make it.

title: Miss Paschal Weds Christopher Reich
description: Eleanor Merriman Paschal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Paschal of Purchase, N.Y., and Christopher Verrill Reich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Donald Reich of Ridgewood, N.J., and Point O'Woods, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley officiated.

title: Campus Life: Webb; Boat Built by Four Looks Like a Bike And May Get Prize
description: Their senior project is called "twentysomething," and although it is technically a boat, it looks like a bicycle and has a propeller.

title: The Graying of a Co-op: Looking Within for Help
description: Not long ago most of the complaints before the tenant relations committee at Morningside Gardens involved the same type of problem: the smell coming from an elderly recluse's apartment, a senile woman's wanderings, an aging alcoholic whose wife locked him out whenever he was drunk.

title: CRIME
description: Jerry Oster calls his new Manhattan police procedural VIOLENT LOVE (Bantam, $19), but a more apt title might be "Sicko Sex." To the artists, authors and other sophisticates in this hyperkinetic crime novel, which opens with the discovery of a fashion model's hacked-up corpse floating in the Harlem River, sex isn't fun unless it's dangerous. Or at least indelicate. Even Joe Cullen, the Mr. Nice Guy detective on the grisly case, is turned on by the exhibitionistic antics of the seductive woman who snaps up the widowed husband of the murder victim.

title: Though Quayle Seems Shoo-In for '92, Leading the '96 Ticket Is No Sure Bet
description: Vice President Dan Quayle will almost certainly be nominated for another term next year, senior officials of the Republican Party say, despite public anxieties about his abilities that have flared up again as a result of President Bush's heart and thyroid difficulties.

title: Amy L. Grotta To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Grotta of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynn Grotta, to Jon Andrew Cummins, the son of Richard J. Cummins of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Eleanor Chanler of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title:
THEATER;
Seeking the Words To Recapture a Past and Shape a Future
description: I sit at the back of a large low-ceilinged room on the 18th floor of a building squeezed in among the porno shops and fast-food places of West 42d Street in Manhattan. The studio belongs to the Women's Project, the producers of "Night Sky," a new play by Susan Yankowitz opening Wednesday at the Judith Anderson Theater down the street. Today is the first read-through.

title: The Annapurna Experiment
description: FOR all I had imagined the soaring splendor of Nepal, little prepared me for the hardscrabble pragmatism of my first night in the Himalayas. My lodging was with Dhan Bhadar Churung, a small entrepreneur at the forefront of an international experiment in conservation, tourism and economic development.

title: Redefining 'Productive'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Oyster Bay, Old Order Changeth Slowly
description: IN the early 1900's, when Theodore Roosevelt established his summer White House in the Victorian mansion of Sagamore Hill, he was lured by the beauty of the sheltered bay and surrounding woodlands, the quiet streets of Oyster Bay and the village's importance in American history.

title: Campus Life: Lock Haven; Fitness Program Helping Faculty To Get in Shape
description: Hollywood stars and busy executives say they can't live without their personal physical trainers, and a lot of other people want them too. So Lock Haven University is trying to meet that demand and, as a byproduct, to improve the health of the school's faculty and administrators.

title: Miss Barth Wed To J. C. Samsen
description: Suzanne Denise Barth, the daughter of Barbara Barth of Uniondale, L.I., and the late William Barth, was married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., to Jeffrey Christopher Samsen, the son of Mrs. George Crohn Jr. and Lester Samsen, both of New York. Msgr. James M. Connolly performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Cheung Is Married
description: Dr. Yvonne Ying Hai Cheung and Michael Newbatt Smith were married yesterday at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Community Baptist Church by the Rev. Jim A. Morrison. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Yeung Hin Cheung of Scarsdale. The bridegroom, 26, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Brian N. Smith of Mount Pleasant, S.C. The bride, who received an M.D. from Columbia University last week, is a cum laude graduate of Harvard University. The bridegroom, a Harvard graduate, is a manager for Mactemps in Cambridge, Mass., a national temporary employment agency specializing in Macintosh computer operators.

title: Lori Shay Wed To D. M. Posner
description: Lori Ann Shay, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Shay of Manlius, N.Y., was married last evening to David Merrill Posner, the son of Dr. Ruth E. Tesler of Pleasantville, N.Y., and Samuel Posner of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Edward C. Pratt, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Hilander in Queensbury, N.Y.

title: Sally Dommerich Weds
description: Sally Morgan Dommerich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Alexander Dommerich of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Dice Lineberry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Dice Kyle Lineberry of Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Terence Elsberry performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church. Mrs. Lineberry, 23 years old, graduated from Vanderbilt University, as did her husband. Mr. Lineberry, 24, is a law student at the University of Alabama.

title:
FORUM;
The Greening of America's Taxes
description: EVIDENCE of the earth's physical deterioration mounts each year. Forests disappear, the concentration of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere rises, ground water supplies dwindle and air pollution spreads.

title: Roslyn Estates
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Images: TV's Mixed Signals
description: The message to the medium is blunt: "It is time for the television industry to realize that 25 million lesbians and gay men in America, along with our families and friends, make up a significant share of the viewing audience. We are tired of seeing gays represented only as buffoons or villains."

title: Ms. Radel Weds Michael Cyran
description: Laura Beth Radel, a daughter of Drs. Stanley and Eva Radel of Yonkers, was married in Yonkers yesterday to Michael Gerard Cyran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cyran of Yonkers. Rabbi Albert Sturmer and the Rev. Giles Spoonhour, a priest of the Federation of Christian Ministries, performed the interfaith ceremony at the Hudson River Museum.

title: Edwards Streaks Into Semifinals of the Travis
description: The golf heroics of 60-year-old Bill Edwards of the Garden City Golf Club were the topic of conversation around the fireplace in the clubhouse today in the 81st edition of the Travis Invitational golf tournament.

title: Letter Writers Missing The Point on Spelling
description: As a parent of a Greenburgh Central School District No. 7 student and as a former English teacher, I was pleased to read the April 14 interview with Principal Nettie Webb [ "Westchester Q&A" ] . After reading the "Letters to the Westchester Editor" on April 28, I feel your readers missed the main idea of the article.

title: A New Sales Drive by Resolution Trust
description: UNDER harsh criticism for delays and bureaucratic foul-ups, the Resolution Trust Corporation says it is rolling out a new and improved campaign to sell thousands of homes, lots and commercial buildings, including hundreds of properties in the Northeast.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 5 about New Hampshire's consideration of the French abortion drug RU-486 referred incorrectly to its status in the United States. The Food and Drug Administration has not banned testing of RU-486. There is a ban on importing it for personal use, and some scientists contend that this has chilled the manufacturer's willingness to provide the drug for new American- based research.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EXACT IMAGE OF MOTHER By Patty Friedmann. Viking, $18.95.

title: Learning to Work With Nature's Clock
description: "WHEN the oak leaves are the size of a mouse's ear, plant corn." This was a treasured bit of planting advice given by many Eastern Indian tribes and followed seriously. The local Indians knew that the soil had to be warm enough to receive the corn seed. And if the oak leaves were beginning to unfurl, the Indians knew that their vital crop of corn would not be chilled in the ground needlessly.

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; New York
description: WHEN MANHATTAN heats up like an electric coil, the bill for that priceless skyline comes due. The city is steel and concrete, materials that soak up solar rays with terrible efficiency and then blast them right back in New York's collective face. The world has devised two solutions to summer: stone, massive enough to remain cool and dank (the low-tech option), and air-conditioning (medium-tech). The Temple of Dendur has both. A shrine to Isis, built circa 15 B.C., Dendur was plucked from the banks of the Nile in the late 70's and dropped into a glass-enclosed addition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It looks like a mausoleum mistakenly delivered to an airport departure lounge.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Playing Poker, Making History
description: COUNSEL TO THE PRESIDENT

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; New Housing Rises on Slab-Disaster Site
description: ON April 23, 1987, national attention focused on a half-finished apartment building in Bridgeport called L'Ambiance Plaza.

title: 2 More Recipients Test Positive for AIDS
description: Two more patients who received transplants from a donor infected with AIDS have tested positive for the virus in preliminary examinations, the service that processed the donor's tissue said today.

title: Wall Street; A Spring of Catastrophes for Property Insurers
description: A disaster. That's what this year has been for property insurers. Industry numbers show that through April catastrophe damage from severe spring weather, mainly in the nation's midsection, was $1.35 billion -- compared with just $550 million in the corresponding season last year.

title:
HO-HO-KUS JOURNAL;
Store Closings Prompt A Move to Revitalize
description: A FEW months after one of two pharmacies and the borough's only hardware store closed on Sheridan Avenue, the main business street, the newly formed Chamber of Commerce has a new sense of urgency as it tries to promote shopping in downtown Ho-Ho-Kus.

title: 'You Are Going to Make a Reputation for Yourself'
description: AUTHOR AND AGENT

title: Rx: For Quick Relief On Sizzling Days; San Diego
description: BY LARRY ROHTER OME JULY AND AUGUST, the days turn muggy in southern California, and many of the region's 14 million people head for the beaches or the mountains in search of a cool, quiet place to relax. But for me the best place to chill out is right in the heart of San Diego: the penguin exhibit at Sea World.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: HIRAM CHODOSH;
Book Outlines Steps to Help the Homeless
description: LAST fall, three former Yale Law School students published "Homes for the Homeless: A Handbook for Action." The book is an outgrowth of their work with the Shelter Project at Yale, a student-staffed legal services organization that has put together more than $5 million in financing for clients, and Home Inc., a community-based nonprofit corporation formed by the Shelter Project to manage and develop low-income housing.

title: Not Too Young to Go to War
description: RED CAP By G. Clifton Wisler. 176 pp. New York: Lodestar Books. THE GHOST CADET By Elaine Marie Alphin. 182 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings for the week ended May 4 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village 290,000 40 East 10th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,350-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, fireplace, landmark building; maintenance $903, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Wells & Gay/Stribling & Associates) Flat Iron 732,500 105 Fifth Avenue (18th St.) (Folio House) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,175-sq.-ft. penthouse co-op in a renovated prewar building; dining area, 2,000-sq.-ft. of private roof space, Hudson River view; maintenance $1,427, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Eychner Associates) Upper East Side 300,000 340 East 64th Street (St. Tropez) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,450-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area; common charge $600, taxes $4,080 (Broker: Equinox Property Co.) title: Miss Buttner Wed To S. M. Carlisle
description: Lindsey Hendry Buttner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Murray Buttner of Easton, Conn., was married in Southport, Conn., yesterday to Stuart Moffatt Carlisle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. B. Carlisle of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Alastair Votaw and the Rev. M. Jennings Matheson performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Part of the problem with deer-eradication programs may be public squeamishness toward the necessary slaughter. It might help if we began to think of deer as "free-range venison." DAVID M. KRAUT New York, N.Y.

title: Kimberly Ann Kossman Is Wed to Michael Craft
description: Kimberly Ann Kossman, a daughter of Dr. Richard J. Kossmann of Englewood, N.J., and the late Geralyn Kossmann, was married yesterday in Ridgefield, Conn., to Michael Craft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Craft of Chesapeake Beach, Md. The Rev. Barbara Pescan, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Stonehenge Inn.

title: Town, Bucking Tradition, Picks Democrat as Leader
description: VOTERS in Woodbridge, long a Republican bastion, had never elected a Democrat or a woman as First Selectman until Nan Mead Birdwhistell won the job this month. Ms. Birdwhistell, a 37-year-old lawyer, will take office in the New Haven suburb on July 1.

title: SUMMER FESTIVAL: DANCE
description: The following is a selective list. Performances are subject to change.

title: A Defector's Story
description: TERRORIST

title: 18 Reported Slain in Gang Strife at Mexican Prison
description: Anti-terrorist troops and riot police officers surrounded a state prison early today after a battle between rival drug gangs in which officials said 18 people were killed and five wounded.

title: Calling for a Return to Sanity in Architecture
description: In coming together to form a community, Europeans have accepted a lot. Will they now allow Brussels to dictate the structure of their cities? They will if they follow the recommendations presented three weeks ago in Madrid by a commission of the European Community. The Prince of Wales was there to lend his support and prestige to the sweeping reforms it proposed for a life without overcrowded cities and smelly automobiles. Its recommendations are lifted almost verbatim from the teachings of the London-based urban theorist Leon Krier, often referred to as Prince Charles's favorite architect.

title: Kuwait Deeply Split on Vision of a Post-Occupation Order
description: All that remains of the Great Dhow is ashes, a black iron anchor and row upon row of hand-fashioned spikes that once held the enormous vessel together. For centuries, Kuwaiti merchants, pearl harvesters and fishermen rode boats like these throughout the Persian Gulf and beyond into the Indian Ocean, defining the life and culture of the people who settled on this nub of sand.

title: Ms. Schwartz to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel W. Schwartz of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Marilyn Ann Schwartz and Greg Adler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Adler of New York. Ms. Schwartz, 25 years old, graduated from Cornell University and is studying for an M.B.A. at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Adler, 26, is an associate at the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. He graduated magna cum laude from Penn and received a J.D. degree from Columbia University.

title: Bush's Illness Shows Folly of 'Cost Containment' in Health Care; Prescription: Broccoli
description: To the Editor:

title: Tips From Bergeron
description: To what does MICHEL BERGERON owe his longevity? Well, by his own account the former Ranger coach has spent much of his adult life smoking two packs of cigarettes and drinking 25 cups of coffee a day, not to mention eating like a pig.

title: Trawlers Challenge Rules on Catching Lobsters
description: TRAWLER owners are challenging a new state fishing rule prohibiting the landing of their traditional 100 lobsters a day from Long Island Sound. Trap lobstermen, who sought the ban, contend that the trawlers' drag nets were destroying the lucrative fishery in the Sound.

title: Gasoline
description: To the Editor: Gasoline is not as cheap as it seems in Florida if one falls prey to a station like the one we encountered near the Fort Myers airport.

title: Surprising Leaders in Bridge
description: A dark-horse team was on track for world championship qualification at the United States Bridge Championships here today. Bernie Miller of Boca Raton, Fla.; Robert Barr of Lynn, Mass., and Harold Stengel of Hingham, Mass., were the nucleus of the winning Grand National team two years ago and now have a good chance to represent the United States in Yokohama, Japan, in October.

title:
ART;
Museum in New Britain Displays 'The Cutting Edge' of Folk Art
description: FOLK art has been acquiring more and more status, in large measure because it preserves tradition as contemporary culture becomes increasingly diverse. But recently, the idea of what can be counted as folk art has undergone some stimulating expansion. The current exhbition at the New Britain Museum of American Art reflects the new liberalization.

title: Encountering Those Mercurial Days in the Bullpens
description: Dennis Eckersley of Oakland, generally considered the best relief pitcher working today, has raised eyebrows by already giving up four home runs (double his total for the entire 1990 season), allowing seven earned runs (two more than all of last season) and failing in two save situations (as many as all of last season).

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE COMING TRIUMPH OF THE FREE WORLD, by Rick DeMarinis. (Norton, $7.95.) When this collection of stories was published in 1988, our reviewer, Russell Banks, said it is "so consistent, original, seductive and delightfully sad that Rick DeMarinis can afford to save his best piece for last, a thing rarely done these days." In the story, "Medicine Man," the narrator meets an ex-Army medic with mystical curative powers in a bar in Montana.

title: A Child's Abduction, a Mother's Search and a Change in the Law
description: AT a time when little girls are just getting a secure foothold in the world, everything that Ashley Nicole Vandolas knew was stripped away from her in the spring of 1987. Ashley was 2 1/2 years old and the object of a custody dispute between her estranged parents.

title: Piercing Fad Is Turning Convention on Its Ear
description: At the age of 9, Michael McDonald wants to have his ear pierced. He says all the girls in his fourth-grade class at Public School 321 in Brooklyn have pierced ears. More important, one boy wears a diamond stud, and Michael likes the way it looks. But he will probably have to wait.

title: Dr. Hocking Weds Robert Armington
description: Dr. Leslie Beth Hocking, a Navy psychiatrist, and Robert Mason Armington, a biomedical engineering consultant, were married yesterday in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral. Dr. Donald Kinloch performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Ban Pesticides, Rally Organic Gardeners for Turf Lawndering; All-Purpose Cover
description: To the Editor:

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
The Great Dinosaur Rip-Off
description: For celebrities, death provides no surcease from exploitation. As surely as Elvis Presley and John Lennon, dinosaurs are spinning in their graves over what we've turned them into -- ravioli, soap, T-shirts, a new prime-time television series, even growling "Tyranno Toes" bed slippers.

title: Lawyer to Pursue Suit On Cross-Endorsement
description: A WHITE PLAINS lawyer said last week that she would continue her fight to prevent political parties from cross-endorsing local judges. She vowed to challenge a ruling handed down this month by an appellate panel that included judges who had themselves been cross-endorsed.

The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Many in U.S. Favor Wider Testing for AIDS
description: Americans overwhelmingly favor testing doctors, dentists, nurses and hospital patients for AIDS, according to a Gallup Poll. The public also strongly supports testing of immigrants, couples applying for marriage licenses, inmates of Federal prisons and members of the armed forces, the poll found.

title: Just How Far Can a Work Of Art Travel?
description: The star of the "The Sculpture of Indonesia" exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Aug. 18) is one of the most magical sculptures to visit New York in a long time. It is a statue of Prajnaparamita, the goddess of transcendental wisdom. It is so splendidly carved, so sophisticated in its sculptural intelligence and such an inspired expression of religious and philosophical ideas that it raises an issue that has become taboo in many influential segments of the American and European art worlds: universality. In other words, can a work of art have an appeal so widespread that it can be considered universal?

title: MANDELA'S GROUP QUITS DISCUSSIONS ON A NEW CHARTER
description: The African National Congress announced today that it would refuse to discuss a new constitution with the Government until progress was achieved on its demands to end fighting between black factions that has claimed about 800 lives so far this year.

title: Festival or Not, Spoleto Shines
description: THE one predictable thing about the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds is its unpredictability. It has few unshakable traditions, few irreplaceable figures (except for its founder and guiding spirit, Gian Carlo Menotti). For most of its 33 seasons, its opening event has been a gala opera peformance in the larger of the town's theaters, the Teatro Nuovo. But last summer's festival was different: the elegant audience gathered in the Nuovo, but the program was not operatic. They heard, instead, a performance of Berlioz's "Symphony Fantastique," then all trooped out of the theater and wended their way across town to the Duomo, where the second -- and more impressive -- half of the event took place.

title: Miss Herrera Marries David Genovese
description: Camilla Aimee Herrera, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Alfonso Herrera of Madrid, was married yesterday at St. Elizabeth of Hungary Roman Catholic Church in New York to David Alan Genovese, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Genovese of Kent, Conn. The Rev. Francis X. Elsinghorst officiated.

title: Travel Advisory; Jazz Festival In Philadelphia
description: A weeklong jazz festival dedicated to a local drummer will be held in Philadelphia from June 14 to 23. The drummer, Granville William (Mickey) Roker, has played with many leading groups. Other performers will include the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, Dave Brubeck and Miles Davis. For information: (215) 561-5060.Tickets at the Academy of Music: (215) 893-1999.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Come fall, I'll be wishing that it is the hunters rather than the deer who could be tranquilized and trucked back to their own states (New Jersey or Pennsylvania). Though I walk on my 60 acres daily, I see more hunters in those three weeks in autumn than I see deer all year long. Deer not only don't eat my garden, they don't shoot my dogs either. GAAL SHEPHERD CROWL South Woodstock, Vt.

title: Headliners; No Powder Puff
description: The dress code at Continental Airlines went too far for Teresa Fischette, demanding that she wear something that she said she had never worn before -- makeup. It was part of a 45-page appearance code that the airline issued this month covering everything from shoes to hairstyle, and when Ms. Fischette refused to comply with the directives on makeup, she was fired from her part-time job at Continental's Logan International Airport ticket counter. Uproar ensued, and last week Continental backed down. The airline chairman, Hollis Harris, personally offered Ms. Fischette her job back, along with back pay for the days she missed. Mr. Harris said that henceforth, compliance with the appearance code would be suggested rather than mandatory. "We just admit we made a mistake," he said. Ms. Fischette said the issue went beyond face powder and lipstick. "It wasn't just a victory about makeup," she said. "This was about company prerogative and personal choice."

title:
MUSIC;
Cape May Festival Is Expanding
description: IN a season when many arts organizations have had to curtail their activities because of cuts in funds from the state, the Cape May Music Festival, which will begin its second season next Sunday, has nearly doubled its activities.

title: John Marshall Is Wed to Joan Morgan
description: Joan Morgan, a daughter of Mrs. Albert Pratt of Osterville, Mass., and Rear Adm. Henry S. Morgan of Gibson Island, Md., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I., to John Marshall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Marshall of Omaha. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: The Region; Dinkins's Nightmare Budget Gains A Frightening Air of Plausibility
description: JUST a week after Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed a New York City budget so grim that he called it a worst-case warning, it seemed the worst might really come to pass.

title: Commercial Property: Corporate Relocations; Heads or Torsos Remain While the Limbs Move On
description: MET LIFE had good and bad news for Manhattan last month. First the good news: Its headquarters would stay on Madison Square. Then the bad news: Some 4,000 jobs would not.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Luxurious New Place on the Shore
description: THE airy hotel with the unabridged name of the Ocean Place Hilton Resort and Spa overlooks the beach in Long Branch. It is perched on the edge of a neighborhood that is not yet gentrified, and so the 12-story building with its California-style decor stands out like a diamond in the rough.

title: Southern College Group Seeking Tougher Supervision of Athletics
description: In an attempt to deal with abuses in college sports, the accrediting agency for colleges and universities in the South has drafted new rules that would link academic accreditation with the integrity of an institution's sports programs.

title: No Royal Connection
description: Sure she was disappointed, and so was he, for that matter, but look at it this way: If QUEEN ELIZABETH II had really had her heart set on having a little Liz-to-Ron chat with Miami Baseball Coach RON FRASER, wouldn't she have issued the invitation for a day the Hurricanes didn't have a road game in Atlanta?

title: Nalcrest Journal; For Mail Carriers, a Dogless Place in the Sun
description: Somewhere between the hard life of a letter carrier and Mailman Heaven there is Nalcrest.

title: Travel Advisory; Villa d'Este Sparkles Again
description: The sparkling fountains of the Villa d'Este, outside Rome, are flowing again after being halted last fall because of fears that the water, which is drawn from the Aniene River, might be polluted. Chemical tests were conducted over the winter and the level of pollution was found not to be a threat.

title:
FORUM;
Taking Cues from Natural Disasters
description: Biologists say that once an ecological order is established, it is unlikely to undergo change unless it is dislodged by a catastrophic event. Managers who take a page from nature may find themselves in a better position to succeed, not just survive, when change strikes.

title: Sports of The Times; 5 Factors in Departure of Parcells
description: If what happened in the weeks after the Giants won Super Bowl XXV had been different, maybe Bill Parcells would still be their coach with a new contract through the 1994 season, if not longer.

title: Stamps
description: From fine art to the lively arts, two groups of hobbyists who collect stamps by topic have just published guides to serve both newcomers and specialists.

title: Kendall Dunn Marries
description: Kendall Leigh Dunn and Jonathan Philip Trenn were married yesterday at Calvary United Methodist Church in Middletown, R.I., by the Rev. Quinton Ivey. The bride, 30 years old, is the daughter of the late Kenneth M. Dunn of Galveston, Tex., and a graduate of Pine Manor College. She is a legislative assistant to Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas. The bridegroom, 29, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Trenn of Cranston, R.I. He is a defense contractors' representative with Bonner & Associates, lobbyists in Washington. He graduated from Boston College.

title: Celebrating Births and Deaths and in Between
description: The following list is selective, and programs are subject to change. More information is available through individual ticket offices. Alaska

title: Why Can't They Just Play Ball?
description: To the Editor:

How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 22 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles to practice in the pursuit of success. 4 25 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 5 8 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Bantam, $4.95.) A regimen for weight loss.
