These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Six Little Girls in a Row
description: THE LITTLE BAND By James Sage. Illustrated by Keiko Narahashi. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: A Boy And His Lizard
description: THE SALAMANDER ROOM By Anne Mazer. Illustrated by Steve Johnson. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) A BOY WANTS A DINOSAUR By Hiawyn Oram. Illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Visual Source For John Dewey
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Tryouts for W.L.A.F.?
description: Jerry Vanisi, vice president of football operations for the World League of American Football, doesn't want to see the day when the W.L.A.F. holds open tryouts for high school football players.

title: Focus: Speculative Mansions; Making Fantasy a Reality -- and Selling It
description: AT night, Sam Caliendo lies awake thinking of interior waterfalls, indoor lagoons and rooftop pools. He is always thinking of unusual features for the multimillion-dollar homes he designs and builds to sell on speculation here.

title: Mozart, Mostly and More
description: The founders of the Mostly Mozart Festival, back in 1966, probably had their hands full with immediate concerns and didn't give much thought to a 25th-anniversary celebration down the road. Even if they had wanted to plan ahead, they could not have anticipated how ripe the climate would be for a Mozart celebration on the 200th anniversary of the composer's death. That climate owes much to the phenomenon of the Peter Shaffer play "Amadeus" and the subsequent film. But it also owes much to the Mostly Mozart festival itself, whose name, though trademarked, soon entered common parlance.

title: Layoffs in Hartford's Budget
description: The City Council approved a $417 million spending plan that calls for layoffs of 119 city employee and a tax rate that stays at its current level. The budget was approved on Friday strictly along party lines, with six Democrats for, the sole Republican against and two independents abstaining. Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry, who will receive the budget early next week, did not rule out using vetoes to protest certain items.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; In the Shade, Subtle Elegance
description: Many people blessed with shade just complain about it. "All I can grow is impatiens," they moan, as their neighbors are sweating to death in the tomato patch.

title: Alcohol and Prom Limousines: Mixed Blessing
description: THE spring evenings beckon, the chariots await and thousands of tuxedoed and taffeted teen-agers are ready to make memories. For the fourth year in a row, a consortium of people who work with the young have taken special steps to assure that prom-night memories will be sweet, free from the bitter and sometimes disastrous aftertaste of too much drinking.

title: Sunday Dinner; Three Places Where Solitary Does Not Mean Punishment
description: Dining alone can be a dispiriting experience, especially in a hushed, formal dining room where you feel woefully conspicuous. Many restaurants in Manhattan, though, seem well-suited to the solitary eater. Some have lively or familial atmospheres, while others have dining bars where you can chat with your neighbors if you like. Here are three places that are pleasant to dine in alone. Baci

title: Travel Advisory; A New Chance To Climb Everest
description: Mountaineers who think they might be ready to tackle Mount Everest can apply to Great Expeditions, a California-based company that is the first American commercial operator to receive permission from the Nepal Government to ascend the world's tallest peak.

title: Towns With Open Space Tally the Cost of Growth
description: THE open fields and farmland in Oxford prompted the Samuelson family to move north from Seymour in 1959, recalled Frank H. Samuelson Jr., who spent his boyhood playing ball on open fields. Burton Alho said that same rural character brought him from Manhattan last year.

title: The Region; Leading The Sacred Cow Of Rent Control To Slaughter?
description: FOR 44 years, New York City's system of rent-control laws, which affect more than a million apartments, has been politically unassailable. But as the city's economic problems deepen, and a rising rental vacancy rate chews at the law's legal foundation, some of the city's leaders have begun to think about ending controls on some higher-priced apartments in order to save the rest of the law.

title:
Making a Difference;
Motown Has a New Play Date: In Court
description: For Jheryl Busby, becoming head of Motown Records in 1988 fulfilled a career-long ambition.

title: WHERE CORN IS A GOD
description: ON A HILLSIDE north of the Mexican village of San Juan Chamula, close to the Guatemalan border, stalks of last year's corn sway like parchment skeletons as two drums beat and nearly 500 Chamula Indians trudge up the path to inaugurate the annual spring festival. Generation after generation, they have climbed through the balsam-scented air and toward the steam that rises from the two tin tubs set in a clearing on the hill. Like so many threads in the intricate pagan-Christian tapestry of their culture, they are pulled toward the unfurling aroma of corn.

title: Review/Film; An Enchanted Peasant Girl And a Magical Necklace
description: It comes as no disappointment that "Mannequin Two: On the Move," which was directed by Stewart Raffill and opened Friday at the Metro and other theaters, is a breezy teen-age comedy having very little to do with the earlier film for which it is named. The setting is again a Philadelphia department store (with a staff that includes Meshach Taylor as Hollywood, a very funny, very flamboyant gay "Minister of Style"), and the plot again involves a mannequin's coming to life to become one store employee's secret dream girl. Beyond that, this film has enough new characters and independent spirit to have a light, cheery style of its own.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JIM THOMPSON Sleep With the Devil. By Michael J. McCauley. Mysterious Press, $19.95.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Treasury Department reports on its three- and six-month bills auction * Spring Comdex computer show opens in Atlanta. TUESDAY: The April statement on the Federal budget will be released by the Treasury Department.

title: Loan Source
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the insurance industry referred incorrectly to efforts to reopen credit unions affected by the failure of a private deposit insurance system in Rhode Island. Federal deposit insurance agencies are not involved in the bailout.

title: Shortage of Warheads Means Subs Won't Be Fully Armed
description: A prolonged shutdown of a crucial nuclear weapons plant has forced the Navy to send some of its new Trident submarines to sea with less than a full complement of nuclear warheads on their ballistic missiles, military officials say.

title: DeWitt F. Helm Jr. Marries Joyce Claire Williams
description: Joyce Claire Williams and DeWitt Frederick Helm Jr., both of New York, were married yesterday in New York at Christ Church United Methodist. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman performed the ceremony.

title: Stephen Short Wed to Julie Shipman
description: Julie Shipman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Shipman of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Donald Short, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Short of Dallas. The Rev. David L. Uhl performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Blair Soyster and Terrance Fiore Wed
description: Margaret Blair Soyster, a daughter of Eliza S. Soyster of McLean, Va., and Dr. Peter Soyster of Cambira, Calif., was married yesterday to Terrance Michael Fiore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic M. Fiore of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Jane Soyster Gould, a sister of the bride, officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JUDITH GILBERT KAUTTO;
Can This Marriage Be Saved?
description: THE Carolyn Warmus trial, which ended recently in a hung jury, brought a lot of attention to adultery. In that case, there was testimony that both the husband of the murdered woman and the woman were having affairs.

title: Sax, Drums and Rock 'n' Roll
description: The following list of performers and concert dates is selective. Performances are subject to change. California

title: The World; Castro Reopens The Gate To Exodus
description: LAST summer, when a few dozen Cubans sought to flee by taking refuge in Havana's foreign embassies, an uncompromising President Fidel Castro defused one of the most delicate crises he has faced in recent years, vowing that not a single asylum seeker would be allowed to leave the island.

title: Riley-Knicks Talks Getting Serious
description: The Knicks and Pat Riley are continuing discussions that could soon lead to Riley's becoming the team's next head coach.

title: World Markets; Divining Europe's Muddled Signs
description: European markets were buffeted last week by political change but were buoyed as interest rates eased. Altogether, however, the week's events showed that the decline in rates is occurring very slowly and that inflation is still a worrisome problem. These factors could lead to disappointments in some stock markets.

title: COLOR ME NEUSCHWANSTEIN
description: Remember paint-by-numbers sets? We do, and offer our own version of Mad King Ludwig's Bavarian dream castle. The numbers are keyed to a standard 64-color box of Crayolas. Neatness counts. Should you prefer to ignore the numbers, you're on your own (although a puce sky has much to recommend it). Originality counts, too. You may award your own prizes.

title: 'Old Boys' Network' Perpetuated by Listing
description: While we were pleased to see you taking an interest in the matrimonial bar on Long Island, we were sorely disappointed in the participation in the legitimization of the "Old Boys' Network." Your article pictured and mentioned attorneys who were listed in "The Best Lawyers in America," implying that those not listed were clearly less qualified than those named.

title: Court to Examine Army Role at Love Canal
description: Documents released on Friday by a Federal court indicate that wastes from the first atomic bomb and an Army chemical weapons plant may have been buried at Love Canal.

title: Crowded Prisons Pose Tough Choice for Florio
description: Like governors across the nation who are contending with budget crises and overcrowded prisons, Gov. Jim Florio is now faced with a growing dilemma: Is it better to ask a tax-weary public to spend more on prisons, or to propose alternatives to incarceration and risk being labeled soft on crime?

title: Choreography Attuned to the Ear as Well as Feet
description: Dancers have been audible as well as visible this spring, and they have sounded good. What's more, their noise-making has made serious esthetic points and revitalized some dance traditions.

title: Sunday Menu; Linguine and Red Clam Sauce but Lighter
description: Many old favorites, updated for the lighter way of eating, fit right into the meals-in-minutes department. Linguine with red clam sauce is one of the oldest from the school of the red check tablecloth Italian restaurant with the candle in the Chianti bottle.

title: Angela Burkhardt Wed To William F. Cruger Jr.
description: Angela Burkhardt and William Frank Cruger Jr. were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. Charles Bevan Jr. The bride, 36 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Burkhardt of Winchester, Mass. The bridegroom, 32, is a son of Mrs. Paul Alexander and Mr. Cruger, both of Marblehead, Mass.

title: Susan H. Baker Weds Richard Adam Leavitt
description: Susan Halliday Baker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Baker of Savannah, Ga., and Wellfleet, Mass., was married in Wellfleet yesterday to Richard Adam Leavitt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Leavitt of Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth C. Roscoe performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: 'Streetcar' Featuring A Strong Blanche
description: "A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE," Tennessee Williams's powerful play of love, lust and betrayal, is an American classic. First presented on Broadway in 1947 with Marlon Brando, Kim Hunter and Jessica Tandy, the play was made into a successful motion picture, and it is one of the plays firmly entrenched in the top number of great American works of art.

title: INSIDE
description: Flight 007 Revisited

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'TOSCA' IN HEMPSTEAD

title: 10,000 Lakes And Stores, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
End of the Trail For Stockyards
description: DEMOLITION of the last remaining abandoned buildings in the Stockyards is under way, the culmination of a 30-year effort to convert what was once the hub of the nation's meat-packing industry into an industrial park.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: There is a simple solution to the deer problem -- get a German shepherd dog. Once we got our shepherd, we were able to remove the ugly, protective fencing from our bushes and shrubs; mallards stopped nesting on our pool cover; raccoons were kept at bay. We are the only residents of the area who are able to maintain a vegetable garden free of woodchucks.

title: BIG BOOKS, TALL TALES
description: Paul Alexander seems to fault Mark Helprin for making up stories about his life and telling them to journalists who interview him ("Big Books, Tall Tales," April 28). But why shouldn't he? The important psychological truths about one's life often are most effectively expressed obliquely, in the form of parables. Who cares, for example, whether Helprin's mother -- a leading lady on Broadway -- was really sold into slave bondage. The creativity of the solution it offers to a child of a professional actress and, perhaps, unavailable mother are of far greater interest than whether this happened in reality or not. ONA HAMILTON Merion, Pa.

title: Samuel O. Kaylin, Editor and Educator, 78
description: Samuel O. Kaylin, an editor and teacher who specialized in the field of retailing, died on Thursday at the Mary Wade nursing home in New Haven. He was 78 years old and had lived for many years in Oceanside, L.I., before moving to Guilford, Conn.

title: 4 Young Y Swimmers Break National Records
description: Four hundred people swim at the W.Y.C.A. of White Plains and Central Westchester on an average day. There are chldren taking lessons, people of all ages trying to stay fit, handicapped swimmers exercising and about 170 youngsters and adults on the Y's swim team, the Middies.

title: An African Park in Peril
description: KENYA's Amboseli National Park is advertised as an extraordinary wildlife experience for visitors to Africa. Set beneath the snowy dome of Mount Kilimanjaro, Amboseli offers lions, cheetah, elephant and buffalo. A photographer's dream shot -- a giraffe or an elephant browsing on a green plain with the blue-tinged mountain as the backdrop -- is usually displayed in tourist brochures.

title: The Executive Life; Trouble Sleeping? Call a 24-Hour Trading Desk
description: The band was loud. The music was good. The beer was cold. But George Kaufman's mind started to drift thousands of miles away from CBGB, the downtown rock club. Around midnight, Mr. Kaufman walked out to the deserted Manhattan street -- the Bowery -- and made a phone call. He came back smiling. "I needed to find out what gold was trading at in Hong Kong," he told his friends, a little sheepishly.

title: Kohl Due in U.S. With Pledge of Strong Ties
description: The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, begins a two-day visit to Washington on Sunday with the message that reunited Germany places great value on continued close ties with the United States.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MIDDLEFIELD;
Plan for 250-Year-Old Farm Raises Ecological Questions
description: BIG things are happening in small Middlefield this year. The 1,100-acre Lyman Farm, which covers almost an eighth of the land in town, is celebrating its 250th anniversary. So far, it has given a tree to the town and been visited by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. And the baker at the Lyman store, the Apple Barrel, made yard-high glazed braided bread to spell out "250 Years"; it hangs on the wall of the store, above the cookies.

title: Baghdad Oppressors Should Pay Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: Marketers Exploit Second-Tier Sports
description: The horses milled about for the first race, as sinewy jockeys busied themselves checking their tack. Sunlight leaked through the Virginia clouds, and decorous men and women tramped to their seats along with rowdier, beer-swigging racegoers still dreaming of upward mobility.

title: Rosenfeld Leaving Agency That He Helped to Found
description: Ronald M. Rosenfeld, one of the leaders of the advertising industry's creative revolution of the 1960's, is off to seek a second revolution.

title: A Software Alliance Is Expected
description: The Lotus Development Corporation and Adobe Systems Inc., will announce today that Lotus will include computer font technology developed by Adobe in the version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet program it is developing for the Microsoft Corporation's Windows software.

title: Work Station From Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company will introduce a new computer work station on Monday that it hopes will appeal to non- technical users.

title: Bridget Bell Weds D. R. Webber 3d
description: Bridget Anne Bell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Clark Bell of Woodstock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Reed Webber 3d, a son of Elaine Schoon of Phoenix and Mr. Webber 2d of Queenstown, Md. The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: Black Driver Qualifies for 500
description: A jubilant Willy T. Ribbs overcame two weeks of frustration and made history today at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway as the record-breaking field was completed for the 75th Indianapolis 500.

title: Are Triple Trailers a Threat?
description: The trucking industry wants a license from Congress to put huge triple-trailer trucks on designated highways from coast to coast. It's an emotion-packed issue that pits truckers against railroads, highway-safety groups and a fearful public. There is reason aplenty to go slow.

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan and the Bulls Take Lesson in Civics
description: IN the end, the object lesson for the Chicago Bulls was the Phantom of the Opera, otherwise known as Bill Laimbeer. If anyone typifies the rotten kid image of the Detroit Pistons, it is Laimbeer, the Pistons' forward, who wears a gleaming clear-plastic mask with two black bands gripping it on his face.

title: Question Box
description: The Babe Misses Out

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about the Cannes International Film Festival misidentified a star of "Life Stinks." She is Lesley Ann Warren, not Susan Sarandon.

title: A Press War Splits Berlin Anew
description: Berlin's newest daily newspaper, a flashy tabloid called Super, hit the newsstands this month, unleashing a fierce price war at the low end of eastern Germany's rumbling newspaper market.

title: Brussels Riots Point Up Failure to Integrate Arabs
description: For horrified Belgians watching television pictures of heavily armed police fighting off firebombs, it seemed for a few days this month that rioting and protests by young Arab immigrants had brought this city to the brink of civil war.

title: Trade Group Gets New Head
description: Anyone familiar with Alex Kroll's exploits as a college and pro football star would not be surprised to learn that he will have a "blocking and tackling" agenda during his term as chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Fox Slows, but Stays Restless
description: The Fox Broadcasting Company turned momentum into money last year. Now the young and restless network has lost ground in the ratings even as it expanded its program base.

title: French Leader Firm on Japanese
description: In her first few days in office, Prime Minister Edith Cresson has come across like a Joan of Arc seeking to save French industry. And for her, the enemy is not the British but the Japanese.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'La Bayadere' American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Alexander Kendrick, CBS Correspondent, 80
description: Alexander Kendrick, who in nearly four decades as a newspaperman and television correspondent covered world events, including World War II from the Russian front, and as an author wrote a biography of of his colleague Edward R. Murrow, died Friday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 80 years old.

title: Sputtering Mets Lose On More Bad Fielding
description: The Mets, after a trip that had at its midpoint fueled their confidence and cohesiveness, flat ran out of gas at its end. The trip's finish without flourish, marked by a breakdown of mechanics and a fitful offense, was finalized with a 7-5 crumbling to the Dodgers today at Dodger Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about rising ethnic and racial separatism on American campuses misstated commencement plans at Vassar College. Black students will not hold their own graduation ceremony on May 26; they have organized special events that will be open to everyone.

title: Public School's Crew: Sport Is Minor, Spirit Isn't
description: When Sean Donnelly, a sophomore at Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Park, Queens, tells people what varsity team he is on, he is often met with a blank stare. After all, crew is not exactly front and center with New York City sports fans.

title: Dutchman Defies Flat Tire and Flies to Victory
description: Since Tuesday, Erik Breukink had struggled in second place in the 11-day Tour Du Pont bicycle race, unable to dent Atle Kvalsvoll's lead. And today, the premier cycling race in the United States was to end with a 16.1-mile time trial on a course that appeared too twisting and too rough for Breukink's silky style.

title: Camacho Works Hard For a Brighter Future
description: Had he lost again to Greg Haugen, it would have been adios to the big-money fights for Hector (Macho) Camacho. But after winning a 12-round split decision for the World Boxing Organization junior- welterweight title Saturday night, after mounting an early lead and nearly squandering it, Camacho still has a future.

title: Corrections
description: A map caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about pre- Columbian catacombs at a site called Casa Malpais misstated its location in some editions. As the map showed, the site is Arizona, not New Mexico.

title: Man Kills 5 With a Hammer
description: A man used a hammer on Saturday to kill his mother-in-law, wife and three children, then stabbed and injured himself with a knife, the authorities said today. The couple's 5-month-old daughter was unharmed. The man, Paul E. Gamboa-Taylor, 30 years old, underwent surgery and was listed in serious condition today. The dead were identified as Valerie L. Gamboa-Taylor, 23; her mother, Donna M. Barshinger, 42; her son, Lance Thomas Barshinger, 2; and two of the couple's children, Paul, 4; and Jasmine, 2.

title: Former Prudential Broker Sues Firm
description: A former stockbroker with Prudential Securities Inc. is seeking $15 million from the brokerage firm, accusing it of forcing him from his job because he threatened to divulge information about what he says was a fraud committed by the firm.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week: Advanced Logic Research Inc., a global offering of 1.5 million common shares, with 1.25 million shares sold in U.S. and Canada. Paine Webber Inc.

title: Wool Cutbacks For Australia
description: Depressed prices and weak demand will force Australian farmers to cut wool production sharply over the next five years, a new study says.

title: To Look for a Stolen Cat, Roman Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Stick Toes In Waters of 1992 Race
description: Nine months before the Presidential contests begin, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts remains the only official candidate for the Democratic nomination, but a number of Democrats are suddenly sniffing the air.

title: Croatia Votes for Sovereignty and Confederation
description: Voters in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today, as expected, overwhelmingly backed a proposition calling for the republic to become a sovereign, independent nation linked in a loose confederation with this country's other republics, provisional referendum results indicated.

title: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for the week includes bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and tomorrow's Treasury auction of a 335-day cash management bill.

title: Judge Tells Hospice To Resume Feeding Comatose Woman
description: A judge ordered hospice workers to resume feeding a severely brain-damaged woman Saturday while a Christian group appealed his earlier ruling affirming her right to die.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Day Before Cannes Awards, No Clear Winners Emerge
description: This afternoon, after the screening of the last 2 of the 20 films in competition at the 44th Cannes International Film Festival, the contest for the top prizes is again wide open. Odds-on favorites come and go by the hour.

title: Searching for a Really High-Profile Investment?
description: The Empire State Building is for sale, and for a mere $45 million to $50 million -- a pittance for a prime property in midtown Manhattan.

title: There Is No Insurance Industry Cartel to Bust; The Better Regulators
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Select Auto Receivables Trust 1991-1, a unit of Chrysler Corp., is offering $642 million in senior certificates backed by car and light-truck loans through Salomon Brothers Inc. The triple-A rated certificates, with an average two-year life and an expected final maturity of May 15, 1996, have a 7.4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.72 to yield 7.677 percent, or about 79 basis points more than a two-year Treasury note. * UAL Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $300 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2001, through First Boston Corp. The debentures are convertible into UAL common stock.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None

title: Downgrade Foreign Policy
description: We are in another Great Debate about American foreign policy. Before the gulf war, the emerging conventional wisdom was that America was in decline, about to be replaced by the new economic giants, Japan and Germany. Military power would count for less, and economic factors would be decisive in shaping the new world order.

title: Anne M. Moon Is Married
description: Anne M. Moon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harley Moon of Nevada, Iowa, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel S. Horwitz, the son of Dr. Dawn Lille Horwitz and Dr. Bert S. Horwitz of Brightwaters, L.I., at Whittemore House, the faculty house at Washington University in St. Louis. Rabbi Susan Talve officiated. The bride, who is keeping her name, is studying in the medical scientist training program at Washington University, where her husband received his medical degree. She is a cum laude graduate of the University of Iowa. The bridegroom is a resident in surgery at the New York Orthopedic Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He graduated from Duke University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title: 'Their Brutal Mirth'
description: Charles Dickens was walking through London in the early morning of Nov. 13, 1849, when he came upon a crowd waiting to watch a public hanging in Horsemonger Lane. People were laughing and singing songs that mocked the condemned person, a Mrs. Manning. Later that day Dickens wrote to The Times of London:

title: CHRONICLE
description: At a benefit celebration of the 25th anniversary of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, about 20 artists aged 10 to 17 will dance, play and sing on Thursday in the main library building on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street. DONALD SADDLER and BEVERLY SILLS are orchestrating the performances: Mr. Saddler, the Tony Award-winning choreographer, director and former dancer, produced the show; Miss Sills is master of ceremonies.

title: Deborah Sloan Married To Richard E. Gang Jr.
description: Deborah Ann Sloan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Sloan of Weston, Conn., was married last evening at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Richard Eugene Gang Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gang of Littleton, Colo. Justice Stanley S. Ostrau of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on March 20 about a private commission's report on problems in college athletics misstated the origin of the Knight Foundation, which financed the commission. A recent letter from the foundation points out that it was established in 1950 by John S. and James L. Knight, not by Knight-Ridder Inc.

title: Bankruptcies in Japan Are Up 59%
description: Labor shortages and falling land prices that hurt small- and medium-sized businesses in Japan pushed bankruptcies up 59 percent in April compared with April of last year, the Commerce and Industry Research Company has reported.

title: John Q. Lawyer Gets His Day in U.S. Court
description: They come from all walks of life: jail cells, the business world, the ranks of the retired. They write with manual typewriters or purple magic-markers, speak in sentences bursting with legalese or a home-cooked version of it. And they have one thing in mind: justice, may it please the court.

title: U.S. Policy on Salvadoran Immigrants Is Attacked
description: An immigrant rights group is challenging Federal policies that allow the Government to charge Salvadoran immigrants eight times as much as others to register for a "safe haven" program for illegal aliens.

title: Companies in Apple Suit Pessimistic on Settling
description: The companies in the closely watched copyright lawsuit filed by Apple Computer Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, have discussed settling the case, according to a court filing. The companies said, however, that "there are no foreseeable prospects for a settlement."

title: Kurds' Fears Not Allayed by U.N. Force
description: Armed with nothing more menacing than handcuffs, 10 United Nations security guards entered this important northern provincial center today on a mission to reassure Iraqi Kurdish refugees that they could return in safety.

title: Nicaragua: Give Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Sholom D. Comay Is Dead at 53; Led American Jewish Committee
description: Sholom D. Comay, the president of the American Jewish Committee and a civic leader in Pittsburgh, died on Saturday while driving with his wife to their country home in Chautauqua, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: Barnes, a Shot-Putter, Gets N.F.L. Tryout
description: The first time, the San Francisco 49ers merely wanted to watch RANDY BARNES run a few basic drills, the kind a nose tackle might do, and it took all of 20 minutes. After two more visits, they were impressed enough to sign him to a two-year contract and invite him back for a five-day camp next month.

title: Ethiopian Guerrillas Mount an Offensive As Peace Talks Near
description: Ethiopian guerrillas have overwhelmed army units in a number of strategic towns and are now threatening to seize control of all roads linking the capital with the last port the Government still controls, military officials said today.

title: RED CROSS ORDERS SWEEPING CHANGES AT BLOOD CENTERS
description: The board of directors of the American Red Cross voted unanimously today for a sweeping reorganization of the way it collects and handles blood in a move intended to restore confidence in a system that has too often come close to shipping contaminated blood for transfusions.

title: Reactor Built in Japan
description: Construction was completed on Saturday of Japan's first prototype fast-breeder reactor power plant. The plant will now start full-scale tests, a spokesman for the Science and Technology Agency said. The 280,000-kilowatt plant was designed to create roughly 1.2 times more fuel than it consumes. The plant, which is to begin full operations in 1994 after extensive tests, was completed after six years at a cost of 600 billion yen, or about $4.4 billion at current exchange rates.

title: BUDGET IN TURMOIL AS CUOMO REJECTS LAWMAKERS' PLANS
description: Warning that he would not be "blackmailed" into signing a state budget by the end of this week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today rejected many revisions legislative leaders had proposed to his $29 billion spending plan. In doing so, the Governor threw state budget talks into a fresh round of turmoil and further raised the stakes in New York City's bid to reach fiscal stability.

title: Trail Blazers Ponder Their Lost Advantage
description: It took the Portland Trail Blazers all season to gain the homecourt advantage in the National Basketball Association playoffs. It took them only one game to lose it.

title: Bankrupt College Has Final Commencement
description: Tarkio College, a century-old liberal arts school that crumbled under the nation's highest student loan default rate, held its final commencement today.

title: German Jobs Aid Is Granted
description: The European Commission has granted $1.1 billion to help create jobs and bolster job training in eastern Germany through 1993.

title: Isuzu and Phillips N.V. Change Media Plans
description: Two companies revamped their arrangements for media planning, buying and placement last week.

title: A New Complaint About City Taxes: They're Too Low
description: George L. Clark Jr. was complaining the other day about property taxes, specifically the $2,400 bill that New York City sent the owner of a $425,000 one-family house in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn this year. He says the tax is too low.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Are Agencies Responsible For the Claims on a Label?
description: WHEN consumers watch a television commercial in which a duck visits a sleeping hunter, murmuring into the man's ear not to use Federal brand shotgun shells on his next hunting trip, they know it is not believable. But what about other advertising, where there is no talking duck to tip off viewers that a tall tale is being told?

title: The Smithsonian's Jazz Orchestra Makes Its Debut in Washington
description: Intellectuals, record collectors, children and their parents, jazz fans, academics, nostalgics and tourists from Omaha flocked to the Smithsonian's Jazz Masterworks Orchestra opening night performance at a packed Carmichael Auditorium tonight. After the often-brilliant show, which consisted of works by Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Fletcher Henderson and more, audience members bunched around the conductors and musicians, thanking them. It was as if water had suddenly been delivered to the desert.

title: But Can They Hit The Cutoff Man?
description: According to the coach, "MADONNA is very well-coordinated and a very hard worker."

title: Americans Find Royal Visit Moving Some to Adulation, Others to Outrage
description: Americans see Queen Elizabeth II as an anachronism, a touchstone of history or the epitome of all this democratic nation's most cherished fantasies of royalty. As she and her husband make their stately way through a 13-day visit to the United States, they are evoking reactions from adulation to outrage, amusement to befuddlement.

title: Memorial Performance For Martha Graham
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company is to present a performance at 5 P.M. on June 3 at City Center in tribute to Graham, who died on April 1.

title: Penguins Miss Lemieux As Stars Take 2-1 Lead
description: The balance of the Stanley Cup finals swung toward the North Stars in a major way tonight when they beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 3-1, to take a two-games-to-one lead in the four-of-seven championship series.

title: Patriot Computer Failure
description: The Iraqi missile that hit a U.S. barracks during the gulf war, killing 28, penetrated air defenses because of a computer failure, Army investigations have concluded. Page A6.

title: Star-Studded India Vote Gets Mixed Reviews
description: Lal Kishan Advani, leader of the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, is a sobersided, meticulously articulate, scrupulously courtly man. He also happens to be a proven vote-getter in this capital city's most powerful district, and Rajiv Gandhi's most serious competitor for the prime ministership of India.

title: Laura Delaney and Michael L. Brody Are Married
description: Laura Delaney, the social-work librarian for Columbia University, and Michael Lawrence Brody, a New York real-estate manager, were married yesterday at the Bretton Woods Inn in Morris Plains, N.J. Msgr. James P. Cassidy, the chancellor of New York Medical College in Valhalla, and Cantor Henry Herman officiated.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Well, It Was Almost the Nets
description: Will Dikembe Mutombo of Georgetown be the top pick in the National Basketball Association's draft on June 26?

title: Council Flexing New Muscles For New York's Middle Class
description: From the shadows of City Hall, the New York City Council is emerging as the greatest beneficiary of a historic fight to make government more reflective of the city's under-represented and often impoverished minorities.

title: At Kuwaiti Trials, T-Shirt Gets Man 15 Years
description: Kuwait today put on trial the first of hundreds of people accused of collaborating with the Iraqi occupation forces, sending five men to prison, including one for 15 years whose only publicly disclosed offense was wearing a T-shirt with President Saddam Hussein's picture on it.

title: Gasoline Up 2.15 Cents
description: Retail gasoline prices rose 2.15 cents a gallon during the last two weeks, according to an industry survey released today. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service pumps on Friday, was 1.2492 a gallon, according to the Lundberg Survey of 13,000 stations nationwide. The price rise reflected the regular increase in demand that comes with the summer driving season, said Trilby Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. She said demand was likely to peak in July and August. On Friday the average price of regular unleaded was $1.1287 a gallon, including taxes, at self-serve stations. Premium unleaded was $1.2865, and regular leaded was $1.0714. At full-service stations, regular unleaded was $1.3951; premium unleaded was $1.5359, and regular leaded was $1.3648.

title: Bet You Thought Athletes Can't Act
description: With the release of his movie "Stone Cold," BRIAN BOSWORTH is attempting a difficult double: succeeding at acting after being a top-flight athlete. For the most part, athletes who have made it as entertainers have not been well-known in their sports, like BURT LANCASTER (gymnastics) and JOHN WAYNE (football).

title: Disorder. Tumult. Yankees.
description: Even in the absence of their world-famous owner, the Yankees are the sort of team that can turn victory into an intramural debate on the merits of the master plan.

title: Gasp! Famous Match Was Fixed
description: ANTHONY QUINN has played a pope, a used-up boxer and an Arab chieftain. But he remembers a real-life role playing tennis second-banana.

title: Appeal for Democracy Opens Meeting of African Leaders
description: African leaders, opening a United Nations-backed conference here, appealed today for democracy and unity to end civil wars, famine and economic collapse on their continent.

title: Army Is Blaming Patriot's Computer For Failure to Stop the Dhahran Scud
description: The Iraqi missile that slammed into an American military barracks in Saudi Arabia during the Persian Gulf war, killing 28 people, penetrated air defenses because a computer failure shut down the American missile system designed to counter it, two Army investigations have concluded.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 19, 1991: MONDAY Bre Pptys Inc Chemed Corp Marion Merrell Dow Inc Questar Corp Watkins-Johnson Co

title: Siderowf, 53, Defeats Sonnier To Capture Travis Tournament
description: By winning the Walter Travis Invitational golf tournament today at the age of 53, Dick Siderowf proved that his remarkable amateur career can still be considered in the present tense.

title: There Is No Insurance Industry Cartel to Bust; Inviting Insolvencies
description: To the Editor:

title: Foyt Starts Indy Engines for Last Time
description: It was like watching John Wayne cry.

title: Literary Echoes, on the Road
description: A New Yorker who has loved to read for most of his life has only recently learned how much he loves to listen. That's because his wife has begun renting books on tape to amuse them when they take long drives.

title: Review/Theater; A Comedy About a Dramatist Courting the Mob
description: "Breaking Legs," the play that has brought Philip Bosco and Vincent Gardenia to the Promenade Theater, is set in an Italian restaurant, and during much of it, people discuss, order or devour hearty Italian food, from antipasto to veal and peppers. Surely it must say something about this show that it leaves you starving for Chinese.

title: A Fifth of Nuclear Arms Spending Is Termed Wasteful or Unneeded
description: The Department of Energy is spending nearly $2 billion a year, a fifth of its nuclear weapons budget, on plants, projects and contracts attacked by its own inspector general as wasteful or by leading members of Congress as unnecessary.

title: Stocks Slide in Tokyo
description: Stock prices fell today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed at 25,523.03, down 178.91 points, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent. Last week, the Nikkei lost 572.35 points, or about 2.2 percent.

title: Ham's Kissing Cousin Gets a Hug
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Com pany threw itself one humdinger of a 100th birthday party today. There was a hot-air balloon, rock music and more cans of Spam, the company's most famous product, than seemed remotely digestible.

title: Move to U.S. Insurance Is Seen at Credit Unions
description: As many as 500 credit unions are expected to convert from private insurance to Federal deposit insurance by Sept. 30, according to officials at the National Credit Union Administration, which runs the Federal program.

title: Trade Is Topic as Cashen and Herr Meet
description: Tom Herr, with his official exile to the bench less than 48 hours away, held a closed-door meeting with General Manager Frank Cashen today in an attempt to clarify his future with the Mets.

title: Review/Theater; Life and Ritual Death Of a U.S. Army Couple
description: Unless the playwright's name happens to be Shakespeare or Shaw, a theatergoer rarely has the opportunity to see an author's plays in context with one another, to weigh individual merits and identify recurrent themes and motifs. The new Signature Theater Company is meeting an artistic need by devoting an entire season to a single writer and by having him in residence. The company begins auspiciously with Romulus Linney, who has a rich and varied body of work, one that should certainly benefit from such scrutiny.

title: The Primary for Mayor Is Leaving Many in Philadelphia Befuddled
description: Against the backdrop of yet another bribery scandal in City Hall, a resurgent fiscal crisis and the likelihood of more municipal chaos, a sales tax increase and severe service reductions this year, seven candidates are vying to become Philadelphia's 127th mayor in Tuesday's primary election.

title: Northwest Air Cutting Fares
description: Northwest Airlines is cutting air fares by 60 percent for children and 17 percent for adults for trips within the continental United States this summer.

title: 83 Brand-New Condos and a Harbor View: What Am I Bid?
description: Battery Park City was a real-estate developer's dream: an opportunity to build apartments with unobstructed views of the Statue of Liberty and New York Harbor, which would attract the up-and-comers of Wall Street working in the gleaming skyscrapers just steps away.

title: Fight Over Liquidation of Eastern
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Air Lines find themselves fighting with the former carrier's retirees over who will get about $125 million expected from its liquidation.

title: Market Place; Apple Pays Price For New Strategy
description: THE move by Apple Computer Inc. to gain market share by introducing lower-priced machines is succeeding, but the resulting strain on profits has driven its stock down. Its supporters among Wall Street analysts say the company is being penalized for long-term planning.

title: Dance in Review
description: J. Fregalette Jansen Dance Dance Theater Workshop

title: Rabies Fear: It's Tough On Pets, Too
description: It didn't take Bill Peterson long to explain what he was doing today in the line of squirmers, sniffers and growlers that stretched behind the town police station.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "To me this is democracy. Over here you've got protesters against the Queen. Over there you've got people who love her. Me, I've got business from both." -- Leibole Muchnik, a hot-dog vendor in Miami. [ A10:2. ]

title: Upward Pressure Seen for Rates
description: Wall Street, still struggling to digest a record $37 billion worth of securities sold at the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions this month, is about to be served another heaping pile of paper.

title: Susan Dritz Wed To Daniel Brown
description: Susan Jane Dritz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Dritz of Armonk, N.Y., and Daniel Reid Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brown of Linden, N.J., were married yesterday at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In May 1952, LILLIAN HELLMAN refused to name names before the House Committee on Un-American Activities investigating possible links between American leftists and the Communist Party. She was blacklisted and saw her income as a screenwriter drop to almost zero.

title: On the Gringo Trail, With Flower Children's Heirs
description: Under the dry, penetrating sun of the Guatemalan highlands, a jewelry maker from Berkeley strung beads, a South African draft dodger dug into a plate of waffles and a young woman from London seasoned a broccoli and tomato salad.

title: Chicago Hangs Tight In Victory
description: Instead of relying on Michael Jordan today, the rest of the Chicago Bulls relied on each other.

title: Review/Dance; The Guests Bring Tap Shoes; The Hosts Are Stars
description: One of New York's undiscovered treasures is a new weekly show called "Tap City" in a theater-district jazz club called Indigo Blues. Essentially a tap-dance party presided over by Jimmy Slyde, a veteran tapster who performed on Broadway in "Black and Blue," each Monday night show features informal dancing by some of the great tappers, including surprise guest artists who just happen to wander in with their dancing shoes. Mr. Slyde will be on hand tonight, for instance, but no one will know until the show is over just who may join him on the stage.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'Encuentro' Downtown Dance Studio

title: INSIDE
description: National Test Questions A report on what is required of foreign students raises questions about an American national test. Page A12.

title: Darman Sees Signs of Revival
description: President Bush's budget director, Richard Darman, said today that the economy was starting to recover from the recession, but that he could not predict how strong or how long the recovery would be.

title: 26,000 Walk For Money To Combat AIDS Virus
description: "When a friend of mine dies of AIDS, I no longer break down and cry," Samuel Rivera said yesterday. "It still hurts, but I'd just rather spend my time trying to comfort the others in the time they have left."

title: Dance in Review
description: Elizabeth Streb Ringside The Kitchen

title: CHRONICLE
description: OSCAR de la RENTA is to receive the Isabella Graham Award on Wednesday at a benefit at the Plaza Hotel. The award is given at the annual gala of Graham-Windham, an organization created in 1806 to provide services to children and families, including foster care, adoption and treatment for abused chldren.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Exams in Other Nations Studied in U.S. for Ideas
description: In France, students must write a four-hour essay on what it means to be free. Germany's national test asks the significance of the French Revolution. Japan's examination demands that high school students hoping to make it into college identify the astronomer Ptolemy and Voltaire.

title: Bush Appoints More Women, But It's All-Male Club at Top
description: The capital has always been a man's town, a monochromatic landscape of button- down and gray flannel, and this White House is no different.

title: 'Prelude to a Kiss' Closes
description: "Prelude to a Kiss," a comic fairy tale by Craig Lucas, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street. The play, which was directed by Norman Rene, ran for 440 regular performances and 8 previews.

title: New Shopping Center Opens in South Bronx
description: Concourse Plaza, a $150 million shopping center just off the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx that has come to symbolize the area's quest for economic well-being, opened for business yesterday with overflow crowds thronging its stores but with the shadow of the city's fiscal problems hanging over it.

title: Protect Deposits -- and the Economy
description: A House banking subcommittee last week rejected two White House proposals to cut back Federal deposit insurance. That might seem odd at a time when the fund that insures depositors is low and sinking. But the subcommittee showed shrewd judgment. There's a much sounder way to fix up bank insurance:

title: Perry, in Playoff, Outduels Irwin to Win The Memorial
description: Ignoring everything but the next shot, Kenny Perry overcame the pressure of Hale Irwin and a sudden-death playoff today to attain his first career victory at the Memorial Tournament.

title: Review/Pop; Deee-lite's Ode to Glamour In the Pop-Culture Idiom
description: About halfway through Deee-lite's packed show at Roseland on Thursday night, the group's lead singer, Lady Miss Kier, said, "The world is ugly," then launched into a short environmental plea. It was the only conventionally articulated verbal moment of the night.

title: Rangers Pound Red Sox Again To Bring Winning Streak to 7
description: Julio Franco drove in four runs and the Texas Rangers won their seventh straight game, taking apart previously unbeaten Tom Bolton and trouncing the Boston Red Sox, 12-4, today.

title: Quayle Visits The Japanese
description: Vice President Dan Quayle, his Air Force plane hobbled by the failure of some navigational equipment, arrived in Japan this morning one day late for a short visit in which he was to press Japanese leaders for greater flexibility on trade issues.

title: Brown and Princeton Lose
description: Previously undefeated Brown lost, and so did Princeton, in triple overtime, while North Carolina and Syracuse advanced yesterday with quarterfinal victories in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: Giants Plan More Changes
description: The Giants' off season of change will continue. Coach Ray Handley said yesterday that he would hire another assistant coach and rearrange the coaches' roles with regard to running backs, tight ends and wide receivers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; The Rush to Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood
description: WITH Bo Jackson sidelined, marketing experts have been wondering who will replace him as the best pitchman in advertising. Some believe the next superstar endorser is David Robinson. David knows basketball.

title: Doane McCarthy, 76, Insurance Executive
description: G. Doane McCarthy Jr., the vice president of the ocean/marine division of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies from 1946 to 1976, when he retired, died on Saturday at the Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 76 years old and lived in Madison, N.J.

title: Parcells Is Gone, All Bets Are Off
description: Minutes after BILL PARCELLS stepped down as coach of the Giants, to be replaced by RAY HANDLEY, three plungers invested $2,000 apiece against the Giants in their game against the 49ers.

title: Extra Time For Trades Expected
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to take an important step on Monday toward 24-hour trading of stocks in the United States, approving a request by the New York Stock Exchange to extend trading beyond the closing bell at 4 P.M.

title: A Hard Sell, Inspired by The Classics
description: Americans bought more than 3.5 million Penguin Classics last year, everything from Aesop's "Fables" to the history of Xenophon. But sales of the classics have been flat for a couple of years and competition is more heated than ever.

title: Brazil Denial On Currency
description: The Economy Minister of Brazil, Marcilio Marques Moreira, has denied rumors that Latin America's biggest economy would imitate Argentina's latest anti-inflation plan and link its currency to the United States dollar.

title: Soviets Cooperating on Military Books in the West
description: With the change in East-West relations, the Soviet Union is now cooperating with Western publishers on books about the Soviet military, providing the sort of facts, figures and even photographs that spies had for decades risked life and limb to obtain.

title: Bridge
description: The conclusion of five days of play here today determined the American representation in the World Team Championships scheduled for Yokohama, Japan, in October.

title: Confusion At a High, It's On To Belmont
description: With two Triple Crown races run and after many wild swings of fortune, the world of horse racing was left today with two things: confusion in the 3-year-old division and a wide-open field of at least 10 horses for the final Triple Crown race, the Belmont Stakes on June 8.

title: After the Flutter
description: "I'm feeling fine. Don't worry about me; I'm in great shape." How often have you said that to your family and friends -- even when you were feeling lousy, and were concerned about your health?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: At Notre Dame, a Call to 'Be Informed'
description: Margaret O'Brien Steinfels, the editor of Commonweal magazine, advised graduates at the University of Notre Dame yesterday not to ignore the poverty and suffering of millions of people around the world but to "be informed, think carefully and take responsibility."

title: Miriam Rubin Is a Bride
description: Miriam L. Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rubin of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles J. Yeager, the son of Mrs. Charles Ackley and the stepson of Mr. Ackley of Harrisonville, Mo. Rabbi Stanley Yedwab officiated at Mountain Lakes House in Princeton. The bride, 30 years old, is keeping her name. She is a psychological associate at the South Bay Mental Health Center in Weymouth, Mass. She graduated magna cum laude from Brown University and received a doctorate in clinical psychology from the University of Missouri at Columbia, where the bridegroom, 35, graduated. He is a computer specialist at the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Roxbury, Mass.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Sanchez Wins in Italy as Mancini Retires Emilio Sanchez won the Italian Open in Rome yesterday when a severe groin pull forced Alberto Mancini of Argentina to quit midway through the third set of their championship match. The ninth-seeded Sanchez was leading, 6-3, 6-1, 3-0, when Mancini said that he could not continue. Fourteen minutes into the third set, with Mancini hobbling and Sanchez holding a 3-0, 40-0 lead in the fourth game, the Mancini motioned to Sanchez that the match was over and trotted gingerly toward the net to shake his hand. (AP)

title: Becky Browder and Ted Neustadt Wed
description: Rebecca Lynne Browder and Frederic Lawton Neustadt were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green by Judge Marcy L. Kahn of New York City Criminal Court in Manhattan.

title: There Is No Insurance Industry Cartel to Bust
description: To the Editor:

title: California Regulator Takes Top Role in Insurance Crisis
description: John Garamendi, California's first elected Insurance Commissioner, stood before 500 angry policyholders of the failed Executive Life Insurance Company, answering their questions, trying to soothe their fears and getting a warm response when he promised, "I'm working for you."

title: IMPASSE ON ARMS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The spear of the kind carried by Zulu migrant workers has become both the immediate cause and the sweeping symbol of the rupture that led the African National Congress on Saturday to suspend talks with the white minority Government on a proposed constitution.

title: Nicaragua: Give Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The Man Who Knew So Much About Numbers
description: The Man Who Knew Infinity A Life of the Genius Ramanujan By Robert Kanigel 438 pages. Illustrated. Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.95.

title: Review/Television; Battling Cancer and an Addicted Son
description: Compulsively searching for upbeat material, television entertainment employs processing methods that are little short of treacherous. The latest unsettling example can be found on NBC tonight at 9: "Reason for Living: The Jill Ireland Story."

title: Lungs From Parents Fail to Save Girl, 9, and Doctors Assess Ethics
description: In a desperate attempt to save the life of a 9-year-old Minnesota girl whose lungs had failed, doctors first transplanted part of her father's lung and, when that was not enough, tried to transplant part of her mother's lung.

title: The Taxi Industry Can and Should Heal Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Letter to an Ex-Hostage, Bush Denies a Plot With Iran
description: President Bush wrote to an American formerly held captive in Iran that he did not know of or participate in any plan to delay the hostages' release until after the 1980 election.

title: Jean P. Tammero Marries Anthony Christopher Uzzi
description: Jean Patrice Tammero, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tammero of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York to Anthony Christopher Uzzi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Domenick R. Uzzi of Garden City. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Clermont.

title: Driver Is Fatally Shot on the West Side Highway
description: Back from an aeronautical college in Florida where he had finished his second year studying to be a commercial airline pilot, 20-year-old David Cargill had been in a festive mood after leaving a party early yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., so he and two friends decided to drive into New York City.

title: Pretoria Panel to Study Issue of Blacks' Lost Land
description: Under pressure to do more for the blacks who were dispossessed in the name of apartheid, the Government today announced the creation of an advisory commission on land issues to consider appeals from those who want to return home.

title: Panel Member Says Chairman Changed Council District to Aid Ally
description: Two members of the New York City Districting Commission charged yesterday that the panel's chairman unilaterally altered a proposed City Council district for Brooklyn, and one said the change was intended to help a political ally of the chairman.

title: Observer; Allergy Was All
description: In New York we rode in a taxi whose driver was allergic to smoke. It brought back old times when it was almost impossible to find in all New York a cab driver who was not allergic to smoke. An allergy to smoke seemed to be the main requirement for anyone seeking work in the taxi trade.

title: Irving Koerner Investment Banker, 84
description: Irving Koerner, a retired executive vice president of the investment banking firm of Allen & Company in Manhattan, died on Thursday at the Carlotta-Good Samaritan Nursing Home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 84 years old and lived in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: Patterns
description: Making Statements

title: Charles B. Colmore Jr., Retired Executive, 78
description: Charles Blayney Colmore Jr., a retired executive of the Procter & Gamble Company and a former chair umpire for the United States Lawn Tennis Association, died on May 12 at his home in Baltimore. He was 78.

title: Divine Dozen for Hobart, An No One Else Has Any
description: There was a turnover, with 30 seconds remaining and Hobart clinging to a 12-11 lead. The Statesmen got the ball back and a surge of relief swept over the players and their coach, B.J. O'Hara. This Hobart lacrosse team was not going to be the school's first to lose the national championship.

title: Video Games Publisher Recruits Soviet Inventor
description: Aleksei Pajitnov, a Soviet software programmer best known as the author of the hit video game Tetris, has joined Bullet-Proof Software as a creator of games. Based in Redmond, Wash., Bullet-Proof is a publisher of video games for the Nintendo Entertainment System and Nintendo's hand-held Game Boy.

title: Soybean Group Backs Chiefs
description: The American Soybean Association said today that its directors had voted to retain the group's top leadership, turning back a challenge amid allegations of financial mismanagement.

title: Output Down in Japan
description: Japan's industrial production in March declined by 2.1 percent from the previous month, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The figure was revised downward from an estimated drop of 1.3 percent. March output rose a revised 3.5 percent from a year earlier.

title: A New Office At Nordstrom
description: Nordstrom Inc., the retail chain based on the West Coast, said today that it had created an office of the president to strengthen its executive management team.

title: Next Bloomingdale's Chief Named
description: Federated Department Stores appointed Michael Gould yesterday to succeed Marvin S. Traub as chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, and both men painted a rosy picture of the innovative retailer's future, including a possible resumption of plans to expand across the United States and abroad.

title: Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers began to prepare for a huge supply of new short-term securities.

title: A Head Start On Wheeling And Dealing
description: No sooner was the National Basketball Association lottery over on Sunday and the order of the league's draft on June 26 determined than the trading season began.

title: Use of Motorcycle Helmets Signed Into Law in California
description: Gov. Pete Wilson signed into law today a requirement that California's 850,000 motorcyclists wear helmets when riding on the state's roads.

title: Ship Orders for Japan
description: Foreign ship orders received by Japanese yards in April rose sharply, to 12 ships of 1.3 million gross tons, from 7 ships of 338,770 million tons in March, the Japan Ship Exporters Association said today. The April order figure is still below the figure for April 1990, when 25 ships were ordered weighing a million tons.

title: By Design; The Vampire Look: A Purple Smile
description: One would suppose most women would want to look healthy and natural as summer approaches, so it is odd that vampire-style makeup is catching on just now. But fashion often has no rhyme or reason. Even Madonna is wearing her version of it.

title: Study Links Smoking To Impotence Cases
description: A BOSTON study indicates that cigarette smoking may be a cause of impotence.

title: For Jefferies, Second; For Team, Jitters
description: For the Mets, it is clearly the most important double switch of the season. At Shea Stadium tonight, Howard Johnson will be returned to third base as a result of the expected activation of shortstop Kevin Elster from the disabled list. Consequently, Gregg Jefferies will be placed in official residence at second.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borden Inc., New York, the food and dairy company, acquired the clam products business of American Original Corp., a unit of Hillsdown Seafoods Inc., Toronto. Terms were not disclosed. * Brown-Forman Corp., Louisville, Ky., a consumer products company, will acquire Dansk International Designs Ltd., Mount Kisco, N.Y., a maker of housewares and giftware, for about $70 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Critic's Notebook; Classical Composers Rediscover The Public
description: I keep running into orchestra pieces called "Wild Angels of the Open Hills," "Beyond the Reach of Wind and Fire" or "From the Ark of Emerging Shadows." Whatever happened to "Knoxville; Summer of 1915," "Slaughter on 10th Avenue" and "The Housatonic at Stockbridge"?

title: Stringent Rules For Fuel Trucks
description: While New York City has the most stringent rules in the country on the transportaton and delivery of gasoline and other flammable liquids, the perfect fireproof tank truck has yet to be built, fire officials said yesterday.

title: 40 KILLED IN INDIA AS VOTING BEGINS
description: India's 10th national election began today in an outburst of political violence that left at least 40 people dead and hundreds wounded. Dozens of polling stations were ordered closed, and several cities have been placed under curfew.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
Salick's Growing Health Care Niche
description: ANALYSTS say that Salick Health Care Inc., which derives 70 percent of its revenues from its cancer centers, has developed a unique niche within the health care industry. Certain recent problems aside, they say, the company is poised for steady, impressive growth.

title: BUSH IN OVERTURE TO CUBAN LEADER
description: In a radio address marking the 89th anniversary of Cuban independence, President Bush today held out the prospect of improved relations with Cuba if Fidel Castro held democratic elections and freed all political prisoners.

title: Launching by Soviets Succeeds, but Advertising Plan Fails
description: Britain and the Soviet Union are apparently better at outer space than at advertising space.

title: Promising Drug Turns Some Cancerous Cells Into Benign Cells
description: DOCTORS have successfully treated a small group of leukemia patients using a new therapy that prods unruly cancer cells to mature into normal cells. Conventional cancer drugs attempt to kill malignant cells, but their aim is so poor that they are often ineffective and destroy many normal cells, producing notorious side effects.

title: A Victory In Trenton For Smokers
description: The State Senate today overwhelmingly passed a compromise measure to protect the employment rights of smokers, making it likely that the bill will become law.

title: In Hockey, Star's Name Is Stanley
description: STEWART GAVIN, a tough, bearded man who makes a living knocking down other men on the ice, was walking through a hotel lobby last week in Pittsburgh when he suddenly felt like a tiny steel filing being pulled to a magnet.

title: U.S. Expands Mortgage Plan
description: The Government expanded a program today that allows elderly homeowners to receive a monthly check by tapping their home equity through a "reverse mortgage."

title: An NCR Portable
description: The NCR Corporation, which has merged into the computer business of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it was entering the portable computer market with one of the smallest and lightest notebook computers in its class. The company said its new NCR 3120 model, which weighs 5.6 pounds, will be available next month. It is based on the Intel Corporation 386SX microprocessor, NCR said. The basic model, with a 30-megabyte hard drive, will list for $3,995, NCR said; a second model, with a 60-megabyte hard drive, will list for $4,395.

title: British Skills Are Winners at Indy
description: This Sunday's Indianapolis 500, which usually attract's the world's largest crowd for a one-day sporting event, will once again be a showcase of British automotive design and engineering skills.

title: Engineers Try to Fix Galileo's Antenna
description: IN their first attempt to unfurl a malfunctioning antenna, flight controllers yesterday maneuvered the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft to absorb warmth from the distant Sun on the chance that the chill of outer space has contracted metal and left the umbrella-like antenna only partly deployed.

title: DEMOCRATS INTEND TO OUTLAW QUOTAS IN CIVIL RIGHTS BILL
description: House Democrats plan to blunt criticism by the Bush Administration of this year's civil rights legislation by specifically outlawing the use of quotas in hiring and promotion.

title: First Capital Has Big Loss
description: The First Capital Holdings Corporation said today that it lost $770 million in the first quarter after accounting for the recent seizures of its life insurance subsidiaries by regulators in California and Virginia.

title: TV SPORTS: Baseball; No Fountains of Cash For Baseball's Newest
description: Eons ago, in the far away baseball past of 1976, Peter Bavasi was running the Toronto Blue Jays, negotiating media deals for the new expansion team, which would start life a year later.

title: INSIDE
description: Military Spending Debate

title: Corrections
description: An annotated map yesterday describing nuclear weapons spending misstated spending at the Hanford Site in Richland, Wash., in some copies. The figure is $253 million a year, not $353 million.

title: Bush Says Suspects in Kuwait Deserve Fair-Trial Protection
description: President Bush said today that Kuwait should extend fair-trial protections to people accused of collaboration with the Iraqi occupation who are being put on trial this week, many of whom have complained of torture and lack of access to defense lawyers.

title: Short, Snappy And Sporty Furs
description: The long hairs endure for women who like to cuddle sybaritically into their furs. But the snappiest styles in the fall shows are sheared furs, mainly mink, which look as supple as velvet and are relatively simple. They take to color gloriously and are best in clean, casual shapes.

title: Spreading Blame for Latest Budget of Them All
description: When the State Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo shattered the record for a late budget last year, the mark of May 19 seemed as unbreakable as Bob Beamon's 29-foot, 2 1/2-inch long jump at the 1968 Olympics.

title: Topics of The Times; Laundry, Lite
description: Procter & Gamble, Lever Brothers and other manufacturers of laundry detergent know how to achieve four virtues at once: save space on the supermarket shelf, save space under the sink, reduce wasteful packaging and strike a blow against deceptive packaging.

title: SOVIET ECONOMISTS IN HARVARD TALKS
description: Reflecting a sense of desperation in the Soviet Union, a team of high-level Soviet economists began meetings here today with American professors to draw up a plan that they hope could save the Russian economy by offering sweeping reforms in exchange for a huge program of Western aid.

title: Q&A
description: Plant Cancer

title: Accounting Seat Denied
description: Robert A. Orben, vice president for accounting policy at the Cummins Engine Company, has been rejected by the Financial Accounting Foundation as a member of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a foundation trustee said yesterday.

title: New Study of Older Workers Finds They Can Become Good Investments
description: Dan Young of Atlanta came out of an unwanted retirement four years ago, took a job booking hotel rooms and now at the age of 74 helps supervise hundreds of reservation agents.

title: Music in Review
description: Ramon Salvatore Pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: Sam Falk, 90, Is Dead; A Times Photographer
description: Sam Falk, a photographer at The New York Times for more than 40 years, died on Sunday at the Sunrise Health Center in Sunrise, Fla. He was 90 years old and lived in Plantation, Fla.

title: Desoto Settlement
description: Desoto Inc., a maker of detergents, agreed to resolve its proxy contest with the Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York investment house, by granting Sutton representatives a majority on Desoto's board of directors. Desoto, of Des Plaines, Ill., was once one of the largest suppliers of paint to Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Elliot Oppenheim, Internist, 75
description: Dr. Elliot Oppenheim, a specialist in internal medicine, especially diabetes, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: Women Swell Ranks of Science, But Remain Invisible at the Top
description: THE National Academy of Sciences announced its annual roll of new members this month, bestowing a highly coveted honor on a small group of American researchers. But of the 60 American scientists elected to the academy this year, only 6 are women. Some women in science take little satisfaction in the academy's election results.

title: Topics of The Times; Sudden Death
description: Is capital punishment so shameful that a judge must be coy about administering it? Judge George Reinhardt in Grangeville, Idaho, concealed from both prosecution and defense that he was considering the death penalty for Bryan Lankford, a convicted murderer, even though the state specifically declined to seek it. After a hearing at which the lawyers argued only about the length of a prison term, the judge decreed death.

title: 80 Million Americans Prove That Beer Is Not a Villain
description: To the Editor:

title: C. Harold Kidwell, 95, Engineer and Executive
description: C. Harold Kidwell, a chemical engineer and the founder of the Reduction Engineering Corporation of Newark, died on Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 95 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Music in Review
description: Jose Carlos Cocarelli Pianist Carnegie Hall

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column of Business Day on Saturday incorrectly described a machine, invented by Auburn International Inc., that analyzes baked goods. The machine measures fats and oils, but not cholesterol.

title: Yield at 9.68% On Hertz Notes
description: The Hertz Corporation, a unit of the Park Ridge Corporation, is offering $100 million in noncallable senior subordinated notes, due in 1998, through Lehman Brothers.

title: Pete Runnels, Baseball Player, 63
description: Pete Runnels, who won American League batting titles with the Boston Red Sox in 1960 and 1962, died today, three days after he had a stroke. He was 63.

title: Challenging the Cold War Today: Scholar on L.I. Battles the 'List'
description: It has been almost five years since Choichiro Yatani's life was interrupted by an accusation that, even then, seemed to echo from another time: immigration officials charged that he was on a sealed Government list of Communists.

title: Thomas M. Biallo, Executive, 66
description: Thomas M. Biallo, an executive in the perfume industry, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: For Councilman's Bigger Job, An Unusual Expense Fund
description: The mood was festive that evening in October at the Park Avenue home of Robin and Carol Farkas.

title: Court Approves Settlement in Marcos Case
description: A Federal judge today approved a payment of $2 million by Imelda Marcos and the estate of her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, to the families of two foes of the Marcos regime who were assassinated in 1981.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This is a sign, finally, that the Soviet Union values human rights, as do people all over the world. It is truly a breakthrough moment for us in building a law-based state." -- Fyodor M. Burlatsky, Soviet legislator and editor. [ A1:6. ]

title: Even With Sax on the Move, Yanks Go Nowhere
description: The most significant news of the night was Steve Sax, whose first major league start as a third baseman became a non-event. He fielded, he threw, perhaps a little wildly, and he said it would take him time to adjust.

title: 4-Day Workweek Ordered By Suffolk in Budget Crisis
description: Faced with a projected $60 million budget deficit and an immediate cash shortage, the Suffolk County Executive signed an order today directing county employees not to report to work on the next 10 Fridays.

title: Nicholas T. Elko, 81, Cincinnati Archbishop
description: The Rev. Nicholas T. Elko, a retired auxiliary archbishop for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cincinnati, died of cancer on Saturday. He was 81 years old.

title: G.I.'s Scout a Kurdish City Beyond the Allied Zone; Iraqi Police Cause Unease
description: The continued presence of the Iraqi secret police in a key Kurdish area of Iraq has dissuaded refugees from returning to their homes, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: Chess
description: There are players -- the methodical ones -- who go into a tournament with everything worked out in advance like a minutely detailed road map. They plan exactly which opponents they will win against and which ones they will concede draws to.

title: Angels Sign Valenzuela To One-Year Contract
description: FERNANDO VALENZUELA, released by the Los Angeles Dodgers in March, signed a one-year contract with the California Angels yesterday and will start in a minor league game tomorrow.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Over the weekend, the National Inventors Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio, welcomed the Nobel Prize Laureate GERTRUDE BELLE ELION to be the first woman to become a member. Two years ago, Ms. Elion, who is 73 years old, won the prize in medicine for her work with GEORGE H. HITCHINGS in synthesizing drugs to treat cancer. Ms. Elion, a researcher at the Burroughs-Wellcome Company who holds 40 patents, has worked for many years on leukemia treatment and now does consulting in AIDS research.

title: Upper Providence Township Journal; Candidate May Be Dead, But He's Still Their Man
