description: Win or lose in Tuesday's primary for township supervisor here, J. Robert Kershner can never take office. He died of a heart attack May 5. But his death has not slowed the Republican Party machine, which is campaigning vigorously for his re-election.

title: G.E. to Build Japan A-Plants
description: The General Electric Company said today that it had won a license from the Japanese Government to begin building two nuclear power plants in Japan that will bring the company more than $1 billion in revenue.

title: Books of The Times; Iris Murdoch Defends Art Against Plato
description: The Fire and the Sun Why Plato Banished the Artists By Iris Murdoch 89 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: Job Seekers Less Likely To Try Move
description: DISCOURAGED about mergers and downsizings, workers with jobs worry about job security, while those who have lost jobs yearn for future security. For the first group, security often involves not making a move out of a job, and for the second group it often involves not making a move out of an area to find a new job.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: After Mexico, the Main Event
description: Fast-track trade legislation, committing Congress to voting on trade agreements promptly and without amendment, is scheduled for vote early this week. Without such protection, foreign governments won't negotiate trade pacts, fearing that hard-fought deals could then be picked apart by special interests. That's why opponents of the Administration's free-trade pact with Mexico have targeted fast-track for attack.

title: Drug Traffickers Free 2 Bogota Journalists
description: In gesture of peace to a Government moving to ban the extradition of drug traffickers, the Medellin cocaine cartel today released two prominent journalists it kidnapped last year.

title: Dow Edges Up 5.59 as Trading Slows
description: Wall Street barely went through the motions yesterday as stock trading dropped to its slowest level of the year.

title: Garfield's Star Role Is Reduced
description: FOR years, the antics of Garfield the cartoon cat have dominated advertising for Embassy Suites hotels. But a forthcoming multimillion-dollar campaign will turn the beast into the Cheshire cat, fading from his once pre-eminent position.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Player Seeks Extended Run as a Pennsylvania Senator
description: Harris L. Wofford, a 65-year-old political insider who helped start the Peace Corps and brought President John F. Kennedy together with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., took an unaccustomed spot in front of the cameras this month when he became Pennsylvania's newly appointed United States Senator. Simultaneously, he became the incumbent running for election in November in the only United States Senate race this year.

title: New Jersey Court Upsets Death Sentence
description: The State Supreme Court today reversed the death sentence of a Camden man who strangled a 14-year-old acquaintance in a dispute over drugs. But the high court upheld the man's conviction.

title: U.N. Monitors for El Salvador
description: In anticipation of an end to the civil war in El Salvador, the Security Council voted unanimously today to set up a 160-member observer force to verify compliance with the cease-fire agreement expected to be reached between the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

title: Bill Would Prohibit Naming Rape Victims
description: A State Senator said today that he would introduce legislation making it a crime for news organizations to disclose the name of a rape victim.

title: Coach Reprimanded
description: The Southeastern Conference yesterday issued a public reprimand to Mississippi football coach BILLY BREWER for labeling the Mississippi State coach, JACKIE SHERRILL, "a habitual liar." ROY KRAMER, the S.E.C. commissioner, said any further violation of the conference's code of ethics along similar lines could mean a suspension of Brewer's coaching duties for one or more games.

title: Review/Film; 3 Novels Are Adapted For 'Angel at My Table'
description: Movies about writers tend to fall to pieces when the writer starts writing, at which point there's nothing for the movie to do except hang around waiting for the writer's reviews to come in. The act of writing is private; whether done with a quill pen or a personal computer, it is singularly uninvolving to the looker-on.

title: Microsoft Plans Basic Research Lab
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest publisher of personal computer software, has quietly begun recruiting talented scientists for its first basic research center. Earlier this month, the company hired three leading scientists away from I.B.M. to join its effort.

title: Ice Age Theory
description: New findings by scientists from Columbia University challenge a widespread theory that algae in the Antarctic Ocean played a major role in reducing carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the last ice age.

title: Quayle Urges Japanese To Open Markets to U.S.
description: Vice President Dan Quayle pressed Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other officials today to open Japan to more American exports and investments as a crucial step toward improving relations with the United States.

title: George A. Custer, 67, Retired Army Colonel
description: George Armstrong Custer 3d, a retired Army colonel who vigorously opposed attempts to rename a national monument dedicated to his great-granduncle, died of a heart attack on Saturday at a hospital in Toledo, Ohio, He was 67 years old.

title: Music in Review
description: Brooklyn Philharmonic Carnegie Hall

title: Comet Is Leaving American Symphony; Botstein Takes Post
description: Catherine Comet, the highly regarded conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, will leave her post at the end of her three-year tenure next season. The orchestra said yesterday that she would be succeeded by Leon Botstein, who is president of Bard College and principal guest conductor of the Hudson Valley Philharmonic.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Anadarko Petroleum Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million in debt securities. * Federal Home Loan Banks will announce today the interest rate for a $300 million bond offering of an issue due on May 25, 1994.

title: Unusual Carbon Yields Ultrahigh Pressure
description: SCIENTISTS at Cornell University predict that diamonds and an unusual form of carbon called "buckminsterfullerene" may permit ultrahigh-pressure laboratory experiments duplicating conditions at the center of giant planets.

title: A Bold Step Toward Safer Blood
description: The American Red Cross is moving forcefully, if belatedly, to strengthen its procedures for testing and handling blood that threatened to allow some patients to receive blood contaminated with the AIDS virus or other diseases. Only three months after taking office, the new Red Cross president, Elizabeth Dole, announced yesterday that the organization will now spend some $120 million on a sweeping reorganization of its entire blood collection system, which supplies half of the nation's blood for transfusions.

title: No Sword and No Kneeling, Schwarzkopf Is Knighted
description: In a brief private ceremony in his office at MacDill Air Force Base here, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf today became the ninth American military officer to receive an honorary knighthood from a King or Queen of England.

title: Will a Master of Control Fit the Knicks' Master Plan?
description: The line starts behind glamorous Pat Riley, because it must be that way. The hairdo, the four championship rings and the network persona demand such status.

title: Our Towns
description: On the surface, they looked just like 100 high school sophomores and juniors dressed for a day at summer camp in a leafy city park. They arrived from four different directions on those huge yellow buses belching blue exhaust smoke. They milled around like teen-agers trying not to look as lost as they felt. Then, in that perennial primal urge that has proved chaperone-resistant for eons, the students clustered for security into 10 groups -- boys and girls from five different schools.

title: Bush Links End Of Trading Ban To Hussein Exit
description: President Bush said today that the United States would oppose the lifting of the worldwide ban against trading with Iraq until President Saddam Hussein is forced out of power in Baghdad.

title: Walesa, in Israel, Regrets Poland's Anti-Semitism
description: In an unusual, emotional speech to the Israeli Parliament, President Lech Walesa of Poland apologized today for anti-Semitism in Polish history.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Saturday about paintings owned by the Japanese industrialist Ryoei Saito misidentifed the auction house at which he bought van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet." It was Christie's, not Sotheby's.

title: Eastern Airlines Fight Continues
description: Lawyers for the retirees and unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines failed to reach agreement on how to divide about $125 million from the liquidation of the company. Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, who is presiding over Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, scheduled another hearing for 2 P.M. today.

title: Sax Is at Third, Rookie to Start At Second
description: At the moment, Steve Sax, the Yankees' new third baseman, says he is neither seeking a trade nor thinking about a request for one. But with this team especially, things can change.

title: Ailing Penguins Need Their Own Miracles
description: The Stanley Cup finals began as a Minnesota miracle story but have also become a Pittsburgh medical story.

title: Fiat Sells Plant
description: Magneti Marelli S.p.A., a unit of Fiat S.p.A., said it had sold a plant that produced diesel fuel injectors for industrial vehicles. A Fiat statement did not give financial details about the sale to the Stanadyne Automotive Corporation, an American company. But Fiat said said the plant, under Stanadyne, would continue to produce fuel injectors for sale in Italy by Marelli.

title: I.C.I. Fills U.S. Post
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that Robert C. Black would succeed William F. Lalor as president of ICI Pharmaceuticals Group, the British company's American drug unit, in July. Mr. Lalor will retire at age 65. Mr. Black, 48, has been vice president of sales and marketing. He joined Stuart Pharmaceuticals, which was later acquired by I.C.I., as a salesman in 1965.

title: Mutual Benefit Life And Cigna Ratings
description: The debt ratings of two large insurance companies were adjusted or affirmed yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Battery System For Electric Cars
description: The Nissan Motor Company and the Japan Storage Battery Company said they had jointly developed new batteries and a recharging system for electric vehicles that could reduce recharging time by 80 percent. The system can recharge the newly developed nickel-cadmium batteries to 40 percent capacity in 6 minutes and newly developed lead-acid batteries to full capacity in 12 minutes, Nissan said.

title: U.S. Lauds Soviet Law but Wants to Read Details
description: The Bush Administration praised the Soviet legistature's passage today of a long-anticipated free emigration bill, but the White House said it wanted to read the fine print before it decided to grant Moscow the trade benefits that were conditioned on the bill's passage.

title: Gomez Out of Paris
description: Defending French Open champion ANDRES GOMEZ announced yesterday that because of a strained thigh muscle he will not return to Paris to defend his title next week.

title: Outsiders' Role In Mexico Pact
description: FOREIGN-OWNED factories in the United States, a spreading phenomenon in the 1980's, left many Americans wondering if the nation's industrial power had been diluted. Now the proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico is renewing debate over that concern.

title: On My Mind; If I Were a Rich Man
description: When I was about 17 years old, I used to daydream about earning some money beyond what I needed for carfare and lunches in the college cafeteria. I mean real money, something like thirty or forty dollars.

title: SOVIETS ENACT LAW FREEING MIGRATION AND TRIPS ABROAD
description: The Soviet Parliament today overwhemingly approved the country's first law granting citizens the right to travel and emigrate freely.

title: Walter Henry Rozell Jr. Banker, 81
description: Walter Henry Rozell Jr., a former vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died May 14 at Toronto Western Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Toronto.

title: Banks Avoid Some F.D.I.C. Fees
description: As the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation prepares to increase insurance premiums charged on bank deposits, a handful of banks are taking advantage of a financing technique that allows them to borrow funds in a way that does not require payment for deposit insurance.

title: Reardon Chalks Up His 300th Save As Red Sox Shut Out the Brewers
description: Jeff Reardon notched his 300th career save and Steve Lyons and Jack Clark hit home runs as the Boston Red Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-0, tonight and ended a losing streak at three games.

title: CHRONICLE
description: An American writer accused of trying to blackmail the British actress JANE SEYMOUR is free in $40,000 bail in Britain. Asserting that he is innocent, GEORGE MENDOZA, an author of children's and sports books, told The Daily Express of London, "I'll tell my side of the story and it will be a real shocker."

title: Better Than the Brady Bill
description: While America should do more to keep handguns away from criminals, the Brady and Staggers bills, which share that objective, are insufficient. An improvement of the Brady bill that I intend to offer as legislation would do more than both to keep handguns out of criminals' hands.

title: Key Rates
A Prince for Passaic?
description: Given the country's fiscal woes and the flutter of attention being directed toward the visit of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, it's a wonder that no one has come up with a simple plan that would both revive the economy and satisfy our fascination with royalty.

title: Bridge
description: A long shot came home for three New England players during the past week. Robert Barr of Lynn, Mass., Harold Stengel of Hingham, Mass., and Bernie Miller, who recently moved South to Boca Raton, Fla., were in some difficulty a year ago. By winning the Grand National Teams in 1989 they had qualified for playoffs to decide the 1991 American representatives in the world championships, scheduled in Japan in October.

title: People
description: * Daniel Zucchi has been promoted to senior vice president-director of consumer marketing, a new position at Hearst Magazines, New York, from publisher of the company's Redbook magazine, effective June 3. Succeeding Mr. Zucchi at Redbook is Gregory W. Dunn, from executive vice president-group president, Family Media Inc., New York. Succeeding Mr. Dunn, as senior vice president, is Jeff Kleinman, publisher of Family Media's Health magazine. * Sanford T. Beldon has been promoted to senior vice president at Rodale Press, Emmaus, Pa. He will continue as publisher of the company's Prevention magazine until a successor is named.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * HPSC Inc., Boston, a finance company specializing in the dental profession, named Louis J. P. Calisti, D.D.S., chairman and chief executive. * John Hancock Financial Services, Boston, named Page Palmer vice president-human resources.

title: Kuwaitis Defend Treatment Of Convicted Collaborators
description: Kuwaiti officials today sought to justify the stern sentences meted out Sunday to people accused of collaborating with the Iraqi occupiers, including a 15-year term to a man who wore a T-shirt with President Saddam Hussein's picture.

title: Orion Is Revising Debt To Lower Its Payments
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation announced a extensive restructuring yesterday, intended to reduce its interest payments by about $400 million through the 1998 fiscal year.

title: Mistrial Is Declared in Capital Lawsuit Involving a Journalist
description: A judge declared a mistrial today in a lawsuit brought by six police officers who sought to compel a Washington Post reporter to disclose her source of information about an unsuccessful drug raid. The judge also said he would lift the contempt citation against the reporter.

title: Soviet-U.S. Economic Meeting
description: High-level Soviet economists began meetings with American professors to draw up a plan of sweeping reforms and Western aid. Page A7.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: W.L.A.F.

title: 5 Die and 11 Bronx Stores Burn As Gas Tanker and Car Collide
description: A gasoline tanker and a car collided at a Bronx intersection early yesterday, killing five people and igniting a fireball with rivers of blazing fuel that engulfed a row of 11 stores and touched off a series of secondary explosions in parked cars.

title: Georgetown Reprimands Author of Article
description: The Georgetown University law student whose article last month questioned the qualifications of black students at the law school was formally reprimanded by the school yesterday.

title: Cuomo's Hard Line: Don't Let Budget Woes Recur
description: In taking a hard line against many of the Legislature's proposed revisions to his budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has decided to risk an uncompromising, and unpopular, insistence on harsh measures now in the hopes that he can avoid criticism later that he failed to solve the state's fiscal problems.

title: Containers Easy On the Ozone Layer
description: To the Editor:

title: National City Makes Bid for Ameritrust
description: The National City Corporation offered to acquire the rival Ameritrust Corporation yesterday in a stock deal worth about $860 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the third game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup final misidentified the Pittsburgh Penguins' goaltender in some copies. He is Tom Barrasso.

title: G.I.'s Scout a Kurdish City Beyond the Allied Zone
description: A small band of United States soldiers carrying automatic rifles walked the streets of this provincial capital today, putting allied troops deeper into northern Iraq than they have been since the start of rescue efforts for Kurdish refugees.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVE BARRY and CALVIN TRILLIN are to face off tomorrow night for the East Harlem Tutorial Program. GEORGE PLIMPTON is to be host of the benefit, an evening of readings, singing and cutting up at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue. Reading is to be done by the author JAMAICA KINCAID and the singing by ASHFORD AND SIMPSON.

title: Panel Finds Wide Abuse in Student Loan Program
description: The Federal student loan program is "plagued with fraud and abuse at every level," allowing shady trade school operators to prey on the poor and rob taxpayers of billions of dollars, a yearlong Senate investigation concluded today.

title: Innovative Portables From Zenith
description: ZENITH Data Systems, which at one time dominated the portable computer market, began its quest to regain a leadership role yesterday with the announcement of several new models that leapfrog the competition. Included in the announcements were the first battery-powered laptop computers to use the Intel Corporation's i486, i486SX and i386SL microprocessors and several innovative features.

title: A Casting Call for James Deans: Is It a Look or Is It an Essence?
description: The address was east of Seventh Avenue rather than east of Eden, but James Dean showed up anyway. In fact, about 200 James Deans made their way to the Actors Theater Workshop on West 28th Street yesterday to take part in a look-alike casting call for a new Off Broadway play, "James Dean/A Dress Rehearsal."

title: Thousands in Romania Join in Day of Protest
description: Tens of thousands of Romanians joined nationwide anti-Government demonstrations today.

title: Ward Seeks Consideration For Santucci Post in Queens
description: Benjamin Ward, the former New York City Police Commissioner, is seeking to become the Queens District Attorney and was interviewed for the post yesterday by aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, one of the aides said.

title: Bronx Homeowner, 60, Is Killed by Burglars
description: A Bronx homeowner was shot and killed yesterday afternoon when he surprised two burglars fleeing from a window into his backyard, the police said.

title: Yugoslavia Perplexed Over Status of Aid
description: Yugoslavia's Prime Minister said tonight that he had received implied assurances from President Bush that the United States would not cut off economic aid to his country because of human rights violations.

title: 3 Indian Masks To Stay In Auction
description: Three American Indian masks, two Hopi and one Navajo, are to remain in an auction this morning at Sotheby's despite protests from both tribes.

title: Station Loss Called Peril To America
description: The loss of the space station program, threatened by budget problems in Congress, would scuttle the United States manned space program and jeopardize relations with other nations investing in the project, the space agency's senior space flight official said today.

title: The Mayor's Deadline: How Absolute Is It?
description: Will New York City simply run out of cash to meet its payroll and pay its bills if a state budget is not adopted by Saturday?

title: LATE STOCK TRADES APPROVED BY S.E.C.
description: Taking the first big step toward round-the-clock trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a request to extend the exchange's hours beyond the 4 P.M. closing bell.

title: Former F.C.C. Chief Named Time Warner Unit's Head
description: Time Warner Inc. yesterday named Dennis R. Patrick, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to be chief executive of a newly created subsidary, Time Warner Telecommunications.

title: Stocks Slip in Tokyo
description: Stock prices in Japan declined slightly today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 41.82 points, or almost two-tenths of a precent, to 25,481.21.

title: Review/Dance; Magic Tricks and Music
description: James Sewell turned himself into a one-man choreographic Penn and Teller on Sunday night when he performed magic tricks as he danced in "Prestidigitations." He even managed to escape from a straitjacket while bounding to recorded ragtime by Scott Joplin.

title: Hostetler Looks Downfield And Spots Ally in Handley
description: They used to talk to each other about not getting the big break. Someone else always seemed to get the brass ring.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Alexander Kendrick, a retired CBS News correspondent, incorrectly described his wife, the former Sarah Kunitz, who died in 1981. A New York City resident, she met her husband while vacationing in the Soviet Union; she was not a Soviet citizen.

title: House Opens Debate on $291 Billion Pentagon Budget Bill
description: The House of Representatives began debate today on a $291 billion military budget bill for next year that is as much a captive of last year's budget agreement as it is largely unaffected by the Persian Gulf war experience.

title: Apple Computer to Reduce Staff 10%, Cutting 1,560 Jobs
description: Apple Computer Inc. confirmed today that it would reduce its work force by 10 percent, or about 1,560 people, as part of the company's efforts to reduce costs. Apple said the work force reduction, the fourth and largest in the company's history, would affect all job classifications worldwide, including contractors and temporary employees.

title: Fleet/Norstar Fills Massachusetts Post
description: Leo R. Breitman worked at the Bank of New England in its heydey and he was around for its demise. Now, at age 50, he is the most senior official to be offered a job by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, which acquired the Boston-based bank last month.

title: Lewis Hears Testimony
description: Two Houston police officers testified yesterday that CARL LEWIS, the track star who won a total of six gold medals in the Olympics of 1984 and 1988, appeared drunk after he drove his car over a curb at 2 A.M. on Jan. 11. Lewis was arrested for driving while intoxicated.

title: The F-22's Crucial Mission in the 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: 17-Month-Old Boy Is Killed In Apartment Fire in Queens
description: A 17-month-old boy was burned to death and his two brothers, who the police said may have been playing with matches, were injured in their Queens apartment yesterday while their mother was out picking up a fourth brother at a bus stop a block from the apartment.

title: Abdul-Jabbar on Tour
description: A little less than two years after he retired from the Los Angeles Lakers as the leading scorer in the history of the National Basketball Association, KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR will return to the basketball courts. Only this time the locale will be Saudi Arabia. The 7-foot-2-inch master of the sky hook left on Sunday for a seven-game exhibition tour sponsored by the Shamel Media Group.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Tommy Lasorda, the once-rotund manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, is expanding his presence in advertising for Ultra-Slim Fast. Mr. Lasorda, who has appeared in campaigns for the weight-loss powder, will start appearing today in a commercial for a new imitation ice cream product, Ultra-Slim Fast Frozen Delight. The commercial was created by Grey Advertising Inc., New York.

title: Liberated in Kuwait: Arrogance
description: Does wearing a T-shirt with Saddam Hussein's portrait warrant conviction as an Iraqi collaborator in liberated Kuwait? Evidently so. A martial law court sent the youth in the shirt to prison for 15 years, followed by deportation. What a deplorable beginning for an old regime reinstated in the name of world law.

title: Indian Treaty Accord in Wisconsin
description: After several years of ugly confrontations between whites and Indians in northern Wisconsin, state officials and the Chippewa Indians today announced an end to a 17-year legal battle over 19th-century treaty rights.

title: Supreme Ironies
description: To the Editor:

title: High Tech Hits City Hall With a Big Beep
description: With an electronic chirp, the 20th century arrived at switchboards in City Hall in New York yesterday, as telephone lines switched to digital technology.

title: Rubenstein Executive To Start an Agency
description: One of the stars of the Howard J. Rubenstein Associates public-relations agency is leaving to start his own company, and it is expected that some of his high-profile clients will follow him.

title: Justices Back Suits by Shareholders
description: The Supreme Court today refused to adopt a uniform Federal rule governing lawsuits by shareholders who contend that corporate management has mishandled a company's affairs.

title: Miss Stier Weds Andrew Newman
description: Elizabeth Ann Stier, a daughter of Barbara G. Stier of Roseland, N.J., and the late Leon M. Stier, was married yesterday to Andrew Frederick Newman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram R. Newman of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman and Cantor Theodore L. Aronson officiated at the Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Serbia, Croatia, Chaos
description: On Sunday, the Croatian Republic of Yugoslavia voted overwhelmingly to become a sovereign state. For weeks, the country has been embroiled in a constitutional crisis over the Serbs' refusal to accept Stipe Mesic, a Croatian, as the next Yugoslav President. There is continued talk, both here and abroad, about the danger of civil war.

title: British Steel Chief Quits
description: British Steel P.L.C. said in a statement today that its chief executive, Martin Llowarch, had decided to leave the company for personal reasons. Mr. Llowarch's resignation will be effective at the end of June, British Steel said. Mr. Llowarch, who has been with the company since 1968, will be succeeded on July 1 by Brian Moffat, British Steel's managing director of finance.

title: Patent Granted For Drug From Yew
description: A CHEMISTRY professor at Florida State University in Tallahassee has received a patent for a method of making a partly synthetic version of a promising cancer-fighting drug that is currently available only in small amounts from the bark of the rare Pacific yew. The newly patented process offers the possibility of making larger quantities of the drug, taxol, without killing the rare trees.

title: President's Thyroid: Questions Of Mood
description: Does an overactive thyroid gland affect mood and judgment? The question has been pertinent ever since President Bush was found to have Graves' disease, a disorder that causes the thyroid to produce excess hormone. Medical experts agree that thyroid disorders can affect mood, but on evidence made public so far, Mr. Bush had only a mild case.

title: Fare Wars Start Anew At Airlines
description: Domestic airlines cut their summer ticket prices today by as much as 20 percent, and said children could come along for half-price.

title: Music in Review
description: 'La Dafne' Mannes Camerata Mannes Concert Hall 150 West 85th Street Through tonight

title: In New York, Few Public Toilets and Many Rules
description: How long can it take New York City to install five streetside public toilet kiosks that a coalition of civic and advocacy groups effusively praises as an inexpensive solution to an acute toilet shortage?

title: Dr. J. B. Schmoker, 88, Executive in Education
description: Dr. John Benjamin Schmoker, a longtime official in international student exchange, died on Sunday at the Highland Farms nursing home in Black Mountain, N.C., where he lived. He was 88 years old.

title: Sentence in Burning of Desk
description: A 13-year-old boy who set fire to his teacher's desk to burn his report card was ordered today to make restitution and get psychiatric help. The boy or his family must pay $225, half the estimated $450 cost of the damage and the response by firefighters to Mayfield Elementary School. The youth, who had pleaded guilty to attempted aggravated arson, said he was "scared of what his report card said."

title: Boston Graduates Cautioned on 'Busyness'
description: Timothy S. Healy, the president of the New York Public Library, addressed 2,500 graduates at Boston College's 115th commencement yesterday and spoke about his dual role as a Jesuit priest and as head of one of the largest libraries in the world.

title: Music in Review
description: Ying Quartet Alice Tully Hall

title: Gas Leak at Ice Rink Kills One
description: A refrigerant gas leaked from an ice skating rink at a shopping mall today, killing one man and injuring at least 11 other people, the authorities said. William Temple, a 24-year-old assistant manager of the skating rink at the Dimond Mall, died while trying to trace the leak, officials said. The gas is heavier than air and can kill by suffocation.

title: Chyron Finds $5 Million Backer
description: The Chyron Corporation, a maker of digital electronic graphics equipment, said it had ended talks of its possible sale to Carlton Communications P.L.C. and had entered into a preliminary agreement with the Recovery Group L.P. on financing that would enable Chyron to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Under the agreement, Recovery Group would inject about $5 million into Chryon.

title: Knicks Near Offer to Riley
description: All signs indicate that the Knicks will offer Pat Riley their head coaching position by the end of this week.

title: Billion to Met, a Paint Job for the Mayor
description: Walter H. Annenberg came to New York City yesterday to be thanked by the Metropolitan Museum of Art for his gift of a collection of artworks valued at a billion dollars.

title: Nuweiba Journal; The Lost Secrets of Sinai Are Discovered. Again?
description: From the start, running the Taba Hilton was something of a challenge. When Neil Mathieson took over as general manager of the resort hotel almost two years ago, Israel had just been forced to hand the Taba enclave at Israel's southern tip back to Egypt after years of argument and negotiation.

title: Two Big California Utilities Plan to Cut CO   Emissions
description: The Southern California Edison Company and the municipal utility that serves Los Angeles said yesterday that they would cut their emissions of carbon dioxide, which is believed to cause climate change, by 20 percent in the next 20 years.

title: Square Deals Will Sell American Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of the Hive: A Soldier Squad Lurks Among the Honeybees
description: WHEN honeybees come under attack, they can repel invaders by calling upon a swarm of reserve forces, soldier bees, that no one suspected even existed, scientists say.

title: Shuttle's Next Mission: Better Health in Space
description: In the 30 years humans have been venturing into space, their wonder at soaring into the heavens has been tempered by the problems their earth-born bodies have in this alien environment.

title: Man Kills 5 With a Hammer
description: A man used a hammer on Saturday to kill his mother-in-law, wife and three children, then stabbed and injured himself with a knife, the authorities said Sunday. The couple's 5-month-old daughter was unharmed. The man, Paul E. Gamboa-Taylor, 30 years old, underwent surgery and was in serious condition. The dead were identified as Valerie L. Gamboa-Taylor, 23; her mother, Donna M. Barshinger, 42; her son, Lance Thomas Barshinger, 2; and two of the couple's children, Paul, 4; and Jasmine, 2.

title: Using Accreditation To Bring Athletics Closer to Academics
description: The battle for control over intercollegiate athletics has taken a significant turn with a proposal by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools to deny accreditation for colleges at which athletic programs fail to meet certain guidelines.

title: MCI Campaign to Show How Savings Add Up
description: The MCI Communications Corporation begins a campaign this week meant to show that a few pennies, multiplied often enough, can add up.

title: Police Weigh Motive in Killing on Highway
description: The police believe that a 20-year-old motorist who was shot and killed by a driver in another car early Sunday may have angered the gunman when he cut him off as they drove onto the West Side Highway.

title: NBC Announces Its Lineup for Fall
description: NBC, seeking to halt its two-season ratings slide, yesterday announced a new fall prime-time schedule that included nine new series and left only two nights intact.

title: Easier for the Boss
description: PROFESSIONAL Write Plus comes close to the elusive goal of being an executive word processor, a program simple enough that even the boss will use it.

title: No Stars but a Fine Chorus for Triple Crown
description: If you're wondering why everybody seems to be beating everybody else in the 3-year-old division of horse racing this year, D. Wayne Lukas will tell you why.

title: Kenneth W. Vaughn, Consultant, 80
description: Dr. Kenneth W. Vaughn, a management consultant and a specialist in educational testing, died on May 9 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Portland, Ore. He was 80 years old and lived in Albany, Ore.

title: Dallas Airport Bonds Are Priced
description: Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport is offering $118 million in revenue bonds intially priced to yield a maximum of 7.67 percent for an issue due in 2021 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Europe's Plan for Japan
description: The European Community introduced a trade promotion program today meant to increase the quantity of community products sold in Japan and to prevent worsening political relations with that country. The move, at a critical time in the community's relations with Japan, came as the European Commission president, Jacques Delors, is leaving on a mission to persuade Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, of the need to mend decades of trade friction.

title: LTV Puts Past Glory On Block
description: The LTV Corporation, which had long insisted it would not sell its once-renowned aircraft and military electronics operations, said today that it was putting those glamour assets on the block to help meet future pension obligations.

title: Poland's Constitution: Hale and Hardy at 200
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Barton Fink' Wins the Top Prize And 2 Others at Cannes Festival
description: Joel and Ethan Coen's "Barton Fink" was awarded the Palme d'Or as best film tonight at the closing ceremonies of the 44th Cannes International Film Festival.

title: Court Overturns Death Sentence, Saying Notice Was Lacking
description: The Supreme Court, ruling 5 to 4, overturned an Idaho death sentence today on the ground that the convicted murderer and his lawyer had not received "fair notice" that a sentence of death was anything more than a remote, theoretical possibility.

title: Amid Pressing Matters, Jordan Accepts M.V.P.
description: Michael Jordan, already recognized as one of the greatest basketball players ever, is no longer motivated by individual awards. So when the National Basketball Association honored Jordan today as the 1991 most valuable player in the league, he had mixed emotions.

title: To Preserve Their Health and Heritage, Arizona Indians Reclaim Ancient Foods
description: GOING back to one's roots could soon take on a more literal meaning for the Indians of the American Southwest, as well as for peoples elsewhere in the world who are poorly adapted to rich, refined foods.

title: Too Much Money Is Never Enough
description: If money truly makes the world go round, then major league baseball's little sphere within a sphere is really twirling on its axis these days.

title: Adopting Kafka's Mantle In His Own Hometown
description: Love and Garbage By Ivan Klima Translated by Ewald Osers. 224 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chrysler Plant Manager Is Hired From Mazda
description: The expansion of Japanese automobile makers in the United States has provided more job opportunities for American factory managers, but few have returned to the Big Three after making the jump.

title: Spotlight Is on Software at Show
description: With manufacturers of small computers continuing to report bad news this week, software publishers took the spotlight here as the personal computer industry convened for the spring version of the semiannual computer show, Comdex.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about taxol, a cancer-fighting drug, referred incorrectly in some copies to the university that was awarded a patent for a method of making a partly synthetic version. It was Florida State University, not the University of Florida.

title: A New Package for Opera From the Met
description: Public television is once again offering viewers a choice seat at the Metropolitan Opera with tonight's presentation of Verdi's "Masked Ball" ("Un Ballo in Maschera") on Channels 13 and 49 at 8 P.M. This broadcast, however, comes under the series heading of "Great Performances," not the usual "Metropolitan Opera Presents."

title: Court Approves Payment in Marcos Case
description: A Federal district judge on Monday approved a payment of $2 million by Imelda Marcos and the estate of her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, to the families of two foes of the Marcos regime who were assassinated in 1981.

title: Personal Health
description: EVEN under the best of circumstances, injuries and operations are not readily forgotten. When they leave behind a scar that is disfiguring or that limits mobility, the legacy can be emotionally scarring as well.

title: Salamis to Fend Off Military Blandness
description: THERE is a branch of the military on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that helps soldiers temporarily escape the blandness of K rations. It is known as Katz's Delicatessen, headquarters for soldier's salami.

title: Philadelphia Water Bonds Are Offered
description: The Philadelphia Water and Sewer Authority negotiated the sale of $300 million in tax-exempt water revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: 4th Bass Donates $20 Million to Yale
description: Fortune may be full of fresh variety, but at Yale University it often comes with the same name: Bass.

title: An Overdue Exit in Ethiopia
description: Nothing befitted President Mengistu Haile Mariam's reign in Ethiopia better than his ending it yesterday. Though he claimed to be a modernizing Communist, his world was closer to that of Macbeth than Marx. For 14 years, he and his military cronies dominated their ancient nation by terror, conspiracy, corruption and massacre. For Ethiopia, the bitter fruit has been unremitting war, the forcible uprooting of peoples, catastrophic famine -- and supine dependence on Soviet bloc arms and Western humanitarian aid.

title: At the Indy 500, A Heady Mixture Of Garlic and Oil
description: THIS Sunday morning, 33 drivers and their racing teams at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway will be making final preparations for the 75th running of the Indianapolis 500, setting tire pressures, practicing pit stops and warming engine oil.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHIRLEY MacLAINE was the host at a celebration of her friend BELLA ABZUG'S 70th birthday last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, and some 600 friends and admirers joined in. A chorus line of GLORIA STEINEM, MARLO THOMAS, JOYCE DINKINS, ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN and DR. RUTH WESTHEIMER sang a special version of "How About You," with Bella-relevant lyrics written by the late Yip Harburg.

title: The Senate: Still for Sale?
description: "The time has come to rid this institution of the perception that the men and and women who serve in this body have a price tag on them," Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, told his Senate colleagues yesterday as he introduced a bill to stop senators from supplementing their public pay with outside fees.

title: Holders Approve Utilities' Merger
description: Shareholders of IE Industries and Iowa Southern Inc. voted to merge the utility companies through an exchange of stock valued at $670 million. The merger, which would create Iowa's second-largest utility holding company, is scheduled to take effect on July 1 but is still subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Ex-Official Says Blacks Still Hobbled by Bias
description: A black former Secretary of the Army told a Senate committee today that black people in America continued to suffer from negative stereotypes held by whites, on the job, in the Senate itself and elsewhere.

title: Health Crisis Said to Grip Iraq In Wake of War's Destruction
description: Public health in Iraq is rapidly deteriorating under the strain of postwar epidemics, power disruptions, shortages of doctors, nurses and medicines and the closing of many overloaded hospitals and clinics, according to a Harvard University medical team that conducted a survey in major cities this month.

title: Harvard's Hottest Tickets
description: Need an extra ticket to Harvard's commencement? What's it worth?

title: CHRONICLE
description: He is what he is, and when JERRY HERMAN sat down to play a medley of his songs yesterday, 600 of Le Tout Broadway heard why the New Dramatists group had bestowed its Lifetime Achievement Award on him. His hits from "La Cage aux Folles," "Hello, Dolly!" and "Mame" evoked a roller coaster of sentiment from sadness to defiance to triumph from a time when sentimentality was more in fashion on Broadway.

title: Where the Streets Are Mean and People Are Even Meaner
description: Matty Rich's "Straight Out of Brooklyn" portrays the downfall of a black working-class family from the Red Hook section of Brooklyn in a style that used to be called kitchen-sink realism. At times gawky and plodding, the film, which represents the producing, directing and screen writing debut of the 19-year-old Mr. Rich, also has an affecting earnestness as it explores the social and economic pressures that drive the Browns, a family of four, to self-destruct.

title: Trial Date in Letelier Case
description: A Federal district judge today set a trial date of Sept. 3 for the Cuban-American arrested last month in the 1976 assassination of former Ambassador Orlando Letelier of Chile. The judge, Aubrey Robinson, set the date during a brief status hearing in the case of Virgilio Pablo Paz Romero, who is charged with detonating the bomb that killed Mr. Letelier and an American aide, Ronnie Moffitt, as they rode in a car in Washington.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FNN Merges With a Rival And Signs Off After 10 Years
description: Surrounded by inventory tags on their equipment, peppered by calls from well-wishers and in many cases laden with worries about future employment, the reporters and staff of the Financial News Network soldiered through their last day on the air yesterday.

title: U.S. Seeks to Avoid Gorbachev Talks
description: President Bush has decided that the idea of inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to a seven-nation summit meeting in London in July is "a non-starter" and is trying to scuttle the plan without embarrassing the Soviet leader, Administration officials said today.

title: Beer-Flinger Sent to a Fitting Cooler: Gay-Rights Office
description: "The punishment fits the crime" is the opinion of the prosecutor who handled the case and fashioned the sentence.

title: The Pop Life
description: Billboard's New Charts

title: These Psychiatrists Make House Calls For Trapped People
description: A RETIRED teacher became so depressed when illness left her weakened that she drew the blinds, stopped eating and refused to leave her apartment. Once proud and independent, she was headed for a nursing home. Though she needed therapy, she could not get to a therapist.

title: Dunlop Layoffs
description: The Dunlop Tire Corporation said that because of substantial losses, it would lay off workers at plants in Tonawanda, N.Y., and Huntsville, Ala. Randall L. Clark, the chairman, said that it had not been determined how many jobs would be cut but that it was likely that at least some passenger tire lines would be eliminated at the Tonawanda plant. Dunlop, which began sharp cost-cutting measures this year, employs about 3,000 at the two plants. The company is a unit of Sumitomo Rubber Industries of Japan.

title: McReynolds Lets Bat Do His Talking
description: In his first appearance at Shea Stadium since trading verbal swings with New York fans, Kevin McReynolds did a little less talking and a lot more hitting last night.

title: RIZZO SAYS HE WINS MAYORAL PRIMARY
description: Frank Rizzo, the former Mayor making a third comeback attempt, claimed victory today in a tight Republican primary, but his opponent refused to concede.

title: History Suggests Bush's Popularity Will Ebb
description: President Bush's high approval ratings, increased by the Persian Gulf war, are not likely to last for long, if the experiences of his nine immediate predecessors are a reliable guide, according to a new study by researchers at the Gallup Organization.

title: Jefferies Finally Rises to the Occasion for Mets
description: The box score was an unruly mess of hits, homers and errors, to say nothing of ejections. For Gregg Jefferies, it was a thing of beauty and he seemed prepared to submit it as Exhibit A for the case he made last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Business Tax Breaks Are Hurting Schools, Educators Complain
description: Many American companies in recent years have made a crusade of trying to rescue the nation's deteriorating public schools, casting themselves as white knights whose donations help the cause.

title: Competition Could Shut Pan Am
description: The Pan Am Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January, said in a document released today that strong competition could force it out of business as early as this year.

title: Many Readers, Few Ads for Bauer
description: As the recession in the magazine industry worsens, the battle to grab readers at supermarket checkout counters has intensified. And no company has been more aggressive at expanding its American operations than the German publisher of Woman's World and First for Women.

title: Cummins Lowers Dividend 50
description: The Cummins Engine Company, suffering under continued losses and a bleak outlook for North American heavy-duty truck sales, said today that it was sharply cutting its quarterly dividend from 55 cents a share, to 5 cents.

title: Restoration Comedy With the Modernist Touch
description: As David Greenspan's production of "The Way of the World" unfolds, almost everyone lights up a cigarette and puffs hard until the air is cloudy. (The artistic weather is already inclement.) Perhaps this is the director's way of indicating atmosphere or the harmful effects of tobacco, but, like so much else onstage, the smoking seems gratuitous.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: India's Third Test
description: Whoever killed Rajiv Gandhi yesterday struck at democracy itself, just as his mother's assassins did seven years ago. But democracy survived then, and there is reason to hope it will respond sturdily now.

title: Crime in New York Declined in January In Major Categories
description: The number of major crimes reported to the New York City police declined in January, the first time since 1983 that the city has had an across-the-board drop in a single month, police officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Starting today, the Health page appears on Wednesdays, in The Living Section.

title: Postnuptial Disagreements, on '48 Hours'
description: How do he and she annoy each other? "48 Hours" counts the ways. Some of the situations reported tonight in "For Better, for Worse," a two-hour special about marriage and divorce American style, are sad. But the program (at 9 on CBS), which seems like the fruit of a marriage of real-life soap opera and "Saturday Night Live," produces more laughs than tears.

title: A Constant for Giants: No L.T. at Mini-Camp
description: Ray Handley was working in two worlds today: keeping alive Giants tradition, which produced a Super Bowl victory only four months ago, and at the same time trying to lead the team into a new era.

title: Ethiopian Ruled Ruthlessly, Killing Colleagues and Shedding Alliances
description: Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, a middle-ranking officer when he wrested sole control of Ethiopia 14 years ago, ruled with a ruthlessness that sapped Ethiopia of many desperately needed resources, intensified a civil war and added the fear of Government repression to the daily troubles of its people.

title: Virginia R. Forrest; Conservationist, 94
description: Virginia R. Forrest, a volunteer who in 1961 became the first woman to win the Florida Governor's Award for Conservation, died Sunday at Pennswood Village in Newtown, Pa. She was 94 years old and also lived in Stuart, Fla.

title: Caterpillar Sees Bleaker Outlook
description: Caterpillar Inc. warned investors that it could lose money for a second consecutive quarter because the weak world economy had depressed sales. The maker of construction equipment lost $32 million in the first quarter, and it has revised its earnings outlook downward twice in two months.

title: Book Notes
description: 2 Volumes at $1.35 a Page

title: Dispute Intensifies Over Job On Accounting-Rules Panel
description: A controversy that has erupted over filling an open slot on the chief rule-making body for accounting issues has stirred passions rarely seen in the accounting world. It has also underscored the jockeying that frequently goes on behind the scenes between the companies that prepare financial statements and the analysts and investors who rely on those statements.

title: Robert A. Herfort; Surgeon, 72
description: Dr. Robert A. Herfort, a surgeon who practiced in White Plains for 35 years, died on Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Bangor, Me. He was 72 years old and lived in West Penobscot, Me.

title: Eximbank Helps U.S. Exporters Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Problems Delay Launching of Space Shuttle
description: Three unrelated technical problems forced the space agency today to postpone for 10 days a space shuttle biomedical research mission involving 7 astronauts, 30 rats and 2,400 jellyfish.

title: Rajiv Gandhi and the Politics of Fear
description: This is not the India I grew up in.

title: Ban on Quotas Spurs Rights Debate
description: Republicans and Democrats fought today to control the political high ground of being against the use of quotas in employment, the biggest emotional issue in this year's civil rights bill.

title: RAJIV GANDHI IS ASSASSINATED IN BOMBING AT CAMPAIGN STOP; INDIA PUTS OFF REST OF VOTING
description: Rajiv Gandhi, a former Prime Minister hoping to return to power in elections this week, was assassinated in a powerful explosion as he walked toward an election rally platform on Tuesday night in a small town southwest of Madras.

title: Du Pont Oil Unit In Soviet Venture
description: Conoco Inc., the oil company owned by the Du Pont Company, has signed an agreement to develop two Soviet oil and gas deposits in the Arctic Ocean near the city of Arkhangelsk, the Soviet news agency Tass said. It did not identify the Soviet partners.

title: Alexander's Chooses A New President
description: Alexander's Inc., the New York department-store chain whose stock has been the subject of recent speculation, named Stephen A. Goldberger its president yesterday. He is the former chairman of Hills Department Stores Inc., a discounter based in Canton, Mass., now in voluntary bankruptcy.

title: Yield at 8.312% on Offering By MBNA Credit Card Trust
description: MBNA Credit Card Trust 1991-A, a unit of the MBNA Corporation, is offering $750 million in securities backed by Visa and Mastercard receivables through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities.

title: Ethiopia's Dictator Flees; Officials Seeking U.S. Help
description: Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, who ruled Ethiopia with an iron hand for 14 years, resigned today and fled the country. Officials of his Government then called on the United States to try to arrange a settlement with Ethiopian rebels who were reported advancing on the capital.

title: Attention-Deficit Disorder Affects Adults Too; Dangers of Ritalin
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama in Review
description: Yokohama Duty SoHo Rep 46 Walker Street, between Church and Broadway Through June 9 Written by Quincy Long; directed by Julian Webber; set design, Stephan Olson; costumes, Patricia Sarnataro; lighting, Donald Holder; stage manager, Monty Hicks. Presented by SoHo Rep, Marlene Swartz and Julian Webber, artistic directors. WITH: Nesbitt Blaisdell, Michael Cullen, Susanna Frazer, Bruce Katzman, Cheri Nakamura, Brett Rickaby, Preston Keith Smith and Peter Yoshida.

title: U.S. Ship Attacked In the Persian Gulf; There's No Damage
description: An American warship came under fire from two small boats in the central Persian Gulf today and chased them off with machine-gun fire, the Defense Department reported.

title: Drama in Review
description: East An Elegy for the East End La Mama E.T.C. 74A East Fourth Street Manhattan Through June 2 Written by Steven Berkoff; directed by Paul Hellyer; technical director, Chris Brophy; lighting and set design, Jeff Rowlings. Presented by La Mama E.T.C. WITH: Paul Finnocchiaro, Stephanie Hunt, Delia MacDougall, Dennis Matthews and Joel Mullennix.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Treasury Bond Prices Increase
description: Treasury bond prices moved higher and long-term interest rates fell a bit yesterday, as investors seeking higher yields purchased long-term securities. Shorter-term note prices, by contrast, posted more modest gains.

title: Suit Is Settled By Paramount
description: Paramount Communications Inc. said today that it had settled a wrongful-termination suit brought by Frank G. Mancuso, the former chairman of Paramount Pictures.

title: Greg Rice, a Champion Runner Of the Early 1940's, Dies at 75
description: Greg Rice, an almost unbeatable distance runner of half a century ago who won the 1940 Sullivan Award, died Sunday at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in River Edge, N.J.

title: Deere Net Down 49.2%
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of tractors and farm machinery, said today that second-quarter earnings dropped 49.2 percent because of reduced demand.

title: Lawmakers Humble in Pleading for Military Bases
description: As Congressional drama goes, the scene was remarkable. Some members of the House and Senate lunged forward as they spoke, others raised their voices, and a few flat out begged. If military bases must be closed, they said, spare me.

title: 5,000 at Penn Hear Koppel On Learning
description: Ted Koppel, anchor for ABC's "Nightline," told 5,000 graduates at the University of Pennsylvania yesterday that "the classroom is not a place for indoctrination."

title: Accounts
description: * Spanish Tourism Ministry, Iberia Airlines and American Express Co. to Ogilvy & Mather, New York, for a marketing campaign to promote tourism to Spain. American Express said the three-year campaign had a $10 million budget. * Marriott Ownership Resorts, Lakeland, Fla., a division of Marriott Corp., to Bozell Inc., New York, for strategic planning, advertising, direct mail and sales promotion. Billings are estimated at $4 million.

title: F-22 = $95 Billion = ?
description: Whether to buy 650 new fighter aircraft for $95 billion is the mother of all Pentagon decisions, the biggest and perhaps the most direction-setting military contract in recent history.

title: Kuwaitis Continue Trials, Accusing 22 of Aiding Iraq
description: Amid a wave of international criticism over the conduct of an earlier trial, Kuwait brought 22 people to court today on charges of collaborating with Iraqi invaders during the seven-month occupation of this country.

title: Two Homers by Bonds Lift Pirates
description: Barry Bonds, who didn't have an extra-base hit in 59 times at bat at home this season, hit home runs on successive pitches in his first two times at bat tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-3.

title: Control Data
description: An Ottawa-based subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation signed a contract with the Canadian Defense Department worth more than $1 billion, Control Data said. Under the contract, the Computing Devices Company will develop and make a new voice and data communications system for the Canadian military.

title: Hartford Plan Would Raise New Funds The Old Way
description: Legislators leading the charge against Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s income tax plan released a package today to resolve the state's fiscal crisis through expanded sales and business taxes, deeper cuts in spending and a system of spending limits written into the State Constitution.

title: A New Chairman For Lintas on Aug. 1
description: Lintas Worldwide, the second-largest advertising agency network under the banner of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will get a new chairman and chief executive effective Aug. 1.

title: New York Has One True Barbecue And Here Are All Eight of Them
description: FOR those who live by barbecue, Kansas City brisket and "burnt ends" sound one siren's call, the ribs and shredded pork of Memphis another. From the pits of Greensboro, N.C., vinegar-basted pork issues a hickory-scented invitation. Lubbock, Tex., where the fuel is mesquite or oak and the meat is brisket of beef, has an allure of a different aroma.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 1.8% on Big Board
description: The latest short-interest figure is equivalent to seven-tenths of 1 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board. Amex Reports Slight Rise

title: Nicholas Dante, 49; Dancer and a Writer Of 'A Chorus Line'
description: Nicholas Dante, who won a Pulitzer Prize and a Tony Award as a co-author of "A Chorus Line," the longest-running show in Broadway history, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 4 Ex-Officials of East Germany Arrested
description: Four of the most senior leaders of former East Germany, including the Prime Minister, were arrested today as part of a drive to find and bring to justice the officials responsible for ordering border guards to shoot to kill people fleeing to the West, prosecutors said.

title: Upjohn Venture
description: The Upjohn Company and Solvay et Cie, the Belgian plastics and chemicals maker, have agreed on a joint marketing alliance for their anti-depressant and anti-anxiety drugs. The venture will focus on markets in Europe and the United States, with potential sales of $7.2 billion by 2000.

title: Eastern Liquidation May Leave Smaller Pie for Creditors
description: Creditors, retirees and others with claims against Eastern Airlines may end up dividing a much smaller amount than anticipated from the airline's bankruptcy liquidation.

title: A Step to Restore Bout
description: A request by promoter MURAD MUHAMMAD for a hearing before the Nevada Athletic Commission could lead to the restoration of a canceled rematch bout between MIKE TYSON and DONOVAN (RAZOR) RUDDOCK that was scheduled for June 28.

title: Across Lawns, the Buzz Is About a Shelter
description: Just off a winding road in the Westchester countryside here rises a shingled structure whose bright white trim and flapping flags evoke a yacht club. Some motorists who don't know any better stop in to ask about the new condominiums.

title: Trail Blazers Get Even With Lakers
description: Terry Porter scored 26 points, including a crucial 20-footer with 1 minute 39 seconds to play, as the Portland Trail Blazers evened the Western Conference finals at one game each by beating the Los Angeles Lakers, 109-98, tonight.

title: New Processor From Matsushita
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said it had developed a high-speed microprocessor for parallel processing computers that can carry out two instructions at once.

title: Murdoch Fills Post in U.S.
description: Leslie Hinton, a former associate editor of The Boston Herald, has been chosen to head the American publishing arm of Rupert Murdoch's media holdings.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq's Health Crisis

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Former Rep. Joseph Maraziti, 78, Defender of Nixon on Watergate
description: Joseph J. Maraziti, a former United States Representative who gained national recognition as a staunch defender of President Richard M. Nixon during the Watergate investigation in Congress, died on Monday at St. Clare's-Riverside Hospital in Boonton, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Boonton.

title: Indy Cars Safest Ever, in Theory That Is
description: By now, the images on nightly television reports from the Indianapolis Motor Speedway each May are almost cliches: driver loses control, car hits wall and flies apart, driver lives to drive again.

title: Adoptive Father of 19 Accused of Sex Abuse
description: A 51-year-old man who the police said had adopted 19 hard-to-place children was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing his 14-year-old adopted daughter.

title: After Decades of a Classless Society, A New Respect for Polish Bluebloods
description: Andrzej Panasiuk manufactures class distinctions. In his cramped shop just off this city's picturesque Old Town, he cranks out signet rings bearing family coats of arms. For Poles whose blood is less than the purest blue, the obliging Mr. Panasiuk will let them pick a family totem from a dusty, leather-bound book.

title: Bridge
description: Many players would be delighted to be able to enter a team event and recruit a famous player to strengthen their line-up. At 1:30 P.M. next Tuesday, as a tailpiece to the Eastern States Regional Championship at the Vista International Hotel in the World Trade Center, there will be a Charity Pro-Am Swiss Teams, a novel concept.

title: Yields 5% to 6.75% On Illinois Bonds
description: A sale of $125 million of general obligation bonds by Illinois yesterday highlighted the competitive calendar, since it is one of the few states whose debt is still rated triple-A.

title: Everett Smith, 98, Dies; Headed Bible Society
description: Everett Smith, who monitored thrift institutions for the Federal Home Loan Bank and who was a former president of the American Bible Society, died on Saturday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 98 years old and had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., for many years before moving to Santa Barbara in the 1960's.

title: South Korea's Premier Quits Amid Protests
description: South Korea's Prime Minister quit today to take political pressure off President Roh Tae Woo, whose Government has been shaken by four weeks of protests set off by the beating death of a student.

title: Trojans Beat Bulldogs for Title
description: Southern California, already the team Georgia tennis fans most love to hate, raised the ire to a higher level today by beating the Bulldogs, 5-2, in the finals of the team portion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships.

title: Senate Passes Ban on Fees But May Not Have to Keep It
description: The Senate voted by a wide margin today to join the House of Representatives and the executive branch in barring the speaking fees with which many of its members supplement their incomes.

title: Sports of The Times; Handley's X Factor As Coach
description: DURING the group drills at the start of his first practice in his first mini-camp as the Giants' head coach, Ray Handley, in a blue cap, red shirt and blue shorts, was tossing the ball to the running backs. As he had for seven seasons as an assistant coach. As if nothing had changed.

title: Judge May Move Officers' Trial After Disclosure
description: The publication today of confidential information on the police beating of a motorist may force a judge to move the trial of four officers out of Los Angeles.

title: Hand Washing Called Vital in Day Care
description: DAY-CARE centers should adopt strict hand-washing policies and be much more vigilant in disinfecting surfaces to prevent the spread of bacteria that cause diarrhea, a new study suggests.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: QUAIL, once an exotic bird rarely available commercially, has become as commonplace as duck. Fresh or frozen quail is available in supermarkets and specialty food shops all the time now, and cookbooks routinely give recipes for its preparation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Justice CHARLES L. WELTNER of the Georgia State Supreme Court is to receive the second annual Profiles in Courage award next week from the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation in Boston. The 63-year-old justice was selected for his lifelong efforts in fighting racial segregation. One of his most dramatic acts was his decision to give up a nomination for a third term in Congress in 1966 rather than support LESTER MADDOX, a fellow Democrat who was running for governor on a platform supporting segregation.

title: 3 Statehouses Struggle With the Budget Mess
description: In the state capitals of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, lawmakers wrestled with their budgets. In Connecticut, opponents of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. proposed huge increases in the sales and business taxes. New Jersey learned that it faces an additional shortfall of $768 million for the next fiscal year. Still without a budget, legislative leaders in New York decided to restore hundreds of millions of dollars in school aid.

title: Knicks Pick a Favorite and Plan an Offer
description: Knicks president Dave Checketts said yesterday that he had made a decision on the team's new head coach, and that he expected to make him a contract offer by the end of the week and to announce the name of coach next week.

title: Those Kind and Considerate New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Sides Are Sharply Divided on Transportation Bill
description: As a Senate committee drafts legislation establishing $105 billion in highway and mass transit programs over the next five years, the Bush Administration and the committee's leaders are negotiating over gaping differences about how to spend the money and no grand compromise appears near.

title: Scandal Over Cheating At M.I.T. Stirs Debate On Limits of Teamwork
description: The largest cheating scandal in the history of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has touched off a campuswide debate over how far collaborative work on scientific projects can go before it crosses the line into cheating.

title: Suspensions Issued
description: Because they used an engine that violated Winston Cup rules, the owner, crew chief and driver of a Budweiser-sponsored Ford must sit out the next 12 weeks of the Nascar season. In addition, the driver, TOMMY ELLIS, was fined $18,000 and the owner, JUNIOR JOHNSON, was fined $7,000. TIM BREWER, the crew chief, was not fined.

title: In the Nation; High Noon, Low Hype
description: The 1960 Presidential campaign between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon was the first in which the candidates debated each other and the last in which more than 60 percent of eligible Americans bothered to vote.

title: Bush Calls Assassination 'Appalling' and a Loss for World Order
description: President Bush today called the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, the former Indian Prime Minister, "appalling" and said he mourned the loss of a friend and world leader.

title: Pennzoil Fighting Chevron Appeal
description: The Pennzoil Company moved for the dismissal of a court appeal by the Chevron Corporation that accuses Pennzoil of acting illegally in buying $2.1 billion of Chevron stock.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What else can I do?" -- Rajiv Gandhi, moments before his assassination, on the risks of plunging into campaign crowds. [ A1:3. ]

title: North Koreans Extend Talks With Japanese For a 3d Day
description: North Korea today apparently softened its hard-line stand toward normalizing relations with Japan and agreed to extend for a third day talks on issues blocking agreement.

title: Who's in Charge Here? Chances Are It's a Woman
description: The Prime Minister of Norway is a woman, and half her Cabinet are women. So are the leaders of two of the main opposition political parties. So are the two candidates running next fall for Mayor of Oslo. And so are 59 of the 165 members of the Norwegian Parliament.

title: Will Steinbrenner Oust Nederlander?
description: George Steinbrenner can no longer fire Yankee managers, but is he planning to engineer the dismissal of Robert Nederlander as the club's managing partner?

title: Yanks, in a Tailspin, Erase an Early Lead On Error by Rookie
description: The rookie had a rough night.

title: Day 2 of Queen's Texas Tour Includes Alamo and 3 Cities
description: Queen Elizabeth II continued her three-day sweep of Texas today, flying from Austin to San Antonio, taking a brief tour of the Alamo, then flying on to Dallas.

title: Parliament in Prague Votes To Return Some Farmland
description: Czechoslovakia's Parliament voted today to return to its owners farmland that had been seized by the former Communist Government, but delayed action on agricultural cooperatives. The measure potentially affects 3.3 million original owners or their heirs.

title: Food Notes
description: Vidalia Problems

title: 2 Young Actresses And Their 'Good Times'
description: They're both at the age where they dot their i's with circles, talk on the phone too much and want to grow up to be Julia Roberts. They describe everyone they meet as "really nice" and everything that happens as "really fun." And maybe it really is. There's plenty of time later to find out otherwise.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former Mayor JOHN V. LINDSAY is leaving the sinking legal ship of Webster & Sheffield to join the law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon, effective June 1. He will be of counsel to Mudge Rose, meaning that he will be affiliated with it, but not a partner. He will work part time at the firm, whose headquarters are in Manhattan. Webster & Sheffield announced last week that it was going out of business.

title: Cable-Sports Merger Talk
description: Two regional sports cable networks, one owned by Tele-Communications Inc., the other by the General Electric Company and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, have resumed discussion of a possible merger, a company spokesman for one of the networks said today. Executives with the networks have reportedly met periodically over the last few years to discuss a possible merger.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its subsidiary Seattle-First National Bank had agreed to acquire up to 19 Olympic Savings Bank branch offices in western Washington. * Chevron Corp., San Francisco, said its California Asiatic Ltd. subsidiary had sold all shares of Chevron Oil Co. of Spain to Cimaz S.A., a Spanish investment company.

title: Intel Expects Higher Net
description: The Intel Corporation said today that its earnings for the current quarter are likely to exceed Wall Street estimates. Company officials also said that revenues in the quarter, which ends in June, are expected to be at least 10 percent greater than the $1.13 billion recorded in the first quarter.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: Bill to Allot Airwaves Advances
description: A House committee voted unanimously today to turn over a large segment of the radio spectrum, previously reserved for the Government, to commercial uses.

title: House Panel Starts Work On Bank Bill
description: A Congressional panel sent a clear signal today in the opening debate on the heart of the Bush Administration's proposal to cure the banking system that lawmakers may expand the powers of banks by permitting the institutions to enter new businesses.

title: Rootless but Ruling for Unity, the Dynasty That Was Modern India Is Gone
description: Their styles and their agendas were each different, ranging from the visionary nation-building of Nehru to the more narrowly opportunistic political maneuvering practiced by Indira and Rajiv. But they all shared a kind of cosmopolitan rootlessness, very rare among Indian politicians, that reinforced an ideological commitment to secularism and strong central government.

title: Tokyo Agrees to Pay Off Shortfall in Gulf War Aid
description: In the midst of a week of tough trade negotiations, Japanese officials said today that they had decided to defuse one simmering dispute with the United States by agreeing to pay about $500 million in assistance to the Persian Gulf to make up for a shortfall in Japan's previously announced $9 billion contribution.

title:
Real Estate;
Commercial Units to Be Auctioned
description: FOLLOWING the New York City residential developers who plunged into the uncharted waters of auctions this spring, the owners of a commercial condominium in Manhattan will put their stubbornly unsold units under the gavel next month.

title: Wine Talk
description: MY last vintage chart was published in April 1989. Like its predecessors over the years, its purpose was to serve as an imprecise but helpful guide through the labyrinthine ways of the wine market. It was, as usual, two years behind. That is to say, it reported on vintages no younger than 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Friday's stock trading misstated the reason for the price decline of Royal Dutch. It reflected a dividend that will be paid only to those who held Royal Dutch shares before Friday.

title: Better Identity For Nutrasweet
description: A new campaign gives a little red gum ball a big job: recasting the image of Nutrasweet.

title: Noach Dear: Master of Overlapping Interests
description: In 1983, members of one of New York City's smallest minority groups -- Tamils from Sri Lanka -- set out to call attention to what they believed were human-rights abuses in their homeland.

title: Buyer Vows to Return 3 Masks to Indians
description: Three American Indian masks, two Hopi and one probably Navajo, that were auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's despite protests by both tribes, were bought by a New York woman who said in an interview later that she would return them to the Indians.

title: A Blast, and Then the Wailing Started
description: On the way to the rally 25 miles southwest of Madras, Rajiv Gandhi had been riding in the front seat, window open. A special fluorescent light mounted on the dashboard of the small Indian-made Ambassador car played on his face so that people could see him in the evening darkness.

title: Economic Scene; Advice to Patriots: Save, Don't Spend
description: SUPPOSE there were Americans so patriotic as to decide to ignore their own material well-being and to deploy their money with the sole aim of benefiting the national economy.

title: Syria, in Lebanon, Extends Own Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention-Deficit Disorder Affects Adults Too
description: To the Editor

title: How Iraqi Dinar Gains Travel Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide Resigns in Dispute About Vietnam's M.I.A.'s
description: The head of a Pentagon intelligence unit assigned to account for United States servicemen missing in Vietnam has resigned, accusing Bush Administration officials of seeking to discredit and perhaps even cover up reports of sightings of Americans in the country.

title: About New York
description: Linda M. is what many people call a "strong sister." In her case it means that she survived childhood rape by her brother and years of beatings by her husband when she could not find a hiding place.

title:
VOICE OF THE NEW GENERATION;
I'm Not Going to Harvard
description: About a month ago, the mailman arrived, lugging a large package from Harvard. Here at last was the reward for all the 30-page admissions forms, the soul-searching essays, the interviews with snotty Ivy League lawyers, the $50 application fees. I opened the package and learned I had been accepted as a "Harvard Scholar."

title: Record Net At Matsushita
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that earnings in the year ended March 31 rose 10 percent from the previous year, to a record 258.91 billion yen, or $1.88 billion.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Stage, and Off" column in Weekend on May 10 misidentified the writer of the book for "Shogun: The Musical." He was John Driver; James Clavell wrote the novel on which the musical is based.

title: Michigan Stadium To Use Real Grass
description: Real grass is coming back to Michigan's football stadium, where artificial turf was used from 1969 through last season. Officials marked the return of natural grass by rolling out a 10-foot-long section of sod in the south end zone on Monday.

title: Drama in Review
