description: Fridays Riverside Shakespeare Company at Playhouse 91 316 East 91st Street Manhattan Through June 23 Written by Andrew Johns; directed by Gus Kaikkonen; set by Bob Barnett; costumes by Steven F. Graver; lighting by Stephen J. Backo; production stage manager, Matthew G. Marholin. Presented by Riverside Shakespeare Company. WITH: Kent Adams, Henderson Forsythe, David Edward Jones, Stephanie Madden, John Peakes and Alice White.

title: Imagine Taking It Easy In a Stackable Chair
description: For years, stackable chairs have been awkward compromises between convenience and comfort, often more suitable for stacking than sitting. But now, new technology allows sitters to recline comfortably.

title: Thai Stance On Piracy
description: Thailand's interim Prime Minister, Anand Panyarachun, has told business leaders that they might have to accommodate an American demand for reducing piracy of American copyrights and drugs patents.

title: CNBC Plays On Theme Of Merger
description: ONE of the most eagerly watched recent business mergers involved two companies that usually cover mergers, rather than participate in them. Now, the results of that transaction are the subject of an ambitious new advertising campaign aimed at three target audiences simultaneously.

title: Bulls Seize 2-to-0 Series Lead As Jordan Tallies 27 in 2d Half
description: The Detroit Pistons are used to frustrating other teams with their defense. Now the Chicago Bulls are doing it to them.

title: Connecticut Sells $200 Million Issue
description: Connecticut sold a $200 million tax-exempt issue of special tax bonds yesterday initially priced to yield a maximum of 6.904 percent for a security due in 2011. The pricing of the bonds was done through negotiation with underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: British Airways Posts Loss
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it had a net loss of $:146 million, or $254 million, for its fiscal fourth quarter. The company attributed the loss to the recession and the Persian Gulf war, as well as an extraordinary charge against earnings.

title: Bush Is Often Tired, but Doctors Say He Is Progressing
description: President Bush said he got a clean bill of health from his doctors today, nearly two weeks after he began treatment for Graves' disease, an auto-immune disorder that makes the thyroid produce too much hormone.

title: Dow Gains 13.86 Points, To 2,906.08
description: Stock prices moved a bit higher yesterday in brisk trading as investors came back into the market in force. Drug, retailing, high-technology and some bank stocks were particularly strong.

title: An Industry Magazine Prepares for the Heat
description: Last summer, when the average temperature in the United States dropped a few degrees from the summer of 1989, advertising in The Air Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration News declined about 5 percent.

title: Amid Pact Dispute, Zimmer Let Go as Manager of Cubs
description: At odds with Don Zimmer over a contract extension and claiming publicly that there had been insufficient returns on the field from their high-priced and highly regarded talent, the Chicago Cubs yesterday dismissed Zimmer as manager.

title: Bush Tells Belgrade That U.S. May Consider Restoring Aid
description: President Bush has informed the Government of Yugoslavia that he would consider lifting suspension of all United States economic assistance to that country, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Harold O. Toor, 92, A Former Chairman Of U.S. Shoe Corp.
description: Harold O. Toor, former chairman of the United States Shoe Corporation, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: Israel Opens New Golan Heights Settlement
description: The Government opened a new Jewish settlement in the Golan Heights today with as much fanfare as Housing Minister Ariel Sharon could muster.

title: Royals Extend Brett At $7.7 Million, 2 Years
description: GEORGE BRETT, the only player ever to win batting titles in three decades, signed a new contract yesterday with the Kansas City Royals worth more than $7 million over the next two years.

title: With Liberals Again, Reaching Out to West
description: After a bitter winter of estrangement from his comrades in reform, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has signaled a readiness to come in from the cold.

title: Connecticut Light
description: The Connecticut Light and Power Company said it planed to cut as much as $20 million off its $228 million rate-increase request now before state regulators. Company officials, citing success in cost management, said they would submit a revised request to the Public Utility Control Department by the end of the month. The utility, based in Berlin, Conn., had applied for a $228 million, 11.5 percent rate increase in December, citing low sales growth and increasing costs.

title: Sony Unit to Build Factory in Britain
description: A Sony Corportion subsidiary will build a $254 million television factory in Britain that will become the Japanese company's technology research center for Europe. The Sony Manufacturing Company U.K. said the plant in Pencoed, Wales, would have 1,400 employees and make color televisions and computer display monitors as well as house the research and development center.

title: U.N. Chernobyl Study Calls Reports Inflated
description: Hundreds of thousands of Soviet citizens suffer stress and anxiety because of the Chernobyl nuclear accident, but there is no evidence of widespread leukemia or thyroid illnesses, according to a study published today.

title: Market Place; Precedents in Rules for Extended Trading
description: In offering two radically different after-hours trading sessions, the New York Stock Exchange is seeking to lure traders back by compromising in two key areas -- public disclosure of trading and the cost to the brokers.

title: Ryan on Disabled List
description: Because of continuing problems with his right shoulder, NOLAN RYAN was put on the 15-day disabled list by the Texas Rangers yesterday. He is scheduled to undergo treatment on the shoulder with medication, exercise and rest. This is the 11th time in his career that Ryan has been on the disabled list, two times with Texas.

title: Japan Fumes at Reliance on West
description: Through the 1980's Japan built what is widely regarded as one of the most technologically sophisticated television systems. Largely forgoing cable networks, it sent aloft satellites that beam programs directly to millions of Japanese households equipped with receiving dishes no larger than pizza pans.

title: A Councilman In Manhattan Is Investigated
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday began a tax investigation of a City Councilman and a special fund that was set up to subsidize his official duties but that paid some of his personal expenses as well.

title: Eating Well
description: "EAT all you want and lose weight."

title: Corrections
description: A headline Friday about a Federal report on pollution misidentified one of the two states leading the nation in the amount of toxic chemicals released into the environment by manufacturers in 1989. The states were Texas and Louisiana, not Texas and California.

title: House, as Expected, Rejects Bush Military Spending Plan
description: The House of Representatives, as expected, today rejected President Bush's $291 billion military spending plan for the 1992 fiscal year, continuing instead to embrace an alternative blueprint drawn up by the House Armed Services Committee.

title: NBC Moves Johnny Carson Starting Time by 5 Minutes
description: NBC has decided to change the starting time of "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson," after three decades as the leading late-night television program,

title: Ameritrust Plans To Consider Bid
description: The Ameritrust Corporation said it would evaluate a merger offer from the National City Corporation as one of several alternatives, which also include remaining independent. On Monday, National City offered a stock transaction for Ameritrust worth $870 million, or about $23 a share. A union of the two Cleveland-based companies would create the nation's 17th-largest banking concern.

title: Hazel Brill Jackson, A Sculptor Known For Animal Statues
description: Hazel Brill Jackson, a prize-winning sculptor whose bronzes won critical praise, died on Friday at her home in the Town of Newburgh, N.Y. Miss Jackson, who remained active in her art well past her 90th birthday, was 96 years old.

title: ABC Is Canceling 'Thirtysomething'
description: ABC announced yesterday that it would cancel its long-running award-winning drama "Thirtysomething" and add eight new shows to its fall lineup.

title: California Opens Bidding For Troubled Executive Life
description: California regulators opened bidding today on the Executive Life Insurance Company by proposing some of the terms under which the state wants the fallen insurer to be acquired. Under the plan, Executive Life would be split into two new companies and the value of policies would be cut to reflect the current company's distressed condition.

title: A Hero Won't Return
description: YANNICK NOAH, a local hero in France and the 1983 champion, has pulled out of the French Open, saying he is not fit enough to play five sets a match in the two-week Grand Slam event, which starts in Paris next Monday. Noah, ranked 116th in the world, was expected to ask the organizers for a wild card to enter the tournament. He has played every French Open since 1977. (Reuters)

title: Suspected Nazi Guard Loses U.S. Citizenship
description: A Federal district judge here has revoked the citizenship of a man who is believed to have worked as a guard at a Nazi concentration camp.

title: Key Rates
Computer Makers Worried By Software Export Curbs
description: Export restrictions on software that transfers data among computers have been tightened in the wake of the Persian Gulf war because United States military and intelligence officials were dismayed by the difficulty the allies had in destroying Iraq's command and control computer links.

title: For Four Canadians in Bronx Crash, a Fiery End to a Holiday
description: It was a gathering of the clan -- relatives and friends from the Treadways district in St. Catherine's Parish on the island of Jamaica exchanging childhood memories and banter Sunday night at an impromptu get-together in New Jersey.

title: Beijing Marks 40 Years of Tibet's 'Liberation'
description: Somewhere in the far west of China, nestled in the Himalayas, is a Shangri-La brimming with contentment and human rights -- or so say the Chinese newspapers these days.

title: Miscellany
description: * TV-commercial producers who want a Hollywood soundtrack for a 30-second spot may be able to find it at Killer Music, Los Angeles. The company recently starting representing 13 film composers for jobs on television commercials. The composers, who may charge as much as $500,000 a job, include Bill Conti, who scored several of the "Rocky"' films; Danny Elfman, "Dick Tracy" and "Batman," and Henry Mancini, "Breakfast at Tiffany's" and "Victor/Victoria."

title:
YUBA CITY JOURNAL;
Issue of Pistol Permits Makes Sheriff a Target
description: Just half an hour's drive north of the state capitol in Sacramento, freeways and housing tracts give way to peach orchards and farms where families live for generations and where you can go a whole day and never meet a stranger.

title: Trenton Treasurer Finds Bigger Budget Shortfall
description: Blaming a weak economy, the State Treasurer said today that New Jersey was facing an additional budget shortfall of $768 million for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: Albany Legislative Chiefs Agree to Restore Millions in School Cuts
description: Inching toward a budget agreement, the state's legislative leaders have reached a tentative agreement to restore hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed school aid cuts, the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said today.

title: Yields Fall For C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts, down for the last three months, fell again for the one-week period ended yesterday.

title: Koch's Campaign Panel Fined $35,000 for '89 Race
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board fined former Mayor Edward I. Koch's campaign committee $35,000 yesterday for violating limits on contributions and for overspending on the 1989 mayoral race.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Minnesota Housing Finance Agency is offering $104 million in tax-exempt revenue and refunding revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum of 7.45 percent for an issue due in 2022, through Paine Webber Inc. Yields on short maturities range from 5.1 percent in 1993 to 6.4 percent in 2000. For longer maturities, all of which are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for certain investors, the yields are 6.8 percent in 2015 and 7.3 percent in 2011. The financing is rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

title: Rajiv Gandhi: A Son Who Won, Lost and Tried a Comeback
description: He was the reluctant Gandhi, content on the political sidelines as his mother and brother strained to command an immense and diverse nation.

title: Honorary Captains
description: Two Hall of Famers, HENRY AARON and ROD CAREW, will serve as honorary captains for the All-Star Game July 9 in Toronto, Aaron for the National League and Carew the American. Carew will be inducted into the Hall July 21.

title: Famous Name Is a Start On the Presidential Trail
description: Cindy Leuschner knew little about the Democratic Senator from West Virginia who was earnestly quizzing her about problems with health care while the television cameras dutifully rolled.

title: The Best of Bloomies
description: During the 41 years that Marvin Traub worked at Bloomingdale's -- first as a merchandising assistant, eventually as chairman and chief executive officer -- the store became to retailing what Barnum & Bailey is to circuses: the Greatest Show on Earth.

title: A Creative Council Reaps an Array of Benefits
description: Respect has never come easily to the New York City Council. And even as the revised City Charter has given it vast new responsibilities, power has remained in short supply for all but a handful of its members.

title: E.P.A. Says It's Ready to Battle Farm and City Water Pollution
description: Addressing the most contentious issue in the debate over rewriting the Clean Water Act, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the Bush Administration was ready to take action on new measures to control water pollution from farms and cities. But he was not specific about how that would be done.

title: Court Papers Provide a Look at Sears Defenses
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company released a trove of documents today, part of a shareholder lawsuit against Sears that had been sealed. While incomplete, the documents support the shareholders' view that one reason for Sears's large-scale restructuring announced in October 1988 was to thwart hostile bidders.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Morris Leads Dodge Kevin Morris, the head pro at Westchester Hills for 14 years, shot a three-under-par 69 and held a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $100,000 Dodge Open Charity Classic yesterday at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J. The 39-year-old Morris had only one bogey and posted four birdies, including a birdie on the 16th hole after he was struck in the head by a ball hit by Chris Masterton from the 15th tee. Morris staggered to his knees, but he recovered and sank a 12-foot putt for a birdie 3.

title: Herman Kalckar, 83, Metabolism Authority
description: Dr. Herman Moritz Kalckar, an educator and biochemist who did pioneering work in metabolism, died Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 83 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Chemicals Far East Ltd., Hong Kong, a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., named Ralph E. Anderson president. * Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, a unit of GM Hughes Electronics Corp., named John C. Weaver president of its radar systems group.

title: After an Early Charge, Penguins Hold On
description: Mario Lemieux returned to the Pittsburgh lineup with one goal, one assist and even some uncharacteristic rough play tonight to help the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 5-3 victory over the Minnesota North Stars in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Indians Express Anger, Revulsion and Disbelief
description: Indians reacted with horror, disbelief and anger at Rajiv Gandhi's assassination and the Government announced a state of mourning for the leader who at one time symbolized the hopes of a generation.

title: Why Blindfold the Camera?
description: California is so eager to keep its executions off television that the state has shut out all the press, prompting two justifiable counterattacks. The ban has been challenged in Federal District Court in San Francisco by KQED, the public television station, and in the Legislature, with a bill that would permit filming of executions, though only with the condemned person's consent.

title: Dayton Hudson Net Off
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the retail chain, said today that the soft economy and the company's acquisition of Marshall Field & Company caused first-quarter earnings to fall more than 43 percent. Dayton Hudson said that it earned $34 million, or 39 cents a share, in the quarter ended May 4, down from $60 million, or 76 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlie. Sales rose to $3.35 billion, from approximately $3 billion in the period a year earlier. The retailer said its per-share earnings were reduced approximately 15 cents by costs associated with last year's acquisition of Marshall Field, the Chicago-based department store chain. Earnings were diluted an additional 10 cents a share by an employee stock ownership plan, Dayton Hudson said.

title: University Research Depends on 'Overhead'
description: To the Editor:

title: Participant in Prison Siege Is Executed in Texas
description: An inmate was executed today for his part in an 11-day prison siege that left four people dead.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION -- 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Care Group Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a provider of home health care for AIDS patients, will acquire Care Line Inc., Dallas, a provider of home infusion therapy. Terms were not disclosed. * Concord Camera Corp., Avenel, N.J., has completed the acquisition of certain assets of Keystone Camera Corp. and Keystone Camera Products Corp., Clifton, N.J., for about $5.5 million.

title: Review/City Ballet; Portraying The Female As Mate And Predator
description: "The Cage" remains a well-told horror story. Choreographed by Jerome Robbins to Stravinsky's String Concerto in D, "The Cage" concerns the way some female insects devour males after mating. Out of this curious scientific phenomenon, Mr. Robbins created a chilling dance drama.

title: Coach for Northeastern
description: Despite posting a won-lost-tied record of 1-24-3 in his only season as head coach at Dartmouth, BEN SMITH yesterday was hired to be head coach at Northeastern, replacing Don McKenney who resigned on March 28 after leading the Huskies to an 8-23-3 record. Smith, a former Harvard player who was an all-Ivy League selection, was an assistnat coach of the 1988 United States Olympic team. His lone victory last season at Dartmouth was over Northeastern.

title:
CURRENTS;
In London, The Public Is Served
description: PAINTING and polishing were taking place at a frenzied pitch this week as the Design and Decoration Building in London prepared to open today at 107A Pimlico Road in Chelsea.

title: Garden Is the Therapist At Rehabilitation Center
description: JEAN HARRIS likes to show people her left hand. "I can move all my fingers pretty well now, except my thumb," the 69-year-old patient said proudly. "It's like a miracle."

title: Hands by the Thousand
description: Klockit P.O. Box 636, Lake Geneva, Wis. 53147; (800) 556-2548.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $283.9 million tax-exempt bond issue by the Northern California Power Agency was initially priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Giants Get Their Glittering Prizes
description: The Giants were extremely generous today with Super Bowl rings, passing out 154 -- the most the Balfour ring company has produced for a professional team -- to players, coaches and front-office personnel.

title: Syria-Lebanon Cooperation Pact Signed
description: The Presidents of Syria and Lebanon signed a treaty in Damascus today and announced that a new era of cooperation between the two neighboring countries had begun.

title: Steinbrenner Gives Up Posts
description: George M. Steinbrenner is stepping down as chairman and chief executive of the American Ship Building Company, and will be succeeded in those posts next month by Vice Adm. Paul D. Butcher, U.S.N., retired.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ADULTS are usually less involved with their parents than they were as children. Their increased emotional and physical distance reflects their independence and self-confidence. It is a sign that the earlier relationship has gone well, but is no longer needed or wanted.

title: Philadelphians Again Looking to Rizzo
description: In Tuesday's mayoral primary, Philadelphia voters planted one foot firmly in the future and another firmly in the past.

title: Top Advice Courtesy of Stu Jackson
description: If Pat Riley accepts the Knicks' offer to become their new coach, a colleague in the fraternity of former coaches has some suggestions for Dave Checketts, the Knick president, and Ernie Grunfeld, the vice president in charge of player personnel.

title: Armco-Kawasaki
description: The Armco Steel Corporation L.P., a joint venture of Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corporation and Armco Inc., has decided to postpone a planned $200 million investment on a new continuous galvanizing line in the venture's Ohio plant, a Kawasaki spokesman said. The decision was made in response to the sluggish United States car market, he said. A continuous galvanizing line makes thin steel plates for car parts. The spokesman said Armco Steel would build the facility when the United States auto market recovered. Armco is 55 percent owned by Armco and 45 percent owned by Kawasaki.

title: Home Library on Disks To Be Offered by Sony
description: The Sony Corporation introduced a product yesterday that will allow home computer users access to vast amounts of information stored on laser disks. A single such disk can store 250,000 pages of text.

title: Florida County's Top Yield Is 6.87%
description: Broward County, Fla., is offering $109.7 million in tax-exempt school board certificates of participation initially priced to yield a maximum 6.87 percent for securities due in 2011.

title: Recovery Expected to Be Weak
description: Ask a White House official, a member of Congress or a Federal Reserve policy maker what might happen when the recession ends, and they give this answer: Growth will be slow and sluggish. The bursts of activity that came immediately after other post-World War II recessions will not materialize this time.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on May 6 with an article about public school districts challenging New York State's school-financing law misstated spending per pupil in Mount Vernon. It is $8,283 a pupil, according to the state Education Department. In addition, the chart, which listed the highest- and lowest- spending districts in the New York metropolitan area, described its scope incompletely. It covered only districts that offer kindergarten through grade 12.

title: Judge Bans Anti-Cruelty Unit, Citing State Rules Violations
description: A State Supreme Court justice dissolved the Westchester Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children today for ignoring state rules and court orders.

title: Money Market Funds Post Mixed Yields for the Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Bush Plan For Banks Dealt Blow
description: A House panel dealt a significant political blow today to the Bush Administration's plan to overhaul the banking system. It unanimously rejected a proposal to restructure the industry's regulatory system.

title: Irony in Health Care: Loss of Local Control
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Officers and Mayor's Kin Charged in Detroit Inquiry
description: The Government has charged 11 police officers with taking payoffs to protect F.B.I. agents who they thought were drug dealers and money launderers.

title: After Rajiv Gandhi: An India Still Governed by Caretakers
description: The assassination of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi does not change the composition of India's caretaker Government, which is headed by Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.

title: Gospel Tunes in Houston Set Royal Toes Tapping
description: The decorum of Queen Elizabeth II's visit to the United States dissolved for a few gleeful moments today when she and Prince Philip took the front pews at the 125-year-old Antioch Baptist Church here.

title: GORBACHEV PLEADS FOR $100 BILLION IN AID FROM WEST
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pleaded today for $100 billion in economic aid from the democratic world, asserting that it would be well worth it to the West to bolster global security by priming a Soviet recovery.

title: Pop in Review
description: Alan Jackson, Vince Gill and Pam Tillis Country Beacon Theater

title: Cuts May Force CUNY To Turn Away Students
description: The Chancellor of the City University of New York said yesterday that the university would be forced to turn away half of all the freshmen entering its seven community colleges in September if budget cuts proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins are made.

title: House Votes Military Budget, Cutting Arms Programs
description: The House of Representatives today approved a $291 billion military budget for next year that differed sharply with the Bush Administration on the cost of two of the Pentagon's most prized weapons systems of the future.

title: Philharmonic Names Managing Director
description: Deborah Borda was named managing director of the New York Philharmonic yesterday. She succeeds Albert K. Webster, who held the job from 1975 until January, and Allison Vulgamore, who has been acting director since then.

title: More Than a Long Hallway Keeps Dinkins and Vallone Apart
description: Only a long hallway separates City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Mayor David N. Dinkins, but they are so far apart they need a hotline to talk. The line -- actually a prosaic black phone -- is a metaphor for the miscommunications and misconnections that pervade their prickly relationship.

title: George Pampel, Advertising Executive, 86
description: George Pampel, a retired advertising excutive, died on Saturday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 86 years old and had lived in Greenwich since 1946.

title: It's New. It's Now. Can You Sit in It?
description: THE French interior designer Andree Putman looked around for something new at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York this week and found what? "Nothing," she replied in her husky, accented English. "But I would never say that because it is quite mean and not quite true."

title: Aaron C. Waters Dies; Earth Scientist Was 86
description: Aaron C. Waters, a prominent geologist, died Saturday at a nursing home in Tacoma, Wash. He was 86 years old and lived in Tacoma.

title: Albany Tries To Close Loopholes In Gun Laws
description: In the state's first package of broad new gun-control measures in almost a decade, legislative leaders have agreed to toughen penalties for illegal possession or sale of firearms and to crack down on loopholes in New York City's gun laws, officials here said today.

title: Martin S. Auer Dies; Ex-State Senator, 72
description: Martin S. Auer, a prominent Onondaga County Republican who served in the New York State Senate for 12 years, died on Tuesday at University Hospital in Syracuse. He was 72 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: Chyron Accord With Creditors
description: The Chyron Corporation, a maker of television graphic equipment that is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors, said its two main bank creditors had agreed to a financial reorganization. It said the European American Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation had entered into a letter of intent with the Pelloni Capital Corporation of Florida on a proposed plan that would eliminate the entire interest of present shareholders.

title: Calendar of Events: A Peek at the Future
description: Future Designers Cooper Union Foundation Building, 7 East Seventh Street; (212) 353-4200.

title: On Philippine Treaty, Gap Is Said to Narrow
description: American and Philippine officials are expressing optimism that they can work out a new treaty permitting American forces to remain at two large military bases in the Philippines after the current lease expires in September.

title: Review/Television; A Salute to Kirk Douglas for His Life
description: Certain awards shows over the years have retained a touch of class. One is "Kennedy Center Honors." Another is the "American Film Institute Life Achievement Award," which this year offers its 19th program, "A Salute to Kirk Douglas" at 10 tonight on CBS . Both of the annual events happen to be produced by George Stevens Jr.

title: Budget Eludes Albany Leaders
description: New York State stumbled through another day without a budget today as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders continued their marathon negotiations on a spending plan, now seven weeks overdue.

title: Low-Rated Notes Sold by Chiquita
description: Chiquita Brands International priced $200 million in 10-year speculative-grade notes yesterday at a price of 100 to yield 11.5 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Sony Profits Are Up 13.7%
description: The Sony Corporation said today that its net income rose 13.7 percent for the year on a 25 percent increase in sales.

title: Ethics Office Is Reviewing Sununu's Travels
description: The White House chief of staff's travel practices, which led President Bush to crack down on the use of Government aircraft, are now under review by the Office of Government Ethics, officials said today.

title: Pop in Review
description: Feelies and Chickasaw Mudd Puppies Rock Town Hall

title: Essian, Named by Cubs, Wins in Debut
description: The baseball rested in Jim Essian's left hand, on its way from the field at Shea Stadium to a trophy case at home.

title: Humpty-Dumpty Yanks Put the Pieces Together For One Night, Anyway
description: For one night, everything fell into place.

title: Doremus Moves to Refresh Creative Image
description: DOREMUS & COMPANY, a midsized agency best known for its financial "tombstone" advertisements, is hiring a well-known, award-winning creative executive and asking him to refresh its image.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Signed Mike Dunne, pitcher, to a minor-league contract. KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Fired John Wathan, manager. Named Bob Schaefer interim manager. MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Placed Darryl Hamilton, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Matias Carrillo, outfielder, from Denver of the American Association. Moved Ron Robinson, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list to the 60-day disabled list. National League CHICAGO CUBS -- Named Jim Essian manager and signed him to a contract through the 1992 season. BASKETBALL United States Basketball League EMPIRE STATE STALLIONS -- Signed Jeffery Robinson, guard-forward, and Steve Downey, center. CAR RACING NASCAR -- Upheld the 12-week suspension of Junior Johnson, car owner, for using an oversized engine. FOOTBALL National Football League CLEVELAND BROWNS -- Promoted Dom Anile to director of college scouting. Announced that Gene Benhart, quarterback, has left the team. NEW YORK GIANTS -- Reassigned Charlie Weis, defensive assistant, to running backs coach. Named George Sefcik wide receivers coach and Bobby Trott defensive assistant. Waived Raul Allegre, placekicker. PHILADELPHIA EAGLES -- Signed Nick Cullen, wide receiver, and Rich Miano and Chris Mitchell, defensive backs, to one-year contracts. Released Fred Gunter, defensive back; Stacy Robinson and Doug Banks, wide receivers; Jeremiah McCleary, defensive tackle; and Stacy Fields, tight end.

title: A Rocking Chair to Soothe the Disabled
description: Some handicapped students can now experience the simple joy of a rocking chair, thanks to five mechanical engineering students at the Rochester Institute of Technology. A chair they made for a senior design course will be used at the Mary Cariola Center for Children in Rochester, a school for about 300 severly handicapped and retarded youngsters between infancy and age 21.

title: Federal Express
description: Van Ommeren Ceteco N.V., a Dutch transport concern, said it was in talks to buy some European operations of the Federal Express Corporation. Van Ommeren said it expects to reach an agreement soon to buy the Federal Express specialized terminals in Vlaardingen, the Netherlands, and in Hamburg, Germany. It said it would also buy 25 tankers, sailing under Dutch and German flags, that transport animal and vegetable oils and fats. It said Federal Express no longer considered those divisions as part of its core business.

title: Syria Invitation To Gulf Parade Is Reconsidered
description: The committee organizing New York City's ticker-tape parade for Persian Gulf war veterans is reconsidering its invitation to the Syrian Government.

title: Two Banks Ask U.S. Aid
description: Two troubled Connecticut banking companies Cenvest Inc. of Meriden and the Suffield Financial Corporation -- have asked the Federal Government for financial help.

title: Review/Film; Living With, Near, or Despite Dogs
description: Film Forum, the exemplary three-screen Manhattan complex that already threatens to monopolize most of our free time (with its Billy Wilder retrospective in one theater and "Paris Is Burning" in another), has now quite literally gone to the dogs. Its third program is devoted entirely to canine attitudes, human perceptions thereof, and the distinct possibility that much of what we think of as doggie behavior is actually doggie-owner delusion on a grand scale. Pet fanciers of any kind will find this an illuminating show.

title: BAKER CITES ISRAEL FOR SETTLEMENTS
description: In an unusually blunt criticism of the Israeli Government, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that nothing has more complicated his efforts to convene Middle East peace talks than Israel's continuing settlement building in the occupied territories.

title: Critic's Notebook; Musicologists Dissect Mozart at a Symposium Honoring Bicentennial
description: "This is not a musicological conference," said Neal Zaslaw, the Cornell University musicologist who had just overseen two sessions on Monday lasting nearly seven hours full of learned papers and virtuosic intellection. "It's a musical conference."

title: Control Data Unit
description: The Computing Devices Company, a Canadian subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, signed a $1 billion contract with the Canadian Defense Department to develop and make a new voice and data communications system for the Candian Land Forces. Computing Devices will also set up a new facility in Calgary, Alberta, to house engineering, manufacturing and business development operations in connection with the contract.

title: U.N. Team Inspects Iraq's Stock of Uranium
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency announced today that a team of international experts had completed the first postwar inspection of Iraq's stock of materials suitable for making nuclear weapons.

title: Chinese Advocates of Change Reportedly Make Small Gains
description: The faction in the Chinese leadership favoring more rapid economic change has scored a pair of modest victories over the hard-liners in recent weeks, Chinese officials say.

title: Investors Are Sought For L.A. Gear Stake
description: L.A. Gear Inc., the financially troubled footwear and clothing maker, said today that it was seeking investors to buy a minority stake in the company, but denied it needed quick cash to get by.

title: One of the Characters In 'Thirtysomething' May Outlive the Series
description: fter months of rumors, the death of a main character, defections by writers and a decline in the ratings, ABC made it official on Tuesday: "Thirtysomething" is kaput. But fans of the series that people either loved or hated but always talked about may have one last straw to grasp at. The indefatigable character of Melissa Steadman -- the confident photographer, the lonely eccentric, the girl with the Davy Crockett cap and crooked smile -- could outlive the series in her own half-hour spinoff.

title: Stocks Climb in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices rose today in moderate trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 244.99 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 25,643.65. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 82.55 points.

title: Lincoln Wouldn't Charge Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: COMPANIES

title: Playing for Power; The Council's Bid for Influence - Last of four articles.; King of New York's Council: Small-Town Boy in Big City
description: Last January, Peter F. Vallone -- a loyal son of Astoria, Queens, and the Speaker of the long-suffering New York City Council -- delivered his first State of the City speech with all the ceremonial trappings (flags, television prompter) of a Presidential address.

title: High Costs Shut Trauma Centers
description: Money troubles have put at least 60 hospital trauma centers out of business, particularly in violent inner cities where speedy treatment is often a matter of life or death, a Congressional study has found.

title: Anthony Maglio, 79, A Retired Judge, Dies
description: Anthony E. Maglio, a retired Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: House Vote for Arms Budget
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 268 to 161 by which the House of Representatives today approved a $291 billion military budget for the 1992 fiscal year. A "yes" vote is a vote for the budget package. Voting "yes" were 242 Democrats and 26 Republicans. Voting "no" were 22 Democrats, 138 Republicans and 1 Independent. X denotes those not voting. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats -- Bevill, Y; Browder, Y; Cramer, Y; Erdreich, Y; Harris, Y. Republicans -- Callahan, N; Dickinson, N.

title: Single-Sex Clubs Have a Place on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Agreement Extends Retiree Benefits for 6 Months
description: Eastern Airlines' retirees won a partial victory yesterday when an agreement was reached with the carrier's trustee to keep their health benefits in effect an extra six months.

title: Free-Spirited Lenny Dykstra Belly-Flops to Earth
description: Years before Lenny Dykstra became a big-league ballplayer with a $7.3 million contract and a fancy sports car, he was a scrappy little kid who liked few things better than hitting, running and scuffling up the basepaths -- even running into outfield walls.

title: Smaller Families, Bigger Futures
description: A Republican President of the United States once made stirring comments about the importance of birth control. "Governments must act and private citizens cooperate urgently through voluntary means to secure this right for all people," Dwight D. Eisenhower said. "Failure would limit the expectation of future generations to abject poverty and suffering and bring down upon us history's condemnation."

title: Hoang Van Hoan, Vietnam Aide Who Defected to China, Dies at 86
description: Hoang Van Hoan, a founding member of the Vietnamese Communist Party who defected to China in 1979, died in Beijing on Saturday, China's official press agency reported today. He was 86 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: With Mengistu Gone, Ethiopian Rebels Gain A day after Ethiopia's President fled the country and handed over power to his Vice President, rebels advanced against the crumbling army to within 23 miles of the capital, Addis Ababa.

title: People
description: * Charles B. Fruit has been named global media director for Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta. He had been president of Anheuser-Busch's Busch Media Group. Mr. Fruit replaces William H. Lynn, the former vice president and director of worldwide media, who died in November.

title: Israeli's Hunger Strike Sets Off Storm
description: The Israeli Parliament fell into a screaming, cursing pandemonium today over Speaker Dov Shilansky's call to an Israeli pacifist to start eating again.

title: Surprise! Checketts Wants Riley
description: The Knicks revealed yesterday what most basketball followers already knew: Pat Riley is the choice to fill their coaching vacancy.

title: Councilman Got $25,000 Check From Developer
description: City Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos of Manhattan received a $25,000 check from a prominent developer whose apartment project he had championed before a city agency, bank records show.

title: IRAQI ARMY AGREES TO A PULLOUT PLAN
description: In a potential breakthrough, allied and Iraqi military commanders agreed today that Iraqi soldiers and secret policemen would withdraw from the important Kurdish city of Dohuk and that allied forces would move in starting Friday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF He Knows the Course Chris Dachisen capitalized on a home-course advantage of sorts yesterday at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J. He hit 17 of the 18 greens in regulation and shot a five-under-par 67 for a two-round total of 140. That led the field in the $100,000 Dodge Open Charity Classic by two strokes, with a 36-hole finale scheduled today. Dachisen, who is 34 years old and the head pro at Maplewood, was born near the 10th hole of the 6.597-yard Rockaway River course. He hit his first golf ball on the 11th tee as a child, and used to caddie and cut the grass at the club. "I know where to hit and where not to hit," he said after a round that included five birdies and no bogeys. Trailing at 142 were Delroy Cambridge of Sunningdale, Tom Joyce of Glen Oaks, Mike Gray of Plainfield, Peter Linhard of Canoe Brook and Ed Whitman of Knickerbocker.

title: North Stars Remain Confident After Loss
description: This spring's version of the Stanley Cup finals has been building the way a good final round should. Each game has been a little better than the one that went before it, with at least two and maybe three more to come.

title:
CURRENTS;
Seeing Is Believing: Architect's Video Model
description: ARCHITECTS usually depend on drawings and models to give a client an idea of how a proposed building will look. Now computerized animation can present a three-dimensional video tour of a project.

title: Man Convicted in Rabbi's Death
description: A jury convicted an unemployed house painter yesterday in the killing last year of Rabbi Chaskel Werzberger, a leader of the Satmar Hasidic community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Sony Is Reportedly Near Deal To Lease A.T.&T. Skyscraper
description: In what is shaping up as one of the biggest real estate deals in New York City this year, A.T.& T. has tentatively agreed to lease its headquarters building, one of Manhattan's architectural highlights, to the Sony Corporation, real estate executives said yesterday.

title: Redeeming Albany's Sorry Record
description: Astoundingly, Gov. Mario Cuomo and New York's legislative leaders have yet to agree on a budget -- 52 days after they were required by law to produce one. That's a record. The word from Albany is that the Governor and lawmakers are finally talking to each other, however sullenly. That's good news, of a sort. But the news would be better still if the state's leaders would also confront New York City's fiscal crisis.

title: Jean Harder Ryan Shields, Volunteer, 76
description: Jean Harder Ryan Shields, a longtime hospital volunteer, died on Tuesday at her home, Panther Ledge Farm in Allamuchy, N.J. She was 76 years old.

title: Tape Offers Glimpse at Capital's Violence
description: A jury in Superior Court today viewed a videotape showing a particularly violent beating that prosecutors say was part of a turf war between drug dealers in a Washington neighborhood.

title: China Revives Its Test of Capitalism
description: After the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, China's bold experiment in fusing socialism and capitalism in this South China city stalled. By last summer, Shenzhen's mayor lost his position, economic reforms were halted, and the city's 10th anniversary celebration was postponed.

title: Libraries Can't Ban the Homeless, U.S. Court in Newark Rules
description: A Federal judge ruled today that public libraries cannot bar homeless people because their presence, their staring or their hygiene annoys or offends other library patrons.

title: Julian Orbon, 65; Cuban Composer, Pianist and Critic
description: Julian Orbon, a Spanish-born Cuban composer, died on Monday at Sinai Medical Center in Miami. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lagos Journal; Nigerian's Plan: Adopt the (250) Mother Tongues
description: "What a lot of people call me here," Prof. Aliu Babatunde Fafunwa said proudly, "is the father of mother tongue."

title: Southern Co. Inquiry Ends
description: The Southern Company said Tuesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had closed its investigation of the utility holding company without pressing charges.

title: NBC Is on Top Again In May Ratings Sweep
description: NBC, relying heavily on strong performances from its lineup of movies, staged a comeback in the May ratings sweep month and will easily claim a win when the special television rating period ends officially tonight.

title: 'Thirtysomething' Turns To the Classified Section
description: Although ABC is canceling "Thirtysomething," the weekly ABC drama that involved an advertising agency in many of its story lines, that fictitious agency lives on, in a way, via classified advertising.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about Katz's Delicatessen in Manhattan described its salami incorrectly. It is Jewish-style, but not kosher.

title: Bolshoi Opera Names Singers For U.S. Visit
description: The casts of the Bolshoi Opera productions that are to be performed at the Metropolitan Opera and at Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va., this summer have been announced by Vladimir Kokonin, the Soviet company's director general. The company is to tour with 450 musicians and singers, and will present three works: Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin" and "Maid of Orleans" and Rimsky-Korsakov's "Mlada." The productions have revolving casts, with two to four singers sharing each major role.

title: Federal Insurance Role Spurs Congress Debate
description: A debate over possible Federal regulation of the nation's troubled insurance companies heated up today with the release of a new study saying state officials cannot adequately police the industry.

title: Bridge
description: In the Pan-American Pairs in Memphis, Tenn., last week, which generated one of two teams to represent the United States in the world championships in Yokohama, Japan, in October, the most experienced pairs were fighting for the crucial top three spots. But there was one pair of upstarts challenging them.

title: Let Catholic Universities Be Universities First; Creeping Secularism
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit-Card Rules Urged
description: Legislation to require that consumers be given at least 30 days to repay credit-card debts before the interest rate could be increased was proposed yesterday by Representative Charles Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.

title: Review/Dance; Jose Greco And Son And Gypsies
description: For many Americans, Jose Greco is Spanish dancing personified, whether they saw him and his company perform on countless tours or on popular television shows from the 1950's on. And while purists may have their reservations about Mr. Greco's popularization of Spanish dance and music, he certainly does know how to put on a good show. That sense of cheerful showmanship was epitomized on Tuesday night in "Recuerdos," a highlight in the opening performance of the Jose Greco Company's three-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).

title: Coach at Georgetown Will Join Nike Board
description: Nike Inc., which has been under fire from some blacks, named John Thompson, Georgetown University's head basketball coach, who is black, to its board of directors yesterday.

title: Ethics Panel To Examine Councilman And Fund
description: As the newly empowered City Council comes under increased public scrutiny, Speaker Peter F. Vallone is turning to a rarely used Council panel -- the Committee on Standards and Ethics -- for an investigation of one Councilman's finances.

title: Georgia Pacific May Laugh Last
description: THE Georgia Pacific Corporation may be poised for the last laugh at the naysayers who said a year ago that it was taking on far too great a burden in its $3.8 billion acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, which made it the nation's largest forest-products concern.

title: My Husband's Nine Wives
description: I married a married man.

title: Top Honor for Hull
description: BRETT HULL, who scored 86 goals for the St. Louis Blues to lead the National Hockey League, yesterday was named the winner of the Lester Pearson Award as the league's best player by the Players Association. He was a runaway choice, being named on 294 of 432 ballots. Second was WAYNE GRETZKY, the Los Angeles Kings' league scoring leader, and third place went to goalie ED BALFOUR of the Chicago Blackhawks. (AP)

title: Back in the Maelstrom; Filming Resumes
description: In any other season, it might have been just another New York nightmare. A film crew had cordoned off 40th Street and Eighth Avenue, and angry cabdrivers were leaning on their horns. The midtown Manhattan sun blasted pedestrians as they detoured past the pavement where the actress Michelle Pfeiffer was shooting a scene. Hustlers and hawkers, beggars and bag ladies were dislodged from their customary territories. In short, it was a mess. Welcome Element of the Raw

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Students and their families are entitled to the full benefits of price competition when they choose a college. This collegiate cartel has denied them the right to compare prices and discounts among schools, just as they would in shopping for any other service or commodity." -- Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. [ A1:2. ]

title: Congress: Landmark Party in Decline
description: When the politicians of the Congress Party moved yesterday to ask Sonia Gandhi to succeed her slain husband as party leader, it was hardly the first time that they were seeking to exploit family connections to link today's party to the one that led India to independence and then shaped the country's institutions and agenda.

title: Ivy Universities Deny Price-Fixing But Agree to Avoid It in the Future
description: Facing Justice Department charges that they violated Federal antitrust laws, the eight colleges and universities in the Ivy League have agreed to stop sharing information on student financial aid and to avoid collaborating on tuition increases.

title: Weicker Says He'll Veto No-Income-Tax Plan
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he would veto the no-income-tax budget plan unveiled by legislators on Tuesday. His announcement, one day before the Senate is expected to begin debate on the plan, raised the stakes further in the battle of wills between the administration and the General Assembly.

title: Key Rates
Rangers Break Their Club Record By Beating Twins for 9th Straight
description: The Texas Rangers won a club-record ninth straight game by beating the Minnesota Twins, 5-2, tonight in 12 innings.

title: Volvo Profit Down by 68%
description: Volvo A. B., the Swedish vehicle maker, said today that it avoided a first-quarter loss because of a $100 million gain from the sale of stock.

title: John B. Carter, 56, A Former President Of Equitable Life
description: John B. Carter, retired head of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died on Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Johnson-Merck to Buy German Drug Unit
description: Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company said yesterday that they had agreed to buy a German drug company as a "first step" into the $5 billion European consumer drug business.

title: Cadets Hear Powell At Commencement
description: General Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told graduates of the United States Coast Guard Academy that they are "part of the nation's life insurance" at a commencement ceremony yesterday in New London, Conn.

title: Indians in the U.S. Now Fear More Violence in Homeland
description: For the Indian immigrants who have transformed a few blocks of Queens into a bustling commercial district with the accents of Bombay, the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi has brought grief and fears that their homeland will once more become engulfed in violence.

title: Report Offers New Answer to Gamma-Ray Puzzle
description: French and Soviet scientists think they have taken a major step toward solving one of the most frustrating enigmas in astrophysics: Where in outer space do brief, intense flashes of gamma rays come from?

title: ASSASSINATION IN INDIA: Woman in the News; The Tragedy's New Player; Sonia Gandhi
description: During Rajiv Gandhi's tenure as Prime Minister, many Indians clung to the belief that his wife, Sonia, wielded undue influence in the shadows of power.

title: Steinbrenner 'Mystery' May Be Solved
description: Although he agreed 10 months ago not to challenge the commissioner's sanctions against him in court, George Steinbrenner may be planning to do just that in a last-ditch effort to extricate himself from baseball purgatory. Or he may take that step as part of a plan that would include the sale of his majority share of the Yankees.

title: Rivalry Over a Boyfriend Ends in a Slaying on S.I.
description: The two young women had argued over a young man before, friends said -- the kind of thing that might lead to harsh words or pushing or punching, perhaps.

title: Childbirth Classes in Just One Weekend
description: MONIQUE CAVARIS is married to an airline pilot who she says is almost never home. When they found out they were going to be parents, they were sure they would not be able to take a standard childbirth-preparation course that runs for six to eight weeks.

title: U.S. and Japan Give Out Economic 'Report Cards'
description: Like two schoolteachers relishing the chance to grade one another, Japan and the United States concluded a novel round of trade talks here today with modest praise for the progress each had made in economic self-improvement over the last year but harsh criticism for continued shortcomings.

title: Sex-Abuse Case in Harlem Leaves Neighbors Confused
description: On Striver's Row, the shady, elegant block of Harlem row houses where Kodzo Dobosu lived with his 18 adopted children, neighbors praised him yesterday for single-handedly raising dozens of unwanted children over the years.

title: 'Mr. Gogol' Delays Opening
description: "Mr. Gogol and Mr. Preen," a comedy by Elaine May, has postponed its opening to June 9 from May 30 because of revisions in the script. The play, directed by Gregory Mosher, is to continue in previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Survey on Family Leave Finds Little Burden
description: Advocates of Federal legislation that would require many employers to provide up to 12 weeks' unpaid leave for childbirth or family illness made public a survey today finding that businesses had encountered little difficulty complying with such laws in four states that have them.

title: N.H.L. Moves Up Expansion Draft
description: The National Hockey League announced today that the 1991 expansion draft, orginally scheduled for June 17, would be held May 30.

title: Thornburgh In On Valdez Talks Despite Stock
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh sought and was granted a White House waiver of conflict-of-interest rules, allowing him to negotiate a settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill despite an investment in two oil companies.

title: Sabena in Talks
description: Sabena S.A., Belgium's national airline, said it was in talks to form a partnership with either British Airways P.L.C. or Air France. Pierre Godfroid, Sabena's chairman, said the airline wanted to reach a deal by August for another carrier to buy at least 25 percent of Sabena. That would offer Sabena a cash infusion of about $170 million. The money-losing airline, majority-owned by the state, said in February that it was seeking an industrial partner as part of a restructuring program to return to profitability in 1992. The restructuring includes a $255 million cash injection by the state, which will also forgive $460 million of debt and pay the bill for laying off 2,200 of Sabena's 11,800-member work force.

title: Pop in Review
description: Charlie Parker Tribute Majestic Theater Brooklyn Academy of Music

title: Essay; Clark Clifford's Confession
description: Do you remember what Watergate was all about? It was about the intrusion by the party in power into the rights of political challengers -- the Ins using their power unfairly to block the Outs.

title: Gulfstream Aerospace Names New President
description: William C. Lowe, a longtime I.B.M. executive who helped lead the nation's largest computer maker into the personal computer market in the early 1980's, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, the nation's largest corporate jet maker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: European Growth Lag
description: The European Commission forecast economic growth in the 12-nation European Community at 1.2 percent this year, less than half the 2.7 percent achieved last year. The Commissioner for Economic Affairs, Henning Christophersen, said inflation would be 5 percent, virtually unchanged from last year's level. But the report warned that "unless inflationary pressures subside clearly, there is no room for a relaxation of monetary policy in the community."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about uncovered short sales on the New York and American stock exchanges for the four weeks ended May 15 included erroneous American Stock Exchange figures, which the exchange has since attributed to a clerical error. Short interest on the exchange fell 2.5 million shares, or 3.2 percent, to 74.7 million shares, from the previous four-week period. It did not rise 494,980 shares.

title: Pop in Review
description: Rock Knitting Factory 47 East Houston

title: Accord Said to Be Near in Semiconductor Talks in Tokyo
description: American and Japanese negotiators said today that they were very close to agreeing on a new semiconductor accord, and that the new agreement should be in place well before the current five-year agreement expires this summer.

title: Youth, 19, Is Found Slain In Park on Upper West Side
description: A 19-year-old youth was found slain in a small park on Manhattan's Upper West Side yesterday afternoon. He had been shot once in the head and once in the chest, the police said.

title: Seals on Tank Truck in Crash Are Missing, Official Says
description: The tank truck that spilled hundreds of gallons of blazing fuel in a fatal Bronx crash early Monday has no gaskets sealing three of its five top hatches, the regional director of a Federal agency investigating the crash said yesterday.

title: Gasoline Price Rises
description: The average price of self-service unleaded gasoline rose one-tenth of a cent a gallon, to $1.161, last week, the American Automobile Association said today. The price in the corresponding week last year was $1.049 a gallon, or 11.2 cents below the current price. The association said the average price has increased in 10 of the last 11 weeks. It has gone up 8.1 cents since the Persian Gulf war ended, the association said.

title: Let Catholic Universities Be Universities First
description: To the Editor:

title:
CURRENTS;
Giving A Royal Touch To 2 AIDS Benefits
description: CROWNS are coming back into fashion, at least in certain circles. Thirty-two crowns by artists, designers and architects are to be auctioned at Barneys New York at 6:30 P.M. on June 5.

title: Barkley Changes Tune And Plans to Stay Put
description: CHARLES BARKLEY didn't mean it after all. Barkley, the Philadelphia 76er forward who hinted strongly several weeks ago that he wanted to be traded, now says he really wants to spend the rest of his career in Philadelphia.

title: Article 107691 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay $2.7 million to eight children who said they were sexually and physically abused in the early 1980's at a day-care center run by the Army at the Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., is offering $100 million in 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due 2001 at 99.50 to yield 9.955 percent through First Boston Corp. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P. * CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $250 million in liquid-yield option notes due 2006 through Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: Johnson Ban Reduced
description: In an unprecedented move, the sanctioning body for stock-car racing's top circuit yesterday reduced the 12-week suspension of car owner JUNIOR JOHNSON for using an oversized engine. The decision was made by Nascar commissioner SEMON E. KNUDSEN less than three hours after officials announced that an appeals panel had refused to ease the ban. (AP)

title:
CURRENTS;
Seductive Twists Of Mallet-Stevens
description: THE French architect Robert Mallet-Stevens never attained the reputation of his contemporary, Le Corbusier, for advancing modernist architecture in Europe in the 1920's and 1930's. Le Corbusier's architecture was pure, rigorous and rational; Mallet-Stevens gave the austere geometry of the International Style a seductive French twist.

title: Review/Theater; Willing One's Brain Into Communication
description: Aphasia is the subject and astronomy the metaphor in Susan Yankowitz's "Night Sky," a play that was generated by Joseph Chaikin's own battle with the communication disorder. That Mr. Chaikin has directed the play (for the Women's Project) adds a personal immediacy, as he and the playwright collaboratively embark on a journey into the mysteries of this affliction.

title: N.F.L. to Add 2 Teams, Realign for '94 Season
description: Twelve cities that have expressed interest in obtaining a National Football League expansion franchise can now officially begin jockeying for position. After nearly four hours of deliberation today, N.F.L. owners voted to expand the league by two teams in time for the 1994 season.

title: Innovative Solutions For Budgets in Crisis
description: California has a projected deficit of $14 billion. New York City expects a $3.5 billion deficit in fiscal 1992. More than 30 states and dozens of cities are grappling with huge deficits. The fiscal crises in state capitols and city halls are not only about balancing budgets. They are about rethinking the way governments deliver services and stretch dollars to do more with less.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about commencement at the University of Pennsylvania misattributed comments made in an address. It was the university's president, Sheldon Hackney, not Ted Koppel, the television anchor, who discussed the debate on campuses about political correctness, saying, "The classroom is not a place for indoctrination" and, "The purpose of a university is not to transform society but to enable individuals to transform themselves." (Mr. Koppel spoke about freedom of the press and restrictions on news coverage during the Persian Gulf war.)

title: A Full Investigation
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Backs Transport Bill Bush Opposes
description: The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee approved major transportation legislation today that differs sharply from the Bush Administration's proposals, setting up a vigorous debate on the Senate floor next month and, perhaps, an eventual collision between the Congress and the White House.

title: Farmer, 76, Gets Death Sentence in Slaying of 5
description: A 76-year-old farmer was sentenced today to death for luring five homeless men into a swindle and then killing them to cover up the scheme.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ajay Sports Inc., Delavan, Wis., a manufacturer and distributor of golf accessories, named L. Dean Cassell president and chief executive. * Ameritech Corp., Chicago, the parent company of the Bell companies serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, named John A. Edwardson executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Memo Says Reagan Trade Policy on Iraq Helped Hussein
description: A State Department memorandum released today by a Congressman said that Reagan Administration policy in the late 1980's, while barring most arms exports to Iraq, allowed the export of military equipment intended to protect President Saddam Hussein.

title: Judge Rules Scouts Can Block Gay Man As a Troop Leader
description: Ruling in a decade-long dispute between a gay man and the Boy Scouts of America, a judge here has held that the Constitution gives the organization the right to bar the man from becoming a scoutmaster.

title: Gizmos for Gizmos
description: Two 43-year-old Ph.D.'s in California, Henry Yuen and Daniel Kwoh, brought relief to millions of frustrated adults when they invented the VCR Plus. President Bush admits he's all thumbs when it comes to setting the timer to tape a TV show on the White House VCR, and he's not alone. Enter the VCR Plus. That's the magical gizmo that automatically sets the timer when you punch coded numbers that appear in the TV listings in about 100 newspapers, including this one. (The magic has something to do with "Huffman coding," but let's not get into that.)

title: Hitachi Plans U.S. Research Center
description: Hitachi Ltd., the leading Japanese electronics maker, said it would open a research center in the United States to develop advanced high-definition television technology. Hitachi America Ltd. will open a HDTV laboratory in July in Princeton, N.J., and initially employ about 20 researchers, a company official said. Hitachi hopes to market HDTV equipment developed at the research center by 1998, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: It's Always Drive Time On Thruway Station
description: The newest radio station in New York State is commercial-free, but then again it is also music-free, sports-free, conversation-free and fun-free. It's all Thruway news, all the time.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about City Councilman Noach Dear of Brooklyn misstated his position in the picture, as well as that of Frank T. W. New, in some copies. Mr. Dear was second from the left and Mr. New second from the right.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JULIA ROBERTS was released from the hospital and was recuperating at home yesterday after a severe case of the flu. Accompanied by her fiance, the actor KIEFER SUTHERLAND, Ms. Roberts checked into Cedars-Sinai Medical Center Thursday.

title: President's Condition Was Worse Than Revealed
description: President Bush has suffered more serious side effects, including mental fatigue, from his overactive thyroid and the drug treatment for it than was previously known publicly.

title: Daniel S. Giddings, 73, An Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Dr. Daniel S. Giddings, an orthopedic surgeon for almost 50 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Lawrence, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: Ethiopians in U.S. Pleased but Fearful Of Further Violence
description: From coffeehouses to cab stands, word that President Mengistu Haile Mariam had fled Ethiopia was met by the large Ethiopian exile community here with enthusiasm muted by the fear that civil war will engulf the capital.

title: Deflated Pistons Go Home With Time Off to Regroup
description: Even the self-confident Detroit Pistons admit they are in a serious bind. The Chicago Bulls have made that abundantly clear.

title: Assembly Plan Offers Fair Solution to New York Budget Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulators Investigate Peat On Its Auditing of S.& L.'s Regulators
description: The Office of Thrift Supervision issued subpoenas earlier this month to the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick seeking information on all its audits of savings institutions for 1989 and 1990, the firm acknowledged yesterday.

title: Albanian Politician, in U.S., Denounces the Communists
description: An Albanian political leader told members of Congress today that the Communist Government that was returned to power in Tirana in March elections faced growing opposition, heightened by a weeklong general strike.

title: Country vs. City: Weekend Diplomacy
description: ELEANOR HARRIS HOWARD is the author of a play called "I Don't Want to Die on Long Island," which had a staged reading in East Hampton last summer. The fact of the matter is that Mrs. Howard doesn't want to live or die on Long Island, or any other island or territory that isn't New York City.

title: Sabotage in Seoul
description: On April 26, Kang Kyung Dae, a college freshman, was beaten to death by riot policemen wielding iron pipes and clubs. Nearly a month later, his death continues to convulse South Korean society.

title: Councilman Received a Check
description: City Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos of Manhattan, who is under investigation, received a $25,000 check from a prominent developer whose apartment project Mr. Dryfoos had championed, bank records show. Page B3.

title: ETHIOPIAN REBELS HEAD FOR CAPITAL
description: Meeting spotty resistance from a crumbling Ethiopian Army, rebel forces advanced within 23 miles of the capital today, Western diplomats said.

title: Pretoria Adds Spears to Arms Ban In Areas Hit by Factional Battles
description: The Government acceded today to a demand by the African National Congress and officially prohibited the carrying of spears, along with other primitive weapons in areas afflicted by unrest around Johannesburg.

title: St. Paul Journal; A Tale of the Madam and the Mayor
description: A few weeks ago, about 10 P.M., the telephone rang at the home of Mayor James Scheibel. The caller said, "Jim, you've been won by Rebecca Rand."

title: Johnson Waits For Team's Call
description: Each time a major league manager is fired the phone in Davey Johnson's office does not ring, the former Met manager cannot help but wonder why.

title: Critic's Notebook; Haunting Cannes: The Monster Americanization
description: Tuesday morning, a newspaper headline described it as "la Moisson Americaine" ("the American harvest"). Supporters of pure French cinema called it a scandal, if not a crime. Nastassja Kinski seemed to think it was all Whoopi Goldberg's fault, while Joel and Ethan Coen, the perpetrators, were modestly ecstatic.

title: John F. Phillips, Restaurateur, 76
description: John F. Phillips, a Manhattan restaurateur who owned Frankie and Johnny's steakhouse in the theater district for several decades, died on Tuesday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: U.S. Move Seen Against Airbus
description: The European Commission said today that the United States planned to lodge a new complaint with GATT, the world trade monitoring group, over government subsidies to the four-nation European consortium Airbus Industrie.

title: Oil Tanker Ban Spurs Lawsuit
description: A group of oil companies led by the Chevron Corporation filed a Federal lawsuit today opposing a ban on using tankers to ship crude from the offshore Point Arguello oilfield to Southern California refineries.

title: Tunisia Arrests 300 Muslims, Charging Plot to Stage Coup
description: Security forces have arrested nearly 300 Muslim militants, including 100 army men, who planned to overthrow the Tunisian Government and create an Islamic state, Interior Minister Abdallah Kallel said today.

title: 2 College Presidents With 2 Pied-a-Terre
description: A COLLEGE president, the old saw goes, is someone who lives in a big house and begs. So what happens when two college presidents are married to each other? They live in two big houses, they both beg, they serve as co-hosts to nearly 20,000 visitors each year and they know they must someday leave their jobs and move out.

title: Cubs Go for a Joy Ride on Viola's Meal Ticket
description: The change-up is Frank Viola's ticket to success. Last night, the Cubs punched that ticket, over and over again, until Viola's night was all but torn apart.

title: U.S. and Soviets Near Settling Arms Pact Dispute
description: The United States and the Soviet Union today moved toward agreement on resolving differences over a treaty cutting non-nuclear armed forces in Europe.

title: Youth Arrested and Father Is Sought in a Bronx Killing
description: A 16-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and charged in the death of a Bronx homeowner who surprised two burglars on Monday, the police said.

title: Panel Votes Particle Smasher Cut
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted today to cut $100 million from next year's budget for a giant particle accelerator planned in Texas and eliminated $43.5 million to begin upgrading an older accelerator in Illinois.

title: Penguins Can't Rely On Mario
description: IF hockey were basketball, everybody would be comparing Mario Lemieux to Cap'n Willis Reed dramatically hobbling out of the locker room to help the Knicks beat the Lakers in the 1970 National Basketball Association finals.

title: DEFECT IN SHUTTLE IS TERMED SERIOUS
description: NASA narrowly avoided a potential disaster by removing a leaky fuel temperature sensor from the shuttle Columbia last fall, a manager for the program said today. An analysis this week showed dangerous cracks.

title: Black Cable TV Service Starts Magazine Drive
description: Black Entertainment Television, the first and only cable television service aimed at a black audience, is seeking to become a media leader among black readers as well as black viewers.

title: 2 Bank Companies Price Offerings of Preferred Stock
description: The First Chicago Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation priced a total of $400 million in preferred stock yesterday, part of a heavy supply of preferred stock that underwriters expect to come to market in the next few weeks.

title: Joe Franklin, Maestro of Mess, Moves It
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation has achieved a major triumph in its long and troubled campaign to clean up Times Square. This week its lawyers are forcing Joe Franklin to clean out his office.

title: Singapore Airlines Orders 4 Airbuses
description: Singapore Airlines Ltd. said it had placed orders for four more Airbus Industrie A310-300 aircraft worth $347 million, including spare parts and spare engines. The planes, two firm orders and two options, are scheduled for delivery in 1993 and 1994, the airline said in a statement. The Airbuses will be powered by the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney PW4152 jet engines, the same engines that are used on the current A310-300 fleet, Singapore Airlines said.

title: 2 Joining Senate Ethics Panel
description: Two Democratic senators, Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, were named to the Senate Ethics Committee today. The panel can now vote on whether to recommend that the full Senate act on the case of Senator Alan Cranston, a California Democrat accused of ethics violations for his relationship with Charles H. Keating Jr., a savings and loan executive. Mr. Bingaman succeeds Senator David Pryor of Arkansas, who resigned recently after a heart attack. Mr. Bryan will join th panel after the Cranston case, replacing Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama.

title: Lino Brocka, Dissident And Director, 52, Dies
description: Lino Brocka, a director whose films had a strong social content, died here early today. He was 52 years old.

title: Steelmakers' Grim Outlook For the Year
description: Executives of the nation's largest steel companies attending the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute conference here said today that the industry would lose tens of millions of dollars this year, making 1991 the worst year of industry losses since 1986, when the losses totaled $4 billion.

title: Books of The Times; A Don Pays the Price of Carelessness
description: Boss of Bosses The Fall of the Godfather: The F.B.I. and Paul Castellano By Joseph F. O'Brien and Andris Kurins Illustrated. 364 pages. Simon & Schuster.

title: Orion Revamping Riles Bondholders
description: IF the Orion Pictures Corporation were to make a movie about the extensive restructuring that it announced on Monday, its idea of a happy ending might prove to be different from that of many who have lent the troubled company money.

title: Dow Up 4.25, To 2,910.33; Volume Slips
description: I.B.M., which held the stock market back on Tuesday, gave it a strong lift yesterday as bargain hunters rushed to pick up what many felt was a good buy.

title: Johnson Warming Up
description: BEN JOHNSON, who was disqualified from a world-record victory in the 100-meter dash at the 1988 Olympics because he tested positive for steroids, will attempt that distance for the first time since then on Saturday at a meet in Granada, Spain. Johnson's appearance will serve as a warmup for a 100-meter race on May 30 in Seville, Spain, at which he is scheduled to run against CARL LEWIS , his main rival. . . . Meanwhile, Lewis testified yesterday in a Houston court that he drank one alcoholic beverage and one beer several hours before he was arrested on a drunken-driving charge on Jan. 10. Tests conducted at the police station showed Lewis had a blood-alcohol level of 0.12. In Texas, the legal intoxication limit is 0.10. "There was absolutely no way I was intoxicated," said Lewis, taking the stand in the third day of his trial. (AP)

title: Peter Buckley, Photographer and Writer, 52
description: Peter Buckley, a photographer, writer and editor, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 years old.

title: EX-ETHIOPIA CHIEF REACHES ZIMBABWE
description: The former Ethiopian ruler, Lieut Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, arrived here early today, apparently to begin his life in exile.

title: Judge Declines to Move Trial in Beating Case
