description: The judge in the case of four police officers accused of beating a motorist said today that he was troubled by a newspaper's publication of confidential information about the case but found that the breach of secrecy was not serious enough to move the trial out of Los Angeles.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WOODEN clapboard siding is durable and should last the life of a house. But individual pieces sometimes warp or crack, particularly on the side of a house hardest hit by storms. Such pieces should be promptly repaired to keep moisture from entering the walls and to prevent decay.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Harris L. Wofford, a onetime civil rights assistant to John F. Kennedy who has been appointed to the United States Senate, misstated the date of a telephone call by Mr. Kennedy to Coretta Scott King. The call, in which Mr. Kennedy, then a candidate for President, offered to help win the release of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from jail, was made on Oct. 26, 1960, not the previous year.

title:
CURRENTS;
Elegance of Old Vienna
description: THE Chicago Atheneum has just installed an exhibition of the Biedermeier style, showcasing the simple elegance of its handsomely crafted designs.

title: Boeing in Pact With Japanese
description: The Boeing Company said its Commercial Airplane Group had signed an agreement with Japanese airframe manufacturers to build major portions of the Boeing 777 wide-bodied twinjet. It said that Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries would design, manufacture and test components of the airframe and would share in market risk with Boeing.

title: How to Aim the Embargo Weapon
description: President Bush, who belittled the international embargo against Iraq as he pushed on to Desert Storm, now lunges for a new ultimate weapon in the Persian Gulf: the international embargo.

title: British Output Off Again
description: Britain's gross domestic product fell six-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter from the previous three-month period, the Government said today. It was the third straight drop in Britain's output of goods and services, extending the country's recession. Two consecutive quarterly declines officially indicate a recession. The seasonally adjusted production measure was down 2.5 percent from a year earlier.

title: Teheran Says U.S. Attacked a Patrol Boat
description: Iran said today that the United States Navy attacked an Iranian patrol boat in the Persian Gulf, wounding a sailor and damaging the vessel.

title: 3 Landscapers Plead Guilty In Kidnapping of L.I. Woman
description: Three landscapers on an Old Westbury estate pleaded guilty today to kidnapping a 47-year-old woman who lived there and holding her for $100,000 ransom before the police rescued her from a nearby hideout.

title: Baltimore Bancorp Adjournment
description: A group of dissident shareholders of the Baltimore Bancorporation, Maryland's fourth-largest banking company, said they had enough votes to take control of the company. Management adjourned the annual meeting, which had been scheduled for yesterday, until May 28 without counting votes. The adjournment "came at the suggestion of the Securities and Exchange Commission because of the confusion about the many proxies sent to shareholders," said Jerome P. Baroch, executive vice president at the Baltimore bank.

title: Marion Merrell Dow Job
description: The president of Marion Merrell Dow Inc., the phamaceuticals concern, will add chief executive to his title at the first of the year. Fred W. Lyons Jr. will succeed Joseph G. Temple Jr., 61 years old, who will stay on as chairman. Mr. Lyons, 55, had been president and chief executive of Marion Laboratories from 1984 until its merger with Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals at the end of 1989.

title: Move by S.E.C. Bars Mulheren
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., the stock speculator convicted of scheming with Ivan F. Boesky to manipulate the price of a stock, was banned from the securities industry today.

title: Deadlock Over Site for Talks On North Ireland Is Broken
description: A deadlock over the site for landmark talks about the future of Northern Ireland was broken today.

title: A Brazilian Gardener (Read That Artist) in Search of Paradise
description: TRY to get Roberto Burle Marx to expound on his Brazilian gardens while pictures of his most famous works are being hung in the Museum of Modern Art and photographers are asking for one more photograph and assistants are discussing the effect of towers of bromeliads ("more than 500 but less than 1,000," said Robert Jungles, a landscape architect who installed the jungle).

title: 2 Blacks in Denver Runoff; Gay Rights Bill Is Affirmed
description: Denver was assured its first black Mayor on Tuesday when two local black officials received the most votes in a nonpartisan mayoral election.

title: Gandhi's Widow Named Head of Party
description: Seeking a large sympathy vote, officials of the Congress Party stunned India today by choosing the Italian-born widow of their slain leader, Rajiv Gandhi, to succeed him as party president.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President ARPAD GONCZ of Hungary was in New York yesterday, beating the drum for American investment, meeting politicians and businessmen. But, being also a playwright and translator, he took time for breakfast on Tuesday with leading American writers at the home of the restaurateur GEORGE LANG, who is taking over Gundel's, Hungary's most famous restaurant.

title: In Canada, Grief Rather Than Blame
description: There was an outpouring of sorrow among the relatives of the four Jamaican immigrants to this Toronto suburb who died far from home in a freak collision with a truck in the Bronx on Monday. But the rituals of grief were missing.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Names A New York President
description: After operating without a president for the last year, Ogilvy & Mather's New York office announced yesterday that Rochelle Lazarus, who has been with the agency for 20 years, had been appointed to that post.

title: Demand for Notes Spurs Bond Selloff
description: An auction of $12.25 billion in new two-year Treasury notes went well yesterday, but after the results of the sale were announced, traders responded by selling longer-term notes and bonds.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Pact
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase, with the French companies Canal Plus and Compagnie General des Eaux, the television division of the W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. of Britain. The division includes the European Sport Network, a satellite television network; production operations, and a 19.6 percent interest in Yorkshire Television Holdings P.L.C. Capital Cities said its interest in the deal would be purchased through ESPN Inc., which is 20 percent owned by the Hearst Corporation.

title: Democrats Block G.O.P. Attack on Campaign Bill
description: Senate Democrats rejected a Republican effort today to remove the most important provisions of their campaign finance bill. But the action, in a replay of past clashes, may turn out to be little more than symbolic.

title: Education Nominee Endorsed
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved by voice vote today the nomination of David T. Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, to be Deputy Secretary of Education. Mr. Kearns, who is expected to be confirmed by the full Senate, acknowledged during the panel's hearings that in a book he wrote in 1988, he opposed what has become a central Bush Administration initiative: allowing poor children to attend private or parochial schools at Government expense. He told the committee that he now favored experimenting with such choice.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALEXANDER DICHTER is giving a piano recital at the Dalton School tonight. Sasha, as he is known, is a graduating senior who elected to perform in exchange for course credit.

title: Home Video
description: Increased Exposure

title: Fed Tells of Inquiry Into Bank Deal Involving Clifford
description: A senior official of the Federal Reserve Board told a Senate subcommittee today that the central bank was trying to determine how Federal regulators were misled in allowing a Luxembourg-based bank involved in money laundering to secretly gain control of a big bank in Washington.

title: South Korean Leader Names Prime Minister
description: President Roh Tae Woo named a new Prime Minister today in his latest attempt to end the violent protests that have plunged his Government into its worst political crisis.

title: Art in Review
description: Sherrie Levine Mary Boone Gallery 417 West Broadway (near Spring Street) Through June 29

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "When David Souter showed his true colors today, the majority of the Supreme Court put Roe v. Wade in immediate peril." -- Judith Lichtman, director of the Women's Legal Defense Fund.

title: Savings Case Legal Plea
description: Government regulators are unfairly trying to "put the thumbscrews" to the former chairman of Centrust Trust by keeping him from selling assets to pay legal fees, one of his lawyers argued today.

title: Tv Weekend
description: 'Hot Summer Winds' Channel 13 Tonight at 9

title: GTE to Cut 4,900 Jobs As It Absorbs Contel
description: GTE Telephone Operations, a unit of the GTE Corporation, said today that it would cut its work force by about 4,900 over the next four years because of GTE's recent merger with the Contel Corporation.

title: Art in Review
description: Jeanne Duval Sherry French Gallery 41 West 57th Street Through tomorrow

title: Auctions
description: German Expressionism Sale

title: Jobless-Benefit Claims Drop
description: The small drop in claims could indicate that if the recession is ending, the recovery is not a robust one, analysts said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Tough Day for Parker Al Parker, the Georgia Bulldogs' No. 1 player, ended his collegiate career in defeat in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's singles and doubles competition yesterday in Athens, Ga. Parker, who will graduate with a degree in finance with a 4.0 grade-point average, was defeated in the second round by Albert Chang, a Harvard junior who is no relation to the 1989 French Open champion, Michael Chang, 7-6, 6-2. Later in the day, Parker and Georgia teammate Patricio Arnold, lost to Scott Campbell and Dan Kronauge of Ball State, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, in the first round of doubles. The 20-year-old Chang is a former top Canadian junior from Calgary, Alberta.

title: Excerpts From Court Ruling Curbing Family Planning Clinics
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist yesterday in Rust v. Sullivan, upholding the Federal regulations that bar employees of federally financed family planning clinics from providing information about abortion. The majority opinion was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Sandra Day O'Connor, John Paul Stevens and Thurgood Marshall dissented. FROM THE OPINION By Chief Justice Rehnquist

title: Economist at Columbia Gets High GATT Post
description: Few economists anywhere in the world are more outspoken in their advocacy of free trade than Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati, or more prolific in writing about its merits. And seldom since World War II have there been greater difficulties in negotiating another round of reductions in tariffs and other trade barriers.

title: Penguins Close In on Cup but Emotions Don't Run Over
description: After they beat Minnesota, 6-4, tonight the Pittsburgh Penguins didn't behave like a team one victory away from a Stanley Cup championship.

title: Edwina Booth, 86; Actress Who Won Fame Due to Illness
description: Edwina Booth, an actress who made headlines in the 1930's when a mysterious illness ended her film career, died Saturday. She was 86 years old.

title: Macy's Sees Higher Sales Over 5 Years
description: Despite the dour retailing environment, R. H. Macy & Company told its suppliers this week that it expected sales to rise by 41.5 percent in five years, or to $10.5 billion a year from $6.8 billion in the current fiscal year. New-store openings, renovations and a credit-card solicitation program were cited as the main reasons for the expected higher sales.

title:
HOUSING IN NEW JERSEY;
A Bergen Suburb Gets Town Houses
description: While condominium town houses sprang up like wild flowers across much of the Northeast over the last decade, this Bergen County suburb remained untried. Now the borough of Norwood is bucking the trend and getting a town-house community at a time when the recession has staved off such projects elsewhere.

title: NASA Debates Removing Sensors on Shuttle
description: Engineers debated today whether to remove three of four temperature sensors in the space shuttle Columbia's hydrogen lines after cracks were found in a sensor that was removed earlier.

title: Executive to Oversee Revamping at I.B.M.
description: David E. McKinney, a senior vice president at I.B.M., has been selected for a special assignment to improve the efficiency of the company's business-support operations, those involving employees not directly engaged in the manufacture, development or sale of computers.

title: When Phone Rang For Nick Willhite
description: A ROOKIE left-hander with the Dodgers in 1963, he earned a World Series ring. But by the end of the 1967 season, his major league career was over.

title: A big Houston firm faces a malpractice charge because a legal brief wasn't brief enough.
description: Of all the oxymora in the English language, none may be as egregious as "legal brief."

title: Find a Better Way to Choose Vice Presidents; Harry Who?
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend
description: 'The Open Mind' Channel 13 Tomorrow at 11:30 A.M.

title: Restaurants
description: Le Regence

title: More and More Young Jews Are Picking Careers as Rabbis
description: Disenchanted with the prospect of careers in law, medicine and business -- and searching for something more satisfying and often as remunerative -- young American Jews are applying to rabbinical schools in record numbers.

title: Congress Party Is Scrambling to Deal With Its Dependence on One Family
description: In a burst of bravado this morning, the Congress Party newspaper, The National Herald, declared in a front-page editorial that the choice of Sonia Gandhi as party president "proves once again that in moments of crisis, only the Congress Party can within a space of a few hours elect a new leader -- a leader who symbolizes stability." The party, it said, "has shown that it has inner strength."

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Camping Out

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Singles and Doubles

title: Thomas R. Dash, Drama Critic, 93
description: Thomas R. Dash, a longtime drama critic for Women's Wear Daily, the garment-industry trade paper, died on Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Filly Tiara Beckons Meadow Star
description: The biggest and most important horse hotel in the country this weekend is Belmont Park, where 2,180 thoroughbreds are being housed, most of them as long-term guests, about 200 of them as performers in the 27 races on this three-day Memorial Day weekend. It is the weekend that tilts the axis of the racing world from Kentucky and Maryland to New York for Act III of the Triple Crown and three dozen other stakes races in the next two months.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Albert King's Blues

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Memborial Day Parade: Broadway between 72d and 86th Streets will be closed from 10 A.M. to noon. Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Office: Express mail and special delivery only. Main POst Office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue open. Banks: Closed Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No street sweeping or garbage collection. Schools: Closed Financial Markets: Closed Transportation: Subways and buses, L.I.R.R. and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Office: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit, Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government Offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Office: Express mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed Schools: Closed Transportaion: Metro-North New Haven line on holiday schedule. Weekend Traffic Alert: TOMORROW Turkish Parade: Madison Avenue will be closed from 47th to 55th Street and 47th Street will be closed from Madison to First Avenue from 2 P.M. to 5 P.M. Broadway Street Fair: The east side of Broadway will be closed from 75th to 86th rom 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. SUNDAY: Loisaida Street Fair: Avenue C from 3d to 10th Street will be closed from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. MONDAY: Second Avenue Street Fair: Second Avenue will be closed from 42d to 53d Street from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Senate Rejects Weicker's Plan For Income Tax
description: The Senate voted early today to reject the revenue overhaul and income-tax plan of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., passing instead a traditional $7.7 billion budget that would resolve Connecticut's fiscal crisis by broadening the sales tax and raising taxes overall by nearly $1 billion.

title: Art in Review
description: Alfonso Ossorio Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery 24 East 81st Street Through June 1

title: CHRONICLE
description: WALTER V. SHIPLEY , chairman and chief executive of the Chemical Bank, has accepted an award from the president of Columbia University, MICHAEL I. SOVERN : the Lawrence A. Wien Prize in Corporate Social Responsibility.

title: Smith Lawyers Try to Bar Discussion in Case
description: Defense lawyers have asked a Florida circuit court to bar prosecutors and the police from public discussion of the rape case against William K. Smith in Palm Beach.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: The Leisure Problem

title: Obsolete Politics in South Korea
description: What a difference four years make. In 1987, street protests by South Korea's radical students spurred Roh Tae Woo, then standard-bearer for a military regime, to initiate profound democratic changes. This year, protests have locked Mr. Roh, now President, and a student activist minority into a deadly, pointless confrontation.

title: Main Lebanese Militia Moves Weapons South
description: Lebanon's largest Christian militia, forced by the Government to disarm in Beirut and surrounding areas, has been moving its heavy weapons into Israeli-controlled territory in the south of the country, security officials said today.

title: Waiting for Riley: Knicks Hope Drama Ends Happily
description: Pat Riley checked into a Manhattan hotel last night, still not ready to accept the Knicks' offer to become their next head coach.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Review/Film; Finding Fun Amid Troubles With an Imaginary Friend
description: In "Drop Dead Fred," Phoebe Cates plays Elizabeth Cronin, a Minneapolis woman who is dumped by her philandering husband (Tim Matheson), loses her job as a court stenographer, and has her car and purse stolen, all in the space of an hour. Defeated, she moves in with her domineering mother (Marsha Mason), and on her first night back reunites with her imaginary childhood playmate Drop Dead Fred (Rik Mayall).

title: Evert Bows Out
description: CHRIS EVERT , a seven-time champion of the French Open who was scheduled to be part of the NBC broadcast team at the event, has had to surrender her television duties because of complications that have arisen in her pregnancy. Evert and her husband, ANDY MILL , are expecting their first child in October.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Wednesday misstated fees to be charged for television commercials by composers represented by Killer Music. Composers' fees were not disclosed but will not be $500,000. The commercials' budgets will generally be $500,000 or more.

title: Why Drugs cost More in U.S.
description: Americans pay some of the world's highest prices for their prescription drugs. While other governments usually negotiate prices, the United States has traditionally let companies decide for themselves what to charge.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE -- Named Ricky Clemons supervisor for business and international partners, effective June 3. American League AL -- Suspended Jack McDowell, Chicago White Sox pitcher, and Mark Whiten, Toronto Blue Jays outfielder, three games for fighting in a game May 19. BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Fired Frank Robinson, manager, and reassigned him within the organization. Named Johnny Oates manager. TEXAS RANGERS -- Signed Eric Nolte and Drew Hall, pitchers, and assigned them to Oklahoma of the American Association. BASKETBALL National Basketball Association HOUSTON ROCKETS -- Signed Don Chaney, coach, to a multi-year contract. United States Basketball League LONG ISLAND SURF -- Signed John Potter, guard. World Basketball League DAYTON WINGS -- Activated Claudio Coldebella, guard. Placed Kenneth Ray Brooks, guard, on injured reserve. MEMPHIS ROCKERS -- Activated Baskerville Holmes, forward. FOOTBALL National Football League DENVER BRONCOS -- Named Riley Odoms as a coaching intern during training camp. NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS -- Signed Bryan Wagner, punter, and Ronnie Lippett, cornerback. Canadian Football League BRITISH COLUMBIA LIONS -- Signed Zock Allen, linebacker, and Maurice Smith, defensive back. World League Of American Football BARCELONA DRAGONS -- Signed Brad Quast, linebacker. NEW YORK-NEW JERSEY KNIGHTS -- Signed Rod Holder, center. ORLANDO THUNDER -- Signed Dewaine Jones, fullback, and Richard Smith, cornerback. SAN ANTONIO RIDERS -- Signed Terrence Cooks, linebacker.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: From Across the Way

title: ETHIOPIANS REJOICE AS REBELS CLOSE IN
description: Thousands of Ethiopians poured into the streets of Addis Ababa today to sing and to dance as Government construction crews pulled down a giant statue of Lenin and carried it away with two cranes.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Buon Giorno!

title: At the Movies
description: Protecting a Client

title: Corrections
description: A reportin the Pop Life column on Wednesday about Billboard, the music industry trade magazine, misstated the title of a Dolly Parton album. It is "Eagle When She Flies."

title: Education Data Subpoenaed
description: A House subcommittee yesterday subpoenaed all documents related to Education Secretary Lamar Alexander's decision last month to defer the reauthorization of one of the nation's leading college-accrediting agencies.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Exhausting Options

title: Miami Is Host With the Most
description: Miami, the site of six previous Super Bowls, was awarded a seventh today when National Football League owners voted to play Super Bowl XXIX there in 1995.

title: Toward Understanding Fractured Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Style Reveals Substance, or Lack, in Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: The World Walks By

title: 'Tar Beach'
description: To fly! To fly freely over the housetops and through the great glowing chains that hold the bridges up -- there isn't a child who doesn't dream of waking up one day with wings.

title: S. D. Moseley, 72, Football Star at Yale And Executive, Dies
description: Spencer Dumaresq Moseley, a transportation executive who was a football star at Yale and a former member of the Yale Corporation, the university's governing body, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Chicago. He was 72 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Bush Backing Seen for Station
description: The head of a Senate Appropriations subcommittee that controls the amount of money going to space projects said today that she had obtained "an all out commitment" from President Bush to persuade Congress to reverse a decision that would kill a proposed space station. "The President is very disturbed that the space station was zeroed out," said Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat. The House counterpart to that subcommittee recently denied the National Aeronautics and Space Administration the $2 billion it sought for the project.

title: Voting in Senate On Campaign Bill
description: Following is the 56-to-42 roll-call vote by which the Senate approved a Democratic-sponsored bill to overhaul the way Congressional elections are financed. A yes vote was a vote for the bill. Voting yes were 51 Democrats and 5 Republicans. Voting no were 5 Democrats and 37 Republicans. Alabama: Heflin (D) Yes; Shelby (D) No. Alaska: Murkowski (R) No; Stevens (R) No. Arizona: DeConcini (D) Yes; McCain (R) Yes. Arkansas: Bumpers (D) Yes; Pryor (D) Not Voting. California: Cranston (D) Yes; Seymour (R) No. Colorado: Brown (R) No; Wirth (D) Yes. Connecticut: Dodd (D) Yes; Lieberman (D) Yes. Delaware: Biden (D) Yes; Roth (R) No. Florida: Graham (D) Yes; Mack (R) No. Georgia: Fowler (D) Yes; Nunn (D) Yes. Hawaii: Akaka (D) Yes; Inouye (D) Yes. Idaho: Craig (R) No; Symms (R) No. Illinois: Dixon (D) Yes; Simon (D) Yes. Indiana: Coats (R) No; Lugar (R) No. Iowa: Grassley (R) No; Harkin (D) Yes. Kansas: Dole (R) No; Kassebaum (R) No. Kentucky: Ford (D) Yes; McConnell (R) No. Louisiana: Breaux (D) No; Johnston (D) No. Maine: Cohen (R) Yes; Mitchell (D) Yes. Maryland: Mikulski (D) Yes; Sarbanes (D) Yes. Massachusetts: Kennedy (D) Yes; Kerry (D) Yes. Michigan: Levin (D) Yes; Riegle (D) Yes. Minnesota: Durenberger (R) Yes; Wellstone (D) Yes. Mississippi: Cochran (R) No; Lott (R) No. Missouri: Bond (R) No; Danforth (R) No. Montana: Baucus (D) Yes; Burns (R) No. Nebraska: Exon (D) Yes; Kerrey (D) Yes. Nevada: Bryan (D) Yes; Reid (D) Yes. New Hampshire: Rudman (R) No; Smith (R) No. New Jersey: Bradley (D) Yes; Lautenberg (D) Yes. New Mexico: Bingaman (D) Yes; Domenici (R) No. New York: D'Amato (R) No; Moynihan (D) Yes. North Carolina: Helms (R) Not Voting; Sanford (D) Yes. North Dakota: Burdick (D) No; Conrad (D) Yes. Ohio: Glenn (D) Yes; Metzenbaum (D) Yes. Oklahoma: Boren (D) Yes; Nickles (R) No. Oregon: Hatfield (R) No; Packwood (R) No. Pennsylvania: Specter (R) No; Wofford (D) Yes. Rhode Island: Chafee (R) No; Pell (D) Yes. South Carolina: Hollings (D) No; Thurmond (R) No. South Dakota: Daschle (D) Yes; Pressler (R) Yes. Tennessee: Gore (D) Yes; Sasser (D) Yes. Texas: Bentsen (D) Yes; Gramm (R) No. Utah: Garn (R) No; Hatch (R) No. Vermont: Jeffords (R) Yes; Leahy (D) Yes. Virginia: Robb (D) Yes; Warner (R) No. Washington: Adams (D) Yes; Gorton (R) No. West Virginia: Byrd (D) Yes; Rockefeller (D) Yes. Wisconsin: Kasten (R) No; Kohl (D) Yes. Wyoming: Simpson (R) No; Wallop (R) No.

title: A Correction: On Gorbachev Aid Plea for Billions
description: The New York Times and some other publications misunderstood a hypothetical reference by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in a news conference on Wednesday and mistakenly reported that he had made a specific request for $100 billion in aid from the West.

title: TV Weekend
description: 'Damon Wayans: The Last Stand' HBO Tomorrow at 10 P.M.

title: Do as We Say
description: Kuwait's trials of supposed collaborators this week were travesties by Western standards of law. The defendants were not confronted with any evidence against them, and their lawyers had no chance to question witnesses. An American diplomat said the convicted men were "railroaded."

title: India Ponders Gandhi Dynasty's Future
description: Stricken with grief and uncertainty, members of India's first family gathered today for the funeral of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi while friends said the dynasty would continue to play a major role in India.

title: Douglas Redesign For C-17 Jet's Tail
description: The Douglas Aircraft Company is redesigning major sections of the tail on its new C-17 military cargo jet to bolster weak spots detected recently, a spokesman for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation unit said. The corrections are being made just five weeks before the scheduled first flight of the C-17, but Douglas expects no major delays, said the spokesman, Jim Ramsey.

title: Art in Review
description: Beverly Buchanan Bernice Steinbaum Gallery 132 Greene Street Through June 11

title: U.S., Seeking Negotiations, Warns Iberia of Suspension
description: The Department of Transportation threatened yesterday to suspend the right of Iberia Airlines to serve Miami and New York from Madrid because the Spanish Government has not allowed American Airlines and United Airlines to fly there from the United States.

title: Factories' Orders Up Last Month
description: Orders for durable goods from American factories climbed 2.9 percent in April, the Commerce Department said today. The rise, the first in four months, was seen as further evidence that the economy has begun to stabilize.

title: Art in Review
description: Scott Kelley Michael Walls Gallery 137 Greene Street Through June 1

title: Kurds, Fed but Fearful, Still Dubious on Future
description: They sell fresh eggs and tomatoes now on the mountain slopes where only recently the Kurds went hungry and counted their dead.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: A Village Stroll

title: The Council and the Sidewalk Cafe: Business as Usual
description: The New York City Council met yesterday in the unfamiliar glare of public attention and in typical unruly fashion passed a few bills, gave a member a medal for valor and approved a permit for a sidewalk cafe owned by its Speaker's orthopedic surgeon.

title: Coney Island Landmark Must Not Be Destroyed
description: To the Editor:

title: Crum & Forster Leaving Canada
description: Crum & Forster Inc., the insurance holding company subsidiary of Xerox Financial Services Inc., said that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Canadian companies to the General Accident Assurance Company of Canada. Crum & Forster said that the net written premiums of its Canadian companies in 1990 totaled about $67 million (Canadian), or $58 million (United States), which represented 2 percent of Crum & Forster's volume for the year.

title: Playoff Home Teams Call the Shots
description: In the first 44 years of the National Basketball Association playoffs, the home team prevailed in two thirds of the games. Nothing has changed in the current playoffs. The tally is 38-19, a winning percentage of .667, in favor of the home teams.

title: Can Nameless Jurors Be Impartial?
description: At the request of Federal prosecutors, the judges in two racketeering and narcotics trials of members of the notorious Chicago gang El Rukn have ordered that the jurors' names be kept secret, to protect them from harassment or retaliation.

title: Justices Limit Use of Extortion Law Against Officials Getting Contributions
description: The Supreme Court today limited the circumstances under which the Federal law against extortion can be used to prosecute elected officials who accept campaign contributions from people seeking to influence their vote.

title: Review/Theater; Singing, Dancing and Stolen Jewels
description: One might expect Indiana Jones to swagger into the nightclub, be served an explosive cocktail and bash a few foes before embarking on his journey to the Temple of Doom. Indy never arrives, but there is a floor show, "Song of Singapore," that sends out an entertainment S O S to all fans of 1940's B-movie melodrama. The show, which opened last night in a lavishly redecorated club hall on Irving Place, is an amiably madcap musical sendup.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the perquisites of membership on the New York City Council misidentified a councilman who used district office funds to buy camera equipment. He was Jose Rivera, not Victor Robles.

title: More of the Same as Robinson Is Let Go
description: Two trends in major league baseball continued without letup yesterday as yet another manager was removed and yet another club overlooked some prominent former major league managers and chose to promote from within.

title: New Campaigns
description: * The Colgate-Palmolive Company, New York, is to begin a $26 million campaign next week for a reformulated toothpaste, New Colgate Tartar Control. The advertising, created by Young & Rubicam, New York, continues Colgate's current theme: "Because your smile was meant to last a lifetime." * General Motors Corp. is starting a corporate campaign focused on safety. A spread appears today in The New York Times on pages D10 and D11, and others are scheduled to run in USA Today and The Wall Street Journal, timed to appear just before the Memorial Day weekend. The tagline is: "Safety isn't one thing. It's everything." The campaign, created by the Detroit and New York offices of Ayer Inc., will continue in the summer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Gibson Greetings Inc., Cincinnati, has privately placed $50 million in 9.33 percent senior unsecured notes due 2001 through First Boston Corp. and Lazard Freres & Co.

title: President Is Reacting Coolly To Aid Plea by Gorbachev
description: President Bush said today that he was keeping "all options" open in his desire to spur Soviet economic reform, but he reacted coolly to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's suggestion that the industrialized democracies should help the Soviet Union financially.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For his debut on the concert stage, Associate Justice HARRY A. BLACKMUN of the Supreme Court will exchange his robes for a tailcoat to narrate "Peter and the Wolf" with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra. HUGH WOLFF will conduct the orchestra for the concerts on June 7, 8 and 9 in St. Paul.

title: Review/Art; Sleek Video Sculptures By Shigeko Kubota
description: In Shigeko Kubota's video sculpture, rapid-fire images, sleek geometries, Mylar surfaces, everyday objects and even falling water create an effect that is part fun house and part cutting edge. The retrospective of this veteran avant-garde artist's work at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, is an alternately entertaining and challenging show, and one that often seems to convey the very essence of artistic experimentation.

title: Valenzuela Draws Fans
description: The jury is still out on FERNANDO VALENZUELA'S pitching following his debut in the California Angels' organization, but there is no question that he's still boffo box office.

title: Apple Broadens Attack In Copyright Lawsuit
description: In a surprise move, Apple Computer Inc. has opened a new line of attack in its copyright infringement lawsuit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard by asking the court to rescind a 1985 licensing agreement between Apple and Microsoft.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on March 12 about the "traveling salesman" problem in mathematics -- finding the shortest path around a group of cities -- misstated the product of 100 X 99 X 98 and so on. The product is about 10 to the 158th power.

title: Hachette Official Leaves
description: Hachette S.A., the French publisher, said today that the head of its book division had stepped down over "policy differences." Jean-Claude Lattes will be replaced by Jean-Louis Lisimachio, the company said. Hachette did not give details of the departure of Mr. Lattes, who headed the book division for 12 years, but people close to the publishing group said difficulties with Hachette's Grolier unit might have been responsible for his departure.

title: Review/Film; 'Backdraft,' Firefighting Spectacular
description: "Backdraft" is undoubtedly the biggest, fanciest firefighting movie ever made, although the question of why this subject should lend itself to such extravagant treatment remains unanswered. Crammed with impressive pyrotechnics, this technically ambitious film observes the firefighter's life with boyishly awestruck fascination. There is about "Backdraft" so much of the wish-I-could-be-a-fireman-when-I-grow-up spirit, in fact, that the occupation itself manages to take center stage. As with last summer's "Days of Thunder," an equally big and much less successful film about race-car drivers, the job and its ambiance seem to come first, with character and story line reduced to secondary considerations.

title: Soviets Protest Bonn Arrest of Leaders in East
description: The Soviet Union has formally protested the arrest of senior leaders of the former East Germany this week, saying there were no grounds for criminal prosecution of them for actions taken against the backdrop of the cold-war, officials here said today.

title: Inmate Is Executed for Role in Prison Siege
description: An inmate was executed early today for his part in an 11-day prison siege that left four people dead.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: On Two Wheels

title: Attempt to Unjam Antenna On Galileo Spacecraft Fails
description: An attempt to deploy the Galileo spacecraft's jammed antenna by warming it in direct sunlight for 48 hours has apparently failed, mission officials said yesterday.

title: The Sport That Roars
description: THEY call basketball the city game. But on this, the weekend of the Indianapolis 500, the biggest event in auto racing, consider how much that sport has in common with life in New York City: speeding traffic, noise and omnipresent danger lurking in the background.

title: Summer: A User's Manual
description: "SUMMERTIME and the living is easy," goes the grand old Gershwin song. So remember being 7 years old and wearing a new pair of sneakers and flying as if there's no tomorrow. Remember the perfumes of suntan lotion, hot dogs roasting and an outboard motor on a little old fishing boat. Remember being forever young and school finally being out and summer starting. Remember the exact feeling in your fingers when bat properly meets ball.

title: From Sub to Sublime: No-Hitter for Phillies' Greene
description: Tommy Greene, a substitute starter on a Philadelphia Phillies staff best known for wild pitches, pitched the second no-hitter of the season yesterday, putting major league pitchers 10 days ahead of last year's pace that created a record nine no-hitters.

title: Art in Review
description: Michael Tetherow Jason McCoy Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through June 1

title: INSIDE
description: A Positive Economic Sign Orders for durable goods -- ranging from computers to tractors -- rose 2.9 percent in April, suggesting that the economy is stabilizing. Page D1. Professors and Retirement

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a settlement between the Federal Government and a group of children who said they were abused at a West Point day-care center misstated the number of children who will receive payments. It is nine, not eight.

title: Review/Film; The True Story Of a Girl, a Horse, A Diving Board
description: Many of the scenes in "Wild Hearts Can't Be Broken," a sweet, old-fashioned movie about a girl who loves horses, are bathed in a soft golden light. That's because the past, in movies of this sort, is always more magical than the present, even if that past is the Depression, the era of this G-rated family picture.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices finished lower today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues lost 114.51 points, or less than 1 percent, to 25,529.14. At midday, the index was down 103.66 points, to 25,539.99. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 244.99 points.

title: TV Weekend
description: 'Memorial: Letters From American Soldiers' Channel 11 Tomorrow at 11:30 P.M.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Serious Browsing

title: Merck's View on Prices
description: P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck & Company, the world's largest drug concern, has called on pharmaceutical executives to adopt "responsible pricing and distribution practices." He added, "If the price is too high and the patient cannot afford the medicine, we have not fulfilled our reason for existence." Dr. Vagelos said in article published today in Science magazine that the pharmaceutical industry, "more than perhaps any other, be responsive to social needs." He said the industry was threatened by possible regulation that would "reduce the potential for the profits" to support research.

title: Rutgers President Defends Codes That Prohibit 'Hate Speech'
description: Rutgers University's new president, Francis L. Lawrence, defended campus codes outlawing so-called "hate speech" and harassment of students based on their race, religion and sexual orientation at the university's 225th commencement yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: TV Weekend; Of India and Its Tragic Dynasty
description: The assassination of Rajiv Gandhi in India on Tuesday is a cruel punctuation to "Life and Death of a Dynasty." The 90-minute documentary on India's turbulent politics, tonight at 9 on Channel 31 and at 10 on Channel 13, focuses on Jawaharlal Nehru, his daughter Indira Gandhi and her son Rajiv Gandhi, who ruled modern independent India for 39 of its 43 years. Mr. Gandhi's widow, Sonia, who was chosen to succeed him as head of the Congress Party but declined, appears briefly on the program.

title: Who Takes the Rap? For Mets, Just Follow The Pointing Fingers
description: There was a lot of finger-pointing in the Mets' clubhouse when it was over. Kevin Elster pointed his finger at himself. Dave Magadan pointed his at himself. Manager Bud Harrelson pointed his fingers at his temples and began massaging the pain

title: Assets Back Large Offer
description: Asset-backed securities totaling nearly $500 million dominated the corporate market yesterday in two large offerings.

title: Flour Tax refund Will Improve Net
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that it will receive a Federal income tax refund, plus interest, that will add more than $12 million, or 14 cents a share, to second-quarter net income. The refund resolves a tax dispute between Fluor's St. Joe Minerals unit and the Internal Revenue Service for the tax years 1975 through 1981.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: A Western Spur to Soviet Reform
description: After a brief but bloody bow to reaction, the Soviet President, Mikhail Gorbachev, seems to be reviving radical reform. He has struck an agreement with 9 of the 15 Soviet republics to decentralize political and economic power. He's giving license to reformers who want to move rapidly to markets. And now he wants to press his case for Western aid on a doubtful Group of Seven industrialized nations in mid-July.

title: Market Place; Focus of Attention In Biotechnology
description: THE stocks of two biotechnology companies one the darling of Wall Street analysts and the other an outcast -- could benefit from a cancer conference held this week in Houston.

title: Review/Film; When Mom Is a Monster And Her Boy Meets a Girl
description: Danny Muldoon (John Candy) may not be someone only a mother could love, but he is no one's idea of a romantic leading man. And as it happens, Danny has a mother (Maureen O'Hara) who does love him, so much that it hurts. This has contributed immeasurably to Danny's isolation from other women.

title: Nuclear Waste Issue Remains Unresolved
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders Disputes Arrest
description: According to DEION SANDERS, the same officer that ticketed him for an illegal lane change earlier in the week is the one that spotted his Corvette outside a supermarket on Wednesday night and arrested him just hours after he had been optioned to the Braves' Richmond farm club. The Braves outfielder said he and his wife had stopped at the store on their way home from Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium to buy thank-you cards for his teammates who had given him a warm, rousing sendoff in the locker room. (AP)

title: Thomas J. Hughes, Judge, 79
description: Thomas J. Hughes, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died on Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 79 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Key Rates
Williams Wins Case
description: Former Washington Redskins quarterback DOUG WILLIAMS , whose career was ended by a back injury in 1989, has been awarded a workers' compensation package worth nearly $1 million. (AP)

title: Books of The Times; Inspecting the Ruins Of a Contemporary Life
description: Jernigan By David Gates 238 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Bridgestone Yen
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said today that it would sell 190 billion yen for dollars by the end of this month to increase its investment in its wholly owned United States unit Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. At current exchange rates, 190 billion yen would bring in about $1.38 billion. Currency dealers said the move should help limit the dollar's downside against the yen. Some dealers said the company might have bought some dollars in Tokyo on Wednesday, when the dollar stayed well below 138.00 yen.

title: Democrats Offer 'Action Plan' for Recession
description: Democratic Congressional leaders today proclaimed an "action plan" for dealing with both the 11-month-old recession and long-term economic growth but conceded that they had no timetable and few specifics to support the effort.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Babcock & Wilcox, a unit of McDermott International Inc., New Orleans, an offshore drilling equipment and services company, has been awarded a $180 million contract to build a process recovery facility to support the James River Corp.'s Naheola mill in Pennington, Ala. * CPI Corp., St. Louis, an operator of photo laboratories, said it would open at least 25 new photo studios in Sears, Roebuck & Co. stores this year and next year.

title: Twice Killed, Once Dead: Drug Suspect Dies for Real
description: Michael Johnson died twice.

title: Head of Base Panel Ends Consulting Link
description: In an abrupt about-face, the chairman of the commission reviewing military base closings, former Representative Jim Courter, said today that he had canceled his $3,000-a-month consulting contract with the Grumman Corporation, a leading military contractor.

title: Chaney Selected As Top N.B.A. Coach
description: DON CHANEY, who guided the Houston Rockets to the best record in the history of the franchise, 52-30, was awarded the Auerbach Trophy as the National Basketball Association coach of the year yesterday. Chaney received 69 of a possible 96 votes, a landslide victory over the runner-up, RICK ADELMAN of Portland. (AP)

title: Vrooom! Live From Indy, It's The 500
description: O.K., time to confess your dirty little TV secret. You used to watch the Indianapolis 500 on tape delay. It didn't matter that the race had been over for six hours or that it was night outside and day on your screen.

title: Art in Review
description: Brice Marden Matthew Marks Gallery 1018 Madison Avenue (at 78th Street) Through June 28

title: Banking Overhaul Bill Clears a Big Hurdle
description: The Bush Administration's plan to free the banking industry of decades-old restrictions cleared a significant hurdle today when a Congressional panel unanimously voted to send it to the House Banking Committee, suggesting that it might be politically possible to reshape the banking industry this year.

title: Recession Hits Home In the City Of Excess
description: Moshe Pereg knew he was really in trouble when it came to be less than a week before Mother's Day and hardly a customer stirred in his jewelry shop on South Beverly Drive. He sold no $32,000 diamond-encrusted emerald rings, and hardly any $100 trinkets.

title: Memphis Builds a Pyramid, But Could Use Tips From Pharaohs
description: For two years this city, which took its name from ancient Egypt, has lived with the expectation that a monumental steel and glass pyramid would rise and become the clarifying symbol of Memphis, just as the Empire State Building symbolizes New York.

title: The Media Protest Too Much
description: Washington editors for 15 major American news organizations sent a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney early this month complaining about press restrictions during the gulf war and criticizing the Pentagon for wielding "virtually total control" over coverage. Blaming the Pentagon for the quality of war reportage is convenient for journalists who may feel embarrassed that reporters more often resembled Government stenographers than news-gatherers.

title: Despite Correcting Its Error, Newspaper Loses Libel Case
description: A state court jury in Chicago has awarded nearly $2.25 million in libel damages to a business executive for an erroneous statement that appeared in a 1976 article in The Wall Street Journal, although the paper published a correction the next day.

title: No Firings, No Sale, No Big Deal: Quiet Meeting by Yankee Partners
description: By the time the Yankee owners concluded their quarterly meeting today at an airport hotel here, the only apparent news was what they didn't do.

title: Warning on Suicide in Prozac Use Is Sought
description: Patients and doctors should get a stern warning about the risk of suicidal impulses for those taking Prozac, the nation's best-selling antidepressant, a health group said today.

title: Files Show East Germans Forced Adoptions
description: Communist East Germany confiscated children from political offenders in the 1970's and handed them over for adoption to approved families, according to documents made public today.

title: Death Penalty Passes, But Not by Two-Thirds
description: The State Assembly today approved a bill that would reinstate the death penalty in New York, but the margin of votes was two short of the two-thirds total needed to override a promised veto from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. He has rejected death-penalty measures in every year of his tenure.

title: U.S. Issues Warning of Obstacles In Adopting Romanian Children
description: Americans seeking to adopt Romanian children were warned by the State Department today that they face formidable legal obstacles both in this country and in Romania, where foreign adoptions are to be suspended pending completion of new legislation.

title: Some Clinics Plan to Advise And Forgo Aid
description: Officials at the South Bronx health clinic that challenged the Federal ban on abortion counseling and at many other family-planning programs around the nation said they would continue to provide abortion information even though the Supreme Court's decision yesterday meant they would lose Federal financing.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about C. Harold Kidwell, founder of the Reduction Engineering Corporation of Newark, included a number of errors in a listing of survivors provided by the family. His widow is the former Nora Middleton. Sara Swann Miller is his daughter, not his stepdaughter. He had 12 grandchildren and 3 great- grandchildren.

title: People
description: * Ketchum Advertising/New York has named Richard Ostroff senior vice president-group creative director and John Brockenbrough vice president-associate creative director. Both had worked previously at Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, New York. * Louis Killefer has been named senior vice president and group director at Ammirati & Puris, New York. He had held a similar position at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, New York. * Barbara Lippert, advertising critic for the trade publication Adweek, has been named the 1991 Communicator of the Year by the New York chapter of the Business/Professional Advertising Association.

title: Security-Force Pact Is Settled With Iraq, Official at U.N. Says
description: The United Nations and Iraq signed an agreement in Baghdad today allowing 400 to 500 United Nations security guards to move into northern Iraq.

title: Bronx Police Unit Suspected Of Robbing Drug Dealers
description: A Bronx police officer has been arrested on charges that he stole jewelry from an undercover agent posing as a drug dealer, and the police are investigating accusations that at least seven other Bronx officers regularly stole money and drugs from dealers.

title: Murdoch Pact With K-III Is Signed
description: The much-heralded agreement for the sale of nine publications owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation Ltd. to K-III Holdings for $650 million was signed Wednesday evening. The sale itself is expected to take place next month.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Jockeying for Position at the Tonys

title: Senior Kuwaiti Military Officers Demand Ouster of 2 Cabinet Aides
description: A group of senior Kuwaiti military officers has sent the Emir a letter demanding the investigation and dismissal of two senior Government ministers for their roles in the days leading up to the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2, Kuwaitis familiar with the letter say.

title: Panel Backs Arctic Drilling, But Not Fuel-Efficient Cars
description: In a move attacked by environmentalists, the Senate Energy Committee approved a national energy bill today that would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas drilling and would not require auto makers to build more fuel-efficient cars.

title: Our Towns
description: The clerks see them coming across the parking lot. They start preparing the customers' favorite items. Then the customers, some of them struggling with age or physical ailments, come through the door.

title: Review/Film; Homeboys Hangin' Downtown
description: New York City after dark has rarely looked as enticingly cheesy as it does in Joseph B. Vasquez's "Hangin' With the Homeboys," which follows the comic misadventures of four buddies from the South Bronx over a long, hot summer night. As they prowl the streets of their neighborhood in search of excitement, and then descend on Manhattan, everything from the girls they ogle, to the discos, pool halls, peep shows and subway stations they visit, shimmers with a dangerous, alluring mystery.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Drops 10.29, to 2,900.04
description: Stocks drifted yesterday in relatively brisk trading as investors continued to lighten their holdings before the Memorial Day weekend. Program selling was particularly strong.

title: The Easygoing Portuguese? Steer Clear of Them
description: The Portuguese have the reputation of being a quiet, law-abiding and introverted people who even in times of political turmoil go out of their way to avoid using violence. But, mysteriously, when they get into their cars, they turn aggressive and dangerous.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Swing at Roseland

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE, Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street, Manhattan. "House of Heritage," a lecture with slides on the history of the museum and the surrounding area. Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission: $2. Information: (212) 431-0233.

title: It's a Thrill Every Minute With Sax at Third Base
description: Probably no one will ever remember the careers of Mike O'Berry and Jeff Moronko as Yankee third basemen, but it's likely that no one will ever forget Steve Sax.

title: TV Weekend
description: 'Return of the 211th' C-Span Today at noon

title: Diner's Journal
description: East Side Spanish

title: George Kaminsky, Lawyer, 84
description: George Kaminsky, a lawyer in Manhattan for more than 40 years and a former New York State Assemblyman, died on Thursday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 84 years old.

title: Recession? Can't Get Enough of It!
description: There is clearly no recession in advertisements with recession-related themes. Anyone unaware that the economy has been in a slump since July need only watch television or leaf through a newspaper to learn all about it -- not from the news, but from the ads.

title: National Research Council Opposes Retirement Age for Professors
description: A special committee of the National Research Council yesterday recommended that teachers be allowed to teach as long as they are able. Specifically, the group said a law allowing universities to force professors to retire at age 70 should be phased out as scheduled in 1994.

title: Bush Backs Baker View of Mideast Peace Barriers
description: A group of senators harshly chastised Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today for his contention that nothing has more complicated his peacemaking efforts in the Middle East than Israel's expansion of settlements in the occupied territories.

title: Nathan J. Goldrich, Lawyer, 88
description: Nathan J. Goldrich, a retired lawyer and certified public accountant, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Bad Abortion Advice, Court-Approved
description: The Supreme Court has now ruled that the Government has the power to pressure clinics to hide information or even mislead poor pregnant women about their right to choose whether or not to bear a child. That's bad enough as a moral and constitutional matter, but the Court did more. It held that Congress has actually authorized the Department of Health and Human Services to promote this coercive, unprofessional assault on a woman's rights.

title: The Clark Bar Finds a Buyer
description: The Clark Bar, the 105-year-old candy bar that was on the road to extinction, was saved today by a local restaurateur who agreed to buy the struggling confection concern from its Finnish parent.

title: More Ford Layoffs, A Newspaper Says
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to lay off 200 more white-collar workers as part of a $3 billion cost-cutting program, according to The Detroit News. The layoffs will be in Ford's North American Automotive Operations division, the newspaper quoted an unidentified top company official as saying. A Ford spokesman, Dick Routh, had no immediate comment.

title: HOUSE VOTE BACKS BUSH'S AUTHORITY ON TRADE ACCORDS
description: In a vote that was divided as much on regional as party lines, the House of Representatives today authorized the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a 108-nation pact to lower international trade barriers.

title: Budget Deal Is Doubtful By Deadline
description: Too divided to respond to a political crisis they themselves helped contrive, the state's legislative leaders today conceded that it was unlikely that they would have a budget in place by Saturday, the deadline Mayor David N. Dinkins has set for New York City to avert serious cash-flow problems.

title: Economic Scene; The Lab's Role In U.S. Growth
description: AMERICA'S research universities are under increasing pressure to find ways to strengthen the United States position in international trade, spur the nation's lagging economic growth and avoid giving the fruits of scientific and technological progress to foreign competitors.

title: Art in Review
description: Leon Golub Brooklyn Museum 200 Eastern Parkway Through June 16

title: Peter Rogers Ends Affiliation
description: A six-month-old affiliation agreement between Peter Rogers Associates, New York, and Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, ended yesterday with Mr. Rogers taking back his premium fashion accounts, which he will again handle independently.

title: Lewis Found Not Guilty
description: Six-time Olympic gold medalist CARL LEWIS was found not guilty on a drunken driving charge by a jury in Houston, which deliberated the case for more than three hours yesterday. Lewis was arrested in January by two Houston police officers and could have been sentenced to a maximum two years in jail and a $2,000 fine if he had been convicted of the charge. (AP)

title: New York's Top Uniformed Officer to Retire
description: Robert J. Johnston Jr., a member of the New York City police force for 39 years and for the last seven years chief of the department, its highest uniformed rank, announced yesterday that he intended to retire this year.

title: Pan Am Warns It May Fail
description: The Pan Am Corporation, which filed in January for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors, has told the Government that it has doubts about whether it can survive through the end of the year.

title: Wendy Jo Serko Weds P. C. Lewis
description: Wendy Jo Serko, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Serko of Muttontown, L.I., was married yesterday at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Peter Charles Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Lewis of Los Angeles. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony.

title: TV Weekend
description: 'Stanley Jordan' Bravo Tonight at 10

title: Girls Don't Need TV
description: To the Editor:

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: A Tight Schedule

title: Allison Barnett, A Student, Weds
description: Allison Barnett, a medical student, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan I. Seckler at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., by Rabbi Stanley Steinhart. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Barnett of Muttontown, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Stanley G. Seckler of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Dr. Seckler.

title: New Jersey Vote Weakens a Ban On Some Guns
description: Several hundred gun advocates demonstrated outside the Statehouse tonight as the New Jersey Assembly voted overwhelmingly to weaken a tough ban on assault weapons that it passed at Gov. Jim Florio's urging just a year ago.

title: Review/Film; On the Run With 2 Buddies And a Gun
description: "I DON'T remember ever feeling this awake!" exclaims one of the two freewheeling runaways of Ridley Scott's hugely appealing new road movie, as they race ecstatically across the American Southwest. Funny, sexy and quick-witted, these two desperadoes have fled the monotony of their old lives and are making up new ones on a minute-by-minute basis. Their adventures, while tinged with the fatalism that attends any crime spree, have the thrilling, life-affirming energy for which the best road movies are remembered. This time there's a difference: This story's daring anti-heroes are beautiful, interesting women.

title: Gay Bias Moves Off The Sidelines
description: THE locker room has closets of its own, deep and dark and crowded.

title: Father in Child-Abuse Case Calls Accuser, 14, Troubled
description: Kodzo Dobosu, adoptive father of 18 unwanted children, denied yesterday that he had sexually abused his 14-year-old adopted daughter, as she had charged.

title: Flawed Plan to Merge New York Ports Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Electronics Profits
description: Four big Japanese electronics companies today reported lackluster profits for the year ended March 31. They blamed intense competition for their performances, but cautiously forecast an improvement this year.

title: For Children
description: 'Access to Art: All Creatures Great and Small' Museum of American Folk Art 2 Lincoln Square Manhattan (212) 977-7298 Recommended ages: 2 and up Through June 16

title: Rolls Withdraws Worker Warning
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British airplane engine maker, agreed to withdraw letters it sent to its 34,000 employees threatening them with the loss of their jobs if they did not accept a pay freeze. Rolls-Royce said it had also agreed to hold talks with the unions about pay and job losses. The move followed talks between the company and union leaders, in which the union warned Rolls-Royce that its workers could take legal action for breach of contract.

title: The Ghosts of Suburbia
description: We moved into Highlands Ranch in the winter of 1988. Months earlier, the prairie had been scraped flat to make the neighborhood. Our house sat on a mud lot on the rise of a hill, looking out at the flank of the Rocky Mountains. The other houses at that end of the block were empty. The wind howled against the siding, rattled the windows, blew snow eddies under the garage door.

title: Review/Film Bruce Willis as a Hip Cat Burglar
description: Now and then, a Hollywood megabomb explodes with so much force that it actually sheds some light. "Hudson Hawk," a colossally sour and ill-conceived misfire, is at least a film from which someone may learn something, if only the hard way.

title: Critic's Choice; Otherworldly Sounds
description: A centerpiece of this year's Bang on a Can Festival is a Harry Partch program at Circle in the Square Downtown, 159 Bleecker Street, Manhattan. Partch, one of the great American iconoclasts, worked outside the standard forms and beyond standard instrumentation. He created an otherworldly orchestra of hybrid instruments with names like chormelodeon, harmonic canon, kithara, diamond marimba, spoils of war and cloud chamber bowls, and he worked in a microtonal scale divided into 43 tones, rather than the 12 of standard Western tuning.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambase Corp., New York, the parent company of the Home Group of insurance companies, named Richard A. Bianco president and chief executive. He was also appointed chairman, president and chief executive of Ambase's subsidiary Carteret Savings Bank, Parsippany, N.J. * Amoco Corp., Chicago, named Robert Cadieux executive vice president for strategic planning, environmental affairs and safety, and public and government affairs.

title: Gorbachev's Pleas for Aid Not Expected to Bear Fruit
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will not get more than a few billion dollars in aid from the economic summit meeting of industrial democracies here in July, Government officials and economic experts say.

title: New Front in Marijuana War: Business Records
description: In a continuing crackdown on the United States' No. 1 cash crop, marijuana, agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration requested the business records at retail outlets and distributors of high-technology gardening supplies around the country this week.

title: Funeral Set For Today
description: Rajiv Gandhi's funeral will be held on Friday on the rolling lawns of the memorial to his mother, Indira, near the banks of the Jamuna River and a short distance from the memorials to his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru, and his younger brother, Sanjay.

title: Israel Angered by Baker's Remarks on Settlements
description: Israeli leaders reacted angrily today to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's complaints about the expansion of Jewish settlements during his visits to the region.

title: A.L. Suspends Two
description: Outfielder MARK WHITEN of the Toronto Blue Jays and pitcher JACK MCDOWELL of the Chicago White Sox were suspended for three games each by American League president BOBBY BROWN for a fight Sunday after McDowell threw a pitch behind Whiten. McDowell immediately appealed the decision through the Major League Baseball Players Association, which means that his suspension will not take effect until after a hearing before Brown. (AP)

title: Vehicle Sales Rose by 4.8% In Midmonth
description: Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose by 4.8 percent in the middle of the month over the comparable period last year, when results were unusually weak because consumer incentives were expiring.

title: CHRONICLE
description: By donating the proceeds from her recording of "The Star-Spangled Banner" to the American Red Cross Gulf Crisis Fund, WHITNEY HOUSTON added about $500,000 to its coffers. The Red Cross, which had its annual convention this week in San Diego, has appointed Miss Houston to its board of governors.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Coney Island Jumble

title: Fiat-Soviet Deal
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian auto maker, said it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire 30 percent of the leading Soviet auto maker and increase that company's production. Fiat said financial terms had not yet been worked out in the deal with Volskij Avtomobilnij Zavod. The accord will replace an agreement Fiat signed in 1989 to take a 31 percent stake in the production of cars at a Soviet plant at Yelabug, 1,500 miles southeast of Moscow. The new preliminary agreement seeks to increase Volskij Avtomobilnij Zavod's production by 300,000 cars a year, to 1.05 million, through the joint development of a new mid-sized model, Fiat said.

title: Jacob Millman, Expert, On Radar, Dies at 80
description: Jacob Millman, an electrical engineer who took part in the development of radar systems, died on Wednesday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: As Albany Stalls a School District Sweats
description: There is nothing fancy or extravagant about the Hiawatha Elementary School, an overcrowded building where many desks are 25 years old and the 11 computers for 726 children are often broken.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Consider the amazing Davis family, OSSIE DAVIS, RUBY DEE and their son GUY DAVIS . Miss Dee's play, "The Disappearance," is now being performed at Brown University. Her new children's book, "The Tower to Heaven," was just published by Henry Holt & Company

title: Incaviglia Erases 0-for-11 Hex And Sends Clemens to 2d Loss
description: Pete Incaviglia, who had struck out in all 11 previous times at bat in his career against Roger Clemens, hit a go-ahead double in the seventh inning tonight and the Detroit Tigers beat the Boston Red Sox, 5-3.

title: More Work for Burnett From McCaw Cellular
description: A special project that the Leo Burnett Company has been working on for McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. is growing into a significant assignment.

title: Indy Qualifier Finds Corporate Sponsors Are Slow to Line Up
description: A $20 check arrived in the mail for Willy T. Ribbs this week at the Indianapolis Speedway. It came from two local seventh- and eighth-grade classes at St. Andrew Apostle School.

title: 5 JUSTICES UPHOLD U.S. RULE CURBING ABORTION ADVICE
description: In a broadly worded 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court today upheld Federal regulations that bar employees of federally financed family planning clinics from all discussion of abortion with their patients.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Keeping Cool

title: New Irregularities Found at A-Weapons Plants
description: The Secretary of Energy said today that an investigation by his department had found that potentially illegal spending practices by private contractors who operate nuclear weapon plants for the Government were pervasive in the industry.

title: Sonia Gandhi Declines Invitation To Assume Husband's Party Post
description: Sonia Gandhi, the widow of Rajiv Gandhi, rejected an offer today by the Congress Party to succeed her husband as its president, leaving the nation's largest political party in turmoil and deepening the political crisis here.

title: Find a Better Way to Choose Vice Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Tv Weekend
description: 'Don't Look Back' Cinemax Tonight at 8

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 553 money market mutual funds increased by $4.1 billion, to $469.34 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 202 institutional funds rose by $2.70 billion, to $136.82 billion. Assets of the 261 general-purpose funds were up by $501.0 million, to $179.70 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds' assets increased by $866.5 million, to $152.82 billion, the institute said.

title: Armco to Cut Jobs At Offices and Mills
description: Armco Inc. said it was cutting 70 corporate positions from its offices in Middletown, Ohio. The company also said that a few of its Middletown corporate functions would be consolidated and moved to Armco's New Jersey headquarters, but that the majority would be folded into the Armco Advanced Materials division in Butler, Pa.

title: Generals vs. Journalists, Cont.
description: There is a good deal of ill feeling among members of the media over how they were treated by the military during the Persian Gulf war. The feeling seems to be mutual. In an interview with David Frost, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf charged that during the war CNN was "aiding and abetting an enemy." His complaint is reminiscent of Lieut. Gen. William T. Sherman's vow that "I will never again command an Army in America if we must carry along paid spies."

title: Senate Approves Bill to Limit Campaign Spending
description: Bitterly divided along party lines, the Senate approved a broad campaign-finance package today that its supporters say will slow the escalating spending in Congressional campaigns and the influence of special interest contributors.

title: A User's Manual for Summer, a Season to Savor
description: Sleeping In

title: Accounts
description: * The Dial Corporation's Breck hair-care line to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss, New York, to reintroduce the Breck brands in advertising later this year. While neither Dial nor the agency would discuss billings, campaigns to restage hair-care products typically cost $8 million to $15 million a year. Dial said that under Breck's previous owner, the American Cyanamid Corporation, the Breck account was assigned to KCS&A Inc., New York. * Swarovski Jewelry U.S. Ltd., New York, a subsidiary of Daniel Swarovski Co., a manufacturer of crystal stones, to McCabe & Co., New York for the Swarovski and Savy lines of jewelry. The Swarovski company said the assignment was for a $4 million print campaign. The company said its incumbent agency was Connell, May & Stevenson Ltd., London.

title: NEW TIES TO DUTCH TEMPT SURINAMESE
description: When this small, ethnically diverse South American country gained sovereignty from the Netherlands in 1975, many here proudly considered it a shining model of a prospering democracy in a continent riddled with poverty and oppression.

title: Crime Proposal's Effect on Gun Use Is Questioned
description: Testifying in support of the Bush Administration's anticrime package, a senior official of the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that the proposed legislation would deter some criminals but do little to curb the availability of firearms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Bush Reappoints Gen. Powell to Top Military Post
description: Acting four months early, President Bush today reappointed Gen. Colin L. Powell of the Army to a second two-year term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The decision fulfilled General Powell's wishes to continue serving and at least temporarily spared the White House further speculation about the military leader's political future.

title: Nancy Corwin Is Married to Joel Malina
description: Nancy Corwin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Corwin of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Joel Malina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Malina of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Reuven Grodner performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale.

title: Endangered Species
description: Once upon a time, but not long ago, there was a species of turtle, soft yellow and tan, that could only live in mountain and high plateau.

title: Dealers Buy Notes, Sell Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed again yesterday, as dealers sold bonds and bought shorter-term notes and bills for the second straight session.

title: A Holiday for Remembering the War Dead and Just Relaxing
description: It is downright curious how other dimensions are imposed on holidays that were created for one purpose. Happy birthday to Washington and Lincoln means an orgy of consumerism that the Presidents had never envisioned. Thanksgiving Day is apotheosized in parades, New Year's Day in a pile-up of tackles. Memorial Day, which is Monday, has gentler overtones.

title: Actor Wins in Ring, But He Isn't Smashing
description: Actor MICKEY ROURKE scored a unanimous decision over STEVE POWELL Thursday night in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in his professional boxing debut, a match that combined pugilism, professional wrestling and a touch of Hollywood.

title: Campaignland, U.S.A.
description: After flirting with the idea for months, George McGovern declares he won't run for President after all, but the decision obviously pains him. Richard Nixon flattened him in 1972, when Watergate was still just a third-rate burglary. But then, and later, Mr. McGovern perfected rare campaign skills.

title: Wilhelm Kempff Is Dead at 95; German Was Romantic Pianist
description: Wilhelm Kempff, a German pianist esteemed for his lucid, searching interpretations of Romantic repertory, died on Thursday at his home in Positano, Italy. He was 95 years old.

title: Training Wheels for Adults? No, Try Helmets
description: There has been a nationwide push in the last five years to teach children about bicycle safety. But an increasing majority of cyclists are adults, many of whom are left to rely on the rules of the road and a touch of instinct when it comes to riding safely.

title: Conference on Black Males Finds Many Problems but No Consensus
description: In a recognition that the problems of black males need urgent attention, politicians, civil rights leaders and corporations held a three-day conference here this week that was long on laments but fell short of any consensus on what to do about those problems.

title: MGM-Pathe Plans Payment on Bonds
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company, the film unit of the Pathe Communications Company, said it would make scheduled interest payments of $26 million to bondholders on June 15. Bondholders of record on June 1 will receive interest payments on MGM-Pathe's 12 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 and the 13 percent debentures due in 1996.

title: Bridge
description: The Goldman Open Pairs, a prestigious event dating to 1929, begins today at 1 P.M. Play at the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center, where the Eastern Regional Championships continue.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: INSIDE
description: Attack on Abortion Ruling

title: Police Find Video of Killer
description: Investigators used a videotape to pinpoint the assassin who killed Rajiv Gandhi, but they have been unable to identify her, officials said today.

title: Water and Growth: Some Californians Want Less
description: In 1979, the voters of Santa Barbara, hoping to limit growth and keep their idyllic coastal city from becoming another Los Angeles, voted overwhelmingly not to connect to the State Water Project, the vital lifeblood of so many arid California cities.

title: G.M. Chief Urges Higher Gas Prices
description: The Federal Government should raise gasoline prices to push consumers toward more fuel-efficient cars and trucks, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: Hillary Simmers Is Married in Rye
description: Hillary Trehare Simmers, the daughter of Hugh Simmers of Darien, Conn., and Mrs. R. T. Sour of Rye, N.Y., was married last night to Philip Livingston Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr. of New York. The Rev. Donald Poole performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: For All Students, $40,000 Loans
description: The Federal student loan program is suffering from huge losses, fraud and abuse. Its future, as Senator Sam Nunn said this week, is "hanging in the balance."
