To reverse losses that have cost taxpayers nearly $13 million in eight years, according to a yearlong Senate investigation, Congress is likely to reform the program.

title: Attempt to Unjam Antenna On Galileo Spacecraft Fails
description: An attempt to deploy the Galileo spacecraft's jammed antenna by warming it in direct sunlight for 48 hours has apparently failed, mission officials said Thursday.

title: Thomas F. Fennell 2d, Arbitration Expert, 87
description: Thomas F. Fennell 2d, a retired lawyer who was an expert in labor arbitration, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: More Shuttle Safety Flaws Prompt NASA Inquiry
description: Concerned with lapses in flight safety procedures, space agency officials yesterday ordered a thorough investigation of the most recent malfunctions of the space shuttles to determine how potentially catastrophic flaws could have gone uncorrected for more than eight months.

title:
SPORTS LEISURE;
East Side, West Side, Bike Lanes All Around
description: Although an April 1990 survey by Bicycling magazine rated New York as the worst city in the country for bicycling, some 75,000 New Yorkers use a bike to commute to work every day, and countless more take a weekend spin around town purely for pleasure. And you can, too. Aside from a helmet, what you need are a few basic techniques for enjoyable and safe cycling in the land of taxis and potholes. These techniques boil down to when, where and how.

title: Sign of a Stalled Economy: Fewer Vehicles in Manhattan
description: For the first time in at least a decade, fewer people are driving into Manhattan.

title: ICN Settlement
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said it had reached a civil settlement with the Justice Department on charges that it had violated Food and Drug Administration regulations concerning the distribution of its anti-viral drug Virazole. The company said that in entering the civil consent decree, it neither admitted nor denied violating any laws. The charges concerned the reported distribution of Virazole, an approved drug, to six physicians for an unauthorized use. ICN agreed to pay a $400,000 fine and to reimburse the F.D.A. $200,000 for certain administrative costs.

title: Hispanics' Promised Land's Broken Promises
description: To the Editor: The recent disturbances in Washington's Mount Pleasant area, a densely populated Hispanic district, focus our attention on the burgeoning Spanish-speaking population nationwide. Approximately 25 million Spanish-speaking people have come to the United States, constituting about one-tenth of our country's population.

title: After 6-Year Shutdown, Reactor Begins Warmup
description: Operators started a nuclear chain reaction today in a Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant reactor, a major step toward power production after a six-year shutdown of the nation's second-largest atomic power plant.

title: Assassination in India; GANDHI CREMATED AMID HINDU CHANTS
description: Rajiv Gandhi, India's sixth Prime Minister and the second leader in the Nehru dynasty to die a violent death, was cremated today on the bank of the Jamuna River.

title: De Klerk Faults Boycotters as Talks on Strife Open
description: President F. W. de Klerk today opened a two-day conference examining the politically motivated violence in South Africa by criticizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups that had stayed away.

title: Fall TV Schedules Go Back to Basics
description: Despite all the signs of radical change swirling around them, the three broadcast networks announced fall prime-time schedules this week that seem to demonstrate a common belief: The more things change, the more they should remain the same.

title: Cone Conquers Cardinals With Signature Performance
description: Last night's Mets game really should have been a tale of two second basemen. It would have focused on Gregg Jefferies finally snapping back at his teammates after three years, then sitting out his second straight game with a stomach virus and watching Keith Miller, the third-string second baseman and utility player supreme, smack his first homer in over a year and help power the Mets toa 6-2 victory over St. Louis at Shea Stadium.

title: Key Rates
Noriega Co-defendant Sentenced to 20 Years
description: A co-defendant of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was sentenced today to 20 years in prison for his part in a guns-for-cocaine scheme.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL Alabama Pitchers Hold St. John's 3 Hits

title: Reports Name Pohl Heir
description: The Government will name the deputy president of the Bundesbank, Helmut Schlesinger, as the successor to the central bank president, Karl Otto Pohl, Government sources said today.

title: With the Cellar in Sight, Yanks and Sanderson Do Quick About-Face
description: The Yankees kept themselves out of last place in the American League East tonight and ruined the managing debut of Johnny Oates, but they also had to be concerned about the condition of Scott Sanderson.

title: On Rejecting Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Concert Will Celebrate Porter's 100th Birthday
description: A concert at Carnegie Hall and a dinner dance celebrating Cole Porter's 100th birthday will take place on June 9. The concert, which is being presented as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts, will feature nearly 50 performers. Among the participants will be William Bolcom, Alfred Drake, Michael Feinstein, Kitty Carlisle Hart, Marilyn Horne, Andrea Marcovicci, Maureen McGovern, Bobby Short, Alexis Smith, Jule Styne, Julie Wilson and Margaret Whiting.

title: Question Time for New York's Educators
description: The bitter budget fight in Albany is likely to produce a host of messy, murky compromises on how much aid New York State will provide to colleges and universities in the coming fiscal year. But the fight has already sent one ringingly clear message: state support for higher education requires a thorough review.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a Federal judge's overturning of regulations to bar a homeless man from the public library in Morristown, N.J., misidentified the park where the man, Richard R. Kreimer, sleeps. It is Lidgerwood Park in Morristown.

title: Top Rusher Arrested
description: Two Georgia Tech football players, including last year's leading rusher, WILLIAM BELL, were arrested by campus security officers yesterday and charged with possession of stolen merchandise. A school official identified the merchandise as schoolbooks.

title: Review/Music; Mehta Says Farewell With a Blockbuster
description: For his farewell gesture, after 13 years as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Zubin Mehta could have chosen few works more appropriate than "Gurrelieder," the grandly scaled work that he conducted on Thursday evening. Schoenberg's fabled monster of a cantata, which partly because of its extravagant personnel requirements seldom rears its head in the concert hall, is itself a leave-taking of sorts. Along with the tone poems "Verklarte Nacht" and "Pelleas und Melisande," this pre-12-tone epic represents the composer's effort to free himself -- and Western music -- from the grip of Wagner and late-Romantic gigantism.

title: Handicapped Critique Of a 1972 Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Concern About Spotted Owl Leads to Ban on Timber Sale
description: Prodding the Government to complete its plans for protection of the Northern spotted owl, a Federal district judge here has blocked the sale of logging rights on more than 60,000 acres of national forest land in the Northwest.

title: Hispanics' Promised Land's Broken Promises; They Do Want to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: GUATEMALA PEACE IN ARMY'S HANDS
description: Negotiations under way between the Government of President Jorge Serrano Elias and leftist guerrillas have raised hopes of ending Latin America's longest-running insurgency, but the army may prove to be the sticking point.

title: Law and History Support Jewish Settlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Vote Backs Bush On Trade
description: The Senate voted today to renew the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit the pacts to Congress with no amendments and limited debate allowed. The House approved the measure on Thursday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., said its APAC Construction group would sell properties in Arizona to a unit of Onoda Cement Co. Ltd., Yamaguchi, Japan, for undisclosed terms.

title: Fletcher Markle Is Dead at 70; Wrote TV and Radio Dramas
description: Fletcher Markle, a writer, director and producer who created many memorable live dramas in the early years of television, died on Thursday at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: Allies Enter a Kurdish City, Seeking to Erase Fear
description: This important Kurdish center in northern Iraq today came under the protective wing of the United States and its allies, whose soldiers started to restore basic city services and to gather unexploded grenades and land mines from gullies and fields.

title: Conservatives Play Doctor
description: The Supreme Court's alarming opinion in Rust v. Sullivan, sustaining the power of executive branch officials to order some doctors to provide incomplete or misleading information to pregnant patients, is cause for deep concern. Conservatives especially should recoil from the idea of Federal bureaucrats dictating the content of doctor-patient conversations.

title: 'Recycled' or 'Reprocessed Industrial Material'?
description: A group of 11 state attorneys general issued a set of guidelines last week regulating the use of such terms as "recycled" and "compostable." The move was intended to restrain the use of environmental claims to promote consumer products.

title: A Mysterious Masseur And His Eager Victim
description: "Noir et Blanc" was shown as part of the 1987 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 13, 1987. The film -- in French with English subtitles -- opened yesterday at the Cinema Village, Third Avenue between 12th and 13th Streets, in Manhattan.

title: Dow Advances 13.87 in Slow Session
description: Stocks advanced yesterday in a sluggish session as dozens of traders took the afternoon off before the holiday weekend.

title: Law and History Support Jewish Settlers; Illegal Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta Journal; A Sign: It's Jesus, or a Lunch Bargain
description: A lot has hap pened here since Joyce Simpson saw the face of Jesus in the forkful of spaghetti on the Pizza Hut billboard near Coleman Watley's Jiffy-Lube.

title: ERITREA'S CAPITAL REPORTED SEIZED
description: Ethiopian separatist guerrillas today captured Asmara, the second-largest city in the country after the capital, a senior Western diplomat said.

title: Boy, 14, Wins Geography Bee
description: A 14-year-old Idaho boy won the National Geography Bee on Thursday, correctly answering the question "What type of land form is commonly associated with orographic precipitation?" The boy, David Stillman of Nezperce, Idaho, replied, "Mountain," beating out nine other finalists and winning a $25,000 college scholarship. The National Geographic Society estimated that five million students in the fourth through eighth grades took part in the initial round in January and February. State bees were held on April 5 to select 57 contestants, who competed in a preliminary round Wednesday from which the 10 finalists emerged.

title: Music in Review
description: Patricia Spencer Flutist Miller Theater Columbia University Broadway at 116th Street

title: Dodgers' Martinez Stifles Reds for His 8th Victory of Season
description: Ramon Martinez became the first eight-game winner in the major leagues as Eddie Murray drove in four runs to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 11-3 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Corporations Are Deserting Group Battling Rights Bill
description: Concerned about the economic impact of publicly opposing a civil rights measure, at least 21 major companies and an organization representing 200 big corporations have pulled away from a group formed last year to lobby against a broad civil rights bill.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be glitter and glamour and gushing galore Wednesday at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan at a benefit dinner honoring AILEEN MEHLE, a k a SUZY of the The New York Post's Suzy column. And just everybody will be there, all those boldfaced people like MRS. WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR., MRS. ROBERT S. TRUMP and MRS. OSCAR DE LA RENTA. Suzy, old-fashioned girl that she is, still calls her ladies by their husbands' names.

title: Music in Review
description: The Dessoff Choirs Alice Tully Hall

title: Senate Democrats to Offer Plan To Restrain Health-Care Costs
description: Trying to seize the initiative on a politically potent issue, Senate Democrats will propose setting annual targets for national spending on health care as part of a new legislative effort to restrain soaring health costs. The proposal would also extend health insurance to the millions of Americans who have no medical coverage of any kind.

title: Tyson Wants More
description: The World Boxing Council yesterday convened a special hearing in New York to determine what split MIKE TYSON, as mandatory challenger, would get against the undisputed heavyweight champion, EVANDER HOLYFIELD, if their fight were to go to purse bids.

title: Wreford Chapple, 83, Submarine War Hero
description: Rear Adm. Wreford G. Chapple, whose World War II submarine heroics became material for books and a television series, died Monday at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: M.I.T. Scholar Speaks at Sarah Lawrence
description: Sarah Lawrence College graduated 300 students yesterday morning on its campus in Bronxville, N.Y., at its 62d commencement ceremony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Just as it's impossible and unwise to say May 25 is the drop- dead date, it is equally silly to say there is no drop-dead date. The fact of the matter is, you only know what the drop-dead date is after you've dropped dead." -- Felix G. Rohatyn, criticizing Albany's failure to pass a budget on time. [ 26:6. ]

title: Clinics Seek to Overturn Rule on Abortion Advice
description: In emergency meetings around the country today, leaders of family planning organizations vowed an all-out campaign to overturn Federal regulations, upheld by the Supreme Court Thursday, that bar employees of clinics receiving Federal funds from mentioning abortion to their patients.

title: No Asterisk in Offer This Time, So McRae Takes the Royals' Helm
description: Hal McRae, the former Kansas City slugger whose competitive fire helped blaze the Royals' way to five division titles, two American League pennants and one World Series victory in his 15 years with the club, was hired as the team's manager yesterday.

title: Computers Give Trucker an Edge
description: Most trucking company chiefs worry about their trucks, drivers and fuel prices. Donald J. Schneider, head of the nation's largest long-distance trucking company, frets more about a breakdown in the company's computers.

title: Assassination in India; On the Funeral Route, Quiet, Uneasy Crowds
description: A helicopter swooped low and showered rose petals over the gun-carriage carrying the body of Rajiv Gandhi. The crowd surged forward as the journey began in heavy heat through the capital.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News columns of Business Day on Thursday misstated the Chyron Corporation's involvement in an agreement by its main bank lenders. Chyron was not a party to the agreement. The report also misstated terms for filing the agreement with the bankruptcy court. The agreement cannot be filed until after June 14.

title: Foundation Leader Charting New Paths
description: Two years ago, residents of the LeClaire Courts public housing development made local history when they organized and took over management of the development, making it the city's first tenant-run operation.

title: A Restoration Becomes a Criminal Case in Italy
description: In a Florentine court, two men have started a fight over the beauty of a young Renaissance woman captured tenderly in marble after she died in childbirth in 1406.

title:
SPORTS LEISURE;
East Side, West Side, Bike Lanes All Around
description: Although an April 1990 survey by Bicycling magazine rated New York as the worst city in the country for bicycling, some 75,000 New Yorkers use a bike to commute to work every day, and countless more take a weekend spin around town purely for pleasure. And you can, too. Aside from a helmet, what you need are a few basic techniques for enjoyable and safe cycling in the land of taxis and potholes. These techniques boil down to when, where and how.

title: Treasury Prices Steady in Short, Brisk Day
description: Treasury securities prices were basically unchanged yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday trading session. The cash market in Treasury debt issues normally has no fixed trading hours, but dealers decided to close at 2 P.M.

title: Jazz Pianist Returns To Spotlight
description: The pianist and composer Freddie Redd, who is making a rare appearance at Birdland tonight, has spent the better part of the last 30 years in and out of the spotlight. Most jazz musicians of his stature -- and Mr. Redd is an exceptional, eccentric pianist, something never quite captured on his recordings -- maintain a regular working schedule in the United States. But Mr. Redd has chosen instead to wander. Not only does he like to travel, he said, but also, when work became scarce in the United States, he would look for it abroad.

title: Havana Rejects Call by Bush For American-Style Elections
description: Rejecting appeals by President Bush for political change, Cuba accused him today of being obsessively anti-Cuban and said his country had nothing to learn from the American style of government.

title: Ilse Lichtenstadter, 89, Middle East Authority
description: Ilse Lichtenstadter, a teacher of Middle Eastern languages and philosophy, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. She was 89 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: 2 Coaches Feud Over Their Players' Hopes
description: The only road trip of the George Washington High School baseball season was a two-hour ride on a school bus to a grassy diamond in the upstate town of Wappinger. The ballplayers from Washington Heights played an exhibition against their friendly rural rivals, Ketcham High, stuffed themselves with hot dogs and came home.

title: Patents; Designing Clothes on a Computer
description: A Michigan company has patented a software system to design clothing, from the composition of threads to the shape of the shoulders, without touching a bolt of fabric.

title: Nike Countersues Avia Over Patent
description: Nike Inc. has countersued Avia Group International Inc., contending that the shoemaker is making shoes that use Nike's sole-cushioning technology. Bill Dragon, Avia's president, denied the contentions, accusing Nike of "typical arrogance." Avia, based in Portland, had sued Nike last month for infringing patents for its Cantilever sole, a system in the concave sole that directs the shock of impact away from ankles and knees. Avia seeks to block sales of Nike Air 180 running shoes, which it says copy the Cantilever technology. Avia is also asking for unspecified damages.

title: U.N. Calls on Israel to Stop Deportations
description: The Security Council unanimously called on Israel today to stop deporting Palestinians from the occupied territories.

title: Estates Can Keep Apartments, Judge Rules
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that if tenants die, their estates can retain control of apartments in certain publicly subsidized middle-income housing cooperatives in New York City.

title: London Journal; First Briton in Space, but Barely in Fame's Orbit
description: When Helen Sharman of Sheffield roared into space atop a Soviet rocketship last Saturday, The Observer of London bannered the moment the next day with a front-page headline that read, "Women From Mars Is First Briton in Space."

title: Edward Rosenthal, 87, Executive at Warner From 1972 Until 1983
description: Edward Rosenthal, a former vice chairman of Warner Communications, now Time Warner Inc., died on Thursday at his home in White Plains. He was 87 years old.

title: A Fan for All Tastes, and All Seasons, Too
description: Paddle fans are popular again. These large-bladed, exposed ceiling fans circulate air rather than draw it into or out of a building. They are pleasing to the eye, cost much less to buy and operate than air-conditioners and can add to comfort and energy savings year round.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, named Robert A. Minicucci senior vice president and treasurer.

title: Patents; Detecting Illegal Drugs in Newborn Infants
description: A pediatrician in Detroit recently patented a method of detecting traces of cocaine and other illegal drugs in the bloodstream of newborn infants whose mothers have been using drugs.

title: Puerto Rico Phone Sale Is Canceled
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico has canceled plans to sell the commonwealth's government-owned telephone system, citing a shortage of potential buyers and the government's apparent inability to obtain its $3 billion asking price.

title: U.S. and Allies Move to Ease Cold War Limits on Exports
description: The United States and its allies have decided to ease restrictions substantially on the kinds of high-technology goods, like personal computers, that the West can export to the Soviet Union and other nations considered security risks.

title: Guy B. Johnson, 90, Longtime Advocate of Interracial Amity
description: Guy B. Johnson, a scholar of black culture and longtime advocate of improved race relations, died Thursday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 90 years old.

title: A Goaltending Crisis As Final Winds Down
description: Going into Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals, both teams have reason for concern about their starting goalies. Neither Tom Barrasso of Pittsburgh nor Jon Casey of Minnesota was guarding a net at the finish of Game 5, won by the Penguins, 6-4, on Thursday night to give them a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven championship round.

title: Paris Delays Barring NEC Stake in Bull
description: The French Government appeared poised today to block the NEC Corporation from buying a stake in Groupe Bull, France's largest computer maker. But the decision, which would almost certainly worsen relations with Japan, was apparently put on hold later in the day after it was reported in the French press.

title:
SPORTS LEISURE;
East Side, West Side, Bike Lanes All Around
description: Although an April 1990 survey by Bicycling magazine rated New York as the worst city in the country for bicycling, some 75,000 New Yorkers use a bike to commute to work every day, and countless more take a weekend spin around town purely for pleasure. And you can, too. Aside from a helmet, what you need are a few basic techniques for enjoyable and safe cycling in the land of taxis and potholes. These techniques boil down to when, where and how.

title: Around Indy Oval Goes Andretti Family Circle
description: Like first-graders lining up in size order on the way to hot lunch, the Andrettis will form a rowdy queue Sunday at the Indianapolis 500.

title: There Is No Letup in the War on Needless Federal Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Blunt the Spears in South Africa
description: It takes nothing from the prior achievements of President F. W. de Klerk to say that he has responded limply to the spiraling violence in South Africa's black townships. His Government waited until this week to ban the carrying of spears and other "traditional" weapons that have contributed to the loss of nearly a thousand lives this year. And the prohibition applies only to the Johannesburg area, not to Natal, homeland of the Zulus who have instigated much of the violence.

title: Tired Ethics on the City Council
description: A revised City Charter has given the New York City Council vast new responsibilities. But, as a series of articles in The Times has demonstrated, the Council's powers have expanded far faster than its members' sense of propriety.

title: Guidepost; Eyes Don't Need Sun
description: Almost all big sunglass manufacturers now use a labeling system that tells how well their glasses protect against ultraviolet rays and what conditions they are best suited for. The labels carry an A.N.S.I. symbol, meaning that they have been rated under criteria set by the American National Standards Institute. Glasses fall into one of three categories: cosmetic, general purpose or special purpose. In the explanations below, UVA denotes ultraviolet A rays and UVB denotes the shorter and potentially more harmful ultraviolet B rays. Physicians suspect that both types can cause cataracts and that UVB rays contribute to retina damage. Recommended colors are gray, brown and green because they distort colors the least; blue lenses can cause the wearer to misinterpret the reds and greens of traffic lights. Cosmetic: Blocks at least 70 percent of UVB and at least 20 percent of UVA. Adequate for nonharsh sunlight. General purpose: Blocks at least 95 percent of UVB and at least 60 percent of UVA. Adequate for boating and hiking. Special purpose: Blocks at least 99 percent of UVB and at least 60 percent of UVA. Needed on ski slopes and beaches. (Sources: American Optometric Association; Sunglass Association of America)

title: Medicaid Payment Ordered for Drug for Schizophrenia
description: The Federal Government has ordered all state Medicaid prescription drug programs to pay for clozapine, an expensive drug that could help tens of thousands of psychotic patients.

title: Devereux Butcher, 84, a Park Preservationist
description: Devereux Butcher, an author, editor and former conservation executive who fought to preserve the national park system, died Wednesday at his home in Gladwyn, Pa. He was 84 years old.

title: Dinkins Sets Plans to Raise $3 Billion
description: With Albany still deadlocked on a new state budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would prepare to borrow $3 billion to keep New York City from running out of cash in the next month.

title: Alabama House Votes Anti-Abortion Bill
description: The Alabama House of Representatives has approved a bill that would be among the most restrictive anti-abortion measures in the nation. Its prospects for enactment, however, are uncertain.

title: Restaurateur Kills 2d Would-Be Robber
description: For Raphael Disla, the owner of a tiny Spanish restaurant in Brooklyn, being ready to confront armed robbers has become almost a part of doing business. On Thursday night, for the second time this year, Mr. Disla drew a gun and shot a robber dead, the police said.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Off 1.5% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that for the month ended May 15 the number of shares sold short and not yet covered fell by 4.1 million, or 1.5 percent, to 260 million. The figures represent short selling in 2,270 stocks; in April the short selling was spread among 2,279 issues.

title: Bush Appeal to Addis Ababa Clears Way
description: Israel began transporting 16,000 Ethiopian Jews to Israel today in an intensive airlift that had secretly been agreed to by a besieged Ethiopian Government on the brink of collapse.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: About New York
description: The dozen young people sang old camp songs like "Kumbaya" and dubbed their clunky yellow school bus "the cheese bus." A few glanced from the windows from time to time, glimpsing the verdurous suburbs that seemed as foreign to these inner-city youths as their own stolen childhoods.

title: Your Money; No Vacation? A False Economy
description: With companies laying people off, freezing salaries and taking other cost-cutting measures, many Americans are running scared and concluding that they had better save more in case the worst happens. Many are deciding to forgo a summer vacation.

title: Bush to Speak at Graduation at Yale and Receive Degree
description: President Bush is returning to Yale University for its 290th commencement, his first visit to his alma mater since becoming President.

title: A New Palestinian Flexibility Is Seen
description: In this wretchedly poor, violently militant town and its adjacent refugee district, a palpable sense of despair and apathy has settled over Palestinians who once clung to great hopes for their future.

title: Compaq Rolls With the Punches
description: Until last week, the Compaq Computer Corporation had racked up nine years of spectacular expansion to become the No. 2 maker of personal computers compatible with I.B.M.'s. Now, the question is whether Compaq has lost its direction or is merely pausing to prepare for resumed growth.

title: Tough Draw for Lendl
description: Three-time French Open champion IVAN LENDL and one of last year's finalists, ANDRE AGASSI, drew tough opening-round opponents for this year's tournament.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Democratic economic proposal misstated the unemployment rate for April and its change from the previous month. The civilian unemployment rate declined to 6.6 percent in April, from 6.8 percent in March.

title: Heartfelt Plea? Vintage Whine? Jefferies Writes Fans
description: Gregg Jefferies is tired of reading anonymous quotes from teammates deriding his play. He is tired of being called the future of the Mets. He is tired of being labeled a spoiled player.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES has come to the rescue of a herd of pigs. An advocate of the preservation of rare breeds, he learned of CHARLES RUSSELL, whose herd of Gloucester Old Spot pigs was destined for ham heaven because Mr. Russell could not get a bank loan to build a breeding enterprise.

title: David Frisch, 73, Dies; a Physicist at M. I. T.
description: David H. Frisch, a professor of physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 40 years, died Thursday at his home in Cambridge. He was 73 years old.

title: U.S. Resumes Aid It Suspended to Yugoslavia
description: The Bush Administration announced today that it was resuming economic aid to Yugoslavia after a 20-day suspension.

title: Greyhound Bus Chief Sets His Departure
description: Fred G. Currey said Thursday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive of Greyhound Bus Lines, nearly a year after a bitter, violent battle with labor unions forced the nation's only transcontinental intercity bus system into bankruptcy.

title: Truck Vents Suspected in Bronx Fire
description: Investigators said yesterday that they may be nearing a solution to the mystery of how 1,800 gallons of gasoline spilled from a sealed tanker in a midnight collision and fire that killed five people and incinerated a row of stores in the Bronx.

title: Political Notebook; In Trenton, 1991's Disputes Seem Like a Rerun of 1990
description: So familiar are the issues and outcries this season in the State House by the banks of the Delaware River, that 1991 at times seems to be nothing but 1990 revisited.

title: Friday Without Pay Provokes a Protest in Suffolk
description: Suffolk County shut down much of its government today, forcing thousands of employees to take the day off to help ease its budget crisis.

title: No Headline
description: The Economy

title: 'Soft' Divac Plays Hard to Pace Lakers
description: Vlade Divac answered the call of his teammates here tonight. Publicly challenged to stand tall and play like a talented 7-foot-1-inch center, Divac keyed a 12-0 run early in the third quarter and the Los Angeles Lakers went on to a 106-92 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Music in Review
description: Thomas Buckner Baritone Merkin Concert Hall

title: Patents; Chip Uses Light Signals to Spur Data Processing
description: Using light instead of electronics to overcome a bottleneck in processing data, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have invented a computer chip that they say can recognize images a thousand times more quickly than desktop computers.

title: In the Nation; Playing Off The President
description: In the face of a pair of veto threats from President Bush, Senate Democrats at last are showing a few signs of courage. Nothing is more needed from a party that has been looking planless, leaderless and gutless.

title: Review/Dance; Beginnings: Peter Martins's First Work
description: Peter Martins's "Calcium Light Night," presented by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, is a first ballet to be proud of.

title: Manning Clark, Historian, 76
description: Manning Clark, whose six-volume "History of Australia" was the first comprehensive history of the continent, died on Thursday. He was 76 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD PRYOR has suffered from multiple sclerosis for five years, his spokesman, GUY McELWAINE, was quoted as telling The Associated Press yesterday. He said the disease was in remission and is not life-threatening. Mr. Pryor, 50 years old, has just completed a film, "Another You."

title: Assassination in India; India Mourns but Avoids Upheaval
description: Terror and rioting in northern India scarred the somber cremation of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi after she was assassinated in 1984, and many in this tumultuous nation expected similar scenes when her son Rajiv was slain on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on May 22 about a Federal court order revoking the citizenship of a Milwaukee man accused of having been a guard at a Nazi concentration camp misstated a judge's finding. The judge, Thomas Curran, said the Government had established that the man, Anton Bauman, served as an armed guard at the Stutthof concentration camp. He did not say that it had not been proved that the man was at the camp.

title: Witnesses to a 'Crime'
description: I doubted that my students were armed, but you never know, so I decided against using guns. A classroom shooting could severely curtail my teaching career.

title: Beach Comfort, in a Bag
description: Beach chairs can be clumsy to lug across the sand and impossible to pack into a suitcase. One alternative is not to bother and just use a towel. But for those who want to marry comfort and convenience there is a new option, the Chair in a Bag, which fits into a carry-on bag.

title: Tax Changes in Argentina
description: The Economy Minister of Argentina submitted a far-reaching package of tax changes today that includes canceling the income tax for wage-earners.

title: Northrop Proposes $18 Million Settlement
description: A stockholders' lawsuit accusing officials of the Northrop Corporation of wrongdoing in the 1980's would be settled for $18 million under a proposal by the military contractor.

title: Creditors Back Polly Peck Plan
description: Creditors of Polly Peck International P.L.C., the heavily indebted British conglomerate, have backed a repayment plan that allows the company to retain rather than be forced to sell its Del Monte fruit and Sansui electronics operations.

title: Exxon Withdraws Guilty Plea in Alaskan Oil Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation today withdrew its guilty pleas to Federal criminal charges arising from the worst oil spill in United States history.

title: Coors Ad Slogan
description: The Adolph Coors Company said it was speeding up the phase-out of a slogan used in its light beer advertising after the Government complained that it was false and misleading. The slogan, "It won't slow you down," will be dropped by Oct. 1, a Coors spokeswoman said. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms contends that alcoholic beverages do slow reactions and reflexes. The spokeswoman said that the phrase was to be dropped by the end of the year anyway, but that the company had stepped up its effort in response to the bureau's request.

title: Music in Review
description: Jane Dressler Soprano Weill Recital Hall

title: Observer; The Enemy Gap
description: Listen to this:

title: Beliefs
description: If good reviews sell books, bad reviews sell church reports. And it would be an understatement to say that bad reviews greeted the report on human sexuality prepared for next month's annual General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.).

title: CHRONICLE
description: The American Institute of Architects has chosen a woman to be president -- SUSAN A. MAXMAN, a Philadelphia architect. At the group's convention in Washington this week, she was elected to the post of first vice president; she takes office in December and becomes president one year later.

title: Big Board Reports '90 Loss, First in Nearly Two Decades
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it experienced its first annual loss last year in almost two decades, a reflection of the deepening recession on Wall Street in 1990.

title: Robert John Landry, Editor, 87
description: Robert John Landry, who worked for the trade paper Variety for more than 50 years as a reporter, reviewer, office manager and managing editor, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; It's That Wild and Crazy Look
description: You knew things were desperate for the Pistons against the Bulls in the second game of their Eastern Conference final series Tuesday night when the coach sent in a little-used 7-foot center named Tree Rollins. Some people wonder what Tree does for a living, since he doesn't shoot much, and he doesn't pass much, and he rebounds only somewhat. What he does pretty well, though, is fall on people. On Tuesday, he committed four fouls in seven minutes. It was as if the coach, Chuck Daly, had given him specific instructions: "Rattle someone's clavicle, quick!"

title: Alison Stilwell Cameron, Author, 70
description: Alison Stilwell Cameron, a daughter of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell who became an artist, author and lecturer on China, died Thursday at the Community Hospital in Monterey, Calif. She was 70 years old and lived in Carmel, Calif.

title: Stores Battle Credit Cards (With Theirs)
description: Department and specialty stores have started a campaign of vigorous promotion of their own charge cards. Buffeted by the rising use of "third-party" cards like Visa, Mastercard and American Express , they are pulling out all the stops.

title: Senate Panel Passes Cabinet Expansion Bill
description: A Senate committee has approved a bill that would add an Environment Department to the Cabinet, an idea that has wide support but became bogged down in Congress last year.

title: U.S. Cuts Fee for Salvadorans In Protected Status Program
description: Bowing to pressure from Congress and immigrant rights groups, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has reduced the fees that Salvadoran immigrants must pay to register for a temporary "safe haven" program for illegal aliens.

title: 2 Coaches Feud Over Their Players Hopes
description: The only road trip of the George Washington High School baseball season was a two-hour ride on a school bus to a grassy diamond in the upstate town of Wappinger. The ballplayers from Washington Heights played an exhibition against their friendly rural rivals, Ketcham High, stuffed themselves with hot dogs and came home.

title: Next Move Belongs to Riley
description: Pat Riley met with the Knicks' president, Dave Checketts, yesterday, but Riley declined to say if he was close to accepting an offer to become the team's coach.

title: Soybean Traders Sentenced
description: A Federal judge sentenced nine soybean futures traders today to up to 37 months in prison for their convictions on charges ranging from racketeering to wire fraud.

title: Media Director at Coke After 15 Years at Busch
description: When Charles B. Fruit joins the Coca-Cola Company on June 3 as its new global media director, he will bring along 15 years of experience marketing beer, snack foods and amusement parks for the Anheuser-Busch Companies.

title: Yugoslavs Free Abducted Slovenian Officers
description: Two military officers of the Yugoslav republic of Slovenia were released today by the national army, 14 hours after they were kidnapped during negotiations over an incident on Thursday at a Slovenian training camp.

title: U.S. Approves Indian Casino In Connecticut
description: The Secretary of the Interior today reluctantly approved an Indian tribe's plan to open a casino on its reservation outside New London, Conn.

title: Travel Advisory; F.A.A. Urges More Space Near Plane Exit
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed requiring more space near emergency exits over airplane wings. These exits, also called window exits, adjoin seat rows that usually have extra space, but testimony about accidents, and tests in the United States and Britain, have shown that passengers fall over each other in their rush. Removing the exit hatch is difficult because the passenger is unable to stand upright while pulling it loose.

title: Diane Ilyse Cohen Is Married to Jason Lee Madfes
description: Diane Ilyse Cohen, the daughter of Muriel S. Cohen of Stamford, Conn., and William A. Cohen of Westport, Conn., was married in New York last evening to Jason Lee Madfes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerson Madfes of Bayside, Queens. Cantor Robert Abelson officiated at the Helmsley Palace.

title: Guarding Against Bats With Rabies
description: FOR the second time in two weeks, a bat found on residential property has tested positive for rabies by the Suffolk County Health Department. In one instance, a dog was attacked, and because it had not been inoculated against rabies, it was put to sleep.

title: Towns Seeking Cuts In Wages and Benefits
description: STAMFORD is one of the few towns in the state where residents' trash is still collected from their backyards. But that could change as a result of contract concessions accepted by municipal workers. Last month the employees, represented by the teamsters union, agreed to curbside pickup along with the elimination of up to 25 of the city's 85 sanitation jobs.

title: A Hometown View of Harding
description: THE first sign that the traveler sees upon entering Marion, Ohio, on state Route 423, proclaims, "Welcome From Marion Service Clubs." This includes greetings from the Exchange and the Lions, the Kiwanis and the A.A.R.P., the Jaycees and Rotary, Beta Sigma Phi and Altrusa. There are Optimists, and Eagles, and Moose and Civitans, and Shriners here, too. The second sign advises, "Here Lived Warren Harding, the 29th President of the United States."

title: Corrections
description: A summer listing under dance in the special Arts Almanac section last week misstated the admissions policy for the Maine Festival of the Arts in Brunswick. There is an admissions charge for the festival; it is not free.

title: Postings: Carroll Gardens Units; Convent to Condos
description: Alfred Menziuso, an architect, and his Brooklyn neighbor Frank Guido, whose family owns the Guido Funeral Home, had long admired the handsome brownstone at 25 First Place not far from their homes in the Carroll Gardens section of the borough.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a stamina-building drug linked to athletes' deaths misstated what is known about the death of the Dutch cyclist Johannes Draaijer. An autopsy did not specify the cause, and it is not known conclusively whether he had used the drug.

title: Nasty New Voices
description: MONKEY BRAIN SUSHI New Tastes in Japanese Fiction. Edited by Alfred Birnbaum. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $18.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JEAN STEWART;
Opening a Path for Those With Disabilities
description: IMAGINE being in a wheelchair and trying to navigate the hills at a typical outdoor festival. Imagine being blind and trying to read most festivals' programs, or being deaf and trying to get any information about the event's goings on -- or even where the bathroom is.

title: Q and A
description: Four Hours in Chicago

title: Fred C. Dent 3d Wed To Jeanine Wittlinger
description: Jeanine Patricia Wittlinger, a student at Louisiana State University, and Fred Columbus Dent 3d, an account excecutive with Smith Barney in Baton Rouge, La., were married yesterday at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J. Msgr. John McDermott officiated.

title: Miss Apperson Weds D. T. Williamson in Capital
description: Nanette Ann Apperson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Apperson of Richmond, was married in Washington yesterday to Donald Thomas Williamson, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Roy Williamson of Utica, N.Y. The Rev. Lyle Brenneman performed the Methodist ceremony in the Oxon Chapel of the Wesley Theological Seminary.

title: Portable Heart Pump Patient Dies
description: A 52-year-old man who two weeks ago became the world's first recipient of a fully portable heart pump died on Thursday, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital here said today.

title: 'Soapdish' Dresses in 'Dynasty' Style
description: Look quickly and carefully during the opening sequence of the new movie "Soapdish" -- the setting is an awards ceremony for daytime soap operas -- and you may spot 300 extras dressed in gowns that appeared at one time or another during the nine-year run of "Dynasty." Look really hard and you may even see a frock or two from "Charlie's Angels," "Hart to Hart" or "The Love Boat." Nolan Miller laughingly refers to this clothing as his "leftovers."

title: Les Miserables: Star Autobiographies
description: "Real life. I was not good at it," Ali MacGraw says in her inane but rapidly selling autobiography, "Moving Pictures." Her first-person story reveals much less than we already knew about the tabloid-shaped life of the woman who launched millions of sniffles in "Love Story," married her producer, Robert Evans, and famously left him for a turbulent marriage to Steve McQueen. But the book taps into the fundamental allure of best-selling Hollywood autobiographies. Stars are different from you and me, these books suggest; they're so much worse at real life.

title: The Nation; Conservatively Speaking, It's An Activist Supreme Court
description: IN approach as well as content, the Supreme Court's sweeping decision last week upholding Federal restrictions on abortion counseling brought the Court itself into sharp focus. Nearly five years into the tenure of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and 10 months after the retirement of Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the Supreme Court is no longer in transition. It has become the Court it will most likely be for the next generation.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; 'Animal House' Adopts Policy: 'Last Call, Please'
description: Dartmouth College, which has been trying to live down its hard-drinking "Animal House" image, adopted a policy last week that will ban kegs and alcohol deliveries on campus and require hired student monitors to enforce state laws against under-age drinking.

title: Judging the Reagans
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Checking It Twice
description: The Soviet Union seems to be out of the evil empire business, but some officials in Washington insist on clinging to at least one remnant of the bad old days. As authorized by the 1952 McCarran-Walter Act, the State Department maintains a list of hundreds of thousands of aliens who are considered to have dangerous beliefs or intentions and ought to be kept out of the country. Graham Greene was on it; Yves Montand, too. And in 1986, Choichiro Yatani learned he was included. On his way from New York State University at Stony Brook to a conference in the Netherlands, he was stopped at the airport, told he was suspected of being a Communist and, despite his denials, detained for 44 days pending deportation. Officials dropped the deportation, but have refused to take Mr. Yatani's name off the list. Now he is suing to compel the Government to strike his name. A Federal judge in New York is scheduled to began hearing the case this week.

title:
ART;
Inviting Audiences to React
description: IT has often been said that the process of creativity is incomplete until a work of art is exposed to public view. As music requires listeners and as literature and poetry need readers, so the visual arts need viewers as respondents to the stimuli that the artist provides.

title: Debra Bromson Weds Mark Lichtenstadter
description: Debra Lynn Bromson and Mark Glen Lichtenstadter, lawyers in Philadelphia, were married last evening at the Rye (N.Y.) Town Hilton. Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated.

title: Jeanne Bilbao Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Bilbao of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jeanne Marie Bilbao and Charles Ernest Griffith 3d, the son of Mr. Griffith Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and the late Susan J. Griffith. Miss Bilbao, 26 years old, teaches science at the Browning School in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Wellesley College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Mr. Griffith, 26, is an assistant vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust in New York. He graduated from Middlebury College.

title: A 'Last Bastion' Gives Way to Social Change
description: AUBREY C. LEWIS would seem an ideal candidate to join the Baltusrol Golf Club, which recently disclosed its decision to accept women and minority members. One of the first black agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Lewis is currently the highest-ranking black executive at the Woolworth Corporation.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: GIVEN the pressures of a career in medicine, there is reason to wonder at the literary output of many a physician, and that includes luminaries like Arthur Conan Doyle and especially William Carlos Williams, the pediatrician-poet from Rutherford.

title: Campus Life: New School; Masterpieces Of Fresco Painting Inspire a Course
description: The simple act of painting a wall takes on new meaning when the wall is at the Parsons School of Design, a division of the New School for Social Research, and the painters are students and faculty members.

title: Strike Threat in Ivory Coast
description: The Ivory Coast's university teachers' union today threatened new strikes unless the Government permits an inquiry into recent campus violence.

title: Travel Advisory; Historic Room In Washington
description: The Library of Congress is offering visitors a rare opportunity to preview the newly renovated Main Reading Room of the Thomas Jefferson Building next Saturday and Sunday (9 A.M. until 4:30 P.M.). The room is normally open only to researchers and writers. It will be the only time in the next two years that visitors will be permitted to enter without reservations.

title: 'Billy Bishop,' a War Hero's Story
description: GIVE him a chair (to dive off in solo flight), a trunk, maybe even a feather boa -- and more than a dozen parts to play -- and the right performer is going to create some neat theatrical illusion.

title: Maureen Sullivan Planning to Wed
description: Joseph F. Sullivan of Manasquan, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter Maureen Louise Sullivan to Jean Gilles Fournier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Paul Fournier of Hawkesbury, Ontario. An August wedding is planned.

title: Cubans Quit Angola, Ending 16-Year Role
description: The last Cuban soldiers in Angola departed today, ending 16 years of military support in battles against American-backed rebels and South African forces, the head of a United Nations verification team said.

title: Lucille Ball's Name Adopted by Theater
description: Lucille Ball's name was be stowed upon the building that houses the theater group where she made her first public performance 61 years ago.

title: New Menu Perks Up East End Favorite
description: THIS weekend marks the unofficial start of the annual Manhattan to Montauk migration. Veteran East Enders will note some changes at one of their favorite restaurants, Sapore di Mare in Wainscott.

title:
MUSIC;
Writing for the Choir He Sang In
description: FOR Malcolm Dalglish, composing "Hymnody of Earth" represented much more than setting poetry to music. It was the combination of a great many influences, which began when the composer was a boy soprano in the Princeton-based American Boychoir.

title: Companies Furlough Thousands of Employees
description: AT the Stanley Works in New Britain, production got ahead of orders late last year, leading the company to give all its employees a furlough -- time off without pay -- during the week before Christmas.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: My husband traveled to Prague last December on Germanrail's Meistersinger from Frankfurt. After boarding a clean, warm train, he was awakened at Nuremburg and hustled onto a cold, wet, windy platform for transfer to a Czech train, which was cold and filthy and had no water. The conductor insisted on being paid again in dollars or marks the face value of his fully prepaid ticket. Reluctantly, my husband paid him, only to have him return in an hour, tipsy, offering bottles of beer for $2. About 4 A.M. there was a knock on his door by a woman shouting "Gifts!" My husband said he did not want to buy anything, but she was insistent and turned out to be a customs inspector.

title: Cooperman Is Back At Center of Storm On School Testing
description: A YEAR to the day after he quit as New Jersey Commissioner of Education, Dr. Saul Cooperman found himself in the thick of controversy again when, at a news conference in Washington, he championed the development of a mandatory national achievement test for high school seniors.

title: What Possessed A.S. Byatt?
description: On a drab, wintry afternoon in the London section of Putney, A. S. Byatt arrives home late by minicab, waving frantically at me through the back window. I have been standing conspicuously by the rosebush outside her Victorian brick house awaiting her, trying to decode a Latin inscription she has placed above her forbidding doorway. Rather grandly, it reads, "Semper eadem" -- "Always the same," Queen Elizabeth I's motto, declaring steadfast reliability -- a more wishful than accurate sentiment, perhaps. Since the unexpected success of her fifth novel, "Possession," Antonia Byatt's routine has been rudely upset by her belated stardom. However, the inscription should not be taken literally; it's only an allusion. In A. S. Byatt's heady world, even a humble doorway is a vehicle for scholastic expression.

title: Nancy Ledogar Weds
description: Nancy Margaret Ledogar, a daughter of Edward J. Ledogar of West Islip, L.I., and Joan A. Berglund of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeff William Minett, a son of Florence Minett of Rockaway Point, Queens, and the late John J. Minett. The Rev. Stephen J. Meany 2d officiated at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I. Mrs. Minett, 33 years old, is a lawyer at the Commodity Exchange in New York. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College and received a J.D. degree from Catholic University. Mr. Minett, 31, is an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn. He graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles and received a J.D. degree from the Illinois Institute of Technology.

title: Corrections
description: A map on May 5 with an article about Cologne mislabeled the Wallraf-Richartz and Ludwig Museums. They are east of the Roman-Germanic Museum, between the cathedral and the Rhine River. (The former location of the Wallraf-Richartz Museum is three blocks west of the cathedral,)

title: REBELS IN ETHIOPIA SEIZE A VITAL PORT, SEALING TAKEOVER
description: Separatist guerrillas today captured the last port controlled by the Ethiopian Government, enabling the rebels to choke off fuel and other vital supplies to the crumbling Government and very likely assuring its downfall within days.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CURANDERO Eight Stories.By Daniel Curley.Bk Mk Press, University of Missouri-Kansas City, 109 Scofield Hall,5100 Rockhill Road, Kansas City,Mo. 64110-2499; $12.95.

title: A la Carte: Quality on Weekdays at Low Prices
description: LONG ISLAND restaurants have always been good buys compared with their cousins in Manhattan. The recession seems to have further widened the gap between the Big Apple and the Island.

title: Monica Eileen Kelbley Wed to Steven J. Gedde
description: Monica Eileen Kelbley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Kelbley of Rochester, and Dr. Steven Jon Gedde, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lance Gedde of McHenry, Ill., were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Rochester. The Rev. Robert Collins officiated.

title: On Sentencing Corporations
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Clark, 49, Dies; a Folk-Rock Musician
description: Gene Clark, one of five founding members of the Byrds, a leading folk-rock musical group of the 1960's, was found dead Friday at his home in Sherman Oaks, a Los Angeles suburb.

title: Doctor Quits Post at Sloan-Kettering
description: Two and a half years after he was wooed from his position as the top Federal cancer official, Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr. has abruptly resigned as the second-ranking doctor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bethel
description: "MARK TWAIN used to stop at my grandfather's house on Grassy Plain Street to fill his water jug before heading home to Redding," said Clifford J. Hurgin, First Selectman of Bethel. "My grandfather would offer him a beer. Then they would sit on the porch and talk."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: 'There wasn't anything that happened over there to the guys that didn't happen to me. Maybe if I was driving a tank, I'd feel like I was doing something more to help than keeping records of spare truck parts." -- Sgt. Sheri L. Barbato of the Army.

title: A Nice Retirement for 12-Meter Boats
description: Most of the big yachts appearing in regattas these days are sailed by professionals. The crews wear uniforms, eat together at crew dinners and take their marching orders from boat owners. But pockets of amateur sailing still exist on the larger boats, if only to re-create past days of glory.

title: Gainey Sequesters Stars as They Fight to Stay Alive
description: For the first time in nearly two months of post-season play, the Minnesota North Stars were facing elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs as they got ready to face the Pittsburgh Penguins here tonight in Game 6 of the final round at the Met Center.

title: U.S.S.R. Without 'Socialist' Is Discussed
description: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that 9 of the 15 Soviet republics were close to an agreement that would fundamentally change the structure and the formal name of the Soviet Union.

title: Bare Bright And Cool: Hot Footwear
description: After being closed up in pumps and booties all winter, women's feet can take a breather this summer. Sandals that reveal the toes and mules that liberate the heels are the styles of choice. And the barer the better.

title: The Times They Are A-Changin'
description: The decision by a consortium of impresarios and musicologists to cancel the Mozart bicentennial came as a surprise to many people, but not to directors of the Institute for Advanced Madonna Studies at Princeton University. Dr. Warren Wetwhistle and Dr. Hildegarde Bingenbingen, appearing on the "Donahue" show, said that they already had the champagne on ice when the announcement came from Salzburg, Austria. They declared themselves in full agreement with the historic action, which was subsequently ratified by the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Talking: Warranties; Premiums For Peace Of Mind
description: A HOME does not normally come with a warranty unless it is new. The standard protection available to buyers of resale homes is to hire an inspector to make a detailed analysis before they sign a contract of sale.

title: U. of Massachusetts Is Losing Money and Morale
description: The seniors of the class of 1991 are not the only people who will be leaving the University of Massachusetts after commencement on May 26. The chancellor, Joseph Duffey, two vice chancellors, three deans and a number of highly respected professors have resigned.

title: Heir to Tragedy; India Confronts Gandhi's Death And Flawed Legacy
description: WHEN Rajiv Gandhi reached out to meet the people on a tropical night last week in southern India, and was instead killed by a bomb, he was nearing the end of an intense political campaign built on the theme of stability. Only the Congress Party, he had said over and over again, could bring the country unity and peace.

title: 'Film Society,' a Good Play Improved
description: ONE of the uncommon pleasures of the new production of "The Film Society" at the McCarter Theater, an upbeat finale for Emily Mann's first season as the theater's artistic director, is that it proves that good plays can get better.

title: Ethiopian Jews and Israelis Exult as Airlift Is Completed
description: Israel fell into joyous celebration tonight as the Government announced the successful conclusion of an emergency airlift of 14,500 Ethiopian Jews, nearly the entire Jewish population, in just under 36 hours.

title: Shelly Hoglund, an Importer, Marries
description: Shelly Louise Hoglund, president of an import and retail business based in Texas, and Michael Edward Dee, an executive at Morgan Stanley in New York, were married yesterday in Dallas. Dr. John R. Walchenbach and the Rev. Mark Ford, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Preston Hollow Presbyterian Church.

title: Selling Picture Frames Instead of Cookies
description: BAKE sales, crafts sales and car washes are the usual fund-raising events, but students at the Blue Mountain Middle School have come up with a new one: picture framing.

title: Blue Cross Finances: Another View
description: The April 28 article on the financial crisis of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey ("Blue Cross Struggles to Survive") may need clarification for readers to understand what is really going on.

title: Farm Stays
description: To the Editor: As an Englishwoman temporarily resident in New York, I very much enjoyed the articles on farm vacations (Travel, May 5). Two hints may help readers wishing to follow the writers' examples.

title: Woman May Have Set Off Bomb Fatal to Gandhi
description: A bespectacled, bewigged woman in her mid-30's, who died in the bomb explosion that killed Rajiv Gandhi, has emerged as the chief suspect in the assassination of the former Prime Minister.

title: Johnson's Erring Ways Mar His Slugging Ways
description: Early in the afternoon, Howard Johnson's home run allowed him to reach a Mets milestone and put some life into a struggling offense.

title: The End of the World, in Brilliant Technicolor
description: Birds eat men's flesh, leering devils threaten Crusaders with scimitars, and Christ on a white charger thrusts his lance into a seven-headed beast attacking from the sea. In the 13th century, the end of the world was at hand -- or so many people thought. This spurred artists to produce vividly colored illustrations of the visions documented in the last book of the New Testament, many examples of which are exhibited in "The Apocalypse and Other Visions in Medieval Illuminated Manuscripts," at the J. Paul Getty Museum through June 30.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas;
All Rented Out Amid History
description: THE Meridian, a four-story development in the historic State-Thomas area just north of the city's last office towers, has just completed a successful rental campaign at rents of $700 to $1,200 a month for one- and two-bedroom apartments. By the April 15 opening day, there were 123 tenants and by mid-May all 132 units had been claimed.

title: Polish State Keeps Its Distance From Church
description: THROUGHOUT the 1980's it seemed that the destinies of Poland and its native-born Pope were inextricably linked. The nation created the Solidarity movement in the afterglow of John Paul's 1979 visit, and drew comfort and strength from his trips in 1983 and 1987. When the Communists silenced overt opposition with martial law in 1981, Poles flocked to their beloved church; every Mass, every baptism, every marriage was both a celebration of faith and a jab at the regime.

title: 'Mom Managers' and the 'Web of Inclusion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial Holiday Tomorrow
description: Here are the holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets' Fogbound Clubhouse
description: That 23-year-old man of letters, Gregg Jefferies, kept saying yesterday that he didn't want to stir the stew anymore. But whenever someone with a notebook or microphone asked him about his epistle to the fans that triggered Friday night's clubhouse meeting, he kept talking about it.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings for the week ended May 11 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill 995,000 1165 Park Avenue (92d St.) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, fireplace, high-ceilings; maintenance $2,094, 34% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Chelsea 660,000 143 West 20th Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 4,000-sq.-ft. loft co-op; dining area, den, 2 studios, 11-ft. ceilings, 3 exposures; maintenance $1,500, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Chelsea 900,000 50 West 29th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3,200-sq.-ft. penthouse co-op in a renovated loft building; dining area, solarium, art studio, 3,000-sq.-ft. of private roof space; maintenance $445, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle-Sulzberger Rolfe) Flatiron District 320,000 105 Fifth Avenue (18th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,765-sq.-ft. loft-co-op; 2 elevators, 11-ft. ceilings, oak-trimed windows; maintenance $831, 43% tax-deductible (Broker: Kathy Fields-Sinvin Realty) Upper East Side 1.625 million 9 East 81st Street 6-bedroom, 5-bath, 5-story, brick town house; dining room, 6 fireplaces, library, garden room, terrace, 19- by 102-ft. lot; taxes $22,000 (Broker: Joan Schlank Real Estate-Vandenberg Real Estate) Upper West Side 192,000 140 Riverside Drive (86th St.) (Normandy) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, renovated kitchen; maintenance $628, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) BRONX Riverdale 225,000 3755 Henry Hudson Parkway (Imperial House) 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2,800-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, breakfast room, study, terrace; maintenance $1,150, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Trebach Realty) Spuyten Duyvil Area 412,500 537 West 232d Street 4-family, detached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in second floor unit; 2 bedrooms on first and third floors, 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, eat-in kitchens in each; terrace, 1/4-acre irregular lot; taxes $4,000 (Broker: ERA/Susan E. Goldy & Co. Realtors) BROOKLYN Boerum Hill 290,000 218 Dean Street 2-family, 4-story, attached brownstone; 4 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths in primary unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths in other; dining room in each; 23.4- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,188 (Broker: Fogarty Real Estate) Park Slope 175,000 273 6th Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. co-op in a limestone building; dining area, eat-in kitchen; maintenance $575, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: F.J. Kazeroid Realty Group) QUEENS Elmhurst 190,000 73-48 57th Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 29- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,190 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Forest Hills Gardens 315,000 37 Ingram Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house; dining room, solarium, fireplace, 28- by 93-ft. lot; taxes $1,700 (Broker: Terrace Realty) STATEN ISLAND Heartland Village 62,000 101 Gardenia Lane (Honey Bee) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. condo in a 5-year-old building; eat-in kitchen, large living room; common charge $75, taxes $400 (Broker: Coldwell Banker/DiSimone Realty) Oakwood 150,000 327 Chesterton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, colonial; dining area, eat-in kitchen, rear deck, finished basement, 23- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate)

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TALKING AT THE GATES A Life of James Baldwin. By James Campbell. Viking, $21.95.

title: Bad Press
description: To the Editor:

title: All About/Automobile Testing; The Test Track Is King Of the Road No More
description: To the auto makers, a skilled driver sensitive to every nuance of a vehicle's performance is still a valued resource at the proving grounds. But increasingly the leading role in automobile testing is being played by computer experts who generate and interpret data from high-tech wind tunnels, simulators and other stationary testing equipment.

title: Travel Advisory; Eastern Europe Air Partners
description: As air traffic between Western and Eastern Europe increases, four relatively small carriers are stepping up their regional cooperation -- Austrian Airlines, Finnair, Scandinavian Airlines System and Swissair. They already account for 45 percent of all flights between Western and Eastern Europe. Their partnership involves check-in facilities, shared information and telecommunications, and interchange of aircraft and crews.

title: Inside the Melt Shop
description: AMERICAN STEEL Hot Metal Men and the Resurrection of the Rust Belt. By Richard Preston. 278 pp. New York: Prentice Hall Press. $19.95.

title: Educators Try to Overcome The Stigma of Vocational Classes
description: FOR more than a decade, administrators of vocational-education programs in most sections of the county have been grappling with some sobering statistics. If enrollment figures are the gauge being used to measure success, their programs are not making the grade.

title:
ART;
Johnson and Boswell Are Reunited at Yale
description: MAY 16 was the bicentennial of the publication of James Boswell's "Life of Johnson." At the Yale Center for British Art, the anniversary was celebrated with a sherry toast and a continuing exhibition, "Boswell's Johnson," organized by Elisabeth R. Fairman, curator of prints and drawings.

title: New Diet Guide to Improve Shape You're In; Don't Blame Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Champions The Working Class?
description: America must make a vast investment at least $2 trillion in the 1990's -- to prepare our workforce for the next century. If the Democratic Party wants the White House, it should lead the charge. It needs the political equivalent of a warrior like Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf to propose a plan for rebuilding America, as Gen. George Marshall did 44 years ago for rebuilding Western Europe.

title: NEW YORK MISSES BUDGET DEADLINE AND ENTERS CRISIS
description: As the deadline that the Governor and legislative leaders had set for approving a budget passed today without a new fiscal plan in place, New York State appeared to have drifted into a political crisis with potentially crippling consequences for its local governments.

title: The Unmaking of a 'Landmark'
description: PRESERVATIONISTS have had more than a generation to mull over what makes a landmark. But the question of what "unmakes" one is an issue that has not yet been seriously joined.

title: Saudi Clergy and Scholars Petition for Change
description: A group of religious scholars and members of the Muslim clergy have presented King Fahd with a petition demanding the creation of an often-promised consultative council through which Saudis who are not members of the royal family could participate in governing.

title: Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Judging the Reagans
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Rhode Island; Homosexual Ban Prompts a Vote Against R.O.T.C.
description: The faculty senate at the University of Rhode Island has voted to eliminate the Reserve Officers Training Corps program by 1998 unless the Defense Department reverses its ban on homosexuals in the military.

title: U.S., in Switch, Plans to Keep Out People Infected With AIDS Virus
description: Bowing to pressure from conservatives, the Government has halted a plan to allow people infected with the AIDS virus to enter the United States, Bush Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: The Region; New York Budget Cuts: Some Scars Don't Heal
description: IF New York City were a typical wage earner, it might get a second job, apply for a home equity loan, subsist on junk food for a while or even leave town for some place less expensive. If it were a business, it could raise prices, shed some assets, shutter some divisions, subsist on junk bonds or even close shop.

title: The Maestro of Chin Music
description: LARRY KING ONCE hung up on my brother. It was 1980, and my brother, who was 14, called King's national radio talk show from his bedroom. The phone rang for 20 minutes. When King picked up the line, he said: "Portland, Oregon. Hello." "Hi, Larry," my brother said. "I was wondering what you think about Mount St. Helens." King paused for a moment, then offered, "How can you have an opinion about a volcano?" And

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BRONXVILLE BOY SCOUT TROOP 1;
For 75 Years, a Reliance on Flint, Knots and Other Traditions
description: FORWARD, HARCH!

title: Making a Difference; Looking for Miracles at Embattled LTV
description: DAVID H. HOAG has taken some bold steps to pry the LTV Corporation out of its tangled bankruptcy since he took command as chief executive in January. But finding peace among 21,000 creditors bitter about $4.9 billion owed by LTV since its 1986 filing may require miracles.

title: Marjorie Whigham Married in Georgia
description: Marjorie Germaine Whigham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raybun M. Whigham of Augusta, Ga., was married yesterday to Homer Desir, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kleber Desir of New York. The Rev. Nathaniel T. Young performed the ceremony at the Thankful Baptist Church in Augusta.

title: Old West, New Twist at the Smithsonian
description: "The West as America: Reinterpreting Images of the Frontier, 1820-1920," at the National Museum of American Art, represents art-historical revisionism of the kind that has given rise to the phrase political correctness. The show preaches to visitors in wall texts laden with forced analyses and inflammatory observations. It has, justifiably, provoked heated criticism and even editorials in major newspapers and magazines.

title: Amtrak
description: To the Editor: I recently thought of traveling by train from Chicago to Washington with a stop in Cleveland to visit friends. Amtrak offers the following "service": an 800-mile trip in about 18 hours (an average of 45 miles an hour), one train per day, stopping in Cleveland at 2 A.M.

title: The Executive Computer; More Oomph With Mac's System 7.0
description: The Apple Macintosh has long been acknowledged as easier to use than the more widely sold I.B.M. PC's and compatibles, and the key to that ease of use has been the computer's operating system software. Apple Computer Inc.'s improved version of the Macintosh operating system, called System 7.0, adds more power to the computer without increasing its complexity.

title: Resist the Anti-Zoo Zealots
description: Imagine opening your morning newspaper to discover that the Bronx Zoo or the National Zoo are shutting their doors forever.

title: Give Student Athletes Free College Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Waddy Fault Captures a Victim
description: The legend of the Bermuda Triangle is mostly a fraud, based on bad weather and boggled navigators over a huge territory, but there is one place in the world that can gobble up unsuspecting college basketball recruits.

title: An Ulster Protestant Group Says It Killed Irish Politician
description: A Protestant paramilitary group said today that it killed a prominent politician last month at his home in the Irish Republic.

title: 'The Enigma of Suicide'
description: To the Editor:

title: Celeste P. Colyer Planning to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Celeste Patricia Colyer and Peter Cornelis Boele have been announced by her parents, Patricia Benedict Colyer of Greenwich, Conn., and John M. Colyer Jr. of New York.

title: The Nation; A Revival: The Campaign Finance Show
description: WATCHING senators rise on the chamber's floor last week to denounce the way they and their peers finance their campaigns was like watching an episode of "Twin Peaks," the slow-moving but sometimes intriguing TV series: It felt as if you had seen it before. And you knew it wasn't going anywhere fast.

title: Royal Hats Are Not For Doffing
description: Even in primitive societies, the most important people in the tribe wear something on their heads. For Queen Elizabeth II of England, who bids farewell to these shores today after exhibiting the sort of quiet style that local glamour queens are not known for, the principal fashion statement was the hat. (Her other important accessory was her structured handbags. But aside from the question of what she carried in them -- certainly not carfare -- they were uninteresting.)

title: Susan E. Sprich To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sprich of Waban, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Elisabeth Sprich, and Kyle Thomas Buckminster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Buckminster of Framingham, Mass.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Georgia and Stanford Gain N.C.A.A. Final Patricio Arnold of the University of Georgia defeated Stanford's Alex O'Brien, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's singles tournament in Athens, Ga. In the other semifinal, Jared Palmer of Stanford beat Southern California's Donny Isaak, 6-3, 7-6. Arnold and O'Brien played a patchy match with 11 service breaks in 20 games, but Arnold's big forehand wore down O'Brien, who double-faulted twice when serving for the second set at 5-4. Arnold evened the score at 5-5, held serve to get to 6-5, then broke O'Brien on another double fault by the Stanford player to win the set, 7-5, and the match. Arnold is planning to transfer to the University of South Florida next fall. Yugoslavia Qualifies for World Team Cup Final: Defending champion Yugoslavia defeated Switzerland, 2-1, on singles victories by Goran Prpic and Goran Ivanisevic in Dusseldorf, Germany, to qualify for the final of the World Team Cup. Ivanisevic defeated Jakob Hlasek, 6-4, 6-3, and Prpic beat Marc Rosset, 6-3, 6-4, to assure Yugoslavia a berth against Sweden in the title match today. Switzerland won the doubles when Marc Rosset and Jakob Hlasek defeated Ivanisevic and Slobodan Zivojinovic, 3-6, 6-1, 7-6. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the world's top player, suffered a strained thigh muscle on Friday, and there had been some doubt about whether he would be able to play. But an official of the Association of Tennis Professionals, Richard Evans, said that Edberg was feeling better and would play both in the singles and doubles.
