(AP) Kelesi Upsets Martinez in Geneva: Helen Kelesi of Canada upset top-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain, 6-4, 6-7, 6-2, in the semifinals of the European Open in Geneva. Second-seeded Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere, a Bulgarian who lives in Switzerland, defeated Tami Whitlinger of the United States, 6-1, 6-3. (AP) Tarango Loses in A.T.P. Semifinal: Paolo Cane of Italy defeated Jeff Tarango of the United States, 6-4, 6-4, in the semifinals of the A.T.P. tournament in Bologna, Italy. Cane will play the winner of the match between Italy's Omar Camporese and Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden. (AP) GOLF Richard Holds Off King to Retain Lead Deb Richard held off Betsy King to retain the lead yesterday after three rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Corning (N.Y.) Classic. King had seven birdies in a near-flawless round of 65 to move to three shots off the lead, while Richard carded an erratic 69. King, the third-leading money-winner in the history of the L.P.G.A. Tour, started at two under, seven shots behind Richard. But King's round, the lowest of the tournament so far, moved her to nine-under 207 on the par-72, 6,070-yard Corning Country Club course. Richard had six birdies and three bogeys to finish at 204, 12 under par. Ayako Okamoto of Japan, the 1989 Corning champion, and Colleen Walker were in third at seven under. (AP) Langer and Riley Share Lead: Bernhard Langer shot a second 67 to moved into a share of the lead with Wayne Riley of Australia after two rounds of the British P.G.A. Championship in Virginia Water, England. Riley, who set a course record with a 63 in the opening round, managed only a 71 in the second round. Tied for third, one stroke back, were Gordon Brand Jr. and Colin Montgomerie of Scotland, Stephen Richardson and Mark James of England and Eamon Darcy of Ireland. Darcy, Montgomerie and Richardson each shot a 66. James had a 68 and Brand a 69. Seve Ballesteros of Spain followed his opening round 67 with a 69 and was two strokes off the lead. Masters winner Ian Woosnam shot his second 70 to fall six shots back, one behind British Open champion Nick Faldo, who also had a 70. (AP) U.C.L.A. Captures Women's Team Championship: LaRee Sugg, who took a two-stroke penalty earlier in her round, rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole to give U.C.L.A. the team title over San Jose State at the N.C.A.A. women's championships in Columbus, Ohio. Annika Sorenstam of Arizona, a freshman from Sweden, won medalist honors with a final-round 74 to finish at two-over-par 290, one stroke better than U.C.L.A.'s Christy Erb at Ohio State's Scarlet Course. U.C.L.A., which won its first women's national championship, began with a two-stroke advantage over San Jose State, which won national titles in 1987 and 1989.(AP) Jerseyans Finish 2 Strokes Off Record: Bob Housen and Vic Gerard of Hominy Hills, N.J., had 2 eagles, 11 birdies and only 1 bogey in scoring a total of 130 to win the 20th annual Wilson Cup, a 36-hole better-ball tournament at the Scarsdale Golf Club in Hartsdale, N.Y.The total was two strokes off the tournament record set by Jon Doppelt and Bill Hadden in 1988. Housen and Gerard closed out their final five holes with four birdies and an eagle. Three teams -- Yale, Woodmere and Mountain Ridge -- were six strokes back at 136 to share second place. COLLEGE BASEBALL Unbeaten Florida State Closing In Florida State reliever Tim Davis had 12 strikeouts and gave up one run in seven innings yesterday to lead the Seminoles to a 5-2 victory over Alabama in the Atlantic Regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament in Tallahassee, Fla. Top-seeded Florida State is the only unbeaten team in the regional and needs just one more victory to earn its fourth trip in six years to the College World Series. An elimination-round game between Georgia Tech (41-25) and St. John's (34-13-1) was postponed in the fourth inning by a sudden downpour with Tech leading, 1-0. The eventual winner is to meet Alabama in another elimination-round game, with the winner needing to beat Florida State twice to upset the Seminoles.

title: Too Many People and Not Enough Places to Go
description: As Memorial Day arrives and the children are let out of school, attention turns to the coveted summer getaway. But the hottest travel destinations are swarming with tourists. Getting away from the crowds has become a mission impossible. And that's not the only price society is paying for the explosion in world travel.

title: Rapist at Large
description: PREDATOR Rape, Madness, and Injustice in Seattle. By Jack Olsen. 366 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $19.95.

title: Marianne Spafford Weds
description: Marianne Wood Spafford, a daughter of Joan Wood Spafford of Oyster Bay, L.I., and John K. Spafford of Lake Wylie, S.C., and Erie, Pa., was married yesterday in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Todd Kerr Glosson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald K. Glosson of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Glosson, 29 years old, is an account manager at Wachovia Bank and Trust in Winston-Salem, N.C. Her husband, 29, graduated from Duke University and is studying management at Wake Forest University.

title: Technology; Refining the Art of Giving Medicine With a Deft Jolt of Electricity
description: Ten years ago, the Alza Corporation introduced the first skin patch that delivered controlled amounts of a drug continuously over a long time. Now, Alza and other companies are working on improving the technology of such transdermal therapeutic systems to deliver new drugs that have resisted this method, to provide greater amounts of existing drugs and to exert greater control over dosage and timing.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NORTH CANAAN;
Zoning Code? On Second Thought, Forget It
description: AFTER weeks of spirited debate over whether zoning regulations would help or hurt North Canaan's nearly 3,300 residents, the verdict is in. Last month, residents in the small town nestled between Canaan Mountain and the Massachusetts border voted 748 to 519 to repeal their first zoning ordinance. The vote came as the process of drafting specific land-use regulations was nearing completion after more than three years of work.

title: Katherine Thomsen, Banker, Wed in Connecticut
description: Katherine Long Thomsen, a community banker for New Connecticut Bank and Trust in Stamford, Conn., and Bruce James Love, an underwriter for the National Insurance Company in Hartford, were married yesterday by the Rev. Edward R. Danks at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The bride, 28 years old, graduated from Mount Holyoke College. She is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald L. Thomsen Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. Her husband, 29, graduated from the University of Rhode Island. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Love of Venice, Fla.

title: Benumbed in Israel
description: THE CONTINUING SILENCE OF A POET The Collected Stories of A. B. Yehoshua. 328 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $9.95.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Burlington, Vt.;
Resolving A 7-Year Battle
description: AFTER seven years, five proposals and considerable controversy, construction will begin this summer on offices for the State Department of Health on a vacant lot in the heart of this city's downtown.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Austin
description: Austin is unabashedly hip. Its glorious hike-and-bike trail, which skirts Lake Austin in the middle of the city, is populated with some of the healthiest, handsomest, best-turned-out young people in America. Its cutting-edge restaurants serve up things like barbecue duck and smoked gouda pizza and sweetbreads in lime butter with cumin, serranos and pumpkin seeds.

title: Debate Over Civil Right Bill Raises Questions About the Law and Job Bias
description: Lurking behind the intense politics of this year's civil rights bill are several serious questions about the law and job discrimination.

title: Review/Dance; Energetic Choreography To Dylan and Hendrix
description: Whenever Bebe Miller steps on stage, she brings excitement with her. She certainly generated energy Thursday night when Bebe Miller and Company performed at St. Mark's Church as an attraction of the church's Danspace Project. She threatened to shake herself apart in "The Hendrix Project," a new work, and she danced frantically about a small plot of grass in her solo, "Rain."

title: Yes, but Can She Make Them Swoon?
description: ONCE upon a time, women assumed that when they became a force in the workplace, they would be judged on their merits rather than their appearance.

title: Thomas Robeson Morse Jr., Retired Justice, 63
description: Thomas Robeson Morse Jr., a retired chief justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court, died of Alzheimer's disease on Wednesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 63.

title: Elizabeth Chuday Wed in Baltimore
description: Elizabeth Ann Chuday, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Chuday of Cinnaminson, N.J., was married in Baltimore yesterday to David Simson Musgrave, the son of David A. Musgrave of Rindge, N.H., and Merlyn Simson of Bowie, Md. The Rev. Harry Holfelder officiated at the First and Franklin Street Presbyterian Church.

title:
DINING OUT;
French Fare That Is Better Than Ever
description: JOSEPH GOMEZ bought Le Petit Chateau in Bernardsville nine years ago. Since then, it has undergone many changes: it has been redecorated, and chefs and servers have come and gone. In fact, the only thing that has really been consistent at this Somerset County restaurant is a steady improvement in all areas.

title: Anne R. Chapin Weds Dr. W. S. Martin
description: Anne Roberts Chapin, a daughter of Neil Chapin Jr. of Sarasota, Fla., and Mrs. Lincoln Stevenson of Rye, N.Y., was married in Rye yesterday to Dr. William Stanley Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Dean Martin of Rochester, Vt. The Rev. Nancy Hanna performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ's Church.

title: Democracy in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PLANETS By James Finney Boylan.Poseidon, $18.95.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Philadelphia Results in Doubt
description: Errors in the reporting of ballot totals from this city's primary election last Tuesday could mean that the outcome of some races believed already decided, including Frank Rizzo's apparent Republican nomination for mayor, will be reversed.

title: Slaney Gropes for a Memory, Then Re-creates It
description: For all the young whippersnappers threatening to nudge them aside, several of the ancients in track and field still seem downright adamant against stepping aside to make room.

title: France Places Its Bets On High Technology
description: WITH its 180-mile-an-hour Train a Grande Vitesse, France is the world leader in high-speed trains, and the Concorde makes it, with Britain, the leader in supersonic passenger planes. Obtaining two-thirds of its electricity from nuclear power, France is arguably No. 1 in reactor technology. The Ariane satellite-launching program that it leads and Airbus, the Toulouse-based aircraft consortium, are strong competitors for American aerospace companies, while the Mirage 2000 fighter and Exocet missile are among the most sophisticated and sought-after wares in the world's arms bazaar.

title: JAPAN ENDS TALKS WITH NORTH KOREA
description: Japan's negotiations with North Korea to establish diplomatic relations have collapsed, at least for the time being, after Pyongyang angrily refused to allow international inspection of its nuclear installations or to investigate the whereabouts of a woman who the Japanese police suspect was kidnapped by North Korean agents and forced to train terrorists.

title: Magic Knew Riley Had Eyes on New York
description: Magic Johnson interrupts his quest for a sixth National Basketball Association championship ring today for an in-depth commentary on Pat Riley's imminent signing to coach the Knicks.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Just when we thought we had a peace that would last, along comes Tom Horton to tell us we have a new enemy ("Deer on Your Doorstep," April 28). And who is it? Not Iraq, not the Soviet Union, but an enemy far more dangerous because it is right here in our midst -- a domestic enemy, if you will. This enemy is none other than Bambi, who is described by one wildlife biologist as a rat with hoofs. "Across the country," writes Horton, "hordes of deer are damaging millions of dollars worth of shrubs and plantings . . . ."

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: BECAUSE politicians sometimes seem to have glass eyes, seeing things other people do not, it's important to have someone around like Meyer S. Schreiber to set the record straight. Since he retired as a professor of social work at Kean College two years ago, he has taken his local government in South Orange at its word of being representative of the people, all the people, including him.

title:
Your Own Account;
Finding Money to Start a Business
description: With bank credit tight and droves of corporate dropouts eager to start their own businesses, finding the necessary capital has become a big hurdle.

title: Disabled Youth to Compete in Games
description: AFTER numerous operations, Clinton Brown 3d, 9 years old, of Hicksville, is due for more surgery. Clinton is a diastrophic dwarf.

title: Food; King Sugar
description: "EVERYTHING IN THE CARIBBEAN IS sweeter," declares my Havana-born friend over dessert, gazing into my eyes just long enough to make me wonder if he's referring to something other than the rich Cuban vanilla-egg custard that's just arrived at our table. The natillas quiver in their cone-shaped aluminum cups, so milky yellow, lush and creamy that they dare you to stick in a finger. Or two. I blush, unsure whether the source of my embarrassment is the line I'm being fed or the pudding.

title: When Paint Looks Like Fiber And Wood Takes Flight
description: TWO disparate forms, wood vessels and quiltlike paintings, are joined by a geometric thread in "Prisms and Spheres," an exhibition on view through June 28 at H. Pelham Curtis Gallery in the New Canaan Library.

title: The Nation; Can NASA Make Space Seem Worth The Price?
description: SINCE President John F. Kennedy's call to put Americans on the moon, the space program has received strong financial and moral support from a country eager to share in the excitement. Although NASA's image has been on one long slide since the Challenger disaster in 1986, the agency's budget has continued to rise.

title: Ethics Issue Clouds Council's Bid for the Spotlight
description: For the better part of two years, Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council, has been marching toward a moment of truth: the last hours of next month's budget-approval process, in which he will, or won't, exert the robust new powers that he hopes will redefine his often belittled legislature.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about Charles H. Wilson, a retired vice president of Philip Morris U.S.A., identified a survivor incompletely. Charles H. Wilson Jr. is a son by the elder Mr. Wilson's first marriage, and is the stepson of Mr. Wilson's widow, the former Ysabel Angulo.

title: Judge Says Alien's Suit Was Filed Too Early
description: A Japanese scholar who was detained for 44 days because his name was on a "lookout list" of undesirable aliens was premature in filing a lawsuit to get his name off the list, a judge ruled.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MORE MOZART

title: Salinas Is Riding a Winning Streak in Mexico
description: When word came this week that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had won an international prize for environmental conservation, his opponents here, in the most polluted city in the world, could only shake their heads in awe. Whatever else can be said about him, Mexico's President is on a roll.

title: An Independent C.I.A., but Leaner, Should Stick to Its Brief
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Party Jostles to Fill Void Left by Gandhi's Assassination
description: India's Congress Party was locked in a struggle today to find a new leader as rivals moved in to fill the vacuum created by the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Making a Difference; Aglow Again in the Valley
description: W. J. (JERRY) SANDERS 3d, never one of the more bashful guys in Silicon Valley, is crowing again. The flamboyant chief executive of the semiconductor maker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is seeing his company's fortunes rise after a $53.6 million loss last year.

title: Preservationist's Crusade: Save the Porch
description: RENEE KAHN is out to save porches. She knows how important they once were, as places to feel the breeze or greet the neighbors. And she says that porches are still important, even in this age of traffic outside and air-conditioning inside. She also knows about serious ailments, like rot, that can attack porches, and she fights against some modern remedies, like replacing worn wood with shiny vinyl.

title: First Step on the Road: Safeguarding Health
description: FOR people planning to visit the tropics, an important benefit is the rising availability of travel medicine clinics. There are probably 400 clinics opening or in the planning stages, and 1,200 clinics, physicians' offices, health services and hospitals are authorized to give yellow-fever shots, a key immunization in tropical medicine. Any number of these yellow-fever stations may be full-scale travel clinics.

title: All the Pentagon's Men
description: THE COMMANDERS

title:
BACK TALK;
In Francs or Pounds, Women Serve Up Equal Entertainment
description: When the women take the court at Roland Garros for the French Open tomorrow they will be, in effect, second-class citizens.

title: Mississippi
description: To the Editor: Thank you, Jennifer Ackerman ("In the Delta, the Blues Play On," Travel, April 21), for solving a 47-year-old mystery. During the winter of 1943-44, when we aviation cadets were allowed off the base outside of Greenwood, Miss., our target was Lusco's restaurant, an Italian grocery that in some miraculous way had been lifted from Mulberry Street and set down in the middle of Mississippi. To reach the restaurant in the rear, one had to pass through the store with its stacked cans of olive oil and cheeses hanging from the tin ceiling. One sniff was enough to convince a homesick New Yorker that he was back in Little Italy.

title: French
description: To the Editor: Bravo to David Finkle for his apt description of a seemingly un-French phenomenon, that of finding it difficult to find someone in France with whom to speak French (Travel, March 31). One wonders, however, whether the battalions of English-speaking people he encountered in France were, well, French.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about five towns' refusal to repay the State of Massachusetts for school repair and construction loans misstated the state's bond rating. The Standard & Poor's Corporation rates Massachusetts bonds BBB, not BB. The BBB category reflects an "adequate capacity to pay interest and repay principle," in Standard & Poor's words; BB is considered "speculative."

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Eastchester, N.Y. 340,000 33 Ridge Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; entry hall, country kitchen, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,100. Pound Ridge, N.Y. 260,000 109 Trinity Pass 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 91-year-old carriage house; full basement, screened porch, security system, 1-car garage; taxes $2,839. Yonkers, N.Y. 278,000 72 Deshon Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 86-year-old stone carriage house; fireplace, sitting room, porch, landscaping; taxes $2,988. Canton, Conn. 160,000 28 Bristol Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; h/w floors, pantry, 1 acre; taxes $2,980. Newington, Conn. 130,000 431 Mountain Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old duplex; new family room, fireplace, fenced yard; taxes $1,378. Old Saybrook, Conn. 166,000 248 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old Dutch colonial; attic fan, pool, walk to beach, 0.50 acre; taxes $2,365. OTHER AREAS Franklin Square, L.I. 164,000 216 Rintin Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath and 2 half-bath, 45-year-old brick Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Garden City, L.I. 253,000 15 Roxbury Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,300. Jackson, N.J. 110,000 1 Stephanie Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, family room, w/w carpeting, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,343.

title: Taking the Rap for Dad
description: IF YOU REALLY LOVED ME

title: From Geo, an Aptly Named Convertible
description: It will come as no surprise that driving in New York is onerous. Defiant pedestrians cross anywhere and anytime. Trucks and taxis own the streets. Bicycle messengers, trying to stave off extinction by the fax machine, seem to seek it in daredevil dashes. Traffic crawls or it races and there is nothing in between.

title: Pie Lady Steals 'Sweeney' Revival
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM'S operatic 1979 Broadway musical, "Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street," has settled in at Theater 3 in Port Jefferson. "Sweeney Todd" is a culinary musical melodrama with villains, heros, heroines and an ending in which everyone receives his or her just desserts.

title: Replacement Doorsills
description: EXTERIOR doorsills are subject to wear and can also develop rot. Mildly decayed sills can sometimes be repaired using two-part wood hardener and filler available. But worn and badly decayed sills have to be replaced. Although the job may look intimidating, it is usually not too difficult for an amateur with modest carpentry skills.

title: Ms. Gottlieb Weds Brad Schwartzberg
description: Jennifer Jo Gottlieb, a daughter of Dr. Terre Larsen of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Allen Gottlieb of New York, was married last evening to Brad Jeffrey Schwartzberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schwartzberg of Old Westbury, L.I., and Williams Island, Fla. Rabbi Mitchell Chefitz officiated at the Turnberry Isle Country Club in North Miami Beach.

title: For Brothers, Poetry Is in Their Genes
description: ALLEN GINSBERG, the flamboyant poet, and Eugene Brooks, a subdued lawyer from Plainview, have a great deal in common.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Times Magazine today about Larry King, the talk- show host, says he and his wife, Julie Alexander, are in the midst of divorce proceedings. On Thursday, after the magazine had gone to press, Mr. King's lawyer, Mark A. Barondess, said the couple were withdrawing the divorce filings.

title: Alaska's Vast Bounty of National Parks
description: "THERE'S a bear!" That statement by a travel companion was roundly amplified as I turned to discover the animal six feet away. I was close enough to see its shaggy fur rippling as it lumbered across our path in an ursine encounter of the unintentional kind. True, I had come to Katmai to see bears in their natural habitat -- but not that close.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My front door is exposed to the sun and needs refinishing this year. It is a birch color and is now bleached-looking and unattractive. Can you tell me how to refinish this?

title: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER
description: Why is it sadder to bury a fallen woman soldier -- a wife, mother, daughter and sister -- than to inter a husband, father, son and brother (Hers: "Requiem for a Soldier," by Linda Bird Francke, April 21)? One seems just as terrible as the other to me.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My front door is exposed to the sun and needs refinishing this year. It is a birch color and is now bleached-looking and unattractive. Can you tell me how to refinish this?

title: Library Captures Its Past On Disks
description: The Library of Congress is a lot more than books. Among its other activities, for example, is a series of live radio concerts that began in 1925 and are now broadcast by American Public Radio. Recently two of these programs have been issued on compact disks by the library, the first of a series called "Living Collections From the Library of Congress."

title: Managing; A Revival of the Quality Circle
description: Quality circles.

title: The Rising Costs of Co-ops and Condos
description: THE owners of New York City's co-ops and condominiums have emerged from a decade of sharply rising operating costs only to face a triple whammy of new increases beginning this spring: the city administration's proposed round of tax rises, a new labor contract for building employees and a wave of mortgage refinancings.

title: Self-Administering Hospital Analgesics
description: We were pleased to see an article on Patient Controlled Analgesia [ "Hospitals Let Patients Control Painkillers," March 10 ] . Some 300 postoperative patients at Huntington Hospital have had the opportunity to have P.C.A. since November 1990. This highly acclaimed service was initiated by the department of anesthesia, implemented by our nursing staff, and is monitored on an ongoing basis by both physicians and nurses.

title: Suzanne Noga Is Married
description: Suzanne Marie Noga, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Noga of Fairfield, Conn., was married in Fairfield yesterday to Edwin Dainis Miska, the son of Karin Miska of Fairfield and the late Laimons Miska. The Rev. Robert Nemeth officiated at St. Emery's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Miska, 29 years old, is an analyst at Neuberger & Berman, an investment advisory firm in New York. She graduated from Wheaton College. Mr. Miska, also 29, is a securities analyst with Lieber & Company in Purchase, N.Y. He is a cum laude graduate of Boston University.

title: Kathleen Mitchell Is Wed
description: Kathleen Anne Mitchell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Mitchell of Darien, Conn., was married in Darien yesterday to Mark Scott Gregory, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gregory of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. William Donovan officiated at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Gregory, 26 years old, is the vice president for operations of European Business Contact Inc., a credit reporting company in Stamford, Conn. She graduated from Catholic University. Mr. Gregory, 30, is an associate in the Stamford office of the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren. He graduated from Brown University and received a law degree from Boston University.

title: Angela B. Wu, Engineer, Weds
description: Angela B. Wu, a daughter of Bevan P. F. Wu of Thornwood, N.Y., and Maybeth M. T. Yen of Fremont, Calif., was married in New York yesterday to Orville G. Lunking, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lunking of Olney, Md. The Rev. Edward C. Horne officiated at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew.

title: What Possessed A.S. Byatt?
description: On a drab, wintry afternoon in the London section of Putney, A. S. Byatt arrives home late by minicab, waving frantically at me through the back window. I have been standing conspicuously by the rosebush outside her Victorian brick house awaiting her, trying to decode a Latin inscription she has placed above her forbidding doorway. Rather grandly, it reads, "Semper eadem" -- "Always the same," Queen Elizabeth I's motto, declaring steadfast reliability -- a more wishful than accurate sentiment, perhaps. Since the unexpected success of her fifth novel, "Possession," Antonia Byatt's routine has been rudely upset by her belated stardom. However, the inscription should not be taken literally; it's only an allusion. In A. S. Byatt's heady world, even a humble doorway is a vehicle for scholastic expression.

title: Making a Difference; Behind Extended Trading: Mr. Ketchum's 'Heresy'
description: When the Securities and Exchange Commission last week approved key parts of a plan by the New York Stock Exchange for 24-hour trading, there were kudos throughout Wall Street about the Big Board's creativity. But few realized that the seed for the initiative had been planted five years ago by a man who now works for a Big Board competitor.

title: Miss Teller Weds Peter Malone in Massachusetts
description: Catherine Alden Teller, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. A. Richard Teller of Findlay, Ohio, was married in Edgartown, Mass., yesterday to Peter Malone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Malone of North Falmouth, Mass. Bishop James M. Ault of the United Methodist Church in Edgartown performed the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church. Mrs. Malone, 29 years old, is a program assistant at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in Cambridge, Mass. She graduated from Ohio Wesleyan University. Mr. Malone, 36, is a managing director of CSP Associates, an aerospace consulting company in Cambridge. He graduated from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and received a doctorate in international relations from Tufts University and a J.D. from Harvard University. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title:
The Cultivated Gardener;
Organically Treated Roses (and Pests)
description: I grow roses organically. To some, these are fighting words. They insist on telling me it is impossible, yet I maintain my landlady's formal garden with more than 40 roses (floribundas, hybrid teas and grandifloras -- no easy-to-grow species here) without a regular regimen of chemical sprays and dusts. I simply keep the plants and soil healthy and vital, rely on natural predators and, when needed, use nontoxic alternatives to chemicals.

title: Son of Police Lieutenant Is Killed After Apparent Mistake of Identity
description: In what was apparently a case of mistaken identity, the 14-year-old son of a Brooklyn police lieutenant was shot in the back and killed while riding his bicycle early Friday evening, the police said yesterday.

title: Headliners; Passing the Baton
description: It's traditional for an orchestra to pick a new conductor after several trial engagements. But the American Symphony Orchestra was apparently so impressed with Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College and principal guest conductor of the Hudson Valley Philharmonic, that they announced last week that he would take over the directorship next season. He will succeed Catherine Comet, who is leaving because of differences over administrative matters. The symphony's management said they felt that with all her guest appearances at other orchestras she was spreading herself too thin. Miss Comet said she was frustrated because the American Symphony, which was founded in 1962 by Leopold Stokowski, consists of freelance musicians. "It is impossible to build an orchestra sound," she said. Mr. Botstein said that he, too, would like to aim for a steadier membership and "to do something serious with contemporary music in a non-ghettoized way that is neither tokenism nor a segregated event."

title: Out in the Proving Grounds, Times Get Tougher
description: One never knows what to expect at Performance Space 122, though the small experimentalist performing-arts center, on First Avenue in lower Manhattan, has been confounding expectations for 11 years now. And that is the charm of the place and of a handful of theaters like it -- places that have not only allowed but encouraged wild experimentation and have served as proving grounds for artists who have become important figures in theater, dance and music.

title: Elizabeth Eldredge Marries
description: Dr. Elizabeth Atwood Eldredge, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. LeRoy Lincoln Eldredge Jr. of Hingham, Mass., was married there yesterday to George Leonidas Alexakos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo N. Alexakos of San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Nicholas Alexakos, a brother of the groom, performed the Baptist ceremony at the Old Ship Church. Mrs. Alexakos, 32 years old, is starting a residency in anesthesiology at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. She graduated from Dartmouth College, as did her husband, and received her M.D. from the University of Vermont. Mr. Alexakos, 31, has a master's degree from the American Graduate School of International Management in Phoenix. He is a bank examiner with the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston.

title: Miss VanHoven Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. VanHoven of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Tracy Brinkerhoff VanHoven and Sherman Taylor Hoyt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Sherman Hoyt of Hollis, N.H.

title: Ms. Robins Wed To Craig Albright
description: Susannah Fitzhugh Robins, a marketing director in San Francisco, and Craig Holeman Albright, the founder and president of an investment firm there, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Rugby Auer performed the ceremony.

title: Stewart Set to Return
description: There is bad news for Oakland's competition in the American League West: DAVE STEWART is ready to return to the mound.

title: Wall Street; Orders for Heavy-Duty Trucks Shift Into High Gear
description: Finally, there is some good news for the heavy-duty truck industry. When the latest industry figures were released earlier this month, net orders in April had surged to 9,530 trucks, a rise of a whopping 43.8 percent over March and the highest monthly total since last October's 11,663.

title: A Guide to Eight Natural Preserves
description: THE National Park Service oversees 54 million acres in Alaska -- 15 percent of the state's land. Of the 15 units managed by the Park Service, eight are national parks, parks that are, for the most part, pure wilderness; roads, trails and park facilities are few or nonexistent. Access is often limited to helicopters or light planes. Campers and hikers, unaccompanied by guides, should be well versed in wilderness survival techniques. For those without such skills, there are scores of guide services offering a variety of tours ranging from afternoon flight-seeing trips to weeklong fishing and camping expeditions.

title: Ms. Clarke Weds Edward Magrab
description: Christa Joan Clarke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Clarke of Rye, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Edward Brendan Magrab, a son of Dr. Phyllis R. Magrab of Cabin John, Md. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Water Club.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Securities and commodities exchanges in the United States will be closed in observance of Memorial Day. TUESDAY: Existing home sales for April will be released by the National Association of Realtors * End of five-week survey of Alaska to determine how much more cleanup is needed from Exxon Valdez spill.

title: Trying to Heal Effects of Head Injuries
description: JOHN SCALIA was 14 years old when a car hit his bicycle as he rode home from a Scout meeting two years ago. His mother, Laraine, recalls the day exactly, April 3.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RAGGED WAY PEOPLE FALL OUT OF LOVE By Elizabeth Cox.North Point, $18.95.

title: 'One Can Stand Up to Lies'
description: OPEN LETTERS

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-17

title: Dye Is Doing Better
description: The condition of Auburn football coach PAT DYE was upgraded to good from satisfactory yesterday, a day after major circulatory surgery, a school spokesman said.

title: Hispanic Voters Struggle to Find The Strength in Their Numbers
description: WHAT do a Puerto Rican single mother in the South Bronx, a Cuban-American businessman in Miami and a Mexican-American social worker from East Los Angeles have in common? The question is a real one to Hispanic politicians and community organizers grappling with the difficulty of translating population gains into increased political power.

title: Jane Adams Is Married to William McNulty Jr.
description: Jane Adams, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Lee Towne Adams of Forestville, N.Y., was married in Silver Creek, N.Y., yesterday to William Leon McNulty Jr., the son of Teresa McNulty of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Mr. McNulty.

title: A LOST VOICE
description: Scud is an ugly word ("A Lost Voice," by Anton Shammas, April 28). It forms clumsily upon the tongue and bruises the ear. It is not surprising that a writer engaged in creating revisionist history (that the Jewish community said no to partition; that the Palestinians did not dance on the rooftops as Scuds fell on Tel Aviv, etc.) takes this ugly word and uses it as his own lethal weapon. Fortunately, like the missile itself, its aim is inaccurate and the intellectual damage it does is irrelevant. GLORIA GOLDREICH Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: Style Makers; Gianna Majzler, Folk Art Clothes Designer
description: Fashion designers almost never cater to the gift industry, a world of sachets, gimcracks and cutesy-poo T-shirts. But Gianna Majzler, a former executive of the Nordstrom stores, decided that simple clothing with folk-art themes could crack the market.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
276 Suffolk Properties Going on the Block
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM Cape Cod in Coram, a three-bedroom colonial in Patchogue and a 100- by 100-foot lot in the Hardscrabble section of East Hampton are among 276 properties Suffolk County will put on the block next month.

title: Wall Street; A Family's Odd Bid To Cash Out
description: The Krieble family of Hartford is a frustrated bunch. Millionaires many times over, the Kriebles are the Rockefellers of the glue business, but they are having trouble getting a premium for their shares of the family business, the Loctite Corporation. And no one except their advisers seems to care.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Springfield, Mass.;
Pooling Funds For Industry
description: THE Massachusetts Government Land Bank, based in Boston, has joined with a consortium of 16 banks in this area to create a $17 million mortgage pool to help prepare three sites for industrial development. The land bank's $6.25 million commitment is the largest in its history.

title: Michelle McGuirk To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Terrence P. McGuirk of Stuart, Fla., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Michelle Connely McGuirk and James David O'Connor, a son of Mrs. David William O'Connor of Albany and the late Mr. O'Connor.

title:
Princeton Journal;
Garden's Splash of Color Will Be Memorial to Vibrant Mayor
description: BARBARA BOGGS SIGMUND, the popular Princeton Mayor who died of cancer last October, ran the borough with a vibrant, witty, unconventional style. Now, thanks to a dozen friends and colleagues, her memorial will also be splashy and alive.

title: Targeting the Grocery Shopper
description: A parade of food beckoned Ursula Lozo through the maze of aisles at the well-scrubbed Wegmans supermarket here on Bridge Street. A peppy woman with a jolly demeanor, she had her cart heaped with pasta, cleanser, frozen vegetables and other groceries. One of the roughly 25,000 people who buy their food each week at Wegmans, Ms. Lozo faithfully appears every Wednesday with her list.

title: Postings: $10.7 Million Grant Nullified; Atlantic Terminal Blow
description: The long-delayed Atlantic Terminal project in downtown Brooklyn was set back further last week when a Federal judge nullified a $10.7 million grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development that was to have subsidized the project's housing and offices. The court found that the agency had failed to consider whether the development would gentrify the neighborhood and force out poor, minority residents.

title: Sanders Will Be Back
description: DEION SANDERS'S next appearance in Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium may be in his other sport. Sanders, farmed out to Class AAA Richmond by the Braves on Wednesday night, may not resurface in the stadium until Aug. 27, when the Falcons meet Tampa Bay in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: Progress in Moving Homeless From Motels
description: A YEAR after the county began a special effort to double its stock of emergency housing, more of Westchester's homeless families are now living in emergency apartments than in motels. It is the first time since the county began keeping track of its homeless eight years ago that motels have not accounted for the majority of placements.

title: This Week: Mulching
description: Lack of rain and warm days make watering and mulching imperative. Soak newly planted roses, trees, shrubs and perennials to get them established. Mulch trees, shrubs and perennials with wood chips, shredded bark and leaves or salt hay. For azaleas and rhododendrons, use pine needles, oak leaves or other acid mulch; for flower and vegetable beds, use shredded chips, straw, salt hay or seaweed. As wood chips decay, they take nitrogen from the soil, so add extra nitrogen if plant leaves turn yellow.

title: The Region; Caught Between A Rock and The Future
description: THE once-thriving Connecticut economy, which pushed per capita income to the highest rungs in the nation in the 1980's, is sputtering on the verge of dramatic change, business leaders and economists say. Few agree on what the future holds, with both optimists and naysayers finding ample statistics to support their positions.

title: Tanya Bilchik to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bilchik of Johannesburg, South Africa, have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Tanya Rochelle Bilchik and Andrew David Wingate, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Wingate of Branford, Conn. Dr. Bilchik, 30 years old, is a fellow in nuclear medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. She received her M.D. degree from the University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg. Mr. Wingate, 36, is the vice president and general manager of the Highway Safety Corporation in Glastonbury, Conn., a maker of guardrails. He graduated magna cum laude from Brown University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: HENRY HASCUP;
Sports Questions? He Has the Answers
description: BY day, Henry Hascup is a corrosion technician for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, protecting underground gas pipes from corroding. But at night, on weekends and in other free time, he is often busy pursuing what he loves best: sports trivia.

title: Thousands of Buildings Lack Fire Sprinklers
description: THOUSANDS of Long Island stores, offices and government buildings are unprotected by sprinkler systems. Experts say such ceiling systems can save lives and reduce damage in case of fires.

title: INSIDE
description: Not Even Socialist Now?

title: What Lurks Inside the Vaults? Producers
description: The recording engineer at the PolyGram tape archives in Edison, N.J., had bad news for Gregg Geller, the producer of a forthcoming boxed set of the early music of Hank Williams Jr. They wanted to make a digital copy of the 1975 song "I Really Did," but playing the deteriorating master tape would strip the oxide that contains the music. The good news was that the oxide could be temporarily bound to the tape by baking it -- for eight hours at 130 degrees -- in a convection oven. This particular strain of faulty tape can be baked only twice before it's truly cooked -- that is, destroyed.

title: Judge Dismisses Case Citing Thornburgh's Policy
description: For the first time, a court has ordered a criminal charge dismissed because of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's policy of allowing talks between Federal prosecutors and defendants when no defense lawyer is present.

title: Data Bank/May 26, 1991
He Had a Heart, and for Oates That Was the Problem
description: In the summer of 1983, Johnny Oates wanted to quit his career as a manager.

title: Tapes Preserve Voices of History's Witnesses
description: THE tapes keep turning, and the tales keep coming -- recollections of fleeing Nazi Germany, of being the child of strikebreaking workers, of seeing a truck fall from the collapsing Mianus River Bridge. Around the state, professionals and amateur volunteers are conducting interviews that preserve the oral history of immigrants, millworkers, estate owners, artists, politicians -- all kinds of people, with memories distant and recent. Such projects reflect the trend among historians to look at the lives of ordinary people.

title: Sunday Outing; In a Mountaintop Park, No End of Great Vistas
description: Only 90 miles from New York City, the Minnewaska State Park atop the Shawangunk Mountains near here is a semi-wild area for enjoying nature in the rough.

title: Gounod's 'Faust' Closes A Season at the Shubert
description: TWO programs on Friday close one season and open another. The finale belongs to the Shubert Opera Company, wrapping up its third year of performances at its namesake theater in New Haven with a new production of Gounod's "Faust."

title: Making a Difference; Hard Times At L.A. Gear
description: ROBERT Y. GREENBERG sold wigs, roller skates and shoe laces before founding L.A. Gear Inc. in 1985, and since then he has sold enough sneakers to make the company third in the athletic footwear market, behind Nike and Reebok. But having been battered recently by poor merchandising and marketing and a weak economy, Mr. Greenberg said last week that L.A. Gear is now trying to sell a "substantial" minority stake in the company in what analysts say is an effort to keep it afloat.

title: Ms. Stone Is Wed to Dimitrios Trigonis
description: Elizabeth Ann Stone, a daughter of Robert L. Stone of New York and Williamstown, Mass., and the late Mary Lee Stone, was married yesterday to Dimitrios Trigonis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Trigonis of San Francisco, at the Conservatory of Flowers in San Francisco. The Rev. Meynardo Roxas performed the Methodist service.

title: Patriot Failures
description: Early in the Persian Gulf war, Americans saw videotaped replays of Patriot anti-missile missiles blowing Iraqi Scuds out of the sky above Dhahran. Later they saw the terrible aftermath of a Scud that had penetrated the Patriot screen and demolished a U.S. military barracks, inflicting the worst American casualties of the war.

title: Jennifer Dennis Wed to Andrew Farley
description: Jennifer Woodson Dennis, the daughter of John Purnell Dennis Jr. of Houston and Mrs. Robert Moorehead Crowell of Boston, was married in Houston yesterday to Andrew Daniel Farley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Newell Farley of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Catherine McKelvey performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral.

title: Style Makers; Frank Giorgini, Drum Maker
description: Some look a bit like bowling balls. Others resemble dumbbells and vases. They produce a variety of sounds like dripping water or rhythmic heartbeats. They are called udu drums, and are designed and sculptured by 43-year-old Frank Giorgini.

title:
KEEPING IT SHORT: A SEASON OF STORIES;
A Man Who Barked and Chased Cars
description: DRINKING DRY CLOUDS

title: Postings: Art Society Tour; A Gothic Castle on the Hudson
description: "This is kinda like a soap opera," said Henry Duffy as he spooled out the history of Lyndhurst. First, in 1838, William Paulding, a former Mayor of New York City, built a Gothic Revival castle overlooking the Hudson at Tarrytown for his retirement. In 1864, it passed to George Merritt, who doubled its size with the money he made by inventing a shock-absorbing spring for railroad carriages, which is how he met Jay Gould, the railroad baron, who bought the house in 1880 and added the country's then largest greenhouse.

title: Q and A
description: Refinancing Troubles Question: I am having extreme difficulty in obtaining refinancing on my Manhattan co-op, which I purchased for $73,000 in September 1989. The sponsor, who has sold only 16 percent of the apartments, financed $65,000 of the purchase price. Now a balloon payment of $52,000 is due next September of this year.

title: Jacob Clayman, Former Lobbyist and AFL-CIO Official, Dies at 86
description: Jacob Clayman, a former president of the Industrial Union Department of the AFL-CIO and retired president of the National Council of Senior Citizens, died Friday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: In a Sign of the Times, a Smaller Job Fair
description: AT 8:30 on a Thursday morning earlier this month a procession of yellow school buses from Mahopac to Mount Vernon began arriving at the County Center here. For 400 high school seniors from 23 Westchester school districts, this was their opportunity to meet face-to-face with the local job market. Each student came with 10 resumes, to leave with prospective employers at the county's fifth yearly Job Information Fair.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on the contents page of The Times Magazine on May 12, describing the cover illustration with an article about the British royal family, misidentified the member shown as No. 4. He was Prince Henry (nicknamed Harry), not Prince Harold.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold 131,900 4 Wildflower Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old patio home; eat-in-kitchen, c/a; monthly charges $120, taxes $2,784. Jackson 110,000 1 Stephanie Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, family room, w/w carpeting, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,343. Pennington 300,000 23 Baldwin Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; vaulted ceilings, deck, full basement; taxes $5,520. Ramsey 302,500 193 Myrtle Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 140-year-old colonial; 4 fireplaces, c/a, beamed ceilings; taxes $7,551. Wayne 135,000 1 Laurel Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old ranch; eat-in-kitchen, near lake and tennis court; taxes $2,322. Westfield 205,000 101 Dickson Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old split level; backs up to park, eat-in- kitchen, full basement; taxes $4,720. OTHER AREAS Eastchester, N.Y. 340,000 33 Ridge Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; entry hall, country kitchen, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,100. Canton, Conn. 160,000 28 Bristol Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; h/w floors, pantry, family room, 1 acre; taxes $2,980. Hicksville, L.I. 133,000 88 Earl Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement; taxes $2,600.

title:
KEEPING IT SHORT: A SEASON OF STORIES;
Crossing Borders
description: WOMAN HOLLERING CREEK

title: A Variation On Odd Couples
description: IF audience identification could determine a play's identity, "Okiboji" would be a shoo-in as a summer stock staple. But let's get real. It's no secret that the summer circuit of the sort that could embrace this play is near extinction, and that the likes of the work by Conrad Bishop and Elizabeth Fuller, now being presented by the Boston Post Road Stage Company, are likely to be found on the home box.

title: On the Street; In White Brides Trust
description: The traditional white or off-white wedding dress is reigning supreme. Color, suggested by fashion designers as the newest thing, was nowhere to be seen when these May brides were photographed at churches and at the Conservancy Gardens at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: The Scary Homes of England
description: Not for Simon Marsden any fear of ghosties and ghoulies and things that go bump in the night. This intrepid Englishman seeks out haunted houses, ruined castles, mysterious grottoes and their attendant spirits. In PHANTOMS OF THE ISLES: Further Tales From the Haunted Realm (Webb & Bower/Viking, $24.95), he shows such vintage haunted houses as Killua Castle, Trollers Gill, Loch Rannoch, Inverary Castle, even Westminster Abbey. (The place names alone are enough to make an Anglophile drool.) Glamis Castle, according to tradition the scene of Macbeth's murder of Duncan, is also included. There, in 1793, Sir Walter Scott wrote that he felt himself "too far from the living, and somewhat too near the dead." Mr. Marsden, a photographer and the author of "The Haunted Realm," is not just a dilettante ghost hunter. He calls himself "an independent folklorist" who collects stories of inexplicable phenomena in order to "restore a little imagination into a world that is daily being dispossessed of any mystery through the relentless and consuming march of science and technology." There are, he says, themes and recurring stories that come down to us through generations, and we must remember our ancient mysteries lest we lose our past. "Hell on earth," Mr. Marsden says, "is surely logic pursued to its futile and tedious conclusion."

title: Marquee Prompts 'Boo Moo!'
description: To the Editor:

title: Coins
description: In a collection of small islands in southeastern Papua New Guinea, a strange system of money and monetary exchange is surviving and even thriving amid the influence of modern culture.

title: Style Makers; Valerie Green, Aerobics and Exercise Instructor
description: Valerie Green knows all too well the boredom that can set in with even the most varied exercise program. An aerobics and exercise teacher in New York for nearly 10 years, Ms. Green was searching for ways to make her classes at the Manhattan Plaza Health Club more invigorating and at the same time more challenging.

title:
THEATER;
Life, With a Little Tenderizer
description: The first time I met Elaine May I was attending the University of Chicago. I was registered. Elaine was not. This did not prevent her from entering a philosophy class and convincing us that the participants in Plato's Symposium were all drunk. She did a good job.

title: Postings: Remodeling a Town House; 2 Apartments On 6 Floors
description: It was once home to Grenville Temple Emmet, law partner of Franklin D. Roosevelt and later F.D.R.'s minister to the Netherlands and Austria. In more recent years, it housed Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children. Now, the town house at 3 East 94th Street is to become an apartment building.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: It was refreshing to read a balanced piece on the issue of deer overpopulation. Horton successfully navigates the emotional subissues (like hunting and those who oppose it) that often bring such reports to polarized and nonconstructive conclusions. KIM LEIGHTON Marietta, Ga.

title: Archeologists to Go Back to Israeli Site
description: A TEAM of archeologists and students from five New Jersey colleges will soon return to Israel, where the group has been excavating a site that is believed to be the ancestral home of King David's wife.

title:
FOCUS;
A Drive to Restore Luster to Downtown Philadelphia
description: Despite a suit that threatened to halt construction, workers on the $523 million Pennsylvania Convention Center had poured 4,600 cubic yard of concrete by mid-May and installed 500 tons of steel reinforcing.

title: Perspectives: Middle-Density Housing; A Courtyard Finds a Place in Marble Hill
description: THE courtyard has an honorable history in New York City housing. The question is: Does it have a place in any of the affordable-housing developments that are mushrooming in middle-density locations of the Bronx? So far, the Bronx pipeline provides two-family or three-family town houses almost exclusively.

title: Unification Church Insists Trump Apologize
description: The president of the Unification Church of America demanded apologies yesterday from Donald J. Trump and two newspapers over what he called false, racist and inflammatory reports that the church was seeking to buy the the developer's Palm Beach estate, Mar-a-Lago.

title: Trading One World for Another
description: ON THE EVE OF UNCERTAIN TOMORROWS By Neil Bissoondath. 271 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $18.95.

title: Corrections
description: A listing last week of companies offering environmental travel vacations characterized the relationship between Salen Lindblad Cruising and the Oceanites Foundation incorrectly. The foundation is an independent nonprofit organization; it is not owned or operated by Salen Lindblad.

title: An Independent C.I.A., but Leaner, Should Stick to Its Brief; Make Full Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Sags Against Mark
A LOST VOICE
description: If Palestinians are so different from other Arabs because of their "Palestinian vernacular," why were they not as victimized by the Jordanian rule as by the Israeli; and why did they not dance in the streets and on their rooftops on that day in November 1947 when the United Nations partition was voted? Why did they save their dancing for the night 44 years later when the scuds of their Arab brothers hit the Israeli heart? SHEILA W. REICHER Linden, N.J.

title: Mutual Funds; For Direct-Sale Funds, a Rising Share
description: As competition in the mutual-fund industry intensifies, the market share of direct-marketed funds, which are mainly sold without sales charges, has steadily risen. Such funds are sold directly to investors, usually in advertising with toll-free numbers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Police Hunt for a Missing Boy, 8, in Central Park
description: Dozens of police officers using dogs and a helicopter searched Central Park yesterday for a missing 8-year-old boy who was last seen on Friday night talking to a stranger just inside the park.

title: When the Teacher Is a Broker/A special report.; Students in a Class on Investments Say the Lessons Meant Big Losses
description: In 1987, after he inherited $50,000 from his mother, Joseph Kallaher, a retired industrial arts teacher, and his wife, Mary, signed up at a local high school for an adult education course on the basics of investing. "We knew we were babes in the woods," he said. "Then, lo and behold, three blocks away is an investment class. And it was taught by Prudential-Bache, and not just the lowest guy on the totem pole, but a vice president."

title:
OUTDOORS;
A Spring Jaunt Through Arizona's Pima Canyon
description: It's been a wet spring in the Arizona desert, which means a couple of inches of rain fell a couple of months ago. The winter was also relatively rainy and snows that built on the mountains have slowly melted. So the canyons around Tucson, Ariz., have been running.

title: Numbers Plus 2
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Chess
description: Why settle for boring defensive play when a gambit can seize the initiative?

title: How to 'Win-Win' by Raising Oil Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Recession Expands Baby-Sitter Pool
description: EARLIER this spring, when Ellen Johnson placed an advertisement in a local paper for a part-time baby sitter for her three young children, more than three-dozen candidates applied for the job. The year before, said Mrs. Johnson, who lives in Hartsdale, the same ad would have drawn perhaps 10 responses.

title: Headliners; Deregulating the Ivy League
description: TO avoid expensive bidding wars, 23 colleges and universities in the Northeast have met each spring to agree on how much financial aid they will offer students who have been accepted by more than one of the schools.

title: Navy Halts Subs' 24-Hour Air Link to Bush
description: Budgetary constraints and the end of the cold war have brought a halt to the Navy's 24-hour air link between the President and nuclear-armed submarines, a Pentagon spokeswoman said today.

title: Jackson Outlines a Plan For Affordable Housing
description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson, accusing the Bush Administration of creating and then ignoring a nationwide homeless problem, called last week for the use of public and private pension funds to build affordable housing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CHARM OF PHYSICS By Sheldon L. Glashow. American Institute of Physics, $24.95.

title: Fasting Refugees in France Given Temporary Residence
description: The French Government has granted nearly 200 Kurdish, Turkish and African refugees on hunger strikes a three-month reprieve from expulsion while it considers their requests for political refugee status.

title: Vicksburg
description: To the Editor: The article on Historic Vicksburg, Miss. (Travel, April 21) mentions the Biedenharn Candy Company and Museum of Coca-Cola Memorabilia where the first Coca-Cola was bottled. I would like to add that it was Joseph A. Biedenharn who first bottled Coca-Cola in 1894. Four years ago I visited the magnificent Biedenharn home in Monroe, La. A guide gave a wonderful tour of the Bible Museum of the Emy-Lou Biedenharn Foundation, the Fountain Gallery, the main house and the beautiful gardens, named ELsong (the E and L standing for Emy-Lou) -- all gratis. The house is on Riverside Drive near the banks of the Ouachita River, a worthwhile detour for anyone in the vicinity. RUTH PUOTI Bronx

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My front door is exposed to the sun and needs refinishing this year. It is a birch color and is now bleached-looking and unattractive. Can you tell me how to refinish this?

title: The World; In Collapse, Ethiopia Calls On Washington
description: WITH the Army collapsing, the guerrillas descending on the capital, and the fallen dictator in flight from the country, Prime Minister Tesfaye Dinka last week exercised an old Ethiopian reflex: he telephoned the United States Embassy.

title: Behind Blueprints for 1 Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: The article "In Hong Kong; Antique Silks Evoke a Patrician Past" (Shopper's World, April 28) by Barbara Basler suggested the purchase of little pink shoes that had been used to bind female children's feet.

title: One Indian's Revolving Path to Prison
description: If the case of Patrick Croy demonstrates one thing, it is that it is sometimes easier to live in prison than on the streets as a symbol of defiance.

title: Data Update
Rangers Send Horava To Quebec for Guerard
description: The Rangers and the Quebec Nordiques swapped defensemen yesterday, with the Rangers sending MILOSLAV HORAVA to Quebec for STEPHANE GUERARD. Horava, a native of Czechoslovakia, played in 29 games for the Rangers last season, scoring one goal and getting six assists. Guerard saw no action with Quebec. (AP)

title: The Pope of the Art World
description: LEARNING TO LOOK By John Pope-Hennessy. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Doubleday. $27.50.

title: Headliners; Recycled Rhetoric
description: With Philadelphia on the verge of bankruptcy, it would seem that most voters' minds would be on how to close next year's projected $265 million deficit. But when Frank L. Rizzo decided to try for a comeback as mayor of the racially divided city, he drew on the same law-and-order themes that have served him in the past. Vowing to "take back the streets from the crack dealers who prey on innocent mothers, from the thugs who terrorize our senior citizens," the former police officer apparently managed to rouse enough voters to give him an upset victory in the Republican primary last week. According to preliminary results, he won the nomination by 1,100 votes of the 123,000 cast, defeating the party's endorsed candidate, former District Attorney Ronald D. Castille. If the vote is confirmed he will face another former District Attorney, Edward G. Rendell, in the November election. W. Wilson Goode, the city's first black mayor, who defeated Mr. Rizzo in 1983 and 1987, is barred from seeking another term.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Quincy, Mass.;
Confidence In the Market
description: IN an effort to turn the real estate slowdown to its long-term advantage, an Italian development company has bought back from Chemical Bank of New York the $15 million construction loan it used to put up an office building here.

title: For Bulls, Revenge May Be Sweep
description: They are not afraid of the Detroit Pistons. They are not afraid of the past. And now, the Chicago Bulls are one victory away from eliminating the team that eliminated them from the playoffs the three previous years.

title: Campus Life: Colgate; Shift in Teaching Seeks to Bolster Skills in Science
description: Science professors at Colgate University are changing teaching strategies in response to growing evidence that many students arrive at college lacking the mathematical skills necessary to succeed in science.

title: Dodgers Explode for 7 Early Runs and Gross Helps With Arm and Bat
description: Eddie Murray drove in three runs and Kevin Gross limited Cincinnati to five hits over seven innings today as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored seven runs in the first two innings and routed the Reds, 8-1.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the "Making a Difference" column last Sunday about the General Host Corporation included an erroneous sales figure supplied by the company for its lawn and garden chain, Frank's Nursery and Crafts. In 1983, the year it was acquired by General Host, Frank's had sales of $150 million, not $63 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's change of plan, an article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the comedy "Mr. Gogol and Mr. Preen" carries an outdated opening schedule. The play, now in previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, will open on June 9.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Yonkers Tackles Blight, Little by Little
description: LARGE-SCALE urban-renewal projects have been common in such Westchester County cities as White Plains and New Rochelle, but Yonkers has taken a different tack: It revitalizes its rundown areas a few blocks at a time.

description: A MODEL WORLD

title: Virginia Guest Weds in South
description: Virginia Guest of New York and E. Massie Valentine of Richmond were married on May 18 in King George, Va. The Rev. E. Allen Coffey performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's father, Raymond R. Guest. She is also the daughter of the late Elizabeth Polk Guest of Dark Harbor, Me. Mr. Valentine is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Corbin B. Valentine of Richmond.

title: The Wrong Medicine
description: First of two articles

title: World Comes Calling in Fairfield County
description: GUESTS from the United Nations in Fairfield County homes on a recent Sunday included the Moroccan Ambassador and his family of four, the Colombian Ambassador's family of six, an information officer from India and the Bulgarian Ambassador's wife and mother-in-law. For the past 35 years, officials from around the world have been visiting Connecticut, thanks to the International Hospitality Committee of Fairfield County.

title: Armed Youths Turn New Haven Into a Battleground
description: AT the funeral mass for Elvis Crnkovic at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in New Haven, the Rev. Robert Newman faced the crowd of more than 300 mourners and began recalling the honesty and kindness of the 16-year-old, who was shot and killed while he played basketball with his brother. The priest said that he was trying to understand why this son of Yugoslav immigrants, who died on May 8, had to become a victim of the violence that has claimed the lives of so many New Haven teen-agers.

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: I'd like to add another museum to those mentioned in "What's Doing in Cologne" (Travel, May 5): Das Ostasiatische Museum (East Asian Museum) near the university, which has a brilliant collection of Chinese, Japanese and Korean art. The only separate Asian art museum in Germany, it is in a contemporary building on a lagoon and has a delightful small restaurant.

title: Susan Gibbs to Wed Theodore Piccone
description: Francis C. Gibbs of Bailey Island, Me., and Margaret B. Gibbs of Brunswick, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Louise Gibbs, to Theodore Joseph Piccone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dante N. Piccone of Larchmont, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Homeless Families Relax at Fresh Air Fund Camp
description: For Constance Adamson, the best part of camping was sleep.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;
Resolving A 7-Year Battle
description: AFTER seven years, five proposals and considerable controversy, construction will begin this summer on offices for the State Department of Health on a vacant lot in the heart of this city's downtown.

title: In Guilford, a Little Taste of France
description: ONE step inside Whitfield Alley removes you in spirit from Guilford to a village inn somewhere in France. The menu adds to the illusion. Only the hearty greeting of the very American host brings you back to reality.

description: The engagement of Constance Crosby White to Stuart Jackson Kapp has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Sumner W. White 3d of Summit and Mantoloking, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Making Healthy Use of the Potato
description: MY Irish grandmother says everyone has a potato-shaped space inside. During my childhood, this meant that at every meal our plates were heaped with potatoes. "They're 90 percent water," she would say as she passed the butter. "There's nothing in them to make you fat."
