title: Glitches Aside, Penske Ready to Roll
description: Everything has been calibrated, tested, disassembled, reassembled, recalibrated, retested.

title: Betty Chien Is Wed to David Watson
description: Betty Shu-Kuei Chien, the daughter of Irene Liu Chien of San Jose, Calif., and the late H. S. Chien of Taipei, Taiwan, was married yesterday to David Murray Watson Jr., the son of Mrs. Frank A. Allen 3d of New York and Nonquitt, Mass., and Mr. Watson of Prince Frederick, Md. Judge Edward J. Nelson of Santa Clara County Criminal Court performed the ceremony in Hakone Garden, a park in Saratoga, Calif.

title: Man Shot to Death in Subway Station
description: A man was fatally shot by a mugger in a subway station in Queens yesterday, the transit police said.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HORSES IN ART

title: Pavin Is Making a Strong Bid to Join Game's Elite
description: Before this year, it was easy to exclude the name of Corey Pavin when speculating about who might become one of the game's next great players.

title: Quayle Asks if Plumbing Made Bushes Ill
description: Vice President Dan Quayle has talked with friends and staff members about the possibility that the thyroid ailment that struck President Bush and his wife might somehow be linked to "the ancient state of the plumbing and lead pipes" in the Vice-Presidential residence, Mr. Quayle's press secretary said today.

title: REQUIEM FOR A SOLDIER
description: Francke expresses mixed feelings about the obligations of women to serve and, perhaps, to die for their country.

title: Being Different Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss Leaders And Secrecy At the Big Board
description: Just over 199 years ago, a group of securities brokers, suffering from competition and a crash in prices, made a deal to fix commissions and set up a cartel to keep other brokers out of the business.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: Funny, while the recession leaves thin pickings for us bipeds, the Bambi boomers are moving into the kind of suburban neighborhods we can't afford anymore. They're helping themselves to such gourmet delights as sprinkler-fed yews, just as many of the Third Avenue watering holes, where we once grazed, are being shut down. And they don't even have Gold Cards.

title: Kyoko Ono Wed to Peter S. Kirby
description: Kyoko Ono, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tokuyuki Ono of Tokyo, and Peter Stenwall Kirby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kirby of Forest Hills, Queens, were married yesterday in Tokyo at the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Edo. Father Johane Petracco performed the ceremony.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Unlike Paul Tardif (Letters on Travel, April 21), I have always had excellent service from Cedok, the Government travel bureau, in Czechoslovakia. May I venture an opinion as to what has been happening? Since the advent of privatization, many former Cedok employees have started their own travel agencies. In fact, one of the best is Golden City Tour, whose representatives speak English, Spanish, German, French and Russian as well as Czech. They offer a room in a hotel only 15 minutes from the center of Prague (only slightly farther away than the Forum) for $50 or $70 a night for two people. They will also find accommodations in private homes. Their address is 24/215 Nerudova, CS 11800 Praha 1, Czechoslovakia. DON KOLL New York, N.Y.

title: Recession Strains Unemployment Funds in Region
description: The layoffs of tens of thousands of workers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut during the recession has strained the trust funds maintained by each state to provide unemployment insurance benefits.

title: I.N.S. Official Accused of Terrorizing Immigrants
description: An immigration official accused of seizing cash and other valuables without search warrants during raids on Hispanic-owned businesses in upper Manhattan was a human "juggernaut" who led a reign of terror against recent immigrants, a Federal prosecutor told jurors on Friday.

title: Curtis Chase Wed To Amy Howard
description: Amy Ruth Howard, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Oliver Howard of Guilford, Conn., was married in New Haven yesterday to Curtis Hamilton Chase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winsor Lyon Chase of New London, N.H. The Rev. Ellen Tillotson performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church on the Green.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. JOHN T. KRISTY;
Precautions to Take Against Rabies
description: RACCOONS have long been considered adorable pests by suburban homeowners trying to keep the contents of their garbage cans intact. But lately, the animals have been posing a health threat as well. Since the late 1970's, an epidemic of rabies has been making its way north along the East Coast, carried primarily by raccoons but quite infectious to other animals, including household pets and humans.

title: Suriname Vote Focuses on Issue of Army Influence
description: Voters were bused to polling places in vans and cars festooned with colorful party slogans today as this country held an election widely seen as a referendum on forging stronger ties with the Netherlands and ending the army's involvement in politics.

title: Review/Theater; Three Lives Entangled In Under 30 Minutes
description: Whenever he comes to New York, a writer (David Rasche) has lunch with his best friend from high school (William Wise). During one of these annual meetings, Mr. Wise suddenly announces that his wife left him 13 years earlier. The writer is astounded, while the friend is abashed at having kept up the charade for so many years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BOB DYLAN Behind the Shades: A Biography. By Clinton Heylin. Summit, $24.95.

title: A 'Mozart Marathon' At the County Center
description: THE bicentennial year of Mozart's death has seven full months to go, but it is hard to imagine that next Sunday's "Mozart Marathon" in White Plains won't turn out to be the high point of celebrations in the county.

title: Lisa Lazarus Married To Marc David Vitale
description: Lisa Beth Lazarus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arlie Lazarus of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Marc David Vitale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Vitale of Haverford, Pa., at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills. Rabbi Barry Green and Cantor Norman Summers performed the ceremony.

title: Florida Enacts Strict Campaign Finance Law
description: Florida has enacted legislation that imposes one of the nation's toughest limits on contributions to candidates for state office and creates a public fund to help finance campaigns for governor and for cabinet-level posts.

title: The Region; A Lesson in Beating Gun Control to the Draw
description: QUESTION: When is an assault rifle not an assault rifle?

title: Monica Roman Marries
description: Monica Roman, a daughter of Theodore Roman and Patricia Roman, both of Albuquerque, N.M., was married in Lambertville, N.J., yesterday to Mark Sullivan, a son of Teresa Sullivan of Hicksville, L.I., and the late John Sullivan. The Rev. Gwen Gillespie performed the Church of Religious Science ceremony at the Inn at Lambertville Station. Both are Syracuse University graduates. Ms. Roman, who is 31 years old and is keeping her name, is an editor at Business Week magazine in New York. Mr. Sullivan, 35, is the publisher of SportStyle and Gold Pro Merchandiser magazines in New York.

title: 'Mom Managers' and the 'Web of Inclusion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Chris Ullrich Wed To Miss Campbell
description: Margaret Moncure Campbell, an assistant vice president at Citibank in New York, and George Christian Ullrich 2d, a vice president of the Bank of New York, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond. The Rev. Dr. John E. Miller and the Rev. W. Holt Souder performed the ceremony.

title: First Cathedral City In the United States
description: As a one-time student at St. Paul's School and confirmed at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, I am saddened by the conflict between these two institutions [ "Cathedral Plan Shakes Up Schools," April 14 ] .

title: On Language; 'Explicit' Is Not a Dirty Word
description: In a "parental advisory," many record companies now include these words of warning on their adult offerings: " Explicit lyrics ."

title: 'Parity' Comes to West, Minus Giants, That Is
description: Joe McIlvaine, general manager of the San Diego Padres, considered the standing in the National League West and said: "I hope we're not getting to that famous N.F.L. word, 'parity.' I don't think so. I hope not. It's early; that's why you play 162 games. After 40 games, you can make some judgments, but you still can't make definitive calls."

title:
ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Once Modest Architect Lets Out the Stops
description: The skyscraper is both the glittering prize and the deadly trap of American architecture. No other building type is more characteristic of this country or more expressive of the desire to make one's mark on the horizon, an impulse common among those attracted to the profession of architecture. Yet the dismal results of most tall buildings show how even talented architects can fall victim to the lure of size at the expense of quality. High-rise design is pitiless in its exposure of the shortcuts and economies often demanded by speculative real estate developers. As Cass Gilbert, architect of the Woolworth Building, said many decades ago, "The skyscraper is a machine to make the land pay."

title: Travel Advisory; African Cruise Free Fare Offer
description: Free passage for the second traveler is being offered to couples sharing a cabin on selected cruises aboard a cargo and passenger ship that has started a series of 12-day voyages in the Indian Ocean between Durban, South Africa, and Mombasa, Kenya. The cost of the trip for the first party aboard the 64-passenger Avalon begins at $2,132 from Durban or $2,038 from Mombasa (air fare not included). The offer is available through September.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AFTERNOON OF MUSIC

title: Review/Dance; After Last-Minute Substitution, Official 'Bayadere' Debut
description: Amanda McKerrow made what could be called her official debut as Nikiya, the heroine of "La Bayadere," at American Ballet Theater's performance on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Yet this was not the first time she had danced at least part of the role.

title: Castle to Castle in Bohemia
description: IT seems hard to believe but in Czechoslovakia (slightly larger than New York State), there are 126 castles, some dating to the 12th century and most of them remarkably well preserved. They are wonderfully vivid illustrations of European artistic and spiritual values as they developed over centuries, reminders of the power of the aristocracy and of the impact of events on the fate of families and nations.

title: The World; What Role For the West In Russia's Revolution?
description: WHAT should you do if you come across a ragged giant slumped in the street? Do you leave him there, grateful that he's powerless, and hope he stays that way? Or do you clean and feed him and try to make him into a friendly and productive neighbor?

title: Elizabeth Berger Engaged to Wed
description: August wedding plans for Elizabeth Harrie Berger and Frederick Leonard Kaufman have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ramon F. Berger of Providence, R.I.

title: Way Out for Maradona
description: Argentine soccer star DIEGO MARADONA, out on bail on cocaine charges, could escape a jail term of up to two years by voluntarily joining a drug rehabilitation program, people familiar with the legal proceeding said yesterday.

title: Marybeth Weston Wed in Greenwich
description: Marybeth Little Weston Bergman of New York and Leighton Mansfield Lobdell of Brooklyn were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely officiated at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: Stay With the Indexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Eroica Racelis Married to Tracey E. Williams 3d
description: Eroica Colmenares Racelis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caesar M. Racelis of Manila, was married in Pocono Pines, Pa., yesterday to Tracey Evans Williams 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Augusta, Ga. The Rev. Thomas Maloney officiated at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Williams, 31 years old, graduated from De LaSalle University in Manila. She is a tax analyst at the Naughton Energy Corporation, a distributor of petroleum products in Pocono Pines. Mr. Williams, 33, is a vice president in the broker-dealer division of Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. He graduated from Yale University and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University.

title: Works Speak For Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: The Market Theory of Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
The Maestro Lists a Few of His Least Favorite Things
description: No. It has taken me 80 years to learn this golden word. Being by nature an optimist, I eagerly accepted the mistaken notion, dear to the Japanese, that "yes" is a positive word and "no" a negative one to be avoided if possible. Only in my old age have I finally discovered that sunny "yes" is deceptive; that it can be a cowardly word full of compromises and illusions, a tacit acceptance of the mediocre. How much stronger and more honest is the word "no"! It is a liberating word that cleanses the soul, even if it may make you a less pleasant or acceptable companion and cause you to lose a few "friends."

title: An Unexpected Foe For Tar Heels in Final
description: North Carolina stole the ball and the thunder from Syracuse, the defending champion, in the Carrier Dome today and won their semifinal match, 19-13, before a crowd of 14,544 at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: Review/Jazz; Kurt Hoffman's View of the Way We Were
description: The saxophonist and clarinetist Kurt Hoffman brought a new band into the Knitting Factory last Sunday night. Mr. Hoffman, one of the co-leaders of the Ordinaires until they broke up recently, has cut down on the references he uses in his compositions, limiting them to early 20th-century American dance music and East European folk music. Using a band that included ukulele, cello, accordion, bass, drums and four horns, he conjured up a polite, near-Victorian world where people wore varsity sweaters and liked sweet white jazz. The music would have sounded fine in a Woody Allen movie.

title: U.S. Health Aide Says He Erred on Times Beach
description: A Federal health official whose recommendation played a central role in the Government's decision to buy out the entire town of Times Beach, Mo., nine years ago because of dioxin contamination says he no longer views the chemical as the deadly substance it was believed to be then.

title: Camera
description: There seems to be no limit to what lens makers can do with glass. Lenses that were once just a gleam in a photographer's eye are now a fact of optical life. Zooms in particular have stretched beyond our wildest dreams. You can get 35-to-200mm zooms, 75-to-300mm zooms, even 100-to-500mm zooms. But not all of the optical action hinges on focal length.

title: Protest Forms Over Radioactive Waste in Brooklyn
description: Residents in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn are organizing to protest the designation of a hazardous-material shipment company in their community as an interim storage site for radioactive waste.

title: Sunday Dinner; For Father's Day, the Basics: Steak, Italian or Seafood
description: No two fathers are alike. Does Dad like a lusty steak on special occasions? Or is he a seafood aficionado? Or maybe his spirit soars with fine Italian food. If his preferences fall within these categories, here are three restaurants suitable for Father's Day dining on June 16. The Post House

title: Mets' Sad Commentary: Defense and Offense
description: No statements were made by the Mets yesterday at Shea Stadium. At least, none were made by players and distributed to reporters. The statement the Mets made on the field against the Cardinals, though, was rather informative.

title: New Diet Guide to Improve Shape You're In; Protein-Rich Peanuts
description: To the Editor:

title:
About Men;
The Last Game
description: I FELT I HAD TO return to Czechoslovakia. I felt I had to be there in the autumn of 1989 as freedom finally came. I had been there when the Nazis marched in. I had fought against them from Britain as a member of the Czechoslovak Air Force. And I had been there when the Communists took over in 1948. I had served five years in a labor camp for fighting with the British rather than the Russians during World War II.

title: Creating an Actress Requires a Dream
description: In 1787, when stealing a bit of bacon was a capital offense in England, the First Fleet set sail for Australia with 736 convicts on board, including many women. In "Our Country's Good" at the Nederlander Theater, Cherry Jones plays Liz Morden, the fiercest and most cruelly misused of those women. Standing erect and rigid, with her cropped head, bare shoulders and ragged gown, she is an icon of defiance, a cross between Joan of Arc and Liberty Leading the People.

title:
KEEPING IT SHORT: A SEASON OF STORIES;
Just Sitting There, Scared to Death
description: WHAT WAS MINE

title: Fashion; Flight Patterns
description: LAST-MINUTE PACKING is an art and a discipline. Choose a tote bag of modest size, which will help you resist the temptation to overpack. The trick is to stick to essentials, but the basics don't have to be boring. Weekends are a perfect excuse to get a little wild: pack up a kaleidoscope of lively prints and whimsical patterns. Silks and synthetic jerseys fold easily, are rumple-resistant and don't take up much room. They're also versatile: loose shirts worn over skinny pants can pass for both casual and elegant. A total look can be put together for very little - or a lot. Perfect accessories are lightweight string sandals or ballet slippers, and perhaps a bracelet of oversize baubles. Also, remember to tuck in a small handbag for day excursions.

title: True Toughness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How Responsible Are Water Suppliers?
description: Thomas Casey, consulting engineer for several Long Island water districts, takes exception to Julian Kane's comments, which placed part of the responsibility for the continuing contamination of Long Island's ground water with the water suppliers.

title: Black People Need Vitamin D Supplements
description: The report of increasing incidence of osteoporosis among black women [ "Why Is Osteoporosis Rising for Blacks?" April 14 ] should not come as a surprise. Bone mass and the calcification of bone are normally maintained by adequate levels of vitamin D, which is both a hormone and a nutrient. The skin produces vitamin D when it is exposed to ultraviolet light, usually from sunlight, and the vitamin is available from fortified milk.

title: Jefferies, in Meeting, Gets an Assist From Teammates
description: Gregg Jefferies was nervous and relieved yesterday at Shea Stadium, one day after he penned perhaps the most public plea ever by a major league player about wanting to fit in with a team.

title: Nadya Olyanova, 91, Handwriting Analyst
description: Nadya Olyanova, a graphologist who analyzed the handwriting of Adolph Hitler before his death and said he showed strong suicidal tendencies, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: The World; Helmut Kohl, A Bit Smaller Than Larger Than Life
description: WHEN the two parts of Germany reunited last October, the 6-foot-5-inch West German Chancellor appeared to dominate the event, physically and politically. These days, the question frequently asked as Germans struggle to make unity work is: Who let the steam out of Helmut Kohl?

title: Singing for Children Makes the Stars Twinkle
description: The notion that a piece of art was created for "children of all ages" has been repeated so many times -- often for the crassest reasons -- that it has lost all meaning. Yet I can't think of a better way to describe the appeal of James Taylor's incandescent rendition of "Getting to Know You" on "For Our Children" (Walt Disney Records 60616; CD and cassette), a new all-star album of songs for young people.

title: American Nightmare in a Family Restaurant
description: Armageddon comes to a family restaurant in Sam Shepard's first drama in six years, "States of Shock" (at the American Place Theater).

title: School District With a Personal Touch
description: SITTING under puffy white clouds carefully glued to a hand-painted landscape from "The Wizard of Oz," the Sagaponack School Board held its budget vote recently. The setting seemed appropriate.

title: KURDS RETURNING BY THE THOUSANDS
description: Truckloads of Kurdish refugees poured into the provincial capital of Dohuk today, raising hopes among allied military commanders that the Kurds might return to their homes sooner than expected.

title: Cost of Ownership Rises Again
description: The cost of owning a car, like everything else these days, seems to keep going up -- and the latest evidence comes from the American Automobile Association.

title:
FORUM;
Retirement Plans That Could Fall Short
description: Legislation sometimes creates results different from its sponsors' intention. Nowhere has this been more true than in retirement savings, where legislative initiatives have undermined traditional sources of retirement income, contributing to a growing national crisis.

title: Seoul Student Killed in a Clash With Police
description: A student was killed today in a street battle here between the police and protesters as anti-Government violence erupted across South Korea.

title: Hershiser Roughed Up
description: OREL HERSHISER said he didn't consider a minor league loss a setback to his major league comeback from reconstructive shoulder surgery. Hershiser, pitching for the San Antonio Missions of the Class AA Texas League, gave up 11 hits and 3 runs, 2 of them earned, in a 3-0 loss Friday night to the Shreveport Captains.

title: Ready to Chronicle the 90's
description: AS a novelist, Julia Markus would like to think of herself as a "chronicler of an age" who looks at society and, from one's own emotional experiences, builds a world between the covers of a book.

title: World Markets; Waiting for the German Market
description: The stock market in Frankfurt rallied last week, rising 4.7 percent despite the announcement by Karl Otto Pohl that he would depart as Bundesbank President and the real prospect of another increase in German interest rates.

title: Foster B. Whitlock, 76, Drug-Industry Leader
description: Foster Brand Whitlock, retired vice chairman of Johnson & Johnson and a leading figure in the pharmaceutical industry, died on Friday at Maine Coast Memorial Hospital in Ellsworth, Me. He was 76 years old and lived in Southwest Harbor, Me.

title: Review/Music; Excerpts From 'Warrior Ant,' a Theatrical Allegory
description: When Lee Breuer and Bob Telson's mammoth music-theater allegory "The Warrior Ant" was presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music three years ago in a very rough form, one thing was clear. Mr. Telson, who composed the music, had created an exuberant world-music score that mixed genres without compromising their integrity. And on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, where Mr. Telson appeared as part of Lincoln Center's Composers' Showcase series, nearly half the evening was devoted to songs from that score.

title: The Nation; Richer Rich, Poorer Poor, And a Fatter Green Book
description: IT is spring in Washington. The cherry trees blossom, and a fat Congressional document called the Green Book thumps across the desks of the city's policy wonks. Its itsy-bitsy type whispers of such alluring topics as "Table 3: Poverty by Region, 1989." The wonks call each other and whistle over the revelations.

title: Bridge
description: There will be a lot of new faces among the United States representatives at the World Championships in Yokohama in October. Among the 24 players will be just five who have won world titles in the past. The great majority are entirely new to this level of international play. This is a result of three different selection contests that ended a week ago in Memphis.

title: In White Plains, a Clock Recalls an Earlier Time
description: PEOPLE having lunch in Tibbits Park here will no longer have an excuse for getting back late to the office.

title:
METRO DATELINES;
Prostitutes' Slayings May Be Connected
description: The police say the slayings of two prostitutes in Brooklyn may be linked, and detectives are trying to determine if a third woman, killed with the same gun as one of the prostitutes, also was a prostitute.

title: U.N. Chief in Saharan Talks
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, arrived in North Africa today to start a referendum process intended to end 15 years of conflict in the Western Sahara. He is to meet with leaders of Morocco, Algeria and the Polisario guerrilla movement.

title: India
description: To the Editor: On Feb. 19 I landed in Bombay. A holiday was planned in Goa. At customs I was asked about a gold bracelet, which I had worn into India on two other occasions. Asked if I had more gold, I said, Yes, a chain with an American gold coin.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SMALL VICTORIES: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students, and Their High School, by Samuel G. Freedman. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) A former reporter for The New York Times spent a year visiting the Lower East Side to discover how Seward Park, ranked as one of the worst high schools in the state, managed to persuade so many of its graduates to continue their education. " 'Small Victories' makes one admire the Seward Park teachers and feel warmly, if also somewhat sadly, about the students," Irving Howe said here last year. "It rouses anger at the fact that in this country of great resources there should still be the kind of social deprivation that surrounds Seward Park."

title: Women's Role in Combat: The War Resumes
description: On the opening night of the American push into Iraq in February, as enemy fire lit the desert sky, one thought kept spinning through the mind of Sgt. Sheri L. Barbato, an Army records keeper.

title: Israel and Lebanese Group Agree on Prisoner Swap
description: Lebanon's principal Muslim fundamentalist group and Israel agreed in principle today to exchange prisoners of war, a move that if carried out could mean freedom for American and other Western hostages held in this country.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 26, 1991

The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Commercial Property: TriBeCa West; A New Historic District Under Landmarks Scrutiny
description: THE PAST may have been made relatively secure under the blanket of a new historic district, but it is the future that concerns property and business owners in the western end of TriBeCa.

title: Virginia Boyer Engaged to D. J. Losito
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Boyer of Harding Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann Boyer, to Daniel Joseph Losito, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis C. Losito of Manhasset, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Clothes for the Street, Court or Course
description: Tennis courts today are no longer solely the province of white cotton, any more than the golf course is held prisoner by lime polyester. This season, clothes suitable for both sports are being made in colors, prints and styles inspired by mainstream casual wear but often with new details and in high-performance fabrics.

title: Travel Advisory; Geologist Picks Top 20 Beaches
description: Rating 650 of the nation's beaches on such factors as water temperature, color of sand, views and litter, a geologist at the University of Maryland in College Park has come up with a list of America's 20 best. Dr. Stephen P. Leatherman, director of the University's Laboratory for Coastal Research, used 50 criteria to rate the beaches.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on May 12 about the return to South Africa of Dennis Brutus, the anti-apartheid activist, misidentified the university at which he was a professor of African literature. It was Northwestern, not Northeastern.

title: Japanese Graphic Treasures
description: THE Newark Public Library, like many museums, has acquired a development office. But this is no cause for alarm. A library blockbuster is still a stately affair, and the method of presentation has not changed. Objects are laid out, as before, in glass cases lining the marble walls and columns of the building's inner court.

title: Benton's Defection From Modernist Abstraction to Figuration
description: EDWARD HOPPER was credited with being the first painter of the "American Scene," an honor that he fortunately survived. The artist himself loathed the term, saying in an interview with James Mellow that it was applied to artists who "tried very hard to be American and I never did." Nevertheless, it was with the intention of focusing on his own country that Hopper returned from Paris in 1910, renouncing its light and rejecting the temptation of its revolutionary art movements.

title: Why the 'Hudson Hawk' Budget Soared So High
description: "Hudson Hawk," a $51 million action comedy starring Bruce Willis, produced by Joel Silver and filmed on locations ranging from the Brooklyn Bridge to Budapest, is either an example of free-spending folly or the kind of grand entertainment that will always be a part of Hollywood. It depends on whom you ask.

title: The Executive Life; Dressing for Success? Try Lifting and Tucking
description: Business associates who run into Matthew Rich this summer may wonder why he looks different. More exercise? Less stress? Better diet? Nope. Mr. Rich, who owns a New York public relations firm, recently underwent a plastic surgery procedure known as autologous fat transplantation -- fat-grafting, for short -- to smooth out facial wrinkles, plump up his brow ridge and strengthen his jawline.

title: OFFICERS' DEFENSE DIVIDED IN SLAYING
description: The lawyer for one of five New York City police officers charged in the killing of a car-theft suspect is demanding that the law firm representing another of the five be removed from the case.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a rendering of Carnegie Hall misidentified the architectural firm responsible for its renovation. It was James Stewart Polshek & Partners, not Cesar Pelli & Associates.

title:
FORUM;
Demystifying the Japanese Mystique
description: Six hundred years ago, an English cleric, William of Ockham, proposed a fundamental principle to guide philosophic inquiry. It stipulates that simple explanations and answers should be preferred to complex ones and that complexities should be introduced only when simple explanations prove inadequate.

title: New Tactics in Battle on Measles
description: WHEN Madeline Altarriba applied for benefits at the Hudson County Division of Welfare here, she was asked for the usual documents: proof of residence, Social Security number, income receipts, unemployment verification. And, in a new, voluntary step in the process, she was asked to bring in her 16-month-old son, Carlos, and his immunization records.

title: Images of Mozart, Writing as Fast as He Can
description: When visitors these days walk into the gallery at the Pierpont Morgan Library, two astonishing things happen in combination.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Thomas Hauser, the author of "Missing" and a forthcoming biography of Muhammad Ali, is not a big name in the field of suspense novels, but few writers currently in action would be able to match the mounting tension of THE HAWTHORNE GROUP (Tom Doherty/Tor, $18.95). The book operates on two levels. One is down-to-the-wire Armageddon. The other concerns the plight of a smart woman caught up in a situation that spins entirely out of her control.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Meadow 215,000 459 Garden Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; dining room, new kitchen, den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,800. Floral Park 240,000 15-17 Crocus Avenue Two 2-bedroom, 1-bath apartments, each with dining room, in a 38-year-old, legal 2-family colonial; 2-car garage; taxes $5,200. Franklin Square 164,000 216 Rintin Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath and 2 half-bath, 45-year-old brick Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Garden City 253,000 15 Roxbury Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,300. Hicksville 133,000 88 Earl Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 50- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,600. Westbury 143,000 616 Rockland Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,100. OTHER AREAS Eastchester, N.Y. 340,000 33 Ridge Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; entry hall, country kitchen, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,100. Canton, Conn. 160,000 28 Bristol Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; h/w floors, pantry, family room, 1 acre; taxes $2,980. Pennington, N.J. 300,000 23 Baldwin Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; vaulted ceilings, deck, full basement; taxes $5,520.

title: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP
description: That was a mangy looking deer on your cover. Maybe I've been spoiled by Walt Disney, but I always thought they were beautiful animals. This one looked as if it needed a nose job and braces. REGINA PAGLIA Edison, N.J. LS>Photo of two white-tailed deer (Bill Eppridge)

title: China's Police Said to Abuse Suspects
description: In some parts of China, the police often torture criminal suspects or detain them illegally, and confine them in excruciatingly crowded rooms, a secret report prepared for Chinese Government leaders says.

title: 'The Commanders': All the Pentagon's Men
description: Since the end of the cold war, George Bush has had two hot wars. They have exposed what appears to be a paradox in his political character. When the issues are simplified to the point of armed conflict, the President seems, at least from a distance, to be decisive and serene. As soon as the smoke of battle clears, however, a fog descends upon him, and his cautious and reactive nature returns. Only as a war President, in fact, has Mr. Bush been able to put energy in the executive branch. His repeated calls for a "new world order" remain as vague as his motives. Very little is known about how the most momentous decisions have been reached, who took which positions in the most crucial decision-making and where the President stood when.

title: 16 Hurt as Maryland Prison Riot Is Quelled
description: Inmates at an overcrowded state prison attacked their guards and fought for two and a half hours today before guards lobbing tear gas quelled the disturbance. At least 9 guards and 30 prisoners were injured, a prison official said.

title: Clarissa Rile Is Married
description: Clarissa Ann Rile, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Rile of Philadelphia, was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Adam Patrick Hayward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hayward of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Robert R. Burke officiated at Our Mother of Consolation Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Hayward, 24 years old, is a booking representative for Rile Artists Management in Jenkintown, Pa. Her husband, 27, is working toward teacher certification at Chestnut Hill College. Both graduated from Princeton University.

title: Poof! The Mommies Vanish in Sitcomland
description: When the television producers Danny Jacobson and Norma Safford Vela were casting their ABC situation comedy "Davis Rules" -- starring Jonathan Winters and Randy Quaid as father and son raising Mr. Quaid's three boys -- they couldn't find the right actress to play Mr. Quaid's wife. So, they killed her off before the show began. Mr. Jacobson recalls that as they wrested with that decision, Ms. Vela balked, asking: "Is this going to be another dead-mom show?"

title: Peter Hazou, 75, Dies; Retired U.N. Official
description: Peter J. Hazou, a retired United Nations official, died on May 19 at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Fast-Spreading Mussels Found in the Hudson
description: Six months after an erroneous report that zebra mussels had entered the Hudson River, scientists say they have finally confirmed a finding of the aquatic pest.

title: Full Range of Renoir
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
The Seaside Motif Prevails in Irvington
description: THERE is a fine line between charm and decay, seaside casualness and squalor, and for us, Benny's may have crossed it. Not that Benny's atmosphere and decor are different from what they have been in the past, but the food, once plain at worst, has become dull and joyless, a spirit that has pervaded the dining room as well. Whereas once this restaurant was crowded with diners as ready to participate in the fun of a festive evening as to eat fresh seafood, these days they seem to be preoccupied with the serious business of clearing the arteries. And while the fish may be fresh and good for you, the thrill is gone.

title: 'Okiboji' At Westport Playhouse
description: IF audience identification could determine a play's identity, "Okiboji" would be a shoo-in as a summer stock staple. But let's get real. It's no secret that the summer circuit of the sort that could embrace this play is near extinction, and that the likes of the work by Conrad Bishop and Elizabeth Fuller, now being presented by the Boston Post Road Stage Company, are likely to be found on the home box.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Geraniums Outdoors

title: Business Diary/May 19-24
description: INTERNATIONAL Gorbachev's Latest Plan Leaves Economists Unimpressed

title:
FORUM;
The Perils of Longer Market Hours
description: Last Monday, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a proposal extending trading hours on the New York Stock Exchange. I voted "no." I did so because one part of the proposal allows portfolio-basket trades -- of at least 15 stocks worth more than $1 million -- without disclosing the number, price or even the identity of the shares traded in those baskets.

title: Free Retirement Offered For Spare Refrigerators
description: FREE pickup service for operable spare refrigerators has been introduced by two Connecticut utility companies, United Illuminating and Northeast Utilities.

title: Topics of The Times; Dancing With Masks
description: Obedient to the laws of commerce, Sotheby's ignored appeals from two Indian tribes to withdraw three ceremonial masks from an art auction last Tuesday. Yet the gods of the Hopi and Navajo nations in Arizona found an unexpected friend. Elizabeth Sackler, who had never bid at an auction before, paid $39,050 for the handsome dancing masks -- and said she would return them to their rightful owners.

title: Margaret A. Warner and Joseph Rusbarsky Marry
description: Margaret Ann Warner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Prince Warner 3d of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday to Joseph Mark Rusbarsky, a son of Col. and Mrs. Francis Richard Rusbarsky of Webster Groves, Mo. Msgr. John Corr performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Christ the King.

title: UNREST MEDIATOR NAMED BY DE KLERK
description: In an effort to sustain the modest momentum of his conference on politically motivated violence, President F. W. de Klerk appointed a prominent church layman today to mediate a search for peace that would encompass the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups that boycotted the Government's talks.

title: Campus Life: Middlebury; 400 People Stage A Funeral March To Protest Layoffs
description: More than 400 people rallied on the Middlebury College campus Friday afternoon to protest recent staff cuts and what faculty members called the "Gestapo-like tactics" used in making them. The rally coincided with the arrival on campus of college trustees for commencement weekend.

title: Foreign Affairs; Best and Brightest
description: U.S. servicemen and women who fought and died in the Persian Gulf earned back honor for those who served and fell in Vietnam. Don't ask me exactly how. There is no real link of honor between the two wars. Nor should there be. Yet there is.

title: Topics of The Times; Car Cultists' Rituals
description: Visitors are often mystified by the morning rites performed by New York City car owners who dash out the door at 7:45, jump into their cars, drive across the street and double-park, then dash back home.

title: Fond Memories of Parcells
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Island's Beach Prospects Are Looking Up
description: AFTER a relatively mild winter, Island beaches are in good condition and ready for the season, which begins on a limited schedule this weekend.

title: Making a Difference; An Assembly Line Cleanup
description: About a year and a half ago, George D. Carpenter and other environmental managers at some of the nation's biggest companies sensed that the environmental agenda for business was being set by outside groups. So with some help from the Business Roundtable, 21 companies, including Mr. Carpenter's employer, the Procter & Gamble Company, organized the Global Environmental Management Initiative with Mr. Carpenter as chairman.

title: For Mehta, the Final Melody Is Bittersweet
description: "I think the Philharmonic is my last job," Zubin Mehta told Musical America magazine a few months before he became music director of the New York Philharmonic in September 1978. Around the same time, he elaborated to his biographers Martin Bookspan and Ross Yockey: "If I like my work in New York, and if everybody else likes it, then I'll stay in New York. That's all there is to it."

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Stony Brook; Sign Language: Foreign Or Merely an Easy A?
description: Students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook do not have to speak to fulfill their undergraduate foreign language requirement.

title: Tech Notes; An Implant That Corrects the Cornea's Curvature
description: Keravision Inc., a start-up company in Santa Clara, Calif., recently gained Government approval to begin human trials of its Intrastromal Corneal Ring, a tiny plastic ring intended to correct vision problems by altering the curvature of the cornea.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHASING WINTER AWAY

title: Janet Carroll Is Married
description: Janet Mary Carroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth P. Carroll of Great Neck, L.I., was married in Great Neck yesterday to Christopher James Blagg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Christopher R. Blagg of Mercer Island, Wash. The Rev. Daniel A. Cassiero officiated at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Blagg is a military analyst at the State Department in Washington. The couple, both 24 years old, graduated from Georgetown University. Mr. Blagg is studying law at the University of Virginia.

title: 3 Friends and Many Foes Among Insects
description: THE bugs are here in all shapes, colors and sizes, and gardeners are learning to look at them with different eyes. Instead of making their usual runs for the spray cans to get rid of them, most homeowners are learning to identify the insects. Some are friends worth having around. Some are foes.

title: Moppets by the Score (and the Libretto)
description: "I'M just waiting while she's in there," George Ryan said anxiously. Mr. Ryan, a marketing consultant from New Canaan was talking about his daughter, Heather, "almost 10" years old. "It's tough to wait," he said. "My wife's always calm. But she isn't here. I pace and smoke."

title: Meadow Star Returns to Take Acorn Stakes at Belmont
description: Meadow Star returned to the races yesterday after five weeks of rest and regrouping, and made a resounding comeback by winning the Acorn Stakes by six lengths over Versailles Treaty.

title: N.F.L. Ownership: Questions, Questions
description: Team owners continued to review the National Football League's ownership policies at their spring meeting in Minneapolis last week, but they did not vote to change any of them, said Commissioner Paul Tagliabue.

title: Wine; Napa's Bench Marks
description: PAUILLAC, CHATEAUNEUF-DU-PAPE, Vosne-Romanee and the Rutherford Bench.

title: Camps Without Boats or Balls or Bats
description: FOR many children, summer camp without swimming, sports and competitive activities would be unthinkable. But for those who shy away from "color wars" -- competitive events between teams of children that often culminate the camping year -- or have strong special interests, there are alternatives. Whether the focus is nature, science or the arts, there are programs that offer youngsters an opportunity to develop special talents.

title: Georgetown Students Hear of Major Changes Across Africa
description: While the world's attention has been riveted on the Soviet Union and the Persian Gulf, astonishing changes are rippling across Africa, Melissa F. Wells, the Ambassador to Zaire, told the graduates of the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University yesterday.

title: Running Engines At Limit
description: As the starting lineup takes its last pace lap before the start of the Indianapolis 500 today, there will be a traditional explosion of aerial bombs at each turn. The ceremony could take on added significance this year, as it may prove to be the overture to a symphony of engine failures.

title: Ashley McAllen Wed to Libby Ginway
description: Mary Elizabeth Ginway, an assistant professor of Romance languages at the University of Georgia, and Dr. Cullen Ashley McAllen, a resident in anesthesiology in San Antonio, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Kerrville, Tex. Archdeacon Carl Eugene Jennings officiated.

title: Miss Ury to Wed Jeffrey H. Steiger
description: August wedding plans for Katherine Savilla Ury and Jeffrey Hugh Steiger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Steiger of Holyoke, Mass., have been announced by her parents, Ann Donovan Ury of Durham, N.H., and Dennis W. Ury Jr. of Jersey City.

title: Sarah Whalen, Executive, Wed
description: Sarah Venetia Whalen, an advertising executive, and Powell Robinson 3d, a software company executive, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. David P. Muyskins officiated.

title: Topics of The Times; Hot Cars
description: Four-time winner A. J. Foyt qualified for today's Indianapolis 500 at 222.443 miles an hour. Few drivers in last week's American Tour de Sol went over 55. But the Indy 500 is old hat, its cars propelled by the same power system as an ordinary automobile, souped up. The Tour de Sol is the cutting edge. Its cars run on the sun.

title: Sunday Menu; Chicken Breasts With a Medley of Spices
description: Americans have a habit of borrowing a little of this and a little of that from different culinary cultures. The results are hard to categorize, although the collection of spices gives this dish a decided Indian slant. It could be a meal in a dish, but it's nicest when served with a salad and some toasted flat bread (lavosh). Spiced Chicken and Potatoes 1 large onion, chopped 2 teaspoons canola oil 1 teaspoon ground coriander 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1/2 teaspoon turmeric 1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg 1/8 teaspoon ground cardamom 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves 3/4 pound tiny new potatoes, scrubbed and thickly sliced 8 ounces skinless, boneless chicken breasts, cut in large chunks 1/2 to 1 finely minced jalapeno pepper 1 28-ounce can no-salt-added tomatoes in tomato puree, chopped 1 tablespoon dark molasses 2 tablespoons chopped cilantro (coriander).

title: Miss del Rio Wed To David Dickson
description: Meline del Rio, an advertising manager for Vanity Fair magazine, and David Martin Dickson, an investment banker in New York, were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Terence Elsberry performed the ceremony.

title: LeMond Confident for Tour of Italy
description: Greg LeMond rates himself a contender in the Tour of Italy, which starts Sunday.

title: The Two-Ton Donut . . . and Other Roadside Attractions
description: For David Graham, America begins where the interstate ends. Since 1979 the 38-year-old photographer has driven two-lane highways and back roads looking for the more peculiar expressions of the national genius: a water tower shaped like an ear of corn, a hamburger stand in the form of a hamburger. Off the main routes, the normal rules of proportion are bent and stretched. A tiny sign puts an entire desert on sale. A string of miniature barns in front of a mammoth concrete grain silo measure the distance between the reality of mega-agriculture and the myth of the family farm. The photographic evidence of Graham's travels - he has worn out five Volvos crisscrossing the United States - has been collected in "Only in America," to be published in September by Knopf, and will be the subject of an exhibition (also in September) at the Laurence Miller Gallery in New York. "Any time people go out of their way to do something, its sparks my interest," Graham says. "I mean, it takes effort to get a truck on top of a pole."

title: Movies With Their Own Language
description: These days, to comprehend a certain kind of film, most often European in origin, you have to understand another language, one that has nothing to do with the Babel of tongues heard in the theaters, hotel lobbies, bars and restaurants during the just-concluded 44th Cannes International Film Festival.

title: Smoking Aloft
description: To the Editor: We should like to caution passengers flying to Tokyo from New York. Our experience with a long flight on Japan Air Lines was miserable due to the lenient smoking policy. The air in the plane was foul just an hour after takeoff. My husband and I were both sick following the flight, with asthma symptoms. My letter to the airline was answered; the explanation reiterated the lenient smoking policy for the "comfort of the smoking passengers."

title: Nonpartisan Groups Finding Fault With Senators' Traditional Strategy
description: As New York's state budget delay moves into its eighth exasperating week, state officials, lobbyists and business leaders are increasingly attributing the deadlock to the traditional legislative strategy of the Republican-led Senate.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My front door is exposed to the sun and needs refinishing this year. It is a birch color and is now bleached-looking and unattractive. Can you tell me how to refinish this?

title: Fund Guides Jobless Soviet Immigrants
description: After a century of helping Jewish immigrants make new lives in America, the Baron De Hirsch Fund faces a bigger challenge: helping find jobs and offering emotional support for the thousands of Soviet immigrants who arrived in New York City after Moscow eased its emigration policy.

title: Road to Men's French Title Is Muddied
description: If the aggregate record of the top half-dozen men is any indication, the French Open, which will start tomorrow at Roland Garros Stadium in Paris, could be the province of any souped-up dark horse, clay-court enthusiast who manages to skid into the draw.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Maybe it started when we were children, when a simple "No, I didn't do my homework" somehow didn't satisfy the teacher, and a plain "I couldn't be home by midnight" certainly didn't satisfy parents. These people weren't the type to accept unadulterated statements of fact. They wanted reasons. Why wasn't the homework done? Why couldn't you be home by midnight?

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Party of Good Sense Joseph Epstein celebrates the utility of quotations, and explains his standards in harvesting and using them, in this piece from "A Line Out for a Walk: Familiar Essays" (Norton).

title: Miss Forster Wed To A. J. Camerota
description: Elizabeth Richards Forster, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Forster of Haverford, Pa., was married in Bryn Mawr, Pa., yesterday to Andrew Joseph Camerota, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Joseph Camerota of Mashpee, Mass. The Rev. Timothy Dobbins and the Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer.

title: Cathy Leonard Weds Dr. Christopher Getch
description: Cathy Marie Leonard, the director of speech and language pathology at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia, and Dr. Christopher Caldwell Getch, a resident in neurosurgery at the hospital, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Stuart H. Perrin performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Fruity Desserts in Germany
description: EVEN the most cursory glance at a dessert cart in Germany makes it clear that this nation has yet to discover the perils of cholesterol.

title: Jaime Shapiro Is Married
description: Jaime Dana Shapiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Shapiro of New York, was married last evening to Kenneth Charles Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cohen of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Jacob Friedman officiated at the Water Club in New York. Mrs. Cohen, 26 years old, is to start work as a trader at UBS Securities in New York. She graduated from New York University. Mr. Cohen, also 26, is a vice president of Lehman Brothers in New York. He graduated from the University of Vermont.

title: Corrections
description: The Record Notes column last week rendered the names of two composers incorrectly. They are Aaron Kernis and Richard Danielpour.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; Good Show! Cricket Becomes Intramural Sport
description: The wickets stood sturdily on the pitch, and the bowlers and batsmen were in fine fettle last week as the graduate-student side trounced the faculty side in cricket on the playing fields of -- no, not Eton -- Syracuse University. The match, at Hookway Field, lasted three hours -- a mere interlude, as cricket aficionados know -- and the score was respectably cricket: 136 runs to 122.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Where the Topiary Is Real MOST people go to Walt Disney World for the rides and exhibitions. Anthony Scopas of Port Washington went to look at the shrubs. "I was riding the monorail and I looked down and noticed this one topiary," he said. "The bush was shaped so perfectly I couldn't believe it was real."

title: Miss Ingram Wed to Eric SchaeferCorrections
description: Suzanne Allison Ingram, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. H. Ingram of Dallas, was married there yesterday to Eric Albert Schaefer, the son of the late Mrs. Samuel H. McIver and the late Dr. J. Albert Schaefer. the Rev. John Drake performed the Episcopal ceremony at st. Michael's and All Angels Churh.

title: Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Plans to Be 'Midwife' to a New Rule in Ethiopia
description: With the Ethiopian Government near collapse, the United States is preparing to help shape a new government for the country as Washington resumes a position of influence it has not had for nearly two decades in a pivotal part of Africa.

title: Headliners; By the Book
description: Richard R. Kreimer, a homeless New Jersey man, may be unwashed and unpleasant but he is not unread. Much to the annoyance of librarians and patrons, Mr. Kreimer made himself at home in the Morristown Free Public Library for a couple of hours a day. To keep him out, the library adopted rules barring people who were not reading or using library materials or who harass or annoy other patrons or whose "bodily hygiene is so offensive" that it is a nuisance. To get back in, Mr. Kreimer sued. Last week, a Federal judge ruled that while a library was not obliged to serve as a shelter and had a right to make rules governing its patrons, the rules aimed at Mr. Kreimer were unconstitutional. "Just because a person doesn't look as good, smell as good or dress as good, you're not going to keep him out of the library," the judge said. Mr. Kreimer, who is 41 years old and has been homeless since 1982, said the ruling was "very fair, very honest, very compassionate, very legal and very socially correct."

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Davis, Calif.;
26 Units Of Co-Housing
description: MUIR COMMONS, a 26-unit residential development that combines private ownership of individual town houses with shared ownership of expansive community facilities, is nearing completion on the outskirts of this city of 43,000. It was designed with the participation of future residents.

title: Mutual Funds; Questions About Performance
description: Several readers of this column have recently asked questions relating to measuring mutual-fund performances. Below are answers to representative questions about interpreting such performance data and about other matters of interest.

title: Social Events
description: Zubin Mehta's Farewell

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 of the Travel section today misstates a telephone number for the automated information line at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Its numbers are (404) 332-4559 and (404) 332-4555.

title: Federal Aid Cutbacks in '80's Hurt New York City
description: While New York City's fiscal problems have prompted Mayor David N. Dinkins to lay a big piece of the blame on New York State, he has also measured out a little bit for the Federal Government.

title:
Focus: Philadelphia;
A Drive to Restore Luster to Market St.
description: DESPITE a suit that threatened to halt construction, workers on the $523 million Pennsylvania Convention Center had poured 4,600 cubic yard of concrete by mid-May and installed 500 tons of steel reinforcing.

title: Miss Weed Wed To Alexis Meeus
description: Susan Elizabeth Weed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Weed of New Canaan, Conn., was married in New Canaan yesterday to Alexis Meeus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Meeus of Antwerp, Belgium. The Rev. Joseph Patrick performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Aloysius Church.

title: Perestroika Missed Art History
description: To the Editor:

title: Is TV Ready for Norman Lear? Was It Ever?
description: He was the king of the sitcom when he walked away from prime time in 1978. Now Norman Lear is returning to television with the first of four series he has in the works, hoping there is still a place on the tube for his distinctive blend of humor and social commentary, and intent on letting America know what's been on his mind.

title: Only 12, but Old Enough to Feed a City's Violence
description: A 12-year-old boy who imitated the swagger of the neighborhood drug dealers and boasted about his prowess with a gun is confined in Juvenile Hall here these days, tearful and frightened as he awaits a trial for murder.

title: A Historic District in South Carolina Struggles to Preserve Black History
description: In 1862, the second year of the bloody campaigns of the Civil War, Quakers from Philadelphia financed an experiment in education beneath the live oaks and Spanish moss here: South Carolina's first school for freed slaves.

title: Focus of Clash on Military Budget Is How to Reduce Reserve Forces
description: The Bush Administration and Congress have squared off in a battle over the role of reservists in the new, shrinking American military.

title: More Restaurants Turning to Alfresco Dining
description: THE time has come to move outside. Eating outdoors in a civilized, charming setting is a special experience. Europeans adore it. Manhattanites try it despite formidable obstacles. But Long Islanders have access to beaches, boats, waterviews and vast farmlands that are unsurpassed for alfresco dining.

title: Correction
description: A map on May 12 with an article about proposed landmark designations in Harlem located the Abyssinian Baptist Church incorrectly. It is at 132 West 138th Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Lenox Avenue.

title: Susan D. Hoey Wed To Brian O'Day on L.I.
description: Susan Diane Hoey and Brian Thomas O'Day were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Bradley Beaupre officiated. Mrs. O'Day, 29 years old, is a magna cum laude graduate of Fairfield University and a marketing manager for the International Business Machines Corporation in Norwalk, Conn. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hoey of Huntington. Mr. O'Day, 29, graduated from Middlebury College and is an account executive for Instinet, an electronic stock-trading firm. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. O'Day of Wilton, Conn.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Co-op Shareholders in a Limbo of Default
description: LEROY STAFFORD thought he had achieved his dream of homeownership in 1988 when he bought a co-op in Washington Towers, a stylish brick building in East Orange. But that dream has eroded.

title: Company Sets Up Reunions
description: THE class "nerd" 25 years later has turned into a fascinating, handsome man who flew in from Tokyo to attend his high school reunion. The "jocks" and the "brains" who once had nothing to say to one another now chatted affectionately all evening.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater Revives MacMillan's 'Concerto'
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's "Concerto," performed by American Ballet Theater on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, at first seems an odd choice for revival. The opening section of the 1966 work now seems a tame, academic evocation of the Shostakovich score, a thing of too-careful placement, ballerina chignons and daintily lifted wrists, though it was led with pert precision by Cheryl Yeager and Wes Chapman.

title: Travel Advisory; Mt. Rushmore's 50th Birthday
description: The golden anniversary of Mount Rushmore National Memorial in South Dakota is being celebrated by Presidential impersonators and band concerts in the memorial's amphitheater from Memorial Day to Labor Day. A formal dedication is planned July 4.

title: Where Bad Guys Are Behind Glass
description: It has Al Capone's tommy gun, the ashes of Brandy the bomb-sniffing dog, and enough guns, knives, blackjacks, brass knuckles and other artifacts of mayhem to outfit a brigade of cutthroats.

title: The Battle That Turned the War
description: GUADALCANAL

title: Give or Take a Few Infidelities
description: O'KEEFFE AND STIEGLITZ An American Romance. By Benita Eisler. Illustrated. 546 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $29.50.

title: My President Right or Wrong
description: A VERY THIN LINE The Iran-Contra Affairs. By Theodore Draper. Illustrated. 690 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $27.95.

title: Amy Jo Zeidman, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Amy Jo Zeidman, a lawyer in New York, and Dr. Jay Bruce Horowitz, a resident in otolaryngology at the Yale University School of Medicine, were married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbi Dale Polakoff officiated.

title: Yankee Scientists End Great Sax Experiment
description: The Steve Sax experiment, a failure almost from the moment it began last Monday night in Cleveland, was finally scuttled by the Yankees, who acknowledged their mistake today and returned the five-time all-star to second base.

title: Weak Sales Put a Damper On an Annual Book Party
description: People in the book business are about to suffer a twin indignity: they will hold the annual American Booksellers Association convention in the midst of an industry recession and in a place so far over on the West Side of Manhattan that finding what they consider to be a decent place for lunch will be a problem.

title: Israelis Rush to Help Ethiopian Arrivals
description: The 1,200 Ethiopian Jews filling every room of the Diplomat Hotel turned absorption center were almost outnumbered today by the Israeli volunteers who streamed through the lobby, looking for some way to get involved.

title: Nancy G. Samson Weds J. W. Cohen
description: Nancy Gail Samson, the daughter of Allen L. Samson of Milwaukee and Mrs. Jeffrey H. Loria of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Joshua William Cohen, a son of Sue L. Cohen of Orange, Conn., and the late Carl I. Cohen. Rabbi Amy Wallk and Cantor Kurt Silberman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. SportsMonday begins on page 25, Business Day on page 33.

title: Publishers Turn More to Bookstores to Sell Encyclopedias
description: Only a few years ago, publishers of expensive reference books put most of their marketing muscle into selling to schools and libraries, which were less resistant than booksellers to paying high prices.

title: Reconciliation Day
description: On an April day in 1866, four young Mississippi women went to a local cemetery to lay flowers on the graves of those lost in the War Between the States. First they decorated the graves of the Confederate soldiers who had been their friends and relatives. Next they walked over to the small plot in which were buried men who had been not only strangers but enemies. They decorated the graves of those 40 Union soldiers, too.

title: Suddenly It's 1941 for a Science Class
description: The last time Arnold Schneidman and Robert Zelvin had seen each other was in 1941, their final year as teammates on the woeful basketball team at the Bronx High School of Science. The United States became involved in World War II soon after graduation, disrupting their lives and scattering them and their classmates around the country and the world.

title: Vera Horn Is Married
description: Vera Natalie Horn, the deputy director of the Bureau of Planning and Management in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, and Robert Steven Silver, a software engineer for Citibank, were married last evening at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Murray Grauer officiated.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Tired of Looking Tired, Bush Relaxes Like Mad
description: When President Bush spent August here last year, he was determined to show he could have fun despite the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Tap Extravaganza Norman Thomas High School Manhattan

title: British Phone Profit at Issue
description: A report by British Telecommunications P.L.C. that its profits last fiscal year had jumped 34 percent has created a political furor over Britain's biggest company.

title: Towson Isn't a Surprise to Everyone
description: When the prognostications about the college lacrosse season were being made back in March, a few knowledgeable forecasters around Baltimore were touting Towson State.

title: King Coffee Bean vs. King Coffee
description: In the cool Andean air of this mountain village, Juan Francisco Gomez shook rainwater from a coffee bush and displayed its glistening, ripening red berries. When dried and roasted, those beans will feed the river of arabica coffee that has swept Colombia to the top of the world coffee business.

title: From Contest to Final Test
description: If you play for Harvard and you're on the road, you must take your exams at the exact time when everyone else does, except if you're in a game. So ALBERT CHANG, a junior who competed in the N.C.A.A. tennis championships in Athens, Ga., took four finals last week. His last, in biology, came immediately after he advanced to the round of 16. A member of the athletic department monitored the exam. . . . When CHESTER (RED) HOFF turned 100 recently, he became only the fourth major league baseball player in history to hit the mark. He hurled for the Yankees starting in 1911. The following year he was joined by an outfielder named PAUL OTIS. They were to share baseball memories for almost 80 years. Otis lived until last December, when he died just short of his 101st birthday.

title: Lisa Cohen Marries David C. Lowy
description: Lisa Margaret Cohen, an insurance executive in New York, and David Charles Lowy, a manager for the Union Carbide Corporation in Danbury, Conn., were married yesterday at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Stephen Franklin officiated.

title: 12 Perfect Innings and 32 Years to Remember
description: Every May 26, the phone rings in HARVEY HADDIX's home in Springfield, Ohio.

title: New York's Buses Need a Better Soot-Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheryl Ann Potash Is Wed
description: Cheryl Ann Potash, an account executive at the Wunderman Worldwide advertising agency in New York, and Stewart Frederic Hescheles, an associate in the New York law firm of Fischbein, Badillo, Wagner, were married last evening by Rabbi Alan Lavin at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Hescheles, 26 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn Potash of Plainview, L.I. Mrs. Hescheles graduated from Syracuse University. Her husband, 26, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Hescheles of Brooklyn. He graduated cum laude from Brandeis University and Brooklyn Law School.

title: BATTLE IS LOOMING ON U.S. COLLEGE AID TO POOR STUDENTS
description: The Bush Administration will submit a plan to Congress this week to increase Federal college tuition grants for the poor and eliminate them for about 400,000 students whose families earn more than $10,000 a year. The plan, which would begin in the 1994 fiscal year, has already met heavy criticism in Congress.

title: Thai Plan for Toshiba
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it would invest $30 million in a plant here that would produce 70 million pieces of semiconductor products a month beginning in February.

title: John Hilson, 66, Dies; Was Investment Banker
description: John S. Hilson, an investment banker with the Wertheim firm for 41 years, died yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 66 years old and also lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Emily Bromberg Is Wed in Queens
description: Emily Dena Bromberg, the daughter of Dr. Eleanor Mallach Bromberg of New York and the late David Bromberg, was married yesterday to Stephen Bruce Silverman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jason Silverman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery officiated at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In memory of Eugenia Doll, who left $1 million to American Ballet Theater when she died in December, ALESSANDRA FERRI and JULIO BOCCA are to dance "Other Dances" by JEROME ROBBINS tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Doll commissioned it in 1976 for NATALIA MAKAROVA and MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV.

title: Cheryl E. Hader Weds C. B. Brod
description: Cheryl Elizabeth Hader, the daughter of Dr. Aaron M. Hader of Paterson, N.J., and Helen Hader of Millburn, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Craig Bruce Brod, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Brod of Elberon, N.J. Rabbi David Silverman and Cantor David Montefiore performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Iran Plans More Oil Output
description: Iran will raise its oil output to 5 million barrels a day by 1993, from 3.5 million, its oil minister says.

title: Lakers On the Freeway To Finals
description: "All roads to the finals go through me," Magic Johnson said during training camp back in October. True to his word, Johnson parked himself at the intersection of the Los Angeles offense today and directed the Lakers to a 116-95 demolition of the Portland Trail Blazers this afternoon in the crossroads game of the Western Conference finals.

title: Yael D. Dubroff and Alan C. Laifer Are Married
description: Yael Dafna Dubroff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Dubroff of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alan Corey Laifer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Franklyn Laifer of Monsey, N.Y., at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Dr. Moses D. Tendler officiated.

title: Miss Chass Weds Dr. Derek Kram
description: Deborah Felice Chass, the daughter of Murray Chass of Fair Lawn, N.J., and Robin Costa of Paramus, N.J., was married in Teaneck, N.J., yesterday to Dr. Derek Adam Kram, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Kram of Encino, Calif. Rabbi Louis Sigel officiated at Loews Glenpointe Hotel.

title: Roh Tries Cabinet Shake-Up To Gain Trust in South Korea
description: President Roh Tae Woo reorganized his Cabinet today, replacing four ministers to try to restore sagging public confidence in the Government, a presidential spokesman said.

title: Vicki Dworetzky Marries
description: Vicki Susan Dworetzky, a sales manager for Anne Klein II, and Jay Stuart Elkins, an assistant vice president at Kidder Peabody & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in White Plains. Rabbi Martin Rosenberg officiated. Mrs. Elkins, 25 years old, a graduate of Clark University, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Dworetzky of Pound Ridge, N.Y. Her husband, 27, is a University of Michigan graduate with an M.B.A. from New York University. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Elkins of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Brandeis Graduates Told, 'Stay Involved'
description: Brandeis University awarded 752 undergraduate and 160 graduate degrees in its 40th commencement exercises, held yesterday at the school's campus in Waltham, Mass.

title: Andrea L. Burns Is a Bride in Ohio
description: Andrea Lydia Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Burns of Athens, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Charles Rapelje DeBevoise Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. DeBevoise of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Fisher of the First Presbyterian Church of Athens officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Suspect in India

title: Review/Television; Not the Sort to Run a Blood Bank
description: Wake up, blond and blue-eyed America! Those swarthy types living down the street, the ones with the dark hair and smoldering eyes, they're very likely to be vampires. Or so Richard and Esther Shapiro would have you believe. Back in the 1980's, the Shapiros created "Dynasty," the perfect packaging of the glitz and greed that would define the Reagan era. Now, for the presumably more hardbitten 1990's, the bloodsucking turns quite literal in "Blood Ties," this evening's "Fox Night at the Movies" presentation at 8.

title: Review/Art; Visual Arts Join Spoleto Festival U.S.A.
description: In the days before the opening here of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.'s "Places With a Past: New Site-Specific Art in Charleston," which may be the most moving and original exhibition of contemporary art in the United States this season, some of the artists seemed to wonder themselves at the force and meaning of what they had brought into being.

title: Abroad at Home; Liberty And Hypocrisy
description: "The freedom to think and speak one's mind," President Bush said recently, "may be the most fundamental and deeply revered of all our liberties."

title: Anna Roffwarg, Student, Is Wed
description: Anna Roffwarg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Roffwarg of Dallas, was married there yesterday to Steven Fisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Fisch of Livingston, N.J. Rabbis Jack Bemporad and Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El.

title: Sandblasting Folly Hastened Arch Erosion
description: To the Editor:

title: ETHIOPIAN REBELS CAPTURE KEY BASE
description: Ethiopian rebels captured the operational base and headquarters of the air force today, destroying the Government's main line of defense for the capital, Government officials said.

title: 'Bring On Monarchs' Is Knights' Playoff Cry
description: Immediately after they had dismantled San Antonio, 38-9, in a World League of American Football game at Giants Stadium on Saturday night, the New York/New Jersey Knights settled into a playoff euphoria.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Swarm of Bees Is a Peaceable Convocation
description: To the Editor:

title: National Parks: An Endangered Species
description: Before video rental outlets, taverns, a golf course, a 22-bed jail, a courthouse and holiday gridlock came to this slice of ancient America, the biggest diversion was the crash of waterfalls on granite walls.

title: Jennifer Seidman and Brian Ross Are Married
description: Jennifer Ina Seidman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gary Seidman of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Brian Craig Ross, a son of Lori Ross of Hewlett, L.I., and Marty Ross of Central Islip, L.I., at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Philmore Berger officiated.

title: Sarah Baird Wed to Benjamin Kerman
description: Sarah Margaret Baird, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brent Dugan Baird of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Benjamin David Kerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Kerman of Leonia, N.J. Rabbi Dr. Martin L. Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Twentieth Century Club.

title: Celebrating a Place Where for So Many The Good Life Began
description: A boatload of visitors docked at Ellis Island the other day to plan the staging of a dramatic extravaganza called "Immigrant Voices." One of their number, an actress, raised her own immigrant voice to recall her personal journey.

title: Fire Forces Campers to Flee
description: A raging wildfire forced the emergency closure today of a major highway and the evacuation of 200 campers in the Kenai National Wildlife Refuge. Officials ordered the campers out of the Hidden Lake area after the fire reached the Kenai River near Skilak Lake. By 4 P.M., the fire jumped the Kenai River and Alaska State Troopers ordered the Sterling Highway closed. The fire had burned about 6,000 acres by this afternoon.

title: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK Memorial Day Parade: Broadway between 72d and 86th Streets will be closed from 10 A.M. to noon.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Newspapers Try, Carefully, To Investigate Subscribers
description: As many newspapers rush toward the brave new world of building extensive data banks about their readers' interests and buying habits to help sell advertising, the issue of privacy looms as a potential land mine.

title: Where New York's Finest Should Live
description: New York City's plan to hire thousands of police officers adds urgency to an old proposal: Require police recruits to live in the city. Deployment strategies for the expanded force make the case stronger than ever.

title: Boy, 5, Vanishes at Carnival; Police Suspect a Kidnapping
description: Police are investigating the disappearance of a 5-year-old boy from a carnival here.

title: Symbol of a City Crumbles
description: A 50-ton cast-iron statue of the Roman god Vulcan, the symbol of this steel-making city, has been closed to the public because it is falling apart. Pieces of the statue's concrete-like grouting have started chipping into pieces three to four inches long. The statue stands 56 feet tall and was placed atop Red Mountain in 1936.

title: Tougher Laws Mean More Cases Are Called Rape
description: Under liberalized state laws, prosecutors have grown more willing to pursue rape charges in cases in which women have been attacked not by strangers but by acquaintances. And criminal justice experts say that rapes by acquaintances are by far the most common type.

title: Pessimism On Survival of Pan Am
