description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that he was "not overly optimistic" that Pan American World Airways would survive and that he hoped it would be taken over by another airline.

title: Dance in Review
description: American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Markets Closed
description: Because of the Memorial Day holiday, financial markets in the United States are closed today.

title: U.S. Now Has Two Who Excel in 10 Events
description: When he considers the other leading decathlon athletes in the world, Dave Johnson has a hard time envisioning anyone else comparable to himself and Dan O'Brien over the next few years. Not Daley Thompson of Britain, the Olympic champion of 1980 and 1984. Not Christian Schenk of Germany, the 1988 Olympic champion. Not even Christian Plaziat of France, who ranked first in the world last year.

title: A Lower Profile for High Fashion
description: Faced with flagging sales and profits, several American department store chains are dropping high-priced designer dresses and suits and are filling their racks with more of their own labels that carry slimmer price tags and fatter profits.

title: In the Growing Shadow, Baseball's Best Year
description: Baseball in '41 By Robert W. Creamer Illustrated. 330 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Business Leaders Challenging Dinkins After a 'Honeymoon'
description: New York City's business leaders, increasingly concerned about the city's financial future and the prospect of higher taxes, have begun to aggressively challenge Mayor David N. Dinkins's handling of his budget.

title: Parties Favoring Dutch Ties Do Well in Suriname Election
description: Two political groupings that favor stronger ties with the Netherlands and clear subordination of the military to civilian authority emerged from national elections today with more than the two-thirds legislative majority needed to undertake constitutional changes.

title: Tyson-Ruddock Rematch Is Back On, Promoter Says
description: A rematch between Mike Tyson and Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, sidetracked earlier this month after action by the Nevada State Athletic Commission, is apparently back on.

title: The Right Medicine
description: The cost of American medical care -- already the most expensive in the world -- is escalating 20 percent a year. Yet nearly one in every seven Americans lacks insurance. The system frustrates taxpayers, physicians, patients and insurers. That's why nine out of ten Americans want fundamental change.

title: Silver Lining in Argentina's Cloud
description: Argentina's President, Carlos Menem, wants the world to invest in Argentina. His Government, he proclaims, is committed to turning around a 60-year legacy of coups, hyperinflation and Government favoritism. Mr. Menem's performance at first undermined his ambitions. But now a revised administration has begun to earn credibility.

title: Amy Craig Is Married To Andrew A. Dutter
description: Caroline Royce Craig, an advertising sales representative in Norwalk, Conn., and Andrew Allen Dutter, a New York book editor, were married yesterday in St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Henry Albeke officiated.

title: Suddenly, Lost Mountain is a Threat in the Belmont
description: Lost Mountain, a late-running colt who hadn't won a race in seven months, finally ran fast as well as late yesterday and won the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park by a head over Man Alright.

title: Campeau Corp. Sues Founder
description: The Campeau Corporation is suing its founder, Robert Campeau, for $12.7 million as well as for the return of paintings and cars that he used in his former capacity as company chairman, The Globe and Mail newspaper has reported.

title: Missing 8-Year-Old Is Found by Police In Apartment on S.I.
description: An 8-year-old Manhattan boy whose disappearance on Friday prompted an extensive police search after he was last seen in Central Park, was reunited with his mother yesterday. The police are seeking the man who they said abducted him.

title: H. W. Lane Wed To Cecily Glavin
description: Cecily Maureen Glavin, a district sales manager in New York for Nestle, and Henry Welling Lane, the national sales manager for the Perrier Group of America in Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Needham, Mass. The Rev. Lawrence J. Carroll officiated.

title: Robert Gates: A Look at the Record
description: By nominating Robert Gates to be director of Central Intelligence, President Bush is betting that the Iran-contra scandal has become irrelevant history. But since February 1987 -- the previous time Mr. Gates was nominated to be C.I.A. director -- thousands of pages of documents and testimony in the Iran-contra affair have been declassified. It is a record Congress cannot ignore.

title: Diana Newman Weds Kenneth Adams
description: Diana Newman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose Newman of Dallas, was married yesterday to Kenneth Green Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Murray Adams of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joshua Taub officiated at the Mandalay Hotel in Irving, Tex.

title: Washington Talk; An Envoy Balances Old Image In New Era
description: Rinaldo Petrignani is one of those rare am bassadors who a real and perhaps lasting effect on their countries' relations with another nation.

title: New Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Ms. Silberstein Weds
description: Devorah Leah Silberstein, a psychiatric social worker at New York Foundling Hospital, and Kenneth Alan Daley, a doctoral candidate in English at New York University, were married yesterday at Congregation Brith Sholom in Bethlehem, Pa. The bride's father, Rabbi Dr. Laurence J. Silberstein of Allentown, Pa., officiated, assisted by Rabbi Alan Juda. The bride, 29 years old, is also the daughter of Muriel Silberstein of Allentown. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, as did her husband, and received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University. Mr. Daley, 28, is the son of Rhoda Daley and Dr. Marvin Daley of Lancaster, Pa.

title: In Addis Ababa, a War Comes Home
description: With rebels at the outskirts of this Ethiopian capital, residents here today demonstrated all the emotions associated with a crisis.

title: Thieves Get $130,000 and Bank Truck, Too
description: Burglars using a fork-lift to break into a cinder-block vault stole an estimated $130,000 in coins from a Chase Manhattan Bank warehouse in Maspeth, Queens, early yesterday, and got away in one of the bank's own trucks, the police said.

title: Cold War Doesn't Explain Slovak Nationalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Nothing Is Hotter Than Texas As Rangers Win 13th Straight
description: The Texas Rangers won their 13th straight game tonight, beating the Seattle Mariners, 6-4, on run-scoring singles by Gary Pettis and Brian Downing in the seventh inning.

title: Anger in New Jersey Grows Over Teachers' Raises
description: After a decade of steady salary increases and an improving image, public school teachers here are falling under attack from politicians who are suggesting that they are overpaid.

title: Jill Gofen Weds Geoffrey Parker
description: Jill Mary Gofen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Gofen of Chicago, was married there last night to Geoffrey Monroe Parker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George G. C. Parker of Portola Valley, Calif. Rabbi Mordechai Rosen performed the ceremony at the Standard Club.

title: Gay Patrol And MGM In a Battle Over Name
description: The Pink Panthers were formed last summer as a civilian patrol group in Manhattan's West Village to try to prevent attacks on Friday and Saturday nights on homosexual men and women. Attacks on homosexuals more than doubled in New York City last year, according to the police.

title:
On Your Mark, Get Set, Vote;
A Modest Declaration
description: My name is not a household word in this country, except, of course, in my own household. Yet we all know that in these days of instant worldwide communication -- with up-links to satellites and down-links from them -- an obscure name can become a household word in just a few weeks. It can happen even when the name is not particularly euphonious. Like Schwarzkopf. This fact has given me an idea as I look at our two political parties and their sharply contrasting attitudes as they approach the 1992 Presidential race.

title: Boston Teen-Ager Gives Motive for a Rape and a Slaying: Boredom
description: The suspects' accounts of the slaying of Kimberly Rae Harbour seem as senseless as the crime itself: Several members of a street gang set out to look for a party on Halloween night but instead ended up beating, raping and stabbing a woman 132 times before leaving her in a field to die.

title: Essay; Reading Fahd's Mind
description: The Americans have proven themselves to be loyal friends of my family and my Kingdom, but I fear they will never understand us.

title: Syria and P.L.O. Start Talks on Ending Feud
description: Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization opened talks in Damascus today intended to end an eight-year-old feud and formulate a common stance on a Middle East peace conference that the United States and the Soviet Union are trying to arrange.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: N.B.A. Two-Timers

title: Who's That Girl? Seles's New Look
description: Monica Seles, the defending French Open champion and at least until the conclusion of this year's event the reigning No. 1 player in women's tennis, paused recently on the front steps of the "21" Club in New York. There she had been host to a roomful of beauty editors to celebrate her new haircut and unprecedented endorsement deal for Matrix hair and skin-care products.

title: Cashen Befuddled By Mets' Situation
description: Frank Cashen has seen days like this at Shea Stadium, when many of the fans have left early and the rest are voicing their displeasure; when the opposition's run total mounts and the home team makes what he calls errors of commission and omission.

title: Dr. Ellen Chazin Is Bride of Mark Steven Putter
description: Dr. Ellen Chazin and Mark Steven Putter were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Joshua Finkelstein officiated.

title: Spokane Shuts Its Exchange
description: The nation's smallest stock exchange has closed because of slumping silver and gold prices and waning investor interest, its president said.

title: Bulls Find a Way to Win: Play Like Pistons Once Did
description: Many of the Detroit Pistons remained in the shower or sauna for almost an hour after Saturday's crushing defeat. Perhaps they were trying to wash away reality.

title: 2 Are Shot Dead and 3 Are Hurt After a Collision
description: Two men were killed and three were critically injured in Manhattan Saturday evening when a driver in an automobile accident opened fire on a crowd of bystanders after one of them complained that the car was blocking traffic, the police and witnesses said yesterday.

title: Half of Egypt's $20.2 Billion Debt Being Forgiven by U.S. and Allies
description: The United States and its allies have decided to forgive half the $20.2 billion that Egypt owes them, partly in thanks for the support it gave the anti-Iraq coalition during the Persian Gulf war, Egyptian officials said today.

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Girl, 10, Shot While Playing Outside Her Bronx Building
description: A 10-year-old Bronx girl, shot in the head Saturday night when gunfire erupted around her as she played in front of her building, was in critical but stable condition yesterday after surgery at Montefiore Hospital.

title: First Polish Visa Card
description: Visa International has begun offering Poland's first plastic payment card, but no credit will be granted and only companies need apply. Companies will pay the zloty equivalent of $20,000 for their first Big Business Visa Card and $5,000 for each subsequent card, valid worldwide and in 600 outlets in Poland. The money will be kept in an interest-paying account as long as the card is held. Charges will be debited to it and monthly payments by the card holder will replenish it. "This is the card we are implementing in the whole of Eastern Europe," a Visa executive, Gosia Cathcart, said today. "They don't know how to monitor credit cards or control credit."

title: Jan Eliasberg and Neil Friedman Wed
description: Jan Pringle Eliasberg, a Los Angeles film and television director, and Neil Alan Friedman, a studio executive, were married yesterday in Mexico. Judge Martha Espinosa Garcia of the Mexican Federal Court in the Los Cabos District officiated at the Twin Dolphin Hotel in Cabo San Lucas, Baja California.

title: Survey Looks At Recession
description: Most members of a prominent business economists' association believe the recession will end soon, followed by a slower-than-usual recovery, a survey found.

title: So Let's Go to the Audiotape for Highlights
description: No, Yogi cannot be found reading from his book "The Wit and Wisdom of YOGI BERRA" (an honest-to-goodness book published in the zany '70's), but BART GIAMATTI can be heard, along with The New Yorker's fiction editor-baseball writer, ROGER ANGELL.

title: Photos Create New Trouble at U.N.L.V.
description: More problems surfaced for the troubled Nevada-Las Vegas basketball program today when a newspaper published photos of three members of the 1990 championship team with a convicted sports-event fixer.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about gun- control proposals under consideration in the New York State Legislature incorrectly described the status of proposals in two other states. A bill that would mandate a permit system in Nebraska for many gun purchases is awaiting final legislative approval, which is expected. A bill requiring a seven-day waiting period in Louisiana for purchases, which was approved by a State Senate committee, was recently defeated in the full Senate.

title: Brasilia Journal; To Get It Off His Chest, Chief Puts It on T-Shirt
description: It was late on a Saturday afternoon when President Fernando Collor de Mello was noisily deserted by a close political ally. But the President had a novel way to quickly control the damage.

title: Yanks Take Bus Home, But They're Flying High
description: The afternoon was over, but the Yankees were still energized. After 4 hours 17 minutes, after 11 innings, after a long climb back to another rousing victory, they seemed full of life as they packed their bags and prepared for a long bus ride home.

title: Susan Ivory Wed To Richard Adler
description: Susan Alison Ivory, a freelance photographer and art historian in Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday to Richard Adler, the composer, of New York and Southampton, L.I. Dr. Eugene Callender, the president of the Siddha Yoga Foundation in New York, officiated at the bridegroom's Southampton home.

title: Olympic Track Is Hottest Ticket
description: Europeans are already moaning about the scarcity of tickets for the glamour events at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, next year. Although an ocean away, Americans appear to be better positioned to attend.

title: Amy Finkel and Warren Gleicher Are Married
description: Amy Isadora Virginia Finkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney N. Finkel of South Orange, N.J., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Warren Richard Gleicher, a son of the late Norman Gleicher and Mrs. Seymour Marcus of Woodmere, L.I., at her parents' South Orange home. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro officiated.

title: Nancy Bell Is Married
description: Nancy Susan Bell, a program officer for the World Wildlife Fund in Washington, and Briece Richard Edwards, a publications assistant for the Association of Science-Technology Centers there, were married yesterday by Rabbi Harvey Goldman at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel in South Orange, N.J.

title: Ms. Drangel and Chip Kaye Are Married in Manhattan
description: Sheryl Jann Drangel, an associate at LaSalle Partners Ltd., a real-estate advisory firm in New York, was married yesterday to Charles Robert Kaye, a vice president of Warburg Pincus Ventures, a venture capital concern in New York. Rabbi Phillip Graubart and Cantor David Rosenzweig officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Black Consumers Suffer Exploitation Too
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The director STANLEY KUBRICK has made a film that won't be seen by a wide audience. Mr. Kubrick, whose accomplishments include "A Clockwork Orange" and "2001: A Space Oddesey," spends his days in leafy seclusion as Childwickbury Mansion in the countryside about 35 miles northwest of London.

title: Auction Fails In Panama
description: A public auction for Panama's state-owned fruit producer and exporter, Citricos de Chiriqui, failed to attract any bidders and a new auction date will be set, a Government official said.

title: On Your Mark, Get Set, Vote; Caucuses for Vice President?
description: The nomination of George Bush as the Republican candidate for President in 1992 is virtually a foregone conclusion. That leaves the state G.O.P. Presidential primaries and caucuses with little to do. Perhaps we should let them choose a Vice President.

title: Elusive Figure Sought in Gandhi Death
description: Indian security authorities have begun circulating the photograph of a man believed to have accompanied the woman suspected of killing former Prime Minster Rajiv Gandhi, people close to the investigation said today.

title: K. E. O'Doherty, 64, a Founder of New York's Conservative Party
description: Kieran E. O'Doherty, a founder and the first state chairman of the Conservative Party of New York, died on Friday at University Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 64 years old and lived in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Attrition and Anxiety Stalk French Open
description: Andre Agassi is anxious, Monica Seles, the defending women's champion, is apprehensive, and attrition has set in before this most grueling of the four grand-slam tournaments has even begun.

title: Largest Airline Disasters
description: March 27, 1977 -- 582 killed in the ground collision of two Boeing 747's operated by Pan American and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at the airport in Tenerife in the Canary Islands.

title: War Ends for Reservists but Their Duty Doesn't
description: For 320 members of the Marine Corps Brigade Service Support Group-2, and for more than 100,000 other reservists and their families, the war is over but the job is not.

title: Coach for All Seasons Takes It All In
description: The small community of Warroad lies near the Canadian border in northern Minnesota, where the hockey faithful enjoy short summers and long memories. Bob Johnson will enjoy these things this year. He and Warroad and hockey go back a long way.

title: Melissa M. Zales Marries
description: Melissa Merle Zales, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael R. Zales of Quechee, Vt., was married there yesterday to Timothy Michael Koller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koller of San Diego. Rabbi Donald J. Pollock officiated at the Quechee Inn at Marshland Farms. Mrs. Koller, 28 years old, is the director of research at M. C. Harrison & Company, a brokerage firm in Westport, Conn. She graduated from Princeton University and received an M.B.A. from Dartmouth College. Mr. Koller, 32, is a consultant at McKinsey & Company in New York. He graduated summa cum laude from Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.

title: Public School Program Offers Ballet Training To the Talented Young
description: The pianist plays through the musical staples of ballet classes around the world. The commands are familiar, too, as the teacher calls out to his solemn-faced students to pirouette and plie correctly. But the look of the class is unusual. It is a nearly even mix of black, Hispanic, white and Asian children pointing their toes and stretching their arms together in the predominantly Caucasian world of ballet.

title: Tara Goldberg Weds Richard Aaron Weiss
description: Tara Gwen Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence T. Goldberg of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Richard Aaron Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Weiss of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Irving Spielman and Cantor Meir Berger officiated at the Rainbow Room.

title: Council Member Elected San Antonio Mayor
description: San Antonio voters chose a two-term City Council member as their new mayor on Saturday, handing defeat to a another City Council veteran who had hoped to become the first Hispanic woman mayor of a major American city.

title: Sports of The Times; These Mets Could Hurt Some Buddy
description: DWIGHT GOODEN will apparently be all right. The same cannot be said for the Mets. This is a club on the way to nowhere, to say nothing of a 15-day road trip. Will Mets' fans ever see all these players together again in New York? And will their dreadful defensive slump take their manager down with them?

title: Tax-Relief Prospects Called Dim
description: Varied proposals for reducing taxes have been floated on Capitol Hill, but despite the recession and the search by Democrats for a campaign issue, there is little likelihood that the tax burden will be eased.

title: Soviet Democracy's Other American Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: Tipsy Boaters to Find Sirens Wail for Them
description: The Coast Guard cutter's siren began wailing just south of the Williamsburg Bridge. The cutter's target: a white-and-blue boat with the words "Party Time" and two champagne glasses painted on the hull.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Palmer Beats Arnold for N.C.A.A. Title

title: German Privatization Issue
description: The European Commission said on Saturday that it was not investigating complaints about closed-door policies in eastern Germany despite a widespread perception that foreign investors were being shut out.

title: Varsity Sports in Recession
description: The other sneaker has dropped on many of the money-strapped college athletic departments.

title: Metro Matters
description: Why, Rudolph W. Giuliani was asked the other day, had his corruption investigations never uncovered evidence that somebody had offered a bribe to sway a decision of the New York City Council?

title: Jacob Clayman, Former Lobbyist and Union Official, Is Dead at 86
description: Jacob Clayman, a former president of the Industrial Union Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and retired president of the National Council of Senior Citizens, died Friday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: With Cup, Penguins' Stock Is Rising
description: For the last few months, vague reports have said that the Pittsburgh Penguins were for sale.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "My son wants to play baseball, but Mom's not a pitcher and she's not a batter. There are just a lot of things you expect your husband to do, and he's not there." -- Deborah Harvin, whose husband, a Marine reservist, is still in the Persian Gulf. [ 6:4. ]

title: Lynn Klotz Weds
description: Lynn Stowe Klotz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lewis Klotz of Wilton, Conn., was married in New Jersey yesterday to Matthew John Vincent Salt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Salt of Broadmayne, Dorset, England. The Rev. Lynn Harrington officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in South Salem, N.J. Mrs. Salt, 29 years old, is a designer of special promotions and packaging at Macy's in New York. She graduated from the University of Connecticut. Mr. Salt, 32, is an architect at Jerry Caldari Associates, a New York architectural firm. He graduated from the University of London and received a diploma in architecture from the Polytechnic of Central London.

title: 2 Brothers Missing as Car Goes Into Creek
description: Searchers hunted in shallow pools and combed the shorelines today for two young brothers presumed drowned after a relative's car went into a river.

title: In Washington, Plots Thicken With the Politics
description: "Politics is a life of artifice. You become, through press releases and self-promotion, a figment of the public's imagination. A man of conviction, principle, strength. The successful legislator, one who makes the Washington establishment take note and yet does not forget his roots."

title: School for Japan's Executives in U.S.
description: The international world of Japanese business requires English-speaking executives -- and a businesswoman from Tokyo is doing all she can to provide the lessons.

title: Mets Still Can't Find Handle on Ball
description: Ozzie Smith's wicked line drive hit Dwight Gooden's left wrist like a missile and then things got scary. The franchise pitcher ambled off the mound, stumbled toward third base and circled toward home. All the while, he clutched at the bruise forming just above his wrist.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A New York City traffic agent has sued KATHARINE HEPBURN for $4.6 million, charging that the 81-year-old actress assaulted her and called her a pig when she tried to ticket a car double-parked outside Miss Hepburn's home last year.

title: Mears Goes to the Wall to Win 4th Indy Title
description: Every once in a while, when you're running second at the Indianapolis 500 with 13 laps to go, you've got to do something crazy.

title: Theater Row Journal; Midtown Theaters Act As Tickets to Stardom
description: Scott Caple grew angry and abusive during his job interview last week. In fact, he became absolutely irrational, especially when he put a gun to his head.

title: Britain Trims Key Rate Again
description: The Government cut Britain's base lending rate today by half a percentage point, to 11.5 percent. It was the fifth cut in the benchmark lending rate since mid-February and brought the rate to its lowest level since August 1988.

title: Martha Stewart Gains a Fan: Time Warner
description: First came "Entertaining" by Martha Stewart. Then "Martha Stewart's Quick Cook," "Martha Stewart's Hors D'Oeuvres," "Martha Stewart's Pies and Tarts," "Martha Stewart Weddings," "Martha Stewart's Quick Cook Menus" and "Martha Stewart's Christmas."

title: Cuomo Shift May Unlock Budget Jam
description: In a move that could signal a break in Albany's impasse over a new state budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said tonight that he may urge the Legislature to pass its own version, rather than insist on one that met his requirements.

title: Foyt Exits: A Wave and Wrecked Wheel
description: When A. J. Foyt drove back into the pits today after 25 unlucky laps, his suspension was wrecked and his left front wheel wasn't even spinning. He had cheated death, again, this time by a foot or two.

title: Edmund Demaitre, Retired Journalist, 85
description: Edmund Demaitre, a journalist and retired political analyst with the Voice of America, has died of respiratory failure. He was 85 years old.

title: Bridge
description: Very few pairs have won the prestigious Goldman Pairs twice, but a consistent New York partnership is making a strong bid to join that short list. Gene Prosnitz of Brooklyn and Ira Ewen of Queens, who won in 1988, headed the field at the end of qualifying play on Saturday. Their closest rivals were Leigh Steinberg of Port Washington, L.I., and Simon Erlich of Queens.

title: Nigeria's Experiment -- A special report.; Marching to Military's Cadence, Nigeria Moves Back to Democracy
description: Four years ago, when Nigeria's military strongman made public an elaborate plan for returning the military to the barracks and leaving the task of governing to civilians, many Nigerians reacted with a mixture of cynicism and incredulity.

title: Notes Tell of Painful Search By Jews Hidden During War
description: "Looking for lost child."

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAN AYCKBOURN has been named the CAMERON MACKINTOSH Professor of Contemporary Theater at Oxford University. The chair, at St. Catherine's College, was endowed in 1989 by Mr. Mackintosh, the producer of such hit musicals as "Cats," "Les Miserables" and "Phantom of the Opera."

title: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices were showing little change by midday today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was off 15.28 points, to 25,513.86, by the end of morning trading. The Nikkei lost 114.51 points on Friday.

title: Dance in Review
description: American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Zulu King Rebukes Mandela And Followers Over Violence
description: The traditional King of the Zulus accused the African National Congress today of waging a campaign of violence against his people.

title: As Time Goes By, Professor's Times Keep Falling
description: JIM LAW celebrated his birthday recently. Then the next day he set a world record at 400 meters and American marks in the 100 and 200.

title: 2 Bear Cubs Could Be Killed
description: Two grizzly bear cubs orphaned last summer may be killed soon because officials at the Alaska Zoo cannot find them a permanent home. The cubs, now 100 pounds each, are quickly outgrowing their temporary quarters. Because the cubs lost their mother when they were so little they do not know how to forage for food and cannot be released into the wild, said Sammye Seawell, the zoo's director.

title: Wendy Hyman Weds
description: Wendy Beth Hyman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harris Hyman 3d of New Orleans, was married there yesterday to Daniel Gordon Jarcho, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard W. Jarcho of Salt Lake City. Rabbi Edward Cohn officiated at Temple Sinai. Mrs. Jarcho, 29 years old, graduated from Brown University. Mr. Jarcho, 32, is a lawyer in the Office of Consumer Litigation at the Justice Department in Washington. He graduated cum laude from Harvard University and its law school.

title: Banks Raise Scrutiny of Credit Cards
description: The bankers' adage "know your customer" is taking on new meaning in the credit card business, as banks increasingly rely on computers to guide their relationships with millions of customers they will never meet.

title: In Kurdish Havens, the Big Danger Is Underfoot
description: Among the standing orders for American soldiers in northern Iraq is that they may not imitate the fabled giveaway habits of their fathers and grandfathers.

title: 'Politically Correct': A Handy Enemy
description: To the Editor:

title: Machine Tool Orders Declined 32.7% in April
description: Orders for machine tools fell 32.7 percent in April from a year earlier, an industry trade group says in its monthly report. Orders were 5.3 percent lower than in March.

title: Virginia Inquiry Includes Schultz's Years There
description: An internal investigation by the University of Virginia into questionable loans to student athletes could cast an uncomfortable light on Richard D. Schultz, the director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the athletic director at Virginia when some of the loans were made.

title: Benjamin J. Wolf, 82, Labor-Issues Mediator
description: Benjamin J. Wolf, a labor-management mediator and arbitrator, died on Friday in an automobile accident outside his home in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: Because of the Memorial Day holiday, financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. News about overseas trading appears on page D14.

title: Gunnar Johansen, 85, a Pianist, Composer and Instructor, Is Dead
description: Gunnar Johansen, a Danish-born pianist of extraordinary energy and scope, died on Saturday at his home in Blue Mounds, Wis. He was 85 years old.

title: Joining Forces to Protect a Paraguayan Forest
description: SINCE 1989, when a military coup ended the 35-year dictatorship of Alfredo Stroessner, there has been a democratic awakening in Paraguay, and interest in safeguarding the country's natural resources has blossomed.

title: Observer; Some Street Sports
description: Here's a film of five low-lifers beating and robbing a man in the street. One of the five filmed it himself with a video camera. It shows how far people will go nowadays to get on television.

title: Bulls Brush Aside Pistons for Eastern Title
description: They ended years of frustration. They ended the Detroit Pistons' two-year reign as champions. And now, the Chicago Bulls can begin thinking about playing in the National Basketball Association championship series for the first time.

title: Eyes of Everyone Upon Texas As Rangers' Streak Reaches 14
description: Texas came home and stayed hot by winning its 14th game in a row as Juan Gonzalez and Julio Franco each drove in three runs to help the Rangers rout the Minnesota Twins, 11-4, tonight.

title: Layoffs Seen At Textron
description: The work force at the Bell Aerospace Textron plant here may be cut by 86 percent because of the loss of a Defense Department program that accounts for most of the plant's work, union officials said last week.

title: The Next Bank Robbery
description: When the big money is in trouble, stillness falls over the nation's capital. The Bush Administration's proposed $70 billion bailout for commercial banks is quietly working its way through the system. If the Democrats and media cooperate, the veil of silence obscuring the banking crisis won't be lifted until 1993.

title: Radar Against Soviet Air Attack to Run Part Time
description: In a cost-cutting measure, the Pentagon plans to shut down one of two radar command centers that watch for Soviet bombers flying toward North America. The other center will begin operating part time on Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: INSIDE
description: Japan Raises the Stakes Angered by cuts that threaten its role in the American space station project, Japan says it may refuse to help pay for other big science projects. Science Times, page C7. Battle Over AIDS Policy

title: On My Mind; India: Death or Life
description: Is this the death of India? Will this terrible new crisis at last end the dream of Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru that such a country could exist in unity and freedom?

title: Public Restrooms, Within Reach
description: A lawsuit filed late last year focused New Yorkers' attention on a homely but acute problem: the lack of public restrooms. Now, remedies are in sight -- but may be blocked by a dispute over access for the disabled. The needs of the disabled deserve consideration. But they ought not to obstruct so welcome a project.

title: Bridge
description: Two of New York's most experienced players won the prestigious Goldman Pairs Sunday night for the second time in four years. Ira Ewen of Manhattan and Gene Prosnitz of Brooklyn, who first played together as graduate students some 33 years ago, were also the winners in 1988. The double victory is something very few partnerships have achieved in the 63-year history of the event. The runners-up were Steve Weinstein of Upper Montclair, N.J., who qualified for the 1991 world team championships a week earlier, and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J.

title: Bush Renewing Trade Privileges For China, but Adds Missile Curbs
description: Declaring that he is "trying to chart a moral course through a world of lesser evils," President Bush said today that he would continue China's trading privileges for another year. But he sought to lessen the political effect of his decision by imposing new restrictions on missile technology exports to China.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on China
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today at Yale University, as recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Prison Settles a Lawsuit on AIDS
description: A county prison has abandoned its policy of segregating inmates with the AIDS virus to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of prisoners who carry the virus.

title: Iraq Appoints Oil Minister
description: Iraq has appointed its first full-time oil minister since October, the Iraqi News Agency reported today.

title: Cell Error Pinpointed In Down Syndrome
description: SCIENTISTS say they have been able to pinpoint the stage at which an error occurs in a mother's unfertilized egg, causing a child to be born with Down syndrome.

title: Continued Weakness Forces Further Layoffs
description: The continuing weakness of the national economy is bringing additional staff reductions at advertising agencies around the country.

title: Ms. Collery Weds Randolph Moss
description: Elizabeth Dorsey Collery, the daughter of Helen Collery of New York and the late Prof. Arnold Collery, was married yesterday in Rockville, Md., to Randolph Daniel Moss, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard A. Moss of Rockville. Cantor Siegfried Rowe performed the ceremony at the Rockville Mansion.

title: Health Dept. Loses in AIDS Rule Dispute
description: The Bush Administration's sudden reversal on admitting foreigners infected with the AIDS virus resulted from a fierce struggle in which the Justice Department prevailed over public health experts, Administration officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The concluding years of the 20th century are marked by world events that have replaced the previous bipolar system by a new order. If this order is to persist, cooperation should replace confrontation." -- President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran. [ A10:4. ]

title: A Day Glowing With Warmth and Pride
description: Ebullient with victory in the Persian Gulf and the end of a half-century of cold war, people across the New York metropolitan area paused on a sumptuous Memorial Day yesterday to remember the nation's fallen warriors and to reflect again on the lessons of Gettysburg, the Argonne, Tarawa and Khe Sanh.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None

title: A G.I. Feast Near Dohuk: Top Chow for the Holiday
description: As the sun set over this Kurdish city today, American soldiers gathered on the terrace of an abandoned hotel for perhaps the first Memorial Day barbecue ever held in northern Iraq.

title: Metro Datelines; New Jersey Woman Dies in a House Fire
description: An Ocean County woman died in her home yesterday after an early morning fire of unknown origin started in her living room, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Monarchs Lose One Scott Erney threw two touchdown passes to Demetrius Davis as the Barcelona Dragons upset the previously undefeated London Monarchs, 20-17, at Wembley Stadium yesterday to clinch the final playoff spot in the World League of American Football. The Dragons (8-2) beat out Frankfurt for the wild-card berth and will play at Birmingham next Saturday. The Monarchs (9-1) had already won the European Division title and will play the New York/New Jersey Knights at Giants Stadium next Sunday. (AP) Thunder 33, Machine 27: Kerwin Bell hit Byron Williams with a 22-yard touchdown pass 1 minute 34 seconds into overtime to give Orlando (5-5) a victory over Montreal (4-6). (AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL 2 Teams Advance Wichita State (63-12) and Creighton (49-20) advanced yesterday to the eight-team College World Series. Wichita State rallied for an 11-5 victory yesterday over California in Wichita, Kan., to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional. Creighton, from Omaha, Neb., the site of the series, defeated Hawaii, 15-8, in Los Angeles to capture the West I Regional tournament and advance to the series for the first time. (AP) GOLF Ballesteros Wins Severiano Ballesteros of Spain won the British P.G.A. championship at Virginia Water, England, on the first playoff hole yesterday, edging Colin Montgomerie of Scotland. (AP)

title: Brooklyn Sprinter Sets Record in 400
description: Andy Bloom and Jermaine Johnson were impressive double winners yesterday in the Joe Fox Eastern States Interscholastic championships at Columbia University's Wien Stadium. But in the 400-meter dash, Ivan Jeanmarie of Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, registered the performance of the day when he won in 46.7 seconds for the meet's only record.

title: 140 BODIES FOUND IN JET'S WRECKAGE
description: Searchers recovered more than 140 bodies today as well as the vital flight data recorders from an Austrian jet that blew up shortly after takeoff from Bangkok with 223 people aboard. No survivors were found.

title: Atlantic City Shivers at Indians' Casinos to Come
description: With the last obstacle to casino gambling on an Indian reservation in Connecticut cleared by the Federal Government, gambling industry analysts and casino operators warn that legalized gambling in the Northeast and around the country could hurt Atlantic City's already tottering casino industry.

title: Market Place; Whole or Split Four Ways, Sears Looks Good to Some
description: Many retailing analysts and consultants say they think Sears's stores will remain mired in a sales slump for many quarters. Nonetheless, some of these experts say the stock may be a good investment. Either Sears's results will improve, they say, or shareholders will benefit from drastic changes that may be forced on the company.

title: IRAN'S LEADERS ASK WIDE COOPERATION AND TIES TO WEST
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani and three other senior officials called today for vastly increased economic and political cooperation with the West and for closer ties with Iran's Persian Gulf neighbors.

title: For the Pistons, Time to Ask Questions
description: Champions no longer, the Detroit Pistons have major questions to face this off season.

title: Unstoppable Yankees Get an Improbable Victory
description: In the bottom of the ninth inning, at the end of a game that had seemed another businesslike victory by the first-place Red Sox and a dreary return to losing by the Yankees, the swing of Mel Hall suddenly, shockingly reduced a holiday afternoon to one question: Fair or foul?

title: Handling of Transplant AIDS Cases Studied
description: Federal health officials are looking into whether there were unnecessary delays in searching for recipients of organs and tissues from the body of a Virginia man apparently infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Unbeaten Tar Heels Take Title
description: At first it seemed so easy. North Carolina had its first score only eight seconds into the match, and by halftime the Tar Heels were ahead by seven goals.

title: Music in Review
description: John Rutter Composer and Conductor Carnegie Hall

title: Aiding Moscow: The Quid Pro Quo Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Souvenirs of Gulf War Find Way to Museums
description: The war in the Persian Gulf ended just three months ago, but some museums are already collecting artifacts from the conflict.

title: A White House Puzzle: Immunity Ailments
description: A medical mystery is still unfolding at the White House.

title: Jillian K. Cowan Weds D. W. Segal
description: Jillian Kay Cowan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Cowan of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday to David William Segal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Segal of Wayland, Mass. Rabbi Phillip Weinberger officiated at Tarrytown House.

title: Northwest London Fares
description: Northwest Airlines says it has lowered fares for summer travel to Gatwick Airport in London from 14 United States cities. The fare between Detroit Metropolitan Airport and London is $408 round-trip. For $20 more, passengers can fly from 13 other cities in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana to London via Detroit. Northwest said the fares offered savings of about 45 percent off normal excursion ticket prices. Travel must begin between July 19 and Aug. 31 and be completed by Sept. 15. A minimum stay of six days is required, and tickets are nonrefundable.

title: Milton R. Wessel, 67, Prosecutor Of 'Crime' Meeting at Apalachin
description: Milton R. Wessel, who prosecuted more than a score of alleged Mafia figures seized in Apalachin, N.Y., in 1957 only to have the case collapse when an appeals court ruled that the defendants' constitutional rights had been violated, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 67 years old.

title: Foster B. Whitlock, 76, Drug-Industry Leader
description: Foster Brand Whitlock, retired vice chairman of Johnson & Johnson and a leading figure in the pharmaceutical industry, died on Friday at Maine Coast Memorial Hospital in Ellsworth, Me. He was 76 years old and lived in Southwest Harbor, Me.

title: Theory of a Tamil Plot to Kill Gandhi
description: India's Law and Justice Minister said today that the killing of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was part of a "planned conspiracy" and not the act of an individual assassin.

title: Accountants' Group to Move From New York to Jersey City
description: In what is basically a bottom-line decision -- to obtain lower rent -- the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants plans to relocate most of its employees from its headquarters in Rockefeller Center to Jersey City next year.

title: Review/Dance; Eight Dramatic Solos, Brief and Simple
description: Seven women danced eight untitled solos in the program that Sara Rudner presented on Sunday afternoon at St. Mark's Church. The dances were brief, the costumes were simple and there was no musical accompaniment. The event, which was part of the Tea Dances series of matinees presented by the church's Danspace Project, was unpretentious in format. Nevertheless, Ms. Rudner's inventiveness made it choreographically rich.

title: Books of The Times; Fighting Against Envelopment by the Mass Mind
description: Mao II By Don DeLillo 241 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Plea for Those Who'd Rather Sit Than Sprint
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; The Slo-Go's and the No-Go's
description: As millions of viewers know, Saturday night's "Golden Girls" is good television and good fun. The folks at NBC know that all that smart-talk among an odd lot of mature women is also good business.

title: Pesticide Runoff
description: Whether it falls in a minute or an hour, a tenth of an inch of rain will remove all the pesticide that is likely to be washed off plant leaves, scientists from the United States Department of Agriculture have found.

title: Respect for Andretti's Skill Gave Mears the Nerve to Go
description: As the last recreational vehicles splattered home today through littered parking areas, Rick Mears posed for pictures inside the Motor Speedway. He was a four-time champion of the Indianapolis 500 because of one brilliant pass Sunday, going wide on the treacherous first turn.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Data General Corp., Westboro, Mass., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $100 million offering of 10-year convertible subordinated debentures through Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: An Architectural Plan That's Fit to Set Before a Prince
description: Four years after Britain's most celebrated architecture critic, the Prince of Wales, snubbed designs for redeveloping a historic neighborhood alongside St. Paul's Cathedral, a team of American and British architects has unveiled a new plan for the site: a dense web of classical buildings of just the sort Prince Charles favors.

title: Little Big Man Of Sumo Retires
description: The Wolf is gone.

title: Making Disposal Easier, by Design
description: Environmental concerns are moving onto industrial designers' drawing boards. Designers of autos and home appliances have traditionally worried about appearance, durability and manufacturing efficiency. Now, with more emphasis on conservation and recycling, they are being asked to anticipate what will happen once a product's useful life is over.

title: Patterns
description: Designer Discounts

title: Metro Datelines; Schoolyard Gunman Kills a 15-Year-Old
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth who was shot on Sunday night while playing basketball in a schoolyard in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, died yesterday at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Even the Victim Can Be Slow to Recognize Rape
description: Lori Slicton-Williams did not call what happened to her "rape" until many years later.

title: Modest Summer Upturn Forecast
description: Some analysts say the prospects of a modest summer upturn in the economy seem to be improving.

title: What Gates Was Told
description: Records disclosed since President Bush's nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, last testified about the Iran-contra affair suggest that he may have had more warning than he has acknowledged about the diversion of profits from the sale of arms to Iran to buy weapons for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: ETHIOPIAN REBELS STORM THE CAPITAL AND SEIZE CONTROL
description: Ethiopian rebels stormed the presidential palace today and took control of the capital after the Acting President effectively surrendered Monday by agreeing to cede control of the city to the advancing guerrillas.

title: Business and Health; Debate on Plan To Limit Lawsuits
description: PRESIDENT BUSH sent a proposal to Congress earlier this month to limit medical malpractice lawsuits, accepting a recommendation that the American Medical Association had been pushing for five years. The association has said the limits work in California and has suggested that changes in the malpractice laws could ultimately reduce health-care spending.

title: Edgar Bonjour, Swiss Historian, 92
description: Edgar Bonjour, a Swiss historian, died on Sunday night, his family said today. He was 92 years old.

title: Ebersol Says He's Ready for Pay-Per-View Time
description: The fetid scent of a fat cigar befouled the Rockefeller Center office of Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports. Ebersol -- looking like a taller, nattier clone of Dr. Frasier Crane, the uptight shrink on "Cheers" -- was chatting about his network's investment in the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, and the pay-per-view experiment he will undertake.

title: Jury Fines Peat on Audit
description: The accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick has been fined $3 million by a jury for failing to uncover in an audit the bad business practices of a defunct real estate syndicator.

title: Music in Review
description: Manhattan Philharmonic Carnegie Hall

title: Braille Is Not the Only And Not the Best Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Troupe's Sleekness Fortified With a Dose of Whimsy
description: It was a pity that Freddick Bratcher and Company chose a holiday weekend to make their New York debut. For Mr. Bratcher is an accomplished and inventive choreographer, to judge by the program he presented on Sunday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. And his Miami-based company is sleek and beautifully trained.

title: New Dublin Stock Law
description: The Dublin Stock Exchange, which has been affiliated with the much larger London exchange, would come under Irish jurisdiction in a proposed law announced last week. Finance Minister Albert Reynolds said Friday that the law would authorize the central bank of Ireland to approve rules and license members of the Dublin exchange, one of the oldest in Europe. Supervision and enforcement of Dublin exchange rules are currently carried out partly by the London exchange under regulations that date to 1799. Mr. Reynolds said the changes would apply only to regulation and supervision and would not affect operational links between the two exchanges.

title: Seth Miller Wed to Miss Neubardt
description: Amanda Jo Neubardt, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Selig Neubardt of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Dr. Seth R. Miller, a son of Justice Sondra Miller of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Paul Miller. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill.

title: In the Realm of Technology, Japan Seizes a Greater Role
description: WITH startling new clarity and detail, indicators of technical vigor are depicting a world in which the United States rapidly gives ground to its Japanese competition, a surprising number of small but vigorous nations mount their own challenges and the Soviet Union virtually withdraws from the field.

title: Metro Datelines; Vault Is Burglarized Of $130,000 in Coins
description: Burglars using a forklift to break into a cement-block vault stole coins estimated to total $130,000 from a Chase Manhattan Bank warehouse in Maspeth early Sunday, then got away in one of the bank's own trucks, the police said.

title: There's Hope for Ethiopia
description: Despite last minute threats yesterday by representatives of its crumbling Government to walk out of U.S.-brokered peace talks in London if rebel troops entered the capital, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia remains on the verge of emerging from nearly two decades of tyranny.

title: Trade Talks Get a Lift In Europe
description: American and European officials said today that faltering international trade talks received a much-needed impetus last week when Congress extended the Bush Administration's authority to negotiate an agreement and when the European Community said it would reduce farm subsidies slightly.

title: New Offspring of Mouse Families
description: MICE clutter the desk and demand a fair amount of free space, and their tails, the cords that attach them to computers, often get in the way.

title: Harrelson Answers Critics On His Handling of Team
description: Mets Manager Bud Harrelson today calmly and confidently addressed the issue of his job security and defended his laissez-faire handling of the team's emotionally tumultuous and otherwise embarrassing weekend at Shea Stadium.

title: 7 Officers Hurt As Melee Erupts In Tompkins Sq.
description: Seven police officers were struck with empty bottles and debris thrown by demonstrators during a melee in Tompkins Square Park last night, the police said.

title: The Film and the Dream: A Brooklyn Story
description: Matty Rich is taking a visitor on a tour of a rooftop in Brooklyn where dreams and horrors are visible. He points out the pockmarked gray metal door of a water tower and says, "They take target practice here." "They" are the kids, like Mr. Rich, who grew up here in the Red Hook section with its drugs and its frequent shootouts and its teen-age felons, but who, unlike Mr. Rich, have not escaped from the cycle of violence.

title: Kollmorgen Selects Candidate for Top Post
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation, a maker of electric motors and controls and optical instruments, plans to appoint Gideon Argov as its president and chief executive. Mr. Argov will replace John L. Youngblood, who resigned on May 10.

title: Baby Found Dead in Bath; His Mother, 17, Is Charged
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday in the death of her 19-month-old son, who was found floating face down on Sunday in scalding bath water in the woman's apartment, the police said.

title: Head of Timken Named Chairman of Steel Group
description: Joseph F. Toot Jr., the president of the Timken Company, has been elected chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the trade association of the nation's large steel producers. He replaces Frank W. Luerssen, the chairman and chief executive of Inland Steel Industries, who served two years. The election was held at the association's annual meeting in Washington last week.

title: Saying Goodbye, Fondly, to a Bit of Reality on TV
description: Self-consciousness and anxiety never had it so good. For four years, "Thirtysomething" has brought painful moments of self-scrutiny and doubt as close to the level of an art form as weekly television ever gets. Michael, Hope, Elliot, Nancy, Melissa, Ellyn, Gary and Susanna -- they became family, an often exasperating family, granted, but oddly touching as they grappled with the unexpected and ironic ways in which life unfolds. ABC has canceled the series and tonight's episode, at 10 o'clock, is the last. From here on out, the series is frozen in reruns.

title: Corrections
description: A baseball roundup yesterday omitted the game to which the headline referred in some copies. Texas beat Seattle, 6-4, on Sunday night for its 13th straight victory.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off a Bit
description: Stock prices in Tokyo were slightly lower today. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks dropped 35.21 points, or a little more than a tenth of a percent, to close at 25,390.67.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Dollar Is Little Changed in Quiet Trading
description: European currency markets were becalmed today with the United States and British markets closed for holidays. The dollar closed little changed in quiet trading.

title: Slump or No, Short Fridays Remain a Right of Summer
description: "SUMER is icumen in," a 13th- century poet wrote. And so are summer hours.

title: Turning Up in Chicago: Pitching and Johnson Get Mets Back on Track
description: Nearly 24 hours had elapsed and half a country had been covered, but for the Mets no real meaningful distance had been put between themselves and their macabre weekend of ineptitude and infighting as they emerged from their dugout today at Wrigley Field.

title: Our Towns
description: It all started 15 months ago in a meeting of the powerful Finance Committee of the Madison Soccer Booster Club at Ed Dowling's house. These are the type of sessions, conducted in seeming suburban secrecy across the country, where it is determined, in effect, how many no-name candy bars, flower-seed packs, Christmas wreathes, crates of oranges, tins of nuts and paper plates of someone else's favorite-recipe brownies must be purchased by every child athletes' parents, the parents' parents, the parents' neighbors and the parents' co-workers to finance the year's youth programs.

title: Family Planners Wooing the Master of the House
description: Like most African men, Fred Sabasi makes the decisions in his household, including the number of children his wife, Constance, will bear. So far, they have a family of 10, ranging in age from 3 to 22.

title: Music in Review
description: Nohema Fernandez Pianist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Connors Warms Up to the Clay, but McEnroe Is Chilled
description: It's not that there were no light-hearted winners: Jennifer Capriati said she would have gotten a heartwarming feeling from opening the French Open's center court program this brisk morning even if the temperature had been "50 billion below zero." Steffi Graf said she was finally so free of extraneous distress that she could worry about tennis only. Andre Agassi revealed that Paris has begun to make such a favorable impression on him that he's even appreciating art along with his tennis.

title: Fire in Alaska Wildlife Refuge Continuing Out of Control
description: A wildfire continued burning out of control today on Kenai Peninsula, but a major highway linking the popular vacation spot to Anchorage reopened after being closed for a day.

title: Simple Device Produces Record-Breaking Cold
description: A DEVICE that cost only a few hundred dollars is yielding discoveries about the fundamental nature of matter that normally turn up only in giant particle accelerators with billion-dollar budgets.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this holiday-shortened week is confined to the bill market beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Careers; First Class To Graduate In Toy Design
description: THE FASHION INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY graduates its first class of toy designers on Friday, with 17 students receiving Bachelor of Fine Arts degrees.

title: Albany Legislative Leaders Agree On Deal to Speed Budget Accord
description: New York's legislative leaders announced tonight that they had agreed on a "joint approach" to ending the longest budget stalemate in state history and predicted that they would formally agree on a budget on Tuesday after conferring with their members.

title: Forceful Signal on Pohl Successor
description: Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank's vice president and the chief ideologist of its rigid anti-inflation policy, is expected to be named this week to succeed Karl Otto Pohl as president of Germany's powerful central bank.

title: Despite Skeptics and a Million Miles, Agency Makes Subway Cars Like New
description: Bearing the battle scars of 28 years and 1,352,501 miles of service on the No. 5 IRT line, cars 9002 and 9003 trundled off the tracks and into the dim, spacious barns at the 207th Street shop, a sort of health spa for out-of-shape, overworked New York subway cars.

title: Hanson Battle On I.C.I.'s Mind
description: Britain's biggest manufacturing company, Imperial Chemical Industries, says it is ready to fight any takeover attempt by Hanson P.L.C.

title: Housebuster Wearies And In Excess Takes Metropolitan Handicap
description: Housebuster, the most exciting sprinter in American racing since the renowned Forego of the 1970's, seemed to be sprinting toward the most important success of his career yesterday at Belmont Park. But he suddenly stopped sprinting as the field of 14 turned into the homestretch and faded back to eighth place as the Irish-bred colt In Excess swept past and won the 99th running of the Metropolitan Handicap.

title: Review/Music; Where Life And Opera Are About The Same
description: Anyone who couldn't get into Gian Carlo Menotti's "Maria Golovin" at the Sottile Theater on Sunday afternoon had only to stand outside on the sidewalk to experience much the same effect. Flaming passions and intrigue have spilled out the doors of this sultry city's opera houses; street corners, drawing rooms, hotel lobbies and restaurants are awash with them.

title: Music in Review
description: Romanian Works Weill Recital Hall

title: Bush's Banking Plan Still Faces Obstacles
description: Despite a significant political victory last week, the Bush Administration's ambitious plan to reorganize the banking industry still faces a long and bumpy road in Congress.

title: U.S. and France Are at Odds Over a NATO Army
description: NATO's defense ministers are expected to endorse plans on Tuesday to establish a rapid-reaction force of about 70,000 soldiers, but friction has developed between the United States and France over who should control such a force, officials of the Western military alliance said.

title: Deirdre Paone Wed to David J. Cohen
description: Deirdre Alisa Paone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario J. Paone of Manhasset, L.I., was married in La Jolla, Calif., yesterday to David Jonathan Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Roy Cohen of Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Sternfield performed the ceremony at the Darlington House.

title: Sports of The Times; New Kids On a Bronx Block
description: WHEN the Yankees had Ruth and Gehrig, they won with homers known as "five o'clock lightning." In yesterday's sunshine at Yankee Stadium, lightning flashed shortly before four o'clock in the ninth inning when Mel Hall's second homer of the game created a 6-5 victory over the Red Sox that also included Jesse Barfield's two homers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption from The Associated Press yesterday about the Pittsburgh-Philadelphia baseball game on Sunday misidentified the Phillies' catcher in some copies and omitted his name in others. He was Darrin Fletcher.

title: Police Search for New Jersey Boy
description: Local, state and Federal law-enforcement officials are "aggressively" searching for a 5-year-old boy whose mother lost sight of him at a carnival in Sayreville, N.J., Saturday night, the Sayreville police said yesterday.

title: Two Ships Collide Off Alaska
description: Two cruise ships buffeted by strong wind collided today while maneuvering to dock in this southeast Alaska port, but only minor injuries were reported. One ship, the Island Princess, suffered a 50-foot gash on one side and damage to eight staterooms, railings and a lounge area. Damage to the other ship, the Regent Sea, was limited to the stern, witnesses said.

title: A Resort in Hibernation Attracts 2 Who Are Not
description: Here in the land of the good life, the signs of springtime are soothing. Gentle breezes whisper through the trees. Birds of every color chirp their sweet melodies. Countless shades of green blanket the forested mountains.

title: Q&A
description: Nosebleeds

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHELBY FOOTE, the historian who starred in the Civil War series on PBS last fall, has become a celebrity, at least in certain circles.

title: Metro Datelines; Hit-and-Run Driver Badly Injures Boy, 4
description: A 4-year-old boy was struck and critically injured by a hit-and-run driver yesterday afternoon as he crossed the street in the South Bronx with his 19-year-old brother, the police said.

title: Oil Rig Count Rises
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose slightly last week, with 28 new rigs working, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The company, which makes oilfield equipment, said 846 rigs were operating nationally, 155 fewer than a year ago at this time. Last week's count was 818. Baker Hughes officials have said heavy spring rains kept the count low, and improved weather would bring on a seasonal increase. Of the rigs working, 361 were handling gas, 451 oil and 34 others were listed as miscellaneous. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: As U.S. Spends More On Courts, Backlog Grows, Study Finds
description: A Congressional study made public today found that a steep rise in spending on the Federal courts had not been enough to keep up with large increases in the number of drug cases awaiting court action.

title: Killer of Two Hikers Is Sentenced to Death
description: A South Carolina man was sentenced Friday to die after a jury found him guilty of killing two hikers on the Appalachian Trail last September.

title: E.P.A. Urged to Broaden Air Pollution Studies
description: AN Environmental Protection Agency report suggests that the agency allocate more resources to the study of noncancer health risks of air pollution.

title: Don't Let AIDS Victims Die in the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Quota? No, More Like a Canard
description: Don't bother me, says President Bush, with the facts. House Democrats, alarmed at the slogan-slinging that defiles their proposed Civil Rights Act of 1991 as a "quota" bill, are revising it to forbid hiring quotas for minorities and women. The President hasn't seen the revised language yet, but hey -- he doesn't have to.

title: Chess
description: When up against a capable opponent, you must be prepared to make concessions because he won't let you have what you want without limiting it or blunting it somehow or presenting stubborn resistance to it. You must therefore figure out how to maneuver yourself into achieving the best of what certainly will not be a great bargain.

title: Pirates Smother cards as Drabek Hurls One-Hitter
description: Doug Drabek pitched his second career one-hitter as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-0, today.

title: Campbell Raises Bid
description: The Campbell Soup Company says it is offering $41 a share (Canadian), or $35.67, for each share of Campbell Soup Company Ltd. that it does not own. Campbell, which owns 71 percent of the Canadian affiliate, increased the offer from a previously announced offer of $34.50 (Canadian), or about $30.

title: C.I.A. Pick May Have Got Early Iran-Contra Hints
description: Records that have been disclosed since Robert M. Gates last testified about the Iran-contra affair suggest that he may have had fuller and earlier warnings than he has acknowledged about the diversion of millions of dollars in profits from the Iran arms sales to buy weapons for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: A Penguin's Perspective
description: For three months of the 1989-90 season, TOM BARRASSO left the Pittsburgh Penguins to be with his seriously ill daughter, ASHLEY BARRASSO , a cancer patient who is now well and back at home.

title: Japan Ties Joint Projects To Space Station Plans
description: The Japanese Government, angered that its participation in the proposed space station is threatened by Congressional budget cuts, has issued an unusually blunt and direct warning that it might refuse to contribute billions of dollars to American-led "big science" projects in coming years unless plans to build a vast outpost in space remain intact.

title: Out of the Blue, Green Lifts Lakers
description: As if the Trail Blazers didn't have enough problems dealing with Magic Johnson, James Worthy, Sam Perkins, Byron Scott and, yes, even Vlade Divac, now they have to figure out what to do about A. C. Green, man on a hometown mission.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 26, 1991: TUESDAY

title: Trade Focus Has Changed
description: As the United States and Mexico discuss environmental cooperation under arrangements to lower trade barriers at the Rio Grande, they are demonstrating how profoundly the nature of trade policy has changed over the last two decades.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters on Sunday about the killing of Eddie Fullerton, a Roman Catholic politician in the Irish Republic, gave an incorrect date for the slaying. It took place on Saturday, not last month.

title: Spanish Socialists Are Dealt Some Big Election Setbacks
description: The governing Socialist Party suffered a setback in nationwide regional and municipal elections on Sunday, losing Madrid city hall and possibly the regional government to the conservative opposition, according to official results.

title: Awaiting Riley's Word
description: The PAT RILEY watch continued yesterday. A week after the Knicks put their offer on the table for Riley to become their fifth coach since 1985, they were still awaiting his answer. Although the Knicks said they had no time limit for Riley to respond, he is expected to accept sometime this week, possibly as early as today.

title: Forceful Signal on Pohl Successor
description: Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank's vice president and the chief ideologist of its rigid anti-inflation policy, is expected to be named this week to succeed Karl Otto Pohl as president of Germany's powerful central bank.

title: Forceful Signal on Pohl Successor
description: Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank's vice president and the chief ideologist of its rigid anti-inflation policy, is expected to be named this week to succeed Karl Otto Pohl as president of Germany's powerful central bank.

title: Resolution Trust Deal Affects Real People
description: To the Editor:

title: Moroney Wins Somerville Cycling
description: Brian Moroney, Karen Bliss, and Glenn Milano each won a division of the 48th annual Tour of Somerville yesterday, the second event of a four-race series that combines the premier cycling events in New Jersey.

title: Separatist Wins Soviet Georgia Vote
description: The nationalist leader of Soviet Georgia won an overwhelming victory in the republic's first direct presidential election on Sunday, according to results announced today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOB HOPE's vacant lot in Burbank, Calif., was just sitting there when a house mover unexpectedly deposited a two-story house on it.

title: Canada Bankruptcies Up
description: The number of bankruptcies in Canada soared 77 percent in April from a year earlier, the Government has reported. It said last week that bankruptcies rose to 6,671 in April, from 3,765 a year earlier, and that the number of business failures was the highest since Canada's recession began a year ago.

title: Bullpen Comes Through for Yanks Again
description: In the warm, sunny optimism of a Florida springtime, before the Yankees lost a game that counted, Stump Merrill volunteered the opinion that his bullpen was as good as any in the American League East.

title: Edmonton Protects Kurri From Draft
description: In order to maintain his National Hockey League rights, Edmonton Oilers General Manager GLEN SATHER has decided to protect JARI KURRI in the expansion draft on Thursday, saying that attempts to trade the flashy wing had fallen through. Sather said the forward's salary demands were out of line.

title: News Cameras in Courts? New York's Law Disputed
description: The experimental law that allowed cameras into New York State's courtrooms -- and dramatic footage of criminal trials into millions of living rooms -- expires this week, with the law's future in dispute.

title: Aid to Education Has No Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week: CBI Industries Inc., global offering of 2 million common shares, 1.6 million in U.S. Lehman Brothers.

title: Downtown and Dishy
description: If you like your fashion exotic and not terribly expensive, head downtown. On the steamy side streets of the Lower East Side, several downtown dressmakers have set up shop, making styles with funk and flair.

title: CHRONICLE
description: He used to live near BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN in staid Rumson, N.J., but the rock star JON BON JOVI is moving to more free-wheeling Malibu, Calif.

title: Brainy Parrots Dazzle Scientists, But Threat of Extinction Looms
description: IN ancient India, where they appeared in the earliest literature, they were cherished as symbols of love: the Kama Sutra stipulated parrot training as one of 64 practices men had to master. The Romans taught parrots to speak, festooned them with ivory, kept them in golden cages and sometimes valued them more highly than slaves.

title: Suit Asserts Dinkins Errs In His Policy On Recycling
description: Two City Council members, two New York City residents, and the panel that oversees recycling, are suing the Dinkins administration to compel it to follow all requirements of the city's mandatory recycling law.

title: Behind the Price Cuts
description: COMPUTER companies are cutting prices once again, partly in response to the recession and decreased demand and partly because regular price reductions are a byproduct of progress in the industry.

title: AIDS Talks in Study Hurt More Than Help
description: PROGRAMS used to educate workers about AIDS may, in fact, only make the workers less tolerant of people who have the syndrome, Georgia scientists say.

title: Almost New Is Good Enough, Much to Detroit's Annoyance
description: Two gray Ford Taurus sedans, seemingly identical, sit in a car dealer's showroom. One, fresh from the factory, has a sticker price of about $16,900. The second is almost but not quite new: shiny and still under warranty, it began life as a Hertz rental car, logged 8,000 miles over four months and is priced at $12,500.

title: By Design; Decolletage Help
description: Little lingerie shops and giant department stores alike are reporting an impressive increase in the sales of push-up bras. These brassieres redefine the contours of the bosom, making it smaller on the sides and puffier in front. Thus, even an A-cup customer can exhibit a little cleavage.

title: Pepsi's Theme, And Variations
description: Is Pepsico again expanding its successful "Uh-huh" advertising campaign for Diet Pepsi? Uh-huh.

title: 2,068 Receive Degrees at Brown University
description: Brown University conferred 1,519 undergraduate degrees and 549 advanced degrees yesterday at its 223d commencement exercises on the university's campus in Providence, R.I.

title: Tom Eyen, 50, Prolific Playwright Specializing in Off Off Broadway
description: Tom Eyen, a prolific experimental playwright who wrote the book and lyrics for the 1981 hit Broadway musical "Dreamgirls," died early Sunday morning at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 50 years old.

title: How Doth the Busy City Bee
description: A swarm of honeybees settled on a Honda parked in the East 80's the other day, bringing the police out in emergency masks to remove them. That really wasn't necessary. The bees, made restless by this spring's profuse and early flowering, were probably just out to build a new hive and had paused on their way to Central Park.

title: Hershiser Is Back
description: OREL HERSHISER of the Dodgers will pitch tomorrow night in Los Angeles against the Houston Astros in his first major league game in 13 months, completing a comeback from reconstructive surgery on his right shoulder. Hershiser, who won the Cy Young Award in 1988, will return to the starting rotation for the first time since April 25, 1990. The right-hander had a 2-1 record in four minor league starts, allowing 21 hits and 5 runs in 23 innings. (AP)

title: Accounts
description: * The Coach Leatherware division of the Sara Lee Corporation to Kirshenbaum & Bond, New York, for its lines of leather goods, apparel and accessories. The account, which has billings of $3 million, has been handled in-house since leaving Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners in December, said Michael Calman, Coach's vice president of marketing. An international campaign is due in August, said Mr. Calman, who identified the finalists in the selection process as Henszey & Albert, Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, TBWA Advertising and Young & Rubicam, all of New York. * The Century Council, Los Angeles, a new nonprofit organization founded by brewers, vintners and distillers, has started a $40 million campaign to combat alcohol abuse. It includes the following assignments: advertising to Livingston & Keye, Los Angeles; public relations to Daniel J. Edelman Inc., Washington, and public affairs to the Wexler Group, Washington. * National Employers Life Permanent Health Insurances Ltd., London, a subsidiary of Unum Corp., to Ayer Ltd., London. The agency said that the account, previously handled by Woollams Moira Gaskin O'Malley, London, has billings estimated at $3.47 million.

title: Vietnamese Find No Home Here in Their Fathers' Land
description: After two years of heavy migration to the United States, more and more abandoned Vietnamese children of American servicemen have retreated here to the refugee community called Little Saigon, the final stop in a sad journey in which they have discovered that they are neither truly Vietnamese nor truly American.

title: Jack Weinstein: Creative U.S. Judge Who Disdains Robe and High Bench
description: When Judge Jack B. Weinstein holds hearings in his Federal courtroom in Brooklyn, he does not sit at the judge's bench wearing the traditional black robe. Instead he wears a business suit and sits with the parties around a conference table.

title: Review/Dance; Duo Dares High Style For a Robbins Revival
description: Jerome Robbins's "Other Dances," a pas de deux to Chopin's piano music choreographed in 1976, was visibly a vehicle for Mikhail Baryshnikov and Natalia Makarova. Mr. Robbins made explicit use of the stylish classicism and powerful projection that characterized these former stars of the Kirov Ballet. At the same time the choreography's folk touches, albeit more Polish than Russian, made a fanciful Slavic connection between two exemplars of Russian ballet training and Poland's most cherished composer.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in extremely sluggish trading yesterday, as credit market participants began a holiday-shortened week on a lethargic note.

title: An Indian Temple of Foam Rubber and Ingenuity
