description: "Don't stand straight, but twist and bend," Jacques d'Amboise was busy advising Lartif Thornton, 12 years old, Emily Levine, 11, and Gregor Georgiadis, 12, 3 of the 1,000 children who would be performing in the choreographer's latest production, "Chakra: A Celebration of India."

title:
TRACK AND FIELD;
California Sprinter Not Just Dreaming
description: Fifteen-year-old sprinter Marion Jones runs with the boys in May so she can run with the women in June.

title: Macy Loses $100.9 Million In Quarter
description: Describing its results as "unsatisfactory" and vowing to take steps to bolster sales, R. H. Macy & Company yesterday reported a loss of $100.9 million for the quarter ended May 4. It was the largest quarterly loss for the company in nearly three years.

title: The Car Buyer's Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spark and the Flute
description: Soon enough, the newcomers will be part of the Israeli potage, rising again to its surface in caustic newspaper accounts of the vagaries of absorption and in bitter reports of despair. But for a brief 24 hours, no mean amount of time to us, we knew a forgotten joy amid our cynical, cantankerous, rapacious existence.

title: Kentucky's No. 2 Wins Race For Democratic Nomination
description: Lieut. Gov. Brereton Jones won the Democratic nomination for governor today.

title: Building at 250 Water Street Wins Approval After 8 Years
description: After eight years, four architects and an uncounted number of revisions, plans for a new office building at 250 Water Street, in the South Street Seaport Historic District, were approved yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Marion Vannett Ridgway, Artists' Agent, 88
description: Marion Vannett Ridgway, who served as an agent for artists and writers for more than 40 years, died on Saturday at her home in Southbury, Conn. She was 88 years old.

title: Legislators Plan Albany Budget Of $51.9 Billion
description: Pressing to avoid a showdown over Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's threatened vetoes, legislative leaders today presented a $51.9 billion budget plan to the Governor that includes about $1.2 billion in new taxes and fees and a program to curb the escalating costs of Medicaid.

title: MCA Files Countersuit
description: MCA Inc. today countersued the Motown Record Company and an investment group for more than $25 million.

title: Dykstra Determined
description: LEN DYKSTRA, recovering from injuries suffered in a car wreck on May 6, will be ready to take batting practice with the Philadelphia Phillies in three weeks, the team physician said.

title: Drama in Review
description: Momentary Lapses Avalon Repertory Theater 2744 Broadway, at 105th Street Through Sunday

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: North Korea Reluctantly Seeks U.N. Seat
description: In a major policy reversal that appears intended to stem its growing diplomatic isolation, North Korea said today that it would apply for separate membership in the United Nations, paving the way for both North and South to join the world organization for the first time.

title: Westland Contract
description: The Westland Group P.L.C. of Britain said its Westland Aerospace Ltd. unit had received a contract from the Allison Gas Turbine division of the General Motors Corporation, with a potential value of $200 million. Westland said it would design and manufacture engine enclosures for the new Saab 2000, a 50-seat prop jet.

title: Bulgaria Releasing Data on Shooting of Pope
description: Bulgaria is releasing more than 127 volumes of documents to investigators from several countries, including the United States, in an effort to discover the truth about allegations of Bulgarian involvement in a 1981 attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: Bring Arab Passport Bigotry to an End
description: To the Editor:

title: Jonas E. Halperin, 60, Publicist and Producer
description: Jonas Eli Halperin, a public relations specialist and an independent movie producer, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: LIKE many home gardeners, I spend much of the late spring and summer concocting recipes for my backyard harvest. While my natural inclination is to use French or American recipes, I occasionally go afield and try my hand at more exotic cuisines like Vietnamese, Chinese and Thai.

title: Book Notes
description: Booksellers Gathering

title: Hardly a Lone Star Lineup for Rangers
description: When the Texas Rangers released slugger Pete Incaviglia in a controversial move late in spring training, Manager Bobby Valentine said they would have a better offense without him. Then the Rangers were shut out in the second and third games of the season.

title: Baltimore Bancorp
description: The Baltimore Bancorp said its leading institutional investors had succeeded in electing six directors to the board. It said in announcing the results of a recent shareholders' vote that a dissident shareholder group was unable to seize control of the 18-member board. The dissidents, led by Edwin Hale, a Baltimore executive, wanted to increase the board's size to 28. David Eisner, the senior vice president at Providence Capital Inc., a New York firm that advised several large investors, said investors were unhappy with the performance of Baltimore Bancorp in recent years and its rejection last year of a merger offer by another Maryland bank.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We expect that Ethiopia will be a really democratic country, united not by force of arms but by the freely expressed will of the people involved." -- Meles Zenawi, the head of the rebel group that has taken over in the capital of Ethiopia. [ A6:4. ]

title: Harry B. Warner, Executive, 74
description: Harry B. Warner, a retired president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, died Friday in Naples, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: Trail Blazers Bounce Back In Game 5
description: The game plan did not so much revolve around X's and O's. On the chalkboard was a simple appeal: "You have to want it," written by one of the Trail Blazers' coaches.

title: Bush Takes Upbeat Tone on Scheduling a Meeting With Gorbachev
description: President Bush moved today to reassure President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he was eager to schedule the next superpower summit meeting and appeared to signal that he was looking favorably on a Soviet request for $1.5 billon in agricultural credits.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a labor-management mediator rendered part of his name incorrectly. He was Benjamin H. Wolf.

title: About New York
description: The scene on a sunny morning last week was triumphant. Banners on the wall at Public School 2 in the South Bronx said, "Welcome back Carlos!" Students sat on the gym floor, nearly bursting with expectation.

title: Choosing Corners on Ruddock Story
description: By the logic of the fight game -- or other earthly pursuits -- Donovan (Razor) Ruddock's decision earlier this month to pull out of a rematch bout with Mike Tyson on June 28 was baffling, to say the least.

title: G.M. Brazil Unit Moving
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would move its Latin American operations from Brazil to Miami after Robert B. Stone retired as the unit's head on Sept. 1. Mr. Stone, 60 years old, will be succeeded by Richard C. Nerod, currently president and managing director of G.M. de Mexico. The move is part of a restructuring of G.M.'s Latin American operations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR has settled her $20 million lawsuit against The National Enquirer, winning an apology and money for articles that said she had a fatal disease, lupus, and was drinking while in the hospital. Miss Taylor nearly died during a hospital stay last year.

title: Consumer and Environmental Bills Pass in Texas
description: In whirlwind voting just before its regular session ended at midnight Monday, the Texas Legislature handed Gov. Ann W. Richards several victories by enacting tough measures on the environment, consumer protection and government ethics.

title: Food Groups
description: To The Living Section:

title: Japan Airline Profits Drop
description: Japan's two major airlines said today that soaring aviation fuel prices and a sudden drop in international passengers because of the Persian Gulf war hurt profits in their last fiscal years.

title: Drug Baron Defiant in Mexican Jail
description: Eleven days after his armed supporters took control of the state prison here in a bloody cellblock battle against other inmates, the convicted Mexican cocaine baron who now runs the jail says he will not surrender because corrupt members of the federal police are trying to kill him.

title: Ethiopian Seeks to Form Temporary Government
description: The 36-year-old leader of the Ethiopian rebel group that marched into Addis Ababa this morning said today that his group was establishing a temporary government for the whole country, an arrangement that appeared to have the clear approval of the American mediator in the peace talks just ended here.

title: Dos and Don'ts of Office Etiquette: Has Rudeness Gotten Out of Hand?
description: YOU'RE standing in the back of a crowded elevator. The elevator stops at your floor and you say "Excuse me," but the people toward the front of the car don't budge. Do you shriek "getting off" and elbow your way to the front or meekly ride to the next floor?

title: Other Opinions by the Court
description: The Supreme Court gave an expansive interpretation of antitrust law in a ruling in favor of a doctor. Page D2.

title: Riley-Knicks Dealing Moves Right Along
description: Talks with Pat Riley regarding the Knicks' coaching position took another step forward yesterday when negotiations between the former Los Angeles Lakers' coach and Dave Checketts, the club president, resumed. They are likely to continue today.

title: Yankees Just Don't Understand Barbecue
description: To the Editor:

title: 209 Receive Degrees at St. Francis College
description: "We must remove the barriers that lock people out of the opportunities for education," Barbara J. Sabol, New York City's administrator of Human Resources, told the 209 graduates yesterday at the 107th commencement of St. Francis College in Brooklyn Heights.

title: High Court Upholds Exclusion of Bilingual Jurors
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a prosecutor did not necessarily violate the Constitution by removing people who are fluent in Spanish from a jury in a case against a Hispanic defendant.

title: U.S. Responds Coolly To Overture From Iran
description: The Bush Administration said today that it would not move to improve relations with Iran until Teheran used its influence to obtain the release of six American hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon.

title: Hear America Singing
description: To The Living Section:

title: Break the Baltics' Vicious Cycle
description: Black-bereted troops of the Soviet Interior Ministry shot up border posts of the Lithuanian republic again last week. Unless Mikhail Gorbachev moves quickly to end such bullying in the Baltics, he could undermine his own pleas for substantial economic aid from the West.

title: Speedier Treatments by Telephone
description: Lake Hospital, by the shores of Yellowstone Lake, has only 10 beds, a clinic and a tiny staff to handle the hordes that visit the national park. But complicated fractures or other injuries can be immediately diagnosed at the parent hospital in Cody, Wyo., 80 miles distant, thanks to the emergence of teleradiology.

title: El Al Reports a Profit
description: El Al Israel Airlines today reported a $14.1 million profit for 1990 despite a slump in tourism caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Revenue increased 10.4 percent, to $785.3 million. It was the fifth consecutive annual profit for El Al, Israel's national airline, but the figure was down from $24.2 million in 1989. El Al said it was one of only a few international carriers to show a profit after overseas travel declined in the gulf crisis. The number of passengers increased to 1.767 million in 1990 from 1.741 in 1989. The airline also converted planes to cargo flights during the tourism downturn.

title: The Pistons Were A Disgrace
description: THE Detroit Pistons finished the N.B.A. playoffs like defending chumps instead of defending champs.

title: Takeover Talks Begun By Newmont Mining
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the largest North American gold producer, said yesterday that it had begun talks to be acquired by the American Barrick Resources Corporation, another leading gold producer, in a stock exchange estimated by analysts to be worth about $2.4 billion.

title: Honors
description: * Advertising Women of New York has named Pat Carbine, a co-founder of Ms. magazine and president of the Ms. Foundation for Education and Communication, as this year's recipient of the American Advertising Federation Silver Medal Award for outstanding achievement. * After a seven-year hiatus, the One Club, an association of art directors and copywriters, has reopened its Creative Hall of Fame. Ralph Ammirati, a co-founder of Ammirati & Puris, and Tom McElligott, a co-founder of Fallon McElligott Rice, will be inducted next month.

title: Killing of Brooklyn Boy Called Act of Retaliation
description: A police lieutenant's teen-age son was shot to death Friday night as an act of retaliation arising from his attempt to help a young woman who had been beaten earlier in the day, the police said yesterday.

title: Bonn Names Pohl Successor
description: The Finance Ministry said today that Helmut Schlesinger, a vice president of the central bank, had been named to replace Karl Otto Pohl as the Bundesbank's chief.

title: Leary Loses His Control By Walking a Fine Line
description: Tim Leary was not pitching against Roger Clemens last night, not unless Clemens wanted to grab a bat and become a designated hitter. Leary had chosen to take the slightly less imposing view that he was facing the Boston Red Sox lineup, not Clemens.

title: Lysle A. Wood, Aeronautical Engineer, 87
description: Lysle A. Wood, a former vice president of the Boeing Company who helped to design bombers and rockets, died on May 18. He was 87 years old.

title: I.B.M. Chief Gives Staff Tough Talk
description: I.B.M.'s chairman read some of his managers the riot act earlier this month, saying the company had "too many people standing around the water cooler waiting to be told what to do," according to notes of his remarks obtained yesterday.

title: Inflation Up in Germany
description: The federal statistics office said today that the rate of inflation in western Germany in the month to mid-May rose three-tenths of a percent from April. It was up 2.9 percent from the period a year earlier and that was the highest annual rate since a 3 percent increase in November. Economists expect inflation to rise further, perhaps cresting above 4 percent in July when a series of tax increases take effect.

title: Home Resales in April Highest Since August
description: Sales of existing homes rose 3.4 percent in April, to the highest level since August, a real estate trade group said today. It was the third straight gain, and the report provided new evidence that the housing recession may have ended.

title: Owner Sells Grocery That Was Boycotted
description: A Korean grocery in Brooklyn that was the target of a boycott last year was sold last week because the owner had become "too stressed" by the confrontations with angry protesters, Mayor David N. Dinkins's office said yesterday.

title: Student Pleads Guilty at Start Of Rape Trial
description: One of six St. John's University students charged with taking part in a sexual assault on a female student pleaded guilty last week to reduced charges and is prepared to testify against the other suspects, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Key Rates
Justices, by 5 to 4, Widen Reach of Sherman Antitrust Act
description: The Supreme Court, in an expansive interpretation of Federal antitrust law, ruled today that a boycott of even a single doctor by a small group of competing physicians could be an illegal conspiracy under the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Baghdad Chief Installs Kinsmen in Key Posts
description: In the three months since the end of the Persian Gulf war, experts say, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sought to tighten his grip on power by turning over key functions of Government to trusted family members.

title: New York State Yield at 5.2%-6.9%
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $180.9 million in revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum of 6.9 percent for a bond due in 2015 through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: New Chief for Ayer Europe Will Focus on Unification
description: RICHARD HEDGER might say "jolly good," and talk of how he "ran a good shoot," but the appointment of this quintessential Englishman to a top post at Ayer Inc. reflects the agency's recognition of the growing importance of all of Europe as an advertising marketplace.

title: At Black Campus, Desegregation vs. Dismantling
description: For almost a year, a $48 million construction project has growled along the gently rolling grounds of Tennessee State University, noisily foreshadowing this predominantly black institution's future.

title: ETHIOPIAN CAPITAL IN REBELS' HANDS
description: Rebels established full control over Addis Ababa today with a display of great firepower and discipline, but the dearth of visible demonstrations of support for the rebels suggested that many citizens in the capital were wary of their new rulers.

title: NORTH CONVICTION IN DOUBT AS COURT LETS RULING STAND
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that threatens the conviction of Oliver L. North in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Utilities Facing Profit Pressures
description: REVERSING a long decline, the nation's electric utilities are turning more often to regulators for higher rates. And there are some indications that the regulators are likely to be less friendly than they once were.

title: Bill Proposed to Strengthen Supervision of Loan Units
description: The Bush Administration sent Congress a legislative package today aimed at tighter regulation of the Government-backed companies that provide low-cost loans to home buyers, students and farmers.

title: SABOTAGE CHARGED IN INDIA ELECTIONS
description: A faction of India's leaderless Congress Party asserted today that there were plots afoot to call off elections and place the country under emergency rule in the wake of the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League

title: State Legislators Back Current Tiger Stadium
description: Legislation to block construction of a new Tiger Stadium was approved today by a State Senate committee as backers testified of their love for the old ball park.

title: Review/Rap; Holding a Mike, With Nothing New to Say
description: The rap double bill at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night was, as usual for rap concerts, less than it could have been. It wobbled unsteadily for two reasons. The first is a common one: no one has bothered to help these groups with their acts, and the result on Thursday was watching performers wanderaround the stage with microphones in their hands for several hours. The second is that Gangstarr, the headline group, doesn't have much new to say, something fatal in a genre that demands novelty.

title: Black Actresses Are Still Waiting for Star Roles
description: The unspoken and deep-seated attitudes about race in America are nowhere more apparent than in film and on television, where images of black women are scarce, at best.

title: REBELS WHO SHED MARXIST RIGIDITY
description: The rebel faction that will provide what was being described by American officials as a temporary Ethiopian government has worked hard in recent years to shed its image as a movement devoted to the most rigid forms and models of Marxism, officials and analysts said today.

title: People
description: * Following the appointment last week of Rochelle Lazarus as president of Ogilvy & Mather, New York, three people have been named to handle the duties of her previous job, president of Ogilvy & Mather Direct. Pamela Reese has been promoted to managing director, from general manager; Janet L. Coombs to executive director, from account group director, and Cathy Tweedy to director of client services, from account group director. * DCA Advertising, New York, a subsidiary of Dentsu, the Japanese advertising company, appointed Robert K. Passikoff senior vice president and director of planning. Also, Chas H. Conklin was named vice president and management supervisor, from management supervisor, Bloom FCA, New York. And Ronald Greenberg was appointed vice president and management supervisor, from a similar post at Griffin Bacal, New York.

title: Goldstar Pays Zenith Balance
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that it had received $13.5 million from the Goldstar Company, the South Korean consumer electronics giant, in connection with the sale of 5 percent of Zenith's common shares.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Medical Technologies Inc., Denton, Tex., a nursing services company, plans to buy all outstanding stock of 3CI Complete Compliance Co., a medical-waste company, for an undisclosed amount of cash and American Medical common stock. * CFM International, Evandale, Ohio, a venture of General Electric Co. and Snecma of France, has received a $317.5 million Air Force contract. It will produce 104 CFM56-2-B1 engines for KC-135 tankers.

title: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence; That's Still Rationing
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Airlines' Pratt Engine Order
description: Pratt & Whitney Inc. said Singapore Airlines had ordered up to 20 PW4000 engines worth nearly $140 million to power its wide-body fleet. It said Singapore Air had placed firm orders and options for eight PW4000 propulsion systems to power two A310-300 aircraft it had just ordered and two of the aircraft on optional order. Engine deliveries begin in 1993.

title: Plan Drawn on Banning Job Quotas in Rights Bill
description: In defining the employment quotas they will seek to outlaw in their civil rights bill, House Democratic leaders would allow employers to use precise numbers or percentages in hiring and promotion, but not if that compelled favorable treatment for unqualified people.

title: U.S. Troops Leave Bangladesh
description: Most of the 7,500 American servicemen and women who brought food, clothing and hope to Bangladeshis who survived a cyclone are to resume their trips home from the Persian Gulf war on Wednesday.

title: Wilhelmina Harris, 95; Directed Historic Site
description: Wilhelmina Harris, for nearly four decades the superintendent of the Adams Presidential Family National Historic Site in Quincy, Mass., died on May 20 at her home in Quincy. She was 95 years old.

title: The City Opera Considers a Move To West 42d Street
description: The New York City Opera is considering a relocation from Lincoln Center to the New Amsterdam Theater, a crumbling Art Nouveau landmark on West 42d Street that epitomized glamorous New York night life between 1913 and 1927 as site of the Ziegfeld "Follies."

title: Putting L'eggs on Ice: Capades Gets a Sponsor
description: Ice Capades, the feathery, glittering ice skating show, has named a corporate sponsor for the first time in its 51-year history.

title: Boeing's Expansion Drive
description: A RECORD $102.5 billion order backlog is driving a far-reaching commercial real estate expansion program by the Boeing Company in its stronghold, the Puget Sound area. The company's own plants, some dating from the World War II period, are being modernized, and huge amounts of acreage are being purchased for expansion and to develop high-technology centers for building the new Boeing 777. The plane is to roll off the production line in 1995.

title: Bull Replaces Chief Of U.S.-Based Unit
description: Groupe Bull said yesterday that Axel Leblois had been named president and chief executive officer of Bull HN Information Systems Inc., the subsidiary responsible for the company's North American and Pacific Rim operations. Based in Billerica, Mass., Bull HN manufactures a broad range of computer systems and includes the former computer operations of Honeywell Inc. and the Zenith Data Systems Corporation.

title: Eating and the Sexes
description: To The Living Section:

title: Texas Fast-Train Franchise Given to French-U.S. Group
description: A franchise for a high-speed rail project in Texas to move riders as fast as 200 miles an hour between Dallas and Houston by 1998 was awarded today to a group of investors led by GEC Alsthom of Paris and the Morrison Knudsen Corporation, the big construction company that is based in Boise, Idaho.

title: Paris Dancer to New York
description: Jean Guizerix, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, will perform with the New York City Ballet on Friday at the New York State Theater. Mr. Guizerix will appear in Jerome Robbins's "Watermill," at the invitation of the choreographer. Created for Edward Villella, now director of the Miami City Ballet, the role will be danced by Bart Cook at later performances.

title: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence; Cost of Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO IS PLANNING TO CUT U.S. FORCES IN EUROPE BY 50%
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization reached agreement today on the outline of a radical reorganization of its forces in Europe that would mean at least a 50 percent cut in the overall American troop level and a smaller reduction for the 42-year-old alliance as a whole.

title: Review/Theater; Contrasting 2 Feminists In a Director's Season
description: Having opened his debut season at the New York Shakespeare Festival with a revival of Sophie Treadwell's "Machinal," a feminist play of 1928, the director Michael Greif now closes it with Constance Congdon's "Casanova," a feminist play of the present day. Mr. Greif's talent remains a constant in both productions, and so, in general terms, do the authors' views of how cruelly the world works.

title: U.S. and Spain in Air Talks
description: Spain has agreed to an offer from Washington to discuss problems over airline routes, a Spanish diplomat said today.

title: Dow Advances by 44.95 to Close at 2,958.86
description: Wall Street came to life late yesterday, but traders said there was little hard news to account for the broad rally.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WAYNE NEWTON has been hospitalized with what his spokeswoman says is walking pneumonia. The 49-year-old singer checked himself into a Las Vegas hospital Monday, a day after finishing a monthlong engagement at the Las Vegas Hilton. The spokeswoman, Cheryl Kagen, would not identify the hospital, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Ameritech To Acquire Cybertel
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the regional Bell operating company based here, said today that it would pay $512 million to acquire Cybertel, one of the two companies providing cellular telephone service in St. Louis.

title: Outside Prison, a Tense and Angry Vigil
description: Off-duty prison guards, many dressed in shorts and sweat clothes, milled tonight in small groups near the roadblock on Institution Road leading to the Southport Correctional Facility.

title: Kodak Introduces Electronic Camera
description: The Eastman Kodak Company took its first real step into digital photography by introducing an electronic camera system that can turn a conventional Nikon into a high-tech electronic camera. Kodak's professional digital camera system will sell for about $20,000 and is intended primarily for photojournalists and government surveillance, the company said. The system also marks Kodak's first move into pure electronic photography, where images are captured and created without film.

title: Review/Television; The War Against Misery at Home
description: Bill Moyers says that as he walked to work in New York City during the ground war in the Persian Gulf, his attention was drawn to what he calls the paradox of America achieving victory across the seas while the numbers of the defeated at home keep growing. "The Home Front," tonight at 9 on Channel 13, carries the faces of defeat amid the bulletins of victory.

title: In Europe, a Boom in M.B.A.'s
description: After 700 years without a graduate business school, Cambridge University will offer the M.B.A. degree starting in October. Eager not to fall behind, its archrival, Oxford University, is soliciting money to open a $36 million business school in 1993 that could become the university's largest graduate program.

title: Robinson Pursues The Executive Track
description: FRANK ROBINSON, dismissed as the Baltimore Orioles' manager last week, said yesterday that he would probably accept a job as the team's assistant general manager with the goal of becoming a major league general manager.

title: Bank Fund and C.D. Yields Post Another Weekly Drop
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts, down for the better part of three months, fell again in the week ended yesterday.

title: Agency Wants to End AIDS Drug Monopoly
description: The National Institutes of Health wants to break the monopoly on supply of the AIDS drug AZT in hopes that competition will lower the price, officials said today.

title: John B. Mulgrew, 78, A Priest and Professor
description: The Rev. John B. Mulgrew, a Dominican priest who was a professor of theology and philosophy, died on Sunday at his home in the rectory of Molloy College in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: P.L.O. Figures Meet With a Rebel Front; Spur to Unity Seen
description: After eight years of animosity, rival Palestinians met today for talks that, if successful, could help the Palestinians end the loss of support they have suffered as a consequence of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about paddle fans misstated the telephone number for the CasaBlanca Fan Company in City of Industry, Calif. It is (800) 759-3267.

title: Washington Talk; Public Left Out in the Rights Debate
description: Rarely has the gap be tween Congres sional concern and public interest in a piece of legislation been as wide as it is over this year's civil rights bill.

title: Lack of Leads Frustrates Police Seeking Missing Boy
description: As the search for a missing 5-year-old boy entered its third day today, police officials said they were frustrated by a lack of any leads about the child who is reported to have disappeared at a carnival while his mother stood a few feet away buying a soda.

title: Performing Arts Library Celebrates
description: For its 25th anniversary, the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center has dug into its archives and pulled out some 200 items, among them a doodle by Charles Ludlam, unsung lyrics by Cole Porter, notebooks and scores, letters and stage designs.

title: 'Thousand Points' as a Cottage Industry
description: As the savvy image maker who picks President Bush's camera angles, Sig Rogich does not usually set domestic policy. As a country star who travels around singing of cheating, trains and Mama, neither does Randy Travis.

title: New President Named By Flow International
description: Ronald W. Tarrant, who was named president and chief executive of the Flow International Corporation this week, has a strong track record as a manager.

title: The Pop Life
description: Classical Jazz

title: Between the Bread, Lower-Fat Fillings
description: WHEN you bid a fond farewell to deli, cheese and mayonnaise, it is pretty hard to put together a sandwich anyone would want to eat. Low-fat diets put a squeeze on the traditional sandwich fillings.

title: Deflating the Post-Gulf Balloon
description: Consumer spirits, which roared back at the end of the gulf war, are receding as postwar euphoria gives way to the realities of recession.

title: Rabbi Isaac Swift, 80; Founded Two Schools
description: Rabbi Isaac Swift, a leader in the Orthodox community in Bergen County, N.J., for 30 years, died on Friday at his home in Englewood. He was 80 years old.

title: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence; What Pharmacists Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Runners Tune Up
description: JOAN BENOIT SAMUELSON, the 1984 Olympic marathon champion, has joined the field for the Advil (formerly L'Eggs) Mini-Marathon, a 10-kilometer race Saturday around the loop in Central Park.

title: Books of The Times; An Iran-Contra Study, With Some New Details
description: A Very Thin Line The Iran-Contra Affairs By Theodore Draper 690 pages. Illustrated. Hill & Wang/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $27.95.

title: The 'Middle-Aged' Confession of Chi Chi
description: OLD golfers never die; they just fade their tee shots. And for Chi Chi Rodriguez, life has begun again at age 55.

title: Exodus Above the Red Sea
description: The great airlift that carried 14,000 Ethiopian Jews from Addis Ababa to Tel Aviv over the weekend was a marvel of speed, efficiency and secrecy. Operation Solomon also touched chords of memory and tradition that connect ancient and modern Israel. And in liberating harmless captives of a disintegrating tyranny, the rescue effort sends an implicit message to factions now scrambling for power in Ethiopia.

title: Restaurants Offer New Appetizers: Hot Lines and Newsletters
description: MICHAEL EVANS was torn. Someone had just called the kitchen at Souen, a macrobiotic restaurant in Greenwich Village, where he is the head baker, requesting his recipe for soy cream, a nondairy whipped cream for the health-food set. "In the old days, I'd call it my secret recipe," said Mr. Evans, who ultimately divulged the ingredients over the telephone. "But these days, what goes on in restaurant kitchens is everybody's business."

title: Fragile Foods From Far Away Are Staples for Today's Chefs
description: REGIONAL food and local ingredients are bywords in many of today's best restaurants. But some of the freshest ingredients may now come from thousands of miles away, as chefs rely on deliveries by overnight mail.

title: 'Separate but Equal' Goes Back to Court - A Special Report.; Epilogue to Integration Fight: Blacks Favor Own Colleges
description: Thirty-seven years after the Supreme Court ruled that segregation of public schools was illegal, a refrain from the past is echoing throughout the South. But this time it is blacks, not whites, questioning the need for integration.

title: The Restaurant Is Small and Intense, And the Chefs and Waiters Are, Too
description: KIDS CAFE II, an exclusive 26-seat restaurant on the Upper East Side, opened yesterday. The cafe serves lunch by reservation only, of course.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alloy Computer Products Inc., Framingham, Mass., promoted Kathleen Haley to vice president of finance, secretary and treasurer. * American Airlines, a unit of AMR Corp., Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, named Scott D. Nason vice president of operations planning and performance.

title: American Airlines' Tie To Rodeos Is Protested
description: The International Society for Animal Rights has given a "Lemon Award" to American Airlines for its advertising at rodeos. The organization contends that the company is using animals to promote products in a tasteless and insensitive way.

title: Editor Imprisoned in Kenya On Treason Charge Is Freed
description: A lawyer and editor of a magazine critical of President Daniel arap Moi's one-party rule was freed today after the state dropped charges of treason and violation of publication laws.

title: High-Tech Weapons To Combat Terrorism
description: Amid continuing fears of attacks at airports and government buildings, several companies are vying to promote new, compact devices for spotting explosives without causing long delays or false alarms. Some of these machines are so small and light that the police can take them anywhere terrorists might be lurking.

title: F.T.C. Acts On Inaccurate Credit Data
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it was moving to protect prospective employees from being turned down for jobs because of inaccurate credit reports.

title: Sampras Overcomes Draw, Grip and Muster
description: There he was, center stage at the French Open for the first time in his career, and Pete Sampras was feeling nothing but disenchantment. He didn't like his draw, which paired him against a player who charges around clay courts like a bulldozer. He didn't like the surface, which retards his turbo-driven serves and volleys. He didn't like his grip or the tension in his racquet, three of which he broke trying to fight his way out of a predicament he especially disliked, a two-set deficit that appeared to leave him at the questionable mercy of Austria's Thomas Muster.

title: Mets New Order Leads to Chaos, and Victory
description: Desperation was the experiment's design. For Manager Bud Harrelson, no genuine offense for weeks meant there were no real risks to his shakeup of the Mets' order.

title: More Blood Banks to Review Procedures
description: About 10 percent of the nation's independent blood collection centers appear to violate Federal guidelines for the testing, storage and dispersal of blood, Federal officials say. The association representing the centers, which supply half of the nation's blood, has begun a major review of their procedures.

title: Mehta Bids Farewell to the Philharmonic
description: At six minutes before 11 last night, festooned with flowers and confetti and his arm around his concertmaster Glenn Dicterow, Zubin Mehta walked off the Avery Fisher Hall stage.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Free Elections Trap
description: Last Sunday, 87 percent of Georgian voters cast their ballots for Zviad Gamsakhurdia and independence from Moscow. On the same day, Saudi fundamentalists petitioned their King to broaden participation in government.

title: Syrians to Skip Gulf Parade
description: Less than a week after organizers of New York City's ticker-tape parade for troops of the Persian Gulf war said that they would reconsider their invitation to Syria, the Syrian Ambassador said yesterday that no troops or representatives of his country would participate.

title: Study Says Anger Troubles Women Denied Abortions
description: WOMEN who are denied abortions only rarely give up their unwanted babies for adoption, and many harbor resentment and anger toward their children for years, a new study has found.

title: Clemens Is as Good As It Gets for Pitchers
description: When the Mets and Boston Red Sox drove the 1986 World Series to a sixth game, the National Leaguers knew they had to get past Roger Clemens, the Sox's 24-game winner and eventual American League most valuable player, in order to hope to win it all.

title: At This Farm in Maine, Where There's Smoke There's Fish
description: There must have been plenty of talk around this town in coastal Maine when Desmond Fitzgerald started blasting bedrock near the Ducktrap River in 1978. No one had ever done anything quite like it.

title: Ed Dodd, 88, Creator of 'Mark Trail' Comic
description: Ed Dodd, creator of the comic strip "Mark Trail," died Monday at Northeast Georgia Medical Center. He was 88 years old.

title: Dinkins Said to Want More Hispanic Districts
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins believes the commission redrawing City Council districts has created too few districts with Hispanic majorities and should have drawn one with an Asian-American majority, a top mayoral aide said yesterday.

title: Otis Elevator Deal
description: The Otis Elevator Company, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, said it had signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in the Hankook Engineering Company, an elevator company based in Seoul, South Korea. Hankook, which makes freight elevators, has been Otis's sales agent in South Korea for the last year. The new company will be named the Hankook Otis Elevator Company. It will sell, manufacture, install and maintain elevator and escalator equipment using Otis designs and technology.

title: Extradition Agreed To In Achille Lauro Case
description: Mr. Khaled, described as a top lieutenant to the Palestinian guerrilla Abul Abbas, was arrested on March 5 with three Greeks after the police found a bomb in an Athens house. The police said they had planned to use the bomb against a Barclays Bank branch.

title: Drama in Review
description: Amerikamachine Cucaracha Theater 81 East Second Street Through June 8

title: Bridge
description: Two major team finals will be played in Manhattan this weekend. The prestigious Reisinger Knockout Teams, which began at the Vista Hotel on Monday, will end on Saturday, and the District Grand National Team final will be played on Sunday.

title: Accounts
description: * Whirlpool Corporation, Benton Harbor, Mich., has named W. B. Doner & Company, Southfield, Mich., as its agency on a new retail-oriented special marketing project. Alan Kalter, vice chairman of Doner, said the project involved testing in two markets an advertising campaign "that builds the brand equity of Whirlpool and also results in next-day business at the retail level." The budget is estimated at $4 million. D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., continues as the agency on Whirlpool's general marketing account. * Jacobs Suchard, Northbrook, Ill., a subsidiary of Kraft General Foods Inc., Glenview, Ill., has awarded its Swiss chocolate products account in the United States, which includes Toblerone candy, to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago. Billings were not disclosed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sixty-two years after CHARLES A. LINDBERGH and ANNE MORROW were married, the room where the ceremony took place on May 27, 1929, will be dedicated as the Lindbergh Room. The room, now a classroom, is in Morrow House, part of the Elisabeth Morrow School, which was founded by Mrs. Lindbergh's mother in Englewood, N.J. The house was formerly the family home and became the site of the school after Elisabeth Morrow died in 1934.

title: Argentine Official Says Missile Project Is Being Scrapped
description: Argentina announced today that it was scrapping a controversial air force project to build a Condor 2 military rocket.

title: Pacific Exchange Extension
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange said today that it would extend its trading hours to 1:50 P.M., Pacific daylight time, beginning on or before June 13. The exchange now trades until 1:30 P.M., half an hour longer than any other United States securities exchange.

title: Countdown Begins for Launching of Shuttle
description: The space agency started a second countdown for the space shuttle Columbia today after checking out the ship's new computer parts and fuel temperature sensors.

title: Amid Discord, Myers Quits as Health Commissioner
description: The New York City Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., resigned yesterday after a tumultuous yearlong tenure that began with controversy over his views on AIDS policy and ends with his department facing deepening budget cuts.

title: Food Notes
description: Sober From the Start

title: New Controversy Emerges For U.N.L.V.'s Tarkanian
description: The recent publication of photographs showing three former University of Nevada-Las Vegas basketball players in the company of a convicted sports-event fixer may be the final blow to a fragile marriage between the university and head coach Jerry Tarkanian, according to a top university official.

title: Oates Wins First as Manager As Orioles End 5-Game Slide
description: Baltimore finally got Manager Johnny Oates his first victory, beating the Cleveland Indians, 5-2, tonight to end a five-game losing streak.

title: Rebounding Clemens Douses the Yankees' Flame
description: The drama at Yankee Stadium was absent last night, unless you count the anticipation of wondering whether fans would return Red Sox home run balls to the playing field. There was no ninth-inning comeback for the Yankees, no celebration and no six-game winning streak.

title: Library Edgy Over Order To Tolerate Homeless
description: Most afternoons and evenings, a uniformed police officer walks the reading rooms and little hallways of the library here -- a symbol of security amid insecurity and, more tangibly, a sign of this community's edgy coexistence with its homeless.

title: Clue to Bushes' Disease Sought in Water
description: Sanitary engineers are testing the drinking water at the White House and three other residences in their search for a clue to why President Bush, his wife, Barbara, and their dog, Millie, all have autoimmune ailments, White House officials said today.

title: Judge Closes Jet Bombing Trial to Protect Airline Security
description: A Federal judge took the unusual step yesterday of closing a civil trial to news organizations and the public, ruling that testimony in the case could endanger lives by disclosing secret information about airline security.

title: Masters Gets New Chairman
description: Jack Stephens, an investment banker from Little Rock, Ark., has replaced Hord Hardin as the chairman of the Augusta National Golf Club in Augusta, Ga., the site of the Masters.

title: Why Dump Recycling?
description: The suit by two City Council members to force New York City to comply with its recycling law usefully challenges the Dinkins administration's decision to suspend the program for a year. The wise course is to improve, not abandon, the recycling program.

title: Ex-University Head Pleads Guilty To Accepting 2 Illegal Payments
description: Completing his precipitous fall from power, prestige and influence, James B. Holderman, the former president of the University of South Carolina, pleaded guilty today to using his position to earn illegal compensation and no contest to violating state tax laws.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Clorox Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $400 million shelf offering of debt securities.

title: Defender to Islanders
description: The Islanders traded the rights to ALAN KERR, a right wing, to the Detroit Red Wings yesterday for RICK GREEN, a 35-year-old defenseman, and possible future considerations. Kerr spent almost all of last season with the Capital District Islanders of the American Hockey League. Green appeared in 65 games with the Red Wings last season, scoring 2 goals and picking up 14 assists.

title: Wild West Images Oversimplify Rescue of a Troubled School
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Makes a Bad Year Worse
description: This year's annual spring spectacle in Albany produced a new definition of political irresponsibility. Not only is the new budget agreement a record eight weeks late, the delay cost cities and towns millions of unnecessary dollars because they had to borrow to make up for absent state aid.

title: In the Nation; A Time for Action
description: "The American taxpayer needs a rest," says Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Others may think that the taxpayer -- particularly the low-income taxpayer -- needs relief more than rest, just as a lagging economy needs stimulation more than deficit reduction.

title: London Journal; Bad Dogs and Englishmen, What's to Be Done?
description: The debate is sharply drawn. Advocates of tough controls say more must be done to protect the public and discourage the lawless. Opponents warn of Orwellian measures that will trample the rights of responsible people who may want only to protect their homes.

title: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence; Volunteer Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case Before the Court
description: Last month the Supreme Court agreed to hear a Mississippi case concerning how far a state is obligated to go to insure the integration of once-segregated public colleges and universities.

title: INSIDE
description: North Korean Shift on U.N.

title: Nicholas Bachko, 71, A Shipping Executive
description: Nicholas Bachko, a shipping industry executive who oversaw construction of the ocean liner United States in the early 1950's, died on Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: Players Free to Sue N.F.L.
description: A Federal judge in Minneapolis yesterday assured that the labor dispute between the Players Association and the National Football League would continue unabated by clearing the way for N.F.L. players to sue the league for free agency, then advising the league to immediately appeal his decision.

title: Personal Health
description: I'M the kind of person who sees the glass as half full, more realistic perhaps than the proverbial cockeyed optimist but a far cry from the gloom-and-doomsayers. To me an obstacle has always been a challenge, not a barrier.

title: How to Advance China's Freedom
description: We want to advance the cause of freedom, not just snub nations that aren't yet wholly free. President Bush defined the right objective in his commencement address at Yale Monday. But he passed up a perfect opportunity to do something concrete about it. Had he coupled his decision to extend China's trade privileges with a strong human rights reporting requirement, Mr. Bush could have contributed to China's freedom and prosperity while upholding America's own democratic values. Congress now has a chance to correct the President's omission.

title: Louisiana Is Bracing For Politics With Gusto
description: It has become a cliche to talk of Louisiana's predilection for politics as theater. The metaphors are dusted off every few years: Politics as spicy as its gumbo. Another adventure on the Louisiana Hayride.

title: Ex-Chief Is Charged
description: JIM MARSALIS, who played cornerback for the Kansas City Chiefs from 1969 to 1975, was charged yesterday with five counts of embezzling in connection with his duties as a vice president of the Hancock Bank in Pascagoula, Miss. EARL KOSKELA, the district attorney, said Marsalis, 46 years old, is accused of extorting money from some people who applied for loans or misappropriated bank funds, according to evidence supplied by a security officer for the bank. (AP)

title: Miscellany
description: * American Isuzu Motors Inc. has hired the consulting firms Morgan, Anderson & Co., New York, and the Canaan Parish Group, New Canaan, Conn., to assist in its search for a new agency on the creative portion of its national advertising account, which has reported billings of $75 million to $100 million. The previous agency, the Los Angeles office of Della Femina, McNamee, Los Angeles, was dismissed on May 9. * Ayer Inc. has signed a joint venture agreement that will bring $12 million in billings to its Detroit office. Brogan & Partners Advertising will leave its Southfield, Mich., offices next month and move in with Ayer. The two will consolidate services and facilities, though each will maintain separate management. The agencies said Brogan & Partners' clients include the Chevrolet division of General Motors and the K Mart Corporation.

title: Pricing Garbage To Reduce Waste
description: HOW much does it actually cost to haul away the trash? Many Americans do not know, because garbage-disposal fees are lumped in with other municipal services, like police and fire protection. As a result, there is little incentive to reduce the amount thrown out, despite the rising costs of disposal in much of the country.

title: Microsoft Europe
description: The Microsoft Corporation today said it was restructuring its operations in Europe by dividing the market into three regions in preparation for the unified European market after 1992. Effective July 1, the northern region will be headed by Rolf Skoglund; the central region, including the Soviet Union, by Christian Wedell, and the southern region by Michel Lacombe. All three new regional directors, promoted from within Microsoft Europe, will report to Bernard Vergnes, vice president of that division. Microsoft had European sales of about $546 million in 1990, representing about 46 percent of the company's total retail sales.

title: Care Ordered For Children In Abuse Case
description: A Family Court judge, expressing concern for the safety of 17 adopted children living with a Harlem father who is charged with sexually abusing his daughter, yesterday ordered the city to place a homemaker in the man's house 24 hours a day.

title: For G.I.'s in North Iraq, the Shopping Is Good
description: The six-inch bayonet made for use with Soviet assault rifles can be a fearsome weapon of war, but now that an uneasy peace has settled over Iraq, it has become the souvenir of choice for American servicemen stationed here.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Chioccioli Keeps Lead Mario Cipollini of Italy won yesterday's hilly third stage of the Tour of Italy but his fellow Italian Franco Chioccioli kept the overall lead. Greg LeMond of the United States was eighth in the overall standing, 20 seconds behind the leader. He was 37th in yesterday's racing in Sardinia but was credited with the same time as Cipollini, who completed the 231-kilometer stage in 6 hours 11 minutes 52 seconds. Chioccioli finished 38th, also in the same time as the winner, to keep his overall lead. He has a five-second advantage over the defending champion, Gianni Bugno, also of Italy. (AP)

title: Hanover Energy Gets $50 Million
description: An investor group that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago has invested $50 million in the Hanover Energy Holding Corporation, a natural gas company in Dallas. The group, GKH Partners, is controlled by Tom and Jay Pritzker, owners of the Hyatt hotel chain. GKH is best known for a $3.3 billion takeover of American Medical International Inc. in 1989.

title: Drama in Review
description: Charge It, Please Puerto Rican Traveling Theater 304 West 47th Street Through June 23

title: Abortion Restriction Is Passed in Nebraska
description: The Legislature today passed a bill that would require almost any pregnant girl under the age of 18 to notify at least one of her parents before she could obtain an abortion, and the Governor is considered likely to sign the measure.

title: Roy Disney Firm to Buy Stake in L.A. Gear
description: L.A. Gear Inc., the athletic footwear company that has fared poorly in the last year, said today that it had agreed to sell a 30 percent stake for $100 million to an investment firm headed by Roy E. Disney.

title: Wine Talk
description: SUPERMARKET receipts that list every purchase by brand as well as by price can be a boon to shoppers who like to know where their money goes. They can be even more valuable to the people, including the wine industry, whose products supermarkets sell.

title: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Tests Show Apparent Match in Rape Case
description: The results of genetic tests made public today by the Palm Beach Police Department show an apparent genetic match between samples taken from William Kennedy Smith and the woman who says he raped her on the grounds of the Kennedy estate.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Dear Diary:

title: Ms. Beery Wed To Oliver Trager
description: Elaine Helene Beery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore T. Beery of Tampa, Fla., was married in Bluff, Utah, yesterday to Oliver Randolph Trager, a son of James Trager and Olivia H. Altschuler, both of New York. Rigby Wright, a justice of the peace of Monticello Township, Utah, performed the ceremony on top of Muley Point Mesa.

title: Convicts Take 3 Guards Hostage At Top-Security New York Prison
description: Inmates took over part of the prison for New York State's most unmanageable convicts on Tuesday and held three guards as negotiations continued early today.

title: Epicurean War Bulletin
description: A GROUP of ousted Americans in the Chaine des Rotisseurs, an international wine and food society, have been ordered reinstated by the New York State Supreme Court. The Paris-based organization has about 7,000 members in this country and about 50,000 worldwide.

title: Germany Rolls Out Its Fast Train
description: Germany's state-owned railroad system formally introduced its new high-speed train service today, as slick, computer-controlled trains capable of speeds of 250 miles an hour carried 4,000 guests to a coming-out party in Kassel, a crossroads city lying almost precisely at the country's geographic center.

title: A Mellowed Marxist: Meles Zenawi
description: When it suddenly seemed plausible a year ago that the Tigre People's Liberation Front would become the new rulers of Ethiopia, the leader of the little-known group made his first trip to Washington. The leader, Meles Zenawi, wanted to correct an impression: He was no longer a hard- line Marxist, he told columnists, members of Congress and State Department officials.

title: Garden Is a Theater In London Exhibit
description: Eccentricity has been an ingredient of the best of British gardens since the days of follies and ha-ha's. In "The Avant Garden," an exhibition running in the vast conservatory at the Barbican Center here until June 16, eccentricity has been elevated to an art form.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Aristar Inc., a unit of Great Western Financial Corp., is offering $100 million of 8.55 percent noncallable notes due 1995 at 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

title: Mets Make It 3 for the Road With Long Way to Go
description: The streak is at three. The needle on the gauge of self-confidence has been nudged off empty. The trip, though, has 10 games to go.

title: Party Picks Loyalist to Succeed Gandhi
description: The Indian Congress Party today elected P. V. Narasimha Rao, a self-effacing party loyalist, as party president to succeed the assassinated Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If Venus had seven veils, previous attempts had removed two of them. Magellan has laid Venus bare." -- Dr. Wesley T. Huntress of NASA. [ B11:2. ]

title: The Health Page
description: The Health page, formerly published on Thursdays, now appears each Wednesday in The Living Section.

title: Victor A. Meyers, 93, A Musician-Politician
description: Victor Aloysius Meyers, a band leader and comedian who turned politician and won five terms as Washington State's Lieutenant Governor and two terms as its Secretary of State, died Monday at the Mount St. Vincent Nursing Center. He was 93 years old.

title: New Hearing for Jim Bakker Is Postponed
description: The resentencing hearing for the imprisoned television evangelist Jim Bakker has been postponed, probably for more than two months, because one of his lawyers is ill.

title: Review/City Ballet; Creating a World of Women in 'Waltz Trilogy'
description: It seemed only yesterday that young dancers as different as Kyra Nichols and Darci Kistler were groomed for greater things by George Balanchine in the New York City Ballet.

title: Seminary Challenges Order to Appoint a Woman
description: The Westminster Theological Seminary in Philadelphia has filed a complaint with the umbrella group representing the nation's recognized educational accrediting associations, protesting an order by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools that the seminary include women on its governing board.

title: Defusing the Nuclear Mideast
description: President Bush's announcement yesterday of an American initiative to control weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East is timely and realistic. Despite the reported misgivings of the Israeli Government, the plan serves the interests of both Israel and the Arab states in avoiding a new arms race.

title: Pop in Review
description: The Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir and Friends Radio City Music Hall With a choir of nearly 200 people on stage and an audience filling Radio City Music Hall that was ready to lift every voice and sing, the Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir had the ingredients for a roof-raising gospel concert on the night of May 22. Instead, the choir (which regularly sings at 290 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn) and a parade of "friends" put on a variety show in which the group and its director and arranger, Carol Cymbala, tried to please every pop taste. The program gave up the inspirational momentum of mass-choir gospel music for an uneven sampler of easy-listening pop.

title: Stoves to Salt Shakers, Basics of an Ad Campaign
description: "YOU always come back to the basics" is the slogan that has been running with print advertisements for Jim Beam whisky since the fall of 1989.

title: Genetic Test Results Show Apparent Match in Rape Case
description: The results of genetic testing that have been made public by the Palm Beach Police Department show an apparent genetic match between samples taken from William K. Smith and the woman who says he raped her on the grounds of the Kennedy family estate here two months ago.

title: Televised Coverage Would End Executions
description: To the Editor:

title: Document Fraud Laid To U.S. Senator's Son
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted the 29-year-old son of United States Senator Steve Symms on charges that he falsified documents for alien workers employed by his family's fruit ranch.

title: Policy on Women Hits Vatican Snags
description: Already assailed by dissatisfied Roman Catholic women's groups in the United States, the eight-year effort by the American Catholic hierarchy to issue a pastoral letter on women's concerns ran into more objections in Rome this week.

title: U.S. to Get $49.5 Million in Silverado Suit
description: Federal regulators agreed in principle today to a $49.5 million settlement in their $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush and 12 other former directors of Denver's defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.

title: Another McEnroe Emerges
description: He's a little late for lunch, but don't bother clearing the sidewalks, because nobody is flagging him down for autographs. And don't wait for a fawning display from the maitre d'hotel because he won't invite one. Here comes a McEnroe without the mania, the baby of the family, the self-described mama's boy, the charmer who could count on his oldest brother, John, not everybody's version of Lancelot, to be his knight in shining armor whenever middle brother Mark tried to manhandle him.

title: INSIDE
description: Encouraging Sign on Profits Corporate profits in the first quarter of this year fell markedly less than in the two preceding quarters, providing the latest sign that the recession may be ending. Page D1. A Crusade's Faded Vestige Eight years after Harold Washington was elected Mayor, black political power and unity in Chicago seem like things of the distant past. Page A20. Violent Protests in Ethiopia Several people were killed when victorious rebels in Ethiopia's capital opened fire on protesters who said the United States was causing the partitioning of the country. Page A10. A Successor to Gandhi P. V. Narasimha Rao succeeded the slain Rajiv Gandhi as Congress Party leader, but is not expected to be a candidate for Prime Minister. Page A3. East Village Stalemate The clash of competing social interests has paralyzed efforts to bring calm to Tompkins Square Park in Manhattan. Page B1.

title: The Wigwam Casino
description: Thanks to a bizarre combination of state-sponsored gambling and court-protected tribal rights, lands reserved as the heritage of the American Indian are soon to be turned into sites of casinos to rival Trump's Taj Mahal. Main differences: The Indian casino will be set in pretty forests, and its profits will be tax-free.

title: Seymour B. Feller, 64, Lindsay Housing Aide
description: Seymour B. Feller, a housing official under Mayor John V. Lindsay and a leader in Democratic Reform politics in New York City, died on Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 64 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: MAGELLAN FINISHES MAPPING OF VENUS
description: The Magellan space probe has completed its first survey of Venus, producing even more detailed images of a surface composed of 'igantic lava flows, thousands of cracks and craters and numerous features indicating the forces of fierce volcanic activity, scientists said today.

title: China's Disabled Get Helping Hand in High Places
description: When she was growing up in the 1970's and 80's, Wang Kui was virtually a prisoner in her room, unable to go to school or to play with other children. Her links to the outside world were her radio and her daydreams.

title: Storage Box: Catchall's New Life as Eye-Catcher
description: STORAGE boxes -- catchalls for flotsam, jetsam, whatnots and thingamajigs -- are gaining new interest as decorative objects for the home.

title: A Pitch for Washington Baseball
description: When the British Queen came to Washington the other day, President Bush had to take her to Baltimore for a demonstration of our national game. This was an embarrassment on two counts: first, he had to admit that the national capital had no team of its own, and, second, he had to pretend that the Baltimore Orioles knew how to play big league baseball.

title: Omens Amid the Ruins: A Voyage Across Iraq's Tattered Southlands
description: In town after town of southern Iraq, places tied by broken bridges and blighted dreams, President Saddam Hussein has reasserted control after revolts in March that threatened his Government.

title: Nepal Picks Prime Minister, In Transition to Democracy
description: Girija Prasad Koirala of the Nepali Congress Party became the elected Prime Minister of Nepal today, completing a transition from monarchist rule and marking the return to power of a family that dominated the struggle for democracy over the last 40 years.

title: Administration Seeks Profits In Plan to Auction Airwaves
description: To investors in the R.A.C.D.G. partnership, it was the American dream come true: In December 1989 the Federal Communications Commission chose it by lottery to run the cellular telephones on Cape Cod. Ten months later, without spending a nickel to put the system on the air, the group sold its license to the Southwestern Bell Corporation for $41.5 million.

title: Where Stepparents Are Understood
description: JIM KUBISAK is the first to admit that he had stars in his eyes when he married Peggy Hough two years ago. He believed that love could conquer all, even the hearts of Ms. Hough's two children, who were 8 and 11 years old.

title: JMB Real Estate Venture Is Battered in London
description: A closely watched $425 million European real estate venture involving the JMB Realty Corporation and several big American pension funds has been battered by falling property values in London and for a second time in less than a year is hard pressed for cash.

title: Gene Causing Common Type Of Retardation Is Discovered
description: Scientists have discovered the gene behind the most common type of inherited mental retardation, a significant advance in understanding not only a mental defect but also the genes that help fashion human intelligence.

title: A Texas Official Questions G.M. Ad
description: The Texas Attorney General is threatening to sue the General Motors Corporation on charges of deceptive advertising about how its Cadillac division won the Government's Baldrige Quality Award. Representatives of G.M. and Texas Attorney General Dan Morales were scheduled to meet on Thursday to discuss a settlement.

title: Roosevelt Island Journal; Dime Bus Ride: A Way of Life Ends
description: A dime isn't what it used to be. It's not enough for a phone call or a stamp or a cup of coffee. A homeless person will take it as an insult; your 6-year-old will take it as a joke.

title: Rose Displays and Contests (No Cheating)
description: TAKE time out this week to smell the roses -- they're coming into their peak bloom and won't last long in the heat.

title: U.N.L.V. Athletes to Sign Ethics Policy
description: In the wake of published photos showing former members of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team with a convicted fixer of sporting events, university officials yesterday approved an ethics policy that all athletes must sign as a condition of receiving and maintaining their scholarships.

title: Product Introductions Up 32% Over Last April
description: The recession might keep some people from buying, but it will not keep other people from making. New-product introductions for April were up 32 percent from the same period last year, according to New Product News, a trade journal published by the Gorman Publishing Company in cooperation with Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News columns of Business Day yesterday about a recent shareholders' vote at Baltimore Bancorp misidentified the source of an announcement that six dissident candidates had been elected to the board. It was made by the dissident shareholders, not by the company, which says an official tally is still awaited.

title: Corporate Profit Fall Is Slowing
description: In the latest sign that the recession may be ending, corporate profits in the first quarter of 1991 fell markedly less than in the two preceding quarters, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Smith Follows Drabek's Act And Tosses Another One-Hitter
description: Zane Smith threw the Pittsburgh Pirates' second one-hitter in three days in a 6-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: Chip Trade Talks Fail to Set Measure for Market Share
description: In what could be another setback for American semiconductor companies, United States and Japanese negotiators have failed to agree on a key aspect of a new semiconductor trade agreement, industry officials familiar with the negotiations said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Athlone Industries, Parsippany, N.J., a metals and clothing company, will discontinue its swimwear business, take a $2 million charge against second-quarter results and set up a $1 million reserve for losses on the disposition. * Bellsouth Enterprises, a unit of Bellsouth Corp., a telecommunications company, will combine its Bellsouth Mobility Inc. and American Cellular Communications Corp. to consolidate all domestic cellular operations under a new company, Bellsouth Cellular.

title: Karl Lagerfeld Takes to Draping Walls
description: THE fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld has a passion for houses. He has decorated many for himself -- a chateau in Brittany, a stone palazzo in Rome and a house on the Left Bank in Paris.

title: Bridge
description: The 62d Reisinger Knockout Teams, the crown jewel of the New York tournament year, began on Monday and will end on Sunday in Manhattan. The oldest team in the event is a clear sentimental favorite.

title: Judges Can Do More Than 'Sprungs'
description: "Sprungs" are huge white plastic tents stretched on steel frames planted in a concrete slab. Popping up on Rikers Island, they are the latest symbol of New York City's jail crisis -- and of the need to find new ways to meet that crisis beyond building more cells. The least expensive, most efficient way is to move criminal cases through the courts more rapidly.

title: Pop in Review
description: Triad Knitting Factory

title: Offer for Eljer
description: Eljer Industries, a maker of plumbing and building products, said its board would consider a $20-a-share merger offer from Jacuzzi Inc. at its next meeting on June 18. Jacuzzi, a unit of Britain's Hanson P.L.C., made the bid earlier this month. The offer is valued at $145 million. Eljer's stock was unchanged at $23 today, on the Big Board.

title: Home Video
description: Surprises in the Ranks

title: Nebraska Enacts Abortion Bill
description: As expected, Gov. Ben Nelson today signed into law a bill that requires a parent to be notified in most cases before a girl under the age of 18 can obtain an abortion. The measure, approved by Nebraska's Legislature on Tuesday, allows a girl to seek court approval for an abortion if she does not want to tell either parent. It also allows a doctor to authorize an abortion if the girl's health is in immediate danger because of the pregnancy, or if she declares that she is a victim of abuse, sexual abuse or neglect.

title: Cuomo Moves To Level Cost Of Insurance
description: Many small companies in New York State with mostly young and healthy employees pay far less for health insurance than do companies where most of the employees are older and prone to more sickness. That will change if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has his way.

title: Tompkins Sq. Park, Where Politics Again Turns Violent
description: Three days after a disturbance erupted in the tinderbox that is Tompkins Square Park -- a reminder of a violent clash there three years ago -- the East Village park's future remains hostage to seemingly irreconcilable political interests.

title: Victory Laps
description: RICK MEARS and his wife, Chris, were in Manhattan yesterday to bear one of the burdens of the fame that comes with his victory in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday: doing a promotional appearance for the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands Sports Complex on July 14.

title: W.L.A.F. Archrivals Are Archenemies
description: Monty Gilbreath, a receiver for the New York/New Jersey Knights, recalls some of the pre-game, during-game and post-game conversations between his teammates and members of the London Monarchs when the two teams last met two weeks ago at Giants Stadium.

title: Boston TV Station Cancels News Program
description: Traditions may die hard here, but one will end on Thursday evening with the last broadcast of the nightly news program on the local public-television station, WGBH. The demise of the program, "The 10 O'Clock News," has angered many viewers, who say that for 15 years it has offered an alternative report of daily events.

title: Stocks Rise; Dow Gains 10.73 Points
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday for the third straight session as more investors apparently felt the economy was improving, if only slightly.

title: Judge Reopens a Closed Trial
description: A Federal judge who closed a civil trial on Tuesday said yesterday that he would reopen it but would reserve the right to close portions that involved testimony about secret airline security procedures.

title: Soviets Propose Foreign-Owned Businesses
description: Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov presented a draft bill on foreign investment today that envisions enterprises fully owned by foreigners and a range of other guarantees and incentives.

title: Calendar: Old Papers, Wildflowers, Old Places
description: Cultural Artifacts International House, 500 Riverside Drive (123d Street); (212) 724-5482.

title: Whalers Dismiss Ley
description: The Hartford Whalers yesterday dismissed RICK LEY with a year left on his contract as coach.

title: Larry Brown Interested In South Carolina Post
description: LARRY BROWN, the coach of the San Antonio Spurs whose career motif seems to be bouncing back and forth between professional and college jobs, may be growing itchy again.

title: Elie Siegmeister Memorial
description: A memorial concert for the composer Elie Siegmeister is to take place at 8 P.M. on Monday at the Ethical Culture Society, Central Park West at 64th Street. He died on March 10 at the age of 82. The concert, featuring the composer's works, will be free and open to the public. The performers are to include Stanley Drucker, the principal clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic; Alan Mandel, pianist, and Elizabeth Kirkpatrick, soprano.

title: ABC Agrees To Broadcast Cable Show
description: ABC and the cable network Nick at Nite have agreed to run a new situation comedy on each network on separate nights. It is the first time that a program produced by a cable network will be carried by a broadcast network.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Monday about the marriage of Amy Finkel and Warren Gleicher referred incorrectly to the bridegroom. He was previously widowed, not divorced.

title: U.N. Family Planning Backed by House Unit
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee approved a measure today that would set aside $20 million for the United Nations Family Planning Agency, the same type of financing decision that drew a Bush Administration veto in 1989.

title: Football Finds Fans in Beijing
description: An American college football team turned Tiananmen Square into an impromptu practice field today, attracting curious Chinese who came up to touch the players' shoulder pads and take turns trying on their helmets.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in listless trading yesterday, as credit market participants awaited reports due next week on the economy and inflation.

title: Seeking Signs of Impending Victory
description: The good news for the Los Angeles Lakers is that James Worthy is optimistic that his sprained left ankle will be well enough for him to play Thursday night in Game 6 of the Western Conference finals. The better news is that Buck Williams hasn't yet forecast a victory for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Philip Morris Sells $300 Million Issue
description: The Philip Morris Companies is selling $300 million noncallable notes due June 1, 2001, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Lynn Stanford, 44, Ballet Accompanist
description: Lynn Stanford, a ballet accompanist who played at the School of American Ballet and for such performers as Margot Fonteyn and Mikhail Baryshnikov, died on Tuesday at Baylor University Hospital in Dallas. He was 44 years old.

title: Sanderson Wins Sixth As Yanks Rout Red Sox
description: Scott Sanderson does not throw as hard as Roger Clemens. Hardly anyone does. Last night at Yankee Stadium, Sanderson tossed some pitches that could have been thrown by Roger Rabbit. They floated, they sank, they danced and they dazzled, and the Red Sox did little with them.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE durability of concrete for outdoor items like patios, sidewalk slabs and steps is well known, but concrete's brittleness and vulnerability to cracking is less known. Water entering small fissures in outdoor concrete is most damaging; when the water freezes, it expands with sufficient strength to fracture even large slabs.

title: Yugoslav Republic Of Croatia Declares Independent Nation
description: Croatia declared itself an independent state today, after receiving overwhelming support for sovereignty in a referendum held on May 19.

title: Airport Parking Fees Revised
description: The minimum parking fee at Newark International Airport will increase to $4 beginning on Saturday, Port Authority officials said. The rate change is intended to encourage long-term parkers to use remote lots, according to David Z. Plavin, director of aviation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Hourly lots closest to the terminal will cost $4 for the first four hours, and $4 for each additional hour to a maximum of $48 for a 24-hour period. The current rate is $3 for the first two hours with $2 for each additional hour, up to a maximum of $48. Rates at the long-term lots will be $4 dollars for the first four hours, and a maximum of $6 a day.
