title: No Formula or Bottles For Needy Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban on Aliens With AIDS to Continue for Now
description: The United States plans to continue excluding foreigners infected with the AIDS virus at least through July while the Bush Administration tries to settle a dispute on the question among several Federal agencies, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Suit Against Actor Halted
description: A Florida judge dismissed Price Waterhouse's complaint against Burt Reynolds and his production company yesterday on a technicality, but left open the possibility that the accounting firm could refile the lawsuit with some modification.

title: H. Struve Hensel Is Dead at 89; Ex-Assistant Secretary of Defense
description: H. Struve Hensel, an international lawyer who served in high Navy Department posts during and after World War II and who was later an Assistant Secretary of Defense, died Monday at Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 89 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: Positing the Discovery That Jesus Was Mortal
description: On the Third Day By Piers Paul Read 259 pages. Random House. $20.

title: Debt Totaling $2.4 Billion Priced by Farm Credit Banks
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation priced through various securities dealers and dealer banks, yesterday a three-part financing totaling $2.4 billion in consolidated systemwide debt.

title: Emotion Runs Hard as Hershiser Returns to the Mound
description: Hours before Orel Hershiser took the mound for the first time in 13 months, he had to get into the batting cage.

title: Doris M. Curtis, 77; Led Geological Society
description: Doris Malkin Curtis, president of the Geological Society of America, died Sunday at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Research Institute in Houston. She was 77 years old.

title: Cardinals Named by Pope
description: Following is a list of the Cardinals whose appointment was announced today by Pope John Paul II: Fiorenzo Angelini, 74, Italian Archbishop, president of the Pontifical Council for health care workers. Anthony J. Bevilacqua, 67, Archbishop of Philadelphia. Edward I. Cassidy, 66, Australian Archbishop, president of the Pontifical Council for Christian Unity. Robert Coffy, 70, bishop of Marseilles, France. Cahal Brendan Daly, 73, Archbishop of Armagh, Ireland. Guido Del Mestri, 80, Italian papal diplomat. P. Paolo Dezza, 89, Italian priest and Jesuit theologian, confessor to Popes Paul VI and John Paul I. Frederic Etsou-Nzabi-Bamungwabi, 60, Archbishop of Kinshasa, Zaire. Ignatius Gong Pinmei, 89, exiled bishop of Shanghai, originally named in secret by the Pope in 1979. Jan Chryzostom Korec, 67, Bishop of Nitra, Czechoslovakia. Pio Laghi, 69, Italian Archbishop, head of the Vatican Congregation for Catholic Education. Nicolas de Jesus Lopez Rodriguez, 54, Archbishop of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. Roger M. Mahony, 55, Archbishop of Los Angeles. Virgilio Noe, 69, Italian Archbishop, Vatican official in charge of St. Peter's Basilica. Juan Jesus Posadas Ocampo, 64, Archbishop of Guadalajara, Mexico. Antonio Quarracino, 67, Archbishop of Buenos Aires. Camillo Ruini, 60, Deputy Vicar General for the Diocese of Rome. Giovanni Saldarini, 66, Archbishop of Turin. Jose T. Sanchez, Philippine Archbishop, secretary of the Vatican's Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples. Henri Schwery, 58, Bishop of Sion, Switzerland. Angelo Sodano, 63, Italian Archbishop, Vatican Secretary of State. Georg Maximilian Sterzinsky, 55, Bishop of Berlin. Alexandru Todea, 78, Archbishop of Fagaras and Alba-Iulia, Romania.

title: In Nikon Ads, Words Get Into the Picture
description: AN eagerly awaited campaign for Nikon pays as much attention to the words as it does to the pictures.

title: 3 Hostages Released In End to Rebellion At New York Prison
description: Inmates at New York State's toughest prison ended a 26 1/2-hour rebellion peacefully this afternoon, releasing three guards they had taken hostage, after giving 15 minutes of television interviews complaining about poor food and other prison conditions.

title: Red Sox Assessment of Yankees: 'Pretty Good Team'
description: The bags were being packed last night for the Red Sox to leave the Bronx after a 7-0 defeat and two losses to the Yankees in three games. And Jack Clark, after a 1-for-11 series against the team that traded him in 1988, was thinking about the changes since his departure.

title: With No Unifying Force, Political Power for Blacks Ebbs in Chicago
description: Ten years ago, this rabidly political city was on the verge of a revolution as the sons and daughters of sharecroppers and other migrants from the rural South took their first tentative steps toward electing one of their own as mayor.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: NATO: Still the Defender of Europe
description: By announcing radical changes in NATO's military structure in response to a sharply reduced Soviet threat, the Western alliance has simultaneously sought to forestall moves by the European Community to develop an independent defense capability.

title: Down by Two Sets, Becker Finally Turns On the Power
description: Boris Becker, after behaving like his own personal gravedigger in the first two sets of his encounter with Todd Woodbridge of Australia, abruptly rediscovered his invincibility today to wring out a 5-7, 1-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 victory and survive the second round of the French Open.

title: 3 White Girls Injured in S.I. Racial Attack
description: In what the police are classifying as a racial bias incident, three 15-year-old white girls were assaulted, two with a razor, by a dozen black teen-agers on Staten Island yesterday morning, the police said.

title: New York at Work; The Woman Who Counts the City's Cash
description: If New York City were to run out of cash -- as city officials have feared was possible -- how would anyone actually know?

title: Televised Coverage Would End Executions; A Poor Spectacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Rodman Fined $5,000
description: ROD THORN, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, yesterday fined DENNIS RODMAN of the Detroit Pistons $5,000 for flagrantly pushing SCOTTIE PIPPEN of the Chicago Bulls in the final game of the Eastern Conference playoff. (AP)

title: Pretoria Overturns Death Sentences for 14
description: The country's highest court today overturned the death sentences of 14 blacks convicted of murder in the 1985 killing of a policeman.

title: Eugene Lourie, Art Director, 88
description: Eugene Lourie, art director for Jean Renoir's films "Grand Illusion" in 1937 and "The Rules of the Game" in 1939, died on Saturday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in suburban Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: The Furniture Is New, The Motifs Ancient
description: THE architect Patrick Naggar recently introduced his first collection of furniture, 18 pieces in such contemporary materials as cast aluminum, cherry wood and compressed canvas, but with shapes and decorations that recall images as ancient as Greek mythology.

title: ETHIOPIA OFFICIALS FLOWN INTO ISRAEL
description: The Israeli Government acknowledged today that at least two senior Ethiopian Government officials were flown here and given temporary asylum as part of the price paid for the release of more than 14,000 Ethiopian Jews brought here in an airlift last Friday and Saturday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW OF TECHNICAL COOPERATION AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Key Rates
Paul Cohen, Retailer, 74
description: Paul Cohen, co-founder of Imperial Wear, a retailing and mail-order clothing business for large and tall men, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: A Cancer Drug Argues for Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Store on Fifth Avenue Will Be 'Totally French'
description: With such formidable competitors as Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel ensconced nearby, the Galeries Lafayette fashion store opening in midtown Manhattan this fall plans an aggressively French merchandising strategy to differentiate itself from its American rivals.

title: Changes Are Gained With Delay on Budget, But Some Think They Fall Short of Hopes
description: After a 59-day delay that cost school districts and municipalities millions of dollars, discredited state government and nearly drove New York City to a cash crisis, what seemed most remarkable today about the State Legislature's still unfinished budget agreement was how little was accomplished by the last few weeks of waiting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NEIL BUSH was disqualified from a tennis tournament last weekend for playing in a category below his United States Tennis Association ranking, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bush, the President's son, and BOB SHOPNECK , his partner, trounced opponents in a doubles match at the Colorado Tennis Association's Clyde Rogers Memorial Day Open in Denver.

title: British-French Group In New Radar Venture
description: Thomson-CSF of France and GEC-Marconi, a unit of Britain's General Electric Company P.L.C., said today that they had agreed to form a joint venture to develop a new generation of radar for combat aircraft.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the sexual assault trial of three St. John's University students misstated the charges against them. They are accused of sexual abuse and sodomy, not rape.

title: The True Oliver North Outrage
description: Brendan Sullivan, the lawyer for Oliver North, thinks it "outrageous" that the Iran-contra special prosecutor will keep trying to reinstate his client's criminal convictions. "Any reasonable prosecutor would determine that enough is enough," he said after the Supreme Court refused to review an important ruling in the case.

title: Northwest Air Settles Suit
description: Northwest Airlines has agreed to set aside $3.5 million over five years to enhance the hiring and promotion of blacks in settlement of a 1989 racial discrimination lawsuit.

title: A Cancer Drug Argues for Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Race-Norming: Necessary, for Now
description: Entangled in the debate over the 1991 civil rights bill is the practice of "race-norming" -- adjusting employment test scores by race to improve minorities' job prospects. The practice raises issues of fairness and racial preference. But it cannot be condemned outright without correcting weaknesses in tests skewed against minorities.

title: Economic Doubt on Uniting Korea
description: Sobered by the staggering costs of German unification and the deep economic problems of North Korea, South Korean policy makers are starting to warn that hasty reunification of this divided peninsula could set back South Korea's economy for years.

title: House Approves Bill For a Texas Collider And Water Projects
description: The House today approved $21.5 billion for energy and water projects, including increased spending to clean up nuclear weapons plants and continued financing for a planned $8.2 billion atom smasher in Texas.

title: New Luster for Lacquer
description: Fitzkaplan 131 Varick Street (near Spring Street), 10th floor, New York, N.Y. 10013; (212) 989-8779.

title: Cutbacks Set At Parker Bros.
description: Hasbro Inc., the world's largest toy maker, said today that it would shift production of the Parker Brothers games it recently aquired in its takeover of the Tonka Corporation to its Milton Bradley operation by the end of the year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KITTY KELLEY, whose unauthorized biography of NANCY REAGAN has become a best seller and provoked a debate on journalistic ethics, now plans to become a television interviewer. She said yesterday that she had signed an agreement with MCA TV to develop a one-hour syndicated daytime talk show. MCA, the program distributor that developed a talk show for MORTON DOWNEY JR., said work hadn't started on the Kelley program and that no information was available on the program's content or when it might appear.

title: Events: Seeing Art in Crafts
description: A Dozen Designers Peter Joseph Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue (57th Street); (212) 751-5500.

title: A New Shop in London Offers a Rococo Variety
description: "A BIT Baroque, a bit Rococo, a bit Jean-Michel Frank and some ultramodern thrown in as well," the interior designer Nicholas Haslam said of the shop he opened six months ago at 12 Holbein Place in the Pimlico section of London.

title: New Xerox Chairman Sees Cheaper Options
description: The Xerox Corporation plans to offer less expensive machines and systems in the future, its new chairman says.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Medical Holdings Inc., Dallas, a hospital operator, elected Robert W. O'Leary chairman and chief executive, replacing Harry Gray, who will remain a director. * Amoco Corp., Chicago, named Robert D. Cadieux executive vice president. The company also made appointments at the Amoco Chemical Company: James E. Fligg was named president; Kevin P. Lynch became vice president and general manager of industrial chemicals, and Ralph E. Anderson was named president of Amoco Chemicals Far East Ltd., based in Hong Kong.

title: G.E. Sells Its 50% Stake In Video Unit
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had sold its 50 percent stake in RCA Columbia Home Video, to the Sony Corporation, its partner in the joint venture. The news came as little surprise to the industry, in which a sale had been rumored for some time.

title: 3 Former Chicago Bankers Charged in Kickback Case
description: The Justice Department announced criminal charges today against three former officers of the First National Bank of Chicago, accusing them of giving preferential treatment to certain of the bank's vendors, who gave them kickbacks.

title: COUNCILMAN QUITS 2 COMMITTEE POSTS AS PRESSURE RISES
description: Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos stepped aside under pressure yesterday as chairman of two New York City Council committees and lost the extra pay that goes with them. At the same time the Council's ethics committee referred an investigation of his finances to the city's Conflicts of Interest Board.

title: Regents Test Killed After Answers Get Out
description: The Regents English examination for June will be thrown out because the test's answers were mistakenly mailed to elementary schools across New York, a state education official said today.

title: Hanover Gets Expert In Corporate Finance
description: Robert C. O'Brien, an expert in the financing of corporate acquisitions, is leaving Bankers Trust to accept a similar job at Manufacturers Hanover in mid-June, he said yesterday.

title: U.S. Envoy Tries to Reassure Lebanese on Pact With Syria
description: Ambassador Ryan Crocker of the United States, trying to reassure Lebanon of Washington's support for peace, today guardedly endorsed a treaty of cooperation between Lebanon and Syria.

title: 2 Held After Attempt to Sell Baby, Police Say
description: The parents of a 10-day-old girl were arrested in Greenwich Village yesterday after they tried to sell the child to passers-by, the police said.

title: Pursuing North Prosecution Poses Major Obstacles
description: The Supreme Court's refusal to consider whether to reinstate the criminal convictions against Oliver L. North confronts Iran-contra prosecutors with a daunting and, some legal experts say, a virtually impossible task.

title: U.S. May Seek End to AIDS Drug Monopoly
description: The Federal Government wants to break the Burroughs Wellcome Company's monopoly on the AIDS-fighting drug AZT and encourage competition in an effort to lower the price.

title: 911 Goes Out of Service in Manhattan for 2 Hours
description: The police emergency telephone number, 911, was out of service for two hours in Manhattan last night until it was replaced at midnight by a backup system, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts included an erroneous figure supplied by The Bank Rate Monitor for the change on a money market account at the Newark-based Howard Savings Bank. The yield for the seven-day period ended Tuesday was unchanged, at 5.65 percent; it was not down half a point, and therefore was not the most changed among banks in the New York area. (Yesterday The Bank Rate Monitor said the money market yield at Chemical Bank was down 21 basis points, to 4.86 percent, making it the most changed.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Fine for Marathon
description: The USX Corporation said its USX-Marathon Oil unit had agreed to pay a $900,000 fine and spend $3 million to improve a water treatment system at its Indianapolis refinery. The agreement, reached with the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Indiana, settled a case the Government brought against Marathon under the Federal Clean Water Act after a 1989 discharge of waste water into the Indianapolis sewer system.

title: The Big Flaw in School Reform
description: Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander is shaking the department out of its lethargy. He may even give the Bush Administration a domestic policy. And, happily for the nation, he seems to understand that the quality of education is not measured by how much it costs.

title: Transit Agency Notes Due in '92
description: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority yesterday priced $175 million in notes due March 2, 1992, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Even Winners Worry at Kentucky's Weak Vote
description: Kentucky's political scene was confused rather than clarified by Tuesday's primary election, in which the Democrat favored in the race for governor ran better than was anticipated and the favored Republican ran worse.

title: Self-Defense at Issue in a Chinatown Slaying
description: Can a man who fatally shot someone 18 times convince a jury that it was self-defense? Or was such an act a "cold-blooded killing"?

title: Accounts
description: * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, a division of Investcorp, Bahrain, to Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss Inc., New York, for the creative portion of its advertising account. Media buying still will be handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed. * Hiram Walker & Sons Inc. and Distillerie Benedictine S.A. to Bloom FCA, New York, for their B&B and Benedictine Liqueurs American account. Billings could not be determined, but the companies said spending would be comparable to that of other leading international liqueur brands.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The novel-writing San Jose Police Chief, JOSEPH D. McNAMARA, resigned yesterday, citing health reasons. The 57-year-old chief leaves a career that has included walking a beat in Harlem, earning a Ph.D. at Harvard and serving for 15 years as chief in San Jose, where he has been vocal on gun control (he's for it) and the resignation of the Los Angeles Police chief DARYL GATES (he's for that, too), and has plugged his three books.

title: Menotti Gives Spoleto Festival An Ultimatum: They Go or I Go
description: In the latest episode of a yearlong feud that has transformed the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. into something of a soap opera, Gian Carlo Menotti, the festival's 79-year-old founder, said yesterday that he would not return to Charleston, S.C., next year unless the festival's general manager and the two top officers on its board resigned.

title: Riley and Ewing Continue To Bargain With Knicks
description: The Knicks and Pat Riley talked again yesterday about the team's coaching position in negotiations that Dave Checketts, the Knicks' president, is hoping will be completed by the end of the week, "one way or the other."

title: Beijing Students Issue Leaflets on Democracy
description: In a rare political protest, students at Beijing University have distributed leaflets and hung a banner commemorating those killed in the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square two years ago.

title: Connors Survives 5-Set Encounter
description: He huffed and he puffed and occasionally he borrowed a chair from the gallery and sat down to catch his breath. Jimmy Connors, at 38 the oldest player in the draw of the century-old French Open, preened and pranced and clutched and clung and somehow steamrolled himself past Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-4, 6-2, 3-6, 0-6, 6-4, today.

title: The House That Jack Built And Built and Built and . . .
description: SWANS glide over the limpid pond; beach grass grows over the rolling dunes; bronze temple bells tinkle in the wind. And Jack Lenor Larsen, the fabrics designer, is moving into Longhouse, his new but not quite finished house here.

title: Rep. AuCoin to Try for Senate
description: Representative Les AuCoin, a Democrat who has served in the House for nine terms, announced Tuesday that he would run next year for the seat held by Senator Bob Packwood, a Republican. The 48-year-old Mr. AuCoin, who had been hinting at such a campaign for weeks, made his plans official at a news conference on the campus of Pacific University here. He said he would adopt the campaign slogan of Wayne Morse, the last Democrat to hold the seat: "Principle above politics."

title: After 3 Terms in Senate, Garn of Utah Is Leaving
description: Senator Jake Garn, the Utah Republican who six years ago became the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, said today that he would relinquish his seat next year to spend more time with his family.

title: Business and the Law; Deciding the Fate Of Asbestos Cases
description: A PANEL of Federal judges will hear from dozens of lawyers today in a proceeding that could turn out to be one of the most significant arguments in the history of product liability.

title: Let Lebanon Lead the Mideast to Peace; A Syrian Dark Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Names 22 Cardinals; Chinese Prelate Is Identified
description: Pope John Paul II appointed 22 new cardinals today, including two Americans, and revealed that 12 years ago he had secretly named a Chinese archbishop who spent 30 years in prison for refusing to renounce his loyalty to the Vatican.

title: Philip Morris to Increase AIDS Donations
description: In response to a consumer boycott by homosexuals, the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products concern, plans to announce today that it will substantially increase its charitable contributions to AIDS medical research.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Activated Mike Boddicker, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Waived Dan Schatzeder, pitcher. MINNESOTA TWINS -- Signed Rusty Richards, pitcher, to a minor league contract with the Orlando of the Southern League. SEATTLE MARINERS -- Placed Rich Amaral, shortstop, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Jeff Schaefer, shortstop, from Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. TEXAS RANGERS -- Activated Nolan Ryan, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Placed Bobby Witt, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled retroactive to May 27. National League SAN DIEGO PADRES -- Extended the contract of Dick Freeman, president, through the 1992 season.

title: Argentina, Acceding to U.S., Ends Missile Program
description: An announcement by Argentina's Defense Minister that the country's secret ballistic missile program, the Condor II, would be "deactivated, dismantled, reconverted and/or rendered unusable" goes a long way toward meeting United States demands that the project be destroyed, Western diplomats said today.

title: Fujitsu Buying Maker Of Computers in Europe
description: Fujitsu Ltd., the world's second-largest computer maker after I.B.M., continued its drive in Europe today by agreeing to buy Nokia Data, Europe's sixth-largest independent computer maker. The move is expected to add fuel to the debate raging in Europe about whether to increase protection from the Japanese for important manufacturing industries like autos and electronics.

title: People
description: * Dennis O'Hearn has been promoted to senior vice president and managing director, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York. * Patrick Doody has been promoted to senior vice president and general manager, Livingston & Company, Seattle. * Joanne Burke has been promoted to senior vice president and corporate media research director at Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., New York.

title: Greenpeace Count Puts Dead From War in Gulf at 200,000
description: The environmental group Greenpeace reported today that as many as 200,000 people may have died as a result of the war with Iraq and that 5 million to 6 million people were displaced.

title: Tale Kafka Might Love: Case of Misplaced Trash
description: The buzzer buzzed for Robert D. Kanter late last Friday afternoon -- not quite an ominous midnight pounding on the door, but startling enough.

title: Philip Atlee, 77, Dies; Wrote Detective Novels
description: James Atlee Phillips, who wrote a series of detective novels under the name Philip Atlee, died Sunday at his home in Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 77 years old.

title: Soviet Economy Letter: Reform Map?
description: Two senior Soviet economic advisers, Yevgeny M. Primakov and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, wrote a letter on Soviet economic change and its links to possible Western assistance that has become a catalyst for discussion between Washington and Moscow. The letter is scheduled to appear in the forthcoming issue of a Washington-based magazine, The International Economy, which translated the document and gave permission for its publication here. Following is the text of the letter.

title: Romania Jails an Ex-Official Of Secret Police for 7 Years
description: A military court sentenced a former secret police general to seven years in prison today for his part in trying to suppress the 1989 anti-Communist uprising, according to the official press agency, Rompres.

title: Ballerina From a Shelter: A Child's Dream
description: Shara Overton dresses her favorite doll, "Little Miss Make-Up," as a prima ballerina and dreams of her doing pirouettes and dancing gracefully in the "Nutcracker."

title: Allies to Close Last Kurdish Camp in Turkey
description: Allied commanders have announced plans to close the last Kurdish refugee camp in Turkey this weekend, a milestone in efforts to end the two-month-old refugee crisis in northern Iraq.

title: Several Rioters Are Killed as Ethiopians Vent Anti-American Anger
description: Thousands of residents of the capital turned out today in violent protests against the American role in negotiations that they say are leading to the partition of Ethiopia among rival guerrilla groups.

title: Under U.S. Pressure, Bristol-Myers Drops 2 Promotional Ploys
description: The Government today announced an agreement to keep a major drug company from promoting its cancer drugs for unapproved uses and to halt promotional materials that officials said were disguised as a scholarly journal.

title: Veneer Repairs an Amateur Can Tackle
description: Veneering is the process of applying thin sheets of fine or rare wood to a framework of plainer stuff. The technique permits the decorative use of many beautiful woods that, when used in solid form, are prone to cracking or twisting.

title: Alfred E. Simon, 83, Show-Music Historian
description: Alfred E. Simon, a historian of theater music, author and pianist, died on Tuesday at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Federal Takeover of Franklin Savings Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the Government's takeover of the Franklin Savings Association, overturning a lower court ruling.

title: Freshman Initiation: Kelly Meets Professor Clemens
description: In his continuing education as a major league rookie, Pat Kelly learns something new all the time. One day he is turning the pivot at second base and the next day he is making the long throw from third. If Kelly is not analyzing what pitchers throw, he is studying the habits of opposing hitters.

title: Let Lebanon Lead the Mideast to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Bhutto's Husband Acquitted On Corruption Charge Again
description: The husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan was acquitted today of fraudulently distributing prime land in the eastern district of Karachi, the nation's largest city.

title: War's Memories Eased At Military Graduation
description: In the final days of the Vietnam War, a South Vietnamese military commander, Quyen Bui, embraced his wife and two sons, ages 3 and 4, and hustled them onto a plane bound for safety in the United States.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Red Star Belgrade Triumphs Red Star Belgrade won its first Champions Cup yesterday by beating Olympique Marseille, 5-3, on penalty kicks in Bari, Italy. The teams were tied, 0-0, after the regulation 90 minutes and played 30 scoreless minutes of overtime before the shootout. Manuel Amoros missed the key penalty kick for the French champions who, like the Yugoslavs, were playing for the first time in the finals of the Champions Cup. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Boden Sets Javelin Record Amid rain and cold in Eugene, Ore., yesterday, former world-record holder Patrick Boden of the University of Texas set a Hayward Field record in the men's javelin throw on the opening day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association outdoor championships. Boden, seeking his third straight collegiate title, threw the javelin 261 feet 10 inches during qualifying, erasing the University of Oregon stadium record of 261-0 by Brian Crouser in 1989. The second-best throw was 247-11 by John Richardson of Tennessee. (AP) Bishop Loughlin Triumphs: Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association girls title yesterday at Randalls Island with 69 points. St. Francis Prep of Queens was second with 38. Mimi Greene led Loughlin with victories in the discus throw and javelin throw. Nicole Dickson of St. Francis set the only meet record with a 39-foot performance in the triple jump.

title: Los Angeles County Bonds
description: The Los Angeles County Transportation Commission priced $500 million in sales tax revenue bonds yesterday through Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Guerrillas in Peru Dynamite Power Lines and Kill Officer
description: Guerrillas blacked out parts of the capital by blowing up power lines today. They also killed a police officer and terrorized bus drivers into staying home, forcing tens of thousands of people to walk to work.

title: Orthodox Jews Upset Over Plan On City Council
description: The panel drawing new City Council districts for New York City has been criticized by black, Hispanic and Asian-American groups. Now another minority has weighed in with criticism: Orthodox Jews.

title: House Democrats Hone Rights Bill In Effort to Gain a Handful of Votes
description: House Democrats went back to work on writing their civil rights bill today, trying to polish the document they had released on Monday night in the hope of firming up a few more votes.

title: Canada Beer-Trade Case
description: Canada was given approval today on its request for an international investigation into what it says is United States discrimination against imports of beer, wine and cider. The council of the 102-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed to set up a neutral panel to rule on the complaint, which Canada raised last year after the United States budget legislation was enacted. Canada contends that Federal excise tax measures enacted in Washington last October violate GATT trade rules by providing exclusive advantages to certain American producers of beer, wine and cider.

title: Behind the Faded Glory, a Home for Sculptures
description: THE Grand Army Plaza Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch at the foot of Prospect Park in Brooklyn seems a dismal place to live. Its concrete interior walls are crumbling and growing brown with mold; there are no windows to freshen its dank, stale atmosphere, and the intimidating newel posts of the circular staircases are battle-axes. But the arch is the home of two art exhibitions a year.

title: Who Are the Best? Sony Takes a Shot
description: It seems like long ago, but there was a time when you could identify the best golfers in the world by glancing at the PGA Tour's official money list.

title: House Tours Offer A Glimpse of 1800's
description: This is the time of year to visit historic landmarks, to explore restored 19th-century houses and to sample ideas for interiors and gardens in and around New York. New York City Historic House Festival

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the choreographer Jacques d'Amboise's latest production, "Chakra: A Celebration of India," misidentified the child being helped with her costume. She was Emily Levine.

title: Suspension Upheld
description: Nevada boxing officials yesterday upheld a one-year suspension and $25,000 fine for promoter MURAD MUHAMMAD 's involvement in a brawl following the March 18 fight between MIKE TYSON and DONOVAN (RAZOR) RUDDOCK . Muhammad told commissioners that the June 28 rematch between the two fighters at the Mirage in Las Vegas, Nev., would go on regardless of the commission's ruling. (AP)

title: Sports of The Times; There Was Another Homer in '51
description: WITH the recent rash of managerial firings -- despite it being so early in the season -- and the heat being turned up on the seats of several others, including the one in Queens, the most unusual ousting of all was recalled, when Phil Cavarretta was bounced as manager of the Cubs in spring training 1954. No manager, alive or dead, was ever fired so early.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: SEVERAL months before the birth of their son in December, William and Kristi Sullivan began to prepare their 6-year-old daughter, Katie, for the event. Katie had been begging her parents for a baby and was thrilled to learn that she would get one. But as her mother's pregnancy progressed and the prospect of having a new baby at home become more real, she began having mixed feelings.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Ketchum Advertising, Los Angeles, has created several new television commercials for Acura cars. In the spots, edited in the style of MTV videos, Acura drivers wear expensive suits, listen to cool music and fly airplanes in their free time. * U S Sprint will feature Candice Bergen in spots for its new Priority Customer Service. A television commercial, created by J. Walter Thompson in San Francisco will use the theme line "You deserve it."

title: A Different Way of Seeing TV
description: "I'VE been watching TV all my life, every day," said John Wells, a Manhattan artist. "I've also been taking things apart all my life."

title: Suits Seek Settlement's Details
description: Two newspapers and the City of San Diego have gone to court seeking public disclosure of a secret $100,000 settlement between top city officials and a former city planner who had filed a sexual harassment complaint.

title: When Nature Needs A Judicious Hand
description: WITHOUT a census or other hard data to back me up, I am still of the firm conviction that the population of birds that either live in my small garden or swoop into it on regular visits has risen sharply in recent years.

title: BEATEN MOTORIST IS ARRESTED AGAIN
description: The motorist whose beating by Los Angeles police has been seen on videotape around the nation was detained Tuesday night by police officers who said he tried to run over an undercover officer with his truck after picking up a male prostitute.

title: Executions on TV: Defining the Issues
description: The dispute over whether executions should be televised has rearranged some political alliances. Defenders and opponents of capital punishment are found on both sides of the argument that the First Amendment gives television cameras a right to a place in the death chamber. The San Francisco public television station KQED is claiming that right in Federal District Court there.

title: Soviets Propose New Economic Changes
description: Three advisers to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, presented the Bush Administration today with new proposals for Soviet economic and political reforms to stabilize the Soviet economy, but they were told by Washington that they would have to make concrete steps -- not just promises -- before any American aid would be considered.

title: Roy Cullenbine, Outfielder, 77
description: Roy Cullenbine, an outfielder who batted .276 with six major league teams from 1938 to 1947, died of heart disease on Tuesday, a spokesman for Mount Clemens General Hospital said. Mr. Cullenbine was 77 years old.

title: Active Trevino Is Here, There and Everywhere
description: Lee Trevino had other things on his mind today, even as he prepared for his next golf tournament.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section last Thursday about the exhibition "Roberto Burle Marx: The Unnatural Art of the Garden," at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, referred incorrectly to a landscape architect installing plants. He was Raymond Jungles, not Robert Jungles.

title: Strawbridge's Net Off Sharply
description: Strawbridge & Clothier, one of the East Coast's largest regional retailers, yesterday reported a sharp drop in its first- quarter profits.

title: Tony Awards' Producers Face the Pressures of TV
description: One morning last week, Joseph Cates was sitting in his office in Manhattan planning this year's Tony Awards broadcast, to be seen Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS . Mr. Cates, who took over as executive producer last year, knew that the show was scheduled to run two hours. But he also knew that the show has almost always run over its allotted time -- last year it ended after 11:20 P.M. -- and he was thinking accordingly.

title: Commencements; Schwarzkopf Praises Navy, And Teamwork, for Gulf Role
description: The Army's biggest hero of the Persian Gulf war, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, told the 146th graduating class of the United States Naval Academy today that cooperation among the services had been instrumental in defeating Iraq.

title: U.S. Auto Makers' Research Venture
description: The Big Three auto makers formed a research consortium to study automotive electronics.

title: American Express Has Concerns Over Ogilvy
description: With the departure from Ogilvy & Mather of several important executives on the American Express Company account, the company has expressed concern about the changes.

title: Trottier Unprotected
description: BRYAN TROTTIER and CHARLIE HUDDY , each of whom has played on five Stanley Cup champions, were among the players made available yesterday in the National Hockey League expansion draft. KELLY KISIO, captain of the Rangers, was also on the list.

title: Review/Theater; Rethought, Refined and Revived: Goodspeed's 'Most Happy Fella'
description: Though "The Most Happy Fella," the haunting and spectacularly ambitious show Frank Loesser wrote after "Guys and Dolls," is receiving two major stagings this year -- one at the Goodspeed Opera House here through July 12, the other to open at the New York City Opera in September -- it has always been the most unlucky musical.

title: Ethiopian Rebel Faction Is to Govern Separately
description: The leader of the rebel group that won control of the Ethiopian province of Eritrea earlier this month said today that it would form its own separate provisional government, until a United Nations-supervised referendum on Eritrean independence could be held.

title: Trade Talks With Tokyo
description: A senior Commerce Department official left for Tokyo today for a final effort to open Japan's construction market to American companies and avert American trade sanctions.

title: Managing Budget Cutbacks: Prelude to a Prison Uprising
description: The heavy strains of a soaring prison population and major budget cutbacks collided when inmates took hostages at what was intended to be the most secure of New York State's 67 prisons, many guards, lawmakers and prison experts said today.

title: BUSH UNVEILS PLAN FOR ARMS CONTROL IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: President Bush unveiled his long-delayed proposal today to ban weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East in an effort to find the middle ground between his pledge to curb the region's arms race and the political pressures frustrating American diplomacy since the Persian Gulf war.

title: Researchers Call Rare Fish Evolutionary Link to Human Race
description: Offering new evidence that a rare fish called a coelacanth is closely related to the ancestor of all four-limbed land animals, a group of German scientists has added fuel to a longstanding debate over the evolutionary lineage of the human race.

title: Math Teachers, Not Students, Make Those Math Moron Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Market Funds Show Decline for Latest Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: 9 Killed by a Car Bomb At a Barracks in Spain
description: A powerful car bomb rocked a Civil Guard barracks in this northeastern town today, killing nine people, four of them children, Government officials said. Fifty people were injured.

title: 2d Police Trial In Los Angeles Goes to a Jury
description: In the same downtown courthouse where four Los Angeles police officers will go on trial in the beating of a black motorist, a jury began deliberations today in another police misconduct case.

title: Teheran Says Hostages' Ordeal Might End Soon
description: A senior Iranian official said today that the ordeal of the Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias might end "soon," but he reiterated Iranian demands that funds frozen in the United States be released to open the way for better ties between the two nations.

title: Pop in Review
description: Red Holloway Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South (at Perry Street) Through June 2

title: Market Place; Macy Spends for Its Future In Spite of Current Troubles
description: Even with sales falling far short of its goals earlier this year, R. H. Macy & Company seems to have spent its available cash on an optimistic bet on the future.

title: 2 New Cardinals From U.S.
description: Roger Michael Mahony

title: Saatchi Chief Warns Of Lower Revenues
description: Robert Louis-Dreyfus, the chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., told shareholders at the annual meeting in London yesterday to expect another weak year for advertising and a decline in the firm's revenues.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has put its 330,000-square-foot central office complex in Sterling Heights up for sale. The 2,200 employees and the complex's operations will remain in the Detroit area, the company, which is based in St. Louis, said. The move is being made to raise cash and cut costs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ISABEL McILVAIN, sculptor of the eight-foot bronze statue of John F. Kennedy that was unveiled in Boston last summer where it stands in front of the Statehouse, said yesterday that the Kennedy Memorial Commission still owes her more than $40,000 for the work.

title: A 2d Civil Rights Battle
description: The White House is moving to ease Federal rules that are intended to prevent discrimination in employment tests. Under new rules being reviewed by the Administration, employers would have wider latitude in how the tests are used to judge workers in hiring and promotion decisions.

title: Auctions
description: By Frank Lloyd Wright

title: Bush Denounces Civil Rights Bill Advocated by House Democrats
description: President Bush denounced the House Democratic leadership's civil rights bill today, saying the provision declaring quotas illegal "shouldn't fool anyone." He said the provision defined quotas so narrowly that it would really encourage their use.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, is introducing its first campaign for the Chase Manhattan Bank. The worldwide multimedia effort is themed, "Profit from the experience." Radio and television commercials use music by the jazz legend Benny Goodman. * In television commercials for Marine Midland Bank, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, employs the theme, "Marine people do it so well, because they do it so much." The campaign presents the idea that bank employees use its services the way average customers do. * A.T.& T. aims at small and medium-size businesses in a campaign for its international communications services. The campaign, by Young & Rubicam, New York, is themed, "A.T.& T., a world of help."

title: Carving Out a Market For Oregon's Yew Tree
description: The Pacific yew tree, once treated as a weed and logged indiscriminately in the forests of the Pacific Northwest, has become so valuable since scientists identified it as effective against some cancers that thieves are now going after it, Forest Service officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Letitia Grierson; Educator, 88
description: Letitia Grierson, an educator and freelance editor, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Transco Settles Claims in Alabama
description: The Transco Energy Company agreed to pay $35.5 million to settle price disputes with natural gas customers and claims that the company destroyed ancient Indian ruins in Alabama. Alabama sued Houston-based Transco in December, accusing it of digging through Indian village sites when the company built a natural gas pipeline. Transco denied wrongdoing when the suit was filed, but said on Wednesday that it would pay $13.5 million over two years for archeological work and environmental research.

title: Bill's Language on Quotas
description: Following is the quota section of the House Democratic leadership's bill on civil rights:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: U.S. Subpoenas Council Data
description: Federal investigators have served subpoenas on the New York City Council seeking documents from its ethics committee as part of their inquiries into the finances and fund raising of Councilmen Robert J. Dryfoos of Manhattan and Noach Dear of Brooklyn, city officials said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONALD TRUMP is pressing the Palm Beach (Fla.) Town Council to go over the heads of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to let him subdivide his Mar-a-Lago estate. His lawyer, PETER BROBERG, wrote to the council, saying that in asking for more time for its findings, the commission had "yielded to the pressure of legions of experts."

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETE ROSE, who served a prison term for tax evasion and is barred from baseball for gambling, may be a fallen role model but he will make his acting debut playing the lengendary hitter Ty Cobb.

title: S.E.C. Eases Canada Rules
description: Federal regulators took the first major step today toward developing a cross-border securities market with Canada by adopting rules that make it easier for Canadian companies to sell their stock in the United States.

title: Sampras Blunders His Way to the Exit
description: The court was drenched in bright sunlight, not fog, but Pete Sampras looked like a vessel meandering and eventually marooned without radar. The defending United States Open champion slouched, stumbled, and blundered his way to a 6-3, 6-1, 6-1 loss today to Thierry Champion of France in the second round of the French Open.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday listing women who have flown on space missions, with an article about the first Briton in space, omitted an American astronaut. She is Ellen Baker, who flew on the space shuttle in October 1989.

title: Growing Elderly Population Finds Shortage of Physicians
description: As the population of the United States grows older and lives longer, the shortage of doctors trained to treat the problems of the elderly has become acute.

title: Announcement by Nissan Sends Platinum Tumbling
description: The global platinum market was shaken yesterday after the the Nissan Motor Company, the Japanese auto maker, said it had developed a catalytic converter that uses palladium instead of more expensive platinum to remove pollutants from motor vehicle exhausts.

title: Relax, but Don't Leave Your Mind Behind
description: LET'S assume you don't want to hear another word about Kitty Kelley. Let's take it for granted that if this is your summer to finish "War and Peace," you're on your own. But in between overexposed gossip and obviously great works, you'll find the most engaging, entertaining and stimulating books of summer -- a lavish assortment of novels, biographies and both serious and satirical takes on politics. By coincidence, most focus on that nagging little issue, American identity. And they prove that beach reading is a state of mind. Any of these books is absorbing enough to block the sound of the radio on the next blanket or to give you a good excuse for ignoring pesky house guests, but they are also perfect for those of us to whom summer weekends mean a glorious escape into air-conditioning and a carefully cultivated library pallor.

title: Bennetta Washington Dies at 73; Started the Job Corps for Women
description: Bennetta Bullock Washington, an educator and a former director of the Women's Job Corps, died Tuesday at Howard University Hospital in Washington. She was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: The East Village Becomes Japan West
description: "KOMPAI!," said Taku Yoshimoto, as he lifted the ceramic cup of sake to his lips in a ceremonial toast: "Dry your glass!"

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the French Open tennis tournament misstated the dates of the United States Davis Cup match against Spain. It will be played June 14-16 in Newport, R.I.

title: Review/Film; Mastroianni As a Boring Father of 5
description: It can be said of Giuseppe Tornatore's "Everybody's Fine" ("Stanno Tutti Bene") that it's the film that everybody who disliked his sentimental "Cinema Paradiso" was afraid he could make if he tried hard enough. It opens today at the Lincoln Plaza.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A World Music Festival

title: Poisoned Meat From Canada
description: Poisoned meat is being imported into the U.S. from Canada as a result of the fast-track procedure under which Congress approved the free trade agreement in 1988. If food provisions in the prospective U.S.-Mexico accord and in pacts with more than 100 countries under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are not carefully drafted, our food safety standards may be further compromised.

title: INSIDE
description: Why U.S. Acted in Ethiopia White House aides say their Ethiopia policy sprang from a desire to help Ethiopian Jews and to avoid a disaster of the Kurdish kind. Page A10.

title: HIGH COURT EASES CAR SEARCH RULES
description: Overturning a 12-year-old precedent, the Supreme Court today broadened the power of police officers who have no court warrant to search bags, suitcases and other containers they find in automobiles.

title: On My Mind; The Case of Alois Brunner
description: "Among Third Reich criminals still alive, Alois Brunner is undoubtedly the worst. In my eyes, he was the worst ever."

title: Lebanon to Give Jobs to 20,000 Ex-Militiamen
description: The Lebanese Government, taking the next step in its plan to regain control over this fractious country, has announced that it will give Government jobs to 20,000 former Muslim and Christian militiamen in the next two months.

title: A Menace for the Very Young: the Shopping Cart
description: Injuries involving grocery store shopping carts sent thousands of young children to hospitals around the United States last year, new Federal safety figures show.

title: New Works for a Benefit
description: What promises to be one of the most exciting -- and likably crazy -- events in dance this summer will occur tonight and tomorrow night when Bill T. Jones performs with Arthur Aviles and Sean Curran in a benefit gala for Performance Space 122 and Movement Research, two of the city's leading centers for new dance, music and theater. Proceeds from the event, to be held at Performance Space 122, are to be used to "help us keep the economy from pulling the floor out from under our feet," as the announcement for the benefit puts it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Jake Garn of Utah described the record of space flight by members of Congress incorrectly in some copies. Mr. Garn was the first incumbent member of Congress to fly in space, not the only one. Representative Bill Nelson of Florida was a member of the crew of the space shuttle Columbia that was launched on Jan. 12, 1986. Senator John Glenn of Ohio was an astronaut before his election.

title: Critics Seek F.T.C. Action On Products as Movie Stars
description: When the alien and Elliot shared some Reese's Pieces in the film "E.T. -- The Extra-Terrestrial," sales of the little-known candy zoomed.

title: Carnival Drops Bid For Premier Lines
description: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. said today that it had decided not to buy the Dial Corporation's Premier Cruise Lines.

title: Fear Grips Sri Lankans in South India
description: On the narrow, choked streets of Madras, members of the Sri Lankan Tamil minority have moved quietly and fearfully since Rajiv Gandhi's assassination last week. Indian friends have stopped talking to some of them. Shopkeepers curse them. Teen-age boys throw stones at them.

title: S.E.C. Official To Step Down
description: Philip R. Lochner Jr., a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that he would be leaving the agency next month rather than seek reappointment.

title: Boxing in the Desert
description: Boxing has come to Palm Springs, Calif., and promoter DAN GOOSSEN was talking up his fights as though they were the greatest since the Roman gladiators.

title: Supercomputing's Speed Quest
description: In the computer world, it is known as the race for the teraflop. The crowds will be sparse, the language arcane and most of the action will take place inside a big, boxy computer. The goal is to design a computer that is more than 1,000 times faster than the most potent current models -- a supercomputer capable of running more than a trillion mathematical calculations each second.

title: Executive to Oversee 2 Columbia Studios
description: Jonathan Dolgen, who is president of the theatrical division of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., has been named president of a newly formed motion picture group at the company. The new division encompasses Columbia Pictures Entertainment's two motion picture studios, Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures Inc.

title: Do Yanks Dare Hope? Maybe, Just Maybe
description: The Yankees have won six of their last seven games and the only pitcher to blemish their splendid stretch was the often invincible Roger Clemens. They have hit 13 homers during the revival and even Clemens has conceded he noticed a new sense of excitement blooming in the Bronx.

title: Insurer Is Seized
description: Massachusetts regulatory officials took control of the Monarch Life Insurance Company to shield the company from the financial problems of its parent concern, the Monarch Capital Corporation. Receivership by the State Division of Insurance came a day after Monarch Life acknowledged delays in negotiations to sell the company. "This receivership has been commenced in order to best protect the interests of the policyholders," said the Acting Insurance Commissioner, Susan K. Scott. She said creditors and the company's 250,000 policyholders would continue to receive payments as usual.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DOUGLAS FAIRBANKS JR. swashbuckled through a dangerous day yesterday: he got married. Mr. Fairbanks and VERA SHELTON exchanged vows at 11 A.M. at St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue, in the company of a few close friends and family members. It was Ms. Shelton's first marriage and Mr. Fairbanks's third. He was married for 4 years to Joan Crawford and for 49 years to Mary Lee Epling, who died in 1988.

title: Nissan's Net Off for Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that higher costs and lagging auto sales contribuited to a 58 percent decline in earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31.

title: Gloom on New York Farms As Milk Price Seesaws Low
description: Behind the picture-postcard beauty of rural upstate New York, where lush green alfalfa waves in the breeze next to the earth tones of newly planted fields of corn, the reality is grim as dairy farmers struggle to survive.

title: An Athlete With 2 Countries but No Place to Compete
description: As South Africa moves closer toward abolishing apartheid, increasing the likelihood that its decades of isolation in sports might end this year, the national record holder in the javelin cringes at the possibility the change might not include him.

title: International Data Corp. Appoints a New Chief
description: The International Data Corporation has named Kirk S. Campbell president and chief executive. Mr. Campbell has been chief operating officer at International Data, based in Framingham, Mass., a leading research and consulting concern for the computer industry.

title: Wake Up Call: Lakers and Bulls in a Dream Matchup
description: Cliff Robinson fumbled the ball out of bounds. Magic Johnson threw the ball out of bounds. The difference in the decisive game of the Western Conference finals was a promising young player who lost his concentration and a veteran champion who, as always, kept his wits.

title: Lasix Factor Marks The Road to Belmont
description: Hansel, who may be the most traveled horse in the business, arrives this morning by van from Chicago after another 800-mile highway journey to a major race. He did it two weeks ago, 835 miles from Chicago to Baltimore, 14 hours on his feet in a stall on wheels, and three days later he won the Preakness by seven lengths.

title: Scientology's Critical Ads
description: Every weekday for the next few weeks, readers of USA Today will find a different four-color, full-page advertisement taken out by the Church of Scientology International to protest Time magazine's May 6 cover article on the church.

title: Sports of The Times; Glory Days Make Cameo In the Bronx
description: THE uniform still has the stylish vertical stripes. The cap still has the "N" intertwined with the "Y." And Bob Sheppard's voice still booms majestically through the Bronx.

title: Review/Art; Reinhardt Retrospective Explores the Vital Absent
description: An Ad Reinhardt retrospective at the end of this sprawling, fast-moving season is a gift. The more than 90 paintings, gouaches and collages at the Museum of Modern Art are distilled and slow, without an ounce of pictorial or rhetorical fat. The catalogue, with just one essay, is lean. So is the installation. The only wall panel is at its entrance. In the second half of the show, the labels are grouped together at the entrance to each gallery. There is almost nothing to detract from what William Rubin, the director emeritus of the department of painting and sculpture at the Modern, describes in the preface as the "austere splendor" of Reinhardt's work.

title: Mr. Bush Waffles on Mideast Arms
description: President Bush's long-awaited arms control initiative for the Middle East is a puzzling blend of decent instincts and half-measures. He proposes sensible ways to curb the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological arms and ballistic missiles. And he's right to call upon other major powers to join the U.S. in drawing up guidelines to restrain arms traffic.

title: Marines Fear Glory of War Will Give Way to Old Stigma
description: The enlisted marines returning from the Persian Gulf have seen their social status rocket. Rounds of drinks are bought by strangers, signs of welcome adorn the stores, and homecoming parades have been thronged by cheering spectators.

title: Polish Leader Treads Tortuous Path
description: As Lech Walesa, the President of Poland, hurtled typically from appointment to appointment on a recent afternoon, his political radar was scanning a wide horizon.

title: Judge Is Picked to Succeed Santucci as Queens Prosecutor
description: Richard A. Brown, a judge on a New York State appeals court in Brooklyn, was named the interim Queens District Attorney yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The appointment makes him the front-runner in a special November election to succeed John J. Santucci in one of the state's most powerful prosecutorial posts.

title: Client Tries MacDougall Innovations
description: AN agency specializing in combining different forms of marketing communications has persuaded a client hoping to start a chain of health-food supermarkets to try its innovative approach coordinating everything from advertising down to shelf stickers.

title: Ex-Teamster Leader Arrested in Death Plot
description: The former president of a major teamsters local in Queens was arrested yesterday on charges that he hired a man to kill the local's current president in what prosecutors described as a desperate jailhouse plot to regain control of the powerful union.

title: Racial-Bias Assault Reported By Youths Is Called a Hoax
description: A claim by three 15-year-old white girls that they were assaulted by a dozen black teen-agers in a racial-bias incident on the way to school on Staten Island Wednesday morning was a hoax, the police said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aequitron Medical Inc., Minneapolis, appointed Stephen A. Pontzer vice president for sales and marketing. * Eastern Enterprises, Weston, Mass., a gas and river barge operations company, named Walter J. Flaherty senior vice president and chief administrative officer. He replaces Gail Deagan, who resigned.

title: Art in Review
description: Matt Mullican Brooke Alexander Gallery 59 Wooster Street Through tomorrow

title: Harlem's Apollo Fights to Keep the Lights On
description: Chicago had the Regal. Philadelphia had the Uptown. Washington had the Howard. But Harlem had "the world famous Apollo Theater" and what was said to be the toughest audience in the world.

title: Daring and Ingenuity of Animals, in New Series
description: Cheers for the 40 wildlife cameramen who bring viewers within touching distance of the animals on show in "The Trials of Life," the estimable new natural science series that begins on Sunday at 8 P.M. on TNT and continues through the week. The six-part, 12-hour documentary, produced by the BBC's Natural History Unit and written and narrated by David Attenborough, explores the ways and whys of animal behavior around the world.

title: Corporate Finance Magazine Suspended
description: Corporate Finance magazine, which was started in 1986, will suspend publication today. The June issue will be the last to be published by the Handelsblatt Group, the magazine's German publisher.

title: 'Ritual,' a New Work
description: Samuel Wong is to conduct the New York Youth Symphony in the world premiere of "Ritual," a new work by Augusta Read Thomas, at 3 P.M. on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. The program also includes Saint-Saens's First Cello Concerto and the Beethoven Fifth Symphony. The soloist in the Saint-Saens is to be Moon-Sun Kang, a 12-year-old cellist who won the orchestra's annual concerto competition. Admission is free, but tickets must be picked up at the box office. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: F.C.C. Renomination
description: President Bush said today that he would renominate James H. Quello, a former Detroit broadcasting executive, to a five-year term on the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. Quello, 77 years old, has served on the commission since 1974.

title: Oil Company to Pay $900,000 in Fines for Dumping Wastes
description: The Marathon Oil Company has agreed to pay $900,000 in fines and to make environmental improvements costing $3 million for illegally dumping explosive petroleum wastes into city sewers, a Federal prosecutor says.

title: On Campus, the Real America Now Emerges; Like Oldest Universities
description: To the Editor:

title: Juries Need Debriefing After the Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Vincent Holds Hearing
description: Commissioner FAY VINCENT conducted a three-and-a half-hour hearing in an effort to determine whether expansion fees should be shared by the American and National Leagues. The National League is expected to name two new teams June 12 and the American League is seeking to share in the $95 million each franchise will pay. Spokesman RICH LEVIN said the commissioner had taken the issue under advisement and indicated he would render a decision next week. (AP)

title: Man Is Held in Child's Death
description: A man was charged with second-degree murder today in the death of his girlfriend's 13-month-old son. Capt. James Harding of the White Plains police said that the man, Michael Vega, and the child's mother, Jennifer Cruz, 19, were questioned and that Mr. Vega was charged because his story, that the baby, Jose Jonathan Medina, had fallen on Mr. Vega's body-building weights, "was not consistent with the injuries." Captain Harding said that the child was "bruised from head to toe" but that the cause of death was not immediately determined.

title: Neiman Has Net Loss Of $7.3 Million
description: Neiman Marcus Group Inc., one of the nation's largest retailers of luxury goods, yesterday reported a net loss of $7.3 million in the fiscal quarter ended May 4, against a net profit of $4 million in the corresponding 1990 period.

title: Shift in Care For Medicaid In Budget Deal
description: In a radical change for New York's hugely expensive welfare system, legislative leaders have agreed as part of their budget accord to force large numbers of Medicaid recipients to seek care from health maintenance organizations and other "managed care" plans.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: With such a thin Broadway season, you would think that giving out Tony Awards wouldn't be too tough. But this year's race is the fiercest in ages.

title: Testing the Exclusion of Male Jurors
description: The United States Supreme Court has ruled that people may not be prevented from serving on juries in criminal cases on the basis of their race. But what about excluding jurors on the basis of their sex? And would it matter if the jury was considering a lawsuit instead of a criminal case?

title: Lawyers Clash on Plan To Hear Asbestos Cases
description: Lawyers representing hundreds of companies and tens of thousands of asbestos victims clashed yesterday in a three-hour hearing in Manhattan over a landmark proposal to coordinate the nation's steadily growing number of asbestos personal injury cases now clogging many dockets.

title: Review/Ballet; Dressed All in White, A 'Souvenir' For Summer
description: John Taras's "Souvenir de Florence" is just the thing for a hot summer night. Presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, the ballet is a continuous sweep of pretty young women and handsome young men, all dressed in white, who race on and off the stage in flurries of lyrical dancing. Occasionally they break into small groups. In the ballet's second section, there are slower, more meditative encounters for three couples on a darker stage. Romance is briefly in the air, but otherwise it's sweet companionship, with dancers occasionally putting their arms around one another on the run.

title: Conagra Merger Data Requested
description: Conagra Inc. and Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc. said they had each been asked by the Federal Trade Commission to provide more information about their April 19 merger agreement. Under antitrust law, the F.T.C. move extends the waiting period for reviewing the transaction until 20 days after compliance with the request. Both companies, which said they would cooperate with the commission, said it was not unusual for the commission to request more information in this type of merger.

title: Detective, Settling Sex-Bias Suit, Wins Promotion
description: After five years of pursuing a sex-discrimination suit against the New York City Police Department, a decorated detective will be promoted today. And so that other women in the department see her as an example, the promotion will be bestowed in a public ceremony. Then she plans to retire.

title: Shift in Creative Posts At Levine, Huntley
description: Rochelle Klein has been promoted from senior vice president and group creative director to executive creative director of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, New York, succeeding Tony DiGregorio, who left the agency in December to join Lintas New York.

title: Medical Concerns Settle Patent Cases
description: Medtronic Inc. said that it and Cardiac Pacemakers Inc., a unit of Eli Lilly & Company, had settled all litigation between the companies. In various cases dating to 1985, Medtronic said, each company had accused the other of infringing certain patents covering implantable pacemakers and defibrillators used to treat abnormal heart rhythms.

title: Chiyonofuji Is Ill
description: CHIYONOFUJI, the recently retired grand sumo champion, has been hospitalized with a fever of 104 degrees and may have to cancel a trip to the United States and Britain. He was to have received the Academy of Victor Award in Las Vegas, Nev., tomorrow. "He's in fair condition," said a spokesman in the hospital in Tokyo where he was being treated. (AP)

title: Johnson And Lewis Look Flat
description: Ben Johnson and Carl Lewis both looked flat today in running in separate 100-meter races a month before their scheduled rematch in France. Johnson looked the flatter.

title: Bob Charles, Sporting Spectacles, Goes Back to the 60's
description: The experiment with contact lenses this season was far from successful for Bob Charles, one of the most consistent winners on the Senior PGA Tour the last five years.

title: Sing-Along Clubs With a Difference
description: Holding a microphone, singing a favorite song, everybody can be a star for a few minutes. That's the lure of karaoke clubs, the casual sing-along places that have sprung up as part of New York's Japanese subculture. Karaoke (pronounced kah-rah-OH-kay) lets pop fans act out the way they feel about a song, whether the song puts unspoken feelings into words or becomes a show-off's springboard.

title: Review/Television; Life's Meaning, Amid a Whisky Haze
description: Ghosts, exorcisms, sexual crises: even though first published back in 1969, Kingsley Amis's story "The Green Man" is as up-to-date as any trendy movie of the week. But Mr. Amis, something of an Evelyn Waugh-manque for our times, is after more than a passing chill or two. His hero ponders, through a boozy haze, nothing less than the meaning, or meaninglessness, of life. Fortunately, Maurice Allington is played by Albert Finney, who brings a wickedly puffy and determined middle-aged zest to the role.

title: No Barnett Merger For Southeast
description: Barnett Banks Inc., Florida's largest banking company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was no longer interested in a possible merger with the money-losing Southeast Banking Corporation. The company declined to elaborate.

title: 2 Leaders Urge Gorbachev Role
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today that they wanted to invite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to the Group of Seven summit meeting in London in July.

title: Review/Dance; What to Do (And Not) While Waiting
description: Everyone was waiting, very possibly for Godot, in "Something Between Them" ("Hay Algo Entre Ellos Dos"), which Grupo Danza Teatro de U.B.A. presented on Tuesday night at the John Houseman Theater Studio, 450 West 42d Street. While the production's lost souls waited, they danced.

title: Investigators in Mexico City Suspect Short Circuit in Fire
description: A fire investigator said today that a short circuit may have caused the fire that raced through an 18-story office building, killing 17 people in one of Mexico City's worst blazes in decades.

title: Our Towns
description: Geologists say the lake in Lake Success was formed by a melting glacier at the end of the Ice Age when property taxes were not so high. Contrary to popular belief, the success in Lake Success had less to do with business triumphs than with the corruption of the name of an Algonquin chief named Sacat, who probably could not afford to live here now.

title: Kuwait City Journal; The Bedoons: Outcasts in the Land They Served
description: Ahmed waved his hand toward a water truck that lurched to a stop next to a shoulder-high pile of garbage, one of hundreds that line the streets of his neighborhood, Jalib al-Shuyukh.

title: John F. Dorritie; Advertising Executive, 57
description: John F. Dorritie, an executive in the field of medical advertising, died on Friday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 57 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: Torborg Gets Extension
description: JEFF TORBORG, who last season managed the Chicago White Sox to a second-place finish in the American League West with a won-lost record of 94-68, yesterday accepted a contract extension through the 1993 season. Financial terms were not disclosed. Torborg, who became the White Sox manager on Nov. 3, 1988, originally signed a two-year contract with an option for this season. (AP)

title: For 70 Minutes, Manhattan Loses 911 Emergency Line
description: The 911 police emergency system in Manhattan crashed Wednesday night, leaving a major lapse in communications for more than an hour when a small wire malfunctioned on a relay board filled with thousands of such wires.

title: Review/Film; Black Comedy on Life In Ontario Mining Town
description: Kirkland Lake, the setting for "Termini Station," is a northern Ontario mining town of such unrelieved drabness that it is easy to see why the movie's characters are either on the brink of going stir-crazy, or well over the line. Under thin, distant sunlight, the streets are encrusted with a layer of dirty slush. What local action there is takes place in the vicinity of a dingy tavern populated by hard-drinking hunters and miners.

title: Apology From Rodman
description: DENNIS RODMAN of Detroit, who was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association Wednesday for flagrantly shoving SCOTTIE PIPPEN of Chicago to the floor during Monday's playoff game, sent a letter of apology to Pippin and the Bulls' organization. But Pippin was highly skeptical of Rodman's sincerity and suggested that the letter may have been written by someone else.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE -- Named Jimmie Lee Solomon director of minor league relations for major league baseball.

title: Dr. Hans Syz, Collector Of Porcelain, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Hans Syz, a psychiatrist and a noted collector of porcelain, died on Wednesday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 96 years old and lived in Greens Farms, Conn.

title: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Sports World
description: IS the Planet of the Jocks spinning out of control? Baseball players menace fans and write them letters. Basketball players menace each other and write letters. Football players behave grossly to female reporters and management thinks it's cute. Prizefighters slug it out on the street in the worst way. For free. Meanwhile, everyone waits for the latest Coach Dad to make things right.

title: Living Among Mathematicians and Apes
description: Brazzaville Beach By William Boyd 316 pages. William Morrow & Company. $21.

title: We Watch as the Machines March Past Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Sees Early Return of Troops in Gulf
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, toured the Turkey-Iraq border area today and said he hoped American troops could be withdrawn from the region "more rapidly than we had expected or could have anticipated a few weeks ago."

title: WISCONSIN GIRL, 13, WINS SPELLING BEE
description: Joanne Lagatta, a 13-year-old from Clintonville, Wis., won the 64th National Spelling Bee today, correctly spelling "inappetence" and "antipyretic" to end 90 minutes of unabridged torture with her last competitor.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a paper products company, said its Paper Corp. of America unit acquired Monumental Paper Co., Baltimore, for undisclosed terms. * Clarcor Inc., Rockford, Ill., a maker of metal containers, will sell its Precision Products group to TCH Group, Grand Rapids, Mich., for $30 million.

title: On Campus, the Real America Now Emerges
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Spending Drops 0.1%
description: Consumers, lacking any appreciable increase in incomes, trimmed their spending one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department said today in a report that suggested the recovery from the recession would be sluggish.

title: 2 Ethiopian Protesters Are Killed As Rebels Fire on Anti-U.S. Rally
description: The rebel government of Ethiopia put down more protests today by firing on demonstrators, killing two of them. At the same time a number of former ranking officials gave themselves up for possible trial.

title: Accounts
description: * British Sky Broadcasting, London, to McCann-Erickson London, from in-house, with a budget of $42 million. * Gerber Products Co., Fremont, Mich., to Font & Vaamonde, New York, for Hispanic marketing efforts. The budget for the account, previously handled in-house, will exceed $3 million. * Lenbrook Industries, Pickering, Ontario, to Hakuhodo Advertising, New York, for its subsidiary, NAD Electronics, Norwood, Mass., which was handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Ex-Aide to Thornburgh Sentenced to Prison
description: A former top aide to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was sentenced in Federal District Court here today to 16 months in prison for cocaine possession and for lying when he denied on his application for the Justice Department job that he had ever used illegal drugs.

title: Surrender Ends Mexico Prison Takeover
description: An imprisoned Mexican drug baron accepted high-level Government guarantees of his safety and surrendered to federal authorities early today, ending a violent two-week prison takeover that he said was staged to protect him from corrupt police officials in the pay of a rival drug gang.

title: How to Stop a Civil War
description: The shouting match among Yugoslavia's ethnic rivals is becoming a shooting match.

title: Broad Rise Lifts Dow Above 3,000
description: With investors more hopeful than ever that the economy is building up steam, the Dow Jones industrial average smashed through the 3,000 barrier yesterday for the first time in a month and a half.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Lower Second Avenue Festival: Second Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 5th to 13th Street from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Coral Browne, 77, Actress, Dies; Australian Worked With Old Vic
