description: Coral Browne, an actress who had leading tragic and comic roles on the stage, mostly in London, and played urbane characters in occasional films, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 77 years old.

title: Hartford Legislators Vote Budget, Setting Up Standoff With Weicker
description: The Connecticut Legislature gave final approval today to a no-income-tax budget plan that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has already said he will veto. That would leave the state government, which has one of the worst budget crises in the nation, stranded without a budget less than a week before the legislative session ends next Wednesday.

title: 'No Title of Nobility'
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Bonds Climb Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher and long-term interest rates fell yesterday, as market participants sold short-term securities and bought longer-dated issues.

title: Putnam's Population Growth
How They Selected At Book-of-the-Month
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: The New Maurice

title: Yoav Talmi to Conduct
description: The Israeli conductor Yoav Talmi is to replace Sergiu Comissiona, who had a scheduling conflict, as conductor of the New York Chamber Symphony concert at 8 P.M. tomorrow and at 3 P.M. on Sunday at the 92d Street Y. The program includes Benjamin Britten's Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings, the Vieuxtemps Violin Concerto No. 5, Mozart's Symphony No. 35 in D (K. 385) and Dvorak's "Czech" Suite. The soloists in the Britten are to be Vinson Cole, tenor, and Paul Ingraham, hornist. Joshua Bell is to be the soloist in the Vieuxtemps. Tickets are $25 to $30. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Sallie Mae Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, commenced a $750 million offering of floating-rate notes yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. Traders said the issue was priced to yield 25 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the one-year Treasury bill. After the first year they said, the issue will float at 25 basis points over the one-year government security unless the yield on the bill is 8.75 percent or higher. After June 17, 1992, the securities will then float weekly at 25 basis points over the one-year bill.

title: Picasso Replaced by Forgery In 80's Appears at Sotheby's
description: A $1 million Picasso painting that had been stolen from the home of a Manhattan woman and replaced with a forgery appeared mysteriously yesterday at Sotheby's, where an art dealer had taken it for an appraisal and possible auction, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram yesterday showing where the uprising began at the Southport Correctional Facility near Elmira, N.Y., omitted a credit. The diagram was adapted from The Elmira Star-Gazette.

title: At the Movies
description: Professional Wanderer

title: Uranium Spills at Plant; Little Threat Seen
description: More than 300 pounds of highly radioactive uranium contaminated a tank of liquid waste on Wednesday at a nuclear fuel plant on the outskirts of this city.

title: Warner L. Wells, 77, Surgeon and an Editor
description: Warner Lee Wells Jr., a surgeon who translated and edited "Hiroshima Diary," an eyewitness account of the nuclear bombing of Hiroshima that became a best seller, died Monday after a stroke. He was 77 years old.

title: Arthur Herschman, 62, Science Official, Dies
description: Arthur Herschman, an official of the American Association for the Advancement of Science for 17 years, died Wednesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 62 years old.

title: STATES AND CITIES WITH DEFICIT WOES MAY SLOW REBOUND
description: States and municipalities across the country plan to raise taxes and cut spending by tens of billions of dollars in the fiscal year that begins July 1, and economists fear that the money this takes out of consumers' pockets could inhibit recovery from the recession.

title: Closing of Hospital Outpatient Pharmacies Dooms Thousands
description: To the Editor:

title: Noriega to Pare Request for U.S. Documents
description: Lawyers defending Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega against drug trafficking charges have backed away from their initial requests for vast amounts of secret Government information, according to court documents made public today.

title: Soviet Shift By U S West
description: U S West Inc. said this week that it would seek alternatives to building a fiber-optic telephone cable system across the Soviet Union because the United States Government considers exporting the technology to be a national security risk.

title: Pretending to Fight the Recession
description: The "action plan" to fight recession announced by Democratic leaders in Congress doesn't call for action, isn't much of a plan and is irrelevant to recession. The leaders advocate extending unemployment benefits, building roads and bridges and cutting taxes for the middle class, all of which would stimulate a sluggish economy. But they provide no specific proposals, no specific costs and no specific commitments.

title: Reporter Faces Stiff Daily Fines Over an Article on Police Beating
description: A judge in Los Angeles imposed a $1,500-a-day fine yesterday on a reporter for The Los Angeles Times until he discloses how he obtained a confidential police report on the beating by police officers of Rodney G. King in March. The beating created a sensation at the time because it was recorded on videotape and televised around the nation.

title: New Claims By Jobless Off
description: New applications for unemployment insurance benefits fell in mid-May, the Labor Department said today, providing fresh evidence that the recession may be bottoming out.

title: White House Weighs Change In Job Discrimination Rules
description: While the House of Representatives argues whether proposed civil rights legislation would create workplace quotas, the White House is moving on another track to ease Federal regulations that are intended to prevent discrimination in employment tests.

title: Westinghouse Note Offering
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is offering $250 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: For Children
description: Riverside Park Community Garden 91st Street Entrance Manhattan Recommended ages: All ages

title: 'Strong and Fit,' Law Teacher Fights Retiring at 70
description: According to the calendar and the policy at Rutgers University, Arthur Kinoy, a renowned human rights lawyer and teacher, will retire at the end of June at the age of 70. But according to Professor Kinoy, the issue is far from settled.

title: A Balancing Act In Military Policy
description: IN struggling to redesign its post-cold war, post- Persian Gulf war military policy, the United States is caught in a time warp between the short run and the long run.

title: Rangers Get Kerr But Lose Kisio
description: On a day in which the National Hockey League held a dispersal draft and an expansion draft involving its newest franchise, the San Jose Sharks, one of the oldest franchises, the New York Rangers, came away with the biggest name.

title: Israel Cautiously Lauds Bush on Mideast Arms
description: Israeli officials offered cautious praise for President Bush's regional arms control proposal today but warned that in no case would this country allow the Arab nations to gain a military advantage.

title: 15 Republicans Ask End to Walsh Inquiry
description: Fifteen House Republicans, including the minority leader and the minority whip, asked Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today to take steps to shut down the office of Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor for Iran-contra cases.

title: Review/Film; Latter-Day Existentialists
description: The art of smoking thoughtfully is of great importance to anyone who has ever seen "Breathless," and Eric Rochant, the writer and director whose first feature film is "Love Without Pity," has undoubtedly seen it many times. His own film's disaffected romantic hero, a petulant Parisian anti-yuppie nicknamed Hippo (Hippolyte Girardot), appears to have modeled much of his own behavior on early roles played by Jean-Paul Belmondo and Gerard Depardieu, although he lacks the traffic-stopping raffishness that each of them had to spare. "You're like existentialists, but 20 years too late," an even less attractive minor figure says of Hippo and an equally sullen friend.

title: Abroad at Home; Paying the Piper
description: Our private institutions -- educational, scientific, artistic -- have come to rely increasingly on government funds. The danger is that with the money will come bureaucratic control and conformity. So a critical question for democratic societies is how to maintain private independence and professionalism in an age of public funding.

title: New View Of Ethiopia
description: The United States became the midwife at the birth of a new leadership in Ethiopia and presided over the death of the old because two unrelated issues grabbed Washington's interest: the exit of Ethiopia's Jews to Israel and the desire to avoid another humanitarian disaster like the flight of the Kurds, Bush Administration officials said.

title: New Job for Witt
description: KATARINA WITT, the two-time Olympic gold medalist in figure skating, was named by CBS Sports yesterday as a figure skating analyst for the 1992 Winter Olympic Games in Albertville, France. Witt, now a professional skater who has done limited commentary on German television, will primarily provide insights into skaters' thoughts and preparation and interview them after their routines. She will join the CBS announcing team of Olympic gold medal skater SCOTT HAMILTON and VERN LUNDQUIST.

title:
A Mixed-Use Development;
Houses to Be Built at Resort Center
description: Despite a soft housing market, the Carol Management Corporation is moving ahead with plans to build 138 residences on the grounds of its 114-acre Doral Arrowwood Resort and Conference Center here.

title: Merrill Lynch Begins Financing
description: Merrill Lynch & Company entered the corporate debt market yesterday with a $200 million offering of two-year notes.

title: Review/Theater; 2 Creepy Clowns And a Wicked Witch
description: Mump and Smoot are an aggressively grotesque pair of Canadian clowns who specialize in comedy of violence. Their show, "Caged" (at the Astor Place Theater), is a petit Guignol with diminishing comic returns.

title: NBC Makes a Faustian Bargain for N.B.A. Finals
description: This fella Applegate, last seen in the company of a dame named Lola, a hunk named Joe Hardy and the Washington Senators in the 1950's musical play and movie "Damn Yankees," has made a comeback of sorts at 30 Rock, home of NBC Sports.

title: At the Bar; 'Did you hear the one about the lawyers who tried to be funny?' Recounting a rather sad story.
description: Not long ago, someone who might have called himself "Unamused Lawyer" sent an anguished inquiry to Karen Aronoff, who writes the "Executive Etiquette" column in The Miami Review, a law and business publication.

title: Key Rates
Pan Am Joins Trump in Lower Shuttle Fare
description: Seeking to attract more leisure travelers, the Trump Shuttle yesterday offered a $119 weekday round-trip fare between New York and Washington or Boston. The Pan Am Shuttle quickly matched it.

title: Space Shuttle Safety Improvements Planned
description: The space agency said today that it would improve the shuttle safety system to make sure equipment problems do not "sneak up and bite us" as they did in last week's countdown for the launching of the Columbia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the murder trial of a Chinatown businessman charged in the slaying of a reputed gang member misidentified the prosecutor. He is Gregory Waples.

title: Milbury Relinquishes Bruins Coaching Job
description: MIKE MILBURY, who guided the Boston Bruins to more than 100 points in each of the last two seasons, announced yesterday that he was giving up coaching to concentrate on his duties as assistant to HARRY SINDEN, the team's general manager and president. One of his first responsibilities will be to hire a coaching replacement for himself. Milbury indicated that he had spoken to JACK PARKER, the head coach at Boston University, a strong candidate for the job. He said other candidates included TED SATOR, a Bruins assistant coach and former head coach for the Rangers and at Buffalo; GORDIE CLARK, another Bruins assistant who also helped Milbury with the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League, and RICK BOWNESS, the present head coach of the Mariners. (AP)

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 556 money market mutual funds decreased by $5.27 billion, to $464.46 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 203 institutional funds decreased by $3.69 billion, to $133.53 billion. The assets of the 263 general-purpose funds were down by $863.8 million, to $179.84 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $712.5 million, to $152.09 billion, the institute said.

title: People
description: * Edie Edelman, a director of research at Bloom FCA, New York, was named senior vice president. * Jeffrey Fine has been named executive vice president of account management at Lintas New York, succeeding Terry Rosenquist, now worldwide client director. Mr. Fine was previously director of client services at Bloom FCA. * Joel Raphael, director of marketing research at A.T.& T., has joined Guideline Research Corporation, New York, as senior vice president. * Suzanne E. Worden has been appointed vice president and director of public relations for the Network Television Association, New York. * Ed Winter, chairman and chief executive of the Whittle Educational Network, has been promoted to vice chairman of Whittle Communications, Knoxville, Tenn. * Dom Fioravanti has been named senior vice president of media marketing for Court TV, New York, from senior vice president of business development, Financial News Network.

title: Palm Beach Rape Defendant Seeks AIDS Test on Woman
description: William K. Smith's lawyers criticized prosecutors today for publicly asking that his blood be tested for AIDS and then asked a judge for a similar test on the woman who says Mr. Smith raped her.

title: 30 in Cleveland Police Held In Federal Gambling Inquiry
description: Federal agents swept through the city early today and arrested 30 former or current police officers on charges of shielding illegal gambling houses set up by the authorities in a two-and-a-half-year undercover operation.

title: New-Home Sales Rose In April
description: Sales of new homes advanced 1.2 percent in April, the Government said today, and analysts cited the third straight monthly gain as further evidence that the housing sector is recovering slowly from its recession.

title: Parents Are Arraigned In Endangerment Case
description: A man and a woman who passers-by said tried to sell their 13-day-old girl on a Greenwich Village street corner on Wednesday were arraigned yesterday on charges of endangering the baby's welfare.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The military is left for us poor boys, and all those rich college kids out there know that." -- Lance Cpl. Joseph E. Smyth of the Marines. [ A14:4. ]

title: Tarkanian Safe, for Now
description: DENNIS FINFROCK, the interim athletic director at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, said yesterday that the current flap over photos showing three former Runnin' Rebels players with a convicted gambler was not enough to cost basketball coach JERRY TARKANIAN his job.

title: The Spoken Word
description: GALLERY TALKS AND LECTURES, South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street, Manhattan. "First Encounters Considered," by Seneca Tom Hill, an art historian, about the current exhibition, "First Encounters First," on the Spanish conquistadors' role in settling the United States, Sunday at 1 P.M. in the A. A. Low Building of the museum at 171 John Street. "Who Discovered Whom," a slide presentation by Mr. Hill on the American Indian response to European exploration, Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street. Free with museum admission of $6 ($5 for the elderly, $4 for students and $3 for children). Information: (212) 669-9400. LECTURE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street. Karin Higa is to present "Curator Explores," a discussion of the role of the curator in presenting works from other cultures, tomorrow at 2 P.M. Free with museum admission of $3.50. Information: (212) 219-1222.

title: Harlem Doctor Charged With Medicaid Fraud
description: An East Harlem doctor once described by a state investigator as "the Dwight Gooden of Medicaid billers," ordering far more prescriptions and services than any doctor in the program's 25-year history, was indicted today for Medicaid fraud.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON REVIEW OF TECHNICAL COOPERATION AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Review/Film; Gossip as Juicy Off the Soap Opera Set as on It
description: Perspective in the frenetic new comedy "Soapdish" is provided by Jeffrey Anderson (Kevin Kline), a down-at-the-heels actor appearing in a dinner-theater production of "Death of a Salesman" in Opa-Locka, Fla. Dinner theater: this means Jeffrey performs in the corner of a big room that is otherwise filled with restaurant patrons, many of whom are hard of hearing. "Death of a Salesman": that means a poster touting Jeffrey's appearance as "Willie" Loman and a stage manager who insists on calling him "Mr. Loman" because she doesn't remember his real name.

title: Bush Quandary: How to Aid Soviets
description: The steadily increasing Soviet demands for economic aid from the United States are beginning to pose a serious quandary for the Bush Administration.

title: 1,700 From Hofstra Graduate, Gradually
description: It took five commencement ceremonies to move 1,700 Hofstra University students out the door, but for the 104th time, they did it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a troubled London real estate venture misidentified a British property company that recently downgraded the value of its holdings. The company is Land Securities P.L.C., not Land P.L.C.

title: Back in Dodger Lineup But Not in the Groove
description: Until it was time to pitch, the scene was exactly the way Orel Hershiser had imagined and hoped it would be. More than 39,000 fans -- his wife, Jamie, among them -- were on their feet at Dodger Stadium, had been for 90 seconds. Hershiser, on the mound, cap in hand, bowed his head in silent prayer.

title: Seurat Drawing Is Stolen From Exhibition in Paris
description: A small drawing by Georges Seurat has been stolen from a major retrospective of work by the 19th-century Pointillist artist at the Grand Palais here, but French art experts said today that it would be difficult for the thieves to find a buyer for it.

title: Riney Official Leaves For Backer Spielvogel
description: Jerrold H. Gottlieb appears to be on a whirlwind tour of the more challenging corners of Madison Avenue. After only seven months as executive vice president and general manager of Hal Riney & Partners' New York office, he has resigned to become an executive vice president at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: Navy Officer Slain at Pentagon
description: A 42-year-old Navy officer was shot to death today at a bus stop outside the Pentagon in what the authorities described as an act of random violence. The victim was identified as Comdr. Edward Higgins of Alexandria, Va., a staff officer with the Defense Department's On-Site Inspection Agency. The authorities said the gunman, whom they identified as Carl E. Campbell, 27, of Manchester, Ga., had walked up to three people sitting on a bench at the bus stop and opened fire.

title: The Public's Right to Public Justice
description: Despite overwhelming evidence that cameras in courtrooms are a boon to justice, the New York State Legislature still balks at making controlled news photography permanent in a state known for major trials. The best that news organizations and the public can hope for at the moment is that Albany will extend a 3 1/2-year-old experimental program beyond today's expiration date.

title: Make Tompkins Square a Park Again
description: park. An area of public land; specif., an area in or near a city usually laid out with walks, drives, playgrounds, etc., for public recreation. -- Webster's New World Dictionary

title: Buhner's Bat Powers Mariners As Rangers Drop Third Straight
description: Jay Buhner hit a home run and drove in a career-high six runs tonight as the Seattle Mariners trounced Texas, 11-4, sending the Rangers to their third loss in a row after a club-record 14-game winning streak.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF 2 Share Kemper Lead Bob Gilder and a rookie, Scott Gump, both had 65's yesterday to share the first-round lead of the Kemper Open in Potomac, Md. Gilder, a 16-year veteran who has not won a tournament since 1983, had seven birdies -- including five on the back nine. Gump, who had broken 70 only twice in 30 rounds this year, had an eagle, five birdies and a bogey to finish with his best round on the PGA Tour. Six players, including Hal Sutton and Chip Beck, were one stroke back. Greg Norman and Ian Baker-Finch, the Kemper runner-up last year, were among seven players at 67. Of the 156 players in the tournament, 102 shot par or better on the 6,904-yard T.P.C. at Avenel course. (AP)

title: Knicks Win a Big One as They're Set to Sign Riley
description: The Riley watch is over. The long, arduous negotiations are nearing an end, and the Knicks are expected to introduce Pat Riley as their new coach at a news conference today.

title: First Chicago Is Offering $1 Billion in Debt Securities
description: The First Chicago Corporation is offering $1 billion in debt securities through First Chicago Master Trust II 1991-D. These securities are backed by Visa and Mastercard receivables through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a House Appropriations subcommittee action referred incorrectly to the international agency being aided. It was the United Nations Population Fund. Formerly known as the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, the agency still uses the initials U.N.F.P.A.

title: Dr. Stanley Levin, 69, Pediatrician, Is Dead
description: Dr. Stanley Levin, a pediatrician and an immunologist who was assistant chief of staff at Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park for the last four years, died on Sunday in Rehovot, Israel. He was 69 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: CHEMICAL PROGRAM GETS WIDE SUPPORT
description: An American-sponsored plan to limit the spread of chemical weapons by strictly controlling the exports of chemicals used to make them has won approval from 19 other industrial nations, American officials said today.

title: Restaurants
description: As is often the case these days, La Colombe d'Or, an engaging Provencal restaurant on East 26th Street, was cruising at the height of its success in 1990 only to have the chef leave for greener pastures. Wayne Nish, who had propelled the restaurant to three-star velocity, departed to open his own place, called March, on East 58th Street. His toque was passed on to Mark May, who had been the sous chef.

title: Investors Flocking to Bond Funds
description: Investors continue to pour cash into bond mutual funds, seeking higher yields as short-term interest rates decline, fund managers said yesterday.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Randy Weston's Pianism

title: F.D.I.C. to Get $49.5 Million From Silverado Settlement
description: Federal regulators agreed in principle on Wednesday to a $49.5 million settlement in their $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush and 12 other former directors of Denver's defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.

title: BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * Coastal Healthcare Group Inc., Durham, N.C., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 3 million common shares through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. * Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, has filed for a public offering of 4 million common shares, 3.2 million to be offered in the United States through the First Boston Corp.

title: Uprising at Prison Renews Debate On Housing of Toughest Convicts
description: As the state moved to transfer the 52 inmates involved in a rebellion this week at Southport Correctional Facility, debate intensified yesterday on whether to keep using the prison in Pine City, N.Y., to house the state's most unmanageable convicts.

title: Lite Light Headed For Filly Showdown
description: Lite Light, who won the Kentucky Oaks by 10 lengths, was withdrawn from the Belmont yesterday and instead was aimed for the Mother Goose Stakes the next day, setting up a confrontation with Meadow Star and a showdown between the two prime fillies in America.

title: Pier 1 Buyback
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc., a retailer of household furnishings, said it would buy back all the Pier 1 formula-rate preferred stock owned by Intermark Inc., a holding company that is Pier 1's largest shareholder. Pier 1 said the stock it was acquiring had an aggregate redemption value of $2.5 million. Pier 1 said the transaction represented 1.4 million shares, or 92 percent of its formula-rate preferred shares outstanding.

title: Top Ten Inexpensive Weekend Activities in New York City
description: 1. Ruptured-pipe steam baths in middle of street. 2. Buy Fake police I.D. in Times Square and strip search self.

title: As Brooks Works at First, Magadan Sees Bonilla
description: Dave Magadan had heard the rumors for so long that he was less than shocked when he looked up to see Hubie Brooks taking ground balls at first base Tuesday evening at Wrigley Field.

title: New Gun Ban In Effect Today In New Jersey
description: A state judge today cleared the way for New Jersey to prosecute some 200,000 gun owners if they do not get rid of their assault weapons or disable them.

title: Judge Orders Joan Kennedy To Take Alcohol Treatment
description: Joan Kennedy, former wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was found guilty today of drunken driving and was ordered to spend two weeks in an alcohol treatment center.
